headline: Transfer Deadline: Dempsey Heads to Spurs
abstract: United States forward Clint Dempsey secured his move away from Fulham in the final hours of the transfer window on Friday by signing a three-year contract with Tottenham Hotspur.
lead_paragraph: United States forward Clint Dempsey secured his move away from Fulham in the final hours of the transfer window on Friday, signing a three-year contract with Tottenham Hotspur that will keep him in England’s Premier League.

headline: Pakistan’s Premier Televangelist
abstract: Aamir Liaquat Hussain is a broadcasting sensation and a contentious figure.
lead_paragraph: Aamir Liaquat Hussain is a broadcasting sensation and a contentious figure.

headline: Way Cleared for November Vote in Texas
abstract: A federal court found that interim redistricting maps could be used after a Washington court had found maps drawn by the Republican-led legislature discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: A federal three-judge panel in San Antonio ruled on Friday that the November elections in Texas would proceed, ending uncertainty about whether a Washington court’s earlier ruling would delay the elections.

headline: View at Practice Courts an Intimate but Possibly Endangered Perk
abstract: The practice courts offer fans an intimate glimpse of the United States Open, but an overhaul to the tennis center could mean more structured viewing.
lead_paragraph: When Sandra Unger heard that Roger Federer was headed to the practice courts at the United States Open, she immediately texted her sister Laurie McLeod, who was having lunch at the food court.

headline: Debt Collector Misled Borrowers, Court Says
abstract: An appeals court ruled that a debt collection agency misled borrowers by claiming their student loans could not be discharged in bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: For borrowers struggling to pay off their student loans, getting rid of the debt in bankruptcy is difficult because they need to convince a judge that it constitutes an “undue hardship.”

headline: Republicans, in Search of a Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Today’s Republicans are as divided on foreign policy as they’ve ever been, and Mitt Romney is finding it hard to bridge the divisions.
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: Cardinal Carlo Martini, Papal Contender, Dies at 85
abstract: Cardinal Martini, one of the Roman Catholic Church’s most influential progressive thinkers, was considered a possible successor to Pope John Paul II.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, one of the Roman Catholic Church’s most influential progressive thinkers, who once was considered as a possible successor to Pope John Paul II, died in a Jesuit retreat near Milan on Friday. He was 85.

headline: Rushing to See Roddick, If Not to Praise Him
abstract: Fans at the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center react to the news of Andy Roddick’s retirement.
lead_paragraph: When Andy Roddick announced his impending retirement Thursday, Ann Morrissey texted Lisa O’Neil: “Turn on the Roddick press conference.”

abstract: Thousands of cat lovers and cineastes gathered at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis to celebrate the Internet sensation that is cat videos.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of cat lovers and cineastes gathered at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis to celebrate the Internet sensation that is cat videos.

abstract: Good news, people! There was plenty of time on the flight home from Tampa to read through the Republican Party’s platform for you.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican convention fades into oblivion, the one thing everybody is still talking about is, of course, the party platform.

keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: The truth was hard to find at the party’s convention this week.
lead_paragraph: Tampa, Fla.

keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Student Loans', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'United States Economy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Environment']
abstract: The Occupy Wall Street protest in Hong Kong ignored a deadline to leave HSBC’s headquarters, European leaders worked again to reassure investors on the debt crisis and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chief, committed to aiding the economy.
lead_paragraph: The Occupy Wall Street protest in Hong Kong ignored a deadline to leave HSBC’s headquarters, European leaders worked again to reassure investors on the debt crisis and Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chief, committed to aiding the economy.

headline: Aug. 31: TV Ratings May Be Leading Indicator of Convention Bounce
abstract: The mediocre television ratings for the Republican National Convention are one sign that Mitt Romney’s convention bounce could be fairly modest.
lead_paragraph: It remains too early to tell exactly what effect the Republican National Convention has had on the polls. But television ratings are one measure that come in almost instantaneously. Ratings for the final two nights of the Republican convention were down quite a bit from 2008, declining by about 30 percent overall.

headline: Giving to a Newborn’s College Savings Plan
abstract: The process of tossing some money into a college savings account as a gift is not as easy as it could, or should, be.
lead_paragraph: The best gift any of us can give to newborn babies is to point their sleep-deprived parents in the direction of a good 529 or other college savings plan and then seed the account with a little bit of money.

headline: A Superstar Televangelist in Pakistan Divides, Then Repents
abstract: Aamir Liaquat Hussain, who has been accused of using his television pulpit to promote hate speech, now portrays himself as a torchbearer for progressive values.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan

headline: Families’ Bond Is Severed as Blood Spills
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: After a fatal stabbing, two families that had been neighbors for 30 years are asking why, and one member believes the motive may have something to do with a slice of pizza.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of two modest, crowded apartments in two buildings in the Tompkins Houses in Brooklyn: 5C at 65 Tompkins Avenue; and around the corner and 10 stories higher, 15G at 919 Myrtle Avenue. The Hartley family lives in one, the Mann family in the other. They share a timeline that spans 30 years.

headline: Trying to Recapture Normal at Penn State
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: With some aspects of the Jerry Sandusky child sexual abuse scandal in the past, the Penn State campus finds relief in the beginning of a new football season.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — This year, more than most, felt like a long overdue reunion: Penn State students converging, the professors awaiting, all savoring their own slice of normalcy.

headline: Sex Charges Cast a Pall on a College Town
abstract: Some longtime fans of the University of Montana Grizzlies are wrestling with their feelings in the wake of a series of allegations of sexual assaults by football players.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — Students are back in their classrooms this week, the heat of summer has cooled and new chalk lines have been placed on the football field as the University of Montana Grizzlies and their devoted fans prepare for the opening kickoff on Saturday.

headline: Risky and Getting Riskier
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Editorials', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Private Placements (Non-Public Offerings) and Mini IPOs']
abstract: A new federal proposal on mass advertising would make stock investing even more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Just what grandpa needed. Soon retirees and other investors will be barraged with advertisements for private stock offerings — via mail, cold calling, television, radio, billboards, the Internet and so on.

headline: Facebook Plays It Safe
abstract: Frank Gehry is an unsurprising choice to design Facebook’s new headquarters — and that’s the problem.
lead_paragraph: I read with some amusement the news that Facebook had brought on the architect Frank Gehry to design an expansion to its Menlo Park, Calif., headquarters. Or more specifically, a new warehouse for engineers at its Menlo Park headquarters. Plans for the Silicon Valley site include a 420,000-square-foot, single-story warehouse topped with a garden that will span the entire roof. A tunnel will connect “Facebook East” to the company’s existing headquarters in the former space of Sun Microsystems, whose more hierarchical floor plan has been demolished to make way for Facebook’s open-plan ethos. (As one British blog so delicately put it, “Facebook moves into Sun Microsystems carcass.”)

headline: Cleaner Cars, a Safer Planet
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Automobiles', 'Editorials']
abstract: Higher fuel efficiency standards will cut oil use and greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: The federal automobile efficiency standards announced this week are an important step on America’s path to a lower-carbon and more-secure energy future. They are expected to yield multiple benefits: reduced dependence on foreign oil, fewer greenhouse gas emissions, consumer savings at the pump and a more competitive auto industry. They may also serve as proof that well-tailored government regulation can achieve positive results and that consensus among old enemies — in this case environmentalists and the car companies — is possible even at a time of partisan discord.

headline: Campaigns Play Loose With Truth in a Fact-Check Age
abstract: Recent events in the contest between President Obama and Mitt Romney have raised new questions about whether the political culture still holds any penalty for falsehood.
lead_paragraph: In his very first television advertisement last year, Mitt Romney highlighted the nation’s dire unemployment crisis, its record number of home foreclosures and the rising national debt, and showed video of President Obama delivering this arresting remark: “If we keep talking about the economy, we’re going to lose.”

headline: Why College Money Is the Best Baby Gift
abstract: Readers weigh in on the etiquette of handing over money to newborns and their families in lieu of blankets or rattles.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column about the ins and outs of giving money as a gift to someone’s 529 college savings account wasn’t meant to be an etiquette lesson. But I do think giving money is totally defensible, even if it means pushing the parents to open a 529 or other savings account to use the gift.

headline: Rage by Miners Points to Shift in South Africa
abstract: The unrest at South African mines has placed the spotlight on the country’s business leaders and politicians, who once led protests and are now wealthy members of the establishment.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — When 360,000 gold and coal miners walked off the job in South Africa in 1987, protesting the poor pay and grim working conditions of apartheid-era mines, a charismatic young man named Cyril Ramaphosa, the firebrand leader of the National Union of Mineworkers, led the charge.

headline: Romney Shows Support in Storm-Battered Bayou
abstract: Mitt Romney on Friday toured hurricane-ravaged regions of Louisiana, a visit that seemed intended to convey an unmistakable air of presidential authority.
lead_paragraph: KENNER, La. — Mitt Romney on Friday used the first day since accepting his party’s nomination for president to tour hurricane-ravaged regions of the Louisiana bayou, a visit that seemed intended to convey an unmistakable air of presidential authority.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Woods Finds a Groove and Stays There
abstract: Tiger Woods ran off six straight birdies in the middle of his first-round 64 at the Deutsche Bank Championship, five days after recording his worst round of the year, a 76 at the Barclays.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — What the butterfly effect is to science, the Tiger effect is to golf. On Friday, a 6-inch putt rolled in the hole at No. 5 and caused a commotion between the 9th and 10th holes at T.P.C. Boston. The roar that punctuated Tiger Woods’s eighth birdie of his morning round of the Deutsche Bank Championship prompted a mass dash to the front nine by fans wanting to catch a glimpse of the new old Woods.

headline: A Fight Over Spending in New York State
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Editorials']
abstract: Two court rulings could unnecessarily cost New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Twice in August, judges declared unconstitutional or otherwise rejected state laws because, they said, the laws ran afoul of a provision in the New York State Constitution known as home rule. Both decisions involved transportation, and both could cost the public a lot of money: New York City in one case; the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in the other.

headline: Suits That Accused Sloan-Kettering Chief of Stealing Research Are Settled
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: As part of the settlement, the biotechnology company Agios Pharmaceuticals entered licensing agreements covering certain intellectual property with the University of Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Two lawsuits that accused the president of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center of absconding with groundbreaking research from the University of Pennsylvania to start a biotechnology company have been settled.

headline: Mexico: Drug Gang Suspect Extradited to the U.S.
keywords: ['Money Laundering', 'Extradition', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Racketeering and Racketeers']
abstract: A 20-year investigation into one of Mexico’s largest drug trafficking organizations came to a close Friday when Eduardo Arellano-Félix, a top operative of the gang, was extradited to San Diego.
lead_paragraph: A 20-year investigation into one of Mexico’s largest drug trafficking organizations came to a close Friday with the extradition of Eduardo Arellano-Félix, a top operative of the gang, to San Diego. After exhausting his legal appeals in Mexico, he will face a variety of charges, including racketeering and money laundering, in a United States court. The Mexican government sent Mr. Arellano-Félix, a capo in the Arellano-Félix organization led by his family members, to the United States more than four years after his arrest following a shootout with Mexican police. His brothers are already serving long sentences in the United States, and the Drug Enforcement Administration contends that the gang has largely been crippled, though several others have taken its place as top suppliers of cocaine and marijuana to the United States. Still, Lanny A. Breuer, a Justice Department official, called the extradition “a milestone in our fight against the Mexican drug cartels.”

headline: The Bullet That Changed History
abstract: How the lowly minie ball made the Civil War an unrelenting gore fest.
lead_paragraph: It was late afternoon on Aug. 30, 1862, the concluding day of the Second Battle of Bull Run, and the largest simultaneous massed assault of the Civil War was about to be unleashed. The Confederate general James Longstreet’s corps was in position on the left flank of the Union general John Pope’s unsuspecting Army of Virginia, and when the signal was given 25,000 Rebels surged forward, catching the surprised Federals in an immense “hammer on anvil” movement.

headline: New York City to Pay in Another Prisoner Suit
abstract: The city will pay $850,000 to settle a lawsuit stemming from the beating of an inmate at Rikers Island, a resolution similar to two other large settlements the city agreed to pay in June and July.
lead_paragraph: New York City will pay $850,000 to settle a lawsuit stemming from the beating of an inmate at Rikers Island that fit a rogue disciplinary pattern cited by law enforcement officials in which favored prisoners, in a system known as the Program, received tacit approval to keep order by assaulting and threatening other prisoners.

headline: Outfielder, Like Team, Detoured To Success
abstract: Lew Ford, a veteran outfielder, has become a symbol for the Orioles, who have relied on contributions from every corner during their unexpected run.
lead_paragraph: At the start of this season, Lew Ford, five years removed from his last stint in the majors, had a single goal: to bring a championship trophy to Central Islip, N.Y., the home of the Long Island Ducks of the independent Atlantic League of Professional Baseball.

headline: The Ice Pick Seems Antiquated, but It Still Shows Up on the Police Blotter
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: While guns top the list of weapons used in violent assaults, every so often, a crime is committed with a weapon that harks back to a different era.
lead_paragraph: The young man staggered down a city street as blood flowed from a puncture wound. The weapon used in the steely attack — an ice pick — was sticking out of his lower back.

headline: A Killing on a Brooklyn Block Known for Its Violence
abstract: Fatima Gordon, 28, was shot and killed on Thursday night on Clarkson Avenue in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, an area where violence has been rampant all summer, residents said.
lead_paragraph: The morning after his mother was killed in Brooklyn, Chinnarie Gordon, 5, took his grandmother’s hand and walked to Parkside Playground. As his cousins played in the fountains, Chinnarie climbed up to a checkers table and began drawing a picture of his mother in blue chalk, giving her long blue hair and a mermaid’s tail.

headline: Mainstreaming Efforts Praised in Schools Study
abstract: A study released on Friday said the New York City Department of Education had done a good job of preparing for significant special education reforms that will begin in earnest next week.
lead_paragraph: A study released on Friday said that the New York City Department of Education had done a good job of preparing for significant special education reforms that will begin in earnest next week, but it expressed concerns about whether schools had enough money and teachers had enough training to carry out the changes.

headline: It’s Roddick’s Opponent Bowing Out
abstract: The day after announcing his intention to retire, Andy Roddick proved that he was not ready to bow out, thrashing the Australian teenager Bernard Tomic in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: As if it were not enough to have to face Andy Roddick the day after he announced his retirement, Bernard Tomic had a tough act to follow even entering Arthur Ashe Stadium on Friday night. The stadium lights were not yet on, but Roddick’s enormous face glowed from a video montage with clips of his electric serve and equally electric smile.

headline: Mercury’s Core
abstract: What’s inside my wheelhouse. And what is not.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I am of two minds about today’s puzzle, by Tim Croce.

headline: Federal Judge in Ohio Restores Early Voting
abstract: A federal judge in Ohio on Friday ordered the state to give all voters the right to cast their ballots in person on the final three days before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Ohio on Friday ordered the state to give all voters the right to cast their ballots in person on the final three days before Election Day.

headline: A New Guide to the Democratic Herd
abstract: A look at the major blocs of the Democratic Party going into the 2012 election.
lead_paragraph: A look at the major blocs of the Democratic Party going into the 2012 election.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Questions about warehouses in Brooklyn and a shared name in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Aviation History

headline: Giants’ Terrell Thomas Will Miss Another Season
abstract: The Giants’ roster was further trimmed Friday, with cornerback Terrell Thomas out for the year with a knee injury.
lead_paragraph: Giants cornerback Terrell Thomas will miss a second consecutive season after the team placed him on injured reserve Friday because of a knee injury. Earlier in training camp, he  aggravated the right knee that cost him the 2011 season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament.

headline: Student Reviews of Introduction to Congress
abstract: Online evaluations of the Harvard class taught by Matthew B. Platt reflect largely scathing opinions of the course. Nearly half of the 279 students enrolled in the spring class were accused of cheating.
lead_paragraph: Online evaluations of the Harvard class taught by Matthew B. Platt reflect largely scathing opinions of the course. Nearly half of the 279 students enrolled in the spring class were accused of cheating.

headline: An Easier Way to Find Adult Classes
abstract: Web sites like Classtivity and Skillshare provide postings for thousands of casual classes around the city.
lead_paragraph: My girlfriend is a teacher and a graduate student, and every year around this time, I get a pang of nostalgia for the school life as she runs around buying new notebooks and checking class schedules while I prepare for another day at the office.

headline: Harvard Students in Cheating Scandal Say Collaboration Was Accepted
abstract: Undergraduates described a culture of sharing notes and materials for a course that once had a reputation for being easy, but whose tests had become confusing.
lead_paragraph: Harvard students suspected in a major cheating scandal said on Friday that many of the accusations are based on innocent — or at least tolerated — collaboration among students, and with help from graduate-student teachers who sometimes gave them answers to test questions.

headline: Giving the Yankees Reason for Pause
abstract: The Orioles, who jumped out to an early lead on Yankees starter Hiroki Kuroda, have made up four games in less than two weeks in the American League East.
lead_paragraph: A few starts ago, Hiroki Kuroda threw a seven-inning shutout in a rain-shortened victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. The win, on July 18, increased the Yankees’ lead in the American League East to a whopping 10 games. The margin has been slashed to two, in part, by a rash of injuries and inconsistent performances.

headline: Pro Medium Repents for Life of Cons
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Magic and Magicians', 'Psychics and Psychic Phenomena']
abstract: Mark Edward, in coming clean about tricks used for duping people, tries to enter a class of magicians and mediums who perform their crafts and also debunk them.
lead_paragraph: Don’t mistake Mark Edward for John Edward. The two men, who are not related, are both professional mediums, men who charge money for their supposed skill at transmitting messages from the dead. But whereas John Edward had a nationally syndicated television show and still plays to large crowds in Las Vegas and across the country, Mark Edward’s biggest gigs were a baby shower at Eddie Murphy’s house and Buddy Hackett’s 70th birthday party.

headline: Striking a Work-Life Balance
abstract: Like many whose champion she has become, Sara Horowitz, 49, the founder of the Freelancers Union, mixes work and home life on Sundays.
lead_paragraph: Sara Horowitz, 49, the founder of the Freelancers Union, has a commitment to workers’ rights that runs several generations deep: her paternal grandfather was vice president of the International Ladies’ Garment Workers’ Union, and her father was a union lawyer. She received a MacArthur Fellowship in 1999. Ms. Horowitz, who grew up in Brooklyn Heights, lives in a brownstone in Park Slope with her husband, Peter DeChiara, 47, a lawyer whose firm represents unions, and their daughter, Rachel, 12. Like many of the freelancers whose champion she has become, she mixes work and home life on Sundays.

headline: Dickey Blanks Marlins for 17th Win
abstract: The Mets’ R. A. Dickey held Miami to five hits and struck out seven batters in his third shutout of the season as the Mets won for the fifth time in six games.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Mets have been anything but a certainty this season, except perhaps when they send R. A. Dickey to the mound against the Miami Marlins.

headline: Old Friends and Oysters
abstract: At Upstate, a restaurant in the East Village, two longtime friends met up for a light dinner after work: beer and oysters.
lead_paragraph: When the wife-and-husband team of Jennifer and Shane Covey opened their 28-seat East Village restaurant, Upstate, last July, the concept was monkishly minimal: beer and oysters. “We’re relatively uncomplicated people,” Ms. Covey said, though she also said her husband used three types of beer glasses at home. Not that more complicated people have found a better way to salute a late summer sunset. The Coveys have since added a few cooked dishes, some wine and free slices of Ms. Covey’s whiskey cake, but it is still the original pairing that brings the customers in — some calling it a light dinner, others pre-dinner ballast, an evening equivalent of elevenses. The décor is spare, and the menu would almost fit in a Twitter post. From 5 to 7 p.m., you get a beer and six oysters for $12. One evening at the end of August, a crowd waited on the sidewalk for seats to open up. Inside, the early birds slurped and slugged. Were oyster happy hours everywhere this summer? Yes, they were. What took them so long?

headline: 2 Campaigns Differ Sharply on Medicaid, Seeking Vast Growth or Vast Cuts
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Few other issues present a starker difference between the two tickets, with President Obama seeking a big expansion and the Republicans pushing big cuts.
lead_paragraph: The way Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan frame it, the debate over social programs that has become a dominant theme of the presidential race is all about the future of Medicare, the government health insurance program for retirees.

headline: Weapons Plant Security Issues Are Described in U.S. Audit
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Uranium', 'Computer Security', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The Energy Department’s inspector general said that managers knew about broken equipment and other lapses at the Y-12 plant where there was a break-in this summer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The contractors in charge of guarding the national stockpile of bomb-grade uranium in Tennessee knew well before an 82-year-old nun and two other pacifists broke through three barriers this summer that a lot of the security equipment was broken, and government managers knew it too, according to an internal audit of Energy Department operations at the weapons facility. The inspector general’s investigation found “troubling displays of ineptitude.”

headline: As a Catalog of Pain Shows, She Isn’t Riding Just for Show
abstract: Determined to continue in show jumping competitions, Georgina Bloomberg, daughter of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City, has come back from multiple injuries and spinal surgery.
lead_paragraph: NORTH SALEM, N.Y. — Georgina Bloomberg, 29, the younger daughter of New York’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, practiced in a white T-shirt and dark helmet, jumping her bay mare Radio City over imposing panels and open water in a grass field at her farm here.

headline: Guiding Golfers to Rock Their Shots
abstract: Hunter Watkins, a veteran of hard-core punk rock bands turned golf pro, uses music as his basis for instruction.
lead_paragraph: TO find the head professional at the Marine Park Golf Course in Brooklyn, look for a flamboyant outfit of plaids and pastels, and follow the smoke.

headline: Tipsarevic Beats Baker at Own Game
abstract: The signature strengths of Brian Baker’s game are his remarkable return of serve and his ability to out-think his opponent.
lead_paragraph: Janko Tipsarevic, the eighth seed from Serbia, outplayed  Brian Baker on Friday, winning, 6-4, 6-3, 6-4, to advance to the third round of the United States Open.  Tipsarevic used his superior movement to thwart Baker, who struggled to return his serve, especially his accurate, deceptive second delivery.  By contrast, Tipsarevic broke Baker five times, including the final game, when Baker had a chance to draw even late in the third set.

headline: First Death Is Reported From New Pig Flu Strain
abstract: Federal health officials confirmed the death of a 61-year-old Ohio woman and said 14 other victims had been hospitalized by the new strain.
lead_paragraph: The first human death from a new strain of pig flu was reported Friday by state health officials in Ohio.

headline: Ryan’s Budget Proposal Is Pitting G.O.P. Troops Against Top of the Ticket
abstract: Republicans, even House challengers, are distancing themselves from the proposed Medicare cuts in Paul D. Ryan’s budget plan, even as he and Mitt Romney urge them to embrace it.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Even as Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan exhort Republicans to embrace their proposed Medicare changes and spending cuts, the party’s rank and file is growing less enthusiastic about the fight than the top of the ticket.

headline: At Paralympics, First Thing Judged Is Disability
abstract: Classifications ensure that Paralympic athletes compete against others with similar levels of ability, but the distinctions are not always obvious.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anthony Dawson, who has cerebral palsy and little muscle function on his right side, rode for South Africa in the first round of the equestrian dressage competition at the Paralympics on Thursday, guiding his horse through an intricately choreographed series of movements.

headline: Too Busy or Just Too Tired, Some Floridians Paid Convention Little Mind
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Voting and Voters', 'Hurricane Isaac (2012)', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Interviews with voters in Florida suggest that Mitt Romney’s moment was well received by some, but was also lost amid a tide of other urgent concerns.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Kaye Collie really wanted to pay attention to the last night of the Republican National Convention, particularly the big moment when the nominee, Mitt Romney, would step out on the huge stage in Tampa, Fla., and make the speech of his lifetime.

headline: Far From Action but Right at Home
abstract: Brooklyn’s Denise Starr trains year-round at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, but in the early part of the United States Open the 17-year-old is relegated to the far practice courts.
lead_paragraph: From where Denise Starr was playing on practice court No. 13, she could see the upper reaches of Arthur Ashe Stadium, and hear the roars of the crowd during Novak Djokovic’s victory over Rogerio Dutra Silva there. Or perhaps it was the cheers coming from Louis Armstrong as Laura Robson beat Li Na.
