headline: Inquiry Finds No Misdeeds by Sheriff in Arizona
abstract: The United States attorney’s office concluded there was insufficient evidence to prosecute Sheriff Joe Arpaio, his current and former employees and a former county attorney.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The United States attorney’s office announced on Friday that it had closed an investigation over abuse-of-power allegations against Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, some of his current and former employees, and the former Maricopa County attorney, concluding that none of them had done anything wrong.

headline: A History of New York in 50 Objects
abstract: An artichoke and an elevator. A Checker taxicab and a conductor’s baton. A MetroCard and a mastodon tusk. From ancient artifacts to common everyday accessories, which objects tell the story of New York City?
lead_paragraph: An artichoke and an elevator. A Checker taxicab and a conductor’s baton. A MetroCard and a mastodon tusk. From ancient artifacts to common everyday accessories, which objects tell the story of New York City?

headline: Who Will Be the Next in Line to Replace Roddick?
abstract: Twenty American men entered the United States Open and seven were playing on Friday — from No. 9 John Isner, the top ranked American, to Dennis Novikov, the No. 1,098 player in the world.
lead_paragraph: Within hours of Andy Roddick’s announcement on Thursday that he would retire after the United States Open, the focus of American tennis turned to the next generation.

headline: Jets Trim Roster as Season Opener Nears
abstract: The Jets cut three draft selections: receiver Jordan White, running back Terrance Ganaway and offensive lineman Robert Griffin.
lead_paragraph: The Jets cut three draft selections: receiver Jordan White, running back Terrance Ganaway and offensive lineman Robert Griffin.

headline: Teenager Dies After Sticking Head Through Bus Hatch and Striking Underpass
abstract: The authorities say that Daniel Fernandez, 16, was traveling to a birthday party when the accident happened near the George Washington Bridge on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: A teenager was killed when he popped his head out of a rooftop hatch on a double-decker bus and struck an underpass near the George Washington Bridge on Friday night, an official at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

headline: Corrections: September 1, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 1, 2012.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Breathing Life Into a Dead Language
abstract: The Vatican wants to revive Latin for the benefit not only of the church but of the wider secular world. But what are the advantages of knowing a dead language in a global economy that operates in languages such as English and Mandarin?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It seems that Latin is a dead language that refuses to lie down.

headline: What I Saw at the Republican Convention
abstract: The outcome of American elections affect the entire world — yet most people outside the United States (and many inside) don’t understand American politics. I anchored our livestreaming coverage from the Republican convention and will do the same at the Democrats. Send me your questions about American politics, the political parties and Barack Obama and Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: The outcome of American elections affect the entire world — yet most people outside the United States (and many inside) don’t understand American politics. In an effort to bring greater understanding to the process, the politics, the personalities and the policies, The New York Times, for the first time, livestreamed coverage from the Republican National Convention. I was one of the anchors of that coverage.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: Recent amendments to the Right to Information Act of 2010 have weakened the State Information Commission, a watchdog agency tasked with safeguarding the law’s provisions, Hindustan Times reported. Civic groups and opposition politicians criticized the changes; the chief information commissioner, G.R. Sufi, accused the state government of trying to make the commission a “toothless body.”

headline: The Weekend Word: Political Theater
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the weekly addresses and the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: How Greek Taxpayers Hide 11 Billion Euros a Year
abstract: The culture of tax evasion in Greece is widespread and “will take some time” to change.
lead_paragraph: After a brief summer holiday, the euro crisis is back. Adam Davidson’s latest column previews seven dramas coming to the Euro zone this fall. As usual, things begin with Greece, which has to cut its budget by an additional 11.5 billion euros in order to secure the next round of debt relief. In a surprising twist, that may be the exact amount of money that Greece loses from tax evaders each year.

headline: In Vietnam, Message of Equality Is Challenged by Widening Wealth Gap
abstract: Vietnam’s political mandarins are struggling to reconcile their party’s message of social justice and equality with the realities of an elite awash in wealth and privilege.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — She wore a pink outfit and matching high heels as she toured the dusty construction site. Soon after To Linh Huong’s visit in April, photos that captured the moment went viral on the Internet, but not because of Ms. Huong’s sense of style.

headline: Three Hours, Four Hours, Whatever
abstract: Marathon truthers, vindicated.
lead_paragraph: Ahem. (Via Mark Thoma, who has more).

headline: What to Watch on Saturday
abstract: Highlight matches at the United States Open include Sloane Stephens vs. Ana Ivanovic and Jack Sock vs. Nicolas Almagro.
lead_paragraph: Down a set and trailing 3-2 in her second round match Thursday, nothing seemed to work for Sloane Stephens. Her first serve was off, her forehand shaky. Tatjana Malek’s route to victory seemed easy enough: Keep balls in play and wait for the inevitable miss.

headline: Woodford on Monetary Policy (Sort of Wonkish)
abstract: The Fed offers the wrong kind of forward guidance.
lead_paragraph: I’m not in Jackson Hole — actually, I appear to have been blackballed for a long time, probably because I had the temerity to criticize the great Greenspan before it was fashionable. No matter. I can still read the papers — and the most important one was by Mike Woodford (pdf).

headline: Live Updates: First Saturday
abstract: The New York Times is providing live analysis of college football on the first Saturday of the season.
lead_paragraph: The stars have aligned for the first Saturday of the college football season. Paul Myerberg is in Manhattan. Tim Rohan is in Happy Valley to watch Penn State host Ohio. Later tonight, Tom Spousta will be in Arlington, Tex., to provide feedback on Alabama’s date with Michigan. Keep close tabs throughout the day for updates and analysis.

headline: A Brief History of Timelines
abstract: Keeping track of stuff that happened, for like a zillion years.
lead_paragraph: 385 million B.C. During the Middle Devonian Period of the Paleozoic Era, a prehistoric fern adds a new growth ring to its trunk, creating the world’s first timeline. A trilobite third-grade teacher immediately assigns it to her class as busywork.

headline: Alice Waters
abstract: What Alice Waters is reading, watching, following, wearing and, of course, eating.
lead_paragraph: A pioneer in the organic, locally grown and slow-food movements, Alice Waters is a chef, cookbook author and owner of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Angola’s Governing Party and Its President Are Poised to Win Election
abstract: The ruling party of President José Eduardo dos Santos received nearly three-quarters of the votes cast on Friday after 60 percent of the ballots had been counted, electoral officials said.
lead_paragraph: LUANDA, Angola — Angola’s governing party was poised on Saturday to sweep parliamentary elections, winning a landslide victory that would ensure President José Eduardo dos Santos a five-year extension to his 33 years at the country’s helm.

headline: N.F.C. South Preview: Saints, Stained by Scandal, Have Staying Power
abstract: The Saints remain the most talented team in the division, and they made the smart decision to replace the interim head coach with the offensive line coach, Aaron Kromer, and keep the coordinators with their units.
lead_paragraph: Player to Watch It’s possible that no quarterback has had to shoulder as much as the Saints’ Drew Brees will this season with Coach Sean Payton suspended and the interim coach Joe Vitt benched for the first six games.

headline: A.F.C. South Preview: Houston Is in Line to Win Division, and Maybe More
abstract: The Texans are stocked with talent that should keep them near the top of the division for years, particularly if they can avoid the kind of injuries that may ultimately have shortened their playoff run in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Player to Watch The Colts may not go far this season, but follow quarterback Andrew Luck anyway. We’re probably going to be watching him win for a long time.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Puns and Anagrams by Mel Taub.
lead_paragraph: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — At one point in the not-too-distant past, I was critical of the Puns and Anagrams puzzles because I thought they were too easy. I had compared them in my mind to the cryptics we work on occasion, and perhaps that was my mistake. Perhaps I was feeling cranky that day.

headline: Excluded From Inclusion
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Homosexuality', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In its omission of gays and lesbians, the Republican National Convention in Tampa was cowardly.
lead_paragraph: Tampa, Fla.

headline: The U.S. Open Chronicles: A Loss, but It’s Cool
abstract: Irina Falconi and Steve Johnson lost a mixed doubles match to Kim Clijsters and Bob Bryan on Friday. The losers are now rooting for the winners. Loudly.
lead_paragraph: Irina Falconi, who is playing at the United States Open this year, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

headline: Bombers Strike Outside U.S. Military Base in Afghanistan
abstract: Taliban suicide bombers killed at least a dozen Afghans and wounded 58 others outside the same American military outpost where a similar attack one year ago wounded scores of American soldiers.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban suicide bombers staged what appeared to be a carefully coordinated attack southwest of Kabul on Saturday that killed at least a dozen Afghans and wounded 58 more just outside the same American military outpost where a similar attack one year ago wounded scores of American soldiers.

headline: California’s ‘Willful Disobedience’
abstract: The state must limit its number of prisoners as the Supreme Court has ordered.
lead_paragraph: Last year the Supreme Court took the extraordinary step of ordering California to reduce the dangerous overcrowding in its prisons. The state had challenged an earlier ruling requiring it to meet a specific limit on the number of state prisoners. The court firmly rejected that challenge.

headline: Nets Show Interest in Blatche
abstract: The Nets’ ongoing search for frontcourt depth has led them to Houston, and a meeting with Andray Blatche, who was cut this summer by the Washington Wizards.
lead_paragraph: The Nets’ ongoing search for frontcourt depth has led them to Houston and a meeting with Andray Blatche, who was cut this summer by the Washington Wizards.

headline: Franklin Delano Romney
abstract: In the Republican campaign strategy, there are echoes of Roosevelt in 1932.
lead_paragraph: THE last time the United States held a presidential election amid the mass unemployment left in a financial crisis’s wake, the challenger offered only a partial glimpse of what he would actually do in office. Mostly, he played the opportunist, attacking the incumbent party for spending too much and helping too little, for being indifferent to human suffering and for failing to balance the budget, for overtaxing and undertaxing and everywhere in between. He claimed to be offering a bold contrast of visions, but mostly he just relied on the unemployment rate to do his work for him.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say They Have Seized an Air Defense Post and Its Missiles
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Opposition fighters seized weapons and ammunition in what appeared to be part of a broader rebel offensive against Syrian military installations across the country.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Opposition fighters in Syria said early Saturday that they had captured an air defense base in the eastern province of Deir el-Zour, taking at least 16 soldiers captive and seizing weapons and ammunition in what appeared to be part of a broader rebel offensive against Syrian military installations in several parts of the country.

headline: Tuning Out Taunts but Not Escaping Doubt, Braun’s Back in Top Form
abstract: Ryan Braun, the Brewers’ left fielder, who leads the National League in home runs, won his appeal of a positive drug test but can’t escape the shadow of suspicion.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As the Milwaukee Brewers’ Ryan Braun jogged to left field in the first inning of a game against the Cubs last week, the catcalls cascaded from the Wrigley Field bleachers.

headline: Loopholes in Tobacco Regulation
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Youth', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Cigars', 'Pipes, Smoking', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: The tobacco industry is evading federal taxes and bans designed to keep tobacco out of the hands of young adults.
lead_paragraph: Give the tobacco industry credit for ingenuity. Just when it looked as if federal regulators could block their ability to addict children and young adults, several companies that make cigars and pipe tobacco have sidestepped the barriers by taking advantage of loopholes in federal law.

headline: Altidore Hears Coach’s Message to U.S. National Team: Get Tough
abstract: Striker Jozy Altidore, a likely member of the United States national team for two World Cup qualifiers against Jamaica, says Jurgen Klinsmann is not seeking dirty play.
lead_paragraph: In some quarters, Jurgen Klinsmann’s admonition that the United States national team needs to be less gentle has been discussed and dissected, called unsporting by some, too cynical and severe by others.

headline: It Began With a Bang
abstract: The 2012 Summer Paralympic Games continue in London after an opening ceremony that was truly cosmic.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t started following the 2012 Summer Paralympic Games, which began Wednesday in London, you’ve missed some good stuff, including an opening ceremony that was truly cosmic. It featured the physicist Stephen Hawking as master of ceremonies and Sir Ian McKellen as Prospero, wearing a gown of stars and telling Miranda, who was floating above the stadium in a wheelchair, to “shine your light on the beautiful diversity of humanity,” which wasn’t Shakespeare but sounded enough like it. The ceremony, whose theme was “Enlightenment,” re-enacted the Big Bang and featured an appearance by the Large Hadron Collider, the Higgs boson, giant falling apples and a choir singing a new piece, “Principia.”

headline: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
abstract: Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: Still No Justice for Mortgage Abuses
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: Borrowers need relief, and banks need to be held accountable for the mortgage mess.
lead_paragraph: It has been six months since the big banks settled with state and federal officials over evidence of widespread foreclosure fraud, promising to provide $25 billion in mortgage relief in exchange for not being sued over past foreclosure abuses.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Obama Takes a Page From an Unexpected Victory in Colorado
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: President Obama is following the path of Senator Michael Bennet, who defeated a conservative Republican in 2010, a year of struggle for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — As President Obama navigates the battleground states that will determine whether he wins a second term, his campaign strategists have unfolded a road map for one in particular. And they are following it closely as the best route to their destination.

headline: Mrs. Clinton’s Asia Mission
abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton travels to Beijing this week as the American focus on the region continues.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney has identified Asia as one place where he wants to focus more attention if elected, but the truth is that President Obama has already staked out a forceful position there with his commitment to rebalance American interests from the Middle East to the Pacific.

headline: In 1972, Hockey’s Cold War Boiled Over
abstract: Forty years ago, Canada and the Soviet Union battled in the Summit Series, which became a defining moment for both nations, on and off the ice.
lead_paragraph: Forty years later, it remains seared in the Canadian consciousness. The Summit Series of September 1972: eight games that not only changed hockey but also became a defining national event.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: How Corporations Behave
abstract: Readers discuss business ethics and priorities over the years.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss business ethics and priorities over the years.

headline: Reagan’s Personal Spying Machine
abstract: When Ronald Reagan needed the government to do him personal favors, he was happy to use it, which might give pause to those who speak glowingly of the Reagan legacy.
lead_paragraph: IN 1961, when Ronald Reagan was defining himself politically, he warned that if left unchecked, government would become “a Big Brother to us all.” But previously undisclosed F.B.I. records, released to me after a long and costly legal fight under the Freedom of Information Act, present a different side of the man who has come to symbolize the conservative philosophy of less government and greater self-reliance.

headline: Road Shows Get Rolling for Romney and Obama
abstract: Big crowds cheered both presidential candidates as Mitt Romney began a post-convention tour and President Obama looked ahead to his own convention next week.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Big crowds cheered both of the presidential candidates on Saturday as Mitt Romney began a cross-country campaign swing here testing his momentum coming out of the Republican convention, and President Obama started his own tour heading into his convention this week.

headline: Ode to the List
abstract: Michael Jackson’s show notes, Picasso’s recommendations and other lists up-close.
lead_paragraph: Michael Jackson’s show notes, Picasso’s recommendations and other lists up-close.

headline: A Trial on Death Row
abstract: In Connecticut, a trial begins Wednesday that challenges the death row sentences for inmates.
lead_paragraph: An extraordinary trial is scheduled to begin Wednesday in Connecticut, held at the prison housing the state’s death row. The petitioners are inmates sentenced to death for violent felonies, who are seeking to have their sentences reduced to life without parole on the ground that the death penalty in Connecticut is unconstitutional because it has been randomly imposed on a small group of people.

headline: Cruel Conservatives Throw a Masquerade Ball
abstract: A Mormon bishop, an Irish undertaker and a dirty Dirty Harry walk into a bar ...
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: Our Longing for Lists
abstract: How do we list things? Let us endlessly count the ways. ...
lead_paragraph: WITH school starting and vacations ending, this is the month, the season of the list. But face it. We’re living in the era of the list, maybe even its golden age. The Web click has led to the wholesale repackaging of information into lists, which can be complex and wonderful pieces of information architecture. Our technology has imperceptibly infected us with “list thinking.”

headline: Where’s Walden? GPS Often Doesn’t Know
abstract: Despite 21st-century conveniences like GPS devices, Walden Pond, Henry David Thoreau’s idyllic retreat in the woods of Concord, Mass., remains hard to find.
lead_paragraph: LYNN, Mass. — Walden Pond, Henry David Thoreau’s idyllic retreat in the woods of Concord, Mass., has long been one of the most famous day trips in New England, drawing droves of visitors seeking the tranquil beauty immortalized in the 19th-century philosopher’s writings.

headline: A Heady Nightcap in a City Not Known for Sleeping
abstract: Night tennis at the United States Open received a chilly reception when it began in 1975, but now players consider matches under the lights an honor.
lead_paragraph: Night tennis began at the United States Open in 1975 with certain stars trying to beg out and certain patrons trying to dump unwanted tickets on scalpers.

headline: The Vengeance of the Lard
abstract: Don’t underestimate empty chairs.
lead_paragraph: I spent a lot of time in England during the early 1990s (Robin was teaching there, while I was at MIT). And when there I regularly watched Have I Got News For You, a quiz show in which two teams competed to answer questions about the week’s headlines. Each timeteam consisted of a show regular and a newsmaker guest.

headline: Drawing With a Purpose, By Michael Graves
abstract: Michael Graves explains, through his art, why drawing is still an important architectural skill.
lead_paragraph: Michael Graves explains, through his art, why drawing is still an important architectural skill.

headline: Monetary Versus Fiscal Policy, Revisited
abstract: Not a contradiction.
lead_paragraph: One recurring complaint from commenters on this blog is that they can’t figure out where I stand on monetary versus fiscal policy as a response to a deeply depressed economy. Sometimes, they say, I declare that monetary policy is ineffective once you’re at the zero lower bound; other times I berate Ben Bernanke for not doing more. Which is it?

headline: Architecture and the Lost Art of Drawing
abstract: The computer is encroaching on the most powerful tool in architecture: drawing.
lead_paragraph: Princeton, N.J.

headline: U.S. Women’s Stars Hope, Cautiously, That a New Pro League Will Form
abstract: The gold medal winners Abby Wambach, Christie Rampone and Alex Morgan hope for the opportunity to play professionally in the United States again.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — Three weeks after a gold medal victory at the Olympics, the United States women’s soccer team gathered here Friday for a leisurely practice in advance of Saturday’s first game of a 10-game celebratory tour.

headline: Hate-Crime Trial Offers a Crash Course in Amish Folkways
abstract: The trial of Samuel Mullet Sr. and some of his followers accused in connection with beard-cutting attacks spotlights the ways of an obscure religious group.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Nancy Mullet entered a federal courtroom here on Thursday to testify in the hate-crimes trial of her father-in-law, Samuel Mullet Sr., and followers of his renegade sect, the jury knew at a glance which side she favored in this wrenching clash among Amish.

headline: Scaring the Voters in the Middle
abstract: Everything you always wanted to know about sex and the G.O.P. (but were afraid to ask).
lead_paragraph: THE claims of Representative Todd Akin that women don’t get pregnant from “legitimate rape” now live in infamy. But a few things you may not know:

headline: It’s Still Halftime in America
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'United States International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Small Business']
abstract: Being at the Republican convention brought to mind what this race really needs: a choice between two exceptional journeys.
lead_paragraph: Tampa, Fla.

headline: Islamists Struggle to Run North Mali
keywords: ['Civil War and Guerrilla Warfare', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Bamako government still controls the southern rump of Malian territory, while the north is in the hands of radical jihadi factions that took over last spring.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The radical Islamists who control northern Mali appear incapable of managing basic services — including electricity, water and schools — and in some cases are asking for the return of state functionaries to run them, according to a delegation that went to the region for talks recently.

headline: N.F.C. West Preview: Makeover Continues for Rejuvenated 49ers
abstract: The 49ers appear ready to shift into a more dynamic passing powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: Player to Watch Randy Moss. You haven’t traveled a decade back in time. Moss may not put up the numbers he did in his best years, or even in 2007 with the Patriots. But if he can still stretch the field, he can make San Francisco even more potent.

headline: In Louisiana, the Water Gives, and Takes Away
abstract: Plaquemines Parish, the marshy peninsula of southeastern Louisiana, was the first landing point of Hurricane Isaac and the scene of perhaps its most thorough destruction.
lead_paragraph: VENICE, La. — The end of the earth was farther away than usual.

headline: A.F.C. West Preview: Broncos’ Success Hinges on Manning’s
abstract: If Peyton Manning is even close to his old self — in the preseason, he seemed to have the most trouble with accuracy on the deepest passes — he makes the Broncos playoff contenders, at the least.
lead_paragraph: Player to Watch Don’t overthink this. Peyton Manning.

headline: Tracking a Subtle Scent, a Dog May Help Save the Whales
abstract: Tucker, a black lab mix, is said to be the world’s only working dog able to track the scent of orca feces, which give clues to the whales’ health, in open ocean water.
lead_paragraph: OFF THE COAST OF SAN JUAN ISLAND, Wash. — A dog named Tucker with a thumping tail and a mysterious past as a stray on the streets of Seattle has become an unexpected star in the realm of canine-assisted science. He is the world’s only working dog, marine biologists say, able to find and track the scent of orca scat, or feces, in open ocean water — up to a mile away, in the smallest of specks.

headline: Salty Dog
abstract: Scientists analyze the scat of orca whales to monitor their health. But finding samples isn’t easy unless Tucker, a black lab mix who can sniff out the droppings from a mile away, is on board.
lead_paragraph: Scientists analyze the scat of orca whales to monitor their health. But finding samples isn’t easy unless Tucker, a black lab mix who can sniff out the droppings from a mile away, is on board.

headline: In Russia, Opening Inquiries and Settling Scores
abstract: A series of inquiries into the business affairs of a prominent opposition lawmaker in Russia has led to finger pointing at governing party legislators and their obvious personal wealth.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When the Russian authorities began a series of investigations this spring into the business affairs of a prominent opposition lawmaker, it was widely viewed as thinly veiled political retribution.

headline: With New Owners, Padres Bullish on Future
abstract: Since June 12 the San Diego Padres are 42-30, a foundation they hope to build on next season.
lead_paragraph: The San Diego Padres officially announced their $800 million sale last week to a group headed by Ron Fowler, the chairman of a beverage-distribution company in California and Colorado, and four grandsons of Walter O’Malley, the Hall of Fame owner who took the Brooklyn Dodgers to Los Angeles in 1958. The group takes over a team that is probably better than most fans realize.

headline: Between the Acts
abstract: Gail Collins and David Brooks discuss the political conventions.
lead_paragraph: GAIL COLLINS David, we’re halfway through the convention process. We’ve spent quite a bit of time conversing about it in different venues and now — print! I’m enjoying the conversing. It’s just the conventions themselves I’ve come to hate.

headline: Is This Title O.K.?
abstract: I think I would be good at coming up with names for perfumes. Or vacuum cleaners. But when it comes to books, the job feels impossible.
lead_paragraph: Beginning – check. Middle – check. End – check. But, hold on a sec, isn’t there something missing? Something rather vital? In fact, couldn’t it be the key to your book’s selling or not? Ah, yes, the title.

headline: At Journey’s End
abstract: Mets Manager Terry Collins endured 10 seasons in the Pittsburgh Pirates and Los Angeles Dodgers organizations, but he never made it to the big leagues as a player.
lead_paragraph: Before a game during the Mets’ last homestand, Terry Collins emerged from the dugout, picked up a baseball and began warming up his arm as he walked toward second base to watch batting practice. Three decades earlier, Collins, 63, would have performed a similar routine, when he was a utility player in the minor leagues.

headline: Clear Goals Matter More Than Mission
abstract: Tracy Streckenbach, president of Innovative Global Brands and a turnaround specialist, says it’s important that a company have clearly defined and measurable goals.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Tracy Streckenbach, president and chief operating officer of Innovative Global Brands, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Why Campaign Reporters Are Behind the Curve
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Journalists are unable to keep up with the the revolution in political information gathering.
lead_paragraph: It becomes popular around this time of year to lament the fact that media coverage treats the presidential campaign as little more than a “horse race.” Journalists, this line of argument goes, choose to fixate on which candidate is a superior campaigner or savvier strategist, not on who has sounder ideas or is better prepared to govern. From time to time, the journalists themselves concede that to maintain daily or hourly tension in the contests they promote, they have little choice but to elevate minor poll shifts into major developments.

headline: Mortgage Registry Muddles Foreclosures
abstract: MERS, the Mortgage Electronic Registration System set up by banks to track mortgages, is under fire for inaccuracies that cost one Ohio homeowner dearly.
lead_paragraph: MORE good news from the housing front last week. Pending home sales rose 2.4 percent in July, to their highest level since April 2010. Mortgage delinquency rates are down: the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported a decline of 6.3 percent at the end of June from the March quarter.

headline: Czech Town’s Other Pride
abstract: Andrea Hlavackova is the only player still alive in singles, doubles and mixed doubles at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: The Czech Republic, with a little more than 10 million people, has produced a disproportionate number of tennis champions. Aside from tennis trophies, another thing the Czechs hoist in disproportionate amounts is beer. Unlike in tennis, the Czechs have little competition in this category, with the average citizen consuming 131 liters a year, more than Germany, Austria and Ireland by 25 liters.

headline: Letters: A Task Unfinished, a Lesson Learned
abstract: Readers respond to “In His Kitchen, You’ll Refrain From Shouting” (Corner Office, Aug. 26).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Breaking the Silence on a Carbon Tax
abstract: Readers respond to “Carbon Tax Silence, Overtaken by Events” (Economic View, Aug. 26).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Harrison Brothers Advance to Third Round
abstract: The American brothers Christian and Ryan Harrison defeated the Israeli doubles team of Jonathan Erlich and Andy Ram, 6-4, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: The American brothers Christian and Ryan Harrison defeated the veteran Israeli doubles team of Jonathan Erlich and Andy Ram, 6-4, 6-4, on Saturday in the second round of the United States Open.

headline: Lengthy Deal, Shrinking E.R.A.
abstract: After only two starts in the majors, the pitcher Matt Moore signed a contract that could keep him in Tampa Bay through 2019.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — In 1996, the year he turned 7, Matt Moore moved with his family to Kadena Air Base in Okinawa, Japan. His father, Marty, worked on Special Operations helicopters and was transferred there from Florida.

headline: Can Europe Survive the Rise of the Rest?
keywords: ['International Relations', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: The European Union will never manage to compete with China and other rising powers unless it unites politically, scales up and becomes a genuine giant.
lead_paragraph: Oxford, England

headline: Sharing the Stage
abstract: Jets quarterbacks Mark Sanchez and Tim Tebow have developed a friendship despite vying for playing time.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As quarterback Greg McElroy conducted an interview after the Jets’ preseason finale Thursday in Philadelphia, Mark Sanchez started plotting the prank. Nodding toward McElroy, Sanchez motioned to the teammate standing between them to pass an orange wedge. Sanchez crept behind McElroy and shoved the fruit down the back of his T-shirt. While McElroy squirmed, Sanchez bumped fists with his co-conspirator, Tim Tebow.

headline: A Weight-Loss Strategy From an Unlikely Pair
abstract: An independent filmmaker and a personal trainer partnered up to start a company whose message is that it’s not what you eat that matters, but how much.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Myles Berkowitz first met Steven Kates through a mutual friend in 2006, Mr. Berkowitz had serious doubts about him.

headline: When GPS Confuses, You May Be to Blame
abstract: A recent study illustrates a drawback of GPS technology: that it could be causing drivers to become too docile as their navigational skills atrophy.
lead_paragraph: The turn-by-turn instructions of GPS-based navigation systems, ingeniously designed though they may be, can’t always save us from ourselves.

headline: German Drug Maker Apologizes to Victims of Thalidomide
abstract: The Grünenthal Group’s apology, but no admission of liability, came 50 years after the defect-causing drug was taken off the market.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Decades of campaigning by victims of thalidomide, a morning sickness drug, have taken a new turn, with the first apology in 50 years to the victims and their families by the drug’s German manufacturer — and an incensed rejection of the apology as too little and too late from many of those it was intended to placate.

headline: On Top, but Off Radar
abstract: No one seems to be talking about the defending N.F.L. champion Giants at all as they prepare for Wednesday’s season opener, which is business as usual for them.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In previous years, the Giants have been quick to embrace Coach Tom Coughlin’s seasonal slogan as a mantra, with the two most notable refrains — “Talk is cheap, play the game” and “Finish” — being featured prominently in the 2007 and 2011 Super Bowl championship seasons.

headline: Troubled Times for Plaquemines Parish
abstract: Venice sits at the end of the road in Plaquemines Parish, the peninsula of southeastern Louisiana that was the first landing point of Hurricane Isaac and the scene of perhaps its most thorough destruction.
lead_paragraph: Venice sits at the end of the road in Plaquemines Parish, the peninsula of southeastern Louisiana that was the first landing point of Hurricane Isaac and the scene of perhaps its most thorough destruction.

headline: Murray Holds It Together in the Heat, and Federer Cruises to a Win
abstract: Andy Murray needed three tiebreakers to dispatch Feliciano López in four sets. Despite flashbacks to a crushing defeat last year, the top-seeded Roger Federer advanced more easily.
lead_paragraph: The Big Four in men’s tennis came to New York minus Rafael Nadal, and for stretches of Saturday afternoon it looked as if the three present might be reduced to two.

headline: Two Americans Are Buried a Year After a Train Crash in China
abstract: After more than a year of fighting with Chinese government officials, the sons of two Americans killed in a train crash finally buried their parents in Queens.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Cao Erxing and his wife, Chen Zengrong, both 56, were killed in a high-speed train crash in China. But it was not until Saturday that their relatives in New York City were finally able to gather to mourn their loss and bury their loved ones.

headline: Music of the Unquiet Mind
abstract: John Cage’s 1944 piece “Four Walls” translated the innermost rooms of my obsessive-compulsive mind into sound.

headline: Mitt Romney and Abortion Politics
abstract: Readers weigh in on my column about the GOP and reproductive health
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at the GOP and reproductive health, from abortion to sex education. As you can see from the column, I think it’s a pathetic sight — but in fairness, one point I wish I had had space for in the column is to note that if the Republican platform is baffling in its message to centrist voters, it’s also arguably a rare example of political courage. Republicans are looking at the same polls I am, and presumably they realize that their reluctance to back exceptions in abortion bans for rape or the health of the mother risk losing voters. It’s not often that politicians risk losing votes for something that they believe in, and I give them credit for that — even though I think their positions are utter nonsense. Your thoughts?

headline: ‘Framing’ Prevents Needed Stimulus
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Government Employees']
abstract: If state and local governments had not cut back so much, the broader economy would be stronger today. So why did they do what they did?
lead_paragraph: WHY have so many teachers, police officers, firefighters and other public workers been laid off since the financial crisis hit — and why are so few being offered new jobs now?

headline: Obama Visits Swing States Before Convention
abstract: With his party’s nominating convention approaching, President Obama started a four-day campaign swing in Iowa on Saturday, returning to the state where he opened his unlikely quest for the presidency five years ago.
lead_paragraph: URBANDALE, Iowa — With his party’s nominating convention approaching next week, President Obama started a four-day, four-state campaign trip on Saturday in Iowa, the state where he opened his quest for the presidency five years ago.

headline: Ryan’s Latest Reclamation Project Stands Out Right Away
abstract: Coach Rex Ryan hopes Jason Smith can revive his career with the Jets in the same way last season’s castoff-acquisition Aaron Maybin did.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets and the Rams thought that by swapping tackles, each could salvage an underperforming player and improve in pass protection. After putting tackle Jason Smith through a crash course on the playbook and evaluating his performance in the preseason finale, the Jets proclaimed themselves satisfied with the deal.

headline: Trying to Win Race He Helped Save
abstract: Michael Andretti, who has prospered as a race promoter, has been enlisted to help revamp and improve this weekend’s Grand Prix of Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — J. P. Grant III knows far more about financing than he does about auto racing. But he is a big civic booster, and he believes that the Indy-car race on the streets around the Inner Harbor can become like the Preakness — only with more horsepower.

headline: 30 Seconds With Fredy Montero
abstract: Fredy Montero, 25, a native of Colombia, has played for the Seattle Sounders since 2009. He hopes to play in Europe someday.
lead_paragraph: After coming off the bench in four of the previous six games, Fredy Montero returned to the Seattle Sounders’ starting lineup last weekend against Chivas USA and scored his first hat trick in his 100th game in Major League Soccer. That increased his season total to 11 goals, giving him four consecutive seasons with 10 or more for the Sounders.

headline: Duquette and Orioles Back in the Game
abstract: Dan Duquette is nearing the end of his first season as the Baltimore Orioles’ executive vice president for baseball operations, and his first team has been better than any rational person could have expected.
lead_paragraph: More than most, Dan Duquette understands the need to share credit for a team’s success. As the general manager of the Boston Red Sox from 1994 to 2001, Duquette acquired many of the players who would win the team’s first championship in 86 years, in 2004. While his successor, Theo Epstein, got the glory, Duquette spent nearly a decade without a job in the majors.

headline: In a Ban, a Measure of European Tolerance
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslim Veiling']
abstract: Defenders and critics in France agree that the actual impact of a law banning full-face veils in public places has been far less dramatic than the politicized prologue to it.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — During a recent protest in Marseille, seven people were suddenly surrounded by the police, bundled into a van and brought in for questioning. Their offense was not the demonstration itself but the balaclavas they were wearing, a violation of the French law banning full-face veils in public places, passed in April 2011.

headline: In a Post-Convention Bump, Romney Draws Huge Crowds in Cincinnati
abstract: In Cincinnati, a crowd of thousands cheered Mitt Romney at a rally on Saturday during the start of a cross-country campaign swing.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI – A crowd of thousands cheered Mitt Romney at a rally here during the opening leg of a cross-country campaign swing on Saturday, testing for the first time whether he can sustain political momentum coming out of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Forward Progress
abstract: At a low point in his injury battle, Peyton Manning sought refuge in Denver. Now he is in a Broncos uniform — and much stronger than he was then.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — “The perfect time to tell this story is after we win the Super Bowl this year.”

headline: ‘Good Girls’ Fight to Be Journalists
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Discrimination', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: “The Good Girls Revolt” is about how a small band of women at Newsweek successfully challenged sex discrimination at the magazine and throughout the industry.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I graduated from college, before the Civil Rights Act of 1964 took effect, sex discrimination was legal. I wanted to write for a newspaper or newsmagazine, but despite an armload of credentials and skills, I soon learned the score: Women could do research, be secretaries and, if very lucky, work for the ghetto called the women’s page. But other than that, the guys were hired as the writers, and that was that.

headline: Unified, in America, by an International Sport
abstract: The men’s squad from the New York City Team Handball Club won its fourth national title in five years in May, bolstering its reputation as the best team handball outfit in the United States.
lead_paragraph: On a makeshift court in Minneapolis, victorious players locked arms around one another’s necks and broke into an unusual cheer.

headline: Don’t Shy Away From Growth Stocks
abstract: It is a mistake to ignore faster-growing sectors, like technology and industrial companies, despite the economic worries that rattle the markets.
lead_paragraph: WHEN economic worries rattle the markets, some investors take cover in defensive areas, like slow-but-steady utilities. This is what has driven the “risk-off” trade that Wall Street types talk about.

headline: Inquiry on Tax Strategy Adds to Scrutiny of Finance Firms
abstract: The New York attorney general is investigating whether private equity firms converted fees into investments to reduce their tax bills, raising pressure on an industry bruised by the campaign season.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general is investigating whether some of the nation’s biggest private equity firms have abused a tax strategy in order to slice hundreds of millions of dollars from their tax bills, according to executives with direct knowledge of the inquiry.

headline: 30 Yards in the Air or 3 Yards in the Dust?
abstract: In the N.F.L., four of the top six individual single-season passing marks — including one by Eli Manning of the Super Bowl champion Giants — were set in 2011.
lead_paragraph: The Giants had finished the first practice of training camp this summer when Coach Tom Coughlin, in a moment that might have seemed to come out of the mid-1970s, announced his hopes for the new season.

headline: Hopes Are Dashed to Have Regular N.F.L. Officials Back for First Week
abstract: Negotiations between the N.F.L. and its locked-out officials broke off Saturday morning, all but ensuring that replacement referees would work at least the first week of the regular season.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations between the N.F.L. and its locked-out officials broke off Saturday morning, all but ensuring that replacement referees would work at least the first week of the regular season, which starts Wednesday. No further talks were scheduled.

headline: When the Work-Life Scales Are Unequal
abstract: The pursuit of “work-life balance,” which sounds so wholesome and reasonable, can be a zero-sum game in the office.
lead_paragraph: KELLY Azevedo used to work upward of 70 hours a week.

headline: In Flexible-Work Debates, Parents Have Unique Position
abstract: When “workplace flexibility” becomes a battle between a 20-something with Mandarin lessons and a venture capitalist taking his children to swim class, we lose sight of the workers most in need of flexibility.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to workplace flexibility, fair doesn’t always mean equal.

headline: Yankees Get a Lift from the Newcomer Pearce
abstract: Steve Pearce, whom the Yankees picked up from Houston, started the decisive three-run rally in the seventh inning with a single in a victory over the Orioles.
lead_paragraph: Steve Pearce was surprised when the Baltimore Orioles designated him for assignment July 21, but he believed the demotion was temporary. He was fully prepared to report to Class AAA Norfolk with the expectation that he would soon be recalled to join the Orioles in a pennant race.

headline: At Age 59, Interning to Fulfill Old Dream
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Careers and Professions', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Internships']
abstract: More than 20 years after leaving college because she ran out of money, the writer earned bachelor’s and master’s degrees in psychology.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the things I’ve learned is that career plans often go awry. Industries change, health problems arise, a baby comes along or other events intervene. I had always planned to become a mental health counselor, but I veered off course years ago and am interning in the field for the first time at age 59.

headline: The Value of Starting Small
abstract: The chief executive of SurveyMonkey started an online music site at age 26 that he later sold to Yahoo.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in Minneapolis. My mother, a former teacher, went back to work when my younger brother went to kindergarten. I was 8. She had a friend whose child had a disability, which inspired the two of them to start the nonprofit Pacer Center. They wanted to help parents of children with disabilities and expand the opportunities for these youngsters. My mother still runs the organization today.

headline: New Era at Penn State Starts With Loss at Home
abstract: In Bill O’Brien’s first game as coach, the Nittany Lions led Ohio, 14-3, at halftime but did not score in the second half.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — The Penn State faithful would have stood here even if they could not see a thing. Thousands of them did. They held their sons and daughters on their shoulders for a glimpse. Down the street they lined up, holding signs that read, “You stayed with us ...,” and on the back, “... We stand with you.”

headline: Obama on Reddit, Ryan in Tweets
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Ben Smith of BuzzFeed talks with The Times’s Jim Roberts about headlines in social media at the 2012 Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Ben Smith of BuzzFeed talks with The Times’s Jim Roberts about headlines in social media at the 2012 Republican National Convention.

headline: Hal David, Songwriter, Is Dead at 91
abstract: The Oscar- and Grammy-winning lyricist was best known for the long strand of hits he and the composer Burt Bacharach wrote for Dionne Warwick.
lead_paragraph: Hal David, the Oscar- and Grammy-winning lyricist who in the 1960s and ’70s gave pop music vernacular the questions “What’s it all about?,” “What’s new, pussycat?,” “Do you know the way to San Jose?” and “What do you get when you fall in love?,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 91 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Tony Hayward Gets His Life Back
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']
abstract: Tony Hayward, the chief of BP who was accused of insensitivity and incompetence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill of 2010, is back in the oil business and seeking redemption.
lead_paragraph: LONDON

headline: After Fed Action, Then What?
abstract: There was broad agreement in Jackson Hole, Wyo., that the stimulus that the Fed is considering, and may announce in two weeks, will not revive the economy. Indeed, given the magnitude of the looming “fiscal cliff,” they may not even be enough to prevent a recession.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The Fed is on the verge of expanding its stimulus policies. We learned that much during the meetings in Jackson Hole, Wyo. But what may be more interesting is the undercurrent of discussion about what happens when those measures prove insufficient.

headline: The Summit Series of 1972: Talking With J.P. Parise
abstract: Forty years ago, the N.H.L. stars of Team Canada played the Soviet national team in the Summit Series. J.P. Parise, who played for the Minnesota North Stars, remembers the time.
lead_paragraph: September marks the 40th anniversary of the Summit Series, the unforgettable clash between the N.H.L. professionals of Team Canada and the titans of international hockey, the Soviet national team.

headline: Pardon Ze Interruption
abstract: Ze news from Joel Fagliano.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Who knew there were so many ways to spell the sound “zee”?

headline: The Agenda: Foreign Policy
abstract: The Times’s Cairo bureau chief David Kirkpatrick discusses the future of foreign policy. Mitt Romney’s foreign policy adviser Kristen Silverberg weighs in with The Times’s Marcus Mabry.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Cairo bureau chief David Kirkpatrick discusses the future of foreign policy. Mitt Romney’s foreign policy adviser Kristen Silverberg weighs in with The Times’s Marcus Mabry.

headline: Syrian Refugees Pour Into Jordan
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Nearly 2,000 Syrians are flooding nightly into Jordan, which says it has accepted about 180,000 refugees since the conflict began.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 2,000 Syrians are flooding nightly into Jordan, which says it has accepted about 180,000 refugees since the conflict began.

headline: Airstrikes Push Waves of Syrians to Jordanian Camps
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Since air assaults by Syria’s government picked up two weeks ago, knocking rebels in the south on their heels, refugees have been arriving at camps in Jordan at a rate of about 2,000 a night.
lead_paragraph: ZAATARI, Jordan — The five Jamous brothers were early recruits to the Free Syrian Army, eager to oust President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: A Nose for Research
abstract: A dog named Tucker has become an unexpected star in the realm of canine-assisted science.
lead_paragraph: A dog named Tucker has become an unexpected star in the realm of canine-assisted science.

headline: A Delayed Mourning
abstract: After more than a year of fighting with Chinese government officials, the sons of two Americans killed in a train crash finally buried their parents in Queens.
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of fighting with Chinese government officials, the sons of two Americans killed in a train crash finally buried their parents in Queens.

headline: Alexander Saxton, Historian and Novelist, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Saxton was a writer ostracized as a Communist, who went on to become a prominent cultural historian, transforming his life in his 40s.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Saxton, who would go on to become a prominent historian of race in America, summed himself up in a blurb on the dust jacket of his first novel, “Grand Crossing,” published when he was 24.

headline: Isaac’s Vestiges Bring Midwest Rain
abstract: The remnants of Hurricane Isaac brought much-needed rain to the Midwest on Saturday, along with scattered reports of tornadoes.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Hurricane Isaac, the slow-moving storm that disrupted the Republican National Convention and flooded towns along the Gulf Coast, brought much-needed rain to the Midwest on Saturday, along with scattered reports of tornadoes.

headline: Party Intrigue Seen in China as Official Is Demoted
abstract: Ling Jihua, who was a close adviser to President Hu Jintao, was named head of a department that deals with unions at a time when powerful factions are forcing China’s leaders to protect their political networks.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Ling Jihua, a senior Chinese official and a close ally of President Hu Jintao, was named Saturday to a new post in a move that some Communist Party experts said was a demotion and a surprising development ahead of this year’s leadership transition.

headline: Byard Lancaster, Jazz Alto Saxophonist, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Lancaster was an alto saxophonist who took part in the great wave of free jazz inspired by John Coltrane.
lead_paragraph: Byard Lancaster, an alto saxophonist who took part in the great wave of free jazz inspired by John Coltrane and then diversified far into other music and cultures — living in Nigeria, France and Chicago, playing blues, reggae and Afrobeat — but kept returning to Philadelphia, his hometown, died on Aug. 23 at a hospice in Wyndmoor, Pa. He was 70.

headline: The Summit Series of 1972: Talking With Vladimir Petrov
abstract: Forty years ago, the N.H.L. stars of Team Canada played the Soviet national team in the Summit Series. Vladimir Petrov, who played for the Soviets, recalls the memorable first game.
lead_paragraph: Forty years ago Sunday, on Sept. 2, 1972, in Montreal, one of the most stunning upsets in the history of sports took place. Team Canada — an N.H.L. all-star team led by Phil Esposito, Brad Park, Yvan Cournoyer, Frank and Peter Mahovlich, Bobby Clarke,Ken Dryden and the Rangers’ GAG Line of Jean Ratelle, Rod Gilbert and Vic Hadfield — met the Soviet national team, the world and Olympic champion but a group that had never played a game against professional opponents.

headline: Almagro Ends Sock’s Run in Four Sets
abstract: Nicolas Almagro of Spain will advance to the fourth round of the Open for the first time after fighting off a spirited challenge from the up-and-coming American teenager Jack Sock.
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Almagro of Spain will advance to the fourth round of the United States Open for the first time after fighting off a spirited challenge from the up-and-coming American teenager Jack Sock on Saturday afternoon. Almagro, seeded 11th, pulled out a 7-6 (3), 6-7 (4), 7-6 (2), 6-1 victory in the sultry afternoon heat of the half-sunbaked, half-shaded Grandstand Stadium.

headline: Peter Shelton, Architect Who Made Luxury Minimal, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Shelton and his longtime design partner, Lee Mindel, were known for interior designs that blended clean lines with references to classical periods to create opulent settings.
lead_paragraph: Peter Shelton, an award-winning architect whose sleek yet luxurious interior designs won his firm commissions for the homes of wealthy people and for corporate showcases like the headquarters of Polo Ralph Lauren, died on Aug. 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

headline: In Battle for Round of 16, Cilic Prevails Over Nishikori
abstract: Marin Cilic of Croatia, seeded 12th and able to force errors, won, 6-3, 6-4, 6-7 (3), 6-3.
lead_paragraph: Early in the third set, into a sky bright with a blistering sun, Kei Nishikori of Japan tossed the ball high and aced Marin Cilic of Croatia to take a 4-3 lead. For nearly 2,800 spectators, there was hope that the contest might extend beyond three sets.  They got their wish.

headline: Once They Stopped Laughing, Things Got Serious Fast
abstract: Canada’s hockey pride nearly proved costly against a mysterious Soviet team in the 1972 Summit Series.
lead_paragraph: On a September afternoon in Montreal in 1972, I stood next to the Rangers’ Brad Park at the Forum as we watched the Soviet Union’s best hockey players go through their bizarre practice rituals. In one routine, they swarmed at center ice like mad bees.

headline: Sept. 1: Romney’s Convention Bounce Appears Middling So Far
abstract: The polling data so far suggests that the Republican convention may produce only a modest bounce in the polls for Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla. received mediocre television ratings — and the polling data so far suggests that it may produce only a modest bounce in the polls for Mitt Romney.

headline: Giving Juveniles Intensive Counseling
abstract: Something like a maximum-security prison for adults, Texas’ Phoenix Program plucks out the most serious offenders in the juvenile-justice system to undergo intensive counseling.
lead_paragraph: MART — The green-black lines of prison life are scrawled on 16-year-old Luis’s face: a cross on his left cheek, three dots arranged in a triangle under his left eye and “cholo” written vertically on his right cheek.

headline: McIlroy Attracts Following at TPC Boston, but Not All Are Watching Him
abstract: Fans followed Caroline Wozniacki, the Danish tennis player, as she watched her boyfriend, Rory McIlroy, who carded his second consecutive six-under-par 65 to take a two-stroke lead.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — The willowy woman with the blond ponytail and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis oversize sunglasses was standing outside the gallery ropes Saturday morning at the T.P.C. Boston waiting for Rory McIlroy to walk past when one man produced a tennis ball for her to sign. He was followed by another fan with another tennis ball. She obliged both with a smile while a bystander observing the scene from a few feet away turned to a friend and asked, “Why the tennis balls?”

headline: Taking a Break From Poker to Win a Championship
abstract: Almira Skripchenko, who won the French championship for the fifth time, was the top seed, but she no longer competes regularly in chess: she is a professional poker player.
lead_paragraph: The French championship was notable for the outcome on the women’s side and for a stirring display of sportsmanship among the men in the face of tragedy.

headline: Top Official at ICE Quits Over Discrimination Claims
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Discrimination', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: Suzanne Barr, the chief of staff to the director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, resigned on Saturday after accusations that she had created an office culture hostile to men.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior official at the Department of Homeland Security resigned on Saturday after accusations that she had created a sexualized office culture that was hostile to men. The official, Suzanne Barr, is a longtime aide to the department’s secretary, Janet Napolitano, and had been on leave from her position as chief of staff to the director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement because of the allegations.

headline: Singing Her Way Toward Exit, Sundhage Steps Down as U.S. Coach
abstract: Coach Pia Sundhage decided it was time to go home to her native Sweden. She will stay on for the next two games of the United States women’s soccer team’s victory tour.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — Before the first game of a victory tour by the gold-medal-winning United States women’s soccer team, Coach Pia Sundhage decided it was time to go home to Sweden.

headline: Sometimes Being a Fighter Isn’t Enough
abstract: Federal courts ruled last week against Attorney General Greg Abbott in two crucial voting rights cases. Even if those fights aren’t over, the losses do little to burnish his reputation.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Sundhage Leaving U.S. Women’s National Team
abstract: Pia Sundhage is stepping down after five years as coach of the United States women’s national team to become the coach of Sweden.
lead_paragraph: Pia Sundhage is taking her tactics, her teaching and her singing voice home to Sweden.

headline: U.S. Open: Day 6
abstract: Serena Williams and Roger Federer advanced, but Jack Sock, a 19-year-old unseeded American, was ousted in the third round.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams and Roger Federer advanced, but Jack Sock, a 19-year-old unseeded American, was ousted in the third round.

headline: Reflecting on Ambitious Education Plan
abstract: Francisco G. Cigarroa, the University of Texas chancellor, says his plan to improve graduation rates and lower education costs has produced tangible results, but some groups are rethinking their support.
lead_paragraph: At a tense meeting of the University of Texas System Board of Regents on Aug. 25, 2011, after several months in which the board was at the center of a tug of war between groups with differing approaches to higher-education reform, Chancellor Francisco G. Cigarroa unveiled his Framework for Advancing Excellence.

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 30, 7 P.M.
abstract: Part one of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Part one of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Clinton Begins Asia Trip, Trying to Ease Tension With China
abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton began a six-nation visit to Asia by saying that the United States would broaden its presence in the region, but that “the Pacific is big enough for all of us.”
lead_paragraph: RAROTONGA, Cook Islands — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton began a 10-day, 6-nation visit to Asia pledging to broaden American diplomatic, economic and security support in the Pacific, but also offering conciliatory remarks toward China at a time when tensions are rising over territorial disputes.

headline: Big-Box Store Has New Life as an Airy Public Library
abstract: Rather than let a vacant Walmart become an eyesore, the city of McAllen spent $24 million to convert it into a 123,000-square-foot public library.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — The hulking husk of a vacant Walmart here in the Rio Grande Valley is enjoying an unlikely second act. When the big-box retailer moved to a larger location down the street, the building might have been destined to house yet another large chain or to fall into disrepair. But rather than let it become an eyesore, the city scooped it up and spent $24 million transforming the drab structure into a 123,000-square-foot public library that serves as a vibrant space for residents here.

headline: Kurt Maetzig, Pioneering German Director, Dies at 101
abstract: Mr. Maetzig, a pioneering figure in East Germany’s socialist film industry after World War II, helped postwar Germany come to terms with its Nazi past.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Maetzig, a pioneering East German director whose socialist films scrutinized anti-Semitism, explored corporate complicity in the rise of fascism and helped compel Germans to come to terms with their Nazi past, died on Aug. 8 at his home in Germany. He was 101.

headline: Radwanska, Seeded Second but Nearly Unknown, Beats Jankovic
abstract: While she has not commanded the type of adoration or attention that Venus and Serena Williams and Kim Clijsters have, Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland has quietly, stealthily continued to advance
lead_paragraph: The second seed in women’s singles at the United States Open finally played in Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday. Even then, she remained largely unknown outside the more hard-core tennis fans.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Questions From Readers
abstract: Andy Murray said he cried a few days after the Olympics, when the whole thing finally sank in. And any movie with Will Ferrell in it is O.K. by him.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray defeated Feliciano Lopez, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (5), 4-6, 7-6 (4), on Saturday to reach the fourth round of the United States Open. In his regular postmatch interview with Straight Sets, Murray took questions from readers of The New York Times who sent their inquiries from all over the world.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 2
abstract: Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles, chairman of the Democratic National Convention, makes the rounds on the Sunday shows to preview the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Presidential politics will again dominate the conversations on the news shows on Sunday, on the weekend between the closing of the Republican National Convention and the opening of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: The Other Power in the West Wing
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Valerie Jarrett, a senior White House adviser with unmatched access to the Obamas, has been a driving force in some of the most significant domestic policy decisions of the president’s first term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama was in a bind, and his chief of staff could not figure out how he had ended up there.

headline: In a Tactical Test, Romney Stakes Hopes on Ohio
abstract: Mitt Romney’s path to the White House would be severely narrowed without the 18 electoral votes from Ohio, where he continues to trail President Obama in polls.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Fresh off his nominating convention, Mitt Romney is cranking up a well-financed political machine that will now bring its full force to bear on President Obama with a hailstorm of ads and nonstop campaigning.

headline: Corrections: September 2, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 2, 2012.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: TimesCast Politics | August 30, 7 P.M.
abstract: Part two of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Part two of Thursday evening's broadcast of the Republican National Convention.

headline: Ninth-Inning Rally Sends Mets Past Marlins
abstract: An anemic Mets offense took advantage of Marlins closer Steve Cishek and some poor defense to turn a 3-1 deficit in the ninth into a thrilling win over Miami.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It looked as if the good vibes that had been carrying the Mets through late August would not last one game into September.

headline: Clijsters, Whose First Retirement Didn’t Take, Says Her Latest One Will
abstract: Clijsters, who retired in 2007 but returned, said that a second comeback is unlikely. Clijsters and her teammate in mixed doubles, Bob Bryan, were defeated in the second round of the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Kim Clijsters walked onto the Court 17 at the United States Open on Saturday night with her signature smile, waved to the crowd and to her family in the stands and wielded her tennis racket for what was very likely the last time as a professional.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: College Football Replay
abstract: The nation watched to see a new era of Penn State football begin, and the Ohio State Buckeyes, led by Coach Urban Meyer, open the season with a win.
lead_paragraph: The nation watched to see a new era of Penn State football begin, and the Ohio State Buckeyes, led by Coach Urban Meyer, open the season with a win.

headline: Anne Szeker, Leif Detlefsen
abstract: A wedding in Hartford.
lead_paragraph: Anne Elizabeth Szeker and Leif Arthur Detlefsen were married Saturday evening at the Riverfront Boathouse in Hartford. Steven S. Mitchell, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

headline: Dana Litowitz, Nathaniel Stokoe
