headline: Campaign References to Afghanistan Are Missing In Action
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: With the exception of that odd Clint Eastwood interlude, the war in Afghanistan and the U.S. troops fighting there were barely mentioned onstage at the Republican convention — and not at all in Mitt Romney’s acceptance speech. Will the Democrats, perhaps sensing an opening, make the war more of an issue at their convention this week?
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The war in Afghanistan — the longest conflict in U.S. history at 128 months and counting — was barely mentioned onstage at the Republican National Convention last week. The actor Clint Eastwood made a loopy and apparently unscripted reference to the war, but in his acceptance speech the presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, did not once bring up the A-word.

headline: U.S. Hopes Dimming as Stephens Falls Short
abstract: Sloane Stephens lost to the 12th-seeded Ana Ivanovic in the third round of the United States Open for the second consecutive year, following fellow Americans Jack Sock, James Blake and Sam Querrey out of the tournament.
lead_paragraph: America’s tennis fans were full of hope at the start of the third round of the United States Open on Saturday.

headline: Rookie Chen Stays Steady in Rotation for Orioles
abstract: Wei-Yin Chen, a veteran of Japan’s Central League, leads Baltimore in starts, victories and strikeouts.
lead_paragraph: Last April, Wei-Yin Chen had a rough initiation into the major leagues. Minutes after he stepped onto the mound to make his first start for the Baltimore Orioles in April, he watched as his fifth pitch whipped off the bat of Derek Jeter and landed 421 feet from home plate at Camden Yards for a home run.

headline: Alabama Shows It May Not Be No. 2 for Long
abstract: The Crimson Tide outplayed No. 8 Michigan, further stamping Alabama’s dominance and solidifying bragging rights for the Southeastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — That Alabama was ranked No. 2 as it opened defense of its 14th national championship did not register much ire heading into Saturday night’s clash with No. 8 Michigan. Still, a fan joyously held aloft a sign deep into the fourth quarter that read, “Road to 15 starts in Big D,” a reference to the only mission that matters to Crimson Tide faithful.

headline: U.S. Halts Training Program for Some Afghan Recruits
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold to better screen out threats to troops, officials say.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The training of Afghan Local Police and special operations forces has been put on hold while their American trainers conduct stricter vetting to try to root out any infiltrators or new recruits who could pose risks to the coalition troops working with them, American officials say.

headline: Has the ‘Burqa Ban’ Worked in France?
abstract: The French law banning the full-face veil from public spaces has been controversial from the start, with loud debates about the meaning of liberty, individual rights, the freedoms of religion and expression, and the nature of laïcité, or secularism, in the French republic.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French law banning the full-face veil from public spaces has been controversial from the start, with loud debates about the meaning of liberty, individual rights, the freedoms of religion and expression, and the nature of laïcité, or secularism, in the French republic.

headline: How the Top 25 in College Football Fared
abstract: Game summaries of the top 25 in college football.
lead_paragraph: 1. SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA (1-0) beat Hawaii, 49-10.

headline: What Would a President Romney Mean for the Arab Spring? For Europe?
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Whether Barack Obama is re-elected or Mitt Romney becomes the 45th president of the United States, the challenges of the Arab Spring will be there to confront either man. In addition, a President Romney might have some international fences to mend.
lead_paragraph: In our video piece above, David Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief of The New York Times, explains the challenges and contradictions of America’s Mideast policy — whoever wins the election in November. And the Bush administration’s last ambassador to the European Union, Kristen Silverberg, a foreign policy adviser to Mitt Romney, outlines to me how a Romney foreign policy would differ from that of President Barack Obama.

headline: After Verdict, Assessing the Samsung Strategy in South Korea
abstract: A company that built its brand by deftly copying and expanding on products developed by rivals, Samsung’s recent legal loss to Apple could serve as a bellwether for South Korea’s economy.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When a jury in San Jose, Calif., ordered Samsung Electronics to pay $1.05 billion in damages for violating Apple’s patents for the iPhone and iPad, it did more than decide who had infringed upon whose intellectual property. To South Koreans, the legal battle highlighted the strengths and weaknesses of both Samsung and their economy in general.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Feature stories of note from India this week on capital punishment, the BJP and falconry.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision to uphold Ajmal Kasab’s death sentence has once again brought into focus the death penalty debate in India. Frontline, in its cover story, “A Case against the Death Penalty,” analyzes some gray areas in the debate.

headline: What to Watch on Sunday
abstract: It will be a big achievement for Fabio Fognini to even capture a set against the fan favorite Andy Roddick at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: Retirement looked like the furthest thing from Andy Roddick’s mind on Friday night as the former No. 1 dismissed the tricky Bernard Tomic in just under 90 minutes.

headline: Mitt Romney, Weaponized Keynesian
abstract: Spending hurts the economy, unless it’s on the military.
lead_paragraph: OK, I missed this. From Romney’s acceptance speech, attacking Obama:

headline: Bronx Community College Gets a Library, and Building, Truly Its Own
abstract: The library is the first big new building on the 43-acre University Heights campus in the Bronx, since 1970, when it was the uptown division of New York University.
lead_paragraph: The new North Hall and Library at Bronx Community College had scarcely been open a day when Dorian Whyte, 21, and Jang Sung Soo, 22, sat down last week to study physics on the light-filled balcony wrapping around an enormous central reading room. Neither had any books in front of him. But they were evidently enjoying the place.

headline: In Pivotal Week for Euro Zone, a Test for the Central Bank’s Leader
abstract: Some analysts say Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank’s president, might have a difficult time convincing investors that the bank will take decisive action against the euro debt crisis.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The last time Mario Draghi addressed the news media after a meeting of the European Central Bank, on Aug. 2, he disappointed investors who wanted him to crack his whip and immediately bring bond markets to heel. The markets dropped even before Mr. Draghi was done speaking.

headline: Henry Herx, Film Critic for Catholic Publications, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Herx judged the moral qualities of movies as well as their aesthetic ones.
lead_paragraph: Henry Herx, who over three decades wrote thousands of movie reviews for Roman Catholic publications, assessing the moral complexities raised on screen through the prism of church tenets, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Ramsey, N.J. He was 79.

headline: Parties Do Some Convention Spin on Sunday Talk Shows
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'Speeches and Statements', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama’s aides say accuse the Republicans of “lies” after their convention, but Republicans say Mitt Romney “a home run” with his speech.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It would probably be safe to say, based on the reviews of the Republican convention offered Sunday by some of President Obama’s top advisers, that the gloves are officially off as Democrats look forward to their own turn on the convention stage in Charlotte.

headline: Scenes from a Subculture
abstract: A look inside the world of youth dance competitions.
lead_paragraph: A look inside the world of youth dance competitions.

headline: South Africa Lifts Charges of Murder in Mine Strike
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Mines and Mining', 'Organized Labor', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Prosecutors provisionally dropped murder charges against the 270 miners who had been accused of killing 34 of their own colleagues when the police opened fire on them during a strike.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Prosecutors provisionally dropped murder charges against the 270 jailed miners who had been accused under an obscure legal doctrine of killing 34 of their own colleagues when the police opened fire on them while engaged in a wildcat strike.

headline: Tap-Tap-Tapping Into a National Obsession
abstract: Hundreds of dance competitions for children across America tap into an abiding national affection for pageantry and contests.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning in February — Super Bowl Sunday, as a matter of fact — out past the strip malls and the auto dealerships and worlds away from nearby Seattle, families streamed into the Highline Performing Arts Center in Burien, Wash., for a traditional American orgy of razzmatazz and rivalries.

headline: Afghans Protest Vengeful Militias
abstract: Villagers near Kunduz say a pro-government militia killed 11 people in the second recent case of reprisal killings of Afghans believed to be Taliban sympathizers.
lead_paragraph: KANAM, Afghanistan — On the bed of this village’s only pickup truck, three bullet-riddled bodies were laid out on Sunday, hastily wrapped in sheets. Behind the truck, several cars, their hatchbacks propped open as they bounced down the dirt roads, carried one or two bodies each. All 15 of the village’s vehicles, most of them shabby and old, joined the grim convoy, stuffed with 200 distraught relatives and 11 of their dead.

headline: Mishmash Not
abstract: Our unstructural problems.
lead_paragraph: Props to Eddie Lazear; he’s a loyal Republican who’s been saying a lot of things I consider totally wrong lately, but his paper for Jackson Hole (pdf) is a professional, well-done piece that offers little aid and comfort to his political allies.

headline: Golf Shoes for on the Course and on the Town
abstract: The casual, street-style shoes some pros have begun wearing in competition have small plastic studs for traction but no spikes.
lead_paragraph: Watching golf on television, you may have noticed that golf shoes are shrinking. The minimalist movement is most obviously exemplified by the casual, street-style shoes some professionals have begun wearing in competition.

headline: The Greg Norman Fan Club Is a Mutual Admiration Society
abstract: Norman’s name comes up an awful lot even though he has played in only three PGA Tour events in the last five years.
lead_paragraph: Greg Norman’s name still comes up an awful lot even though he has played in only three PGA Tour events in the last five years.

headline: Shorter Days and a Chill in the Air Can Warm Fate’s Heart
abstract: A theory: Those bad bounces and strange snags of summer turn favorable when days shorten and the air cools down.
lead_paragraph: I have a theory that the golf gods go on vacation in the fall. In the summer, they are much too busy to take time off. They have the major championships to keep an eye on, all the amateur tournaments and thousands of club championships.

headline: With ’08 on Their Minds, Democrats Gather in Charlotte
abstract: President Obama’s 2012 convention in North Carolina will be weighed down by four years of politics, wars overseas and promises kept and broken.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Democrats will gather here on Tuesday to nominate President Obama for a second term in the White House, setting in motion the final sprint to Election Day.

headline: Isaac Brings Touch of Relief, and Hope for Next Season, to Corn Belt
abstract: Farmers from Missouri to Ohio welcomed the three to five inches of rain the hurricane deposited, but they said it came too late to save much of this year’s crop.
lead_paragraph: WARRENTON, Mo. — All through the scorching summer, as their crops withered under cloudless skies, Corn Belt farmers waited and prayed for this moment. Now, courtesy of Hurricane Isaac, it has finally arrived: three days of rain to soak their parched fields and soften the cracked soil.

headline: Aliens With Dance Moves and the Midas Touch
abstract: In Shirish Kunder’s Bollywood comedy “Joker” a scientist trying to contact space aliens also creates schemes involving extraterrestrials to save his hometown from economic hardship.
lead_paragraph: There might be a utopian vision inside Shirish Kunder’s “Joker,” a Bollywood comedy about establishing contact with extraterrestrials. But if so, it’s buried under a mountain of static.

headline: A SEAL’s Own Story, Bin Laden and All
abstract: In “No Easy Day,” a member of the Navy SEALs team that killed Osama bin Laden recounts his story.
lead_paragraph: The Navy SEALs who killed Osama bin Laden on May 2, 2011, learned from ABC News that they had “gazelle legs, no waist, and a huge upper body configuration,” not to mention calloused hands and gigantic egos. They learned from other American news sources that they had taken part in a 45-minute firefight and that an armed bin Laden, once cornered, had tried to defend himself in his final moments, staring straight at the fighters who would shoot him. Their raid was being turned into a bad action movie.

headline: Mormon Says Romneys Are Leading Church Into Mainstream
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The Mormon church is gaining widespread acceptance in part because of Mitt Romney, another prominent Mormon says.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON – With Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, looking on, a prominent member of the Mormon church, J.W. Marriott Jr., told his congregation on Sunday that the Romneys were helping to lead the church “out of obscurity” and into the mainstream.

headline: Despite Eviction, Settlers of West Bank Outpost Maintain Goal
abstract: Following a court order, Israeli authorities evacuated 47 families from the Migron settlement, which the Supreme Court ruled had been built on land owned by Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: MIGRON, West Bank — The police officers went door to door on Sunday morning in this hilltop settlement outpost east of the West Bank city of Ramallah, handing out final eviction notices and waiting patiently for residents to come out.

headline: Double Faults Prove Verdasco’s Undoing
abstract: Fernando Verdasco is tied for second in double faulting in the men’s draw at this year’s United States Open with 21 from three matches, and it played a major role in his straight-sets loss to Roger Federer Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Double faulting is absolutely the worst way to lose a point in tennis.

headline: Dark Tale Told in an Atmospheric Tongue
abstract: Opera Slavica presented “Jenufa,” a dark tale that fits into the company’s Slavic-language repertory.
lead_paragraph: Janacek’s “Jenufa,” which Opera Slavica presented in a wrenching performance on Thursday evening at the Bohemian National Hall, has always struck me as a thoroughly wintry work. That may be because of its almost ceaseless grimness, or because its final act includes the discovery of a murdered baby, buried in ice. But then, much of the music that Opera Slavica specializes in — the Russian and Czech repertory — is set in dark, chilly landscapes. So a challenge that faces the company’s young singers, along with bringing the music and characters to life, is evoking a suitably icy spirit for an audience that has just wandered in from the summer heat.

headline: Seeing One Child Off to Preschool, Another to High School
abstract: Mothering a kindergartner and a high-schooler at the same time puts a nostalgic perspective on ‘back-to-school.’
lead_paragraph: When my daughter, now 4, was born, I was 44 1/2. The half is important — or was, to me, at the time, as I imagined the late summer morning I would drop her off five and a half years hence to start kindergarten, when she’d be 5 1/2.

headline: For Stephens, Lessons in a Loss to Ivanovic
abstract: Ana Ivanovic raised her level of play late in the second set, then stayed on the attack to come from a set down to beat Sloane Stephens at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday night to advance to the fourth round.
lead_paragraph: Ana Ivanovic raised her level of play late in the second set, then stayed on the attack to come from a set down to beat Sloane Stephens at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Saturday night to advance to the fourth round of the United States Open. The match turned Ivanovic’s way when Stephens’s first-serve percentage plummeted and Ivanovic moved inside the baseline to attack the second serve. This led to four breaks of serve for Ivanovic, a pivotal break at 4 all in the second set followed by three service breaks in the final set. And as the pressure on her second serve mounted, Stephens began to visibly struggle with her serve, giving away six points on double faults in the third set as the tall, lithe Ivanovic moved even further inside the baseline.

headline: U.S. Companies Brace for an Exit From the Euro by Greece
abstract: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American firms are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece may soon be forced to leave the euro zone.
lead_paragraph: Even as Greece desperately tries to avoid defaulting on its debt, American companies are preparing for what was once unthinkable: that Greece could soon be forced to leave the euro zone.

headline: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, Self-Proclaimed Messiah Who Built Religious Movement, Dies at 92
abstract: The Korean evangelist’s Unification Church was notable for mass weddings, fresh-faced proselytizers and links to vast commercial interests.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the Korean evangelist, businessman and self-proclaimed messiah who built a religious movement notable for its mass weddings, fresh-faced proselytizers and links to vast commercial interests, died on Monday in Gapyeong, South Korea. He was 92.

headline: Everybody Does It
abstract: Or so they say, but it’s not true.
lead_paragraph: That seems to be the new Beltway line, now that the shock over the lie-fest in Tampa has died down a bit. At the Washington Post (except at Ezra’s blog), at Politico, and so on, it’s excuse time — sure, Ryan and Romney told a few whoppers, but isn’t that just how politics is?

headline: In Swing State, Ryan Shows His Ohio Chops
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan may live in Wisconsin, but he often uses his college years to highlight his Ohio ties.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Before Mitt Romney announced a running mate, many political strategists predicted he would choose Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, if for no other reason than his home state is a must-win state for the Romney campaign.

headline: Bay’s Power Makes Rare Appearance for Mets
abstract: Jason Bay hit the fifth grand slam of his career in the first inning to help the Mets sweep Miami in three games.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Things have been going well for the Mets of late. They have not for outfielder Jason Bay.

headline: Rivals Jostle Before Apple Announces New iPhone
abstract: Some major tech companies are running elaborate product announcements this week, hoping to grab the news media’s undivided attention before Apple announces its new iPhone on Sept. 12.
lead_paragraph: Back when Apple was an underdog, it had an easier time shrouding its product announcements in mystery and perhaps catching its competitors off guard.

headline: The Hippocratic Oath, With Fingers Crossed
abstract: “Coma,” a mini-series on A&E, revisits the Robin Cook medical thriller with a cast of veteran actors and a high-budget look.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment when it seemed as if Lauren Ambrose would be taking on 2012’s scariest acting assignment. She was cast in the Barbra Streisand role in a revival of “Funny Girl” that was to hit Broadway in April. Reprising the career-defining role of a legend? Yeah, that’s scary.

headline: Electronic Dance Music Goes Hollywood
abstract: The genre’s appeal, obvious at festivals and raves, is making its D.J.’s a new force in the film industry.
lead_paragraph: Once marginalized as a novel European import, electronic dance music, or E.D.M., has become the dominant trend in American pop these days. Its lively synthetic beats and booming bass lines are inescapable, and its top D.J.’s draw sold-out crowds to outdoor raves like Electric Daisy Carnival and even rock bastions like Lollapalooza and Coachella, earning them thousands, if not millions, of dollars for a single set.

headline: Eat and Run to Another Channel
abstract: “Anthony Bourdain: No Reservations” begins its ninth season, its last, on the Travel Channel.
lead_paragraph: In the world of lifestyle television, few people get as much attention as Anthony Bourdain, and it’s fair to ask why a middle-aged former chef whose TV show draws fewer than 500,000 viewers deserves so much ink. (Figuratively speaking.)

headline: Yankees Still Have the East Lead, but the Orioles Have the Momentum
abstract: A four-run sixth helped Baltimore pull away from the Yankees and within two games of first place in the American League East.
lead_paragraph: The third question to Manager Joe Girardi about his ill-fated choice to leave Phil Hughes in to face Mark Reynolds in the sixth inning drew his ire.

headline: Is Riff Raff Eccentric? Yes. Next Question?
abstract: Riff Raff, the eccentric rapper, songwriter and performance artist, brought his show to the Santos Party House nightclub.
lead_paragraph: The Riff Raff concert on Thursday night at Santos Party House began with a news conference, podium and all, except it wasn’t nearly a news conference. It was after midnight in a sweaty, crowded nightclub, and Riff Raff, wearing a pink neon windbreaker, mostly took banal questions from the crowd: Will Riff Raff bring the rice out? “Rice shall be brought.” (More on the rice later.) Does Riff Raff play basketball? “I hoop so good I damn near could’ve been Sheryl Swoopes.”

headline: Telluride Film Festival: Geoff Dyer, Tarkovsky’s ‘Stalker,’ Chaplin and More
abstract: The program has always included restored and rediscovered older films—classics as well as curios—alongside the newest Cannes prize winners and Academy Award aspirants.
lead_paragraph: Late Saturday night, near the end a lively dinner at a local restaurant, Tom Luddy, one of the Telluride Film Festival’s triumvirate of directors, was lamenting that journalists covering the festival focus too much on the Oscar race. Timing has something to do with this. Telluride, synchronous with Venice and just ahead of Toronto, is inevitably one of the first steps on the long march to the Dolby Theater. For the past two years it has presented the eventual Best Picture winner. The presence of movie stars stopping through to receive tributes, answer audience questions and humbly promote their new movies may also contribute to the hype. Bill Murray, Ben Affleck, Dennis Quaid and Marion Cotillard are all here doing just that, sometimes accompanied by thunder and lightning at Elks Park in the center of town.

headline: Left Alone by Its Owner, Reddit Soars
abstract: Reddit, built on open-source software and guided by the ethos of its community of 20 million users a month, is a classic Web start-up in which opportunity seems mixed with barely controlled anarchy.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to measure the traction of a social media platform: time spent, page views or unique users. But it might be useful to add one more metric: if the leader of the free world stops by to answer questions from your users, you’re probably doing O.K.

headline: In Praise of the Clash of Cultures
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Philosophy', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: We humans are deeply divided on fundamental moral, religious and philosophical questions. But that can be a good thing.

headline: Obama Casts Republicans as Stuck in the Past
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Following the Republican National Convention, President Obama added a new element to his usual stump speech, describing Mitt Romney and Congressional Republicans as backward-looking.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — As President Obama heads into the Democratic National Convention this week, he is seizing on the just-concluded Republican convention to ramp up his argument that Mitt Romney and his party are stuck in the policies of the past and are afraid to spell out the details of their plans.

headline: Roddick Staves Off Retirement With a Win
abstract: After announcing this United States Open would be the last tournament of his career, Andy Roddick has continued winning, this time dispatching Fabio Fognini to advance to the fourth round.
lead_paragraph: For stretches after Andy Roddick’s latest victory, the one that extended his farewell tour at least another two days, he seemed unsure how to react — what to do and how to celebrate.

headline: Twitter’s Free Speech Defender
abstract: Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea. As the company considers going public, he thinks it is a competitive advantage.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea. He thinks it is a competitive advantage for his company.

headline: Roddick Is Having His Last Laugh
abstract: Andy Roddick, the face of men’s tennis in the United States for over a decade, has a bounce in his step even as his career draws to a close after announcing his retirement.
lead_paragraph: Sure, Andy Roddick said he was retiring, but have you noticed the bounce in his step in his victories against Bernard Tomic and Fabio Fognini?

headline: Be of Use
abstract: A whole bunch of fun from C. W. Stewart.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Labor Day to all! This will be a brief one today, since I am desperately trying to squeeze every last bit of summer out of this weekend. Also, this is a Monday, and you really don’t need my help for that, do you?

headline: Storm Coverage Online Hints at Future of Times-Picayune
abstract: As Hurricane Isaac passed through New Orleans, the Times-Picayune still printed newspapers, but its Web site, Nola.com, became the primary destination for residents seeking storm coverage.
lead_paragraph: As the staff at The Times-Picayune in New Orleans applied their well-developed hurricane-reporting skills last week, it was not just flooded roads and power failures that they contended with. Hurricane Isaac struck the region a month before the paper is to cut back print publication to just three days a week, lose part of its newsroom staff and merge into a new company with the Web site Nola.com.

headline: Ryan Admits Misstating Marathon Time
abstract: Paul D. Ryan admits he got it wrong in talking about his marathon performance.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan has taken back his claim that he had run a marathon in under three hours, an assertion that had drawn great skepticism in the running community and one that came after his convention speech faced scrutiny for some questionable and misleading statements.

headline: Second World Mind Sports Games, in France
abstract: At the Second World Mind Sports Games in Lille, France, last month there was a subsidiary event of the subsidiary event.
lead_paragraph: At the Second World Mind Sports Games in Lille, France, last month there was a subsidiary event of the subsidiary event.

headline: A Chance to Dance
abstract: A look at the world of dance competitions for youngsters.
lead_paragraph: A look at the world of dance competitions for youngsters.

headline: National Geographic Takes Hunter Off TV Show
abstract: The National Geographic Channel said that Melissa Bachman, an animal hunter who writes for a blog called “Hardcore Huntress,” will no longer be a participant in the coming reality series “Ultimate Survivor Alaska.”
lead_paragraph: The National Geographic Channel said on Friday that Melissa Bachman, an animal hunter who writes for a blog called “Hardcore Huntress,” will no longer be a participant in the coming reality series “Ultimate Survivor Alaska,” after an online petition protesting her involvement received more than 13,000 signatures in less than 24 hours. According to the Hollywood Reporter’s Web site the petition posted on Change.org by Tim Martell, a Florida resident, called for a boycott of National Geographic and stated that the cable channel had abandoned its “traditional stance of conservation and protection” by working with Ms. Bachman, who also has her own Web site that contains hunting videos, tips and a photographic trophy room. “The National Geographic Channel has carefully considered the public discussion of our series on surviving the wilds of Alaska currently in production and premiering sometime next year,” the cable channel said in a statement. “Upon further reflection we plan to eliminate one of the survivalists from the ensemble cast, Melissa Bachman. Hunting is not the focus of the show, and we regret the misinformation that has clouded what we hope will be an exciting adventure series set in the incredible Alaskan landscape.”

headline: Spanish Filmmaker Wins Prize at Online Festival
abstract: The Spanish filmmaker David Victori was the grand prize winner of the first Your Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish filmmaker David Victori was the grand prize winner of the first Your Film Festival, an online competition sponsored by YouTube, Scott Free Productions and Emirates airlines, for his short film “The Guilt,” about a man out for revenge after his wife’s murder. The announcement was made at the Venice Film Festival on Sunday after his film was selected from a pool of 10 finalists by a jury that included the director Ridley Scott and the actor Michael Fassbender.

headline: ‘Live Read’ Series at Toronto Festival
abstract: The festival will host the latest installment the series — in which popular movie scripts are performed by contemporary actors — with a reading of Alan Ball’s screenplay for the 1999 film “American Beauty.”
lead_paragraph: The Toronto International Film Festival will host the latest installment of the director Jason Reitman’s “Live Read” series — in which popular movie scripts are performed by contemporary actors — with an unrehearsed reading of Alan Ball’s screenplay for the 1999 film “American Beauty.” The performance will take place on Thursday at the Ryerson Theater in Toronto; Mr. Reitman, above, will announce the cast for the reading on his Twitter account, @jasonreitman, in the days before the event. Tickets can be purchased at tiff.net/festival. Mr. Reitman created the series last year in collaboration with Elvis Mitchell, a former film critic for The New York Times, for the film society at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Previous entries included presentations of “The Apartment” with Paul Rudd and Emma Stone at the TimesCenter in Manhattan, and “The Big Lebowski” featuring Seth Rogen in Los Angeles, among others.

headline: Garden & Gun Claws Its Way Back From the Brink
abstract: Since losing financial support from its publisher in 2009, the Southern lifestyle magazine Garden & Gun has made an impressive recovery, adding more than 20,000 subscribers in 2011.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Among the many magazines that were battered by the recession, few survived such a precarious financial state as Garden & Gun.

headline: Young U.S. Player Relishes First Taste of Spotlight
abstract: At 16, Victoria Duval of Boca Raton, Fla., is signing autographs and basking in the warmth of attention and curiosity befitting a United States girls 18-and-under champion and wild-card entrant in the United States Open women’s singles championship.
lead_paragraph: At 16, Victoria Duval of Boca Raton, Fla., is signing autographs and basking in the warmth of attention and curiosity befitting a United States girls 18-and-under champion and wild-card entrant in the United States Open women’s singles championship.

abstract: Readers take issue with an Op-Ed article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
