abstract: A reader comments on a news article, “Satellites Show Sea Ice in Arctic Is at a Record Low.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hate Attacks in Israel
abstract: A reader suggests that Palestinians react to violence with the same introspection recently expressed by many Israelis.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Klinsmann Includes Dempsey for Jamaica Qualifiers
abstract: Clint Dempsey was one of 24 players named by Coach Jurgen Klinsmann to the United States national team roster for a home-and-home set of World Cup qualifiers against Jamaica
lead_paragraph: Clint Dempsey may be out of practice, and possibly out of form, but he is not out of the United States national team.

headline: The Arms Trade Treaty
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Gun Control', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A professor of public policy at the University of Michigan responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Reasons for Public Ire Toward Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Readers disagree with an Op-Ed essay denying a need to break up large banks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For the Giants, a Leader and Some Fresh Followers
abstract: As the season begins, the Giants are counting on the eighth-year veteran Corey Webster to lead Michael Coe and other inexperienced cornerbacks against the Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Michael Coe, who has never started an N.F.L. game, will probably be called upon Wednesday night to help shut down Cowboys receivers Dez Bryant and Miles Austin.

headline: N.F.L. and Officials Still at Odds
abstract: People on both sides of the negotiations say it is doubtful a deal can be completed in time to use regular officials for Week 1.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. sent a memo to its teams Sunday indicating that it thought Friday that it was close to a deal to end the lockout of officials but that negotiations broke off the next day after a brief meeting in which officials made clear that retirement benefits remained the key sticking point. Now, people on both sides say it is doubtful a deal can be completed in time to use regular officials for Week 1, which starts Wednesday when the Giants host the Cowboys.

headline: What Muffins Say About Mitt Romney
abstract: The Romney campaign clearly hasn’t thought about how eating only the tops of muffins will play to a crucial voting bloc: Asian immigrants.
lead_paragraph: SOME supporters of Mitt Romney, in an effort to make him seem more human (or at least humanoid), have been disseminating a story, first told by a biographer, about how their candidate has a charmingly eccentric habit: he eats only the tops of muffins. His theory is that during the baking process, the butter sinks to the bottom. This story conveys so many things: our guy is an everyday Joe — he eats muffins, not crumpets. And look, even his breakfast is an opportunity to make disciplined decisions — just think how he’ll do with the budget.

headline: HBO Will Offer Channel by Internet in Northern Europe
abstract: Beginning in October, people in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden will be able to subscribe to HBO Nordic via the Internet, bypassing traditional cable and satellite distributors.
lead_paragraph: The pay television service HBO is about to make a lot of Internet users in Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden very happy.

headline: When Capitalists Cared
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Productivity', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Henry Ford recognized that business succeeds when workers do.
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: Small Music Labels to Court Asia
abstract: A delegation representing members of the American Association of Independent Music will visit Hong Kong; Seoul, South Korea; and Shanghai to meet with business contacts and study foreign markets.
lead_paragraph: To compete in the global marketplace, the major record companies have branches and subsidiaries all over the world. Most small labels do not have that advantage, so for help they are turning to federal and state government agencies.

headline: Rebels Bomb Heavily Guarded Damascus Neighborhood
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Civil War and Guerrilla Warfare', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Rebels set off two bombs amid military buildings in the Syrian capital Sunday, as the new United Nations envoy to the country refused to call for President Bashar al-Assad to step down.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebels set off two bombs among a cluster of military headquarters buildings in the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Sunday, as the new United Nations envoy for Syria pointedly refused to call for President Bashar al-Assad to give up power.

headline: Rounding the Seasonal Mark
abstract: Labor Day is the last stop before we go careening into fall, a holiday in school-bus yellow.
lead_paragraph: Other holidays are celebrated for the day and the season itself — Thanksgiving, Christmas, the Fourth of July. But Labor Day, as most of us know it, is a holiday about what comes next.

headline: Alan M. Kriegsman, Who Won Pulitzer for Criticism, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Kriegsman, whose long career at The Washington Post coincided with a period of growth and diversification in American dance, was the first dance critic to win a Pulitzer Prize.
lead_paragraph: Alan M. Kriegsman, a longtime dance critic for The Washington Post and the first dance critic to win a Pulitzer Prize, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 84.

headline: At Least Fun in the Sun Isn’t Banned. For Now...
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Local Government', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: In Southern California, once known for its freewheeling disposition, cities, school districts and even libraries have been outlawing beach bonfires, napping and perfume.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Whatever it is, I’m against it!” Groucho Marx sang in a 1932 picture filmed on the Paramount lot here.

headline: Advertisers Join the Social Video App Showyou
abstract: As marketers debate the efficacy of online display advertising, a unit of the Omnicom Media Group has partnered with the video platform Showyou to show users video ads alongside other content.
lead_paragraph: As marketers debate the efficacy of online display advertising and users ignore the standard blocks of ads found on many Web sites, many advertisers are turning to videos that blur the line between content and marketing.

headline: Egypt Abuzz as Newsreader on State TV Wears Hijab
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Television', 'Muslims and Islam', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The appearance is said to be the first of a veiled news presenter on state television, which had enforced a de facto ban during the Mubarak era.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In what was called a first for Egyptian state television, a woman wearing a head scarf presented headlines in a newscast on Sunday, breaking with a code of secular dress that for decades effectively barred the wearing of Islamic head coverings.

headline: A Pitch-Perfect Voice for a Team in Need of Fine-Tuning
abstract: Pia Sundhage took over a United States women’s national team in crisis and led it to two Olympic gold medals and a second-place finish at the 2011 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: When Pia Sundhage became coach of the United States women’s soccer team in November 2007, she gathered her players and sang “The Times They Are A-Changin’.” Sour notes were evident, not in Sundhage’s voice, but in the team’s internal discord.

headline: Pakistani Blasphemy Case Shifts as Cleric Is Arrested
keywords: ['Vandalism', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The Muslim cleric who had expressed anger at a Christian girl’s alleged desecration of sacred Muslim texts has been accused by a colleague of falsifying evidence.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Muslim cleric at the forefront of a campaign to prosecute a Christian girl for blasphemy has suddenly found himself at risk of facing the same charges, after one of his colleagues went to the authorities and accused him of falsifying evidence of burned holy papers.

headline: Gen. William W. Momyer, Celebrated Pilot, Dies at 95
abstract: General Momyer was a famed World War II fighter pilot who would go on to command aerial combat and bombing operations during the early years of the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: Gen. William W. Momyer, a celebrated World War II fighter pilot who helped plot postwar tactics for the Air Force and commanded aerial combat and bombing operations during the early years of the Vietnam War, died Aug. 10 at an assisted-living center in Merritt Island, Fla. He was 95.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Unemployment', 'Building (Construction)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Economic data will include construction spending for July and the unemployment rate for August, and Campbell Soup and Kroger are among the companies reporting results.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index for August and construction spending for July (Tuesday); revised second-quarter productivity, Automatic Data Processing employment for August, weekly jobless claims, and the I.S.M. service index for August (Thursday); and unemployment for August (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Account Says Navy Author Wrote Book After a Slight
abstract: A new e-book says that Matt Bissonnette, a former Navy SEALs member who wrote a first-person account of the Osama bin Laden raid, was willing to speak out because of “bad blood” with his unit.
lead_paragraph: The former Navy SEALs member who is a co-author of a first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden was willing to break “the code of silence” honored by many commandos because of “bad blood” with his former unit, the elite SEAL Team 6, according to a new e-book written by other Special Operations veterans.

headline: For Times Square Patrol, a Stage the Tourists Don’t See
abstract: Two police partners embarked one evening on a journey into a parallel world, a backstage apart from Broadway’s gloss that most visitors never glimpse or even consider.
lead_paragraph: The tour began just after dusk, as the lavender sky dissolved into night, backlit by the pulsing luminescence of Times Square.

headline: Likely Successor to Disgraced Brooklyn Party Leader Is a Friend and Protégé
abstract: Frank R. Seddio, like his mentor, Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, has vowed to effect long-promised reforms to Democratic Party politics in the borough.
lead_paragraph: Each time a Brooklyn kingmaker falls in this borough of the back-room deal — the tenures of three of the last four Democratic bosses have ended in scandal — the outrage turns to an outcry for one of New York’s last political machines to be dismantled.

headline: Oosthuizen Catches McIlroy With Early Flurry of Birdies
abstract: Louis Oosthuizen made birdies on 8 of the first 10 holes, including seven in a row, on his way to an eight-under-par 63 in the third round of the Deutsche Bank Championship.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — As he stood over his 23-foot birdie attempt on the ninth green Sunday, Louis Oosthuizen never doubted that his stroke would be pure. Playing TPC Boston as if it were a putt-putt course, Oosthuizen made birdies on 8 of the first 10 holes, including seven in a row, on his way to an eight-under-par 63 in the third round of the Deutsche Bank Championship.

headline: After Wedding, Money Box Is the Something Borrowed
abstract: When a Long Island maître d’hôtel saw a man later identified as the date of the groom’s niece holding the box, a confrontation, a chase and an arrest followed.
lead_paragraph: The bride and groom had said their “I dos,” the guests had danced the night away and the goodbyes were being exchanged as a glorious Saturday night was winding down. And then the maître d’hôtel at the West Sayville Country Club on Long Island noticed something amiss in the coat room: someone inside was clutching the “money box,” the white box in which the guests had deposited envelopes, many filled with cash, intended for the newlyweds.

headline: Ticket Sales Fail to Make Hollywood’s Summer
abstract: Even higher prices could not offset empty seats this summer as ticket sales at North American cinemas declined an estimated 3 percent from the period a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This is one summer Hollywood would like to remake.

headline: Trust, Immigrants and Gov. Brown
abstract: A bill to limit unfair detentions and make communities safer deserves Gov. Jerry Brown’s signature.
lead_paragraph: There is a significant and immediate step Gov. Jerry Brown of California can take to protect community safety and civil liberties in his state.

headline: A Growing Nuclear Program
abstract: Iran has been developing its nuclear enrichment program since 1985.
lead_paragraph: Iran has been developing its nuclear enrichment program since 1985.

headline: As Democratic Convention Nears, Demonstrators Take to the Streets of Charlotte
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Foreclosures', 'Illegal Immigrants']
abstract: The list of grievances Sunday included the crackdown on illegal immigrants and foreclosures across the country, but there were fewer protesters than some had anticipated.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Protesters from scores of groups around the country filled the streets of Charlotte on Sunday afternoon to push their agenda as Democrats gathered in the city for their convention.

headline: Success at Open Bodes Well for Britons’ Chances at Wimbledon
abstract: The success of Andy Murray and the emerging Laura Robson at the United States Open adds hope for those awaiting the first homegrown Wimbledon singles champion since 1977.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens from here on out at the United States Open, the tennis summer of 2012 shall in no small part be remembered for compelling evidence of a country’s climate change. Those dark clouds of defeatism that hovered for decades over the famed Wimbledon lawns and British tennis have finally rolled out and been replaced by a sky of gold and silver hue and hope.

headline: To Calm Israel, U.S. Offers Ways to Restrain Iran
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The Obama administration is taking steps it hopes will force Iran to reconsider almost stalemated nuclear negotiations — and forestall an Israeli attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Israel openly debating whether to strike at Iran’s nuclear facilities in the coming months, the Obama administration is moving ahead with a range of steps short of war that it hopes will forestall an Israeli attack, while forcing the Iranians to take more seriously negotiations that are all but stalemated.

headline: When a Coach Called a Shift
abstract: After decades operating with the option offense, Frank Solich switched to the spread before last season with Ohio. The move proved successful against Penn State.
lead_paragraph: Frank Solich’s faith in the option offense had been forged and confirmed over an almost three-decade association with Nebraska. Solich played fullback there under Bob Devaney. He coached under Tom Osborne, winning three national championships with the same reliable, grinding attack. When he replaced Osborne, the option helped him win 49 games in his first five seasons, more than either Devaney or Osborne over a similar stretch.

headline: Health Care Where You Work
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Editorials']
abstract: On-site clinics, like one in Green Bay, Wis., can improve workers’ health and lower companies’ costs.
lead_paragraph: In the scramble to find ways to slow rising health care costs, experts are finding good ideas from organizations that are virtually unknown beyond their hometowns.

headline: Siblings’ Throats Slit by Intruder; Boy, 6, Dies
abstract: A 12-year-old girl was in critical condition after an assailant broke into the children’s bedroom in Camden, N.J., early Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A knife-wielding attacker broke into the bedroom of a boy and a girl in Camden, N.J., early Sunday and slit their throats, killing the boy, the authorities said.

headline: Mexico City’s Aztec Past Reaches Out to Present
abstract: Mexico City might be one of the world’s classic megacities, but it is also an archaeological wonder, with surprises still being uncovered in the city’s superimposed layers.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The skeleton is that of a young woman, perhaps an Aztec noble, found intact and buried in the empire’s most sacred spot more than 500 years ago. Almost 2,000 human bones were heaped around her, and she is a mystery.

headline: A Spotlight With Precedent Beckons a Mayor From Texas
abstract: Mayor Julián Castro of San Antonio will give the Democrats’ keynote address, the role that brought national attention to Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Mayor Julián Castro will be closely watching two elections on Nov. 6.

headline: Rosie Ruiz Republicans
abstract: There are a lot of big boasts in this campaign, and not all of them are about the budget.
lead_paragraph: Remember Rosie Ruiz? In 1980 she was the first woman to cross the finish line at the Boston Marathon — except it turned out that she hadn’t actually run most of the race, that she sneaked onto the course around a mile from the end. Ever since, she has symbolized a particular kind of fraud, in which people claim credit for achieving things they have not, in fact, achieved.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 2
abstract: A look at the day in sports around the world, from auto racing in Belgium to baseball in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: A look at the day in sports around the world, from auto racing in Belgium to baseball in Chicago.

headline: A House Speaker Proves a Mighty Fund-Raiser
abstract: John A. Boehner has assisted G.O.P. candidates with what some say is a record amount of money raised by a House speaker, surpassing the former speaker Nancy Pelosi in this cycle.
lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — Speaker John A. Boehner, tanned, relaxed and seeming slightly giddy, slid up to the microphone and tossed off some one-liners to a small group of Iowans who had paid $100 for the pleasure of 12 minutes of his company on a recent Friday evening.

headline: Hitting Pause in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Police', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits was the first tap on the brakes for one of the most controversial programs in the Afghan security plan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American commander’s decision to suspend the training of new Afghan Local Police recruits for at least a month was the first tap on the brakes for what has been a headlong drive to fill out a police force. From the very beginning, the program has been one of the most controversial in the Afghan security plan.

headline: U.S. Open: Day 7
abstract: Andy Roddick put off retirement for at least two days by winning his third-round match, but Lleyton Hewitt saw his Open run come to an end.
lead_paragraph: Andy Roddick put off retirement for at least two days by winning his third-round match, but Lleyton Hewitt saw his Open run come to an end.

headline: Federer Is Busiest After the Match
abstract: Roger Federer’s schedule ends with multiple interviews conducted in several languages that can last hours, sometimes longer than his matches.
lead_paragraph: The questions started almost as soon as Roger Federer’s last match ended, same as always, the news media gantlet often longer and more intense than what happened on the court.

headline: Data Show a City’s Car Sharing May Be Working, but Doubts Persist
abstract: Thanks to a car-share program, Hoboken, N.J., has seen a slight decrease in the number of residential parking permits, but the effort has not reduced residents’ dependence on cars.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — It has been more than two years since officials in this parking-starved city placed a counterintuitive bet: Hoboken would create parking spaces, they said, by taking them away.

headline: Football’s Future Rests on Parents as Much as Players
abstract: As health and safety concerns become increasingly pronounced, the divergent points of view on whether to allow children to play football reflect intensifying debates on the issue.
lead_paragraph: Sherman Howard, 87, played professional football for five years and was a longtime high school coach in Chicago. “The biggest problem you have now is in coaching,” he said. “I don’t think the kids now have the best of coaching.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: After Daring Restart, Hunter-Reay Holds On at Grand Prix of Baltimore
abstract: Ryan Hunter-Reay moved to 17 points behind the IndyCar points leader, Will Power, heading into the final race of the season.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Stacks of tires lined the sharp right turn at the end of the long main straightaway at the Grand Prix of Baltimore, and Ryan Hunter-Reay probably lucked out after the biggest restart of Sunday’s chaotic race by not barreling into them.

headline: Muslims From Abroad Are Thriving in Catholic Colleges
keywords: ['Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Women and Girls', 'Religion and Belief', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: More Muslims have enrolled in Roman Catholic colleges in the United States in recent years, with students saying they prefer a place where religious talk and observance are encouraged.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — Arriving from Kuwait to attend college here, Mai Alhamad wondered how Americans would receive a Muslim, especially one whose head scarf broadcasts her religious identity.

headline: The Cost of Living Blues
abstract: How our political and economic problems look through the lens of country music.
lead_paragraph: Last year, on Feb. 10, in the kind of pronouncement that has become all too familiar, Richard Kramer, the chairman and C.E.O. of Goodyear Tire & Rubber, announced the closing of a plant in Union City, Tenn:

headline: To the Boys, Her Role Is Simple: Teammate
abstract: Erin DiMeglio, a 17-year-old senior at South Plantation High School, is believed to be the first girl to play quarterback in a Florida high school football game.
lead_paragraph: South Plantation High School’s third-string quarterback was warming up on the sideline before the fourth quarter of a recent preseason game, and each pass was quick, concise and purposeful. The quarterback’s nervous mother, Kathleen DiMeglio, was capturing the moment on video from the bleachers. Then, in an instant, the quarterback vanished from the frame, lost amid the sea of white jerseys.

headline: Corrections: September 3, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 3, 2012.

headline: Slugger Guides Orioles on Strange Path Toward Playoffs
abstract: The slugging infielder Mark Reynolds, who tormented the Yankees this weekend, was on the 2007 Diamondbacks — the last playoff team with a negative run differential.
lead_paragraph: Because of Mark Reynolds, certain notions about the Baltimore Orioles may need to be reconsidered.

headline: School Choice Is No Cure-All, Harlem Finds
abstract: Harlem parents have been expressing frustration at the still limited number of high-quality choices in the city’s push to add charter schools in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: When it came time to pick a Harlem middle school for her daughter, Eula Guest did her research. She inquired with friends, principals and PTA presidents, and talked to students inside art studios and auditoriums. “I got down to the nitty-gritty,” she said. “I asked about everything.”

headline: Presidential Zeal
abstract: Whether shooting pool, reading to children or working to raise his bowling scores, President Obama cannot contain his competitive nature.
lead_paragraph: Whether shooting pool, reading to children or working to raise his bowling scores, President Obama cannot contain his competitive nature.

headline: The Competitor in Chief
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Athletics and Sports', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama has earned a reputation as a perpetually aspiring overachiever, striving to perfect his skills even in mundane pursuits like doodling.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day approaches, President Obama is sharing a few important things about himself. He has mentioned more than once in recent weeks that he cooks “a really mean chili.” He has impressive musical pitch, he told an Iowa audience. He is “a surprisingly good pool player,” he informed an interviewer — not to mention (though he does) a doodler of unusual skill.

headline: Sharapova Finally Returns to Quarterfinals
abstract: Maria Sharapova defeated Nadia Petrova, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4, to advance to the quarterfinals of the United States Open for the first time since she won the event in 2006.
lead_paragraph: When Maria Sharapova and Nadia Petrova met at the net for the coin toss before their match Sunday night, it was hard to tell which player was more focused.

headline: Breaking It Down: Querrey vs. Berdych
abstract: Sam Querrey fails to maximize his power game because he does not follow enough shots to the net to pressure his opponents and finish points.
lead_paragraph: Being up a set and a break in a tennis match is not all it’s cracked up to be.

headline: Sporting News
abstract: The latest fitness gear broadcasts your health to the world. Motivational or mortifying?
lead_paragraph: Where was a time, not so long ago, when my girlfriend, Rose, and I had the sort of conversations couples across the globe have when reuniting at the end of a long day. We talked about work, about whether to eat in or go out, about trivial gossip regarding the lives of our friends and (more trivially) those of celebrities. All this, however, has come to be replaced by a peculiar, often snippy back-and-forth that begins the moment we see each other and that, to the uninitiated, would sound a whole lot like gibberish.

headline: Training Day
abstract: Five gadgets that track and share your every move.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Picasso Online for Just $450? Yes, It Is a Steal
abstract: As the Internet has opened the art market to the masses, the volume of fraud has vastly increased, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Bargain hunting online? How about an original Rembrandt for $900 (“you can clearly tell its age by the paper,” the seller of this etching attests), or a signed piece in ink by Matisse for $1,250. (The artist’s work is, the online seller notes, “radical and unprecedented in the history of Western art.”)

headline: In China, a Ferrari Crashes and the Party Is Dented
abstract: The mysterious crash of a Ferrari in Beijing last March is now having repercussions at the highest levels of the Chinese Communist Party. President Hu Jintao’s chief aide has been effectively sidelined — his son died in the crash — amid allegations of an elaborate coverup and questions about how the young man could have afforded the $788,000 car.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the chief of staff to President Hu Jintao was moved to a lesser position last week, it sounded like so much inside baseball, a ho-hum reshuffling of personnel as the Chinese Communist Party prepares for a leadership change this autumn.

headline: Pitch on the Pasture: Cricket in the Cowboy State
abstract: Indian students battling homesickness in Wyoming head for the cricket pitch.
lead_paragraph: The heart of the University of Wyoming’s campus in Laramie is Prexy’s Pasture, a big, grassy area surrounded by blue spruce and mountain pine. According to university lore, the pasture was where students grazed their horses in the late 19th century; a standing university rule dictates that the president, or “prexy,” has sole rights to the area for livestock grazing.

headline: Hey, Teacher, Leave Those Kids Alone
abstract: Students all around the world have been preparing for the start of the school year this month, and what a start it has been, with protests and scandals in Hong Kong, in London, in the Ivy League.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Students all around the world have been preparing for the start of the school year this month, and what a start it has been, with protests and scandals in Hong Kong, in London, in the Ivy League.

headline: Gasquet Tops N.C.A.A. Champion Johnson
abstract: Richard Gasquet, seeded 13th, ended Steve Johnson’s wild-card run one match short of the third round.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Johnson’s final shot sailed long on Sunday, Richard Gasquet of France lifted a fist and shook it wearily in triumph as he walked to shake hands with him.

headline: Aliens With Dance Moves and the Midas Touch
abstract: Review of Shirish Kunder’s ‘Joker.’
lead_paragraph: “There might be a utopian vision inside Shirish Kunder’s ‘Joker,’ a Bollywood comedy about establishing contact with extraterrestrials,” Andy Webster wrote in The New York Times. “But if so, it’s buried under a mountain of static.”

headline: Twitter’s Free Speech Defender
abstract: Can Twitter stand up for privacy, free expression and profitability all at the same time?
lead_paragraph: “Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter’s chief lawyer, says that fighting for free speech is more than a good idea,” Somini Sengupta wrote for The New York Times. “He thinks it is a competitive advantage for his company.”

headline: When People Stood on Soapboxes
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A teacher planning to describe a speech by Eugene V. Debs realized there was one detail her students probably wouldn’t understand.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Avoiding Chaos in His Wake, Button Wins at Spa
abstract: Avoiding the crashes and chaos unfolding behind him at the Belgian Grand Prix on Sunday, Jenson Button led from start to finish for his first Formula One victory at Spa.
lead_paragraph: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium — The great track here has seen some of Formula One’s most exciting races, but that excitement has often come from the predictably unpredictable weather, which sometimes has it raining on one part of the track while other parts remain dry.

headline: Dodging the Police at the 1968 Democratic Convention
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Photography', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct']
abstract: When they convened in 1968 in Chicago, the Democrats, like the nation, were deeply divided. Outside the convention, protests got out of hand and the police came down hard — a Times photographer captured it all, including an arrest.
lead_paragraph: One of our favorite photos on the picture desk at The New York Times is a black-and-white image (below) that shows three young men in the back of a police wagon.

headline: In Mumbai, Open Spaces Are Rare, and Rarely Open
abstract: The city has just 9 square feet of open space per person, new study shows.
lead_paragraph: With over 13 million residents, Mumbai has earned its reputation for being a  congested city, one where being jostled in crowded spaces is part of daily life.

headline: U.S. Vehicle Is Rammed by a Bomber in Pakistan
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: There were conflicting reports of American casualties after a suicide bomber crashed into a vehicle belonging to the United States Consulate in the northwestern city of Peshawar on Monday.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A suicide bomber rammed his explosives-laden vehicle into a sport utility vehicle belonging to the United States Consulate in the northwestern city of Peshawar on Monday morning, Pakistani and American officials said, in one of the most brazen attacks against Americans in the country in recent years.

headline: The Early Word: Playing for Keeps
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Bartoli Blitzes Kvitova for Spot in First Open Quarterfinal
abstract: Marion Bartoli, who won the girls’ singles title in Flushing Meadows in 2001, has now reached the quarterfinal stage of all four Grand Slam tournaments.
lead_paragraph: No. 11 seed Marion Bartoli roared back to beat fifth-seeded Petra Kvitova, 1-6, 6-2, 6-0, on the Grandstand court Sunday to reach her first United States Open quarterfinal. Bartoli, who won the girls’ singles title in Flushing Meadows in 2001, has now reached the quarterfinal stage of all four Grand Slam tournaments.

headline: What to Watch on Monday
abstract: What to watch Monday at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to find the right word to describe what Milos Raonic did to James Blake on Saturday.

headline: The Twilight of the Public Corporation
abstract: Disillusionment with the stock market and shareholder activism are contributing to the drop in the number of Americans investing in equities and to the decline of the publicly traded corporation, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: St. Louis Rams, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
abstract: Things are pointing in the right direction for St. Louis, but there are still a lot of upgrades needed at wide receiver and offensive line.
lead_paragraph: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He’s entering the home stretch with the last division, the N.F.C. West. First up are the St. Louis Rams.

headline: Sept. 2: Split Verdict in Polls on Romney Convention Bounce
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: Polls have delivered a muddled picture of what sort of bounce Mitt Romney received from the Republican convention in Tampa, Fla.
lead_paragraph: My view is that the consensus of evidence so far points toward Mitt Romney having received a small bounce in the polls of perhaps two or three percentage points from the Republican convention in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Q&A: Replacing a Sealed MacBook Pro Battery
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Guarantees and Warranties', 'Laptop Computers']
abstract: Replacing the battery in a newer Mac laptop is not as easy as it used to be.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Hanna Rosin on Women Who Support Their Husbands
abstract: The author of this week’s cover article discusses small-town women who find some empowerment as breadwinners and men who view the loss of manufacturing jobs as “a phantom limb.”
lead_paragraph: Hanna Rosin wrote this week’s cover story about middle-class women in Alabama who are supporting their out-of-work husbands. The article is adapted from her new book, “The End of Men: And the Rise of Women,” to be published this month by Riverhead Books. Rosin is a senior editor at The Atlantic and at Slate, where she co-founded the “DoubleX” blog.

headline: Angered Isner Is Upset in Five Sets
abstract: John Isner, normally one of the most even-keeled American players, became incensed by a key foot fault call.
lead_paragraph: For John Isner, the 2012 United States Open will be remembered for its major missed opportunities.

headline: Fuel Efficiency Standard Could Jump-Start Electric Cars
abstract: New U.S. fuel efficiency standards for cars and light trucks should accelerate sales of electric-powered and hybrid vehicles. What prevents more people from buying more energy efficient vehicles? Do they have to get better before drivers are willing to make the switch?
lead_paragraph: The White House announced last week a significant tightening of future fuel efficiency standards.

headline: In Beijing, Clinton Will Push for Talks Over Disputed Islands
abstract: As tension mounts between China and its neighbors over islands in nearby strategic waterways, China has scored some subtle victories, making the United States and its friends increasingly uneasy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As tensions mount with its neighbors over islands in nearby strategic waterways, China has scored some subtle victories, making the United States and its allies increasingly uneasy about the potential for violent confrontations.

headline: E.U. Trade Commissioner Is Getting a Raw Deal
abstract: European Union nations are increasingly making their own bilateral deals with China, damaging the unifying efforts of Karel De Gucht, the E.U. trade commissioner.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Being the European Union trade commissioner must sometimes be a thankless job, as Karel De Gucht is finding out. He has been fighting long and hard to establish a level playing field with China.

headline: In-Store | House Blend
abstract: The men’s floor of Excelsior Milano, a new department store in Milan, offers a mix of difficult-to-find designers, cutting-edge style and old-school Italian panache.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Britain’s Paul Ryan
abstract: But no Ayn Rand.
lead_paragraph: In a lot of ways George Osborne, the Chancellor of the Exchequer (finance minister) is Britain’s answer to Paul Ryan. True, he’s a toned-down version — no Ayn Rand, please, we’re British — but other aspects of package are there in full force: he’s articulate, has a vision that’s completely at odds with everything we actually know about macroeconomics, and he was for a while the darling not just of the right but of self-proclaimed centrists on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Monday Reading: They’re Souvenirs, Not Stuff!
abstract: They’re souvenirs, not stuff; Last plea on student loans means proving hopeless future; D.I.Y. digital cookbooks and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Dolgopolov Says His Timing Left Him
abstract: Alexandr Dolgopolov explained why he was not able to adapt in his third-round loss to Stanislas Wawrinka at the United States Open on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Alexandr Dolgopolov is a chameleon.

headline: David Lindsay-Abaire and Naomi Wallace Receive Horton Foote Prize
abstract: The playwrights are the 2012 recipients of the Horton Foote Prize, a biennial award named for the playwright and screenwriter.
lead_paragraph: The playwrights David Lindsay-Abaire and Naomi Wallace have been named the 2012 recipients of the Horton Foote Prize, a biennial award named for the playwright and screenwriter who died in 2009 at 92. Mr. Lindsay-Abaire’s “Good People” was chosen as the outstanding new American play, and “The Liquid Plain” by Ms. Wallace received the award for promising new American play. Each winner will receive $15,000 and a photograph of Mr. Foote.

headline: Activists Against Corruption Claim Police Harassment
abstract: Protestors say police should be arresting politicians instead.
lead_paragraph: Arvind Kejriwal offered himself up for arrest Monday as part of a “Jail Bharo” or “Fill the Jails” protest, designed to draw attention to what anti-corruption activists say is police harassment of the movement’s supporters.

headline: On the Lens Blog: Dodging the Police and Tear Gas at the 1968 Democratic Convention
abstract: When they convened in 1968 in Chicago, the Democrats, like the nation, were deeply divided. Outside the convention, protests got out of hand and the police came down hard — Barton Silverman, a Times photographer, captured it all, including an arrest.
lead_paragraph: When they convened in 1968 in Chicago, the Democrats, like the nation, were deeply divided. Outside the convention, protests got out of hand and the police came down hard — Barton Silverman, a Times photographer, captured it all, including an arrest.

headline: Seasonal Parking Bans Please Rockaways Residents but Irk Visitors
abstract: The rules in Belle Harbor and Neponsit in Queens can keep beachgoers off quiet residential streets but can be an inconvenience even for homeowners.
lead_paragraph: The houses in Neponsit and Belle Harbor, Queens, out past the last stop on the A train on the Rockaway Peninsula, are not what you picture when you think of New York City. Sandwiched between Jamaica Bay and the Atlantic Ocean, the homes have cedar shingles or vinyl siding, wraparound porches or, occasionally, a modern, boxy structure that stands Hamptons-ready. They are lovely and suburban, and feel very far from the frenetic boom-boom-boom of Midtown footsteps.

headline: Welcome to Charlotte, a City of Quirks
abstract: Visitors to Charlotte may have trouble getting around but will find a wealth of quirky attractions.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Politicians, delegates, lobbyists, journalists and protesters were gathering on Monday in Charlotte for the Democratic National Convention, which begins on Tuesday. They will find an Old South gold rush town that grew up to be a New South banking center with tall, shiny buildings, artsy statues and a few quirks — from a statue believed to be modeled after Alan Greenspan’s face to the “Disco Chicken.”

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: August 27-31
abstract: A look back at the week in politics at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the week in politics at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla.

headline: The Quiet American
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Armed only with his books, Gene Sharp has helped spread peace around the world for four decades.
lead_paragraph: On a quiet street in an unfashionable East Boston neighborhood not far from Logan Airport lives an 84-year-old man whom dictators around the world fear and despise. On the morning I go to meet Gene Sharp, the taxi driver cannot even find his house, and there is no sign on the door to mark the building as headquarters of the Albert Einstein Institution, the nonprofit organization he founded in 1983. When I arrive, Jamila Raqib, the institution’s executive director, answers the door dressed in jeans and a T-shirt. “We want to be low-key,” she says. “And keep it that way.”

headline: Image of the Day: September 3
abstract: University awards diploma and degree certificates to 79 prisoners at Ahmedabad Central Jail in Gujarat.

headline: Chess Gets the Artistic Treatment in a New Saatchi Show
abstract: Sixteen chess sets designed by contemporary artists are the focus of a new exhibition at the Saatchi Gallery in London.
lead_paragraph: Since the new Islamic art galleries opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last fall, one of the most popular objects on display has been a chess set dating from 12th-century Iran, one that looks surprisingly modern because the pieces are highly abstracted. The Shah (king), for example, is represented by a large throne.

headline: 100 Years After the Titanic, Still Wondering Who Got the Story
abstract: The answer to who got one of the biggest scoops of the early 20th century — the interview with the surviving telegraph operator from the Titanic — is murky.
lead_paragraph: If newspaper articles had routinely carried reporters’ bylines 100 years ago, there would be no question now about who got one of the biggest scoops of the early 20th century, the April 18, 1912, interview with the surviving telegraph operator from the Titanic.

headline: To Beat the Execution Clock, the Justices Prepare Early
abstract: A clerk of the Supreme Court provided a rare inside look at how the justices are prepared to rule on matters of life and death in capital cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Balentine was an hour away from being put to death in Texas last month when the Supreme Court granted him a stay of execution.

headline: The Day of Knowledge
abstract: Russian public and private schools seem to exist in two different countries, with public schools still firmly rooted in the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — My kids are first-class citizens, and so are the children of about half of my friends. The other half’s children are second-class citizens. The second-class citizens had to cut their summer vacations short and rise at the crack of dawn this past Saturday to take part in a brief but bizarre ritual.

headline: To Back Democracy, U.S. Prepares to Cut $1 Billion From Egypt’s Debt
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypt’s failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the country’s new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypt’s failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the country’s new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt as part of an American and international assistance package intended to bolster its transition to democracy, administration officials said.

headline: Venice Film Festival: Audiences Cheer P.T. Anderson Film, Jeer Terrence Malick’s Entry
abstract: At the Venice Film Festival, the audience unites behind “The Master,” from Paul Thomas Anderson,” and turns on “To the Wonder,” from Terrence Malick.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — The middle weekend of the Venice Film Festival saw the premieres of the two most eagerly awaited films in the official competition. Both, as it happens, are unorthodox love stories — as well as tales of spiritual crises — by American auteurs with perfectionist reputations and loyal followings.

headline: The Stonewall of the West
abstract: Patrick Cleburne, an Irish immigrant turned Confederate major general, led the rebels to a decisive victory in Richmond, Ky.
lead_paragraph: As Generals Robert E. Lee and Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson were winning their smashing victory at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia, another Confederate army triumphed even more decisively at the little known battle of Richmond, Ky., led in part by the man destined to be known as the “Stonewall of the West”: Gen. Patrick Cleburne. Richmond was potentially even more decisive than Bull Run — it opened Kentucky to Confederate invasion, giving the rebels a possible route to the aorta of the Union war effort, the Ohio River.

headline: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again
abstract: Up to 15 percent of strokes affect people no older than 45 — and the sooner the correct diagnosis is made, the less likely the result will be lifelong impairment.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Todd McGee was a lean, athletic 34-year-old working in construction and living with his wife and toddler daughter on Martha’s Vineyard, where he spent summer weekends surfing. A stroke changed his life forever.

headline: Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, 5:40 A.M.
abstract: The scene on Empire Boulevard in Brooklyn on Monday morning during an unofficial parade that precedes the West Indian Day Parade.

headline: Plan for Change in Schools Stirs Protest in Hong Kong
abstract: Controversy has erupted over a new plan by the Hong Kong government that requires schools to teach courses in modern Chinese history. Opponents say the plan amounts to pro-Beijing indoctrination.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A plan by the Hong Kong government to require schools to teach courses in contemporary Chinese history has set off an acrimonious dispute here with political implications. The controversy may threaten the prospects of pro-Beijing candidates in the legislative elections scheduled for this Sunday, and it has opened a broader discussion over the city’s future.

headline: All You Can Eat, All Over Mumbai
abstract: A roundup of Gujarati thalis, restaurants that serve several courses of all-you-can-eat platters of food with a variety of subtle flavors.
lead_paragraph: The Gujaratis are best known in Mumbai’s culinary scene for thalis, restaurants offering several courses of all-you-can-eat platters of food with a variety of subtle flavors. The restaurants take pride in leaving their customers full; one has a Web site that claims, “We serve as long as you can eat.”

headline: White House Beer: A Brewer Weighs In
abstract: Garrett Oliver of Brooklyn Brewery assesses the beer recipe the Obama administration released over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Now that the White House has revealed its recipe for Honey Brown Ale, brewed by cooks in the White House kitchen using honey from its own hives (along with releasing a nifty video of the beer-making process), I thought it would be worth assessing the recipe and methods, and conjecturing on how the beer would taste. This required a beer-making professional, so I called on Garrett Oliver, brewmaster at the Brooklyn Brewery and editor of the encyclopedic “Oxford Companion to Beer.”

headline: G.O.P. Seizes on a Question: Are You Better Off Than You Were 4 Years Ago?
abstract: As Democrats begin gathering for their convention, President Obama’s top strategists hesitate when asked whether the country is better off than four years ago.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice presidential nominee, slammed President Obama’s handling of the economy on Monday, seizing on hesitant responses by Mr. Obama’s top strategists when asked whether the country was better off than it was four years ago.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Returns to Yankees’ Lineup
abstract: Alex Rodriguez hit cleanup and was 1 for 4 as the designated hitter in his first game since July 24, when he was hit by a pitch and broke a bone in his left hand.
lead_paragraph: 11:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: Arborio and Friends: Multigrain Risottos
abstract: Nutty whole grains like wild rice, red rice and farro join with traditional starchy rice to make a creamy and utterly satisfying series of vegetarian dishes.
lead_paragraph: These days chefs get away with calling all sorts of grainy dishes risottos. I’ve seen farro risottos, barley risottos and even quinoa risottos on plenty of menus. The problem with calling these dishes risottos is that if they’re made with grains other than starchy rice like arborio, carnaroli or the rice from the Camargue I used when I was in Provence this summer, they don’t have the creamy texture that makes classic risottos so appealing.

headline: Warhol Soup Cans, Now at Your Local Target
abstract: On Sunday, Target began selling a special edition of Warhol-themed soup cans to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Pop artist’s first paintings of Campbell’s soup cans.
lead_paragraph: Christie’s may have been able to get nearly $10 million for a 1962 painting of Andy Warhol’s “Four Campbell’s Soup Cans’’ back in November, but now everyday shoppers can buy their own piece of the Pop artist for just 75 cents. On Sunday Target started selling a special edition of 1.2 million Warhol-themed tomato soup cans.

headline: Really? Some Plants Can Filter Airborne Chemicals
abstract: NASA has found that at least 15 common indoor plants can filter pollutants from the air, to some degree.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: Citing Health Reasons, Fish Pulls Out
abstract: Mardy Fish withdrew from the United States Open on Monday, hours before his scheduled fourth-round match against No. 1 Roger Federer, citing “health concerns.”
lead_paragraph: Mardy Fish withdrew from the United States Open on Monday, hours before his scheduled fourth-round match against No. 1 Roger Federer, citing “health concerns” probably related to his continuing heart problems.

headline: At Democratic Convention, Rove Can Cause a Stir, Simply by Being Here
abstract: Karl Rove caused a minor uproar aboard the bus carrying the New York State delegation to the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — All was pleasant aboard the shuttle bus ferrying New York Democratic convention delegates to the convention center here Monday morning.

headline: Squirrel Watch
abstract: Just because you do not see them does not mean they are not there.
lead_paragraph: Q. What has happened to all the squirrels in Central Park? I have not seen any this summer.

headline: In Ruined Apartments, a Symbol of Ireland’s Fall
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Residents of Priory Hall, the most notorious of Ireland’s ruined ghost developments, are in legal limbo, barred from living in homes that they still have to pay for.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — To visit Graham Usher’s dream apartment in Priory Hall, the most notorious of Ireland’s ruined ghost developments, is to see what Ireland aspired to be, and what it became instead.

headline: Inside the Royal Society
abstract: A selection of objects and images from inside the archives.
lead_paragraph: A selection of objects and images from inside the archives.

headline: Anticonvulsant May Relieve Chronic Cough
abstract: A study of 62 patients with chronic cough in Australia found that those given gabapentin, an anticonvulsant, saw a decline in severity and frequency of coughing.
lead_paragraph: A medicine commonly used for seizures and nerve pain may help treat chronic cough, a new study has found.

headline: Abortions Linked to Risk of Preterm Birth
abstract: A study of births and induced abortions in Finland finds that the risk of very premature birth — 28 weeks or fewer — increases with the number of previous abortions.
lead_paragraph: Induced abortions may raise the risk for very preterm birth in subsequent pregnancies, a new study reports.

headline: Setting the Mood for Smaller Meals
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Food', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Diners in a quiet section of a Hardee’s restaurant decorated with white tablecloths and indirect lighting ate less of what they ordered and rated the food more highly, a study found.
lead_paragraph: A change in fast-food restaurant ambience can affect the amount of food consumed by customers, an unusual study has found.

headline: China Faces New Scandal Over Crash of a Ferrari
abstract: Chinese officials said the son of Ling Jihua, a close ally of the departing president, died in a crash in which two women in the Ferrari he was driving were seriously injured and all were in various states of undress.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s carefully scripted leadership transition appears to have suffered another glitch: a fatal car crash involving a Ferrari, a privileged son and two women.

headline: On Labor Day, Obama Talks Up Auto Bailout in Ohio
abstract: President Obama pointed to his bailout of the auto industry, which Mitt Romney opposed, as a major argument for his re-election over the Republican rival as he spent a fourth Labor Day with union workers in a swing state.
lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio – President Obama pointed to his bailout of the auto industry, which Mitt Romney opposed, as a major argument for his re-election over the Republican rival as he spent a fourth Labor Day with union workers in a swing state.

headline: In Pursuit of Truth, Corporeal and Cosmic
abstract: A selection from a trove of early findings, predictions and reflections at the Royal Society.
lead_paragraph: In the Royal Society’s early years, scientists wrote of research both bizarre and elegant, made seemingly uncanny predictions, and sought to reconcile their findings with prevailing beliefs about God. A few samples from the archives:

headline: A Redoubt of Learning Holds Firm
abstract: The Royal Society in Great Britain, the world’s oldest continuous scientific society, is striving to stay relevant in the modern world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To stroll out of Carlton Gardens into the elegant confines of the Royal Society is to find a trove of centuries-old wonders, from Sir Isaac Newton’s reflecting telescope to the first electric machine to fantastical illustrated catalogs of fish and birds.

headline: Farm Use of Antibiotics Defies Scrutiny
abstract: A dearth of information makes it difficult to document the precise relationship between routine antibiotic use in animals and antibiotic-resistant infections in people, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: The numbers released quietly by the federal government this year were alarming. A ferocious germ resistant to many types of antibiotics had increased tenfold on chicken breasts, the most commonly eaten meat on the nation’s dinner tables.

headline: European Proposal Presses for Women to Join Boards
abstract: Companies allocating fewer than 40 percent of seats on supervisory boards to women could face sanctions, according to a proposal by the European Union justice commissioner.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Companies allocating fewer than 40 percent of seats on supervisory boards to women could face serious sanctions later this decade, according to a proposal made Monday by Viviane Reding, the European Union justice commissioner.

headline: Syrian Minister Assails Egyptian and Turkish Leaders
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Harsh remarks from Syria’s minister of information may signal that condemnation from former allies is starting to worry the leadership around President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s top government spokesman declared Monday that the refugees fleeing its borders were welcome back “at any time,” mocked the leaders of Egypt and Turkey for their condemnations and called the armed opposition unfit for negotiations.

headline: Mustard’s Spiciness Related to Its Hardiness
abstract: Very slight differences in a family of genes regulating spiciness in wild mustard plants determine not only the degree of heat but also a plant’s prospects of survival.
lead_paragraph: A small family of genes regulates not only the spiciness of mustard plants but also their prospects for survival, scientists report.

headline: Jordan’s King Cancels Fuel Price Rise in Face of Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: King Abdullah II moved to block a 10 percent increase in fuel prices after protesters took to the streets over the weekend, raising the specter of renewed social unrest in the cash-poor kingdom.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II of Jordan moved quickly to block a recent increase in fuel prices after angry protesters took to the streets over the weekend, raising the specter of renewed social and political unrest in the cash-poor kingdom.

headline: Ancient Warriors Unearthed in Denmark
abstract: Scientists have found human remains bearing wounds as well as a cache of weapons 2,000 years old in wetlands in East Jutland.
lead_paragraph: A fractured skull and a thighbone hacked in half were found at the lake.

headline: Taking the Measure of a Single Molecule
abstract: Scientists have made a vibrating bridgelike device millionths of a meter long that changes frequency when a molecule arrives; the change is measured to determine the molecule’s mass.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, a device can measure the mass of a single molecule.

headline: A Glimpse of Lobbyists’ Convention Exile
abstract: Tony and Heather Podesta, the K Street power couple, held an extravagant brunch for corporate clients and political friends on Monday at the Mint Museum in Charlotte, N.C.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Lobbyists are beside themselves: the president’s public cold shoulder has exiled them to the fringes of the convention. Just how far afield?

headline: Literature in Any Language: Journal Takes That Literally
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Chinese Language', 'Translation']
abstract: The literary journal Granta has a new Chinese edition, its latest attempt to go beyond its English-language base.
lead_paragraph: When the first issue of its new Chinese-language edition appears next month, the London-based literary journal Granta, a publication that has existed in English since the Victorian era, will have a presence in four of the five most widely spoken languages. But plans for the globalization of a leading quarterly that proudly calls itself “the magazine of new writing” don’t stop there.

headline: Tuberculosis: Stubborn and Expensive to Treat, Drug-Resistant Strains Show Growth
abstract: A new study has confirmed, once again, that hard-to-cure drug-resistant tuberculosis is a growing problem.
lead_paragraph: A new study has confirmed, once again, that hard-to-cure drug-resistant tuberculosis is a growing problem.

headline: School Bullies Prey on Children With Autism
abstract: New research shows that children with autism spectrum disorders, who typically have difficulty in communicating and forming relationships, are far more likely to be bullied than their non-autistic peers.
lead_paragraph: Connie Anderson didn’t know what was bothering her 17-year-old son, a Baltimore-area high school senior with Asperger’s syndrome, a form of autism. He was usually a diligent student, but his grades began to plummet.

headline: Battling Progress and Other Demons
abstract: “Telegraph Avenue” by Michael Chabon pictures a David-and-Goliath battle between a vinyl record shop and a proposed mall in California.
lead_paragraph: The title of Michael Chabon’s pungent new novel, “Telegraph Avenue,” refers, of course, to the famous Telegraph Avenue that bridges Berkeley and Oakland, Calif., that frisky, clamorous thoroughfare so identified, since the 1960s, with the counterculture and community life.

headline: Dreamers Who Sell Out on the Road to Success
abstract: Keith Lee Grant directs an intimate chamber version of “Dreamgirls,” the 1981 R&B musical about the rise of a 1960s girl group.
lead_paragraph: Whether you love or hate “Dreamgirls,” the vintage Michael Bennett musical about the rise and death of a 1960s singing group that strongly resembles the Supremes, you cannot deny the power of its signature number. When Jennifer Holliday opened her mouth to sing “And I Am Telling You I’m Not Going” at the Imperial Theater in 1981, Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, Broadway history was made. And Dion Millington’s performance as Effie at the Harlem Repertory Theater’s inviting chamber production of the show is a thrilling reminder of how and why. The lyricist, Tom Eyen (who also wrote the book), and the composer, Henry Krieger, gave theater an undeniable moment of greatness.

abstract: Alex Rodriguez was 1 for 4 in his first game since he broke his hand on July 24, but Tampa Bay broke a 3-3 tie in the eighth inning off reliever Dave Robertson.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — As the Yankees’ once-formidable lead in the American League East continues to slip from their hands like melting ice on a hot day, they continue to talk about it as if it is still something they can hold onto. They may be able to, but if the lead continues to dwindle at its current rate, the Yankees will be in second place by Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: The tsunami that hit Japan in March 2011 swept an estimated 5 million tons of debris into the ocean.

headline: With Diversity Still Lacking, Industry Focuses on Retention

lead_paragraph: FOR many in the advertising business, the results of the 2010 census were a tipping point in terms of highlighting the growing importance of minority consumers. It showed that there were more than 50 million Latinos in the United States, nearly 40 million African-Americans and almost 15 million Asians. Nine million people identified themselves as belonging to more than one race.

lead_paragraph: The stereotype of business trip dining consisted of an artery-clogging succession of meeting-room pastries, oversize restaurant portions and fast food snagged at the airport. Anyone on a vegetarian or gluten-free diet had an especially hard time.

Biden Jr. drummed up support in Detroit. And Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, spoke to an overflow audience in North Carolina, the state where the Democrats were set to open their national convention this week.

headline: Dimensions of Data, Turned Into Art That Speaks
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A new book, “Visual Strategies,” is meant for scientists and engineers, but it will be useful for anyone who wants to make clear presentations.
lead_paragraph: Scientists and engineers have a tremendous capacity to detect, track, measure and otherwise observe phenomena of all kinds. This growing capacity is perhaps their most powerful tool. But it presents problems, too, because it is no easy task to marshal this flood of data and present it in ways that others — or sometimes even they themselves — can understand and make use of it.

headline: Use of Inhalers May Affect Growth
abstract: Children who use glucocorticoid inhalers to prevent asthma attacks may be shorter as adults, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: Children who use glucocorticoid inhalers to prevent asthma attacks may be shorter as adults, researchers said on Monday.

headline: Relief for Severe Asthma, at a High Price
keywords: ['Asthma', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A new procedure provides relief to severe asthmatics when little else works, but it’s expensive and insurers are reluctant to pay for it.
lead_paragraph: For two decades, Patricia DiGiusto struggled with severe asthma. Powerful medications and frequent use of her inhaler could not prevent repeated trips to the emergency room.

headline: Rare Infection Prompts Neti Pot Warning
abstract: After two cases of a deadly brain infection were linked to neti pots, government health officials have issued new warnings about using them safely.
lead_paragraph: Neti pots — those odd teapotlike vessels used to wash out the nasal passage — have won legions of fans who rely on them for relief from allergies, congestion and colds.

headline: How to Cope at the Airport Without a Wallet
abstract: Mark Zupan, a dean at the University of Rochester, will remember how he hustled for change at the airport in Boston.
lead_paragraph: DESPITE all the traveling I do, I’m still a bit of a nervous flier. Therefore, it doesn’t really make any sense that I flew with the Blue Angels last year after they offered the University of Rochester one seat on one of their planes. Several of us at the university received an e-mail invitation, and the first person to respond would get to go. I responded first. I figured it would be a good thing to do, until the day started approaching.

headline: Science Times Podcast
abstract: The Royal Society; and a food safety conundrum.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Society; and a food safety conundrum.

headline: Flying Nonstop to Bangkok? Time for Airborne Theater
abstract: Many travelers are using long-haul international flights to catch up on the latest movies and television programs.
lead_paragraph: I WAS at the airport in Singapore some years ago chatting with an oil company roustabout who was waiting to board Singapore Airlines for its 19-hour nonstop flight to Newark. He was traveling in business class, which features sumptuous food and free-flowing drink, seats that recline into lie-flat beds and an in-flight entertainment system with 80 on-demand movies available on personal high-definition screens.

headline: Think You Know Loud? Try Throbbing Sound as the Body Vibrates
abstract: The Power of the Riff Festival with Sunn O))) on Sunday night at Warsaw in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The live sound of Sunn O))) can draw you toward a kind of negative listening: paying attention to the movements between notes rather than the notes themselves. On Sunday — in hooded robes and in front of 18 amplifier cabinets — the two guitarists in the band, Greg Anderson and Stephen O’Malley, made those movements, slow slidings up or down the neck, sound like buildings crumpling in slow motion. A fantastic, physical, indeterminate sound.

headline: Five Questions for Michelle Rhee
abstract: Michelle A. Rhee, the former schools chancellor in Washington, D.C., is now pushing education reform through her organization Students First — and continuing to annoy the teachers’ unions along the way. What follows is a condensed and edited transcript of her conversation with Michael D. Shear.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Michelle A. Rhee, the former schools chancellor in Washington, D.C., is now pushing education reform through her organization Students First — and continuing to annoy the teachers’ unions along the way.

headline: With First-Round Open Juniors Victory, Less Teasing by the Other Kids
abstract: Tornado Alicia Black, 14, of Boca Raton, Fla., won her first-round match in the United States Open junior girls tournament with a bandaged left thigh and a stiff back that required a trainer’s assistance. She suggested she had an additional burden: her name.
lead_paragraph: Tornado Alicia Black, 14, of Boca Raton, Fla., won her first-round match in the United States Open junior girls tournament with a bandaged left thigh and a stiff back that required a trainer’s assistance.

headline: Stevie Wonder Backtracks on Comments About Frank Ocean
abstract: Mr. Wonder sent a statement to MTV News over the weekend saying his words that Mr. Ocean was confused about his sexual orientation were misconstrued.
lead_paragraph: Stevie Wonder has issued a statement clarifying comments he had made about the R&B singer Frank Ocean, who recently surprised the hyper-masculine world of urban music by acknowledging on his Tumblr site that he’d fallen in love with a man several years ago.

headline: The Agenda: Climate Change
abstract: New York Times environment reporter John Broder says Mitt Romney is not a proponent of government action on climate change, while President Obama knows a climate change bill won't realistically pass.
lead_paragraph: New York Times environment reporter John Broder says Mitt Romney is not a proponent of government action on climate change, while President Obama knows a climate change bill won't realistically pass.

headline: Film Festival With Truths to Tell
abstract: This year’s lineup at the Telluride Film Festival featured movies that, while clearly fictional, have that bracing feeling of reality.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — A film festival held almost 9,000 feet above sea level on a holiday weekend may not be the likeliest setting for philosophical speculation, but for the past four days the Telluride Film Festival has offered something like a seminar on the nature of truth. In an age of reality television, journalistic fakery and political mendacity everyone knows that words and images can distort and mislead. And film is a particularly unstable medium, alluring us with a promise of honesty while it feeds us ever more elaborate fantasies.

headline: Staying Back Is a Losing Strategy for Isner
abstract: The writer uses statistics to show that John Isner should put more emphasis on his net game over his baseline game to produce the best results.

headline: Social Media Site Creates Buzz With Convention Parties
abstract: On Tuesday, BuzzFeed will take over the science museum in Charlotte, N.C., and allow conventioneers to mix with other party animals.
lead_paragraph: At the Republican convention last week, the big bash sponsored by BuzzFeed at the Florida Aquarium in Tampa was among the most exotic and most talked about, featuring mermaids (undulating in full fin alongside fish in glass tanks) and penguins (sitting adorably in little wagons, with a helpful handler reminding revelers that, yes, even cute penguins do bite).

headline: Mets’ Comeback Hopes Hindered by Disputed Call in Loss to Cardinals
abstract: Kelly Shoppach and Daniel Murphy hit two-run shots in a Mets rally, but the Cardinals hung on.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — As reporters filed into the visiting manager’s office at Busch Stadium on Monday morning, one mentioned to Terry Collins that the Mets were roughly the same number of games outside a playoff spot that the St. Louis Cardinals were one year ago during their exhilarating World Series-winning run.

headline: Expectation of Stimulus Lifts European Markets
abstract: As reports show that the global economic slowdown is worsening, investors speculate that central banks will do more to stimulate growth.
lead_paragraph: European stocks rose for a second day on Monday, and copper advanced on speculation that central banks would take more steps to stimulate growth, as reports signaled that the global economic slowdown was deepening. The markets in the United States were closed for the Labor Day holiday.
