headline: Project Aims to Harness the Power of Waves
keywords: ['Tidal and Wave Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Energy development groups will be watching closely when the first commercially licensed grid-connected wave-energy device in the nation is launched in October.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — About 15 years ago, this environmentally conscious state with a fir tree on its license plates began pushing the idea of making renewable energy from the ocean waves that bob and swell on the Pacific horizon. But then one of the first test-buoy generators, launched with great fanfare, promptly sank. It was not a good start.

headline: With Time Running Out, 3 Chase Fixtures Are Back in the Pack
abstract: With one race left to increase position before the Nascar Chase field is established, three regulars are all in danger of failing to qualify.
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Ga. — It has seemed preordained that the Chase for the Sprint Cup, Nascar’s playoff wrapped into a season, involves Jeff Gordon, Carl Edwards and Kyle Busch.

headline: How Plan to Help City Pay Pensions Backfired
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Credit and Debt', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Local Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A bond sale that was intended to help Stockton, Calif., reduce a shortfall in pension money wound up making the problem worse.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey A. Michael, a finance professor in Stockton, Calif., took a hard look at his city’s bankruptcy this summer and thought he saw a smoking gun: a dubious bond deal that bankers had pushed on Stockton just as the local economy was starting to tank in the spring of 2007, he said.

headline: Moody’s Reduces Its Outlook for Europe’s Credit Rating
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Moody’s said the European Union’s rating would be particularly vulnerable to any changes in the ratings of Germany, France, Britain and the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: Moody’s Investors Service cut the European Union’s credit outlook to negative on Monday, reflecting the risks to Germany, France, Britain and the Netherlands, the four countries in the group with AAA ratings, which account for about 45 percent of the group’s budget revenue.

headline: Tempers Cool in Brooklyn After Pool’s Rocky Rebirth
abstract: The reopening of McCarren Park Pool in June was marred by fistfights and thefts, but as summer came to a close, the pool became a family-friendly community center.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning at McCarren Park Pool in Brooklyn, the crowds that had gathered there soon after it reopened were nowhere to be seen. Gone were the litter and the noise they brought with them, and gone was the heat wave that had throttled New York in early July, raising tensions in the long lines that had stretched around the pool.

headline: Valeant to Buy Medicis, Maker of Dermatology Drugs
abstract: The $2.6 billion all-cash deal would be the largest for Valeant since its creation in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, the largest publicly traded drug maker in Canada, agreed to buy Medicis Pharmaceutical on Monday for about $2.6 billion to expand in dermatological products.

headline: In Charlotte, as in Tampa, the Weather Becomes a Worry
abstract: After a hurricane upended the schedule at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., Democrats are facing storms where President Obama is set to accept the nomination in an outdoor stadium on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mother Nature is apparently bipartisan in her wrath.

headline: Fears Rising, Spaniards Pull Out Their Cash and Get Out of Spain
abstract: While the situation in Spain is not as dire as that of Greece, some Spaniards are taking their euros, and sometimes themselves and their families, out of the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is, Julio Vildosola concedes, a very big bet.

headline: Electric Zoo and Rock the Bells Festivals
abstract: Music festivals feature two descendants of ’70s disco, laptops at the ready.
lead_paragraph: Music festivals feature two descendants of ’70s disco, laptops at the ready.

headline: From First Shot to Last, Williams Is Dominant
abstract: Dominant only begins to describe Serena Williams’s 6-0, 6-0 fourth-round win over Andrea Hlavackova of the Czech Republic in 57 minutes at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams shouts, shrieks, squats, slouches, grimaces, huffs and puffs, grits her teeth and purses her lips and, on occasion, stares into her racket as if it were a mirror magnifying every little wrinkle and imperfection. And this is when she is winning.

headline: First Lady Strives for Caring Image Above Partisan Fray
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2008', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Michelle Obama’s enthusiastic embraces have become a minor phenomenon, with people lining up for hugs at events. Her signature gesture is warm and striking.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — This is how Michelle Obama delivers a hug: The nearly six-foot-tall first lady envelops her target, her long arms often wrapping all the way around the recipient’s back. She leans in close, unafraid to press her body against a stranger’s. Working crowds with her husband, she sometimes falls behind him, because he is more of a hand-shaker or high-fiver, and in the second-to-second choreography of a rope line, the Michelle Obama hug takes time.

headline: Federal Trial Set to Open for Ex-Mayor of Detroit
abstract: Kwame M. Kilpatrick was a rising star when he was elected mayor of Detroit at 31. Now 42, he could face a 30-year prison term.
lead_paragraph: During his nearly seven-year stint as mayor of Detroit, there was little about Kwame M. Kilpatrick that was not big. His 6-foot-4 frame. His “hip-hop mayor” persona and the 1 ½-carat diamond that pierced his ear. His wide appeal made him, at the age of 31, the youngest person ever to lead the city.

headline: Multinationals Stake a Claim in Venture Capital
abstract: Companies like American Express and General Motors have opened small offices in Palo Alto to stay closer to innovation, as an investment and a mind-set.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — New York, London and Hong Kong are common addresses for blue-chip multinationals. Now Silicon Valley is, too.

headline: Northern Ireland: Protesters Injure Police Officers in Belfast
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Parades', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The police said that 47 police officers were injured Sunday when Protestant protesters angered by a Catholic parade in northern Belfast threw homemade bombs, bricks and fireworks.
lead_paragraph: The police said Monday that 47 police officers were injured Sunday when Protestant protesters angered by a Catholic parade in northern Belfast threw homemade bombs, bricks and fireworks. Four officers were hospitalized, and 43 were treated at the scene. The police used a water cannon to disperse hundreds of protesters, some as young as 12, and one person was arrested, the police said. Chief Superintendent George Clarke said most of the violence occurred after the parade and was aimed at police officers who were trying to keep the two sides apart. Late Monday night, a second round of sectarian clashes in Belfast left nine officers injured, Reuters reported.

headline: A Summer of Easy Guns and Dead Children
abstract: Matt, a college graduate; Kemar, an A student; a 4-year-old girl; a young boxer — fatal shootings in New York City are up.
lead_paragraph: In Harlem, Paula Shaw-Leary talks of her youngest, Matt, who got his college degree in May and was accepted to graduate school, a soulful-eyed young man with a broad nose and an impish sense of humor.

headline: Largest Settlements Under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
abstract: The largest settlements have not been with American companies.
lead_paragraph: The largest settlements have not been with American companies.

headline: Foreign Firms Most Affected by a U.S. Law Barring Bribes
abstract: A law intended to prohibit bribery of foreign officials by United States businesses has led to more than $3 billion in settlements, but nine of the top 10 were with foreign companies.
lead_paragraph: A law intended to prohibit the payment of bribes to foreign officials by United States businesses has produced more than $3 billion in settlements. But a list of the top companies making these settlements is notable in one respect: its lack of American names.

headline: A Woman Finds a Niche in a Cuban Tradition
abstract: Ana Pérez, who was born in Cuba, learned to roll cigars from her father. She combines the skill with her looks and education making cigars at corporate functions and other events.
lead_paragraph: Ana Pérez reached into a pile of Connecticut shade tobacco leaves and placed one on the small table in front of her. She began spraying the leaf with water and carving it up with a chaveta knife.

headline: Trick Shot Ignites Doubles Comeback
abstract: Two points away from elimination, the Bryan brothers were kept alive in part by a between-the-legs return. The shot-taker, Bob Bryan, advised: Don’t try it at home.
lead_paragraph: A between-the-legs trick shot may have kept alive the Bryan brothers’ chances of winning their fifth United States Open title. Down a set, Bob and Mike Bryan were two points from losing their third-round match when Bob Bryan executed the shot and followed it with a winner.

headline: Health Issue Leads Fish to Withdraw Before Federer Match
abstract: Mardy Fish withdrew from the U.S. Open because of his latest health scare. He has had a traumatic season, missing multiple tournaments because of an accelerated heartbeat.
lead_paragraph: On the day when Rafael Nadal announced that he was extending his break from tennis for two more months, he ended up sending long-distance condolences to another player with physical concerns: Mardy Fish.

headline: Lobbyists and Friends in Exile (Wink, Wink)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2008', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: From a spot not so distant from the convention, two superlobbyists held court at a high-powered brunch — in cheeky accordance with presidential restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Rules are rules, and President Obama’s scrupulous restrictions on lobbyists have exiled them to the fringes of the convention in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Another Star Turn by McIlroy and Hard American Choices
abstract: Rory McIlroy held off Louis Oosthuizen and Tiger Woods at the Deutsche Bank Championship in a finish that left the American Ryder Cup captain, Davis Love III, facing tough choices.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — The final round of the Deutsche Bank Championship was shaping up to be golf’s version of “America’s Got Talent,” with at least seven competitors vying for the last four United States Ryder Cup spots before a national television audience and a judging panel headed by Davis Love III.

headline: People Don’t Vote When No One Asks Them To
abstract: What I learned about the Latino vote while running a city council campaign on the south side of Julián Castro’s San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats selected Julián Castro, the mayor of San Antonio, to deliver the keynote address at their national convention — the same honor that propelled State Senator Barack Obama into the national spotlight just eight years ago — as part of its courtship of Latino voters, whom the President needs to vote in large numbers if he wants to be re-elected. As it happens, as the campaign manager for a young, outsider candidate for San Antonio’s city council in 2011, I learned something simple but crucial: while younger Latinos are increasingly the focus of national political strategists, they are still largely ignored at the local level.

headline: A Vast Frank Lloyd Wright Archive Is Moving to New York
abstract: Thousands of Frank Lloyd Wright’s architectural drawings, models, photographs and documents are moving to New York, where the collection will reside at Columbia University and the Museum of Modern Art and become more accessible.
lead_paragraph: The Modernist architect Frank Lloyd Wright wasn’t a hoarder. But he did save just about everything — whether a doodle on a Plaza Hotel cocktail napkin of an imagined city on Ellis Island, his earliest pencil sketch of the spiraling Guggenheim Museum or a model of Broadacre City, his utopian metropolis. Since Wright’s death in 1959 those relics have been locked in storage at his former headquarters — Taliesin, in Spring Green, Wis., and Taliesin West, in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Obama Makes Detour to Visit Hurricane Site
abstract: President Obama’s stop in Louisiana took on outsized political overtones in this campaign season.
lead_paragraph: KENNER, La. — President Obama took a short detour from campaigning on Monday to inspect the damage wrought by Hurricane Isaac last week and the government response, a stop that took on outsized political overtones in this campaign season.

headline: Union Jobs Plummet in the Private Sector
abstract: Although the city has replenished the positions it lost during the 2008 recession, a recent report shows that organized labor has not bounced back.
lead_paragraph: New York City has regained all of the jobs it lost during the last recession, but its labor unions have not, and the steep decline in the last several years may signal a lasting erosion of one of the few remaining bastions of union power, according to the authors of a report to be released this week.

headline: Frank Lloyd Wright’s Archives
abstract: MOMA and Columbia University are teaming up to make Wright’s archive more accessible to the public.
lead_paragraph: MOMA and Columbia University are teaming up to make Wright’s archive more accessible to the public.

headline: The Man Behind Facebook’s I.P.O. Debacle
abstract: The company’s chief financial officer badly misjudged demand for Facebook’s I.P.O., and will be under pressure until the stock rebounds.
lead_paragraph: It is David Ebersman’s fault. There is just no way around it.

headline: Michael Clarke Duncan, Actor, Dies at 54
abstract: Mr. Duncan rose from working as a ditch digger to employ his booming bass voice and immense physical presence in many movie roles, most notably a tragic prisoner with a healing touch in the 1999 film “The Green Mile.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Clarke Duncan, who rose from working as a ditch digger to employ his booming bass voice and immense physical presence in many movie roles, most notably a tragic prisoner with a healing touch in the 1999 film “The Green Mile,” died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 54.

headline: In Final Tournament, Roddick Is Last American Man Standing

lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Success in the passing game revolves around communication. After a quarterback comes to the line of scrimmage and surveys the defense, a glance from him to a potential receiver can be charged with meaning. When a play breaks down, a quarterback and a receiver must be able to anticipate each other’s actions.

headline: Man Arrested in Grisly Attack on 2 Siblings in New Jersey

lead_paragraph: A 31-year-old man has been arrested in a grisly attack in Camden, N.J., that killed a 6-year-old boy and wounded the boy’s sister, authorities said Monday.

headline: Syrian Children Offer Glimpse of a Future of Reprisals
keywords: ['Sunni Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Alawite Muslims', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: If Syrian rebel fighters portray their battle as a struggle for democracy, refugee children at the Zaatari camp in Jordan tell a much uglier story of sectarian revenge against Alawites.
lead_paragraph: ZAATARI, Jordan — Like all the small children in the desert refugee camp here, Ibtisam, 11, is eager to go home to the toys, bicycles, books, cartoons and classmates she left behind in Syria.

headline: As Vendors Hustle for Space, Tempers Flare
abstract: Street vendors who work a stretch of East 161st Street near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx say a fatal shooting last week, in which police say one seller shot two others, was bound to happen.
lead_paragraph: They flip over tables of those who do not respect the rules of the block, scattering inexpensive jewelry and handcrafted artwork. Sometimes they get into yelling matches that threaten to ignite the hot summer streets. For street vendors in New York, turf is the name of the game — and to turn a profit, some resort to violence.

headline: Mr. Bernanke’s Next Task
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman seems to know the economy needs help, but will the Fed provide it?
lead_paragraph: It will be another week — at a meeting of the Federal Reserve policy-making committee on Sept. 12 and 13 — before anyone knows for sure what Ben Bernanke thinks the Fed should do, if anything, to stimulate the weak economy. What is known is that, without more help, the economy is likely to remain weak, or grow weaker, through the rest of this year.

headline: South Africa: Striking Miners Hurt in Clash With Police
keywords: ['Gold', 'Strikes', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Mines and Mining', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The police used rubber bullets to disperse a crowd of striking gold miners on Monday at the Gold Fields mine, just east of Johannesburg, injuring four of them.
lead_paragraph: The police used rubber bullets to disperse a crowd of striking gold miners on Monday at the Gold Fields mine, right, just east of Johannesburg, injuring four of them. Four people were arrested. The miners have been on strike since June. The clash came days after Julius S. Malema, a former leader of the Youth League of the African National Congress who has called for South Africa’s mines to be nationalized, visited the miners. It also followed an episode on Aug. 16, when the police opened fire on workers engaged in a strike at a platinum mine in Marikana, northwest of Johannesburg, killing 34 of them, a response that reminded many of apartheid-era police violence against demonstrators.

headline: U Visas Hit a Ceiling
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Visas', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: The failure of Congress to agree on a protection law for women threatens abused immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Although the federal government’s fiscal year doesn’t end until Sept. 30, the Department of Homeland Security has already reached the annual 10,000 limit on special visas for undocumented immigrants who are victims of domestic violence and sexual assaults and who also assist in investigations or prosecutions. This is the third consecutive time that the cap has been reached, and the earliest.

headline: Ohio Unions Battle Conservative ‘Super PACs’ for Votes
keywords: ['Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Political Action Committees', 'Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Unions’ get-out-the-vote efforts face a daunting challenge: Conservative “super PACs” with unlimited donations have saturated Ohio and other crucial states with anti-Obama ads.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — From a line of cubicles inside a union headquarters here, phone-bank volunteers hunched over laptop computers, improvising into their headsets their own versions of an anti-Mitt Romney script, which asserted that he had played a role in factories that closed, wages that dropped, workers who were fired.

headline: A Fight for Fair Courts
abstract: After recent Supreme Court rulings, are states foreclosed from using a public financing system just for judicial elections?
lead_paragraph: Having freed corporations, unions and other institutions to spend unlimited amounts of money on elections in its Citizens United ruling in 2010, the Supreme Court compounded the damage last year by striking down an element of Arizona’s public financing system that was meant to provide a workable alternative to all that corrupting campaign cash.

headline: Two Are Fatally Stabbed and Two Are Shot as Violence Follows Parade
abstract: A 26-year-old and a 27-year-old were killed after the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn, which has been marred by several fatal shootings over the past nine years.
lead_paragraph: The day had been mostly quiet, except for the thunder of police helicopters and the boom of reggae music coming from the colorful floats of the annual West Indian American Day Parade.

headline: Bernstein at Green-Wood
abstract: While surveying the damage done by vandals at the famed Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, a historian finds gifts left for the prodigious composer Leonard Bernstein.
lead_paragraph: Vandals lately have been marauding through Green-Wood Cemetery, the historic gem atop the heights of Brooklyn, toppling and shattering dozens of gravestones, befouling mausoleums and beheading a marble angel at the grave of a 5-year-old boy. But, just a few days earlier, a visitor to the cemetery had found the truer spirit of Green-Wood displayed at the simple grave of Leonard Bernstein, the prodigious composer and conductor who died in 1990. Someone had left a small garland of blossoms and an empty bottle of Jack Daniel’s sour mash whiskey to honor the maestro at rest.

lead_paragraph: Most of the illegal ivory seized in large-scale shipments in the past three years originated in Kenya and Tanzania.

lead_paragraph: Heavily armed platoons of rangers at Garamba National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo wage war against elephant poachers.

headline: Elephants Dying in Epic Frenzy as Ivory Fuels Wars and Profits
abstract: Conservation groups say poachers are wiping out tens of thousands of elephants a year, more than at any time in the previous two decades, with the ivory trade becoming increasingly militarized.
lead_paragraph: GARAMBA NATIONAL PARK, Democratic Republic of Congo — In 30 years of fighting poachers, Paul Onyango had never seen anything like this. Twenty-two dead elephants, including several very young ones, clumped together on the open savanna, many killed by a single bullet to the top of the head.

lead_paragraph: The way Andy Murray played Monday at the United States Open, it sometimes felt like 1985, as if Murray hopped into a tennis DeLorean and transported his game back in time.

abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — “Would you like a roasted oyster?” asked the server in black, bouncing slightly to the throbbing bass, as guests entered the StartUp RockOn party. “They’re an aphrodisiac.”

headline: Nets Players May Find Brooklyn a Tempting Place to Live
abstract: Brooklyn, the borough the team now calls home because of the Barclays Center, offers plenty of tantalizing real estate choices.

headline: How Should India Deal With Changing Monsoons?
abstract: Rainwater harvesting, new crops and river management could help, experts say.
lead_paragraph: In many parts of India, including in New Delhi and Mumbai, monsoon rains have picked up in recent weeks, bringing much-needed relief. But much of north, west and south India still have gotten only a fraction of the rain they normally receive, as I reported recently.

headline: Striving to Lead More of an Heirloom Life
abstract: Carl Richards makes the case for considering cost-per-use and buying things that last (and last).
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: In Harm’s Way in Pakistan: Diplomats Are Targets, Too
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A suicide bomber’s deadly attack on a U.S. consular vehicle in the Pakistani frontier town of Peshawar reminds us that diplomats in dangerous regions, like soldiers, journalists and aid workers, are often in the line of fire.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Pakistani city of Peshawar, dusty, chaotic and venal, has long been a sanctuary for Taliban and Qaeda fighters in need of a break from the fighting in the adjoining tribal areas along the Afghan border. It’s hard to articulate, but you go there and you can feel the danger.

headline: News Quiz | September 4, 2012
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Tough, Rewarding Journey to India’s Valley of Flowers
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The remote national park, nestled in the Himalayas, is home to more than 600 varieties of plants.
lead_paragraph: A grueling four-hour trek from the village of Ghangria in the Garhwal district of Uttaranchal brings visitors to one of India’s most stunning national parks, the Valley of Flowers. These grassy pastures, at an altitude of 13,000 feet in the western Himalayas, are covered in snow most of the year. During July and August, though, many of the valley’s more than 600 varieties of flora are in stunning bloom. The trek, which runs across streams and below shining, snow-covered peaks, eventually brings the traveler to a field of pink and white flowers.

headline: Nomura Reshuffles Investment Banking Unit
abstract: William Vereker is stepping aside as Nomura’s joint head of investment banking, leaving Kentaro Okuda as chief of the unit, according to an internal memo.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Nomura has started a shake-up at its investment banking unit after announcing a $1 billion cost-cutting program last week.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 4, 2012
abstract: Can you choose the adverb that best describes that notion that Scotland’s relationship with England would improve if the two nations were independent of one another?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the op-ed “Will Scotland Go Its Own Way?”

headline: Fifty Objects Tell the Story of New York
abstract: What objects past or present represent New York City for you?
lead_paragraph: Before you look at “A History of New York in 50 Objects,” answer the question, WHAT objects past or present represent New York City for you?

headline: A Collective Eye on Social Justice
abstract: Members of Noor, the photo collective that will observe its fifth anniversary at the Visa pour l’Image photojournalism festival in Perpignan, France, discuss their approach and practice.
lead_paragraph: The photographer-owned photo agency, Noor, was started on Sept. 6, 2007, at the Visa Pour l’image photojournalism festival in Perpignan, France. This week the photographers will return, commemorating their fifth anniversary with the unveiling of a new Web site and an 11-volume book project. The Noor members Alixandra Fazzina, Kadir van Lohuizen and Jon Lowenstein spoke with James Estrin. The interview has been edited.

headline: What Are You Looking Forward To, or Dreading, This School Year?
abstract: Tell us how you feel about the new academic year, whether you’re in middle school, high school or college.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the 2012-13 school year.

headline: European Leaders Step Up Talks
abstract: European leaders crisscrossed the Continent to discuss strategies for handling the debt crisis, a day after the central bank president described plans to buy short-term government bonds.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders crisscrossed the Continent on Tuesday for meetings on strategies for handling the sovereign debt crisis, a day after the president of the European Central Bank seemed to set the stage for a policy announcement for later in the week.

headline: Counselor’s Calendar | September Checklist for Seniors
abstract: Webster T. Trenchard, the director of college guidance at The Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor, Conn., advises seniors to “channel your inner Goldilocks and try to find the academic schedule that is just right.”
lead_paragraph: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: So You Want to Be an Hivernaut?
abstract: There are many opportunities to serve as a research conductor — and subject — in the multitude of space-analogue environments around the world.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agency’s human spaceflight program.

headline: Republicans Are Wrong on Call for Gold Standard
abstract: Once again, the Republican Party platform is calling for a return to the gold standard, a plan that has little support among economists, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: A Speaker With a Firm Grip on Sound
abstract: The Zooka from Carbon Audio is a bar-shaped wireless speaker designed to slide onto the edge of a MacBook or iPad.
lead_paragraph: As wireless speakers become more abundant in the marketplace, it’s getting harder to tell them apart. So companies are coming up with distinct designs and kooky names, hoping to stand out from the crowd.

headline: Sept. 3: Par or Bogey?
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: By now we can say that Mitt Romney very probably got a bounce in the polls after last week’s Republican National Convention. What’s trickier to figure is whether the increase failed to live up to reasonable expectations.
lead_paragraph: We’re reaching the point of diminishing returns in analyzing Mitt Romney’s convention bounce. But we can say two things almost for certain. First, Mr. Romney very probably got a bounce. And second, it’s a below-average bounce by historical standards.

headline: Daily Report: Multinationals Push Into Venture Capital
abstract: From downtown San Francisco to Palo Alto, Calif., companies like American Express and General Motors are opening offices and investing millions of dollars in local start-ups, reports Evelyn M. Rusli in Tuesday’s New York Times. But the push into Silicon Valley comes even as the broader venture capital industry goes through a shaky time.

headline: Those Madmen Driving Our National Highways
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Serial Murders', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: In “Killer on the Road,” Ginger Strand examines the links between random killings and the soullessness bred by the Interstate System.
lead_paragraph: When Vladimir Nabokov wrote in “Lolita” that “you can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style,” he was not predicting the arrival of the serial killer and necrophile Ted Bundy. But he might have been.

headline: Smiles and Barbs for Clinton in China
abstract: As Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in China on Tuesday, editorials, articles and comments by analysts in Chinese media contained unusual bite.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived here on Tuesday night to a barrage of unusually harsh coverage in China’s official news media over what they called American meddling in territorial disputes in the region — and then a strikingly warm welcome from the country’s foreign minister.

headline: A Searing Look at Ties Between Africa’s Wars and the Ivory Trade
abstract: An in-depth look at the links between African insurgent movements and the rising slaughter of elephants for the China ivory trade.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Gettleman (with video reporting by Ben Solomon and photographs by Tyler Hicks) has launched an important series of articles exploring the interrelationship of Africa’s destabilizing insurgencies and the recent surge in elephant poaching. The driving force, of course, is the high value of the resulting caches of illicit ivory in China.

headline: Tuesday Reading: A Study Questions the Advantages of Organic Food
abstract: A Stanford University study questions advantages of organic food, a reminder that strokes aren’t just for older people, coping at the airport without a wallet and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Whom The Gods Would Destroy, They First Make Bipartisan
abstract: When an icon becomes a punchline.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong points us to a truly weird column by Clive Crook, which apparently was supposed to be a satirical take on Paul Ryan’s critics but falls completely flat. This follows on an almost equally weird piece by Ben Smith berating all those people who had the temerity to judge Ryan the great Truthteller on whether he actually, you know, told the truth.

headline: Gujarat’s ‘Hitler’ Clothing Store to Be Renamed
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: After receiving hundreds of phone calls and international pressure, owners say they are looking for a more positive name.
lead_paragraph: The owners of a men’s clothing store in Ahmedabad named Hitler say they have decided to rename the shop after receiving hundreds of phone calls and   pressure from international groups.

headline: Gas Prices Rise, but So Do Auto Sales
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Analysts said a wide range of fuel-efficient models, particularly from Detroit automakers, has helped spur demand and accelerate the industry’s recovery.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In the past, nothing slowed down strong car sales faster than a spike in gasoline prices.

headline: Edible Selby | Kirk Lombard
abstract: Dig deeper into Todd Selby’s global culinary tour, starting with this video with Kirk Lombard, a fisherman in California.
lead_paragraph: Meet Kirk Lombard, the “Intertidal Harvester.” In his latest film, The Selby follows the San Franciscan forager as he digs for saltwater treasures — horseneck clams, rock pricklebacks and monkeyface eels. His wife and partner in crime Camilla Lombard also plays a mean accordion to his harmonica. Quite the duo!

headline: Dick Clark Productions Sold to Guggenheim Partners
abstract: Dick Clark Productions, the company that produces the Golden Globe Awards show and the New Year’s Eve broadcast hosted for nearly 40 years by its late founder, was sold to Guggenheim Partners and a pair of multimedia investors on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Dick Clark Productions, the company that produces the Golden Globe Awards show and the New Year’s Eve broadcast hosted for nearly 40 years by its late founder, was sold to Guggenheim Partners and a group of investors on Tuesday.

headline: Santander Seeks $4.2 Billion I.P.O. of Its Mexican Unit
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The listing would be one of the largest I.P.O.’s ever in Mexico, and comes as the country’s economy continues to grow on the back of strong local demand. At the same time, American depository receipts of the unit would list on the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Banco Santander of Spain said on Tuesday that it was looking to raise as much as $4.2 billion through the initial public offering of its Mexican unit.

headline: The Bookworms of China
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Censorship', 'Cultural Revolution', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Hardline Communism may have stalled Chinese literature, but it did not stamp it out. The Chinese publishing industry is the world’s largest and perhaps its most promising.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The traditional publishing industry’s prospects may be bleak overall, but there is a promising story to be found in an unexpected place, in a country plagued by censorship and bureaucracy: China.

headline: Fuse Introduces ‘Fuse News,’ With Some Recognizable Hosts
abstract: The music-themed cable channel is creating “Fuse News,” a daily live news show that will be anchored by Ashanti, Elaine Moran, Alexa Chung and Jack Osbourne.
lead_paragraph: Fuse, the music-themed cable channel that mixes videos and documentaries with offbeat fare like the comedy game show “Funny or Die’s Billy on the Street,” is increasing its commitment to music journalism. On Tuesday it said that it was creating a dedicated news division and introducing a daily news show whose hosts may be familiar to viewers of its sometime rival MTV.

headline: Looming Over State’s Delegation, the Shadow of a Harassment Case
abstract: The Day: The post-Labor Day workweek begins with leading figures in Albany facing investigations into the actions they took — or should have taken, but didn’t — in Assemblyman Vito Lopez’s sexual harassment scandal.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees once had a player whose fielding lapses inspired a New York Post label that stuck to him like flypaper: Hector (What a Pair of Hands) Lopez. That was 50 years ago. But retro is fashionable. Thanks to the New York State Assembly and its shenanigans, there is reason to revive the sobriquet.

headline: Arizona Cardinals, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
abstract: Even the Cardinals themselves don’t sound too optimistic about 2012, but their defense gives them reason for hope.
lead_paragraph: These days, there’s about as much optimism in Arizona as there is rain. Even the Cardinals themselves don’t sound too amped about their chances in 2012. They seem to understand that it’s never good when your quarterback competition carries on through the entire preseason. Coach Ken Whisenhunt reluctantly made a final decision after the fourth meaningless contest, naming John Skelton the starter. This comes a year after Whisenhunt and General Manager Rod Graves traded cornerback Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie and a second-round pick, and forked over $12 million guaranteed (which has since become $20 million) to acquire Kevin Kolb.

headline: Family Life According to the Brotherhood
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Families and Family Life', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood is committed to upholding patriarchal and traditional values around a woman’s place in society, and many Egyptian women need no convincing.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Women are erratic and emotional, and they make good wives and mothers — but never leaders or rulers. That, at least, is what Osama Abou Salama, a professor of botany at Cairo University and a member of the Muslim Brotherhood, told young men and women during a recent premarital counseling class.

headline: Priorities USA Action Reports Record Monthly Donations
abstract: The Democratic super PAC backing President Obama raised $10 million in August, a record increase in contributions that may be a demonstration of growing concern among some elite Democratic donors that Republican outside groups will swamp Mr. Obama’s re-election effort
lead_paragraph: The Democratic “super PAC” backing President Obama raised $10 million in August, as donors gave a record amount to the group amid growing concern among some elite Democratic contributors that Republican outside groups will swamp Mr. Obama’s re-election effort.

headline: Valeant Sticks to Torrid Pace of Deal-Making
abstract: The $2.6 billion acquisition of Medicis Pharmaceutical is the 11th deal this year for the Montreal-based Valeant, which merged with Biovail of Canada in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International has not been afraid to spend its cash.

headline: What We’re Reading

lead_paragraph: The New York Times: Though they are undoubtedly more expensive, organic fruits, vegetables and meat aren’t more nutritious than their conventional counterparts, according to scientists at Stanford University. — Emily Weinstein

headline: In Interview Blitz, Ryan Plays Defense and Offense
abstract: With Mitt Romney keeping a low profile this week, Paul D. Ryan is the face of the Republican ticket, and on Tuesday he blitzed all three morning network television shows, pressing the attack against President Obama days before he is renominated at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, N.C. — With Mitt Romney keeping a low profile this week, Representative Paul D. Ryan is the face of the Republican ticket, and on Tuesday he blitzed all three morning network television shows, pressing the attack against President Obama days before he is renominated at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: On the Fringes of Europe, a Crackdown on Migrants
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The economic crisis in Europe has failed to deter migrants from fleeing poverty and unrest at home by attempting the sometimes perilous journey to the Continent. As the latest would-be immigrants were turned back by Spanish authorities, human rights groups have been expressing concern about measures being taken to protect Fortess Europe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the early hours of Tuesday, units of Spain’s paramilitary Civil Guard rounded up a group of would-be African immigrants on an otherwise uninhabited Spanish rock off the North African coast and shipped them back to the Moroccan shore just a few dozen yards away.

headline: How We Teach Students to Cheat
abstract: Our culture tells our children that lying and cheating are acceptable ways to get ahead in life.
lead_paragraph: When I was in high school, I saw a dear friend unroll a slip of paper and copy answers onto an exam we were taking. I was floored. After a lot of time trying to decide if it was better to feel like an accomplice or a prig, I opted for prig.

headline: Stefano Pilati Returns to Italian Fashion
abstract: After getting knocked around a bit during his years as the designer of Yves Saint Laurent, Stefano Pilati has landed at Ermenegildo Zegna.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good fit. After getting knocked around a bit during his years as the designer of Yves Saint Laurent, Stefano Pilati has landed at Ermenegildo Zegna. The fate of Mr. Pilati, as you will recall, was the subject of much speculation, well before he was out the door at YSL. And all that talk had a clear effect on his work and his psyche, so much so that it was a wonder when everyone stood up to give him an ovation at his last show.

headline: Love and Marriage in a Traditional Climate
abstract: Instead of hiding behind her notepad, a reporter opens up to her subjects to better understand the context behind a Muslim Brotherhood premarital counseling workshop.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When raising issues related to culture and women, I often remember that the very realities that perplex us are the ones truly worth understanding. And in order to fully understand, we must consider context.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Building the Perfect Player
abstract: In his regular post-match question-and-answer session, Andy Murray talked with The TImes’ Greg Bishop about which players he like to borrow shots from.
lead_paragraph: After Andy Murray played a nearly perfect 6-4, 6-4, 6-2 trouncing of Milos Raonic, Murray sat down with Straight Sets for his regular post-match question-and-answer session. From the perfect match, he attempted to build the perfect player.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Boom-Bust Summer of Movies, and Hugo Awards Cut Short
abstract: Also, advertisers and marketing firms try to promote more diversity in their industry, and a Pirate Bay co-founder facing charges of copyright violations is arrested in Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: As summer vacations were ending, the movie industry took stock of the season just past and found reasons for concern, Brooks Barnes writes. Ticket sales at North American cinemas in the summer declined an estimated 3 percent, to $4.28 billion, the first decline in seven years; total attendance was the lowest since at least 1993, when independent records first were kept. There were specific reasons that could, perhaps, explain the decline — the Olympics; the shootings in Aurora, Colo. — but still the results were sobering.

headline: Live and Let Live: Humans and Tigers
abstract: Coexistence is possible with the right safeguards, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: In an increasingly crowded world, wildlife conservation often requires that humans share space with large carnivores. But living alongside potentially deadly 670-pound tigers poses its challenges, and the tigers must similarly contend with human disturbances. Two new studies suggest that it is possible to find an equilibrium, however.

headline: Do You Have a Hurricane Deductible?
abstract: Coastal states can have different insurance deductibles for hurricanes and named storms.
lead_paragraph: Many homeowners in Louisiana who were affected by Hurricane Isaac are probably getting familiar with an aspect of their insurance policies known as a hurricane deductible.

headline: Obama’s Speech Will Be Outdoors, Unless Safety Is an Issue, Aides Say
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Weather']
abstract: Campaign officials have this overriding thought in mind: If the weather would be good enough for the Carolina Panthers to play in the rain, it will be good enough for the president.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — If the Carolina Panthers can play in the rain, President Obama can speak in the rain.

headline: His Biggest Fan Was Himself
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The crime writer R.J. Ellory faked reviews of his own work on Amazon, according to reports in the English media over the weekend, which were confirmed by Mr. Ellory. It’s yet another example of how fake reviews percolate throughout the Internet.
lead_paragraph: In a recent article I wrote on faked book reviews on the Internet, a Chicago researcher, Bing Liu, estimated that a third of all online reviews are suspect. Perhaps that seems hard to believe. Surely the bright promise of peer reviews on the Internet has not degenerated so far so fast.

headline: Bomber Kills at Least 25 at Afghan Funeral
abstract: Dozens of people were killed Tuesday by a suicide bomber in an area of eastern Afghanistan where members of the Shinwari tribe have long been engaged in internal tribal warfare.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — At least 25 mourners were killed when a suicide bomber struck at a funeral on Tuesday in eastern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said.

headline: Handle With Flair
abstract: For every man, a man bag.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, when a friend was turning 40, Prada came up with the perfect joke gift at the Milan men’s shows: a golf bag patterned with stylized flowers. I still tease the birthday boy about it being time to take up golf. And although I did not invest in the ultimate man bag, it made me think about how those fancy accessories from the 1980s have become just another easily accepted branch of leather goods.

headline: After a Year, Business Group Members Discuss Their Progress
abstract: Even in a tough economy, all five of the women-owned businesses are growing.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, the She Owns It business group began meeting with the goal of exploring the day-to-day challenges faced by four women who own and run companies. Since then, the group, which now has five members, has gathered regularly to discuss topics such as hiring and managing employees, health insurance, manufacturing, growing pains, and customer service.

headline: Two Views of Felton as He Takes Over for Lin
abstract: According to dueling narratives, point guard Raymond Felton will either be a fine complement to the Knicks’ two high scorers or a mediocre floor general prone to petulance.
lead_paragraph: At the height of the Jeremy Lin free-agency drama in July, just days before he was officially cast adrift by a front office still mired in lock step silence on the matter, the Knicks signed Raymond Felton.

headline: Microsoft Moves Further Into the Cloud
abstract: Windows Server 2012 is designed both to work independently and to connect with some 200 online services that Microsoft offers through its Azure cloud computing system.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft just went further into the cloud.

headline: British Premier Reshuffles Cabinet, Promoting Official Linked to Murdoch Case
abstract: In a bid to reshape his government, Prime Minister David Cameron shook up his cabinet on Tuesday, appointing Jeremy Hunt, who became entangled in the News Corporation scandal, to a top ministerial post.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a bid to reshape his government halfway through its five-year term, Prime Minister David Cameron shook up his cabinet on Tuesday, but produced only one major surprise: the promotion of a Cameron insider, Jeremy Hunt, to health minister, despite his entanglement in a furor over ties between the prime minister’s inner circle and Rupert Murdoch’s scandal-tainted media empire.

headline: Image of the Day: September 4
abstract: Reliance Group chairman Anil D. Ambani discussed future plans to offset the business house’s debt.

headline: Near the Convention Site, ‘Occupy’ Takes Root
abstract: A low turnout of protesters as the Democratic convention kicks off.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Eric Verlo waved an “Occupy the DNC” flag as he stood among the dozens of tents pitched around Marshall Park in uptown Charlotte on Monday in advance of the Democratic National Convention. The flag was not so much a rallying point as a declaration of the Occupy movement’s defiant presence here.

headline: Lunch Trays Got Too Lean in City’s Fight Against Fat
abstract: New federal guidelines have reduced the food minimums for this school year, but some meals for students still require more calories than New York City schools have been providing.
lead_paragraph: Worried that children were losing the war on obesity, New York City began to slim down its school lunch offerings several years ago, replacing fries with baked potato strips and introducing nonfat chocolate milk, whole grain pasta and salad bars, among other tweaks.

headline: Motorsports: Jenson Button Avoids Pileup to Win Belgian G.P.
abstract: The McLaren Mercedes driver broke away from a field diminished by an early crash for his second win of 2012.
lead_paragraph: The Spa-Francorchamps circuit in Belgium is revered by Formula One drivers for its daunting features, chief among them the Raidillon-Eau Rouge portion, with its blind uphill turns. But for some of the series’ most recognized drivers, the most fateful section of the track on Sunday was the very first right-hander.

Bill Clinton of Arkansas, deemed a rising young pol making his debut on the national stage, gave a much-anticipated but ultimately disastrous nominating speech for Michael Dukakis.

abstract: A look at the 2012 platform from the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Big Data in the (Heated or Cooled) Air Around You

The company incorporates what it learns from this, along with data like weather forecasts, into software updates that can be remotely installed in the $249 machine. More is on the way.
lead_paragraph: Big Data is in more places than you know, perhaps even your living room.

headline: When It Comes to Reservations, Time Is Money

headline: U.S. Open Weather Nemesis Returns
abstract: Rain has scrambled Tuesday’s schedule at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: 5:53 p.m. | Updated United States Open tournament officials have postponed the remainder of the women’s quarterfinal match between Maria Sharapova and Marion Bartoli — which was stopped with Bartoli leading, 4-0, in the first set — until Wednesday, but have left all other day session matches still on the schedule to hopefully be completed on Tuesday.
