headline: Going Against the Grain of Complacency
abstract: Lester Brown, who has long been tracking how much grain the world grows, figures the global cupboard has a 77-day supply, only half the amount of a good year. Food supply, as he has warned, also serves as a kind of barometer for social unrest.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Lester Brown finally gets to say, “I told you so,” we are all in very deep trouble.

headline: Apple Confirms Sept. 12 Event
abstract: Apple issued invitations for an event next week where it is expected to introduce its next iPhone. The invitation’s vague teaser says, “It’s almost here.”
lead_paragraph: Apple on Tuesday sent invitations to news organizations for an event next week where it is expected to introduce the sixth model of the iPhone.

headline: Celebrating a Transit Hub, in All Its Blandness
abstract: Every few years, we revisit the question of what to do about the “problem” of Pennsylvania Station. But, the author asks, is there no one who would miss it if it were gone?
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I swept through Penn Station. My oldest sister, Clare, had agreed to take us four “little kids” into the city to see the new movie “Sounder” at Radio City Music Hall. I held fast to her hand as we raced through the crowded station to make the show — it was hot and noisy and confusing, but oddly thrilling when we finally pushed through the mass of dark coats and reached the bracing night air on Seventh Avenue.

headline: In North Carolina, Romney and Obama Are in a Tight Race
abstract: In North Carolina, where the Democratic faithful have descended to hold their convention, 47 percent of likely voters are supporting the Republican candidate, Mitt Romney, and 43 percent are supporting President Obama.
lead_paragraph: In North Carolina, where the Democratic faithful have descended to hold their convention, a new poll shows that Mitt Romney and President Obama are running closely in the state.

headline: Restaurants Opening in Early September
abstract: You don’t have long to wait for a new seafood shack, a burger joint and a restaurant 39 floors up.
lead_paragraph: BAIT & HOOK This easygoing but citified seafood shack will serve traditional clam chowders, lobster rolls and crab cakes, in addition to inventions like crab, chorizo and corn pizza. Some non-seafood items, like regular mac and cheese, will also be available. (Monday): 231 Second Avenue (14th Street), (212) 260-8015.

headline: Coming to Australia
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Hazaras (Ethnic Group)', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Catering to an immigration-sensitive electorate, the Australian government is making it harder for Afghan refugees to make a new home on a land they’ve risked death to reach.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE — A takeaway kebab shop in a leafy Australian suburb seems a far cry from the troubles of Afghanistan. But even here the anguish of war and centuries-old prejudices bite.

headline: Commander Preble’s Very Bad Day
abstract: How a miscalculation near Mobile Bay led to a political firefight in Civil War Washington.
lead_paragraph: Imagine it’s the summer of 1862, and you have just one job: guarding a few miles of the Gulf Coast to keep enemy ships from crossing the Union naval blockade. But you’ve been on the job less than a week, with a creaky ship and little time to train your crews or establish an effective strategy. Your engineers took down one of the two boilers on your vessel for repairs, and you are just now coming back to about half strength.

headline: Q. and A.: Climate Change and the Monsoon
abstract: In decades to come, global warming is likely to result in heavier bursts of rain and longer dry spells.
lead_paragraph: As I report today in The Times, the South Asian monsoon is critical to sustaining plants, animals and 1.6 billion people on the subcontinent. When it brings too little rain between June and October, shortages of food and drinking water can develop. When its bounty is too great, floods can displace millions and cause hundreds of deaths.

headline: Roddick’s Legacy: Work Ethic and Willpower
abstract: Andy Roddick, who will play Tuesday night at the United States Open, participated in some of the most memorable matches of our time.
lead_paragraph: Andy Roddick’s stirring first-week run, coming after he announced that this would be his last tournament, has prompted many accolades, along with the belated acknowledgment that in addition to being his era’s best American player he has also been its least understood. As Karen Crouse pointed out Monday in her fine appreciation, Roddick’s story has been consistently, and mistakenly, represented as a narrative of failed promise — in part because his one major championship came so early (at the 2003 Open, when he was 21).

headline: Sockets & Streams: Tickets Now Available
abstract: Tickets are now available for our Sept. 12 event, Sockets and Streams.
lead_paragraph: We’ve just opened up registration for our Sept. 12 event, Sockets and Streams. Get your ticket today via EventBrite.

headline: Party Platforms Are Poles Apart in Their View of the Nation
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Democratic National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The Democratic Party platform approved Tuesday offered a stark contrast to the Republican one adopted last week, especially on abortion rights, gay marriage and the future of Medicare and Social Security.
lead_paragraph: Voters are forever being told that they face stark choices. But the platform that Democrats approved Tuesday at their convention in Charlotte, N.C., was, in areas from social issues to entitlements, a mirror image of the platform that the Republicans adopted last week in Tampa, Fla.

headline: TimesCast Politics and Democratic Convention Day at a Glance
abstract: A look at the day’s events and the broadcast schedule for TimesCast politics.
lead_paragraph: 12:48 p.m. | Updated  CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As Democrats gather here, seeking to recapture the unity from 2008, the convention officially opens on Tuesday, and The Times’s political unit will be broadcasting live with the latest from the convention, beginning at 2 p.m. Here are a few of the highlights from the program:

headline: Kitchen Knives by a Household Name
abstract: All-Clad, known for pots and pans, has made some useful cutting tools.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of well-made, useful knives on the market these days, with new models showing up regularly. All-Clad, the company that made its name in pots and pans, is the latest player in the game. Its knives offer high-carbon stainless steel blades fitted into sleek, beautifully finished rosewood handles smoothly wrapped with steel at the end. Of the 10 models, 2 are especially worthwhile: what it calls a seven-inch daily slicer and a four-inch daily parer. The well-balanced slicer has a rectangular blade, similar to a hard-to-find Japanese nakiri or vegetable knife; it’s like a chef’s knife on its way to being a cleaver. I own one of these from Japan and rely on it, though mine is a little lighter than the All-Clad. The parer has a rounded end, almost like a mini-santoku, making it useful for all kinds of fine cutting and paring jobs.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Jonathan Adams joined iCrossing, New York, part of the Hearst Corporation, in a new post, senior vice president of media for North America, leading the media practice.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Adams joined iCrossing, New York, part of the Hearst Corporation, in a new post, senior vice president of media for North America, leading the media practice. He had most recently been senior vice president and director for global media at Digitas, part of the Publicis Groupe.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A viewer wonders about the intent of a Chevrolet commercial.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Nuclear Politics
abstract: The father of Pakistan’s nuclear weapons program is mulling a new career in politics.
lead_paragraph: In Pakistan’s history, Abdul Qadeer Khan holds a unique place as the father of the country’s nuclear weapons program. Now at the age of 76, he’s mulling another vocation – political candidate, in elections expected next year.

headline: A TMZ Moment at the Democratic Convention
abstract: As an Obama adviser, Valerie Jarrett, exited a Bloomberg breakfast panel, a reporter from the celebrity-stalking Web site TMZ shouted out the most surprising question of the morning, hand-held video camera at the ready.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Valerie Jarrett, a senior adviser to President Obama, had completed a monotonously on-message performance Tuesday morning — no slip-ups, no leaks, and no accidental news-making.

headline: Hackers Claim to Have 12 Million Apple Device Records
abstract: Hackers have released a file that they say contains more than one million identification numbers for Apple iPhones, iPads and iPod Touch devices. They claim to have obtained the file by hacking into the computer of a federal agent, though the F.B.I. denied that this had happened.
lead_paragraph: 8:00 p.m. | Updated Hackers released a file that they said contained a million identification numbers for Apple mobile devices, claiming that they had obtained it by hacking into the computer of an F.B.I. agent. The F.B.I. said it had no evidence that this was true.

headline: Walkabout – 9/4: Avoiding Airport Fast Food and Snagging Expensive Souvenirs
abstract: A capsule of travel news for the week of September 4, 2012, curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: No More Pastry Buffets A number of mobile applications and Web sites can now direct business travelers, once condemned to eating greasy meeting-room and airport fare, toward healthier options. (The New York Times)

headline: Never Too Far From a Yoga Mat
abstract: In observance of National Yoga Month in September, hotels at home and abroad are offering incentives to pose on the road.
lead_paragraph: In observance of National Yoga Month in September, hotels at home and abroad are offering incentives to pose on the road.

headline: Large Format | Stéphanie Zwicky’s Blog de Big Beauty
abstract: The Paris-based plus-size model is happily Rubenesque and out to defy the stereotype that all French women are rail-thin.
lead_paragraph: The belief that French women’s vaunted chic and their slender waistlines are inseparable — indeed, self-propagating — is so reflexive that it’s spurred its own ever-expanding self-help genre. So it may come as a surprise to learn that one of the most popular fashion bloggers in France is the Swiss-born, Paris-based plus-size model, actress and television host Stéphanie Zwicky of Le Blog de Big Beauty, who is happily and unabashedly Rubenesque. Zwicky started blogging in 2005 as a resource for other women struggling to find stylish clothes in sizes larger than 42 (an American 12) — which, she notes, is what 60 percent of French women wear. Today, she logs 230,000 readers from around the world every month, many of whom post ecstatic reviews of her colorful, body-conscious outfits (“J’aime, j’aime, et je sur-aime!” reads a typical comment.) “There are girls like me on every block, I’m just lucky to be so visible,” she says.

headline: Q&A: Telling Android Widget From App
abstract: On an Android phone, an app and a widget are two different things.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: In North Carolina, Obama’s 2008 Victory Was Ahead of Schedule
abstract: The new economy in North Carolina has made the state more competitive, but it still leans Republican.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here, a look at North Carolina, the Tar Heel State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Eric Heberlig, an associate professor of political science at the University of North Carolina-Charlotte, and Ferrel Guillory, a longtime writer and editor for the The News & Observer in Raleigh, N.C., and an adjunct faculty member in the Department of Public Policy at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill.

headline: Sometimes Formica Beats White Tablecloths
abstract: What makes a restaurant work? For one thing, personalization, a place with a working chef, not a cookie-cutter spinoff or a circus.
lead_paragraph: THE last time I ate in a four-star white-tablecloth restaurant, I was frustrated and unhappy. (Bear with me; I’m not asking for sympathy.)

headline: Filling Regis’s Shoes … Michael Strahan
abstract: Tuesday was the first day of “Live With Kelly and Michael.”
lead_paragraph: Kelly Ripa and Michael Strahan  hosted the first “Live With Kelly and Michael” on Tuesday. After the departure of Regis Philbin, a number of co-hosts joined Ms. Ripa, with word leaking out in August that Mr. Strahan would be chosen.

headline: Clip: ‘For Ellen’
abstract: A scene from the So Yong Kim film “For Ellen,” featuring Paul Dano as a struggling musician estranged from his wife (Margarita Levieva) but seeking to remain a part of his daughter’s life.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the So Yong Kim film “For Ellen,” featuring Paul Dano as a struggling musician estranged from his wife (Margarita Levieva) but seeking to remain a part of his daughter’s life.

headline: What Makes a Good Teacher?
abstract: Paul Tough’s new book highlights educators whose unsparing style actually helps children succeed.
lead_paragraph: New York City children start school this week, and, like many parents, I hope that each of my kids will get the perfect teacher. The new book from Paul Tough, “How Children Succeed: Grit, Curiosity and the Hidden Power of Character,” has given me a new sort of perfection to hope for: someone like Elizabeth Spiegel, the chess teacher at I.S. 318 in Brooklyn. Here is Spiegel writing in a blog post after her girls’ team won a national championship in 2010:

headline: On the Road to North Carolina, Obama Stops to Shore Up Support in Virginia
abstract: Of all the swing states this election, there are few more coveted by Democrats than this former capital of the Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: MECHANICSVILLE, Va. — Of all the swing states this election, there are few more coveted by Democrats than this former capital of the Confederacy, where an influx of Hispanics and population growth in Northern Virginia has turned this formerly red state, if not blue, then at least, purple.

headline: For the Fashion World, Spring 2013 Has Arrived
abstract: Visit the Fashion and Style section of The New York Times daily for continual fashion week coverage, on and off the runways. Here’s what to expect from our reporters and editors.
lead_paragraph: Though the official kickoff comes on Thursday, with more than 300 designers presenting their spring 2013 collections at Lincoln Center, Milk Studios and other spaces around town, New York Fashion Week has already begun in the minds of the designers, journalists, buyers and followers.

headline: Natural Born Recovery Killers
abstract: Mumbo-jumbo about interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Hmm. Brad DeLong finds Niall Ferguson touting a paper by William White (pdf) that I read as a desperate attempt to find some reason why we should be raising interest rates despite a deeply depressed economy and an absence of obvious inflationary pressure. Why the desperation? There’s a certain kind of central banker who just hates the idea of easy money; plus the desire to raise rates is closely identified with the political right. No surprise, then, that Ferguson likes the paper.

headline: Ad Takes Aim at Obama Health Overhaul
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A new ad warns that Americans would face delays in medical treatment because of President Obama’s health care overhaul.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-leaning non-profit group Americans for Prosperity is debuting a new commercial at the start of the Democratic National Convention, suggesting that President Obama‘s health care overhaul would leave the United States with a system much like Canada’s, one in which costly delays in treatment would threaten people’s lives.

headline: Vince Gilligan on ‘Breaking Bad’ and ‘the Plumbing of It All’
abstract: Mr. Gilligan, the creator and show runner of AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” spoke to reporters on Tuesday in a telephone news conference.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Season 5 of “Breaking Bad” and Sunday’s semi-season finale.

headline: An Outdoor Retailer Takes a Big Step
abstract: Gander Mountain is expanding its shoe offerings, a move it will promote with an elaborate campaign.
lead_paragraph: One of the most popular trends in retail is the expansion of shoe departments, which is taking place at stores like Macy’s, Barneys New York and Saks. Another retailer is joining the parade, encouraging shoppers to wear shoes that are more sensible than the Jimmy Choos and Manolo Blahniks being sold by the department stores.

headline: United Nations Says 100,000 Refugees Fled Syria in August
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The flow of refugees out of the country grew sharply after President Bashar al-Assad’s government started using airstrikes against towns and neighborhoods that support rebels.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than 100,000 Syrians fled their country last month, a sharp acceleration of the exodus prompted by 18 months of conflict, the United Nations said Tuesday, adding renewed urgency to the mission of a new peace envoy given dim prospects for success.

headline: Protest Outside Convention Leads to Standoff With Police
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: A protest greets the first day of the Democratic convention, hours before it is to start.
lead_paragraph: 7:15 p.m. | Updated CHARLOTTE, N.C. – An antiwar march at the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday afternoon led to a standoff with the police, one arrest and ultimately a peaceful protest through the streets of Charlotte.

headline: In UBS Convictions, Parallels to the Libor Investigation
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Statutes of Limitations']
abstract: A case against the three former UBS executives who were convicted last week has a number of interesting parallels to the Libor investigation, and can provide the framework for cases that might emerge.
lead_paragraph: The conviction on Friday of three former UBS executives on conspiracy and wire fraud charges for rigging bids in the municipal bond market may serve as a template for how prosecutors can pursue cases in the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate, or Libor.

headline: Another $100 Million Month for Romney and the R.N.C.
abstract: Mitt Romney and the Republican National Committee raised about $100 million in August, a person briefed on the total said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney and the Republican National Committee raised about $100 million in August, a person briefed on the total said Tuesday.

headline: Do as I Say, Not as I …
abstract: The Energy Department fails to take some relatively easy low-cost steps to cut its energy consumption, an audit found.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Energy Department preaches energy conservation and efficiency, it is failing to take advantage of readily available, low-cost opportunities to reduce its energy consumption, the department’s inspector general said in a report released on Tuesday.

headline: First Lady to Extol First-Term Record in Convention Kickoff
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Speaking on the first night of the Democratic convention, Michelle Obama will promote the president’s accomplishments, particularly the health care law, campaign aides said.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Democrats gathered here on Tuesday to begin a brisk three-day convention intended to draw sharp programmatic differences with the Republican Party and walk a line between promoting President Obama’s first-term accomplishments while recognizing the continuing economic despair that has marked the last four years.

headline: The Democrats’ Identity Politics Problem
abstract: The Republicans aren’t the only party struggling to deal with racial politics.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the Democratic convention here in Charlotte, Time Magazine’s Joe Klein calls on the party to move away from identity politics:

headline: Target Margin to Explore Yiddish Theater
abstract: Target Margin Theater plans a two-year project focusing on Yiddish theater.
lead_paragraph: Target Margin Theater, the alternative New York theater company known for its frisky interpretations of plays ranging from Shakespeare to Brecht, is turning its attention to Yiddish theater. The company has announced a two-season exploration of Yiddish theater called Beyond the Pale,  which begins with a festival of plays, readings, a scholarly panel and a concert of Yiddish music, to be held Oct. 17 through Nov. 3 at The Brick in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The festival, all in English, will present four fully staged plays including “God, Man, and Devil,” the circa 1900 play by Jacob Gordin, an influential Yiddish dramatist. In March, Target Margin will present a reworked drama from the Yiddish canon at the Abrons Art Center at the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Other productions, workshops and concerts are also planned.

headline: Facts, Truth … and May the Best Man Win
abstract: Whatever the conclusions, whatever the effectiveness, of challenging facts, the idea that we have to debate the necessity of the media doing so strikes me as absurd.
lead_paragraph: In “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man,” now in an enjoyable and timely revival on Broadway (extended but scheduled to end this week), the lead character – a candidate for president in 1960 – poses a rhetorical question:

headline: Digital Notes: Justin Bieber’s Manager Signs Korean Web Star Psy
abstract: Scooter Braun, whose stable includes Carly Rae Jepsen, announced via YouTube that he would be representing the rapper from Seoul, whose comic video “Gangnam Style” has been an online sensation.
lead_paragraph: Can Scooter Braun turn another online phenomenon into a bona fide star?

headline: What’s a $4,000 Suit Worth?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Textiles']
abstract: Tailors pose an odd riddle for our economy: Why can’t a wealthy city support a niche business like bespoke suits?
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Peter Frew came to New York with an important professional skill. He was one of maybe a few dozen people in the U.S. who could construct a true bespoke suit. Frew, who apprenticed with a Savile Row tailor, can — all by himself, and almost all by hand — create a pattern, cut fabric and expertly construct a suit that, for about $4,000, perfectly molds to its owner’s body. In a city filled with very rich people, he quickly had all the orders he could handle.

headline: Troubleshooting the Wine Salt
abstract: If the wine salt in this week’s pork loin recipe turned into an oozing mess in your oven, here’s why.
lead_paragraph: A few readers wrote in that their wine salt (used as a rub for pork loin in this week’s column) turned to an oozing mess in the oven, or it caramelized, browned and hardened. The reason for this is that many home ovens are not properly calibrated, and chances are if this happened to you, your oven might run a bit hot.

headline: Europe Opens Inquiry Into Gazprom Trade Practices
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The case highlights the challenge Europe faces to create a competitive market for natural gas when Russia supplies about a quarter of what Europe needs.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union antitrust authorities opened a formal investigation Tuesday into whether the Russian export monopoly Gazprom had blocked fair competition in the natural gas markets of Central and Eastern Europe.

headline: Ashe Stadium Hosts the Stars, and Also the Routs
abstract: Over the last five years, the losers in singles matches at Arthur Ashe Stadium have won an average of only 35.3 percent of the games.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams achieved an elusive “double bagel” in her fourth-round match Monday afternoon on Arthur Ashe Stadium, beating Andrea Hlavackova, 6-0, 6-0, in 57 minutes. Impressive as that is, she accounted for only half of the Ashe bagel haul in the day session — Ana Ivanovic and Marin Cilic each won a 6-0 set as well in the day’s other two matches.

headline: DC Introducing an Arab-American Character
abstract: Simon Baz, an Arab-American from Michigan, finds himself wearing a Green Lantern power ring.
lead_paragraph: When the DC universe of superheroes was reintroduced last year  one of the commitments from the company was diversity. Cyborg, a black hero, was promoted to the Justice League; Bunker, a new Teen Titan, is Mexican and gay; and female or minority-group characters were the headliners in many series.

headline: Rolling Stones’ Greatest Hits Album to Offer 2 New Songs
abstract: The new releases are among several projects in the works to mark the band’s 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The Rolling Stones will release two new original songs when they put out a greatest hits record in November, Mojo magazine reported on Tuesday.  The two songs – entitled “Gloom and Doom” and “One Last Shot” – were recorded in Paris last month and will appear on a three-CD set of the band’s hits, “GRRR!,” which is set to be released on Nov. 13.

headline: For Michelle Obama, Convention Speech Is a New Point in Transformation
abstract: Michelle Obama’s convention speech will mark a new point in her transformation from a Chicago hospital executive who openly called politics a waste of time to a hugely popular first lady.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In her speech here on Tuesday night, the first lady, Michelle Obama, will have a chance to define her husband on her own terms. But the speech will also mark a new point in her remarkable transformation from a Chicago hospital executive who openly called politics a waste of time to a hugely popular first lady and polished political communicator considered essential to her husband’s re-election efforts.

headline: Black Rice and Arborio Risotto With Beets and Beet Greens
abstract: This risotto, tinted red from the beets, is packed with nutrients.
lead_paragraph: The red from the beets will bleed into the white rice in this nutrient-dense risotto. Both the beets and the black rice contribute anthocyanins, flavonoids with antioxidant properties.

headline: Zegna Hires Designer From Saint Laurent to Bolster Brand
abstract: Stefano Pilati, who worked at Saint Laurent in Paris for eight years before being let go after mixed reviews, will join Zegna as creative director, where his mission will include building up the Agnona women's brand.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Italian men’s wear company Ermenegildo Zegna moved on Tuesday to strengthen its core brand and breathe new life into its little-known women’s fashion line by hiring a designer best known for his work at Yves Saint Laurent.

headline: An Artist Uses Blood to Bring Life to His Works
abstract: Jordan Eagles, who has an exhibition opening Wednesday, says using animal blood gives his works a certain power and energy.
lead_paragraph: Van Gogh’s palette included chrome yellow, Prussian blue, emerald green and black.

headline: Arborio and Red Rice Risotto With Baby Broccoli and Red Peppers
abstract: This satisfying dish features a pleasing mix of colors and textures.
lead_paragraph: Baby broccoli has thinner stems than regular broccoli and long, feathery flowers that cook up nicely in this mixed-rice risotto.

headline: What Restaurants Know (About You)
abstract: In the name of good service, many restaurants keep a computer file on regular customers, noting their favorite foods and other information.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Tim Zagat dines out in New York, many of the restaurants he goes to know that he prefers his soup served in a cup and enjoys iced tea with cranberry juice in a large glass over lots of ice. Jay-Z’s fondness for white Burgundy is also no secret among the city’s headwaiters.

headline: U.S. Open: Competitive Tennis, Anyone?
abstract: The top two men's players, Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic, have yet to be challenged at the U.S. Open. But fans should be in for a treat when Andy Roddick plays Juan Martin Del Potro.
lead_paragraph: The top two men's players, Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic, have yet to be challenged at the U.S. Open. But fans should be in for a treat when Andy Roddick plays Juan Martin Del Potro.

headline: Tell Me Something New
abstract: The president should freshen his approach, and bring new material into the campaign.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – To fire up the crowd in a pre-convention speech in Norfolk, Va., today, President Obama ran through a list of his first-term greatest hits – tax cuts, a program to hire veterans, the Iraq pullout, health care reform, etc. But he had no new material, and his recital sounded almost rote, compressing a long list of domestic and foreign policies into a blur.

headline: Suspended Principal Among 5 Fined by Conflicts Board
abstract: A principal was fined for trying to get her sister a job at a nonprofit that does business with her school; an elevator repairman also was fined for selling scrap metal from a city building.
lead_paragraph: An elevator repairman who sold scrap metal from a city building and a Bronx high school principal who was already in hot water were among five city workers fined by the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board in proceedings announced on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Flashdance’ Musical Set for Broadway in August 2013
abstract: The stage adaptation of “Flashdance,” based on the 1983 movie about a female welder-turned-dancer, will begin performances on Broadway in August 2013.
lead_paragraph: The stage adaptation of “Flashdance,” based on the 1983 movie about a female welder-dancer, will begin performances on Broadway in Aug. 2013, the show’s producers announced on Tuesday. A theater, dates and casting are still to be announced.

headline: Profile in Style | Barry McGee
abstract: The San Francisco-based artist’s urban-inspired paintings and installations may pack a serious visual wallop, but his family’s cozy Colonial Revival-style house, in the city’s Mission district, is completely chill.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco-based artist’s urban-inspired paintings and installations may pack a serious visual wallop, but his family’s cozy Colonial Revival-style house, in the city’s Mission district, is completely chill. Artworks by friends and treasures culled from vintage stores and antique markets around the world stand in for formal décor. “Everything in the house is connected to us personally,” McGee says. As much can be said of his no-frills fashion sense. “Some of my favorite pieces are from thrift shops. When I find something I really love, I live, work and sleep in it.” Some things, however, he’d sooner let go of. Asked about his current midcareer retrospective at the Berkeley Art Museum, he says, “It’s very intense to go back to the past and revive work that I’ve already experienced and moved forward from. It’s like seeing an old girlfriend — awkward at times, nostalgic at times and downright maddening and embarrassing.” More…

headline: Obama and Romney Weigh in on Science Questions
abstract: The Obama and Romney campaigns answer 14 questions on science, health, innovation and related policies.
lead_paragraph: The Science Debate initiative, launched with the 2008 presidential campaign to try to develop reasoned discussion of science-framed issues by the candidates, produced a list of 14 questions this year with advice from an array of scientists and scientific organizations and publications. The answers provided by the Obama and Romney campaigns are now posted at the following links:

headline: Chefs Try New Terrain, Like the Upper East Side
abstract: Italian, Spanish and Asian appear to be on the uptick, based on restaurant openings planned for fall in New York.
lead_paragraph: EACH fall brings New York a harvest of new restaurants, with most of the prime destinations in downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn. But this season the Upper East Side will rub its eyes and perk up at the sight of several exciting arrivals.

headline: Edward Villella Departs Miami City Ballet Early
abstract: The Miami City Ballet and Edward Villella, its artistic director, announced on Tuesday that he would leave immediately instead of next April. The development was the latest turn in the long and painful separation between the company and Mr. Villella.
lead_paragraph: Edward Villella, the ousted patriarch of the Miami City Ballet, is making an early exit from the stage. Under the hawklike gaze of lawyers, the company and Mr. Villella said on Tuesday that he would leave as artistic director immediately instead of next April.

headline: My Thoughts on E-Book Pricing? Let Me Draw You a Picture
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: Bob Kohn, an outspoken critic of the Department of Justice’s settlement with three publishers over e-book pricing, said he hoped to be more economical with his words by using pictures as well.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice’s proposed settlement with three book publishers over accusations of e-book price fixing has prompted hundreds of court filings, responses and public comments in advance of the settlement’s final approval before a federal judge.

headline: Airport Delays Undermine Image of German Efficiency
abstract: Technical and budgetary problems have repeatedly delayed the opening of Berlin’s new airport, which was supposed to be a symbol of the city’s dominance and a tribute to German unification.
lead_paragraph: The ambitious Berlin airport project conceived two decades ago as a glittering symbol of German unification and the city’s importance as a global hub has hit yet another delay and may not open before late next year, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Solving the Ocean Methane Paradox
abstract: Scientists may have found the answer to why oceans emit so much methane.
lead_paragraph: Four percent of the methane found in the earth’s atmosphere comes from oceans. But for decades, researchers have been flummoxed by how that could be. The only known biological source of methane is a class of microorganisms that produce methane when they are alive but die when exposed to oxygen. How could these microorganisms, called methanogens, be so plentiful in the oxygen-rich ocean?

headline: Mean Streets? Not With Free Ice Cream
abstract: The Columbus, Ohio, company will present tastings in Manhattan and Brooklyn Sept. 8 to 15.
lead_paragraph: Jeni’s Splendid Ice Creams, based in Columbus, Ohio, has earned a national reputation thanks to quality and uncommon flavors, a Web site that offers mail order, an expanding distribution network and a cookbook. Now, for a week, the company’s ice cream truck heads east to patrol the streets of New York, dispensing sample scoops of its summer flavors: sweet corn and black raspberries, roasted strawberry buttermilk and salty caramel ice creams, and lemon-blueberry frozen yogurt. The trucks will mostly be parked outside retailers that sell Jeni’s ice cream.

headline: His Biggest Fan Was Himself
abstract: According to reports in the English media, the crime writer R.J. Ellory praised himself on Amazon under pseudonyms.
lead_paragraph: In a recent article, David Streitfeld wrote about fake book reviews on the Internet. Now, on the technology blog Bits, Mr. Streitfeld writes about a new scandal involving the crime writer R.J. Ellory. Mr. Ellory posted raves for himself on Amazon under pseudonyms, saying, for instance, that he was “one of the most talented authors of today.”

headline: 12 Ways to Use The Learning Network Blog This School Year
abstract: Happy academic year 2012-13! Here’s what our blog has and how you can use it, whether you’re a teacher, student (of any age) or parent.
lead_paragraph: Update | Oct. 22, 2012: We now have a 1-minute-48-second video that gives a big-picture overview of what we do. Our new weekly e-mail newsletter sign-up page is also live.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Pulled Pork
abstract: It’s not Memphis quality, but the pulled pork sandwich at the United States Open is a filling and reasonably priced meal.
lead_paragraph: This is an installment of our daily food reviews from the United States Open concession stands.

headline: Famous Sports Mustache Is Going ... Going ... Gray
abstract: Keith Hernandez no longer endorses a hair product, and his signature mustache, which gets grayer with each Mets game, may be on the chopping block.
lead_paragraph: Keith Hernandez’s mustache has rarely left its perch below his nose in his adult life. It is the thicker, longer cousin to his eyebrows, the hirsute geometric center of his face. His mustache is an entity and a signature. After years of renown, it was voted the top sports mustache of all time in a survey by the American Mustache Institute in 2007.

headline: After AMC Acquisition, Chinese Mogul Sees $10 Billion in New U.S. Investment
abstract: Wang Jianlin, the chairman and president of Dalian Wanda Group, said the company’s $2.6 billion acquisition of the theater chain AMC Entertainment was only a beginning.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For China’s Dalian Wanda Group, the $2.6 billion acquisition of AMC Entertainment — now complete — is just the beginning.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: Local breweries pour their products on the Rockaway Beach Boardwalk, a series of pop-up dinners, and Meatopia on Randall’s Island, with hearty tastings of meat dishes by more than 40 chefs.
lead_paragraph: Sampling Privileges

headline: What’s at Issue in the Private Equity Tax Inquiry
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The New York attorney general’s office is said to be investigating private equity firms’ use of a tax strategy known as management fee waiver programs — programs that might not hold up if challenged in court.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is said to be investigating private equity firms’ use of a tax strategy known as management fee waiver programs.

headline: A New First for Top-Ranked Azarenka
abstract: Top-seeded Victoria Azarenka outlasted Sam Stosur in a third-set tiebreaker on Tuesday and moved on to play Maria Sharapova or Marion Bartoli in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: During the one extended dry spot of an otherwise soggy Tuesday afternoon, top-seeded Victoria Azarenka and the defending United States Open champion, Samantha Stosur, packed in a quarterfinal match worth all the waiting.

headline: After Loss in Singles, Krueger Remains Upbeat About Turning Pro
abstract: Mitchell Krueger lost in the junior championships at the United States Open on Monday, but says he is encouraged about a professional career.
lead_paragraph: Mitchell Krueger, the top-ranked American who gained the semifinals at the French Open and Wimbledon junior championships, found himself in an unfamiliar position on Tuesday at the United States Open junior championships.

headline: In Baltimore, a Rookie Races With a Sizable Fanclub
abstract: The death of Patrick McCusker, a Baltimore restauranteur known as Scunny to friends and acquaintances, galvanized local businesses to support an aspiring professional racer.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — During the grand prix weekend here, attendees at the USF2000 race, an entry-level open-wheel series sanctioned by IndyCar, saw a blue racecar bearing the name Scunny in white letters on a black nose. The car was run under the name of Patrick McCusker, known as Scunny to friends and acquaintances, a man who did not drive the car, did not sponsor it and, according to those who knew him, was not a particular fan of motorsports.

headline: At Democratic Convention, Eastwood Joke Is a Recurring One
abstract: Clint Eastwood’s sketch-comedy routine with an empty chair has become a seemingly mandatory (read: worn out) joke here, dropped with as much frequency as the names Michelle or Barack.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — It is the punch line that won’t die.

headline: Illegal Logging Deals Rife in Liberia, Group Reports
abstract: A report says that control of one-quarter of Liberia’s land has been granted to logging companies in just two years through permits that were illegally or fraudulently awarded.
lead_paragraph: For years, the environmental group Global Witness has been investigating the destruction of forests in the developing world. Much of the wood illegally harvested there ends up in the hands of international companies that manufacture furniture, paper and biofuels. Global Witness has campaigned against illegal harvesting of ebony and rosewood in Madagascar, exposed illegal exports of timber from Myanmar to China and documented the killings of antilogging activists in Cambodia.

headline: Drilling Down: The Impact of a Very Small Loan
abstract: The Intersect Fund focuses on sole proprietors with one or no employees that operate in traditional, “bread-and-butter” industries — beauty salons, cleaning services and caterers.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to an article about a new program introduced by the New Jersey Department of Labor in partnership with the nonprofit Intersect Fund, a microlender. With loans as small as $500, the program will support small-business development in poor and distressed areas of the state. We decided to contact Rohan Mathew, one of the founders of the Intersect Fund, to learn more. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: The Caucus Click: Heading Toward the Floor
abstract: The Rev. Rodney McFarland made his way to his seat inside the Time Warner Cable Arena before the first evening of the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: The Clinton Foundation in Africa
abstract: A recent trip to Africa gave Bill Clinton, his daughter, Chelsea, and a handful of donors and aides from the Clintons’ years in Arkansas and the White House a firsthand look at the philanthropic work of the Clinton Foundation.
lead_paragraph: A recent trip to Africa gave Bill Clinton, his daughter, Chelsea, and a handful of donors and aides from the Clintons’ years in Arkansas and the White House a firsthand look at the philanthropic work of the Clinton Foundation.

headline: At Paralympic Games, a Lesson in a Loss
abstract: For Joshua George, a race at the Paralympic Games made him realize that nobody gives you a medal for a month of solid workouts.
lead_paragraph: The wheelchair racer Joshua George will be competing in the 2012 Paralympic Games in London and writing for the 2012 London blog.

headline: The Chip Return, the Drop Shot and Andy Murray
abstract: Andy Murray went old-school to disarm Milos Raonic’s power game in their United States Open match on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray used the chip return to get into the point against Milos Raonic’s huge first serve, then played shrewd neutralizing groundstrokes, taking away his two chief weapons: the booming serve and the first strike forehand. It was a clinic in how to disarm the power game, as Murray massaged the ball in the tricky, gusty conditions on Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday, using chips, counterpunching backhands and, on several occasions, soft drop shots to destroy Raonic’s rhythm.

headline: California’s Quiet but Crucial Role in Shaping Fuel Economy Standards
abstract: The state, with the power to set its own emissions policy, was at the negotiating table throughout the creation of the next round of federal fuel economy standards.
lead_paragraph: When the Obama administration completed the Corporate Average Fuel Economy, or CAFE, standards for 2017 to 2025 last month, it was a milestone in a long and frequently contentious process, but not the last word.

headline: Reinvention, With Card Tricks and a Drink Cart
abstract: At Eleven Madison Park, the chef Daniel Humm and general manager Will Guidara believe a restaurant should take risks in the quest for “endless reinvention.”
lead_paragraph: THERE’S something Whitmanesque about what Daniel Humm, the chef of Eleven Madison Park, and Will Guidara, the general manager, envision for their restaurant when it reveals its reinvention on Friday. Think of it as a gastronomic paean to New York City, full of dishes and gestures that make reference to the four-century saga of the metropolis.

headline: Finra Executive Departs for Wilmer Hale
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said its vice chairman, Stephen Luparello, was leaving to join the law firm Wilmer Hale in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s self-policing organization has lost one of its top cops.

headline: New Bars Shy Away From Serving It Neat
abstract: As competition intensifies, bar owners are pursuing novel touches to distinguish their wares, including offering liquor smoothies and garnishes that become small plates.
lead_paragraph: IN New York’s bar scene this fall, beer mugs and wineglasses will take a back seat to cocktail coupes. The recent deluge of wine bars and beer gardens seems to have abated a bit, but the mixology craze rages on.

headline: Anti-Abortion, Pro-Democrat
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: At a Democrats for Life of America event, Bart Stupak, Kathy Dahlkemper and others defended health care reform on pro-life grounds.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–The big question heading into the Democratic Convention is just how forcefully the party will defend the Affordable Care Act, which the president fought to pass and then declined to sell. On Tuesday, an unusually vocal endorsement of the law came from an unlikely source: Anti-abortion Democrats.

headline: Weight-Loss Leaders Back Bloomberg Soda Plan
abstract: Several well-known weight-loss specialists announced their support for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks.
lead_paragraph: The names read like a who’s who of diet tycoons.

headline: Carving a Legacy of Giving (to His Party, Too)
abstract: On a recent trip to Africa, Bill Clinton showed how he is bringing his family deeper into the Clinton Foundation, perhaps confronting a future without him.
lead_paragraph: KAYONZA, Rwanda — Bill Clinton could not stop talking about soybeans. Over dinner in Kigali with a handful of longtime political aides and deep-pocketed donors, he recited the price of soy (“It never exceeded $8, and now it’s $16”) and extolled its virtues as a miracle crop (“You can grow it with just a thin layer of topsoil”).

headline: Who Is to Blame for Facebook’s I.P.O.? A Mix of Responses
abstract: The DealBook column on Tuesday, which pinned the blame of Facebook’s mess of an initial public offering on its chief financial officer, David Ebersman, has provoked a wide range of reactions among the online financial commentariat.
lead_paragraph: My column on Tuesday, pinning the blame of Facebook’s mess of an initial public offering on its chief financial officer, David Ebersman, has caused quite a reaction — including Mark Cuban denouncing my view, saying “Facebook Handled their IPO Exactly Righ,t” and Forbes saying “The Man Responsible For Facebook’s Stock Debacle Is Mark Zuckerberg.”

headline: Stuart J. Boesky
abstract: Mr. Boesky, 55, is the chief executive of Pembrook Capital Management, an investment adviser and fund manager focused on debt.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Boesky, 55, is the chief executive of Pembrook Capital Management, an investment adviser and fund manager focused on debt. The company, which is based in New York, also originates first mortgages and bridge and mezzanine loans for all property types.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from India, Afghanistan, Portugal and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Afghanistan, Portugal and Syria.

headline: Egypt to Try Ex-Official on Charge of Corruption
abstract: Farouk Hosni, who was culture minister for more than two decades, was charged with corruption on Tuesday, joining other former officials accused of using their positions to enrich themselves.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Farouk Hosni, who for more than two decades served as culture minister under President Hosni Mubarak, was charged with corruption on Tuesday, the state news media reported, joining a number of other former government officials and businessmen accused of using their positions and connections to enrich themselves.

headline: Can We Have Your Autograph, Mr. Gibbs?
abstract: Robert Gibbs, the former press secretary who is now an outside adviser to Mr. Obama, was mobbed when he walked through the convention hall on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – If you are into celebrity-spotting – and who isn’t? — trolling the halls of political conventions can be rewarding, as long as your standards are not too high. Think less George Clooney and more Andrea Mitchell or Chuck Schumer.

headline: It’s Not Easy Seeing Green
abstract: How many shades of green can you distinguish?
lead_paragraph: Describing color is more properly a poetic art than a scientific one, argues Merriam Webster’s Kory Stamper in a recent, charming post that I cited in my latest dispatch for The One-Page Magazine. Looking back over more than 150 years’ worth of definitions, Stamper tracks the evolution (or, depending on your perspective, devolution) in approach from more picturesque comparisons — blue with “the clear sky,” red with “blood or rubies” — to the more formulaic color chart system used in Webster’s Third New International Dictionary, which is currently undergoing revisions. “With its zeal for modernism and science and objectivity,” Stamper says, the most recent edition of the dictionary “sometimes lost sight of the forest for all the xylem and phloem.”

headline: Saving Rubles in St. Petersburg
abstract: On his first trip to the Russian city, the Frugal Traveler scores two deals from the Hermitage, finds ideal budget boxers and does a shot to get a shot.
lead_paragraph: IT is hard not to like St. Petersburg. Its canals invite unavoidable comparisons with Venice, its Baroque and neo-Classical architecture recall, Rorschach-style, whatever other European city you know best. Meanwhile, Russia is in the details: the onion-domed Church of the Savior on the Spilled Blood, the public tram fare collectors straight from babushka central casting, the Cyrillic signs, the young women for whom beauty comes naturally but a light touch with the mascara does not.

headline: Timely | The Prophet
abstract: In the work of a 24-year-old poet, the Internet’s staccato vernacular comes alive.
lead_paragraph: Prepare to love a poet, to get poems stuck in your head like they were pop songs — like it was the age of Homer or Milton or Poe, when poets were pop stars. According to the 24-year-old M.F.A. dropout Steve Roggenbuck, “We are entering a golden age of literature” that is perfect for poetry. Chunks of verse should populate the “content streams” on phones and Facebook feeds. His do.

headline: Street Style: Straw Hats
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of August 27.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of August 27.

headline: Get Out The Vote
abstract: Jeff Zeleny looks at the grassroots voter registration efforts in Charlotte to help President Barack Obama win North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Zeleny looks at the grassroots voter registration efforts in Charlotte to help President Barack Obama win North Carolina.

headline: A Pride of Literary Lions, Unleashed All at Once
abstract: This fall will usher in new books from a wide range of literary authors, including Ian McEwan, Zadie Smith and Tom Wolfe.
lead_paragraph: The list reads like a Who’s Who at an exclusive book party: Junot Díaz, Ian McEwan, J. K. Rowling, Zadie Smith and Tom Wolfe.

headline: Connecticut Looks to Airport as a Business Draw
abstract: The state is following a trend in which it hopes to develop idle buildings and vacant land surrounding its main airport.
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn. — For more than a year, Martin Seifert, president of Nufern, a fiber optics company based in East Granby, Conn., felt like the most beautiful girl at the dance. With the purchase of a small company in Maryland in 2010, he started scouting places to expand his labs and found himself being wooed by economic development officials from Connecticut, Maryland and Canada.

headline: Republicans Ask ‘Are You Better Off?’ and Many Reply ‘Yes’
abstract: The Republican National Committee received a flood of responses to this question, some they expected, but many that perhaps they did not.
lead_paragraph: Early on Tuesday, the first day of the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte, N.C., Republicans took to Twitter and moved to shape the conversation on the Internet about the state of the country since President Obama was elected in 2008. Using Twitter’s sponsored hashtag feature, they promoted a question that was anything but rhetorical: #areyoubetteroff

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tech Stars’ Mansions, and Kickstarter Refunds
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes photos and price tags for the homes of 25 people like Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg, Kickstarter investors’ rights if the project doesn’t deliver and how Twitter’s efforts to become more of a business are affecting its users.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Nougatine at Jean Georges
abstract: Inside the more relaxed restaurant next door to the demure Jean Georges.
lead_paragraph: Inside the more relaxed restaurant next door to the demure Jean Georges.

headline: A Lively Room Comes Into Its Own
abstract: A redesign of the room, once meant as a hotel lounge, has allowed Nougatine to stand proudly next to its well-known sister restaurant, Jean Georges.
lead_paragraph: YES, Nougatine. You didn’t forget about it, did you?

headline: Wasserman Schultz Comments Draw Denial from Israeli Ambassador
abstract: Michael B. Oren, Israel’s ambassador to the United States, denied characterizing Republican policies as harmful to Israel, rebutting a comment by Debbie Wasserman Schultz, chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – For the last two years, Democrats have worked hard to dispel the impression that their party is losing its traditional hold on Jewish voters because of the chilly relationship between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the efforts of Republicans, including Mitt Romney, to cultivate Israeli leaders.

headline: Organic Food vs. Conventional Food
abstract: A new study by Stanford researchers has added fuel to a debate about the differences between organic and conventionally grown foods, and why consumers choose one over the other. Kenneth Chang, New York Times reporter, is responding to your questions about organic eating.
lead_paragraph: Why do consumers buy organic foods?

headline: Salvaging a History
abstract: Melanie Martinez, who has called Southern Louisiana home her entire life, has lost much to the hurricanes that batter the Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: Melanie Martinez, who has called Southern Louisiana home her entire life, has lost much to the hurricanes that batter the Gulf Coast.

headline: In Israel, the Burden of History
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Music', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The history of the history of the Holocaust is part of what’s on display in Israel’s Holocaust museums.
lead_paragraph: The history of the history of the Holocaust is part of what’s on display in Israel’s Holocaust museums.

headline: Holocaust Museums in Israel Evolve
abstract: In Israel, where preserving memories of World War II atrocities has special resonance, Holocaust museums are evolving in message and approach.
lead_paragraph: KIBBUTZ LOHAMEI HAGETAOT, Israel — It isn’t only the history of the Holocaust that you see on display in Israel’s Holocaust museums. It’s also the history of the history of the Holocaust. There is an archaeology of trauma to be found if you look closely, and in its layers and transmutations you see how a nation has wrestled with the burden of one of history’s immense horrors.

headline: With Lax Regulation, a Risky Industry Flourishes Offshore
abstract: Reinsurance, already something of a murky business, may become even more complicated as hedge funds rush to open their own firms in Bermuda.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund industry has been rushing headlong to open Bermuda-based reinsurers.

headline: An Orgy Of False Equivalence
abstract: What to expect on your teevee.
lead_paragraph: That’s what I expect over the next three days from the news media. There was no way to gloss over the extraordinary dishonesty on display in Tampa — but the urge to be “balanced” will probably mean enormous efforts to portray whatever Joe Biden, for example, says as being just as bad as Ryan’s barrage of deceit. Never mind whether there’s any real equivalence, which there probably won’t be.

headline: G.O.P. Shift Moves Center Far to Right
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A look back at Richard Nixon’s stands on big government programs and new regulations underscores how much the political center has moved.
lead_paragraph: To hear Republicans on the campaign trail, the United States could not have elected a more left-wing president than Barack Obama, one more hostile to business or more eager to expand government power. Left-wing Democrats, I’m sure, would disagree. If they had their druthers, they would probably make a more liberal, more pro-big government choice. Somebody, perhaps, like Richard Nixon.

headline: Finding a Path to Mexico in Appalachia
abstract: David Wax and Suz Slezak of David Wax Museum explain how their sound has evolved with their new album, “Knock Knock Get Up.”
lead_paragraph: These days it is not uncommon for indie musicians to range far from their home culture, traipsing through cyberspace to harvest sounds from the world’s folk idioms and then plugging them into their music.

headline: The Heart of Fifth Avenue Shopping Is Edging to the South
abstract: Retailers from around the world are adding some notable spaces to the avenue south of 49th Street.
lead_paragraph: Long the retail stepsister of upper Fifth Avenue, the stretch of the avenue south of 49th Street and north of 42nd Street seems finally to be coming into its own with the opening of several flagship stores by retailers from around the world.

headline: Live Updates From the Democratic Convention
abstract: The Times will be providing updates and analysis from Charlotte on our live dashboard. You can also follow along on Twitter @thecaucus, or follow our list of Times journalists covering the convention.
lead_paragraph: The Times will be providing updates and analysis from Charlotte on our live dashboard. You can also follow along on Twitter @thecaucus, or follow our list of Times journalists covering the convention.

headline: A Star Swerves a Bit; He’s Fine With That
abstract: “The Master” is Joaquin Phoenix’s new film and his return to the mainstream after “I’m Still Here.”
lead_paragraph: VENICE — The last time Joaquin Phoenix was at the Venice Film Festival, in 2010, he was many months into a supposed career transition — from acting to rap — that coincided with obvious weight gain, an unruly new beard and several widely noted instances of erratic public behavior. Much of this was chronicled in “I’m Still Here,” a supposed documentary by Mr. Phoenix’s friend Casey Affleck, and all of it was later revealed as a satirical performance-art project of sorts.

headline: Italians Are a Team Today, but Opponents Tomorrow
abstract: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci are buddies off the court and doubles partners on the court, and on Tuesday, they teamed up to win their quarterfinals match in straight sets. But come Wednesday, they will also play each other in the quarterfinals of the singles tournament.
lead_paragraph: In tennis terms, Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci might be called frenemies. They are buddies off the court and doubles partners on the court, and on Tuesday, they teamed up to win their quarterfinals match in straight sets.

headline: Mind-Bending Films Go Head-to-Head at Toronto Festival
abstract: Two ambitious films — “Cloud Atlas” and “The Master” — are poised for a face-off at the Toronto International Film Festival this weekend.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They are big. They are superintelligent. They are out to conquer the world.

headline: TimesCast Politics | D.N.C. Night One
abstract: Getting out the vote. | A conversation with Patty Murray. | BuzzFeed on the protests. | Valerie Jarrett’s influence. | Opinion: Charles M. Blow and David Firestone.
lead_paragraph: Getting out the vote. | A conversation with Patty Murray. | BuzzFeed on the protests. | Valerie Jarrett’s influence. | Opinion: Charles M. Blow and David Firestone.

headline: Green Party Ad Featuring Bleeped Obscenity Challenges TV Indecency Rules
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: The Green Party won a public-relations battle with Google on Tuesday, forcing its television advertising division to book time for a commercial in which its presidential candidate uses a (partly bleeped) obscenity.
lead_paragraph: The Green Party won a public-relations battle with Google on Tuesday, forcing the company’s television advertising division to book time for a commercial in which its presidential candidate uses a (partly bleeped) obscenity to describe the policies of the major-party candidates.

headline: ‘War Horse’ to Close in January
abstract: The Broadway play about a British boy and his friendship with a horse will close on Jan. 6, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “War Horse,” the hit Broadway play about a British boy and his friendship with a horse which is tested by World War I, will close on Jan. 6, 2013, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, the show’s producers announced on Tuesday. When it closes it will have played 718 performances and 33 previews.

headline: A Chinese City Moves to Limit New Cars
abstract: Guangzhou wants to improve quality of life through license plate auctions and lotteries expected to halve the number of new cars on the streets.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — It is as startling as if Detroit or Los Angeles restricted car ownership.

headline: Caught Between Rock Music and a Hard, Lonely Place
abstract: A musician on the verge of divorce tries to find some connection to his estranged young daughter in So Yong Kim’s “For Ellen.”
lead_paragraph: Even though its protagonist is a heavy-metal singer, “For Ellen,” So Yong Kim’s third feature, is a remarkably quiet film. This simple, closely observed story — of a musician on the verge of divorce trying to find some connection to his estranged young daughter — certainly seems wired for melodrama. But Ms. Kim and the lead actor, Paul Dano, turn down the emotional volume, betting that whispers and downcast looks will be more effective than shouting and raging.

headline: The Parents Who Really Need Flex Time
abstract: Craig Blankenhorn, a photographer, turned his camera on the plight of the 1.6 million homeless children in America. How can we best help them and their parents?
lead_paragraph: This weekend’s Sunday Review featured a series of images of homeless children across America. Craig Blankenhorn, the photographer, wrote:

headline: Little Cover Girls Star in an Adult Reality
abstract: The documentary “Girl Model” details how the industry grooms young Russian girls to become models in Japan.
lead_paragraph: Favoring insinuation over investigation, the documentary “Girl Model” is as much a tease as the profession it portrays. Dipping into a very specific corner of the modeling industry — the search for fresh Russian faces to feed the seemingly insatiable Japanese appetite for prepubescent-looking clotheshorses — David Redmon and Ashley Sabin’s film presents an international transaction sustained by the twin forces of illusion and delusion.

headline: Digital Style Start-Ups Get Nimble at New York Fashion Week
abstract: There’s no better time for a fashion start-up to ride the fashion week momentum and access to reel in new users.
lead_paragraph: When it’s all about splashy big-budget runway shows what’s an app maker to do? With all eyes soon to be on New York Fashion Week, digital style start-ups have been scrambling for ways to get involved. Problem is they don’t have the cash or the clout to compete with big brands for attention. Here’s how seven start-ups are nimbly getting in on the action.

headline: But Wait, There’s More. Excerpts From Conversations With President Clinton.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2008', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On a recent trip to Africa, former President Bill Clinton discussed a range of topics — from health care and the political climate in Washington to the shooting in Aurora, Colo., to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s plans.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Clinton Foundation trip to Africa, former President Bill Clinton discussed a range of topics — from health care and the political climate in Washington to the shooting at an Aurora, Colo., movie theater to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s future plans. Here are edited excerpts of those conversations, which took place in mid-July in South Africa, Rwanda, Uganda and Cyprus.

headline: Prolonged CPR Holds Benefits, a Study Shows
abstract: The findings challenged conventional medical thinking, which holds that prolonged resuscitation for hospital patients that go into cardiac arrest is usually futile.
lead_paragraph: When a hospital patient goes into cardiac arrest, one of the most difficult questions facing the medical team is how long to continue cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Now a new study involving hundreds of hospitals suggests that many doctors may be giving up too soon.

headline: From Cowboys, the Grinding of Teeth
abstract: The Dallas Cowboys will open their N.F.L. season Wednesday against the Giants, who knocked them out of the playoffs last year and have owned the series lately.
lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex. — Eight months and three days seems like a long time for motivation to marinate. But as the Dallas Cowboys continued to stew in the buildup to Wednesday night’s N.F.L. season opener against the Giants, they sounded trapped somewhere between seeking revenge and suffering championship envy.

headline: Nearly 800 Firefighters Battle Blaze in National Forest in Southern California
abstract: With hot, dry conditions continuing, officials said they did not expect to fully contain the fire for at least another week.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A wildfire in the Angeles National Forest has consumed 3,600 acres, driving local residents and thousands of holiday weekend visitors from the popular wilderness area about 25 miles east of here. With hot, dry conditions continuing across Southern California, officials said they did not expect to fully contain the blaze for at least another week.

headline: Colombia Will Restart Peace Process With FARC
abstract: President Juan Manuel Santos and the leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia said that the two sides would soon sit down to a new phase of peace talks.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia and the leader of his country’s largest guerrilla group said Tuesday that the two sides would soon sit down to a new phase of peace talks with the goal of ending the long conflict.

headline: Experts Issue a Warning as Food Prices Shoot Up
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Drought', 'International Relations', 'Food', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: With climate change affecting crops, United Nations officials urged countries to guard against global hunger.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the worst drought in half a century withering corn across the Midwest, agricultural experts on Tuesday urged international action to prevent the global spike in food prices from causing global hunger.

headline: School District Bets Future on Real Estate
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Gervais, Ore., decided to sell off its outlying elementary schools and consolidate on a campus in the middle of town.
lead_paragraph: GERVAIS, Ore. — This tiny farm-country community is having a back-to-school sale, on the schools themselves. Interested in a well maintained, one-owner elementary with playground and orchard view? Or a 1990s charmer, now used for teaching second through fifth grades but convenient to shopping and the Interstate?

headline: Wayward Peacock Returns for the First Day of School
abstract: After two weeks on the lam, Kevin the peacock has returned to John Bowne High School.
lead_paragraph: In a long narrow run behind the poultry house at John Bowne High School in Queens, a chastened peacock clucked quietly on Tuesday.

headline: Ryan Carries Load While Romney Readies for Debates
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan was the face of the Republican ticket once again on Tuesday, fully embracing the role of tormentor in chief of President Obama.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — With Mitt Romney keeping a low profile, Representative Paul D. Ryan was the face of the Republican ticket once again on Tuesday, blitzing morning television shows and skipping between battleground states, fully embracing the role of tormentor in chief of President Obama.

headline: Representative Charlie Rose, Tobacco’s Friend in the House, Dies at 73
abstract: As a Congressman in rural North Carolina, Mr. Rose worked to protect the tobacco industry and its farmers when political pressure on the industry was on the rise.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Rose, a former United States representative from rural North Carolina who fought to protect the tobacco industry and its farmers when political and regulatory pressure on the industry were on the rise and smoking in steady decline, died on Monday in Albertville, Ala. He was 73.

headline: Giants’ Secret Weapon No Longer
abstract: A year removed from his breakout season, wide receiver Victor Cruz will be on every opponent’s radar as one of the N.F.L’s biggest threats.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The biggest difference between last September and this one for Victor Cruz is not his endorsement deals with soup and soda companies. It is not his occasional encounters with models like Kate Upton while dashing about town, nor is it the increase in celebrities’ numbers, including President Obama’s, that he now has saved in his cellphone.
