headline: Words Not Spoken
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Editorials', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: The Democratic Party’s principles are worth trumpeting, but many are going unmentioned at its convention.
lead_paragraph: Not many people know it, but the Democratic Party supports a ban on assault weapons. It’s a position that, if enacted, could save many lives by reducing the lethality of mass shootings, but you have to flip more than halfway through the party’s new 26,500-word platform to find it.

headline: As a Taxi-Hailing App Comes to New York, Its Legality Is Questioned
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Start-ups', 'Mobile Applications', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The app’s creators plan to introduce it on Wednesday, but taxi officials say the program may have a significant problem: city rules do not allow prearranged rides in yellow taxis.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have long adopted their own techniques in the fine art of hailing a taxicab, a theatrical, frustrating, competitive ritual of the city.

headline: A Tribute to Kennedy and a Tweak for Romney
abstract: The Democrats honored one of their liberal lions, the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and used him to tweak Mitt Romney, who challenged him unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1994.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats honored one of their liberal lions, the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and used him to tweak Mitt Romney, who challenged him unsuccessfully for the Senate in 1994. In a video tribute, Mr. Kennedy was shown debating Mr. Romney over abortion rights during that campaign. Mr. Romney insisted he supported Roe vs. Wade, a position he later disavowed.

headline: Iran Supplying Syrian Military via Iraqi Airspace
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Iran has resumed shipping military equipment to Syria over Iraqi airspace, showing the limits of American influence in the region after the White House pressed Baghdad to close the corridor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has resumed shipping military equipment to Syria over Iraqi airspace in a new effort to bolster the embattled government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, according to senior American officials.

headline: Welcome to the MSNBC, Er, Democratic Convention
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Sure, the events here in Charlotte are a national celebration of the Democratic Party and its presidential nominee. But in many ways, it’s the MSNBC Convention.
lead_paragraph: It started in the bathroom at the Charlotte airport.

headline: Judge Allows AMR to End Pilot Contract
abstract: AMR said labor costs exceeded competitors’ by as much as $800 million a year and led to its bankruptcy filing.
lead_paragraph: The AMR Corporation’s American Airlines won court approval Tuesday to throw out its labor agreement with pilots, ending a dispute with the only union it had failed to reach a deal with on concessions as it goes through bankruptcy reorganization.

headline: Ohio Delegates at the D.N.C.
abstract: Delegates from Ohio discuss President Obama and the Democratic Party's platform at the 2012 Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Delegates from Ohio discuss President Obama and the Democratic Party's platform at the 2012 Democratic National Convention.

headline: If This Brooklyn Kingmaker Is Asking, Saying No Is Risky Option
abstract: State Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, now engulfed in accusations of sexual harassment, demands loyalty, but some criticize what they call heavy-handed tactics.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Elliot G. Sander, the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority at the time, got a call at home from Vito J. Lopez, the assemblyman and Brooklyn Democratic leader. Mr. Lopez wanted his son-in-law, a transit manager named Keith Summa, promoted. Mr. Sander was dubious, and soon after called Mr. Lopez to say it would not happen.

headline: Two Hungry Nations Collide Over Fishing
abstract: A fishing war is straining relations between India and Sri Lanka, as Indian fishermen, often poor and desperate, regularly cross international waters and run afoul of the Sri Lankan Navy.
lead_paragraph: VELLAPALLAM, India — Drifting on the strait between India and Sri Lanka, an Indian fisherman named Sakthivel cowered in his boat. A Sri Lankan naval officer, who took the man’s photograph, delivered a warning: If we find you in Sri Lankan waters again, you will never leave.

headline: Israel: Trappist Monastery Is Vandalized
abstract: Vandals burned the door of a Trappist monastery at Latrun, near Jerusalem, early Tuesday and scrawled anti-Christian slogans on the walls.
lead_paragraph: Vandals burned the door of a Trappist monastery at Latrun, near Jerusalem, early Tuesday and scrawled anti-Christian slogans on the walls. The Israeli authorities said they suspected it was the work of Jewish extremists avenging recent moves against unauthorized settlement outposts in the West Bank. The graffiti included “Jesus is a monkey” and the names of two small outposts where security forces have destroyed structures several times. The vandals also wrote “mutual concern,” code in settler circles for the policy of exacting a price for army and police actions against the outposts. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other Israeli leaders condemned the act, as did regional leaders of the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Brooklyn Rabbi and His Brother Plead Guilty in Section 8 Fraud
abstract: Rabbi Leib Glanz and Menashe Glanz were accused of stealing more than $220,000 over 15 years in housing subsidies for low-income people.
lead_paragraph: An influential Brooklyn rabbi and onetime chaplain in New York City’s jails who drew notoriety several years ago for arranging a lavish jailhouse bar mitzvah for an inmate’s son pleaded guilty on Tuesday to making false statements in connection with a federal housing fraud scheme.

headline: Candidate on Virginia Ballot Poses Worry for Romney
abstract: Virgil Goode, of the conservative Constitution Party, qualified Tuesday for Virginia’s ballot in November, complicating Mitt Romney’s chances of winning the key swing state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Virgil Goode, the presidential nominee for the conservative Constitution Party, qualified Tuesday for Virginia’s ballot in November, complicating Mitt Romney’s chances of winning the key swing state. Polls show a tightly contested race between Mr. Romney and President Obama.

headline: Facebook Moves to Aid Its Shares
abstract: The chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, aimed to instill confidence in Wall Street by saying he would hold on to his shares and options longer and allow his employees to start selling their shares sooner.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — “Stay focused and keep shipping” may be the motto Facebook has sought to follow since its flubbed public offering three months ago. But on Tuesday, the company seemed focused mostly on how to stabilize its hemorrhaging stock.

headline: Matt Bai on Carter and Clinton
abstract: Marcus Mabry and Matt Bai discuss the roles of former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton in the presidential election at the 2012 Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Mabry and Matt Bai discuss the roles of former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton in the presidential election at the 2012 Democratic National Convention.

headline: Joe Frazier Wins Belated Embrace as Philadelphia Starts a Fight
abstract: A year after Mr. Frazier’s death, a movement has taken off to cement the boxer’s legacy in his adopted city.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The three-story brick building stands like a ghost of what it once was, the letters “Joe Frazier’s Gym” stenciled across the facade in washed-out letters. A former destination for aspiring fighters and children seeking refuge from the gang violence of North Philadelphia, the gym is now a discount furniture store.

abstract: A defiant Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez said he would not resign from the Legislature over multiple sexual harassment allegations.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A defiant Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez said Tuesday that he would not resign from the Legislature over multiple sexual harassment allegations, even as elected officials began to debate whether to seek to expel him and the state’s ethics commission met to discuss an investigation.

headline: Mexico: Major Drug Suspect Is Arrested
abstract: Mario Cárdenas Guillén, a presumed top leader of one of the country’s largest and most powerful criminal groups, was caught by the Mexican Navy on Monday as he was carrying a large gun.
lead_paragraph: A presumed top leader of the Gulf Cartel, one of the country’s largest and most powerful criminal groups, was caught by the Mexican Navy on Monday as he was carrying a large gun. The kingpin, Mario Cárdenas Guillén, was detained in Tamaulipas State, where violence has surged in the past couple of years. The navy did not detail what kind of gun he had, but said he was also in possession of cash, ammunition, fragmentation grenades and other arms. Mr. Cárdenas took over the group — reluctantly, some analysts say — when his brother was killed by Mexican forces in 2010. The Gulf Cartel has waned as a spinoff group, the Zetas, has battled for its turf.

lead_paragraph: It is a rare breed headed for extinction — a New York City taxi charging the old rates after the city allowed cabbies to charge new, higher fares.

headline: Searching for Answers After Violence Mars Parade
abstract: The West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn once again ended violently, and people questioned why a beloved cultural celebration had become synonymous with assaults.
lead_paragraph: The only reminders of a spirited and clamorous parade a day earlier were a few blue wooden barricades lying on the sidewalk that had been part of heightened crowd-control efforts by the police.

headline: Critics Say California Law Hurts Effort to Add Jobs
abstract: With high unemployment in California, environmentalists and politicians see the need to overhaul the state’s landmark environmental law, which can delay even green projects.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Environmentalists in this greenest of places call the California Environmental Quality Act the state’s most powerful environmental protection, a model for the nation credited with preserving lush wetlands and keeping condominiums off the slopes of the Sierra Nevada.

headline: In a Forthright Campaign, More Unmentionables Mentioned
abstract: Laxatives are taking their place in the ad world, alongside toilet paper, condoms, tampons, flushable wipes and other previously silent products.
lead_paragraph: FOR those who need another sign of how much franker Madison Avenue has become in discussing subjects that were once mentioned in whispers and euphemisms, if at all, there is to be quite a large one on display at Penn Station on Thursday: an inflatable prop, 18 feet high, shaped like a pill bottle.

headline: Former Mayor Koch Is Hospitalized for Anemia
abstract: Edward I. Koch, 87, had been “extraordinarily weak” in recent weeks and was barely eating, a friend said.
lead_paragraph: Edward I. Koch, the former three-term mayor of New York City, was hospitalized on Tuesday for anemia, said George Arzt, his former press secretary and longtime friend.

lead_paragraph: An employee with the New York City parks department was fatally stabbed on Tuesday near a recreation center in Queens after a fight with a fellow worker, the authorities said.

headline: With Lead All but Gone, Yankees Dwell on the Finish
abstract: Starting Wednesday, the Yankees have 27 games to make sure that a late-season swoon won’t cost them a playoff spot.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — For days, if not weeks, the Yankees have been holding dear to one irrefutable fact of the American League East race. As poorly as they have played, and as well as the Baltimore Orioles and Tampa Bay Rays have performed, the Yankees have still held the lead.

headline: Better and Worse
abstract: Whether the economy is doing better or worse than it was four years ago can depend on when you start counting.
lead_paragraph: Whether the economy is doing better or worse than it was four years ago can depend on when you start counting.

headline: A Hero’s Welcome for a Convicted Killer Reignites Tensions
abstract: The pardon of Ramil Safarov by the president of Azerbaijan has caused tension with Armenia, the home country of the serviceman that Mr. Safarov killed eight years ago.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ramil Safarov stepped uncertainly off the plane in his native Azerbaijan last Friday, returning home after spending eight years in a Hungarian prison for a gruesome murder. But it took only a few minutes for the celebrations to begin. There was a pardon, a new apartment, eight years of back pay, a promotion to the rank of major and the status of a national hero.

headline: Players, Coaches and Fans Must Adjust to Replacement Refs
abstract: The N.F.L. knows it is taking a chance using replacements during the officials’ lockout, and coaches and players have no choice but to bite their tongues.
lead_paragraph: Long before 11th-hour negotiations to resolve the N.F.L. officials’ lockout devolved into dueling news releases and lost hope last weekend, a former league executive used to say that there were two teams on the field, not three. That pointed barb about the perceived place of officials is one the N.F.L. would surely like fans to remember this week.

headline: Egypt’s Economic Struggle
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Aid', 'Editorials']
abstract: The United States, the I.M.F. and the Egyptian government must work together to revive the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen months after Egypt’s revolution, President Mohamed Morsi, the United States and the International Monetary Fund finally seem to be pulling in the same general direction on the question of how best to revive the country’s devastated economy. Their efforts are long overdue and will require a sustained commitment as Egypt struggles with its transition to democracy.

headline: ‘Are You Better Off?’ The Answer Is Less Clear Than It Was in 1980
abstract: Mitt Romney is hoping the question that helped Ronald Reagan turn around an election will be political kryptonite for President Obama. But it’s not so simple in 2012.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When Ronald Reagan asked voters a week before the 1980 election whether they were better off than four years earlier, he turned a race that had been nip-and-tuck for months into a landslide victory — and showed how a pointed question can be a lethal political weapon.

headline: Michelle Obama Tops Opening Night for Democrats
abstract: Democrats had two simple messages for voters: Mitt Romney does not get it, and President Obama does. The main attraction was Mr. Obama’s lead character witness: his wife, Michelle.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Democrats opened their convention here on Tuesday night with a parade of officials telling voters that Mitt Romney does not get it and with a rousing speech from Michelle Obama making the case that President Obama does.

headline: Out on a Pier, Putting On a Concert for the Birds
abstract: At the end of Dyckman Street in northern Manhattan, examples of selfless service to the community can be found in many forms.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, Jose Modesto Castillo, retired from a job in a plastics factory, walked just about as far west in northern Manhattan as it is possible to go, to the end of a long pier fingering into the Hudson River at Dyckman Street. A harmonica rigged to his head was just a breath away from his lips. Lashed to his hands with hair ties were 17 miniature percussion instruments made from items like a Snapple cap, the lid of a prescription bottle, a Spider-Man figurine, the shells of plastic eggs that once held toys from supermarket vending machines.

headline: A’s Are Hitting Home Runs and Beating the Odds
abstract: The Athletics, who have not finished above .500 since 2006, started play Tuesday with the best record in the majors since the All-Star break, and held one of the two wild-card spots in the American League.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The faded yellow wordmark of the Oakland Athletics — neat, cursive script, with an underline — watches over baseball games at the Coliseum from high atop the center-field seats. It is printed on a canvas that will come off Monday, when the Raiders open their N.F.L. season, and obscures what was once a crisp view of the Oakland hills.

headline: It’s Mitt’s World
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The world has become more interdependent, and this new reality requires a new kind of American leadership.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney has been criticized for not discussing foreign policy. Give him a break. He probably figures he’s already said all that he needs to say during the primaries: He has a big stick, and he is going to use it on Day 1. Or as he put it: “If I’m president of the United States ... on Day 1, I will declare China a currency manipulator, allowing me to put tariffs on products where they are stealing American jobs unfairly.”

headline: Massachusetts: Sex Change Is Ordered for Inmate
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexual', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Gender']
abstract: A federal judge in Boston on Tuesday ordered the Massachusetts Department of Correction to provide an inmate with a sex change.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Boston on Tuesday ordered the Massachusetts Department of Correction to provide an inmate with a sex change. Doctors for Michelle L. Kosilek, a transsexual prisoner who was convicted of murdering his wife in 1990, say gender reassignment surgery is the only way to treat his severe gender identity disorder. Corrections officials had denied the surgery, saying that it could create security problems. In his decision, Judge Mark L. Wolf found that the denial of the surgery, which would be financed with state taxes, amounted to a violation of the Eighth Amendment, which prohibits cruel and unusual punishment. He is believed to be the first federal judge to order gender reassignment. Mr. Kosilek is serving a life sentence without parole. He sued the Department of Corrections over the matter in 2000.

headline: Pentagon Says Book Contains Classified Information
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Pentagon press secretary said on Tuesday that the Defense Department believed there was classified information in a new first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon press secretary, George Little, said on Tuesday that the Defense Department believed there was classified information in a new first-person account of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. Mr. Little did not specify what the information was or do more than repeat threats of legal action. The book, “No Easy Day,” written by a former member of the Navy SEALs, Matt Bissonnette, with a co-author, Kevin Maurer, went on sale on Tuesday. Pentagon officials say Mr. Bissonnette violated nondisclosure agreements he signed with the government, but Mr. Bissonnette and his lawyer say he did not. Penguin, the publisher, is printing 575,000 hardcover copies, placing “No Easy Day” among the biggest books of the year.

headline: Jets Make Late Punting Switch
abstract: The Jets changed punters Tuesday, jettisoning T. J. Conley in favor of Robert Malone.
lead_paragraph: The Jets changed punters Tuesday, jettisoning T. J. Conley in favor of Robert Malone. Conley’s inconsistency frustrated the Jets, whose hope for a spirited competition in training camp never materialized. After Conley beat out two challengers, Travis Baltz and Spencer Lanning, the Jets went with Malone, who ranked higher in both yards per punt (44.8 to 44.0) and net average (39.9 to 37.9) during the preseason. Malone, released two weeks ago by San Diego, has appeared in 13 N.F.L. games across the past two seasons with Tampa Bay and Detroit. The Jets also swapped defensive tackles, waiving Isaako Aaitui and re-signing Marcus Dixon.

headline: The Obamas’ Party
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: The convention’s primetime lineup almost seems designed to suggest that the Democratic Party has a past and a present, but not much of a future.
lead_paragraph: After Ann Romney spoke in Tampa, Fla., last week, much of the next day’s conversation revolved around whether the convention organizers had made a big mistake by having her precede Chris Christie to the lectern. Her speech was praised to the skies, his was criticized for being self-serving and self-absorbed – and by leaving the last word to the New Jersey governor, critics argued, the convention swept the spotlight off her husband and undercut the power of her pitch.

headline: Relations Between India and Sri Lanka Sour
abstract: Fishing disputes, harassed religious pilgrims and a suspended sports official signal weakening of ties.
lead_paragraph: Last week, while traveling down the coast of Tamil Nadu for  my article about the fishing wars between India and Sri Lanka, I noticed pilgrims walking along the side of the road. They trudged along, despite the heat, as they walked kilometers on a pilgrimage to Christian shrines in the state of Tamil Nadu. What I had not realized is that some of the pilgrims visiting the state were from Sri Lanka.

headline: Did Barack Obama Save Ohio?

abstract: Why the battle to take credit for Ohio’s ever-so-slightly above-average economy could swing the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: The way John Kasich sees it, he is fulfilling a grand design, a mission for which he was chosen by God, to save Ohio. “It’s like what what’s-his-name told the hobbit,” Ohio’s Republican governor told me as we flew on the plane that ferries him around the state. “What’s that guy’s name? Gandel? Gandorf?” A pair of young aides seated across from Kasich called out helpfully over the drone of the engine. “Gandalf,” Kasich repeated. “Do you remember what he told the hobbit?”

keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Plans for an initial public offering in Toronto are in the works for the Hudson’s Bay Company, parent of The Bay stores in Canada and Lord & Taylor in the United States, according to two people briefed on the talks.
lead_paragraph: Two of the oldest department store chains in North America are on the verge of a public stock listing.

headline: Still No New Pynchon Photo, but Here’s Emily Dickinson
abstract: Until now only one authenticated portrait of Dickinson as an adult was known to exist. But a second image of the poet, with a smile on her face and a friend by her side, may have been confirmed.
lead_paragraph: In her own words, Emily Dickinson said she was “small, like the wren; and my hair is bold, like the chestnut burr; and my eyes, like the sherry in the glass that the guest leaves.” (She also had a strange propensity for accepting rides from carriage drivers who are the physical embodiment of Death.) But what did that celebrated Massachusetts poet, who died in 1886 – long before the ubiquity of Instagram – actually look like? Until now only one authenticated portrait of Dickinson as an adult, a daguerreotype showing her sitting upright in a chair, was known to exist. But as The Guardian reports, a second image of Dickinson, with a smile on her face and a friend by her side, may have been confirmed.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Slate: A gravely obsessive Pepperidge Farm fan samples every variety of the label’s cookies and emerges with alarming insights like this: “I don’t quite understand how a Milano slice is really a Milano — it would seem an open-faced Milano would be a contradiction in terms, seeing as the sandwich structure of the original is the defining feature.” Willie Wonka, meet Jacques Derrida. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Canine Conservationists on the Move
abstract: Dogs adopted from humane shelters track the scent of an endangered salamander in New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The high energy levels of many dogs in animal shelters can be off-putting to some people seeking to adopt one as a family pet. When that happens, the dogs can end up as candidates for euthanasia. But wildlife conservationists have found a way to capitalize on that intensity, enlisting canines to track threatened species and thereby help protect ecosystems.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Fall Book Bonanza and the New Cosmo Girl
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: It’s a big fall season for the book industry, and there’s a new editor at an iconic brand as Joanna Coles takes over at Cosmopolitan magazine.
lead_paragraph: The book industry is looking forward to some good news for a change. This fall, the big publishers are unleashing a murderer’s row of authors – including Salman Rushdie, Zadie Smith and Junot Díaz – in what it hopes will be a huge season. The two biggest swings: Tom Wolfe writing his first novel in eight years and a work of adult fiction by J.K. Rowling, the creator of Harry Potter.

headline: Obama Convention Speech Moved From Stadium
abstract: President Obama’s acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention has been moved indoors, aides said, because of concerns over threatening storms in Charlotte, N.C., on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: 11:09 a.m. | Updated CHARLOTTE, N.C. – President Obama’s plans to deliver his acceptance speech on Thursday evening at an outdoor stadium rally has been foiled by a forecast of rain and heavy thunderstorms, aides said Wednesday, forcing organizers to scramble and move the final night of the Democratic National Convention indoors.

headline: Greenhill Expands Capital Advisory Group
abstract: The boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company has hired three people in its private capital advisory group, betting the division will become a significant source of revenue at a time when merger-related work can be scarce.
lead_paragraph: Greenhill & Company, the boutique investment bank, is building up its division for private equity and real estate clients as it turns to new sources of revenue.

headline: Microsoft and Nokia Unveil New Lumia Phones
abstract: Nokia and Microsoft, two companies that have not gotten much traction in the smartphone market, are hoping for another chance. The companies on Wednesday unveiled Lumia smartphones that include the Windows Phone operating system — new models of products that have not sold well.
lead_paragraph: 12:39 p.m. | Updated  Adding market and analyst reaction.

headline: Why Not Carry Different E-Book Readers?
abstract: A reader suggests that readers of e-books buy three different devices to deal with incompatible systems. David Pogue disagrees.
lead_paragraph: From my e-mail bag:

headline: Wheelies: The Transatlantic Crossing Edition
abstract: Audi announced it would build the next generation of the Q5 crossover at a new plant in the central Mexican state of Puebla.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Key Figure in Scandal That Felled Bo Xilai Is Charged
abstract: A once powerful Chongqing police official, Wang Lijun, is accused of defection, abuse of power and corruption, China’s state media reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The once-powerful police officer at the center of a scandal that felled the senior Communist leader Bo Xilai was charged Wednesday with defection, abuse of power and corruption.

headline: A Real Tea Party
abstract: “The Boston Tea Party,” the latest entry in Russell Freedman’s Library of American History series.
lead_paragraph: Now that “Schoolhouse Rock!” is no longer around to whip young children into heady waves of patriotism, nonfiction picture books are doing the job — only far more accurately and without putting songs in your head.

headline: Kurds and (the Turkish) Way
abstract: The government of Turkey used to say it had no Kurdish problem. Now it’s suggesting there’s no solution to it. Is that progress?
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When I first started covering Turkey in the early 1990s, my foreign colleagues and I were sometimes mocked for referring to the brewing resentment in southeastern Turkey as “the Kurdish problem.” There was no sectarian or ethnic discrimination, we were told; the problem was terrorism. The Kurdistan Workers Party, better known as the PKK, resorted to violence and extortion, which no civilized society could abide.

headline: A Tool for Those Who Fall Behind on Student Debt
abstract: An online guide may help you evaluate options if you are behind on student loan payments.
lead_paragraph: Have you fallen behind on your student loan payments? The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau this summer introduced an online tool to help you evaluate your options.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Dress in High Definition
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Dresses']
abstract: Mrs. Obama’s choice of designer sent a message. She has frequently worn dresses sent to her by Tracy Reese, a successful self-made businesswoman whose prices are also in the middle ground.
lead_paragraph: IT says a lot about politics today that it was possible, during a speech by Michelle Obama that was described as “genius” for its subtlety by both David Brooks and Mark Shields, that a parallel conversation was happening online, and in real time, about her shimmering brocade dress and matching fingernails. If you were following along on Twitter, where comments reportedly reached a peak of 28,000 a minute by the end of her speech, you might wonder how many people were really listening to what she was saying.

headline: Shifting Views on Climate Change
abstract: Responding to questions about science, Mitt Romney says he believes the world is getting warmer and “humans play a role in that warming.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, have spelled out their views on climate change in a bit more detail than they usually do on the campaign trail in response to questions from a group of scientific organizations.

headline: Roundabout to Revive ‘Talley’s Folly’ in February
abstract: Lanford Wilson’s two-character romance will play the Roundabout’s Laura Pels Theater, one of its Off Broadway spaces, next spring.
lead_paragraph: A revival of Lanford Wilson’s two-character romance “Talley’s Folly” will be part of the Roundabout Theater Company’s 2012-13 season, the theater announced on Wednesday.

headline: Stereotypes in Toeshoes
abstract: Though race-blind casting has been widespread in ballet for decades, clichéd and sometimes offensive views of race remain alive and well across the art form.
lead_paragraph: Calendars for the coming ballet season have now been announced across much of America. As usual, story ballets abound. But what stories do they tell? Narrative ballet remains a heritage park: an Old World never-never land. How many of us would actually like to inhabit those onstage worlds? Which choreographers are telling stories for our time?

headline: Desert Stories: Claire Vaye Watkins Talks About ‘Battleborn’
abstract: The stories in Ms. Watkins’s debut collection are all set in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: Claire Vaye Watkins’s first book, “Battleborn,” a collection of short stories, arrives with notable provenance (the stories originally appeared in The Paris Review and elsewhere) and an unusually compelling author biography. Ms. Watkins’s father, Paul Watkins, was once a member of Charles Manson’s “family.” In Vincent Bugliosi’s “Helter Skelter,” he’s described as “a good-looking youth with a way with women” who “had been Manson’s chief procurer of young girls.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Watkins discussed learning about her father’s life, the hold Nevada has on her imagination, her “obsessive and controlling” sense of play when she was a child and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Q&A: Setting Up A Wireless Printer
abstract: Setting up a wireless printer on a home network usually takes a little time, software configuration and a network password.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: In China, Drogba Draws Crowds and Controversy
abstract: The former Chelsea star Didier Drogba has been a sensation for Shanghai Shenhua, but some say money would have been better spent nurturing domestic talent.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With five defenders smothering him at the top of the penalty box, Didier Drogba, the former star player for Chelsea in England’s Premier League, calmly slid a lead pass to his new Shanghai Shenhua teammate Cao Yunding, who was dashing full-speed through the box. The nifty pass caught the defenders and the goalkeeper off guard. With a near-open net, Drogba’s teammate hesitated, perhaps perplexed by how easy it had seemed, then fired the ball past the dumbstruck goalkeeper.

headline: Eating Where It Feels Like Home (But You Don’t Have to Do the Dishes)
abstract: Mark Bittman has had enough of white-tablecloth restaurants. Now, he writes, he wants “his” place, and has some specific thoughts on what that means. Is there a place you think of as yours? If so, are you willing to share?
lead_paragraph: The cookbook author and New York Times food writer Mark Bittman has had enough of white-tablecloth restaurants, he writes. He wants his own place, wherever he is in the world, and he’s got some specific requirements for it:

headline: Marriage Equality Goes Prime Time
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Homosexuality', 'Marriages', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In a glancing fashion, the headliners on the first night of the Democratic National Convention nod to same-sex marriage.

headline: At the Democratic Convention, an Emphasis on Social Issues
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Homosexuality', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: At times, it seemed as if every speaker on the first night of the Democratic National Convention was touting same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — On Monday night, Michelle Obama told the nation that her husband wants everyone to succeed no matter “who we love.”

headline: Tiger Triplets Make Their Debut in the Bronx
abstract: Three Siberian tiger cubs, now 4 months old, are part of an effort by the Bronx Zoo’s parent organization, the Wildlife Conservation Society, to educate people about tigers’ critically endangered status.
lead_paragraph: It is a busy time for local youngsters. Just as the city’s children prepare to go back to school, three 4-month-old Siberian tiger cubs made their debut on Wednesday at the Bronx Zoo (see video below or click here).

headline: New Yorker Festival to Include ‘Cloud Atlas’ Premiere
abstract: Highlights of this year’s festival include a premiere of the film adaptation of “Cloud Atlas,” followed by a conversation with its directors Tom Tykwer and Andy and Lana Wachowski.
lead_paragraph: The first United States showing of the film version of “Cloud Atlas” – as well as a rare showing-up by its co-directors Andy and Lana Wachowski – will be one of the marquee events of the 2012 New Yorker Festival. On Wednesday organizers announced the lineup for the annual festival, which runs this year from Oct. 5 through 7 and features public events with various cultural luminaries and contributors to The New Yorker magazine. Among its highlights is a premiere screening of “Cloud Atlas,” adapted from the David Mitchell novel, followed by a conversation with the Wachowski siblings (“The Matrix,” “Speed Racer”) and their co-director, Tom Tykwer. (The “Cloud Atlas” team will be interviewed by Aleksandar Hemon, who wrote about them in this week’s issue of The New Yorker.)

headline: Business and Pleasure
abstract: In Atlanta, where hip-hop rubs up against notorious strip clubs, rappers who want to make it big get their start by making it rain.
lead_paragraph: In Atlanta, where hip-hop rubs up against notorious strip clubs, rappers who want to make it big get their start by making it rain.

headline: Image of the Day: September 5
abstract: Remembering Mother Teresa on her death anniversary in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Bespoke Tailors in New York
abstract: Designers like Martin Greenfield and Peter Frew charge thousands of dollars for a single custom-made suit. So why aren’t they rich?
lead_paragraph: Designers like Martin Greenfield and Peter Frew charge thousands of dollars for a single custom-made suit. So why aren’t they rich?

headline: What Should the President Say?
abstract: On Thursday night, should he linger on his record or focus on the future?
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–Only 38 percent of respondents in a new Gallup poll said Mitt Romney’s performance at the Republican Convention was good or excellent, the lowest approval rating for any presidential candidate’s acceptance speech since Gallup started asking the question.

headline: Breaking It Down: Ferrer vs. Gasquet
abstract: David Ferrer emphasized his hit-and-run tactics to defeat Richard Gasquet at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: In Malcolm Gladwell’s 2005 best-seller, “Blink,” he focused on the subject of “thin-slicing” – the ability to understand what is important from an extremely narrow moment in time.

headline: Why the Minimum Wage Doesn’t Explain Stagnant Wages
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Is the minimum wage one of the most important causes of the American income slowdown?
lead_paragraph: Until the mid-1980s, only a single state – and one of the smallest in population, Alaska – had set a minimum wage higher than the federal minimum. But with the federal minimum remaining unchanged at $3.35 an hour for most of the 1980s, more states began to set higher floors for wages.

headline: Start-Up Offers a New Way to Shop for Office Supplies
abstract: Poppin, an e-commerce start-up that opened to the public on Tuesday, thinks it has a solution to the problems suffered by office supply companies like Staples: an uncluttered Web site, colorful staplers and pens and designing, manufacturing and selling products itself. But will penny-pinching office managers order $14 magenta staplers?
lead_paragraph: The renaissance of e-commerce has brought us new ways to shop for pants, diapers and eyeglasses. Next up: office supplies.

headline: Yankees Borrow a Page From the Mets
abstract: The erosion of a big lead, the growing sense of panic in the fan base — that’s something that just hasn’t happened in the current Yankees era of success.
lead_paragraph: In New York, it’s the Mets who normally have a copyright on collapses. They fell apart after the All-Star break this season, going 11-29; they blew an easy shot at the postseason in 2008 with some unbelievable bullpen mayhem in the final weeks of September; and they made history by blowing a seven-game division lead with 17 games to go in 2007.

headline: Obama Counts on Clinton to Help Sway Independents
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Stadiums and Arenas']
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton tried to rebut Republican arguments against the re-election of President Obama in a major speech at the Democratic National Convention Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Former President Bill Clinton tried to rebut Republican arguments against the re-election of President Obama in a major speech at the Democratic National Convention Wednesday night, saying Mr. Obama has taken steps to turn around an economy left in shambles by Republicans.

headline: Pruning Hedge Fund Regulation Without Cultivating Better Rules
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Hedge Funds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed rules to lift advertising restrictions for hedge funds, but the way this looks on paper and the way it will play out in the real world are a tad different.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from having declined to constrain money market funds, the Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to loosen marketing constraints on hedge funds.

headline: Video of Quebec Gunman’s Rant After Shooting at Separatist Rally
abstract: Canadian television images showed a man suspected of opening fire at a rally for a Québécois separatist party in Montreal on Tuesday night shouting, in French, “The English are awakening!”
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Ian Austen reports, the leader of Canada’s separatist Parti Québécois was hustled offstage during a speech after her party’s victory in a provincial election Tuesday night when a 62-year-old man opened fire outside the rally, leaving one man dead and another in critical condition.

headline: Safeway Plans I.P.O. of Gift Card Unit
keywords: ['Gift Cards and Certificates', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Shares of Safeway climbed after the supermarket chain announced plans to sell a minority stake in its fast-growing Blackhawk Network gift card business.
lead_paragraph: Safeway, the supermarket chain based in California, said on Wednesday that it planned to file for an initial public offering of a minority stake in its fast-growing gift card unit, Blackhawk Network Holdings. Shares of Safeway were up 5 percent by midday.

headline: The Get | Van Cleef & Arpels Touch Wood Vintage Alhambra Pendant
abstract: The new collection was inspired by a discovery in the brand’s Place Vendôme maison.
lead_paragraph: After discovering a trove of letter wood in the attic of the brand’s Place Vendôme maison, Van Cleef & Arpels’s North America president and CEO Nicolas Bos and team decided to honor the find and use it to create the touch wood Vintage Alhambra collection. Each necklace, bracelet and earring in the collection is limited and numbered and set in rose gold — a first for the brand’s signature, four-leaf clover-shaped Alhambras. “It’s a warm color and the modern alternative to yellow gold,” Bos says of the choice to use rose gold. “With the wood it was an interesting feeling — more of a vintage feeling that still felt like a very new combination.” Charmed, for sure!

headline: Polls: Little to No Bounce for Romney
abstract: Several surveys conducted after the Republican National Convention show little lift for Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Several new polls show that in the immediate days after the Republican National Convention, Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, did not see much of a boost to his campaign, although slightly more Americans now see him as someone who can understand the needs of the middle class.

headline: Lincoln’s Handwitten Draft of the Emancipation Proclamation Is Coming to Harlem
abstract: The only surviving draft of the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation in Abraham Lincoln’s handwriting will be displayed in an exhibition that will travel to several New York state museums.
lead_paragraph: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem will be the first stop for the New York State Museum’s traveling exhibition of the only surviving draft of the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation in Abraham Lincoln’s handwriting.

headline: Barbara Marcus to Lead Random House Children’s Books
abstract: Ms. Marcus, who is known for her time at Scholastic and her acquisition of the Harry Potter books, will succeed Chip Gibson.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Marcus, the children’s publishing veteran who acquired the seven Harry Potter books when she was an executive at Scholastic, has been chosen to lead Random House Children’s Books, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Candice Childress
abstract: Candice Childress, a student at Las Vegas Academy of International Studies, Visual and Performing Arts in Nevada, is one of eight high school seniors who are blogging about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: Candice Childress, a student at Las Vegas Academy of International Studies, Visual and Performing Arts in Nevada, is one of eight high school seniors who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: Folk Art Museum Picks New Director
abstract: American Folk Art Museum selects new director.
lead_paragraph: The American Folk Art Museum in New York, which almost went out of business last year because of financial struggles, has appointed a new director, the museum announced Wednesday.

headline: How Hard Is It to Make a $4,000 Suit?
abstract: Photographs of bespoke tailors at work.
lead_paragraph: When the rich get richer, luxury-goods proprietors often see their fortunes rise, too. (For evidence, check out the decidedly pre-Lehmanesque heft of the September issue of Vogue.) But as Adam Davidson notes in this week’s column, bespoke suit makers, maybe the world’s second-oldest profession, are struggling to survive. This is puzzling on a number of levels, the most obvious of which is that there are huge markets of wealthy guys who care about whether their jacket is double-breasted or single-vented, and for whom $4,000 is not an ungodly sum to spend on a garment. So why wouldn’t they want the best possible value for their dollar — a suit hand-sewn just for them?

headline: Europe to Investigate Chinese Exports of Solar Panels
abstract: The case could lead to steep tariffs on much of China’s exports of solar products to Europe. China has threatened to retaliate against European wines and industrial materials.
lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — Defying Chinese threats of retaliation against European wines and industrial materials, the European Union is preparing to begin on Thursday morning a broad investigation into whether Chinese companies have been exporting solar panels for less than it costs to make them.

headline: Real Life Intrudes
abstract: Blogging derailed.
lead_paragraph: Dealing with matters filial. I will try to put up a couple of posts, but limited time and access.

headline: Mo’Nique  Lends Support to  Ailey Gala
abstract: The evening will kick off the company’s five-week season at New York City Center.
lead_paragraph: The actress and comedian Mo’Nique will serve as the honorary chairwoman of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s gala benefit performance on Nov. 28. The evening will kick off the company’s five-week season at City Center and will also feature Ailey’s signature 1960 work “Revelations,” with special guest musicians. Featured vocalists will include the Tony Award-winning actors and singers Audra McDonald, Brian Stokes Mitchell and Anika Noni Rose. Ticket and additional information is available at www.alvinailey.org.

headline: W Hotels Seek to Attract Local Residents, Too
abstract: A renovation of public spaces; no check-in required.
lead_paragraph: W Hotels has announced that 11 of its 28 North American properties are undergoing a $100 million renovation, the biggest overhaul in the nearly 15-year history of the brand. But guests aren’t the only ones in mind: much of the change is focused on public spaces.

headline: How to See Fall’s Leaves for Less
abstract: The thermometer may not show it, but the calendar does: Fall foliage season is almost upon us. Here are tips for scoring leaf-peeping deals in five Northeast locations.
lead_paragraph: IT feels like summer in the Northeast, but if you have yet to make reservations for a fall foliage getaway, you’re behind schedule.

headline: A Sandal Samaritan
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The day was going badly when her sandal broke, with a long commute ahead. Fortunately, a stranger knew what to do.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Bits of Mystery DNA, Far From ‘Junk,’ Play Crucial Role
abstract: At least four million gene switches that reside in sections of the human genome once thought to be inactive turn out to have critical functions in the body, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: Among the many mysteries of human biology is why complex diseases like diabetes, high blood pressure and psychiatric disorders are so difficult to predict and, often, to treat. An equally perplexing puzzle is why one individual gets a disease like cancer or depression, while an identical twin remains perfectly healthy.

headline: Close Encounters With Homo Sapiens’ Closest Kin
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Monkeys and Apes']
abstract: A roving ambassador for island conservation takes a side trip to see some primate relatives.
lead_paragraph: In recent months I’ve become familiar with the work of the nonprofit group Seacology, which scours the world for opportunities to conserve island ecosystems and cultures. Investments are made in infrastructure — from solar panels to school equipment or medical clinics — in return for community commitments to protect environmental assets. Duane Silverstein, the group’s executive director since 1999, recently sent a Dot Earth “postcard” following a visit to two different projects in sub-Saharan Africa working to conserve Homo sapiens’ primate kin, chimpanzees and gorillas:

headline: McDonald’s Vegetarian Restaurants: Latest in Long, Tough Battle to Woo India
abstract: For nearly twenty years, McDonalds has been trying to win over Indian consumers, but the company’s most famous food gets in the way.
lead_paragraph: The announcement by McDonald’s on Tuesday that it would open a few vegetarian-only restaurants in India next year marks the fast-food chain’s latest attempt to appeal to consumers in an unlikely market.

headline: Newspaper Publisher Journal Register Files for Bankruptcy and Plans for a Sale
abstract: The company, which is part of Digital First Media and publishes The New Haven Register and The Trentonian, emerged from bankruptcy three years ago.
lead_paragraph: The Journal Register Company, whose newspapers include The New Haven Register and The Trentonian, has again filed for bankruptcy protection and hopes for a quick sale, said Digital First Media, which operates the company along with the MediaNews Group.

headline: Ryan Cites Policy Kinship With Bill Clinton
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan suggests that President Obama is more like Jimmy Carter than Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: ADEL, Iowa — From tying President Obama to the economic stagnation under one former president, Jimmy Carter, the Romney-Ryan campaign has moved on to offering rosy recollections of another Democrat in the White House, Bill Clinton. In both cases the aim is to paint an unflattering contrast with Mr. Obama.

headline: Wicksell Goes To China
abstract: We don’t want them buying our bonds.
lead_paragraph: The idea that we are at the mercy of the Chinese — that terrible things would happen if they stopped buying our bonds — is very influential. Yet it’s just wrong.

headline: Survey Deems JPMorgan’s Investment Bank Best Place to Work
abstract: In a survey of some 3,500 Wall Street professionals, JPMorgan’s investment bank was selected as the best firm to work for in North America this year, judging by quality of life and overall prestige.
lead_paragraph: A multibillion-dollar trading loss and multiple regulatory investigations apparently haven’t made life too miserable at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Volkswagen Previews Redesigned Golf Ahead of Paris Motor Show
abstract: The seventh generation of Volkswagen’s compact hatchback bears a smoother, more upscale appearance and rides on the automaker’s new global vehicle architecture.
lead_paragraph: The Golf, the backbone of Volkswagen’s global product lineup since its debut in 1974, with more than 29 million units sold, has received a complete redesign for the 2014 model year. The seventh generation of the Golf was unveiled in an elaborate ceremony on Monday in Berlin, at the city’s Neue Nationalgalerie.

headline: In Clinton and Warren, Competing Messages for the Middle Class
abstract: Wednesday begins the hard sell of President Obama to the middle class. And for this task, the campaign has juxtaposed two prime-time speakers – Elizabeth Warren and Bill Clinton, one right after the other – who in their core philosophies represent contradictory, even irreconcilable strains of American liberalism.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a candidate for president, the convention affords you a fleeting window of opportunity, about three hours total of network airtime, to present speakers who will get across your one central message to the wide section of America. In the case of this Democratic convention, though, Wednesday’s lineup reveals the essential dilemma that has often made President Obama’s re-election campaign, and much of his presidency, seem as muddled as a Clint Eastwood monologue.

headline: Former Goldman Executive Joins Strategic Value Partners
abstract: Stephen J. McGuinness, the former co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs Asset Management, has joined the investment firm Strategic Value Partners as a senior managing director.
lead_paragraph: Stephen J. McGuinness, the former co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs Asset Management, has joined the investment firm Strategic Value Partners as a senior managing director.

headline: The New Season in Theater: Fall 2012
abstract: A look at some of the season’s new shows.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the season’s new shows.

headline: The UndocuBus
abstract: A rolling platform for immigration activism, painted aqua, has reached Charlotte after more than a month on the road.
lead_paragraph: The UndocuBus, a rolling platform for immigration activism, painted aqua and covered with butterflies, has reached Charlotte, N.C., after more than a month on the road. It started in Arizona in late July and wove its way through states where there have been immigrant crackdowns: New Mexico, Colorado, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee.

headline: The New Season in Art
abstract: A look at artworks and exhibitions of the fall.
lead_paragraph: A look at artworks and exhibitions of the fall.

abstract: Why Clint Eastwood’s performance art seemed like more of a disaster to the political media than it actually was.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Children Come First. Should They?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: When Michelle Obama declares that her most important title is “mom in chief,” does she make things easier, or more difficult, for working mothers?
lead_paragraph: “At the end of the day, my most important title is still ‘mom in chief.’ My daughters are still the heart of my heart and the center of my world.”

headline: Running a Business With Staff Scattered Around the World
abstract: It can be difficult to get far-flung employees to work cohesively. The suggestions in this guide come from small-business owners who have tried.
lead_paragraph: When Ralph Dandrea needed to hire a handful of employees for his rapidly growing Web design business, he figured he would have no trouble finding information technology professionals. It was 1998, and the technology boom was in full swing. But even though Mr. Dandrea, founder and chief executive of ITX Corporation, based in Pittsford, N.Y., looked all across the country, he struggled to find candidates.

headline: Viva la Villa | Palatial Near Pienza
abstract: The next installment in a series on house-hunting in Tuscany.
lead_paragraph: Adventures in house-hunting: a writer chronicles her attempt to find the perfect home in Italy.

headline: Obama Faces Test From Voters Who Drifted Away
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: President Obama is preparing to make an aggressive pitch at the Democratic convention, hoping to return to the fold voters who supported him in 2008 but now express disappointment.
lead_paragraph: Dahlgren and Robert McElwain, retired business owners who live outside Kansas City, were in agreement in 2008. Despite their nearly lifelong support of Republican candidates, they made a bold move together and cast ballots for Barack Obama, enchanted by what they saw as his intelligence and charm.

headline: TimesCast Politics and Democratic Convention Day 2 at a Glance
abstract: The Times’s political unit will be broadcasting live with the latest from the convention, beginning at 7 p.m. Here are a few of the highlights from the program.
lead_paragraph: 5:57 p.m. | Updated Democrats on Wednesday will try to continue to build on the energy from Tuesday night’s speeches, highlighted by an emotional address from the first lady, Michelle Obama.

headline: Are Your Employees Really More Productive Working at Home?
abstract: What have you learned about managing remote employees?
lead_paragraph: Ralph Dandrea’s company, ITX Corporation, has 128 employees but only 46 of them report to the main office in Pittsford, N.Y. The rest are scattered internationally (72 in Argentina, plus Peru, Spain, Uruguay and Venezuela) as well as in the United States (California, Missouri, Oregon, Washington,  Virginia). “It’s a lot of fun working this way,” Mr. Dandrea said. “But there are always challenges.”

headline: A Plebe First, a Player Second
abstract: As a first-year player on the Army football team in 2011, Larry Dixon quickly learned that being a college running back was easy compared with being a plebe at West Point.
lead_paragraph: Larry Dixon was looking for someone to hug. He had just scored the first touchdown of his collegiate career, a 2-yard burst straight up the guts of the Tulane defense to tie the game.

headline: As Iran Assists Syria, Iraqi Airspace Becomes a Diplomatic Battleground
abstract: Michael R. Gordon reports in Tuesday’s Times that the airspace over Iraq is becoming a complicated proxy of Iraq’s relations with the United States and with its neighbors across the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Gordon reports in Tuesday’s Times that the airspace over Iraq is becoming a complicated proxy of Iraq’s relations with the United States and with its neighbors across the Middle East.

headline: Before Heading Into Space, Photos Will Land at Bryant Park
abstract: Space launch of a micro-disc containing images of Earth and modern human history to be previewed at Bryant Park event.
lead_paragraph: While the Curiosity rover searches the surface of Mars, an artist will be sending his own microvision of life on Earth into space this fall.

headline: When Fairness Opinions Are Used Outside of Mergers
abstract: The growth of fairness opinions, which are used in merger deals to provide a gauge of a company’s worth, in nontraditional situations is an emerging trend that deserves scrutiny, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Jill R. Goodman is a managing director at Rothschild, where she leads the firm’s practice representing special committees of independent directors in M.&A. transactions.

headline: Exploring Islam, Pompeii and the Factory
abstract: A look at exhibitions across the country this fall.
lead_paragraph: Dates and touring sites are subject to change.

headline: Anna Dello Russo’s Fashion Shower
abstract: Teaser videos are the new thing in viral marketing, and after H&M’s latest campaign, you will never look at Anna Dello Russo the same way again.
lead_paragraph: Teaser videos are the new thing in viral marketing, as H&M demonstrated with the introduction of its Lanvin collection two years ago, using clips that showed the humorous side of Alber Elbaz. But after its latest campaign, you will never look at Anna Dello Russo the same way again. Ever. Not if you poke your eyes out.

headline: A Button for Every Delegate
abstract: If you’re at the Democratic National Convention and you support President Obama, there is a button for you. No group is too obscure to profess support for the president’s re-election.
lead_paragraph: Are you left-handed? A cat lover? If you’re at the Democratic National Convention and you support President Obama, there is a button for you. No group is too obscure to profess support for the president’s re-election. Pearl divers, rejoice.

headline: 2 Injured at Power Plant in France
abstract: A steam release from a chemical reaction at France’s oldest nuclear power plant gave two workers slight burns on their hands but did not cause a fire or radiation problem, officials said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A steam release from a chemical reaction on Wednesday at the Fessenheim nuclear power plant, France’s oldest, gave two workers slight burns on their hands but did not cause a fire or radiation problem, government and fire officials said.

headline: Motorola Introduces First Phones of Its New Google Era
abstract: After being quiet for nearly a year, Motorola Mobility, recently acquired by Google, is returning to the mobile market with three new smartphones for Verizon customers.
lead_paragraph: After being quiet for nearly a year, Motorola Mobility, recently acquired by Google, is returning to the mobile market with three new smartphones.

headline: Women, Women, Everywhere — but Not Much About Their Paychecks
abstract: Where, after what seemed like women’s night on Tuesday at the Democratic National Convention, was the coverage of pay equity, along with gender-economic issues in general?
lead_paragraph: The stage at the Democratic National Convention was awash in women Tuesday night. And it’s no wonder, since President Obama needs women desperately to win in November. Female voters tend to like Mr. Obama more than Mitt Romney — though Mr. Obama’s popularity among women has fallen sharply.  So women were very much in the mix.  (A nifty interactive graphic on NYTimes.com shows that “women” was the keyword mentioned third most often Tuesday night – after Obama and work.)

headline: Emanuel to Raise Money for Democratic ‘Super PAC’
abstract: Rahm Emanuel, the mayor of Chicago, gives Democratic outside groups a dedicated rainmaker.
lead_paragraph: Rahm Emanuel, the mayor of Chicago, said on Wednesday that he had stepped down from his honorary position as co-chairman of President Obama’s re-election campaign to help raise money for Priorities USA Action, a super PAC founded by two former Obama aides.

headline: Fashion’s Night Out and About
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: In New York, more than 700 stores will stay open late for Fashion’s Night Out. A selective sampling.
lead_paragraph: WHAT do Justin Bieber, Taylor Swift and Kendall Jenner have in common?

headline: U.S. to Retain Role as a Jailer in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The United States military will continue indefinitely to operate a section of the Parwan complex holding foreign combatants, even as the two countries mark a transfer of authority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States military will maintain control over dozens of foreign detainees in Afghanistan for the indefinite future, even as the two countries prepare to ceremonially mark the hand-over of detention operations to the Afghan government, officials from both countries say.

headline: As Arenas Go Green, Will Fans Follow?
abstract: Starting first with individual sports teams and then expanding to leagues, the environmental movement has won converts.
lead_paragraph: Can sports make environmentalism more popular?

headline: Democrats Restore Language Declaring Jerusalem Israel’s Capital
abstract: President Obama, seeking to quell a storm of criticism from Republicans and pro-Israel groups over his support for Israel, directed the Democratic Party to amend its platform to restore language declaring Jerusalem as the Israeli capital.
lead_paragraph: 6:43 p.m. | Updated  CHARLOTTE, N.C. – President Obama, seeking to quell a storm of criticism from Republicans and pro-Israel groups over his support for Israel, directed the Democratic Party to amend its platform to restore language declaring Jerusalem as the Israeli capital.

headline: Philip Roth to Cooperate With New Biographer
abstract: The novelist has signed an agreement to share his papers and work with Blake Bailey, who has written biographies of John Cheever and Richard Yates.
lead_paragraph: Philip Roth has a new biographer: Blake Bailey, the author of highly regarded biographies of Richard Yates and John Cheever.  Mr. Bailey said on Wednesday that in June he and Mr. Roth signed a collaboration agreement guaranteeing him unlimited access to Mr. Roth’s archives and correspondence, and help in encouraging friends to cooperate, and that he had already spent several marathon sessions interviewing the 79-year-old novelist.

headline: Two for the Runway
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Hair', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Friends since the 1980s, Guido Palau and Diane Kendal still collaborate at fashion shows.
lead_paragraph: DURING New York Fashion Week, editors will seek standout microtrends like the long, tousled side braid of Alexander Wang’s spring 2010 collection or the glowing sun-kissed complexion and feathery full brow that went with it.

headline: Wacky Meets Khaki
abstract: Daniel Silver and Steven Cox, the designers behind the quirky men’s wear label Duckie Brown, signed on with Perry Ellis for a line that will make its debut next week.
lead_paragraph: UPON meeting the design duo behind the men’s wear label Duckie Brown, it is hard to learn who is who. Daniel Silver and Steven Cox, who are partners in business and romance, call each other “Duckie.” If they use their actual names, watch out: it might get awkward.

headline: Harrison Brothers Lose in Doubles Quarterfinals
abstract: The dream of a showdown between Mike and Bob Bryan and Ryan and Christian Harrison at the United States Open will have to wait.
lead_paragraph: The dream of a showdown between the Bryan brothers and the Harrison brothers at the United States Open will have to wait.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Fish Tacos
abstract: The fish tacos at Fresca Mexicana at the United States Open are a go-to dish.
lead_paragraph: This is the latest in our daily series of food reviews of items at the United States Open concession stands.

headline: Southern Supergroup to Bring Its Barbecue to Meatopia
abstract: The Fatback Collective, an informal association of a dozen celebrated southern chefs and pitmasters, will cook at the Meatopia festival on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Meatopia, that nine-year-old be-in for carnophiles, is migrating to Randalls Island for the first time, anticipating 3,000 attendees this Saturday at its four-hour bacchanal of pork, beef, lamb, chicken, duck, turkey and quail.

headline: Romney to Appear on ‘Meet the Press’
abstract: Mitt Romney will make his first appearance Sunday on “Meet the Press,’’ a move clearly intended to inject himself back onto the main stage of the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mitt Romney will make his first appearance of the campaign season this Sunday on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” a move clearly intended to thrust himself back onto the main stage of the presidential campaign after ceding it to President Obama.

headline: Regulators Clarify Timing of New Derivatives Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: After months of uncertainty, federal authorities now say some new derivatives rules will not take effect until Jan. 1, providing a brief — but important — extension to Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: As Wall Street gears up for an overhaul of the $600 trillion derivatives business, big banks have grumbled that regulators failed to specify when the new policies will take effect.

headline: On The Road With Uber
abstract: After 23 years, Shadid Mahmood traded in his cab to work for Uber, a start-up company that runs an app to help people hail cars more efficiently.
lead_paragraph: After 23 years, Shadid Mahmood traded in his cab to work for Uber, a start-up company that runs an app to help people hail cars more efficiently.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Design']
abstract: Christian Louboutin opens a men’s store in the United States, and Henri Bendel hosts a Thierry Mugler event.
lead_paragraph: OPENINGS

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: New Raspberry Pi and Revamping Google
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a former member of Twitter’s board worried about changes at the service, a taxi-hailing app offering free cab rides and a start-up carmaker’s plan to change the way vehicles are sold.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Wearing Two Uniforms at West Point
abstract: Athletes at West Point, like running back Larry Dixon, have to adjust to the speed of the college game and to the rules and traditions of a military academy.
lead_paragraph: Athletes at West Point, like running back Larry Dixon, have to adjust to the speed of the college game and to the rules and traditions of a military academy.

headline: A Christian Album Tops the Charts
abstract: It is the first time in 15 years that a Christian album has reached No. 1.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 15 years, a Christian album is No. 1 on the Billboard chart.

headline: Apple Denies Giving F.B.I. Device Information
abstract: Apple denied claims that it had worked with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. to share unique identification numbers from Apple devices and its customers.
lead_paragraph: Apple on Wednesday denied claims that it had worked with the government to share millions of device identification numbers, a day after the hacking group known as AntiSec claimed to have obtained numbers from an F.B.I. laptop.

headline: What the Democrats Didn’t Say
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Kathleen Sebelius and others defended the health care law, but didn’t dwell on its main purpose: To provide coverage for 30 million uninsured Americans.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – After years of waiting for Democrats to acknowledge President Obama’s pre-eminent achievement – health care reform – it was good to hear them talk about it with pride from the convention stage on Tuesday night. Speaker after speaker reminded the audience of the law, vigorously refuting the Republican dogma that it is an Orwellian disaster.

headline: Bank of America Adopts Simpler Checking Account Disclosure
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Checks and Checking Accounts', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Bank of America is the latest bank to adopt a simplified format for checking account disclosures.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America recently became the last of the three biggest United States banks to adopt simplified checking account disclosures, as advocated by an arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts.

headline: Consumers Say No to Mobile Apps That Grab Too Much Data
abstract: A new study shows that American adults who download applications to their smartphones are wary of giving up too much of their personal information.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday nudged application developers to take steps to protect consumer privacy. But many consumers seem to be already taking steps to guard their personal information from data-grabbing apps.

headline: An Award for Oscar de la Renta
abstract: A week after Ann Romney wore a cherry red Oscar de la Renta dress to deliver her speech at the Republican National Convention, the designer himself was being honored with a lifetime achievement award at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: A week after Ann Romney wore a cherry red Oscar de la Renta dress to deliver her speech at the Republican National Convention, the designer himself was being honored with a lifetime achievement award at Lincoln Center.

headline: Scene City: A New Benefit in the Hamptons Ecosystem
abstract: Cindy Sherman hosts the inaugural fundraiser for the Azuero Earth Project.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Sherman hosts the inaugural fundraiser for the Azuero Earth Project.

headline: Leaving a Footprint for a Cause
abstract: A party held at Cindy Sherman’s new property in the Hamptons, at a $1,000 a head, was an ambitious send-off for the social animals of summer.
lead_paragraph: THE word “sustainable” has become very popular in recent years, almost as popular as benefit parties in the Hamptons. Last Saturday, the Azuero Earth Project, a nonprofit organization with the lofty mission of preserving the earth’s ecosystems and protecting biodiversity, broke into the very competitive fund-raising ecosystem of East Hampton.

headline: Engine Coolant Leak Prompts 3rd Recall of 2013 Ford Escape
abstract: The recall affected 6,100 of the redesigned crossovers, but it applied only to those equipped with the 1.6-liter EcoBoost engine.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling about 6,100 of its 2013 Escape crossovers because a coolant leak may cause fires, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. It is the third recall of the redesigned Escape and the second involving a fire risk.

headline: For Blue Dog PAC, Cash but Few Candidates
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Blue Dog Coalition, facing a decimation in the ranks of centrist House Democrats in recent years, has significant cash on hand but not enough viable candidates to support.
lead_paragraph: The “super PAC” supporting Blue Dog candidates has a problem that on the surface would seem enviable: tons of cash on hand! But the reason is one no one would wish for a group — it does not have enough viable candidates to support.

headline: Greek Government and Public at Odds Over New Cuts
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Greece is running out of cash while international lenders push through austerity measures. The required cuts may force a confrontation between Athens and the public.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Anastasia Kastaniotou, a struggling mother of three, stood near the Greek Parliament building on Wednesday and threw up her hands as she contemplated an €11.5 billion austerity package that her country’s government was trying to tie up this week to keep Greece in the euro.

headline: Excluded From Democratic Convention List, Liu Tours Asia
abstract: John C. Liu, the focus of a federal investigation into his campaign fund-raising, is traveling in South Korea and Taiwan, affording him the chance to meet potential donors for a presumed mayoral bid.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Two months ago, John C. Liu, New York City’s comptroller, said he was “heartbroken” that the state’s top Democrats, skittish about a federal investigation into his campaign fund-raising, had excluded him from their delegate list to the Democratic National Convention.

abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.

headline: Great Free Web Sites for Teaching Election 2012
abstract: We gathered a list of the best election-related Web sites for teachers and organized them by category. Have your students play fantasy election games or find pen pals in a different part of the country to exchange ideas about important issues.
lead_paragraph: If you’re like us, you see the election everywhere on the Web. But finding useful Web sites for teaching the election? That’s a different story.

lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton gave the nominating speech for Michael Dukakis in 1988.
