abstract: Representative Yvette D. Clarke’s appearance on “The Colbert Report” included a curious exchange about slavery.

headline: President of Madison Square Garden Sports Leaving Post
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Basketball', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: Scott O’Neil, who stabilized the Knicks after the Isiah Thomas era, has stepped down after four years on the job.
lead_paragraph: Scott O’Neil, an energetic executive who helped stabilize the Knicks after the controversy and tumult of the Isiah Thomas era, has left his post as president of Madison Square Garden Sports, after only four years on the job.

headline: Egyptian President Warns Assad That ‘Your Time Won’t Be Long’
abstract: A statement by President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt directed at Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, added to regional acrimony as Syrian forces shelled the battleground city of Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt on Wednesday warned the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, that “your time won’t be long,” as Syrian warplanes and artillery shelled the battleground city of Aleppo and opposition groups reported heavy fighting around the Euphrates River city of Deir el-Zour.

headline: Shell to Test Capturing of Carbon in Canada
abstract: The project is intended to permanently store more than a million tons of carbon dioxide a year, which Shell said is equivalent to taking about 175,000 cars off the road.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In a bid to make oil sands production less polluting, Royal Dutch Shell announced on Wednesday that it would go forward with the first carbon capture and storage project ever tried in the fields of western Canada.

headline: Leaning Into the Learning Curve
abstract: Early in her first season playing professionally in Sweden, Yael Averbuch reflects on lessons from youth soccer, some of which still work and some that don’t.
lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — From the moment my dad bought me my first pair of cleats (he actually called them spikes, thanks to his running background … at least he didn’t call them boots) and shin guards, I have been bombarded with instructions and advice. Some things I’ve learned from coaches, videos and various experts have stuck with me over the years, and others I’ve chosen to throw by the wayside. In the spirit of my love of lists, here’s another!

headline: Al Jazeera Wrests Back Its Web Sites From Pro-Assad Hackers
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The news organization reported that the cyber attack lasted several hours, by affecting a third-party service provider that distributes the station’s online content worldwide in a security breach.
lead_paragraph: Updated | 6:15 p.m. Hackers said to be supporters of the Syrian government temporarily seized control of the Arabic and English news sites of Al Jazeera, the Qatari satellite network, which has been accused of bias in favor of protesters and rebels by the government of President Bashar al-Assad and its supporters.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Africa, Syria, Portugal and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Africa, Syria, Portugal and India.

abstract: Follow this post for live updates and analysis of the N.F.L.’s opening night game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Giants.
lead_paragraph: Follow this post for live updates and analysis of the N.F.L.’s opening night game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Giants from The Times’s Justin Sablich, who also provides fantasy football advice on The Fifth Down. Follow Sablich on Twitter at @JSablichNYT and @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Is the Venue Change Good for Obama?
abstract: It might save the president from the kind of ridicule he endured after his 2008 Denver address.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Obama campaign aides are mightily disappointed that a bad weather forecast has forced them to cancel President Obama’s plan to deliver his acceptance speech at a stadium, just as he did in Denver in 2008. Instead he’ll speak indoors at the smaller Time Warner Cable Arena.

headline: The Caucus Click: Gabby Douglas at the D.N.C.
abstract: Gabby Douglas, the gold-medal-winning gymnast from the London Olympics, walked across the stage during rehearsal for Wednesday’s events at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Reaping Secrets Ancestors Sowed
abstract: In Attica Locke’s “Cutting Season” a woman who grew up as the daughter of a cook on what was once a plantation now manages the house, which is a wedding hall and tourist attraction.
lead_paragraph: The slaves stand around the Louisiana plantation house wearing tattered calico and head scarves. They’re greeting party guests at Belle Vie, an antebellum manse turned tourist attraction. For $10.75 an hour, it’s not bad work.

headline: Sharapova Advances, With Rain to Rescue
abstract: Maria Sharapova recovered from a shaky start and outlasted Marion Bartoli, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, while Sara Errani beat her doubles partner, Roberta Vinci, 6-2, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: Rain may have made a mess of the United States Open for many players, but Maria Sharapova is a big fan.

headline: Kaushik Basu Named to World Bank Post
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: He will be the first Indian chief economist at the bank and the second from the developing world.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the World Bank announced its new chief economist: Kaushik Basu, a Cornell University economist and the former chief economic adviser to the Indian ministry of finance.

headline: Warhol Foundation Will Donate or Sell Its Whole Collection
abstract: The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts plans to disperse its cache of Andy Warhol’s work, including some unseen by the public, as it shifts to a focus on grants.
lead_paragraph: Beginning this fall the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts will disperse its entire collection of Warhols, donating some and selling others through Christie’s auction house as it shifts almost exclusively into a grant-making organization, foundation officials said in interviews.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Night at the D.N.C.

lead_paragraph: Amy Chozik of The New York Times talks about how this moment will highlight just how far Former President Bill Clinton has come to restore his relationship with the Democratic Party.

headline: The No-Waste, More-Work Lunch Box
abstract: Helping my children pack a “good mother” lunch makes me nostalgic for the foil-wrapped sandwich and baggie of chips of my childhood.
lead_paragraph: What’s in your child’s lunch box? If you’re a good parent, that lunch meets all of the big three requirements: it’s healthy, no-waste and allergen-free. The classic brown-paper-bag lunch of your childhood (P.B. & J. on white, chips, Twinkie, soda) is so last-century. It’s not just the nutrition-free content, it’s the packaging. (Although a few weeks of that lunch would surely get you a note from the school politely suggesting that less sugar might make for more learning.)

headline: Smartphone? Presto! 2-Way Radio
abstract: This new variation on electronic communication is quietly winning over millions of mobile device users.
lead_paragraph: Cave drawings, smoke signals, letters, Pony Express, telegrams, phone calls, text messages. From the dawn of civilization, man has experimented with different modes of communication, each with pros and cons. Smoke signals, for example, contribute to far fewer car accidents than text messages. Text messages, on the other hand, leave much less soot.

headline: Despite New Fame, Still Struck by Stars
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: When the two men behind TomandLorenzo.com are doing their jobs, they aren’t above falling apart near celebrities.
lead_paragraph: THE bloggers behind TomandLorenzo.com have been to countless fashion shows, but one stands out as surreal. It was Oscar de la Renta’s pre-fall collection last December, a tough ticket to score. Not only were the pair seated front row, but Anna Wintour was six seats away.

headline: ‘War Horse’ Is to Close in January
abstract: After slipping box-office grosses, “War Horse,” the award-winning hit Broadway play, will close in New York on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: In choosing to close the Tony Award-winning hit play “War Horse,” Lincoln Center Theater and its producing partners decided that the costs of running the show, with its elaborate production and cast of 37, were too big to guarantee profitability. The show is midway through its second year, an unusually long run for a nonmusical on Broadway.

headline: Ryan Says Prayer in Schools Is a State Issue
abstract: Prayer in public schools was prohibited by the Supreme Court in 1962, but Representative Paul D. Ryan said on Wednesday he believed states should have the right to decide whether it should be allowed.
lead_paragraph: PROVO, Utah — Prayer in public schools was prohibited by the United States Supreme Court in 1962, but Representative Paul D. Ryan said on Wednesday that he believed that states should have the right to decide whether it should be allowed.

headline: Report Assails Palm Oil Project in Cameroon
abstract: Two groups assert that a planned palm oil plantation would threaten wildlife and is opposed by many locals.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, we told you about land grabs by timber companies in Liberia that are threatening that country’s tropical rain forest. Today environmental groups and forestry experts are abuzz about a project in nearby Cameroon that is overseen by Herakles Farms, an affiliate of the New York-based company Herakles Capital that pursues agricultural initiatives in Africa.

headline: Spotify Is Said to Profit From Its Subscribers, but Lose More Luring Them
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Company Reports', 'Music', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: According to a report by Enders Analysis, a British research firm, the challenge for Spotify is how to add paying customers without giving away too much of what the report calls “expensive free music.”
lead_paragraph: Media Decoder recently looked at the books of Spotify and Pandora, two of the most popular digital music services, and noted that both companies — despite having very different business models — wind up paying most of their revenue in music royalties.

headline: Painting by the Beatles Heads to Auction
abstract: A painting created by all four Beatles in 1966 is being offered as part of a music memorabilia sale by Philip Weiss Auctions.
lead_paragraph: A painting created collaboratively by all four Beatles in 1966 is being offered as part of a music memorabilia sale by Philip Weiss Auctions, in Oceanside, N.Y., on Sept. 14. The auction house estimates that the painting, now called “Images of a Woman,” will sell for between $80,000 and $120,000.

headline: Despite Rainy Day, Dickey Records 18th Victory
abstract: R. A. Dickey became the first pitcher in the major leagues to reach 18 victories this year and Ike Davis hit a three-run home run to lead the Mets past the Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — R. A. Dickey added more credibility to his campaign for a Cy Young Award and took another step toward a 20-win season Wednesday afternoon, as he guided the Mets to a 6-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: For a Baby, Mobile Screens to Shake and Rattle
abstract: Think of the hundreds of baby-centric apps as sophisticated tactile toys for the 21st century. Here are some that can entertain or educate a child as young as 3 months.
lead_paragraph: My two babies have one thing in common that they don’t share with me. Some of their first toys were software apps on mobile devices that are more powerful than the computers that took Neil Armstrong to the moon.

headline: Two Veterans Give a Nod to a Talented Youngster
abstract: Michael Feinstein and Marilyn Maye, delivering pop and jazz standards at Feinstein’s, are a perfect show-business fit.
lead_paragraph: Michael Feinstein, Marilyn Maye and Justin Bieber, together at last. Well, not quite. But at the opening on Tuesday night of Mr. Feinstein and Ms. Maye’s show “Swingin’ the Night Away” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, the big surprise was the appearance of a fresh-faced 16-year-old crooner, Nick Ziobro.

lead_paragraph: The California native (who lives in Catalonia, Spain, the sport’s new epicenter) on the challenges of rock climbing.

headline: Putin Pulls Off Latest Feat: Flying With the Birds
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia piloted a motorized hang glider over an Arctic wilderness area while guiding a flock of migratory birds toward their winter habitat as part of an operation called “The Flight of Hope.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vladimir V. Putin is the unquestioned supreme leader of Russia, known for his icy stare and steely ways. But now Mr. Putin has taken on a new, perhaps more tender, leadership role. He has guided a flock of birds — through the air.

lead_paragraph: For years, two major Amsterdam museums — the Stedelijk and the Rijksmuseum — have been largely closed for renovations, with only some of their prized artworks on public view. But that is about to change.

lead_paragraph: The best-selling author Jodi Picoult has jumped to Ballantine Bantam Dell from Atria for her next book deal, a three-book acquisition that the company announced on Wednesday. The first novel is scheduled for release in 2014. Ms. Picoult is the author of 19 novels including “Sing You Home” and “House Rules.” Her novels have more than 22 million copies in print.

headline: Stone Links: Is Doping Cheating?
abstract: In this week’s links: the ethics of human enhancement, Wittgensteinian vision, and more.
lead_paragraph: Human enhancement has been high on the minds of philosophers in the wake of the Lance Armstrong affair. At The Atlantic, Evan Selinger wonders how the argument “that Armstrong still deserves our sympathy even if he is guilty of using banned substances” might affect our approach to problems like sustainability and climate change. Feeling bad for Lance, Selinger suggests, is roughly analogous to “feeling bad for the present state of the world,” and thus less conducive to attacking its problems.

abstract: A selection of 14th-century parables reworked by the Chinese government to encourage parental devotion in modern times.
lead_paragraph: A selection of 14th-century parables reworked by the Chinese government to encourage parental devotion in modern times.

headline: For U.S. Open Grounds Crew, an Arsenal to Combat Wet Courts
abstract: After every rain delay at the U.S. Open, 75 or so workers use an array of machines to push hundreds of gallons of water off the courts, then get on their hands and knees and use towels to mop up what’s left.
lead_paragraph: For most of last week, they were out of sight, out of mind. This week, they have been working around the clock.

lead_paragraph: BRADLEY DARRYL WONG is finally settling into his apartment. Not that the place, a ground-floor loft with a subterranean bedroom on East Fourth Street, is new, exactly. Mr. Wong, otherwise known as B. D., bought it in 2005 and moved in, sort of, four years ago.

headline: Hearing Voices in the Clutter
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The task of excavating 20 years of family possessions leaves a hole in the heart.
lead_paragraph: HOUSES, if we look and listen, have secrets to tell us. I didn’t fully understand my parents until I finally faced up to emptying their house. Doing so would have been hard at any time, but it was even harder because I had waited 20 years after their deaths.

lead_paragraph: The founders of the Brooklyn design firm Workstead go shopping for special-height stools for kitchen islands.

headline: Counter Stools
abstract: A relatively new development, the kitchen island calls for a special-height stool.
lead_paragraph: IN planning kitchens for clients, the founders of the Brooklyn design firm Workstead have discovered there’s one piece of furniture that is particularly hard to find: the counter-height stool.

headline: Open Teams at Second World Mind Sports Games
abstract: The performance by Sweden in winning the Open Teams at the Second World Mind Sports Games in France last month was remarkable.
lead_paragraph: The performance by Sweden in winning the Open Teams at the Second World Mind Sports Games in France last month was remarkable.

headline: Designing Sets for Oprah, Ellen, Tyra and Now Ricki
abstract: The production designer Anton Goss takes cues from his clients’ home décor when designing their talk show sets.
lead_paragraph: Ricki Lake, who next week begins her second go-round as a daytime talk-show host with “The Ricki Lake Show,” lives in a house that’s beautiful but “not too precious,” likes the color purple and follows “a somewhat green lifestyle.” She also wanted her new set to feel less like a stage and more “like someone’s living room, where everyone’s opinion is heard.”

headline: Turning the Tables on Gravity
abstract: Fifty plywood discs stacked together form an asymmetrical table that defies gravity.
lead_paragraph: Marcello Pozzi, the Italian architect and designer now living in Los Angeles, has designed his first mass-produced piece for the home. Commissioned by Restoration Hardware for its fall line, the Stack 50 table consists of 50 discs of plywood. Forty-eight inches wide, it has a metal disc embedded in the tabletop that secures a metal rod to keep the discs in place, and an asymmetrical base that juts hither and yon in the spirit of a bonsai. The table costs $2,495, and much is made in the promotional materials of its design: “Stack 50 taunts gravity by shifting each disc away from the rod’s axis.”

headline: Eye Candy With a Sweet Center
abstract: Available in October, this versatile light fixture demands to be touched.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Johnson’s goal in designing Kiss for Artecnica was to create a lamp that demands to be touched. “It was important for me to give it a real physicality,” said Mr. Johnson, a London-based designer, adding that the versatile piece can be plunked on a desk as a task lamp or dangled over a table as a pendant. “It’s something you want to pick up and explore.”

headline: Explorations in Glass, Deceptively Simple
abstract: The Belgian designer Sylvain Willenz experiments with the moody material.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, the Belgian designer Sylvain Willenz began working with CIRVA, a research center in Marseilles, France, to explore new ways to manipulate glass. Today, in a show called “Glassworks,” the Victor Hunt gallery in Brussels will unveil the results of his experiments with the moody material: Shift, an asymmetrical side table (about $11,100); Spot, a globe-shaped lamp sprinkled with glass shards (about $4,160); and Block, above, a collection of geometric containers (from about $1,575).

headline: Accessories That Can Withstand a Little Steam
abstract: With his multipurpose bathroom accessories made of silicone, the designer Josh Owen has been exploring what he calls other “overlooked opportunities” for that often overlooked room.
lead_paragraph: Since the release of his first collection of bathroom accessories for Kontextür earlier this year, Josh Owen has been exploring what he calls other “overlooked opportunities” for that often overlooked room. Four of them were introduced last month at the New York International Gift Fair: two mirrors, a toilet-paper holder and a towel rack/accessories holder, all in silicone. “The bathroom is such a wet environment, and most things are made of materials that are fighting the relationship with moisture,” Mr. Owen said. Silicone “can live on in perpetuity in those challenging conditions.”

headline: Sales at Sferra, Desiron, Westin Hotels and Resorts and Others

lead_paragraph: Sferra will offer up to 75 percent off first-quality discontinued and overstocked bedding from Wednesday to Sept. 16 (a queen-size Sasha 100-percent Egyptian cotton sateen jacquard duvet set, above, usually $890, will be $445; a queen-size Franco 600-thread-count cotton sheet set, usually $190, will be $75); Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), sferra.com.

lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Orioles are expecting sellouts, or close to them, when they host the Yankees beginning Thursday night for what is arguably their biggest four-game series since 1997.

headline: As China Ages, Beijing Turns to Morality Tales to Spur Filial Devotion
abstract: China’s updated book of parables, “The 24 Paragons of Filial Piety,” has drawn ridicule for not addressing the complexities of life that keep children from taking care of their parents.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Reading it now, six centuries after Guo Jujing wrote this paean to parental devotion, “The 24 Paragons of Filial Piety” comes off as a collection of scary bedtime stories. There is the woman who cut out her own liver to feed her sick mother, the boy who sat awake shirtless all night to draw mosquitoes away from his slumbering parents and the man who sold himself into servitude to pay for a father’s funeral.

headline: Chavez Takes Part in Pregame Ritual
abstract: The Yankees tried to change their luck on Tuesday by having Eric Chavez take the lineup card to the umpires. It didn’t work.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Eric Chavez wants to be a major league manager one day, and he got some practice Tuesday night when he was asked, minutes before the first pitch, to carry the lineup card to the home plate conference with the umpires.

headline: Same Museum, but a Brand-New Look
abstract: The thoughtful renovation of art museums, rather than building new showcases, has been enjoying a renaissance, and several examples are reopening this fall.
lead_paragraph: FOR a few years there, museum construction projects seemed to be synonymous with lavish and expensive new architecture. But lately the thoughtful renovation of existing buildings has enjoyed something of a renaissance, and this fall a few notable examples are coming to fruition.

headline: Making Room for Returning Offspring
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Do It Yourself', 'Beds and Bedding']
abstract: A loft bed, built in three days, can work well in a tight space.
lead_paragraph: OUR 23-year-old daughter, Rikki, recently returned home from nursing school to embark on her career, and found she had been downsized by her loving siblings to the worst bedroom in the house: a dark 63-square-foot green vise that’s less than half the size of her previous room.

headline: Reaction to Change of Venue for Obama’s Speech
abstract: While a decision to move President Obama’s speech at the Democratic National Convention to a smaller venue might have left some volunteers and visitors here feeling left out in the cold — or the rain, as the weather forecast was predicting — many took it in stride, their support for the President undiminished.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — While a decision to move President Obama’s speech at the Democratic National Convention to a smaller venue might have left some volunteers and visitors here feeling left out in the cold — or the rain, as the weather forecast was predicting — many took it in stride, their support for the President undiminished.

headline: Romney Focus Is on Preparing for the Debates
abstract: As Democrats formally nominate President Obama, Mitt Romney is getting ready for what aides believe will be a decisive moment for his campaign.
lead_paragraph: WEST WINDSOR, Vt. — The sessions begin at 9 a.m. in the living room of a friend’s mountainside getaway here in Vermont’s verdant interior. There are three folding tables: one for Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, who plays President Obama; one for Peter Flaherty, a senior aide who plays the moderator; and one for Mitt Romney, who plays himself.

headline: Qatar Imperils Big Merger of Commodity Companies

lead_paragraph: A huge merger in the natural resources business is close to falling apart.

headline: Germany: Officials in Berlin Clarify Guidelines on Circumcision
abstract: To create legal clarity since a court ruling in June equated circumcision with bodily injury, justice officials in Berlin laid out guidelines to allow the practice to continue in the city.
lead_paragraph: In the first move to create legal clarity since a court ruling in June equated circumcision with bodily injury, justice officials in Berlin laid out guidelines on Wednesday to allow the practice to continue in the city pending nationwide legislation that is expected to back the procedure. The move comes after an outcry from doctors who feared they could be prosecuted for carrying out circumcisions after the June 26 ruling in a Cologne court. While it is not applicable in other jurisdictions, it created legal confusion across the country. The ruling also provoked strong protests from religious communities in Germany and abroad. The Berlin guidelines stipulate that both parents must confirm they wish to have their son circumcised because of religious beliefs and that the practice must be performed in a sterile environment.

headline: $1 Pizza Slice Is Back After a Sidewalk Showdown Ends Two Parlors’ Price War
keywords: ['Pizza', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The pizzerias, a few feet apart on Avenue of the Americas, both raised their prices after cutting them to 75 cents a slice in March.
lead_paragraph: The signs have been changed. The invectives have softened. The products remain, well, unlikely to win any culinary awards.

headline: Gay Democrats Celebrate a Newfound Visibility
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Homosexuality', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Nearly every speech at the Democratic National Convention has mentioned gay rights issues, including Michelle Obama’s.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — After years of struggling for attention and recognition from the nation’s political parties, gays and lesbians have catapulted to the forefront of the Democratic convention here, prominent on the stage, in speeches, in the platform and at parties that go on after the proceedings have finished.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Like the Army Itself, Recruiters Prepare to Make Do With Less
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Economy', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Army is remaking its recruiting structure amid concerns over whether budget cuts scheduled for 2013 will make joining the service a tougher sell.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From Uncle Sam saying “I want YOU” through “Be All You Can Be” to today’s “Army Strong,” the United States Army has tailored its recruiting strategy to fill its ranks in war and in peace, in the years of the draft and with an all-volunteer force. It has reframed its education targets, sometimes opening its doors to high school dropouts, at other times pursuing college graduates and, more recently, finding a way to assess home-schooled students.

headline: Russia: Police Convoy Is Attacked in Restive Ingushetia
abstract: Five people died and at least one was wounded when a police convoy came under attack on Wednesday in the volatile southern Russian republic of Ingushetia.
lead_paragraph: Five people died and at least one was wounded when a police convoy came under attack on Wednesday in the volatile southern Russian republic of Ingushetia. A hidden explosive device ripped through the first of the convoy’s two vehicles as it moved through the republic’s Sunzhen district, said a local official of the Investigative Committee. Unidentified fighters then opened fire from a nearby wooded area before fleeing, the Investigative Committee said. Officials have begun an investigation and are searching for the attackers. The bombing came after several weeks of increased violence in the North Caucasus region.

headline: Republicans Use Lopez Case as a Weapon
abstract: The G.O.P. is seeking to make Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez’s sexual harassment scandal a campaign issue against Democrats.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — New York Republicans, sensing that the sexual harassment allegations against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez could become a liability for Democrats, are moving to make the scandal a campaign issue.

headline: Leak Prompts Netanyahu to Cancel Security Cabinet Meeting on Iran Issue
abstract: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, angrily cut short a key gathering of top security officials, accusing an unnamed participant of leaking details of the sensitive meeting to the media.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu abruptly canceled a meeting of his security cabinet on Wednesday, saying information was leaked from the highly confidential deliberations, a security failure that could undermine his efforts to project a unified front to the West about how to deal with Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Illinois: Man Sues Over Terrorist Status
abstract: In the suit the man, Muhammad A. Salah, says, in essence, that it is impossible for him to lead a normal life without seeking approval from the government.
lead_paragraph: A Bridgeview man has filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking to lift restrictions placed on him by the Department of Treasury when it deemed him a “specially designated terrorist” in 1995. In the suit the man, Muhammad A. Salah, says, in essence, that it is impossible for him to lead a normal life — to open a bank account, get a job or donate to his mosque — without seeking approval from the government. In 2007, Mr. Salah was convicted of lying in a civil lawsuit about ties to Hamas, the Palestinian organization, but he was acquitted of more serious charges of racketeering conspiracy after prosecutors accused him of helping to funnel aid to Hamas. A spokesman for the Treasury Department, named as a defendant in the suit, said he could not comment on pending litigation.

headline: Young Golfer Makes Progress in Focusing on Process
abstract: After earning his first PGA Tour victory in February, Kyle Stanley was surprised by how empty he felt. He has since taken on a more holistic approach.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL, Ind. — It started with a shy request, made last week on the eve of the Deutsche Bank Championship. Kyle Stanley found himself on the practice green alongside Steve Stricker, one of the best putters in the game, so he asked if he could look at his stroke.

headline: Emanuel Takes On New Role as a ‘Super PAC’ Wrangler
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Rahm Emanuel’s departure from the Obama campaign reflects Democrats’ worries about the fund-raising gap enjoyed by Republican-leaning outside groups.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Senior Democrats put aside any remaining qualms about jumping into the “super PAC” era, enlisting Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago to focus on raising money for outside groups that are seeking to help the White House rather than keep a leadership role in President Obama’s re-election campaign.

headline: Gaza: Israeli Airstrike Kills Three Militants
abstract: An Israeli airstrike killed three Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip late Wednesday and seriously wounded a fourth, according to Palestinian and Israeli officials.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike killed three Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip late Wednesday and seriously wounded a fourth, according to Palestinian and Israeli officials. Israel said the militants had been preparing to launch a rocket to attack Israel. The raid came days after Palestinian militants fired about a dozen rockets into southern Israel from Gaza, the coastal enclave controlled by Hamas. Groups affiliated with Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for those attacks and criticized Hamas this week for cracking down on them.

headline: Manning Fails to Solve Cowboys’ New Look on Defense
abstract: Eli Manning, the two-time Super Bowl most valuable player, found limited opportunities against the Cowboys. He completed 21 of 32 passes for 213 yards and a touchdown.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning got a different look when he surveyed the Dallas defense in the season opener. For the most part, he did not like what he saw in a 24-17 loss to the Cowboys on Wednesday night.

headline: Missouri: Bishop Will Face Judge, Not Jury
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Priests', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The trial of Bishop Robert W. Finn and the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph on charges of failure to report suspected child abuse avoids a lengthy public trial that was set to start Sept. 24.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Bishop Robert W. Finn and the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph on charges of failure to report suspected child abuse has been moved up to Thursday and will be decided by a judge, not a jury. The change was made public in a court filing on Wednesday, and avoids a lengthy public trial that was set to start Sept. 24. Bishop Finn is the first Roman Catholic prelate in the country to be indicted in the sexual abuse scandals. He and the diocese each face two misdemeanor counts of failing to report hundreds of lewd photographs of young girls on a laptop computer belonging to the Rev. Shawn Ratigan. Father Ratigan pleaded guilty to pornography charges in August.

headline: Texas: Mosquito Spraying Shows Results
abstract: Officials said the insects had declined by 93 percent in places that received two consecutive nights of spraying.
lead_paragraph: State health officials said Wednesday that the death toll from West Nile virus continues to rise, but they were encouraged by data that suggested the virus had peaked in the Dallas area. The mosquito-borne disease has sickened hundreds of people there and killed 13. A recent spraying operation in the area appeared to reduce the population of mosquitoes. Officials said the insects had declined by 93 percent in places that received two consecutive nights of spraying. Nationwide, 1,993 cases have been reported, including 87 deaths, a 25 percent increase over last week’s numbers. In Texas, there have been 1,113 cases, including 40 deaths, the most fatalities of any state.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department said Wednesday that Iraq has an obligation under United Nations Security Council resolutions to insist that Iranian planes that are suspected of flying arms to Syria over Iraqi airspace land so the cargo can be inspected.

headline: Georgia: Fraud Suspected at Family Services
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Falsification of Data']
abstract: The state is investigating whether child-protection officials falsified records to qualify for millions of dollars in federal money.
lead_paragraph: The state is investigating whether child-protection officials falsified records to qualify for millions of dollars in federal money. Agents raided a Division of Family and Children Services office in Columbus on Wednesday and issued arrest warrants for two former officials. The former director, Deborah Cobb, and a protective services supervisor, Phyllis Mitchell, were charged with destroying, changing and falsifying child abuse reports. They are suspected of having falsified reports to make it seem as if they had met federal rules for investigating abuse in a timely way.

abstract: Dr. Cermak’s tunnel, which was roughly 10 times as long as aeronautical tunnels, could produce vertical wind currents and simulate powerful gusts.
lead_paragraph: Jack E. Cermak, an engineer who was among the first to use a wind tunnel to gauge the wind’s impact on skyscrapers and who did consulting work on the World Trade Center and the Sears Tower, among other projects, died Aug. 21 at his home in Fort Collins, Colo. He was 89.

headline: Wide Area of Nation Still Parched After Storm
abstract: Many states, and their crops, saw very little rain from Hurricane Isaac’s remnants.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The remnants of Hurricane Isaac that blew through the middle of the country over the weekend softened the worst drought in decades in some areas, but a large portion of the nation remains desiccated with ponds still too shallow to water cattle, fields too dusty for feeding and crops beyond the point of salvage, meteorologists and agriculture experts said Wednesday.

headline: Joe South, Singer and Writer of Hit Songs, Dies at 72

The Phillies collapsed so dramatically in 1964, losing 10 games in a row to blow a six-and-a-half-game lead, that the performance stood for decades as a benchmark for choking.

headline: Despite Protections, Botanists Fear Drought’s Toll on a Pink-Petaled Rarity
abstract: Dry conditions across the country, including Long Island, are worrying the botanists closely monitoring the area’s six populations of sandplain gerardia.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — At the eastern end of Long Island, on the South Fork, tucked among the wobbly clam shacks and the steroidal homes, there are a few small grassy plots sectioned off by short chicken-wire fences. The wire is rusty, and the wooden posts that hold it upright are weathered to a milky gray. One plot is not far from a cliff that drops straight to the sea. Another is within eyeshot of a condominium association’s swimming pool.

headline: A Touchy Relationship
abstract: After Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s trip failed to get deals on two big items, Beijing and Washington have a long way to go to translate soothing rhetoric into action.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was in a philosophical frame of mind on Wednesday as she surveyed the impasse between the United States and China on a daunting range of issues. “Our two nations,” she said, “are trying to do something that has never been done in history, which is to write a new answer to the question of what happens when an established power and a rising power meet.” As the secretary’s fifth trip to China demonstrated, that is proving to be a complicated process.

headline: An AK-47 in a Tennessee Park

abstract: The Constitution does not let someone go into a public place with a legal handgun and terrify the public.
lead_paragraph: In camouflage gear one Sunday afternoon, Leonard Embody went into a state park near Nashville carrying a Draco AK-47 pistol fully loaded with 30 rounds to test his constitutional rights. Frightened visitors reported that a man was in the park with an “assault rifle.” A park ranger, thinking the weapon might be ready to fire, sensibly ordered Mr. Embody to the ground, removed his gun, patted him down for other weapons and detained him.

headline: Louisiana: Storm Churns Up Oil Off Coast
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'Water Pollution', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hurricane Isaac (2012)', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']
abstract: The area that was among the hardest hit by the BP spill that state wildlife officials announced the emergency closing of some coastal waters to commercial fishing.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Isaac churned up enough oil in a part of south Louisiana that was among the hardest hit by the BP spill that state wildlife officials announced the emergency closing of some coastal waters to commercial fishing. Six heavy tar mats were found just offshore of a 13-mile stretch of sandy and marshy coastline, and tar balls were found on the beach as well. Tests are being performed to determine whether the oil belongs to the well drilled by the Deepwater Horizon, and results are expected within days. “It possibly could be our oil, but we don’t know,” said Ray Melick, a spokesman for BP, adding that crews were engaged in cleanup activities in the area only days before the storm.

abstract: Novak Djokovic, the defending Open champion, seems to be waging a one-man campaign to cover courts with tarps during rain delays.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic, the defending men’s champion at the United States Open, seems to be waging a one-man campaign for tarps at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. At last year’s Open, after two days of play were wiped out by rain, Djokovic said, “What I have to say is I just don’t understand why, you know, if you have ‑‑ for example, if you don’t have a roof, O.K., on this Grand Slam, why you don’t have covers on the court, you know?”

headline: The Buddy to Shop With
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Mr. Porter, an online-only men’s shopping outlet, is a sharp collection of men’s wear that cuts across all style boundaries.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES you have occasion to look inside a stranger’s closet (hey, it happens), and you can see what they’re about. I recently had that opportunity and, affixed to the inside of the door, the gentleman in question had a Mr Porter sticker with his name on it. I didn’t know very much about the guy, but quickly, I understood him.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Announces Winners of Project Pop-Up N.Y.C.
abstract: Today in an effort to support fashion and technology entrepreneurs Mayor Bloomberg announced the winners of Project Pop-UP N.Y.C., a competition that the Mayor’s office and the Economic Development Corporation.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, in an effort to support fashion and technology entrepreneurs Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced the winners of Project Pop-UP N.Y.C., a competition that the mayor’s office and the Economic Development Corporation. Would-be winners had four weeks to get their applications in starting from the end of June. The nine application questions solicited thetype of information that one would put on a business plan: Who is your competition, and how are you different or better? Who is on your management team? What market does it address, and how big is thismarket?

lead_paragraph: WHILE designers parade their creations this week and next on the New York runways, the Danziger Gallery in Chelsea is bringing fashion back to street level with an exhibition by the photographer Scott Schuman, whose blog, The Sartorialist, has made him one of fashion’s most notable documentarians.

lead_paragraph: IT takes a lot of nerve to have an art opening on the first night of Fashion Week — which is also Fashion’s Night Out, in case you hadn’t heard. Andy Valmorbida isn’t worried. This is the fourth time that Mr. Valmorbida, the young pop-up exhibitionist and cocky Australian-born art entrepreneur, has crashed the all-important night with a big party. He says the timing is coincidental. Oh, sure.

headline: Bill Clinton Speaks

headline: A Startling Truth Amid the Hyperbole
keywords: ['Homeowner Affordability and Stability Plan', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Democrats have made a number of misleading claims about taxes, civil liberties and a Mitt Romney quote. But Bill Clinton’s claim about job creation under Democratic presidents appears to be true.
lead_paragraph: Speakers at the Democratic National Convention used an out-of-context quote on Wednesday night to give the misleading impression that Mitt Romney enjoys firing people, and some referred imprecisely to his tax proposals. The party’s platform also contained questionable assertions about President Obama’s record on civil liberties.

headline: The Slaughter of Elephants in Vietnam Is Nearly Complete
abstract: An “epic slaughter” of wild elephants is under way in Africa, with tens of thousands being killed every year for their ivory. Poachers have already done their worst in Vietnam, where only a few dozen elephants remain in the wild.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The plight of elephants in Africa is being explained, in graphic and saddening detail, in a new series of stories by my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman of The New York Times. “An epic elephant slaughter,” he calls it, with poachers wiping out tens of thousands of elephants a year for their ivory.

headline: Libyan Alleges Waterboarding by C.I.A., Report Says
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Waterboarding', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Torture', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Interrogations']
abstract: A new report by Human Rights Watch, based on interviews with 14 Libyans, documents accounts of detention in Afghanistan and, in one case, of waterboarding by the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days after the Justice Department closed out its criminal investigation of the deaths of two detainees while in the custody of the C.I.A., new information has surfaced calling into question official accounts of the extent of waterboarding by American interrogators.

headline: Clinton Delivers Impassioned Plea for Obama Second Term
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton drew sharp lines between the choices voters face, using the economic successes in his presidency as a case for re-electing President Obama.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Former President Bill Clinton and President Obama hugged onstage Wednesday night after Mr. Clinton delivered an impassioned plea on behalf of Mr. Obama’s re-election, the 42nd president nominating the 44th to a second term with a forceful and spirited argument that Democratic values would restore the promise of the middle class.

headline: After Pregame Pomp, a Pratfall
abstract: Eli Manning, sacked three times by the Dallas defense, struggled to find a rhythm on offense for the Giants, and Tony Romo passed for 307 yards and 3 touchdowns in the Cowboys’ victory.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants players and coaches were adamant this past week that they had moved on. The Super Bowl victory was months ago, they said, and last season was in the past. Coach Tom Coughlin even invoked his pithy phrase-of-the-moment, “Build the Bridge,” more often than usual to remind everyone that the goal now is to link the 2011 title season to this one.

abstract: Quarterback Tony Romo led the Cowboys to becoming the first team since the N.F.L. began staging a kickoff spectacular in 2004 to beat a defending Super Bowl champion.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

lead_paragraph: Opening night of the N.F.L. season was opening night for the replacement referees.

headline: A Fuller Explanation of Bain Stories Told at Democratic Convention
abstract: The basic outlines of the stories told at the Democratic convention about layoffs and plant closings that occurred after Bain bought three companies were accurate, but they lacked context and mitigating details.
lead_paragraph: The three people who told their stories about their experiences with Mitt Romney’s firm, Bain Capital, Wednesday night during the Democratic National Convention laid out the by-now-familiar Democratic critique that he prized profits over people during his 15-year career in private equity and that he was a job destroyer, rather than a job creator.

lead_paragraph: The rousing start to the Democratic convention here in Charlotte, N.C., makes last week’s Republican convocation in Tampa, Fla., look like, well, a tea party.

headline: Boy, 2 Months, Is Grazed by a Bullet

lead_paragraph: A 2-month-old boy was grazed by a bullet in the Bronx on Wednesday night, the police said.

headline: 4 Years Later, Scarred but Still Confident
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2008']
abstract: President Obama is making the case that while progress is slow, he is taking America to a better place — and that he will be a better president over the next four years than the last.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — He warned them in 2008, and when he formally opened his re-election campaign in May, he put it in his speech again. He will “never be a perfect president,” he said, a line he now repeats at stop after stop. The unspoken subtext: It’s not my fault if you didn’t listen or expected too much.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Federer Always Seems to Be Lurking
abstract: After Andy Murray came back to beat Marin Cilic in the quarterfinals of the United States Open on Wednesday, attention turned, as it usually has for Murray lately, to Roger Federer. Murray detailed his rivalry with Federer, who later lost to Tomas Berdych.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after Andy Murray came back to beat Marin Cilic, the No. 12 seed from Croatia, 3-6, 7-6 (4), 6-2, 6-0, in the quarterfinals of the United States Open on Wednesday, attention turned, as it usually has for Murray lately, to Roger Federer. In his regular postmatch conversation with Straight Sets, Murray detailed his rivalry with Federer, who later was upset by Tomas Berdych.

headline: India’s Latest Reservations Bill Stirs Controversy
abstract: The bill is the latest volley between political parties and the Supreme Court over the issue.
lead_paragraph: In a measure that could expand India’s affirmative action programs, the government introduced a bill Wednesday that would make it easier to grant promotions to members of India’s lowest castes and tribal people in government jobs.

headline: Carine Roitfeld’s New Magazine
abstract: The first issue of CR, which has been the subject of much speculation since Ms. Roitfeld, after leaving French Vogue in December 2010, announced she would start her own title, comes with a theme of rebirth.
lead_paragraph: The first issue of CR, which has been the subject of much speculation since Ms. Roitfeld, after leaving French Vogue in December 2010, announced she would start her own title, comes with a theme of rebirth.

headline: Who Built That?

abstract: American success and growth has drawn on a deep partnership between business and government, a history and practical approach that many Republicans seem eager to deny, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson is Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund. His books include “13 Bankers.”

headline: Embedded on the Front Lines of the Digital Revolution

lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — When Doug Menuez covered the Ethiopian famine in 1985 for Newsweek, he was devastated by the sheer scale of human suffering and by his inability to do anything about it.

abstract: Give us your playlist for inspiration, then tell us why you chose it and what it inspires you to do, think about or feel.
lead_paragraph: In honor of Fashion Week, The Times asked 10 fashion designers what tunes have aided their creative vision. How would you answer that question? What music inspires you — whether to create things, or to exercise, study, pursue a hobby or just to feel good in general?

headline: O.E.C.D. Warns of Recession in Germany
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned that Germany, Europe’s pre-eminent economic force, could not stand apart from the euro zone’s problems
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The euro zone’s woes are finally taking their toll on Germany, the European economic powerhouse that has long avoided the worst of the crisis that began two and a half years ago.

headline: A Conversation With: Author and Police Officer Nazrul Islam
abstract: Author of a controversial book for Muslims answers questions about standing up to government, vote bank politics and his future plans.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA – Despite his reputation as a tough, no-nonsense police officer who has stood up to the government on several occasions, Nazrul Islam is soft-spoken and gentle, even when refusing to discuss the controversy surrounding his latest book, “Musalmander Koroniyo” (What Muslims Should Do).

headline: Qantas in a Venture to Improve International Reach
abstract: A new 10-year partnership ended a previous alliance between the Australian carrier and British Airways, and aimed to reverse losses on Qantas’s international business.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Qantas Airways of Australia said Thursday it had ended a long-running partnership with British Airways and would instead form one with Emirates of Dubai on European routes in an effort to help turn around its beleaguered international operations.

headline: Lost in Time in the Antarctic Ice Age
abstract: At Concordia Station, researchers track their circadian rhythms by measuring levels of hormones like cortisol and melatonin in urine and saliva over 24-hour periods.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agency’s human spaceflight program.

headline: Tip Sheet | How to Succeed in College
abstract: In a letter to recent high school graduates, college counselors give parting words of wisdom to students as they transition to college life, including a reminder to “always go to class.”
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Durso-Finley and Holly Burks Becker are co-directors of college counseling at the Lawrenceville School in Lawrenceville, N.J.

headline: What to Watch on Thursday
abstract: Novak Djokovic, the defending U.S. Open champion, faces Juan Martin del Potro in the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: It took Novak Djokovic barely more than 90 minutes to go up by two sets and a break over Stanislas Wawrinka on Wednesday before his opponent called it quits — another dominant performance for the defending champion. Through four matches at the United States Open, Djokovic has lost just 20 games and has not dropped a set.

headline: San Francisco 49ers, 2012 N.F.L. Season Preview
abstract: Imagine how different the N.F.L. could be right now if Kyle Williams hadn’t muffed that punt in overtime of the N.F.C. championship game.
lead_paragraph: Today, Andy Benoit completes his marathon tour of  32 team previews. The final team is the 49ers, his pick to win the N.F.C. West.  A complete look at Andy’s work this summer is available here.

headline: Shopping for a Nursing Home? There’s a Tool for That
abstract: A new interactive tool from ProPublica allows you to search and compare nursing home inspection reports.

headline: The Migron Settlement Myth
abstract: Too eager to evacuate Migron without a clash, Israel’s leaders have failed to question the wisdom of moving the settlers just a couple of miles away.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Sunday was an eventless day. Yes, Migron, the most famous of illegal Jewish outposts in the West Bank, was evacuated. But nothing happened, really. The move was peaceful, with only minor protests. The settlers’ warnings that they’d resist proved hollow, and the government’s fear that they might, baseless.

headline: Sept. 5: Looking Ahead After Charlotte
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Measuring the bounce the incumbent party gets out of its convention is trickier than doing so for the challenger, but a golf analogy can help us to understand the possibilities.
lead_paragraph: There was almost nothing worth talking about in the polls that were out on Wednesday. So let’s take a quick look forward instead — to about a week from now, by which point we will have plenty of data on what effect the Democratic National Convention had on the polls.

lead_paragraph: The former N.F.L. director of officials Mike Pereira, who has supported his former colleagues in their labor dispute with the N.F.L., gave the replacement officials a passing grade in the Dallas-Giants game on Wednesday. Pereira, now a Fox analyst, wrote on FoxSports.com:

lead_paragraph: Chocolaty, citrusy, sugary or savory.

headline: Short and Sweet
abstract: A dozen (or so) easy variations on the perfect shortbread cookie.
lead_paragraph: If you use half a pound of butter in a batch of cookies, it becomes “short” — because “short” means, historically, pastry with a high percentage of fat.

headline: How Dangerous Is Your Couch?
abstract: One woman’s crusade to rid our lives of flame-retardant chemicals.
lead_paragraph: In September 1976, a mail runner from Katmandu arrived at Base Camp on Mount Everest with a package for Dr. Arlene Blum, a member of the American Bicentennial Everest Expedition. The package had nothing to do with the climb, or Blum’s status as the first American woman to attempt the world’s highest peak. It concerned pajamas. Inside were the proofs of an article she co-wrote for the journal Science about a chemical then widely used in children’s sleepwear. The subtitle was unusually blunt for a scientific paper: “The main flame retardant in children’s pajamas is a mutagen and should not be used.”

headline: Are the Big Banks Keeping Their Commitment to Small Businesses?
abstract: Last September, 13 of the nation’s largest banks promised to increase their lending to small businesses by $20 billion over three years. How’s that going?
lead_paragraph: Last September in Cleveland, 13 of the nation’s largest banks stood beside Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Karen Mills, chief of the Small Business Administration, and announced a commitment to increase small-business lending by $20 billion over the following three years.

headline: A Phone That Can Take a Dunking
abstract: The Kyocera Hydro, available without a contract through Boost Mobile, is waterproof for up to 30 minutes in water about three feet deep with no additional protective case.
lead_paragraph: People prone to dropping their phones in the drink – a drop in the toilet is one of the most common cellphone accidents — are usually condemned to buying vaultlike cases to protect their phones from everything including the kitchen sink.

headline: Daily Report: Motorola and Nokia Fight for a Shred of the Smartphone Market
abstract: Motorola Mobility and Nokia unveiled their latest smartphones just ahead of Apple’s introduction of its next iPhone.
lead_paragraph: In the smartphone market, Apple and Samsung have become the two giants. Is there room for a third?

headline: Climate Change and the Food Supply
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Food', 'Global Warming', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Wheat']
abstract: A new report offers a stark warning about potential crop shortages and soaring prices; another proposes a possible way to avoid catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: 1:30 p.m. | Updated A small bit of good news about food prices from the Food and Agriculture Organization, a United Nations agency in Rome: The price spiral seen earlier this summer as markets reacted to droughts and other bad news has leveled off, with the agency’s closely watched index of global food prices essentially unchanged in August compared with July.

headline: Grading the Giants With All-22 Film
abstract: One Giants blog is restructuring to take advantage of the new insights available from film that only N.F.L. coaches were once privy to.
lead_paragraph: For a fee, fans this season can see full-length game film that was once exclusive to N.F.L. personnel. The film, known as the All-22, shows the whole field and all 22 players on it.

headline: Tip of the Week: Linux on a Stick
abstract: If you are not sure Linux is for you, you can give it a test drive from a USB stick or a CD before you install it.
lead_paragraph: An aging computer that cannot quite meet the requirements for a Windows 7 upgrade can sometimes find a few more years of usefulness with a switch to the Linux operating system. Ubuntu, which makes a free and easy-to-use version of Linux, has traditionally made it easy to try out the system by posting instructions for making a compact disc that can boot up and run Linux for a test drive before installing it. But for old computers with broken disc drives, Ubuntu Linux can also be run from a USB flash drive. The Ubuntu site has detailed instructions here for making a bootable USB stick (or CD) with the current version of Ubuntu from either a Windows or Mac computer, and an online demo here.

headline: Huge Step Taken by Europe’s Bank to Abate a Crisis
abstract: The European Central Bank took its broadest step yet toward easing the euro zone crisis, throwing its financial clout behind an effort to fend off financial collapse for Spain and Italy.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank on Thursday took its most ambitious step yet toward easing the euro zone crisis, throwing its unlimited financial clout behind an effort to protect Spain and Italy from financial collapse.

headline: Papering Over Cracks in Europe’s Union
abstract: As the European Central Bank unveils measures to help the debt-plagued economies of the euro zone, some European leaders are calling for tighter integration to solve the Continent’s economic problems in the longer term. Is closer union the answer, and how will proposals for treaty changes be greeted by a majority of governments and voters?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When cracks in the roof of the European Parliament building in Brussels resulted in the building’s partial closure this week, skeptics were quick to seize on a handy metaphor for the state of the European Union.

headline: Creating Characters You Worry About
abstract: Two London imports arrive this month: Nick Payne’s “If There Is I Haven’t Found It Yet,” and Simon Stephens’s “Harper Regan.”
lead_paragraph: EVERY now and then — and it’s a blessed now and then — a first encounter with a playwright leaves you surprised, intrigued and at least a little infatuated, as if you’d had an unexpectedly successful blind date. “This could be the beginning of a beautiful friendship,” you think. You find yourself wondering and maybe fretting about the characters you’ve just met, as if they were friends, and anticipating more to come from their creator.

headline: The Bride, Ahem, Needs That Dress
abstract: “Bachelorette,” the film version of Leslye Headland’s play, comes at you with the crackling intensity of machine-gun fire.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll get the Cobb salad with no chicken, no bacon, no cheese, no avocado,” declares Regan (Kirsten Dunst), a snippy, overgrown alpha girl ordering lunch in a New York restaurant.

headline: Thrive Capital Raises $150 Million Fund, Bolstering Profile
abstract: Thrive Capital, a venture capital firm run by Joshua Kushner, has raised $150 million for its latest fund as it seeks to become more competitive against larger firms.
lead_paragraph: Thrive Capital, a venture capital firm based in Manhattan and run by Joshua Kushner, has raised $150 million for its latest fund as it seeks to raise its profile and become more competitive against larger firms.

headline: Ford Expands Offerings for Europe
abstract: Ford Motor Company said it would introduce several models to bolster its struggling European division, including the Edge sport utility vehicle and the Mustang sports car.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Even during the American auto industry’s collapse three years ago, the Ford Motor Company kept investing heavily in new products for the future. As American auto sales recovered, so did Ford’s revenue and profit in what previously had been its most troubled market.

headline: Not by Design, Another Clinton Watches a Convention From Afar
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: As Democrats gathered in Charlotte, N.C., Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has been doing what she has done throughout President Obama’s term: forswearing partisan politics.
lead_paragraph: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei — When Michelle Obama addressed the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday night in Charlotte, N.C., it was already Wednesday morning in Beijing, and Hillary Rodham Clinton was meeting with China’s president in the Great Hall of the People.

headline: Publishers Back African Literacy Effort With E-Books
abstract: David Risher, a former Amazon executive, has gradually found acceptance for Worldreader, the nonprofit he founded to bring e-books to Africa. Now book publishers have agreed to donate e-books to Worldreader, allowing it to triple the size of its digital library.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, David Risher, a former Amazon executive, came up with the unlikely plan of distributing Kindles to children in the developing world to help increase literacy.

headline: A.I.G. to Sell $2 Billion Stake in Asia Unit for Share Buyback
abstract: The insurance giant intends to sell a $2 billion stake in its Asian insurance unit as part of plans to repurchase $5 billion worth of its own stock from the United States government.
lead_paragraph: The insurance giant American International Group said on Thursday that it planned to sell a $2 billion stake in its Asian insurance unit as part of a plan to repurchase $5 billion worth of its own stock from the United States government.

headline: It’s Only September, but Motion Picture Academy Is Naming Some Awards Winners
abstract: Jeffrey Katzenberg and D.A. Pennebaker are among those honored.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — As much of Hollywood moved to Toronto for its annual film festival, which begins on Thursday, some of the rest convened on Wednesday night to select four film veterans — Jeffrey Katzenberg, George Stevens Jr., D.A. Pennebaker and Hal Needham — as recipients of the next Governors Awards from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

headline: Thursday Reading: Tips for Succeeding in College
abstract: How to succeed in college, clothing retailers open stores just for men, a phone that can take a dunking and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: At ‘India Fantastique,’ Silk, Stars and High Fashion
abstract: A London book party for two of Mumbai’s most-loved designers draws an A-list crowd.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – It is not often that stilt walkers wearing columns of silk sway and totter on the pavement on New Bond Street. But on Wednesday evening, towering models in a fanfare of silk outfits embroidered with tiny mirrors greeted guests, including the steel baron Lakshmi Mittal and film director Gurinder Chadha, at a book launch and auction for the celebrated Indian designers Abu Jani and Sandeep Khosla.

headline: Meet the Parents, Part II
abstract: Julian Castro’s grandmother was an orphan. Michelle Obama’s father was a pump operator.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–The G.O.P. convention last week, an opportunity to introduce “the real” Mitt Romney to America, doubled as a genealogy of the Republican leadership. Bob McDonnell said his grandfather, a poor farm boy, left Ireland 100 years ago and came to Ellis Island; Ted Cruz said his dad was imprisoned and tortured in Cuba; and Chris Christie noted that his Irish father worked at the Breyers Ice Cream plant.

headline: A Collision on the Lake

headline: Opponents of Malaysia Rare Earth Plant Promise to Protest
abstract: Concerned groups said they would shut down a nearby port over fears about radioactive byproducts from the Lynas plant.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Opponents of a rare earth refinery in Malaysia refused to back down Thursday after the authorities gave the Australian company behind the project the approval to proceed.

headline: Bill Clinton and Structural Unemployment
abstract: One thing he got wrong.
lead_paragraph: I’m pretty annoyed with Bill Clinton right now; he’s just spoiled one of my standard joke lines. You see, when giving talks about the economy, I’ve often said that I have a different take from other pundits, because I know some stuff most political reporters don’t, like … arithmetic. I’ll never be able to use that line again without being accused of stealing it from the Big Dog.

headline: Summer’s (More or Less) Out. School’s In.
abstract: City Room will be providing posts from public schools around the city on Thursday as children return to class.
lead_paragraph: Today is the first day of school for New York City’s 1.1 million public school students, virtually all of whom will encounter at least one significant change this year. Teachers are beginning to roll out the new common core curriculum, a set of standards that emphasize more critical thinking and nonfiction reading.

headline: Ford Transit and Transit Connect Make Landfall in Amsterdam
abstract: The revised vans are the clearest indication of the models to be offered when Ford begins to phase out its E-Series in North America.
lead_paragraph: As part of a lavish event held to announce its European product plan, Ford introduced refreshed versions of its van fleet on Thursday in Amsterdam: the Transit, Transit Connect commercial van and Transit Connect Wagon. And in keeping with the automaker’s strategy of uniting its global vehicle lines, the vans are the clearest indication of the models to be offered in North America.

headline: Face Time | Rachael Taylor
abstract: The Tasmanian actress opens up about her beauty routine and life in New York City.
lead_paragraph: I met with the actress Rachael Taylor in her new Manhattan apartment, where the gorgeous Tasmanian transplant made me feel instantly at home with her warm, welcoming personality and candid conversation. We chatted a bit about her new television series, “666 Park Avenue” (which airs Sept. 30 on ABC at 10 p.m.), a bit about her upcoming movie, “The Loft,” which co-stars the sexy James Marsden, and a whole lot about her beauty regimen.

headline: Japan Said to Have Tentative Deal to Buy 3 Disputed Islands From Private Owners
abstract: Owners of three uninhabited islands in the East China Sea have made a verbal agreement to sell, according to a source close to the talks.
lead_paragraph: KYOTO, Japan — The Japanese government has struck a tentative agreement to buy three uninhabited islands that are part of a chain at the center of a heated territorial dispute with China, a person close to the talks said Thursday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Bill Clinton Grabs Spotlight, and New Tablets and Phones
abstract: Also, hackers briefly take over Al Jazeera’s Arabic and English Web sites.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton addressed the Democratic National Convention for 45 minutes Wednesday night, giving a detailed and impassioned endorsement of President Obama, Jeff Zeleny and Mark Landler reported. He frequently spoke off the cuff — according to NPR, which paired the written text to a tape of Mr. Clinton’s delivery, he added 2,300 words to a speech that started with 3,200 words of prepared text. Mr. Clinton pushed well past the start of 11 o’clock local news on the East Coast.

headline: Hailing a Cab May Be Easier, but the Ride Remains Unchanged
abstract: The Day: A new app may help taxi seekers hail cabs, but it is incapable of making the ride a more pleasant enterprise than the tribulation it all too often is.
lead_paragraph: Can you see Holly Golightly stepping outside her East Side apartment and using a smartphone app to call a cab?

headline: ‘Big Fish’ Musical to Open in Chicago
abstract: The show, based on a 2003 film, will be directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman.
lead_paragraph: A stage musical adaptation of the 2003 film “Big Fish” will play a five-week engagement in Chicago next spring, the producers announced on Thursday. The two-time Tony Award-winner Norbert Leo Butz (“Catch Me if You Can”) will star in the show, which has music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa (“The Addams Family”) and a book by the film’s screenwriter, John August. Susan Stroman (“The Producers”) will be the director and choreographer.

lead_paragraph: The Realty Income Corporation agreed to acquire American Realty Capital Trust on Thursday, striking a $2.9 billion deal involving hundreds of retail and commercial properties.

headline: The Clinton Magic
abstract: What Bill Clinton did for Democrats (and to Republicans) last night.
lead_paragraph: In a sweeping, sprawling, drawling 48-minute stemwinder of a speech last night, the former President of the United States drove a rhetorical truck through the biggest opening that Mitt Romney and the Republicans created for Democrats last week. The G.O.P. convention promised to make difficult choices and hard calls and be bracingly honest with the public, but the Republican speakers discussed policy in only the broadest and loosest terms, eschewing detail in favor of generalizations and creativity in favor of boilerplate. In response, Bill Clinton did everything they didn’t, diving deep on policy detail, covering issues ranging from Medicaid to welfare to prescription drugs to student loans, and effectively defining the Republicans — defining them negatively, it need hardly be said — on a range of issues where they declined to define themselves. Writing on Paul Ryan last week, I said that we shouldn’t be surprised that his speech was less wonky than his reputation, since a VP address is “hardly the time to talk about block grants and premium support and whether to peg spending rates to inflation or G.D.P. plus one percent.” But Clinton reminded us that this need not be true — that it’s possible to get wonky without losing your audience, and to embrace policy detail as a weapon against your opponents. Journalists tend to assume that voters tune policy substance out, and when the substance is delivered droningly or too abstractly no doubt they often do. But for the most effective rhetoricians, the mere act of talking in detail about the work of government can be a more effective way to persuade the public that you’re serious than a hundred vague promises to “make the hard choices” and “level with the American people.”

headline: Unfit for Any Post
abstract: Narendra Modi, the poster boy for growth in India, is a scaremongering sectarian. He shouldn’t hold any public position — let alone that of prime minister of India.
lead_paragraph: DELHI — Narendra Modi, the chief minister of Gujarat and the poster boy for growth in India, may be in trouble finally. At least he should be.

headline: A Base Line for Methane in Water Supplies
abstract: A federal agency says that 9 percent of the wells it tested in New York State had high enough levels of naturally occurring methane to warrant future monitoring.
lead_paragraph: Measurements in recent years of naturally occurring methane in New York State wells could serve as a base line for assuring the quality of water supplies if and when fracking for natural gas gets under way in the state, the United States Geological Survey reported this week.

headline: Syrian Army Attacks Village Near Jordanian Border
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The move into Tal Shehab is the latest step in a sweeping military campaign seeking to wipe out the opposition and raises fears that tens of thousands of refugees who have been fleeing across the border may be cut off.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian Army stormed the village of Tal Shehab near the Jordanian border, opposition groups and activists said on Thursday, raising fears that the forces of President Bashar al-Assad may seek to cut off the torrent of tens of thousands of refugees who have been fleeing across the border.

headline: Ludo Lefebvre Is Coming to New York
abstract: The French chef, who has made a name for himself hosting pop-up dinners in Los Angeles called LudoBites, will do a New York dinner in October.
lead_paragraph: Ludo Lefebvre, the French chef who relocated to Los Angeles years ago and has made a name for himself doing pop-up dinners there called LudoBites, will be coming to New York to celebrate the publication of his new cookbook based on those dinners. “LudoBites” will be published on Oct. 9, and to celebrate the occasion he will do a dinner at Blue Ribbon Bakery in Greenwich Village, cooking with Bruce Bromberg, whom he met when they were in the Michelin three-star kitchen at Pierre Gagnaire in Paris.

headline: From Passion to Transcendence
abstract: Along with George Balanchine and Merce Cunningham classics this season, dance audiences will see new choreographic works as well as international artists.
lead_paragraph: THREE of the world’s greatest dancers, each from a different continent, each from a different dance idiom, come to New York this fall. The Spanish flamenco artist Soledad Barrio returns, with her troupe Noche Flamenca, to the Joyce Theater for two weeks starting Sept. 18. Nov. 1 through 3 the Indian Bharata Natyam dancer Malavika Sarukkai performs at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. And the Argentine tango master Gabriel Missé returns to New York from Nov. 23 through December, teaching workshops and appearing in the city’s milongas, or social tango gatherings.

headline: The Postmodern Revolution, Redefined
abstract: Danspace Project remembers and pays tribute to the seminal postmodern troupe Judson Dance Theater with the three-month program Judson Now.
lead_paragraph: IT’S hard to imagine there was a time when postmodern dance was considered extreme, but on a hot July night in 1962 at Judson Memorial Church, the fireworks happened onstage. Judson Dance Theater was born: now, 50 years later, the dance world is looking back to the artistic movement that inspired generations to come.

headline: The Accidental Audience
abstract: One of the most exciting contemporary art events of this fall is Some sweet day, a three-week series of performances at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: HOW do you solve a problem like the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium? By even the most generous of views, the cavernous, corporate arena is not an easy or even conducive setting in which to contemplate art. It has foiled many a maker and viewer.

headline: On Our Radar: Tar Balls on the Gulf Coast
abstract: The state of Louisiana closed a 12-mile stretch of coastline where Hurricane Isaac churned up oil and tar balls.
lead_paragraph: The state of Louisiana closes a 12-mile section of the gulf coastline after Hurricane Isaac washes up oil and tar balls in an area that was a hot spot for inundations of oil during the Deepwater Horizon spill of 2010. Testing must be conducted to verify that the oil is from the Macondo well; if it is, BP will have to help finance the cleanup, officials say. Meanwhile, Greenpeace photographs oil washing up in Alabama and Mississippi. [The Times-Picayune, Greenpeace]

abstract: Mr. Modell, an innovative promoter of the game, was idolized by N.F.L. fans in Cleveland, then vilified when he moved the club to Baltimore for the 1996 season.
lead_paragraph: Art Modell, who helped make professional football more popular than baseball and rich beyond its wildest dreams but who broke Cleveland’s heart by killing his money-losing team, the Browns, to give birth to the Baltimore Ravens, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 87.
