headline: Danish Art-Rock, and Beethoven, Too
abstract: Forthcoming musical performances at the Metropolitan Museum include compositions by Tan Dun and David Lang as well as 16 Beethoven string quartets.
lead_paragraph: THINK of the new concert season at the Metropolitan Museum of Art as the Met Remixed. Limor Tomer, who was appointed in 2011 to run the museum’s concerts and lectures department, has already staged several concerts at the museum, most notably a 10th-anniversary commemoration of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and a celebration in April of the composer Philip Glass and the violinist Timothy Fain in the Temple of Dendur. But the season about to open is the first she planned fully.

headline: 36 Hours in Galway, Ireland
abstract: Nestled along the country’s western coast, Galway is often called Ireland’s most Irish city. And while you can still get a Guinness served with Gaelic, a global flavor is emerging.
lead_paragraph: FREQUENTLY called Ireland’s most Irish city, this coastal metropolis is a place where Celtic culture and literature have long thrived, often in the traditional Gaelic language. But these days you’re just as likely to hear Spanish, Polish or Japanese along Galway’s crowded streets in this increasingly international college town (the National University of Ireland, Galway, is here). While the fall is less crowded than the tourist-clogged summer, Galway’s festival culture keeps going strong, with the 10,000-person Galway International Oyster and Seafood Festival in late September and the Galway Theater Festival in early October, to name just two events. Of course, the city’s notoriously lively pubs can provide a few pints and plenty of craic (Irish slang for “a good time”) any night of the year.

headline: A Rare Breed: New Operas at the Met
abstract: In Peter Gelb’s tenure at the Metropolitan Opera, new productions by living composers have been rare, despite his stated goal of bringing the company into the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: ON Oct. 23 the Metropolitan Opera will offer something that has been too infrequent during Peter Gelb’s six years as general manager: a new production of an opera by a living composer.

headline: Spotlight Illuminates Work by 2 Composers
abstract: The composers Olga Neuwirth and David T. Little both have significant performances and premieres this season that should earn them broader appreciation.
lead_paragraph: APART from dark, tousled hair; a taste for fashionably understated eyewear; and a knack for overturning musical conventions, the composers David T. Little and Olga Neuwirth do not seem to have much in common. Mr. Little, a 33-year-old American composer based in Weehawken, N.J., is known for bracing, rock-infused, politically pointed works; Ms. Neuwirth, 44 and Austrian, is among Europe’s leading postmodernists, with operas, orchestral works and chamber pieces that demonstrate a formidable grasp of history and technique.

headline: Fore!
abstract: John Baldessari, the 81-year-old conceptual artist, drew on a pun in re-imagining our signature letter.
lead_paragraph: This issue’s artist-created ‘‘T’’ comes from the 81-year-old conceptual artist John Baldessari, who took inspiration from his days as a grade-school art teacher. Instead of gluing beans or macaroni onto construction paper, he used golf tees, which, he readily admits, made for a bad pun: a ‘‘T’’ made of tees. “The ideal form of this T,” he says, “would be that every copy of T magazine would have real tees glued onto it. But this is as close as I can come. It’s kind of like trompe l’oeil tees.”

Walcott’s back-to-school tour, Mr. Walcott spent some time helping kindergartners draw and leading a ninth-grade English class in a discussion of the question, “Is man a victim or agent of his fate?”

headline: World Premiere by Craig Lucas Added to Atlantic Theater Company Season
abstract: “The Lying Lesson,” starring Carol Kane, is scheduled to open on Feb. 27, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “The Lying Lesson,” a new play about a movie star who may or may not be Bette Davis, written by the Pulitzer Prize finalist Craig Lucas (“Prelude to a Kiss”), will have its world premiere off Broadway this winter at Atlantic Theater Company, executives for the organization announced on Thursday.

headline: What Obama Should Say
abstract: Readers weigh in on what the president should say at the D.N.C. tonight.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–Yesterday I asked readers what Obama should say tonight at the Democratic Convention. Here’s a small selection of their responses. (To see the rest, go to the comments section of the original article.)

headline: Not a Cancer Survivor
abstract: Many people with cancer define themselves as cancer survivors. But some of us cringe at adopting such an identity.
lead_paragraph: I am not a cancer survivor, and neither are the women in my cancer support group.

headline: The House That Hova Built
abstract: Jay-Z has a piece of the Nets, a glamorous wife and a baby girl who melts his heart. Brooklyn, meet your once and future king.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult to know what to ask a rapper. It’s not unlike the difficulty (I imagine) of being a rapper. Whatever you say must be considered from at least three angles, and it’s an awkward triangulation. In one corner you have your hard-core hip-hop heads; the type for whom the true Jay-Z will forever be that gifted 25-year-old with rapid-fire flow, trading verses with the visionary teenager Big L — “I’m so ahead of my time, my parents haven’t met yet!” — on a “rare” (easily dug up on YouTube) seven-minute freestyle from 1995. Meanwhile, over here stands the pop-rap fan. She loves the Jiggaman with his passion for the Empire State Building and bold claims to “Run This Town.” Finally, in the crowded third corner, stand the many people who feel rap is not music at all but rather a form of social problem. They have only one question to ask a rapper, and it concerns his choice of vocabulary. (Years pass. The question never changes.) How to speak to these audiences simultaneously? Anyway: I’m at a little table in a homey Italian restaurant on Mulberry Street waiting for Mr. Shawn Carter, who has perfected the art of triangulation. It’s where he likes to eat his chicken parms.

headline: It’s Official: Facebook Closes Its Acquisition of Instagram
abstract: Five months after the deal was first announced, the Federal Trade Commission cleared Facebook to complete its acquisition of Instagram, the popular mobile photo-sharing application.
lead_paragraph: 11:50 a.m. | Updated  Adding details.

headline: The Family Barge, Minus a Flotilla of Personal Technology
abstract: Even with two young daughters, the Beutlers of Traverse City, Mich., eschewed iPads, laptops and portable DVD players on a road trip in a 1971 Oldsmobile Vista Cruiser.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — It’s one thing to take a 41-year-old station wagon for a Sunday drive, quite another to put it on the road for a six-day, 1,400-mile family vacation.

headline: Soldiering Amid Hyacinths and Horror
abstract: “The Yellow Birds,” a brilliantly observed novel by a veteran of the war in Iraq, stands with Tim O’Brien’s enduring Vietnam book, “The Things They Carried,” as a classic of war fiction.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Powers joined the Army when he was 17 and served as a machine-gunner in Iraq in 2004 and 2005. Drawing upon those experiences, he has written a remarkable first novel, one that stands with Tim O’Brien’s enduring Vietnam book, “The Things They Carried,” as a classic of contemporary war fiction.

headline: Film Is Dead? Long Live Movies
abstract: Digital technology is changing movies in such groundbreaking ways that “film” is usually a word of convenience and tradition.
lead_paragraph: IN the beginning there was light that hit a strip of flexible film mechanically running through a camera. For most of movie history this is how moving pictures were created: light reflected off people and things would filter through a camera and physically transform emulsion. After processing, that light-kissed emulsion would reveal Humphrey Bogart chasing the Maltese Falcon in shimmering black and white.

headline: Three Days in the Fishbowl, and Here to Tell the Tale
abstract: It’s important that the public editor’s job at The New York Times be a two-way street, or even one of those insane intersections where traffic is going every which way.
lead_paragraph: “Welcome to the fishbowl,” the corporate spokeswoman Eileen Murphy told me a few weeks back when I was named public editor at The New York Times. She was right. The scrutiny began immediately, in the form of interviews, commentary from pundits, welcoming messages on Twitter and the dredging up of old stories I’d written and forgotten.

headline: World’s First Pizza Museum Opening in Philadelphia
abstract: Pizza Brain, a pizza parlor that is home to the world’s largest collection of pizza memorabilia, opens Friday in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Visit any of the nation’s more than 60,000 pizza joints, and you will find plenty of people who believe that the perfect pie is a work of art. Certainly, pizza has become as embedded in American cuisine and culture as the hamburger and apple pie.

headline: The God of Marriage
abstract: Every girl, Jewish or Muslim, wonders: how it is that some girls get married, and I don’t?
lead_paragraph: After a month in San Francisco, Townies returns to New York City.

abstract: Three musicals about heroic girls facing down crises — “Annie,” “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” and “Matilda the Musical” — are joining the coming Broadway season.
lead_paragraph: OF the three coming Broadway musicals about plucky girls persevering against cruel adults and grim circumstances, which show will break out of the pack and become a box office hit?

headline: Pakistan May Be Expelling Aid Group’s Foreign Staff
abstract: A senior aid official in Pakistan said the staff members of Save the Children had been given until Sept. 12 to leave the country, but hours later the interior minister issued a temporary reprieve.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government appeared Thursday to have moved to expel international staff members at the aid agency Save the Children, apparently over accusations that one of its employees helped the C.I.A. recruit a Pakistani doctor who played a role in tracking Osama bin Laden last year.

headline: For Madrid, a Few Encouraging Words From Germany
abstract: The German chancellor said she supported the efforts the Spanish government was making to right its finances, even as additional measures were being taken to prop up the euro zone’s weaker economies.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Even as the European Central Bank was taking further steps to help Spain and other struggling euro economies, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Thursday that she had “full confidence” in the Spanish government and its efforts to deal with the debt crisis.

headline: Installation View of Los Angeles
abstract: A retrospective of the work of the sculptor Ken Price is one of the major exhibitions coming soon to Los Angeles museums.
lead_paragraph: THE past year has been a roller-coaster ride for the Los Angeles art scene. First there were thrills galore offered by “Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A. 1945-1980,” a celebration of the city’s postwar art history to which some 60 institutions contributed exhibitions extending from October through March. Then there was Jeffrey Deitch’s bumpy second year as director of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, culminating in the departure of the museum’s much admired chief curator Paul Schimmel and the resignation of artists like Barbara Kruger and Ed Ruscha from the museum’s board.

headline: ‘Ken Price Sculpture: A Retrospective’
abstract: Images from the new exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Images from the new exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: French Institute Alliance Francaise to Unveil Gould Hall Renovation
abstract: The institute’s second annual open house on Sept.12 is a chance to preview the $500,000 renovation of the 361-seat-hall.
lead_paragraph: The French Institute Alliance Française, a New York French cultural center, will officially unveil its major renovation of Florence Gould Hall on Sept. 14 with a concert featuring the jazz musician Bill Frisell along with his groups, the 858 Quartet and the Beautiful Dreamers.

headline: From ‘We Can’ to ‘We Can’t’
abstract: Bill Clinton put a twist on Barack Obama’s 2008 “yes we can” slogan. “We can’t let that happen” is a more apt call to arms for the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.–Among the more startling lines in Bill Clinton’s keynote address last night–for this listener, anyway–was “we can’t let it happen,” which seemed to encapsulate the Democratic Party’s shift in pitch from 2008 to 2012.

headline: National Ad Campaign for Citibank Reward Program to Feature Alicia Keys
abstract: The Private Pass program offers cardholders early access to tickets for sporting events and concerts, but in its latest version, there are also small group events with celebrities like Ms. Keys.
lead_paragraph: Add being boring to the list of reasons to break up with someone. While there are many women who would gladly jump at the chance to date a “boring” guy, a new television ad for a Citibank reward program features one woman who has had enough of her boyfriend’s staid ways.

headline: Rosemarie Trockel
abstract: A look at some of the work from the artist’s retrospective at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the work from the artist’s retrospective at the New Museum.

headline: Here’s Looking at You, Conceptualism
abstract: Many forthcoming exhibitions are treating Conceptualism and its artists as old masters.
lead_paragraph: CONTEMPORARY art is occupying hallowed halls this season: Andy Warhol at the Met, Matthew Barney at the Morgan Library.

headline: Going Beyond Marquee Names on Museum Walls
abstract: The expected figures (Picasso, Warhol and the like) will be the focus of art shows this season, but unexpected artists will have a strong showing too.
lead_paragraph: IT may be a mite simplistic to divide artists into usual and unusual suspects. But the truth is there are names that don’t surprise when it is announced that they are to be the subjects of coming exhibitions, and others that do, and pleasantly. This year such surprises are on the rise.

headline: Ai Weiwei
abstract: In Washington, the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden will mount the first American retrospective of the Chinese artist.
lead_paragraph: In Washington, the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden will mount the first American retrospective of the Chinese artist.

headline: Bartoli’s Signatures: Power and Intensity
abstract: Marion Bartoli, who lost to Maria Sharapova on Wednesday, has an aggressive second serve — and a growing number of fans.
lead_paragraph: Marion Bartoli hits both her forehand and backhand with two hands. She volleys with two hands and bounces the ball between serves with two hands on her racket. During changeovers, she raises her bottle of water to her mouth using both arms.

headline: A Theme Change on Opening Night
abstract: New story lines for the 2012 N.F.L. season began to emerge on Wednesday with the Giants’ 24-17 home loss to the Cowboys.
lead_paragraph: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: A ‘Dreamer’ Addresses the Democratic Convention
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Deportation', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Endorsements', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: One unnoticed speaker at the Democratic convention was Benita Veliz, a leader of a group of young undocumented immigrants who call themselves Dreamers, because they would be eligible for legal status under the long-stalled Dream Act.
lead_paragraph: Benita Veliz was only at the lectern at the Democratic convention for a few minutes on Wednesday night. CNN did not even turn its cameras on the stage during her brief speech. But for many Latinos in the hall, her moment under the lights was a stunning surprise.

headline: Obama Girls’ Role: Not to Speak, but to Be Spoken Of
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The girls’ appearance at the Democratic convention will underscore their importance to their father’s image as a likable family man.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — On Friday, Malia Obama will be at her desk at Sidwell Friends School for the fourth day of high school — hours after waving onstage at the Democratic National Convention with her sister, Sasha.

headline: A White House Childhood
abstract: Sasha and Malia Obama are rarely seen, but they remain an important part of President Obama’s public image.
lead_paragraph: Sasha and Malia Obama are rarely seen, but they remain an important part of President Obama’s public image.

headline: Doctor Is Charged in Death of Slipknot Bassist
abstract: The doctor also reportedly faces manslaughter charges in the deaths of seven other patients.
lead_paragraph: An Iowa doctor who helped run a pain clinic has been charged with involuntary manslaughter in connection with the death of Paul Gray, the Slipknot bassist and co-founder who died of an overdose of narcotics in May 2010, The Des Moines Register reported.

headline: Why Such Suspicion of the ‘Submerged State’?
abstract: The idea of the “submerged state” — largely unrecognized government benefits — is treated with greater suspicion in the United States than in Canada or Europe. The original architects of the submerged state were Republicans and conservative Democrats, although Bill Clinton and Barack Obama have energetically built on that legacy.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — In my column this week I write about Suzanne Mettler’s idea of the “submerged state” — the government benefits that Americans receive, like tax credits, or support channeled through nonprofits, which is paid for by the state but which are either invisible or feel as if they’ve come from some other source.

headline: The Get | Stephen Russell Earrings
abstract: A pair of mesmerizing, monochromatic earrings that put old world glamour back in the moment.
lead_paragraph: Known for exceptional estate gems, the fine jeweler Stephen Russell has created a pair of mesmerizing monochromatic earrings that put Old World glamour back in the moment. Modeled after an 18th-century pendeloque shape, they’re made of almost 200 sapphires, their setting upstaged by all that brilliant blue. And about that setting: Russell chose 18-karat blackened gold to augment the vintagelike quality.

headline: What Goes Up, if Only in Stages
abstract: Several long-planned architectural projects, including Barclays Center in Brooklyn and 4 World Trade Center, are making their ways, at varied speeds, to completion.
lead_paragraph: ARCHITECTURE is slow. So slow it sometimes appears not to be moving forward at all. Projects get bogged down — more now than ever, it seems — by financial shortfalls, public opposition, disputes over labor or design. All on top of the mundane difficulties of putting together, piece by piece, the stuff that makes a building.

headline: The U.S. Open Chronicles: Summer in the City
abstract: Out of the United States Open, Irina Falconi is in a New York state of mind. The Beast is included.
lead_paragraph: Irina Falconi, who is playing at the United States Open this year, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

headline: Appeals Court Revives Insider Trading Case Against Obus
abstract: A Federal Appeals Court has revived a decade-old insider-trading case brought against a New York hedge fund manager by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s longest-running insider trading lawsuits has just gotten longer.

headline: Traveling With Children, With Help From Apps
abstract: Family iTrips created apps that allow users to nimbly explore listings, including shops, hotels and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Figuring out an itinerary for children can feel like a game of Whac-A-Mole. That puppet show in Boston that your niece loved during her last stay? She’s aged out of it. Your 17-year-old son is happy to crash lectures at Georgetown during a trip to Washington? His 10-year-old brother is not so into it.

headline: Live Updates From Amazon’s Press Event
abstract: At an event in Los Angeles, Amazon.com showed off new products including the Kindle Paperwhite, with a new whiter screen than its earlier black-and-white Kindles, and a new Kindle Fire HD that is a more direct competitor to the iPad than the old Kindle Fire. Here are live updates from the event.
lead_paragraph: Amazon.com invited journalists to Santa Monica, Calif., for a briefing on new Kindle products. It showed off the Kindle Paperwhite with a new whiter screen, and a new Kindle Fire HD that is a more direct competitor to the iPad than the old Kindle Fire. The company gave a sneak preview of some new Kindle devices in a TV commercial that was broadcast Wednesday night.

headline: The Caucus Click: Axelrod Getting Anxious
abstract: David Axelrod, center, seated with other top advisers to the Obama campaign, tapped his watch during Bill Clinton’s address to the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday.

headline: The Peanut Gallery Takes On the Democrats
abstract: Sampling comics’ tweets in response to Bill Clinton’s speech at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Let the historians decide who was the greatest president in American history; I would argue that the best modern commander in chief for comedians is pretty clear. Sure, Nixon is a solid contender, but Bill Clinton, a man with big appetites and a distinctive accent, has given joke tellers a wealth of material. So it’s no surprise that his return to the spotlight at the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday night in Charlotte, N.C., inspired an avalanche of jokes on Twitter. (Just as the Republicans’ gathering did last week). Here are a few highlights:

headline: France Sends Funds to 5 Syrian Civic Groups in Rebel-Held Areas
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: A senior French diplomat said the government was providing funds to five revolutionary councils in rebel-held parts of Syria to help them restore water supplies, sanitation, health services and bakeries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government is providing funds to five revolutionary councils in rebel-held parts of Syria to help them restore water supplies, sanitation, health services and bakeries, a senior French diplomat, Éric Chevallier, said Thursday.

headline: Migrants Die as Boat Sinks Off Turkey
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Boats and Boating', 'Drownings', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Palestinians']
abstract: The boat was carrying more than 100 Syrians, Iraqis and Palestinians who were apparently trying to migrate to the European Union, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — At least 58 migrants drowned in the Aegean Sea just off the Turkish coast after the fishing boat that was carrying them sank early Thursday morning, local officials told a Turkish news agency.

headline: JPMorgan Names New Head of Chief Investment Office
abstract: Craig Delany, 41, who was most recently the chief operating office of JPMorgan’s mortgage banking unit, will take over the reins of the chief investment office, which was at the center of a multibillion-dollar trading loss.
lead_paragraph: As it works to move past a multibillion-dollar trading loss tied to a complex credit bet, JPMorgan Chase has been reshuffling its management ranks — focusing specifically on the chief investment office, the powerful unit at the center of the soured trade.

headline: In One Class, Time to Draw, and in Another, a Return to the Olympics
abstract: At the Young Scholars’ Academy for Discovery and Exploration in Brooklyn, the pencils and Popsicle sticks came out.
lead_paragraph: The first graders at Young Scholars’ Academy for Discovery and Exploration in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, know how to write their first names, though not necessarily their last names, as they demonstrated for reporters on their first day back to school. A group of them sat around a tiny table Thursday morning, frowning with concentration as they tried to decide how to draw themselves.

headline: BMW Motorrad and Bloomingdale’s, Riding Tandem
abstract: Featuring the BMW R1200R Classic in its stores and print advertising has been a boon to clothing sales, the retailer said.
lead_paragraph: In the men’s department at Bloomingdale’s, featured fashions this fall include a $795 Michael Kors Leather Utility Jacket, a $45 Vince V-Neck Tee and a $15,675 BMW R1200R Classic.

headline: The Baffling Nexus of Climate Change and Health
abstract: At the Department of Health and Human Services, new efforts are under way to understand what effects a changing climate could have on infectious diseases, allergies, air pollution and so on.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, a rare tropical fungus caused a string of respiratory failures and neural disorders along the Pacific Northwest coast, baffling the health community. That same year, Alaskan cruise ship passengers dining on local oysters fell sick with a gastric virus typically found in warm water estuaries. Now Texas, after an unusually wet spring and dry summer, is battling what may become the country’s worst recorded outbreak of West Nile virus.

headline: Breaking It Down: Berdych vs. Federer
abstract: In a loss to Tomas Berdych at the United States Open, Roger Federer’s forehand disintegrated.
lead_paragraph: Roger Federer more than doubled his forehand errors from any of his previous three United States Open matches to lose in four sets to sixth-seeded Tomas Berdych, 7-6 (1), 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, Wednesday.

headline: Cuomo, in Convention City, Gives Spirited Speech From Small Stage
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: By turns stirring and scathing, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo sounded unmistakably like a man with ambitions well beyond Albany even as he tried to stay out of the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Giant clusters of red, white and blue balloons hung overhead and an imposing black rope line stretched across the room. Campaign-style bunting festooned the podium and Bon Jovi’s “Working for the Working Man” blared through loudspeakers. A seasoned political spouse leapt to her feet at applause lines, and the candidate shouted to be heard over an adoring crowd.

headline: Clinton Was a Bipartisan President, Except When He Wasn’t
abstract: Perhaps only Bill Clinton could deliver one of the most brutal partisan poundings of the other party in recent memory and come out of it with people talking about how bipartisan he is.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – Perhaps only Bill Clinton could deliver one of the most brutal partisan poundings of the other party in recent memory and come out of it with people talking about how bipartisan he is.

headline: Singaporean Tells China U.S. Is Not in Decline
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong pointedly addressed the question of America’s world standing, a subject that Chinese academics and writers in the state-run media have written caustically about in recent months.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In an unusual public airing of strategic problems surrounding China’s rise, the prime minister of Singapore, Lee Hsien Loong, warned China on Thursday that it should view the United States not as a declining power, but as a nation with the ability to innovate and bounce back.

headline: What to Watch For in Obama’s Speech
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Executive Orders', 'Homosexuality', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Will President Obama attack Mitt Romney, and which issues will he dwell on?
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — President Obama takes the stage Thursday night competing against a formidable array of convention speakers: Mitt Romney, Michelle Obama, Bill Clinton — and Barack Obama.

headline: E-Mail Birthday Intrigue
abstract: Who invented e-mail? There’s a story about that.
lead_paragraph: The other day, I got snookered.

headline: Small Plates Are a Big Surprise
abstract: A commitment to seasonality and sustainability is at the heart of this Mediterranean restaurant in the outer orbit of Bloomingdale’s.
lead_paragraph: NO one at the table notices the duck leg confit trailed by a retinue of chanterelles and peaches; or the whole dorade, dappled with olive oil; or the tangle of linguine, lump crab, grilled corn, mascarpone and rendered bacon. We are too busy eating our broccoli.

headline: Focusing on What Is Local, Not Just Organic
abstract: The Portland, Ore., chef Jenn Louis reacts to the Stanford study that cast doubt on the value of organic food.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of Americans, Jenn Louis wasn’t raised on a noble diet of organic food.

headline: Culture Clash With Afghans on Display at Briefing
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: A press briefing by American and Afghan commanders on insider attacks led to complaints, and a wider cultural discussion.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was billed as a news briefing by American and Afghan commanders on what the allies are doing to stop insider attacks by Afghan forces against NATO troops. The first question, though, was just about the last thing the three generals on the dais wanted to hear.

headline: Judge Approves E-Book Pricing Settlement Between Government and Publishers
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'E-Books and Readers']
abstract: In a widely expected decision, Judge Denise L. Cote approved conditions that curb publishers’ ability to restrict a retailer’s “discretion over e-book pricing.
lead_paragraph: 8:35 p.m. | Updated In a decision that could start an e-book price war in the publishing industry, a federal judge on Thursday approved a settlement between the Justice Department and three major publishers in a civil antitrust case that accused the companies of collusion in the pricing of digital books.

headline: Obama Praises Clinton and Talks Stadium Move in Call With Supporters
abstract: Bill Clinton’s prosecutorial speech to the Democratic Convention on Wednesday night went as far as anyone has this year to delineate the differences between the Democratic and Republican agendas, President Obama said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Bill Clinton’s prosecutorial speech to the Democratic convention on Wednesday night went as far as anyone has this year in delineating the differences between the Democratic and Republican agendas, President Obama said on Thursday.

headline: Venice Film Festival: Olivier Assayas Returns to the 1970s
abstract: At the Venice Film Festival, Olivier Assayas discusses balancing his memories of the 1970s with the need to be clear-eyed in his new film “Something in the Air.”
lead_paragraph: VENICE — In his previous movie, “Carlos,” the French filmmaker Olivier Assayas tackled a few big themes of the 1970s — the demise of idealism and the rise of terrorism — through a biopic of the international guerrilla and media star known as Carlos the Jackal. Mr. Assayas’s new film, “Something in the Air,” which had its world premiere in competition at the Venice Film Festival, is another immersion in those tumultuous times, but from a very personal perspective. (The film is also being shown at the Toronto and New York festivals, and will be released in the United States by IFC.)

abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Nathan Harden’s “Sex and God at Yale.”

abstract: The 2004 French Open was the last time neither Roger Federer nor Rafael Nadal played in a Slam’s semifinals.
lead_paragraph: In the minutes after Roger Federer’s stunning quarterfinal loss to Tomas Berdych at the United States Open on Wednesday night, the factoid went shooting around Twitter:

headline: Dress Code | Richard Chai Love
abstract: The designer took a unique approach to his runway preparations this season.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Why Can’t School Be More Like Summer?
abstract: As I grudgingly send my girls back to school this week, I can’t help wishing — just as they do — that school would learn just a little from summer.
lead_paragraph: From their perspective, the worst thing that happens to my two daughters at the conclusion of each summer is that they have to leave their friends and their joyous days of exploration at their mountain summer camp and come home. The next worst thing that happens to them is that they have to immediately start an experience — school — that feels almost exactly the opposite. The onset of camp-sickness is immediate.

headline: A Look Behind the U.S. Decline in Global Competitiveness
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Productivity', 'United States Economy']
abstract: According to the latest rankings from the World Economic Forum, the United States slipped in rankings for the fourth consecutive year. It is now in seventh place, out of 144 counties ranked. Switzerland came in first for the fourth year in a row.
lead_paragraph: For the fourth consecutive year, Switzerland is the most competitive economy in the world, according to a ranking from the World Economic Forum. And, for the fourth consecutive year, the United States fell in the rankings — largely because of worsening criticism of the American government — and is now in seventh place.

headline: Bernadette Corporation
abstract: A show at Artists Space gathers together the prolific output of this influential and intentionally enigmatic quasi-corporation.
lead_paragraph: A show at Artists Space gathers together the prolific output of this influential and intentionally enigmatic quasi-corporation.

headline: Conversations with Voters: The Economy
abstract: In a Google+ Hangout, the Op-Ed columnist Frank Bruni and the editorial board writer David Firestone talk to voters from around the country about their views on the economy.
lead_paragraph: In a Google+ Hangout, the Op-Ed columnist Frank Bruni and the editorial board writer David Firestone talk to voters from around the country about their views on the economy.

headline: Weighing Prepaid Cards vs. Checking Accounts
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Checks and Checking Accounts', 'Consumer Protection', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Consumers with less financial experience may be better off with a prepaid debit card than with a checking account.
lead_paragraph: Prepaid cards can be a better deal than checking accounts for some people, but the cards need more consumer safeguards, a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts finds.

headline: Clinton Was Not Always an Obama Fan, Romney Ad Recalls
abstract: The day after Bill Clinton forcefully made the case for the president’s re-election, a new Romney ad notes Mr. Clinton’s reaction to Barack Obama was once “Give me a break.”
lead_paragraph: 3:12 p.m. | Updated Bill Clinton proved Wednesday night to be one of President Obama’s most forceful and substantive surrogates, but he has hardly been the most consistent. In fact, in a new ad, Mitt Romney’s campaign is reminding voters that Mr. Clinton was once a sharp critic of Mr. Obama, in 2008.

headline: Blasting Your Way Into the Fall
abstract: New video games out this fall include Call of Duty: Black Ops 2, Assassin’s Creed III, Dishonored and Luigi’s Ghost Mansion.
lead_paragraph: FOR video game players the summer begins after Labor Day. The preceding months have the prestige titles and the intriguing independent projects. In that category 2012 has served up Dear Esther, Fez, Journey and Papo & Yo, to name a few. The fall is the time for blockbusters, many of them sequels with big explosions.

headline: New York City Marathon, in Reversal, Will Ferry Bags
abstract: Marathoners complained when race organizers said two weeks ago that they would stop transporting bags from the starting line in Staten Island to the finish line in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: After criticism from marathoners, New York Road Runners reversed itself and said it would allow runners to check a bag at the starting line of the New York City Marathon on Nov. 4.

headline: Navigating Darkness, or Enlightenment
abstract: NBC’s new series “Revolution,” Mondays at 10 p.m., depicts an Earth without electricity.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S the challenge for Eric Kripke, the producer in charge of “Revolution,” an NBC series set on a future Earth without electricity: Take a horror story and make it a fantasy.

headline: Putin Says Missile Deal Is More Likely With Obama
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin praised President Obama and said that if he is re-elected, a compromise could be reached on the contentious issue of American plans for a missile defense system in Europe.
lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sauntered into American presidential politics on Thursday, praising President Obama as “a very honest man” and chastising the Republican nominee, Mitt Romney, for describing Russia as “without question our No. 1 geopolitical foe.”

headline: Going Straight (or Otherwise) for the Center
abstract: Gay marriage and gay characters have become staples of network television. This season they are not only normal, they seem de rigueur.
lead_paragraph: GAY is the new straight.

headline: Video Shows Killer of Gas-Station Worker
abstract: The police are offering a $12,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer and his accomplice, who struck Tuesday night in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Police officials are offering a $12,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the two men who carried out the fatal armed robbery of a gas station in the Bronx, the chilling exchange captured by video surveillance cameras.

headline: A Writer’s Inspiration? Oh, Brother!
abstract: In creating “Ben and Kate,” a new Fox series, the screenwriter Dana Fox was inspired by her older brother, Ben, now a title character.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

headline: Amáli
abstract: Inside the Mediterranean restaurant once known as Persephone.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Mediterranean restaurant once known as Persephone.

headline: French Police Nearby, Girl Hides in Car for Hours Under Relatives’ Corpses
abstract: The discovery of the girl around midnight on Wednesday provided a glimmer of relief after a grisly and murky shooting deaths of two parents and a grandmother in the Alps.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Apparently frozen in terror, a 4-year-old girl crouched silently for eight hours below her dead mother and grandmother in the back of a BMW on a forest road in the French Alps while just steps away investigators hunted for clues, officials said Thursday.

headline: New Jerusalem
abstract: Why did the Democrats leave out language on Jerusalem in the original version of the 2012 platform?
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney and the Republicans have been working overtime to make fealty to Israel a wedge issue in the campaign and to grossly misrepresent President Obama as insufficiently loyal to the Jewish state. So why did the Democrats give the Republicans an opening to pounce?

headline: Week 1 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
abstract: It’s that time of year again, when blood pressure rises and productivity drops: here is some fantasy football help for Week 1.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Traveling at the Speed of Molasses
abstract: ZZ Top has a new album after nine years.
lead_paragraph: ZZ TOP has been idling for a while. It tours regularly, playing the road and radio-tested base of its blues and boogie 1970s and ’80s catalog with such delicious control over sound and feel and medium-to-slow tempos that you wonder whether this band, in earthly-purpose terms, needs to do much else.

headline: Whole New State of Mind
abstract: Alicia Keys, now a wife and mother, also has a new album: “Girl on Fire,” coming in November.
lead_paragraph: ALICIA KEYS’S recording studio, the Oven, is on a high floor of a West Chelsea building, with a panoramic city view. The little alcove used for vocals gazes out toward the Empire State Building.

headline: Woody Johnson Says Circus Isn’t in Town
abstract: The Jets’ owner declined to discuss the consequences for Rex Ryan and Mike Tannenbaum if the team misses the playoffs for a second consecutive year.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, said he was “very optimistic” that the team would rebound from its disappointing 2011 season but declined to discuss the consequences for Rex Ryan and Mike Tannenbaum if the team misses the playoffs for a second consecutive year.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Burrata
abstract: It’s not much of a meal, but the burrata at the United States Open is an outstanding snack.
lead_paragraph: Another installment in our daily reviews of food from the United States Open concession stands.

headline: Rise and Shine for Richard Chai
abstract: Pulling up to Lincoln Center this morning for the first day of New York Fashion Week, the first thing that caught the eye was the incredible number of people standing in the plaza to gawk at the fashionistas.
lead_paragraph: Pulling up to Lincoln Center this morning for the first day of New York Fashion Week, the first thing that caught the eye was the incredible number of people standing in the plaza to gawk at the fashionistas. There had to be 100 people out there, half with cellphone cameras. Somehow, people just know when there’s a big fashion happening.

headline: President Obama’s Girls
abstract: Jodi Kantor of The New York Times talks about the vital role that President Obama’s daughters, Malia and Sasha, have played in his political life.
lead_paragraph: Jodi Kantor of The New York Times talks about the vital role that President Obama’s daughters, Malia and Sasha, have played in his political life.

headline: Errani Tries to Distance Herself From Barred Spanish Doctor
abstract: Sara Errani, a semifinalist at the U.S. Open, has had to face questions about her connection to the Spanish doctor Luis Garcia del Moral, who recently was barred by the United States Anti-Doping Agency as part of the case against Lance Armstrong.
lead_paragraph: Reaching the singles semifinals and women’s doubles final in New York continues a career season for Sara Errani, who was also a finalist at the French Open. But she has had to face questions about her connection to the Spanish doctor Luis Garcia del Moral, who recently was barred by the United States Anti-Doping Agency as part of the case against Lance Armstrong, a punishment recognized by the International Tennis Federation.

headline: Envelope, Please: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf
abstract: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, South Africa, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, South Africa, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: News and Verse: Our Weekly Poetry Pairings
abstract: With the start of the school year, we usher in a new season of Poetry Pairings. Here is our first one: Marilyn Taylor’s “Subject to Change” matched with photographs by the teacher Will Okun.
lead_paragraph: With the start of the school year, we usher in a new season of Poetry Pairings, a feature we first introduced in 2010.

headline: The Fraying Hospital Safety Net
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Medicare', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: So-called safety-net hospitals have long been considered the ugly stepchild of the American health care system, but as a new study reports, you can’t judge the quality of a hospital’s care by its decor.
lead_paragraph: Slender and in his 60s, the patient had been short of breath for several days, a result of untreated heart failure causing fluid to build up in his lungs. Despite his wife’s entreaties, he had refused to go to the hospital, one of the biggest in the city, and waited at home, gasping, until his appointment at our clinic.

headline: President Obama’s Second Chance
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Editorials']
abstract: The president makes a strong case for a vision of government that serves the middle class.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s dilemma has always been that he has been far more successful a president than his opponents claim, but far less successful than he needs to be at making voters see that. Powerful speeches by former President Bill Clinton, Vice President Joe Biden and others did a lot to fix that impression during the convention. But it was up to Mr. Obama to make the case for another term, with a speech that was every bit as fraught with uncertainty and risk as his 2008 convention address.

headline: Before School Lets Out, a Basketball-Playing Robot Takes the Court
abstract: Dennis M. Walcott may be the leader of the city’s school system, but he was no match for a basketball-shooting robot built by students at one Staten Island school.
lead_paragraph: The first day of school was coming to an end at Staten Island Technical High School, but the members of the school’s robotics team, Team 375: The Robotic Plague, still had one hurdle to clear. They couldn’t wait to demonstrate their champion basketball-launching robot to Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott and other dignitaries who had dropped by.

headline: Making the G.I. Bill Work for Veterans
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Veterans']
abstract: The Post 9/11 G.I. Bill has helped tens of thousands of veterans attend college, but the potentially lucrative source of guaranteed student tuition needs to be safeguarded from less the scrupulous actors in the higher education market.
lead_paragraph: Today’s veterans have faced incredible challenges, but have also received extraordinary opportunities – like the Post 9/11 G.I. Bill. Each year, it helps tens of thousands of veterans attend college by helping pay for tuition and living expenses. Through this program, many veterans have been able to transition successfully from combat back to civilian life.

headline: Romney Isn’t Planning to Watch Obama’s Speech
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Tens of millions of people are expected to tune into President Obama’s acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night. But Mitt Romney doesn’t plan on being one of them.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. – Tens of millions of people are expected to tune into President Obama’s acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night. But Mitt Romney doesn’t plan on being one of them.

headline: Blistering Bands and Bingo
abstract: Shades of the old 1970s and ’80s downtown New York at the Ding Dong Lounge and Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: Along with innumerable other starry-eyed provincials, the Miser moved to New York more or less because of “downtown.” The allure of figures like Laurie Anderson and Spalding Gray, Cindy Sherman and Jean-Michel Basquiat, John Zorn and Jim Jarmusch was difficult to resist for us yuppie-oppressed, MTV-addled Generation Xers desperate for deliverance.

headline: Rodents Too Cute Not to Share
abstract: The Wildlife Conservation Society’s photographer has been busy tugging at our hearts, now offering up pictures of Patagonian cavies.
lead_paragraph: Our friends at the Wildlife Conservation Society have been inundating us with cute baby animal pix lately, and at some point it might be time to call a moratorium, but Baby Patagonian Cavy Day is definitely not the time.

lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Amazon announced a barrage of new tablets and e-readers on Thursday that makes its challenge to Apple’s iPad a little more serious.

abstract: Cornel Lucas made his name photographing celebrities for decades, understanding light in a way as to almost stitch it into the faces of famous subjects like Brigitte Bardot, Gregory Peck and Marlene Dietrich.

lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — A day after Bill Clinton attacked Representative Paul D. Ryan‘s Medicare plan by saying “it takes some brass” to make the claims he has, Mr. Ryan did not mention the former president at a rally here on Thursday.

headline: Fort Hood Shooting Suspect’s Beard Must Be Shaved, Military Judge Rules
keywords: ['Beards and Mustaches', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A ruling finds valid reasons to curtail the religious rights of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist charged in a deadly rampage in 2009.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — A military judge on Thursday ordered officials to forcibly shave Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist charged in the shooting rampage at the Fort Hood base here in 2009, a move that is likely to delay the start of his trial for weeks as his defense lawyers appeal the ruling.

lead_paragraph: MoMA PS1

headline: A Thing for Lamé and Condemned Men
abstract: Nicole Kidman talks about her life and career, including her new film “The Paperboy.”
lead_paragraph: NICOLE KIDMAN, movie star, Oscar winner and red-carpet regular, recently played a cow. Talk about your glamour roles.

headline: Theater Talkback: Finding Inspiration in Improvisation
abstract: Musical-theater composer David Yazbek describes why an improv comedy duo has excited him more than most scripted theater he’s seen recently.
lead_paragraph: During the summer, ArtsBeat invited members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. Trav S. D., a historian of vaudeville, talked about the long bare-knuckles history shared between the boxing ring and the stage; Alexis Soloski, a critic and theater professor, highlighted unforgettable stage entrances; and the playwright Sarah Ruhl explained why critics were not invited to review her “Melancholy Play.”

headline: Putin’s Ambitions Turn to the Far East
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin is hoping to strengthen ties with the Pacific Rim and pursuing ambitious development in Russia itself.
lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is seizing on the Asia-Pacific economic summit conference being held here this weekend to turn assertively to the Far East, hoping to strengthen ties with the Pacific Rim and pursuing ambitious development in Russia itself, starting with this formerly secret naval fortress turned shipping hub on the Sea of Japan.

headline: First Day of School, Brooklyn
abstract: I love the industry of the second-grade classroom. And I also love the unassailable logic of keeping the tissues in the country-music corner.
lead_paragraph: So today is the first day of public school in New York City. My three kids are all old hands at this by now, so the drop-off was easy. They’re going into second, fifth and eighth grades. For some reason, the eighth grader doesn’t begin school until tomorrow, so he got to go back to his elementary school to see off his younger brother and sister. He was fawned over by his old teachers, who seemed truly amazed that he is now a very tall 13-year-old. I could tell he was enjoying the attention until it happened that the director of his middle school has a second grader he was dropping off; my 13-year-old quickly vanished.

headline: Harriet Jacobs’s First Assignment
abstract: The former slave and memoirist goes to Washington as a correspondent. What she finds among the city’s black refugees shocks a nation.
lead_paragraph: Harriet Jacobs arrived in Washington in June 1862, she later reported, “without molestation.” Lots of people traveled in and out of the capital at the time, but for Jacobs it was quite a feat. By then a correspondent on assignment for William Lloyd Garrison’s newspaper The Liberator, Jacobs was a former slave and author of the book “Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl,” which she wrote under the assumed name Linda Brent. Traveling through Maryland, where slavery was still legal, and Pennsylvania, where anti-black animus still ran high, would have made for tough going for most free blacks. Even fewer could have taken in the squalor that Jacobs found among the thousands of refugees from the South now huddled in the capital.

headline: The Dangerous Center
abstract: The president will outline his plan for cutting “what we don’t need” tonight, which should worry anyone concerned about the future of Medicare and Medicaid.
lead_paragraph: Many of the Democrats who thrilled to Bill Clinton’s defense of an active government last night have conveniently forgotten how angry they were every time he tacked to the center, most notably by drastically reducing welfare benefits in 1996. President Obama shares some of those instincts toward ideological concessions, creating a bit of suspense regarding the nature of the second-term agenda he intends to unveil tonight.

headline: Partners Create a Superdealership
abstract: Former executives at Sotheby’s and Christie’s join forces as part of a new partnership of superdealers.
lead_paragraph: When was the last time an expert from a top auction house dispensed with longtime allegiances and joined forces with someone from the enemy camp? In the fiercely competitive world of Sotheby’s and Christie’s, such an occurrence is rarer than a prized Vermeer.

abstract: Knoedler & Co., an art gallery that recently closed after 165 years in business, is selling off its remaining inventory at auction.
lead_paragraph: The now-shuttered Knoedler & Co. gallery, which is the subject of several lawsuits charging it sold fakes, will sell nearly three dozen works from its remaining inventory at auction this fall.

lead_paragraph: New York

lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Gaza Strip, Turkey and Lebanon.

headline: Lost Tracks
abstract: Michael Chabon’s new novel is set in and around a used record store in Northern California.
lead_paragraph: “Telegraph Avenue,” Michael Chabon’s rich, comic new novel, is a homage to an actual place: the boulevard in Northern California where Oakland — historically an African-American city — aligns with Berkeley, whose bourgeois white inhabitants are, as one character puts it, “liable to invest all their hope of heaven in the taste of an egg laid in the backyard by a heritage-breed chicken.” The novel is equally a tribute to the cinematic style of Quentin Tarantino, whose films its characters study and discuss, and whose preoccupations pepper its pages: kung fu, cinematic allusions and the blaxploitation films of the 1970s; and an interest in African-American characters and experience. Chabon and Tarantino make an unlikely duo; while the latter’s films tend toward gaudy eruptions of violence, Chabon bends Tarantino’s sensibility to a warmhearted novel about fatherhood in which the onstage violence consists of two graphic childbirth scenes and a 15-year-old boy whacking a chubby thug with a wooden sword. A self-help book in the style of Andrei Tarkovsky would be hardly more oxymoronic.

headline: How Does Denzel Washington Take Off?
abstract: Denzel Washington and his directors and co-stars try to characterize his work as an actor.
lead_paragraph: THE art of acting is so peculiar that even its most skillful practitioners (and the co-workers who love them) can’t quite explain how they do what they do. When you watch a performance like Denzel Washington’s in Robert Zemeckis’s “Flight” (opening Nov. 2), you want to get under the hood of it somehow, to understand what this remarkable thing is made of and what keeps it, improbably, aloft for two perilous hours. But when you ask Mr. Washington or his co-stars how it’s done, they’re mostly at a loss for words, or rather, they talk around it, trying to get at its mysterious workings by way of metaphors, anecdotes and the odd sweeping generality.

headline: Bill Clinton Draws More Viewers Than N.F.L. Opener
abstract: More people watched former President Bill Clinton’s speech to the Democratic National Convention than tuned in to the N.F.L. season opener.
lead_paragraph: More people watched former President Bill Clinton’s speech to the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday night than tuned in to see the N.F.L. season opener.

headline: An Unfit Friend
abstract: Planning a vacation with friends, the challenges of career talk and debating who pays a bill for home repairs.
lead_paragraph: I am inviting several friends on a week’s vacation abroad, all expenses paid. All of the guests (but one) are extremely fit, and I’m planning lots of hiking and biking. But I fear that the unfit guest, who is also needy, will ask others to stay behind with her, depriving them of wonderful experiences. The villa has a pool and is near the village, so she should be able to entertain herself. May I discourage her from asking others to keep her company, or ask guests to take turns baby-sitting, or should I let the chips fall where they may? Anonymous

headline: Adrift With a Tiger and the Film God
abstract: Ang Lee’s latest movie is an adaptation of the fantastical novel “Life of Pi,” about an Indian teenager marooned on a boat with a tiger for 227 days.
lead_paragraph: “YOU become the movie you are making,” the Oscar-winning director Ang Lee said in a recent telephone interview. Given that the movie in question is “Life of Pi,” based on the award-winning, fantastical novel about a boy and a Bengal tiger marooned on a boat for 227 days, Mr. Lee is feeling a bit more at sea than usual these days.

lead_paragraph: John Stanton, BuzzFeed’s Washington bureau chief, on conflicts that have arisen within the party at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Cooling a Computer Server With Mineral Oil
abstract: In a yearlong trial, Intel found that substituting oil immersion for the circulation of air reduced its energy costs by 10 to 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: When they’re using their smartphones or tapping away on laptops, few people pause to think about the enormous amount of energy needed to power the data centers that store and deliver the information in all those e-mails and on Web sites and Facebook pages.

headline: Makarova and Soares, Last-Minute Teammates, Win Mixed Doubles
abstract: The mixed doubles title at the United States Open was won by Ekaterina Makarova and Bruno Soares, who registered to play together less than one minute before the deadline.
lead_paragraph: A pick-up team that registered to play with less than one minute remaining before the tournament deadline won the 2012 United States Open mixed doubles championship.

headline: Hello, Mummy! We’re Here About That Inheritance
abstract: The theme of filial ingratitude looms in Fred Schepisi’s dramatically unsteady, blustery if likable film “The Eye of the Storm.”
lead_paragraph: The curtain rises in “The Eye of the Storm” with the old lady in bed, angrily grasping at the covers and a life that she refuses to relinquish. Much as she has in the past, Elizabeth Hunter (Charlotte Rampling), an Australian matriarch, lords over all, including her servants and two children, Basil (Geoffrey Rush) and Dorothy (Judy Davis), who have returned to her, reluctantly, skittishly, to secure their inheritance. During their visit Elizabeth fades in and out, by turns raging and murmuring as she fights the world, her seemingly ungrateful children and maybe herself.

lead_paragraph: Unlike Darlene O’Hara, the fictional detective at the center of his novels, Peter de Jonge has opened Milano’s only once. “For research,” he said, sitting in the century-old dive bar on East Houston Street in Manhattan early one recent morning.

headline: A Chinese Dealer, Trafficker in Mystery
abstract: Christie’s is auctioning research materials used by C. T. Loo, a leading dealer in Chinese artifacts in the first half of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese art dealer C. T. Loo held court at his galleries in Paris, New York, Shanghai and Beijing. From the 1910s through the 1940s, he spoke mysteriously of his “friends” who could acquire artifacts in the countryside, while he angled spotlights on stone Buddha heads and opalescent jade bowls for sale.

headline: Treasures of an Heiress From a Personal Paradise
abstract: The home at the center of “Doris Duke’s Shangri La” unites diverse styles and periods with great taste and great wealth. Its treasures are on display in New York.
lead_paragraph: The 1930s modernist home at the center of “Doris Duke’s Shangri La: Architecture, Landscape and Islamic Art,” at the Museum of Arts and Design, is a masterpiece of refined eclecticism. Designed for its site in Honolulu by an architect from Palm Beach, Fla., and filled with treasures from the Islamic world, it unites diverse styles and periods with great taste and, it must be said, great wealth.

headline: Israel to Admit 3 of 21 Africans Waiting in Desert
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Illegal Immigrants']
abstract: The government is in the midst of putting in place a tough new policy intended to stem the influx of African immigrants and asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For days, their blurred images had appeared on Israeli television screens and in the newspapers, a group of 21 African migrants crouching on the desert floor behind the new steel fence that Israel has built along its border with Egypt.

headline: At Convention, Obama Surrogates Extol Foreign Policy Successes
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: One of the Obama campaign’s goals during the Democratic convention is to convince voters that they are better off than they were four years ago. On Thursday President Obama’s surrogates drew on the administration’s foreign policy record to make the case.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — One of the Obama campaign’s goals during the Democratic convention is to convince voters that they are better off — or at least no worse off — than they were four years ago. On Thursday night President Obama — along with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts — will draw on the administration’s foreign policy record to make the case.

headline: Is This Not the Best-Looking Bug You’ve Ever Seen?
abstract: Vote for the critter you think is prettiest.

abstract: The interest in California trousseau is a sign that the state’s wine industry may evolve in unexpected directions.
lead_paragraph: KELSEYVILLE, Calif.

headline: Common Threads, Uncommon Ties
abstract: “Bound Unbound: Lin Tianmiao,” at Asia Society, focuses primarily on theatrical, technically refined installations by this Chinese artist that have been less widely shown.
lead_paragraph: Lin Tianmiao, whose derivative, portentously surrealistic sculpture is the subject of “Bound Unbound” at Asia Society, is one of a rare kind in China, where she lives: a nationally and internationally renowned female artist. It was an epic journey that brought Ms. Lin to this eminence.

headline: Hermès and Craftsmanship
abstract: Hermès hosted a Fashion Week cocktail party and dinner in a deconsecrated Park Avenue church, a fine place in which to gather a group of prosperous New Yorkers to show reverence for the efforts that go into making a Kelly bag.
lead_paragraph: The question was surely rhetorical. “Do you know the right way to eat caviar?’’ said John Martinez, a cater-waiter.

headline: Complaints Against Lenders
abstract: The new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau says that just over half the mortgage complaints over the last year centered on problems borrowers encountered when they fell behind in payments.
lead_paragraph: THE new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau received 23,500 complaints about mortgage lenders from last December through this past June, according to a recently released semiannual report. And, not surprisingly, just over half the complaints centered on the problems borrowers encountered when they were unable to make payments.

headline: All of Their Business | Bernadette Corporation at Artists Space
abstract: A show at Artists Space gathers together the prolific output of this influential and intentionally enigmatic quasi-corporation.
lead_paragraph: Since the mid-1990s, Bernadette Van-Huy, John Kelsey and Antek Walczak, operating as the collective Bernadette Corporation, have run a critically acclaimed underground fashion label; published a magazine, Made in USA, as well as a novel, “Reena Spaulings”; and produced a handful of films, including “Get Rid of Yourself” (2003), which revolves around the riots at the 2001 G8 Summit and features an awkward star turn by the actress Chloë Sevigny.

headline: Songs of Innocence, à la the Monkees
abstract: Marin Mazzie, in her show at 54 Below, uses cabaret as a time machine to revisit her musical past.
lead_paragraph: What sweet, silly dreams we have as naïve adolescents soaking up popular culture and mooning over the teen idols of the moment. When the Broadway singer Marin Mazzie (“Kiss Me, Kate,” “Passion”) was growing up in Rockford, Ill., she recalled on Wednesday evening at 54 Below, she was in the thrall of the Monkees’ Davy Jones and of David Cassidy and fantasized about being “the long-lost Partridge” on “The Partridge Family.”

headline: Where Anxieties Roam
abstract: “Toxic Beauty: The Art of Frank Moore,” a retrospective in two galleries at New York University, reflects an intellectually fervent maverick commenting on contemporary issues.
lead_paragraph: Frank Moore had a busy, productive career in and around painting until it was cut short by AIDS in 2002. He was 48, one among many artists felled by the disease.

lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Flea recently announced plans to expand on the success of their all-food market, Smorgasburg, by launching a second weekly location in Brooklyn Bridge Park.

headline: Obama Would Be Big Favorite With ‘Fired Up’ Base
abstract: If President Obama can get a good turnout from his base, he’ll be the heavy favorite to win in November — even if Mitt Romney gets a strong turnout as well.
lead_paragraph: There’s one advantage that President Obama has that Mitt Romney probably doesn’t. If he can get a good turnout from his base, he’ll be the heavy favorite to win in November — even if Mr. Romney gets a strong turnout as well.

headline: The Inspiration Didn’t Fade
abstract: Discarded plastic provides ideas for new porcelain containers.
lead_paragraph: When Foekje Fleur van Duin was an art student in the Netherlands, she read about the masses of discarded containers that float in the ocean. She went to the Maas River near Rotterdam in search of her own “plastic soup.”

headline: Putin Jokes About Orgies to Cast Pussy Riot Protesters as Degenerates
abstract: In comments broadcast on Thursday, Russian President Vladimir Putin joked about the reputed benefits of group sex for the lazy as he attacked the morals of three women from the punk band Pussy Riot.
lead_paragraph: In comments broadcast on Thursday, the Russian President Vladimir V. Putin joked about the reputed benefits of group sex for the lazy as he attacked the morals of three women from the punk band Pussy Riot who were jailed by a Moscow court last month.

headline: Step and Lunge and Forge Bonds
abstract: At the 92nd Street Y, an exercise class called Relentless has several components and tends to have repeat participants.
lead_paragraph: AS a fan of old-school workouts, I find many fitness classes too fancy and gimmicky. But once in a while, something comes along that excites and intimidates the skeptical, hard-core exerciser in me. That something right now is Relentless, a 75-minute class held on Tuesday nights at the 92nd Street Y on the Upper East Side.

headline: A Few Hungry Writers, Playing Fast and Loose
abstract: In “The Words,” a novelist comes up with the story of a writer who plagiarized yet another writer. Where did that come from?
lead_paragraph: “The Words” is a clever, entertaining yarn that doesn’t bear close scrutiny. Even superficial examination of this film reveals myriad flaws, despite a compelling performance by Jeremy Irons as a fictional writer in a book also called “The Words.” At the heart of this story-within-a-story is a tale of plagiarism and ambition.

headline: The Enduring Erotic Life Cycle of an Unpromising Relationship
abstract: “Keep the Lights On,” by Ira Sachs, follows two men as their relationship grows, falters and endures over more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: When we first meet Erik (Thure Lindhardt), a Danish filmmaker living in New York in 1997, he is on the telephone looking for a casual sexual hookup. He seems fickle and impatient, hanging up on potential partners at the first hint that the chemistry might be wrong, but eventually he finds more or less what he is looking for. Quite a bit more, actually, in the person of Paul (Zachary Booth), even though Paul says he has a steady girlfriend, and Erik is not interested in commitment.

headline: Generations United for Improvisation, Refined but Violent
abstract: The emerging jazz duo of Peter Brötzmann and Jason Adasiewicz, now on tour, offered a set of improvisation at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: “You take when a high note comes through, lifting and going and then stopping because there’s no place else for it to go,” the saxophonist Sidney Bechet explained some time in the 1950s. “That’s stepping music — it’s got to rush itself right off your voice or your horn because it’s so excited.”

headline: A Centennial, With Toy Pianos and a Coffee Table
abstract: John Cage’s centennial was commemorated this week by programs at the Stone, in the East Village, and Symphony Space, on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: For a composer who was a true rebel, a pioneering American maverick, John Cage was frequently celebrated in programs and festivals at the world’s most prestigious concert halls. But he surely would have been delighted to see the centennial of his birth commemorated in New York at “Cage100,” a three-day festival at the Stone, the nonprofit performance space in the East Village dedicated to experimental and avant-garde music.

headline: Where Bronze Takes Fine Form
abstract: At Modern Art Foundry in Astoria, Queens, the work of prominent sculptors goes big.
lead_paragraph: At Modern Art Foundry in Astoria, Queens, the work of prominent sculptors goes big.

lead_paragraph: Some may say that women's tennis is boring, but the women remaining at the U.S. Open are set up for an intriguing semifinals. Lynn Zinser has the latest from Flushing

lead_paragraph: Scenes from New York City public schools as students returned for the first day of classes.

headline: A Towering Career; a Collision With War
abstract: Even though Yasuo Matsui lived in New York for four decades and designed several New York buildings, the architect was among the Japanese detained during World War II.
lead_paragraph: THE mass imprisonment of Japanese in World War II remains a painful blot on our history. There were no internment camps for the Japanese on the East Coast, but you didn’t need to live in the West to be touched by the hand of fear, as Yasuo Matsui found out. Even though he had lived here for four decades, designed one of New York’s tallest buildings and ran a major construction company, the Japanese-born architect was rousted out of bed on the night of the Pearl Harbor attack, held at Ellis Island for two months and spent the war under house arrest.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  iPhone 5 Video and Apple TV Delay
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes Vanity Fair anointing a collection of technology executives as “The New Establishment,” the prospect of mobile apps for 4Chan and an 84-second video that claims to show an iPhone 5 starting up.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Leaps, Flips, Twists and Pyramids Pave Way to Texas
abstract: The reality show “Cheer” on CMT focuses more on cheerleaders than on their parents, and their leader doesn’t veer into abusiveness for the benefit of the cameras.
lead_paragraph: Take the nastiness and willful boorishness out of a certain breed of reality show, and what do you have? A series you can actually bear to watch.

headline: Dropping the Beats at the Democratic Convention
abstract: Instead of choosing a veteran band or arena group, the Democratic National Convention gave the musical responsibilities to one man: DJ Cassidy.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As the first notes of Fleetwood Mac’s “Don’t Stop” rang through the Time Warner Cable Arena here on Wednesday night, the packed crowd whipped into a frenzy, nearly drowning out the song as they cheered for minutes for former President Bill Clinton.

headline: Collaborative and Solo, With a Certain Feminist Bent
abstract: T-shirt descriptions inspired the works in “Raw/Cooked: Ulrike Müller,” at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: Collaboration is one of the hallmarks of feminist art and scholarship. The art system doesn’t really accommodate this, however. Instead, criticism, art history and institutions are set up to canonize (historically male) individual artists. And for curators, it’s considerably easier to work with one artist than a hundred.

headline: A Walk on Fire Island
abstract: “Island Night” is part philosophic dialogue, part poetic reverie and part nature walk.
lead_paragraph: “Island Night” is part philosophic dialogue, part poetic reverie and part nature walk.

headline: Socrates on the Beach: An Island Walk
abstract: “Island Night,” a 12-hour overnight walk on Fire Island, hosted by the arts group Elastic City, is part philosophic dialogue, part poetic reverie and part nature walk.
lead_paragraph: EVERY summer thousands of New Yorkers go to Fire Island, a narrow barrier island off the South Shore of Long Island, in search of sun, sand, sex and sea breezes. But this year, on the last weekend in August, a motley group of nine disembarked at the Pines, the famous gay resort at the island’s midpoint, hellbent on Socratic dialogue.

headline: New 9/11 Programs Are a British Task
abstract: For the 11th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, specials include relatively thoughtful documentaries from Testimony Films about firefighters and a remarkable survivor.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 11 is approaching, and American television is maintaining a polite distance. Since last year, when more than two dozen new documentaries and memorials were presented for the 10th anniversary of the 2001 attacks, our attention has receded again. Apparently the most appropriate gift for an 11th anniversary is reruns.

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — State ethics regulators decided this week not to authorize a full-fledged investigation of use of public money by the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, to finance a confidential settlement with two women who said they were sexually harassed by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, people with knowledge of the inquiry said Thursday.

lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A Roman Catholic bishop was found guilty on Thursday of failing to report suspected child abuse, becoming the first American bishop in the decades-long sexual abuse scandal to be convicted of shielding a pedophile priest.

keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Representative John Lewis of Georgia, a veteran of the civil rights movement, warned delegates that new voting laws passed in several Republican-led states requiring voter IDs and limiting early voting would make it harder for people to vote.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis of Georgia told the delegates at the Democratic convention on Thursday that he first came to Charlotte, N.C., on a Freedom Ride in 1961, the year President Obama was born, and warned them that new voting laws passed in several Republican-led states requiring voter IDs and limiting early voting would make it harder for people to vote.

headline: Intricate and Odd, With Little Child’s Play
abstract: “Toys in the Attic,” not always childlike, is an animated tale full of odd characters.
lead_paragraph: The strange, often beautiful beings in the animated feature “Toys in the Attic” exist in a faraway land located somewhere between Czech surrealism and Pixar communitarianism. A simple story intricately told, it centers on a small familial group — a doll named Buttercup, a teddy bear, a marionette and a blob — whose happy life is threatened by a bust of a bald man that looks as if it once sat on a pedestal in Communist Party headquarters. The bust is attended to by a motley assortment of minions, including what looks like a termite with a human head, and a severed arm wearing a black leather glove, which suggests that the director Jiri Barta is a Stanley Kubrick fan.

headline: A New Marriage License and Each Other, and Little Else
abstract: A homeless couple panhandled enough for a license, and then slept on church steps before filling out forms.
lead_paragraph: Tiana Polomaine was stretched out on a bench sleeping next to her fiancé, Dave Merritt, when their number came up just before noon on Thursday at the marriage bureau on Worth Street in downtown Manhattan.

headline: The, Yes, Upside of Broadcast
abstract: Cable series often enjoy many advantages over broadcast shows, but there are advantages to being a broadcast show as well.
lead_paragraph: SHED no tears for “The Good Wife.”

abstract: The Bryan brothers will face a familiar opposing team in the men’s doubles final.
lead_paragraph: Marc Lopez of Spain, his left leg bandaged from ankle to knee, started toward a drop shot and stopped, the promise of pain too great. Moments later, his partner, Marcel Granollers, looked Lopez in the eye. Lopez nodded.
