headline: Visas-for-Dollars Program a Boon to Hotel Developers
abstract: A federal program that grants so-called EB-5 visas to foreigners who invest at least $500,000 in an American business has become a popular source of cheap financing for hotel companies.
lead_paragraph: When Marriott International wanted to open a new hotel in downtown Seattle, the company’s developers didn’t sell bonds, take out a mortgage or tap other traditional forms of financing for the $88 million project. Instead, it raised the bulk of the money from wealthy immigrants who wanted a green card.

headline: Unhappy Hooligans, Dripping With Lust
abstract: The teenage characters of a popular British TV sitcom take their antics to the big screen in “The Inbetweeners.”
lead_paragraph: In “Among the Thugs,” Bill Buford’s horrifying nonfiction book about the brutal excesses of British soccer hooliganism, he writes about gangs of fans who travel to European cities like Turin ostensibly to support their teams. In one unforgettable scene Mr. Buford watches as hordes of Manchester United followers swarm out of a Turin stadium and into the streets in a frenzy of violence, savagely beating anyone, children included. In the middle of the mayhem, in between the stomping and punching, he overhears one of the rampaging goons say, “The city is ours” and repeat the word ours, ours, ours. There’s a sense that the rioting is a kind of postcolonial invasion for at least this one thug, an idea that’s cemented when later he says, “We took the city.”

headline: Draghi
abstract: A step in the right direction, but hopefully not the last.
lead_paragraph: I’m still bogged down in family health-related stuff, hence limited interventions here. Still, I guess I’d better weigh in on what would, if it weren’t for the DNC, be the story of the day: the latest announcement from the European Central Bank.

headline: In Speech, Obama to Plead for Patience
abstract: President Obama prepared to accept the Democratic nomination to run for a second term on Thursday night, and planned to say that “our problems can be solved.”
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — President Obama prepared to accept the Democratic nomination to run for a second term on Thursday night, and planned to say that “our problems can be solved,” while making a forceful case that in four years, he has brought the economy from disaster to a recovery which would be imperiled by a return to Republican stewardship.

headline: The Coming Tug of War Over a New State Budget
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Some analysts expect things to be tight, but easier than they were in the 2011 legislative session, which resulted in significant cuts.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Divorce Blues, Waylaid by a New Infatuation
abstract: A 19-year-old actor’s passionate, late-adolescent restlessness awakens some of a 30-something divorced woman’s dormant enthusiasm for life.
lead_paragraph: The ostensibly grown-up man residing in the parental nest — usually in a boyhood bedroom full of movie posters, video games and action figures — is a staple of American comedy. He is a figure to be pitied and ridiculed, but also envied, since he still dwells in a juvenile paradise that the rest of us, with our jobs and kids and dreary domestic routines, supposedly long to recapture.

headline: A New Way to Tackle College Algebra
abstract: The University of Texas at Arlington has opened a computer-filled math emporium to address the “single greatest academic barrier to student success”: mathematics.
lead_paragraph: Alexzandria Siprian, a senior at the University of Texas at Arlington who is double-majoring in Spanish and theater, is not a math person. Early in her college career, she squeaked through her required algebra course with a D.

headline: Where Bronze Transforms Into Fine Art
abstract: Modern Art Foundry, in Astoria, Queens, was opened in 1932 and is where many prominent sculptors go to have their creations cast in bronze.
lead_paragraph: THE brick-walled workshop is dark and quiet. Fine white dust hangs in the air and coats the walls and floor. A small group of men work intently, dressed in silver spaceman jackets and long leather aprons that cover their bluejeans.

headline: Far Beyond ‘Playhouse,’ Artist Remains Playful
abstract: “Beauty Is Embarrassing” looks at the artist Wayne White, known for his work on “Pee-wee’s Playhouse” and other projects.
lead_paragraph: The creativity grows like kudzu in “Beauty Is Embarrassing,” Neil Berkeley’s enlightening and often hilarious portrait of the Los Angeles artist Wayne White. And it yields a thousand blossoms. Mr. White, an Emmy-winning puppeteer for “Pee-wee’s Playhouse,” has had his share of career dips, only to arrive as a popular painter of some very amusing canvases. Tracing his evolution, the film gets at larger issues — about imagination, relationships and laughter.

headline: Rap Rivalry and Twitter Outrage Lead Pitchfork to Pull Video
abstract: Pitchfork retracted a video interview with the rapper Chief Keef that was taped at a gun range after an outcry over his comments about the shooting death of another Chicago rapper.
lead_paragraph: Pitchfork, the usually irreverent music blog, has apologized for publishing a videotaped interview with the Chicago rapper Chief Keef that was filmed at a shooting range and features images of the young hip-hop star firing a gun. “This concept was rushed and never should have happened,” Pitchfork’s editor, Mark Richardson, said in an online statement. He called the episode, one of the site’s “Selector” interviews with rappers, “insensitive and irresponsible.”

headline: His Last Battle for Chelsea, or So He Says
keywords: ['High Line (NYC)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Edward Kirkland, 87, Chelsea’s longtime champion, is preparing to fight the expansion of the Chelsea Market.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Edward Kirkland gazes out the windows of his 16th-floor apartment at Seventh Avenue and 23rd Street, he zeros in, no binoculars necessary, on the construction cranes lately commandeering the western horizon. It is not a view he treasures.

headline: For International Students, College Checklists for September
keywords: ['ACT (Examination)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'SAT (College Admission Test)']
abstract: College counselors in the United States offer monthly advice for juniors and seniors who want to stay on track during the admissions process.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselor’s Calendar, designed to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

headline: Woodward Book Details Battles Over Deficit
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Bob Woodward’s “The Price of Politics” paints a portrait of dysfunction that began even before President Obama was inaugurated and has only grown worse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new book by the journalist Bob Woodward chronicles the descent of Barack Obama’s Washington into partisan trench warfare and mines the minutiae of the largely failed negotiations between House Republicans and the White House to tame the nation’s deficit problem over the last two years.

headline: These Wedding Crashers Are Zombies
abstract: Newlyweds struggle to reunite after an undeadly virus separates them in the Spanish-language horror film “[REC] 3: Genesis.”
lead_paragraph: “[REC] 3: Genesis,” the latest in the “[REC]” franchise and the first without the co-director Jaume Balagueró, strips away the strengths of its predecessors — among them a spooky sound design and gloomy, warrenlike location — to deliver an altogether brighter, jokier blood bath. In doing so, however, the remaining director, Paco Plaza, may have murdered his fan base along with his film’s victims.

headline: Back to China, Clueless Child in Tow
abstract: Mulberry Child,” a documentary heavy on re-enactments, shows the generation gap between a Chinese-American writer and her daughter.
lead_paragraph: Living through China’s social and political upheaval in the 20th century tends to raise the stakes on a typical parental lesson in family history and forbearance, as shown in the documentary “Mulberry Child.” Directed by Susan Morgan Cooper, this lumbering, re-enactment-heavy film adapts a memoir that was written by Jian Ping in hopes of enlightening her thoroughly Americanized daughter, Lisa, and perhaps forging a deeper bond.

headline: Insurance Chief Answers Industry Bias Charges
keywords: ['Insurance', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Eleanor Kitzman, whose first year as Texas’ insurance commissioner has led to complaints about pro-insurance-company bias, responds to her critics, some of whom have called for her removal.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Kitzman has been Texas’ insurance commissioner for only a year, but her tenure in a usually obscure political post has already included headline-grabbing controversies.

headline: Italian Doubles Team Wins a Shootout
abstract: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci reached their third Grand Slam final of the year.
lead_paragraph: Two point-blank shootouts enlivened Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci’s semifinal doubles victory on Thursday. The Italians won, 6-3, 6-2, over Nuria Llagostera Vives and Maria Martinez Sanchez of Spain.

headline: Jets Seem Ready to Unveil Closely Guarded Wildcat
abstract: The Jets, who kept the Wildcat offense under wraps during the exhibition season, may be ready to unleash Tim Tebow in their season opener against Buffalo on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Fifty-one seconds into his opening remarks at Monday’s news conference, Jets Coach Rex Ryan coolly slipped in a mention of the offensive formation he had spent weeks trying to play down.

headline: Moody Shots of Detroit’s Urban Decay
abstract: In the documentary “Detropia,” residents lament their city’s plight and artists seek real estate bargains.
lead_paragraph: Late in “Detropia,” Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady’s dreamy documentary about a slowly crumbling Detroit, a Swiss tourist confesses an appreciation for the aesthetics of decay. That interest is not only shared by the filmmakers, but it also may be their driving force: in this visual caress of postindustrial blight, disintegration has never looked so gorgeous.

headline: Softening a Trucker’s Rough Edges
abstract: “Las Acacias” follows the interaction between a trucker and a woman with toddler.
lead_paragraph: Beating a sweet retreat from exposition and event, the Argentine director Pablo Giorgelli turns his minimalist road movie, “Las Acacias,” into a swelling meditation on wounded hearts and rekindled hopes.

headline: Russia: Pussy Riot Lawyer Questioned
abstract: The police summoned a lawyer for the punk band Pussy Riot for questioning in a criminal case that the authorities say is unrelated to the Pussy Riot case.
lead_paragraph: The police summoned a lawyer for the punk band Pussy Riot for questioning in a criminal case that the authorities say is unrelated to the Pussy Riot case. They plan to question the lawyer, Mark Feygin, about disturbances during a large street protest last spring in Moscow. The wide-ranging investigation has led to the arrests of many opposition figures. Mr. Feygin was one of the speakers at the protest, but he said that he never scuffled with the police and that he thought the summons was indeed related to his work as a defense lawyer for the band members, three of whom were recently convicted of hooliganism for a protest in a Moscow cathedral. “I link this with the Pussy Riot case, there are no doubts about it,” he said in an interview. “I think this is simply an attempt to pressure us.”

headline: An Ad Agency Crowdsources Its Own Employees’ Morale
abstract: A New York advertising firm has chosen two ideas from a crowdsourcing competition, including one that will give employees 4,500 square feet of office space for personal projects.
lead_paragraph: AN advertising agency that has been crowdsourcing ideas from its employees is at it again, adopting additional suggestions from staff members on how to improve operations and, by extension, morale.

headline: Russia: Fighter Jet Crashes, Killing Pilot
abstract: A Russian Air Force MiG-29 fighter jet crashed Thursday afternoon near Chita, a city in Eastern Siberia, slamming into a hill close to a local airport and killing the pilot.
lead_paragraph: A Russian Air Force MiG-29 fighter jet crashed Thursday afternoon near Chita, a city in Eastern Siberia, slamming into a hill close to a local airport and killing the pilot. Flights of MiG-29 fighters have been grounded pending further investigation, a Defense Ministry spokesman, Igor Konashenkov, told the RIA Novosti news agency. The pilot’s body was found by a search party, and there were no weapons on board, Mr. Konashenkov said. The Interfax news service reported that a second fighter plane crashed Thursday near the Siberian city of Novosibirsk, this one a Sukhoi Su-27.

abstract: New York Fashion Week officially kicked off on Thursday, and nerves were already jangled, schedules strung tight.

headline: From Convention Floor, Delegates Give Obama Benefit of Their Doubts
abstract: Many of the grass-roots activists, union members and others at the convention acknowledged that the president had fallen short in some areas, but they said he had earned a second term.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In a perfect world, Sara Riley, a delegate to the Democratic National Convention from Cedar Rapids, Iowa, would have preferred that President Obama had done more to fulfill what the party saw as the transformative nature of the 2008 campaign and election.

headline: Friendship Turns Into a Tense Triangle
abstract: In “Green,” a couple’s friendship with a woman is the source of tension.
lead_paragraph: “Green,” more sketch than fully realized film, musters a decently eerie cabin-in-the-woods tone and look. But Sophia Takal, writing and directing her first feature, has only immature ideas amateurishly executed to bring to her familiar troubled-couple-and-a-stranger setup.

headline: A Fashionable Face-Off in 1973
abstract: “Versailles ’73: American Runway Revolution” reflects on a battle between American and French designers.
lead_paragraph: What began as a clever stunt to raise money to restore Versailles — a fashion show featuring five French designers and five Americans — became a kind of battle: in one corner Europe, formal and staid; in the other the razzle-dazzle New World. The winner in a K.O.: America!

headline: Conventional Contrast
abstract: Who’s disciplined now.
lead_paragraph: I still remember 2004, when the contrast between the party conventions was painful to watch: disciplined, on-message Republicans, wimpy Democrats afraid to take a stand and hoping that biography would save the day.

headline: Romance, the Quirky Souvenir
abstract: Strangers often seem to carry important information about what is valuable in life, and this makes them incredibly alluring.
lead_paragraph: THIS summer, during a conference in Berlin, a fellow attendee told me about the kind of summer love that arises in his profession.

abstract: What’s happening in Charlotte.

headline: A Man, and a Potential Meal
abstract: Suburban cannibalism is central to the plot of “Serving Up Richard.”
lead_paragraph: Is “tasty” an acceptable word to use in reference to performances in a film about cannibalism?

headline: Assassination Highlights Rifts Facing Syria Rebels
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The killing of a rebel fighter linked to Al Qaeda called new attention to the ideological differences among rebels fighting the government of President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The assassination of a Syrian rebel fighter linked to Al Qaeda called new attention on Thursday to the ideological differences among the Islamists fighting the government of President Bashar al-Assad and threatened to set off new strife among the rebels.

headline: Living in a Material World
abstract: “Desperate Endeavors” is a 1970s immigrant tale about American materialism.
lead_paragraph: The poster for “Desperate Endeavors” says it all: “Get It Today, Pay for It Later. Welcome to America.” The film — about a man who moves to New York from Bombay in 1973 — does little more than illustrate this point again and again. Directed by Salim Khassa from a script he wrote with Donald L. Wilhelm, the movie, stuck like a scratched record, doesn’t know what to make of this one point it compulsively and clumsily dramatizes.

headline: With Their Food Scarce From Drought, More Animals Try Dining in Town
abstract: Growing numbers of bears and other animals are descending from mountains and mesas, desperate to eat whatever they can find before winter arrives.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — People move to the mountains to be closer to nature. But not this close.

headline: Oops! The Mysterious Case of the Twice-Stolen Motorcycles
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: Kawasakis, Yamahas and a Ducati Monster were among the motorcycles that the authorities said a New York crime ring made disappear; then some of the stolen goods vanished from police storage.
lead_paragraph: With entirely justifiable pride, the police commissioner and the Manhattan district attorney held a news conference in July to announce that a cast of many, many good guys had broken up a gang of motorcycle thieves who, it was believed, were so voracious that they had been responsible for most thefts of cool bikes in New York City during the preceding year.

headline: Why Brokers Study Chinese
abstract: With a torrent of money flowing into the United States from China, some real estate brokers are trying to jump in farther upstream to better position themselves to win new clients.
lead_paragraph: WITH a torrent of money flowing into the United States from China, some savvy real estate brokers are trying to jump in farther upstream to better position themselves to win new clients.

headline: Dodgers and Giants Rejuvenate a Rivalry
abstract: This weekend at AT&T Park, the Dodgers and Giants meet for the first time since the Dodgers’ industry-rattling trade last month, with the Giants holding a four-and-a-half-game lead.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Black and White Kindles Are Here to Stay
abstract: Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, believes that black-and-white e-readers will always have a home in the e-reader family. The new Kindle Paperwhite is the latest evidence of this belief.
lead_paragraph: You would think that to announce a black-and-white e-reader in 2012 would be to invite ridicule. Yet when Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, showcased an updated black-and-white e-ink Kindle on Thursday, called the Kindle Paperwhite, people clapped with excitement. There were even a few “oohs” and “ahhs” from the assembled crowd.

headline: Hoping for Change at Queens School Where Chancellor Has Ties
abstract: Dennis M. Walcott, New York City’s schools chancellor, is not only an alumnus of Public School 36 in Queens, he is also a grandfather of one of its students, and thus a frequent visitor.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, Public School 36 looks like any other utilitarian school building in New York City. Its red brick walls rise three stories over St. Albans, a venerable working-class neighborhood in southeastern Queens.

keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Vitaly Borker, who terrified customers of his online eyewear store, DecorMyEyes, was sentenced to four years in federal prison and ordered to pay $100,000.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who terrified customers of his online eyewear store with threats of violence, including rape, was sentenced on Thursday to four years in federal prison and ordered to pay nearly $100,000 in restitution and fines.

headline: For Ryan, Perks of Joining Ticket Can Be Weighty
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the candidate for vice president, has learned that added scrutiny can turn even marathons and mountains into treacherous topics.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Flying high above the Rocky Mountains on Wednesday, Representative Paul D. Ryan and his brother Tobin jogged their memories to complete a list of the 14,000-foot summits below them that the vice-presidential nominee had climbed.

headline: A Lack of Name Power, but Tipsarevic and Ferrer Have Staying Power
abstract: David Ferrer earned a trip to the United States Open semifinals with a 6-3, 6-7 (5), 2-6, 6-3, 7-6 (4) victory over Janko Tipsarevic in a marathon full of gritty play and gutsy shots.
lead_paragraph: The people who bought tickets for the men’s quarterfinals session at the United States Open on Thursday afternoon were not rewarded with a marquee matchup when Janko Tipsarevic of Serbia and David Ferrer of Spain fell into their laps, but they were rewarded with perhaps the best match of the tournament.

abstract: President Obama’s speech Thursday night was quite solid, but it lacked the audacity to tackle the big policy problems ahead.

headline: Cleaning Up the Economy
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The next four years are likely to be much better than the last four years.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton’s speech at the Democratic National Convention was a remarkable combination of pretty serious wonkishness — has there ever been a convention speech with that much policy detail? — and memorable zingers. Perhaps the best of those zingers was his sarcastic summary of the Republican case for denying President Obama re-election: “We left him a total mess. He hasn’t cleaned it up fast enough. So fire him and put us back in.”

headline: Anything Woods Can Do, McIlroy Does Better
abstract: Rory McIlroy, currently ranked No. 1 in the world, shot an opening-round 64 Thursday to share the lead with three other golfers at the BMW Championship. Tiger Woods shot a 65, good for fifth place.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL, Ind. — Tiger Woods produced a deft display of scoring, if not shotmaking, with a seven-under-par 65 at Crooked Stick Golf Club on Thursday in the first round of the BMW Championship. With a little bit of magic, including a holed bump and run shot for a birdie on his final hole, Woods managed to escape mediocrity but not the shadow of his playing partner, Rory McIlroy.

headline: New York’s Moonlighting Lawmakers
abstract: If we are serious about uprooting corruption in Albany, the next step is to make service as a legislator a full-time job and ban outside sources of employment and income for our public officials.
lead_paragraph: TO read the news, one might think that the “perp walk” was a necessary rite in the career of a New York State legislator. Eighteen Albany lawmakers have left office as a result of criminal charges or ethical misconduct since 1999, according to the government-reform organization Citizens Union — a run that the organization appropriately terms a “crime wave.” There are many reasons to account for this dismal record, but one in particular concerns a practice that, at first glance, may seem endearingly quaint: the legislators are part-timers.

headline: Defunct Law Firm Keeps Its Troubles Off the Softball Field
abstract: The softball team of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the behemoth firm that went bankrupt this year, is 10-1 and is defending its league championship from last season.
lead_paragraph: On a field of bright green turf, a group of men and women trotted about on Wednesday evening, catching and throwing, hitting, spitting and sliding. They were ballplayers, but in a sense, they were also ghosts, casualties of an immense corporate collapse, with the name of their defunct former employer emblazoned on their torsos: Dewey.

headline: Louisiana: Oil Linked to BP
keywords: ['Hurricane Isaac (2012)', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: Tests performed on Thursday confirmed that the oil found on the Louisiana shoreline after Hurricane Isaac was in fact from the BP spill in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Tests performed on Thursday confirmed that the oil found on the Louisiana shoreline after Hurricane Isaac was in fact from the BP spill in 2010. While the oil led to the closing of some waters to commercial fishing, samples taken elsewhere in the Louisiana marsh also matched the oil from the spill, said Edward B. Overton, an environmental sciences professor at Louisiana State University. BP said that it was performing its own tests, but that the cleanup of oil was continuing.

lead_paragraph: If you are a New Yorker who hasn’t been to a Mets game this year — and who but the die-hards has, given their cruddy season? — you’ll want to clear your calendar this month and get to Citi Field. Yes, true Mets fans will mock your fair-weatherness, but it’s too late to worry about that now. You have about five more chances to see R. A. Dickey play, and it would be a shame to miss them.

abstract: A federal court ruled that the Obama administration was overstepping its authority, and violating the separation of powers in regards to restrictions on lawyers’ access to prisoners at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Accusing the Obama administration of “an illegitimate exercise of executive power,” a federal judge on Thursday rejected the government’s effort to impose new restrictions on lawyers’ access to prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, if they were no longer actively challenging the prisoners’ detention in federal court.

headline: New Orleans Levees Hold, and Outsiders Want In
abstract: Residents outside the ring of levees that protect New Orleans want the federal government to erect walls to protect them, too, especially after Hurricane Isaac caused the river to overflow.
lead_paragraph: LaPLACE, La. — As the motorcade swept through waterlogged stretches of St. John the Baptist Parish earlier this week, Natalie Robottom, the parish president, made her case to President Obama. Using maps and force of will, she told him that while a new ring of levees had saved New Orleans from the waters of Hurricane Isaac, LaPlace and other communities in St. John, west of the city, were still unprotected despite years of study and discussion.

headline: No Team, No Ticket Sales, but Plenty of Cash

The owners of the Spirits of St. Louis agreed to be paid a small fraction of the N.B.A.’s television money to comfort them for being cut out of joining the older league.

headline: Despite Bunts, Yankees Aren’t Sacrificing Identity
abstract: Runs are scarce, but Manager Joe Girardi doesn’t want power hitters to change their approach.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — At the most critical point in the Yankees’ season, mixed messages appeared to be emanating from the clubhouse over a two-day stretch against the Tampa Bay Rays. Kevin Long, the team’s hitting instructor, talked about bunting. Manager Joe Girardi scoffed at the idea. But later, Alex Rodriguez talked about the virtues of playing small ball.

headline: A Long, Slow Buildup to an Adoption

lead_paragraph: According to its publicity materials, “Normalcy,” a new drama at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, “tackles themes of identity, race, terrorism, nationalism, manifest destiny, marriage and the media” as it presents a “brutally honest look at transracial adoption.” Perhaps. But while someone was minding all those issues, the story got up and wandered away.

As Coach Jurgen Klinsmann looked on, he had to hope that his players would take that same bounce to Kingston for Friday night’s World Cup qualifying match against Jamaica.

headline: No. 1 With a Sound and Style All Her Own

lead_paragraph: He came ever so close to capturing the presidency in 2000, and even spoke at the 2008 convention, but this time around, Al Gore was nowhere to be seen as Democrats gathered in Charlotte, N.C., this week.

headline: The President Plays It Safe
abstract: The Democratic convention concludes with a workmanlike nomination speech.
lead_paragraph: The strongest impression left by Mitt Romney’s convention speech last week was that the Republican nominee’s campaign sees itself on pace for a narrow victory in November, with no risks or course corrections needed. The impression left by President Obama’s convention speech tonight was that incumbent’s campaign feels exactly the same way. This was a pure stay-the-course speech, workmanlike and occasionally somewhat distant, with a few inspired and moving passages standing out amid a litany of rhetorical moves that the president has made many times before. There was only the most general sketch of a second term agenda, only a relatively cursory defense of the president’s economic stewardship, and mostly assertions, rather than sustained arguments, to back up his claim that the country is headed (slowly) in the right direction. The strongest and most detailed portions of his remarks came on foreign policy (where his record is more popular and easier to defend) and in his late-in-the-speech attacks on the Republican ticket, which did effectively exploit some of the vulnerabilities that Romney’s rather content-free address created. And yes, maybe if Bill Clinton hadn’t covered so much of that territory so effectively last night, these strengths would have been enough to make the speech feel successful as a whole. But in the shadow of Clinton’s performance, the president often felt flat, rote, and unconvincing — almost as though he wasn’t quite convinced by his own arguments and promises, and felt a little awkward selling them to us.

headline: The Weatherman Is Not a Moron
abstract: In the hocus-pocus realm of predicting the future, weather forecasting is an area of progress. Your own experience may differ.
lead_paragraph: From the inside, the National Centers for Environmental Prediction looked like a cross between a submarine command center and a Goldman Sachs trading floor. Twenty minutes outside Washington, it consisted mainly of sleek workstations manned by meteorologists working an armada of flat-screen monitors with maps of every conceivable type of weather data for every corner of the country. The center is part of the National Weather Service, which Ulysses S. Grant created under the War Department. Even now, it remains true to those roots. Many of its meteorologists have a background in the armed services, and virtually all speak with the precision of former officers.

headline: Reflections of a Mets Killer
abstract: No player has tormented the Mets more than Chipper Jones, who is playing his last season and has some surprisingly warm feelings for New York and for Mets fans.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — On May 9, 1995, at Shea Stadium, the Braves’ left fielder, Chipper Jones, singled in the third inning off the Mets’ Bret Saberhagen. Later, with the score tied at 2-2, Jones led off the ninth inning with a solo homer off reliever Josias Manzanillo. It was the game-winner and the first home run of Jones’s major league career. The next night, he homered again, this time off Pete Harnisch.

He doesn’t want to lose the electorate — he’s been to couples counseling, he’s learned to listen, and he knows what to say, and most of all, what not to say.

headline: No News On Jobs
abstract: Jobs growing with population, same as it’s been.
lead_paragraph: The headline number came in a bit below expectations, but that’s probably just the noisiness in the data. The best hypothesis about the US economy this past year and more is that it has been steadily adding jobs at a pace roughly fast enough to keep up with but not get ahead of population growth. Today’s report was consistent with a continuation of that story. Nothing to see here.

headline: Before Blanchett Leaves Sydney Theater Post, Some Housekeeping
abstract: Cate Blanchett will star with Isabelle Huppert in a new production of “The Maids” for Sydney Theater Company before she leaves her job as co-artistic director. Her husband, Andrew Upton, will stay on alone as artistic director for another term.
lead_paragraph: Cate Blanchett will bid farewell to her role as co-artistic director of Sydney Theater Company by starring with Isabelle Huppert in a new production of “The Maids” as part of the company’s 2013 season, it was announced on Thursday. The Jean Genet play, about a pair of house servants with murderous designs on their employer, will be directed by Benedict Andrews, who previously directed Ms. Blanchett in “Gross und Klein (Big and Small)” and “The War of the Roses” for Sydney Theater Company. Its new translation is by Mr. Andrews and Andrew Upton, Ms. Blanchett’s husband and co-artistic director. At the start of the year Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Upton said they would step down from their posts at Sydney Theater Company, after presenting several internationally acclaimed productions including “A Streetcar Named Desire” (which starred Ms. Blanchett as Blanche DuBois) and “Uncle Vanya” (which featured her as Yelena). But last month the theater company said it had appointed Mr. Upton to stay on alone in a new term that begins next year.

headline: Jennifer Granholm's Speech
abstract: Former Governor of Michigan, Jennifer Granholm, gives a fiery address at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Former Governor of Michigan, Jennifer Granholm, gives a fiery address at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Friday Reading: How to Add Missing Titles to iTunes Tracks
abstract: How to add missing titles to iTunes tracks, long-term care looms as a rising Medicaid expense, why can’t school be more like summer and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: U.S. Blacklists Militant Haqqani Network
abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton signed an order designating the network, responsible for some of the deadliest attacks against American troops in Afghanistan, a terrorist organization.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani officials reacted cautiously on Friday to news that the United States had designated the Taliban-affiliated Haqqani network as a terrorist group, allaying fears that the move could drive a fresh wedge between the two uneasy allies.

headline: Steady Progress or More of Same? Politicians React
abstract: The jobs report was described by Democrats as a sign of progress and disparaged by Republicans as another month of sluggish underperformance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A modest improvement in the unemployment rate and a marginal increase in job creation were greeted by Democrats as signs of slow but steady progress and disparaged by Republicans as another month of sluggish economic underperformance.

headline: Off to Broadway and Back to School
abstract: Jessica Chastain, soon coming to Broadway in “The Heiress,” paid a visit to her alma mater, the Juilliard School.
lead_paragraph: JESSICA CHASTAIN has turned up lately in so many movies all at once that audiences may be forgiven for imagining that with her ethereal manner (in “The Tree of Life,” anyway) and Botticelli looks — the alabaster skin, huge green eyes and cascade of auburn hair — she wafted into Hollywood on a seashell. In fact Ms. Chastain, who makes her Broadway debut in “The Heiress” on Nov. 1, is a trained stage actress who spent four transformative years at Juilliard, from which she graduated in 2003.

headline: Lawless in Srinagar
abstract: A 12-year-old’s brush with the Indian prison system is a stark reminder that, even if it now attracts tourists, Kashmir remains a police state.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — On the morning of Aug. 21, during the foremost Muslim festival of Eid al-Fitr, I drove through Srinagar, the summer capital of the disputed Indian-controlled region of Kashmir.

headline: Parliament’s ‘Monsoon Session’ Ends in Washout
abstract: Protests and disruptions kept Parliament from passing bills and discussing issues.
lead_paragraph: The Indian Parliament’s “monsoon” session ended Friday after repeated disturbances, with little to show for its 19-day stretch in the way of bills passed or legislation debated.

headline: Big Data in Your Blood
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Sensors']
abstract: Sensors of your heart, blood, and brain are coming to market. These may a boon to science and personal health. For the companies involved, they may be goldmines of intimate real-time data on millions of subjects. How this information will be used will vary over all kinds of products and places.
lead_paragraph: “Stretchable electronics” will be able to measure heart rate, brain activity, body temperature and hydration levels.

headline: Niu Noodle House: Not Quite New, but Up to Speed
abstract: A Chinese noodle parlor that opened in June is finally in full swing.
lead_paragraph: Niu Noodle House, a Chinese noodle and dumpling parlor done in 1940s style, opened in late June. But the chef, Lo Lung Kit, had to return to China to straighten out his visa and did not return until late August. Now the restaurant is in full swing.

headline: ESPN Radio to Broadcast Jets Games in Spanish in New York
abstract: ESPN Deportes, the Spanish-language division of ESPN, has reached a three-year agreement with the New York Jets to broadcast their games in Spanish.
lead_paragraph: 11:56 a.m. | Updated The New York Jets had a rough preseason this year, but they will soon have a chance to make a fresh start, this time in Spanish.

headline: Who Made That Spray Tan?
abstract: The birth of a fake-bronze breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, Eva Wittgenstein, a researcher at a Cincinnati hospital who had been treating children with a rare metabolic disorder, noticed that when the medicine she was using splattered, it stained the patients’ bodies but not their clothes. Curious, Wittgenstein painted her own skin with the solution, which contained dihydroxyacetone (DHA). Within hours these patches turned brown. Soon the miraculous substance was bottled into products like Coppertone QT, which promised 1960s-style convenience: bronze yourself while you sleep; “tan groom” your legs, so you won’t need stockings. DHA produced the color changes by what was called a Maillard reaction, browning the top layer of human skin much the same way a steak browns as it cooks. The reaction turned some people as orange as Oompa-Loompas.

headline: Jane Harman Can Take a Punch
abstract: The former California representative on Newsweek, catfights and why she left the House.
lead_paragraph: Last April, your 92-year-old husband, Sidney Harman, the owner of Newsweek, died after being given a diagnosis of leukemia a month before. Was there anything left he wanted to do?  He left an unfinished manuscript for a book called “Geezer Golf,” about how golf is a metaphor for life, and if you have an excellent short game, you can play with people 20 or 30 years younger, because although your drives are shorter, the rest of your game is better.

headline: 30 Variations and a Microphone
keywords: ['Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Books and Literature', 'Music', 'Classical Music']
abstract: How Glenn Gould freed classical music from the concert hall.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Gould was booked into 30th Street Studio for the two middle weeks of June in 1955. The weather in New York was sunny, the temperature in the 60s. He arrived at the studio by taxi from a hotel near Central Park, wearing an overcoat, a beret, a scarf and gloves, and carrying a leather suitcase and his folding chair. He stripped down to a dress shirt and a sleeveless V-neck sweater. Opening the suitcase, he set out pills, bottled water and towels. Rolling up his sleeves, he ran hot water in a sink, the sort of deep-basin porcelain sink that mops are wrung out in, and soaked his hands and forearms until they were red.

headline: How My Mother Disappeared
abstract: Death would have been easier to grieve than the ‘ambiguous loss’ of dementia.
lead_paragraph: The meatloaf fooled me.

headline: The 8.26.12 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: VENUS AND SERENA AGAINST THE WORLD

headline: Voting for Dad
abstract: Knowing his mind; knowing they’d mind.
lead_paragraph: My 92-year-old father has entered hospice care. He is a lifelong member of one particular political party and is always the first one in line on voting day. There’s no way I can get him to his polling place this November, and while he couldn’t begin to fill out an absentee ballot on his own, is it ethical if I fill it out for him provided he’s still alive in November? JAN SHULMAN-CLEMENT, WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF.

headline: Wheelies: The Eurocentrism Edition
abstract: In Europe, a former Formula One driver turned Olympian wins gold, Ford warns of overcapacity and the Range Rover receives a diesel-hybrid powertrain.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Firefox Smartphone for the Developing World
abstract: The foundation that oversees Firefox says it will have a smartphone operating system on the market in early 2013. The phone is expected to cost one-sixth that of an iPhone. The first market is Latin America, then the rest of the developing world.
lead_paragraph: The smartphones going into the world’s next two billion pairs of hands may not belong to either Google or Apple, but to Mozilla.

headline: World Cup Qualifiers on the Screen
abstract: The road to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil is paved with satellite feeds and Internet streams with games on ESPN3 and WatchESPN.
lead_paragraph: The road to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil is paved with satellite feeds and Internet streams.

headline: The Reluctant Vamp
abstract: Brit Marling — actress, screenwriter, Georgetown grad — knows it’s not her brains you’re staring at.
lead_paragraph: With a finger to her lips, Brit Marling contemplates this image of her glowing hair and sensuous pose, and she seems pleased — if a bit surprised — by the inner bombshell she’s unleashed. “As a girl you have this problem . . . the whole world is about the male gaze,” she says later, after changing back into her own more demure skirt and blouse. “This shoot is kind of scandalous now that I’m thinking about it.”

headline: Eastwood Says He Balked at Sharing Speech With Romney Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Clint Eastwood, in an interview with a local paper, says he came up with his empty chair idea in the green room.
lead_paragraph: Clint Eastwood said the idea for the most controversial convention speech in a generation came to him in the green room off stage, just after he greeted Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan, the country’s most influential Roman Catholic bishop.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | The First Daughters, a Cheating Scandal and More
abstract: Our latest collection of recent Times reporting and multimedia focusing on young people. How will you use this new feature? Let us know.
lead_paragraph: Here is our latest edition of “Teenagers in The Times,” a feature we started in July. In it, we collect all the latest news and multimedia about young people — roughly defined as those under 25 — and supply a thumbnail photo and short summary for each piece.

headline: Workers Drop Out of the Labor Force
abstract: Business Day Live: William M. Rodgers III, chief economist at the Heldrich Center, on why some people have stopped looking for work. | Competing for the attention of would-be space tourists.
lead_paragraph: Business Day Live: William M. Rodgers III, chief economist at the Heldrich Center, on why some people have stopped looking for work. | Competing for the attention of would-be space tourists.

headline: Business Day Live: Hiring Slows in August, Adding to Pressure on Fed and Obama
abstract: What the job figures mean for the economy. | Competing for the attention of would-be space tourists.
lead_paragraph: What the job figures mean for the economy. | Competing for the attention of would-be space tourists.

headline: Very, Very High Season
abstract: A quick rundown of what’s being offered by some space salespeople.
lead_paragraph: A quick rundown of what’s being offered by some space salespeople.

headline: Spaceport America Eyes the (Near) Future
abstract: Officials call the facility the first specifically designed to serve commercial space companies, and they hope to draw as many as 200,000 visitors a year to see the spaceport.
lead_paragraph: AS you approach from the west, the Spaceport America main terminal looks like a gigantic moth, its rounded wings outspread against the arid, reddish-brown dirt of southern New Mexico.

headline: Space Tourism Is Here! Wealthy Adventurers Wanted
abstract: No, it’s not science fiction: for those who have run out of places to go, companies are competing to take amateur astronauts into the heights, and beyond.
lead_paragraph: WEDGED between a strip-mall chiropractor and a cluster of optometrists in Rochester, N.Y., the offices of the DePrez Group of Travel Companies hardly seems like the kind of place where someone would begin a journey to the stars.

headline: At One With the Earth, and the Clients
abstract: Volunteers building a straw bale house in Utah have found mud and straw to be a forgiving medium.
lead_paragraph: The skeleton of the straw bale house has risen with remarkable speed. In little more than a week, we framed out the walls and almost finished the roof. Now there is no doubt that a house is coming into being, although at this point it is not obvious that it will be anything out of the ordinary. The trained eye will notice the lack of the evenly spaced studs that are normally needed to hang drywall, as well as the presence of a second set of wooden sill plates to support the inside edge of the 18-inch-thick straw bales.

headline: In Maine, Walking Where Waves Moved Winslow Homer’s Brush
abstract: For years, the artist painted some of his most majestic works along this rocky knuckle of coastline. Later this month, his studio will open to the public for the first time.
lead_paragraph: IN the summer, when the sun played on the juniper bushes, and in the fall, when the air was clear enough to see to the white lighthouse on Wood Island, and in the winter, when the sea battered the granite rocks, Winslow Homer thrived at Prouts Neck, a spit of land off the Southern coast of Maine.

headline: Underwater Paradise at a Pacific Eco-Resort
keywords: ['Eco-Tourism', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Snorkeling']
abstract: In a place that offers both muted luxury and abundant marine life, the author discovers the “singular feeling of, at last, having escaped.”
lead_paragraph: WHEN, after two days of flying, one reaches the island of Bali only to realize that more days of travel lie ahead — from Denpasar to Makassar, then to Sorong in West Papua on one dodgy Indonesian airline after another, and finally a five-hour boat trip — a traveler begins to wonder whether a stay at an eco-resort on a remote Pacific Island will make all the jet lag, chaotic airports and carbon dioxide emissions seem worth it.

headline: Restaurant Report: Nota Bene in Prague
abstract: For years, good food and good beer were hard to find under the same roof in Prague — until this place opened.
lead_paragraph: Tracking down great beer in Prague has never been a problem. Finding a decent meal has certainly gotten easier. But for years, good food and good brews were like the Czech capital’s version of Clark Kent and Superman: you never saw them in the same place.

headline: Hotel Review: The Surrey in New York
abstract: The city’s only Relais & Chateaux hotel, this overhauled property is steps from Central Park and offers amenities like a roof garden and room service from Café Boulud.
lead_paragraph: THE UPSHOT

headline: Costa Rica Goes Locavore
abstract: In a country not known for its food, a small but growing number of restaurateurs and chefs are applying creativity and skill to homegrown flavors.
lead_paragraph: LOOKING at the sunny waters of the Pacific through the eyes of a hungry chef, Demian Geneau saw a smorgasbord. He also knew what was available to his own kitchen, at a posh resort on Costa Rica’s Nicoya Peninsula. Between the two lay a great disconnect.

headline: Ska Groove, Teen Vibe and Glam-Punk Fury
abstract: Pop music listings for the new season.
lead_paragraph: WAYLON JENNINGS Waylon Jennings cut some voice-and-guitar only songs in 1999 at the home studio of his steel guitarist, Robby Turner, intending to add instruments to them later. He never did, and died in 2002. Finally, here’s the posthumous 12-song result produced by Mr. Turner: “Goin’ Down Rockin’: The Last Recordings,” your basic outlaw-country mix of dire and tenderhearted songs for sports bars and campfires. Tuesday. Saguaro Road. (Ben Ratliff)

headline: Namibia’s Dramatic Dunes
abstract: The filmmaker Mark Magidson describes visiting the vast Namib desert, where giant dunes plunge into the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: MANY sights of Namibia, from its grassy savannas to its lush waterfalls, appear in “Samsara,” the visually stunning, nonverbal film by Ron Fricke and Mark Magidson.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to an article about shoes to wear while traveling.
lead_paragraph: Regarding “Fleet of Foot, on Land or in the Air” (Sept. 2):

headline: Police Seeking Man Who Abused Dog in Elevator
abstract: A man was caught on video kicking a small dog in an elevator at the Wagner Houses in East Harlem last month.
lead_paragraph: For at least the fifth time in less than three years, the police are seeking the public’s help in tracking down someone caught on video beating a dog in a housing-project elevator. The latest incident happened Aug. 26 at the Wagner Houses in East Harlem, site of a similar episode in 2011.

headline: Medicaid Changes Loom for the Elderly
abstract: States are turning to managed care in an effort to reduce Medicaid costs, and the elderly may bear the brunt of the changes.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning on states’ efforts to rein in Medicaid costs with managed care programs and how these may affect the elderly in nursing homes.

headline: Fire This Guy?
abstract: The haters will never budge. President Obama’s speech wasn’t intended for them anyway. It was pitched to the grumpy undecided.
lead_paragraph: Get rid of him. Hit the road, Barack. Epic fail. You’re fired.

headline: Shepard Fairey Is Fined and Sentenced to Probation in ‘Hope’ Poster Case
abstract: The artist was sentenced to two years of probation and fined $25,000 for tampering with evidence.
lead_paragraph: The artist Shepard Fairey, whose 2008 poster of Barack Obama became an optimistic symbol of the last presidential campaign before spawning a bitter copyright battle with criminal overtones, was sentenced in federal court in Manhattan on Friday to two years of probation and fined $25,000 for tampering with evidence in the case.

headline: Its Own Reason for Being
abstract: At Fashion’s Night Out, there was a line around the block to get into Diane von Furstenberg’s store for a sighting of Allison Williams, who appears in “Girls,” and who (like everyone else) was dressed for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: OSCAR DE LA RENTA was singing in his Madison Avenue boutique. Lines of people waited behind barricades to get into Bergdorf Goodman. Most of SoHo and the meatpacking district looked like a police state for fashion victims.

headline: T-Mobile Offers a New Unlimited Data Plan
abstract: Unlimited data plans usually come with an asterisk – the speed at which you get the data slows to a crawl after you have used a certain amount of data. T-Mobile is reversing the trend, adding an unlimited plan without restraints, but there is a catch.
lead_paragraph: You may have noticed that “unlimited” data plans usually come with an asterisk – the speed at which you get the data slows to a crawl after you have used a certain amount of data. But T-Mobile is reversing the trend.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Jennifer Egan discusses Michael Chabon’s “Telegraph Avenue”; Parul Sehgal on the flood of important fiction this fall; Daniel Smith talks about his book “Monkey Mind: A Memoir of Anxiety”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jennifer Egan discusses Michael Chabon’s “Telegraph Avenue”; Parul Sehgal on the flood of important fiction this fall; Daniel Smith talks about his book “Monkey Mind: A Memoir of Anxiety”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Sept. 7
abstract: The New York Times critics share their thoughts on “Bachelorette,” “The Inbetweeners” and “Keep the Lights On.”
lead_paragraph: In This Week’s Movies, the New York Times critics share their thoughts on “Bachelorette,” “The Inbetweeners” and “Keep the Lights On.” Full reviews can be found here.

headline: Obama Counterpunches on Climate Change
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Global Warming', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A week after Mitt Romney ridiculed concern about rising seas, President Obama declared that climate change was real and a threat to future generations.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee, took a not-too-subtle jab at President Obama in his convention speech last week, mocking Mr. Obama’s soaring 2008 campaign language about rolling back the rising seas and healing the planet. Mr. Romney’s gibe drew thunderous applause from the Republican delegates, many of whom express doubt about the existence of climate change.

headline: Quirky Gets Backing From Andreessen Horowitz and Kleiner Perkins
abstract: A start-up that uses social media to develop product has raised $68 million in a venture capital fund-raising round.
lead_paragraph: Social media has transformed many areas, including real estate and online communications. Now, venture capitalists are betting the sector can even tackle product manufacturing.

headline: Six Days After 9/11, Another Anniversary Worth Honoring
abstract: On Sept. 17, 2001, President George W. Bush visited a mosque and spoke eloquently about respect for Islam — an act of leadership that should be celebrated instead of overlooked.
lead_paragraph: In the coming days, the calendar will bring the anniversaries of two signal events. One, of course, is Sept. 11, a Tuesday this year, as it was in 2001, when Al Qaeda terrorists in four hijacked planes killed more than 3,000 Americans. With public memorial services and private tears, those deaths will be recalled and mourned.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the start of the new school year, free soft serve yogurt will be handed out from 2 to 6 p.m. Friday at Chelsea’s Table, located at Pier 62 (just west of the 23rd Street entrance to Chelsea Piers). One free small cup of the yogurt with one topping will be available to each customer at the café or the Stonyfield Organic Dairy Bar.

headline: Family Property Means Managing for a Legacy
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Personal Finances', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A gift of property is one way to take advantage of a $5.12 million tax exemption that will soon expire. But shared property raises the question of its management.
lead_paragraph: SOME wealthy people will have to make a decision soon if they are to take advantage of the $5.12 million gift tax exemption that is due to expire at the end of the year.

headline: Off the Charts
abstract: The fallen rock star gets an encore in contemporary fiction.
lead_paragraph: At the onset of last summer, the magazine that employed me as a rock critic decided to continue publishing without me, no longer supplying a salary or respite from the office water cooler. My dismissal came via a private equity group situation — “No hard feelings, right?” — yet I couldn’t help taking offense. For the next several months, I steered clear of the music world that for years I had cherished.

headline: Share of Men in Labor Force at All-Time Low
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Just 69.8 percent of all men over age 16 were either working or looking for work in August.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s jobs report for August was chock full of all sorts of bad news. Among the most distressing: The share of men actively participating in the labor force — that is, working or looking for work — was at an all-time low.

headline: A Soldier on the Tennis Court
abstract: After losing a leg because of an injury in Afghanistan, Ryan McIntosh was determined to remain physically active. For the past two weeks, he has been working as a ball boy on the United States Open tennis courts.
lead_paragraph: The players aren’t the only ones breaking a sweat on the courts at the United States Open.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Jennifer Gilmore says her new novel was motivated in part by her observations of how motherhood is discussed in our culture.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jennifer Gilmore reviews “The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving,” a novel by Jonathan Evison, in which a former stay-at-home dad who lost his children in a grisly accident becomes a caregiver for hire. “Caretaking is often stereotyped as women’s work,” Gilmore wrote in an e-mail, but in Evison’s book, “caring deeply, dealing with grief, transcends gender.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The novelist Tess Gerritsen — whose mystery “Last to Die” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3 — was long reluctant to include elements of her Chinese-American heritage in her books.
lead_paragraph: DOCTOR, LAWYER, WRITER? The suspense novelist Tess Gerritsen — her latest Rizzoli and Isles mystery, “Last to Die,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3 — told The New Zealand Herald last year that she had been reluctant for more than 20 novels to introduce elements of her Chinese-American heritage into her fiction. That’s because early in her career, when she had just quit medicine to write romantic thrillers, editors warned her there was no market for Asian characters, and the advice stayed with her even as she moved away from the romance genre.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY,  by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $22.99.) Like virtually everything Hitchens wrote over his long career, these dispatches from “Tumorville,” written after he learned of his ultimately fatal esophageal cancer, are diamond-hard and brilliant.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BUSY MONSTERS,  by William Giraldi. (Norton, $15.95.) Speaking in a pastiche of idioms (Southern, Victorian, Western), Charles Homar, the cuckolded hero of Giraldi’s first novel, wrestles with notions of manliness. Pledging to win back his errant fiancée, who has run off with a squid hunter, Charles chronicles his haywire schemes — involving Bigfoot, U.F.O.’s and an oversexed Italian bodybuilder — in installments for a weekly magazine.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
abstract: New fiction by Amanda Coplin, Bridget Siegel, Vincent Lam, Erik Orsenna and David R. Gillham.
lead_paragraph: THE ORCHARDIST  By Amanda Coplin.  Harper/HarperCollins, $26.99.

headline: Indecent Exposure
abstract: Garret Keizer considers privacy and the economic and class dimensions of its erosion.
lead_paragraph: Privacy is a topic that tends to inspire discursive essays rather than philosophical treatises. In “A Bachelor’s Complaint,” in 1823, Charles Lamb deplored the exhibitionism of married couples who “perk up” their public displays of affection when in the company of single friends. In 1890, Samuel Warren and Louis Brandeis lamented that American law, which protects privacy indirectly through laws safeguarding property, contains no remedies for the mental suffering that results from an offense against honor. Rather than attempting a comprehensive treatment of the subject, the privacy essayist identifies a distinctive value that privacy protects (ranging from dignity and autonomy to intimacy and friendship) and defends its value by using concrete examples and anecdotes from daily life.

headline: Outback Outcasts
abstract: In this historical novel, Kate Grenville explores modern Australia’s origins through the story of one family.
lead_paragraph: Kate Grenville’s latest novel, “Sarah Thornhill,” provides a wrenching conclusion to a tough-hearted trilogy about the colonizing of Australia. In her previous excursions into this rough, unforgiving land, shiploads of transported convicts, indentured servants and down-on-their-luck gentry were seen carving out English-style estates and tangling with aboriginals who somehow — to the newcomers’ astonishment — couldn’t accept the fact that they’d been conquered. By the time the heroine of this new book is born, in 1816, the country’s future is almost settled.

headline: Why Were We in Vietnam?
abstract: A historian examines the end of French rule in Vietnam and the beginning of American involvement.
lead_paragraph: During the Casablanca conference in January 1943, Franklin Roosevelt spoke bitterly to his son about European imperialism: “Don’t think for a moment, Elliott, that Americans would be dying in the Pacific tonight if it hadn’t been for the shortsighted greed of the French and the British and the Dutch.” Earlier, he had spoken openly to the White House correspondents: “There has never been, there isn’t now and there never will be, any race of people on earth fit to serve as masters over their fellow men. . . . We believe that any nationality, no matter how small, has the inherent right to its own nationhood.” That was the core of the Atlantic Charter in 1941, which both Churchill and Roosevelt signed. It called on “the right of all peoples to choose the form of government under which they will live.”

headline: Haunted Highways
abstract: An examination of the disproportionate fear around violence on the freeway.
lead_paragraph: What would highway killers do without highways?

headline: Panic Buttons
abstract: Daniel Smith describes what it’s like to live with anxiety and its destructive absurdities.
lead_paragraph: The long list of things that, over the years, have made Daniel Smith nervous includes sex, death, work, water, food, air travel, disease, amateur theater, people he’s related to and people he’s not related to, so the prospect of a book review probably wouldn’t seem like a very big deal to him. Or would it?

headline: Effect of Jobs Numbers on Presidential Race Is Uncertain
abstract: Politically, it is not certain that the report is going to matter that much. The unemployment rate declined for superficial reasons, which makes for a gentler headline for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s jobs report was a weak one — with August’s job growth more in line with the tepid growth of the spring than the stronger numbers in July or over the winter months.

headline: Side Effects
abstract: In these stories, women are subject to appraisal by men, and one another.
lead_paragraph: When 14-year-old Nora gets a pair of diamond earrings in the mail from the father she’s never met, her mother, Ruby, looks at them and dryly remarks, “They’re the size of birth control pills.”

headline: Assisted Living
abstract: His family life a shambles, Jonathan Evison’s floundering hero looks elsewhere for a sense of purpose.
lead_paragraph: “Failure makes me hungry,” Ben Benjamin says in “The Revised Fundamentals of Caregiving,” Jonathan Evison’s third novel. Ben responds to defeat with a Mr. Goodbar and a bag of chips, which is just part of what makes his funny and relatable voice the linchpin of this engaging book.

headline: Two Cuts of Brisket
abstract: With Rosh Hashana approaching, Melissa Clark talks about how to select a brisket perfect for your family dinner.
lead_paragraph: With Rosh Hashana approaching, Melissa Clark talks about how to select a brisket perfect for your family dinner.

headline: Long Divisions
abstract: Rajiv Chandrasekaran reports on America’s involvement in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Rajiv Chandrasekaran has done it again. Like “Imperial Life in the Emerald City,” his chronicle of Washington’s hapless management of the Iraq war in its early days, “Little America” is a beautifully written and deeply reported account of how a divided United States government and its dysfunctional bureaucracy have foiled American efforts abroad, this time to suppress the Taliban insurgency and bring stability to Afghanistan. It tells a story of political foibles, overly ambitious goals and feckless Afghans and Americans. The United States seems condemned to lurch between disastrous quick fixes and unrealistic visions of remaking countries overnight in its own image, never finding a middle road. No doubt most readers of this book will come away with the conclusion that our principal enemy in all this is ourselves.

headline: Many Wars in One
abstract: Antony Beevor’s survey of World War II reconstructs the battles at sea, on land and in the air.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of this powerful narrative of World War II, Antony Beevor quotes a report, by the Australian war correspondent Godfrey Blunden, of an encounter with some American troops who had just been released from German P.O.W. camps. They had been in Europe only a few months, thrown into combat and almost instantly captured during the Ardennes offensive, Hitler’s last big throw of the dice. The men now had “xylophone ribs” and “gangling arms.” Some of their fellow prisoners had been beaten to death by their guards for attempting to take sugar beets from fields. Blunden wrote: “They were more pitiful because they were only boys drafted from nice homes in a nice country knowing nothing about Europe, not tough like Australians, or shrewd like the French or irreducibly stubborn like the English. They just didn’t know what it was all about.”

headline: These Wild Solitudes
abstract: Paul Auster’s memoir includes an elegy for his mother, reflections on aging and an examination of the body’s frailties and desires.
lead_paragraph: Paul Auster was a novelist in Brooklyn before there were novelists in Brooklyn. (When I was growing up there in the 1980s, my father used to point him out to me as we did the grocery shopping in Park Slope — this was a rare kind of sighting.) Back in those days, his novels — the New York Trilogy, “Leviathan,” “Moon Palace” — seemed postmodern and fresh. They mingled the tropes of detective fiction with a kind of European quasi-philosophical ambiguity. “Kafka goes gumshoe,” as one of his editors described it. The novels comprised stories nested within stories; there were characters named Paul Auster, and there were doppelgängers even for the ­doppelgängers.

headline: Murder in the Cathedral
abstract: As chancellor, Thomas Becket was Henry II’s confidant; as archbishop, he became a bitter enemy.
lead_paragraph: “The biographer’s trap,” John Guy remarks in “Thomas Becket,” his portrait of that foremost friend turned foremost foe of Henry II, “is to look for a decisive moment of change.” But, he adds, “to do that is to write the history of the saint without his shadow.” With ­Becket, this temptation often seems to have been irresistible, from the very night of his murder, Dec. 29, 1170, near the high altar of Canterbury Cathedral. As a crowd swooped down on the battered corpse of the archbishop, tearing off pieces of clothing to dip in the gruesome puddle of his blood and brains, the outlines of the story of Becket’s sudden conversion from ­luxury-loving chancellor to ascetic defender of the church were already being rehearsed, soon to be followed by tales of his miraculous powers.

headline: When Audio Books Do and Don’t Count for School
abstract: Can a student use an audio book for a school assignment? It depends on the reason the book or reading was assigned.
lead_paragraph: Does listening to an audio book count for school reading, and if it does, when? I ran across this quandary when helping my rising third grader fill out her “summer reading” list before going back to school. She wanted to include the books she’s listened to (I’d like to say it was to show her teacher what she enjoyed, but I know full well it was to make her list look longer), and I hesitated. Did a book listened to, I asked here last week, really count as a book “read?”

headline: Killing Time
abstract: How card playing shaped the Civil War, and how the war shaped cards.
lead_paragraph: “The temptations that will beset you will be very great,” a Mississippi man, already a veteran in the Civil War, warned his newly enlisted younger brother. The evil he warned of wasn’t treason or desertion or theft. It was cards. “Of all the evil practices that abound in Camp, gambling is the most pernicious and fraught with the most direful consequences.”

headline: Bonus Tracks: Bruuuuuuuuce!
abstract: My experience at a Bruce Springsteen concert.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Lizzy Goodman wrote about the New Jersey band the Gaslight Anthem. Her article highlighted the Gaslight Anthem’s anxiety — if you can call it that — of being seen as the heirs to Bruce Springsteen’s legacy. Last weekend, she got to see the real thing. Her dispatch from the floor seats follows.

headline: Invite Brisket’s More-Tender Brother for the Holidays
abstract: You have to ask butchers for a second-cut brisket, but it’s worth the effort.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, I thought brisket was by nature a somewhat stringy, dry and chewy cut of beef. No matter how exacting the recipe or how careful the cook, the leanness of the meat dictated the texture.

headline: Peter Som: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Book Review Podcast: Michael Chabon’s ‘Telegraph Avenue’
abstract: Jennifer Egan discusses Mr. Chabon’s new novel.
lead_paragraph: This week in the New York Times Book Review, one Pulitzer Prize winner reviews another as Jennifer Egan considers Michael Chabon’s “Telegraph Avenue.” The novel is set in and around a used-record store on the boulevard where Oakland aligns with Berkeley. Ms. Egan writes:

headline: At Peter Som’s Show, Birds Suddenly Appear
abstract: The first few notes of “Close to You” by the Carpenters played at the beginning of the Peter Som show Friday morning. That was enough to suggest a romantic nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: The first few notes of “Close to You” by the Carpenters played at the beginning of the Peter Som show Friday morning. That was enough to suggest a little bit of romantic nostalgia, the kind that usually describes Mr. Som’s dreamy floral prints. For spring, he made jeans in a pink print that looked like bubble gum, part of a collaboration between Mr. Som and Earnest Sewn, the jeans company, and a series of multicolored pieces, like a T-shirt, a coat and a skirt, each made of a patchwork of snakeskin in an oversize herringbone pattern.

headline: Collect Call | Steven Kolb’s Owls
abstract: The C.E.O. of the Council of Fashion Designers of America agrees to explain why he has surrounded himself with at least 1,000 owl objects.
