headline: Judge Widens Scope of Prosecutor’s Investigation in Lopez Case
keywords: ['Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'State Legislatures', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A judge gave a special prosecutor the power to examine whether crimes were committed when public and private funds were paid to settle complaints against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez.
lead_paragraph: A judge authorized a special prosecutor on Friday to expand his criminal investigation into sexual harassment claims that two female staff members brought against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, giving the prosecutor the power to examine whether crimes were committed when public and private money was paid to settle similar complaints brought by two other female staff members.

headline: The Sweet Spot | The Film Festival
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.

headline: What Ails the U.S.?
abstract: People across the political spectrum are peddling the notion that America is in big trouble. And their diagnoses vary. It’s the schools! The high taxes! The low taxes! The unions! The corporations! The greed of the rich! The sloth of the poor! What do you think most ails the United States today?
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Like hawkers on a crowded street, observers of all persuasions are busy peddling the notion that America is in big trouble.

headline: Managing a Child’s Allowance, the Online Version
abstract: A look at some Web sites that aim to help children and their parents track chores, allowances, savings and spending — and maybe teach some financial literacy in the process.
lead_paragraph: Giving children an allowance always seems like a good idea at first. But just try following through in practice.

headline: Sept. 9 — 15
abstract: A selection of events.
lead_paragraph: THE Zimbabwe-born NORA CHIPAUMIRE, now working out of New York, has spent most of her (still relatively short) choreographic career exploring ideas about African identity — and even more specifically, ideas about female African identity. Until now her pieces have been largely abstract, even if they have dealt with Zimbabwean history and her experience of it. But in “Miriam,” which opens on Wednesday in the Fishman Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s new Fisher Building, Ms. Chipaumire turns to the life of the South African singer MIRIAM MAKEBA, taking inspiration from her dramatic narrative — first as an exiled, worldwide symbol of protest against the apartheid government, later as the beloved artist known as Mama Africa.

headline: What My Father’s Dementia Told Me
abstract: My father’s dementia told me things about him that he never could or never would tell me himself.
lead_paragraph: I was the copy editor assigned to work on Alex Witchel’s memoir about her mother’s dementia. I was fortunate because her writing is compelling and didn’t need any help from me, and also because it forced me to focus on the quality of my father’s dementia, maybe for the first time.

headline: What Citizenship Means
abstract: To sum up his case against Mitt Romney, President Obama offered a new theme: citizenship.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. – He didn’t deliver a clear second-term agenda, or a speech that thrilled. He didn’t explain how his re-election will spell an end to Washington’s policy stalemate. But President Obama did offer a sort of consolation prize in his convention speech: a new theme to sum up his case against Mitt Romney.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Sept. 7, 2012
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk Telluride, Toronto and the taxonomy of the film festival.

headline: As PC Sales Turn Down, Intel Trims Its Outlook
abstract: Weak demand in growing markets like China affects the demand for computer chips.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With the personal computer market stalled, Intel, the primary maker of computer chips, warned its investors Friday that revenue would be lower than expected, as would profit margins.

headline: Image of the Day: September 7
abstract: Women protest a dam project in Madhya Pradesh by standing in neck deep water for almost two weeks.

headline: Study Finds Some African Farmers Adapting to Withstand Climate Stresses
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Drought', 'Global Warming', 'Poverty', 'Sustainable Living', 'Weather']
abstract: A new study shows the capacity, and untapped potential, of farmers in East Africa to adopt resilient agricultural practices in a harsh and changing climate.
lead_paragraph: It’s been clear for many years that the stresses that come with extreme climate conditions have an outsize impact on poor communities, and nowhere more so than in sub-Saharan Africa. Given the studies projecting how greenhouse-driven warming will worsen drought and heat in regions that already tend to be dry and hot, it’s encouraging to see signs in one hard-hit African region of farmers’ capacity to shift practices to deal with intensifying climatic stresses.

headline: Influence of Money Market Funds Ended Overhaul
keywords: ['Money Market Accounts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Opposition to proposals intended to prevent another financial panic puzzled the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: Four years after the fall of Lehman Brothers, and with a presidential campaign in full swing, everyone can surely agree on one thing: we shouldn’t risk another financial crisis.

headline: The Employment Situation
abstract: Not much action these past three years.
lead_paragraph: My current favorite gauge of the jobs picture is the employment-population ratio for prime-age adults (25-54). EP ratio instead of unemployment rate, because U may be distorted by workers dropping out. Prime-age not because the old and young don’t matter, but to take demographic change out of the picture.

headline: After a Disappointing Jobs Report, Romney Attacks Obama
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Mitt Romney questioned on Friday whether President Obama “knows what he’s doing” when it comes to fixing the economy.
lead_paragraph: SIOUX CITY, Iowa – Seizing on a disappointing jobs report, Mitt Romney questioned on Friday whether President Obama “knows what he’s doing” when it came to fixing the economy.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Blue Girl Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 17-year-old girl whose skin mysteriously turns blue.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 17-year-old girl who was turning blue. We received more than 400 colorful responses that ran from Smurfitis and the occasional reference to Willy Wonka to the very serious suggestion of methemoglobinemia, a disorder in which patients turn blue intermittently because of abnormal red blood cells that cannot hold on to oxygen.

headline: Lowercase Minimalists
abstract: “Coexist” is the second album by the British band the xx.
lead_paragraph: THE day that “Coexist,” the second album by the miserabilist British band the xx, was mastered, the group’s three members — Romy Madley Croft, Oliver Sim, Jamie Smith — went out for McDonald’s. Each day during the months of recording the album, on the way to the studio with black velvet-covered walls they were hunkered down in, they’d walk past McDonald’s and sigh, tempted by the smell but not giving in.

headline: Freezing Brisket
abstract: If you’re braising brisket for a holiday meal, you can save time by cooking ahead and freezing the results.
lead_paragraph: This week’s column is about braising brisket for a holiday meal. For years, my mother often cooked her brisket ahead and froze it. This was extremely convenient and the results were good. She would transfer the cooked and cooled meat to a plastic Ziploc, spoon in the sauce and then close the bag, squeezing out the air. Squeezing out the air is the key step. Sometimes she created a faux vacuum by inserting a straw into the bag, inhaling the air and quickly closing it. Of course a vacuum sealer works even better if you have one.

headline: Former Tennis Star Makes a Mark at Columbia Law School
abstract: Had things worked out differently, Mario Ancic would have spent the past two weeks grinding it out at the United States Open. Instead, he has been holed up in the Columbia law library, poring over his contracts casebook.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, Columbia Law School admits a couple hundred students to its prestigious master’s program. This year’s crop includes a civil rights activist from Armenia, a terrorism-finance expert from Bangladesh and a Croatian lawyer with a win over Roger Federer.

headline: Truck Driver in Kerry Kennedy Crash Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Rocco Scuiletti was charged with leaving the scene of an accident after Ms. Kennedy swerved into his truck in July.
lead_paragraph: ARMONK, N.Y. -- The driver of a tractor-trailer who was involved in an accident with a car driven by Kerry Kennedy two months ago pleaded not guilty on Friday to leaving the scene of an accident and vowed to fight the charge.

headline: Remembering Ashe, in Triumphs and Images
abstract: Photographs of Arthur Ashe on display at the United States Open capture the star people knew–and also show him in a new light.
lead_paragraph: Tennis has produced many champions but few heroes — winners whose accomplishments have merged with or even shaped the larger currents of their time.

headline: Andrea Hailey and David Williamson
abstract: Having different political views teaches compromise and “keeps our conversations spicy,” the bride said.
lead_paragraph: THERE was very little Andrea Hailey disliked about David Williamson when she first met him through friends nearly six years ago.

headline: Deciding What to Leave to Heirs
abstract: Bucks readers tell their tales of how they have determined which of their heirs get what parts of their property and cash.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about the $5.12 million gift tax exemption that is due to expire at the end of the year.

headline: On Whether to Use Allowance-Tracking Web Sites
abstract: Sites like Tykoon, Three Jars, FamZoo and others make tracking allowance for children easier. But are they best for children?
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I write about Tykoon, the newest of a group of Web sites and apps that help parents dole out allowances, track chores and encourage saving.

headline: Fashion Week Parties, Night 1
abstract: Richard Chai, Futura and Supreme kicked off New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Richard Chai, Futura and Supreme kicked off New York Fashion Week.

headline: In Midtown, Pedestrians’ Secret Shortcut Is Now Official
abstract: From 51st to 57th Streets, along a stretch of pedestrian arcades connected by crosswalks, New Yorkers can find themselves on “Sixth-and-a-Half Avenue.”
lead_paragraph: For years, it was an open secret — a midblock portal that kept the savviest travelers away from the pedestrian gridlock of Midtown avenues, even if they had to jaywalk a bit to execute the shortcut.

headline: Out of the Box
abstract: When you own a classic house by Philip Johnson, what more could you want? How about a barn for your art?
lead_paragraph: Among the houses that Philip Johnson designed in New Canaan, Conn., the suburban enclave that became a laboratory for postwar Modernist design, the Robert C. Wiley house, completed in 1953, remains one of his most elegant. It is a strikingly simple composition of two rectangular boxes: one, a glass and wood pavilion with a single, 15-foot-tall living, dining and kitchen space, is cantilevered over the other, a stone and concrete base that contains, among other things, four small bedrooms, bathrooms and a sitting room. The 3,000-square-foot house typifies Modernism’s insistence on efficient use of space, but by the advent of the McMansion era, despite its architectural pedigree, it merely seemed quaintly, and unsalably, tiny.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Jason Wu
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a Jason Wu heel with pearls and a contrasting animal print strap.
lead_paragraph: Jason Wu showed a very pretty and semiformal collection full of sex-pot signatures (leather harnesses, lace and leopard, lots of transparency) that, under Wu’s command, took a turn toward boudoir dressing without falling into bed. Some of the stilettos had nail-sharp heels studded with rhinestones. Others featured black netting bejeweled with circles and stars. These with tiny pearls dotting the contrasting ankle strap were the ones that T editors would, if they could, take home tonight.

headline: So That’s How They Do It
abstract: Workers on ropes cleaned the exterior of the Guggenheim Museum on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Workers cleaning the exterior of the Guggenheim Museum on Friday morning, the first such work since the museum’s restoration was completed in 2008. View a larger version.

headline: French President Must Cut Deficit, but How?
abstract: François Hollande is facing rising discontent as he prepares to assemble the package of tax increases and spending cuts required to reduce the deficit.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Samir Chaffar shook his head slowly on a recent weekday as he scanned a raft of newspapers at a kiosk near the Louvre.

headline: Through Fire, Glimpsing the Next Mercedes-Benz S-Class
abstract: A new sculpture to be displayed at the Mercedes-Benz stand at the Paris motor show is said to contain clues about the new S-Class.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz has unveiled a sculpture hinting at the lines of the marque’s redesigned flagship sedan.

headline: Life Without Indian Point, Redux
abstract: A study sponsored by Westchester County business coalitions disputes the notion that shutting down the Indian Point nuclear plant would cause no significant problems.
lead_paragraph: The consequences of running the Indian Point nuclear reactors or shutting them down run from easy-to-spot to hard-to-calculate.

headline: Now the Rutgers Coach, but Still a Teacher
abstract: When Kyle Flood left his job teaching high school math in the 1990s to give coaching football a shot, some of his old job habits stayed with him.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — The blinds in the corner office at the Hale Center abutting the Rutgers football stadium are always shut, keeping the square room dim, the dark leather couches cool and the flat-screen monitors shaded, so that Coach Kyle Flood can see his PowerPoint presentations.

headline: What Happens When the Two Israels Meet
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Women and Girls', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The expiration of the law exempting ultra-Orthodox Jews from serving in the Israeli army places female soldiers in a more uncertain position.
lead_paragraph: Kfar Vradim, Israel

headline: Jobs Numbers Prompt Obama to Account for Anemic Recovery
abstract: His convention speech was only hours old when President Obama, confronted by a dismal new jobs report, found himself having to use precious time on his campaign trail to account for the country’s continued anemic economic recovery.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — His convention speech was only hours old when President Obama, confronted by a weak new jobs report, found himself Friday having to use precious time on the campaign trail to account for the country’s continued anemic economic recovery.

headline: Outdoor Ad Company Already Had Planes, Now Adds Blimps
abstract: Van Wagner Communications in New York is acquiring the Lightship Group, which operates ad blimps, and the American Blimp Corporation in Hillsboro, Ore., which designs and builds them.
lead_paragraph: A leading outdoor advertising company is expanding its air force by adding ad blimps to its fleet of planes that carry ad banners.

headline: Excerpt: 'Nashvile'
abstract: The new ABC series starts on Oct. 10.
lead_paragraph: The new ABC series starts on Oct. 10.

headline: Excerpt: '666 Park Avenue'
abstract: The new ABC series starts on Sept. 30.
lead_paragraph: The new ABC series starts on Sept. 30.

headline: Venice Film Festival: James Franco and Harmony Korine on ‘Spring Breakers’
abstract: At the Venice Film Festival, the actor James Franco and the director Harmony Korine talk about their new film, “Spring Breakers,” which both is and isn’t what it sounds like.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Harmony Korine made his first splash as the screenwriter of the 1995 sensation “Kids,” which was both hailed and denounced for its in-your-face depiction of sexually active, substance-abusing teenagers. His latest film, “Spring Breakers,” is another generational portrait of youthful debauchery, but Mr. Korine, at 39, is observing from the outside this time.

headline: Tiny Lifesaver for a Growing Worry
abstract: Mylan, the maker of the epinephrine injector EpiPen, is expanding its marketing efforts in the face of new, competing devices and the surging rates of allergies in children.
lead_paragraph: It has become an all-too-familiar story in schools across the country: a child eats a peanut or is stung by a bee and suffers an immediate, life-threatening allergic reaction known as anaphylaxis.

headline: Trying on an Old Soul With Some Alterations
abstract: Nina Simone’s often forthright work is draped with Meshell Ndegeocello’s more ambiguous approach in a new album.
lead_paragraph: MESHELL NDEGEOCELLO is wary of giving the wrong impression with “Pour Une Âme Souveraine: A Dedication to Nina Simone” (Naïve), her 10th studio album, due out on Oct. 9. “I don’t want to necromance,” she said recently. “I feel like that’s going on a lot.”

headline: Nokia’s Misleading Video Dents Lumia’s Image
abstract: Taking the stage a week before Apple, Nokia had the chance to put on a bold and confident performance with its demonstration of new smartphones. Instead, a misleading promotional video has left the company looking a little desperate.
lead_paragraph: Taking the stage a week before Apple, Nokia had the chance to put on a bold and confident performance with its demonstration of new smartphones. Instead, a misleading promotional video has left the company looking a little desperate. Its underwhelming presentation and a big drop in its stock price added up to a less than stellar week for Nokia.

headline: Scenes From the New Season
abstract: A look at the new network series debuting this fall.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new network series debuting this fall.

headline: Riff Bonus: A Night in the Life of the Culture
abstract: An excerpt about the cultural landscape in America on June 8, 1955, from the book “Reinventing Bach.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s bonus feature to Paul Elie’s Riff on using recording-studio equipment for classical music is just that: a bonus excerpt from Paul Elie’s book, “Reinventing Bach,” in which he surveys the American cultural landscape around one night that Glenn Gould was recording the “Goldberg” Variations in New York City.

headline: The Old Mix and Match Inspires New Fall Shows
abstract: Shows like “The Mob Doctor,” “The Neighbors,” “666 Park Avenue” and “Made in Jersey” include plenty of recycled stock concepts that are oddly paired with archetypal TV characters.
lead_paragraph: THE new fall season makes one thing clear: The television industry’s Random Show-Idea Generators have been getting quite a workout.

headline: Three Searches for a First Apartment
abstract: Four new graduates kept track of the ups and downs of their search from the moment they began looking for a place to the day they signed the lease.
lead_paragraph: Four new graduates kept track of the ups and downs of their search from the moment they began looking for a place to the day they signed the lease.

headline: Launching Space Tourism
abstract: Companies are competing to take amateur astronauts into space.
lead_paragraph: Companies are competing to take amateur astronauts into space.

headline: Williams and Azarenka Will Play in Open Final
abstract: Serena Williams and Victoria Azarenka won their women’s semifinals at the United States Open on Friday.
lead_paragraph: No. 1 Victoria Azarenka and No. 4 Serena Williams will meet in the 2012 United States Open final, after winning semifinals Friday of very different difficulty levels.

headline: Soldiers’ Friendship, Shared Across Generations, Ends With More Gained Than Lost
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Books and Literature', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Friendship', 'Veterans', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: One veteran, in the waning years of his life, gives another, fresh from war, comfort and perspective that couldn’t be found anywhere else.
lead_paragraph: My friend Bob Kotlowitz died two weekends ago. He was 87 — lucky enough to live a long, rich life — but he just as easily could’ve been killed before the age of 19. Death is an integral part of an infantryman’s life, floating around us in a thin, grim fog. We’re trained and conditioned to kill, we go to war to kill: that’s the heart of the life. There’s a cosmic balancing act to all this: death is pretty impartial. Our friends are killed in the war — whether they’re shot, blown up or snuffed out in accidents — or during training. It doesn’t get easier, all this dying, even after leaving the Army. After all, we’re still at war and friends still die overseas. At the same time, some, faced with the cumulative weight of all this, seek their own quietus.

headline: The Launching Pad
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The first apartment in New York is the proverbial needle in the haystack.
lead_paragraph: FOR countless newly minted college graduates, it’s a rite of passage. After the mortarboards have been tossed into the air, they head for New York City, ready to embark on the next chapter of their lives. In 2010, some 40,000 graduates age 22 to 28 moved to the city in search of jobs, according to the latest figures from the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey.

headline: African-American Theater in Minnesota Suspends Programming
abstract: The Penumbra Theater in St. Paul has cut its budget and laid off staff, hoping to raise enough money to put on one production next spring.
lead_paragraph: Penumbra Theater in St. Paul, Minn.,which describes itself as the country’s largest African-American theater, has announced that it is suspending programming this season until it can resolve a severe budget crunch.

headline: Ratings Gold for Gordon Ramsay’s Reality Empire
abstract: His three reality shows on Fox rank in the Top 10 of all summer programs in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the age group most coveted by advertisers.
lead_paragraph: The reality television stars Simon Cowell, Nicole “Snooki” Polizzi and the Kardashian clan may have hoarded most of the headlines this summer, but the chef Gordon Ramsay has quietly (at least for him) cemented his spot as one of TV’s most popular personalities. His three shows on Fox – “Hell’s Kitchen,” “MasterChef” and the recently launched “Hotel Hell” – all rank in the Top 10 of all summer programs in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the age group most coveted by advertisers.

headline: To Contend at the Paralympics, Race Brave
abstract: A wheelchair racer discusses strategy and what it takes to win a medal these days in the Paralympic Games.
lead_paragraph: The wheelchair racer Joshua George will be competing in the 2012 Paralympic Games in London and writing for the 2012 London blog.

headline: After High Note for Euro Plan, Discord Emerges
abstract: The bond-buying plan that was announced to much fanfare on Thursday ran into political problems a day later in Germany, Spain and Italy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the long euro crisis, there is almost always a sobering morning-after whenever European leaders appear to have made a major breakthrough. And so it went again on Friday.

headline: A Possible Renoir Surfaces at a Virginia Flea Market
abstract: The Potomack Company auction house has listed the small pastel-colored painting as Renoir’s “Paysage Bords de Seine” and is scheduled to auction off the work on Sept. 29.
lead_paragraph: Calling “Antiques Roadshow.” It was a Paul Bunyan doll that captured her eye, but the Virginia flea market buyer, who paid less than $50 for the box lot that held it, also purchased what could turn out to be a painting by the French artist Pierre-Auguste Renoir.

headline: Not Looking, but Still Wanting to Work
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Youth']
abstract: The share of people who are not in the labor force but say they still want a job has generally been rising since the recession began almost five years ago.
lead_paragraph: The number of people not in the labor force — that is, neither working nor looking for work — rose by almost 600,000 in August.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 7
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including the continuation of the Tour of Spain cycling race and the London Paralympic Games.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including the continuation of the Tour of Spain cycling race and the London Paralympic Games.

headline: New Arrivals, in High-Def
abstract: A look at some breakout actors of the new television season.
lead_paragraph: Mamie Gummer, ‘Emily Owens, M.D.’

headline: All Is Forgiven as Jets Lineman Re-Signs After Being Cut
abstract: After a week of career uncertainty, defensive tackle Marcus Dixon said “the business sometimes gets you.”
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On Tuesday, four days after he thought he made the Jets’ roster — and three days after the team cut him to make room for another defensive tackle — Marcus Dixon was at his home in Morristown when his phone rang.

headline: Week in Review: Off to the Principal’s Office
abstract: A company tries to win over investors for a huge merger in the natural resources business. We visited multinationals staking a claim in venture capital. And Andrew Ross Sorkin pointed to the man behind Facebook’s I.P.O. debacle. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.
lead_paragraph: A company tries to win over investors for a huge merger in the natural resources business. We visited multinationals staking a claim in venture capital. And Andrew Ross Sorkin pointed to the man behind Facebook’s initial public offering debacle.

headline: Wholesome Risotto With Whole Grains
abstract: You can add whole grains to risotto and still end up with an appealingly creamy dish, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.
lead_paragraph: If you love creamy risotto but want to make it more wholesome, try these tips from Martha Rose Shulman. This week’s Recipes for Health explores new ways to add whole grains to risotto.

headline: Ahead of His Time | Norman Bel Geddes
abstract: The visionary industrial designer, urban planner and futurist is the subject of an exhibition at the University of Texas at Austin this fall.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Close to the City, but With a Life of Its Own
abstract: A borough bordering the George Washington Bridge has the suburban feel of a New Jersey town with the ethnic diversity of a New York City neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: AFTER 13 years in a house in Oradell, N.J., Florence Fleischman and her husband, Glenn, were ready to return to high-rise living. In May, the couple moved back to the same Fort Lee apartment building where they had lived as newlyweds and raised two children, now teenagers, through toddlerhood.

headline: Chevy Thinks Small
abstract: The small 1.2-liter 84-horsepower Chevrolet Spark is thrifty and says something about G.M.’s ability to adapt to the current marketplace.
lead_paragraph: The small 1.2-liter 84-horsepower Chevrolet Spark is thrifty and says something about G.M.’s ability to adapt to the current marketplace.

headline: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 7-9
abstract: The Kirkland Concours d’Élégance moves to the newly opened LeMay, Ferraris line up in Pennsylvania Dutch country and Mustangs burn out in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $6.3 Million
abstract: A four-bedroom triplex condo, with high ceilings and dramatic skylights, was owned by Thomas Krens, the former Guggenheim director.
lead_paragraph: A luminous TriBeCa penthouse at 45-47 Warren Street, acquired in 1999 by Thomas Krens during his provocative tenure as the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in New York, sold for $6.3 million and was the most expensive residential sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Korean-Flavored Chevy Is Thrifty and City-Smart
abstract: The Chevrolet Spark suggests a road to Damascus experience for G.M., as it turns away from relying on large S.U.V.’s for its profits. But while the Spark is about the slowest thing on wheels, its very existence says something good about the company.
lead_paragraph: AT the 2001 Detroit auto show, before he was pulled back into the family business like the movie mobster Michael Corleone, General Motors’ godfather-for-hire, Robert A. Lutz, gravely assessed the design studies on display: “A whole family of angry kitchen appliances, demented toasters, furious bread machines and vengeful trash compactors.”

headline: Singer Gets His Van Back, but Pays a Price
abstract: The Bronx man who paid $1,000 for the van at a city auction sold it back to Mr. Arthur for $5,500.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Arthur, the Brooklyn-based singer and painter whose touring van was towed and sold at auction last month, has tracked down and retrieved his vehicle, full of amplifiers and artwork. But it cost him $5,500.

headline: Taking the ‘Cheap’ Out of the Small Car
abstract: In the past, small cars tended to lack refinement, and Americans often sniffed at them. But the picture is much brighter today because small cars have benefited from years of development and polish.
lead_paragraph: THE idea that good things come in small packages has rarely played well with American car buyers. And who can blame them?

headline: Q&A
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Condominiums', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']

lead_paragraph: Still Awaiting Financial Statements

headline: Syrian Rebels Say They Freed 350 Prisoners, as Others Appeal for Unity
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Syrian rebels claimed they had freed 350 prisoners held in a security building in the divided city of Aleppo, while the rebels’ supporters in Homs protested the lack of unity among their forces.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rebels claimed Friday night that they had freed 350 prisoners held in a security building in the divided city of Aleppo, while in the opposition stronghold of Homs the rebels’ supporters held a public protest against the disorganization and lack of unity among their forces.

headline: Jason Wu: Naughty or Nice
abstract: His show Friday had models in glove-tight leather dresses, exposed bras and a lot of thin leather harness straps.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Helmut Newton is a touchstone for any designer who’s in the mood for the naughty, the kinky or the downright dark. So what’s a sweetie pie like Jason Wu doing in that territory? His show today had models in glove-tight leather dresses, exposed bras and a lot of thin leather harness straps.

headline: U.S. Open Food of the Day: Niman Ranch B.L.T.
abstract: The writer’s weakness for bacon was enough to turn heads.
lead_paragraph: This is the final installment of our daily reviews of food from the United States Open concession stands.

headline: Black Voter in a Blue Dog District
abstract: Congressman Larry Kissell represents a white, rural district in North Carolina. He is not endorsing President Obama. Marcus Mabry talks with Walter Rogers, a black voter in the district.
lead_paragraph: Congressman Larry Kissell represents a white, rural district in North Carolina. He is not endorsing President Obama. Marcus Mabry talks with Walter Rogers, a black voter in the district.

headline: Enjoying Results of Summer’s Labor
abstract: Fattoush, the Lebanese bread salad, is made with crisp toasted stale pita or other Arab flatbread; tomatoes, peppers and cucumbers; and an olive oil dressing with lots of sweet herbs.
lead_paragraph: LABOR DAY is long past, but I’m not ready to say goodbye to summer, and I’m certainly not ready to give up on late-summer produce, most of which is still quite glorious. It would be a shame to fast-forward prematurely into autumn fare.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from India, Hong Kong, Syria and Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Hong Kong, Syria and Iowa.

headline: Small Cars Are Changing; Will They Fit in the U.S.?
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Paris Motor Show']
abstract: Trends in small-car style in Europe and Asia, which will be on display this month at the Paris auto show, are bound to influence cars sold in the American market. Expect to see more daring colors.
lead_paragraph: CARS have scale; they look different depending on the background they are set against. The Smart that seemed dashing when driven around Paris by Tom Hanks may look like a recycling container in the setting of a Montana highway.

headline: Fixes to Get You Started and Cool
abstract: Infinitis and Volvos with air-conditioning troubles and Chevrolet Silverados with failing starter motors are among the problems covered in the latest technical service bulletins.
lead_paragraph: INFINITIS and Volvos with air-conditioning troubles and Chevrolet Silverados with failing starter motors are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘The Invisibles’ at the Top
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Graphic Novels']
abstract: “The Invisibles Omnibus” is No. 1 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: “The Invisibles Omnibus,” a collection of the entire run of the Vertigo series from DC Comics created by Grant Morrison and originally serialized in the 1990s, lands at No. 1 on our hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week.

headline: The Trouble With Numbers: Complaints on a Much Anticipated Jobs Report
abstract: With the importance of jobs to Americans, many of whom have long been out of work, it’s no wonder the monthly jobs report gets so much weight. But some experts, and some readers, think it gets too much emphasis, or the wrong kind.
lead_paragraph: There’s a drumroll beforehand and a great crashing of cymbals as it happens. It’s the federal government’s monthly report on the nation’s employment – a matter that’s given huge political weight in the current presidential campaign, as Jim Rutenberg’s news analysis on today’s front page makes clear. The Wall Street Journal and many other news organizations also gave it front-page treatment, before the fact.

headline: Bahraini Activists Document Crackdown on Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Detainees', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Military Tribunals', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Security forces again fired tear gas and arrested demonstrators in Bahrain’s capital on Friday, as protesters renewed their calls for reform and the release of political prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Security forces again fired tear gas and arrested demonstrators in Bahrain’s capital on Friday, as protesters renewed their calls for reform and the release of political prisoners in the island kingdom that is home to the United States Navy’s Fifth Fleet.

headline: R. A. Dickey Signs Deal for Three Children’s Books
abstract: The star pitcher for the Mets will publish two picture books and an adaptation of his memoir for young readers.
lead_paragraph: The knuckleball pitcher R. A. Dickey is putting together a historic season for the Mets. He’s also been busy building a literary career. Mr. Dickey, the author of an acclaimed memoir, has now signed a deal to publish three children’s books with Dial, an imprint of the publisher Penguin.

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Meet the Nixons: Anthony LaPaglia, Kathryn Erbe Will Star in ‘Checkers’
abstract: Douglas McGrath’s play will open at the Vineyard Theater on Oct. 28.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award winner Anthony LaPaglia will play Richard Nixon and Kathryn Erbe (“Law & Order: Criminal Intent”) will play Pat Nixon in the world premiere of Douglas McGrath’s play “Checkers” this fall at Off Broadway’s Vineyard Theater, executives there announced on Friday. The play, set during the 1952 presidential election, is a character study of Nixon (then the Republican nominee for vice president) as well as a rendering of the Nixon marriage in a moment of crisis, as he delivered his so-called Checkers speech addressing allegations of financial improprieties.

headline: Breaking It Down: Ferrer vs. Tipsarevic
abstract: David Ferrer’s quarterfinal victory over Janko Tipsarevic was everything the writer wanted in a tennis match and then some.
lead_paragraph: Thank you, Janko. Thank you, David.

headline: Why My Kindergartner Will Stay Home for School
abstract: I expected to send my son off to kindergarten this year, but after looking at all the options, I’ve decided to teach him at home.
lead_paragraph: When my son was 2 and a half and our daughter was born, I fantasized about the day I would take him to kindergarten. But by the time he turned 4, he had evolved from a demanding toddler who seemed to wake his sister from every nap to a delightful little boy. We enjoyed each other’s company and I could tell that he was benefiting from our extended time together. Surrendering him to another person’s influence for more than 40 hours a week didn’t hold the same appeal as it once had, and suddenly, I wasn’t sure what to do about school. What seemed like an easy default decision — sign your kid up for kindergarten, and off he goes — felt more complicated when I looked at my son.

headline: A Key Witness in Rajaratnam Trial Is Set to Be Sentenced
abstract: Federal prosecutors say that Rajiv Goel, whose testimony helped convict the hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam of insider trading crimes, deserves a lenient sentence because of his cooperation with the government.
lead_paragraph: A disgraced former Intel executive whose testimony helped convict the hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam of insider trading crimes deserves a lenient sentence because of his cooperation with the government, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: Suspensions Vacated for Players in Bounty Case
abstract: The decision was a victory, for now, for the players, but it did not affect the punishments given to Saints coaches or the general manager.
lead_paragraph: Four players suspended by the N.F.L. for their roles in what the league said was a bounty program conducted by members of the New Orleans Saints had their suspensions vacated by an appeals panel Friday, allowing them to rejoin their teams and play in season openers this weekend.

headline: Alan Arkin’s Gallery of Heroic Roles
abstract: Mr. Arkin, who plays a wily movie producer during the Iran hostage crisis in the new movie “Argo,” describes his three most heroic roles.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — During an encounter at the Shangri-La Hotel here, we managed to ask Alan Arkin whether his role in “Argo” is possibly the most heroic he’s ever played. In the movie, which has a gala screening at the Toronto International Film Festival on Friday evening, Mr. Arkin plays a wily movie producer who sets up a fake film, called “Argo,” to help spring a group of people from the clutches of hostile militants during the Iran hostage crisis of years past.

abstract: Images from New York City and the region include the West Indian American Day Parade, the first day of school and the return of a lost peacock.
lead_paragraph: Images from New York City and the region include the West Indian American Day Parade, the first day of school and the return of a lost peacock.

headline: A Windmill Comes to Life in Israel
abstract: Late last month, the still windmill that had served primarily as a symbol in Israel began to turn its sails once again, becoming the second working windmill in the country.
lead_paragraph: With high hopes, the wooden sails of a new white stone windmill in Jerusalem began to turn in 1858. It had been commissioned by a Jewish financier in London who hoped to entice Jews to move from inside the walls of the old city and, once there, to grind their own grain. But the mill soon fell into disuse, probably because newer steam models rendered it obsolete, a historian said.

headline: Mayor’s Office Shines Spotlight on Broadway
abstract: The first winners of annual awards celebrating Broadway include Chita Rivera and Tommy Tune.
lead_paragraph: As part of an effort to celebrate Broadway, which contributes $11 billion to the New York economy, the mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment has named its first annual Spotlight Award winners. Among them are  Chita Rivera, the actress and dancer; Charles Strouse, the composer of “Bye Bye Birdie” and “Annie”; Arlene Dahl, the actress and author; and Tommy Tune, the actor, director and choreographer.

headline: Stale Bread, That Versatile Vehicle
abstract: All wheat-eating cultures have for centuries devised delicious ways to use stale bread, and not only as a means of frugal sustenance.
lead_paragraph: This week’s City Kitchen column features the Middle Eastern bread salad called fattoush, which utilizes stale pita.

headline: Indonesia’s Furtive Snake Trade
abstract: A survey of traders suggests that many reptiles and amphibians captured in Indonesia were illegally seized and wind up as Western collectors’ pets.
lead_paragraph: Rhinos may be poached for their precious horns and tigers for their skin and bones, but with reptiles it’s often about the allure of possessing live exotic animals. Illegal trading of reptiles and amphibians in Southeast Asia is aimed mainly at stocking the international pet trade.

headline: Not The Time To Be Demanding
abstract: Save the bully pulpit for later.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been pounding the drum for Keynesian policies ever since the financial crisis struck; I was one of the few people to talk negatively about Obama’s inaugural address, because it seemed to miss the point that we were suffering from inadequate demand; and I was frantic about the inadequate size of the stimulus.

headline: A Special Day (Online)
abstract: What to get the social-media savvy couple who have everything? A wedding hashtag that trends locally.
lead_paragraph: IT started, as many crazy ideas do, with too much whiskey at the bachelor party. That’s when a groomsman, Ed Dale Jr., decided to create the Twitter hashtag #massewedding and enlist the wedding party, plus as many guests and vendors as possible, to tweet, he said, “about every two minutes” on the day his childhood friend Bryan Masse married Jill Solilak in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

headline: Paying the Hidden Cost of a Destination Wedding
abstract: Couples have been increasingly getting married away from home, but experts in the hospitality industry say there is no such thing as the so-called free wedding.
lead_paragraph: DANIELLE and Tim Jennings of Indianapolis booked a seven-night stay at the Couples Tower Isle resort in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, last August. They took advantage of one of those deals that couples considering destination weddings hear about all the time: pay for a week and get the wedding ceremony free.

headline: Garda Security Gets $1.1 Billion Buyout Offer
keywords: ['ARMORED CAR SERVICES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The founder of Garda World Security, an armored car and security company based in Montreal, has joined with the private equity firm Apax Partners to make a $1.1 billion offer to take the company private.
lead_paragraph: QUEBEC CITY _ The founder, chairman and chief executive of Garda World Security, an armored car and security company based in Montreal, joined forces with a private equity fund to make a $1.1 billion offer to take the company private on Friday.

headline: Now Online | T Men’s Fashion Fall 2012
abstract: Our latest issue features Jay-Z and Zadie Smith, rock climbing with Chris Sharma, and David Cronenberg in Cannes.
lead_paragraph: Jay-Z and Zadie Smith discuss his music, his life, politics and, oh yeah, the new Barclays Center in Brooklyn, in the cover story of the fall men’s fashion issue of T. Inside, the actor Nico Tortorella models the latest knits, the musicians in Sweet Swing Trio show off looks from Paris, and the rock climber Chris Sharma proves he’s actually pretty grounded. For the newest fashion trends, check out our roundup of svelte new overcoats or see what Suzy Menkes has to say about man bags. Don’t forget to check out David Amsden’s report on fitness gear that broadcasts your results to the world; Lynn Yaeger’s look at Artcurial in Paris, where the auction lots include hunks of meat; and Janine di Giovanni’s profile of Gene Sharp, who has helped spread peace around the globe for 40 years. When you’re done, visit a classic Philip Johnson house filled with art; meet Brit Marling, an actress, screenwriter and Georgetown grad; and hit the Cannes red carpet with the likes of Zac Efron, Chris O’Dowd and David Cronenberg, who show off the season’s premier essential: a non-red-carpet coat.

headline: Bryan Brothers Win 12th Grand Slam Doubles Title
abstract: Bob and Mike Bryan defeated Radek Stepanek and Leander Paes, 6-3, 6-4, to claim the open era record for major championships in doubles.
lead_paragraph: Bob and Mike Bryan won the United States Open men’s doubles title on Friday, 6-3, 6-4, over Radek Stepanek of Czech Republic and Leander Paes of India.

headline: Philip Roth Goes Public With Fact Check of Wikipedia
abstract: Mr. Roth says the online encyclopedia’s entry for his novel “The Human Stain” contains gossip, not truth.
lead_paragraph: Philip Roth has written an open letter to Wikipedia that goes on for nearly as long as some of the celebrated author’s recent short novels. The letter appeared on Page-Turner, the books blog of The New Yorker magazine, and in it Mr. Roth adamantly denies that his novel “The Human Stain” was based on the life of Anatole Broyard, a longtime cultural critic for The Times.

abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Plant Sprouting in Asphalt Leads to High-Minded Discussion
abstract: A weed that erupted through pavement caught curious eyes, and a man quite happy to give it a home.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, when you walk your dog, and your dog is a hound dog who moves very slowly and insists on sniffing every little thing, you notice things that might otherwise escape your attention. Such was the case on Thursday as Bart Quillen ambled along Grand Avenue in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: State Seeks to Set Up Unit to Oversee Pre-K Contractors
abstract: In a memo, the Education Department said it wanted to train contractors about their financial responsibilities and subject them to rigorous audits on a regular basis.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Education Department said Friday that it wanted to create a unit to oversee contractors in its program for disabled preschoolers, train the contractors about their financial responsibilities and subject them to rigorous audits on a regular basis.

headline: Jamaica Beats U.S. in World Cup Qualifier, 2-1
abstract: Andrew Keh is live blogging the 2014 World Cup qualifying game between the United States and Jamaica in Kingston on the Goal blog. Television coverage of the game, which starts at 8 p.m. Eastern, is limited.
lead_paragraph: Friday night’s 2014 World Cup qualifier between the United States and Jamaica will be broadcast exclusively on beIN Sport — a new channel carried only on Dish Network, DirecTV, and, in certain markets, Comcast — forcing many fans, this reporter included, over to the local sports bar to catch the action.

headline: As 9/11 Anniversary Nears, Guerrilla Cleaners Scrub the ‘Sphere’ Memorial
abstract: In the belief that it ought to appear as if someone cared about the city’s second-most-prominent 9/11 memorial – the “Sphere for Plaza Fountain” sculpture – a guerrilla cleaning crew took matters into its own hands.
lead_paragraph: In the belief that it ought to appear as if someone cared about the city’s second-most-prominent 9/11 memorial — Fritz Koenig’s “Sphere for Plaza Fountain” sculpture from the original World Trade Center — a guerrilla cleaning crew took matters into its own gloved hands on Thursday.

headline: For Azarenka and Williams, Paths Diverge but Go to Final
abstract: Top-ranked Victoria Azarenka needed almost three hours to outlast Maria Sharapova, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, but Serena Williams took only 64 minutes to eliminate Sara Errani in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: The women’s final at the United States Open is going to be a test of which is the better way to advance through a draw at a major championship: rolling over everyone in your path, or having to dig for every point in grueling victories.

lead_paragraph: At the start of New York Fashion Week, we caught Preetma Singh running to a show mixing Dries Van Noten and Marni.

headline: 2 Leading Lights, Very Much Alive
abstract: The choreographers Elaine Summers and Dianne McIntyre were honored at the performance festival of the American Dance Guild.
lead_paragraph: The performance festival of the American Dance Guild usually honors two dance luminaries a year, one living, one dead. This year, however, both of the honorees — the choreographers Elaine Summers and Dianne McIntyre — are very much alive. And if the performances at the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Thursday weren’t the strongest arguments for the enduring merit of their art, the spirit of happy vitality was just right.

headline: Editor’s Letter
abstract: Designers are trying to make fashion more responsive to the way men actually aspire to dress, i.e. to look on-trend but with offhand elegance.
lead_paragraph: This issue is about the fall men’s collections, so perhaps it is best to start with the news: this season, you’ll want a new coat, because there haven’t been so many terrific options in years, but you’ll come to wear it counterintuitively. An impeccably tailored number in the finest cashmere? Pair it for day with knits and slouchy trousers, as the artist Jeremy Everett does under the chic guidance of Bruce Pask. An oversize parka in waterproof nylon? Make like the director Michael Haneke and toss it over your red-carpet suit. If it all sounds a bit mad, consider it thus: in reversing the normal codes of dressing well (evening coat with evening look, casual jacket with casual wear), designers are trying to make fashion more responsive to the way men actually aspire to dress, i.e. to look on-trend but with offhand elegance.

headline: Teenager Arrested in Killing of 13-Year-Old
abstract: The suspect, Akbar Johns, is accused of shooting the 13-year-old, Ronald Wallace, last month in what the police said was a gang-related dispute.
lead_paragraph: A 17-year-old from Brooklyn who was wanted in the murder of a 13-year-old boy was arrested on Friday, the police said.

headline: How a Contraband Coolant Entered the United States
abstract: On June 26, Carlos Garcia, vice president of the St. Louis-based appliance supplier Marcone, was sentenced to 13 months in prison for his role in the illegal importing of more than $11 million worth of a controlled refrigerant gas called HCFC-22 by Marcone’s Miami branch. Federal laws strictly limit imports of this ozone-depleting gas while its use in this country is being phased out.
lead_paragraph: On June 26, Carlos Garcia, vice president of the St. Louis-based appliance supplier Marcone, was sentenced to 13 months in prison for his role in the illegal importing of more than $11 million worth of a controlled refrigerant gas called HCFC-22 by Marcone’s Miami branch. Federal laws strictly limit imports of this ozone-depleting gas while its use in this country is being phased out.

headline: New Pussy Riot Video Released as Jailed Members Reject Attacks on Crucifixes
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Music', 'Russian Orthodox Church', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Russian protest band Pussy Riot released a new video message, as three jailed members of the group denounced attacks on symbols of the Orthodox Church carried out in their name.
lead_paragraph: As the Russian news site Gazeta.ru reports, the all-female punk protest band Pussy Riot released a new video on Thursday in which they thanked fellow musicians for their support and burned a huge image of President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Many Regions of India, All on One Menu
abstract: Taj Palace, which opened two months ago, has a dinner menu listing more than 200 items.
lead_paragraph: IT has been two years since a fire in downtown White Plains demolished the popular Bengal Tiger restaurant, and it’s a hard act to follow. But two months ago, Taj Palace opened in the space last occupied by Graziellas, and the promising menu may take up the slack.

headline: Akin Defends Cashflow After Ad Dispute
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Todd Akin’s campaign is disputing reports by a Missouri television statement that its ads were pulled because of lack of payment.
lead_paragraph: It’s not quite “Mad Men Missouri,” but a little drama is playing out in a dispute between a beleaguered Senate candidate and a television ad department in the state.

headline: Darting and Stuttering Through Many Points of Light
abstract: “Eclipse,” by the choreographer Jonah Bokaer and the visual artist Anthony McCall, has inaugurated the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s intimate new theater, the BAM Fisher.
lead_paragraph: An eclipse, when one celestial object obscures another, is fairly rare, just as the opening of a new experimental theater is these days.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Twitter Challenges French, and Facebook-Related Spam
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selection includes Twitter challenging a basic part of the French language, how Kindle Serials could change the way some books are written and a famous author taking on Wikipedia.

lead_paragraph: Many, perhaps most, of the students seen in “Broadway or Bust,” a PBS documentary about the National High School Musical Theater Awards, will not end up with careers in theater. But all of them seem to have already mastered vacuous showbiz-speak.
