headline: Betting on the Proenza Boys
abstract: For the fashion designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler, who have new financial backing, the challenge is to figure out what’s next.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent weekend the fashion designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez met for a company retreat at the Hamptons home of John Howard, an investor in their Proenza Schouler label. They made pizzas and hung out in a pair of treehouses Mr. Howard installed in his yard, one with a television set that drops down from the ceiling.

headline: An Actress in a Jealous Rage
abstract: A Bollywood star, sent into a psychotic spiral when a best actress award goes to a rival, enlists her boyfriend to poison her nemesis.
lead_paragraph: Opened on Friday nationwide.

headline: Creating a Line of Must-Haves
abstract: Runway looks designed by Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler.
lead_paragraph: Runway looks designed by Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler.

headline: The Choice
abstract: Join Jacques Steinberg and Tanya Abrams as they examine all facets of the college admissions process.
lead_paragraph: Join Jacques Steinberg and Tanya Abrams as they examine all facets of the college admissions process.

headline: For Spy’s Family, a Bad Trip
abstract: In “The Cold Light of Day,” directed by Mabrouk El Mechri, a vacation off the coast of Spain turns deadly for a C.I.A. officer, played by Bruce Willis, and his loved ones.
lead_paragraph: So murky that it is hard to discern shapes, let alone faces, in many of its scenes, and so crudely edited that its frenzied action has scant continuity, “The Cold Light of Day” is a catastrophe worth noting only for the presence of its name cast. Who knows why stars of the caliber of Henry Cavill (the next Superman), Bruce Willis and Sigourney Weaver signed on for this thoroughly incompetent “Bourne” movie imitation.

headline: Fleeing Music, but Finding It Everywhere
abstract: Anthony Tommasini visits Bolzano, Italy, and the castles of Ludwig II of Bavaria and a Grigory Sokolov recital at the Busoni International Piano Festival.
lead_paragraph: BOLZANO, Italy — On the classical music beat, I get to travel around the world to newsworthy premieres and performances: a great privilege. Yet when it comes time for a real summer vacation, a complete break from music is appealing and beneficial.

headline: Week in Pictures for Sept. 7
abstract: Subjects include the West Indian American Day Parade, the first day of school and the return of a lost peacock.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the West Indian American Day Parade, the first day of school and the return of a lost peacock.

headline: The Crazy Things That Get in People’s Heads. And Throats. And Eye Sockets.
abstract: “I Was Impaled,” on Discovery Fit & Health, takes a look, grisly photographs included, at victims of spikes, spears and, in one case, a French fry.
lead_paragraph: “I Was Impaled” isn’t necessarily the type of television show I would choose to watch, let alone write about. Except for one thing: I was impaled!

headline: Pot for Parents
abstract: I am a more loving, attentive and patient father when I take my prescribed marijuana medication.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco

headline: Air of Rustic Formality, by Way of Italy
abstract: La Zingara Ristorante in Bethel has had continued success based in part on its use of fresh ingredients that it cultivates from a farm nearby.
lead_paragraph: LA ZINGARA RISTORANTE has anchored a prominent spot on P. T. Barnum Square in Bethel since 2002. One reason for its continuing success is that, unlike Bethel’s native son Phineas Taylor Barnum, La Zingara knows how to put on a good show without relying on gimmicks like a “Feejee” mermaid or General Tom Thumb.

headline: Joe Kennedy III Wins Primary for Barney Frank’s Congressional Seat
keywords: ['Elections', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Joseph P. Kennedy III, whose great-uncle was Senator Edward M. Kennedy, won 90 percent of the vote against two relatively unknown rivals and will face the Republican Sean Bielat.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — Days after Joseph P. Kennedy III stood in front of the Democratic National Convention to offer a tribute to his great-uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, he found himself on a smaller platform just outside Boston, shaking hands with commuters at a public transit station here on the first day of his general election campaign in the Fourth Congressional District of Massachusetts.

headline: Plenty to Pull You Away From Poolside
abstract: The New York spring shows began in the modern fashion — with a slap, a high heel and a tacky bride.
lead_paragraph: The New York spring shows began in the modern fashion — with a slap, a high heel and a tacky bride.

headline: When a Disorderly Life Rattles an Enviable Existence
abstract: “Harbor,” at the Westport Country Playhouse, starts as a horror story of houseguests who swear they are staying only one night but refuse to leave, then the tale takes surprising turns.
lead_paragraph: Kevin and his sister, Donna, are very, very different people. He lives in Sag Harbor, the fashionable New York beach community, with his husband, Ted, and works on a novel and the occasional promotional brochure. She lives in a van with her 15-year-old daughter, Lottie, and dreams about being hired as a singer on a cruise ship. When she hears about the salary, she says breathlessly, “$30,000 — that’s almost a double-wide trailer.” The only double-wide anything Kevin and Ted know about are the prams (they use the British word, of course) pushed by breeders who’ve had twins.

headline: Pact Is Signed to Protect Great Lakes
abstract: The United States and Canada signed an accord in Washington on Friday to protect the Great Lakes, the world’s largest freshwater system.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada signed an accord in Washington on Friday to protect the Great Lakes, the world’s largest freshwater system. The agreement, which updates promises between the two nations first made in 1972, sets goals for each country to address invasive species like the Asian carp; curb phosphorus runoff, which can contribute to algae blooms; and cut pollution from industry and vessels. Each nation will now need to develop policies to implement their common objectives, according to the agreement.

headline: A Marketing Man Fights the Madness
abstract: Divine intervention leads an ad man in Moscow to turn against his industry and battle the corporate world.
lead_paragraph: Opened on Friday nationwide.

headline: A Writer Evokes Loss on South Korea’s Path to Success
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Shin Kyung-sook, one of South Korea’s most acclaimed and successful writers, focuses on social upheaval and the price of her country’s success in novels like “Please Look After Mom.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
abstract: A withering drought in India, a new editor for Cosmopolitan, an ambitious bond-buying program from the European Central Bank and a lineup of new Kindle devices from Amazon.com were in the news this week.
lead_paragraph: A withering drought in India, a new editor for Cosmopolitan, an ambitious bond-buying program from the European Central Bank and a lineup of new Kindle devices from Amazon.com were in the news this week.

headline: Buffett Cup in Bridge to be Played in Omaha
abstract: The fourth Buffett Cup will be played from Monday to Thursday in Omaha, the hometown of Warren Buffett, the tournament’s namesake.
lead_paragraph: The Buffett Cup, held every two years, is a tournament fashioned after the Ryder Cup in golf and usually held in the same area soon after the Ryder. This year, though, the fourth Buffett Cup will be played from Monday to Thursday in Omaha, the hometown of Warren Buffett, the tournament’s namesake. The Ryder Cup will be held at Medinah Country Club, Medinah, Ill., over the last six days of September.

headline: Let the Parties and the Games Begin
abstract: New York Fashion Week kicks off with an Hermès dinner, Fashion Night Out and a movie screening.
lead_paragraph: DINNER was at 8 or 8:30 or 9 or 9:30 or 10 or, well, you never know just when you are going to get fed a cracker anymore, now that New York has turned into Madrid. And so people were doing what New Yorkers prefer anyway, and that is to eat the air.

headline: Saris: No Longer Under Wraps
abstract: Attractive young women are wearing shapely saris by new designers to accentuate their figures.
lead_paragraph: SHE came, she saw, she wore.

headline: At a Thai-Laotian Spot, Hot Dishes and Caution
abstract: The menu at Pho Thai-Lao Kitchen in Maywood includes familiar Thai dishes and Lao-inspired fare from the Isan region.
lead_paragraph: IF you lean over the counter at the rear of the tiny Pho Thai-Lao Kitchen and peer past the two refrigerators, you can almost glimpse the bustling kitchen. Not quite, though, as a dark curtain obscures all but a sliver of the action. That’s a shame, because after encountering some of the unusual — and intensely flavored — dishes at this otherwise unassuming place, you might find yourself wondering whether the Wizard of Oz is working the controls back there.

headline: Behind the Scenes, the Bloodiest Beltway Battle
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Bob Woodward provides an exhaustive account of how the “Grand Bargain” debt deal between President Obama and House speaker John A. Boehner collapsed last year.
lead_paragraph: As a plethora of election-year polls and surveys indicate, Americans are fed up with a deeply dysfunctional Washington paralyzed by partisan gridlock and increasingly incapable of dealing with the daunting problems facing the nation: a White House plagued by infighting, disorganization and inconsistent leadership; a Republican Party bent on obstruction and increasingly beholden to its insurgent right wing; and a Congress riven by party rivalries, intraparty power struggles, petty turf wars and an inability to focus on long-term solutions instead of temporary Band-Aids.

headline: College Letter Men Look Back and Ahead
abstract: Last week, Alabama came up with a great game plan for containing Michigan’s Denard Robinson, while Oregon and U.S.C. started fast, too. But don’t be too quick to disparage “old-man football.”
lead_paragraph: Each week, two of college’s football’s seasoned observers, Pre-Snap Read‘s Paul Myerberg and Robert Weintraub of Football Outsiders,  get together over e-mail to discuss the  biggest games and story lines around the country.

headline: Who’s That Handsome Man at Tommy Hilfiger?
abstract: Mr. Hilfiger’s snappy show distracted the editors from the celebrities in attendance as models wearing suits in vibrant preppy stripes appeared on the runway.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in the open-air cabanas at the Maritime Hotel, waiting for the Tommy Hilfiger men’s show to start Friday afternoon, several editors kept an eye on the seats reserved for celebrities. There was a very tall, handsome man, clearly someone famous, wearing a navy suit and blue shirt, but no one could quite put a finger on his name.

headline: Spreading the Word (and Pictures) on ‘Real’ Sex
abstract: Cindy Gallop has started a site that shows films made by real people having real — not porno — sex.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT a decade ago, Cindy Gallop, a pixie-like businesswoman, said she began dating and sleeping with men about half her age. While their stamina and her experience made a good combination, Ms. Gallop said, she also discerned a disturbing trend: the boudoir moves of many of her young lovers seemed drawn entirely from pornography.

headline: From Israel’s Archives, Papers on Munich Killings
keywords: ['Olympic Games (1972)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Terrorism', 'Archives and Records', 'Palestinians', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Dozens of classified documents relating to the 1972 killing of Olympic athletes in Germany have been made public after sitting for four decades in cardboard boxes at the Israel State Archives.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The instructions from the Israeli government were clear in the hours after Palestinian terrorists killed two Israeli athletes at the Munich Summer Olympics in 1972, took nine others hostage and demanded the release of more than 200 Arab prisoners.

headline: A Fall Theater Season of Infinite Variety
abstract: World premieres, audience favorites, fresh Off Broadway hits and a Shakespearean drama are among the mix of works arriving this fall at New Jersey’s professional theaters.
lead_paragraph: WORLD premieres, audience favorites, fresh Off Broadway hits and a Shakespearean drama, along with a mix of recent, familiar and uncommon works, are arriving this fall at New Jersey’s professional theaters.

headline: Big Names at Top Offer Inspiration
abstract: Nick Watney said he was motivated by being paired with Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy, who with Ryan Moore were a stroke behind the leader Vijay Singh at the BMW Championship.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL, Ind. — He was inside the ropes, with the best vantage point to view two superstar golfers at their grinding bests, unbothered by the officious state troopers and overbearing marshals who have overrun Crooked Stick Golf Club this week.

headline: The Bullet Didn’t Leave the Only Scar
abstract: Patria de los Santos and the eight other bystanders hit by police bullets in the Empire State Building shooting last month are tending to their changed lives and bodies.
lead_paragraph: Twice a day, Patria de los Santos, a squat woman in her 50s, bends and gently rubs a little water on this new and tender and unwelcome addition to her otherwise unmarked body. She follows with a bit of antibiotic ointment. Then she replaces the bandage above her left knee. Her bullet wound.

headline: Just After Closing Time, a Fatal Split Second
abstract: The police said that as Reynaldo Cuevas, 20, fled a robbery in progress at the bodega where he worked in the Bronx, he was accidentally and fatally shot when he collided with an officer.
lead_paragraph: In the early hush of Friday morning, the manager and his young employee had finished another long shift, shuttered their Bronx bodega and headed home. But the young assistant had forgotten to grab a bar of soap that he needed. They went back, and when they unlocked the door, the thing so feared by those who work in neighborhoods contaminated by crime followed them in.

headline: From Politics to Ads, Israel Archives Meet YouTube
abstract: In line with a recent policy of giving the public as much access as possible to historical material, the country’s national archivists have taken to relying on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In grainy black-and-white film, David Ben-Gurion, a founding father of modern Israel and its first prime minister, is reading out the new state’s Declaration of Independence for the first time in May 1948. There are crowds in the streets of Tel Aviv and families huddled around their radio sets, hanging on every word. Video: David Ben-Gurion Reads Israel’s Declaration of Independence

headline: When the Express Came to the East End
abstract: An exhibition at the East Hampton Historical Society on Long Island features photographs taken by residents in the aftermath of a hurricane that ripped across the East End in September 1938.
lead_paragraph: THE September day when the brutal hurricane of 1938 hit the East End started out warm and sunny, but it ended up leaving behind a wasteland of uprooted trees, ruined houses and smashed cars. All that destruction, and more, is chronicled in an exhibition in East Hampton, “The Long Island Express: Rare Photographs of East Hampton Town After the 1938 Hurricane.” The Long Island Express is one of several names by which the hurricane came to be remembered.

headline: They’re Not With the Band
abstract: Drumming workouts like Pound and Drums Alive are winning converts.
lead_paragraph: CRISTINA PEERENBOOM wasn’t looking to pound away pounds. All she wanted in the summer of 2010 was to escape some romantic drama by disappearing into her drum playing. But the petite Ms. Peerenboom had broken her drum stool standing on it to reach a book, so she spent an hour squatting as she practiced her favorite Rage Against the Machine songs.

headline: Father Waldo’s America
abstract: Lincoln and the Civil War, as seen through the eyes of a centenarian veteran of the Revolution.
lead_paragraph: Sleep eluded the clergyman Daniel Waldo during the eve of his 100th birthday on Sept. 10, 1862. The former chaplain of the House of Representatives tossed and turned in bed at his home in Syracuse, lost in thought. What kept him awake were not reflections on his past, but concerns about the future of the Republic. Waldo had lived long enough to know firsthand that the leaders of the Southern rebellion were in deadly earnest, for he himself was once a rebel.

headline: European Central Bank Candidacy Delayed Over Lack of Women
abstract: There are no women on the European Central Bank’s executive board, a point that is delaying a hearing to consider the candidacy of Yves Mersch, governor of the Luxembourg central bank.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The leader of an influential committee of the European Parliament said Friday that a hearing to fill a seat on the executive board of the European Central Bank had been postponed after officials ignored demands to develop a plan to promote more women as candidates.

headline: Questions Atop Men’s Game as Big Three Thins to Djokovic
abstract: Is a final four of Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray, Tomas Berdych and David Ferrer indicative of the A.T.P.’s depth, or a sign that the Big Three’s stranglehold has weakened?
lead_paragraph: For seven years now, the very best men’s players have monopolized the Grand Slam trophies. Either Roger Federer won, or Rafael Nadal won, or Novak Djokovic won. Simple as that. The rest of the field played in both the same tournament and another stratosphere.

headline: School Year Just Begun, Teachers Strike Looms in Chicago
abstract: Teachers, city officials and parents in the country’s third-largest school system hope a contract is approved and a strike avoided.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With the possibility looming for a strike beginning on Monday across Chicago’s public schools, contract talks for city teachers were expected to stretch into the weekend, as hundreds of thousands of families began grappling with the prospect that school, only a few days old for many students, may come to an abrupt halt.

headline: The Fine Mess-Maker at Home
abstract: A visit with the great Stan Laurel, near the end of his life, is recollected.
lead_paragraph: “Fat and skinny guys comin’!”

headline: Canada Closes Tehran Embassy and Orders Iran Envoys to Leave
abstract: Calling Iran “the most significant threat to global peace and security in the world today,” Canada’s foreign affairs minister said his government had cut all diplomatic ties with the country.
lead_paragraph: QUEBEC — Calling Iran “the most significant threat to global peace and security in the world today,” Canada’s foreign affairs minister, John Baird, abruptly announced Friday that his government had cut all diplomatic ties with the country.

headline: A Planned Mosque Inches Along, but Critics Remain
abstract: Opponents view the unfinished mosque and Islamic center as a beachhead for Muslim expansion in Brooklyn and a beacon for anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: A cluster of young Muslims in matching yellow T-shirts and broad smiles handed out free school supplies to a line of needy families in front of a gated construction site in the waning days of summer. Across the quiet residential street, two men glared at them, holding up protest signs.

headline: Race Is On in Earnest as Candidates Hit the Road
abstract: As the campaigns go into high gear, voters can expect a blur of ads and an endless number of unsolicited phone calls.
lead_paragraph: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — Mitt Romney’s plane touched down here on Friday, and with it arrived the beginning of what is expected to be the most expensive and intense political advertising war ever.

headline: Dry Reds to Pair With Pizza
abstract: Several Long Island winemakers with Italian backgrounds who make their own pizzas said they favored reds, some pricey.
lead_paragraph: The current pizza craze prompted me to ask some Long Island vintners with Italian backgrounds: Does your family make pizzas at home, and, if so, which of your wines accompany them?

headline: Said K. Aburish, Palestinian Journalist, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Aburish, a former arms dealer with a Harvard M.B.A., skewered Arab leaders in his 11 books.
lead_paragraph: Said K. Aburish, an American-educated Palestinian journalist who drew on his experience as an arms dealer in the Middle East to write 11 books on the region, including a portrait of three generations of his sprawling family and indictments of Arab rulers, died on Aug. 29 in Bethany, a West Bank village controlled by the Palestinian Authority. He was 77.

headline: A Day After the Party, It’s Still the Economy
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The disappointing jobs report leaves President Obama with fading hopes that the economy will surge before Election Day, straining his argument that he has put the country on the right path.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — Only hours after accepting his party’s nomination for a second term, President Obama found himself on the defensive over a jobs report that was weak in almost every way.

headline: Taylor Townsend’s Fitness Report
abstract: Townsend, the 16-year-old American, is having a good run in the junior tournament, but she spent much of her time Friday answering questions about the financing of her trip to the Open.
lead_paragraph: The American Taylor Townsend, the top-ranked girls’ player, lost in singles and won in doubles in the United States Open junior tournament Friday. But most of the questions she faced after her matches were about a report in Friday’s edition of The Wall Street Journal that said the United States Tennis Association declined to finance her trip to the Open over concerns about her fitness.

headline: Far From Flushing, Authentic Sichuan Fare
abstract: Yao’s Diner in Centereach, N.Y., is a Chinese restaurant that diverges from the current trend of pan-Asian fare, serving authentic cuisine from Sichuan Province.
lead_paragraph: A GENERATION ago, nearly every Long Island community had at least one Chinese restaurant, and usually a few takeout places as well. These days, new Asian restaurants are Japanese, Thai, pan-Asian or Asian fusion. Most existing Chinese restaurants have either disappeared or adapted, usually by adding dishes like sushi.

headline: Record Number of Foreigners Were Deported in 2011, Officials Say
abstract: About 390,000 foreign-born people were deported last year, according to the Department of Homeland Security, which is on track for similar figures for fiscal 2012.
lead_paragraph: Immigration enforcement authorities detained and deported record numbers of illegal immigrants in 2011 and are on track for similar figures this year, even as the numbers of migrants crossing the border illegally dropped to a 40-year low, according to data published Friday by the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: U.S. Suspends Its Antidrug Radar-Sharing With Honduras
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: The move, a shift in what American officials had described as a model of international cooperation, came after the Honduran Air Force shot down two planes that might have been carrying drugs.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Seeking better controls for its militarized approach to combating drugs in Central America, the United States has suspended all sharing of radar intelligence with Honduras after the Honduran Air Force shot down two planes that might have been carrying drugs in July, American officials said Friday.

headline: Sept. 7: Polls Find Hints of Obama Convention Bounce
abstract: The three national tracking polls that were published on Friday all moved toward President Obama, probably reflecting momentum from the Democratic convention.
lead_paragraph: The three national tracking polls that were published on Friday all moved toward President Obama, probably reflecting momentum from the Democratic convention.

headline: Rag & Bone: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Abandoned Bank Accounts of Brooke Astor’s Surface, Their Value a Secret
abstract: A newspaper listing of abandoned Citibank accounts includes two that belonged to the philanthropist Brooke Astor, who died in 2007 and left an estate of more than $100 million.
lead_paragraph: Tucked into a long newspaper listing of everyday people who had forgotten a few dollars left in an old bank account, one name still had enough of its old boldface pop to jump out from the squint-inducing type.

headline: Coming Together Without Cabrera, Giants Manage to Play Even Better
abstract: The Giants have gone 13-7 since Melky Cabrera was suspended after testing positive for testosterone, building their lead in the National League West to four and a half games.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Defying Canon and Civil Laws, Diocese Failed to Stop a Priest
abstract: As recently as 2011, a bishop and Catholic officials in Kansas City, Mo., didn’t act to prevent a priest from taking pornographic photographs of young girls.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, the Rev. Shawn Ratigan was just the kind of dynamic new priest that any Roman Catholic bishop would have been happy to put in a parish. He rode a motorcycle, organized summer mission trips to Guatemala and joined Bishop Robert W. Finn and dozens of students on a bus trek to Washington for the “March for Life,” a big annual anti-abortion rally.

headline: Unpredictable Danger Looms Close to the Heart
abstract: Patients who received damaged defibrillator wires made by St. Jude Medical are learning that removing them can be risky, but so can leaving them in place.
lead_paragraph: Monsters attacked Avery de Groh when she was 4. That is how she remembers the day in 2007 when the defibrillator in her chest misfired, sending nine electric shocks through her body in less than 30 minutes.

headline: New SEC Opponents Have the Look of Old Rivals
abstract: Texas A&M hosts Florida for its first SEC game, and on top of the intrigue of the Aggies’ new system and quarterback, the teams have traded barbs.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. — Little would suggest any animosity between Texas A&M and Florida. But fuel the pregame hype with a hurricane, a gift basket and a strategically placed billboard, and a heated rivalry might be born Saturday at Kyle Field.

headline: Man Says He Questioned Safety Before Quebec Shooting
keywords: ['Security and Warning Systems', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The host of an election night party in Quebec, where a gunman killed one person and wounded another, said that the police ignored his warnings about security deficiencies at the event.
lead_paragraph: QUEBEC — The host of the election night victory party where a gunman killed one person and wounded another, apparently as part of an attempted assassination of Quebec’s premier-designate, said that the police ignored his warnings about security deficiencies at the event.

headline: Jobs and Politics
abstract: Republicans have the wrong answers for fixing the weak job market.
lead_paragraph: Coming two months before Election Day, the employment report for August is a problem for President Obama. The economy added 96,000 jobs last month, a slow pace that lowered the monthly average this year to 139,000, versus 153,000 in 2011. Even the decline in the jobless rate, to 8.1 percent from 8.3 percent in July, was a disappointment, because it indicated a shrinking labor force as people gave up looking for work.

headline: A Court Denounces ‘Executive Fiat’
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Detainees', 'Editorials']
abstract: In a scalding opinion, a Federal District Court judge rejected new rules that limit access to counsel for prisoners at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: In a scalding opinion issued on Thursday, Judge Royce Lamberth of Federal District Court rejected new rules imposed by the Obama administration last spring that limit access to counsel for prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who are not actively challenging their detention.

headline: Democrats Face a Juggling Act Over Economy Message
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Democratic National Convention', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: For President Obama, the Democratic National Convention captured his tricky balancing act: a four-year struggle to show that pro-worker does not mean antibusiness.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — With both parties’ conventions now concluded, what is clear is that each played to type — Republicans as the party of business, Democrats of the worker. For President Obama, however, the week here captured his tricky balancing act: a four-year struggle to show that pro-worker does not mean antibusiness.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for Sept. 7, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Justice Ventures Up the Church Hierarchy
abstract: In a long-overdue verdict, a Catholic bishop was found guilty of shielding a priest known to be a threat to children.
lead_paragraph: The verdict was long overdue in the pedophile priest scandal, but a Roman Catholic bishop has become the highest-ranking church official found criminally guilty of shielding a priest known to be a threat to children. In a brief nonjury trial, Bishop Robert Finn, head of the Diocese of Kansas City-St. Joseph, Mo., was pronounced guilty on Thursday and sentenced to two years of probation for failing to alert law enforcement authorities about a predatory priest he knew was addicted to taking lewd photos of schoolgirls.

headline: Building Ties by Opening Up
abstract: James Franklin brought a personal touch to a Vanderbilt football program that had two winning seasons in the last 35 years.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE —  A certain brand of optimism had been required for James Franklin to forgive his father, to forget their past. But now it was being tested. In his father’s new home, Franklin listened to his father’s new wife deny his father’s sins against him, his sister and their mother.

headline: Impasse in Japan Forces Delay in Spending
abstract: The opposition Liberal Democrats scuttled a budget bill, dealing a blow to the ruling Democratic Party and darkening Japan’s economic outlook.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A political standoff forced Japan on Friday to postpone budget spending for the first time in decades, underscoring the beleaguered state of the country’s ruling party. The action clouded the country’s economic outlook just as analysts were warning of a slowdown.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Questions about a memorial beam beneath 1 World Trade Center and strange markings on the nearby streets.
lead_paragraph: Signed and Sealed

headline: New York’s Thursday Primary
abstract: Because of New York’s dysfunctional State Legislature, a primary election will be held on Sept. 13. Here are our recommendations for some important Democratic races.
lead_paragraph: Next Thursday, New York will hold a primary election that will come as a surprise to many voters. This election is the costly result of a dysfunctional State Legislature, which was incapable of making a sensible decision to hold the state primary on June 26, the primary for Congressional seats. The only consolation is that every single vote could make a difference.

headline: Reading, Math and Grit
abstract: Character matters as much as schoolwork, or maybe even more. And new initiatives are showing how it can be taught.
lead_paragraph: Early in his acceptance speech Thursday night, President Obama gave a nod to his administration’s backing of education reform. “Some of the worst schools in the country have made real gains in math and reading,” he said, calling on the country to add 100,000 math and science teachers in the next decade. Then he moved on to other topics, like foreign policy and Medicare, that he clearly views as more vital to the campaign as it enters the home stretch.

headline: Britain: Prince Harry Begins New Afghan Deployment
abstract: Three weeks after making headlines with a game of strip billiards in a Las Vegas hotel suite, Prince Harry, third in line to the British throne, has begun a four-month deployment to Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after making headlines with a game of strip billiards with a group of women in a Las Vegas hotel suite, Prince Harry, third in line to the British throne, has begun a four-month deployment to Afghanistan as the co-pilot and weapons officer of an Apache attack helicopter. The 27-year-old prince joined his unit of the Army Air Corps at Camp Bastion in Helmand Province, where he will fly combat missions against the Taliban. His previous service in Afghanistan was in 2007 and 2008, when he served 10 weeks as a forward air traffic controller, helping direct strikes on the Taliban. The Apache deployment was one he had lobbied strongly for with British defense chiefs.

headline: Take One’s Lumps
abstract: How I approach a Byron Walden puzzle (Hint: It involves furniture.)
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Byron Walden puzzles don’t come up in The New York Times that often anymore (he’s a busy dad and a professor of mathematics), but when they do, I treat them as they deserve to be treated: with fear and respect, much as one would approach a wild lion that had suddenly materialized in one’s living room.

headline: Backstage McQueen: Q and A With Anne Deniau
abstract: For 13 years, the photographer Anne Deniau had a rare view into the backstage world of Alexander McQueen’s runway shows.Her images are compiled in the new book, “Love Looks Not with the Eyes: Thirteen Years with Lee Alexander McQueen.” Here, a Q. and A. with the photographer.
lead_paragraph: For 13 years, the photographer Anne Deniau had a rare view into the backstage world of Alexander McQueen’s runway shows. Hired by the designer to create images that captured the spirit of his collections, she found a perspective on his work that audiences in the front rows never had a chance to see. Her images are compiled in the new book, “Love Looks Not With the Eyes: Thirteen Years With Lee Alexander McQueen.” Here, a Q and A with the photographer.

headline: A 20-Year-Old Father’s Goal Was to Make His Slain Father Proud
abstract: Reynaldo Cuevas, who was killed by a police bullet, was working at his uncle’s bodega with myriad aspirations to move forward with his life.
lead_paragraph: Reynaldo Cuevas cried when his father, Maleno, was fatally shot in the street two years ago in the Dominican Republic over a gold necklace and a bracelet, relatives said. He was changed by it.

headline: Pulling Levers to Play the Piano
abstract: Randolph Herr says he can’t find middle C with a flashlight, but he is renowned for repairing, restoring and making sweet music with player pianos.
lead_paragraph: RANDOLPH HERR, 64, sat at one of the two Steinway grand pianos in his cluttered living room in Queens on Thursday afternoon and began playing Liszt’s “Liebestraum” No. 3.

headline: Students Are Suspended in Stuyvesant Cheating
abstract: Twelve students were suspended and more than 50 others face suspensions in a continuing investigation of cheating during final exams in June, school officials said.
lead_paragraph: A dozen Stuyvesant High School students have been suspended and more than 50 others are facing suspension because of new evidence that has emerged in a continuing investigation of cheating during final exams in June, school officials said Friday.

headline: Studies Find More Students Cheating, With High Achievers No Exception
abstract: Recent examples of school cheating are just more evidence that the problem has gotten worse, and experts blame schools, parents and technology.
lead_paragraph: Large-scale cheating has been uncovered over the last year at some of the nation’s most competitive schools, like Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, the Air Force Academy and, most recently, Harvard.

lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The goal of the Democratic convention was to draw a sharp contrast between the visions offered by President Obama and Mitt Romney, promote a first-term record that many Democrats feel Mr. Obama has failed to articulate and persuade nervous Americans to stick with this president through tough times.

keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention']

keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: If you just look at social media and the number of likes, tweets and views, it seems as if President Obama is winning the race.

headline: Alexander McQueen Behind the Scenes
abstract: Images from “Love Looks Not With the Eyes: Thirteen Years With Lee Alexander McQueen,” a book of 400 images taken and compiled by the photographer Anne Deniau, who chronicled the late designer.
lead_paragraph: Images from “Love Looks Not With the Eyes: Thirteen Years With Lee Alexander McQueen,” a book of 400 images taken and compiled by the photographer Anne Deniau, who chronicled the late designer.

headline: McQueen Backstage, in Front of the Lens
abstract: In a new book, the photographer Anne Deniau compiled 400 images that give a sense of what Alexander McQueen’s life was like behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: THE coming weeks will bring at least three monographs examining the life of Alexander McQueen, including a biography by Judith Watt, the fashion historian at Central Saint Martins, as well as books made up almost entirely of images from his fantastic runway shows, which in themselves have enormous value.

headline: A Walmart for Chinatown Stirs a Fight in Los Angeles
abstract: Some local residents and business owners fear this historic immigrant community is now threatened by the newest big-box addition to the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Along Broadway here, in the heart of Chinatown, immigrants crowd around fruit and vegetable shops, asking prices in Mandarin and Cantonese. Men hawk huge red grapes from a pile in the back of a pickup truck. And poultry shops sell not only chicken, but roosters, guinea hens and pheasants — live poultry is available on request.

headline: Islamic Poultry for Latino Tables (Yes, They Have Chilies, Too)
abstract: A halal butcher in East Los Angeles expected patronage by fellow Muslims. Latino immigrants became its customers instead, making for some admirable cultural interaction.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sebastian Flores walked out of Al Salam Pollería with a free bag of white-feathered chicken heads.

headline: Yanks, Behind Three Homers, Knock Orioles Back Down
abstract: Home runs from Russell Martin, Steve Pearce and Alex Rodriguez accounted for all but one of the Yankees’ runs as they again moved a game ahead of Baltimore in the American League East race.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Ever since the Orioles used a six-homer barrage Thursday night to hammer their way into a first-place tie with the Yankees in the American League East, the specter of second place had hung over the Yankees like the humidity that draped this city all day and night.

headline: Private Sector Role Is at Heart of Campaigns’ Split on College Costs
abstract: While President Obama would work to increase grants and extend a tax credit, Mitt Romney would work to make financial aid available for students who “need it most,” an aide said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ballots cast in November will help decide how the federal government confronts the costs of college and what role the private sector plays in higher education.

headline: As Coolant Is Phased Out, Smugglers Reap Large Profits
abstract: As government authorities in the industrialized world work to phase out an air-conditioner coolant, HCFC-22, a black market has sprung up for it.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The chief executive of the century-old company from America’s heartland shifted nervously on the witness stand here as he tried to explain how a trusted senior vice president had been caught on a wiretap buying half a million dollars in smuggled merchandise, much of it from China.

headline: A Queen, a Poem and a Handbook, All Big
abstract: A look at the life of Eva Tanguay, a poem by young poets that celebrates New York City and a handbook about government in the Empire State.
lead_paragraph: WATCH out when an academic press approaches a popular subject. Chances are that whatever merriment might have been mined from it will be buried again in footnotes or suffocated by scholarly jargon. In “Queen of Vaudeville: The Story of Eva Tanguay” (Cornell University Press, $29.95), Andrew L. Erdman defies that unfortunate stereotype in resurrecting an early-20th-century celebrity who was suggestively famous as the “I Don’t Care Girl” because she popularized the song “I Don’t Care” and made it her mantra.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Mets Honor a Longtime Rival, Who Returns the Love
abstract: Chipper Jones, who made a career out of pounding Mets pitching, reflects on the Mets and their fans in his farewell visit to Queens.
lead_paragraph: Chipper Jones said he was asked the other day how he would feel about himself if he were a Mets fan. “I would respect the body of work,” Jones said, “but I would hate his guts.”

abstract: Simple styles by two European designers, Azzedine Alaïa and the label Alexander McQueen, designed by Sarah Burton, popped up consistently.
lead_paragraph: Simple styles by two European designers, Azzedine Alaïa and the label Alexander McQueen, designed by Sarah Burton, popped up consistently.

headline: Local Stop: Fordham Road
abstract: Emerging from the Fordham Road subway stop in the Bronx, observers see majestic architecture and signs of decline, niche shops, ethnic restaurants, a university and Edgar Allan Poe’s old clapboard house.
lead_paragraph: Emerging from the Fordham Road subway stop in the Bronx, observers see majestic architecture and signs of decline, niche shops, ethnic restaurants, a university and Edgar Allan Poe’s old clapboard house.

headline: We Saints Fans Thrive on Embracing the Horror
abstract: It’s when we’re convinced that somebody is out to get us, whether it be Isaac, Roger Goodell or any other conspirator out there, that we turn genuinely optimistic about our chances.
lead_paragraph: “The Saints are going to win it all, baby,” Pat Bode, the proprietor of Mugz’s Bar in the New Orleans suburb of Metairie, her excited eyes wide with unwavering certainty, proclaimed to me on a recent evening. “I got a lot of faith in that.”

headline: From Poe to Paradise in the Bronx
abstract: With its mishmash of architectural periods, streets packed with colorful shops and Edgar Allan Poe’s clapboard cottage, the neighborhood has a little of everything.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn has its multitudes, Queens its fathomless diversity. The Bronx trades more in sharp contrasts: lush parks and roaring expressways, majestic architecture and harder times. Exiting the Fordham Road subway station you’ll find elegant 1920s buildings on the Grand Concourse; chain stores on East Fordham Road; Edgar Allan Poe’s tidy, tragic cottage in Poe Park; and down the hill, the campus of Fordham, with its close-cropped lawns and impressive gates, open only to those affiliated with the university. For the students who matriculate here each year, these surroundings might be as much an education as college itself.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Day 12
abstract: Victoria Azarenka and Serena Williams both advanced to the United States Open final, and Bob and Mike Bryan won their 12th Grand Slam doubles title.

headline: Fresh Beer and Brain Teasers
abstract: Serkan Piantino, the head engineer in charge of Facebook’s Manhattan office, lives in Greenwich Village and typically spends much of his Sunday in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Serkan Piantino, with his newish job in new media — he has, for a year now, been the head engineer in charge of Facebook’s Manhattan office — is also a relatively new New Yorker. Raised in Greenwich, Conn., Mr. Piantino, 29, studied computer science at Carnegie Mellon University and spent four years in California helping to develop Facebook’s News Feed and Timeline features before he returned to the metropolitan area full time last year. He lives on Horatio Street in Greenwich Village and typically spends much of his Sunday in the neighborhood.

headline: Photo in an Attic Leads to a Forgotten Team’s Place in the Hall of Fame

headline: Bulk of Charitable Giving Not Earmarked for the Poor
abstract: If big cuts are made to federal programs that benefit the lives of the less fortunate, private donations are unlikely to help fill the gap left by government.
lead_paragraph: One weekend several years ago, as I was arriving at my neighborhood farmers’ market, a college student approached me with a clipboard and an impassioned, if easily forgettable pitch for Greenpeace. If I signed the papers he had in his hand, a $20 charge would appear on my credit card statement each month and a small but vital fraction of the world’s marine life could be saved. Confronted by an actual person and standing in the vicinity of cheese whose per-pound price was equal to the monthly cost of potentially saving a monk seal, I was too embarrassed to say, “Thanks, but I’ll pass,” only then to move on to the artisanal cheddars of Pennsylvania.

headline: Clinton Tells Russia That Sanctions Will Soon End
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']

lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged Saturday that the United States would soon lift cold-war-era trade sanctions on Russia, but she did not address human rights legislation in Congress that has so far stalled passage, infuriated the Kremlin and become an unexpected issue in the American presidential race.

headline: Russia and Japan in Agreement on Natural Gas Deal
abstract: Gazprom, Russia’s state-controlled gas monopoly, signed an accord on Saturday with the government of Japan to continue with plans for construction of a $13 billion natural gas terminal.
lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — Gazprom, Russia’s state-controlled gas monopoly, signed an accord on Saturday with the government of Japan to move forward with plans for the construction of a $13 billion natural gas terminal here that would propel the Kremlin’s ambitions to multiply its business and trade ties in the Far East.

headline: Grand Dreams on the Far Edges
abstract: Going beyond the obvious angles of the amusement park and the beach, a photographer explores Coney Island.
lead_paragraph: When the photographer Emily Berl visits a place for the first time, she said, she likes to go to its farthest edges, because she knows she will find something interesting happening there. In New York this instinct took her to Coney Island, the neighborhood defined by the two things it was not: the amusement park and the beach. “Thousands of people go to the amusement park and never walk the three blocks into the neighborhood,” she said. “There was just so much life there that I didn’t know existed.”

headline: Murray Reaches Final; Second Semifinal Is Suspended
abstract: No. 3 seed Andy Murray faces sixth-seeded Tomas Berdych, then No. 2 seed Novak Djokovic, the defending champion, takes on fourth-seeded David Ferrer.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine that a final four that consists of the Nos. 2, 3, 4, and 6 seeds would be considered a surprise, but that’s the state of the men’s semifinals at the 2012 United States Open. It was the first time in 33 Grand Slam events in which neither Roger Federer nor Rafael Nadal reached the semifinal round, though the cast of remaining characters was hardly an obscure one.

headline: Hitching His Wagon to Obama’s Star: a Republican Senator

headline: Clashes Worsen Misery in Syria’s Biggest Cities
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Water', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Battles between the Syrian military and rebels burst a main pipe that delivered drinking water to hundreds of thousands of residents of Aleppo, opposition groups said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Clashes between the Syrian military and rebel fighters burst a main pipe that delivered drinking water to hundreds of thousands of residents of Aleppo, opposition groups said Saturday, as the United Nations refugee agency said more than 1.2 million Syrians still inside the country, half of them children, had been displaced from their homes.

Tim Rohan, Tom Spousta, Zach Schonbrun and Hunter Atkins are scattered across the country, from New Jersey to SEC country, whether in Baton Rouge or College Station, Tex. Keep tabs throughout the day for updates and analysis.

headline: A Terrifying Way to Discipline Children
abstract: My daughter was one of tens of thousands of students isolated or restrained by teachers.
lead_paragraph: IN my public school 40 years ago, teachers didn’t lay their hands on students for bad behavior. They sent them to the principal’s office. But in today’s often overcrowded and underfunded schools, where one in eight students receive help for special learning needs, the use of physical restraints and seclusion rooms has become a common way to maintain order.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Delayed, Again, After Major Investor Dies
abstract: The producers of one of the most expensive, and troubled, musicals of the fall season are in talks with the investor’s estate to secure the promised money.
lead_paragraph: 3:30 p.m. | Updated One of the most expensive — and troubled — musicals of the Broadway fall season, “Rebecca,” is once again in limbo, with producers announcing on Saturday that a major investor in the show has died and they are in protracted talks with the estate to secure the promised money. The investor was responsible for an investment pool of $4.5 million for the musical, more than one third of its $12 million capitalization costs for Broadway, according to the producers, who declined to divulge the investor’s name.

headline: Rain and Rest Days Spell the End of Super Saturday
abstract: Next year, the men’s and women’s semifinals and finals will not be played on back-to-back days at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Say goodbye to Super Saturday, as we have known it. With its meteorological and emotional intensity, its drama kings and drama queens, Super Saturday has been the centerpiece of the United States Open for nearly three decades.

headline: U.S. Moves to Grant Former Mexican President Immunity in Suit
abstract: The State Department said Ernesto Zedillo should be immune from a federal civil lawsuit filed over a 1997 massacre during his term.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A former Mexican president who is now a scholar at Yale University should be immune from a civil lawsuit brought against him in the United States in connection with a 1997 massacre during his term, the State Department said Friday.

headline: Obama’s English
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'English Language', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: President Obama’s selective use of black speaking styles gives him a linguistic advantage over Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: TWO aspects of President Obama’s acceptance speech to the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night were of linguistic interest. The first was “signifying” — the use of indirect humor as critique, and a much discussed feature of black speech. “My opponent and his running mate are ... new ... to foreign policy,” he said, adding the two pauses for great comedic effect. The second, and more familiar, was the soaring crescendo, beginning with “in the words of Scripture, ours is a future filled with hope,” in which Mr. Obama demonstrated his strongest mode of linguistic performance — the black preacher style — to end his remarks (“knowing that providence is with us and that we are surely blessed”).

headline: India and Pakistan Sign Visa Agreement, Easing Travel
abstract: The agreement, which will make travel easier for businessmen, tourists and others, is seen as a tentative step between the rival countries to normalize their troubled relations.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan and India signed a new visa agreement on Saturday, easing restrictions for travelers in what was seen as a step toward warming relations between the rival South Asian countries after years of heightened mistrust and hostility.

headline: Five Crucial Factors to Watch, Just 58 Days From the Election
abstract: Two months before the election, President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on at least one thing: the collection of states where the race will be decided.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two months before the election, President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on one thing: the collection of states where the race will be decided.

headline: If Achilles Used Facebook...
abstract: A mathematical examination of the social networks in three mythological narratives reveals a degree of historical reality for each tale.
lead_paragraph: WHEN we pick up a mythological text like “The Iliad” or “Beowulf,” we like to imagine that the societies they describe existed. Even if the stories are fiction, we believe that they tell us something about ancient Greece or the Anglo-Saxons, and that some of the characters and events were based on reality.

headline: Why Fathers Really Matter
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Sperm', 'Men and Boys', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Parenting', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Research', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: Modern biology is making it clearer by the day that a man’s health and well-being have a measurable impact on his future children’s health and happiness.
lead_paragraph: MOTHERHOOD begins as a tempestuously physical experience but quickly becomes a political one. Once a woman’s pregnancy goes public, the storm moves outside. Don’t pile on the pounds! Your child will be obese. Don’t eat too little, or your baby will be born too small. For heaven’s sake, don’t drink alcohol. Oh, please: you can sip some wine now and again. And no matter how many contradictory things the experts say, don’t panic. Stress hormones wreak havoc on a baby’s budding nervous system.

headline: The Issues? Yawn.
abstract: Count on candidates to reference “the issues,” but not explore them.
lead_paragraph: In this or any election year the candidates can be counted on to make regular references in their campaign speeches to “the issues.” It’s important to realize that in doing so they are not actually alluding to the real-world challenges facing Americans. They are alluding to “the issues” — just that, that actual two-word phrase.

headline: Obama, Stumping in Florida, Tries to Turn Focus to Medicare From Jobs
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: President Obama’s advisers have indicated that they are eager to re-engage their opponents on their Medicare plan, while the Romney camp would prefer to talk about the economy.
lead_paragraph: SEMINOLE, Fla. — President Obama on Saturday began hammering away at the Republican ticket’s plans for Medicare, using a campaign swing through Florida, with its large number of retired and elderly voters, to try to turn the page from anemic employment growth, his biggest weakness, to entitlements, a Democratic strength.

headline: After Jobs Report, Obama Tries to Change the Subject
abstract: President Obama began hammering away at the Republican ticket’s plans for Medicare, using a campaign swing through Florida to try to turn the page from anemic employment growth, his biggest weakness, to entitlements, a Democratic strength.

headline: Playing Now: Hail to Us Chiefs
abstract: Will there be a second chance for We, the President?
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE

headline: For Texans, Playoff Lost and Perspective Gained
abstract: Houston’s run to the playoffs last season set the stage for what the Texans now expect: to rise into the upper echelon of the N.F.L.’s American Conference.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The sting of a playoff loss was only a few minutes old, so fresh that the Houston players had not even removed their shoulder pads inside the visitors’ locker room in Baltimore. In their decade of existence, the Texans had never before reached the postseason, let alone dealt with losing in one. Perhaps that explains the players’ unorthodox reaction last January when their best season screeched to an unceremonious halt in the second round.

headline: Simple Treatments, Ignored
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Blood Pressure', 'Hypertension', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Editorials']
abstract: Too often, our dysfunctional health care system is failing to control high blood pressure.
lead_paragraph: A new federal health analysis has found that 36 million adults in the United States have high blood pressure that is not being controlled even though 32 million of them get regular medical care and 30 million of them have health insurance.

headline: Elephant Slaughter
abstract: China’s lust for illegal ivory has turned Africa into a poachers’ playground.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago it looked as though elephant poaching in Africa was on the downswing, in part because of more rigorous enforcement of a global ban on trade in most elephant ivory imposed in 1989. That moment is gone and with it, elephants in the tens of thousands every year. These astonishing creatures, which seem more intelligent and emotionally aware the more we know about them, are being gunned down by poachers for their ivory tusks at a fast pace — the worst slaughter seen since the 1980s.

headline: The Constitution on Skid Row
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Search and Seizure', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials']
abstract: Federal courts have rightly sided with the homeless whose personal property was seized by Los Angeles city employees.
lead_paragraph: Skid Row in Los Angeles, which has one of the highest concentrations of homeless people in the country, has been the site of extended legal battles over the rights of individuals to live on the streets and the power of the government to impose order.

headline: A Congress for the Many, or the Few?
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Serving constituents one at a time is expensive, distracting and un-American.
lead_paragraph: OUT of work and stuck with an expensive mortgage, my friend was on the verge of losing her house. Attempts to get the bank to modify her loan led to a situation Kafka would have recognized: scores of letters, hundreds of phone calls — but no modification. Then she called one of her senators. Soon a member of the senator’s staff had contacted the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the federal agency that regulates national banks. Not long after, my friend received the loan modification she had been requesting, unavailingly, for years.

headline: A City’s Heartbreak Outlives Its Source
abstract: An expansion team called the Browns made its debut in 1999, but the connection with the team’s past will probably, like Cleveland itself, never be the same.
lead_paragraph: On a bright, yet metaphorically dark day in 1995 — temperature in the high 30s, balmy for Cleveland in December — my 6-year-old son and I trudged down toward the lake to witness the real Cleveland Browns’ dying day.

headline: Milk of Human Kindness
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof visits the dairy of his childhood friend Bob Bansen, who has names for every cow in his herd and treats “his girls” like co-workers, not widgets.
lead_paragraph: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof visits the dairy of his childhood friend Bob Bansen, who has names for every cow in his herd and treats “his girls” like co-workers, not widgets.

headline: When Family Trees Are Gnarled by Race
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Editorials', 'Slavery', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: For many families, including President Obama’s, genealogical research has uncovered painful stories of America’s past.
lead_paragraph: My paternal grandfather, Marshall Staples (1898-1969), was one of the millions of black Southerners who moved north in the Great Migration. Those of us in the family who were born Yankees in the years just after World War II were given an earful about our place in 19th-century Virginia — and specifically about Marshall’s white grandfather, a member of a slaveholding family who fathered at least one child with my great-great-grandmother, Somerville Staples.

headline: Another Title for U.S. Women
abstract: The United States defeated Germany early Saturday, 1-0, to win the FIFA U-20 Women’s World Cup in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: Another group of American women were crowned champions of an international soccer tournament when the United States defeated Germany early Saturday, 1-0, to win the FIFA U-20 Women’s World Cup in Tokyo.

headline: Doubts as Portland Weighs Fluoride and Its Civic Values
abstract: In Portland, Ore., the largest American city not fluoridating its water, a decision involves questions of personal choice and societal burden.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Who bears responsibility for an impoverished child with a mouth full of rotting teeth? Parents? Soda companies? The ingrained inequities of capitalism? Pick your villain, or champion. They are all on display here as the largest city in the nation with no commitment to fluoridating its water supply — and one of the most politically liberal cultures anywhere — has waded into a new debate about whether to change its ways and its water.

headline: How to Find Weeds in a Mortgage Pool
abstract: A computerized compendium of housing transactions could help investors identify the bad mortgages in many bundled securities.
lead_paragraph: IT sounds like the Domesday Book of the housing bust. In fact, it is a computerized compendium of millions of housing transactions — a decade’s worth from across the country — that could finally help us get to the bottom of troubled mortgage investments.

headline: Grand Finale in Grand Slam
abstract: After an embarrassing early loss at Wimbledon, Pete Sampras won what proved to be his last tournament 10 years ago, beating Andre Agassi in the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: It was the last all-American men’s final in a Grand Slam tournament; the last match between Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi; and though this was not clear at the time, the last match of Sampras’s career.

headline: Defying Parents, Some Pakistani Women Risk All to Marry Whom They Choose
abstract: Women are increasingly asserting their rights against the traditions of forced marriage and parental authority, challenging one of the most powerful institutions in Pakistani society.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Nusrat Mochi, now 25, left her parents’ home one day to go to work and never returned. Instead of starting a job as a domestic worker, she ran away to begin a new life, against her family’s wishes, with a husband of her choosing rather than the one they had chosen for her. Her parents’ wrath has trailed her ever since.

headline: His First Rule of Business: Don’t Hope
abstract: Ben Lerer of the Thrillist Media Group never wants his employees to rely on luck in their work.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Ben Lerer, co-founder and C.E.O. of the Thrillist Media Group, which oversees men’s lifestyle and shopping Web sites, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Selling It With Extras, or Not at All
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Guarantees and Warranties', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Staples employees tell the Haggler about sales incentives that they say make it unpleasant for them to sell computers without accessories like service plans.
lead_paragraph: THE Haggler once knew a guy who worked as a salesman at a mattress chain in the Washington area. Every week, the chain ran a full-page ad in The Washington Post, advertising deep discounts on one make and model of mattress. And the rule among sales staff could not be simpler: if you sold any customers that discounted mattress, you were fired.

lead_paragraph: THE unemployment rate is 8.1 percent, hiring has slowed to a trickle and the economy is weak. For a president seeking re-election, those are high hurdles.

headline: Cutting the Deficit, With Compassion
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Democrats have a chance to go on the offensive this year about reducing the deficit — in a way that does as little harm as possible to people, jobs and economic opportunity.
lead_paragraph: ASIDE from the empty chair that Clint Eastwood debated, the main prop at the Republican convention was a debt clock, highlighting the federal deficit and the growing national debt. The importance of dealing with the deficit will clearly be a major Republican theme this fall. So far, Democrats have mostly been playing defense on this issue by criticizing the Romney-Ryan approach. It’s time for them to go on offense by putting their own plan front and center.

headline: Strikeouts Record Unmatched 50 Years Later
abstract: Fifty years ago this Wednesday, Tom Cheney of the Washington Senators struck out 21 Baltimore Orioles over 16 innings. It remains a record for strikeouts in a game, and no pitcher has thrown more innings in any game since.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago this Wednesday, Tom Cheney of the Washington Senators struck out 21 Baltimore Orioles over 16 innings. It remains a record for strikeouts in a game, and no pitcher has thrown more innings in any game since.

headline: 2 Jets Defensive Linemen Hope Reunion Continues at the Quarterback
abstract: Muhammad Wilkerson and Quinton Coples, defensive linemen who played together in military school, were the Jets’ top draft picks in consecutive years.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — That Muhammad Wilkerson’s teammates and coaches on the Jets rave about his modesty does not seem to surprise Robert Prunty, who remembers his reaction the day players at Hargrave Military Academy were given three ham sandwiches as part of their lunch to eat during a six-hour trip to Annapolis, Md. As a practicing Muslim, Wilkerson cannot have pork. So he ate his apple and his cookies, and he drank his milk, and he did not complain. He did not even tell his coach.

headline: What Work Is Really For
abstract: For most of us, work is a means to something else: it makes a living, but it doesn’t make a life. So shouldn’t leisure be our goal?
lead_paragraph: Is work good or bad?  A fatuous question, it may seem, with unemployment such a pressing national concern.  (Apart from the names of the two candidates, “jobs” was the politically relevant word most used by speakers at the Republican and Democratic conventions.) Even apart from current worries, the goodness of work is deep in our culture. We applaud people for their work ethic, judge our economy by its productivity and even honor work with a national holiday.

headline: Prabal Gurung: Calm Before the Storm
abstract: Before an audience that included a first daughter, Barbara Bush, and the already reigning young actresses of this runway season (Allison Williams, Hailee Steinfeld and Kate Bosworth), Prabal Gurung showed a spring collection that seemed to be trying to straddle the fence between uptown and downtown.
lead_paragraph: Before an audience that included a first daughter, Barbara Bush, as well as a few socialites and the already reigning young actresses of this runway season (Allison Williams, Hailee Steinfeld and Kate Bosworth), Prabal Gurung showed a spring collection that seemed to be trying to straddle the fence between uptown and downtown. It started with street-tough outfits of layered trousers, sheer undershirts with an ominous bird-wing print, artfully folded skirts and an asymmetrical jacket or two — all in black and white — which had me thinking I was at the wrong show. Did I end up at Alexander Wang by mistake?

headline: Wider Warning After 3rd Yosemite Hantavirus Death
abstract: So far, eight people out of the thousands who visited the park this summer have been infected with the mouse-borne virus, which has no known cure.
lead_paragraph: After the death last week of a third person exposed to the deadly mouse-borne hantavirus, public health officials were expanding their warning to include more than 22,000 visitors to Yosemite National Park.

Ryan will hunker down for his first full day of debate prep before he faces off against Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. next month.

headline: When Happy Cows Produce Happy Milk
abstract: Readers comment on my column about agriculture, and a dairy farm that keeps cows happy and milk healthy.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column takes a break from politics and looks at something even more basic: food. Regular readers know that I’m distressed by what’s happening in rural America and the way we’re drifting to vast corporate food factories that produce food that tastes plastic and raises public health concerns. Yet the defenders of industrial farming point out, correctly, that their system does produce food that is very cheap at the grocery store. They argue that family farms just can’t compete and are an anachronism in the 21st century.

headline: Armstrong, Back When It Wasn’t Tennis Rocking the House
abstract: The Singer Bowl, which was built for the 1964-65 World’s Fair, then divided and incorporated into the National Tennis Center, had an eclectic history before the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: It is fair to say that nearly every top-ranked tennis player during the last three decades has played at least one match at Louis Armstrong Memorial Stadium, the second-largest venue at the National Tennis Center in Flushing. Thousands more have faced off at the Grandstand, a smaller locale attached to Armstrong.

lead_paragraph: “Why can’t we sit with the press?” Donna Karan asked before the start of a show Saturday morning for the first graduating class of a new M.F.A. program in fashion design at Parsons the New School for Design.

lead_paragraph: It is beyond dispute that the Chicago Cubs franchise is a never-ending, mind-numbing repository of bad luck and freakish occurrences.

headline: Violence, Dissected
abstract: Photographs situate the actions of a killer and his accomplice in their time and place.
lead_paragraph: A boy, a girl, a car, and a gun. The formula lies deep in American mythology. Imagine the appeal: you and your love object are desperadoes on the run, death the only possible outcome. It’s a suicide mission, the sort of fantasy that emerges when people are trapped. To go on the run is to chase the dragon of some other life, in full knowledge of the futility of the effort and the inevitability of the end. With sex, speed and ballistics stirred together, you simply have to accept that you will explode.

headline: Other Men’s Flowers
abstract: The techniques that served Cicero will just as effectively serve modern writers of opinion.
lead_paragraph: Rhetoric, simply put, is the study of how language works to persuade. So any writer seeking to make a case, or hold a reader’s attention — which is more or less any writer not in the service of the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea — has something to learn from it.

headline: In Defense of the Power of Paper
keywords: ['Paper and Pulp', 'Workplace Environment', 'Reading and Writing Skills', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Pens and Pencils', 'Productivity']
abstract: Though surrounded by computer terminals, many office workers still have practical reasons for using pen and paper in their daily tasks.
lead_paragraph: PAPER still matters. The frequent whirring of printers in offices — despite the Internet, Microsoft Word, social media, scanners, smartphone apps and PDF files — attests to that. We may use less of it than we once did, but reading and writing on paper serves a function that, for many workers, a screen can’t replicate.

headline: Adelson Chooses Madrid Over Barcelona for New Casino
abstract: Sheldon G. Adelson, the American billionaire casino magnate, is set to build a giant resort around Madrid, ending a bidding battle between the Spanish capital and Barcelona.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Sheldon G. Adelson, the American billionaire casino magnate, is set to build a giant gaming and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid, ending a lengthy bidding battle between the Spanish capital and Barcelona, the country’s second-largest city.

headline: Controlling My Own Destiny
abstract: The chief executive of Imax says he started out as a lawyer but changed careers because he thrived on taking risks.
lead_paragraph: MY parents raised me in a blue-collar neighborhood of Plainview, N.Y., on Long Island. My mother was a homemaker and my father was a furrier, a job that left him unemployed for months at a time, because no one bought fur coats during the summer.

headline: Ups and Downs on Roster’s Fringes
abstract: After a week of career uncertainty, Jets defensive tackle Marcus Dixon said “the business sometimes gets you.”
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Last Tuesday, four days after he thought he made the Jets’ roster — and three days after the team cut him to make room for another defensive tackle — Marcus Dixon was at his home in Morristown, N.J., when his phone rang.

headline: Searching for a Speed Limit in High-Frequency Trading
abstract: From their small brokerage firm, two men have led the fight against the surge of computer-driven, high-frequency trading on Wall Street.

abstract: Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, are to appear on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” Representative Paul D. Ryan will speak for the Republican ticket on CBS’s “Face the Nation” and ABC’s “This Week.”
lead_paragraph: With the conventions in the rearview mirror, the general election is off and running. The Romney campaign is wasting no time, branching out from the nominee’s almost exclusive appearances on “Fox News Sunday” to date by scheduling Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, for an interview with NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Venice Film Festival: ‘Pieta’ and ‘The Master’ Come Up Winners
abstract: At the Venice Film Festival, the divisive film “Pieta,” which one Catholic organization considers blasphemous, won the top prize, while the lead actors and director of “The Master” also took home awards.
lead_paragraph: Fittingly for a festival where about half the titles in the official competition had religious themes, the 69th Venice Film Festival awarded its top prize, the Golden Lion, to “Pieta,” a mother-and-son drama with a sadistic streak from the prolific Korean director Kim Ki-duk. The film sharply divided critics — as do most of Mr. Kim’s confrontational movies — but it was deemed the best of the 18 competitors by a jury led by the filmmaker Michael Mann. Other members of the jury included the actress Samantha Morton, the filmmakers Matteo Garrone and Pablo Trapero and the artist Marina Abramovic.

headline: Game Maker Without a Rule Book
keywords: ['Software', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Wearable Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Headphones and Headsets']

lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Wash.

headline: Envoy for the Game
abstract: Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, made a rare visit last month to the United States, where he taught chess classes and participated in a simultaneous exhibition against 20 players.
lead_paragraph: Viswanathan Anand, the world champion, is a natural ambassador for chess. He has promoted the game all over Europe and has fostered programs in many schools across his native India.

headline: Penn State Hits Road, Only to Stumble
abstract: Virginia’s Michael Rocco found tight end Jake McGee for a 6-yard touchdown with 1 minute 28 seconds remaining, and Penn State’s Sam Ficken missed a 42-yard field goal as time expired.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The Penn State football team, dressed all in white, sprinted out of the visitor’s tunnel veiled by a plume of silvery smoke.
