headline: Young Talent Gives Mariners Hope for a Revival
abstract: Seattle is heading for its third consecutive last-place finish, but it has a solid foundation.
lead_paragraph: Nothing has ever come easily for the Seattle Mariners. Even in their glory years, when they had Ken Griffey Jr., Randy Johnson and Alex Rodriguez in their primes, the Mariners could not win a pennant. When all three left and the Mariners won 116 regular-season games, they still lost in the American League playoffs.

headline: Gabriel Vahanian, Professor, Dies at 85; Was Linked to ‘Death of God’ Movement
abstract: Mr. Vahanian’s 1961 social critique, “The Death of God: The Culture of Our Post-Christian Era,” gave a name to a seemingly atheistic but widely misunderstood theological movement.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Vahanian, a theologian whose 1961 social critique, “The Death of God: The Culture of Our Post-Christian Era,” gave a name to a seemingly atheistic but widely misunderstood theological movement, died on Aug. 30 at his home in Strasbourg, France. He was 85.

headline: Panthers Make Best of Hitch in Preparations for Their Campaign
abstract: The Carolina Panthers went to Florida to prepare for their N.F.L. season opener at Tampa Bay because President Obama was supposed to speak at their stadium during the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Carolina Panthers abandoned Bank of America Stadium last week after the chain-link fences went up and security personnel moved in. The stadium was preparing for what was supposed to be President Obama’s acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night.

headline: Circling the Job Listings
abstract: A job search by Kevin G. Der.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — This was a cute idea. I liked the way the job qualifications matched each successive listing, so that while a BASEBALL PLAYER might need to “wear gloves in the field,” so would an ARCHAEOLOGIST, and that ARCHAEOLOGIST would also need to be “experienced in surveying for sites,” as would an ONLINE MARKETER.

headline: Physical Therapists Turn to Wii Golf
keywords: ['Golf', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Wii (Video Game System)', 'Physical Therapy', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: Rehabilitation centers have added Nintendo’s Wii golf game as a tool in therapy sessions to assist patients with motion and coordination skills and also keep them motivated.
lead_paragraph: In the world of health care, Nintendo Wii golf is more than a high-tech toy. The video game has become a tool in physical, occupational and neurological rehabilitation.

headline: Max Bygraves, Jovial British Entertainer, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Bygraves’s easy singing and humor — a signature phrase was “I wanna tell you a story” — led to a long career of radio and stage shows, music and films.
lead_paragraph: Max Bygraves, whose smart-alecky humor, Cockney charm and myriad renditions of easy-listening hits made him a British show-business institution, died on Aug. 31 in Queensland, Australia. He was 89.

headline: A Big Default Problem, but How Big?
abstract: There appears to be no true count of how many people who borrowed to attend school are in default or having trouble paying back their loans.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Education plans to release its official default rate in the next few weeks. Prepare to be underwhelmed.

headline: Bad Student Debt Stubbornly High as Collection Efforts Surge
abstract: The amount of student loans that are delinquent has remained constant or increased at a time when delinquencies on mortgages and other types of consumer credit have declined.
lead_paragraph: The amount of student loans that are delinquent has remained constant or increased at a time when delinquencies on mortgages and other types of consumer credit have declined.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Constance Jablonski at Helmut Lang
abstract: Constance Jablonski transforms with makeup by Hannah Murray and hair by Paul Hanlon.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Constance Jablonski before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Hannah Murray and hair by Paul Hanlon.

headline: Debt Collectors Cashing In on Student Loans
keywords: ['Series', 'Credit and Debt', 'Student Loans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Collection Agencies', 'United States Economy', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: In 2011 the Department of Education paid $1.4 billion to collection agencies to find defaulters, a group that includes nearly one in six borrowers with a balance.
lead_paragraph: At a protest last year at New York University, students called attention to their mounting debt by wearing T-shirts with the amount they owed scribbled across the front — $90,000, $75,000, $20,000.

headline: Rescued by Music, Happy to Mail Out His Own CDs
abstract: Ryan Bingham has moved on from the hardships of his Texas years and is releasing a new album, “Tomorrowland,” this time on his own label.
lead_paragraph: Just two years ago, “Junky Star,” the album by Ryan Bingham & the Dead Horses, was released by the celebrated Nashville label Lost Highway Records. It was the most commercially successful album of Mr. Bingham’s career, reaching No. 2 on the Billboard country charts. But on Sept. 18, when he releases its follow-up, “Tomorrowland,” the record will not appear on Lost Highway or any other major label. It will be put out by his own label, Axster Bingham Records, which has  no track record and no other artists on its roster.

headline: Martin Continues to Find His Groove
abstract: Yankees catcher Russell Martin has six runs batted in in his last three games.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Russell Martin said he had not made any drastic changes to his swing of late and had not gotten over any serious injury to help explain his recent offensive productivity. In fact, he has been playing through a nagging neck strain that has limited his mobility, especially turning his head to the right.

headline: In School Finance Tangle, Wealth Doesn’t Necessarily Mean More
abstract: For public schools, which get half their money from property taxes, some districts get to keep sudden riches, but others don’t.
lead_paragraph: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Turkey’s Female Athletes, Like Women Nationwide, Reap Rewards
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Track and Field', 'Olympic Games (2012)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The success of the runners Asli Cakir Alptekin and Gamze Bulut at the London Games has brought an outpouring of support at home in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: BODRUM, Turkey — The gifts started pouring in for Asli Cakir Alptekin almost as soon as she sprinted across the finish line at London’s Olympic Stadium on Aug. 10, becoming Turkey’s first female track and field gold medalist.

headline: Program Gives Migrant Students Extra Help
abstract: The federal College Assistance Migrant Program, or CAMP, helps young people from migrant-worker families obtain a higher education, and St. Edward’s University has been involved from the beginning.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen-year-old Alfonso Lucio remembers the sun beating down on the back of his neck as he toiled in asparagus fields in Michigan, something he began doing at age 12. His cousin Jazmine Hernandez, who is the same age and also came from a family of migrant farm workers, was often at his side.

headline: Considering Death Row for Organs
abstract: Allowing executed prisoners to be organ donors could make transplants available to many Texans on the waiting lists, but the prospect is fraught with moral, ethical and medical challenges.
lead_paragraph: Before Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon established a moratorium on his state’s death penalty last year, Christian Longo, a death row inmate, started a campaign to allow the condemned to donate their organs.

headline: Afghans Wary in Push for Mineral Riches
abstract: Afghanistan’s estimated $1 trillion in untapped mineral resources seems imperiled by corruption and violence.
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan’s estimated $1 trillion in untapped mineral resources seems imperiled by corruption and violence.

headline: Potential for a Mining Boom Splits Factions in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: With a trillion-dollar cache of oil, gold and other resources underground, hopes of self-sufficiency in Afghanistan are tempered by worries about corruption and security.
lead_paragraph: KALU VALLEY, Afghanistan — If there is a road to a happy ending in Afghanistan, much of the path may run underground: in the trillion-dollar reservoir of natural resources — oil, gold, iron ore, copper, lithium and other minerals — that has brought hopes of a more self-sufficient country, if only the wealth can be wrested from blood-soaked soil.

headline: Sy J. Schulman, Planner for New York City Parks, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Schulman, a former mayor of White Plains, was a New York City parks official who helped ease residents’ opposition to a sewage plant in Harlem by creating Riverbank State Park.
lead_paragraph: Sy J. Schulman, who smoothed the way for a controversial sewage plant in Harlem by offering state financing for a park with playgrounds and ball fields atop the structure, now known as the popular Riverbank State Park, died on Sept. 1 at his home in White Plains, where he once served as mayor. He was 86.

headline: Obama Makes Birth Certificate Joke
abstract: Introduced to a boy born in Hawaii, President Obama flashed the shaka sign and jokingly asked the child for his birth certificate.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Birthers, you’re not going to like this one.

headline: Mow Yard. Drop Off Kids. Take a Drive on Mars.
abstract: As one member of the team that operates the remote rover Curiosity at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory put it, “Last night I drove on Mars, today I mowed the lawn — it’s completely surreal.”
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Matt Heverly, 36, started a recent workday as any young father might: up at 5:30, gulping coffee, fixing a bottle for the baby. He threw on jeans and a T-shirt and drove his two sons to day care. He stopped to get the brakes on his Toyota checked and swung by the bank.

headline: Yanks Eye Pettitte’s Return
abstract: Andy Pettitte, recovering from a broken bone in his leg, felt strong after throwing three simulated innings Saturday and hopes to face the Blue Jays in a three-game series that starts Wednesday in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — As the Yankees head into the final weeks of the season, engaged in a tight race for the American League East title with the Baltimore Orioles and the Tampa Bay Rays, they could be adding one of the most game-tested pitchers in baseball to their rotation for the final two weeks.

headline: Super Saturday Skies: Cloudy, Partly Happy
abstract: Andy Murray defeated Tomas Berdych in four sets, but severe weather conditions caused the day’s other two big matches — the second men’s semifinal and the women’s final — to be postponed.
lead_paragraph: On Super Saturday at the United States Open, weather dominated instead of Serena Williams. This included torrential downpours, wind gusts so powerful they picked up chairs, a postponed women’s final, a postponed men’s semifinal and even an evacuation for an impending tornado.

headline: Townsend Wins Doubles Title
abstract: Taylor Townsend won her third Grand Slam doubles title of the year and kept answering questions about her relationship with the U.S.T.A.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Townsend, 16, of Boca Raton, Fla., won her third junior Grand Slam doubles title of the year on Saturday, claiming the United States Open title with Gabrielle Andrews, 15, of Pomona, Calif. They scored a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Belinda Bencic of Switzerland and Petra Uberalova of Slovakia.

headline: A Rave at an Alexander Wang Show

lead_paragraph: Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo has been a consistent supporter of legalizing same-sex marriage. In 2011, he filmed his own video backing this November’s ballot initiative in Maryland and posted it on YouTube, and he recently donated Ravens tickets to a Marylanders for Marriage Equality fund-raiser.

headline: Romney to Appear on ‘Meet the Press’
abstract: In an interview on “Meet the Press” to be aired on Sunday morning, Mitt Romney praised former President Bill Clinton’s speech at the Democratic National Convention and criticized President Obama over defense cuts.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney, in an appearance on “Meet the Press” to be aired on Sunday morning, praised former President Bill Clinton’s speech at the Democratic National Convention, suggesting that his performance outshone President Obama’s speech accepting his party’s renomination. He also criticized Mr. Obama and Congressional Republicans for agreeing to automatic cuts in defense spending as a way to force a deal on deficit reduction, in a process called sequestration.

headline: Yanks Miss a Chance to Distance Themselves

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Mark Teixeira, his calf aching and anger boiling, pulled up on his knees and fired his helmet into the dirt. The first-base umpire, Jerry Meals, had just made an incorrect call, according to both the naked eye and television replays, and instead of the Yankees completing a comeback with Chris Dickerson crossing the plate to tie the score, the game was over.

headline: L.S.U. Crushes Washington Without Having to Strain

headline: In Toronto, Moviegoers Waiting to See ‘The Master’ Ask What It’s About
abstract: At the Toronto International Film Festival, a public screening of “The Master” proved a puzzle to moviegoers waiting to get in, even as one of its stars, Philip Seymour Hoffman, scoffed at the notion that it was about Scientology.
lead_paragraph: 8:39 a.m. | Updated  TORONTO — What is it with all the talk of time travel up here? “Looper” and “Cloud Atlas,” both introduced at the Toronto International Film Festival in the last few days, are loaded with migrating souls or leaps across the years. And Paul Thomas Anderson used the phrase “time travel” at least three times as he described his movie, “The Master,” at a press conference here on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Taliban Rages Over U.S. Decision on Terrorist Group
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: When the United States last week declared the Haqqani network in Afghanistan to be a terrorist organization, the Taliban’s reaction was angry, swift and deadly. Noting the close ties between the Haqqanis and Pakistan’s main spy agency, some analysts saw a possibility that Pakistan itself might some day be declared a state sponsor of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Washington has formally branded the Haqqani network a foreign terrorist organization for its attacks against American and NATO forces and for its role in the Taliban superstructure in Afghanistan. The Taliban’s response? Angry, swift and deadly.

headline: The ‘Control Freaks’ Behind the Wheel
abstract: Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button were the fastest drivers during qualifying on Saturday for the Italian Grand Prix. The relatively flat course at Monza, unlike the wet, hilly and sometimes scary track at Spa last week, is the fastest of the season.
lead_paragraph: MONZA, Italy — For the third time this season the two McLaren Mercedes drivers qualified first and second on the grid — Lewis Hamilton edging out his teammate, Jenson Button, for pole position at the Italian Grand Prix. The two drivers are certainly on a roll, as Hamilton won the Hungarian Grand Prix at the end of July before the summer break, and Button won the Belgian Grand Prix last weekend, the first event after racing resumed.

headline: Tim Tebow Plays Football Today
abstract: The endless summer of Tim Tebow speculation on ESPN and elsewhere is over. So how’d you hold up?
lead_paragraph: “I think you can never have too much Tebow.” — Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, in August.

headline: On Being Nothing
abstract: I know that the world only tramples me as a street crowd does an earthworm — not out of malice or stupidity, but because no one sees it.

headline: This Week This Week
abstract: Head, talking.
lead_paragraph: Actually today. My head will be talking on Stephanopoulos again; I understand that we’ll be discussing Honey Boo Boo, and maybe also economics and politics.

headline: Another Way to Take Your iPad Underwater
abstract: LifeProof, which claims to make the thinnest waterproof iPhone case made, has made a waterproof iPad case without a plastic membrane to cover the screen. But it is a struggle to get the case on.
lead_paragraph: LifeProof, which claims to make the thinnest waterproof iPhone case, has gone one step further for its iPad case by doing away with the plastic membrane that goes over the screen.

headline: Arms And The Mitt
abstract: Weaponized Keynesianism rides again.
lead_paragraph: A week ago I noted that Mitt Romney’s convention speech included a sudden lurch into weaponized Keynesianism, the doctrine that government spending destroys jobs unless it’s spending on defense contractors, in which case it’s the lifeblood of the economy.

headline: Construction and Real Estate Hinder China’s Growth
abstract: Investment in new buildings and other fixed assets, once a mainstay of the nation’s economy, grew at the second-lowest pace since 2002.
lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — With more than 100 tall cranes on the skyline, this metropolis in western China looks vibrant at first glance despite the country’s sharp economic slowdown.

headline: Europe Plan Faces Threat in Germany
abstract: On Wednesday, the work of the European Central Bank could be undone in a stroke by judges in Germany, who have the power to block the country from contributing to the European rescue fund.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — With a few choice words last week, the European Central Bank and its president, Mario Draghi, managed to tame bond markets and inspire a market rally. But the coming week may reveal whether the rescue plan for Spain and Italy was a turning point in the euro zone crisis or just a short-lived spell of relief.

headline: Death Sentence for a Top Iraqi Leader in a Day of Bloodshed
abstract: Tariq al-Hashimi, the Iraqi vice president accused of commanding sectarian death squads, was sentenced hours after a wave of attacks that claimed at least 100 lives.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A vice president of Iraq, a prominent Sunni Muslim, was convicted of murder and sentenced to death on Sunday in a trial conducted in absentia. The verdict coincided with a wave of bombings and insurgent attacks that claimed at least 100 lives, making Sunday one of the bloodiest days in Iraq since American troops withdrew last year.

headline: Off Court, Tennis Stars Are Putting Pressure on the Grand Slams
abstract: The ATP Player Council, with Roger Federer as its president, is pushing for more prize money at Grand Slam tournaments in an attempt to address an earning gap in a top-heavy sport.
lead_paragraph: There were rain delays and lost sessions at the United States Open, pushed again to a Monday men’s final. There was a tornado warning and a chair blown onto the court in the midst of the men’s semifinal between Tomas Berdych and Andy Murray, the eventual champion.

headline: Should Parents Impose a Dress Code?
abstract: If the school hasn’t imposed a limit on bra tops or T-shirts with dubious slogans, should parents?
lead_paragraph: In 2009-10, about 57 percent of public school principals reported that their schools enforced a dress code. The codes themselves vary; some rules are intended to promote modesty (skirts and shorts must extend beyond fingertips; there can be no spaghetti straps) and others to encourage a respectful learning environment (no jeans; no screen prints or text on shirts).

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Top magazine and long-form articles this week.
lead_paragraph: Politics and political leaders dominated the magazine covers this week. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh found himself at the center of many stories that highlighted his government’s predicament and his own loss of credibility. Outlook’s cover carried the words “King is Singed,” a play on the title of a popular Indian movie. “Manmohan Singh’s integrity was the Congress’s USP in 2009,” it read. “By making the P.M. the target of the coal scam, the BJP has turned the middle-class mascot into an electoral liability ahead of 2014,” when the country will hold its next national elections.

headline: Romney Has Conciliatory Remarks on Obama and Health Overhaul
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Republican National Convention', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mitt Romney says there are parts of President Obama’s health care reform that he likes.
lead_paragraph: 3:09 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney said Sunday that he would retain elements of President Obama’s health care overhaul, blamed Republicans as much as Democrats for the “mistake” of agreeing to automatic cuts in military spending to avoid a fiscal crisis and acknowledged that Mr. Obama’s national security strategy has made America in “some ways safer.”

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Alexander Wang
abstract: A clean, matte complexion and ponytail with a taped center-part complemented the minimalist nature of Alexander Wang’s Spring 2013 collection.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Modern MinimalismThe Makeup: The makeup artist Diane Kendal opted for a clean, matte complexion to complement the minimalist nature of Alexander Wang’s Spring 2013 collection. Skin was first primed with NarsSkin Optimal Brightening Concentrate, then coated with the brand’s Pure Radiant Tinted Moisturizer SPF 30/PA+++. Next, using a contoured blush brush (in place of the classic, dome-shaped powder brush), Kendal applied two shades of Nars Sheer Glow Powder Foundation — a lighter one on the outside of the face and a darker one across the cheeks — to perfect. (At press time, Kendal was not at liberty to disclose why, but a selection of models were given a more futuristic finish using Nars Light Reflecting Loose Setting Powder and Albatross Highlighting Blush on the high points of their cheeks, with some also sporting bleached or whited-out brows.) Eyes were contoured using Cayenne eyeshadow, while the same product in Blondie (light) or Bali (dark) were used to fill in the brows. Lashes were left bare.The Hair: “Ponytails are always very prevalent in New York,” says the stylist Guido Palau. “Half my career has been based on trying to reinvent it.” For Wang’s presentation, Palau used a variation on a look he’d originally conceived in the early ’90s: the taped center-part. To modernize the look, the stylist opted for dual texture — a sleek top with movement in the back — and low positioning. To achieve this, the top of the head (to behind the ears) was first dampened, then parted and treated with Redken Satinwear 02 Ultimate Blow-Dry Lotion before being blown straight. Once secured into a ponytail, the ends were sectioned and curled.

headline: Government Employment
abstract: Way down.
lead_paragraph: During today’s round table on ABC, Rand Paul seemed shocked at my claim that government employment is down under Obama. Of course, it is. But maybe he’s thinking of the fact that since govt employment rose under Bush, we’re still at higher absolute levels than we were a decade ago.

abstract: Gretchen Reynolds, the Phys Ed columnist, talks about the latest research and a promising exercise to combat the pain of tennis elbow.
lead_paragraph: Gretchen Reynolds, the Phys Ed columnist, talks about the latest research and a promising exercise to combat the pain of tennis elbow.

headline: Djokovic Defeats Ferrer to Advance to Final
abstract: The Times will live blog the men’s semifinal match between David Ferrer and Novak Djokovic at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Defending champion Novak Djokovic of Serbia has advanced to his third consecutive United States Open final with a 2-6, 6-1, 6-4, 6-2 win over David Ferrer of Spain. Djokovic, the No. 2 seed, will play No. 3 Andy Murray of Great Britain in the Monday final, which will begin at 4 p.m. E.S.T.

lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever flown Virgin America, you will have seen the cartoonlike safety video that plays before the flight takes off.

headline: A Slow Weekend at the Box Office
abstract: The No. 1 movie at North American theaters was a holdover: “The Possession” (Lionsgate) took in an estimated $9.5 million, for a two-week total of about $33.3 million.
lead_paragraph: The fall movie season got under way, just barely, with what may turn out to be one of the least-attended weekends at cinemas in years. The only new release of note was “The Words” (CBS Films), a poorly reviewed drama about a plagiarizing novelist. It placed third, taking in about $5 million; CBS paid $2 million for domestic distribution rights. The No. 1 movie was a holdover: “The Possession” (Lionsgate) took in an estimated $9.5 million, for a two-week total of about $33.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. The Weinstein Company’s “Lawless” was second, selling about $6 million in tickets, for a two-week total of $23.5 million. In its fourth weekend “The Expendables 2” (Lionsgate) placed fourth, grossing about $4.8 million and lifting its total to $75.4 million. “The Bourne Legacy” (Universal Pictures) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4 million, for a five-week total of $103.7 million. Deadline.com summed up the weak box-office results this way: “The weekend of Sept. 5, 2008, was the last time no films grossed over $10 million. Ouch!”

headline: A Sunny Sunday for Victoria Beckham
abstract: The Sunday weather brought a break in the humidity for New Yorkers, and the first fashion show of the day, that of Victoria Beckham, also spelled relief.
lead_paragraph: The Sunday weather brought a break in the humidity for New Yorkers, and the first fashion show of the day, that of Victoria Beckham, also spelled relief. It was a pleasant surprise to see the opening looks of the collection actually included a few loosely fitted blouses and skirts, rather than the usual skintight dresses that can look rather constricting. (Those came later.)

headline: A Sense of Waiting for Godot for Texas Democrats
abstract: Mitt Romney will win Texas this year. Of that,there is no doubt. And Democrats will be left with another series of what-ifs.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Texas. FiveThirtyEight spoke with James R. Henson, the director of the Texas Politics Project at the University of Texas at Austin; Robert D. Miller, the chairman of the Public Law Group at Locke Lord L.L.P.; and Steve H. Murdock, a professor in the department of sociology at Rice University in Houston.

headline: Cancer Study Points to Tighter Pairing of Drugs and Patients
abstract: Research on a common lung cancer could foretell a type of treatment in which drugs — many of which are in the pipeline already — are chosen to match the genetic mutation in each patient.
lead_paragraph: The first large and comprehensive study of the genetics of a common lung cancer has found that more than half the tumors from that cancer have mutations that might be treated by new drugs that are already in the pipeline or that could be easily developed.

headline: Spotlight on Safety for Shows Outdoors
abstract: After numerous fatal accidents when outdoor concert stages collapsed, an effort to establish industrywide safety standards is gaining traction.
lead_paragraph: Jim Digby, the tour manager for Linkin Park, knows better than most how dangerous a rock ’n’ roll show can be. In 1983 he was a 19-year-old technical director at a new nightclub outside Philadelphia when a piece of equipment he was operating came off a faulty overhead track, plummeted toward the floor and killed a young woman standing just a few feet from him.

headline: Syria Criticizes France for Supporting Rebels, as Fears Grow of Islamist Infiltration
abstract: Days after the French government said that it would provide assistance directly to Syrian rebels, Syria accused France of undermining the new United Nations envoy.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Syrian government accused France of “schizophrenia” on Sunday for pledging to support a peaceful resolution to the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad and simultaneously aiding the armed groups driving the insurrection. At the same time, a French doctor returning from a rebel-controlled hospital raised new alarms about the presence of foreign Islamist militants in Syria, stoking fears that have discouraged the West from more forceful support for the rebels.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican nominee for vice president, on Sunday defended his decision to support automatic cuts in defense spending as a way to force a deal on reducing the deficit, an approach that was sharply criticized by his running mate, Mitt Romney.

abstract: But I still can’t get no satisfaction.

headline: Weather Is Nice; Djokovic Is Fierce
abstract: When their semifinal match was postponed Saturday because of weather, David Ferrer led, 5-2, in the first set. When it resumed Sunday, Novak Djokovic battered Ferrer throughout.
lead_paragraph: At the end of his United States Open semifinal, Novak Djokovic hardly celebrated. He let out a small scream, pumped a quick fist and skipped across the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Altuzarra
abstract: The makeup was minimal and hair was set in a strict, equestrian-inspired bow-like chignon to offset the designer’s opulent collection.
lead_paragraph: The Look: French (With a) TwistThe Makeup: “Imagine Catherine Deneuve meets Monsieur Yves Saint Laurent,” says the makeup artist Tom Pecheux. “The girl is perfectly done, but in a very simple way.” M.A.C. Face and Body Foundation was applied to even skin tone and conceal imperfections, followed by the brand’s Sculpting Powder Pro in Definitive (as needed, to contour). The eyes were dressed first with shadows from the M.A.C. Archie’s Collection Spoiled Rich palette in Ron Ron Ron (using the #266 brush),then finished with a line of Technakohl Liner in Auto-de-Blu — drawn to the curve of the lid, with no extension — and a swipe of Haute & Naughty Lash mascara.

headline: Congress Comes Back to a Face-Off With Angry Farmers
keywords: ['Farm Bill (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Lawmakers, fresh off their parties’ conventions, appear to favor action this fall on bills that emphasize their political agendas over actual lawmaking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Congress returns to business this week, it will be met not by the Code Pink antiwar protesters or the Tea Party supporters who often gathered near the Capitol last year. Instead, farmers will be out in force, rallying for a bill that lawmakers failed to pass before they recessed five weeks ago.

headline: Why Weather Forecasters Are Role Models
abstract: An except from Nate Silver’s forthcoming book, “The Signal and the Noise,” takes a comprehensive look at prediction across 13 fields, ranging from sports betting to earthquake forecasting and asks: What makes predictions succeed or fail?
lead_paragraph: An excerpt from my forthcoming book, “The Signal and the Noise,” was published this week in The New York Times Magazine. You can find an online version of the excerpt here.

headline: Michael Bastian: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Envelope, Please: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf
abstract: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, South Africa, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, South Africa, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.

headline: Williams Beats Azarenka for U.S. Open Title
abstract: The Times will live blog the women’s final between Serena Williams and Victoria Azarenka at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams rallied back from the brink of defeat to win the women’s singles championship of the 2012 United States Open with a 6-2, 2-6, 7-5 victory over Victoria Azarenka. It was her fourth Open title and 15th Grand Slam title overall.

headline: Take These Bawdy Ditties as Balms for Melancholy
abstract: Musica Nuova’s fast-paced program, “Men, Maids and Mischief: Bawdy English Songs,” included drinking songs and tales by Purcell, Weelkes, Eccles and others.
lead_paragraph: The classical-music club scene in New York grows ever livelier. Though “grows” may seem an odd word applied to the tiny performance space at Jimmy’s No. 43, a basement bar and restaurant in the East Village. Musica Nuova, a spunky Boston-born early-music ensemble, opened its second New York season at Jimmy’s on Thursday evening with a fast-paced, 50-minute program, “Men, Maids and Mischief: Bawdy English Songs,” and delivered the goods (bads?) handsomely.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Band of Outsiders
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: DKNY: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Obama Gets a Lift on the Trail
abstract: An Republican Obama supporter throws his muscle around with the president.
lead_paragraph: FORT PIERCE, Fla. — Scott Van Duzer, pizza parlor owner and blood donator, can bench press 350 pounds. So he had no trouble with the 6-foot-1, 176-pound, skinny President Obama.

headline: Frayed Man of Action With a Head for Figures
abstract: “A Wanted Man” is Lee Child’s 17th Jack Reacher novel and the last to be published before Reacher goes Hollywood with a big Christmas movie.
lead_paragraph: “A Wanted Man” is Lee Child’s 17th Jack Reacher novel and the last to be published before Reacher goes Hollywood with “Jack Reacher,” a big Christmas movie based on book No. 9, “One Shot,” and starring — can’t say it ain’t so, because it is — Tom Cruise. Mr. Cruise seems such a wrong choice to play this jumbo vigilante that this is a good moment to contemplate the essential Reacher: not just what he looks like but also what he really is.

headline: With a Composer as Your Umbrella
abstract: The tenor Damien Top and the pianist Linda Hall performed works by Massenet as part of the New York Chamber Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: The weather on Saturday was seething and unsettled. Tornadoes even touched down in Queens and Brooklyn.

headline: For Putin, a Flight of Fancy at a Summit Meeting’s Close
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia hit back at political opponents who mocked his latest stunt: flying a motorized glider to help lead endangered cranes from Siberia south.
lead_paragraph: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia — At times, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia seemed to be limping and in pain this weekend, but as the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting wrapped up here on Sunday, the Russian leader showed some of his trademark swagger, hitting back at political opponents who mocked his latest stunt: flying a motorized glider to help lead endangered cranes from Siberia on their migration south.

headline: Before ‘Chickadee’ Fame, Fields Had Canary Trouble
abstract: One night in 1928, when he was topping the bill at the Earl Carroll Theater on Seventh Avenue, W.C. Fields was hauled before a judge after his show and charged with torturing a canary.
lead_paragraph: The scene unfolded like something out of one of W.C. Fields’ movies. A quick-handed, wisecracking entertainer wowed a packed house, only to find himself grabbed by two police officers after the show, paraded before the flashbulbs, and hauled before a judge, where he was charged with torturing a canary.

headline: Any Other Questions?
abstract: The Jets’ demolition of the Bills was not as close as the score indicated, amounting to an emphatic I-told-you-so from Coach Rex Ryan.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A miserable winter for the Jets bled into an optimistic spring, which gave way to a summer bursting with promise and possibility — at least from their perspective. For months, they were besieged with questions about the potential for a quarterback controversy, then dismissed them with a steely glance. They absorbed criticism for a sputtering offense, for curious personnel decisions — an unproven right tackle, an inexperienced receiving corps, a sociocultural phenomenon as Mark Sanchez’s backup — for being equal parts carnival attraction and football team.

headline: Crawford, Unseeded, Wins Junior Girls Title
abstract: Samantha Crawford of Atlanta, who was not seeded, defeated Anett Kontaveit of Estonia to win the junior girls championship on Sunday at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Unseeded Samantha Crawford of Atlanta won the 2012 United States Open Junior Girls’ Championship on Sunday with a 7-5, 6-3 victory over Anett Kontaveit of Estonia.

headline: Skaist-Taylor: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Innovation in Journalism Goes Begging for Support
keywords: ['Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Despite receiving positive press attention, Homicide Watch, the Web site that tracked every murder in Washington D.C., is on hiatus and seeking funds to continue.
lead_paragraph: Journalism has a shortage of many things: capital, advertisers and, in some instances, readers. But certainly its most precious commodity is innovation.

headline: Third Annual Charity Pro-Am for BackStoppers
abstract: A pro-am bridge event at Bridge Haven in Hazelwood, Mo., raised almost $5,000 for BackStoppers, a nonprofit organization that gives money to the families of police officers, firefighters and emergency medical personnel who have been killed in the line of duty.
lead_paragraph: The BackStoppers, a nonprofit organization in St. Louis, gives money to the families of police officers, firefighters and emergency medical personnel who have been killed in the line of duty. A pro-am bridge event at Bridge Haven in Hazelwood, Mo., on Aug. 26 raised almost $5,000 for BackStoppers. The winners, John Samsel and Alan Lemley, scored very well in the diagramed deal.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Victoria Beckham
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.

headline: Glamour Campaign Tries to Claim a Generation
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Glamour magazine is moving forward with a campaign, called “Generation Glamour,” that presents a modern take on the youthful woman in an attempt to reach so-called millennials.
lead_paragraph: FOR almost three decades, Hearst attracted younger readers, and the advertisers who crave them, to Cosmopolitan magazine with a campaign carrying the theme “I guess you could say I’m That Cosmopolitan Girl.” Now, a principal Cosmo competitor, Glamour, is seeking to reach the readers and advertisers of 2012 and beyond with a campaign that presents a contemporary take on the youthful woman.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
abstract: Carine Roitfeld’s news “book” and Alexander Wang’s rap-themed rave.
lead_paragraph: Carine Roitfeld’s news “book” and Alexander Wang’s rap-themed rave.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Jones and Braves Depart With a Sweep
abstract: Continuing a run of futility in their home ballpark, the Mets fell to the Braves in what was probably Chipper Jones’s last game in Queens.
lead_paragraph: The fans in Queens have developed a complicated relationship with Chipper Jones of the Atlanta Braves, their enduring and frequent tormentor, who this year announced he would retire at the end of the season. As evidence, consider their response to him Sunday afternoon, when he entered as a pinch-hitter in the ninth inning of a tied game.

headline: Transcending Real Sound in Real Time With the Unexpected
abstract: The guitarist Rafiq Bhatia played instrumental music that owes a debt to jazz but departs in countless ways from the traditions of the genre.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you notice about the young guitarist Rafiq Bhatia’s music is its hunger to combine, though it never sounds like established tradition A plus established tradition B. He’s merging more volatile tendencies — propositions, not facts — and he’s in a hurry.

headline: Spotlighting Prizewinning Composers
abstract: Twelve in 12, part of Trinity Wall Street’s long-running series of free, hourlong programs at 1 p.m., offers works by the 12 recent winners of the Pulitzer Prize for music.
lead_paragraph: The music program of Trinity Wall Street, which was largely suspended and seemed in jeopardy in the spring as the church’s vestry was reassessing its costs and purposes, has come roaring back for the new season, more varied than ever. Under the direction of Julian Wachner the program has become a hotbed of early music, and Mr. Wachner has said that among other innovations he plans to do the same for contemporary music, giving greater scope to Trinity’s instrumental ensemble Novus NY.

headline: On Facebook, Bullies ‘Like’ if You Hate
keywords: ['Bullies', 'Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: My little brother went to school on a Friday morning last June, and he heard that another boy had updated his Facebook status the previous night, asking his friends to “like” if they hated my brother. 57 fellow students gave that a Facebook “thumbs up.”
lead_paragraph: For the digitally native generation, self-worth is accrued in likes.

headline: The Sadness of a Wife Mistrusted
abstract: The kuttiyattam performer Kapila Venu of India played all the characters in a production of “The Abandonment of Sita,” sponsored by Asia Society and Sanskriti Center.
lead_paragraph: Rama is the hero of the ancient Indian epic the Ramayana, but heroes don’t always behave admirably.

headline: Treasury to Cut A.I.G. Stake Below 50%
abstract: The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it planned to sell an additional $18 billion worth of shares in the American International Group, drastically reducing the government’s stake in the bailed-out insurer.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it was planning its biggest sale of shares in the American International Group to date, making the federal government a minority shareholder in the bailed-out insurer for the first time since it took control of the company four years ago.

headline: Britain Exports Its Soul
abstract: Soul artists like Jessie Ware and AlunaGeorge manage to have an R&B sound that is British.
lead_paragraph: The desperate center of Jessie Ware’s debut album, “Devotion,” is “Taking In Water,” a languorous and arresting tragedy about punishing oneself so that someone less worthy might live. Over gaseous, melancholy synths Ms. Ware unfurls her tale heavily.

headline: Little Guy in the Garden
abstract: Andrea Carla Michaels is a very nice person. So why would she make a puzzle like this?
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — BACFill (formerly the Bay Area Crossword Tournament) was held on Saturday to benefit the Families of SMA, a support and fund-raising group dedicated to finding a cure for Spinal Muscular Atrophy. The Monday through Thursday New York Times puzzles that you will be doing this week were generously donated by Will Shortz.

headline: Victorian London, Hypocrisy and Filth Included
abstract: Encore’s “Crimson Petal and the White,” set in Victorian London, brings the novel to the screen.
lead_paragraph: The Victorian London on display in “The Crimson Petal and the White,” a four-hour mini-series beginning Monday on Encore, is not the one we’re accustomed to seeing on American television. Chamber pots, and the rear ends of those using them, figure prominently, as do blood, vomit, foul odors and the fully naked bodies of men and women who have not been to the gym in a long time, if ever.

headline: Travel Site Built on Wiki Ethos Now Bedevils Its Owner
abstract: Internet Brands, which bought Wikitravel in 2005 without securing copyright to the site’s travel reviews, is now in a legal battle with the Wikimedia Foundation over reproduction of its content.
lead_paragraph: LIVE by the wiki, perhaps die by the wiki.

headline: Queens Carwash’s Employees Are First in City to Join Union
abstract: The 21-to-5 vote by workers at Astoria Car Wash and Hi-Tek 10 Minute Lube Inc. is the first major victory in a six-month effort by organizers in New York City to reform the industry.
lead_paragraph: Workers at a carwash in Queens have overwhelmingly voted to join a union, organizers said Sunday, in the first major victory in a six-month effort in New York City to unionize workers in an industry the organizers say is rife with labor law violations.

headline: Errani and Vinci Win Another Slam Doubles Title
abstract: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci defeated Andrea Hlavakova and Lucie Hradecka to win the women’s doubles title at the United States Open on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Sara Errani and Roberta Vinci of Italy launched into a victory dance, tapping shoulders and leaping forward and back, after they won the final point that earned them the 2012 United States Open women’s doubles title Sunday.

headline: The Zombie That Ate Rand Paul’s Brain
abstract: Undead misinterpretations of the Census blip.
lead_paragraph: Aha. It seems that I was giving Rand Paul  more credit than he deserved. Think Progress has the video, and it’s clear that Paul was completely shocked at the notion that government employment had fallen under Obama, rather than soaring.

headline: Tracy Reese: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: With Offense on Track, Yanks Plow Through Orioles
abstract: Even as Mark Teixeira was lost again with an aggravated calf strain, the Yankees routed the Orioles to once again pushed Baltimore a game behind them in the A.L. East.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The mood in the Yankees’ clubhouse was decidedly more relaxed and cheerful Sunday than it was the night before, when loud, angry words rang out after a controversial loss. Thirteen runs and a breezy victory will do that.

headline: To Smuggle More Drugs, Traffickers Go Under the Sea
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Smuggling']
abstract: American authorities have discovered models of a new drug-ferrying submarine capable of traveling, unseen from the surface, from Ecuador to Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: KEY WEST, Fla. — For more than 24 hours last September, a Coast Guard helicopter and speedboat pursued drug traffickers and their contraband across the Caribbean Sea. Finally they caught up with the improbable vessel, the latest innovation in the decades-old drug war. It was a submarine.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Victoria Beckham
abstract: A sculpted look, and dual-textured hair, for Victoria Beckham’s Spring 2013 showcase.
lead_paragraph: The Look: The Sophisticate.

headline: Where Did the Free Spirits Go?
abstract: Early Fashion Week collections lack some of the free-spiritedness usually associated with newer designers.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t the heat or threat of my colleagues being sucked into a tornado. No, that didn’t annoy me. It was the soggy drama taking place in the name of daring new fashion: namely, Prabal Gurung and Alexander Wang.

headline: Documentary Takes a Business View of Street Drug Trade
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Movies']
abstract: “How to Make Money Selling Drugs,” a new documentary film, takes a businesslike look at the world of street drugs, offering professional advice to and assessing the prospects of low-level dealers.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Films that take an outsider’s view of business are routine at the Toronto International Film Festival. In 2010, for instance, financial corruption was in vogue, as “Inside Job,” “Client 9,” and “Casino Jack” all exposed the seamy underside of Wall Street and the lobbying business.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Consumer Price Index', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Governments reports will include the trade deficit for July and the Consumer Price Index for August.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include consumer credit for July (Monday); the trade deficit for July (Tuesday); import prices for August and wholesale trade for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the producer price index for August (Thursday); and retail sales for August, the Consumer Price Index for August, industrial production for August, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for September and business inventories for July (Friday).

headline: Thakoon: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The Daily Shoe | Derek Lam
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s shoe: an ivory-embossed crocodile slingback.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Google Struggles to Unseat Amazon as the Web’s Most Popular Mall
abstract: As it inches into e-commerce, Google is now charging retailers to appear on its site, a move it says will improve product listings.
lead_paragraph: Whether you are looking to buy a power tool or neon jeans online, chances are you start your search on Google or Amazon.com. But which one?

headline: DVF Gives Google Glasses a Spin on the Runway
abstract: Look there, in the front row of Diane von Furstenberg’s runway on Sunday afternoon. Isn’t that Oscar de la Renta? And then, wait a sec, Sergey Brin from Google?
lead_paragraph: Look there, in the front row of Diane von Furstenberg’s runway on Sunday afternoon. Isn’t that Oscar de la Renta? And Valentino? Ooh, and Bravo’s dapper Andy Cohen sitting with his bestie Sarah Jessica Parker? And Barry Diller, Ms. von Furstenberg’s husband was there, as usual. And then, wait a sec, Sergey Brin from Google?

headline: ‘Forgotten Neighborhood’ Underscores the Poverty of an Isolated Enclave
abstract: A United Nations report cites widespread shortages of food, water, electricity, jobs, hospital beds and classrooms amid an exploding population in an area of Gaza.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — In the Forgotten Neighborhood, houses have walls but no floors: people sit, eat and sleep on the sand.

headline: U.S. Puts Transfer of Detainees to Afghans on Hold
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: While American concerns halted one of the requirements for switching control of the Parwan prison, Afghanistan vowed to go on with a ceremony marking its takeover.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — One of the centerpieces of the hand-over of American control to Afghan authority encountered a last-minute unexpected obstacle on Sunday when the United States paused the transfer of the final couple of dozen Afghan detainees at the Parwan detention facility.

headline: William Moggridge, Designer and Laptop Pioneer, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Moggridge designed the first laptop, called the Grid Compass. Most recently, he was director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum.
lead_paragraph: Just after he had presciently opened a product design business in Silicon Valley in 1979, William Moggridge was hired by a start-up firm, Grid Systems, to design a new type of computer — one that could fit into a briefcase.

headline: What Keeps the Chinese Up at Night
abstract: In China, a spiritual hunger has taken hold even as physical hunger has receded.
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Amateur Mapmakers Redraw Boundaries, Working Online
abstract: The city does not codify neighborhood boundaries, but unsung arbiters are using sites like Google Maps and Wikipedia to draw lines between, say, Park Slope and Gowanus in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Reshaped and renamed by generations of developers and gentrifiers, the borders of New York City’s neighborhoods are often hazy at best. Yesterday’s Chinatown is today’s east TriBeCa; a resident of Bedford-Stuyvesant may, after some real estate alchemy, morph into a citizen of Clinton Hill.

headline: Cleaning Up Tornado Mess: Exhaustion Along With Relief
abstract: While the two tornadoes that hit Breezy Point, Queens, and Canarsie, Brooklyn, caused no serious injuries, property owners had plenty of debris to throw out.
lead_paragraph: As Charlene Kahn trudged up a flight of stairs outside her home in Canarsie, Brooklyn, on Sunday, with a pile of debris the size of a sedan in the driveway and, above her, a blue tarp where part of the roof used to be, she did not have much to say.

headline: Fashion Week Casting | Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: Behind the scenes at the casting for today’s Tommy Hilfiger show at 8 p.m. in New York.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Intersection: N.Y. Fashion Week Downtown
abstract: Ian Milan, a men’s wear enthusiast, confessed that he takes pictures of his New York Fashion Week outfits.
lead_paragraph: Ian Milan, a men’s wear enthusiast, confessed that he takes pictures of his New York Fashion Week outfits.

headline: Surprising Even Herself, Williams Rallies to Title
abstract: Fourth-ranked Serena Williams defeated No. 1 Victoria Azarenka of Belarus, 6-2, 2-6, 7-5, after a tense third set in the United States Open women’s final.
lead_paragraph: After a set, a fourth United States Open title for Serena Williams looked like a foregone conclusion as she ripped serves and ground strokes Sunday at Arthur Ashe with the same intimidating blend of power and precision that has defined her summer.

headline: Do-It-Yourself New York Geography
abstract: The Internet has drawn would-be cartographers into the argument over neighborhood borders in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Internet has drawn would-be cartographers into the argument over neighborhood borders in New York City.

headline: Accident Kills Police Officer Assisting Obama’s Motorcade
abstract: A Jupiter, Fla., police officer assisting President Obama’s motorcade was killed after the motorcycle he was driving was hit by a pickup truck.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH — A Jupiter, Fla., police officer assisting President Obama‘s motorcade was killed on Sunday after the motorcycle he was driving was hit by a pickup truck.

headline: Romney’s Tax Plan Leaves Key Variables Blank
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Mitt Romney has pledged to cut individual income tax rates for everyone, but he has provided few specifics, confounding analysts and leaving himself open to attack from Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If any single question can be said to dominate the presidential campaign, it is whether the conservative policies advocated by Mitt Romney would help or hurt the middle class. And no issue hits the heart of that question more than taxes.

headline: Attorney General and Comptroller Play Down Their Roles in Settlement
abstract: The offices of the attorney general and the comptroller received draft copies of the confidential settlement of sexual misconduct allegations against Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, but did not intervene.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In late May, a lawyer for the New York State Assembly sent a note to his colleagues in the attorney general’s and comptroller’s offices, soliciting their advice.

headline: Sanchez Shows There Is No Quarterback Debate
abstract: The Jets’ victory marked the official relaunch of Mark Sanchez, whose 266 yards and 3 touchdowns ended any contention that Tim Tebow will challenge him at quarterback.
lead_paragraph: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: On Campus, an Experiment to Save Local News
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Public Broadcasting', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Journalism Schools', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Mercer University is undertaking a $5.6 million project, which partners student work with news organizations in the area, in the hopes of reviving local journalism.
lead_paragraph: MACON, Ga. — From the rattling cicadas at twilight to the willow trees bending in the late summer heat, the lush campus of Mercer University seems like the last place to find one of the nation’s boldest journalism experiments.

headline: Fighting Off Biggest Names, McIlroy Again Tops the List
abstract: Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland had three birdies on the closing nine en route to a 20-under-par 268 to win the BMW Championship by two strokes over Phil Mickelson and Lee Westwood.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL, Ind. — As Phil Mickelson and Vijay Singh stalked their putts on the 18th green, Rory McIlroy stood outside the scoring trailer scrolling through his congratulatory messages. McIlroy, ranked No. 1 in the world, had secured his second title in two weeks and his third in his last four starts with a two-stroke victory in the BMW Championship. Among the first texts he retrieved on his smartphone was one from the tennis superstar Rafael Nadal, who wrote, “Well done.”

headline: Lawmakers Push to Increase White House Oversight of Financial Regulators
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Under a bill that could curb the influence of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the White House would receive explicit authority to influence the rule-making process at independent agencies.
lead_paragraph: Financial regulators may face a new obstacle in their efforts to police Wall Street.

headline: ‘Soda Ban Explained’
abstract: The filmmaker’s guide to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict the sale of big, sugary drinks.
lead_paragraph: I don’t drink much soda, I don’t buy Big Gulps, and my body mass index is right where it should be. Until the public hearing on July 24, I had largely ignored Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposed ban on large, sugary drinks because it would have no effect on my daily life. It was watching supporters of the ban struggle to articulate exactly what it would mean that motivated me to educate myself and ultimately make a movie about it. The proposal is best conveyed visually, not verbally.

headline: Soda Ban Explained
abstract: The filmmaker Casey Neistat presents a guide to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks in New York.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Casey Neistat presents a guide to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks in New York.

headline: Nuclear Mullahs
abstract: So what if Iran gets the bomb? It might be less risky than a pre-emptive war.
lead_paragraph: IRAN has returned to the front pages after a summer hiatus. Negotiations aimed at preventing the dreaded Persian Bomb have resumed their desultory course. Iran, although suffering from the international sanctions choreographed by the Obama administration, keeps adding new arrays of centrifuges while insisting the program is strictly nonmilitary. Israel is — or maybe isn’t — edging closer to a unilateral strike. The U.S., we learn from The Times’s reliable David Sanger, is considering more and bigger bouts of cybersabotage. Meanwhile, the mullahs are shipping arms to their embattled fellow despots in Syria.

headline: German Envoy Goes to Greece, Leaving Lectures Behind
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, has sent Hans-Joachim Fuchtel, a jovial, brass-band-loving Black Forester, to Greece to help mend frayed relations.
lead_paragraph: RHODES, Greece — To long-suffering Greeks, German officials embody the diktats from abroad that have deepened their country’s descent into insolvency and depression. Listening to Angela Merkel, Germany’s Iron Chancellor, her tough-talking finance minister or the uncompromising head of the Bundesbank, it often feels like a game of bad cop, worse cop, worst cop.

headline: Y-3: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The Roar of the Night
abstract: The ensemble of crickets on late summer nights sounds like the end of a season, and like the start of one, too.
lead_paragraph: In 1899, Dr. Robert Thaxter Edes, a Harvard graduate and Civil War veteran, noted that “the tree cricket does not say much in the daytime.” Dr. Edes was trying to calibrate the change in the pitch of a tree cricket’s note as the temperature changes. He offered a graph but not the actual pitches. F. H. Hall, writing in 1912, was more specific. The song is “a clear mellow whistle resembling the words treat, treat, treat, pitched about in C, two octaves above middle C, on a warm evening rising to D.” One species sings a half pitch higher and another “about F# on an average summer evening.”

headline: Interactive One’s Site for Latinos
abstract: Interactive One, a digital media company best known for creating content for African-Americans, is set to announce on Monday that it has started Zona De Sabor, a Web site aimed at urban Latinos.
lead_paragraph: Interactive One, a digital media company best known for creating content for African-Americans, is set to announce on Monday that it has started a Web site aimed at urban Latinos.

headline: Separatist Victory, but Not Separation
abstract: The recent election was more about ousting the tired and corruption-tainted Liberal Party than about independence.
lead_paragraph: For the past four decades, proponents of an independent Quebec have fought a political battle with the federalist Liberals without achieving, or putting to rest, the separatists’ dream of an independent French-speaking state. Last Tuesday, Quebecers again voted into office the Parti Québécois, whose purpose since its formation in 1968 has been separatism. This time separatism is not a serious prospect. Nor was it the main issue in the election.

headline: Pro-Beijing Candidates Outmaneuver Opponents as Hong Kong Votes
abstract: Voters turned out in big numbers after a controversy over a government plan to introduce mandatory pro-Beijing patriotic education in Hong Kong schools.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy candidates won strong voter support in legislative elections here on Sunday, but came away with fewer seats than expected because pro-Beijing political parties with greater financial resources proved more skillful in navigating Hong Kong’s complex electoral system.

headline: Corporate Contributions and Disclosure
keywords: ['Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new ruling blocks an effort to overturn Minnesota’s corporate contribution ban.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s Citizens United ruling in 2010 let loose a flood of unlimited independent spending in political campaigns. It has also inspired a wave of lawsuits seeking to overturn the reasonable campaign finance restrictions that remain on the books in various states.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: For Savannah State, a 55-0 Defeat Served Its Purpose
abstract: Savannah State received payments totaling $860,000, about 17 percent of its athletic budget, for a 55-0 loss to Florida State and an 84-0 loss to Oklahoma State.
lead_paragraph: The heavens opened, lightning flashed, thunder struck. Savannah State trailed Florida State, 55-0, in Tallahassee, Fla., on Saturday, and with each crash and bang, it seemed, nature was bellowing, “Enough.”

headline: A New Kind of Warfare
abstract: Nations are developing disruptive offensive software — at great potential risk.
lead_paragraph: Cybersecurity efforts in the United States have largely centered on defending computer networks against attacks by hackers, criminals and foreign governments, mainly China. Increasingly, however, the focus is on developing offensive capabilities, on figuring out how and when the United States might unleash its own malware to disrupt an adversary’s networks. That is potentially dangerous territory.

headline: With Balanced Offense and Physical Defense, 49ers Control the Packers
abstract: With its balanced offense, led by quarterback Alex Smith, and an opportunistic defense, San Francisco contained Green Bay and Aaron Rodgers.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Even after quarterback Alex Smith directed five fourth-quarter comebacks in last year’s regular season and one more in the playoffs, the San Francisco 49ers emerged with a reputation as a dynamic defensive team with a one-dimensional, functional offense. Smith threw only five interceptions and managed the offense decently, but he certainly was no Aaron Rodgers, the electrifying Green Bay Packers star with whom he shares draft history.

headline: Man Surrenders in Police Shooting
abstract: The suspect, John Thomas, was wanted in the shooting of Sgt. Craig Bier in Jamaica, Queens, on Aug. 9.
lead_paragraph: A man wanted in the shooting of a New York police sergeant in August turned himself in on Sunday evening, the police said.

headline: Obstruct and Exploit
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A cynical Republican strategy: block all efforts to strengthen the economy, then exploit the economy’s weakness.
lead_paragraph: Does anyone remember the American Jobs Act? A year ago President Obama proposed boosting the economy with a combination of tax cuts and spending increases, aimed in particular at sustaining state and local government employment. Independent analysts reacted favorably. For example, the consulting firm Macroeconomic Advisers estimated that the act would add 1.3 million jobs by the end of 2012.

headline: Family of Bodega Worker Killed by Officer’s Bullet Wants Grand Jury to Investigate
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Relatives of 20-year-old Reynaldo Cuevas believe his death was not an accident, but was murder.
lead_paragraph: The family of the bodega worker killed by a police bullet met with the Bronx district attorney on Sunday to request that a grand jury investigate the actions of the police officer who fired the fatal shot on Friday, representatives for the family said.

headline: 400 Years Later, Still Revered in Cuba (and Miami)
abstract: Our Lady of Charity, Cuba’s patron saint, plays a central role in the lives of Cubans, and in the lives of many Miami residents, as well.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As the statue of La Virgen de la Caridad, Our Lady of Charity, completed its 30-minute journey across a stretch of the Biscayne Bay for her 400th anniversary celebration here on Saturday, a rainbow burst into view to frame her arrival.

headline: Young Receivers Give Jets a Spark
abstract: Stephen Hill and Jeremy Kerley combined for four touchdowns, including a punt-return score by Kerley, in the victory over Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — If he had wanted to, the rookie wide receiver Stephen Hill could have looked up to Section 117 and seen his family in the stands at MetLife Stadium. His parents, sister and cousin all came from Georgia to watch his first N.F.L. game.

headline: Traffic Safety Campaigner Finally Achieves His Goal
abstract: A father on the Upper East Side persistently asked neighbors, legislators and the Transportation Department to heed his simple request: for a safe way for him and his daughter to walk to the park.
lead_paragraph: He pleaded with neighbors. He pestered his councilwoman. He hounded the city, though city officials say that by now they have gotten used to it.

headline: A Watcher of the Police Says He Is Now a Target
abstract: Joseph Hayden, 71, who posts videos of Harlem officers’ activity on his Web site, claims that his arrest on weapons charges was payback.
lead_paragraph: In the streets of his native Harlem, Joseph Hayden is a familiar presence, patrolling the neighborhood with his video camera, ready to document interactions between the police and the residents they stop — and doing so at an age when most people have retired.

headline: Textured Sportswear at Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: Like Mr. Hilfiger’s men’s collection, his women’s wear had a lot of rope stripes – red ones, blue ones, white ones – running up and down suits and flowing trapeze dresses in multiple fabrics.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, Tommy Hilfiger took over a long portion of the High Line north of West 14th Street, building a runway that looked like a boardwalk with hundreds of illuminated lanterns dangling from an overhang. It was a beautiful setting for a collection he called “American Voyage,” which had a nautical theme and resembled a big Hamptons-style beach wedding.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Tortured Empathy, a Ghost Hovers
abstract: “The Train Driver,” written and directed by Athol Fugard, tells how a death on the tracks has left the train operator emotionally scarred.
lead_paragraph: A ghost haunts the graveyard setting of “The Train Driver,” the latest play by Athol Fugard, which opened Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center in a production directed by the playwright. This particular specter is made of flesh and blood. Roelf Visagie (Ritchie Coster) is unquestionably a living man, and yet there is something hollowed out about his presence, as if the soul that once inhabited his body has withered away, leaving an echoing emptiness behind.

headline: Acting It Out, Like Valentino
abstract: “Silent,” a play written and performed by Pat Kinevane, is about a homeless Dubliner who believes he has become invisible and inaudible.
lead_paragraph: Eeew. Did that filthy old pile of rags just move?

headline: Roll Call and CQ Today to Merge Into One Paper
abstract: In November, Roll Call and CQ Today will become a single daily newspaper called Roll Call and will merge both newsrooms, which have already been working alongside each other.
lead_paragraph: As many Washington-area news outlets continue their hiring sprees to feed the appetite for political news, two political newspaper stalwarts, Roll Call and CQ Today, are following what recently has been a far more common path in journalism. They are cutting back and merging.

headline: A Tight Election May Be Tangled in Legal Battles
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Minorities', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: With federal and state courts handing down decisions on ballot casting and counting, the presidential election may hinge partly on last-minute legal battles by both parties.
lead_paragraph: The November presidential election, widely expected to rest on a final blitz of advertising and furious campaigning, may also hinge nearly as much on last-minute legal battles over when and how ballots should be cast and counted, particularly if the race remains tight in battleground states.

headline: Fighting for Bangladesh Labor, and Ending Up in Pauper’s Grave
keywords: ['Series', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Minimum Wage', 'Organized Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The murder of a labor organizer bore a grim familiarity in a country with a brutal legacy of politically motivated killings.
lead_paragraph: ASHULIA, Bangladesh — His tiny office was lost among the hulking garment factories that churn out cargo pants or polo shirts for brands like Gap or Tommy Hilfiger, yet workers managed to find Aminul Islam. They came with problems. Unpaid wages. Abusive bosses. Mr. Islam, a labor organizer, fought for their rights.

headline: Honoring Cuba’s Patron Saint
abstract: Thousand gathered at Miami’s American Airlines Arena to attend Mass and celebrate La Virgen de la Caridad.
lead_paragraph: Thousand gathered at Miami’s American Airlines Arena to attend Mass and celebrate La Virgen de la Caridad.

headline: In Capital, Protecting a Treasured Right (Arm)
abstract: The Nationals’ decision to end the successful season of the young pitcher Stephen Strasburg, who had elbow reconstruction surgery in 2010, has drawn mixed reactions from baseball fans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No baseball city has suffered like Washington, its losing teams so renowned they spawned a hit Broadway musical (“Damn Yankees”) and a vaudeville joke: “First in war, first in peace and last in the American League.”

headline: With Help of Schools, Trickle of Talent Could Become a Flood
abstract: The United States is suffering the consequences of leaning on a model that often limits tennis to those who can afford it. The solution would be using the public school system to widen the talent pool.
lead_paragraph: The retirement of Andy Roddick leaves Serena Williams as the United States’ only consistent championship-caliber tennis player and raises a question:

headline: Girardi Shows His Faith; Chamberlain Shows His Stuff
abstract: With the Yankees holding a 5-3 lead in the fourth, Joba Chamberlain came in and struck out four in an inning and two-thirds and earned the victory.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When Yankees reliever Joba Chamberlain returned to the mound on Aug. 1 after missing 14 months with elbow and ankle injuries, he did not feel like the cocksure pitcher he once was.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Day 14
abstract: Serena Williams won her fourth U.S. Open title and second Grand Slam title this year, and Novak Djokovic advanced to Monday’s men’s final.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams won her fourth U.S. Open title and second Grand Slam title this year, and Novak Djokovic advanced to Monday’s men’s final.

headline: Dorothy McGuire, of Singing Sister Act, Dies at 84
abstract: The McGuire Sisters’ hits, like “Goodnight, Sweetheart, Goodnight” and “Sugartime,” kept their sweet innocence in the face of rock ’n’ roll trends.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy McGuire, who reached the top of the pop charts in the 1950s with the McGuire Sisters, one of the era’s most popular vocal groups, and continued to harmonize with her two sisters on and off for another 50 years, died on Friday in Paradise Valley, Ariz. She was 84.

headline: In One City, Signing Up for Internet Becomes a Civic Cause
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Poverty']
abstract: Leaders pushed to sign up poorer, predominantly black neighborhoods of Kansas City, Mo., to qualify for Google’s new Internet service, fearing that otherwise they will lag further behind.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — With Google’s promise last year to wire homes, schools, libraries and other public institutions in this city with the nation’s fastest Internet connection, community leaders on the long forlorn, predominantly black east side were excited, seeing a potentially uplifting force. They anticipated new educational opportunities for their children and an incentive for developers to build in their communities.

headline: Refereeing the Referees
abstract: Replacement referees will be under the microscope early this season. The New York Times will monitor games for plays that appear to be incorrectly called.
lead_paragraph: Replacement referees will be under the microscope early this season. The New York Times will monitor games for plays that appear to be incorrectly called.

headline: Putting Bay Area’s Water Source to a Vote
abstract: San Franciscans will vote on a measure that could lead to the draining and restoration of Hetch Hetchy Valley, and force the city to look elsewhere for most of its water.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — It is one of the oldest environmental battles in the United States, and it involves one of the country’s most famous national parks, one of its most liberal cities, leaders of Silicon Valley and a perennial source of conflict in California: water.

headline: U.N. Report Questions Gaza’s Future
abstract: The United Nations questioned whether Gaza will be “a liveable place” in 2020, citing shortages of important services.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations questioned whether Gaza will be “a liveable place” in 2020, citing shortages of important services.

lead_paragraph: The Jets controlled the game against the Bills from the start and scored touchdowns on offense, defense and special teams in the victory.

headline: Romney, Easing, Says Health Law Isn’t All Bad
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: In a rare interview on NBC’s “Meet the Press,” Mitt Romney offered praise for some of President Obama’s policies, and said he would retain some aspects of his health care overhaul.
lead_paragraph: Adopting a new tone, Mitt Romney on Sunday said he would retain elements of President Obama’s health care overhaul, blamed Republicans as much as Democrats for the “mistake” of agreeing to automatic cuts in military spending and said Mr. Obama’s national security strategy had made America in “some ways safer.”
