headline: Ideological Opposites Prepare to Meet in Debate
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Ahead of their matchup, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan are lobbing personal barbs while stalking each other across the same few Midwestern states.
lead_paragraph: Both root for the Green Bay Packers. Both are charged with rallying white working-class voters. And with a debate a month away, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan are increasingly lobbing personal barbs while stalking each other across the same few Midwestern battleground states.

headline: The Ryan Sinkhole
abstract: Let’s talk about where the $897 billion of unspecified cuts in Paul Ryan’s budget will come from.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the Republican platform, which has mostly been ignored outside of the abortion issue, the Paul Ryan budget is the core document of the 2012 campaign. It is the most explicit expression of the Republican agenda, endorsed by the party’s presidential candidate, Mitt Romney, and backed by decisive majorities of House and Senate Republicans.

headline: With No Contract Deal by Deadline in Chicago, Teachers Will Strike
abstract: Union leaders for Chicago’s public schoolteachers said they would strike Monday morning after negotiations ended late Sunday with no contract agreement.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Union leaders for this city’s public schoolteachers said that they would strike on Monday morning after negotiations ended late Sunday with no contract agreement between the union and the nation’s third largest school system, which have been locked for months in a dispute over wages, job security and teacher evaluations.

headline: Obama Campaign Says It Beat Romney in Fund-Raising for August
abstract: The Obama campaign said it raised $114 million in August, bringing in more than the Romney campaign for the first time since April.
lead_paragraph: 12:51 a.m. | Updated The Obama campaign announced early Monday that it had raised $114 million in August, saying it had brought in more than the Romney campaign for the first time since April.

headline: More Young Adults Have Insurance After Health Care Law, Study Says
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Youth']
abstract: The share of young adults without health insurance fell by one-sixth in 2011 from the previous year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The share of young adults without health insurance fell by one-sixth in 2011 from the previous year, the largest annual decline for any age group since the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began collecting the data in 1997, according to a new report released on Monday.

headline: Records Missing on Afghan Army Fuel Costs
abstract: American investigators say that records covering more than four years may have been shredded.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American and NATO training missions in Afghanistan have told United States government investigators that more than four years of financial records covering about $475 million worth of fuel purchases for the Afghan National Army may have been shredded, raising concerns about potential fraud.

headline: Popular Antibiotics May Carry Serious Side Effects
abstract: Fluoroquinolones are an important class of antibiotics, but their often inappropriate prescription raises the risk of very serious side effects, including retinal detachment and kidney failure.
lead_paragraph: Antibiotics are important drugs, often restoring health and even saving lives. But like all drugs, they can have unwanted and serious side effects, some of which may not become apparent until many thousands of patients have been treated.

headline: Kazakhstan Is Accused of Abusing Oil Workers
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: A Human Rights Watch report, which investigated violence last winter in the western oil town of Zhanaozen, says Kazakhstan and three oil companies repressed workers.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A human rights group on Monday accused three oil companies and the government of Kazakhstan of abusing and repressing workers in the country’s oil fields.

abstract: The New York Times invited students from Kansas State University’s College of Architecture, Planning and Design to brainstorm how they might keep the rain out of Arthur Ashe Stadium. Here are their proposals.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times invited students from Kansas State University’s College of Architecture, Planning and Design to brainstorm how they might keep the rain out of Arthur Ashe Stadium. Here are their proposals.

headline: Manning in a Familiar Role: Winner
abstract: Peyton Manning, playing his first game in 20 months after four neck surgeries, completed 19 of 26 passes for 253 yards and two touchdowns as the Broncos beat the Steelers.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — In the weeks before Peyton Manning played his first meaningful game in 20 months, he did not know what to expect — of himself, of his team, of his opponents.

headline: Making Mandarin Mandatory — in U.S. Kindergartens
abstract: A school district in Georgia has begun teaching Mandarin to its youngest pupils — the classes are mandatory — in an effort to have every student fully bilingual by the time they graduate from high school. With instructors from a program underwritten by the Chinese government, the ambitious new curriculum is not without its skeptics.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Bibb County sits smack-dab in the center of Georgia, and 150 years ago it was at the very center of the Confederacy. Its foundries supplied weapons and ammunition to the rebel army, and no county supplied a larger percentage of its men to the cause. Toward the end of the Civil War, the only local men not carrying a musket for the South were elderly, blind or disabled.

headline: Contador Wins Second Vuelta
keywords: ['Vuelta a Espana (Bicycle Race)', 'Doping (Sports)', 'Cycling, Road', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: Alberto Contador won his second Vuelta a España on Sunday, capturing a fifth victory in cycling’s major races just over a month after his doping ban ended.
lead_paragraph: Alberto Contador won his second Vuelta a España on Sunday, capturing a fifth victory in cycling’s major races just over a month after his doping ban ended. Contador easily navigated the largely processional final leg, into and around Madrid, to edge out Alejandro Valverde and Joaquim Rodríguez in the 21-stage race. Valverde, the 2009 winner, finished 1 minute 16 seconds behind. Rodríguez was 1:38 back.

headline: Norwegian Takes Montreal Race
abstract: Lars Petter Nordhaug of Norway held off the field to win the Grand Prix Cycliste de Montreal, one of the final events in cycling’s elite World Tour series.
lead_paragraph: Lars Petter Nordhaug of Norway held off the field to win the Grand Prix Cycliste de Montreal, one of the final events in cycling’s elite World Tour series.

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Trade Data Reinforces Slowdown in Chinese Economy
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inflation (Economics)']
abstract: Export growth remained in the single-digit range in August and imports shrank, falling short of expectations and adding to speculation that the government will expand stimulus measures.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Exports from China inched up in August and imports shrank unexpectedly, data released Monday showed, cementing the view that the Chinese economy has slowed abruptly in recent months despite a string of government measures devised to bolster it.

headline: Children Who Sell Themselves
abstract: Extreme poverty forces some Indian children to offer themselves as child labor.
lead_paragraph: “Children as young as 10 had begun to directly offer themselves to traffickers because they could no longer go hungry, Sonia Faleiro wrote of children in the northern state of Bihar in The International Herald Tribune.

headline: In Monza, a Race That Resembles the Season
abstract: Lewis Hamilton drove his McLaren Mercedes to a dominating victory at the Italian Grand Prix, and the race was full of other interesting plots and angles as well, which befits the current Formula One season.
lead_paragraph: MONZA, Italy — In what has become something of a habit in Formula One this season, the series served up yet another race with significant and intriguing stories, plots and subplots.

headline: Pro-Beijing Candidates Outmaneuver Opponents as Hong Kong Votes
abstract: Pro-democracy candidates won strong voter support but came away with fewer seats than expected as pro-Beijing candidates used electoral procedures to their advantage.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy candidates won strong voter support in legislative elections held here over the weekend but failed to capture some key seats because pro-Beijing political parties with greater financial resources proved more skillful in navigating Hong Kong’s complex electoral system.

headline: Does Delhi Need a Cap on Car Ownership?
abstract: Should India learn from China, and limit car ownership?
lead_paragraph: Is it time for India to take lessons from China about pollution and congestion?

headline: Glencore Says Higher Bid for Xstrata Is Its Final Offer
abstract: Glencore International confirmed its increased all-share offer for Xstrata, but said on Monday that it would not raise its bid again.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Glencore International, the world’s largest commodities trader, officially unveiled its new offer for the mining company Xstrata on Monday, although the outcome of the merger remains uncertain.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 10, 2012
abstract: Can you calculate the summer movie ticket sales if given last summer’s sales and the percentage of decline between then and now?
lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “Ticket Sales Fail to Make Hollywood’s Summer.”

abstract: BP has agreed to sell stakes in a group of oil fields in the Gulf of Mexico to the Plains Exploration and Production Company of Houston for about $5.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: 9:53 a.m. | Updated

headline: JAL Aims to Raise $8.5 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: Japan Airlines has set the price of its initial public offering at a level that would make the listing the world’s second-largest I.P.O this year after that of Facebook.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan Airlines set the price of its initial public offering on Monday at a level that could value the bailed-out carrier at 663 billion yen, or $8.5 billion, setting the stage for the world’s second-largest I.P.O. this year, after that of Facebook.

headline: A Panoramic View of China’s Cultural Revolution
abstract: The photographer Li Zhensheng documented China’s Cultural Revolution for his local paper in Harbin, but soon started taking pictures that didn’t align with the Community Party dogma and, fearing retribution, hid them.
lead_paragraph: Li Zhensheng’s photographs of the Chinese Cultural Revolution are perhaps the most complete and nuanced pictorial account of the decade of turmoil ignited by Mao Zedong.

headline: Is Cheating Getting Worse?
abstract: Tell us what you have observed about cheating in your school.
lead_paragraph: A recent study shows that more students are cheating — and that many are cheating not just to survive, but to thrive. What have you observed about cheating at your school? If there seems to be more of it, why do you think that is?

headline: Sustainable Innovation: The Vegan Shoe
abstract: Betting that “modern consumers want to be fashionable, but they don’t want to do it at the expense of the world,” three former corporate suits created an innovative start-up.
lead_paragraph: When three shoe-industry professionals met in 2009 to start their own company, they were not driven by ideals of sustainability, veganism or even durability. Instead, they wanted to find a creative independence that had been missing in their corporate offices.

headline: The Envelope, Please | Students from Across the Country (and Abroad) Blog Their College Searches
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Foreign Students (in US)']
abstract: Eight high school seniors — from Seattle, Kenya, India, Arkansas, Las Vegas, Ohio, New York City, and Kansas — are sharing videos in a series of first-person blog posts about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: Nothing can quite convey the roller coaster of emotions of applying to college — bewilderment, elation, dejection, hope, fear — as powerfully as the voices of the applicants themselves. And so, as in years past, The Choice blog has selected eight high school seniors to tell their stories throughout the new school year as part of the latest installment of a first-person series we call “The Envelope, Please.”

headline: What to Watch on Monday: Men’s Final Preview
abstract: A preview of the men’s final match between Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray has reached a Grand Slam final four times, and four times he has played like a guy with the weight of an entire nation on his shoulders.

headline: What Romney Could Learn From the N.F.L.
abstract: Heavily regulated and thriving, the National Football League offers lessons as well as excitement, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to “For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.“

headline: The Tebow Effect, and Unreasonable Doubts About the Jets’ Offense
abstract: It may be hard to believe, but the Jets scored the fifth-most points in the A.F.C. last season, and were only 5 points shy of passing Houston as the third-highest scoring team in the conference.
lead_paragraph: Quick quiz.

headline: Never Cured Cancer or Built a Spaceship, But Trying to Capture a University’s Attention
abstract: Will Walker, a student at University School in Hunting Valley, Ohio, writes that he has “absolutely no edge over anyone else in the college process.”
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I got back from an enormous East Coast college visit trip that was supposed to help me find and explore the school where I will spend the next four years of my life.

headline: British Bomb Squad Visits Home of Murder Victims
keywords: ['Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The British police on Monday evacuated an area around the home of a British-Iraqi family targeted in last week’s killing in the French Alps.
lead_paragraph: CLAYGATE, England — In a further twist to a story of murder and mystery that has seized headlines for days in France and Britain, the British police summoned an army bomb squad on Monday to search a work shed at the home of a British-Iraqi family targeted in last week’s killing in the French Alps.

headline: Despite Outcry, Crime and Number of Migrants Falling in Mumbai
abstract: Statistics from Mumbai don’t bear out Raj Thackeray’s claims.
lead_paragraph: Days after a court in Bihar ordered the Muzaffarpur police to register a case against Raj Thackeray, the head of the far-right Maharashtra Navnirman Sena party, for threatening to drive workers from the north Indian state out of Mumbai, Mr. Thackeray reiterated a popular perception that migrants from poorer parts of India are pouring into Maharashtra, raising crime levels.

headline: Coping With Mild Cognitive Impairment
abstract: A researcher at the University of Toronto answers questions about detecting and dealing with mild cognitive impairment.
lead_paragraph: About 10 to 15 percent of adults age 65 and older are believed to have mild cognitive impairment — a condition commonly characterized by memory problems, well beyond those associated with normal aging.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Matt Bai on Ohio’s Comeback
abstract: The author of the cover article answers questions about who deserves credit for Ohio’s recovery.
lead_paragraph: Matt Bai wrote this week’s cover story on the contest between President Obama and John R. Kasich, the governor of Ohio, to claim credit for the state’s economic uptick. Bai is a staff writer and chief political correspondent for the magazine; his most recent articles were about the former senator Bob Kerrey, the debt deal crisis, the former weapons inspector Scott Ritter, Tea Party politics in South Carolina and Newt Gingrich.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Best Facebook Pages

headline: Oscar Mayer Proposes a New Bacon as a New Currency
abstract: To promote its new Butcher Thick Cut bacon, an actor will be given 3,000 pounds of the bacon to barter for food, fuel and a place to spend the night. He starts in New York, and is expected to make it to Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Many people, even those who are not New York State residents, have probably heard the lottery slogan, “All it takes is a dollar and a dream.” Now comes an actor, comedian and writer, seeking to make his way across the country in the next two weeks with only a dream and, oh, yes, instead of a dollar, a trailer filled with 3,000 pounds of a new bacon.

headline: Iraq’s Vice President Calls Death Sentence ‘Unjust’
abstract: The verdict against Tariq al-Hashimi, a prominent Sunni Muslim, and a wave of attacks on Sunday threatened to deepen an already intractable political crisis.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Tariq al-Hashimi, a vice president of Iraq and a prominent Sunni Muslim who was convicted of murder and sentenced to death in a trial conducted in absentia, denounced the verdict on Monday as “false and unjust,” depicting the court’s finding as “an acquittal, confirming my innocence.”

headline: On Our Radar: Shell Begins Preparatory Drilling Off Alaska
abstract: Shell has yet to meet Interior Department requirements for a spill response vessel, however.
lead_paragraph: A Royal Dutch Shell vessel sends a drill bit into the ocean floor in the Chukchi Sea in the Arctic, beginning preliminary work on an exploratory well 70 miles off the northwestern coast of Alaska. The Interior Department approved the preparatory move but has not yet certified Shell’s oil spill response barge. [Associated Press]

headline: Driving the Chevrolet Spark

headline: Amazon and Apple’s Giant Markups on Flash Storage
abstract: Apart from the look and feel of their products, there’s a key difference between Amazon’s new tablets and Apple’s iPads: the amount of money each company charges for storage. Apple customers typically pay more to get extra gigs, but overall, both companies do a major markup on memory.
lead_paragraph: Apart from the look and feel of their products, there’s a key difference between Amazon’s new tablets and Apple’s iPads: the amount of money each company charges for storage. Apple customers typically pay more to get extra gigabytes, but over all, both companies do a major markup on memory.

headline: Flying Putin, Fired Editor
keywords: ['Birds', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Gliders, Hang Gliding and Paragliding', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Magazines', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: How Putin’s latest PR stunt cost me my job.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Losing my job as editor of one of the world’s oldest popular-science magazines, Vokrug Sveta (Around the World), was faster and less painful than I had imagined. And I had spent a couple of months imagining how this might happen.

abstract: Stan Lee, the venerated Marvel Comics writer and editor, thought he was making a quick cameo on the reality series set at Kevin Smith’s New Jersey comic-book shop. But the day unfolded differently than he expected.
lead_paragraph: RED BANK, N.J. – Friday seemed like a special morning in the life of Jack Davis, a towheaded boy who had been granted entry to Jay and Silent Bob’s Secret Stash, a comic-book store here. Though a familiar sign in the window said “I Assure You We’re Open,” the shop was in fact closed for a taping of “Comic Book Men,” the AMC reality series about its proprietors.

headline: Sept. 9: Call It as You See It
abstract: Saying “wait for more data” misses the point: a forecast model’s value is determined when the information is murky.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been picking up some sentiment from analysts and journalists in my Twitter feed recently, who correctly note that polling around the party conventions can be volatile. They suggest that we ought to wait for more data before concluding very much about the bounces that the conventions have produced.

headline: An Obvious Shyster

Edsall goes into more detail than anyone else I’ve read about just how much is hidden in that “sinkhole” and how it calls everything else Ryan claims into question.

headline: Teachers’ Strike in Chicago Tests Mayor and Union
abstract: The strike left 350,000 children without classes, and placed both the powerful teachers’ union and Mayor Rahm Emanuel in a risky standoff.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — This city found itself engulfed on Monday by a sudden public school strike that left 350,000 children without classes, turned a spotlight on rising tensions nationally over teachers’ circumstances, and placed both the powerful teachers’ union and Mayor Rahm Emanuel in a risky, politically fraught standoff with no clear end in sight.

lead_paragraph: Design Sponge: Desserts that maximize and magnify the last of the season’s berries. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Journalism’s Big Tent, and Google vs. Amazon on Search
abstract: In Georgia, a university’s journalism department injects life and resources into local coverage, and a chronicler of police misconduct in Harlem says he has been punished for his work.
lead_paragraph: An experiment in journalism education at Mercer University in Macon, Ga., will also inject life and resources into the professional journalism in the city, Christine Haughney writes. Backed by a $4.6 million grant from the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Mercer’s Center for Collaborative Journalism will be home to reporters and editors of the city’s 186-year-old paper, The Telegraph, and the local public radio station. Students will do reporting legwork, with guidance from professors and working journalists, in what the university’s president compares to the way medical schools use hospitals to train their students.

headline: Kathy Ryan Honored by Royal Photographic Society
abstract: Our director of photography received the award for Outstanding Service to Photography at a ceremony last week in London.
lead_paragraph: At a ceremony last week in London, the magazine’s photo director, Kathy Ryan, was one of several people recognized by The Royal Photographic Society for their significant contributions to photography. Kathy received the society’s annual award for Outstanding Service to Photography.

lead_paragraph: Although we get digital photos instantly, it generally takes a quite a bit longer – days, in fact – to send away for prints of your shots.

headline: Stoops Grow in Value, and Not Just as Seating
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The stairs, removed from many New York City residences throughout the 20th century, are becoming popular again and are often restored by homeowners.
lead_paragraph: When Alex Barrett bought a four-story brick town house in Cobble Hill five years ago, on a picturesque stretch of Henry Street in Brooklyn lined with idyllic homes, it was, he recalled fondly, “the worst one of the block.”

headline: Worker Killed in Brooklyn Building Collapse
abstract: At least one other worker was critically injured when a roof or ceiling fell on workers at a building under construction in Fort Greene.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:51 p.m. | A worker was killed and another seriously injured on Monday when a third-story construction floor overloaded with cinder blocks collapsed beneath the men and they fell 30 feet at an apartment building under construction in Brooklyn, officials said.

headline: Leading Off: Manning Wins Big; Irsay Loses Bigger
abstract: Peyton Manning, making his first start for Denver, had a better Week 1 than Jim Irsay, the Colts’ owner who allowed Manning to leave Indianapolis.
lead_paragraph: The resounding conclusion of the circus that was Indianapolis’s jettisoning of quarterback Peyton Manning after last season was that the Colts’ owner, Jim Irsay, had better be right about this. He had better be right that Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck would be franchise savior No. 2, as polished and poised as the original. And he’d better be right that Manning was finished because, even if Luck is all that, Colts fans were always going to fume every time Manning engineered a winning drive for the Broncos, were always going to blame Irsay for shipping their beloved hero out of town, were always going to cringe when they thought of the man who cut Peyton Manning.

headline: In the Caribbean Coral Die-Off, Myriad Wrinkles
abstract: The causes are many, from overfishing to the warming of the seas, and damage is far more dire in some places than others.
lead_paragraph: At its ongoing conference in South Korea, the International Union for Conservation of Nature released a report on Friday indicating that live coral coverage on reefs in the Caribbean has plummeted from nearly 50 percent in the 1970s to less than 10 percent today. Yet describing the entire Caribbean as a region where reefs are in a state of general collapse tends to cloud the problem’s complexity, the study suggests.

headline: Daily Report: Google Fights Amazon for Shoppers’ Clicks
abstract: Amazon.com and Google are waging a war to become the pre-eminent online mall, Claire Cain Miller and Stephanie Clifford report in Monday’s New York Times. And e-commerce sites large and small are caught in the cross-fire.
lead_paragraph: Amazon.com and Google are waging a war to become the pre-eminent online mall, Claire Cain Miller and Stephanie Clifford report in Monday’s New York Times. And e-commerce sites large and small are caught in the cross-fire.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Attacks on Police']

abstract: Barring a settlement, the collective bargaining agreement will expire Saturday and the N.H.L. is expected to lock out players for the third time in 18 years.
lead_paragraph: The final countdown begins Monday, and the N.H.L. work stoppage that everyone has expected since mid-July impends, less than six days away. Unless something unforeseen and astoundingly cooperative happens between the deadlocked parties on or before Saturday the current collective bargaining agreement will expire, and Commissioner Gary Bettman will follow through on his promise to lock out the players for the third time in 18 years.

lead_paragraph: Monday morning at 9, for a change of pace from the runways, I stopped by the Spanx by Sara Blakely presentation to see another side of fashion. The phenomenally successful innerwear company is best known for its compression garments, and somehow there is always the impression that products like bras and panties are designed in a world far removed from what is happening at the shows in Lincoln Center.

headline: In Northwest Corner of India, the Work of Centuries
abstract: The craftsmen of Gujarat struggle to keep their art alive.
lead_paragraph: “In scattered hamlets, weavers, embroiderers, textile painters, tie-dyers, bead workers, potters, carvers, cobblers and bell-makers work as they have for centuries, often taking weeks, even months to finish a single flawless piece,” Claire Spiegel wrote in The International Herald Tribune of the craftsmen of Kutch, in the northwestern state of Gujarat.

headline: Polo Dobkin to Leave the Kitchen at Dressler
abstract: Mr. Dobkin’s cooking won a Michelin star for the restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Polo Dobkin has announced that he is leaving Dressler, the restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where he has been the executive chef for seven years. Mr. Dobkin, a graduate of the French Culinary Institute, said his plans were still evolving, but were likely to involve opening his own place.

headline: Cartoonist Charged with Sedition in Mumbai
abstract: Charged with sedition for a drawing that substituted a wolf for a lion.
lead_paragraph: A Mumbai court sent Aseem Trivedi, a young cartoonist, to judicial custody for two weeks on charges of sedition and violating the information technology act after he drew a cartoon that mocked the corruption in the Indian government.

headline: For a Goldman Executive, More Real Estate Dealings
abstract: According to people familiar with his plans, J. Michael Evans, a Goldman Sachs vice chairman, will list his Upper West Side condominium for $26 million. He has also put up for sale another apartment that he owns in the building and has recently purchased a $27 million Fifth Avenue apartment.
lead_paragraph: In Wall Street parlance, J. Michael Evans is long Manhattan real estate and looking to reduce his exposure.

headline: India’s Congress Party Leads in Donations
abstract: The party controlled by the Gandhi family draws more than twice the donations of its biggest rival.
lead_paragraph: India’s governing Congress Party received the largest donations of any political party in the last seven years, and donations to the party’s primary opposition, the Bharatiya Janata Party, were less than half of Congress’s.

headline: Big Step in Selling A.I.G. Stake, but Other Bailouts Remain
abstract: The Treasury Department’s plan to sell a big chunk of its A.I.G. holdings is a big step in unwinding one of the most controversial bailouts of the financial crisis. But there are still plenty of other rescue programs to dismantle.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department announced on Sunday the biggest sale of its holdings in the American International Group yet, taking its stake below 50 percent for the first time since 2008.

headline: App Smart Extra: Cat Apps Work for Babies
abstract: If you are looking for great apps for babies and toddlers, don’t confine yourself to apps for that age group. Several apps for older children, adults and even cats could be hits.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s App Smart column was all about apps for babies, because they really will love playing with your tablet and smartphone as much as you do (though you may need to pay a lot of attention lest they drop your expensive electronic item onto the floor or dribble on it).

headline: Indie Filmmakers Feel Heavy Hand of Beijing
abstract: The Beijing Independent Film Festival was thrown into chaos after a power failure in the middle of the first screening. In China, filmmaking without approval of the ruling Communist Party is discouraged.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Independent filmmaking is tough anywhere in the world, but in China, especially, it is not a vocation for the faint of heart.

headline: Communist Leader’s Absence Sets Off Rumor Mills in China
abstract: Speculation intensified over the whereabouts of Xi Jinping, China’s presumptive new president, who has been missing from public view in recent days.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The strange disappearance from public view of China’s presumptive new leader is turning a year that was supposed to showcase the Communist Party’s stability into something of an annus horribilis.

headline: Crabs May Rely on Color to Tell Food From Poison
abstract: Two species appear to have eyes sensitive to ultraviolet light, which could help them tell the difference between glowing blue plankton (food) and green coral (poison), researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Two species of crabs that live on the seafloor have color-coding abilities that help them detect food, a new study suggests.

headline: Michael Pietsch of Little, Brown to Be Hachette Book’s Chief Executive
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Mr. Pietsch is known as a skilled editor who can handle literary titans like David Foster Wallace as deftly as blockbuster commercial authors like James Patterson. He replaces David Young.
lead_paragraph: 2:41 p.m. | Updated Michael Pietsch, the publisher of Little, Brown and Company and a hands-on editor known for his work with both literary titans and mass-market commercial authors, has been named chief executive of the Hachette Book Group.

headline: Numberplay: Catbird Seat
abstract: A simple geometry puzzle with a surprising answer.
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Numberplay reader Matthew Albright, who had come across the puzzle among a collection of compendious amusements at the blog Futility Closet. I asked Futility Closet’s creator Greg Ross where he happened to find the puzzle, and what he liked about it.

headline: Designed in Iran
abstract: Iranian designers who were born around the time of the Islamic Revolution in 1979 have produced some mesmerizing work.
lead_paragraph: Nothing has captured my attention as much lately as the graphic design coming out of Iran. While I’ve been familiar with the incredible work of more established designers like Reza Abedini, recently I’ve been mesmerized by the generation of designers who were born around the time of the Islamic Revolution of 1979 — those who grew up at a time when Iranians were grappling with an Islamic society. You can see this most notably in the work of Homa Delvaray, Iman Raad and Farhad Fozouni, who combine disparate cultural influences as well as technology and traditional applied arts. They utilize Farsi script as imagery, rather than simply as type.

headline: Issues Linger as Afghans Take Control of a Prison
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Top American commanders were absent from the ceremony marking the hand-over of Bagram prison to Afghan control, and even agreement on a crucial point of the signed prison deal itself was elusive.
lead_paragraph: BAGRAM, Afghanistan — It was supposed to be a ceremony to celebrate the full transfer of Afghan detainees and prison operations to Afghan control. But top American commanders were absent on Monday, hundreds of Afghan prisoners remained under American detention, and details of the deal remained in dispute.

headline: Company Says It, Not F.B.I., Was Hacking Victim
abstract: A company in Orlando, Fla., said it was the source of a file hackers posted online last week that contained a million identification numbers for Apple mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: A company in Orlando, Fla., said on Monday that it — not the F.B.I. — was the source of a file hackers posted online last week that contained a million identification numbers for Apple mobile devices.

headline: An Updated Great Lakes Accord
abstract: The United States and Canada revise their environmental pact to reflect threats like invasive species and climate change.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Canada have amended a 40-year-old environmental accord on the Great Lakes, expanding its goals to tackle problems like invasive species, pollution and climate change.

abstract: A man charged with assaulting an officer had his case dismissed after a grand jury watched footage of the encounter, which may be crucial evidence in a lawsuit filed in federal court.
lead_paragraph: The shaky and frenetic video, lasting less than a minute, appears to show two New York police officers holding a man on the floor, with one repeatedly slamming his right fist into the man’s face.

headline: Can the S.E.C. Win an Insider Case the Old-Fashioned Way?
abstract: A recent appeals court decision may result in a test of whether the S.E.C. can win an insider trading verdict by putting on a circumstantial case built around a well-timed trade and contacts with an insider.
lead_paragraph: Over thirty years ago, the actor John Houseman intoned about brokerage firm Smith Barney: “They make money the old-fashioned way. They earn it.”

headline: Millennials, in Uniform or Not, Come of Age in the 9/11 Decade
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World Trade Center (NYC)']
abstract: Eleven years after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a whole generation has grown up with a defining moment — and a reason to serve.
lead_paragraph: “Raise your hand if you know someone serving in the military,” my political anthropology professor asked one day during a senior seminar. I looked around the room and saw a few scattered hands in the air, then down at my own, firmly planted in my lap. It was the fall of 2007, and the United States military had been engaged in two theaters of war for the better part of a decade. I was about to graduate with a degree in global security, and I could not think of a single person I knew who was serving — nor had the thought even crossed my mind until the question was posed so directly. While public service was featured prominently in my schools and community growing up, and certainly among my peers in college, the thought of service was always relegated to the civilian sphere — Peace Corps, Teach for America, infrastructure projects in South America. Military service, though not portrayed in a negative way, was simply absent from discussions of post-graduation endeavors.

headline: Romney Criticizes Teachers’ Union and Obama
abstract: Mitt Romney suggests that President Obama has taken sides in the Chicago labor dispute.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney issued a statement Monday criticizing the teachers’ union in Chicago for going on strike, and faulted President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for their words in support of labor, suggesting that the president has already taken sides in the fight.

headline: Reader Ideas | Teachers and the 9/11 Anniversary
abstract: Teachers describe how they used technology, collaboration and Times materials to teach about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: Last year, for the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, we asked teachers to share their plans for teaching about it. Ideas poured in, and we published scores of suggestions from disciplines across the curriculum and teachers on every level from early childhood to college.

headline: Sweet Tooth
abstract: Artificial sweeteners do not have the same effect on enamel that sugar has. Some, in fact, have antibacterial properties that inhibit decay.
lead_paragraph: Q. Are there certain sugar substitutes that are as corrosive to dental enamel as sugar?

headline: Why ‘User Friendly’ Is So Friendly: A Tribute to Bill Moggridge
abstract: The Briton who pioneered interaction design is remembered by colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Some considered it an inspired choice, others simply surprising, when Bill Moggridge was appointed director of the Smithsonian Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in 2010. The 115-year-old New York institution is a treasure house of decorative objects, from panoramic wallpapers to dessert forks. Mr. Moggridge, who died Saturday at the age of 69,  was an industrial designer who invented the first laptop computer, the Grid Compass, in 1980, and was a founder, in 1991, of the global industrial design company IDEO. A British-born resident of Silicon Valley, with the intellectual curiosity of Nikola Tesla and the affability of Father Christmas, he had investigated the modes through which people manipulate machines, and used this research to pioneer a field known as interaction design.

headline: Public Theater Announces ‘Giant’ Casting
abstract: Brian d’Arcy James, Kate Baldwin, and P.J. Griffith will play the lead roles in the musical adaptation of Edna Ferber’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Public Theater executives said on Monday that their fall production of the new musical “Giant,” based on Edna Ferber’s epic novel about a powerful Texas ranching family, will star the Tony Award nominees Brian d’Arcy James (“Shrek”) and Kate Baldwin (“Finian’s Rainbow”) as the patriarch Bick Benedict and his wife, Leslie, the roles played in the 1956 movie by Rock Hudson and Elizabeth Taylor.

headline: TimesCast | Sept. 10, 2012
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Michael Slackman, a deputy foreign editor at The Times, looks at the impact of Syria’s civil war both inside the country and around the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Michael Slackman, a deputy foreign editor at The Times, looks at the impact of Syria’s civil war both inside the country and around the Middle East.

headline: Steel-Cut Oats, Sweet and Savory
abstract: An annual porridge competition in Scotland inspires oatmeal dishes that go beyond the basic breakfast. Today: Steel-Cut Oats and Vegetable Torta.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago in the course of touring Bob’s Red Mill, the whole-foods purveyor based in Portland, Ore., I learned a new word: spurtle. A spurtle is a wooden dowel-like implement used to stir oatmeal. They are common in Scotland, where an international porridge-making competition called the Golden Spurtle is held every year in October. There are two sections to the competition: one for plain porridge made with steel-cut oats (also known as pinhead oats) and nothing more than water and salt; and one for specialty porridges, in which the steel-cut oats are used in a dish with other ingredients, sweet or savory.

headline: Science Times Podcast
abstract: Organic food, a lion invades the suburbs, and seeking medical connections between humans and animals.
lead_paragraph: Organic food, a lion invades the suburbs, and seeking medical connections between humans and animals.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Jonny Bauer and Ted Florea were named to new posts at Droga5, New York. Mr. Bauer becomes chief strategy officer and Mr. Florea becomes head of brand planning.
lead_paragraph: Jonny Bauer and Ted Florea were named to new posts at Droga5, New York. Mr. Bauer, head of strategy, becomes chief strategy officer, and Mr. Florea, group strategy director, becomes head of brand planning.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Another question about the Honda Pilot “Crazy Train” spot.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: U-20 World Cup: A Glimpse Into the Future
abstract: Now a pro soccer player in Sweden, Yael Averbuch, a former national team player, reflects on the United States’ victory in the U20 world championship.
lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — I love watching athletes celebrate. It’s that moment of pure joy in accomplishment and extreme relief that the nerves, fatigue and struggle were worth it. Seeing these celebrations gives me chills every time. As the young American women ran to embrace — sweaty braids and ponytails swishing across their faces — they acknowledged the fact that together they had achieved the ultimate feat: being the best in the world at what they do.

headline: Ads for the Standard Are Far From Standard
abstract: A campaign to promote the five locations of the Standard Hotel uses provocative photographs by Erwin Wurm.
lead_paragraph: A lodging brand known for being unconventional is taking a particularly offbeat tack with a campaign that seeks to burnish its cool-kid credentials by celebrating the eye-opening — and eyebrow-raising — work of an Austrian artist.

headline: Why Facebook Is Paying the Tax Tab on Employee Compensation
keywords: ['Capital Gains Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Facebook’s restricted stock program was a clever solution to the problem of keeping the company private under securities laws, but it left its employees with a tax problem.
lead_paragraph: Facebook announced last week that it planned to use cash to pay off a $1.9 billion tax bill related to restricted stock units that Facebook had granted to employees over the years. It’s odd timing for a tax bill. Why would Facebook, not the employees, owe tax on compensation income?

headline: How Pat LaFrieda Cooks a 900-Pound Steer
abstract: The butcher’s recipe for Angus beef slices as prepared at Meatopia, the festival of more than 40 chefs and 2,600 carnivores that invaded Randall’s Island on Saturday evening.
lead_paragraph: A recipe for Angus beef slices from the butcher Pat LaFrieda as prepared at Meatopia, the festival of more than 40 chefs and 2,600 carnivores that staged a five-hour invasion of Randalls Island on Saturday evening, undeterred by rain.

abstract: An abundance of desirable, easy-to-wear looks was prevalent at Diane von Furstenberg.
lead_paragraph: The Look:  To Each Her Own

headline: Elliott Carter to Join Legion of Honor
abstract: The 103-year-old composer will receive France’s highest honor.
lead_paragraph: The composer Elliott Carter, who turns 104 in December and is still composing prolifically, has collected his share of prestigious awards over the decades, among them two Pulitzer Prizes and the National Medal of Honor in the United States, Germany’s Ernst von Siemens Music Prize and the Commander of the Order of Arts and Letters, from France.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Andy Murray Wins U.S. Open
abstract: Andy Murray defeated Novak Djokovic in a grueling United States Open men’s singles final on Monday, earning his first Grand Slam title with a 7-6 (12), 7-5, 2-6, 3-6, 6-2 victory.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray won his first Grand Slam title, surviving a mid-match collapse to outlast defending champion Novak Djokovic 7-6 (10), 7-5, 2-6, 3-6, 6-2 in four hours and 54 minutes for the men’s singles championship at the 2012 United States Open.

headline: God and the Troops
abstract: Mitt Romney didn’t use the word troops in his convention address. Then he attacked the Democrats for (initially) not using the word God in their platform.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney has about had it with reporters and politicians asking why he didn’t mention American troops (who are still dying in Afghanistan for a war that he thinks they should be fighting) during his speech at the Republican convention in Tampa.

headline: Driving the Volkswagen Golf GTD
abstract: Wheels spends a holiday weekend with the diesel-burning equivalent to the GTI, which is not available for sale in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The sixth generation of the Volkswagen Golf has been on American roads for three years. That may seem like sufficient time for a vehicle not named Murciélago, Zonda or Veyron to shake off the incredulous gasps and covetous glares of passers-by. But the Golf I drove over Labor Day weekend, painted a Kermit-like shade of green, was on a tourist visa, its German license plate gleaming below its honeycomb grille. The car prompted children to squeal and fanboys to fumble for their camera phones.

headline: Ask a Hostage Negotiator
abstract: Taking Questions: This week, Frank A. Bolz Jr., a retired New York Police Department captain, responds to readers’ questions.
lead_paragraph: Updated | We are no longer accepting questions.

headline: A 1973 Hostage Situation, Revisited
abstract: Retro City: A 47-hour-long hostage situation at a sporting goods store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is still one of the longest in the city’s history and a turning point in police practices for handling similar situations.
lead_paragraph: “We know some of you are hurt. We want to help you,” boomed a bullhorn on top of an armored police vehicle. “Please come out with your hands on your heads and you will be treated. There is no place for you to go. The building, the block and the entire area is surrounded.”

headline: The Perfectly Fried Egg
abstract: José Andrés demonstrates his method for cooking an egg in the kitchen of the International Culinary Center in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: José Andrés demonstrates his method for cooking an egg in the kitchen of the International Culinary Center in Manhattan.

headline: Toronto Film Festival: Partying With Ben Affleck and Reactions to ‘The Master,’ ‘Cloud Atlas’ and More
abstract: The two big-budget, big-expectation tentpoles, “Cloud Atlas” and “The Master” had audiences waiting for hours and industry speculating.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO – The front-loaded schedule at the Toronto International Film Festival  has yielded a few expected payoffs and a few unpredicted ones. Eagerly-awaited movies like Ben Affleck’s “Argo” (which earned good word-of-mouth at a sneak preview at the Telluride Film Festival last month) delivered, earning a standing ovation at its packed premiere on Friday. Reviews called the film, about the Iranian hostage crisis in the 1970s, Mr. Affleck’s coming-of-age moment as an actor-director. At the after-party last week, Mr. Affleck was jovial, ordering pizza and chatting with friends like Matt Damon, John Krasinski and Emily Blunt late into the night. He talked eagerly about shooting at CIA headquarters in Langley, Va., but admitted to some worry that the geo-political theme would make the film “challenging” to market. “I’m working harder to promote this movie,” he said. “I can furnish you with endless” material. (We will expect it.)

headline: Lasker Awards to Honor 7 Scientists
keywords: ['Cancer', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Liver', 'Medicine and Health', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Research', 'Science and Technology', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: The Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announced that seven scientists would be honored with the 2012 Lasker Award, one of the world’s most prestigious scientific prizes.
lead_paragraph: The Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announced on Monday that seven scientists would be honored with the 2012 Lasker Award, one of the world’s most prestigious scientific prizes.

headline: Putting Spain Back in Spanish Food
abstract: José Andrés, the best-known Spanish chef working in the United States, has helped create a program that immerses future professionals in the cooking and language of Spain.
lead_paragraph: IT seems an impossible dream, if not the one that the Man of La Mancha crooned onstage. But here it goes: Over the next decade, dozens of American cooks schooled in the authentic cooking of Spain and trained in Spanish restaurants will begin to populate the United States. In due time, hundreds, then thousands, will serve up a cuisine that is not Mexican, or Caribbean, or Latin American, but one faithful to Spain. Not only will they staff a national roster of credibly Spanish restaurants, but they will go on to create new ones. Ultimately, that will ramp up American demand for the wine and products of Spain.

headline: Netherlands Encounters Ghosts and Shadows in Budapest
abstract: The Netherlands’ trip to Budapest for a World Cup qualifying match has deep cultural undertones.
lead_paragraph: Political racists and soccer revolutionaries haunt the clash between Hungary and the Netherlands as the Dutch team arrives in Budapest on Tuesday ready to decide who will top the fledgling Group D table in World Cup qualifying.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee, a Former Hunger Striker, Dies
abstract: The detainee, whose identity and nationality were not immediately released, was found unconscious in his cell, the United States military said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A detainee at the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, died over the weekend, the United States military announced on Monday.

headline: Really? Using a Computer Before Bed Can Disrupt Sleep
abstract: A recent study showed that exposure to light from tablets significantly lowered levels of the hormone melatonin, which plays a role in the sleep cycle.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: Nation Rich in Land Draws Workers From One Rich in People
abstract: The influx of Chinese farm labor in Russia reflects the growing trade and economic ties between the two countries, one rich in land and resources, the other in people.
lead_paragraph: OSTANINO, Russia — When a Chinese investor bought a farm outside this village a few years back, he was pleased enough to name it Golden Land. The soil was rich, the sunshine and rain bountiful.

headline: Samurai Shopper | High and Dry
abstract: A round-up of superior dry shampoos that do double duty as waterless cleaning machines and styling aids.
lead_paragraph: The Samurai Shopper takes her skin care very seriously, but hair care is barely a blip on the radar. I’m more focused on fighting follicles that bloom outside the scalp zone; when fuzz attacks, I’m already in the lounge chair at Browhaus, 56 Spring Street. The hair on my head simply requires occasional pruning, regular washing and daily brushing. Every so often, though, a hair product comes along that proves noteworthy. Take dry shampoo: apparently I’m the last earthling to discover that dry shampoo does double duty as a waterless cleaning machine and a styling aid. Best of all, the cheap ones are pretty good, even if the good ones are better.

headline: An Empathetic Eye on the Paralympics
abstract: For Emilio Morenatti, who lost his foot in Afghanistan in 2009, photographing the Paralympics for The Associated Press was a special opportunity to work, honoring disabled athletes whose challenges resemble his own.
lead_paragraph: The first Paralympic Games since 2009, when Emilio Morenatti lost his foot to a roadside bomb in Afghanistan, ended in London on Sunday night. For Mr. Morenatti, who does not consider himself a sports photographer, the Paralympics were a priority, a more personal assignment that better connected him with a community he recently joined.

headline: Geithner Holds His Own on Triathlon Front
abstract: Timothy F. Geithner is well known as being something of a fitness nut. And on Sunday, the Treasury secretary showed off his athletic abilities with a highly respectable finish of a triathlon held in the nation’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Paul D. Ryan may not have finished a marathon quite as fast as he initially recounted. But Timothy F. Geithner can point to a respectable time for his latest triathlon.

headline: Scourge of the Lionfish, Part 3: The Newest Fish in the Kitchen
abstract: About 20 years ago, the beautiful and otherworldly red lionfish started showing up in south Florida and the Caribbean. Now they’re a plague.
lead_paragraph: Carl Safina is founder of Blue Ocean Institute at Stony Brook University and a MacArthur Fellow. His books include “A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout,” and “The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World,” which won the  2012 Orion Award. His series “Saving the Ocean” will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

headline: Greece Wrestles With Cuts to Unlock Bailout Funds
abstract: Greece had tough talks with its European lenders over an 11 billion euro package of budget cuts needed for the country to receive its next allotment of bailout money.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greek officials had another day of tough negotiations Monday with representatives of its so-called troika of European lenders, trying to agree to an €11 billion package of budget cutting measures that would enable Greece to receive its next allotment of bailout money.

headline: A Crop Dividend: Restored Bird Habitat in New Jersey
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Birds', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Invasive Species']
abstract: Sales of sunflower seeds have financed the conversion of a 70-acre tract of state-owned land into a grassland habitat.
lead_paragraph: Farmers and wildlife advocates don’t often see eye to eye; each can look at a field and see widely divergent possibilities. Yet by encouraging farmers to plant fields of flowers, an innovative program in New Jersey is helping to finance the rehabilitation of wildlife areas for endangered species of birds.

headline: Political Hurdles Clog Spain’s Path Out of Debt

headline: No, Nicki Minaj Did Not Endorse Mitt Romney

lead_paragraph: Lest there be any lingering confusion: sometimes performers say things in the context of their work that they do not mean literally – political endorsements included.

headline: Head Injury to Revis Could Leave Jets Vulnerable
abstract: Darrelle Revis’s availability for Sunday’s game in Pittsburgh was cast into doubt Monday when the Jets announced that he sustained a “mild” concussion in their season-opening victory against Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A newcomer to football whose only exposure to the sport consisted of the Jets’ victory Sunday might have come away convinced that Mark Sanchez is an elite quarterback, better than those Manning fellows; that Austin Howard resembled a young Dan Dierdorf at right tackle; and that a sculptor would be visiting team headquarters this week to survey the rookie receiver Stephen Hill’s facial features — you know, for his Hall of Fame bust.

headline: After Summer of Turmoil, Oxford American Appoints Roger Hodge Editor
abstract: Mr. Hodge, a veteran of the New York media world and former editor of Harper’s magazine, replaces Marc Smirnoff, who founded the Oxford American in 1992 but was fired in July.
lead_paragraph: After enduring weeks of unflattering attention over the firing of its editor, The Oxford American has hired a successor: Roger D. Hodge, a Texas-born editor and veteran of New York media.

headline: Wisconsin Ranks First in Extreme Heat
abstract: The most blistering, record-breaking heat was concentrated in the middle of the country.
lead_paragraph: Which state had the most extreme heat this summer? Wisconsin, according to the organization Climate Central.

headline: Chuck Close Makes Art in a Fund-Raiser for Obama
abstract: The New Yorker report that Mr. Close is creating tapestries and prints based on different images of Mr. Obama to raise money for the Obama Victory Fund.
lead_paragraph: Actors aren’t the only stars trying to help the president get elected. Artists are doing their bit, too. In a Talk of the Town piece in this week’s New Yorker, Calvin Tomkins reports that Chuck Close — who made a tapestry based on a larger-than-life size portrait of the president that was on view at the Mint Museum in Charlotte, N.C., throughout the Democratic National Convention — is making other artworks to raise money for the Obama campaign.

headline: Member of Manhattan Political Royalty Celebrates a Birthday
abstract: The Hell’s Kitchen Democratic club still evokes the Tammany Hall era, and an annual gathering honoring James McManus, its fourth-generation leader, drew a crowd.
lead_paragraph: It had the feel of a nominating convention, or an Election Day victory party. The big-name Manhattan politicians were there, and so were hundreds of rank-and-file voters. Hundreds of balloons lined the ceiling, the food and drink were free, and a jazz combo belted out “Happy Days Are Here Again.”

lead_paragraph: The voting is now closed in our Bug Beauty Contest, and the results are staggering: the three grasshoppers in the pageant took home the gold, silver and bronze medals (tiaras?). The Colorful Eupropacris Grasshopper edged out Toxic Grasshopper No. 1 with 2,289 votes to 2,143. Toxic Grasshopper No. 2 hopped into third place with 740 votes.

headline: Doubts on Ginkgo Biloba as a Memory Aid
abstract: A new randomized placebo-controlled study by French researchers indicates that ginkgo biloba extract does not work as a preventive for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Ginkgo biloba extract is widely marketed as a preventive for Alzheimer’s disease, but a new randomized placebo-controlled study indicates it does not work.

headline: GoDaddy Goes Down, and a Hacker Takes Credit
abstract: A supporter of Anonymous, the loose hacking collective, claimed responsibility for an attack that apparently brought down Web sites hosted by Go Daddy. The company’s site was down Monday afternoon, as were many of the Web sites hosted on its servers.
lead_paragraph: 1:07 p.m., Sept. 11 | Updated  GoDaddy now says its problems were not hacker-related.

headline: Earlier Mass Extinction for Most of Marine Life
keywords: ['Paleontology', 'Volcanoes', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Dinosaurs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: A volcanic eruption in India may have been responsible for the disappearance of many marine animals about 200,000 years before the dinosaurs met their end.
lead_paragraph: Most scientists agree that dinosaurs became extinct as a result of a catastrophic meteor strike 65 million years ago near the Yucatán Peninsula.

headline: Stagehands and Merkin Concert Hall Wrangle Over Contract
abstract: A dispute over a strike clause is holding up an agreement.
lead_paragraph: The stagehands union and Merkin Concert Hall are close to sealing their first contract, but a dispute over the language in a strike clause has kept the two sides apart. The union, Local One of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, said it would set up picket lines and inflatable rats on Tuesday and Wednesday mornings. Merkin has already begun paying stagehands at the higher negotiated rates and put in place new work rules. But a final agreement remains elusive after nearly a year of negotiations.

headline: Metabolic Syndrome and the Teenage Brain
abstract: A combination of disorders that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes and is associated with cognitive deficiencies in adults now shows a similar effect in teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Metabolic syndrome, the combination of disorders that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes, is known to be associated with brain changes and cognitive deficiencies in adults. Now a new study, published online in Pediatrics, has found a similar effect in teenagers with the disorder.

headline: Families, Responders Get View of Exhibition Planned for 9/11 Museum
abstract: Victims’ families and first responders were given an advance showing of the memorial exhibition that is planned for the National September 11 Memorial and Museum Foundation.
lead_paragraph: The September 11 museum gave victims’ families and first responders a preview Monday of the memorial exhibition that will eventually be the main attraction in the underground museum at the World Trade Center plaza.

headline: Without Alcohol, Red Wine Is Still Beneficial
abstract: A study from Spain concludes that the blood-pressure-lowering effects of red wine come from the beneficial chemicals called polyphenols that it contains, though alcohol may limit their effects.
lead_paragraph: Drinking red wine may help lower blood pressure, but a new study from Spain suggests that alcohol is not the reason.

headline: Vets and Physicians Find Research Parallels
abstract: Researchers are turning their attention to the naturally occurring diseases in dogs, horses, sheep and pigs, whose physiology and anatomy more closely resemble that of humans.

headline: Alexander Skarsgard Answers Your Questions
abstract: The actor Alexander Skarsgard, at the Toronto film festival to promote “What Maisie Knew,” answers reader questions.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO— During our time at the Toronto International Film Festival, we’ve been talking to filmmakers and actors and, on this occasion, taking some of your questions with us. On Saturday, we solicited questions for Alexander Skarsgard, who plays the Teutonic vampire Eric Northman in the HBO series “True Blood” and is here to promote “What Maisie Knew,” an adaptation of the Henry James novel set in New York City. We received quite a number of varied questions and chose a selection to ask the Swedish-born Mr. Skarsgard, whose character, Lincoln, is a bartender who gets caught up in a nasty custody battle after he marries Julianne Moore’s Susanna. Below are his responses.

headline: Door to Door in the Heartland, Preaching Healthy Living
keywords: ['Obesity', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: With money allocated by the Obama health care law, local governments are creating programs to help curb the incidence of obesity and other diseases and promote healthy lifestyles.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Like a missionary, Michael Bailey, a county health worker, spends his days driving his beat-up Nissan around this city’s poorest neighborhood, spreading the word in barber shops and convenience stores about the benefits of healthy diet and exercise. “Look at the kids,” he said. “Overweight, huffing and wheezing. Their lives will be miserable if this doesn’t change.”

headline: A Messy, Exuberant Case Against Being Too Clean
abstract: Has a loss of intestinal bacteria caused our immune systems to go haywire? Moises Velasquez-Manoff lays out the hygiene hypothesis.
lead_paragraph: Never fall in love. Oh, well, go ahead, if you must, but make sure you fall for a living being. A romance with anything else, be it a pair of shoes or a scientific theory, is only asking for trouble, so seldom will the inanimate beloved live up to your besotted expectations.

headline: Miles Enjoys L.S.U.’s Victories but Would Like More Turnovers
abstract: The Tigers have won two games by a combined score of 82-17, but have forced just three turnovers.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Louisiana State’s defense dominated Washington on Saturday — scaring its quarterback, smothering its running game — but Coach Les Miles, perhaps grasping for motivation, said he wished the Tigers bullied the Huskies into more turnovers too.

lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The lioness lay sleeping in the bed of a dark green pickup, her eyes covered with a soft blue cloth, as a veterinarian in camouflage stood over her. “Ni kubwa!” he said in Swahili: “She’s big!”

The inaugural 2012 Berkeley-Rupp Architecture Professorship and Prize, awarded by the University of California, Berkeley’s College of Environmental Design, was announced Monday.

headline: Does Mitt Romney Deserve Credit for Bin Laden’s Death?
abstract: Some Ohio Republicans say he does.
lead_paragraph: The obvious answer to the question in the headline is no, he doesn’t. But Public Policy Polling has a new survey suggesting that six percent of Ohioans, and 15 percent of Ohio Republicans, think Mitt Romney “deserves more credit” for the killing of Osama bin Laden than Barack Obama.

headline: Romney’s Post-Convention Predicament
abstract: Trailing after the convention, the Republican nominee needs to emulate George W. Bush in 2004.
lead_paragraph: To my admittedly non-expert eye, today’s 7-day rolling averages from Gallup and Rasmussen suggests that President Obama’s polling numbers leaped upward after Bill Clinton’s epic speech (and maybe Michelle Obama’s as well) at last week’s Democratic convention and have held pretty much steady since. If the Democratic ticket had received extra boost from the president’s own remarks last Thursday, one would have expected his numbers to keep climbing over the weekend. Instead, his Monday advantage looks a lot like his Saturday advantage, which suggests either that 1) viewers were as underwhelmed as I was by Obama’s performance, 2) there’s a ceiling on the president’s poll numbers that no bounce can break through, or 3) Friday’s mediocre jobs number prevented the bounce from bouncing higher.

headline: Stalinists on the Scrimmage Line
abstract: Oh noes — we’ve been found out.
lead_paragraph: I gotta say, it’s hard being an enemy of American values when George Will is on the case. Last year he uncovered our plot to undermine individualism by making people ride trains; now he’s uncovered our long-term strategy of inculcating collectivist values through, um, college football.

headline: Champions Are Floored by Their Victories

lead_paragraph: Tests commonly recommended to screen healthy women for ovarian cancer do more harm than good and should not be performed, a panel of medical experts said on Monday.

But the actual runway at the show today looked as smooth and wet as a slick of black oil, so you could imagine the designer Olivier Theyskens was playing with textures, or something like thats.

The proto-S.U.V., said to have chauffeured Churchill around his estate in his later years, is scheduled to hit the auction block on Oct. 20 in Sutton, near Cambridge, England.

headline: The Time I Played for a Championship at the 1977 U.S. Open
abstract: The 2012 U.S. Open goes away for good today, but compelling as this year’s tournament has been, it won’t challenge the 1977 edition, when I got to play.
lead_paragraph: The 2012 U.S. Open goes away for good today, but as compelling as this year’s tournament has been, it won’t challenge the 1977 edition — the last to be held at Forest Hills and chronicled by Michael Steinberger two weeks ago — as the craziest U.S. Open ever. It also makes this the 35th consecutive year without a mixed singles champion.

headline: In a Setback, Sanofi’s Dengue Fever Vaccine Falls Short of Its Goal
abstract: Sanofi Pasteur’s vaccine results were called “a huge breakthrough” despite an effectiveness rate of only 30 percent.
lead_paragraph: The leading candidate to become the world’s first vaccine against dengue fever was only 30 percent effective in its first large clinical trial, dealing at least a temporary setback to efforts to control a disease that threatens half the world’s population.

headline: Piano and Cello in Beethoven Dialogues
abstract: Bargemusic, the floating concert hall, hosted an appealing lineup that included the cellist Edward Arron and the pianist Jeewon Park playing Beethoven.
lead_paragraph: Before the late 18th century sonatas for keyboard and a second instrument did not exist as we now know them. Rather than featuring the other player, the works would usually be written and billed as keyboard sonatas with instrumental accompaniment; the cellist in what we would now think of as a cello sonata would often simply mimic the left hand of the keyboard part.

headline: Treasury’s A.I.G. Stock Sale Is Priced at $32.50

headline: Thom Browne in His Bauhaus Period
abstract: Walking into Thom Browne’s women’s presentation at the New York Public Library, I thought, that’s it, he’s finally lost his mind.
lead_paragraph: Walking into Thom Browne’s women’s presentation at the New York Public Library, I thought, that’s it, he’s finally lost his mind. Nine or more handsome men wearing gray seersucker suits were lined against a backdrop of funhouse mirrors, each with a bulbous silver turban propped upon his head. One was plonking away on a xylophone. Then came the women with their hair in stiff orbs, a troupe in conical dresses pirouetting on round platforms painted with black and white spirals.

headline: Mostly Blue Skies Keep the Clouds in Perspective
abstract: Barbara Carroll, still at the piano and microphone at 87, celebrates experience as well as love and optimism.
lead_paragraph: There are few sights more heartening than an 87-year-old musician in complete musical command leaning back at the piano and singing, “I’m in love again” with a rapturous sigh of exultation. That performer, seen on Sunday afternoon at 54 Below, was the elegant jazz pianist and singer Barbara Carroll. Her transition from the defunct Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel to the recently opened 54 Below along with her longtime bassist, Jay Leonhart, has been seamless.

headline: Passions Smolder at Factory for Bombs

lead_paragraph: “Bomb Girls” has a serviceable premise: a group of women bond while working at a Canadian munitions factory in the early years of World War II. It promises emotion and uplift along the lines of “The Life and Times of Rosie the Riveter” or “Swing Shift,” but with the added suspense of wondering whether everyone is going to be blown to smithereens.

headline: Horses’ Ability to Pace Is Written in DNA
abstract: Researchers in Sweden have discovered a single gene that could explain why some horses can trot or pace and why others cannot, a finding that could greatly affect harness racing.
lead_paragraph: Eadweard Muybridge, an English photographer, settled a bet in 1872 by showing, with a single photographic negative, that a horse has four feet off the ground at the trot. This evidence was groundbreaking for photography, and now, 140 years later, trotting horses have yielded another breakthrough, this time in the field of genetics.

headline: Bets on European Bonds Paying Off for Funds

headline: Ron Taylor Dies at 78; Filmed Sharks for ‘Jaws’

headline: Spinning for Dollars

Instead, Romney didn’t get a bounce — but Obama did. It’s far from over, but at this point Obama is the clear favorite to win.

headline: Albert Marre, Director, Is Dead at 87

lead_paragraph: Albert Marre, the Tony Award-winning director of the original Broadway production of “Man of La Mancha” — and three of its four Broadway revivals — died in Manhattan on Sept. 4. He was 87.

headline: Obama Nominates Envoy to Iraq
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States International Relations']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced Monday that he would nominate Robert Stephen Beecroft, a career diplomat, as the next ambassador to Iraq after his first choice was forced to withdraw after the disclosure of racy e-mail messages.

headline: Ecuadoreans Close Ranks in Assange Standoff
abstract: While some Ecuadoreans have only a vague idea of who Julian Assange is, they are clear in their pleasure that their country stood up to Britain in the asylum dispute.
lead_paragraph: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador — Juan José Illingworth has English bona fides that are hard to beat. He is the sixth-generation namesake of an Englishman who became one of Ecuador’s national heroes, fighting for independence from Spain, helping to lead the young nation, founding its naval academy and drafting the law that freed the country’s slaves.

keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hit-and-Run Drivers', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']

headline: New York Is Lagging as Seas and Risks Rise, Critics Warn
abstract: New York City is facing up to the threats posed by rising seas and flooding in the subway system during severe storms, but the city is years away from — and billions of dollars short of — armoring itself.
lead_paragraph: With a 520-mile-long coast lined largely by teeming roads and fragile infrastructure, New York City is gingerly facing up to the intertwined threats posed by rising seas and ever-more-severe storm flooding.

headline: China Contractor Again Faces Labor Issue on iPhones

keywords: ['Referendums', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Income Tax', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Education (K-12)']

headline: D’Souza Responds
abstract: Reader comments about a new documentary by Dinesh D’Souza are relayed to the filmmaker, who replies.
lead_paragraph: Ninety-nine percent of the more than 500 readers who responded to my account of Dinesh D’Souza’s blockbuster documentary “2016: Obama’s America” objected both to D’Souza’s arguments and to my taking them seriously. The editors and I thought it might be useful if D’Souza replied to the most-often-voiced objections. He and I sat down last Thursday for the following interview. — S. F.

And the reading of names, whether to honor the three victims from Nutley, N.J., or the nearly 3,000 others from around the world who died in the attacks.

headline: Verghese Kurien, Leader of India’s Milk Cooperatives, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Kurien helped thousands of dairy farmers create cooperatives to produce and market milk, reducing hunger and poverty and eventually transforming India into the world’s largest milk producer.
lead_paragraph: Verghese Kurien, an engineer who led India’s so-called White Revolution, in which he helped thousands of dairy farmers create cooperatives to produce and market milk, reducing hunger and poverty and eventually transforming India into the world’s largest milk producer, died on Sunday in Nadiad, in the western Indian state of Gujarat. He was 90.

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday that he would be open to seeking changes in one of the signature achievements of his time as governor, a new state ethics commission, as a former member of the panel warned of “possible illegality and corruption” and other commissioners worried that the body was losing its credibility.

Lack of coordination at every point in the health care system is a big culprit.

headline: Munnu Kasliwal, a Favorite Jeweler of Connoisseurs, Dies at 54
abstract: Mr. Kasliwal’s designs were sold in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, collected by European royals and prized by celebrities, who were drawn to his sometimes monumental gems.
lead_paragraph: From an old mansion on Mirza Ismail Road in Jaipur, India, the jeweler Munnu Kasliwal presided over an unlikely global empire. To the broader public Mr. Kasliwal’s name was not nearly as familiar as those of Cartier or Harry Winston, but his family-owned emporium, the Gem Palace, has for decades been a valued secret passed along via word of mouth by international connoisseurs.

headline: The Unexpected Impact of Coded Appeals
abstract: College-educated whites are simultaneously more racially tolerant and more likely to express the racial resentment that they do feel politically.
lead_paragraph: After signing into law the landmark Civil Rights Act of 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson famously told an aide, “we just delivered the South to the Republican Party for a long time to come.” Indeed, the Johnson-Goldwater contest was notable in two important respects related to race: it featured the first appearance in almost a century of racial animus as a central dimension of partisan conflict in a presidential election, and it was the last time a Democrat received a majority of the white vote.

headline: Knicks Add Shooting Forward
abstract: The Knicks signed John Shurna, a sweet-shooting forward from Northwestern, to a one-year contract, said his agent, Mark Bartelstein.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks signed John Shurna, a sweet-shooting forward from Northwestern, to a one-year contract, said his agent, Mark Bartelstein. The deal is partly guaranteed. Shurna, who stands 6 feet 10 inches, converted 44 percent of his 3-pointers last season at Northwestern while averaging 20 points a game. He is frequently compared to the Knicks’ Steve Novak because of his height and shooting ability. With Shurna, the Knicks have 16 players under contract, counting training camp invitees.
