headline: Marc Jacobs: Sex Talk in a Straight Package
abstract: With Marc Jacobs’s new collection, for the first time in a while, a designer has successfully pushed the sex button in a compelling way.
lead_paragraph: “There’s nothing sexier than a girl covered up,” Marc Jacobs said on Monday night after his spring show, which featured a spree of suits with below-the-knee skirts worn low on the hips, leaving a vast expanse of midriff. Many of these outfits came in wide vertical stripes — black, maroon, taupe — with matching purses and dippy little shoes with low heels. Conventional office attire. The models’ hair was ratted at the crown and pulled into a low ponytail. Their eyebrows were penciled thick, and they wore an insolent pout. The music was from The Fall, the British post-punk band.

headline: Soccer’s Not-So-Great Wall
abstract: Forming a wall of players in front of the goal remains a common but imperfect way to defend free kicks, as the United States learned in its World Cup qualifier loss to Jamaica.

headline: For Handcyclist, Paralympics Are a Stirring Triumph

lead_paragraph: BRANDS HATCH, England — He averaged just a fraction under 20 miles per hour for the two-hour handcycle road race, and he reached a maximum speed, running downhill, of 46 m.p.h. He did it on this track famous for the Grand Prix races run here in the years before he became a marquee name in Formula One and IndyCar racing.

headline: Murray, Battling More Than Djokovic, Clears All Obstacles
abstract: In his five-set win over Novak Djokovic, Andy Murray had myriad foes to defeat in this final, most significantly the expectations put upon him in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare’s quote “Sweet are the uses of adversity” is what came to mind as I watched Andy Murray triumph over his longtime nemesis Novak Djokovic in five grueling sets to win the United States Open, his first Grand Slam, and the first for a British man since Fred Perry in 1936. Murray had myriad foes to defeat in this final, most significantly the expectations put upon him in Britain, where his every match is an indicator of national well-being. This victory comes on the heels of his breakthrough win over Roger Federer on Centre Court at Wimbledon in the gold medal match of the London Olympics.

headline: The Risks of Hosting a Successful Olympics
abstract: London’s wildly successful Games may have others thinking that if they can host a successful global event their country’s image will soar. Not true. Ask South Africa. And Brazil?
lead_paragraph: After London’s triumphant Olympic Games and Paralympics, I’m sure that most of the foreign government officials who descended on London went away fervently believing that if only they too can win the chance to host a major event, and pull it off successfully, this will catapult their nation into the realms of international celebrity. But research suggests otherwise.

headline: Lehman Brothers, We Heard You Were Dead
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: It’s time to forget about the bank that almost destroyed the world.
lead_paragraph: Lehman Brothers is having a great year. The bank, which almost destroyed the global economy four years ago this week, recently emerged from bankruptcy, resolved a third of its debts and executed the largest U.S. real estate deal of the year. Today, the company appears an awful lot like a normal investment bank. Its trading floor — on one of the two floors Lehman occupies in the Time & Life Building in Midtown Manhattan — is filled with dozens of young people who stare at financial graphs on Bloomberg terminals and talk in the hallways about the deals they’re working on.

headline: With Extra Frames, a Chinese Photographer Looks Inward
abstract: The photographer Li Zhensheng, whose images of the Chinese Cultural Revolution are getting fresh attention, turned the camera on himself using frames left on a roll.
lead_paragraph: Li Zhensheng, a newspaper photographer who was active in the 1960s in northern China, documented the country’s Cultural Revolution, in honest, cinematic images.

headline: When Have You Ever Succeeded When You Thought You Might Fail?
abstract: Have you ever come from behind and surprised yourself with greatness, whether on the field, in school or in some other aspect of your life?
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams just won the United States Open women’s singles title, after fending off a match point — not to mention 11 months of injuries and health concerns that plagued her during the last two years. Have you ever come from behind and surprised yourself with greatness, whether on the field, in school or in some other aspect of your life? When have you ever managed to perform better than you imagined?

headline: NATO Copter Destroyed by Taliban at Base
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Three Afghan service personnel were killed on board the helicopter, which was parked inside Bagram Air Base.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A coalition heavy-transport helicopter parked inside the sprawling Bagram Air Base was hit and destroyed by insurgent fire late Monday, killing three Afghan service members who were on board, NATO said Tuesday.

headline: Qatar Holding Makes Glencore Wait on Revised Xstrata Bid
abstract: The sovereign wealth fund Qatar Holding says it has yet to decide whether to support Glencore International’s increased all-share offer for the mining giant Xstrata.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Glencore International, the world’s biggest commodities trader, will have to wait a bit longer to see whether its increased all-share offer for the mining giant Xstrata will be backed by one of that company’s largest shareholders.

headline: Launching an American College Search from Africa, By Web and Word of Mouth
abstract: Maimuna Abdi Yussuf, a Somali student at African Leadership Academy in Johannesburg, South Africa, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had my life all figured out since I was ten. The plan? Finish primary school with the best scores so that I could get into a national high school. Once there, I would work even harder to get the best grades so that I could gain admission into the University of Nairobi Law School.

headline: Mitt Romney, Carried Interest and Capital Gains
abstract: A device used by money managers to lower their tax liability is a loophole that can be closed without abandoning the lower tax rate for capital gains, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Kicking Off the Fall TV Season
abstract: Looking ahead at the new fall television season.
lead_paragraph: Ladies and gentlemen, start your DVRs.

headline: A Closer Look at the Replacement Refs
abstract: The N.F.L. replacement officials did not steal an inordinate amount of attention from the players on the field in Week 1.
lead_paragraph: It was an uneventful Week 1, in a good way, as the N.F.L. replacement referees did not steal much attention from the players on the field.

headline: Women’s Golf Money Leader Could End U.S. Drought
abstract: This weekend, as the L.P.G.A. heads into the year’s final major, the Women’s British Open, Stacy Lewis has the chance to record the finest season by an American woman in nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: Stacy Lewis froze when a reporter broke the news to her on live television: By winning at the ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic in June, her second victory in three events, she had climbed to No. 3 in the world rankings and supplanted Cristie Kerr as the top-ranked American on the Ladies Professional Golfers’ Association Tour.

headline: Warhol Has Your Mac Products Covered
abstract: The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, working with Incase, has borrowed the graphics from one of Warhol’s most famous works, the sculpture Brillo Boxes, to make covers for the MacBook, iPad and iPhone 4S. It’s the sixth in the foundation’s Warhol series.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to wait for The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts auction of 20,000 Andy Warhol works to claim a bit of Andy-bilia.

headline: How I Interview Job Candidates
abstract: I want candidates to pitch me! If they don’t seem passionate about our mission and vision — or worse, if they don’t know what we do — the interview is over.
lead_paragraph: Job interviews can range from lengthy, committee-type processes that take months to quick sit-downs with quick decisions. While the former is appropriate for senior positions, I don’t think it is necessary for most employees.

headline: Anatomy of a Campus Coup
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Philanthropy', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: What does the failed ouster of Teresa Sullivan, the University of Virginia’s president, mean for higher education?
lead_paragraph: On a languorous Sunday in June, low season on the campus of the University of Virginia, Prof. Larry Sabato opened a perplexing e-mail. “My instant reaction,” he said, “was that I thought we’d been hacked.” The message, sent to the entire university, announced the resignation of the university’s president, Teresa Sullivan, obliquely citing a “philosophical difference of opinion” with the institution’s governing board. Sullivan had held the job for just two years, without any scandal, and Sabato couldn’t believe she had been pushed aside with so little evident justification. “I said that if this was true,” he recalled, “this was going to be a P.R. disaster of national proportions.”

headline: Burberry Warns of Weakness in Luxury Market
abstract: The announcement was taken as a sign that slower growth in China and the European debt crisis are ending a global boom in luxury goods.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Burberry, the iconic British fashion retailer, sent shock waves through the global luxury industry on Tuesday, saying that it had begun to see signs of weakness in the market and that its annual profit would probably disappoint investors.

abstract: The Financial Services Authority of Britain has fined BlackRock for failing to follow rules governing the protection of its clients’ money.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British authorities have fined the giant money manager BlackRock £9.5 million for failing to protect some of its clients’ money.

headline: Daily Report: Chinese Plant Faces New Labor Issue on iPhones
abstract: As Apple prepares to unveil its latest iPhone this week, the company’s manufacturing partner in China, Foxconn Technology, is coming under renewed criticism over labor practices. Foxconn is accused of compelling vocational students to work at plants making iPhones, report David Barboza and Charles Duhigg in Tuesday’s New York Times.
lead_paragraph: As Apple prepares to unveil its latest iPhone this week, the company’s manufacturing partner in China, Foxconn Technology, is coming under renewed criticism over labor practices. Foxconn has been accused of compelling vocational students to work at plants making iPhones and their components, report David Barboza and Charles Duhigg in Tuesday’s New York Times.

abstract: The discovery of the Braken Bat Cave meshweaver halts construction at a highway underpass project in San Antonio.

headline: How to Cover the 11th Anniversary of 9/11?
abstract: The pain continues, but the journalism comes to an end. How does The Times continue to remember the anniversary of Sept. 11?
lead_paragraph: The pain, the outrage, the loss – these never fade. The amount of journalism, however, must. This is the 11th anniversary of Sept. 11, 2001 – that infamous date in the history of New York, the nation and the world. Last year, on the 10th anniversary, The Times produced a huge special treatment – an elaborate Web presence and an ambitious special section, along with major stories on the days leading up to the anniversary.

abstract: The designer Umit Benan Sahin describes a few of his favorite spots in the city by the Bosporus.

headline: Save the Subjunctive!
abstract: A critique of grammar, style and usage in The Times. This week: a verb form in peril.
lead_paragraph: The peril is not new. Indeed, one Ida M. Mason warned darkly of the danger in the pages of The Times back in 1924.

headline: Broken Windows and the iPhone 5
abstract: Bully for obsolescence.
lead_paragraph: There’s been some buzz about a report suggesting that the iPhone 5 could, all by itself, give a significant boost to the US economy. I can’t judge how plausible the sales estimates are; but it’s worth pointing out how the economic logic of this suggestion relates to the larger picture.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Early Music Lessons Have Longtime Benefits
abstract: Early music lessons have longtime benefits, ovarian cancer screenings that are ineffective, inescapable in-flight entertainment and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Born on Sept. 11
abstract: Long before the terrorist attacks in 2001, events on Sept. 11 carried a special significance for a man whose birthday was that date.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: In Lower Manhattan, Assembling to Remember 9/11
abstract: On a sun-drenched Tuesday, relatives, emergency workers and dignitaries assemble in Lower Manhattan to commemorate what happened 11 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The bagpipes began filling the 9/11 Memorial plaza with sound a little after 7:30 a.m., readying for the procession that will begin New York’s 11th anniversary commemoration of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks at 8:39 a.m. on a cool Tuesday. Halfway between the rising towers of 1 World Trade Center and 4 World Trade Center, which stand at opposite corners of the memorial quadrangle, an honor guard of policemen and firemen held up an American flag and slowly marched away.

headline: U.N. Details Flows of Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In “an extraordinary acceleration,” the U.N. refugee agency said Tuesday, the number of people fleeing Syria jumped from 18,500 in June to 35,000 in July to 102,000 in August.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As fighting continues in Syria, an “extraordinary acceleration” in movements of refugees is compounding the difficulties for humanitarian relief efforts, the United Nations refugee agency said on Tuesday.

headline: The Moving Middle
abstract: Where’s the top?
lead_paragraph: Just a quick note: Ezra Klein goes through Martin Feldstein’s attempt to defend the Romney tax plan against the charge that it’s mathematically impossible to make the numbers add up without raising taxes on the middle class, and concludes that it depends on big tax increases on people making between 100K and 200K a year — and hence on the assertion that people with incomes even slightly over 100K aren’t middle class.

headline: Teachers’ Leader in Chicago Strike Shows Her Edge
abstract: In Karen Lewis, the president of the Chicago Teachers Union, which completed a second day on strike from public schools, Mayor Rahm Emanuel may have met his match.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When it comes to demanding, pushing and sparring, few people could even begin to compare with Rahm Emanuel, the famously foul-mouthed mayor whose no-holds-barred tactics once included sending a dead fish to someone whose work he found lacking.

headline: Ad Campaign Will Encourage People to ‘Love People’
abstract: People magazine is addressing a slump in single copy sales with what executives are calling their most comprehensive advertising campaign to date.
lead_paragraph: People magazine is addressing a slump in single copy sales – issues sold one by one, in venues like newsstands and supermarkets, rather than by annual subscription — with what executives are calling their most comprehensive advertising campaign to date.

headline: The Brute Force Computing Revolution
abstract: The centuries-old scientific and engineering idea of progress through observing, modeling, testing and modifying is under attack. Now it is better to collect and examine lots of data, looking for patterns, and follow up on the most promising. The latest example: Autodesk says designers should generate a thousand product versions.
lead_paragraph: Autodesk has announced that it is selling design simulation software that works online, via Amazon’s AWS cloud service. This continues the company’s move into a lower-paying, hopefully higher-volume, world of mobile devices and cloud computing.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Shu Pei at DKNY
abstract: The model Shu Pei transforms with makeup by Charlotte Willer and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

headline: Happy First Birthday, India Ink
abstract: Looking back at some of the year’s most-read pieces.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, we launched India Ink, The New York Times’s first country-specific blog/news journal, with a promise to provide “more in-depth, on-the-ground coverage of the world’s biggest democracy — and of a people who know that no matter how far they roam, their hearts will always be Indian.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Foxconn’s Use of ‘Interns,’ and Good Nipples, Bad Nipples
abstract: Also, YouTube has a new app for the iPhone, but you have to download it; and as the curtain comes up on Katie Couric’s new daytime talk show, the battle for inheriting Oprah Winfrey’s mantle begins in earnest.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s Chinese manufacturing partner, Foxconn Technology, has come under criticism recently after reports of students being forced to “intern” at the company’s factories that make iPhones and their components, David Barboza and Charles Duhigg report. The reliance on so-called interns — including those studying law or English, worker advocates say — is particularly high as Foxconn attempts to meet demand for the new iPhone 5. “They don’t want to work there — they want to learn,” one advocate said. “But if they don’t work, they are told they will not graduate, because it is a very busy time with the new iPhone coming, and Foxconn does not have enough workers without the students.”

headline: China Accuses Japan of Stealing After Purchase of Group of Disputed Islands
abstract: The charge comes after Japan bought the islands in the East China Sea for nearly $30 million from private owners.
lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — The Chinese government accused Japan on Tuesday of stealing a group of disputed islands in the East China Sea, hours after the Japanese government announced that it had bought them from their private Japanese owners for nearly $30 million.

headline: T-Mobile USA Says Bring Us Your iPhones
abstract: T-Mobile USA is the one major carrier in the United States that has not had a deal with Apple to sell iPhones to its customers. But it is aiming to take advantage of the iPhone by introducing a marketing campaign aimed at people who want to bring older versions of the iPhone to T-Mobile’s network.
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile USA is the one major carrier in the United States that has not had a deal with Apple to sell iPhones to its customers. That will not change when Apple introduces a new iPhone this week. But T-Mobile is still aiming to take advantage of the iPhone by introducing a new marketing campaign aimed at people who want to bring older versions of the iPhone to T-Mobile’s network.

headline: University Ranking Shows Boom in Global Student Mobility
abstract: More and more university students are choosing to study abroad, according to a new league table ranking the world’s top academic institutions. Is it a positive trend and how important are the rankings in picking the right school?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The compilers of a leading league table of the world’s top universities on Tuesday reported an “unstoppable rise” in the numbers of students choosing to travel abroad to study.

headline: As Another Anniversary Passes, Still Waiting for Justice
abstract: The Day: Today, politicians may speak about the strength of this country’s institutions and how no terrorist could make us afraid, but that last part will not reflect reality.
lead_paragraph: On another Sept. 11 morning with skies so blue you could hurt your eyes as well as your heart looking at them, the annual remembrance of the city’s worst day echoed across the space where the twin towers once stood.

headline: The Casino Is Coming to Town
abstract: The government of Madrid hocked too much public trust to lure to the city a mega gambling project with uncertain financing.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — On Friday, the American casino magnate Sheldon Adelson announced that he’d chosen Madrid over Barcelona to host EuroVegas, a multibillion-dollar casino and resort complex. For months the two cities, both desperate for jobs, had competed to court him and his company, Las Vegas Sands.

headline: Remembering 9/11 at the White House
abstract: The president and the first lady paused to remember victims of the Sept. 11 attacks at the White House.
lead_paragraph: In Washington, President Obama and his wife, Michelle, observed a moment of silence on the South Lawn of the White House at approximately 8:46 a.m., the minute American Airlines Flight 11 hit the north tower 11 years ago. They were joined by hundreds of members of the White House staff and a full Marine color guard. A Marine trumpeter signaled the end of the ceremony by playing taps.

headline: A Somber Reading of the Names of the Dead
abstract: A simple act, the reading of the names of those killed 11 years ago, continues to evoke strong emotions.
lead_paragraph: Though they were not to speak, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani created a small stir when they arrived shortly before the ceremony was to begin. They stopped together about 10 yards from the platform where 200 readers, reciting the names of the dead, were to stand at lecterns.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The Economist: Tracking the explosion in the number of American craft distilleries: a decade ago there were 24, and now there are more than 200. Their vodka, gin, rum, rye and whiskey is claiming a greater share of the once-moribund spirits market – and 16 states have voted to repeal bans on Sunday alcohol sales in the last decade. – Glenn Collins

headline: Morgan Stanley to Take Over Smith Barney, With Citigroup’s Blessing
abstract: Morgan Stanley and Citigroup agreed on Tuesday to value their brokerage joint venture, Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, at $13.5 billion, allowing Morgan Stanley to buy full control of the business at a favorable valuation.
lead_paragraph: 9:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: Projects Without Architects Steal the Show
abstract: The 13th Venice Architecture Biennale makes a nod to urbanism and collaboration, though big-name designers hog much of the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Save for a few projects and pavilions, probably the less said, the better, about “Common Ground,” the 13th Venice Architecture Biennale, organized by the fine British architect David Chipperfield.

headline: A Quiet and Solemn Day of Remembrance
abstract: President Obama and Mitt Romney make no public remarks, but release statements honoring those that died on Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: 10:53 a.m. | Updated SHANKSVILLE, Pa. — On another Tuesday morning with another clear, late-summer sky that seemed eerily familiar, the nation’s leaders briefly put aside a divisive political campaign to mark the anniversary of the worst terrorist attack on American soil.

headline: Portion of Suit Over Warhol’s Velvet Underground Banana Is Discarded
abstract: The legal battle over a 45-year-old banana – in this case, one that Andy Warhol created for the debut album by the Velvet Underground – can continue, even after a federal judge threw out a portion of the suit brought by the band against Warhol’s foundation.
lead_paragraph: The legal battle over a 45-year-old banana — in this case, one that Andy Warhol created for the debut album by the Velvet Underground — can continue, even after a federal judge threw out a portion of the suit brought by the band against Warhol’s foundation.

headline: Licensing Rules Slow Tours to Cuba
abstract: Tour operators worry that recent changes to licensing rules could spell the end of an important cultural exchange between Americans and Cubans.
lead_paragraph: AS part of a newly approved “people to people” tour in Cuba last summer, a group of Americans met with 40 blind Havana residents, who welcomed them with poetry and conversation. Then, Cubans being Cubans, four of them pulled out instruments and within minutes, arms and legs were intertwined as Americans and Cubans danced with abandon in the front yard of Cuba’s National Association for the Blind.

headline: How Politicians Are Marking the 11th Anniversary
abstract: Political reporters describe how President Obama, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Mitt Romney plan to honor victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. Read more on The Caucus.
lead_paragraph: Peter Baker and Ashley Parker, two political reporters for The New York Times, describe how President Obama, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Mitt Romney plan to honor victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Read their coverage from Illinois and Pennsylvania on The Caucus.

headline: In Chicago, a Test for Organized Labor
abstract: Business Day Live: What the teachers’ strike in Chicago means for organized labor. | Morgan Stanley’s deal with Citigroup for a brokerage.
lead_paragraph: Business Day Live: What the teachers’ strike in Chicago means for organized labor. | Morgan Stanley’s deal with Citigroup for a brokerage.

headline: Protecting Children From Raw 9/11 Memories
abstract: This morning, colleagues and relief workers who share the grim bond of having worked through twin tower debris are calling to share gentle condolences. But my young sons, walking to school past the new construction there, still don’t know what happened.
lead_paragraph: On the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, it was hard for me to comprehend that a decade had passed since I watched the towers burn in Lower Manhattan. I could still picture the bodies free-falling through the sky like broken twigs. I could still remember the feeling of white tower dust in my mouth. And the smell of burning jet fuel, even just the faintest wisp, would send my body into full-fledged panic.

headline: Business Day Live: In Standoff, Latest Sign of Unions Under Siege
abstract: What the teachers’ strike in Chicago means for organized labor. | Morgan Stanley’s showdown with Citigroup over a brokerage.
lead_paragraph: What the teachers’ strike in Chicago means for organized labor. | Morgan Stanley’s showdown with Citigroup over a brokerage.

headline: Too Much Protection for Derivatives in Bankruptcy
abstract: Several courts have lately been expanding the already broad protections that derivatives and repo contracts enjoy.
lead_paragraph: I have written before about my opinions regarding the “safe harbors” in the bankruptcy code. These are the provisions that exempt derivatives and repo contracts from the automatic stay, the prohibition on termination of contracts with the debtor, the prohibition on constructively fraudulent transfers and the prohibition on obtaining preferential treatment on the eve of bankruptcy.

headline: Britain’s Triumphant Summer
abstract: Andy Murray capped off Britain’s incredible sports summer by breaking through to win his first Grand Slam final.
lead_paragraph: Sure, it came in the wee hours of the morning in Britain, and who knows how many Britons stayed awake to witness it as it happened, but Andy Murray’s victory over Novak Djokovic in a wild United States Open final made it official. Britain owned the summer of sports. Its best cyclist won the Tour de France. It played the triumphant Olympic host to a T, reveling in the spectacle as much as its own success, then moved on to stage a worthy Paralympics. But men’s tennis was an even more daunting frontier, a Grand Slam drought that stretched to 1936, and Murray, well, let’s just say Britain has long taken measure of its rumpled, brooding star and thought, “Oh, bother. ...”

headline: The Growing Might of Solar Power
abstract: Solar installations in the second quarter of this year were more than double those of a year earlier. And the solar energy generated on California’s grid topped one gigawatt for the first time in August.
lead_paragraph: From California to New Jersey, the summer sun was hot this year — and so was the solar industry. While the business of solar energy is still small enough and young enough to record firsts at the fearsome pace of a toddler, the milestones are getting more substantial.

headline: Conversations With Andy Murray: Savoring the Victory
abstract: Andy Murray, the U.S. Open champion, caught up with Straight Sets after he walked back onto the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium for the first time since his victory. He looked back at what he had just done and looked ahead to what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Within hours of winning the United States Open, Andy Murray had done nearly a dozen interviews, posed for thousands of photographs with his trophy, held a news conference, and had done several additional television and radio interviews. He caught up with Straight Sets at a unique moment, after he walked back onto the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium for the first time since his victory. As he stood in the now empty stadium where he had made history, he looked back at what he had just done and looked ahead to what comes next. (All of Murray’s interviews during the tournament can be found here.)

headline: Wheelies: The Rounding-Errors Edition
abstract: Pricing levels at two extremes, the SRT Viper and the Honda Accord, were announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Israeli Sharpens Call for United States to Set Iran Trigger
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the Obama administration for not setting clear “red lines” on Iran’s nuclear progress that would prompt the United States to undertake a military strike.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel inserted himself into the most contentious foreign policy issue of the American presidential campaign on Tuesday, criticizing the Obama administration for refusing to set clear “red lines” on Iran’s nuclear progress that would prompt the United States to undertake a military strike. As a result, he said, the administration has no “moral right” to restrain Israel from taking military action of its own.

headline: U.S. Missile Defense Strategy Is Flawed, Expert Panel Finds
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Scientists and military experts working for the National Research Council are critical of the Obama administration’s strategy and suggest changes to the United States’ antimissile system.
lead_paragraph: After two years of study, a panel of top scientists and military experts working for the National Research Council has concluded that the nation’s protections against missile attacks suffer from major shortcomings, leaving the United States vulnerable to some kinds of long-range strikes.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Marc Jacobs
abstract: Makeup artist Francois Nars’s infatuation with all things Warhol was apparent in this retro-inspired look.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Mod-ular.

headline: Obama Participates in 9/11 Ceremony at the Pentagon
abstract: President Obama stepped off the campaign trail on Tuesday to participate in 9/11 commemorations.
lead_paragraph: At the memorial garden at the Pentagon, President Obama and Michelle Obama participated in a wreath-laying ceremony to honor the 184 people who died when American Airlines Flight 77 slammed into the military headquarters. They were joined by relatives of the victims, members of the military and others.

headline: Image of the Day: September 11
abstract: The Dalai Lama and India’s former president A.P.J. Kalam at a seminar on world peace in New Delhi.

headline: A List of Names, and Words of Remembrance
abstract: As New York’s Sept. 11 ceremony reached its second hour, the relatives of the dead read their family members’ names and shared memories and news.
lead_paragraph: They spoke of mothers and cousins, husbands and brothers-in-law. As New York’s Sept. 11 commemoration ceremony reached its second hour, the relatives of the dead continued to read their family members’ names and those of many others, in voices steady and cracked, strong and shaky.

headline: Gaeton Fonzi, Investigator of Kennedy Assassination, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Fonzi was called Ahab by colleagues who likened his relentless pursuit of details of the Kennedy assassination to the fictional hunt for a white whale.
lead_paragraph: Gaeton Fonzi was one of the most relentless investigators on the House Select Committee on Assassinations in the late 1970s, remembered by former colleagues with both awe and echoes of the impatience he inspired with his pursuit of the full story behind the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 12 in Yemen, but Targeted Minister Escapes Harm
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A blast alongside a convoy of vehicles used by Yemen’s defense minister came one day after a top operative for Al Qaeda in the country was killed.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — A car bomb exploded Tuesday alongside a convoy of vehicles used by Yemen’s defense minister, killing seven bodyguards and five civilians in the heart of the capital, Sana, while the minister escaped unharmed, government and hospital officials said. The attack came one day after a top operative of Al Qaeda in Yemen was killed in what Yemeni officials called an American drone strike.

headline: A Hooters in Queens Is Sued for Racial Discrimination
abstract: A Korean-American customer at a Hooters in Fresh Meadows said he was shocked at the word used to refer to him on his receipt.
lead_paragraph: Hooters, the restaurant chain widely known for the skimpy outfits of its waitresses, has built its reputation in part on its fun-loving and mildly provocative spirit. But a Korean-American customer has accused a Hooters restaurant in Queens of taking that carefree ethos too far and has sued the company for racial discrimination.

headline: A Fix for Tennis Elbow
abstract: In the latest installment of the Phys Ed video series, Gretchen Reynolds tackles the science of tennis elbow and new research that offers a way to relieve the pain.

headline: Ms. Yarrow and the Road to Antietam
abstract: A black woman in Maryland is caught between the armies gathering for the war’s bloodiest day.
lead_paragraph: Looking east across Maryland’s Pleasant Valley on Sept. 11, 1862, Polly Yarrow could see men in Confederate gray coming through Brownsville and Crampton’s Gaps in South Mountain and just a few miles from the 10,000 Union troops garrisoned in and around Harpers Ferry. If the Confederates attacked, which seemed likely, they would take the road that ran by her front door.

headline: Tory Burch’s Slice of American Pie
abstract: For spring, Tory Burch went for a “prep remix,” which meant pulling disparate ideas together in a way that still looks compelling.
lead_paragraph: Good news, shoppers: This has been a great season for daywear, the category most often overlooked by designers of runway fashion. In fact, it’s been such a commercial-friendly spring season in New York that even Marc Jacobs is making what could be described as somewhat office-friendly attire. Of course, that is Tory Burch’s forte, and it was clear at her show this morning that she’s not about to give up any ground.

headline: With Rulings on Rubbish and Tattoos, Safeguarding the City for Centuries
abstract: The Board of Health, an obscure city board that will rule on a proposed ban on large sugary drinks, has had a major influence on the health habits of New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: The 11 largely faceless members of the New York City Board of Health who will decide Thursday whether to ban the sale of super-size sugary soft drinks in certain establishments trace their authority to 1805, when the power to monitor the city’s health was formally vested in a city “inspector,” John Pintard, a Renaissance man who is most famous for popularizing Santa Claus.

headline: Plasma Gasification Raises Hopes of Clean Energy From Garbage
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: This alternative to mass-burn incineration, proponents say, disposes of garbage and toxic contaminants while minimizing emissions and providing electricity and usable byproducts.
lead_paragraph: David Robau tours the country promoting a system that sounds too good to be true: It devours municipal garbage, recycles metals, blasts toxic contaminants and produces electricity and usable byproducts — all with drastic reductions in emissions.

headline: Acupuncture Provides True Pain Relief in Study
abstract: Acupuncture outperformed sham treatments and standard care when used by people suffering from osteoarthritis, migraines and chronic back, neck and shoulder pain.
lead_paragraph: A new study of acupuncture — the most rigorous and detailed analysis of the treatment to date — found that it can ease migraines and arthritis and other forms of chronic pain.

headline: Republican Turf
abstract: The G.O.P. used to dominate on likability, stick-to-it-ive-ness and military toughness. Not any more.
lead_paragraph: For decades Republican presidential candidates have campaigned on stick-to-it-ive-ness, likability and military toughness, and in these areas have generally had the edge on their Democratic opponents.

abstract: The organization is gearing up to recruit a fresh batch of 100 fellows and exploring a handful of cities for expansion in 2013. The long-term objective is to create 100,000 jobs by 2025.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year now, Andrew Yang has been traveling the nation evangelizing Venture for America. From gritty inner cities to college campuses and the White House, the former corporate lawyer has made dozens of stops pitching the nonprofit organization, which he hopes will become a Teach for America for young entrepreneurs.

headline: Nuclear Mullahs, Continued
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Responding to reader comments about how to deal with a nuclear Iran.
lead_paragraph: My column on confronting the prospect of a nuclear-armed Iran seems to have caught a lot of readers by surprise. The surprise ranges from approving (“Thank heavens, at last a voice of sanity!”) to indignant (“Are you out of your [expletive] mind?!?”)

headline: The Fog of War: Helping Students Make Sense of Syria
abstract: In this lesson, students evaluate firsthand accounts of the war in Syria and make judgments about the role President Bashar al-Assad’s government may have played in stoking long-buried sectarian divisions.
lead_paragraph: Overview | How does a multiethnic society come undone, and who’s to blame when it happens? If the “Arab Spring” uprisings across the Middle East inspire hope for democracy, the nearly 18-month-old conflict in Syria raises a darker possibility: civil conflict. Observers say religious and sectarian differences are increasingly fueling a war that has claimed an estimated 20,000 lives, pitting members of the ruling Alawite minority against a fractious Sunni Muslim majority.

headline: Sleep Training Won’t Hurt, Might Help
abstract: My mother called last night to report that researchers have found that a few wails from a baby learning to sleep on her own don’t seem to hurt one bit. She was laughing.
lead_paragraph: My mother may still be laughing.

headline: A Class to Teach You How to Use Google
abstract: Using Google seems simple enough. But the company says that most people are not taking advantage of all the features Google offers, from simple to sophisticated, to make searching more efficient. So it is offering a free online course to teach people how to do a better Google search. Registration starts Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Think you know how to use Google? Think again.

headline: Away From the Piano, He’ll Pick Up His Sketchbook
abstract: Misha Dichter, a concert pianist, is inspired by his view from his Manhattan balcony to take on another pastime — doodling.
lead_paragraph: There is “A Pianist’s World,” and there is the world of a pianist — a world that, at the moment, includes a big, bluish blimp floating across the late-afternoon sky above Central Park. The pianist is sketching it in the colors of the keyboard, black on white paper. “I can’t deal in color,” he says.

headline: Does It Pay to Become a Teacher?
abstract: The average primary school teacher in the United States earns about 67 percent of the salary of an average college-educated worker in the United States. The comparable figure for all of the developed world is 82 percent.

It might help provide some context for what Chicago teachers are fighting over.

headline: What Happens After Midnight in Toronto …
abstract: The Midnight Madness program at the Toronto International Film Festival includes a mixture of blood, action and laughs.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — “Would you like to see a movie with lots of naked witches worshiping goats?” asked Rob Zombie, the musician and filmmaker, as he introduced his latest movie, “The Lords of Salem,” on Monday night. For the amped-up audience at that midnight screening, there was only one answer to that question.Carnage, mayhem and rowdy crowds are the order of the evening during the Toronto International Film Festival’s Midnight Madness program. Those willing to stay up until the wee hours will have the pleasure (or displeasure) of seeing a stream of blood-soaked genre films unspool each night of the festival.

headline: Children’s Book Coming from Jessica Lange
abstract: The Jabberwocky imprint of Sourcebooks has acquired a book called “It Is About a Little Bird,” written by Ms. Lange, the Oscar- and Emmy-winning star of “American Horror Story,” and which will use photographs that she took and illustrated by hand.
lead_paragraph: If you know Jessica Lange only from her Emmy-nominated role as the mother from hell on “American Horror Story” you might think twice before sharing her handiwork with offspring of your own. But performers are not their characters — nor has Ms. Lange ever worked on a soap opera with a co-star who turned out to be Dustin Hoffman in drag — and now this Oscar- and Emmy-winning actress is about to become the author of a picture book for young readers.

abstract: Jerry Garrett recalls a drive in 2001 with Zanardi, the Cart champion and double amputee who last week won two gold medals at the London Paralympics, in his special-edition NSX.
lead_paragraph: Last month, while attending the collector car events and auctions around the Monterey Peninsula, Calif., I reviewed a morning-after report from a sale organized by Russo & Steele. There was a double-take when, listed among the sales, I spotted what the auctioneer called a 1999 Acura NSX Alex Zanardi Edition Coupe.

headline: Addressing a Gap in Nuclear Regulation
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Radiation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Some officials and critics suggest that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission’s rules do not adequately address land contamination from an accident, as opposed to a human radiation dose.
lead_paragraph: For almost 40 years, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission’s mantra has been that public health and safety are adequately protected by the agency’s regulatory standards. But the triple meltdown at Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi plant 18 months ago suggests that the commission needs to go beyond direct health impacts in adopting safeguards, commission staff members and outside experts argued at a three-hour hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Two New Films Peer Into Celebrated Kitchens
abstract: “Step Up to the Plate,” about the chef Michel Bras and his son, Sébastien, and “Three Stars,” about the highest Michelin rating, are opening in New York this month.
lead_paragraph: Among the opening scenes in “Step Up to the Plate,” an 89-minute documentary by Paul Lacoste about the Michelin three-star restaurant Bras Michel et Sébastien, is a display of Mr. Bras and his son, Sébastien, arranging dozens of herbs and pieces of vegetables in a dish, seemingly random but ever so carefully composed, called gargouillou (pronounced gar-goo-YOU). As each leaf and strip is placed, they name the item. (Sorrel, celery leaf, pea shoots, red amaranth, valerian, broom, sesame powder and bear’s garlic were among those used in the month of May.) The salad has become a signature of the restaurant.

headline: Sotheby’s to Auction Robert McNamara Memorabilia
abstract: Included in the former secretary of defense’s possessions are the flag from his office and original drawings of editorial cartoons about him, many of them unfavorable.
lead_paragraph: Robert S. McNamara, secretary of defense during both the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, turns out to have been a meticulous pack rat. Next month Sotheby’s is auctioning off his personal memorabilia, including letters, many of them annotated in McNamara’s own hand; photographs; the flag and globe from his office at the Defense Department; a collection of North Vietnamese propaganda; crib notes he made before appearing in “The Fog of War,” the Errol Morris documentary; and three albums containing the original drawings of editorial cartoons about him, a great many of them unfavorable.

headline: An Ounce of Prevention in New York City
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Levees and Dams', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Buildings under construction at a recycling site in Brooklyn are being raised four feet beyond legal requirements so they can withstand flooding in decades to come.
lead_paragraph: As I note in my article about climate change, rising seas and the risks for New York City, many local governments in the United States are drafting contingency plans to address the prospect of more severe flooding in coming decades.

headline: 9/11 Coverage, Part 2: With Little New to Say, Should Media Say It, Anyway?
abstract: If the Kurt Eichenwald Op-Ed does not break any new ground, why did The Times publish it all?
lead_paragraph: Kurt Eichenwald’s Op-Ed piece on Tuesday about the Bush administration’s response to warnings about Al Qaeda’s plans generated response among some readers, who thought that it was important enough to be treated as news, not opinion. “Why is NYT op-ed on 9-11 warnings an op-ed and not a news article?” the ProPublica editor Eric Umansky asked on Twitter.  Its author, a former New York Times reporter, has written “500 Days: Secrets and Lies in the Terror Wars,” and is a contributing editor at Vanity Fair.

headline: After Criticism of His Convention Speech, Romney Thanks Nation’s Armed Forces
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Speaking to National Guard members in Reno, Nev., Mitt Romney expressed gratitude for troops serving overseas and said the defense budget should not be cut.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — Facing criticism for failing to mention American troops or the Afghan war effort in his convention speech, Mitt Romney spoke before National Guard members on Tuesday and called for robust support of the nation’s armed forces, saying that “the return of our troops cannot and must not be used as an excuse to hollow out our military through devastating defense budget cuts.”

headline: Eleven Years After 9/11, Afghanistan Still Matters
abstract: On an occasion when many Americans remember that terrible day in 2001, one Afghan asks that we remember his country too.
lead_paragraph: My family and I were refugees in Pakistan on Sept. 11, 2001. Like most Afghan refugees, we did not pay particular attention to world news. In fact, many refugees did not even own a television so they could watch what was happening in the world. Little did we know that the tragic events of that day would drastically change the lives of millions of Afghans.

headline: Rodarte: From Ivy League to Leather Pants
abstract: The sisters Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte packed a lot of energy into collages of guipure and jacquard with metal cages, built-in jewelry and panels of silk printed with an ivy trellis, on evening gowns and short strapless dresses.
lead_paragraph: Minutes before the Rodarte show was to begin this afternoon, Jennifer Graylock, one of the veteran front-row photographers, stopped by to hand out business cards for one of her side ventures, what she describes as a line of art furniture. Ms. Graylock takes portraits of celebrities and prints them on the seats of chairs, you see. The concept is called “Sit on My Face,” and you can imagine that a designer might adapt it to a runway show, so that editors could find their places by looking for their mugs in the front row.

headline: Military Identifies Guantánamo Detainee Who Died
abstract: Adnan Farhan Abdul Latif, a Yemeni man, was ordered freed in 2010 by a Federal District Court judge but remained in captivity after the ruling was overturned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The detainee who died on Saturday at the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, was a Yemeni man who had been ordered freed in 2010 by a Federal District Court judge but remained in captivity after the ruling was overturned by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit last year.

headline: Late Arrival to British Open Has Good Excuse
abstract: Paula Creamer traveled all night Monday to arrive at the Women’s British Open, distancing herself from her recent loss to Jiyai Shin in the longest playoff between two goflers in L.P.G.A. history.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — Roughly 23 hours after her par putt spun out of the cup at Kingsmill Resort in Williamsburg, Va., Paula Creamer stuck her tee in the ground on the fourth hole at Royal Liverpool Golf Club on the Wirral Peninsula.

headline: Stone Links: Answerable Questions
abstract: In this week’s links: a science of ethics; a yearning for Rome and reality; and the importance of parody.
lead_paragraph: At The Guardian, a lengthy exchange between Julian Baggini and Lawrence Krauss on how philosophy relates to science. Krauss, a physicist, takes the view that all answerable questions are empirical; any philosophical question that turns out to be answerable, then, is in fact a disguised (frequently nascent) scientific one. Baggini contends that ethical questions are the great counterexample to Krauss’s reductive view. They cannot be settled by any simple appeal to empirical facts (concerning biology or evolutionary psychology, say); yet we do not consider them unanswerable or fit merely for idle philosophical debate. (One also wonders what Krauss would say about mathematical knowledge, which is, on most views, nonempirical.) Krauss, however, digs his heels in, arguing that ethical questions can indeed be settled empirically: “Ultimately, I think our understanding of neurobiology and evolutionary biology and psychology will reduce our understanding of morality to some well-defined biological constructs.”

headline: For Paton, Bankruptcy for Journal Register Is ‘Embarrassing’ but Necessary
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'News and News Media', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: The head of Digital First Media Group has been heavily criticized since his Journal Register Company filed for bankruptcy last week, but he asserted that it was “the absolute right thing to do.”
lead_paragraph: The last few days have provided a lesson in humility, John Paton acknowledged.

headline: Exploding Government
abstract: Or maybe not.
lead_paragraph: I gather that Rand Paul has made a lame effort to defend his claim that we’ve seen “exploding” government under Obama by claiming that he only meant the federal workforce, which has gone up slightly even as state and local employment has fallen. But as I’ve pointed out, the vast majority of government workers actually are at the state and local level. (And yes, the feds have an influence: the Recovery Act contained substantial aid to lower levels of government, which should have been continued).

headline: The Caregiver
abstract: The death of Juanita Hawkins, who watched over the writer’s mother for more than 35 years, conjures memories and gratitude.
lead_paragraph: I was driving through Kansas, taking the kids back to college, when my cellphone buzzed. It was my sister-in-law letting me know that Juanita Hawkins had died.

headline: Japanese Whiskeys, Translated From the Scottish
abstract: Made commercially since the 1920s, Japanese whiskeys are gaining ground in the United States.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the most expensive cocktails in New York can be found at Ryu, the Japanese-inspired restaurant that opened last spring in the meatpacking district. It’s a Sazerac variation called Shogun’s Grip and it’s ticketed like a four-star entree: $35. Adam Schuman, then the beverage director, had a good excuse for the stiff tariff. Its base is 18-year-old Yamazaki, the Japanese single malt made by Suntory that can cost $140 a bottle.

headline: Rodarte: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Baking Their Own Way
abstract: Dorie Greenspan and Susan Berlin are each making the leap into opening a brick-and-mortar shop.
lead_paragraph: Dorie Greenspan’s butter cookies have gone from pop-up to permanence. Ms. Greenspan, a food writer and author of several cookbooks, mostly on baking, joined forces with her son, Joshua, right, a few years ago and started selling her cookies, mostly around special occasions like Valentine’s Day. Now, with another partner, Daniel Seehoff, left, they are opening retail shops called Beurre & Sel (butter and salt) on Saturday in La Marqueta in Harlem, where they do the baking, and in a snazzy red-and-white walk-in closet of a space in the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side. They are starting with a dozen flavors of French-style sablé cookies, mostly sweet, some savory.

headline: Preserves for Many Seasons
abstract: American Spoon, in northern Michigan, makes its jams, syrups and sauces from local fruit, some of it gathered in the wild.
lead_paragraph: American Spoon was ahead of the curve when it comes to the artisanal movement. Justin Rashid founded the company in northern Michigan in 1982, in partnership with the chef Larry Forgione, and started making preserves from local fruit, some of it gathered in the wild. Over the years the company prospered and expanded its line to include lightly sweetened spoon fruits, conserves, fruit butters, savory jams, syrups, sauces and mustards. This year, some new items include rich triple berry conserve (strawberries, black raspberries and blueberries), which will prolong the taste of summer. Also notable is rare tart-sweet wild thimbleberry jam. Whole-seed mustard will enhance a plate of braised pork shank once fall sets in.

headline: Street Style | Serene vs. Extreme
abstract: T tracks one statement worn two ways. The looks: baseball caps, bare midriffs, leather skirts, blue jeans, denim shorts and floral jumpers.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: After Militant Is Killed, Car Bomb Targets Yemen Minister
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism']
abstract: At least 12 people were killed in a car bombing in the capital of Yemen on Tuesday, in what appeared to be an attack targeting the country’s defense minister.
lead_paragraph: At least 12 people were killed in a car bombing in the capital of Yemen on Tuesday, in what appeared to be an attack targeting the country’s defense minister. The bombing came after a top Al Qaeda leader in Yemen, and six people traveling with him, were killed in what Yemeni officials said was an airstrike by an American drone.

headline: Saving Space for Tigers on a Crowding Planet
abstract: A fresh look at ways to conserve tigers despite growing pressure for land and tiger body parts.
lead_paragraph: Tigers, the biggest of the great cats, are having a tough time finding space as the growth spurt in human numbers and appetites in Asia presses in on their last wild havens. Alan Rabinowitz, a biologist who has been studying and working to save tigers and other wild cat species for decades (see him in the field in the video above), recently helped run a Bangkok meeting of scientists, law enforcement officials and conservationists developing new tactics for boosting tigers’ prospects in the face of relentless poaching pressure driven by the booming demand for tiger skins and products in China and parts of Southeast Asia.

headline: A World of Salami
abstract: Volpi Foods of St. Louis has expanded not only the distribution of its products but also the variety of its dry-cured salami.
lead_paragraph: Lorenza Pasetti is a member of the third generation of the family that founded Volpi Foods in St. Louis in 1902. And since she has taken the reins of the company, which specializes in cured meats, she has expanded not only the distribution of the products but also the variety of dry-cured salami the company makes. Most are Italian, but as a self-described “history nut,” she has just introduced a line called Un Mondo, an assortment of small 6-ounce varieties inspired by traditional international styles: fine-textured German landjäger and Hungarian, more rustic Catalan called fuet, Spanish chorizo, French with herbs and with cepes mushrooms, and even spicy-sweet Chinese lap cheong. Also new are some Italian versions seasoned with cheeses like aged asiago and Parmesan. They are made without sodium nitrites or nitrates and contain no fillers.

headline: ‘Is This the Pose of a Free Man?’
abstract: A new report calls TSA operations “costly, counterintuitive, and poorly executed.”
lead_paragraph: On the Sunday before the Republican convention, Senator Rand Paul ranted against his least favorite government bureaucracy: The Transportation Security Administration. Addressing a crowd at the University of South Florida, he mimicked the backscatter-machine stance (arms up in the air, legs apart) and asked “Is this the pose of a free man?”

headline: Vera Wang: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: For a Brazilian Vacation, 7 Rules to Save By
abstract: From fares to food, pousadas to Portuguese, the Frugal Traveler has advice for seeing Brazil on a budget.
lead_paragraph: Brazil is too expensive for budget travelers. Or is it?

headline: Rachel Roy: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Absence of Asterisks
abstract: Not all budgets are the same.
lead_paragraph: Some readers ask why I’m not giving the Obama budget plan a grilling comparable to the one I’m giving to Romney. Well, I’m glad you asked that: it’s because the Obama plan, whether you like it or not, doesn’t have anything like Romney’s reliance on magic asterisks.

headline: Gov. Rick Perry, in the Hot Seat at Ferrari Headquarters
abstract: The Texas governor met with Luca di Montezemolo, chairman of the Italian supercar manufacturer, and drove the company’s vehicles during his visit to Italy.
lead_paragraph: He recently signed a bill that would allow a speed limit of 85 miles per hour on a 41-mile toll road between Austin, Tex., and San Antonio. The metropolitan area of his state’s capital is preparing to host the first Formula One race in the United States since 2007. And he watched the Ferrari driver Fernando Alonso expand his lead in the driver’s championship at the Italian Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: The former space of Japonais and then Kibo is becoming a sports bar; add Boomer Esiason’s name to the Stadium Grill.
lead_paragraph: Opening

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: More than 30 chefs will be cooking at the Taste of the Village in Washington Square Park; the Annual Vendy Awards will be presented on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Benefits

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 11
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including Sept. 11 memorials and World Cup qualifying matches.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including Sept. 11 memorials and World Cup qualifying matches.

headline: Venice International Architecture Biennale
abstract: Images from the Biennale.
lead_paragraph: Images from the Biennale.

headline: Knicks Add to Their Training Camp Roster
abstract: They signed guard Oscar Bellfield, center Henry Sims, forward Mychel Thompson and forward John Shurna.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks added three new players Tuesday to its training camp roster. The team signed free agents in guard Oscar Bellfield, center Henry Sims and forward Mychel Thompson. The Knicks also signed forward John Shurna on Monday to a partly guaranteed deal.

headline: Perry Ellis by Duckie Brown: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Treasury Sells Additional $2.7 Billion Worth of A.I.G. Shares
keywords: ['Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The Treasury Department said on Tuesday that it had sold an additional $2.7 billion worth of its holdings in A.I.G., as underwriters for the offering exercised what’s known as an overallotment option to meet higher-than-expected demand.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, $18 billion worth of American International Group shares weren’t enough for investors.

headline: Pregnant at 49
abstract: My husband and I agreed that we would terminate a fetus with genetic defects. We’re too old to parent a special-needs child.
lead_paragraph: I was pregnant the week of the Republican convention, when they ratified their platform regarding abortion. Pregnant and considering an abortion, and not one that would fit into any of the “exceptions” identified by many Republican politicians: rape, incest or to save the life of the mother. It was a more usual condition, an unplanned pregnancy at my age. But not because I’m a young teenage girl with my life stretching out before me. It was quite the opposite: I’m 49.

headline: Nothing Like Reality to Break Up a Party
abstract: “Independents,” a musical held over from the New York International Fringe Festival, alternates between stoner comedy and romance, until dramatic storm clouds gather.
lead_paragraph: The sunset of youth is witnessed from a crow’s nest in Marina Keegan’s “Independents,” a musical held over from the New York International Fringe Festival at the SoHo Playhouse. And like the show itself, it is a thing to savor.

headline: Wall Street Sits Courtside for a Marathon Match
abstract: A number of bankers and financiers were at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday to witness tennis history as Andy Murray defeated Novak Djokovic in the men’s singles final. But as the night wore on, some turned to unconventional means to stay warm.
lead_paragraph: John Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager, will be forever known on Wall Street as the man who made nearly billions shorting subprime mortgages. But on Monday night at the United States Open men’s singles final, DealBook witnessed Mr. Paulson do something that, while not nearly as remunerative, was almost as impressive: He turned his necktie into an ascot.

headline: Past Forward: Why Do We Still Buy $5 Umbrellas at the Last Minute?
abstract: How uncertainty is built into the science of weather forecasting.
lead_paragraph: Oumar Diallo, a merchant with a tiny sliver of a shop, sells umbrellas at the entrance to the subway near the corner of 40th Street and Seventh Avenue. Whenever it’s raining, Diallo is the busiest person at the top of the subway stairs, taking cash, making change and opening umbrellas over his customers’ heads. I asked Diallo, who is from Guinea and has been selling umbrellas for five years, what it’s like for his income to be so dependent on the weather. “When it’s not raining, I get bored,” he said. Like many people, Diallo checks the weather forecast when he wakes up in the morning and before he goes to bed. Still, his business relies on the fact that the weather — and meteorology — is unpredictable. “I make money when people are unprepared.”

headline: Scarf Tricks | Olivia Bee for Hermès
abstract: The young photographer’s short film for Hermès is sweet yet sensual, with a fairy tale-like guilelessness.
lead_paragraph: Olivia Bee, 18, started photographing her friends when she was just 11, gradually developing a dreamy, color-drenched aesthetic that is a visual metaphor for the emotional lushness and near-religious sensory intensity of adolescence. Neither are qualities normally associated with the bourgeois elegance of Hermès, but after seeing Bee’s work in Le Monde, a representative of the house contacted her about photographing for Le Monde d’Hermès, the brand’s magazine, and shooting a short film, “Il Est Pour Nous,” which stars Bee, her boyfriend Cooper Campbell and a pair of pastel bunnies, for its Web site. Sweet yet sensual, with a fairy-tale-like guilelessness, the resulting images are a whole new way of looking at the foulard, which Bee fashioned into both a giant hair bow and a curvy elf hat. “They suggested I make them into head wraps or skirts but I was thinking more stylized,” she said. Touché!

headline: Ex-Mayoral Aide to Help Assembly Speaker in Harassment Case
abstract: Stu Loeser, the former press secretary for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been hired by Speaker Sheldon Silver to help navigate a sexual harassment scandal engulfing the State Assembly.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — It did not take Stu Loeser long to find a high-profile client.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, Washington, D.C., Greece and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Washington, D.C., Greece and Egypt.

headline: CBS Adjusts Schedule to Account for Longer N.F.L. Games
abstract: On Sunday afternoons when it carries National Football League games, the network will start its prime-time schedule a half-hour later, providing some relief to DVR users who have missed their favorite shows.
lead_paragraph: CBS is bowing to reality and making it official: on Sundays, when it carries late-afternoon National Football League games, the schedule of programs that follows will start at 7:30 p.m. and not 7.

headline: Breaking It Down: Murray vs. Djokovic
abstract: Analysis of the United States Open men’s final.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic had battled each other in the howling wind for more than four hours and gotten nowhere.

headline: Should the 401(k) Be Reformed or Replaced?
abstract: Less than half of the nation’s private sector workers are in 401(k) plans and 40 percent of businesses do not even offer them, leading experts and economists to question the value of the system.
lead_paragraph: JOHN GREENE worked for 30 years at an Oscar Mayer plant in Madison, Wis., deboning hams and loading boxes of hot dogs. His 401(k) plan grew to $60,000, and soon after retiring he began withdrawing $3,600 a year from it, money that allowed him and his wife to take what he called a wondrous two-week trip to Scotland, his ancestral homeland.

headline: Employers Oversee an Army of Retiree Volunteers
abstract: Corporation-sponsored programs that match retirees with volunteer opportunities are helping retirees put their skills to good use at schools and other nonprofit institutions.
lead_paragraph: THE day Alan Toney retired from Michelin North America he bought a Triumph Bonneville motorcycle and made a plan to ride on all seven continents.

headline: For Top Executives, Richer Retirement Plans
abstract: Economic conditions have many workers worried that their company retirement plans will not provide enough income, but top executives could actually benefit from those conditions.
lead_paragraph: WITH traditional pensions disappearing, tax rates and the future of Social Security in flux and even well-known businesses facing financial trouble, many workers are worried that their company retirement plans will not provide enough income.

headline: A Silver Tinge to the Political Ring
abstract: Organizations on both sides of the political spectrum are reporting increasing involvement in campaign activities by voters of retirement age.
lead_paragraph: HAVING made his fortune in advertising and the television talk show industry, Bob Turner was enjoying a wealth of retirement pursuits — he played golf and tennis, had a home on the beach and a weekend ski house, five children, 13 grandchildren and a tight circle of longtime friends, and kept a toe in the business world with seats on a few boards.

headline: Paring 401(k) Expenses
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Retirement', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A new federal rule requires disclosures on what fees 401(k)’s are being charged by administrators, bookkeepers, fund managers and other middlemen.
lead_paragraph: NOW that some sunshine is being shed on 401(k) expenses, it’s time to see how you can improve returns by lowering the costs of the middlemen.

headline: Old, Trusting and Tricked Out of Life Savings
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Personal Finances', 'Elderly', 'Identity Fraud', 'Computer Security', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: People who grew up in the 1930s, ’40s and ’50s were generally raised to be polite and trusting. Con artists exploit these traits.
lead_paragraph: GRACE, an 81-year-old widow in Colorado, lost her life savings recently to identity thieves who had stolen her personal and financial information. She has hard-earned advice for anyone who gets a call from a stranger.

headline: As Medicare Fraud Evolves, Vigilance Is Required
abstract: Medicare fraud costs the government billions, but it can also take a toll — both financially and physically — on Medicare recipients.
lead_paragraph: DEBORAH GILMAN, 44, a nurse who lives in Newark, Calif., knows that Medicare fraud is out there. But she never thought her father, Jerry Gilman, 68, would become a victim.

headline: Work Out, but Know Your Limits
abstract: Staying physically fit is important for older people, but are those popular high-intensity regimens appropriate?
lead_paragraph: “I’M 39,” says the shirtless man on the TV commercial, “and I’m in better shape now than when I was a swimmer in high school.”

headline: A Longer Life Is Lived With Company
abstract: Recent research suggests that loneliness is a risk factor for functional decline and early death in later life.
lead_paragraph: YOU die alone, philosophers say. But you could die sooner if you live your life in loneliness. Close connections to friends and family may ward off poor health and premature death, recent research suggests.

headline: Spouse’s Consent Is Required to Change Retirement Account Beneficiary
abstract: Spousal consent guidelines can vary, so investors should know the specific requirements for their account.
lead_paragraph: WHY does a married person who has certain kinds of retirement accounts have to get his or her spouse’s permission to change the beneficiary of those accounts?

headline: Childless and Aging? Time to Designate a Caregiver
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Single Persons', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elderly', 'Elder Care']
abstract: As more people in the United States remain childless, lawyers are emphasizing the importance of setting up health care proxies and powers of attorney.
lead_paragraph: SUSAN SOMMERS and her sister always kept a close eye on their mother, who was 94 and had dementia when she died this summer. Both sisters made sure they lived near their mother in Manhattan, and together they handled her bills, bought her food, took her to doctors’ visits and oversaw her caretakers.

headline: The Tightwire Act of Living Only on Social Security
abstract: The average monthly benefit puts one around $3,000 above the poverty line, at what can be a vulnerable time of life.
lead_paragraph: LIVING on an inflexible budget, one that teeters on the brink of poverty, is not what most people equate with retirement. But that is pretty much what anyone who lives solely on Social Security can expect.

headline: Heading South, but Stopping Short of Florida
abstract: Retirees say the friendliness and the relaxed lifestyle of the South appeals to them.
lead_paragraph: SCOTT WOODCOCK knew he wanted to move someplace warmer when he retired from his job as an Amtrak engineer based in Philadelphia.

headline: Cornmeal and Oatmeal Polenta With Tomato Sauce and Parmesan
abstract: Oatmeal adds texture and creaminess to this simple and satisfying dish.
lead_paragraph: I think I like this combination even more than I like traditional cornmeal polenta, and that’s saying a lot. The oatmeal contributes both texture and a wonderful creaminess to the dish. It’s a comforting, satisfying meal.

headline: Abused East Harlem Dog Getting Care at Animal Shelter
abstract: Hazel, the pit bull who was captured on security video being beaten by a man in an elevator, is “doing O.K.,” an agency spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Several readers have asked what became of the dog we wrote about Monday who was captured on a security camera being beaten by a man in the elevator of an East Harlem housing project.

headline: Bicycle Thieves: World-Class Cycling’s Drug Trade
keywords: ['Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Doping (Sports)', 'Books and Literature', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: “The Secret Race,” by Tyler Hamilton and Daniel Coyle, describes the systematic illegal doping by professional cyclists, most notably Lance Armstrong, Mr. Hamilton’s former teammate.
lead_paragraph: After Lance Armstrong decided last month not to contest doping charges and a move to strip away his seven Tour de France titles, he left the cycling world anxiously awaiting the release of a report documenting the illicit ways he boosted his performance.

headline: Hungarians Stage a Fast Over Rules for Voters
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Hunger Strikes', 'Elections']
abstract: The weeklong fast outside Parliament is the latest protest against the policies of Hungary’s prime minister, who has been accused of undermining the country’s young democracy.
lead_paragraph: The dispute seems arcane, but in Hungary the passions behind it are running high — high enough that a former prime minister has begun a hunger strike over it.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Sept. 13
abstract: J. W. Anderson is creating a collection with Topshop; the Antonia bag from Marc Jacobs is roomy and no fuss; and other shopping related news.
lead_paragraph: J. W. Anderson is creating a collection with Topshop; the Antonia bag from Marc Jacobs is roomy and no fuss; and other shopping related news.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 6
abstract: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Fashion Week Casting | Marc by Marc Jacobs
abstract: Behind the scenes at the casting for today’s Marc by Marc Jacobs show at 4 p.m. in New York.
