headline: Bonding With Pets, Not People
abstract: Melissa Leo plays a granite-faced, taciturn woman who connects more easily with animals than with people.
lead_paragraph: In “Francine,” a small gem of bleak, neorealist portraiture, Melissa Leo plays a granite-faced, taciturn woman who connects more easily with animals than with people. In the opening scene, Francine is shown naked in a shower, just before her release from a prison where she has served an unspecified time for unnamed crimes.

headline: Marc by Marc Jacobs: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Met Museum Considers Opening on Mondays
abstract: Rising tourism and a steady stream of attempted Monday visits have led the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s director, Thomas P. Campbell, to propose opening every day of the week.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday streams of would-be visitors climb the grand stairs to the Metropolitan Museum of Art only to discover that it is closed. Now the museum’s director is proposing to open the doors on Mondays, starting next July, so that the Met would be open every day for the first time in more than 40 years.

headline: A Wacky Stagehand Seeks the Audience’s Eye
abstract: Suzanna Geraghty stars in the one-woman comedy “Auditions, Zoe’s Auditions Part 2,” part of the 1st Irish Theater Festival.
lead_paragraph: Some people work out their biceps. Others work out their glutes. Suzanna Geraghty works out her face.

headline: Two Centuries of Creating U.S. History
abstract: “In Pursuit of a Vision,” a survey of the 200-year-old American Antiquarian Society’s collections, shows how a new country started thinking of its past and present.
lead_paragraph: When the Society of Antiquaries of London was celebrated in an exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art this year, you could see how the society gradually discovered and interpreted Britain’s history, shaping a nation’s understanding of itself. Now, in a new show at the Grolier Club, “In Pursuit of a Vision,” you see the American counterpart to that narrative in a survey of the collections of the American Antiquarian Society in Worcester, Mass. The American society was partly inspired by the London one, but what a different world it imagines, and what a different sense of history it creates.

headline: Bearing Burdens of the Ages, In Darkness and in Light
abstract: Nora Chipaumire’s latest dance work, “Miriam,” inspired by the South African singer and activist Miriam Makeba, will have its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Nora Chipaumire is powerful. Nora Chipaumire is strong, imposing, ferocious. So reviewers of this choreographer and dancer have been pointing out for at least a decade, since she gained prominence as a member of Urban Bush Women. Who could not notice her muscular physique and the deep rivers of energy she can make flow and surge through it? Who would not be impressed by her sculptural head and the arresting face that can stare down an audience?

headline: A Steely Fighter From the City That Care Forgot
abstract: “I’m Carolyn Parker” is an account of a woman’s five-year effort to rebuild her house in the Lower Ninth Ward of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: Jane Jacobs would have loved Carolyn Parker. Honestly, it’s hard to imagine anyone not liking Ms. Parker, though there are those who might be intimidated by her toughness or overwhelmed by her energy. But Jacobs, the great 20th-century philosopher-evangelist of urban life, would surely recognize this retired restaurant cook, a resident of the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans and the subject of Jonathan Demme’s marvelous new documentary, as an indispensable “public character.” With her stubborn attachment to place, her vigilant, sympathetic “eyes on the street” and her unsentimental civic-mindedness, Ms. Parker is the exactly the kind of person Jacobs identified as crucial to the life of great American cities.

headline: Where Words Are the Notes
abstract: Zeena Parkins was doctor to her “patient,” the harp, in “Spellbeamed” at Roulette, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. Then descriptions of objects made up a score.
lead_paragraph: In a question-and-answer session after her concert at Roulette on Monday evening, the composer and harpist Zeena Parkins said that she had long had the recurring image of her harp as a patient. So for the first part of “Spellbeamed: Fixexploded; Fixabolished,” the work she performed with the JACK Quartet and members of the Ne(x)tworks Ensemble, Ms. Parkins treated the instrument as exactly that.

headline: Toronto Film Festival Spotlights Real Lives
keywords: ['Movies', 'Toronto International Film Festival', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: This year’s Toronto film festival was long on biopics about lives large and small — Franklin D. Roosevelt to an Icelandic fisherman.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Gudlaugur Fridthorsson was small in the world’s eyes. His claim to fame was failing to die in 1984, when his fishing boat sank off Iceland.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Marc by Marc Jacobs
abstract: Quirk factor alert: a sweet dotted stripe on a covered platform wedge gets paired with a woolly ankle sock.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Seeking Critical Mass of Gender Equality in the Boardroom
abstract: European Union leaders are considering a law to require that 40 percent of a company’s directors be women, but the Deal Professor asks whether that will make a difference in how companies are run.
lead_paragraph: There’s a remarkable lack of women in corporate boardrooms around the world. The European Union is considering a remedy that would require that 40 percent of a company’s directors be women. This may be a milestone for gender equality, but the question is, will it make any difference in how companies are run?

headline: Integrating Banks Spurs Last-Minute Fears in Europe
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Even as the European Commission puts the final touches on a regulatory plan for banks, some countries are seeking to modify or delay the proposed system.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Even as European Union officials put the final touches on a plan for a central bank supervisor, prominent Germans and some leaders in Central and Eastern Europe were trying on Tuesday to modify or delay the proposal.

headline: Names of the Dead
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The Department of Defense recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,097 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Moody’s Warns That U.S. May Face Debt Downgrade
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: Congressional leaders dug in their heels against any quick deal to resolve a looming fiscal disaster before the election, even as the ratings agency warned of a downgrade if no solution was found by year’s end.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders dug in their heels on Tuesday against any quick deal to resolve a looming fiscal disaster before the election, even as a major ratings agency warned that it would downgrade the government’s debt if no solution was found by year’s end.

headline: Photos of The Moment | J. Crew
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.

headline: Childress Set to Sign with Nets
abstract: Josh Childress agreed to terms with the Nets on Tuesday and will be the favorite to win the backup job at small forward when training camp opens next month.
lead_paragraph: Josh Childress is set to join the Nets, completing their likely opening-night roster for their inaugural season in Brooklyn.

headline: Online Critics Fault Anniversary Coverage on ‘Today’
abstract: “Today” received a barrage of online criticism on Tuesday for being the only network morning news show not to observe a moment of silence on the 9/11 anniversary.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s “Today” show, already drawing widespread attention because of a recent decline in the ratings, received a barrage of online criticism on Tuesday for being the only network morning news show not to observe a moment of silence in commemoration of the attacks on the World Trade Center, which took place 11 years ago.

headline: Marc Jacobs Gets the Meaning of It All
abstract: At the New York shows, Mr. Jacobs hits on three fronts at once: synergy, humor and sex.
lead_paragraph: That fashion editors tend to go bonkers for Marc Jacobs should be obvious by now. You could peel them off the floor of the armory on Lexington Avenue, where he stages his shows, so many have fallen at his genius feet.

headline: Zuckerberg Acknowledges ‘Disappointing’ Wall Street
abstract: Facebook’s founder, in his first public appearance since the initial public offering in May, told a TechCrunch conference that the company should be measured by its lasting impact. “Ten, 20 years from now, the legacy of this company should be, we have connected everyone in the world,” he said. “That’s a lot.” After Mr. Zuckerberg’s remarks, Facebook stock rose 3 percent in after-hours trading.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg spoke to a hometown crowd here Tuesday afternoon, acknowledging his company’s “disappointing” performance on Wall Street, hinting at new moneymaking strategies, and casting his company as one that continued to build new things in the face of criticism.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Vera Wang
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Intersection: N.Y. Fashion Week Milk
abstract: Standing outside Milk Studios, we spotted Sean Risley covered in tattoos and Rajni Lucienne Jaques running into a show for Made fashion week, wearing a peplum pencil skirt and cut-off tee.
lead_paragraph: Standing outside Milk Studios, we spotted Sean Risley covered in tattoos and Rajni Lucienne Jaques running into a show for Made fashion week, wearing a peplum pencil skirt and cut-off tee.

headline: Sophie Theallet: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Fuel Taxes and Consumption
abstract: Fuel consumption tends to be lowest in countries with the highest fuel taxes. The United States taxes fuel at much lower rates than most European countries, and consumes more.
lead_paragraph: Fuel consumption tends to be lowest in countries with the highest fuel taxes. The United States taxes fuel at much lower rates than most European countries, and consumes more.

headline: Looks for Everyone, All Mixed Together
abstract: At Marc by Marc Jacobs show, the design team for the designer’s lower-priced line appeared to be having a great time this season with a wide variety of styles.
lead_paragraph: Juergen Teller, the photographer, was there in the front row of the Marc by Marc Jacobs show wearing a T-shirt and onion-skin running shorts. Harry Louis, Mr. Jacobs’s beau, was wearing a kilt. Two of the Jonas brothers were dressed more wholesomely in rolled khakis and a windbreaker.

headline: Obscure Film Mocking Muslim Prophet Sparks Anti-U.S. Protests in Egypt and Libya
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Egyptian-Americans', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Angered by reports in the Egyptian media that members of the Coptic Christian diaspora in the United States had produced a crude film mocking the Muslim prophet, protesters climbed the walls of the U.S. Embassy in Cairo on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Our colleagues in Cairo have more on these events in a more recent news article.

headline: Seven Lean Years of Peacemaking
abstract: Seven years after the Gaza withdrawal, Israel has successfully entrenched its control over 98.5 percent of the land, after giving up only 1.5 percent.
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Players in Bounty Case to Meet Commissioner
abstract: The four players whose suspensions for alleged roles in New Orleans’ bounty program were recently vacated will meet with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell, as he determines their new punishment.
lead_paragraph: The four players whose suspensions for their suspected roles in the New Orleans Saints’ bounty program were vacated by an appeals panel on Friday will meet with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell, as he prepares to determine what new discipline he will impose.

abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Ioulex.

headline: Schools Look to Weed Out Nonresidents
abstract: In Greenwich, Conn., as well as in other high-performing public school districts, administrators are resorting to surprise home visits and legal affidavits to ensure students live in the district.
lead_paragraph: Like many before her, Susie T. Ponce bought a house in Greenwich, Conn., for the schools. Her son and daughter attend the Hamilton Avenue School, a magnet school that offers foreign languages in kindergarten and a Suzuki music program.

headline: A Real Estate Company Finds a Boom in Boston’s Back Bay
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Mixed-Use Developments', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: With a $226 million purchase in Boston, Jamestown Properties has become part of a submarket with nearly $2 billion in other projects in the works.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In a blockbuster deal last fall, Jamestown Properties paid $226 million for a 130,000-square-foot portfolio spread over 28 buildings, mostly on Newbury Street — the fashionable thoroughfare that hosts shops ranging from a Chanel boutique to nail salons in 19th-century town houses.

headline: TimesCast Politics | D.N.C. Night Three
abstract: Coverage of the final evening of the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Coverage of the final evening of the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Lehman Is Biding Its Time to Market Its Real Estate
abstract: Lehman Brothers has been waiting for the real estate market to improve so it can sell its properties at higher prices than it would have received during the depth of the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four years after Lehman Brothers touched off a worldwide financial crisis when it filed for bankruptcy protection on Sept. 15, 2008, the estate of the failed investment bank continues to control more than $10 billion of real estate assets in its $40.5 billion portfolio. And all of it eventually must be converted to cash to repay creditors.

headline: N.H.L. Union Tries Legal Maneuver in Canada
abstract: As formal negotiations have broken off, the N.H.L. Players’ Association is trying an unusual legal gambit to block team owners from locking out players in Quebec and Alberta.
lead_paragraph: With an owners’ lockout looming at week’s end and formal negotiations broken off, the N.H.L. Players’ Association is trying an unusual legal gambit.

headline: Taxes Show One Way to Save Fuel
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Gasoline Tax (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Energy Efficiency']
abstract: Some economists say that new fuel-efficiency standards for cars and trucks will do less good for the environment than a straight tax on gasoline.
lead_paragraph: Just the other day, President Obama unveiled another example of how our hostility to anything that even remotely looks like a tax is leading us down the wrong path, ultimately making us worse off.

headline: Mail-Truck Driver Tried on Charges of Leaving Scene of Fatal Bike Accident
abstract: Ian Clement’s seven-ton postal truck rolled over Marilyn Dershovitz and her bicycle in 2011. The prosecutor says the defendant knew or should have known that someone was hurt.
lead_paragraph: On a holiday weekend last year, Nathan Dershowitz sat on his bike at 29th Street and 10th Avenue waiting for his wife of 43 years to navigate through the postal trucks crowded on the street behind him.

headline: Gay Marriage Vote Rises as Test in Upstate G.O.P. Race
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Elections, Legislature', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The re-election bid by State Senator Roy J. McDonald has become a referendum on one issue: his decision to vote to legalize same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: TROY, N.Y. — Before State Senator Roy J. McDonald, a Republican, voted last year to legalize same-sex marriage, he told reporters that anyone unhappy with his position could “take the job and shove it.”

headline: In Refining Succession Plans, Ford May Name a New No. 2
abstract: The Ford Motor Company’s board will meet this week to consider possible succession plans for the company’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Ford Motor Company’s board will meet this week to consider possible succession plans for the company’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, a person with knowledge of the meeting said on Tuesday.

headline: Hoping to Lure Riders With Scenic Commutes
abstract: The East River Ferry service is in the second year of a $9 million subsidies contract with New York City, but questions remain about its chances for profitability.
lead_paragraph: Titania Inglis, a 33-year-old fashion designer who wears her own flouncy avant-garde creations, likes to take the East River Ferry from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, where she keeps her work samples, to the East 34th Street slip in Manhattan and then bicycle to the garment center. Indeed, Ms. Inglis, who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, can wax rhapsodic about the pleasures of sailing on a swift tidal river glistening with sunlight.

headline: Coalition Drops Opposition to a Dow Engineered Crop
abstract: The group, which included canners and other food industry members, said it was heartened by Dow’s response to its concerns.
lead_paragraph: A group representing fruit and vegetable growers and canners has dropped its opposition to regulatory approval of genetically engineered crops resistant to the powerful herbicide 2,4-D.

headline: New Medical Care Networks Show Savings
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors']
abstract: A study indicated a slowing of costs for hospitals and doctors that collaborated to keep a defined group of patients healthier, a model promoted by the federal health care law.
lead_paragraph: A new model for delivering medical care, one promoted by the federal health care law, holds promise for slowing the cost of treating the sickest, most expensive patients, according to a new study.

headline: Subdued Anniversary of 9/11
abstract: Readers at Ground Zero reminded the crowd that even if the rest of the country seemed ready to move on, their grief, at least on this day, was still vivid.
lead_paragraph: Readers at Ground Zero reminded the crowd that even if the rest of the country seemed ready to move on, their grief, at least on this day, was still vivid.

headline: A Pointless Blacklisting
abstract: Washington’s move to blacklist and marginalize the Haqqani network threatens the prospects for a political settlement — the only way out of the Afghan conflict.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, the United States designated the Taliban-affiliated Haqqani network a “foreign terrorist organization,” placing it alongside Hamas and Al Qaeda. But to what end?

headline: In China We (Don’t) Trust
abstract: When there is trust in society, sustainable innovation happens. China is beginning to see the fruits of a little bit of that trust.
lead_paragraph: Hangzhou, China

headline: A Defeat for Impartial Courts
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials']
abstract: The damage caused by influence-seeking campaign money unleashed by recent Supreme Court rulings is spreading to state judicial elections.
lead_paragraph: The damage caused by enormous amounts of influence-seeking campaign money unleashed by recent Supreme Court rulings is spreading beyond elections for legislative and executive posts to contests for important state court judgeships. Following on those destructive decisions, the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals ruled last week to deny matching funds under the state’s pilot campaign financing program for judicial races to a Republican candidate, Allen Loughry II, for a seat on that court.

headline: Laying Bare the Roots of a Shooting Outside a Bodega
abstract: The family of Reynaldo Cuevas, accidentally killed by an officer on Friday as he fled a bodega holdup, wants to know if the shooting was a criminal act.
lead_paragraph: Stepping into the sunshine on upper Broadway on Tuesday afternoon, by the marble facade of the Ortiz Funeral Home, the lawyer Sanford L. Rubenstein gave the phrase “wrongful death” a heavy workout.

headline: Economic Stimulus as the Election Nears? It’s Been Done Before
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Federal Reserve said it does not consider politics when setting policy, but it is again poised to announce an economic stimulus effort during an election season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In September 1992, the Federal Reserve culminated a long-running effort to stimulate the sluggish economy by cutting its benchmark interest rate to 3 percent, the lowest level it had reached in almost three decades.

headline: At Harvard, Suspects in Cheating Take a Leave
abstract: Some students suspected in a cheating scandal have opted for a leave of absence rather than face possible suspension.
lead_paragraph: Facing academic and financial deadlines, some of the Harvard students suspected in a cheating scandal have decided to take a leave of absence rather than face possible suspension for a year, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: At Ground Zero, Readers Offer Plain-Spoken Tributes to Those Lost
abstract: On a subdued anniversary of the terrorist attacks, the names of the dead were intoned by friends and relatives for almost four hours where the towers fell 11 years ago.
lead_paragraph: This time, there were no presidents reading psalms, no sounds of Yo-Yo Ma’s cello echoing across the plaza, no national outpouring of decade-later reflections.

headline: Dying to Play
abstract: We know more about concussions than we used to, but even the best helmets can’t prevent them.
lead_paragraph: THE beating goes on. This past Saturday a Tulane University football player, Devon Walker, collided with a teammate while making a tackle. Walker, who is 21, broke his neck. Fans gasped. Doctors performed C.P.R. He may or may not walk again.

headline: Murray Elbows His Way Into Exclusive Men’s Club
abstract: Andy Murray, with his victory Monday at the U.S. Open, has joined the rarefied company of Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic at the top of men’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: For years, more than seven to be exact, men’s tennis was defined by its three best players: Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic. They divvied up almost every Grand Slam trophy, and in the process created a separation from the pack.

headline: Watching Murray Prepare on His Way to Championship
abstract: The U.S. Open practice courts offered a glimpse at how Andy Murray gets ready for matches.
lead_paragraph: In his news conference following his grueling five-set victory over Novak Djokovic in the United States Open final, Andy Murray said he was happy that he was “ able to do it for all the guys I work with.” There are many such guys in today’s hyper-refined game. The top earners employ small armies that include coach, trainer, “physio” and one or more on-court practice partners.

headline: Georgia: More Charges In Militia Plot
abstract: Five more people in southeast Georgia have been charged with helping an antigovernment militia accused of killing two people.
lead_paragraph: Five more people in southeast Georgia have been charged with helping an antigovernment militia accused of killing two people. District Attorney Tom Durden of the Atlantic Judicial Circuit said Tuesday that five suspects had committed burglaries, thefts and car break-ins to finance a militia called FEAR, or Forever Enduring Always Ready. Three other people suspected of membership in the militia already face the death penalty for the murder of a soldier and his girlfriend in December. Prosecutors say the militia was formed by former soldiers at Fort Stewart near Savannah. The group plotted several attacks, including poisoning the apple crop in Washington State, attacking a dam and assassinating President Obama.  The five charged are Christopher Jenderseck, Adam Dearman, Timothy Joiner, Anthony Garner and Randall Blake Dearman.

headline: Scouted
abstract: The filmmakers David Redmon and Ashley Sabin examine the lives of teenage girls in Siberia who audition at open casting calls for fashion models.
lead_paragraph: The filmmakers David Redmon and Ashley Sabin examine the lives of teenage girls in Siberia who audition at open casting calls for fashion models.

headline: Samuel P. Latone II
abstract: Mr. Latone is the president and co-chief executive of the Shopping Center Group, a company that serves as a consultant and adviser to property owners and retailers.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Latone, 51, is the president and co-chief executive of the Shopping Center Group, a company based in Atlanta that serves as a consultant and adviser to property owners and retailers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for Sept. 11, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ‘Scouted’
abstract: The filmmakers examine the lives of teenage girls in Siberia who audition at open casting calls for fashion models.
lead_paragraph: In this Op-Doc video we present Masha, a 13-year-old aspiring model who attends an open casting call in Siberia, Russia. Sometimes hundreds of girls audition at these model castings; other times a few dozen show up. Rural Siberia is a thriving location for scouts hoping to recruit teenage girls as young as 12 and export them overseas. The Op-Doc also introduces Ashley Arbaugh, a former American model turned international model scout, who seeks out teenagers with her Russian comrades. When we filmed Masha in 2009, the scouts said that these girls — often poor in a society of extreme income inequality — are desirable not just for their looks but because they are malleable and easier to guide and direct.

headline: The Fire HD: More Soot Than Sparks
abstract: Amazon says its Kindle Fire HD is “the best tablet at any price.” But there’s no GPS, no to-do list, no notes app. What’s the attraction?
lead_paragraph: I’m not exactly sure what’s been seeping into the water supply at Amazon’s Seattle offices, but it’s making the executives a little loopy.

headline: Aurora’s Aftermath
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Editorials']
abstract: Victims of the July 20 shooting spree continue to struggle to rebuild their lives. And the cost of doing so is a little-noticed part of the tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two months after the shooting spree in Colorado that left 12 dead and 58 wounded, survivors, civic leaders and generous citizens are confronting the victims’ traumas and a future of costly care. This is the painful challenge that communities across America typically have to face after the national spotlight moves elsewhere. It is a little-noticed part of the repetitious ritual of gun tragedy — the reckoning in fuller measure of the damage shooters inflict in the absence of sensible gun controls.

headline: False Promises on Ovarian Cancer
abstract: New evidence on screening tests is disturbing. The tests provide no gain, but can lead to harmful surgeries and complications.
lead_paragraph: New evidence that women are more likely to be harmed than helped by screening tests for ovarian cancer is disturbing. The tests do nothing to prevent healthy women from dying from the usually fatal disease. Yet they often lead doctors to perform needless surgeries that cause serious complications in many patients.

headline: Quick Start to Program Offering Immigrants a Reprieve
abstract: More than 72,000 young immigrants who are in the United States illegally have applied for two-year deportation deferrals, and this week the first approvals have been granted.
lead_paragraph: One month after the Obama administration started a program to suspend deportations of young illegal immigrants, more than 72,000 of them have applied for the temporary reprieve, senior immigration officials said on Tuesday, and this week the first approvals have been granted.

headline: Mets Fail to Generate Enough Runs Behind Dickey
abstract: For the 12th consecutive home game, the Mets could not score more than three runs, setting a franchise record, as R. A. Dickey failed in trying to pitch for his 19th victory.
lead_paragraph: Competing impulses collided Tuesday during the Mets’ 5-3 loss to the Washington Nationals at Citi Field, providing a glimpse at how the team will align its priorities moving through these final weeks of the season.

headline: A Mystery in Harlem as Several Vehicles Are Set on Fire
abstract: About 10 cars were damaged, most of them in the hours before dawn. Police and fire officials said the investigation was continuing, and no motive had been established.
lead_paragraph: The day began like any other for Oral Walker: he left his apartment in Harlem on Tuesday morning to take his daughter to school, and from there planned to continue on to work. But he got no farther than the sidewalk, stopped by the sight of his family’s new car, destroyed by fire.

headline: Bigger Dorms, Bigger Bills
abstract: The size of college dorms has grown, but so has the tuition, a reader observes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Accountable for Torture
abstract: A lawyer with Human Rights First responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tough Choices in Dealing With Iran
abstract: Readers react to Bill Keller’s column about whether we can live with a nuclear Iran.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Putin Impedes European Inquiry of State Fuel Supplier
abstract: A decree issued by President Vladimir V. Putin prevents Russian companies like the natural gas giant Gazprom from providing foreign regulators with information without Kremlin approval.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia issued a decree on Tuesday that had the effect of prohibiting Gazprom, the state natural gas giant, from cooperating with European Union investigators trying to build an antitrust case against it.

headline: Chicago Teachers’ Folly
abstract: The strike hurts students and their families, and it could damage the union’s credibility.
lead_paragraph: Teachers’ strikes, because they hurt children and their families, are never a good idea. The strike that has roiled the civic climate in Chicago — and left 350,000 children without classes — seems particularly senseless because it is partly a product of a personality clash between the blunt mayor, Rahm Emanuel, and the tough Chicago Teachers Union president, Karen Lewis. Beyond that, the strike is based on union discontent with sensible policy changes — including the teacher evaluation system required by Illinois law — that are increasingly popular across the country and are unlikely to be rolled back, no matter how long the union stays out.

headline: For Valentine, a Ruined Season and Spoiler’s Role
abstract: Stuck in last place in the A.L. East, the Red Sox and Manager Bobby Valentine could salvage some respect if they can block the Yankees’ road to the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON

headline: Dissecting Romney’s Vietnam Stance at Stanford
abstract: Mitt Romney’s position in favor of the war during his freshman year reflected his family’s views and his faith in traditional values but later shifted markedly.
lead_paragraph: It was late November 1965 when the poet Allen Ginsberg ignited the flower-power movement in Berkeley, Calif., urging protesters against the Vietnam War to greet the police with blossoms, not rocks. A few miles south, at buttoned-down Stanford University, young men would exchange chinos for jeans that academic year. An antiwar activist would become student body president; anti-draft protesters would occupy the university president’s office.

headline: Mitt Romney at Stanford
abstract: In 1966, Mitt Romney stood in support of the Vietnam War, protesting students who were upset with Stanford University’s draft deferment policies. His pro-war stance later changed.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, Mitt Romney stood in support of the Vietnam War, protesting students who were upset with Stanford University’s draft deferment policies. His pro-war stance later changed.

headline: Equity Firms Like Bain Are Depicted as Colluding
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Heavily redacted documents showed top private equity firms agreeing among themselves on which would bid on takeover targets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In court documents that lawyers for Bain Capital sought to keep secret, the company and other leading private equity firms are depicted as unofficial partners in a bid-rigging conspiracy aimed at holding down the prices of businesses they were seeking to buy.

headline: A Lawsuit Against Private Equity
abstract: A section of a federal lawsuit brought against Bain Capital and other leading private equity firms discussed the $32.1 billion leveraged buyout in 2006 of HCA, a health care company, by Bain, KKR, Merrill Lynch and other other firms.
lead_paragraph: A section of a federal lawsuit brought against Bain Capital and other leading private equity firms discussed the $32.1 billion leveraged buyout in 2006 of HCA, a health care company, by Bain, KKR, Merrill Lynch and other other firms.

headline: In Quest for River’s Power, an Underwater Test Spin
keywords: ['Tidal and Wave Power', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Hydroelectric Power']
abstract: If Verdant Power is to generate electricity at the bottom of the East River, it will first have to build a turbine that can withstand the river’s strong and shifting currents.
lead_paragraph: Could cars in New York City someday run on electricity generated at the bottom of the East River?

headline: Spain: Marchers Demand Independence for Catalonia, as Budget Cuts Bolster Separatism
abstract: Hundreds of thousands, waving flags and carrying signs, rallied in Barcelona on Tuesday for independence for the region of Catalonia.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of people rallied in Barcelona on Tuesday for independence for the region of Catalonia. Marchers waved yellow-and-red-striped Catalan flags, below, and carried signs demanding independence from Spain. The police estimated the crowd at 1.5 million people. In response to Spain’s financial crisis, the Spanish government is forcing regions like Catalonia to enact drastic budget cuts. Catalonia, which accounts for 19 percent of Spain’s gross domestic product, has long demanded greater fiscal autonomy from Madrid and a lower contribution to a system that redistributes tax revenue to poorer regions. Catalonia also has the largest debt among Spanish regions, which has forced its government to make some of the deepest budget cuts in Spain.

headline: Rhode Island Primary Tests New Voter ID Law
abstract: Rhode Island’s state primary on Tuesday gave its new voter identification law its most strenuous exercise yet, stirring dissent and praise from voters who lined up with ID cards, but few problems were reported.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Candy McSwain and Bonnie Stevenson, two poll workers in this city’s diverse Elmwood neighborhood, peered at Jeziel Jared Lopez’s passport and expired state ID card and consulted the state’s new list of acceptable forms of voter identification.

headline: Simple Yet Effortless Mastery
abstract: Narciso Rodriguez packed so much into his show, from minimalist dresses to nearly baroque embroidery.
lead_paragraph: Narciso Rodriguez started out as a minimalist designer 15 years ago, became known as a sublime colorist over the last several years and now, after showing his spring collection tonight, can henceforth be known simply as the master. So much was packed into his show, from the minimalist dresses to the nearly baroque embroidery, and yet he made it all look so simple and effortless.

headline: National Schools Debate Is on Display in Chicago
abstract: Questions on how teachers should be evaluated have been added to traditional issues of pay, benefits and working conditions as Chicago teachers walk picket lines.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — What started here as a traditional labor fight over pay, benefits and working conditions has exploded into a dramatic illustration of the national debate over how public school districts should rate teachers.

headline: Letter to Odin
abstract: Robert W. Harris gets possessive.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This is interesting. We’ve seen scores of letter and word addition themes, but have we ever seen a (virtual) punctuation addition theme?

headline: Corrections: September 12, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 12, 2012.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: France: Former Premier Is Questioned in Fraud Case
abstract: Gendarmes questioned Dominique de Villepin on Tuesday on suspicion of involvement in fraud that investigators believe was committed by a friend, the businessman Régis Bulot.
lead_paragraph: Gendarmes questioned the former prime minister Dominique de Villepin on Tuesday on suspicion of involvement in fraud that investigators believe was committed by a friend, the businessman Régis Bulot. It was unclear whether charges might be brought against Mr. de Villepin, who was released after several hours of questioning, a police spokesman said. Investigators believe that Mr. Bulot, the former president of Relais et Châteaux, a luxury hotel and restaurant network, embezzled more than $2 billion from the company. In a recorded telephone conversation from 2010, Mr. de Villepin, who was no longer in government, appears to tell Mr. Bulot that he pressured managers at the company to keep the fraud a secret, according to French news media reports. Mr. Bulot’s lawyer told the newsmagazine Le Nouvel Observateur that his client had embezzled about $640,000, but that Mr. de Villepin had been unaware of it.

headline: New Breed of Robotics Aims to Help People Walk Again
abstract: Several companies and research labs are working on wearable robots to help disabled people walk or to make the human body superhuman.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Calif. — When Joey Abicca pokes a metal crutch into the ground with his right arm, tiny motors start whirling around his left leg, lifting it and moving it forward. When he does the same with his left arm, the motors whir to life again and his right leg takes a step. The metallic whine is like something out of the movie “RoboCop.”

headline: Study of U.S. Health Care System Finds Both Waste and Opportunity to Improve
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Research', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors']
abstract: The Institute of Medicine says the American medical system loses $750 billion annually by squandering 30 cents of every dollar spent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American medical system squanders 30 cents of every dollar spent on health care, according to new calculations by the respected Institute of Medicine. But in all that waste and misuse, policy experts and economists see a significant opportunity — a way to curb runaway health spending, to improve medical outcomes and even to put the economy on sounder footing.

headline: Britain: British Schools Offer More Upward Mobility for Students Than American Ones, Report Says
abstract: British schools now do a better job of lifting students up the social ladder, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report published Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: British schools now do a better job than American schools of lifting students up the social ladder, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report published Tuesday. In Britain, a student whose parents never graduated from high school has a 60 percent chance of attending college, while in the United States the odds are just 29 percent, one of the lowest levels among the 34 countries with advanced economies that make up the O.E.C.D., which is based in Paris.

headline: In A.L. Central Race, It’s Old School vs. Older School
abstract: Preaching basics in his first season managing, Robin Ventura has the White Sox two games ahead of the Tigers, who are led by the grizzled and veteran Jim Leyland.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — One is old by a manager’s standards. At 67, he smokes Marlboro Reds before and after games, dispensing nuggets of baseball wisdom collected over a more-than-20-year managerial career as the smoke curls up past his silver mustache and around his thinning hair.

headline: Candidates Look to Balance Need for Campaigning With Need for Money
abstract: Having both declined public money, President Obama and Mitt Romney are committing to ambitious fund-raising schedules that are eating into valuable campaign time.
lead_paragraph: In the closing weeks of a closely fought presidential campaign, Mitt Romney will be mingling with wealthy Republican donors in Chicago, San Diego and San Francisco, hundreds of miles from the swing state voters who will make or break his White House bid.

headline: Gaza: Bulldozers Raze Part of Forgotten Neighborhood
abstract: The Hamas government demolished more than a dozen makeshift homes this week in the impoverished enclave, and officials said they would soon remove the rest of the structures.
lead_paragraph: The Hamas government demolished more than a dozen makeshift homes this week in an impoverished enclave known as the Forgotten Neighborhood, and officials said they would soon remove the rest of the structures, which were built without permits on public land. Residents said that two bulldozers came to the Gaza City enclave on Monday and razed the rusted-zinc shanties that housed about 18 Bedouin families, some for more than two decades. The neighborhood was the focus of an article on Monday in The New York Times about poverty in Gaza. Amal Shamaly, a spokeswoman for the Land Authority, said that all “illegal building” on government land would be removed, and that a security compound was planned for the area. Residents said that they had been sent demolition orders several years ago, and again several months ago, but that no action was taken until this week. The families who lost their houses were staying in a tent on Tuesday, while some of the women and children moved in with relatives.

headline: Dr. Thomas Szasz, Psychiatrist Who Led Movement Against His Field, Dies at 92
abstract: Dr. Szasz wrote “The Myth of Mental Illness,” a book that questioned the legitimacy of his field and made enemies of many fellow doctors.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Szasz, a psychiatrist whose 1961 book “The Myth of Mental Illness” questioned the legitimacy of his field and provided the intellectual grounding for generations of critics, patient advocates and antipsychiatry activists, making enemies of many fellow doctors, died Saturday at his home in Manlius, N.Y. He was 92.

headline: Lake Is Blamed for Stench Blown Across Southern California
abstract: Decaying organic matter in the Salton Sea, a shrinking saline accident of irrigation in the Colorado Desert, is thought to have caused a sulfurous olfactory insult.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Across Southern California, as far afield as Ventura County to the north of here, Orange County to the south and San Bernardino to the east, residents awoke this week to an olfactory insult: a sulfurous smell, like rotten eggs, wafting across hundreds of miles, source unknown.

headline: States Where Amazon Collects Taxes
abstract: A map showing states for which Amazon collects taxes now, and in the future.
lead_paragraph: A map showing states for which Amazon collects taxes now, and in the future.

headline: Must Teachers and School Officials Be Foes?
abstract: Do relations between teachers and officials need to cool off and become more cooperative, or can needed change come only through confrontation? What approach would retain the best teachers?

headline: Obama Plans Wisconsin Advertising, Signaling the State Is Now in Play
abstract: Television ads for the president will start Thursday, a sign that the state is more competitive than his campaign had once expected.
lead_paragraph: “On, Wisconsin!”

headline: Questions Surround Agents Absent From Steroids Report
abstract: Questions have arisen as to why two prominent agents were not mentioned in the Mitchell report on steroid use in baseball, even when players they represented were implicated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since George J. Mitchell released his report nearly five years ago on the use of steroids in baseball, he has been repeatedly praised by members of Congress, Commissioner Bud Selig and others for conducting a robust and independent investigation that produced the most comprehensive account of how steroids soiled the sport.

headline: Grey Poupon Ups the Ante on Assuming an Elite Image
abstract: A centuries-old mustard brand will use a Facebook campaign to ensure that its users meet its standards.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, a sign of sophistication was to use Grey Poupon mustard, just like the rich guys in their Rolls-Royces in the brand’s memorable commercial of that era. The premium condiment brand — returning after a long quiet period — is again focusing its marketing on good taste, but this time consumers have to qualify for it.

headline: With Swift Kick, U.S. Picks Up Important Win
abstract: The United States dominated play in its second World Cup qualifying match against Jamaica, but the team needed a free kick by Herculez Gomez in the second half to earn the victory.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Jurgen Klinsmann shouted. He pleaded. He gestured frantically, bending his knees and hunching over as if poised to pounce when his players happened to come near. Klinsmann, the United States national team coach, wore a path in front of the Americans’ bench on Tuesday night, never sitting down during a World Cup qualifying match against Jamaica that was more meaningful — and difficult — than many observers expected.

headline: Anger Over a Film Fuels Anti-American Attacks in Libya and Egypt
abstract: Protesters upset over an American-made video denouncing Islam attacked the United States Consulate in Libya, while Egyptian demonstrators stormed over the walls of the United States Embassy in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Protesters angry over an amateurish American-made video denouncing Islam attacked the United States Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, on Tuesday, killing a State Department officer, while Egyptian demonstrators stormed over the fortified walls of the United States Embassy here.

headline: President of PepsiCo Resigns to Become a Chief Elsewhere
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Suspensions, Dismissals and Resignations']
abstract: With John Compton leaving, the company promoted Zein Abdalla, the chief executive of PepsiCo’s European operations.
lead_paragraph: PepsiCo’s president, John Compton, is stepping down after less than a year in the job to run a large privately held company in his home state of Tennessee, PepsiCo said in a statement Tuesday.

headline: Embracing Role as Surrogate, Clinton Hits Campaign Trail
abstract: Before a crowd of 2,300, Bill Clinton reprised much of the defense of President Obama’s first term that he delivered at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Bill Clinton, fresh from an appearance at the Democratic convention that confirmed his status as President Obama’s No. 1 surrogate and all-around B.F.F., took to the campaign trail in this battleground state on Tuesday, declaring that “we’ve got a lot of reasons to vote, and we’ve got a good candidate to vote for.”

headline: Western and Afghan Officials Split Over Karzai Nomination for Spy Chief
abstract: President Hamid Karzai’s pick to lead the Afghan spy agency, Asadullah Khalid, has been accused of torture and drug trafficking, but is also seen as a man with political skills and wide connections.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai’s determination to make a close aide, Asadullah Khalid, his next intelligence chief has divided Western officials here, some of whom say they are troubled by allegations of torture and drug trafficking against Mr. Khalid and worry that in such a powerful role he would be a step back for the country.

headline: Amazon, Forced to Collect a Tax, Is Adding Roots
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'E-Commerce', 'Delivery Services']
abstract: By building warehouses across the country, the retailer hopes to cut as much as a day off its two-day shipping times.
lead_paragraph: PATTERSON, Calif. — At the moment, it is little more than dirt and gravel. But a sunbaked field at the edge of this farming town will play a significant role in one of the most ambitious retailing ventures of the era: the relentless quest by the online mall Amazon.com to become all things to all shoppers.

headline: Yankees Slide Back in Loss to Red Sox
abstract: Jacoby Ellsbury hit a game-winning single in the bottom of the ninth inning to lift the struggling Boston Red Sox over the Yankees in front of a sold-out crowd at Fenway Park.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Fenway Park has had very few opportunities for celebration over the past calendar year. After one of the most excruciating collapses in baseball history last season, the Red Sox are coming to the end of another agonizing season in which their fans have soured on a team fraught with controversy, negativity and mounting losses.

headline: Mapping Military Needs, Aided by a Big Projection
abstract: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is asking top military officials to examine what challenges will face American forces in five years and beyond.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three times so far this year, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the regional war-fighting commanders have assembled at a military base south of the capital, where a giant map of the world, larger than a basketball court, was laid out on the ground, giving the sessions an appearance of a lethally earnest game of Risk.

headline: The Elephant in the Room
abstract: Is the memory of George W. Bush’s presidency dragging Mitt Romney down?
lead_paragraph: If a polling lead in the first week of September were a guarantee of victory two months later, then John McCain and Al Gore would have both been sworn in as president of the United States. So no, President Obama’s convention bounce has not – repeat, has not — sealed the election for the Democrats.

headline: Dutch Voters May Point Way for Rest of Europe
abstract: The Dutch electorate will go to the polls on Wednesday with economic stagnation and euro skepticism on its mind, in a vote that may foreshadow next year’s elections in Germany.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — The Netherlands is an unusually good European weather vane. It may be comparatively tiny, with only 16.7 million people, and comparatively rich and secure, but it forecasts where the Continent is headed.

headline: Relief Crisis Grows as Refugees Stream Out of Syria
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Two million Syrian citizens who desperately need help are not receiving it, according to international officials, and with thousands fleeing daily, the exodus now exceeds a quarter of a million.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — International relief officials reported an increasingly grim aid crisis stemming from the Syria conflict on Tuesday, with two million people there not getting desperately needed help, and a sudden acceleration of refugees overwhelming the ability of neighboring countries to absorb them.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Chain Stores Said to Lead Firms in Use of Sun Power
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: Large chain stores, more than any other type of business, rely on rooftop solar power to help meet their energy needs, according to a report.
lead_paragraph: The aisles of a typical Walgreens drugstore are stacked with products promoting their green attributes, whether they are towels made from recycled paper or makeup brushes made from fast-growing grass.

headline: Building a Home Online to Suit Electronic Music
abstract: A new company, DJZ, plans to introduce an online hub that will aggregate news about electronic dance music and celebrate top D.J.’s as cultural heroes.
lead_paragraph: The music industry’s latest gold rush is over dance music, which lures tens of thousands of fans to festivals and dominates pop radio.

headline: How Testosterone May Alter the Brain After Exercise
abstract: New science on sex hormones and the brain sheds light on how jogging and other workouts may improve the ability to remember and think.
lead_paragraph: It’s widely accepted among scientists that regular exercise transforms the brain, improving the ability to remember and think. And a growing and very appealing body of science has established that exercise spurs the creation of new brain cells, a process known as neurogenesis. But just how jogging or other workouts affect the structure of the brain has remained enigmatic, with many steps in the process unexplained.

abstract: This word has appeared in 36 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: wizened •\ˈwi-zənd also ˈwe-\• adjective

headline: Beck Takes His Conservative Internet Shows to the Dish Network
abstract: The conservative talk show host, Glenn Beck, is taking his show, TheBlaze TV, to the satellite television network and plans for it to be available on cable TV, too.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Beck is bringing his brand of conservative commentary back to the television set.

headline: Teixeira Learns a Lesson in Caution
abstract: The Yankees’ first baseman, Mark Teixeira, has learned from a previous injury that returning prematurely can come with more risks.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Mark Teixeira’s decision to play Saturday night when his stiff left calf was not healed will not be forgotten when it comes time to make a similar decision in the next few weeks.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (1) vs. Jamaica (0)
abstract: Player ratings for the United States’ 1-0 victory over Jamaica in a World Cup qualifier in Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The United States national team put itself back on track to qualify for the final round of Concacaf World Cup qualifying when it earned a 1-0 victory over Jamaica on Tuesday night.

headline: Will China Arm Its Fishermen to Protect a ‘Core Interest’?
abstract: The baleful rhetoric in a territorial dispute between China and Japan took a turn for the worse on Wednesday as Beijing signaled that the issue was now one of its “core interests,” terminology that puts the matter on the level of political issues like Taiwan and Tibet.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The bellicose bluster between China and Japan continues to grow more heated, with two armed Chinese surveillance vessels circling the disputed Diaoyu islands and the Foreign Ministry in Beijing saying that “long gone are the days when the Chinese nation was subject to bullying and humiliation from others.”

abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: In India, the Music Fest Comes of Age
abstract: Better organization and top-notch acts mean a great line-up of upcoming events.
lead_paragraph: Music festivalgoers in India are a happy lot these days. After spending the last decade looking enviously westward, and bemoaning the lack of Coachellas and Glastonburys at home, festival options now crowd India’s social calendars.

headline: The Chevaline Murders and Journalism on the Two Sides of the Channel
abstract: The grisly and gripping murder at Chevaline reveals once more that the difference in how you view “news” depends on where you are.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Headlines to compare and contrast: Sept. 7, on bbc.co.uk, “Annecy killings: French media hunt for answers in murder case;” Sept. 9, on guardian.co.uk, “Alps shootings: how French press buried the story.”

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 12, 2012
abstract: Can you find the possible average product review score on a Web site, if given the percentage of reviews that have four or five stars?
lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “The Best Book Reviews Money Can Buy.”

headline: What to Do With a Lion in the Suburbs
abstract: Who captured a “fat, fluffy and young” lioness who had been living in the suburbs of Nairobi for at least four months?
lead_paragraph: WHO captured a “fat, fluffy and young” lioness who had been living in the suburbs of Nairobi for at least four months?

headline: What ‘Back-to-the-Land’ Skills Do You Have, or Wish You Had?
abstract: Gardening, beekeeping, cheese-making, house-building: what skills of this kind do you have?
lead_paragraph: Gardening, beekeeping, cheese-making, house-building: all these are skills being celebrated around the nation during International Homesteading Education Month.

headline: In Victory for Merkel, German Court Ruling Favors European Bailout Fund
abstract: Germany’s constitutional court gave Chancellor Angela Merkel a significant victory in her bid to master the debt crisis that has buffeted Europe and endangered its common currency.
lead_paragraph: KARLSRUHE, Germany — The Federal Constitutional Court in Germany gave Chancellor Angela Merkel a significant victory on Wednesday in her bid to master the debt crisis that has buffeted the Continent for years and endangered its common currency, granting approval to one of the main pillars of her strategy.

headline: Four Decades of Photographing the Human Condition
abstract: In an exhibition in Paris, four decades of Peter Turnley’s photographs are on display from around the world, encompassing major conflicts and quiet, quotidian moments.
lead_paragraph: Peter Turnley is an archetypal photojournalist. At last count, he had worked in more than 90 countries, traveling to far-flung corners of the earth to cover many of the most important international news events of the last 30 years. Choose a historic moment and Mr. Turnley was there: from revolutions in Eastern Europe to the collapse of the Soviet Union; the end of apartheid in South Africa and genocide in Rwanda; and both the Persian Gulf and Balkan wars.

headline: Keeping Up With the Kennedys
abstract: Joe Kennedy III is trying to follow in the steps of his father (and grandfather and great-uncles and so on).
lead_paragraph: Doggone-It is a small doggie day-care and grooming salon in Needham, Mass., a quiet suburb of Boston. It caters to area residents and their pets, but on a hot morning in July, a young man in a dark suit, followed by an equally young and well-dressed entourage, entered the store and sent Doggone-It’s half-dozen dogs into a frenzy. Joseph P. Kennedy III introduced himself to the store’s owners and explained, over the din of barking dogs, that he was running for Congress. Kennedy smiled and asked the women how their day was going (“Good!”), if they had any concerns that he should know about (“Don’t think so!”) and if they would please e-mail him if they ever did (“Sure!”).

headline: Hong Kong Impedes Trip to Islands, Activists Say
abstract: A group of activists who set off a confrontation between China and Japan by sailing to disputed islands last month said Wednesday that a return trip was complicated by legal and financial barriers.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Ending the immediate likelihood that they would repeat their visit to disputed islands last month and worsen a confrontation between China and Japan, a group of activists revealed Wednesday that their vessel was not seaworthy enough for a return to the islands and that they faced legal and financial barriers to fixing it.

headline: More Than 300 Killed in Pakistani Factory Fires
abstract: Fires engulfed two factories in two major cities, killing more than 300 and reviving long-running questions about the regulation of the country’s manufacturing sector.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Fire ravaged a textile factory complex in the commercial hub of Karachi early Wednesday, killing almost 300 workers trapped behind locked doors and raising questions about the woeful lack of regulation in a vital sector of Pakistan’s faltering economy.

headline: Changes in Inequality the 21st Century
abstract: Inequality in wage growth — with more highly skilled workers gaining ground more quickly than the less skilled — was unabated in the Great Recession and its aftermath, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Early Word: Defense
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.

headline: Dealers Peer Into Chrysler Product Pipeline
abstract: At a meeting in Las Vegas, the automaker discussed details of its second major product push since emerging from its bankruptcy in 2009.
lead_paragraph: Although Chrysler Group has made significant strides toward rehabilitating its finances since emerging from bankruptcy in 2009, the company has avoided the complacency that plagued it in previous times of growth. Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Chrysler and Fiat, introduced 66 car and truck models to the company’s dealers at a meeting in Las Vegas on Monday.

headline: A Nonconformist Sizes Up Her College Prospects
abstract: Chandler Buckingham, a student at Rogers High School in Rogers, Ark., is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: The best thing that could happen during my college admissions experience would be to get accepted to a college that I really love and receive a full ride to go there.

headline: A 210-Million-Year-Old Puzzle
abstract: The geologic record contains a rich archive of past life and its environments.
lead_paragraph: Randall Irmis, curator of paleontology at the Natural History Museum of Utah and assistant professor at the University of Utah, is investigating the rise of dinosaurs in southeastern Utah.

headline: Play Music, Not Politics
abstract: Thank you, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, for holding a concert Monday in Tel Aviv when so many other musicians won’t play here.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — The crowd and the critics were happy, but to me, the Red Hot Chili Peppers’s concert on Monday night was a nuisance. Hayarkon Park, where the band performed in front of some 50,000 sweaty Israelis, is ten minutes away from home. And it’s where I jog in the evenings.

headline: Week 1 Film Review: In Praise of Patriots’ Defense
abstract: If this is how the Patriots’ defense is going to play all season, the N.F.L. might as well save us all time and give Robert Kraft the Lombardi Trophy right now.
lead_paragraph: A closer look at the opening week of games, with the benefit of film analysis.

headline: Weary of Crisis, but Wary of Change
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A proposal to give the European Union more control over banking has stirred up dissent from countries that have doubts about the plan’s practicality.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Commission president, José Manuel Barroso, described the proposal for a single supervisor for the region’s banks on Wednesday as the first step in a renewed drive for a federally unified Europe.

headline: Jungle Nook
abstract: In the unspoiled wilds of southwestern Uganda and northern Rwanda, Volcanoes Safaris has built a string of high-design lodges that have played host to image-conscious politicos like Rahm Emanuel and former Senator Bill Frist.
lead_paragraph: In the unspoiled wilds of southwestern Uganda and northern Rwanda, Volcanoes Safaris has built a string of high-design lodges that have played host to image-conscious politicos like Rahm Emanuel and former Senator Bill Frist. What brings them here are not just the land-before-time vistas and the chance to track the elusive silverback gorilla. It’s also the company’s strenuous commitment to do-gooding — a comfort to travelers who might otherwise be reluctant to visit very poor countries rivened by past conflicts. Volcanoes’ newest outpost, Kyambura Gorge (above), sits on a once-derelict coffee plantation near Uganda’s Queen Elizabeth National Park. The eight-room eco-lodge supports a collective of coffee farmers and has cleverly used detritus from local villages in its design. Human-animal conflict is a very real problem in these parts; elephants can destroy a family’s subsistence crops in minutes. So Volcanoes has helped villagers learn beekeeping — elephants are terrified of bees — which allows them to protect crops and establish a sweet new revenue stream: honey. Four-day safaris from $510 per night; volcanoessafaris.com.

headline: Teaming Up to End Homelessness
abstract: Two social change groups recently joined forces. The result? They are now housing homeless people faster than ever.
lead_paragraph: This week in Washington, people from Detroit, Tucson, New Orleans, San Diego, Atlanta and nine other cities gathered to celebrate doing the impossible. The participants share a tough job:  getting homeless veterans off the street and into apartments and social services.  They work in cities that have large numbers of homeless vets — but most of their cities were making only modest progress toward housing them.

headline: Is It a Mistake to Pick an Employee of the Month?
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Small Business']
abstract: People seem happy, but the question I now ask myself is, Is it all a front?
lead_paragraph: I recently met a management consultant and business author who asked me if I had an “employee of the month” program. I said I did, at which point he reprimanded me for the error of my ways. His argument was that it was a waste of time and was actually counterproductive; only one person wins, and the rest are resentful. My managers and I actually considered that before we started the program, but the conversation with the consultant, Aubrey C. Daniels, got me thinking about it again. As I have gotten older, I have become more open-minded about recognizing that my way might not be the best way.

headline: Libya Attack Brings Challenges for U.S.
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: The violent deaths of four American diplomatic personnel in Libya provoked an uproar in Washington on Wednesday, presenting new challenges in the volatile Middle East less than two months before the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Islamist militants armed with antiaircraft weapons and rocket-propelled grenades stormed a lightly defended United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, late Tuesday, killing the American ambassador and three members of his staff and raising questions about the radicalization of countries swept up in the Arab Spring.

headline: Q&A: Digital Copies for DVD Owners
abstract: The UltraViolet system provides a digital copy of a purchased DVD or Blu-ray disc for use on mobile devices.

headline: Private Equity Group Aims to Relate to Average Americans
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Private Equity', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A public relations campaign from the Private Equity Growth Capital Council seeks to counteract the image problems the industry has faced during the election year cycle. The latest installment points to the industry’s ties to pension funds, university endowments and charities.
lead_paragraph: The private equity industry would like you to know that buyouts are not just about making Wall Street rich.

headline: Europe Presses Israel to Put Faith in Iran Sanctions
abstract: European governments are increasingly nervous about the possibility of an Israel strike on Iran and have been trying to persuade the government of Benjamin Netanyahu to give tougher sanctions on Tehran time to work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European governments are displaying increasing nervousness about the possibility of an Israeli strike on Iran and are trying to persuade the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that tougher sanctions are still the best weapon to curb Tehran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: A Phone Good to 2027 on One Charge
abstract: The SpareOne emergency phone claims a standby time of up to 15 years using a standard AA lithium battery.
lead_paragraph: How long the battery lasts in a phone when you aren’t using it is called standby time, and is usually measured in days or, in the case of a battery life champ like the Droid RAZR Maxx, about two weeks.

headline: Rockers Playing for Beer: Fair Play?
abstract: The rock musician Amanda Palmer has invited fans who play strings, saxophone and brass to join her on stage during a tour, not for money but for beer, and many professional musicians are outraged.
lead_paragraph: The rock musician Amanda Palmer says she is giving a gift to her fans by inviting those who play strings, saxophone and brass to join her on stage during a tour. Joy and beer are the recompense.

headline: On Our Radar: A Pipeline Land Grab?
abstract: The replacement of a pipeline that ruptured in 2010 with a line that has a far bigger diameter has some Michigan residents up in arms.
lead_paragraph: The replacement of Line 6B, a 43-year-old pipeline that leaked more than one million gallons of heavy crude into the Kalamazoo River in Michigan, faces opposition from landowners who do not want more of their land taken over to accommodate the new one. [InsideClimate News]

headline: The Potential Value of In-Game N.F.L. Predictions
abstract: A smartphone application that gives an updated prediction for football games after each play may be as notable for what it says about gambling as for what it reveals about football.
lead_paragraph: The creator of a new smartphone application that gives an updated prediction for football games after each play in real time says it can offer fans a fresh look at the game. But the app may be as notable for what it says about gambling as for what it reveals about the game.

headline: Answers to Your Questions About Student Loans, Part 1

lead_paragraph: This week, two New York Times reporters and Geoffry Walsh, an expert on student debt and bankruptcy at the National Consumer Law Center, are answering questions about ways to avoid default, pay off student loans or try to expunge student loans through bankruptcy court. The first set of answers is below.

headline: Obama Condemns Attack That Kills Ambassador to Libya
abstract: An attack that killed the United States ambassador to Libya on Tuesday night has brought the issue of foreign policy to the forefront of the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: An attack that killed the American ambassador to Libya on Tuesday night has brought foreign policy to the forefront of the presidential race, puncturing the solemn unity seen on the campaign trail one day earlier as both candidates observed the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Tinsel Gowns
abstract: The splashy show opening next month at London’s Victoria and Albert Museum, “Hollywood Costume,” will unspool like a highlight reel of classic cinema getups.
lead_paragraph: The splashy show opening next month at London’s Victoria and Albert Museum, “Hollywood Costume,” will unspool like a highlight reel of classic cinema getups. There’s Dorothy’s pinafore and ruby slippers, Walter Plunkett’s immortal “drapery dress” for Scarlett O’Hara and Hubert de Givenchy’s sleeveless black gown from “Breakfast at Tiffany’s.” The exhibit, which runs through January, is curated by Deborah Nadoolman Landis, a costume designer who’s thrown in her own rugged creation for Indiana Jones from “Raiders of the Lost Ark.”

headline: Sept. 11: Florida a True Must-Win for Romney
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: In a close election, Mitt Romney would face a daunting challenge if he failed to win Florida’s 29 electoral votes.
lead_paragraph: Florida has a well-established reputation as a swing state. But as the election season has worn on, it has come to look even more important. Florida now ranks a clear second on our list of tipping point states, those most likely to provide the decisive votes in the Electoral College, behind only Ohio.

headline: In Letter to Friends, Slain U.S. Ambassador Expressed Hope
abstract: Chris Stevens arrived back in Tripoli in May as the U.S. ambassador. In July, he e-mailed friends to give his first impressions about the country after the fall of Muammar al-Qaddafi and his hopes for the future.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I last heard from Chris Stevens two months ago, just after he hosted a July 4 reception in the gardens of the U.S. embassy in Tripoli, Libya.

headline: Daily Report: Amazon Will Collect Sales Tax to Expand Boldly
abstract: By building warehouses across the country, Amazon.com hopes to cut as much as a day off its two-day shipping times. But the warehouses also mean it must start collecting sales tax in many states. Amazon will begin collecting sales tax in California on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is building massive distribution centers near several major cities. This multibillion-dollar building frenzy means Amazon is about to lose perhaps its biggest competitive edge — that it does not charge sales tax on the vast majority of its customers, reports David Streitfeld of The New York Times.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: These senryu, haiku that focus on people, not nature, were written from a Central Park bench at 72nd Street.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Study Finds Acupuncture Provides True Pain Relief
abstract: A study finds that acupuncture provides true pain relief, how to pare 401(k) expenses, three tips for better Google searching and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Under the British, Satire and Critical Cartooning Thrived in India
abstract: A sharp contrast to the government’s reaction to cartoon critiques today.
lead_paragraph: On Christmas Day in 1887, a Mumbai paper, Parsee Punch, ran a cartoon depicting India striking a gong of Congress by the ear of a slumbering John Bull. “Rousing the sentinel,” ran the caption. It was only one of thousands of politically charged illustrations that would be carried in the weekly, which first appeared in July 1854 and was still being published well into the 1930s under the name Hindi Punch.

headline: Jason Sudeikis, and His Romney Impression, to Stay at ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: Retaining him had been a priority for the show, which is losing two of its biggest recent stars, Kristen Wiig and Andy Samberg.
lead_paragraph: With just four days before somebody will have to play Mitt Romney on NBC’s “Saturday Night Live,” Lorne Michaels cleared up any lingering doubts.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Lindsey Wixson at Donna Karan
abstract: The model Lindsey Wixson transforms, with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury and hair by Eugene Souleiman.
