headline: Economic Fundamentals and the Election
abstract: Consider Ohio.
lead_paragraph: One thing you keep hearing from political pundits is that the state of the economy should lead to a crushing defeat for Obama — no president has ever been reelected with unemployment this high, etc.. But as quite a few better-informed people have pointed out, the political science literature is unambiguous on this point: what matters isn’t the state of the economy, it’s the perception of trend. If the economy appears to be improving, the incumbent tends to do well even if in absolute terms it’s still pretty bad.

headline: The Patent Clues to the Apple iPhone Beyond ‘5’
abstract: An analysis of Apple’s patent filings offer a look at the company’s long-term ambitions for the iPhone. The report by Thomson Reuters points, for example, to a miniature fuel-cell as a power source that could keep an iPhone going for days or weeks without recharging.
lead_paragraph: Bigger screen, longer battery life, clever new features. It’s another version of the iPhone, waiting in the wings to be announced on Wednesday, as everyone expects.

headline: Chesapeake Energy to Sell Assets for $6.9 Billion
abstract: The Chesapeake Energy Corporation said on Wednesday that it had agreed to a series of asset sales as part of an effort to reduce its considerable debt burden.
lead_paragraph: The Chesapeake Energy Corporation said on Wednesday that it had agreed to a series of asset sales, including the majority of its holdings in the Permian Basin. The move will raise $6.9 billion as it seeks to repay some of its considerable debt burden.

headline: Hundreds Die in Two Pakistan Factory Fires
abstract: A fire at a shoe factory in Lahore killed at least 25. Hours later, a fire ravaged a textile factory complex in Karachi, killing almost 300 in Pakistan’s worst industrial accident, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A fire at a shoe factory in Lahore killed at least 25. Hours later, a fire ravaged a textile factory complex in Karachi, killing almost 300 in Pakistan’s worst industrial accident, officials said.

headline: U.S. Lowers Forecast of Crop Yields for a 3rd Time as Record Heat Lingers
abstract: For the third time in three months, the Agriculture Department has decreased its estimates for this fall’s harvest of corn and soybeans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Agriculture Department on Wednesday slightly lowered its forecast of corn and soybean yields as record heat continued to batter crops in the Midwest, making it likely that farmers will bring in one of the lowest harvests in years.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Beck Back on TV, Facebook on Nipplegate
abstract: Also, Katie Couric’s big debut and 9/11 anniversary coverage, or lack thereof.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Beck, who left Fox News for his online TheBlaze TV network, has decided to return to television. Today, the conservative talker is expected to announce a deal with the Dish Network to bring his streaming network to television subscribers, the first of what he hopes are many deals with more traditional distributors.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal: If adulthood is all about accepting the bitter along with the sweet, one of its highest pleasures may well be marmalade. …

headline: TheStreet to Buy The Deal for $5.8 Million
abstract: TheStreet has agreed to acquire The Deal, publisher of a longtime bible of the mergers industry, from the investment firm that manages money for the estate of the late Bruce Wasserstein and other investors.
lead_paragraph: 10:07 a.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Homeland’ Raises the Anxiety Level
abstract: The first season of “Homeland,” Showtime’s terrorism series, gripped many viewers. It returns this month with promises of more intensity and realism in the lives of its troubled characters.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

headline: Why A.I.G. May Not Be Able to Avoid the Volcker Rule
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Robert H. Benmosche, A.I.G.’s chief executive, told CNBC that the insurance company was planning to sell a small bank it owned in an effort to shield the insurer from curbs on proprietary trading. But it is not as simple as that.
lead_paragraph: The American International Group, of all companies, wants to avoid a rule designed to stop risky trading.

headline: The Old Man and the Squirrels
abstract: In the third “Darn Squirrels” book by Adam Rubin and Daniel Salmieri, squirrels join birds on a trip down south.
lead_paragraph: Just what makes a picture book great is often a mystery. A captivating story needn’t be a great adventure or have an especially happy ending. It may not include a single dragon or dinosaur, no princesses, pirates or petulant children. There may be no children at all. And yet somehow the book is still great.

headline: As Chicago Teachers Strike, Students Are on the Loose and at Loose Ends
abstract: Students could be found in contingency programs at schools, in churches and in day care centers. Some slept late, stayed home alone and wandered neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For hundreds of thousands of families here, ordinary life has turned upside down. As Chicago public schoolteachers on Wednesday spent a third day on picket lines, their students could be found in contingency programs at schools, in churches and in costly day care centers. Some slept late, stayed home alone, then wandered their neighborhoods as if there were one more chapter of summer.

headline: Why Men Drop Out of the Labor Force
abstract: The most frequent reason given by men 25 to 54 for leaving the labor force over the last 15 years was illness or disability. For women, a majority left to become household caregivers.
lead_paragraph: As I mentioned on Friday, the share of men who are actively in the labor force is at an all-time low (a trend David Brooks also explored in his column Tuesday). Now Steve Hipple, an economist at the Labor Department, points me to a related paper from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, which helps explain why.

headline: Ask Us Your Digital Etiquette Questions
abstract: By now, we know that it’s rude to play Angry Birds at the table, or ignore your date while you post an update to Facebook and Twitter. But what are the other rules that are starting to form concerning the dos and don’ts of digital etiquette?
lead_paragraph: Most of us know that it’s rude to text at the dinner table or talk on the phone while paying for groceries at the store — even if we do it anyway.

headline: New App to Help Voters Expose Trouble at the Polls
abstract: PollWatchUSA, which enables reports in real time of undue delays, trouble getting or casting a ballot, or harassment or intimidation, will be tested at the primary elections on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A new app that lets voters flag polling-place irregularities will be tested at the primaries on Thursday and, if it works well, will be rolled out citywide for the November general election.

headline: A New Movie Streaming Service Has Commitments From Studios
abstract: The start-up, called M-Go, is expected to announce agreements with five of Hollywood’s six major movie studios that will allow it to stream or rent movies as soon as they are released on DVD or Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: A new digital entertainment service called M-Go is expected on Wednesday to announce agreements with five of Hollywood’s six major movie studios that will allow M-Go to stream or rent movies as soon as they are released on DVD or Blu-ray.

headline: Delhi’s Gutka Ban Hailed, Even By Users
abstract: The popular chewing tobacco and betel nut product is linked to India’s high rates of oral cancer.
lead_paragraph: The Delhi state government’s ban of gutka, a popular product made from betel nut and chewing tobacco, has drawn protests from manufacturers, but found support from an unlikely group of people – those who actually buy and sell the product.

headline: Johnny Got His Part
abstract: The new play “The Two Worlds of Charlie F” casts wounded soldiers in the roles of wounded soldiers. The result is extraordinary.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A letter written by Corporal Stephen Shaw of the Princess of Wales Royal Regiment should have arrived at the White House by now. In it Shaw describes a play in which he has acted, “The Two Worlds of Charlie F.” And he says that he and the rest of the theater company — Bravo 22 Company — who have just finished touring Britain, would love to come to Washington to perform for President Barack Obama and help American W.I.S. (wounded, injured and sick) service personnel get involved in a similar project.

headline: Released From Jail, Cartoonist Vows to Fight Sedition Law
abstract: Cartoonist held in Mumbai wants overturn of sedition law.
lead_paragraph: The cartoonist Aseem Trivedi was released from jail Wednesday, following the Mumbai High Court’s orders.

headline: Three Proven Ways to Convert Visitors Into Buyers Online
abstract: Companies often focus too much on Web traffic and forget to work on turning that traffic into revenue.
lead_paragraph: When potential customers search the Internet for Botox or laser hair removal in the greater New York City area, Verve Medical Cosmetics has long been easy to find. But the company’s Web site has been more successful attracting visitors than it has been converting those visitors into new customers, according to Michele Bracci, the company’s director of marketing and the wife of its founder, Dr. Stephen Bracci.

headline: Budget Airlines Fly South
abstract: As low-cost airlines have grown, their focus has shifted south of the border to destinations like Mexico and Colombia. So what does that mean for fliers?
lead_paragraph: LOW-COST carriers in the United States started out with a domestic agenda, mostly serving shorter routes with no first-class frills like multicourse meals or seats that fold out to beds.

headline: Philip Glass Among Winners of Japanese Arts Awards
abstract: The Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang was also named as a winner of a $187,000 prize.
lead_paragraph: The composer Philip Glass and Cai Guo-Qiang, the Chinese contemporary artist who designed the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2008 Summer Olympics, are among the winners of the Praemium Imperiale arts awards given out by the Japan Art Association. The awards, which recognize lifetime achievement in the arts, carry an $187,000 prize. The winners were announced at a ceremony at the Museum of Modern Art in New York on Wednesday. Cecco Bonanotte from Italy won the sculpture award, while Henning Larsen of Denmark was named in the architecture category and Yoko Morishita for theater and film.

headline: 3 Injured in Scuffle at Queens Subway Station
abstract: A 25-year-old woman was arrested in the rush-hour attack in Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:49 a.m. |  Two people were slashed and another injured in a dispute that began on a rush-hour subway train in Queens and spilled out onto a platform on Wednesday, transit officials said.

headline: Many Republicans Join Democrats in Denouncing Attack in Libya
abstract: A parade of Senate Republicans came to the chamber floor Wednesday or issued statements projecting unity after a mob killed J. Christopher Stevens, the ambassador to Libya, and three others in Benghazi, Libya.
lead_paragraph: After an initial burst of criticism, most Republicans in Washington — even some of President Obama’s fiercest critics — joined Democrats in denouncing the violent attacks on American diplomatic outposts in Egypt and Libya while refraining from criticizing the Obama administration’s response.

headline: Bionic Suits Aid Paraplegics
abstract: A new generation of bionic suits, or wearable robots, are being designed for the disabled as well as for industrial and military purposes.
lead_paragraph: A new generation of bionic suits, or wearable robots, are being designed for the disabled as well as for industrial and military purposes.

headline: Employers Use Carrots and Sticks to Promote Worker Health
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Firms are offering financial incentives or penalties to encourage employees to live healthier lives.
lead_paragraph: Employers are using financial carrots and sticks to get workers to adopt healthy lifestyles, in an effort to improve well-being and lower health costs, a new report on employer health benefits finds.

headline: U.S. Income Gap Rose, Sign of Uneven Recovery
abstract: The median household income in 2011 was $50,054, a level last seen in 1996.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The income gap between the wealthiest 20 percent of American households and the rest of the country grew sharply in 2011, the Census Bureau reported, as an overwhelming majority of Americans saw no gains from a weak economic recovery in its second full year.

headline: The Charm of the Underdog
abstract: The Orioles may be outmanned, underpaid and injured, but they are also tied for the division lead deep into September.
lead_paragraph: For all that baseball pennant races offer in extended drama and excitement, they do not always offer much in the way of charm. Sure, the Red Sox and Braves’ collapses last year were oodles of fun for anyone not a Red Sox or Braves loyalist, but the beneficiaries were the Rays and the Cardinals. O.K., the Rays can claim a little bit of charm despite that dreadful ballpark and its empty seats, but they are so four years ago.

headline: Kennedy Center Honors for Buddy Guy, Dustin Hoffman and Led Zeppelin
abstract: David Letterman and Natalia Makarova are also receiving lifetime achievement awards in the performing arts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON— The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Wednesday named Buddy Guy, Dustin Hoffman, David Letterman, Natalia Makarova and Led Zeppelin to receive this year’s Kennedy Center Honors.

headline: At Juventus, It’s All in the Stars
abstract: Juventus, the defending champion in Italy’s Serie A, is tainted by a new scandal even though the club and its players and officials were not involved.
lead_paragraph: When Juventus won the Serie A title at the end of last season it marked a triumphant return for Italy’s most successful team. The Old Lady of Italian soccer finished the season undefeated and has continued its unbeaten run with two wins to open the new season. With Milan and Inter experiencing financial troubles, the team from Turin is favored to win another Scudetto this season.

headline: Do You Track Your Site’s Conversion Rates?
abstract: And what have you done to improve those rates?
lead_paragraph: Last year, Dr. Stephen Bracci, owner of Verve Medical Cosmetics, realized that his Web site was doing a better job attracting visitors than it was converting those visitors into customers. As Katherine Reynolds Lewis explains in a small-business guide we’ve just published, there are a lot of things a business can do to improve its conversion rates.

headline: Romney Criticizes Obama on Handling of Embassy Attacks
abstract: The presidential candidate is tested in real time on a fast moving foreign policy crisis.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Mitt Romney on Wednesday took aim at the Obama administration’s handling of unfolding developments in the Mideast, including the death of an American ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, accusing the administration of a “severe miscalculation” and calling its handling of the matter “akin to an apology.” He also defended his own actions after coming under fire from Democrats for politicizing the issue.

headline: A.C.C. to Add Notre Dame, but Not Its Football Team
abstract: The Atlantic Coast Conference said the Irish would play five football games a year against league opponents and be a full member in all sports except football and hockey.
lead_paragraph: Notre Dame announced Wednesday that it would soon jump from the Big East Conference to the Atlantic Coast Conference while still retaining much of its football independence.

abstract: Lord Ganesha’s idol with the body of Spiderman, in Bangalore, Karnataka.

abstract: The Packers looked out of sorts in their opener and now face a revamped Bears receiving group.
lead_paragraph: Bears (1-0) at Packers (0-1)

headline: Museum of Modern Art to Show ‘The Clock’
abstract: Christian Marclay’s 24-hour chronicle will be presented for one month starting in December.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art announced on Wednesday that it would exhibit Christian Marclay’s wildly popular video installation, “The Clock,” which  won the Golden Lion award at the 2011 Venice Biennale.

headline: Corporations Slow to Act on Climate Change, Report Says
abstract: Only 20 percent of 379 large companies surveyed have firm long-term targets for reducing their greenhouse gas emissions, a report says.
lead_paragraph: While many continue to argue, along with Milton Friedman, that “the business of business is business,” more and more publicly traded companies around the world have been embracing sustainability as a long-term strategic asset in the face of climate change.

headline: A One-Way Street Leaving Cleveland
abstract: Reflecting on the death last week of Art Modell, who moved the Browns to Baltimore, the writer laments the one-sided talent exchange between Cleveland and New York.
lead_paragraph: The death of Art Modell last week has prompted a lot of soul-searching in Cleveland, my hometown. Looking into a grave will do that. For some of us, a hard truth is staring back.

headline: Romney’s Statement on Libya
abstract: The Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, criticized the Obama administration over its statement about the attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four diplomats, including the ambassador.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, criticized the Obama administration over its statement about the attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four diplomats, including the ambassador.

abstract: Taking stock of Obama.
lead_paragraph: Larry Kudlow:

headline: Weekly Reader: Organics, Epigenetics and a Wish List for Doctors
abstract: “Falling Down the Rabbit Hole of Why,” “Why Fathers Really Matter,” the house rules of the White House and other stuff you might have missed this week.
lead_paragraph: A  study from researchers at Stanford University, published online in the Annals of Internal Medicine, suggested that organic food is no more nutritious than that which is conventionally grown. At Room for Debate, they’re debating: Is Organic Food Worth the Expense?

headline: Goldman Analyst Headed to David Yurman
abstract: Adrianne Shapira, a retail industry analyst at Goldman Sachs, is headed to the jewelry company David Yurman to be its chief financial officer.
lead_paragraph: A Goldman Sachs analyst is headed to the jewelry company David Yurman to be its chief financial officer.

headline: Investing in Good Governance
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Research shows that market prices already reflect the value of good-governance provisions to investors.
lead_paragraph: Can investors generally beat the market by concentrating their portfolios on companies that practice good corporate governance? There is evidence that good-governance features included in standard governance indexes do improve the performance of companies – but that their significance is already reflected in market prices.

headline: Embassy Attacks Fuel Escalation in U.S. Presidential Race
abstract: Mitt Romney assailed President Obama while Democrats accused the Republican nominee of politicizing a crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deadly attack on Americans in Libya fueled a harsh escalation of the presidential campaign in the United States on Wednesday as Mitt Romney assailed President Obama’s handling of the situation, while Democrats accused Mr. Romney, the Republican nominee, of politicizing an international crisis.

headline: Dress Code | Bibhu Mohapatra
abstract: Mohapatra’s inspiration for this dress, and his Spring 2013 collection, came from hand-cut origami and images of a butterfly-covered Kate Moss.

headline: Clinton’s Statement on Libya
abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton condemned the attack on the consulate in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four diplomats, including the ambassador, Christopher Stevens.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton condemned the attack on the consulate in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four diplomats, including the ambassador, Christopher Stevens.

headline: BAE Systems and EADS Say They Are in Merger Talks
abstract: The aerospace giant EADS, which manufactures Airbus passenger aircraft, says it is in merger talks with its British rival, BAE Systems.
lead_paragraph: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

headline: Apps That Recall a Time Before There Were Apps
abstract: Programs for your smartphone can recreate favorite computer games from your childhood, apply nostalgic effects to your photos and even turn your MP3 collection into a virtual stack of vinyl records.
lead_paragraph: Haven’t we all at some time been struck by such an overwhelming sense of nostalgia that we wished we could take a time machine to a moment in our past? Perhaps it’s a scent that reminds us of previous romances, or as we get older, the sights and sounds that take us back to a childhood time when everything was simpler.

headline: Tailgating Recipes: Holy Smoke Ribs
abstract: A New Yorker moves to Texas and learns to barbecue pork ribs, but he doesn’t forget his beloved Giants.
lead_paragraph: We could open tailgating season with a gentle dip or some basic nachos, but much in the same way the college football season had Alabama-Michigan and the N.F.L. season had Cowboys-Giants on the opening schedule, we thought we would give you something meatier. Enter Ricardo Vera’s ribs. Vera tends to use pork spare ribs but said the recipe could be used with baby back ribs or even pork butt or shoulder.

headline: More Arrests of Retirees in Fraud Case at L.I.R.R.
abstract: The arrests were the latest in an investigation that has led to charges against 20 other people in what prosecutors said was a major disability fraud scheme at the Long Island Rail Road.
lead_paragraph: Ten more retired Long Island Rail Road workers have been charged with federal crimes, accused of falsely claiming to be disabled so they could obtain federal disability pensions in addition to their railroad pensions in what prosecutors have called a huge fraud scheme, the authorities announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Romney Routine
abstract: He responded to the riots in Libya and Egypt like he responds to everything: By attacking the president, regardless of the facts.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s fallen into quite the campaign routine – attack President Obama over anything, at any time, regardless of the facts. He followed this script to a T in responding to yesterday’s riots in North Africa.

headline: Jake Eberts, Accidental Film Producer of Oscar Winners, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Eberts, after trying engineering and banking without success, turned to film and produced gems like “Chariots of Fire,” “Gandhi,” “Dances With Wolves,” “The Killing Fields” and “Watership Down.”
lead_paragraph: Jake Eberts, who trained to be a chemical engineer but instead built a career producing and financing acclaimed and successful films like “Chariots of Fire,” “Gandhi,” “Dances With Wolves” and “The Killing Fields,” died on Sept. 6 in Montreal. He was 71.

headline: God, Mary Karr and Ronald Reagan: D.T. Max on David Foster Wallace
abstract: Mr. Max said he found the subject of his new book “entirely absorbing,” adding, “He consumed me.”
lead_paragraph: Less than six months after David Foster Wallace committed suicide in 2008 at the age of 46, D. T. Max published a long article in The New Yorker about Wallace, his depression and his attempts to write a new novel. That essay  spurred Mr. Max’s new book, “Every Love Story Is a Ghost Story,” the first biography of Wallace. Michiko Kakutani called it a “revealing” book that “gives us a sympathetic appraisal of Wallace’s life and work, tracing the connections between the two, while mapping the wellsprings of his philosophical vision.” In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Max discussed Wallace’s literary influences, his sometimes tumultuous relationships with women, the role of God in his life and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Lee’s Lost Order
abstract: Who was to blame for the Union discovery of secret Confederate documents before the Battle of Antietam?
lead_paragraph: By early September 1862, having culminated his triumphant Second Manassas campaign with Gen. Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson’s postscript victory at Chantilly, Va. — within an easy commute of present-day Washington — Robert E. Lee was laying plans to win the war. He had concentrated his army at Frederick, Md., about 40 miles northwest of Lincoln’s capital. A few months before, the Union had been on the verge of taking the Southern capital of Richmond, Va. Now Lee was a victory away from, if not capturing Washington, demonstrating the South’s military and political viability on the doorstep of the Union.

headline: Holmes & Yang: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Suggested Retirement Savings Goals, by Age
abstract: Fidelity suggests age-based retirement savings guidelines.
lead_paragraph: For those of you wondering if you’re saving enough money for retirement, here are some new savings guidelines to ponder.

headline: Suspects Sought After Crowd Trashes Car During Fashion Week
abstract: The police are looking for a cyclist who they say incited a crowd to trash a car in NoHo on Thursday and a man who they say jumped on the car.
lead_paragraph: The police are looking for a cyclist who they say incited a crowd to trash a car in NoHo during Fashion Week last Thursday night and a young man who they say jumped on the car and broke several of its windows. The police released a photo and video of the suspects late Tuesday.

headline: Russians Say Anti-U.S. Attack in Libya Vindicates Their Position
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Russia has argued that the West should not support popular uprisings against dictatorships in the Middle East lest Islamic fundamentalism take hold.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Upon learning of the violent death of the United States ambassador to Libya on Wednesday, many Russians responded with variations on “I told you so.”

headline: Updates on Rage Over Anti-Islam Film
abstract: The Lede is following angry protests and violence in the Muslim world in response to a film trailer posted on YouTube that insults Islam’s prophet.
lead_paragraph: The Lede is following the angry protests and violence in the Muslim world which began on Tuesday in response to a film trailer posted on YouTube that insults Islam’s prophet.

headline: Updates From the Apple iPhone 5 Event
abstract: Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, took the stage on Wednesday at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco to unveil the company’s highly anticipated, next-generation iPhone, the iPhone 5. Here are live updates from the event.
lead_paragraph: Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, took the stage on Wednesday at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco to unveil the company’s highly anticipated, next-generation iPhone, the iPhone 5.

headline: British Banker Barred Over Role in Financial Crisis
abstract: Peter Cummings, former head of corporate lending at HBOS, was barred from working in Britain’s financial services sector and fined $805,000 for aggressive lending practices that eventually led to major losses at the British bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British authorities have barred a top British banker from working in the country’s financial services industry for his role in the collapse of a major British bank during the financial crisis.

headline: Hotel Rates Rise In Latin America
abstract: Latin American cities were among those with the highest percentage increase in hotel room rates.
lead_paragraph: Though it has no shortage of luxury accommodations, Latin America has long held a reputation as a place where budget travelers can pinch pennies.

headline: Dylan Says Slavery Still Stains United States
abstract: In an interview with Rolling Stone Bob Dylan speaks out about race relations, and responds to critics.
lead_paragraph: In a new interview in Rolling Stone, Bob Dylan spoke out about the continuing taint of slavery on the United States, according to The Associated Press. America was “founded on the back of slaves,” Mr. Dylan said. “If slavery had been given up in a more peaceful way, America would be far ahead today.”

headline: Really, We’re Just Here to See Katie
abstract: Holmes & Yang is the fashion collection started by the actress Katie Holmes and the stylist Jeanne Yang three years ago. But, for some reason, everyone was particularly excited about seeing it this season.
lead_paragraph: Holmes & Yang is the fashion collection started by the actress Katie Holmes and the stylist Jeanne Yang three years ago. But, for some reason, everyone was particularly excited about seeing it this season. There were paparazzi outside Lincoln Center, or more than usual, anyway. It was as if the designers were famous for something.

headline: What’s Bubbling Up From Newtown Creek?
abstract: Researchers warn that the city’s aeration process could pose risks for air quality.
lead_paragraph: Reached aboard a boat in Newtown Creek the other day, John Lipscomb of the advocacy group Riverkeeper described the water by phone. “It’s this green-blue chalky color,” he said. “You’re floating around and there are dead rats, condoms, and there’s this stench of sewage – this sulphuric smell.”

headline: An Update on a Student Debt Case
abstract: The man featured in a New York Times article about student loans and bankruptcy must return to federal court on Jan. 28 to discuss his medical issues and whether he is employable.
lead_paragraph: In an article about what happens to people who try to get a judge to discharge their student loans in bankruptcy court, I told the story of Doug Wallace, a blind man in Ohio in the middle of his own case. He’s trying to prove that paying his debt would cause an “undue hardship,” according to the governing legal standard. To do so, he needs to prove, among other things, that there is a “certainty of hopelessness” that he will be unable to pay his debt during the term of the loans.

headline: Afghan Leader Condemns Anti-Islam Film
abstract: President Hamid Karzai condemning the attack on Wednesday said his office “strongly and resolutely denounces this desecrating act and declares its serious abhorrence in the face of such an insult.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai condemned an anti-Islam film that has been backed by the American pastor Terry Jones, issuing a statement on Wednesday that said his office “strongly and resolutely denounces this desecrating act and declares its serious abhorrence in the face of such an insult.”

abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Bryan Derballa.

headline: Answers About Hostage Negotiation, Part 1
abstract: Taking Questions: Frank A. Bolz Jr., a founder of the New York Police Department’s hostage-negotiation team, is answering reader questions.
lead_paragraph: This is the first set of responses from Frank A. Bolz Jr., one of the founders of the New York Police Department’s hostage-negotiating unit answering reader questions. Read the second and third sets of responses and the introductory post about Mr. Bolz.

headline: Freund With Benefits
abstract: Meeting locals abroad while traveling can seem like a daunting proposition. A new hotel in Berlin strives to change that.
lead_paragraph: For the impatient, socially awkward, unilingual traveler — in other words, for many of us — meeting locals can sometimes seem like a daunting proposition. But what if they came bundled in your hotel price, like Wi-Fi or a fruit basket? In March, Clare Freeman, a British expat and a veteran of Design Hotels, opened Plus One Berlin, a one-room concept hotel that operates a bit like a platonic escort service. Freeman gut-renovated a studio apartment in the city’s rapidly gentrifying Kreuzkölln district and turned the space into an airy urban refuge. She has since enlisted 35 locals, many of whom are her friends, to show guests Berlin from a Berliner’s point of view. “It’s a curated network,” she says of her associates. “You know you’re not getting just anyone.” You might get a German portrait photographer, a Serbian astrophysicist or a Roman coffee aficionado for, say, a quick afternoon drink to get restaurant suggestions or a half day spent as a guide’s plus-one. Past outings include record-release parties, lessons on flea-market haggling and pop-up film screenings at Yaam, a Jamaican beach club on the Spree. Each booking includes a jaunt with a local, and guests can pick whom they’d like to meet and schedule an appointment online. From about $150 per night; plusoneberlin.com.

headline: Academy Finds Mixed Climate Impacts on Himalayan Glaciers, Water Supplies
abstract: A new look at the fate of Himalayan glaciers in a changing climate, and the implications for 1.5 billion Asians, cuts through caricatures.
lead_paragraph: Given all the oversimplified assertions over the years about Himalayan glaciers in a warming global climate, it’s great to see a committee assembled by the National Academy of Sciences weigh in on the question with some data-based findings in a new report, “Himalayan Glaciers: Climate Change, Water Resources, and Water Security.” The bottom line — in sync with other recent analysis — is that the region is seeing a mix of changes, with glaciers growing in some places and shrinking in others and impacts on water supplies mostly inconsequential for decades to come. In most regions, monsoon patterns, population and consumption pressures and dependence on groundwater pumping will remain the dominant source of water-related risks, the report concludes. Read on for an excerpt from the news release and link to the full report, followed by related background:

headline: Mitt and Bibi: Diplomacy as Demolition Derby
abstract: A review of the latest foreign policy missteps of Bibi Netanyahu and Mitt Romney in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: It turns out Bibi Netanyahu and Mitt Romney have more in common than a background in management consulting and an unswerving devotion to the security of Israel. When it comes to international diplomacy, we are reminded this week, both have the subtle grace of cattle on loco weed.

headline: Medvedev Says Rockers Have Served Enough Jail Time for Cathedral Performance
abstract: The Russian prime minister said further incarceration of the three women in the group Pussy Riot would be unproductive.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev said Wednesday that he believed that three female punk rockers jailed for a profane stunt in Moscow’s main Russian Orthodox cathedral should be released rather than serve out their two-year sentences, weighing in on a case that has drawn widespread condemnation in the West.

headline: Homes for $1.2 Million
abstract: Properties in Vermont, Illinois and Northern California.
lead_paragraph: Properties in Vermont, Illinois and Northern California.

abstract: A contemporary in Vermont, a prairie-style house in Illinois and a house in Northern California.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, VT.

headline: A New Blog: Booming
abstract: An online destination aims to capture the voice of the baby boomers.
lead_paragraph: An online destination aims to capture the voice of the baby boomers.

headline: Buffett Cup in Omaha
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Bridge (Card Game)', 'Cards and Card Games']
abstract: At the fourth Buffett Cup in Omaha, after the pair and team events, Europe leads the United States by 70 points to 62.
lead_paragraph: At the fourth Buffett Cup in Omaha, after the pair and team events, Europe leads the United States by 70 points to 62. So there is all to play for in the 66-board individual on Wednesday and Thursday, in which every player partners each teammate for six deals. The United States won the pairs by 36 points to 24. But Europe rebounded in the teams, taking it by 46 to 26.

headline: Rachel Zoe and Reality
abstract: There was a baby Skyler sighting at the uberstylist Rachel Zoe’s runway show, but he got a little fussy. Otherwise, things looked more or less like any other runway show, rather than a reality spectacle.
lead_paragraph: There was a baby Skyler sighting in the front row of the über-stylist Rachel Zoe’s runway show, but he got a little fussy and had to be removed. Otherwise, things looked more or less like any other runway show, rather than a reality spectacle.

headline: The Well Quiz: Cutting Health Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: How much do you know about the excess spending that goes on in our health care system? Take this quiz to find out.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Institute of Medicine issued a new report documenting the waste and misuse that is rampant in the American health care system. The good news is that there is a lot of room for improvement.

headline: Exclusive: For One Raiders Fan, the Pain Continues
abstract: Steve Almond feared the Raiders would find some miraculous new way to lose — and he was right.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Steve Almond wrote a Riff essay about the torment of being a life-long fan of a perennially incompetent sports team: in his case, the Oakland Raiders. In the essay, he wrote of the (then-forthcoming) season opener for the Raiders: “There is no doubt in my mind that they will lose in some new and innovative fashion,” which, it turns out, they did. Here, in a 6th Floor exclusive, Almond records his feelings following that opening game:

abstract: A nine-bedroom home on 30 acres was built about 200 years ago on the outskirts of the village of Durrow.
lead_paragraph: A nine-bedroom home on 30 acres was built about 200 years ago on the outskirts of the village of Durrow.

abstract: Prices for residential property in Ireland are down 50 percent, on average, from their 2007 peak.
lead_paragraph: NINE-BEDROOM GEORGIAN MANOR HOUSE ON 30 ACRES IN COUNTY LAOIS, IRELAND

headline: Ryan Says Obama Leaks Led to Doctor’s Sentence
abstract: The vice presidential candidate says leaks resulted in the arrest of a doctor whose information led to the killing of Osama bin Laden.
lead_paragraph: ASHWAUBENON, Wis. — Representative Paul D. Ryan accused the White House on Wednesday of leaking information that led to a 33-year prison sentence for a Pakistani doctor who helped American intelligence locate Osama bin Laden.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Softens Her Image in New Ad
abstract: Democrats in Massachusetts have expressed concern that her ads have been too generic and not grounded enough in the lives of Massachusetts voters.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren’s campaign released a new television commercial on Wednesday,  just as some of her supporters have expressed unhappiness with her ad campaign.

abstract: Photos from Washington, Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Washington, Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan.

headline: An iPhone 5 Case Arrives Before the iPhone 5
abstract: Before the announcement of the new iPhone 5 was made, the first protective cases were being shown. How is it possible to build a case for a phone wrapped in secrecy?
lead_paragraph: Before the announcement of the new iPhone 5 was made, the first protective case for the 5 arrived on my desk. I also got a news release promising me that another case was available as well.

headline: Scouting Report
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Belstaff opens its first store in the United States, and the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology hosts an exhibition tracing the preppy look.
lead_paragraph: OPENINGS

headline: An Artist Who Delineated the Money
abstract: Mareike Wegener’s documentary, “Mark Lombardi: Death-Defying Acts of Art and Conspiracy,” examines the Conceptualist artist whose work delineated the networks of money and power.
lead_paragraph: The intricate Conceptualist drawings of Mark Lombardi attempted to map the vast, convoluted networks of money and power behind the likes of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal or the Iran-contra affair. One begins to wish for a similar explication of Mr. Lombardi and his work during Mareike Wegener’s frustratingly self-evident documentary, “Mark Lombardi: Death-Defying Acts of Art and Conspiracy.”

headline: Lang College Offers Academic Credit for Taking a Gap Year
abstract: A partnership between Eugene Lang College, part of the New School, and Global Citizen Year would allow students who took a gap year to arrive on campus as newly minted sophomores.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, after a hectic high school experience overshadowed by a competitive — or perhaps, disappointing — college admissions process, seniors just need a break.

headline: Murder in Benghazi
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Editorials', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States should stay engaged with Libya despite the killing of Ambassador Stevens and three other Americans.
lead_paragraph: Libya and its pro-democracy revolution had no better friend than J. Christopher Stevens, the United States ambassador who was killed along with three other Americans in Tuesday’s attack on the consulate in Benghazi. It was an outrageous act that deserved the strongest condemnation.

headline: Rachel Zoe: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Matchbox Twenty Tops Album Chart
abstract: “North” sold 95,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan.
lead_paragraph: Matchbox Twenty has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the first time with “North” (Atlantic), its first studio record in a decade. “North” sold 95,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and leads a handful of high-charting new titles as the music industry begins releasing its fall albums. Imagine Dragons, an alternative-rock band from Las Vegas, is No. 2, with 83,000 sales of “Night Visions” (Interscope), its first full-length album. The Christian rapper Lecrae is No. 3, with “Gravity” (Reach), which sold 72,000 copies. Last week’s No. 1, “Eye on It” (ForeFront), by another Christian rapper, TobyMac, fell to No. 8 in its second week out, with 26,000 sales. Cat Power opened at No. 10 with 23,000 sales of “Sun” (Matador).

headline: The iPhone 5: My First Impressions
abstract: Bigger screen, longer battery life, more sophisticated camera, better sound. Overall, Apple seems to have put its focus on the important things you want in an app phone.
lead_paragraph: Apple unveiled the new iPhone 5 today in San Francisco. As it turns out, most of the individual rumors about it were true — but even so, they didn’t describe the whole package.

headline: Take This Job and Obsess About It (Sing, Too)
abstract: “The Why Overhead,” by Adam Szymkowicz, depicts the consequences of workplace tedium in comic, even musical, terms.
lead_paragraph: Adam Szymkowicz’s office comedy “The Why Overhead” has some genuinely funny moments and an odd sensibility. It’s a decent play that pushes against its own boundaries with varying success.

headline: D.J.’s Stretch Out and Find More Fans
abstract: Increasingly, D.J.s are convinced that the place where rap, hip-hop and dance intersect is fertile ground.
lead_paragraph: When the police showed up at the Fool’s Gold Day Off party this month, it wasn’t completely clear why. Sure, the lines for the event, held in an empty lot behind City Winery, in TriBeCa, had been long for much of the afternoon, but not evidently rowdy. There were some loose cannons: at least one person climbed a 20-foot-high fence and jumped over, only to get netted by security and removed.

headline: Long-Forgotten Picasso Is a Museum’s Windfall
abstract: A newly rediscovered Picasso work on glass, mistakenly put in storage more than 40 years ago, is being sold by an Indiana museum.
lead_paragraph: When Arlan Ettinger, the president of Guernsey’s auction house in New York, first called the Evansville Museum of Arts, History and Science back in February to ask about a layered glass mosaic by Picasso that he had traced to the museum, officials there said, in effect, “Sorry, wrong number.” They had never heard of it.

headline: Pop Striver From Britain Arrives for a Debut in Full Regalia
abstract: Paloma Faith, whose second album, “Fall to Grace,” has been in the British Top 10 since it was released in May, is a contender in the search for the next Adele.
lead_paragraph: The search for the next Adele is a full-time quest in the British — and worldwide — music business. That would be a singer steeped in American soul music, a songwriter who touches on pop universals and is retro enough to draw grown-up listeners, a charmingly uninhibited stage personality, a fashion-conscious entertainer and an unambivalently ambitious trouper.

headline: A Challenger’s Criticism Is Furiously Returned
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: From Mitt Romney’s perspective, the time was ripe to cast the president as someone who apologizes for America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deadly attack on an American diplomatic post in Libya propelled foreign policy to the forefront of an otherwise inward-looking presidential campaign and presented an unexpected test not only to the incumbent, who must manage an international crisis, but also to the challenger, whose response quickly came under fire.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Inside Foxconn, and Technology’s Limits
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes why writing for the Web requires more clarity and brevity, not less; an app that gives you information it thinks you will need based on the context of your conversation; and a report about working at a Foxconn plant in China.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Combining Taped Voices From 9/11 and Live Strings
abstract: Steve Reich’s “WTC 9/11,” performed on Tuesday at Le Poisson Rouge, was an intensely personal account of the tragedy.
lead_paragraph: When a composer takes up the theme of unthinkable man-made tragedy as the impetus for a new piece, what is the proper tone to adopt? Richard Strauss, responding to the World War II bombing of Munich with “Metamorphosen,” fashioned a lament not only for a city but also for a culture vanished in violence and guilt. John Adams, asked to imagine a response to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, produced “On the Transmigration of Souls,” a complex, contemplative work that used personal mementos as a springboard to transcendental concerns.

headline: Fashion Week Street Style Is Often a Billboard for Brands
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Was it only a couple of years ago that these showily outfitted swans — stylists, bloggers and fashion editors — click-clacked on the pavements in what used to be seen as a commerce-free zone?
lead_paragraph: Was it only a couple of years ago that these showily outfitted swans — stylists, bloggers and fashion editors — click-clacked on the pavements in what used to be seen as a commerce-free zone?

headline: Decades Later, a Vision Survives
abstract: A new park on Roosevelt Island is based on a plan four decades old: Louis Kahn’s Four Freedoms Park. It opens on Oct. 24 as Kahn’s only work in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The park — a memorial to Franklin Delano Roosevelt — was conceived four decades ago. The visionary architect who designed it died in 1974. The site, a landfill along one of the more dramatic stretches of waterfront in New York City, remained a rubble heap while the project was left for dead.

headline: Of Chryslers, Fashion Plates and Beards: ZZ Top Introduces 300C John Varvatos Limited Edition
abstract: The boogie-woogie band was on hand in SoHo on Tuesday night to introduce the limited-edition sedan.
lead_paragraph: Whether by positioning Eminem behind the wheel of a 200, Clint Eastwood in a dank, dimly lighted tunnel or Jennifer Lopez in an imaginary Bronx, Chrysler has strove to associate itself with totems of popular culture since emerging from bankruptcy in 2009. That impulse was given full rein on Tuesday night in SoHo when the automaker organized a meeting of ZZ Top, Jack Daniels, John Varvatos and GQ magazine under one roof.

headline: Update: The Times Denies State Department Request to Remove Photo From Web Site
abstract: The New York Times decides not to remove the photo of the dying ambassador to Libya, J. Christopher Stevens, from NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: The State Department asked The New York Times on Wednesday afternoon to remove a photograph of the dying ambassador to Libya from a gallery on the newspaper’s Web site. The ambassador, J. Christopher Stevens, was killed Tuesday in an attack on the American Consulate in Libya.

headline: Who Am I Wearing? Funny You Should Ask.
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: What is being paraded as street style — once fashion’s last stronghold of true indie spirit — has been breached, infiltrated by tides of branding consultants and public relations gurus.
lead_paragraph: PIVOTING smartly, a hand on her hip, the better to show off her pipette jeans, Laura Ellner seemed the incarnation of street style. As she posed at Lincoln Center Plaza on Day 1 of New York Fashion Week last Thursday, a brace of cameras clicked and whirred, each competing to catch her performance.

lead_paragraph: Images of Louis Kahn’s memorial on Roosevelt Island.

headline: Democrats Apologize for Image of Russian Ships at Convention
abstract: Democratic National Convention planners have apologized for a display of what appeared to be Russian warships during a tribute to veterans on the convention’s last night.
lead_paragraph: On full display in all the pageantry of the Democratic National Convention as veterans gathered onstage last week was an odd backdrop: an image of the Russian naval fleet. And for this, convention planners have now apologized.

headline: A Vreeland Library
abstract: Why don’t you ... buy any number of books about Diana Vreeland for a fashionista in your life?
lead_paragraph: Why don’t you ... buy any number of books about Diana Vreeland for a fashionista in your life?

headline: The Daily Shoe | Reed Krakoff
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s shoe: a monochromatic heel with a double ankle strap, sheer siding and pink leather toe cap would look prim if not for that sporty bandeau and stacked wooden heel.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Mapping a Path to Vreelandia
abstract: Lisa Immordino Vreeland discovers not only a great fashion editor but also a philosopher of sorts and a personal muse.
lead_paragraph: YOU might think that dating a grandson of Diana Vreeland would lead to scintillating dinner conversation, especially if he and you both work in the fashion industry. But according to Lisa Immordino Vreeland, who did just that and went on to marry him, the late, legendary editor hardly loomed over their relationship.

headline: Yankees Go West for 2013 Interleague Play
abstract: The preliminary schedule, in which the Yankees will play 19 of their first 32 games at home, includes only four games against the Mets.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Yankees’ preliminary schedule for 2013 was released Wednesday, and it features several interesting new twists.

headline: ATP Adopts Rules Changes to Address Pace of Play
abstract: The ATP modified the punishment for a time violation between points and will experiment with the removal of the service let.
lead_paragraph: The ATP Board of Directors announced two rule changes Wednesday that would allow for the quickening of matches, a growing priority given the consistently increasing length of matches on the men’s tour.

headline: Old Standbys, New Stand-Ins
keywords: ['Nails (Body Part)', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Skin', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Makeup artists weigh in on why the classics have never gone out of style, whether they deserve the reputation and which newer items are qualified to unseat them.
lead_paragraph: EVEN through the latest cloud of glitter dust backstage at Fashion Week one can see a handful of beauty products, some on the market for over a century, that continue to pop up again and again. Herein, makeup artists weigh in on why these classics have never gone out of style, whether they deserve the reputation and which newer items are qualified to unseat them.

headline: Photographer and Subject
abstract: Images from a new retrospective of the artist Carrie Mae Weems.
lead_paragraph: Images from a new retrospective of the artist Carrie Mae Weems.

headline: Photographer and Subject Are One
abstract: The photographer Carrie Mae Weems has made a career of representing American life in terms of race, gender and class, often using her own image to illustrate her point of view.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Carrie Mae Weems was first teaching photography in the late 1980s at Hampshire College in Massachusetts, she was struck by the difference in how her male and female students presented themselves in pictures. “The women were always turning away from the camera, always in profile,” said Ms. Weems, demonstrating by obscuring her face seductively with her graceful hands. “They never squared themselves. The boys were squaring themselves.”

headline: The Cult of Disappearing Design
abstract: Some architects and interior designers are using technology and sleight of hand to hide annoying details like switches, grates and knobs to create a streamlined space.
lead_paragraph: THE first thing you see when you walk into Patrick McInerney’s living room is that there’s nothing to see. The walls are bare, and ditto for the ceiling. You try to switch on the lights, but there doesn’t appear to be a switch. There’s music playing, but where is it coming from? The lamp is obviously working — the bulb is lighted, after all — but it seems to be plugged into ... the plaster?

headline: A Disappearing Act
abstract: A sampling of furniture and accessories that embrace the all-invisible aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of furniture and accessories that embrace the all-invisible aesthetic.

headline: Tell the Dishwasher to Be Quiet
abstract: Appliance manufacturers are starting to pay attention to the demand for less noise.
lead_paragraph: AN appliance may be hidden from the eyes, but that doesn’t mean it escapes notice entirely. Manufacturers of household machinery are also taking heed of the demand for quiet.

headline: A Sound System as Resonant as a Concert Hall
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads', 'Speakers (Audio)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A digital-to-analog converter can help your music sound much more as if it were live.
lead_paragraph: Chances are, your sound system isn’t very good at math. It would sound a lot better if you could make it a little smarter, and you can.

headline: In 2013, Mets Open at Home and Host All-Star Game
abstract: The Mets start the season against San Diego and will face American League Central teams in interleague play.
lead_paragraph: Mets fans looking toward next season may be pleased to hear that Major League Baseball has released its 2013 schedule. The Mets will get a fresh start on April 1, when they open the season at home against the San Diego Padres.

headline: Reported Handwritten Union Proposal
abstract: Chicago Public Schools said this handwritten page of notes was the only proposal the Chicago Teachers Union had placed in writing during talks so far.
lead_paragraph: Chicago Public Schools said this handwritten page of notes was the only proposal the Chicago Teachers Union had placed in writing during talks so far.

headline: After ‘Today’ Criticism, NBC News Chief Apologies to Affiliates
abstract: NBC News, in a message to NBC’s affiliated stations Wednesday, acknowledged that there had been a storm of criticism from viewers over the network’s decision not to observe a moment of silence during the “Today” show on Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: As it promised, NBC did not apologize on the air Wednesday for its decision not to observe a moment of silence during the “Today” show on Sept. 11.

lead_paragraph: Kaitlyn Crabbe, 11, was fishing for sunfish and catfish last week at Brooks Pond in Clove Lakes Park in Staten Island when she hooked into something ferocious.

lead_paragraph: The designer Miles Redd shopped for mirrored objects that introduce the right amount of reflection to an interior.

abstract: Abercrombie & Fitch has retained Goldman Sachs as an adviser as the troubled clothier assesses potential responses to moves by one of its investors, the activist hedge fund Relational Investors, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Abercrombie & Fitch has retained Goldman Sachs as an adviser as the troubled clothier assesses potential responses to moves by one of its investors, the activist hedge fund Relational Investors, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Mirrored Accessories
abstract: The designer Miles Redd loves mirrored spaces and objects, but admits that selecting the right pieces can be tricky.
lead_paragraph: TEN years ago, the designer Miles Redd spotted an entire bath and dressing room at a salvage warehouse in Chicago. And it wasn’t just any bathroom: it was from the home of the banker Lester Armour and had been designed by the architect David Adler, with interiors by Mr. Adler’s sister, Frances Elkins. It was also almost completely mirrored.

headline: Reed Krakoff: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Why The Vileness Matters
abstract: Romney disqualifies himself.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t weighed in on Romney’s awesomely awful intervention on events in Egypt and Libya; with even Republicans joining in the chorus of shocked disapproval, not much I can add.

headline: Market Ready
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Windows', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: I own a historic home that has its original windows. Should I replace them with insulated windows to save energy or keep the originals for their aesthetic value?
lead_paragraph: Q. I own a historic home that has its original windows. Should I replace them with insulated windows to save energy or keep the originals for their aesthetic value?

headline: Nate Berkus on Writing the Story of a Home
abstract: The interior designer talks about his new book and what it takes to design a 150-piece collection for Target.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer Nate Berkus first appeared on the national scene in 2002 as a guest on “Oprah.” He was such a hit with the audience and the star that he became the show’s featured design expert. Since then, his career has boomed. He has written a book, “Home Rules: Transform the Place You Live Into a Place You’ll Love,” and starred in his own television program, “The Nate Berkus Show,” which ended this spring. In October, Mr. Berkus, 40, will have two major introductions: a 150-piece collection of furnishings for Target, and a new book, “The Things That Matter” (Spiegel & Grau, $35). Speaking from his office in Chicago (he has another in New York), he spilled details about both projects.

headline: Lawmakers Delay Plans to Increase Oversight of Regulators
abstract: Lawmakers postponed plans to advance a bill that could curb the influence of Wall Street regulators, a move that came as some federal officials mounted opposition to the effort.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers postponed plans to advance a bill that could curb the influence of Wall Street regulators, a move that came as some federal officials mounted opposition to the effort.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Michael Kors
abstract: The makeup was graphic and ’60s-inspired, and the hair was sleek and reminiscent of the ’90s.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Sharp Lines.

headline: Feeding Believers and Doubters Alike
abstract: Fishs Eddy serves up President Obama’s birth certificate on a plate.
lead_paragraph: Manners dictate that one avoids politics at mixed partisan gatherings, but if you are determined to annoy certain family members, what better gift than the Obama Birth Certificate dish, which arrives today at the Manhattan housewares store Fishs Eddy? At $19.95, it’s not excessively expensive (though admit it, you’d spend a lot more to zetz Uncle Frank), and at 8 by 7 inches, it’s not so big that when Uncle Frank slams it down on your head he’ll be able to do any real damage. And if you’re thinking that it represents a point of view of the store’s owners, you’re right.

headline: Mixing Man’s Work With Nature’s
abstract: “Trees and Stones,” a show of Andrea Branzi’s furniture, opens at the Friedman Benda gallery in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Italian designer Andrea Branzi, 73, has been integrating rocks and trees into household objects for some 30 years. His Animali Domestici collection from 1985 featured laminate chairs with backrests of raw birch. A decade later, he hollowed containers out of stones and lumps of wood.

headline: A Ghostly Glow in Paper and Steel
abstract: Cast in papier-mâché and mounted on black or chromed steel, Harry Allen’s collection includes a table lamp, floor lamp and chandelier.
lead_paragraph: Harry Allen deals in twisted household archetypes. The New York-based designer’s ongoing Reality series includes a fruit bowl cast from a bunch of bananas, a coat hook shaped like a hand and a roller skate playing the role of door stop. For his latest project, Paperwork lanterns for Hive, he has transformed an old barn lantern into a ghostly light fixture. “It’s humble, like a found object,” Mr. Allen said. Cast in papier-mâché and mounted on black or chromed steel, the collection includes a table lamp, floor lamp and chandelier, all designed to hang from hooks attached to an armature. The lights are illuminated with LED bulbs. A single lantern measures 15 ½ inches high, 9 5/8 inches wide and 4 ¾ inches deep, and costs $350. Information: (888) 889-9005 or designbyhive.com.

headline: Designer Seating Made of Recyclables
abstract: Jean Nouvel collaborated with Emeco on the So So collection of chairs and stools made entirely of recycled aluminum.
lead_paragraph: Jean Nouvel, one of a handful of marquee architects who also design noteworthy furniture, has collaborated with Emeco, the Pennsylvania-based manufacturer of high-design seating, on the So So collection of chairs and stools.

headline: Sales at Molla Space, Property, Jensen-Lewis and Others
abstract: Discounts offered on vases, napkins, sleeper sofas and more.
lead_paragraph: Molla Space is taking up to 60 percent off some accessories, while supplies last (the Printing Vase bottle cover, shown, usually $26, is about $10); (888) 665-5277, mollaspace.com.

headline: Travel Day Tomorrow
abstract: Fly, fly away.
lead_paragraph: Also, I have a nasty cold — the perfect combination. Expect few if any posts.

headline: When You Want to Say That’s How to Dress
abstract: Reviews for the Narciso Rodriguez, Oscar de la Renta, Sophie Theallet and Michael Kors spring collections.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week has been a lavish rat race, an incredible assault on the nerves, with people rushing down to Chelsea, up to Lincoln Center, back to Chelsea while being bombarded by aimless weirdos with cameras and clothes you can’t forget fast enough.

headline: Pettitte Stays on Track for Return
abstract: Andy Pettitte threw a four-inning, 55-pitch simulated game Wednesday, his third such exercise, and afterward said, “I’m ready.”

headline: 23 Years After Soccer Tragedy, an Apology and a Shift in Blame
abstract: The British prime minister, David Cameron, apologized for the handling of the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 people died, after a new report cited failures and cover-ups by authorities.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nearly a quarter of a century after 96 Liverpool soccer fans were crushed to death in one of the worst stadium disasters in history, Prime Minister David Cameron formally apologized on Wednesday to the victims’ families, saying their “appalling deaths” were compounded by an attempt by the police, investigators and the news media to depict the victims as hooligans and to blame them for the disaster.

headline: Fewer Uninsured People
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Wider coverage strengthens the case for retaining President Obama’s health care reform law.
lead_paragraph: The number of Americans who lack health insurance declined last year, the first drop since 2007. This is, in large part, the result of the health care reform law and better coverage under public programs like Medicaid. This also shows why repealing the health care law or revamping and shrinking Medicaid, as many Republicans want to do, would be disastrous moves.

A voter must present a government-issued or other approved photo ID at a polling place to vote or can file a provisional ballot, which must be validated later by a submission of a photo ID or proof that the voter is indigent.

headline: Opportunity Knocks at Death’s Door
abstract: Two caregivers debate how to handle their dead charge in “Fly Me to the Moon,” a Marie Jones work that’s part of the 1st Irish festival at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: “Just hear me out.” This innocuous phrase, spoken by one young Irishwoman to another, betokens another painful turn of the screw in “Fly Me to the Moon,” a dark comedy written and directed by Marie Jones that opened Tuesday night at 59E59 Theaters as part of the 1st Irish festival. When Francis (Katie Tumelty) turns to her fellow caregiver Loretta (Tara Lynne O’Neill) and utters those four imploring words, chances are that both are going to find themselves drifting ever closer to calamity.

lead_paragraph: Portland, Ore., which never fluoridated its water supply and over time earned the distinction as the biggest city in the country to just say no, reversed course on Wednesday with a unanimous vote by the City Council to add fluoride beginning in early 2014.

lead_paragraph: Even the boos at Citi Field spewed forth without their usual bite. But that is just how things have gone recently in Queens. Everything has felt a bit halfhearted.

lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Greg Schiano is a native of Wyckoff, N.J., who coached Rutgers for 11 seasons. None of that is affecting him, he said, as he prepares to lead the Tampa Bay Buccaneers into MetLife Stadium to face the Giants on Sunday.

abstract: Some political analysts say the strike by Chicago teachers could open fissures between Obama supporters like unions and wealthy liberal donors who sometimes back causes that unions oppose.
lead_paragraph: Democrats left their convention in Charlotte, N.C., with an unusual amount of unity and enthusiasm, but the three-day-old strike by 26,000 teachers in Chicago has quickly deflated some of that enthusiasm — and could, some political analysts say, ultimately put some sizable cracks in the coalition that President Obama hopes to ride to re-election.

They were greeted by an unusually bipartisan group of lawmakers pushing for action in the House, where Republican leaders have declined to pursue legislation.

lead_paragraph: Eli Zborowski, a survivor of the Holocaust who made it his mission to ensure that it would never be forgotten, founded an American organization to support Israel’s official Holocaust memorial and raised more than $100 million for it, died on Monday in Queens. He was 86.

Muammar el-Qaddafi and earned the United States deep popular gratitude.

headline: Missteps Don’t Become Stumbles
abstract: Derek Jeter aggravated a bone bruise, but David Phelps pitched five and two-thirds sharp innings, helping the Yankees beat the Red Sox to remain tied with Baltimore for first place.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Yankees have been sitting precariously atop the American League East standings for a week. One misstep could cast them into second place for the first time in three months. That misstep appeared to have cropped up Wednesday night when Derek Jeter landed awkwardly on first base while trying to beat out a double play ball in the eighth inning.

keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The Egyptian government’s response to violence at the American Embassy in Cairo gave the Obama administration further cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the harrowing images of the deadly attack on the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, the Obama administration is grappling with the possibility that its far bigger long-term problem lies in Egypt, not Libya.

headline: Support for the Euro Is Seen in Dutch Election Results
abstract: Dutch voters appeared to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte a narrow victory, which will bring a sigh of relief to European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — In a closely watched election, Dutch voters appeared Wednesday to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte and his center-right Liberal party a narrow victory over the center-left Labor party, which will bring a sigh of relief to European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.

headline: France: New Leader Is Named for the Socialist Party
abstract: Harlem Désir, a member of the European Parliament and former leader of an antiracism organization, was designated Wednesday as the next leader of France’s governing Socialist Party, replacing Martine Aubry, who is stepping down.
lead_paragraph: Harlem Désir, a member of the European Parliament and former leader of an antiracism organization, was designated Wednesday as the next leader of France’s governing Socialist Party, replacing Martine Aubry, who is stepping down. Mr. Désir, 52, is an Aubry ally and replaced her as interim party leader when she ran unsuccessfully for the party presidential nomination. She and Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault nominated Mr. Désir; next month’s party vote on the nomination is considered a formality.

headline: Young Children’s Deaths Said to Drop Again in 2011
abstract: Fewer than seven million children around the world died before their fifth birthday from disease and birth complications in 2011 — a new low, several agencies announced Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Fewer than seven million children around the world died before their fifth birthday from disease and birth complications in 2011 — a new low — the World Health Organization, the United Nations Children’s Fund and other agencies announced Wednesday. About 12 million children that age died in 1990, and the number fell below 10 million for the first time in 2007, so the pace of saving children’s lives is accelerating, experts said. Half of all the deaths occurred in five countries: India, Nigeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Pakistan and China. The leading causes, in descending order, were pneumonia, premature birth, diarrhea, birth complications and malaria. Most of those deaths were preventable with relatively cheap interventions, the United Nations agencies said.

headline: Quality Defense a Key to U.S. Victory
abstract: A solid defense was the backbone of the U.S. victory over Jamaica in a World Cup qualifying match in Columbus, Ohio, Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Of all the positives coming out of the United States’ 1-0 victory over Jamaica in Tuesday’s World Cup qualifier in Columbus, Ohio — the way the Americans  dominated the first half, Danny Williams’s quality showing, another strrong match from Geoff Cameron, Graham Zusi’s solid performance, the number of chances the team created, Herculez Gomez’s free kick for the game’s only goal — perhaps one has been overlooked: the confident and strong play on defense.

headline: The Widow’s Doctor Visit
abstract: The patient had died months before. Now his widow, along with the children, wanted to meet with me, the doctor who had treated him.
lead_paragraph: I walked into the examination room and saw her sitting there, her arm around her 10-year-old son, her teenage daughter across the room.

headline: Must All U.S. Embassies Now Be Fortresses?
abstract: Even as it actively promotes its democratic values around the world, the United States has also been building massive, expensive, fortress-like embassies that are often seen as anything but open and welcoming. In these troubled times, can a safe embassy also be an accessible one? Can tight security and elegant design co-exist?
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — There is certain to be a demand — any minute now, wait for it — for more rigorous security at American embassies and consulates around the world. The attacks this week on the consulate in Benghazi, Libya, and the embassy in Cairo almost require a review of how U.S. diplomatic facilities are sited, designed, built and guarded.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Dole Food has said it is in advanced talks to sell its packaged foods and Asian fresh fruit businesses to the Japanese trading house Itochu.

headline: Yuvraj Singh’s Roaring Comeback Quiets Critics
abstract: The cricket star made a triumphant return after cancer treatment.
lead_paragraph: India may have lost the second Twenty20 game by a solitary run against New Zealand on Tuesday, but the team’s biggest consolation was the successful return of Yuvraj Singh after his battle with cancer.

headline: Mexico Announces Capture of Gulf Cartel’s Top Leader
abstract: Jorge Eduardo Costilla Sánchez, known as El Coss, was arrested Wednesday afternoon, the Mexican Navy said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a major strike against one of Mexico’s largest drug-trafficking organizations, the Mexican Navy said Thursday that it had detained one of the most sought-after drug kingpins in Mexico and the United States, the top leader of the Gulf Cartel.
