abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Delhi Don’ts: High Heels in Khan Market
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: For Delhi’s fashionista crowd, high heels are a must in Khan market, despite the precarious pavement.
lead_paragraph: Khan Market looks like many other outdoor markets in Delhi – a crowded inner lane, uneven pavement, spontaneous potholes and an occasional pile of garbage or stray dog. Like the others, this U-shaped market is not the easiest to navigate, but many of its patrons wouldn’t dream of shopping there without the “right” footwear – high, high heels.

headline: A Farewell to India’s Milkman
abstract: Verghese Kurien, who died this week at age 90, was one of India’s most important social revolutionaries. His enterprising leadership in the national dairy industry helped India to become the world’s largest milk producer.
lead_paragraph: My latest column is an inadequate eulogy to one of the most useful Indian men ever, Verghese Kurien, who died this week. Mr. Kurien, who helped make India into the world’s leading milk producer, was among a generation of extraordinary social revolutionaries who are the proof that sometimes some Indian politicians do fully back good people and give them complete freedom.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 13, 2012
abstract: Can you choose the correct verb form to complete the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the restaurant review “Where Fresh Flavors Flip.”

headline: American Ambassador Killed in Libya
abstract: Where did the attack against American diplomats take place?
lead_paragraph: Please note: Though our questions today seek to help students understand basic facts about this event, you may want to check the New York Times homepage for the latest updates as the story develops.

headline: Boomers vs. Millennials: Who’s Really Getting Robbed?
abstract: The millennials whose future I’m robbing are my four children, and it’s costing me a fortune to do it.
lead_paragraph: The only way to save America’s children is to lock up the baby boomers. We are robbing the next generation’s future.

headline: Looking Toward Retirement
abstract: A special section offers news on social security and advice on how improve your financial standing.
lead_paragraph: In case you missed the special retirement section on Wednesday, it’s worth having a look, particularly if you’re a boomer heading that way. It’ll give you a lot to think about. Paul Sullivan has a more than a little worrisome story on how hard it is for retirees to rely on Social Security alone, “The Tightwire Act of Living Only on Social Security.” The numbers are not on our side.

headline: Getting Back to Work
abstract: Tory Johnson will answer questions about returning to work or starting a business.
lead_paragraph: While the unemployment rate for baby boomers is lower than for younger workers, once boomers lose a job, it takes them longer to find a new one.

headline: Mellow Drinks in a Surprising Neighborhood
abstract: The Summit Bar in the East Village is an excellent destination for a grownup drink.
lead_paragraph: Unless you live there, the East Village is usually not the first neighborhood that comes to mind when you want a drink after work. The East Village is where your kids go with their friends — or where they rent an apartment (also with their friends).

headline: Welcome to Your Living Room, Boomers
abstract: A new destination for news, entertainment and commentary about baby boomers and the way they live now.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t the best thing to admit, but the term “baby boomer” makes me a little queasy. In my mind it conjures images of 65-year-old hippies skipping through meadows on their way to the local Social Security office.

headline: If Football Is So Dangerous to Players, Should We Be Watching It?
abstract: The journal Neurology reported that football players are three to four times more likely than the rest of us to die from brain diseases.
lead_paragraph: Devon Walker, a Tulane University football player, broke his neck last weekend while making a tackle during a game. Three days earlier the journal Neurology reported that football players are three to four times more likely than the rest of us to die from brain diseases. If football, America’s most popular spectator sport, is inherently dangerous to players, should we be watching it?

headline: Why Can’t I Read This AARP Bulletin?
abstract: People with presbyopia find that it is harder and harder to make out objects that are close to them.
lead_paragraph: Your arms can push that book only so far away before you have to admit there is a problem, and it isn’t with your arms: it is with your eyes. It’s called presbyopia, and let’s not sugarcoat it. “That’s a Greek word for old eyes,” said Dr. James J. Salz, a Los Angeles ophthalmologist.

headline: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
abstract: Margaret Trudeau turns 64, and Tommy Lee Jones and Oliver Stone hit the 66 mark, among others.
lead_paragraph: Baby boomers are aging gracelessly. It’s exhausting listening to us. How many times have you heard a boomer say, “I can’t believe I’m this old” — as if we are the first people in the history of the planet to turn 58. According to the Yankelovich research firm, the average boomer thinks old age begins at 79. Since average life expectancy is 77, this means boomers believe that first they will die, then they will get old.

headline: For Better, for Worse, Couples Who Endure
abstract: A new feature profiles marriages, civil unions and partnerships that have lasted over 25 years. In the first of the series, one couple reminisces on the glue that holds it all together.
lead_paragraph: In Tom Brokaw’s best seller “The Greatest Generation,” he makes the case that the men and women who survived the Depression and led America to victory in World War II — the baby boomers’ parents and grandparents — made a contribution to this country like no other in history. Among the many reasons he cites is their commitment to family. Only one in six of their marriages ended in divorce; for the boomers it has been one in two.

headline: I’m Not Getting Any Better
abstract: One woman throws in the towel on self-improvement, and instead will hang on to what she’s got.
lead_paragraph: I’m turning 58 next month, and the birthday present I’m giving myself is to call a halt to all of my efforts at self-improvement. I’m done trying to better myself. This is as good as I’m going to get. From now on, the goal is to try to hang on to what I’ve got.

headline: Introducing the Latin Euro
abstract: The tide in Europe is running against Germany and toward a weaker European Central Bank, two economists write.
lead_paragraph: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a director of Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

headline: A Long View of Afghanistan’s Wars
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Hazaras (Ethnic Group)', 'Pashtun (Ethnic Group)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Uzbeks (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: The photographer Robert Nickelsberg has been making trips to Afghanistan since 1988. His new book-length project, “A Distant War,” goes past the current, seemingly intractable American invasion to show how a nation has been beleaguered by decades of almost perpetual conflict.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — One of the most troubling things about the national conversation about Afghanistan is that it tends to focus almost solely on the decade since the 2001 American-led invasion. Perhaps this is understandable, since the Afghan conflict marks the longest stretch of time that the United States has actively been at war. And as always, the latest crisis­, any of them, dominates attention: the growing threat posed by Afghan forces who kill their NATO colleagues, the unwillingness of Pakistan to stop sheltering militants who carry out attacks in Kabul, the plague of official corruption that undermines Western trust and the Afghan public’s support.

headline: Egypt May Be Bigger Concern Than Libya for White House
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The tepid response from the Egyptian government to violence at the American Embassy in Cairo gave American officials cause for worry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the harrowing images of the deadly attack on the American mission in Benghazi, the Obama administration is grappling with the possibility that its far bigger long-term problem lies in Egypt, not Libya.

headline: Europe’s Governments and Investors Are Wary of a Giant Aerospace Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Lagardere, a key shareholder in EADS, the owner of Airbus, said it wanted to examine the deal announced Wednesday before giving its consent.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — European governments and shareholders reacted with caution on Thursday to news that the region’s two largest aerospace and military companies were in advanced discussions to create a $49 billion behemoth to rival the likes of Lockheed Martin and Boeing.

headline: Turmoil Over Contentious Video Spreads
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In Yemen, hundreds of protesters attacked the American Embassy, two days after assailants killed the American ambassador in Libya and crowds tried to overrun the embassy compound in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Deadly outrage in the Arab world over an American-made video insulting Islam’s founder spread to at least half a dozen places across the Middle East on Thursday and threatened to draw in Afghanistan, two days after assailants in Libya killed four American diplomatic personnel, including the ambassador, and caused a foreign policy political clash in the United States.

headline: The New New List
abstract: Tracking the latest ideas in travel and where they’ll take you next.
lead_paragraph: Chennai is the new Mumbai

headline: Big Data Gets Its Own Photo Album
abstract: Big Data is the subject of a forthcoming glossy photo book, a smartphone application for personal data analysis and comparison, and an interactive version of the book for the iPad. The project is the brainchild of Rick Smolan, creator of the “Day in the Life” series of books.
lead_paragraph: Rick Smolan, the photographer and impresario of media projects, has tackled all sorts of big subjects over the years, from countries (“A Day in the Life of Australia” in 1981) to drinking water (“Blue Planet Run” in 2007). He typically recruits about 100 photographers for each, and their work is crafted into classy coffee-table books of striking photographs and short essays.

headline: The Early Word: Fallout
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times:The deadly attack on an American consulate in Libya on Tuesday pushed foreign policy to the front of the presidential campaign, with Mitt Romney quickly attacking President Obama for his response to the situation, Peter Baker and Ashley Parker write. But Mr. Romney’s attempt to use the event to draw a contrast with Mr. Obama on foreign policy started a confrontation that landed him on the defensive and drew attention away from questions about Mr. Obama’s handling of uprisings in the Arab world.

headline: Searching U.S. Colleges, Doubt Creeps In Amid the Confidence
abstract: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student at Sardar Patel Vidyalaya, in New Delhi, is one of eight high school seniors around the world blogging about their college searches for The Choice.
lead_paragraph: In fifth grade, I knew I wanted to study computer science when I grew up. My school did not offer much in that subject, so I spent my time building Web sites and silly apps on Visual Basic, and exploring random software. In high school, when I could finally take programming classes, I fell in love with programming. It was the perfect mix between art and science. I knew just what I wanted to do.

headline: Support for the Euro Is Seen in Dutch Election Results
abstract: Dutch voters appeared to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte a narrow victory, which will relieve European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — In a closely watched election, Dutch voters appeared on Wednesday to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte and his center-right Liberal Party a narrow victory over the center-left Labor Party, which will bring a sigh of relief to European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.

headline: David Simon on Ravens, Gay Marriage and Free Speech
keywords: ['Football', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: David Simon, the writer/producer of shows like “The Wire,” has commented on the Maryland politician who tried to silence a Ravens player over his stance on gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: David Simon, the former Baltimore Sun crime reporter who went on to create award-winning shows like “The Wire,” commented on Saturday on the Maryland politician who attempted to silence Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo over his support of gay marriage.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Full Flight’
abstract: This Poetry Pairing matches “Full Flight” with by Bob Hicok with “At Ground Zero, Readers Offer Plain-Spoken Tributes to Those Lost,” an article that appeared on Tuesday, the eleventh anniversary of the terrorist attacks of 9/11.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches “Full Flight” by Bob Hicok with “At Ground Zero, Readers Offer Plain-Spoken Tributes to Those Lost,” an article that appeared on Tuesday, the eleventh anniversary of the terrorist attacks of 9/11.

headline: Always Be Crisping
abstract: Closing the deal on a perfect breast of lamb.
lead_paragraph: Cooking is sales, as any child or restaurant chef will tell you. “The single word ‘crispy’ sells more food than a barrage of adjectives describing the ingredients or cooking techniques on a menu,” Mario Batali writes in “Babbo,” the best restaurant cookbook of the modern age, dedicated to the menu at his flagship restaurant in Greenwich Village. “There is something innately appealing about crispy food.”

headline: Introducing: Creating Value
abstract: Most business owners concentrate on keeping their customers happy and having enough cash in the bank to pay their bills, at least at first. They don’t think about their long-term goals.
lead_paragraph: Business owners start businesses for a variety of reasons. A few do it to make a lot of money, but a vast majority do it for other reasons.

headline: Silent Echoes
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Tensions between the United States and Venezuela have so cooled that neither is an issue in the other’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: It’s the rare campaign skirmish that barely makes a splash. President Barack Obama shrugged off a question about Venezuela from a popular television anchor in Miami, saying the country posed no serious threat to the national security of the United States. Mitt Romney declared himself “stunned” by the idea that Hugo Chávez isn’t a danger. To think so, Romney said, is “simply naive.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Photos in Full Screen View
abstract: Photos can fill the screen with the press of a key or two.
lead_paragraph: The ability to see photos in full-screen mode on the computer cuts down background distraction from icons cluttering the desktop. In Windows, when you open a photo in Windows Explorer, press the F11 key on the keyboard to expand the picture to the full screen. If it does not work, the manufacturer may have modified the keyboard function; try pressing the Function key and F11 or check the computer’s manual.

abstract: Shares of the European aerospace giants EADS and BAE Systems tumbled on Thursday as investors reacted negatively to the announced merger talks between the two companies.

headline: Larry Gibson, 66, a Foe of Mountaintop Mining, Is Dead
abstract: Larry Gibson died on Sunday of a heart attack at his home in West Virginia
lead_paragraph: Larry Gibson, the retired autoworker who gained national attention for his fight against mountaintop-removal coal mining in his native Appalachia, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in West Virginia. He was 66.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — More evidence of a weakening global economy emerged Thursday ahead of the Federal Reserve’s decision to take aggressive new steps to stimulate growth in the United States.

headline: ESPN, Aided by Arbitron and comScore, to Follow the Audience Wherever It Goes
abstract: The plan is to measure the media consumption patterns of consumers across five platforms: radio, television, mobile phones, tablets and desktop computers.
lead_paragraph: With more people using Twitter while they watch television, surfing the Web while they listen to the radio, or toggling between the content on their tablets and smartphones, advertisers and media companies are struggling to keep track of the eyeballs they covet.

headline: Midwest Musketeers Storm Broadway
abstract: Three Chicago theater buddies — the director Dexter Bullard, the actor Michael Shannon and the playwright Craig Wright — make their Broadway debut with Mr. Wright’s “Grace.”
lead_paragraph: TO sit in the orchestra of a Broadway theater in the week before a show begins previews is to wonder that any show ever opens at all. Late on a Friday night, at the close of a technical rehearsal for “Grace,” a play by Craig Wright at the Cort Theater, doors wobbled, lines faltered and costume changes dragged.

Along with questions, some readers proposed their own answers. The first set of answers is here, and the second set is below.

headline: India Leads World in Deaths of Children Under Five
abstract: Child health improving slower in India than the rest of the world, United Nations study shows.
lead_paragraph: The world welcomed a piece of good news today: The number of children dying under the age of 5 has steadily dropped over two decades, according to a report by United Nations Children’s Fund.

lead_paragraph: India’s central government hopes to push through significant financial reforms in coming weeks aimed at kick-starting the country’s slowing economy, but Mamata Banerjee, West Bengal’s chief minister, may again stand in the way.

headline: Protests Stir Fears for Arab Spring
abstract: Continuing anti-American protests, following the death of the U.S. ambassador to Libya and three colleagues, have raised fears in the Arab world about the future of democratization and relations with the West.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — While Americans were mourning the death of their ambassador to Libya and three of his embassy staff, many in the Middle East were lamenting the latest blow to their hopes for the Arab Spring.

abstract: Epix, the premium movie channel, said it had acquired rights to “Filthy Gorgeous: The Extraordinary World of Bob Guccione.”

lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s new effort to bolster the economy and support the housing market was greeted enthusiastically on Wall Street on Thursday, but mortgage experts were already doubting whether the benefits would be passed along to American homeowners.

headline: Hey, Elmo, That Concept Has Legs
abstract: To match preschoolers’ interests with age-appropriate learning, “Sesame Street” is putting Elmo in a musical environment starting this fall.
lead_paragraph: ON a steamy June morning five 4-year-olds at a Harlem day care center lined up on the floor and focused intently on a tiny television set. Around them a half-dozen young women sat on miniature chairs and intensely monitored their every reaction. Were the children looking away? Smiling? Making a negative comment? Clapping?

headline: Instruments of Young Dreams
abstract: A conversation about the new indie film “Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best.”
lead_paragraph: A combination of road movie, buddy comedy and musical, the new indie film “Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best” (coming Sept. 21) is out to have a good time. It is the brainchild of Ryan O’Nan, an actor making his directorial debut. He also wrote the film and co-stars with Michael Weston, who has appeared on TV shows like “House” and “Six Feet Under” and now gets to flex his comedy muscles in a lead role.

headline: Humans and Nature: Can the Gulf Be Bridged?
abstract: To grieve for the loss of something, the thinking goes, humans first have to develop a deep connection with it.
lead_paragraph: Basking in a surprise dose of early morning sun, we sat together on a bench made from yellow-cedar at the Gustavus Forelands Preserve, a landscape of spruce and cottonwood forests and beaches overlooking the Icy Strait waters. We were staring at a diagram on a piece of paper I had handed to Hank Lentfer, a lifelong Alaskan and longtime resident of the tiny town of Gustavus.

headline: Balanchine’s Enduring Pact With Stravinsky
abstract: New York City Ballet is opening its fall season with two weeks of ballets choreographed to the music of Igor Stravinsky.
lead_paragraph: FOR over a hundred years now the music of Igor Stravinsky has been central to ballet. In 1909, while still a virtual unknown, he orchestrated a Chopin number for the ballet “Les Sylphides” as part of the opening season of Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes. The next year Diaghilev presented the premiere of “The Firebird” with Stravinsky’s new score. The 20th century certainly spawned modernist composers, but none of them matched his profound instinct for dance rhythm; and none kept on so restlessly unlocking aspects of the new.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post: A dish of loin with roasted apples and Cumberland sauce is just one of the dishes the ubiquitous chef José Andrés will bring to the upcoming NBC series “Hannibal,” concerning Hannibal Lecter, the serial killer/gourmand who favored human liver “with some fava beans and a nice Chianti.” Andrés is now the show’s food consultant. – Glenn Collins

lead_paragraph: In 2009-10, about 57 percent of public school principals reported that their schools enforced a dress code. Some rules are intended to promote modesty, others to encourage a respectful learning environment.

headline: Sept. 16 — 22
abstract: A selection of events.
lead_paragraph: The weekend-long festivals by the London promoter All Tomorrow’s Parties have often been in faded vacation spots — English holiday camps and their counterparts in the Catskills and Atlantic City. As musical experiences the American events have been blissful but not boffo; costs ran high and attendance ran low. So the company is trying a new model with ALL TOMORROW’S PARTIES AMERICA PRESENTS I’LL BE YOUR MIRROR  — nearly 40 acts across three days at Pier 36, an entertainment complex on the Lower East Side. Frank Ocean, the R&B man of the hour, headlines on Friday, after a day including the comedian Hannibal Buress, a collaboration between Tyondai Braxton and Philip Glass, and Lee Ranaldo’s “Hanging Guitar” project, involving suspended, swinging Fender Jaguars. The reunited Afghan Whigs headline next Saturday, and other bands that day include the Roots, José González, Dirty Three and Chavez; for next Sunday the organizers have a slate including Godspeed You! Black Emperor, along with the Make-Up, the Washington punk-soul band, in reunited form. 5 p.m. to 1 a.m. Friday; noon to 1 a.m. next Saturday and Sunday; South and Montgomery Streets; atpfestival.com; $60 to $199.

headline: Cambodia’s Most Unwanted
abstract: Internet pirates and disgraced politicians, gunrunners and pedophiles, terrorists and mob bosses — why do so many criminals drift to Cambodia?
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH — The municipal council recently hung a neon sign across Sisowath Quay, on the capital’s popular riverfront. “Phnom Penh — The Charming City,” it boasted.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Peacock on the Loose
abstract: The escape and capture of Kevin, a peacock kept by John Bowne High School in Queens, is the subject of drawings submitted by children.
lead_paragraph: The escape and capture of Kevin, a peacock kept by John Bowne High School in Queens, is the subject of drawings submitted by children.

headline: The Death of a ‘Butterfly’ in Kabul
abstract: A little girl died in a suicide bombing on the streets of Kabul, and with her, so too died the last shred of innocence she brought to one woman.
lead_paragraph: Parwana means butterfly in Dari, and that is exactly what she was, fluttering around the grit and gloom of the green zone. She was killed last week, along with several other children, as they tried to call attention to a suicide bomber a few blocks from my house in Kabul. They were killed in part because I and so many well-meaning people drew them to a place where we could not keep them safe.

headline: Fresh Hopes for End to Chicago Teacher Strike by Weekend
abstract: Reports that progress was being made helped build hope that the city’s public schools could reopen on Monday.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Meeting behind closed doors into the evening, leaders on both sides of this city’s teacher strike voiced optimism on Thursday that a deal could soon be reached, bringing an end to a walkout that has halted classes for 350,000 students in the nation’s third-largest school system.

headline: Daily Report: An iPhone Tweak That Could Cost You
abstract: The iPhone 5 has plenty of new features to keep Apple fans happy. But as Brian X. Chen reports in Thursday’s New York Times, there is one feature Apple unveiled that is likely to annoy many: a new connector on the phone’s base.
lead_paragraph: The iPhone 5 has plenty of new features to keep Apple fans happy. But as Brian X. Chen reports in Thursday’s New York Times, there is one feature Apple unveiled on Wednesday that is likely to annoy many: a new connector on the phone’s base.

headline: Do Romney’s Budget Pledges Threaten S.B.A. Loans?
abstract: The Romney campaign declined to comment either on whether S.B.A. appropriations would be squeezed or, more generally, on the agency’s place in Mr. Romney’s small-business agenda.
lead_paragraph: Should Mitt Romney become president next year, he will face a difficult question pitting his eagerness to help small businesses against his eagerness to shrink the government: What to do with the Small Business Administration?

headline: There Will Be Megalomania
abstract: Philip Seymour Hoffman and Joaquin Phoenix star in Paul Thomas Anderson’s imposing, confounding and altogether amazing new film.
lead_paragraph: “The Master,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s imposing, confounding and altogether amazing new film, is partly concerned with the life and work of one Lancaster Dodd, leader of a therapeutic, quasi-religious cult known as the Cause. Dodd’s “process,” a stew of Freud, hypnosis and carnival sideshow mumbo-jumbo, is based on a kind of mental time travel. The subject is led, by a series of pointed, painful questions, on a search for past trauma — earlier in life, before birth, in a previous existence — that can be identified as the source of negative emotion and destructive behavior in the present.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Tornadoes in New York
abstract: The new “Kids Draw the News” assignment: tornadoes that hit the city last week. Also, the results of the last assignment: Peacock on the Loose.
lead_paragraph: New Assignment

headline: Checking Social Security Benefits Online
abstract: If you register to check your annual Social Security statements online, you’ll get an e-mail reminder to do so.
lead_paragraph: 12:52 p.m. | Updated  To add how much higher benefits would be at age 70 than at age 62.

headline: At Apple Event, With Secrets Spilled, No Surprises
abstract: Based on the accuracy of those Apple rumors leading up to the iPhone event, it doesn’t look like the company’s effort to double down on secrecy is possible.
lead_paragraph: One of the big surprises at Wednesday’s Apple Event was the lack of surprises.

headline: The Label Says Organic — But Is It?
abstract: Business Day Live: California ballot initiative has national implications for food labels. | Standard Chartered prepares to settle in money laundering case. | Controversy over movie about Nina Simone.
lead_paragraph: Business Day Live: California ballot initiative has national implications for food labels. | Standard Chartered prepares to settle in money laundering case. | Controversy over movie about Nina Simone.

headline: At UConn, It’s Time to Go
abstract: Writers look at Jim Calhoun’s decision to retire as coach, leaving the Connecticut men’s basketball program in disarray.
lead_paragraph: These aren’t necessarily good days to be a sporting icon, or at least one who clawed his way to the top with help from some moral or ethical sidestepping along the way, which in college sports, we now have come to expect, is just about everyone. But even a few years ago Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun could have expected his retirement to be greeted by universal acclaim. He did, after all, lead a basketball backwater to the big time and establish himself as a great coaching mind, all while professing to be above the unethical muck dragging down lesser mortals in the sport.

headline: If You Like Crosby, Stills and Nash . . .
abstract: Lovers of the classic “Helplessly Hoping” can find dreamy harmonies in the music of Local Natives.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Val Haller, a suburban Chicago mom, started valslist, a Web site aimed at exposing her generation — she’s 55 — to the music of the generation of her sons, ages 20 to 27. Unlike Pandora, a digital music recommendation service governed by an algorithm, Ms. Haller is governed by her ear, long hours of listening and serendipity. At Lollapalooza Chicago 2012, she was 25 years older than the average music reporter. “My goal every single day is to find that one new track that speaks to me and won’t let me go,” she says.

headline: Health Panel Approves Restriction on Sale of Large Sugary Drinks
abstract: The measure, which bars the sale of sweetened drinks larger than 16 ounces, will take effect in six months unless blocked by a judge.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to reduce runaway obesity rates, the New York City Board of Health on Thursday approved a ban on the sale of large sodas and other sugary drinks at restaurants, street carts and movie theaters, the first restriction of its kind in the country.

headline: Right Begins to Rally Around Romney’s Response to Attacks
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: A day after many Republicans seemed reluctant to endorse Mitt Romney’s critique of the Obama administration in Libya and Egypt, The Wall Street Journal and other prominent conservatives came to his defense.
lead_paragraph: Republicans were not exactly rushing to defend Mitt Romney’s brisk critique of the Obama administration’s response to a controversial Web video and the protests it seemed to help spawn. However, by Thursday, the right’s  establishment was starting to circle the wagons around Mr. Romney, the Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Answers to Your Questions About Apple’s iPhone 5
abstract: Apple’s announcements on Wednesday unveiling its much-anticipated iPhone 5, as well as upgrades for the iPod Touch and iPod Nano, elicited many questions from readers. Here are some answers.
lead_paragraph: 4:40 p.m. | Updated Adding more questions and answers.

keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'United States Politics and Government']

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The radio station operator Emmis Communications took several steps that have gutted its preferred stock, making the company a much easier target for a management takeover.
lead_paragraph: You have to marvel at the lengths to which the radio station operator Emmis Communications has gone to strip its preferred stock of voting rights and accrued dividends worth millions. And deal watchers will salivate over the clever legal structures devised by Emmis’s lawyers.

headline: At Tech Conferences, All Eyes Are on the Celebrities
abstract: At the TechCrunch Disrupt conference in San Francisco this week, the banter was not about a bubble, but rather the tech and Hollywood celebrities at the event.
lead_paragraph: The chatter in the hallways of conferences are usually a better barometer of the tech scene than the conversations taking place on the stage.

abstract: The Brooklyn-based chefs, brothers and roommates eat Chinese food and discuss their new cookbook, “This Is a Cookbook.”
lead_paragraph: A big fish head in a hot pot? Max and Eli Sussman had no choice.

headline: Soros’s Wisdom and Markets’ Ignorance
abstract: The euro crisis erupted, George Soros says, because the markets didn’t recognize European construction’s fundamental building flaw.
lead_paragraph: In my column this week, I discuss George Soros’s headline-grabbing insistence that the euro will survive only if Germany “leads or leaves.” My column focuses on his passionate conviction that a united Europe’s value goes beyond economics — this is also a political, and even moral, story.

headline: Wheelies: The Dr. Sid Edition
abstract: Prof. Sid Watkins, the official neurosurgeon for Formula One from 1978 to 2004 who tended to the Formula One driver Ayrton Senna on multiple occasions, died on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Promotion for Francesca Zambello at Washington National Opera
abstract: She now will have complete oversight of casting, repertory, the young artists program and a new commissioning project.
lead_paragraph: The Washington National Opera said on Thursday it had promoted Francesca Zambello  from artistic adviser to artistic director, solidifying its reorganization after the departure of Plácido Domingo and its merger with the Kennedy Center. Mr. Domingo stepped down as artistic director at the end of the 2010-2011 season, and the company became a Kennedy Center affiliate in response to serious money problems. Ms. Zambello, who is also the artistic and executive director of the Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown, N.Y., had stepped in at Washington to fill the void after Mr. Domingo’s departure. She now will have complete oversight of casting, repertory, the young artists program and a new commissioning project. She will continue to direct one production a year, the company said. She will assume the position in January.

headline: Louise Goldin: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Another Murder on the Resource Frontier – This Time a Journalist in Cambodia
keywords: ['CAMBODIA', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Logging Industry', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The murder of a journalist in Cambodia may be related to his reporting on illegal logging.
lead_paragraph: Speaking truth to power is never easy. In some places, particularly where valuable resources are pursued in places with limited governance, it can be deadly.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials are expected to conclude a two-day meeting Thursday and announce new measures to aid the ailing American recovery.

headline: My Night as a Billionaire
abstract: A case of mistaken identity earned me an invitation to an intimate evening at the Met.
lead_paragraph: This summer, a case of mistaken identity earned me a seat at a formal dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Led Zeppelin to Release Concert Film
abstract: “Celebration Day,” a documentary record of a 2007 benefit concert performed by the influential hard-rock band, will hit theaters in October.
lead_paragraph: Led Zeppelin, the hard-rock and seminal heavy metal band, will release a concert movie in October, just two months before the band is scheduled to be honored at the Kennedy Center in Washington for its weighty role in transforming rock music.

headline: Nicholson Baker: By the Book
abstract: The author of “The Way the World Works” suspects Shakespeare is the most overrated writer of all time. “Although I must say his sonnets are incredible.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “The Way the World Works” suspects Shakespeare is the most overrated writer of all time. “Although I must say his sonnets are incredible.”

headline: ’60 Minutes’ to Produce a Monthly Sports Show for Showtime
abstract: “60 Minutes of Sports” will stay inside the CBS corporate family, and give Showtime another way to compete with its bigger rival, HBO, on sports coverage.
lead_paragraph: “60 Minutes” is extending itself to another network, Showtime, for a monthly newsmagazine called “60 Minutes of Sports.”

headline: J.&J. Names Outsider to Run Its Troubled Consumer Unit
abstract: The new executive, Sandra E. Peterson of Bayer, will be responsible for the company’s consumer units, which have been hit by a series of recalls.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson named an outsider on Thursday to fill a top leadership role overseeing its troubled consumer health unit, a break from the company’s longstanding tradition of promoting executives from within.

headline: E-Book Planned on Embattled Russian Punk Group
abstract: The book will include prison letters from the three members of Pussy Riot who have been jailed.
lead_paragraph: The women of Pussy Riot, the Russian punk group protesting President Vladimir V. Putin, will have their message out in a new medium: an e-book. “Pussy Riot! A Punk Prayer for Freedom,” to be released in about two weeks by The Feminist Press, part of the City University of New York, will include previously unavailable material, including prison letters from the three Pussy Riot members who have been jailed for “hooliganism inciting religious hatred” after a brief performance in an Orthodox cathedral in Moscow. The book will also include statements by their defense attorneys, poems and tributes from performers and artists, including Yoko Ono, Karen Finley and the poet Eileen Myles. Proceeds will go to the legal defense fund for the group.

headline: Turmoil at U.S. Posts Abroad
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Protesters angered by an anti-Islam film attacked the American Embassy in Sana, the Yemeni capital, on Thursday, two days after the American ambassador to Libya was killed.
lead_paragraph: Protesters angered by an anti-Islam film attacked the American Embassy in Sana, the Yemeni capital, on Thursday, two days after the American ambassador to Libya was killed.

headline: Fed Ties New Aid to Jobs Recovery in Forceful Move
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: The Federal Reserve opened a new chapter in its efforts to stimulate the American economy, saying that it intends to buy large quantities of mortgage bonds until the job market improves substantially.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve opened a new chapter Thursday in its efforts to stimulate the economy, saying that it intends to buy large quantities of mortgage bonds, and potentially other assets, until the job market improves substantially.

headline: 15-Year-Old Trails by Two at Women’s British Open
abstract: Lydia Ko, a 15-year-old from New Zealand, shot an even-par 72 and was two strokes off the clubhouse lead at Royal Liverpool Golf Club.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — Lydia Ko was climbing the first-round leader board Thursday at the Women’s British Open when her group was put on the clock for slow play. The move was probably funnier to her than any punch line delivered by her coach and caddie, Guy Wilson, who told her jokes between shots at Royal Liverpool Golf Club to relax her.

headline: Hey, Señorita!
abstract: Hemingway has always been a big influence on Ralph Lauren, so you could imagine those bullfighting stories come to life on the runway, with models wearing gaucho pants, boleros and toreador jackets.
lead_paragraph: Olympic swimmers Conor Dwyer and Ryan Lochte attended the Ralph Lauren show this morning, suggesting all is forgiven over the designer’s production in China of ceremonial uniforms for the athletes this year. But if you thought Mr. Lauren might make a big pro-America statement on the runway, you would have thought wrong.

headline: Kevin Costner Plans Book Project
abstract: The actor and director will produce an illustrated adventure series that will first be released in book format and later as films.
lead_paragraph: The director and actor Kevin Costner has signed a deal with Atria Books for a book project — an illustrated adventure series titled “The Explorers Guild” that will be released in 2014.

headline: A Red Tide Epidemic?
abstract: Algal bloom is responsible for many of these events, an oceanographer says, but he warns against assuming that 2012 is setting a record.
lead_paragraph: As we mentioned here in an On Our Radar item this week, the Yangtze River in China changed from a warm brown to a deep, rusty orange a few days ago. Striking photographs showed a   crimson current advancing alongside a stretch of untainted water. One Green reader wrote in to describe what she saw as  a spate of red tide events around the world and inquired about the cause.

headline: Watch List: How Film Might Look After Google’s Glasses
abstract: A video shot with Google Glass offers a preview of what filmmaking may look like a few years from now.
lead_paragraph: For a preview of how we all may be making movies in a few years, take a look at “DVF Through Glass,” a short video made for, and partly shot by, the fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg. Other camera operators included employees of Ms. von Furstenberg’s label, DVF, and models who walked in her recent Fashion Week show. All were wearing Google’s futuristic “Glass” glasses, which come equipped with tiny cameras (as well as tiny computer monitors) and are poised to take us a big step closer to the cyborg age, once they become available to the public.

headline: Dreamliner Makes Its Debut in Chile
abstract: Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner, the lighter, more-fuel efficient aircraft recently made its American debut with the Chilean carrier LAN Airlines.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner, the lighter, more-fuel efficient and purportedly more comfortable aircraft that has forged fans of hopeful fliers, recently made its American debut with the Chilean carrier LAN Airlines.

headline: Fashion Week Stargazing: Day 7
abstract: And on the seventh day, there was Kanye West and Kim Kardashian.
lead_paragraph: And on the seventh day, there was Kanye West and Kim Kardashian. From the mayhem caused by the couple, first at Marchesa and later at Louise Goldin, you would have thought Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor had been reincarnated.

headline: Bookshelf
abstract: A round-up of new books with exotic settings around the world.
lead_paragraph: Han Han, China’s smart-aleck blogger (who’s also a pro racecar driver), uses satire to skewer philandering pols and media censors. His posts are now translated in ‘‘This Generation’’ (Simon & Schuster, $24). Set in New York, London and Maine, Christine Schutt’s novel ‘‘Prosperous Friends’’ (Grove, $24) tracks a young couple lost in a game of psychosexual brinkmanship. ‘‘The Grand Tour’’ (Harper, $28) collects Agatha Christie’s unpublished letters from an epic 1922 journey from South Africa to Hawaii. Neil Steinberg’s ‘‘You Were Never in Chicago’’ (University of Chicago, $25) is both a rollicking newspaperman’s memoir (he’s a Chicago Sun-Times columnist) and a strong case for Second City exceptionalism — belied, a bit, by the city’s inferiority complex: Chicago, Steinberg notes, ‘‘once conducted a study to prove its pedestrians walk faster than those in New York.’’

headline: The Nile Special
abstract: A particular patch of turbulent water on the Nile River in Uganda attracts the world’s best freestyle kayakers.
lead_paragraph: A particular patch of turbulent water on the Nile River in Uganda attracts the world’s best freestyle kayakers.

headline: A Source of Thrills
abstract: Amid concerns of further industrialization of the Nile, the best freestyle kayakers make sure to visit Uganda to try out their skills on the Nile Special.
lead_paragraph: HAIRY LEMON ISLAND, Uganda — There is a wave, far from passable roads and deep in the center of Africa, where those who seek to become the best of the best freestyle kayakers come to train.

headline: Many Struggling With Prescription Drug Costs
abstract: Nearly half of American adults take prescription drugs, a new report finds.
lead_paragraph: While health insurance premiums may be increasing more modestly than they were a year or two ago, consumers who take multiple drugs but lack prescription drug coverage are nearing a “crisis point” because they can’t afford to pay for them, a new report finds.

headline: Man of Many Names Is Tied to a Video
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Federal authorities identified Nakoula Basseley Nakoula as part of the network that produced an online video that has drawn violent protests across the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The spotlight in the search for the creators of an incendiary video mocking Islam that set off a wave of anti-American violence in the Middle East shifted Thursday to a shadowy gas station owner with a record of criminal arrests and bankruptcy, who associates said expressed anti-Muslim sentiments as he pushed for the making of the film.

headline: Taking Pointers From Web Sites, USA Today Modernizes Its Look
abstract: The Gannett-owned newspaper will look more like a Web site and its new Web site will read more like an iPad.
lead_paragraph: McLEAN, Va. — It’s face-lift time for the newspaper known for its pie charts.

headline: Living With Cancer: The Trials of Cancer Trials
abstract: There are many trials associated with enrolling in a cancer trial. Patients can fail to qualify, or later they can be thrown out or end up in a group that doesn’t get the drug. There are also challenges of geography and timing. But for some of us, a clinical trial is our best hope for living a little bit longer.
lead_paragraph: I spent last week trying to hope for the recurrence of a malignancy, a tumor of at least 1.5 centimeters (a bit more than half an inch) that would be visible on a CT scan.

headline: How to Find (or Make) Real Buttermilk
abstract: Advice on tracking down the genuine article.
lead_paragraph: Many thirsty readers wrote in to Dining on Wednesday after reading about the pleasures of buttermilk, asking how to get their hands on the good stuff.

headline: Google Glass and the Future of Technology
abstract: David Pogue tries out a pair of Google glasses (Google calls it Google Glass) and is impressed by the early prototype.
lead_paragraph: New gadgets — I mean whole new gadget categories — don’t come along very often. The iPhone was one recent example. You could argue that the iPad was another. But if there’s anything at all as different and bold on the horizon, surely it’s Google Glass.

headline: Legitimate Criticism
abstract: Why it was right to take issue with Mitt Romney’s statement on the attacks in Libya and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Stung by the furious response to Mitt Romney’s attack on President Obama over the killings in Libya, some right-wing commentators have defended Mr. Romney’s right to challenge Mr. Obama on foreign policy. Just for instance, Jennifer Rubin wrote in The Washington Post that “Obama has no right to insist he is beyond criticism.” She added: “If [the media] are going to insist that holding a president accountable for his national security is out of bounds, then perhaps journalism is now farce.”

headline: Lionfish for Lunch, But Also Here For the Long Haul
keywords: ['Coral', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Invasive Species', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: A marine conservationist describes efforts to control a lionfish invasion by catching and eating the invaders.
lead_paragraph: Just in case you missed it, my friend and occasional fishing tutor Carl Safina has a string of posts on Mark Bittman’s blog on the continuing invasion of American waters by lionfish, a reef denizen, studded with toxin-tipped spines, that was most likely brought here from Asian waters by the aquarium trade.

headline: 36 Hours in Managua, Nicaragua
abstract: This city may lack conventional addresses, but determined visitors can find everything from boiled-cheese snacks to a swimmable volcanic lake in Nicaragua’s capital.
lead_paragraph: FOUNDED just before the Spanish left the country in the early 19th century, Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, is a city without a center, and, bizarrely, without conventional addresses; instead there are locations, many referring to Lake Managua, which the city, otherwise, doesn’t much celebrate. The 1972 earthquake shattered Managua’s once glorious boulevards, and today building styles vary wildly, from the squat residential buildings that popped up after the tremors, to older, more majestic neo-Classical and modern edifices. But despite an initial impression of chaos, you will find smooth roads and a full range of hotels and restaurants serving hearty local fare. The years of political upheaval marked by the 1979 revolution and then the brutal civil war of the 1980s have finally given way to stability. Yet travelers on their way to the coasts or quaint colonial towns still rush away from the capital upon arrival. That’s too bad. There is a blossoming of culture in this city that is the key to understanding modern Nicaragua.

headline: Now Streaming | Calvin Klein Spring 2013 Women’s Collection
abstract: The Spring 2013 women’s collection show from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The Spring 2013 women’s collection show from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Palace in Haiti, Damaged by Quake, Is Being Razed
abstract: The white French Renaissance palace, which ended up as little more than a symbol of the stalled recovery from the 2010 earthquake, will be ripped apart over the coming months and carted off.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Armed mobs have marched on it. Desperate presidents have fled it. Crowds have partied outside its majestic gates.

headline: Children of Aging Parents Are Often Nearby, Study Finds
abstract: Many adult children struggle to provide care from afar, but recent research suggests that distance may be less a problem than once thought.
lead_paragraph: Who moves?

headline: Gagosian and Perelman File Suits Against Each Other Over Artworks
abstract: The billionaire investor Ronald Perelman and his longtime friend and art dealer Larry Gagosian both filed lawsuits in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Wednesday, with each man claiming the other cheated him out of millions of dollars over art purchases.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Ronald Perelman and his longtime friend and art dealer Larry Gagosian both filed lawsuits in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Wednesday, with each man claiming the other cheated him out of millions of dollars over art purchases, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Bobwhite Lunch & Supper Counter
abstract: Inside the no-fuss Alphabet City storefront that makes a mission out of Southern fried chicken.
lead_paragraph: Inside the no-fuss Alphabet City storefront that makes a mission out of Southern fried chicken.

headline: A Southern Spot on a Mission
abstract: Bobwhite Lunch & Supper Counter, in Alphabet City, produces the kind of fried chicken worth dreaming about.
lead_paragraph: FIRST the chicken is baptized in sweet tea, a Southern elixir giddy with sugar, in which tea is an afterthought. It is left to brine overnight, then dredged in milk, flour, salt, pepper and mystery spices that the chef refuses to divulge. Into the pressure fryer it goes, then onto your plate.

headline: Romney Delivers Broad Criticism of Obama on Foreign Policy
abstract: Speaking to a modest-sized crowd in Northern Virginia Thursday, Mitt Romney sought to move beyond his criticism of President Obama’s response to the turmoil in Libya and Egypt and instead broadly paint the president as weak on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX, Va. — Speaking to a modest-sized crowd in Northern Virginia on Thursday, Mitt Romney sought to move beyond his criticism of President Obama’s response to the turmoil in Libya and Egypt and instead broadly paint the president as weak on foreign policy.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 7
abstract: Details Fetes Michael Phelps, and Marchesa and Proenza Schouler Toast Their Collections
lead_paragraph: Details Fetes Michael Phelps, and Marchesa and Proenza Schouler Toast Their Collections

headline: Paul Ryan Gets His Own Meet-and-Greet Room on Capitol Hill
abstract: A few months ago, Representative Paul D. Ryan was just another up-and-coming member of the House of Representatives. Now the vice presidential nominee is holding office hours for his colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Only a few months ago, Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, was just another member of the House of Representatives, shuffling to the floor for votes with his iPod earphones stuck in his ears, or walking among colleagues in the Longworth House Office building.

headline: Board Votes to Regulate Circumcision, Citing Risks
abstract: The Board of Health passed a regulation that will require written consent before an infant can have a form of Jewish ritual circumcision, prevalent in the ultra-Orthodox community.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Board of Health passed a regulation on Thursday that will require consent from parents before an infant can have a form of Jewish ritual circumcision, prevalent in parts of the ultra-Orthodox community, in which the circumciser uses his mouth to remove blood from the incision.

headline: Wisconsin Uses New N.C.A.A. Rule to Solve Quarterback Woes, Again
abstract: A string of injuries to quarterbacks the last two seasons has prompted Wisconsin Coach Bret Bielema to twice use a new N.C.A.A. rule allowing immediate transfers for players who have graduated.
lead_paragraph: Confronted with devastating injuries to quarterbacks for the second consecutive season, Wisconsin has employed an inventive method to replenish its stock, far from college football’s conventional approach to cultivating the position.

headline: ‘Our Condolences,’ the Muslim Brotherhood Says
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: From Cairo, a Brotherhood official writes about the attack on the American Embassy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: At Film Society, Two Programmers Will Take Over From Festival Veteran
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center named Kent Jones and Robert Koehler to replace Richard Peña, who is stepping down after 25 years as the group’s programming director and chairman of the New York Film Festival selection committee.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after the longtime programming director of the New York Film Festival said he was stepping down, the organization that runs it has chosen not one but two replacements. The Film Society of Lincoln Center on Thursday announced the appointment of Kent Jones as director of programming for the festival and Robert Koehler as director of programming, year round.

headline: TimesCast Politics | Sept. 13, 2012
abstract: Romney's reaction to Benghazi. | Another foreign policy hurdle: Israeli relations. | Same-sex marriage and the New York primaries. | A deeper look at Obama's bundlers.
lead_paragraph: Romney's reaction to Benghazi. | Another foreign policy hurdle: Israeli relations. | Same-sex marriage and the New York primaries. | A deeper look at Obama's bundlers.

headline: Theater Talkback: Flattened
abstract: The movie versions of “Bachelorette” and “Rock of Ages” are a reminder of how hard it is to translate stage comedies and musicals to the screen.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it sounds a little perverse, but I usually try to avoid seeing any movies made from stage plays or musicals I have particularly enjoyed. A natural curiosity about how the material has been translated into a new medium tends to be outweighed by a general foreboding born of past experience. Too often the particular delights of a stage production evaporate considerably — if not entirely — in the translation.

headline: Fiercest Competition This Season May Be Among Singing Competitions
abstract: Fox’s alternate singing entry, “The X-Factor,” was hurt by going up against “The Voice” on NBC for an hour. Meanwhile, Fox’s “American Idol” is pursuing high-profile judges for its next season.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday night brought further evidence that network television may be saturated with singing competitions, even as news reports circulated about which celebrated recording artists the Fox network would be adding as judges to revive the flagging flagship of singing shows, “American Idol.”

headline: Photos of The Moment | Proenza Schouler
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Carlyle Buys Controlling Stake in Brazilian Furniture Retailer
abstract: The Carlyle Group said Thursday that it had acquired a 60 percent stake in Tok & Stok, a Brazilian furniture company, in a move that positions it to take advantage of the country’s consumer retail market.
lead_paragraph: SAO PAULO, Brazil – The Carlyle Group said Thursday that it had acquired a 60 percent stake in Tok & Stok, a Brazilian furniture company, in a move that positions it to take advantage of the country’s consumer retail market.

headline: Disney Unexpectedly Reveals Movie Write-Down and Sluggish Ad Revenue
abstract: The company’s chief financial officer told Wall Street analysts that it was stopping production on an animation film, and that summer ad revenue at ABC was softer than expected.
lead_paragraph: James A. Rasulo, Disney’s chief financial officer, unexpectedly revealed two important tidbits at a gathering of Wall Street analysts on Thursday: The company will take a $50 million write-down at its movie studio, and summer advertising revenue at ABC was softer than expected.

headline: Warm-Weather Leathers
abstract: Set on making the most of a good thing, a clutch of designers has reprised last season’s swoony romance with leather, trotting out unlikely springtime variations.
lead_paragraph: Set on making the most of a good thing, a clutch of designers has reprised last season’s swoony romance with leather, trotting out unlikely springtime variations. Counterintuitive though it first seemed, the decision to experiment with skins proved an apt one, underscoring the starchy, crisply formal feel of some collections, and handily brightening others.

headline: In His Narrative, Time to Get Back ‘Into the Game’
abstract: Izhar Patkin, once a major player in the New York art scene but hardly seen in years, has a new overtly political exhibition at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: IN the 1980s the Israeli-born painter and sculptor Izhar Patkin often seemed to be everywhere in the New York art world. He was a star in the stable of the flamboyant dealer Holly Solomon, for whom he made not only art but occasional apartment décor (painted dining-room curtains); an adventurous free floater among the worlds of art, fashion and design; and a standout in the 1987 Whitney Biennial, which featured his “Black Paintings,” an ominously beautiful series of images on pleated, hanging neoprene that is now in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Americans Look to Be Conquistadors on Clay
abstract: The United States meets Spain and the Czech Republic plays Argentina in the Davis Cup semifinals, beginning Friday.
lead_paragraph: The United States Davis Cup team upset Roger Federer and the Swiss on red clay in February. The Americans upset Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and the French on red clay in April.

headline: Reaction to Libya Attack Could Color Poll Analysis, and Vice Versa
abstract: In the next week or so, it may be hard to discern what polling effects reflect momentum from the conventions and what are a response to the fallout from Libya.
lead_paragraph: Earlier on Thursday, I suggested that we have now gotten some pretty good guidance on the size of President Obama’s convention bounce. For the next week or two, most of our attention will be focused on how much of that bounce he maintains — and how it translates into swing states — and not on trying to gauge its magnitude.

headline: Diplomats Pulled 2 Ways, Between High Walls and Open Doors
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: An ambassador’s death most likely will only increase efforts to protect American diplomatic personnel from the chaos of the countries where they are posted.
lead_paragraph: Security breaches at American diplomatic compounds in the Middle East this week highlight the two competing challenges that United States diplomats confront: keeping safe in a world full of anti-American extremism and interacting with foreign populations outside the towering walls of government installations overseas.

headline: Why These Kids Get a Free Ride to College
abstract: Thanks to mystery donors, every kid in Kalamazoo, Mich., who completes high school wins a college scholarship. Will that help the city’s economy?
lead_paragraph: Wings Stadium, a dim, beery sports barn in Kalamazoo, Mich., is an appropriate home for the K-Wings minor-league hockey team and the Killamazoo Derby Darlins. Yet every year, in June, the site hosts a spectacle more uplifting than a season of flip checks. This is when it is the setting for the graduations of the city’s two main high schools. A couple of nights after Kalamazoo Central High fills the arena, it’s Loy Norrix’s turn. The rink is covered, and students, friends and family take over most of the 5,100 seats.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Releases Crash-Test List for 2013
abstract: The safety agency included a number of alternative-powertrain vehicles on its list of vehicles that are scheduled to be subjected to front, side and rollover tests.
lead_paragraph: 3:54 p.m. | Updated

headline: In Toronto a Number of Films Find Homes
keywords: ['New York Film Festival', 'Toronto International Film Festival']
abstract: A roundup of film sales at the Toronto International Film Festival includes Joss Whedon’s “Much Ado About Nothing” and “Imogene,” starring Kristen Wiig.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto International Film Festival is wrapping up with a spate of sales. Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions bought Joss Whedon’s adaptation of “Much Ado About Nothing,” which played well with “Buffy” fans at the festival. Shot in black-and-white in just 12 days, it has a modern tone (and a cast full of Whedon favorites, from “Angel,” “Dollhouse” and “Firefly”).

headline: Hitting Hard Off the Field
abstract: William C. Rhoden hopes more professional athletes follow the lead of the Ravens' Brendon Ayanbadejo and the Vikings' Chris Kluwe when it comes to social issues.
lead_paragraph: William C. Rhoden hopes more professional athletes follow the lead of the Ravens' Brendon Ayanbadejo and the Vikings' Chris Kluwe when it comes to social issues.

headline: Britain’s National Theater To Open New York Office
abstract: After the success of “War Horse” and “One Man, Two Guvnors,” the theater plans to take a more active role developing productions for a North American audience.
lead_paragraph: Following the financial and critical success of their London-to-Broadway productions of “War Horse” and “One Man, Two Guvnors,” executives at the National Theater of Great Britain announced on Thursday that they are opening their first office in New York next month to oversee future shows and deepen relationships with theaters and donors in the United States. While no new National shows are in the immediate offing for Broadway, the executives said, the new office is poised to make the National even more of a force in American theater than it already is.

headline: Dear FloFab: Black Tie and Paper Plates
abstract: Florence Fabricant offers advice on what to do when a black-tie affair doesn’t live up to its billing.
lead_paragraph: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.
