headline: On the Trail in Colorado, Obama Tries Balancing Campaigning With Mideast Events
abstract: President Obama spent the second day of what was to be an upbeat swing through the politically vital Mountain West on Thursday balancing the somber tone that a foreign policy crisis demands and the hyper-partisan rhetoric that eight thousand Coloradoans came to hear.
lead_paragraph: GOLDEN, Colo. – President Obama spent the second day of what was to be an upbeat swing through the politically vital Mountain West on Thursday balancing the somber tone that a foreign policy crisis demands and the hyper-partisan rhetoric that eight thousand Coloradoans came to hear.

headline: Would You Take a Pregnancy Test in a Bar?
abstract: For $3 and a swipe of your credit card, you can buy a pregnancy test from a dispenser in a bar in Mankato, Minn.
lead_paragraph: If you make a  beeline to the stalls, you might miss the pregnancy test dispenser fastened to a wall in the women’s restroom of Pub 500 in Mankato, Minn. There, with the swipe of a credit card, for a $3 fee, you can use a nearby toilet and learn whether you may proceed in good conscience with the martini you were about to order.

headline: This City Confused Me
abstract: Readers tell us which cities they find most confusing.
lead_paragraph: Even after 36 hours, we still couldn’t figure out Managua’s unconventional addresses. Readers tell us which cities they find most confusing.

headline: Primary Day in New York
abstract: The results of some New York State primary races could have national implications.
lead_paragraph: The results of some New York State primary races could have national implications.

headline: A Warning on Bank Complexity, From Someone Who Would Know
abstract: Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former Bank of America and Citigroup executive, discussed her concerns about the complexity of financial behemoths at a conference. “It makes you weep blood out of your eyes,” she said.
lead_paragraph: It’s still the talk of Wall Street: Are big banks too complex? And if so, what should be done?

headline: ‘The Truth Is Out Today, but We Begin Looking for Justice Tomorrow’
abstract: One revelation in the report on the Hillsborough disaster — more harrowing than anything since that terrible day in 1989 — suggested from postmortem reports that the hearts and lungs of 41 victims had continued to function beyond the arbitrary time that the coroner at the inquest decided they must have died.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The most shocking experience imaginable in a sports venue is to witness the suffocation to death of 96 fans — men, women and children — in the stadium.

headline: Week 2 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
abstract: We expect Cam Newton and a few others who had disappointing season debuts to bounce back in Week 2. Here are our favorable and unfavorable matchup picks for Week 2.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: 4 Years After Lehman’s Demise, Regulators Debate Overhaul
abstract: Mark Wetjen, a Democratic member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, told an industry group that the agency was debating how to crack down on foreign derivatives trading.
lead_paragraph: Four years after Wall Street teetered on the brink of collapse, regulators are struggling to rein in foreign risk-taking that imperils American banks.

headline: On Our Radar: Putin’s Wildlife Exploits
abstract: Russia’s president admits that some of his photographed wildlife encounters were not as spontaneous as they seemed.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, acknowledges that many of his outdoor adventures with wildlife have been carefully staged. For example, a tiger he was shown shooting in the wild with a tranquilizer gun was apparently a captive one that had been transported to the scene. [Reuters]

headline: Profile in Style | Ulrika Lundgren
abstract: In her many pursuits, this Swedish-born, Netherlands-based tastemaker stays true to her roots.
lead_paragraph: Whether she’s designing her rock ’n’ roll-romantic fashion label, Rika, decorating the Amsterdam apartment she shares with her family or choosing art for the walls of Maison Rika, her tiny canal-side guesthouse, this Swedish-born, Netherlands-based tastemaker stays true to her roots — for the most part. “I’m super-Scandinavian in my style,” she says, “but because I haven’t lived there for so long, I’m influenced by other cultures and the places I go, like London, Paris, Mexico, Mallorca and Bali.” A common visual vein that runs through all of Lundgren’s work is her signature palette: black and cream punctuated by jolts of primary color in the form of art and accessories. “My interiors, like my clothes and bags, are quite urban,” she says. “But I don’t like coldness, so I soften the edges and add warmth.” More…

headline: Dusting Off a Horseman for New Battles
abstract: “Armor for the Joust of Peace” will be on display at the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to celebrate the arms and armor department’s centennial exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is such a busy place that it’s easy to miss the artworks periodically on view there. Two 1967-68 silk-screens of Warhol’s “Flowers” — a teaser to “Regarding Warhol: Sixty Artists, Fifty Years,” opening on Tuesday — were recently hung on the eastern side of the hall. A colossal statue of a pharaoh, weighing about nine tons, sits regally on the north side.

headline: Defending ‘Conscience,’ Restricting Rights
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Two Republican senators introduced legislation that would forbid same-sex marriages on military bases.
lead_paragraph: Having lost the fight over Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell—repealed a year ago this month— Senators James Inhofe of Oklahoma and Roger Wicker of Mississippi are trying to make it as hard as possible for gay men and lesbians to exercise their civil rights while serving their country in the armed forces.

headline: The Cost of Adapters Adds Up
abstract: The cost of adapters for iPhone chargers can add up fast.
lead_paragraph: In my post about the new iPhone 5, I grumbled about the new power/sync connector, which doesn’t fit any of the millions of existing cords, docks, speakers and accessories. Unless, that is, you buy an insanely overpriced $30 plug adapter or a $40 cable adapter from Apple.

headline: A Tax Tactic That’s Open to Question
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Private Equity', 'Capital Gains Tax']
abstract: Private equity’s use of carried interest to lower tax bills, though legal, has drawn criticism. But another lesser-known method might not withstand an I.R.S. challenge.
lead_paragraph: “Anyone may arrange his affairs so that his taxes shall be as low as possible; he is not bound to choose that pattern which best pays the treasury. There is not even a patriotic duty to increase one’s taxes.”

headline: The New York Finale at Calvin Klein
abstract: Calvin Klein’s Francisco Costa brought the New York collections to a close this afternoon with a new take on the geometric black-and-white graphics that have been seen all over the runways in the form of stripes, grids and checks.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Costa brought the New York collections to a close this afternoon with a Calvin Klein collection that showed a new take on the geometric black-and-white graphics that have been all over the runways in the form of stripes, grids and checks.

headline: Video: Primary Day in New York State
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In a TimesCast video, Michael Paulson, Metro’s political editor, and Thomas Kaplan, Albany reporter, discuss the day’s races.
lead_paragraph: Thursday was Primary Day in New York, and some state legislative and judicial races were on the ballot. Though primaries tend to attract a small number of races, some of the day’s races could have national implications.

headline: Protests Spread as Anger Over Anti-Islam Film Mounts
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Two days after assailants killed four Americans in Libya, protests were reported at American missions in Morocco, Sudan and Tunisia, where the police fired tear gas to disperse crowds.
lead_paragraph: Protests spread across the Middle East and North Africa on Thursday, most of them directed at American Embassies and offices linked to United States diplomatic activities, as anger mounted over a video denigrating the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Ralph Lauren
abstract: The focus was on the signature, fresh-faced beauty of the Lauren woman.
lead_paragraph: The Look: South American Aristocrat.

headline: Suspect Sought in Rape of Occupy Wall Street Protester Near South Street Seaport
abstract: The police circulated a photo of a man who they said sexually assaulted a woman and then threw her over a second-story railing.
lead_paragraph: The police released a photo on Thursday of a man wanted for raping a woman and throwing her over a second-story railing near the South Street Seaport on Monday, breaking her pelvis.

headline: A New Kind of Monkey, With Colors That Set It Apart
abstract: Known as lesulas, the monkeys live in the central part of the Democratic Republic of Congo. They have blond chins and chests, dark limbs, reddish tails and brilliant blue buttocks.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have identified a new species of African monkey whose coloring “is unlike anything I’ve ever seen,” as one of them put it.

headline: In Japan, a Bird’s-Eye View
abstract: A treehouse offers spaces for birds to live and a human-size entrance where a visitor can observe them.
lead_paragraph: The Tokyo design studio Nendo has created a treehouse for the Ando Momofuku Center in Japan that is part birdhouse, part human observation deck.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Yemen, Syria and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Yemen, Syria and Afghanistan.

headline: SFJazz Names Artists to Open Its Permanent Home
abstract: The San Francisco jazz institution will open its new permanent home in January with performances by a host of jazz notables.
lead_paragraph: SFJazz, the Bay Area jazz institution which has for nearly 30 years presented concerts and festivals in rented spaces, announced on Thursday the lineup for a series of opening concerts and a wide-ranging full-season schedule in its new permanent space — with concerts by local as well as international artists and educational programming.

headline: Mary Weatherford: ‘Manhattan’
abstract: Mary Weatherford’s works, at Brennan & Griffin, are quite lively, pulled off with verve and an ecumenical historical awareness.
lead_paragraph: Brennan & Griffin

headline: Bloodstains With a Story: The Allure of Artifacts Linked to Famous Crimes
abstract: Artifacts from gangsters, murderers and high-profile outlaws are popular items at auctions and fill museums, feeding a fascination with felonious figures.
lead_paragraph: A bloodstained tan stocking was unrolled across a Manhattan cafe table the other day. It had belonged to Bonnie Parker, the murderous robber, and was found in her getaway car in 1934 after she and her partner, Clyde Barrow, died in a hail of police bullets.

headline: In Chinatown, Martial Arts Alfresco
abstract: A dedicated teacher drills students in martial arts in a Chinatown park, rain or shine.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent Saturday morning, I joined eight kung fu students and their master, David Kaplan, in Chinatown for a lesson in martial arts. It was 8 a.m. and raining, but Mr. Kaplan’s outdoor classes run six days a week, year-round and without regard for weather.

headline: ‘Ruptures’: ‘Forms of Public Address’
abstract: A group show at Cooper Union spreads a net over international art of protest and change.
lead_paragraph: 41 Cooper Gallery

headline: Penny Slinger: ‘An Exorcism Revisited, 1977-2012’
abstract: Samples of early feminist art hint at what’s to come in Penny Slinger’s first solo exhibition in New York, at Broadway 1602.
lead_paragraph: Broadway 1602

headline: Manhattan Race in Jeopardy as Its Organizer Steps Aside
abstract: The Coogan’s five-kilometer race, a fixture on the New York road running scene for more than a decade as it evolved into a neighborhood party in Washington Heights, may have run its course.
lead_paragraph: The Coogan’s five-kilometer race, a fixture on the New York road running scene for more than a decade as it evolved into a neighborhood party in Washington Heights, may have run its course. Peter Walsh, who started the run 14 years ago, has decided to step aside, citing personal reasons and rising race costs.

headline: Rising Up, After It’s O.K.
abstract: The exhibition “Performing Histories (1)” is an example of how museums are reflecting the spirit of contemporary events.
lead_paragraph: A banner attached to a lamppost on West 53rd Street outside the Museum of Modern Art has the word “REBELLION” in capital letters overlapping the MoMA logo, and a dotted line attached to the phrase “starts here.” It is a bold statement for a museum to make, since rebellious art (and behavior) invariably starts elsewhere and ends up in a museum only after reaching some consensus in the art world.

headline: Jesper Just: ‘This Nameless Spectacle’
abstract: The Danish artist Jesper Just’s 13-minute video, “This Nameless Spectacle,” follows a woman in a wheelchair in Paris.
lead_paragraph: James Cohan Gallery

headline: Big Movies for Little Kids on Governors Island
abstract: Movies made by students under 18 will be shown on Sunday on Governors Island; for adult fare there’s “Shaboygen” reception at the Invisible Dog in Brooklyn on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Cinemagoing highbrows tend to praise Buster Keaton in reverent tones. But the Miser knows from experience that nothing beats seeing “Steamboat Bill Jr.” while sandwiched between breast-feeding moms and enduring endless potty-break exoduses, all underscored by an aria of teething tantrums and the crunch of Skittles underfoot.

headline: Passion for Victory That Knew No Bounds
abstract: For 26 years, through bouts with cancer, and other afflictions and distractions, Jim Calhoun badgered and bullied his Connecticut program to dizzying heights.
lead_paragraph: This was back in the spring of 1990, almost a decade before Jim Calhoun won the first of three national championships at Connecticut, the state university in the middle of nowhere that he helped turn into quite the destination on the college basketball map of the United States. Behind the blue curtain that separated the postgame interview area from the locker room pathway, Calhoun was holding court with well-wishers, making a mole hill out of a miracle.

headline: Calvin Klein: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Afghanistan Tries to Block Video and Head Off Rioting
abstract: Afghanistan officials asked Internet companies to block access to YouTube, where an anti-Islamic video can be viewed, and asked local officials to urge calm in the country.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Racing to head off potentially violent demonstrations over an anti-Islamic video, the Afghan government on Thursday pushed Internet providers to shut down access to Web sites hosting the clip, and asked political and religious leaders to urge calm, senior Afghan officials said.

headline: Erik Hijweege, a k a Kevin Erskine, the Storm-Chasing Photographer
abstract: Haunting photography of supercell and monsoon storms in the United States, and the alter ego behind them.
lead_paragraph: To illustrate Nate Silver’s recent article on the state of weather forecasting, we turned to the work of the storm photographer Kevin Erskine, whose haunting pictures of atmospheric disturbances are the subject of his book “Supercell,” which came out last year. “Erskine” is the professional pseudonym used by Erik Hijweege, a Dutch photographer who was inspired to combine his longstanding interests in storms and landscape photography when he visited the United States seven years ago and met the meteorologist and well-known storm chaser Tim Marshall.

headline: Rebirth for Cave Buddhas
abstract: “Echoes of the Past” brings to the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World sixth-century treasures from Chinese Buddhist cave temples and showcases modern efforts to save them.
lead_paragraph: In the Buddhist way of thinking, all things must pass, though it seems a shame when they do, especially if they’re out-of-this-world beautiful, as so much Chinese Buddhist art is. But could that vision of transience be changing in the 21st century, as technology lets all kinds of things, including art, live on forever out there in digital clouds?

headline: Dutch and Germans Give European Union Reasons to Cheer
abstract: A decision by the German Constitutional Court and results from a Dutch election may mean that the worst is over for the euro, or so European Union leaders hope.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There was a general sigh of relief in the European Union this week. The cause was not better performance in the troubled and highly indebted southern countries of the euro zone, but crucial decisions made in the rich northern nations with perfect credit ratings, where skepticism about the common currency is running high.

headline: High Flier, Poised for Steep Descent
abstract: In Nicholas Jarecki’s “Arbitrage” Richard Gere plays a hedge-fund magnate whose glittering, rarefied world may be coming undone.
lead_paragraph: “Arbitrage,” a sleek entertainment about how very good greed can be, is a fairy tale masquerading as a tragedy. It pivots on Robert Miller (Richard Gere), a shifty hedge-fund manager and 21st-century robber baron who’s foxed his way to the top of New York’s moneyed classes. Charmed and charming, with a quicksilver stride and the self-possession of a man accustomed to hearing the word yes, Robert lives in a rarefied world of private jets, live-in help and seven-figure checks made out to favorite charities. Masterworks adorn his Gramercy Park mansion where a multistory crystal chandelier cascades in the foyer like a waterfall of diamonds.

headline: The In-Crowd Is All Here
abstract: In “Regarding Warhol: Sixty Artists, Fifty Years,” the Metropolitan Museum makes a foray into showing contemporary art that is relentlessly au courant and sometimes baffling.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has rushed in where museums more experienced in the new and the now might have feared to tread. It is highlighting its growing commitment to contemporary art with an examination of the immense, amorphous influence of one of the most important artists of the 20th century: Andy Warhol, the visionary Pop Art painter, innovative filmmaker, trenchant social observer, image thief, deadpan quotation machine, boho magazine publisher and forthright gay artist about town. This effort is not an encouraging sight, but then the Met has a long way to go where contemporary art is concerned.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Calvin Klein
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s: a bottom-heavy black satin platform with an elaborate gold heel.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: How Much Would Free College Cost for All New Yorkers?
abstract: Less than you might think.
lead_paragraph: In the magazine’s Education Issue, I write about the Kalamazoo Promise, a scholarship program that gives a full ride to all students who graduate from Kalamazoo public schools and go to college in Michigan. To replicate the program in New York City, to cover the college tuition of all 52,000 students who graduate from the nation’s largest school system every year, an endowment of something like $20 billion would be needed, according to Keith Luke, at the Connecticut-based Commonfund, which manages $25 billion in assets for nonprofit institutions. “Such an endowment,” he says, “would provide for annual tuition payments of $5,000 for each student for four years, growing annually at the rate of inflation for higher education.” Forbes magazine estimates that 57 billionaires live in the city. Mayor Bloomberg himself has donated more than $2.4 billion to favorite causes, and in 2013 Columbia University will finish a $5 billion fund-raising campaign, bringing in $1 billion more than its initial goal. So the money for a New York Promise is probably out there, but it would require one of the world’s biggest philanthropic efforts.

headline: A Trip With Beyonce or on Hair Force One? You Decide.
abstract: The presidential campaigns got creative with their pleas for cash, trying to grab supporters’ attention after a summer filled with increasingly desperate fundraising e-mails.
lead_paragraph: First came the e-mail from Beyoncé Knowles: want to fly to New York to hang out with her and President Obama?

headline: Overdue Links
abstract: Links for summer’s end.
lead_paragraph: To start off, here’s a little roundup of stories contradicting that Stanford study discrediting organics:

headline: Fashion Week Stargazing: Day 8
abstract: Olivia Wilde, Ryan Lochte and Amy Adams were among the famous faces floating around at the shows.
lead_paragraph: Orange juice, iced coffee and tiny, tiny chocolate cake. The breakfast of fashion champions. That was the menu, served by waiters on silver trays, for the 9 a.m. Giulietta presentation at the Classic Car Club on Hudson Street, where J. Crew’s Jenna Lyons made rolling out of bed look sassy: the president and creative director sported mussed hair, a white shirt and navy pajama pants with white piping. O.K., so the neon orange pumps helped.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 8
abstract: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: My Eyes Were Heavy, but I Didn’t Doze Off During the Show, Mike Francesa Says
abstract: The sports radio talk show host on WFAN-AM appeared to nod off during an interview on Monday, but he says no. “I was dragging during the show,” is the most he will concede.
lead_paragraph: The sports radio talk show host Mike Francesa — who appeared to take a brief nap while conducting an interview on Monday on WFAN-AM in New York — said on Thursday that while he had been tired from getting no sleep the night before, he had not actually fallen asleep while talking to Sweeny Murti, who covers the Yankees for the station.

headline: Met Opera Concerts Set For Le Poisson Rouge
abstract: The Met has arranged with Le Poisson Rouge, the high-art cabaret space in Greenwich Village, to present two concerts.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera is going downtown. The Met has arranged with Le Poisson Rouge, the high-art cabaret space in Greenwich Village, to present two concerts based on Met productions of two contemporary operas: “The Tempest” by Thomas Adès and Nico Muhly’s “Two Boys.” The collaboration gives the Met some visibility in the slightly hipper, younger and more contemporary music scene, and adds big-institution luster to Le Poisson Rouge, which has become firmly established as a New York concert site. The Met often collaborates with major institutions like Juilliard, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art but rarely with such a small fish. “It seemed like a good idea, as a way of educating the audience and reaching out to a new audience, to have performances down there,” Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, said. Mr. Gelb said the first performance, on Oct. 26, would involve a few cast members of “The Tempest” and Mr. Adès as pianist performing scaled-down numbers from the opera. The concert will include works by Ives, Purcell, Stravinsky and Tippett, with other instrumentalists joining in, a spokesman later added. Mr. Muhly will play and program the second concert in May. Mr. Gelb said the Met was paying for the performances and would split the ticket take with Le Poisson Rouge.

headline: A Convention ‘Bounce’ for the Boss
abstract: Bruce Springsteen’s song “We Take Care of Our Own” was played immediately after President Obama’s speech at the Democratic National Convention on Sept. 6. By the end of the week, the song’s sales had surged 409 percent, according to Billboard, with 2,000 downloads.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen did not perform at the Democratic National Convention, but he is still enjoying a convention “bounce.”

headline: Striving for New Standards, Just the Way They Are
abstract: The singer-songwriter-playwright Jason Robert Brown performed a set of his songs that are just short of being cabaret staples at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: If you pay little attention to the insular world of musical theater, you might not know that the 42-year-old singer, composer and playwright Jason Robert Brown is the Billy Joel of his generation. The heartfelt outpourings of this brainy, driven, hypersensitive, self-conscious introvert deserve to be standards, but still aren’t.

headline: Life After Bankruptcy
abstract: A bankruptcy filing typically remains on a credit report for seven years, but that doesn’t mean borrowers have to wait that long to apply for a mortgage.
lead_paragraph: EVERY month tens of thousands of people file for federal bankruptcy protection, mostly to wipe out debts and start anew.

headline: Both Versions of Romney Critique Should Have Remained on Web
abstract: The Times’s “write-through” of Mitt Romney’s response to the actions in Libya should have been handled as a separate article.
lead_paragraph: It’s standard practice for news organizations to change breaking news stories as more information comes in. You start with what you know at, say, 6 p.m., and add to it, change it, refine it as the night goes on.

headline: Let’s Put on a Circus, and Let’s Put It on Outdoors
abstract: “Moo,” by Circus Amok, is a free, outdoors and has a scrappy, let’s-put-on-a-show sense of enthusiasm.

headline: Going Back to His Old School, Where Ties Wind Up Binding
abstract: In “Liberal Arts,” a college alumnus returns to his alma mater for the retirement dinner of a favorite professor and finds himself tangled in a nest of new relationships.
lead_paragraph: The slick, feel-good “Liberal Arts” has enough dark notes to make the smug, obsequious performance of its star, Josh Radnor, who also wrote and directed, tolerable and at times even likable. As an actor and filmmaker, Mr. Radnor, of “How I Met Your Mother,” is steeped in sitcom conventions.

headline: Whatever Happened to the Fourth Footman?
abstract: James Silvia, who in the 1950s served Alexander H. Rice as fourth footman, has a unique perspective on servant life on the American continent.
lead_paragraph: CAN’T wait until the new season of “Downton Abbey” starts in January? Well, then, how about the New York version, starring James Silvia, who in the 1950s served Alexander H. Rice as fourth footman in his Newport, R.I., mansion and New York town house at Fifth Avenue and at 71st Street. Now retired from a career of teaching in Manhattan, Mr. Silvia, the son of a Portuguese gardener who worked on the estates of Newport, has a unique perspective on servant life on the American continent.

headline: Argentines Turn Cash Into Condos in Miami
abstract: Argentines are eager, and desperate, to direct their money out of their country and into real estate in Miami and New York.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google Glasses Movie and iPhone Fatigue
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes a case that the iPhone has become so good that the latest changes didn’t, and couldn’t, improve it very much, and the discovery of a way to penetrate the https encryption used by financial and e-commerce institutions.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Birds of a Feather: A Boy and Flamingos
abstract: In “Bird in the Hand” the playwright Jorge Ignacio Cortiñas chronicles the teenage years of a lonely, gay, precocious Cuban-American boy in Miami, with flamingos helping tell the tale.
lead_paragraph: Felix is an untrustworthy narrator. But really, when it comes to recounting our pasts, aren’t we all?

headline: Searching the Soul of a Soulful Singer
abstract: Leonard Cohen is universally misunderstood, but that doesn’t matter: the biography “I’m Your Man” is a mesmerizing labor of love.
lead_paragraph: Writing about a living subject, Sylvie Simmons says, means having “to immerse yourself in that person’s life to a degree that would probably get you locked up in any decent society.” It can also mean abandoning all hope of objectivity. But despite her simpatico feel for the life and work of her subject, Ms. Simmons’s “I’m Your Man” is the major, soul-searching biography that Leonard Cohen deserves.

headline: Sid Watkins, Formula One Safety Pioneer, Dies at 84
abstract: Professor Sid Watkins, responsible for saving lives in Formula One racing, has died at the age of 84. The tributes have flooded in from all corners of the F1 world.
lead_paragraph: His reputation, his status, his influence were as big and important as any world-champion driver in Formula One. But the number of drivers’ lives he was directly responsible for saving made him even bigger. Yet probably nothing was quite as impressive as his humanity.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 14-20
abstract: A selected, critical guide to comedy shows in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Comedy

headline: What You Need to Know About Thousands of Pages of UVA E-Mails
abstract: E-mails behind the controversy over Teresa Sullivan of the University of Virginia provided more than enough breadcrumbs to feed reporters, as well as conspiracy theorists who followed every stray reference, sometimes to questionable conclusions.
lead_paragraph: The story of Teresa Sullivan’s resignation and reinstatement as president of the University of Virginia — which I wrote about for the cover article in the Education Issue — would have been a campus drama under any circumstances, but it probably would not have become a national news story if not for Virginia’s open-records laws, which have allowed news organizations an unusually complete view into the e-mail accounts of the major participants. The first batch of e-mails, obtained by the student-run Cavalier Daily in the midst of the leadership crisis, provided the tantalizing glimpses into what had been, up to that point, a decision shrouded in secrecy. While they didn’t provide definitive answers, the e-mails provided more than enough breadcrumbs to feed reporters, as well as conspiracy theorists who followed every stray reference, sometimes to questionable conclusions.

headline: Movie Listings for Sept. 14-20
abstract: A guide to movies playing in and outside the New York area as well as noteworthy film series.
lead_paragraph: Movies

headline: Manhattan, Elusive by Land, Comes Into Focus by Sea
abstract: A round-the-island architectural cruise, with commentary on Manhattan landmarks and sites, yields views of new waterfront greenery worth a closer look on shore.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan has one of the most recognizable faces in the world. Yet it can be strangely elusive, even Garboesque. The buildings are too tall and too close together to see in their entirety from the ground, so New Yorkers who want to get a good look at the skyline have to go to the movies, visit a prime viewing spot like the Brooklyn Heights Promenade or look out an airplane window.

headline: Uneasy Allies in the Grocery Aisle
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Food', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Labeling and Labels']
abstract: A ballot measure to require labeling of foods that contain genetically modified ingredients is putting organic brands like Kashi, owned by Kellogg, at odds with their owners.
lead_paragraph: Giant bioengineering companies like Monsanto and DuPont are spending millions of dollars to fight a California ballot initiative aimed at requiring the labeling of genetically modified foods. That surprises no one, least of all the proponents of the law, which if approved by voters would become the first of its kind in the nation.

headline: Clip: 'Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best'

lead_paragraph: A performance scene from the comedy “Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best,” featuring Ryan O’Nan and Michael Weston.

headline: Madrigals, Tripe and Other Treats
abstract: Le Poème Harmonique, a French early-music group, is conjuring up the musical world of 17th-century Venice at the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: Venice in the early 17th century was home to a heady mix of high and low culture. The city opened the doors to the first public opera house in 1637, making this new art form, the plaything of princes, more accessible. The plazas were alive with commedia dell’arte troupes. Citizens could hear lofty tragic operas, sensual madrigals exploring the pangs of desire and bawdy street songs. Venetian composers drew from every genre.

headline: Reversing Time to Honor Guthrie and Other Heroes
abstract: The opening-night performance of Judy Collins’s sixth season at the Café Carlyle, on Sept. 11, had a ceremonial sense of occasion as she sang “Kingdom Come,” a tribute to New York City firefighters.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday being the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks on top of the continuing Woody Guthrie centennial, the opening-night performance of Judy Collins’s sixth season at Café Carlyle had a ceremonial sense of occasion. As she delivered a stirring rendition of her anthem “Kingdom Come,” a tribute to New York City firefighters killed in the World Trade Center, my mind flashed back to the day of the tragedy on a similarly clear and mild September morning.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Sept. 14-20

headline: Riding High on ‘Hatfield and McCoys,’ A&E Gives Dubuc a New Deal
abstract: The executive has turned the network into a ratings winner with shows like “Pawn Stars” and the miniseries “The Hatfield and McCoys.”
lead_paragraph: The A&E Networks announced a new deal on Thursday for a woman who has become one of the most important programming executives in cable television, Nancy Dubuc.

headline: Why the iPhone 5 on Verizon and Sprint Won’t Juggle Calls and Data
abstract: A lot has changed in Apple’s new iPhone. But with the Verizon Wireless and Sprint versions of the iPhone 5, there’s something that will remain the same from the old model: The phone still won’t be able to place a call and handle data activity over the cellular network at the same time.
lead_paragraph: A lot has changed in Apple’s new iPhone. But with the Verizon Wireless and Sprint versions of the iPhone 5, there’s something that will remain the same from the old model: The phone still won’t be able to place a call and handle data activity over the cellular network at the same time.

headline: The Heart of Darkness To the Soul of Defiance
abstract: The choreographer Nora Chipaumire and Okwui Okpokwasili perform in the New York premiere of “Miriam,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Like so many dances Nora Chipaumire’s “Miriam” begins in darkness, so that you hear the actions onstage before you see them. Viewers dutifully sit, letting these aural mysteries wash over them, waiting for a fuller picture to emerge.

headline: Droll and Exaggerated, Murderous and Strange (In a Family Sort of Way)
abstract: “A Guide to Kinship and Maybe Magic,” a Lewis Forever production, includes a film and a commentary at Dance New Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: “A Guide to Kinship and Maybe Magic,” by the choreographer Isabel Lewis, is billed as a production of Lewis Forever, the artistic collective that Ms. Lewis formed a few years back with her globe-scattered siblings — Sarah, Ligia and George Jr. But during the show’s debut at Dance New Amsterdam on Wednesday, the only Lewis onstage was a decoy.

headline: A Woman’s Place
keywords: ['Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Hanna Rosin argues that the revolution feminists have been waiting for is happening now, before our very eyes.
lead_paragraph: “The End of Men”? This is not a title; it is a sound bite. But Hanna Rosin means it. The revolution feminists have been waiting for, she says, is happening now, before our very eyes. Men are losing their grip, patriarchy is crumbling and we are reaching “the end of 200,000 years of human history and the beginning of a new era” in which women — and womanly skills and traits — are on the rise. Women around the world, she reports, are increasingly dominant in work, education, households; even in love and marriage. The stubborn fact that in most countries women remain underrepresented in the higher precincts of power and still don’t get equal pay for equal work seems to her a quaint holdover, “the last artifacts of a vanishing age rather than a permanent configuration.”

abstract: Getting a good look at Manhattan’s skyline can be difficult from the ground.
lead_paragraph: Getting a good look at Manhattan’s skyline can be difficult from the ground.

headline: High School Is Over, but the Angst Is Not
abstract: In the high school reunion comedy “10 Years,” some old classmates are struggling to grow up.
lead_paragraph: It takes a while to sort out who’s who in the gabby high school reunion comedy “10 Years.” But once you do, the movie that comes together is an unpretentious, well-acted ensemble piece that doesn’t aspire to be a portentous generational time capsule like “The Big Chill,” “American Graffiti” or “Diner.” But it has enough markers — a grown-up, married white rapper who break dances; a karaoke bar — to suggest an approximate date.

headline: ‘Regarding Warhol’
abstract: Images from a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Images from a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Jeter Says He Feels Great, but Does He?
abstract: The Yankees’ shortstop came up limping on a double-play ball in Boston, but he insists he can keep playing, and his manager believes him.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Derek Jeter is, in the eyes of his manager, difficult to read. So when he arrived at Fenway Park on Thursday and told Joe Girardi than his left ankle felt great, Girardi had to interpret what this actually meant.

headline: Making a Case for Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Movies']
abstract: Cassie Jaye’s “Right to Love: An American Family” chronicles the family of Jay Foxworthy and Bryan Leffew to make a case for same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: The kids are adorable, their two dads effortlessly likable and the love that binds them all inarguable. Yet Cassie Jaye’s squishy documentary, “The Right to Love: An American Family,” tries the patience, and not just because of its regrettably saccharine soundtrack. Any film this committed to arguing in favor of same-sex marriage needs at least as much spine as heart.

headline: Searching U.S. Colleges, Doubt Creeps In Amid the Confidence
abstract: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student at Sardar Patel Vidyalaya, in New Delhi, is one of eight high school seniors around the world blogging about their college searches for The Choice.
lead_paragraph: Nothing can quite convey the roller coaster of emotions of applying to college — bewilderment, elation, dejection, hope, fear — as powerfully as the voices of the applicants themselves. And so, as in years past, The Choice blog has selected eight high school seniors to tell their stories throughout the new school year as part of the latest installment of a first-person series we call “The Envelope, Please.”

headline: Sweet 16 ... and a Runway Model
abstract: Guidelines released this year stipulate that girls must be 16 to walk the runways. Is this an appropriate age? Or still too young?

headline: A Changing Landscape
abstract: While gold and copper mining have made Mongolia the world’s fastest-growing economy, they have also created some health and environmental problems in boom towns throughout the Gobi Desert.
lead_paragraph: While gold and copper mining have made Mongolia the world’s fastest-growing economy, they have also created some health and environmental problems in boom towns throughout the Gobi Desert.

headline: Though Not Yet Open, a Huge Mine Is Transforming Mongolia’s Landscape
abstract: Enormous reserves of gold and copper will bring prosperity, but at a human, cultural and environmental cost.
lead_paragraph: KHANBOGD, Mongolia — In the dry expanses of southern Mongolia, a handful of large blue buildings are clustered together, ringed only by a thin metal fence. A single plane sits on an airstrip, while power lines stretch off into the distance. They, along with the scattered flocks of sheep and goats, are almost the only things dotting the vast landscape.

headline: Microsoft Finds PCs That Ship Pre-Infected
abstract: Microsoft said it had discovered several new computers, fresh from Chinese factory floors, that carried a particularly pernicious computer virus — one capable of invading bank accounts, starting computer attacks and creating back doors to let criminals have their way with infected machines.
lead_paragraph: One more thing to worry about: Your brand-spanking-new computer could be infected with a virus that will raid your online bank account.

headline: A Makeover on 34th St., but Not All Believe in It
abstract: The $400 million face-lift at the flagship department store on 34th Street is compromising the Art Deco look of the ground-floor pillars, Theodore Grunewald says.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s is giving itself a $400 million makeover that it says will maintain the store’s “architectural integrity,” but one preservationist, Theodore Grunewald, is not happy.

headline: Rebels With Fishing Poles
abstract: “The Manzanar Fishing Club” is a subdued documentary about the World War II internment of Japanese-Americans.
lead_paragraph: I don’t detect an overload of films documenting the World War II-era internment of Japanese-Americans, even though the political, social and cultural history clearly is significant enough to warrant more interest. An artifact in the new documentary “The Manzanar Fishing Club” makes that case: a badge reading, “Jap Hunting License — Open Season.”

headline: A Former No. 1 Calls It a Career
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Davis Cup', 'French Open (Tennis)', 'Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)']
abstract: Juan Carlos Ferrero, the French Open titlist in 2003, will retire after the coming tournament in Valencia.
lead_paragraph: Juan Carlos Ferrero of Spain announced Wednesday that the ATP Valencia Open would be the final tournament of his career, ending a 14-year run in which he won a Grand Slam title and reached the No. 1 ranking in the time just before the tour takeover by Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal.

headline: An Expiring Tax Credit Threatens the Wind Power Industry
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'State Legislatures', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: If the production tax credit is not renewed in December, the state’s wind power industry may face significant declines.
lead_paragraph: When Brad Sawyer graduates next spring from Texas State Technical College in Sweetwater, he hopes to get a job as a wind turbine technician, working on the towering three-bladed machines that dot the West Texas countryside.

headline: Panetta Set to Discuss U.S. Shift in Asia Trip
keywords: ['International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta will outline how the Pentagon is refocusing on the Pacific, as the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are over or winding down.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta travels across Asia next week, on an arc from Japan and China to New Zealand, he will face two almost contradictory challenges.

headline: Food Artistry, Served Family Style
abstract: Step Up to the Plate” looks at Michel and Sébastien Bras, renowned father-and-son chefs, as their restaurant and family undergo a changing of the guard.
lead_paragraph: If “Step Up to the Plate” were fiction, its players would deserve an award for best ensemble performance. But as this calmly intelligent film from Paul Lacoste is a documentary, the focal figures — the renowned chef Michel Bras and his son Sébastien, now leader of his father’s restaurant — should win acclaim as committed, heart-driven artists best appreciated in relation to each other.

headline: Texas Law to Protect Student Athletes With Concussions Takes Effect
abstract: Natasha’s Law requires trainers and coaches at public schools to undergo training on how to react when players get concussions.
lead_paragraph: As public school athletic programs adjust to a new state law on how to respond when student athletes get concussions on the field, doctors and legislators say the health of the players will benefit.

headline: For Slain Contractor, a Life of Risks Overseas
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: For Glen Doherty, killed Tuesday in the attack on a diplomatic compound in Libya, being assigned to a high-stakes security detail was just one of many adventurous overseas missions.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For Glen A. Doherty, being assigned to a high-stakes security detail in Libya was just one of over a decade’s worth of adventurous overseas missions he had participated in as a security contractor and a member of the Navy SEALs.

headline: What Libya Lost
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: I was going to meet with Ambassador Stevens on a project that was the kind of partnership that he believed could help Libya move beyond decades of stagnation and despotism.
lead_paragraph: ON Wednesday morning, my colleagues and I were to meet in Benghazi with J. Christopher Stevens, the American ambassador to Libya, to discuss a plan for a new division of emergency medicine at Benghazi Medical Center, the largest and most modern hospital in eastern Libya. The meeting never took place. The night before, militants laid siege to the American Consulate in Benghazi, killing the ambassador and three other Americans. The ambassador was taken, without a pulse, to the hospital we hoped to upgrade.

keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Security and Warning Systems']

abstract: If and when China’s presumptive new leader, Xi Jinping, re-emerges, he will do so in the midst of a contentious Communist Party preparing to shake up its leadership.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With still no sign of China’s designated new leader, Xi Jinping, who has not been seen in public since Sept. 1, many insiders and well-connected analysts say the Chinese political ship is adrift, with factions jockeying to shape an impending Communist Party conclave.

headline: The iPhone Stimulus
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'iPhone', 'Consumer Behavior', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: If you think sales of the latest iPhone will help the economy, then you should support the government stepping in and doing more, too.
lead_paragraph: Are you, or is someone you know, a gadget freak? If so, you doubtless know that Wednesday was iPhone 5 day, the day Apple unveiled its latest way for people to avoid actually speaking to or even looking at whoever they’re with.

headline: In Central Park, a Birders’ Secluded Haven Comes With a Dark Side
abstract: With its paths and cloak of dense vegetation, the Ramble in Central Park has long been known as a place where people prowl for anonymous sexual encounters, but the same elements have made it a magnet for bird-watchers.
lead_paragraph: The Ramble in Central Park has long been known as a place where people prowl for anonymous sexual encounters. They are drawn by the cloak of dense vegetation, serpentine paths, giant boulders and meandering streams created by the park’s designer, Frederick Law Olmsted.

headline: Trial to Begin for Former UBS Trader Accused of Hiding Huge Loss
abstract: Opening arguments begin Friday in the trial of Kweku M. Adoboli, who faces charges of false accounting and fraud in connection with a $2.3 billion loss at the UBS investment bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — UBS will face the harsh glare of the spotlight again on Friday, as opening arguments begin in the trial of a former trader accused of hiding a multibillion-dollar loss at the investment bank.

headline: Warren Ad Paints Her as a Fighter, and Throws a Punch
abstract: Elizabeth Warren’s new 30-second advertisement is the first to venture off safe ground and is a sign of how much the Senate race in Massachusetts is intensifying in the run-up to the first debate.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Elizabeth Warren is throwing the first punch in the ad wars in the increasingly bitter Massachusetts Senate race, with a new television commercial on Thursday that accuses Senator Scott P. Brown, her Republican opponent, of “siding with the big-money guys.”

headline: At Euphoric Louisiana-Monroe, Coach Isn’t Ready to Smile
abstract: With the Warhawks celebrating an upset over Arkansas, Coach Todd Berry quickly shifted focus to their next opponent, Auburn.
lead_paragraph: The day after perhaps the biggest victory in the history of Louisiana-Monroe’s football program — an overtime win against then-No. 8 Arkansas last Saturday — Coach Todd Berry was already wishing his team would forget about the thousands of fans who had greeted its return to campus at 2 a.m. He hoped the players would remember they had arrived not by plane, but by bus.

headline: Drifter Known for Menace Is Charged With Raping Woman, 73, in Central Park
abstract: The suspect, David A. Mitchell, 42, recently arrived in New York after a string of incarcerations in the South for felonies including kidnapping, abduction and robbery.
lead_paragraph: A drifter who hailed from the South and spent most of his adult life in and out of prison on a grab bag of felonies, including kidnapping and abduction, was arrested on Thursday and charged with the rape, beating and robbery of a 73-year-old woman in Central Park.

headline: Facts, Arguments and Politics
abstract: In political debates, getting the facts right doesn’t guarantee a valid argument.
lead_paragraph: Emotions drive politics. So why all the concern about facts and fact-checking? Because, among the whirl of our feelings, there is a desire for our beliefs to be rational, to have support from the facts. We’re uneasy if we can’t make a plausible case that what we say is true. Notice that political campaigns do all they can to undermine the analyses of the fact-checkers who award them “Pinocchios.” At a minimum, citing the facts is one important rhetorical ploy. I recall hearing of a university administrator who allegedly admitted, “Sometimes telling the truth is the best way to get people to do what you want.”

headline: The Burden of Speech
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Mitt Romney’s words about the attack in Benghazi were all too revealing.
lead_paragraph: A fanatic makes a hate movie, filled with wild claims about the founder of one of the world’s major religions. Fanatics of another sort are inflamed by the crude film, crying blasphemy.

headline: Wright Creeping Closer to Kranepool
abstract: David Wright is closing in on Ed Kranepool’s record for most career hits by a Met.
lead_paragraph: As the Mets stumble toward the close of another forgettable season, fans are left with two reasons to watch games: R.A. Dickey’s pursuit of 20 victories and a possible Cy Young award and David Wright’s pursuit of the Mets’ career hit record.

headline: For Those Who Breathe Smoke
abstract: Don’t go looking for traditional cigarettes at Smoking Culture, on West Fourth Street near Avenue of the Americas, which features all the accouterments of more furtive adult pleasures.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent Friday evening, a man walked into Smoking Culture in Greenwich Village, a store whose sign promises to fulfill “all your smoking needs,” and asked for a pack of Newports.

headline: Amid Mideast Turmoil, Aides Say What a President Romney Would Do
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Tying Egypt’s debt forgiveness to the country’s efforts to protect American interests there and shaping a post-Qaddafi Libya were among the specific positions Mitt Romney’s advisers said he would take.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Mitt Romney were in the Oval Office during this week of turmoil in the Middle East, his foreign policy advisers said on Thursday, he would have already told Iran that he would not allow it to get close to building a bomb, setting a “red line” in a far different place from President Obama’s.

headline: A Shift in Energy Ads
abstract: Presidential and policy ads this year are more likely to promote policies that are friendly to fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: Presidential and policy ads this year are more likely to promote policies that are friendly to fossil fuels.

headline: Orioles Keep Showing Flair for the Dramatic
abstract: A bloop single gave Baltimore its 13th straight victory in extra-inning games and put an end to a run of 14 consecutive losing seasons.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When the Baltimore Orioles loaded the bases with no outs in the bottom of the 13th inning of a tied game on Thursday afternoon, only to squander their opportunity, the team’s long-deprived fans would have been forgiven for expecting something miserable to immediately follow. And it nearly did, when the Tampa Bay Rays put two men on base in the top of the 14th.

headline: In Libya, Chaos Was Followed by Organized Ambush, Official Says
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The mayhem that killed and wounded more than a dozen American officials was actually two attacks — the first spontaneous and the second organized, a top Libyan security official said.
lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — The mayhem here that killed four United States diplomatic personnel, including the ambassador, was actually two attacks — the first one spontaneous and the second highly organized and possibly aided by anti-American infiltrators of Libya’s young government, a top Libyan security official said Thursday.

headline: As Violence Spreads in Arab World, Google Blocks Access to Inflammatory Video
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Censorship', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Google blocked an anti-Muslim video on YouTube, which it owns, in Egypt and in Libya, but did not take it down altogether.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As violence spread in the Arab world over a video on YouTube ridiculing the Prophet Muhammad, Google, the owner of YouTube, blocked access to it in two of the countries in turmoil, Egypt and Libya, but did not remove the video from its Web site.

abstract: Numbers for Sept. 13, 2012

headline: Prosecutors Seek Hearing in ’95 Killing
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Two people have asked that their convictions in the killing of a Bronx cabdriver be lifted, arguing that two others had confessed.
lead_paragraph: Bronx prosecutors, saying that they cannot yet substantiate claims suggesting that five people were wrongfully convicted in the 1995 murder of a livery-cab driver, are declining to support a request that a court immediately vacate the convictions of two of the defendants.

headline: Freed From the Constraints of Plaids and Stripes
abstract: Reviews of Calvin Klein, Marchesa, Proenza Schouler, Ralph Lauren and Reed Krakoff spring 2013 shows.
lead_paragraph: Far from the madding crowd, far from even Kanye and Kim — now the organically blended Kimye — a small band of design explorers is getting closer to entering a new dimension.

headline: Giants Deal With Loss: Assistant’s Mustache
abstract: Kevin Gilbride, the Giants’ offensive coordinator, inadvertently cut off half his longtime — and legendary — mustache in the days leading up to a preseason game late last month.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Kevin Gilbride’s mustache, a legendary lip adornment that won two Super Bowl championships and was respected as one of the most enduring examples of responsible facial hair in sports, died last month in a shaving accident at the Giants’ practice facility here. It was believed to be about 41.

headline: Israeli Fallout
abstract: For all his talk about American power and sovereignty, Mitt Romney seems willing to let Benjamin Netanyahu decide whether to start a regional war.
lead_paragraph: It should go without saying, but apparently does not, that the tragic crisis unfolding in the Middle East calls for sober statesmanship rather than political posturing. The jihadist murder of the American ambassador to a newly liberated Libya; the carnage unleashed by the Assad regime on the Syrian people; the emergence of a Muslim Brotherhood regime in Egypt; the conundrum of Iranian nuclear ambitions — the region presents decades worth of complex challenges telescoped into real time.

headline: Despite Virus, Visitors Trek to Yosemite, if a Bit Warily
abstract: Though anxious, thousands of people went to the park over the weekend, just days after the authorities announced that a third person had died from hantavirus.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — A stone’s throw from the cluster of tent cabins where three victims of a deadly rodent-borne virus stayed earlier this summer, two tourists from the New York area were meticulously sorting their trash into sealed garbage bins while making sure that a ravenous-looking squirrel did not slip inside.

lead_paragraph: Eric Wilson reports on the shows and the emerging spring trends that had editors and retailers talking at New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Post-9/11 Conundrum
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Detainees', 'Law and Legislation', 'Terrorism', 'Editorials', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A federal judge rightly challenges the government’s authority to detain individuals indefinitely, while Congress renews unneeded spying powers.
lead_paragraph: For 11 years, Americans have struggled to reach a sensible legal balance that protects both national security and civil liberties — an existential challenge made harder by the last president’s wild excesses and abuses of power in the name of combating terrorism. This week, a vote in Congress and a decision by a federal judge, Katherine Forrest, made starkly clear how much that remains a work in progress.

lead_paragraph: Images by and of the photographer, who died on Sept. 13, 2012.

headline: Après Rahm, Le Déluge
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Organized Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Productivity', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The Chicago teachers’ strike is a test of who has a plan that can help the nation as a whole prosper.
lead_paragraph: Modern nations have two economies, which exist side by side. Economy I is the tradable sector. This includes companies that make goods like planes, steel and pharmaceuticals. These companies face intense global competition and are compelled to constantly innovate and streamline. They’ve spent the last few decades figuring out ways to make more products with fewer workers.

headline: Pedro Guerrero, Who Captured Art in Photos, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Guerrero said that in photographing architecture he approached it as if it were sculpture.
lead_paragraph: Pedro E. Guerrero, a former art school dropout who showed up in the dusty Arizona driveway of Frank Lloyd Wright in 1939, boldly declared himself a photographer and then spent the next half-century working closely with him, capturing his modernist architecture on film, died on Thursday at his home in Florence, Ariz. He was 95.

headline: Spots for Healthy Choice Try to Feel Dieters’ Pain
abstract: “Consumers are telling us over and over again that they’re tired of dieting, tired of deprivation, tired of being irritable,” said Jenn Freeman, the brand director for Healthy Choice.
lead_paragraph: A NEW commercial for Healthy Choice opens at a supermarket meat counter, where an elegantly dressed woman takes an inelegant bite of a turkey drumstick, then reaches into another shopper’s cart for a loaf of French bread, which she breaks over a knee and waves menacingly.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Broken Machinery of Death
abstract: The state’s need to abolish capital punishment is obvious with the flawed case of Terrance Williams, a death row inmate.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania is scheduled to execute Terrance Williams on Oct. 3. The state has sentenced more than 400 people to death since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976 and has executed three who gave up on their appeals. But he would be the first person in 50 years to be put to death there while still fighting his sentence.

headline: Belated Response From Egypt
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Is this friendship? President Morsi of Egypt waited until Thursday before condemning the deaths of 4 Americans in Libya and promising to protect embassies in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: The response from President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt to the murder of the American ambassador in Libya and the attacks on the United States Embassy in Cairo should have been swift and unequivocal. Condemn the violence, express condolences for the killings and pledge to strengthen security at foreign missions.

headline: The Fed Makes Its Move
abstract: A bold plan to spur economic recovery will not, as in past efforts, be confined by preset limits and expiration dates.
lead_paragraph: If the economy falters from here on out, it will be difficult to blame the Federal Reserve. Ben Bernanke, the Fed chairman, and all but one of the other members of the Fed policy committee, took decisive steps on Thursday to spur the economy, pledging to buy $85 billion worth of assets each month until the end of the year and to continue pumping money into the economy until the job market improves “substantially.”

headline: Unclear Future for Airport That Is Seeking a Buyer
abstract: The zoning of the 37-acre Montauk Airport property would permit housing, and the $18 million asking price seems too steep for a pilots’ group to meet.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — The easternmost airport in New York State has things that La Guardia and Kennedy International do not. A beach just beyond the runway, where pilots can work on their tans and swim in the ocean. An outdoor shower, where they can rinse off before they climb back in their cockpits. And a for-sale sign.

headline: Howard Moody, Who Led a Historic Church, Dies at 91
abstract: Rev. Moody was a church leader who hurled himself and his Greenwich Village congregation into roiling social issues.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Howard R. Moody the longtime minister of the historic Judson Memorial Church, who hurled himself and his Greenwich Village congregation into roiling social issues, at one point helping women from around the nation get illegal abortions, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Washington to Get Bronze Representative in Capitol
abstract: The District of Columbia will get another delegate, of sorts, in Congress: a statue of the abolitionist Frederick Douglass.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Perhaps nowhere in America do the people of the District of Columbia feel less respected than in the District of Columbia. Their lone delegate to the House must sit, seething, as Congress approves the District’s annual budget, absent the vote of that delegate, who is prohibited from voting in the House.

keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Elections']

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Department of Justice has approved Florida’s early voting schedule for the five counties in the state protected by a civil rights-era law, all but clearing the last significant conflict in the path of November balloting.

headline: Egypt, Hearing From Obama, Moves to Heal Rift From Protests
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A blunt phone call from President Obama prompted Egyptian leaders to scramble Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Following a blunt phone call from President Obama, Egyptian leaders scrambled Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington, tacitly acknowledging that they erred in their response to the attack on the United States Embassy by seeking to first appease anti-American domestic opinion without offering a robust condemnation of the violence.

headline: House Republicans Welcome Back Ryan, and His Vote, on a Spending Measure
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan detoured from the campaign trail to vote on a measure that will avoid a government default and an election-season battle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, returned to the House on Thursday for a hero’s welcome from adoring Republicans, jeers from opposition Democrats and a mission that was as painful as it was politically necessary: to give his blessing to legislation financing the government into next year at a level higher than the one set in his own budget.

headline: Internal Affairs to Investigate Officer’s Stabbing
abstract: With details scarce, the investigation seems to cast doubt on the officer’s account of being attacked at home by an intruder.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has opened an internal affairs investigation into a police officer who reported that he had been stabbed by an intruder on Wednesday, Paul J. Browne, the department’s chief spokesman said. The move seemed to cast doubt on the officer’s story.

lead_paragraph: The day in sports included an international bodyboarding competition in Rio de Janeiro.

lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Three days before what is shaping up as a tough test for the Jets’ defense, cornerback Darrelle Revis got to do calisthenics Thursday with the team. But he was not wearing his shoulder pads and did not have his helmet with him.

lead_paragraph: GOLDEN, Colo. — President Obama and Mitt Romney entered new political terrain on Thursday as their campaign debate moved more solidly onto issues of foreign policy, a subject that had largely been absent as a major general election issue until this week.

keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Search and Seizure', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']

lead_paragraph: When the police cleared Occupy Wall Street protesters from Zuccotti Park last November, the movement lost not only its central gathering spot, but also one of its more popular institutions: a collection of 3,600 donated books known as the People’s Library.

headline: McGrady Works Out With Knicks
abstract: Tracy McGrady, a 33-year-old former All-Star, could be the team’s latest veteran addition of the off-season.
lead_paragraph: Since the start of the off-season, the Knicks have been recruiting veteran free agents, some of them fairly old by N.B.A. standards. The latest to get a look is 33-year-old Tracy McGrady, a seven-time All-Star who is not as old as some of the other players the Knicks have signed but who has had significant injuries during his career.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday rejected an appeal by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to spell out a specific “red line” that Iran could not cross in its nuclear program, a senior administration official said, deepening the divide between the allies over how to deal with Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

Instead, it stands as a testament to greed and corruption at a factory where 289 trapped employees died.

lead_paragraph: MOUNT AIRY, N.C. — In his nearly 50 years as an avid motorcyclist, Grady Howard has roared down the tobacco roads of North Carolina and through the mountains of old Kentucky, all with his wife, Barbara, tucked behind him. But with a balky left leg and myriad other maladies, he knew the only way to stay wild was to add a wheel.

headline: Higuaín Finds Comfort in Columbus
abstract: Federico Higuaín, the brother of the Real Madrid star, Gonzalo, has made an immediate impact since joining the Columbus Crew of M.L.S. six games ago.
lead_paragraph: The Columbus Crew locker room had already emptied when Federico Higuaín emerged from his ice bath, still visibly irritated with his team’s performance in its 2-0 loss to the New England Revolution. After all, it was the first loss Higuaín had experienced in the Argentine’s six games with his new club, ending a streak of four consecutive wins. When the conversation shifted from the match to his first impressions of the ambiance in Major League Soccer, Higuaín smiled and said “of course” there were differences between M.L.S. and Argentina’s Primera División.

headline: Brain Implant Improves Thinking in Monkeys, First Such Demonstration in Primates
abstract: The device gives researchers a model for how to support and enhance fairly advanced mental skills in the frontal cortex of brain, the seat of thinking and planning.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have designed a brain implant that sharpened decision making and restored lost mental capacity in monkeys, providing the first demonstration in primates of the sort of brain prosthesis that could eventually help people with damage from dementia, strokes or other brain injuries.

headline: Missouri: Documents Turned Over in Priest’s Abuse Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Priests', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Survivors Network had argued that the documents, mostly e-mails, should remain confidential because they contained information about victims.
lead_paragraph: After losing its appeals, the Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests has turned over about 180 documents that were subpoenaed by lawyers for a Roman Catholic priest accused of sexual abuse. The Survivors Network had argued that the documents, mostly e-mails, should remain confidential because they contained information about victims. The organization, the nation’s largest advocacy group for victims of clergy sexual abuse, was supported by rape crisis centers, news media outlets and several former prosecutors, but the Missouri Supreme Court upheld a judge’s order to comply. The Survivors Network said it had not yet released all of the subpoenaed documents and was considering its options. Among the documents it withheld were those pertaining to the Rev. Shawn Ratigan, a Kansas City priest who pleaded guilty last month to child pornography charges and is still the target of civil lawsuits. The documents are under a protective order and supposed to be viewed only by the lawyers.

headline: A Little R&R for a Hit Man
abstract: In “Snowman’s Land,” Jürgen Rissmann plays a two-bit hit man who, in need of a break, takes what seems like an easy job, protecting a twisted mobster’s wife in a mountain getaway.
lead_paragraph: With his ill-fitting puffy coat and curtain of greasy hair, Walter (Jürgen Rissmann), a two-bit German hit man, seems as burned out as any wage slave in a depressed economy. So when a botched assignment in a public restroom necessitates some off-the-grid R&R, he accepts his temporary banishment with customary resignation.

headline: Second Thoughts on Marriage
abstract: In “The Trouble With the Truth,” John Shea and Lea Thompson are a divorced couple, meeting when their daughter becomes engaged and looking back at their romance.
lead_paragraph: Following Meryl Streep and Tommy Lee Jones in “Hope Springs” in the autumnal romance department — but a tad younger, and with smidgens of “My Dinner With André” and “Before Sunrise” — are John Shea and Lea Thompson in “The Trouble With the Truth,” written and directed by Jim Hemphill. The ambition is laudable, the results less so.

abstract: In “The Stand Up,” Jonathan Sollis is a stand-up comic who is in a deep funk over the death of his girlfriend. So his father finds him a job as a kindergarten teacher.
lead_paragraph: Commend David Wexler for not going where you expect in “The Stand Up,” an oaf-in-kiddieland story, or at least not lingering there when he does. It’s too bad that he didn’t bring a little more creativity to the predictable tale he does fashion, though.

headline: Rising Tension — and Stakes — in Japan-China Island Dispute
abstract: After Japan’s purchase this week of three disputed islands from a Japanese family, attacks in China on Japan and Japanese and a disruption in private relations. And things are likely to get worse.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It has all the ingredients of a future tragedy, peppered with grim farce. A collapsing Japanese ambassador. A noodle soup attack. A nuclear war threat. Music concerts canceled along with tens of thousands of private vacations and major friendship celebrations. An 81-year-old national trauma revived. And underneath all that, the shopping continues. Welcome to Chinese-Japanese relations in 2012.

headline: History in the Making
abstract: The Associated Press’s “Today in History” videos should resonate with boomers. On Sept. 14, contraception and Princess Grace.
lead_paragraph: By the time you reach your 50s and 60s, you’ve lived through a good deal of history, although a lot of the time, as it was happening, you may not have realized it would turn into history. For many of my generation, that first memory is of Nov. 22, 1963, when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. But during the recent memorial tributes to the astronaut Neil Armstrong, I was reminded of an earlier moment. When I was in third grade, in 1961, several classes at our school were led into the one room that had a TV, to watch America’s first manned spaceflight. Alan Shepard’s entire trip lasted 15 minutes — we watched the whole thing, broadcast live, in black and white. I remember the clapping when we knew he was safe and in particular how excited our usually reserved teachers were. I’d forgotten this until I saw the old news clip.

headline: What’s Your Favorite ’60s or ’70s Song?
abstract: Wanted: Your opinions on the more serious matters, along with some questions of absolutely no consequence.
lead_paragraph: Each Friday we’re going to ask you to give us your opinion about something or other that has to do with the boomer era. This is definitely not a test. Nor a scientific poll. In some cases it will be a more serious matter, like, “What has been the biggest societal change in your lifetime?” Other questions will be of absolutely no consequence, like, “Name the worst clothing fad not including bell bottoms.”

headline: The Fragility of Our Superheroes
abstract: A daughter recalls, at age 12, her baby boomer father moving out and suddenly having “two home phone numbers — that’s 14 digits.”
lead_paragraph: I will miss my family, but especially my dad.

headline: Looking Back on the Party Conventions
abstract: In his sixth and seventh installments of the continuing series “Smoke-Filled Rooms,” the Times staff photographer Stephen Crowley examines the recent presidential nominating conventions.
lead_paragraph: The summer presidential nominating conventions in Tampa, Fla., and Charlotte, N.C., came and went — promises were made, stances were taken, confetti and balloons tumbled from the ceiling. The Republican spectacle was beset by bad weather, and the Democrats made every effort to demonstrate confidence. But the prevailing opinion of the pundits was that the conventions hardly mattered. Did they? Only 53 days remain until voting, and polls continue to show a neck-and-neck race, suggesting an electorate unmoved by all the fanfare.

headline: Anti-American Protests Flare Beyond the Mideast
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Anti-American rage that began over a video insult to Islam spread to nearly 20 countries in the Middle East and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Anti-American rage that began this week over a video insult to Islam spread to nearly 20 countries across the Middle East and beyond on Friday, with violent and sometimes deadly protests that convulsed the birthplaces of the Arab Spring revolutions, breached two more United States Embassies and targeted diplomatic properties of Germany and Britain.

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?

headline: France and Germany at Odds Over Aiding Spain’s Economy
abstract: Ministers indicated at the start of a two-day meeting that recent decisions had provided breathing room to find longer-term solutions to the debt crisis.

headline: Questions for Paul Elie, Author of ‘Reinventing Bach’
abstract: We hear more thoughts from last Sunday’s Riffs writer Paul Elie, concerning Bach, technology and the digital era.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Riff, “30 Variations and a Microphone,” Paul Elie traces the fascinating relationship between the famously performance-averse pianist Glenn Gould, his landmark 1956 recording of Bach’s “Goldberg” variations, and the rise of new recording technologies made it all possible. The essay was adapted from Elie’s forthcoming book, “Reinventing Bach,” which interweaves the stories of famous Bach interpreters — Gould, Pablo Casals, Albert Schweitzer and Yo-Yo Ma — as they grappled both with the legacy of Bach and the promise of new technologies. Elie is currently a fellow at Georgetown University, where he works on exploring the relationship of religion to the arts and literature. We spoke to him about his book.
