lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Pope Benedict XVI traveled to Lebanon on Friday with a message of tolerance that took on wider resonance as protests over an anti-Muslim video produced in the United States spread to about 20 countries.

headline: An Argument Over Wind
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Wind Power']
abstract: A new study suggests that distortions in the wholesale electricity market are getting bigger as more wind power is added. But wind proponents say that consumers are benefiting from lower prices.
lead_paragraph: With the wind industry facing the expiration of a production tax credit at the end of the year, the sector’s main trade association is facing off against Exelon, the big power generation company, over whether the tax break should be renewed. Last week, the American Wind Energy Association expelled Exelon as a member because the company opposed a renewal of the credit.

headline: Poetry’s Cross-Dressing Kingmaker
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Stephen Burt makes a passionate, quirky case for why we need poetry.
lead_paragraph: When I asked Stephen Burt’s parents if they worried about him when he was young, Burt’s father, Jeff, replied by asking me if I was Jewish. I told him I was. “Well,” he said, “to ask Jewish parents if they were worried about their children — it is a statement of fact! But were we more worried about Stephen than about the other children? The answer is yes.” As a boy, Stephen, the eldest of their four sons, was, in his dad’s words, “extremely precocious”; his parents’ reminiscences make him sound lovable but very intense, with interests out of step with other boys his age. His mother, Sandra, told me that in third grade he wrote an essay about “a little boy whose mother forced him to go out and play.”

headline: The Machines Are Taking Over
abstract: Advances in computerized tutoring are testing the faith that human contact makes for better learning.
lead_paragraph: Neil Heffernan was listening to his fiancée, Cristina Lindquist, tutor one of her students in mathematics when he had an idea. Heffernan was a graduate student in computer science, and by this point — the summer of 1997 — he had been working for two years with researchers at Carnegie Mellon University on developing computer software to help students improve their skills. But he had come to believe that the programs did little to assist their users. They were built on elaborate theories of the student mind — attempts to simulate the learning brain. Then it dawned on him: what was missing from the programs was the interventions teachers made to promote and accelerate learning. Why not model a computer program on a human tutor like Lindquist?

headline: How Many Times Can You Tweet the Same Tweet?
abstract: How do you strike a balance between making sure you reach all of your followers and making sure you don’t annoy all of your followers?
lead_paragraph: I’m a heavy Twitter user. I love how fast it moves. If you are looking for instant feedback on anything, Twitter is the place to test your content or messaging. It’s also the place to get answers to your questions. And it’s the best listening device on the Internet. You can search for keywords, customers, competition, and industry thought leaders and find out what everyone is thinking. And no one even knows you are listening.

headline: Poll: Obama Holds Narrow Edge Over Romney
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS news poll found that the presidential candidates remained essentially tied among likely voters.
lead_paragraph: President Obama holds a narrow three-point advantage over Mitt Romney among Americans most likely to vote in November, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Daily Report: Google Blocks Access to Inflammatory Video
abstract: Google’s decision to block access to a controversial video raises fundamental questions about the control that Internet companies have over online expression. Should the companies themselves decide what standards govern what is seen on the Internet? How consistently should these policies be applied?
lead_paragraph: As violence spread in the Arab world over a video on YouTube ridiculing the Prophet Muhammad, Google, the owner of YouTube, blocked access to it in two of the countries in turmoil, Egypt and Libya, but did not remove the video from its Web site, reports Claire Cain Miller on Friday in The New York Times.

headline: Q&A: Undoing AutoFormats in Microsoft Word
abstract: If you find Microsoft Word’s time-saving text formats are slowing you down, you can turn off the feature.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Sept. 13: After Convention Bounce, Holding Obama’s Polls to a Higher Standard
abstract: The FiveThirtyEight forecast model figures that President Obama’s convention bounce probably causes poll results to exaggerate his standing.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday at 6:30 p.m. Eastern time, there was a deluge of comments in my Twitter feed when NBC News and Marist University released poll results showing President Obama with clear leads in three swing states. Mr. Obama led by five points in their polls of Virginia and Florida, and by seven in their poll of Ohio.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Nostalgia
abstract: Many retro apps try to recreate past technologies pretty closely, but there are of course other apps that take a retro idea and modernize it.
lead_paragraph: This week’s App Smart column took you into the wonderful world of retro apps — apps that give you a bit of a blast from your past by emulating things from yesteryear.

headline: Answers to Your Questions About Student Loans, Part 3
abstract: Answers to questions about consolidating loans, paying late fees, loan forgiveness for public service, and declaring bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: This week, two New York Times reporters and Geoffry Walsh, an expert on student debt and bankruptcy at the National Consumer Law Center, are answering questions about ways to avoid default, pay off student loans or try to expunge student loans through bankruptcy court. Along with questions, some readers proposed their own answers. The first set of answers is here, the second is here, and the third set is below.

headline: Layover Country
abstract: An extraordinary new book collects 25 years of photos taken by two artists in airports around the world.

headline: Royal Couple Sue Over Photos of Topless Duchess
keywords: ['Privacy', 'News and News Media', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Royal Family']
abstract: Britain’s royal household rebuked a French magazine for photographs of the former Kate Middleton topless, evoking the furor around press coverage of Diana.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a dispute evoking the furor that swirled around press coverage of Diana, Princess of Wales, Britain’s royal household began legal proceedings on Friday against a French magazine that published paparazzi photographs of the former Kate Middleton, the wife of Diana’s elder son, Prince William, sunbathing topless at a secluded villa in Provence.

headline: Friday Reading: Would You Take a Pregnancy Test in a Bar?
abstract: Taking a pregnancy test in a bar, new PCs that were shipped pre-infected with a virus, the most confusing cities and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Tricycle-Harley-Tricycle Cycle
abstract: Boomers love their bikes. But then it gets hard to stay on the Harley.
lead_paragraph: Boomers love their bikes. First it was those little red tricycles with the fringe hanging from the handle grips. Then the 18-inchers with the training wheels. Then the banana seats and the baseball cards attached to the back wheel to making a flapping noise. Then the cruisers, with their thick tires, the Raleighs with the hand brakes and the racing bikes with the handlebars bent down.

headline: Chicago Forges Outline to End Teacher Strike
abstract: After a weeklong strike, Chicago teachers and the school board said that they had the outlines of a contract deal. Schools in the nation’s third largest district are expected to reopen on Monday.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Five days into a teachers’ strike that halted classes for 350,000 public school students across this city, leaders on both sides of the contract dispute said on Friday that they had reached the outlines of a deal.

headline: Naming Names on the Court
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A reporter was surprised when his article about two unidentified men fighting over a Central Park tennis court appeared — with the names filled in.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Japan Sets Policy to Phase Out Nuclear Power Plants by 2040
abstract: Japan’s government said it intends to stop using nuclear power by the 2030s, marking a major shift from policy goals set before last year’s Fukushima disaster.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan said Friday that it would seek to phase out nuclear power by 2040 — a historic shift for a country that has long staked its future on such energy, but one that falls far short of the decisive steps the government had promised in the wake of the world’s second-largest nuclear plant disaster last year.

headline: National Archives in New York to Move to Custom House
abstract: The National Archives and Records Administration is to move in late October and will make more of its holdings accessible to the public.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives and Records Administration  is to move its New York facility to a new site in late October: the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House at 1 Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan. The move will provide greater visibility for the institution and make its holdings more accessible to the public, archive officials said.

headline: Energy Takes Center Stage in Political Ads
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'Campaign Finance', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The energy industry is pouring money into election commercials aimed at ousting President Obama. The clean energy sector is running a countercampaign, but with far less money.
lead_paragraph: The energy industry is pouring money into election commercials aimed at ousting President Obama. The clean energy sector is running a countercampaign, but with far less money.

headline: Energy Policy in France Divides Governing Coalition of Socialists and Greens
abstract: Compromises on nuclear power have placed the Green Party’s leadership at odds with its base, and some are wondering if the Greens’ alliance with the Socialist Party can survive.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After just four months in power, the governing coalition of the Socialist Party and the Greens is already marred by deep ideological divisions over energy policy, in particular how quickly and sharply France should move to reduce its heavy dependence on nuclear energy.

headline: India Opens Door to Foreign Investment
abstract: A government in crisis passes biggest economic reforms in twenty years.
lead_paragraph: India ushered in the biggest economic reforms in two decades on Friday, allowing big foreign retailers like Walmart, foreign broadcasters and foreign airlines to invest in the country, among other reforms.

headline: Lawmaker Who Defied Putin Is Expelled by Colleagues
abstract: The legislator, Gennadi V. Gudkov, crossed a political line in the sand when he joined crowds calling for the ouster of the Russian president.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s Parliament on Friday took the rare step of expelling one of its members, a four-term lawmaker and former K.G.B. officer who last year crossed a political line in the sand, joining crowds calling for Vladimir V. Putin to give up power.

headline: China, Framed by the Cinema and the Web
keywords: ['Toronto International Film Festival', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Movies']
abstract: The director Chen Kaige looks to contemporary China and a contemporary issue — damaging Web searches — in his new film, “Caught in the Web.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING

headline: Bailed Out by Obama, but Rooting for Romney
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Automobiles', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Even Wentzville, Mo., where a new General Motors plant is under construction, is expected to favor Mitt Romney, who opposed saving the automaker.
lead_paragraph: If there’s anywhere President Obama should expect to get a boost from the success of the government’s rescue of General Motors, it’s Wentzville, Mo., and Lordstown, Ohio.

headline: Healthy Food, Clear Labels
keywords: ['Organic Foods and Products', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Genetic Engineering']
abstract: Business Day Live: Food companies, even those that make healthy products, fight consumers in California over a ballot initiative to label products with genetically modified ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Business Day Live: Food companies, even those that make healthy products, fight consumers in California over a ballot initiative to label products with genetically modified ingredients.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Details: “It’s like a sad bachelor’s life threw up on itself.” Keith Wagstaff takes a look at Guy Fieri’s globe-scouring new Times Square menu. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Topless Royal Photos Expose Public’s Bottomless Fascination
abstract: Sneaked shots of Britain’s Duchess of Cambridge sunbathing have prompted fresh outrage about the royals’ privacy and fed the inexhaustible interest they generate at home and abroad. Do they deserve the celebrity treatment — and do we care?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European media were all aflutter on Friday as a French magazine published topless photos of Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, wife of Britain’s Prince William and the future Queen of England.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: USA Tomorrow? And an Anti-Muslim Video Vexes YouTube
abstract: USA Today hits newsstands with a redesigned look, and YouTube’s decision to block an anti-Muslim video in Libya and Egypt highlights the role of its parent, Google.
lead_paragraph: A redesigned USA Today was on newsstands on Friday, and the redesign owes a big debt to the aesthetics and customs of the Internet, Christine Haughney reports. The USA Today Web site, which will be unveiled this weekend, has been redesigned to resemble an e-reader, with a smoother scroll from page to page. The twist, however, is that the abundance of information on the Internet has largely taken away what made the national newspaper special 30 years ago. The moves are part of a broader rethinking by USA Today’s parent company, Gannett, to consolidate the news gathering of its TV and newspaper assets.

headline: Room With A View
abstract: Starting this month, visitors will be able to tour Winslow Homer’s studio, a hunter green clapboard cottage overlooking the coastline in Maine.

headline: Need Ryan Gosling’s Bacon Number? Ask Google
abstract: Google has a new way to search for how many people stand between a famous person and Kevin Bacon. But it’s more than a game. Google says it demonstrates the potential of its Knowledge Graph, which it says is the next step in search, showing how people, places and things are related.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of how committed Google is to helping people answer their most pressing and urgent questions, the search engine has unveiled a way to find famous people’s Bacon number.

headline: Shock Me if You Can
abstract: A hundred years after “Rite of Spring” sparked an uproar in Paris, shock has grown mainstream, raising a question: Can art still shock today?
lead_paragraph: THE morning of “The Rite of Spring” premiere, on May 29, 1913, at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in Paris, Le Figaro predicted that ballet would deliver “a new thrill which will surely raise passionate discussion” and “leave all true artists with an unforgettable impression.” That turned out to be one of the greatest understatements of the new artistic century. The passionate discussion began during the first few bars of the music, as derisive laughter rose from the seats, and soon grew into an uproar that sent Stravinsky fleeing the hall in disgust.

headline: Shocker Cools Into a ‘Rite’ of Passage
abstract: “The Rite of Spring,” Igor Stravinsky’s ballet that celebrates human sacrifice, is widely praised today but was a flop when it was first produced, in Paris in 1913.
lead_paragraph: “THE RITE OF SPRING,” or “Le Sacre du Printemps,” Igor Stravinsky’s historic shocker, a ballet that shows and celebrates a remorseless human sacrifice, will be 100 years old next May. The bandwagon of centennial commemorations is getting an early start on Thursday with the  New York Philharmonic. But in stark contrast to its present-day lionization, it was a spectacular flop at its first showing, by Sergei Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes, at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in Paris.

headline: It Was Just Cutler’s Luck
abstract: After Jay Cutler wished Packers defensive backs good luck trying to stop him, Green Bay intercepted him four times.
lead_paragraph: There are more than a few things that make almost no sense in sports. Normally, we’d get right to the most outrageous one, but we need to build up to the proper level of incredulous eye roll for the N.H.L.'s impending lockout. So we’ll start with something simpler, a forehead slapper with universal appeal: that Chicago quarterback Jay Cutler was actually trash-talking in the leadup to Thursday night’s game against the Packers.

headline: From Ancient Deforestation, a Delta Is Born
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Lakes', 'Land Use Policies', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Rivers']
abstract: Humans may have inadvertently engineered the Danube Delta and Black Sea ecosystems a millennium ago.
lead_paragraph: Humans were tampering with nature long before the Industrial Revolution’s steam and internal combustion engines arrived on the scene. The invention of agriculture around 8,000 years ago, some argue, significantly changed ecosystems as it spread around the globe.

headline: On the House
abstract: The after-party.
lead_paragraph: I recently had a party and afterward had quite a few large bottles of leftover wine (they were opened and wouldn’t keep). There is a particular corner in my neighborhood where benign “drunkards” hang out and drink. They have done so for years, and everyone accepts this as part of our neighborhood. My question is, Should I drop this mother lode of wine off on their perch for them (because who am I to judge their choices?), or pour it down the drain (which would be a “waste”)? DEAN D., LOS ANGELES

headline: Who Made That Marshmallow?
abstract: The hard-labor makings of the fluffy treat.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, confectioners made marshmallows from a froth of sugar, starch and gelatin, in a laborious process that involved lots of primping. Each candy had to “sweat” for several hours to form its delicate skin, and then it was sprinkled with starch. In the 1950s, Alex Doumak — an executive at the Doumak candy company — dreamed up an efficient solution to the problem of the slow marshmallow: he treated the candy goo as an industrial material. Machines forced the marshmallow slurry through tubes, subjected it to blasts of gas at 200 pounds per square inch, extruded it into long tails and then cut it into bite-size chunks. Doumak filled the candy with air, like a tire, trapping nothingness in an architecture of sugar. “Extrusion allowed for the marshmallow we’re used to today — with that springy, fluffy texture,” Sue Watson, manager of the company archives at Kraft Foods, says. Kraft began extruding its own marshmallows in the late 1950s, but its most creative touch might have been the space-age name it gave to the factory process — jet-puffed — as if the marshmallows had exploded out of a rocket-ship engine. As part of a 1959 promotion, children sent in empty Kraft marshmallow bags for a chance to own a 29-foot spaceship equipped with astronaut suits, countdown lights and an “astro projector for space observation.” The modern marshmallow may be mostly air, but it’s a sweet lesson in less is more.

headline: Melissa Leo Is a Fighter
abstract: The Oscar-winning actress on self-promotion, imaginary boyfriends and the right way to lose a job.
lead_paragraph: Your new film, “Francine,” is about a woman, fresh out of jail, who seems destined to become one of those people on “Hoarders,” with a home piled with animal carcasses and feces. What is your own biggest eccentricity?  What you see is what you get.

headline: The 9.2.12 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WHO WEARS THE PANTS IN THIS ECONOMY?

headline: I’m With Stupid
abstract: The pleasures of learning to tap-dance (badly) in middle age.
lead_paragraph: There they were, my mother and my father, smiling up at me from the third row at my first-ever tap-dance recital. My husband, my teenage daughters and my daughter’s friend were also in the audience, but it was my parents I was most aware of as I sashayed through my shuffle-ball-changes and cramp rolls. Especially my father, who sat there beaming as if I’d just won a Tony Award.

headline: Feeling Blue
abstract: A young woman turns a strange hue.
lead_paragraph: The 17-year-old girl was eating lunch in her high-school cafeteriain the Netherlands when one of her friends gave her a funny look.“Your face is turning blue,” the friend told her. The others at the table stared. They saw it, too. The young woman hurried to the bathroom, where she saw a faint bluish tinge across her cheeks.

headline: Not So Hot for Teacher
abstract: How did fictional educators go from ‘To Sir, With Love’ to ‘Breaking Bad’?
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address in 2011, President Obama made a point of applauding the nation’s teachers and exhorted Americans to do the same. “In South Korea,” Obama reminded us, “teachers are known as ‘nation builders.’ . . . It’s time we treated the people who educate our children with the same level of respect.”

headline: She Makes Sure Actors Step Up to the Plate
abstract: As the baseball coordinator for the film “Trouble With the Curve,” the former college athlete Aimee McDaniel ensures that the sports scenes are realistic and accurate.
lead_paragraph: THE first-time director Robert Lorenz anticipated several challenges with the baseball sequences in “Trouble With the Curve,” about an aging scout, his daughter and his rivals. Quite a few roles required actors skilled at the game; one character is even described in the movie as a combination of Randy Johnson, Sandy Koufax and Steve Carlton, three of the greatest left-handed pitchers in the sport’s history.

headline: Bookshelf: Woof
abstract: Picture books starring dogs.
lead_paragraph: Picture books starring dogs.

headline: Great Drama, but the Star’s a Bit Stiff
abstract: In this Animal Planet special, the carcass of a hippopotamus provides dining challenges and rewards to other animals in Zambia.
lead_paragraph: Animal Planet, whose schedule of shows includes fluff like “Call of the Wildman” and scare fare like “Man-Eating Super Croc,” isn’t anyone’s first choice for serious nature programs. On Sunday, though, it proves that it can still work that territory with an odd, fascinating special that stars a dead hippopotamus.

headline: Bookshelf: Woof

lead_paragraph: BAILEY AT THE MUSEUM  Written and illustrated by Harry Bliss.  32 pp. Scholastic Press. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)
