keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The authorities in much of the Muslim world braced for demonstrations after Friday Prayer — an occasion often associated with public displays of dissent.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in much of the Muslim world braced for demonstrations after Friday Prayer — an occasion often associated with public displays of dissent.

headline: The Third Musketeer
abstract: Before père and fils, there was the first Alexandre Dumas, a mixed-race general of the French Revolution.
lead_paragraph: In the 1790s, the son of an aristocratic white father and a black slave woman became a charismatic French general who for a time rivaled Napoleon himself, and afterward languished in an Italian dungeon. His story inspired the novel “The Count of Monte Cristo,” written by his son, Alexandre Dumas, who also drew upon his father’s adventures in “The Three Musketeers.” Posterity remembers this son as Dumas père, to distinguish him from Alexandre Dumas fils, also a writer, whose novel “La Dame aux Camélias” was the source for Verdi’s “La Traviata.” But the general was the first of the three Alexandres (he preferred to be known as Alex), and in “The Black Count,” Tom ­Reiss, the author of “The Orientalist,” has recovered this fascinating story with a richly imaginative biography.

headline: The Poisoned Earth
abstract: A new biography of Rachel Carson, who warned against the indiscriminate use of pesticides.
lead_paragraph: On the bookshelves of many a contemporary environmental journalist looms at least one canonical text she’s hesitant to read. For this reviewer, it was Rachel Carson’s “Silent Spring,” among the gloomiest books ever written, an unrelenting catalog of crimes committed by man against nature. But after reading William Souder’s engrossing new biography of Carson, “On a Farther Shore,” I returned to the book and discovered its central message to be — depressingly — timeless. Substitute organic pesticides and herbicides with the endocrine-­disrupting compounds found in everyday household items or the creep of chemicals used in hydrof­racking, and you may experience the same hair-prickling alarm felt by Carson’s readers 50 years ago.

headline: Vile Bodies
abstract: Grave robbers and serial killers populate this novel set in 19th-century England.
lead_paragraph: “The Thing About Thugs” is an odd confection of a novel, set mostly in what looks like late-Victorian London. The streets are gaslit. The underworld teems with the flotsam of empire: lascars, Irishmen and so on, the undesirables of many nations. The city is overwhelmed with crime and prostitution and an influx of immigrants. Opium dens abound. And a serial killer is on the loose. Known as the “head cannibal,” he decapitates his victims after murdering them, but the heads are never found. The Metropolitan Police are baffled, as they were by Jack the Ripper, active in 1888, who also desecrated the bodies of his victims. Meanwhile, characters with names like One-Eyed Jack make shady deals in low taverns, and at the dinner tables of the upper classes Darwinian ideas are hotly debated. It feels as if we’re in the disillusioned twilight of the 19th century, but our narrator — or one of our narrators — sitting in his grandfather’s library “surrounded by Dickens and Collins,” claims that his story is set in 1837, the year Victoria ascended to the throne.

headline: California Gothic
abstract: In Tatjana Soli’s second novel, a cancer patient is cared for by an enigmatic Caribbean woman.
lead_paragraph: In her ambitious and much admired 2010 novel “The Lotus Eaters” (which won the James Tait Black Prize, one of the most prestigious in Britain), Tatjana Soli explored the experiences of a female war photographer who spent nearly a dozen years in Vietnam, and connected her themes and subject matter not only to Alfred Tennyson but to the “Odyssey.” In her second novel, “The Forgetting Tree,” she is no less daring, and no less haunting. Soli refuses to do the easy thing — she demands of the reader both patience and trust.

headline: The Peeping Savant
abstract: In Linwood Barclay’s “Trust Your Eyes,” a schizophrenic savant who witnesses a murder suffers from a credibility problem.
lead_paragraph: Some days, all you really want is for someone to tell you a ­wicked-good story. Linwood Barclay answers the reader’s perpetual prayer with TRUST YOUR EYES (New American Library, $25.95), an offbeat thriller about a schizophrenic savant who witnesses a murder but is so clearly nuts that no one will take him seriously. In a neat twist on Hitchcock’s “Rear Window,” Thomas Kilbride, who has been crazy about maps since he was 6 years old, is obsessively poring over Whirl360, a computer program rather like Google Street View, when he fixates on the image of someone being suffocated while standing at a window in an apartment building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. But because he believes the C.I.A. has assigned him the job of committing to photographic memory all the streets in all the major cities of the world, Thomas has a bit of a credibility problem.

headline: Benjy’s Red-Letter Days
abstract: Acting on a suggestion Faulkner once made, the Folio Society is publishing “The Sound and the Fury” with 14 colors of ink.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you add colored ink to the previous black-and-white type of a William Faulkner classic? Could the technology somehow compromise the reader’s experience, or do multiple inks actually make for a greater novel? Is this what Faulkner had in mind — and does it matter?

headline: A New Effort to Stimulate the Economy
abstract: Business Day Live — Fed opens new chapter in effort to stimulate the economy. | James B. Stewart on towns that benefited from auto bailout, but are voting for the man who opposed them — Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Business Day Live — Fed opens new chapter in effort to stimulate the economy. | James B. Stewart on towns that benefited from auto bailout, but are voting for the man who opposed them — Mitt Romney.

headline: A Long Lens on Afghanistan’s Wars
abstract: Robert Nickelsberg has been making images of Afghanistan’s various conflicts since 1988, and in a new project he puts the fighting into historical context.
lead_paragraph: We tend to think of the phrase “war in Afghanistan” mostly in present-day terms. But for Robert Nickelsberg, one of the region’s longest-serving photojournalists, the current war is only the latest of four distinct periods of violence he’s seen and documented in the country since 1988. On the Lens blog, Richard A. Oppel Jr. — who has been with Mr. Nickelsberg in Afghanistan quite a few times — writes about the photographer’s new book-length project, “A Distant War,” that outlines those four ages of war. Mr. Oppel writes:

headline: Business Day Live: Bailout’s Success Is No Guarantee of Votes
abstract: Federal Reserve opens new chapter in efforts to stimulate the economy. | Benefiting from the auto bailout, but voting for Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve opens new chapter in efforts to stimulate the economy. | Benefiting from the auto bailout, but voting for Mitt Romney.

headline: Testing Horror’s Threshold for Pain
abstract: The demands placed on actresses in horror movies reaches a new extreme in “The Bunny Game.”
lead_paragraph: ACTRESSES are asked to do some arduous things in horror films, like running through the woods topless or shrieking until there’s no shriek left.

headline: For Young Athletes, Good Reasons to Break the Fast-Food Habit
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Calories', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Medicine and Health', 'Parenting', 'Snack Foods', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: When I ran high school cross-country 14 years ago, the bus that took us to meets always stopped at a Wendy’s or McDonald’s after the event. Things haven’t changed much, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: When I ran high school cross-country 14 years ago, the bus that took us to meets always stopped at a Wendy’s or McDonald’s after the event. Most of the team would order some variation of burgers, fries and a big soda. It was fast, easy and satisfying.

headline: Upstairs, Downstairs
abstract: Naomi Wolf says new science about the connection between sex and the brain can lead to improvement in women’s lives.
lead_paragraph: Sit back and relax, will you? Naomi Wolf has got her orgasm back. Yep. I know you were worried. We were all worried. I mean, to lose one’s orgasm at a time like this, what with Syria undergoing mass civilian murder and Romney closing in on Obama, it is really enough to put a liberated gal’s thong in a knot.

headline: New York Stock Exchange Settles Case Over Early Data Access
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange agreed to adopt new internal controls and pay a $5 million penalty to settle accusations that its trading data gave select clients a split-second advantage.
lead_paragraph: In the latest federal action against a major exchange, the New York Stock Exchange settled accusations on Friday that its trading data gave select clients a split-second advantage over retail investors.

headline: Banana Republican
abstract: Rich Cohen describes the rise of Samuel Zemurray, the fruit peddler who came to control much of Central America.
lead_paragraph: Amid the vast outpouring of literature about America’s banana empire in the Caribbean, no one seems to have written a full-fledged biography of the remarkable Samuel Zemurray, who guided the United Fruit Company through perilous times. Rich Cohen has rectified that oversight. Cohen, the author of “Tough Jews: Fathers, Sons, and Gangster Dreams” and “Sweet and Low: A Family Story,” now gives us the fascinating tale of “Sam the Banana Man,” a poor Russian Jew who emigrated to Alabama as a teenager and ended up controlling much of Central America.

headline: Unnatural Women
abstract: Breast milk is full of chemicals; breasts are full of silicone.
lead_paragraph: The breast milk of the writer Florence Williams contains a striking level of perchlorate, a key component of rocket fuel. This does not, however, invest her with superpowers, as it might if she were a comic-book hero, or even make her special. Rather, as she explains in “Breasts: A Natural and Unnatural History,” her mammary glands are no different from those of most American women. In the year 2012, breast-feeding still passes many good things from mother to baby: vitamins, minerals and “a solid hedge of extras to help ward off a lifetime of diseases.” But the practice also typically transfers “paint thinners, dry-cleaning fluids, wood preservatives, toilet deodorizers, cosmetic additives, gasoline by-products, rocket fuel, termite poisons, fungicides” and varieties of flame retardants, one of which, Penta-BDE, was banned by the European Union because of its chronic toxicity to humans.

headline: Truth in Masquerade
abstract: In Clare Clark’s novel, the wife of a radical politician leads a double life in Victorian London.
lead_paragraph: Clare Clark’s fiction manages to maintain historical accuracy even as it indulges in great storytelling and lush prose. In her first novel, “The Great Stink,” a thriller that takes place in the sewers of Victorian London, Clark wrote with such rich detail that you could almost smell the fetid air as you turned the pages. In “Savage Lands,” she transported readers to the young colony of Louisiana in the early 1700s, setting a complex love story against a fecund yet relentlessly cruel landscape that became as important to the plot as the characters themselves.

headline: Riding Future and Freudian Frontiers
abstract: Robert Mitchum and Teresa Wright play adopted siblings in Raoul Walsh’s western “Pursued” (1947); Romy Schneider stars in Bertrand Tavernier’s “Death Watch” (1980).
lead_paragraph: Pursued

headline: Introducing an Experiment: Weekly Common Core Practice Prompts
abstract: We’re collaborating with two New Jersey teachers and their freshman classes to bring you three quick, engaging tasks each week that match the demands of the Common Core Standards with the content of that week’s New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Last year we took some baby steps in thinking about how the new Common Core State Standards will affect the work we do on this blog.

headline: Unplugged
abstract: In a pair of picture books, imagination triumphs over boredom and electronic gadgets.
lead_paragraph: Our brave new quickly expanding technological world has in it less human contact than ever before and less connection with — hence, less caring for — the natural world. Two new picture books explore this (oh, let’s call it a) situation. Both contain an important message for young readers, but neither is burdened by it, as so many “message-y” books have been.

headline: Night and Fog
abstract: Two shivery books for middle schoolers are set in Victorian England.
lead_paragraph: What a literary legacy those Victorians left us! Not only are Charles Dickens, H. G. Wells and Charlotte Brontë still widely read, but they and their compatriots continue to inspire writers today: steampunk aficionados with their marvelous mechanisms; those who go for Gothic shivers; and the many others who set their narratives in 19th-century England. Among them are writers for young people who, in addition to creating great stories, engage an audience with little knowledge or interest in Victoriana. Two who rise to the challenge this fall are the debut author Stefan Bachmann, a teenager who is studying music at the Zurich Conservatory, and the Newbery Award winner (for “Good Masters! Sweet Ladies!”) Laura Amy Schlitz.

headline: On ‘Mortality’
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Christopher Hitchens’s “Mortality.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Victims’ Revolution’
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Bruce Bawer’s “Victims’ Revolution.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Not Unpublishable
abstract: A reader responds to a recent review of Tom Bissell’s “Magic Hours.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New York Top 5 | American Sexy and the New Surf
abstract: These men’s fashion designers and their distinct philosophies won our hearts at New York Fashion Week this season.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Going to School on Rosh Hashana
abstract: His parents never went to school on Rosh Hashana while living under their parents’ roofs. But their son, a man according to Jewish law, is determined to go on the High Holy Days.
lead_paragraph: This year my 15-year old son and I are having yet another conversation about Judaism’s High Holy Days. He’s intent on capitalizing on his hard-won victory last year, the outcome of which was that he went to school on the second day of Rosh Hashana. This was no small concession for his parents. His father and I had never attended school on the High Holy Days while living under our parents’ roofs. But neither of us went to a high school as academically challenging as our son’s.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Kelly Blair on the representation of women in the publishing world.
lead_paragraph: Since this week’s issue assesses an array of feminist ideas and arguments, it made particular sense to commission illustrations from a woman, in this case Kelly Blair, who created the cover image and the three other illustrations that accompany our lead essays (by Toni Bentley and Jennifer Homans).

headline: India Lets in Wal-Mart, With Conditions
abstract: The government opens up India’s retail sector, but asks for sizable investment.
lead_paragraph: The Indian government’s decision Friday to let big department stores like Wal-Mart Stores into the country could dramatically impact everything from the country’s food chain to its roads.

headline: Rescue Dogs
abstract: How pets can help us through the most difficult times.
lead_paragraph: As any reader of middle-grade novels knows, it’s a cruel, viciously uncertain world out there, and all too often the adults in a child’s life are more a source of harm than help. Sometimes a child can trust no one but the loyal dog at his side. Together, they will survive and conquer.

headline: Updates on Protests Over Anti-Islam Film
abstract: The Lede is following protests across the Muslim world on Friday in response to a film posted on YouTube by Christian extremists in California that mocks Islam’s prophet.
lead_paragraph: The Lede is following protests across the Muslim world on Friday in response to a film posted on YouTube that mocks Islam’s prophet.

headline: On Our Radar: Temperature Record Is Cast Out
abstract: Scientists conclude that a record high temperature measured in Libya in 1922 was inaccurate.
lead_paragraph: A team of meteorologists casts serious doubt on a world temperature record of 136.4 degrees recorded on Sept. 13, 1922 in El Azizia, Libya. They cite the antiquated instrument used, the likelihood that the observer was inexperienced and the wide disparity with subsequent temperatures recorded at the site. That means that officially, the “new” record surface temperature is 134 degrees, recorded on July 10, 1913 at Greenland Ranch in Death Valley, Calif. [Arizona State University]

headline: Date Set for Unleashing of ‘Godzilla’
abstract: Circle May 16, 2014, on your calendar if you’re a fan.
lead_paragraph: Godzilla last lumbered into American movie theaters in 1998 and gobbled up a respectable pile of money – $136 million in domestic ticket sales – while swatting away swarms of nasty reviews with his big scaly C.G.I. paws.

headline: Image of the Day: September 14
abstract: Locals burnt American flags to protest the film “Innocence of Muslims,” in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Lamborghini Recalls 1,500 Gallardos for Fire Hazard
abstract: The affected supercars, Coupe and Spyder models, are from the 2004-6 model years.
lead_paragraph: Lamborghini is recalling almost 1,500 of its 2004-6 Gallardo Coupe and Spyder models. In a report (PDF) posted recently on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Lamborghini outlined a kind of thermochemical conga line of misfortune that could potentially lead to a fire.

headline: In Lima, Literary Slams and Music
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The writer Daniel Alarcón shares some favorite spots from his native city, including a place where writers “wrestle.”
lead_paragraph: “IT’S a city with terrible traffic, alarming crime rates and a sky that’s gray for eight months a year,” said Daniel Alarcón, the 35-year-old author of the novel “Lost Radio City,” of his birthplace, Lima, Peru.

headline: Mexico City for Tamales, Tortas and Tacos
abstract: Tamales wrapped in a roll? Taco filling carved from a spit? The New York restaurateur Roberto Santibañez returns to his native city to reveal variations on these well-known foods.
lead_paragraph: ROBERTO SANTIBAÑEZ drove with me to a bakery in Mexico City called La Espiga expecting to be disappointed. Before leaving the city many years ago, he loved the tamales that a man sold on the sidewalk in front of the bakery, and he was hoping that maybe, just maybe, he could get those same tamales at that spot now.

headline: Bookshelf: Harvest
abstract: Picture books about apples, carrots, potatoes, pumpkins and Johnny Appleseed.
lead_paragraph: Picture books about apples, carrots, potatoes, pumpkins and Johnny Appleseed.

headline: Drawn to the Magnet of Chile’s Surf Coast
abstract: In a beachfront area near Chile’s wine country, long waves roll, ceviche is served by a fire and the landscape resists comparison.
lead_paragraph: I FOUND Pichilemu through a local’s tip. In planning an itinerary that would start in Santiago and end a couple of hours south in the wine country, I was looking for a low-key weekend spot near the two destinations where I could stop for a few days and recharge with my family. “Well, there is a new hotel in Pichilemu that opened a few weeks back,” said a new friend who was born in Chile and travels all over the country. I figured if anyone would know, he would. One look at the Web site and I booked in.

headline: Why the iPhone 5 Does Not Have N.F.C. — It Can’t
abstract: Apple’s iPhone 5 got bigger than its predecessor, and some wonder why the company didn’t make room for a technology called near-field communications (N.F.C.), which enables devices to exchange information wirelessly over very short distances. It appears that Apple chose beauty over added functions with its aluminum-and-glass phone.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s iPhone 5 got bigger than its predecessor, and some wonder why the company didn’t make room inside for a technology called near-field communications (N.F.C.), which enables devices to exchange information wirelessly over very short distances. This feature could make paying for things with a phone less of a hassle. (You’d swipe the phone over a device at the checkout counter.) It turns out that getting N.F.C. to work right with the new design of the iPhone wasn’t even possible.

headline: A Tourist Revival in the Heart of Bogotá
abstract: As conflict cools in Colombia’s capital, a centuries-old quarter of pastel-colored homes and cultural attractions is drawing a flood of visitors.
lead_paragraph: IT was a windswept Saturday in the Candelaria neighborhood of Bogotá, and the Plaza de Bolívar was packed. Troubadours, jugglers, balloon vendors, pineapple sellers and Amazonian fruit-juice pressers vied for the attention of tourists. Grizzled Andean Indians led children around on llamas. Pilgrims gathered at the Bogotá Cathedral, a soaring Gothic structure that contains the remains of the city’s 16th-century founder, the conquistador Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada. Beside a statue of the South American liberator Simon Bolívar, a tattooed comedian held an audience of hundreds rapt.

headline: Off the Charts: The Job Score
abstract: Government jobs have been most affected during the current economic cycle, and they continue to decline while private sector employment recovers at a moderate rate. The top chart shows the percentage of jobs held by public sector employees since 1957. In recent decades, that proportion has tended to fall under Democratic presidents and rise under Republican ones. The other charts show the annual rate of change in the number of jobs during four-year presidential terms, and through August during President Obama’s administration. While private sector employment is now a little higher than it was when Mr. Obama took office, overall government employment has declined at a rate not seen during any full presidential term since the reductions that followed the end of World War II.
lead_paragraph: Government jobs have been most affected during the current economic cycle, and they continue to decline while private sector employment recovers at a moderate rate. The top chart shows the percentage of jobs held by public sector employees since 1957. In recent decades, that proportion has tended to fall under Democratic presidents and rise under Republican ones. The other charts show the annual rate of change in the number of jobs during four-year presidential terms, and through August during President Obama’s administration. While private sector employment is now a little higher than it was when Mr. Obama took office, overall government employment has declined at a rate not seen during any full presidential term since the reductions that followed the end of World War II.

headline: Bookshelf: Harvest
abstract: Picture books about apples, carrots, potatoes, pumpkins and Johnny Appleseed.
lead_paragraph: APPLE  Written and illustrated by Nikki McClure.  40 pp. Abrams Appleseed. $12.95. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

headline: In Guatemala, a Torturous Drive to a Remote Eden
abstract: Stepped pools, parrots in the trees, miles of caves and exotic isolation. That’s what awaits in Semuc Champey. As for getting there, let’s just say it makes the arrival sweeter.
lead_paragraph: YOU might have thought years had passed since a foreigner had traversed this remote stretch of road in the interior of Guatemala. Here, in Alta Verapaz state, just the sight of our big American vehicle cruising over the endless and totally unnecessary speed bumps in the small and even smaller villages was enough cause for children to abandon their soccer balls of crumpled-up paper and wave as we passed by.

headline: A Santiago Barrio Recreates Its Image
abstract: A handmade-paper shop and a bookbinding workshop are just two of the creative businesses in an evolving Santiago neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: BARRIO ITALIA, a neighborhood of once-monotonous facades in the western part of Santiago, was built as an alternative to the squalid tenements that dotted the Chilean capital in the early 20th century. After arriving from Italy, members of the Girardi family opened a hat factory along the district’s northern edge in the 1910s, giving the area its commercial pulse and its name, for their country of origin.

headline: Restaurant Report: Tarquino in Buenos Aires
abstract: A former Ferran Adrià pupil infuses some wizardry — think provolone pizza in a glass — into this Buenos Aires newcomer.
lead_paragraph: Dining out at a Buenos Aires hot spot these days often means sampling the cooking of an internationally trained Porteño chef who is now back home interpreting local cuisine with his newly acquired skills.

headline: For 2013 Range Rover, a Stage as Monumental as the Vehicle
abstract: The fourth generation of the luxury S.U.V. was unveiled in North America on Thursday at Stone Mansion in Alpine, N.J.
lead_paragraph: ALPINE, N.J. — The Palisades Parkway runs opposite the northern reaches of Manhattan, skirting the former estates of titans of the Gilded Age. In the approach to this enclave high above the Hudson River, eight miles from Manhattan, a sign reads “Rockefeller Lookout.”

headline: Village Voice Editor Blogs That He Is Quitting
abstract: Tony Ortega said he would be working on a book proposal about Scientology.
lead_paragraph: Tony Ortega, the editor of The Village Voice, announced Friday morning on the site’s news blog that he would be leaving — effective next week — to “pursue a book proposal about Scientology in its time of crisis.”

headline: In Germany, Gay Player Mulls Coming Out
abstract: A player in Germany’s Bundesliga spoke about his homosexuality, but only on the condition he not be identified.
lead_paragraph: German soccer is abuzz after a professional player in the country’s top-flight league, the Bundesliga, gave an interview earlier this week in which he recounted his life as a homosexual.

headline: A Story Exposes How the Chinese Government is Fueling Elephant Slaughter
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Elephants', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Ivory', 'Smuggling']
abstract: An investigation reveals how the Chinese government has cornered the ivory trade and fueled poaching pressure on elephants.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a lot of hard-edged coverage of the bloody burst of African elephanticide of late, including the new series coming from Jeffrey Gettleman of The Times and “Agony and Ivory,” Alex Shoumatoff’s devastating Vanity Fair portrait of the ivory flow from Africa to Asia.

headline: Obama to Attend Ceremony Honoring Americans Slain in Libya
abstract: President Obama will accompany Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton for a ceremony formally transferring the remains of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and the other three Americans who were killed during an attack on the United States Consulate in Benghazi.
lead_paragraph: President Obama plans to go to Joint Base Andrews outside Washington on Friday afternoon to mark the return of the four Americans slain in Libya, the White House announced.

headline: Obama’s Jobs Number Still Beats Predecessor’s
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The pace of creation of jobs in the private sector during the current administration is now greater than the pace in either of President George W. Bush’s terms in office.
lead_paragraph: THE job numbers in recent months have been disappointing, encouraging Republicans who hope that the slow pace of recovery will cause voters to reject President Obama.

headline: The Secrets to Buying Excellent French Wine Right Now
abstract: Most of the big French supermarket chains are gearing up for their annual wine fairs this week. Amid the hype, there are some good deals, too. Here’s how you can make the most of them.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s that time of year in France — “la rentrée” or “the return.” It’s when people come back from the beach, don their fall fashions and go back to work or school. It’s also the time of year when retailers ring up the bulk of their wine sales for the year.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ARGUABLY: Essays,  by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $18.) The esophageal cancer that killed Hitchens last December throws a shadow over this provocative collection, one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2011. Nearly 800 pages and containing more than 100 essays, it addresses an extraordinary range of topics, including Afghanistan, Harry Potter, Thomas Jefferson, waterboarding, Henry VIII, Saul Bellow and the Ten Commandments.

headline: No Quarterback Controversy: One Starts, One Finishes
abstract: Trevor Siemian, a backup quarterback, has played an important late-game role in each of Northwestern’s two victories this season.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. – Northwestern quarterback Trevor Siemian was a baseball player as well, playing shortstop, third base and outfield for Olympia High School in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Jennifer Szalai and Parul Sehgal discuss several new books about women’s issues; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Tom Reiss talks about “The Black Count”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jennifer Szalai and Parul Sehgal discuss several new books about women’s issues; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Tom Reiss talks about “The Black Count”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: In Search of a Middle Eastern Strategy
abstract: Mitt Romney and Barack Obama in the foreign policy briar patch.
lead_paragraph: Here are four thoughts on the sudden intrusion of foreign policy into our all-about-the-economy political year:

headline: No Explosives Found After Bomb Threats at Colleges
abstract: The University of Texas at Austin and North Dakota State University in Fargo, N.D., had ordered campus evacuations on Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The authorities in Texas and North Dakota said on Friday that they had found no explosives after two large public universities were evacuated over bomb threats — false alarms that forced tens of thousands of students and staff members to flee in the middle of classes at the University of Texas at Austin and at North Dakota State University in Fargo.

headline: The Choice on the ‘Today’ Show
abstract: Jacques Steinberg discussed the student-led series, “The Envelope, Please,” on the “Today” show.
lead_paragraph: Jacques Steinberg of The Choice, a senior editor at The New York Times, appeared on NBC’s “Today” show on Friday morning to talk about college admissions and our student-led series, “The Envelope, Please.” Watch the full interview below.

headline: Answers About Hostage Negotiation, Part 2
abstract: Taking Questions: The second set of answers from Capt. Frank A. Bolz Jr., a retired New York Police Department hostage negotiator.
lead_paragraph: This is the second set of responses from Frank A. Bolz Jr., one of the founders of the New York Police Department’s hostage-negotiating unit, answering reader questions. Read the first and third set of responses and the introductory post about Mr. Bolz. We are no longer accepting questions.

headline: Romney Statement on Iran at Odds With His Foreign Policy Advisers’
abstract: While two of his advisers in interviews said that Mitt Romney has a different “red line” on Iran from President Obama, Mr. Romney told ABC News that his red line is the same as that of the president.
lead_paragraph: 11:06 p.m. | Updated An updated version of this post can be found here.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: TELEGRAPH AVENUE, by Michael Chabon. (Harper/HarperCollins, $27.99.) Chabon’s rich comic novel about fathers and sons in Berkeley and Oakland, Calif., juggles multiple plots and mounds of pop culture references in astonishing prose.

headline: Latin America Through a Lens
abstract: Vibrant hues, playful art and zesty food are all part of this online-only collection of photos from our Latin America issue.
lead_paragraph: Vibrant hues, playful art and zesty food are all part of this online-only collection of photos from our Latin America issue.

headline: A Guaranteed Return on an Annuity Has Limits After All
abstract: Because the annuity payment is based on how much is in the annuity, policyholders who had planned to add to their accounts will now see much smaller payments than they had expected.
lead_paragraph: ANNUITIES are sold with the word “guaranteed” sprinkled through the marketing material. A set payment for life seems mighty attractive when many people are worried about having enough income in retirement and interest rates on savings and Treasury bonds are almost nonexistent.

headline: Nine Months of Hell
abstract: The waves of Northerners who signed up for short Army stints in 1862 had no idea what awaited them.
lead_paragraph: It was mid-September 1862, and the 900 soldiers of the 130th Pennsylvania Infantry were marching through western Maryland. Pvt. Edward Spangler — all 16 years and 92 pounds of him — struggled to stay with his regiment. The heat was “intense,” Spangler later wrote, “and the suffocating dust more than ankle deep.” Hundreds of raw recruits, ill-prepared and exhausted, were collapsing by the roadside.

headline: In a Deck of Cards, Finding ‘52 Shades of Greed’
abstract: In time for the anniversary of the occupation of Zuccotti Park on Sept. 17, Occupy Wall Street’s Alternative Banking group is offering for sale a set of anti-capitalist playing cards.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for the one-year anniversary of the occupation of Zuccotti Park on Sept. 17, Occupy Wall Street’s Alternative Banking group is offering for sale an acerbically educational set of anti-capitalist playing cards.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: The annual Feast of San Gennaro is in full swing this weekend as local restaurants offer special menus during this street festival full of live music, parades and family-friendly activities. Bolstered in recent years by the presence of restaurants like Torrisi Italian Specialties, guests will find better food than what’s offered at typical New York street festivals. The 11-day event ends on Sept. 23.

headline: A New Opera Center, for Practicing as Well as Performing
abstract: The new National Opera Center in Midtown Manhattan will provide spaces that are many steps up from the basements where opera auditions and rehearsals have often been held.
lead_paragraph: No more arpeggios in the bathroom. Goodbye, church basements. Hello, soundproofing.

headline: iConfusion
abstract: I neither love nor hate Apple.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had some bizarre reactions both to my iPhone post and to today’s column. For some reason a number of people thought that the blog post was an attack on Apple, while a number of people thought that the column — which made the same point! — was a love letter to Apple.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Adaptations
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the dilemma that filmmakers are presented with when adapting movies from books.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the dilemma that filmmakers are presented with when adapting movies from books.

headline: What New Polls Say About the Campaign
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Voters are more likely to blame George W. Bush than Barack Obama for the sluggish state of the economy. And they think the economy will improve.
lead_paragraph: New presidential election polls out today, including a New York Times/CBS News poll, don’t resolve the uncertainty of this race, which remains too close to call. But they do provide insight into how some of the big issues in the campaign have been playing – the economy, women’s rights, and Medicare.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Board Game
abstract: Three designers have shared their spring 2013 mood boards with T. The challenge: To identify the images on each.
lead_paragraph: Three designers have shared their spring 2013 mood boards with T. The challenge: To identify the images on each. See all the mood boards here >>

headline: The Sweet Spot | Sept. 14, 2012
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the dilemma that filmmakers are presented with when adapting movies from books.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the dilemma that filmmakers are presented with when adapting movies from books.

headline: Putting the S.B.A. Into Perspective
abstract: If the Small Business Administration makes progress, that’s great — but the problems are bigger than the S.B.A.
lead_paragraph: In this political season, there will be a lot of dialogue about the Small Business Administration as a possible solution to the small-business lending crisis in America. As two examples, the S.B.A.’s administrator, Karen Mills, spoke recently at the Democratic National Convention and Robb Mandelbaum wrote a post for this blog about the effect a Romney administration might have on the S.B.A. budget.

headline: More Fedding
abstract: Did Bernanke really take a stand?
lead_paragraph: Now that I’ve coughed my way through the morning, I thought I would offer a bit of clarification on my Bernanke post from last night.

headline: Hot Dogs and Hamburgers? During Fashion Week? How Déclassé!
abstract: The choice of words becomes a spat between a fashion critic and a well-known fashion designer.
lead_paragraph: When The Times’s fashion critic Cathy Horyn called the noted fashion designer Oscar de la Renta a “hot dog,” in her review of his Tuesday runway show at Fashion Week, the octogenarian decided to add to the menu. He took out a full-page ad in Women’s Wear Daily on Friday, in the form of an open letter objecting to what he saw as personal criticism. “If you have the right to call me a hot dog, why do I not have the right to call you stale 3-day old hamburger?” he asked.

headline: The Emerald City Gang
abstract: Romney turns to the people who failed in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: I have to admit that I haven’t been paying much attention to Mitt Romney’s foreign policy; the domestic side already offers a target-rich environment. But my eyebrows shot up when Dan Senor popped up speaking for Romney in the Libya/Egypt flap. Dan Senor?

headline: Loyalty to Embattled Assemblyman Is Seen in a Brooklyn Election
abstract: Vito J. Lopez, the Democratic assemblyman who stands accused of sexual harassment, saw his favored candidate for a district leader leading an incumbent, partly because of Hasidic politics.
lead_paragraph: He may be down, but he’s not out.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Matt Bissonnette, the ex-Navy SEAL who took part in the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, visited a Taco Bell drive-through as soon as he got back from the mission.
lead_paragraph: HEAD FOR THE BORDER: The new king of the hardcover nonfiction list is, no surprise, Mark Owen — or, as he’s known to his friends (and the rest of America by now), Matt Bissonnette. A former member of the Navy SEALs, Bissonnette is the author of “No Easy Day,” which enters the list at No. 1 and describes, among other things, his role in the raid that killed Osama bin Laden. The book (written with Kevin Maurer) has received admiring reviews — in the daily New York Times, Janet Maslin called it “an exciting, suspenseful account” — but it has also stirred anger among special operations forces, who adhere proudly to a code of silence. Breaking it means Bissonnette is unlikely to be included in future SEAL reunions, one retired Navy officer told The Washington Times: “The guys who run their mouths are typically not invited back.” But Bissonnette hasn’t let the critics keep him down. He sat for a recent “60 Minutes” interview (heavily disguised, inset) and told Scott Pelley the first thing he did upon returning from the mission was visit a Taco Bell drive-through.

headline: Summer Nights 2012
abstract: A roundup of photographs from the articles that made up the Summer Nights series.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of photographs from the articles that made up the Summer Nights series.

headline: Stephen Burt Explains His Favorite Poems
abstract: The poet and poetry critic describes what he loves about “Hospital Parking Lot, April,” and “Ignatz Aubade” in words those who are unfamiliar with poetry can understand.
lead_paragraph: I asked Stephen Burt, the poet and poetry critic, to comment on two favorite poems, which accompany my profile of him. “Why do you like them?” I asked. “Can you help the reader unfamiliar with poetry understand them?” His answers are below.

headline: The Romneys Tape Appearance on ‘Live With Kelly and Michael’
abstract: Mitt Romney — newly professed fan of the iPhone, Snooki and sleeping in “as little as possible” — offered a lighthearted, humanizing glimpse of himself Friday morning in an interview with Kelly Ripa and Michael Strahan, set to air Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney — newly professed fan of the iPhone, Snooki and sleeping in “as little as possible” — offered a lighthearted, humanizing glimpse of himself Friday morning in an interview with ABC’s Kelly Ripa and Michael Strahan, set to air Tuesday.

headline: With High Winds, Play Is Halted and Day’s Scores Are Voided
abstract: The second round at the Women’s British Open was suspended, and scores were voided as winds up to 60 m.p.h. created unplayable conditions at Royal Liverpool Golf Club.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — On the 10th tee, her first hole of the day, Cristie Kerr stuck her teed ball in the ground. Never mind the ball staying put; Kerr said she was nearly swept off her feet by the strong winds that whipped through Royal Liverpool Golf Club on Friday, turning the second round of the year’s final major into the Women’s Brutish Open.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Hanna Rosin’s ‘End of Men’
abstract: Jennifer Szalai and Parul Sehgal discuss Ms. Rosin’s work and other books about women’s issues.
lead_paragraph: This week’s edition of The New York Times Book Review includes considerations of several new books about women’s issues, including Hanna Rosin’s “The End of Men: And the Rise of Women.” Ms. Rosin argues that we’ve entered a new era in which women are increasingly dominant in both public and private spheres. In her review of the book, Jennifer Homans takes issue with the triumphant tone of Ms. Rosin’s subtitle. Ms. Homans writes:

headline: Making It Exclusive: Signing With an Agent
abstract: Choosing a real estate agent for selling a home may seem simple, but there is much to understand about the role of the agent and how the relationship works.
lead_paragraph: CHOOSING a real estate agent for selling a home may seem simple, but there is much to understand about the role of the agent and how the relationship works. And the stakes are high — the sale of what is likely the owner’s most valuable asset.

headline: An Unqualified Success, at Least in London
abstract: In his final installment for the 2012 London blog, the wheelchair racer Joshua George says London is the gold standard against which future Paralympic Games will be judged.
lead_paragraph: The wheelchair racer Joshua George competed in the 2012 Paralympic Games in London and wrote for the 2012 London blog. Readers can continue to follow him on his Web site, joshgeorgeracing.com

headline: Speaking at Values Voter Summit, Ryan Says Obama Creates ‘Straw-Man’ Issues
abstract: Paul D. Ryan dialed up the rhetoric against President Obama a few degrees hotter than it has been, caustically accusing the president of only being able “to talk a good game.”
lead_paragraph: Paul D. Ryan dialed up the Republican rhetoric against President Obama a few degrees hotter than it has been, caustically accusing the president of only being able “to talk a good game” and of using “straw-man arguments” because he has no record on which to run.

headline: Under Cover of Darkness, a New Season Slips In
abstract: Autumn nears, bringing fresher air, cooler weather, shorter days and confusion about what to wear.
lead_paragraph: Autumn begins in the night.

headline: Liz Garbus on 'Love, Marilyn'
abstract: The director Liz Garbus discusses her documentary "Love, Marilyn," which looks at letters and journal entries written by Marilyn Monroe.
lead_paragraph: The director Liz Garbus discusses her documentary "Love, Marilyn," which looks at letters and journal entries written by Marilyn Monroe.

headline: A City Perch for a Reverse Commuter
abstract: Alfredo Sosa-Velasco went looking for a no-frills studio on the Upper East Side for $270,000, tops.
lead_paragraph: LAST fall, Alfredo Sosa-Velasco landed happily in New York as a visiting scholar at New York University. He was provided with a furnished studio with a balcony, for $1,275 a month, in Washington Square Village, the university-owned housing complex.

headline: When Children Get Medals for Standardized Test Results
abstract: What should a parent say to a child after standardized test results are effectively broadcast to the entire class with the presentation of “medals” for achievement?
lead_paragraph: A parent in California wrote me last week about the state’s STAR testing, and, more important, the practice, in some schools, of awarding medals for achievement on the tests to students. Her child’s school presented “gold” medals for advanced achievement in language arts and/or math, and “silver” to children whose score was “proficient.” (Yes, a medal for “proficiency.”) The medals were given to the children in an assembly. Children who weren’t given a medal were given a certificate.

headline: A Reminder of the Perils of Retirement Planning
abstract: Bucks readers talk about their retirement financial planning in the wake of a decision by Prudential Securities to suspend contributions by some annuity policyholders.
lead_paragraph: People without a pension who want to set up something that will pay them set amounts of money when they’re in retirement often turn to annuities. But Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about a decision by Prudential Annuities to suspend the ability of some policyholders to make further contributions. And annuity experts told Paul that they expect other insurers to take similar steps because they made promises before the financial crisis that they are now unable to keep.

headline: Near the Zoo’s Snakes, a Hospital’s Collection of Medicine
abstract: A collection of antivenin is stored at the Bronx Zoo because it is just a few miles from Jacobi Medical Center, which has one of the nation’s leading snakebite-treatment centers.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx Zoo has an impressive collection of venomous snakes on display in its Reptile House. But out of sight it also has an impressive collection of antivenin to treat snakebites — though none of the zoo’s snakes have ever bitten an employee or a visitor.

headline: Emmys Watch: Don Roy King on Directing ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: An Emmy nominee for directing a variety show discusses the “intense butterflies” he gets before every “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards show on Sept. 23. First up is Don Roy King, nominated for best director for a variety show for his work on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: When It Comes to Calling Fouls, N.B.A. Should Look to the Playground
abstract: The league needs to move from referee-whistled fouls and adopt a practice as time tested as the game itself: letting the players call their own.
lead_paragraph: A long-standing criticism of the N.B.A. has been the influence of referees on the flow and outcome of games – especially how, when, and in what context certain fouls are called.

headline: The Hamptons, for $500,000
abstract: A growing number of modest but more affordable properties are popping up for $500,000 or less, creating opportunities for second-home buyers who were previously priced out.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Jahil Maplestone and Alexandria Fisk began looking for a second home in the Hamptons a couple of years ago, they were quickly discouraged by what their $500,000 budget would buy.

headline: Patrice Kunkel: 1951-2012
abstract: A lifelong Las Vegan turned card counting into security.
lead_paragraph: The obituaries in The New York Times are about people who were leaders in their fields, including some of the best known humans on the planet.

headline: Those Youthful Kennedys
abstract: Joining politics at a young age is, no doubt, a time-honored Kennedy tradition, and it’s one that has often brought mixed results.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s issue, Edith Zimmerman profiles Joseph P. Kennedy III, who is running for Barney Frank’s House seat — and who, if he beats out his Republican opponent, Sean Bielat, will become the latest Kennedy to hold an elected office. With $1.96 million in his campaign’s coffers, Joseph has the financial upper hand on Bielat, who’s running on roughly $65,000. At 31, Joseph has another advantage, too, one that the Kennedy clan has drawn on for generations: youth. (Bielat is 37.)

headline: Try Curling Up With a Good Meatball
abstract: The extensive Italian repertory may be thought of first when it comes to these delicious spheres, but their counterparts are found everywhere.
lead_paragraph: MEATBALLS are comfort food the world over, cheap, easy to love and simple to make.

headline: Couscous, Large and Small
abstract: Which kinds of couscous to buy, according to David Tanis, and which ones to avoid.
lead_paragraph: I wanted to serve couscous with the North African meatballs in this week’s City Kitchen column. But what kind?

headline: Man, 21, Arrested in Murder of Bronx Gas-Station Worker
abstract: Freddie McGrier, of Harlem, who has served time for robbery, was arrested in connection with a fatal robbery at RC Petroleum in East Tremont.
lead_paragraph: A 21-year-old parolee who has served time for robbery has been arrested in connection with last week’s murder of a Bronx gas-station worker, the police said on Friday.

headline: Times Co. Offers Former Employees Lump Sum Option for Pension
abstract: The New York Times Company, trying to contain pension costs, is offering former employees the choice of a monthly payout for their pension or a lump sum in cash or to roll into a retirement plan.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company, which like many of the nation’s newspaper publishers is dealing with large pension obligations, is offering former employees the option of taking a lump sum payment for their pensions instead of a monthly payout.

headline: Analysts See Minor Boost for Housing in the Fed’s Plan
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Credit and Debt', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: Economists said the Federal Reserve’s plan to buy mortgage-backed securities and other assets was a sign of its confidence in a nascent housing recovery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s ambitious effort to spur the recovery by aiding the housing market is likely to have a modest effect on home sales, given the pervasive weakness in the real estate market and the economy, analysts said Friday.

headline: India Backs Foreign Investment in Retailing
abstract: The government of Manmohan Singh, which is facing political troubles, gave backing to measures that could open the country’s retail sector to global behemoths like Wal-Mart and Ikea.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After years of intense debate, India’s government agreed on Friday to open the country’s retail sector to global behemoths like Wal-Mart and Ikea, pushing for a profound shift in India’s economic and political direction.

headline: A Set Designer Sets Up Shop
abstract: A production designer’s shop in Downtown Los Angeles is host to a rotating roster of eclectic antiques, home goods and other vintage finds.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the production designer Coryander Friend (“Beginners“) opened Storefront, a vintage shop in Downtown Los Angeles’s arts district. Housed adjacent to the popular eatery Wurstküche and around the corner from Apolis: Common Gallery and Poketo, Storefront showcases Friend’s rotating roster of eclectic antiques, home goods and other vintage finds. On my visit, I spotted everything from a brown Borge Mogensen leather sofa ($6,500) to a green dummy bomb ($650) to a 1960s jet-propelled aluminum surfboard ($1,800). Not to be missed are the store’s collection of Navajo rugs and prison keys. As the store’s head curator, Friend plans to switch up Storefront’s aesthetic on a quarterly basis by featuring new collectors and artists. Currently Storefront is selling pottery by Victoria Morris and surf photography by Will Adler, whose uncle Tom Adler is well known for his own surf-themed work. For her next installation, Friend will feature the work of her friend and mentor, the Window’s Greg Wooten. As for the theme? “The next one has to do with music, geometry and something I haven’t figured out yet,” Friend wrote in an e-mail. “I come from set decoration and production design. We are always telling stories with our environments. I want to work that way in my store. Who knows where it will go?”

headline: Fashion Week’s Version of the Rockettes
abstract: If you want a front-row seat at a fashion show, be prepared to tie your legs into a tight knot.
lead_paragraph: WHEN you pack many famously thin and fashionable people into a confined space, strange things happen. Consider the pretzel twist seen on the crossed legs of front-row fashionistas like Anna Wintour; Carine Roitfeld, editor of CR Fashion Book; and the dedicated fashion follower Sarah Jessica Parker, among others.

headline: Who Could Oppose a Jobs Bill for Veterans?
abstract: Republicans, that’s who.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans, resolute in their commitment to deny the Democrats anything that looks like an accomplishment in an election year, have spent the week obstructing passage of the Veterans Job Corps Act of 2012. It’s a perfectly inoffensive bill from Senator Patty Murray, the Washington Democrat, meant to increase hiring and job training for veterans, especially those who served in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 14-16
abstract: Ferraris rally through the coastal fog of California, a vintage Bonneville racer visits Ohio and burnouts precede a drive on Sebring International Raceway this weekend.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: U.S. Says Fast Pace Continues on Reprieves for Young Immigrants
abstract: Officials said 63,000 applicants had already been scheduled for fingerprints and photographs, the second step in the process.
lead_paragraph: More than 82,000 illegal immigrants have applied for a two-year reprieve from deportation in the first 30 working days of an Obama administration program, and 29 have been approved, officials from the Department of Homeland Security said on Friday.

headline: Rethinking the New Plant Hardiness Zone Map
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Global Warming', 'Maps', 'Seasons and Months', 'Temperature', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: A researcher contends that the recalculated zone does not take full account of the extent of climate change over the last 30 years — above all, warmer winters.
lead_paragraph: For gardeners sad to see the summer drawing to a close, there’s some comfort to be drawn from the fall planting season for perennials, trees and shrubs, which is just around the corner. What’s more, there’s the novelty of this year’s updated Plant Hardiness Zone Map, released early this year.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A four-bedroom Colonial in Garden City, N.Y., and a four bedroom with water views in Pelham Manor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom Colonial in Garden City, N.Y., and a four bedroom with water views in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Financial District condo, a Bedford-Stuyvesant condo and an Upper East Side co-op.
lead_paragraph: A Financial District condo, a Bedford-Stuyvesant condo and an Upper East Side co-op.

headline: Michael Learned to Star in New Play by Bruce Graham
abstract: “The Outgoing Tide” is scheduled to open in November at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: Michael Learned, the Emmy Award-winning actress, will star in “The Outgoing Tide,” a new play about family struggles by Bruce Graham that is set to open in November at 59E59 Theaters, on East 59th Street in Manhattan, the Delaware Theatre Company announced Friday.

headline: Answering Questions on Student Loan Rates and the Murky Future
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Paying for college can be one of a household’s most complex financial decisions. Here, we try to supply answers to four of the most important questions on rates and avoiding financial surprises.
lead_paragraph: Figuring out how to pay for college has quickly turned into one of life’s most complicated financial decisions.

headline: New York Fashion Week From the Ground Up
abstract: A ground-level view of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: A ground-level view of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Mr. Madison Moves On
abstract: After more than 20 years at 1070 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, Eliot Rabin sent a letter to his customers this month telling them that the men’s shop, Peter Elliot, is closing at the end of October.
lead_paragraph: ELIOT RABIN, the founder of the Upper East Side temple of navy blazers and sherbet-colored sweaters that is Peter Elliot, is a retailer of a bygone era of gentility. He loves to amuse a customer with a good cliché, like his store motto: “The whimsical mood of timeless elegance.”

headline: Rape Victim, 73, Says She Reported Earlier Confrontation With Suspect
abstract: The woman said that when she saw a man masturbating in Central Park two weeks ago, she told a park ranger.
lead_paragraph: The 73-year-old woman who was raped in Central Park said Friday that when she encountered a man masturbating in the wooded Ramble area two weeks ago, she not only took his photograph, but also reported what she saw to a park ranger.

headline: White House Details Potential Effects If Automatic Budget Cuts Go Through
abstract: Line by line, an account of the results if Washington fails to act to head off about $100 billion spending cuts scheduled to begin Jan. 2, 2013.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Army operations and maintenance would lose nearly $7 billion next year, and the Navy more than $4 billion under a looming series of automatic cuts in federal spending. Educational achievement and special-education programs would be shaved by $2.3 billion. Medicare payments to hospitals would fall by $5.6 billion.

headline: Bill Clinton Is More Popular Than Ever, Poll Finds
abstract: Michelle Obama is a close second in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton is more popular now than at any time during the 20 years since his emergence as a presidential candidate, with two-thirds of registered voters viewing him favorably, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Week in Review: Contrarian Bets Looking Smart
abstract: We examined contrarian bets on European bonds that are looking pretty smart right now. And with Treasury set to reduce its A.I.G. bet below 50 percent, Andrew Ross Sorkin called a critic of the bailout. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.
lead_paragraph: We examined contrarian bets on European bonds that are looking pretty smart right now. And with Treasury set to reduce its A.I.G. bet below 50 percent, Andrew Ross Sorkin called a critic of the bailout.

headline: Kansas Ballot Challenge Over Obama’s Birth Is Ended
abstract: A Kansas man withdrew a petition in which he argued that President Obama should be removed from the state’s election ballot because he did not meet citizenship requirements.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Citing a wave of angry backlash, a Kansas man on Friday withdrew a petition in which he argued that President Obama should be removed from the state’s election ballot because he did not meet citizenship requirements.

headline: Q & A
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Condominiums', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: When a home isn’t a primary residence; understanding the rules of co-op living; rent-controlled tenant in a condo conversion.
lead_paragraph: When a Home Isn’t a Primary Residence

headline: Official Challenge by Joe Montgomery and Obama Response
abstract: The official challenge filed by Joe Montgomery to keep President Obama’s name off the ballot in Kansas, and the response by the Obama team.
lead_paragraph: The official challenge filed by Joe Montgomery to keep President Obama’s name off the ballot in Kansas, and the response by the Obama team.

headline: Revis Is Ruled Out of Steelers Game
abstract: Darrelle Revis did not receive the N.F.L.-mandated authorization to resume contact after sustaining a concussion in the season opener.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Darrelle Revis attended the University of Pittsburgh and grew up in nearby Aliquippa, but there will be no homecoming for him this weekend when the Jets play the Steelers at Heinz Field.

headline: My Brief Career as a Kennedy Speechwriter
abstract: In 1992, Congressman Joseph P. Kennedy II went on a fact-finding trip to Germany. Before he came home, he needed a punch line.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never met Joseph P. Kennedy III, the Congressional candidate profiled in this week’s magazine. But as a reporter at The Boston Herald in the early 1990s, I covered his father, Joseph Kennedy II, who was then a congressman. I found the older Kennedy (whatever you may think about his politics) charismatic and curious about the world outside Massachusetts, which led him, and me with him, to Germany.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 8
abstract: Lady Gaga ends Fashion Week with fragrance launch at the Guggenheim.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga ends Fashion Week with fragrance launch at the Guggenheim.

headline: In ‘Detropia,’ Leveraging the Remnants of a Proud City
abstract: The documentary, which takes an unvarnished view of the metropolis, had its Detroit premiere on Thursday at Wayne State University.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It’s a well-chronicled tale with an undetermined ending: the rise of Detroit as the Motor City; its dismal, protracted slide; and its current posture, where it wobbles but stands, proud but buffeted, in the grip of transformation.

headline: Altima: Sailing Into the Mainstream
abstract: The Nissan Altima is now the second-best-selling passenger car in the country. The company has redesigned the sedan for 2013, and although the new car drives beautifully, Nissan has played it safe.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Nissan unveiled a new Altima for 2002, it heralded the company’s redesign as much as the car’s. Nissan’s workaholic new leader, Carlos Ghosn, was engineering a remarkably fast turnaround that made him a global auto-industry superstar. And the great-looking Altima — formerly an obscure runt among family sedans — was the model that, more than any other, transformed Nissan from a debt-ridden basket case into one of the most profitable automakers.

headline: Reality Check From Honda, in Touch With Economics
abstract: The Honda 2012 NC700X is aimed at the mainstream, no apology offered. It is a tempting choice for riders who want versatility and don’t need scare-you-to-death speed.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Calif.

headline: The Beginner’s Ninja Raises the Ante at the Entry Level
abstract: Kawasaki has elevated its game with the 2013 Ninja 300, a lightweight sportbike with an upgraded engine.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, the most thrilling new motorcycles have been those at the top of the model line: the racetrack replicas splashed with a Valentino Rossi livery or the high-stepping machines with the go-anywhere styling of a Dakar rally competitor.

headline: Playing It Straight (And Why Not?)
abstract: The all-new and all-better Honda Accord does nothing to betray the car’s enormous and well-established customer base.
lead_paragraph: The all-new and all-better Honda Accord does nothing to betray the car’s enormous and well-established customer base.

headline: Accord: Once More With No Nonsense
abstract: The Accord, a sedan that doesn’t call attention to itself or to its owner, has long been a stalwart for Honda. But the 2013 model, which goes on sale on Wednesday, is so thoroughly pleasant that its buyers may be tempted to admit enjoying it.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

headline: When Work Makes You Choose
abstract: A new study portrays “family responsibilities discrimination” as a growing problem.
lead_paragraph: 4:50 p.m. | Updated  Rachel Robinson was doing well at T-Mobile in Chattanooga, Tenn. The company hired her in 2006 as a customer service representative, promoted her twice in two years and honored her with an employee award that included a trip to Hawaii.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Three Adolfs
abstract: Osamu Tezuka’s “Message to Adolf” is part of an all-new manga best-seller list this week.
lead_paragraph: The entire manga list is new this week, but the most significant book by far is the first volume of “Message to Adolf,” by Osamu Tezuka, at No. 6. Mr. Tezuka, who died in 1989, is frequently described as “the godfather of manga.” Clocking in at 648 pages, “Message to Adolf” begins in modern times, quickly jumps to the 1936 Olympics in Berlin and moves through World War II. It chronicles the fate of three men with the same first name: Adolf Kamil, a Jewish boy; Adolf Kaufmann, the young boy with a German father and a Japanese mother who befriends him; and Adolf Hitler. The boys become entangled in a struggle between opposing sides — one that wants to expose Hitler’s Jewish ancestry and another that wants to suppress it at all costs. The book has a sprawling cast, and the relationship between the two young boys and their struggle to remain friends is touching.

headline: Liz Garbus’s Personal Look at Marilyn Monroe
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Toronto International Film Festival']
abstract: Liz Garbus discusses her documentary on Marilyn Monroe, “Love, Marilyn,” at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It is rare for documentaries to receive gala screenings in one of the festival’s largest venues, Roy Thomson Hall, but when the subject is Marilyn Monroe, there will be  fanfare. “Love, Marilyn,” directed by Liz Garbus, focuses on letters and journal entries by the actress and uses celebrities like Uma Thurman and Marisa Tomei to bring her words to life on screen.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.5 Million
abstract: A five-bedroom co-op that fills the top two floors was once owned by the Andy Warhol muse Jane Holzer.
lead_paragraph: A starkly modern penthouse duplex with a Pop Art pedigree — the Andy Warhol alumna Jane Holzer once owned it — which fills the top two floors at the Volney, a former hotel built in 1928, sold for $17.5 million, making it the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Model for a Day
abstract: A writer tries the catwalk during Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: A writer tries the catwalk during Fashion Week.

headline: Model Behavior
abstract: Looking out of place and starving for a bagel, a writer hits the runway during Fashion Week and discovers his inner Zoolander.
lead_paragraph: I’D love to tell you that my modeling career got its kick-start when the photographer Larry Clark found me skateboarding in a disused swimming pool in Tulsa. Or when Karl Lagerfeld tweeted some photos he had taken of me in my capacity as the towel boy at his day spa.

headline: How Much Does the Fed’s Plan Really Help Main Street?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Credit Cards', 'Interest Rates', 'Mortgages', 'Personal Finances', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In theory, the Fed’s latest bond purchases should drive down borrowing costs for companies and consumers, making them more likely to take out loans to buy goods and services and thus stimulate the economy. But many rates, like those for credit card loans, remain stubbornly high.
lead_paragraph: Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Thursday that the Fed’s new stimulus was meant to help Main Street.

headline: Richie Jackson and Jordan Roth
abstract: A place where ‘It’s complicated’ and ‘It’s worth it’ coincide.
lead_paragraph: THE initials JR and RJ on the marquee of the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Sept. 8 announced a one-night-only event that, for its main players, Jordan Roth and Richie Jackson, was the culmination of a multiyear tryout as long and as full of emotion and humor as the shows appearing in the Broadway houses that Mr. Roth oversees as the president of Jujamcyn Theaters.

headline: Slovenia Encounters Debt Trouble and May Need Bailout
abstract: Five years after joining the euro zone, this alpine nation risks the dubious distinction of becoming the first ex-socialist country in the European Union to need a bailout.
lead_paragraph: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia — Small, affluent and westward-leaning, Slovenia was welcomed with open arms into the European Union in 2004 and slipped, almost unnoticed, into the euro union three years later.

headline: Ex-UBS Trader Is Accused of Gambling in a Big Loss
abstract: In an opening statement, prosecutors in London portrayed Kweku Adoboli, a former USB trader facing fraud and false accounting charges, as a free-wheeling trader who doctored documents, invented profits and fabricated clients to cover up trading that led to a $2.3 billion loss at the Swiss bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fictitious trading and brazen gambling by a single individual could have brought down the Swiss financial giant UBS, a British prosecutor said on Friday at the trial of a former bank employee accused of causing a multibillion-dollar trading loss.

headline: Oats for Dinner and Dessert
abstract: Steel-cut oats can make a hearty and healthful breakfast, but as Martha Rose Shulman recently discovered, oats are a great grain at dinnertime.
lead_paragraph: Steel-cut oats can make a hearty and healthful breakfast, but as Martha Rose Shulman recently discovered, oats are a great grain at dinnertime too. She writes:

headline: Village Voice Is Losing Its Editor in Chief and Music Editor
abstract: Two top editors of The Village Voice are departing, and the newspaper is moving out of the building where it has had its headquarters for two decades.
lead_paragraph: After five and a half years as editor of The Village Voice, Tony Ortega announced in a blog post that he would be stepping down to work on a book about Scientology. The music editor, Maura Johnston, took to Twitter to say she was leaving the newspaper as well.

headline: Learning to Love the Middle
abstract: The 2013 Nissan Altima is a terrific family car, among the best in the current field of midsize sedans. And that’s saying something, considering the depth and multinational breadth of that class.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 Nissan Altima is a terrific family car, among the best in the current field of midsize sedans. And that’s saying something, considering the depth and multinational breadth of that class.

abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: New Animated Series Make Inroads in Ratings
abstract: Looking at the ratings for animated children’s shows over the summer.
lead_paragraph: Now that youngsters have headed off to school, it seems like a good time to take a look back at the animated shows they – and their parents – watched over the summer.

headline: Friday Afternoon Music: Wilco w/Feist
abstract: You and I need a break.
lead_paragraph: It’s early, but I’m leaving for the airport soon, so something pleasant after a hard week:

headline: Defining Middle Class
abstract: Both presidential candidates have suggested that the threshold for being rich starts around $250,000. That’s about the 96th percentile for American households.
lead_paragraph: In a discussion on “Good Morning America” about his tax plan, Mitt Romney suggested the cutoff for middle income was for households earning “$200,000 to $250,000 and less.” President Obama has used a similar threshold in talking about extending tax cuts for the middle class.

headline: 3 Experts, and Many Tips for Visiting Brazil
abstract: Advice on timing, eating and booking from three Brazil-based travel experts.
lead_paragraph: To supplement my seven rules for lowering the cost of a trip to Brazil, I asked three Brazil-based colleagues to come up with their own tips. They are Ricardo Freire, widely regarded as the dean of Brazilian travel bloggers; Fábio Peixoto, the editor of a Brazilian travel guide; and Kevin Raub, a Lonely Planet author who lives in São Paulo.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: H.P.’s Smartphone and Twitter’s New Hacker
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selection includes a study that shows that some mobile carriers are overcharging for data, where big technology money is going in the presidential campaign and a case that Apple’s products are more complicated to use than they once were.
lead_paragraph: A Geeky Way for Children to Learn Their ABCsLaughingsquid.com |  The new ABCs? A is for Apple, the company. B is for Bezier curve. Fun, nerd eye candy for a Friday afternoon. — Damon Darlin

headline: Wrapping Up TimesOpen: Sockets and Streams
abstract: Wrap-up and links for the Sept. 12 TimesOpen event, “Sockets and Streams.”
lead_paragraph: This past Wednesday night, more than 80 developers came to the Times building for the second TimesOpen event of 2012, “Sockets and Streams.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Sudan, Morocco and Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Sudan, Morocco and Yemen.

headline: Michigan State Tailback Thrives on Doubts
abstract: Le’Veon Bell has been the hot back in Michigan State’s first two games, gaining 280 yards on 62 carries with 4 touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Le’Veon Bell took the handoff, his second of the season, moving fast enough to make everyone else look slow. He spotted a safety 7 yards away and ran purposefully toward him. Beyond the safety was space.

headline: Exclusive | Bassman Carriage House
abstract: A three-story, 7,000-square-foot brick structure, now reconfigured as two residences, once served as home and studio for the fashion photographer Lillian Bassman.
lead_paragraph: A three-story, 7,000-square-foot brick structure, now reconfigured as two residences, once served as home and studio for the fashion photographer Lillian Bassman.

headline: The Carriage House in the Close-Up
abstract: A three-story, 7,000-square-foot brick structure, now reconfigured as two residences, once served as home and studio for the fashion photographer Lillian Bassman.
lead_paragraph: THE highly personalized Upper East Side carriage house that for half a century served as home, studio and muse of sorts to Lillian Bassman, the iconoclastic fashion photographer, is being offered for sale for $14.9 million by her heirs.

headline: BMW Previews Concept Active Tourer Before Paris Motor Show
abstract: The plug-in hybrid fits within the automaker’s eDrive program, its new designation for purely electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The BMW Concept Active Tourer fits squarely in Europe’s predilection for efficient, premium small cars, pairing a turbocharged 1.5-liter 3-cylinder engine with an electric motor that sends power to — stand back — the front wheels.

headline: Somber Ceremony as Bodies of Slain Americans Return
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: President Obama said the victims “laid down their lives for us all” and vowed to honor their memory by never retreating from the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Four flag-draped coffins bearing the bodies of the Americans killed in Libya arrived in the United States on Friday for their final journey home as President Obama said the victims “laid down their lives for us all” and vowed to honor their memory by never retreating from the world.

headline: What’s in Store | Dior Homme
abstract: The newly reopened store on 57th Street captures the magic of fashion.
