headline: Remembering the Forgotten Borough
abstract: “From Farm to City” at the Museum of the City of New York explores Staten Island, home of Linoleumville and of America’s first tennis match.
lead_paragraph: It’s not called the forgotten borough for nothing (a dubious distinction it sometimes shares with Queens). Chances are that you have forgotten, or may never have known, that the first American tennis match was played there, that Cornelius Vanderbilt got his start there, that Sandy Ground was the first community established by freed slaves in North America, that by one account Manhattan’s first suburb sprouted there, that the last commercial farm there closed only three decades ago and that it will soon be home to a greensward three times bigger than Central Park.

headline: Why Consumers May Not Win Much From Latest Fed Action
abstract: Is it the banks that are standing in the way?
lead_paragraph: Over on Dealbook, there’s a post making the case that it may be the banks that are standing in the way of the Federal Reserve’s latest move to try to improve the economy. At the moment, many of them simply do not want to give up the profit margins they’re earning on new mortgages.

headline: Constant Motion, Elusive Point
abstract: The scores, or hundreds even, of events, during the New York Fashion Week continuum made it feel that one had wandered into a glossier version of “Groundhog Day.”
lead_paragraph: AND so there was Carine Roitfeld being stopped at the door of a West 54th Street town house where the W party was held — one event among scores, or hundreds even, that made it feel during the New York Fashion Week continuum that one had wandered into a glossier version of “Groundhog Day.”

headline: The Week in Metro Pictures for Sept. 14
abstract: Subjects include the 11th anniversary of 9/11, a controversial circumcision ritual and the New York primary race.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the 11th anniversary of 9/11, a controversial circumcision ritual and the New York primary race.

headline: Canning Jam, From Preparing the Jars to Testing the Seal
abstract: Canning means you can keep the jams in the pantry, freeing valuable fridge space.
lead_paragraph: REFRIGERATOR jams will last for weeks, maybe even a few months, when kept cold and tightly sealed. You can also freeze the jams for up to six months before they start to lose their texture. But any of these recipes can also be canned for longer storage — up to a year. And canning means you can keep the jams in the pantry, freeing valuable fridge space.

headline: Moving Past Traditional to the Science Fictional
abstract: Whether sticking to religious themes, or working in touches from a favorite TV show, variety appears to be emphasis for many couples.
lead_paragraph: WHILE planning their wedding, which took place last October in Mesa, Ariz., Amber Balmer and Trey Memmott wanted to not only have references to one of their favorite television shows, “Firefly”  — a space Western in which the universe was called the “verse” — but to change their last names to Reynolds, after Capt. Malcolm Reynolds, the lead character on the old Fox series.

headline: All Cut Up
abstract: Sliced, diced and inter-spliced: it was a novel way of approaching color, and it made for some riotously kaleidoscopic effects on the runways this week.
lead_paragraph: Sliced, diced and inter-spliced: it was a novel way of approaching color, and it made for some riotously kaleidoscopic effects on the runways this week. For quite a few designers, who introduced separates last season in madly clashing hues, combining disparate tints in a single item represented a continued commitment to color while advancing its cause by degrees.

headline: Cathy Horyn's N.Y. Fashion Week Wrap-Up
abstract: An analysis of the spring collections from Calvin Klein, Proenza Schouler, Marc Jacobs and Narciso Rodriguez.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of the spring collections from Calvin Klein, Proenza Schouler, Marc Jacobs and Narciso Rodriguez.

headline: Romney Calls for Moment of Silence During Ohio Rally
abstract: Mitt Romney also attacked President Obama’s foreign and military policies.
lead_paragraph: PAINESVILLE, Ohio — Mitt Romney began his rally here on Friday afternoon by calling for a moment of silence for the four Americans who were killed in the attack on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, on Tuesday.

headline: The Price of Politics (Shorter Bai Edition)
abstract: Reviews for Bob Woodward’s new book, “The Price of Politics,” credit our political reporter Matt Bai with having already reported the important information in the book.
lead_paragraph: This just in from the Dept. of Shameless Plugging: It has been gratifying to read reviews of Bob Woodward’s new book — by Michiko Kakutani in The New York Times, David Lauter in The Los Angeles Times and Jeff Shesol in The Washington Post — and see the various references to Matt Bai’s excellent article about the debt deal gone bad, from our April 1 issue, saying that Bai had already revealed all the important information contained in Woodward’s book. If you need to purchase “The Price of Politics” to complete your Woodward collection, don’t let us stop you. But for those who want to understand how the deal went south and what the implications are — in shorter but exhaustively reported form — check out Bai’s article.

headline: Making and Canning Jam
abstract: Try making your own jam with all those summer fruits available this time of year. Melissa Clark is joined by Cathy Barrow, a canning expert, to show how easy it is to make and can your own jam.
lead_paragraph: Try making your own jam with all those summer fruits available this time of year. Melissa Clark is joined by Cathy Barrow, a canning expert, to show how easy it is to make and can your own jam.

lead_paragraph: The Look: Rosy Outlook. Clean hair, a pink pout and black accessories — pump plus clutch — turn a simple jersey dress into an absolute standout.

headline: One on One: Reggie Fils-Aime, President of Nintendo of America
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Nintendo DS (Video Game System)', 'Wii (Video Game System)']
abstract: Reggie Fils-Aime, president and chief operating officer of Nintendo of America, says the game maker’s new Wii U, a game console that can be operated with a touch-screen controller, and Nintendo TV, its new online video service, show that the company is becoming more of a full-fledged entertainment business.
lead_paragraph: In an event in New York this week, Nintendo had demonstration booths where people could play with its new Wii U, a game console that can be operated with a touch-screen controller. It also introduced Nintendo TV, its new online video service that is intended to make its Wii U competitive with set-top box systems like the Apple TV, Google TV and Roku.

abstract: In the City of Light, September seems to be interior design month.

headline: Women Running for Congress in Record Numbers
abstract: More women than ever before have been nominated to serve on Capitol Hill, with 18 running for the Senate and 163 vying for the House.
lead_paragraph: If the parties are indeed engaging in some sort of “war on women,” record numbers of them are successfully enlisting in the fight. More women have been nominated to the major parties for House and Senate seats than ever, according to researchers.

headline: Broome Street, Manhattan
abstract: Scenes from along Broome Street, including shopping for yarn, guitars and Japanese food, al fresco dining and a traffic jam near the Holland Tunnel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from along Broome Street, including shopping for yarn, guitars and Japanese food, al fresco dining and a traffic jam near the Holland Tunnel.

headline: Kansas Birthers
abstract: Kansas is considering tossing President Obama from the November ballot because it’s not sure that he’s a citizen.
lead_paragraph: Birther alert: Kansas is considering tossing President Obama from the November ballot because it’s not sure that he’s a citizen. A citizen from Manhattan (Kansas) named Joe Montgomery filed a complaint to that effect, so the State Objections Board, controlled by Republicans, is duly looking into it. “I don’t think it’s a frivolous objection,” said the Kansas Secretary of State, Kris Kobach.

headline: How Tolstoy Learned to Ride a Bike, and Other Tales of Late-Life Learning
abstract: Including Miles Davis’s discovery of boxing and Marie Curie’s first-time swimming lesson in her 50s.
lead_paragraph: In our Education Issue this Sunday, we explore what it takes to send every child to college; get people reading poetry; create an always-on tutor; and fire up a university. Below, accounts of notable people learning new things at an older age.

abstract: Broome Street maintains a grimy, hardworking atmosphere as it intersects with chic side streets.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Bill and Jean Conlon moved into a loft on Broome Street 41 years ago, they felt like pioneers.

abstract: Notre Dame, fresh off its A.C.C. announcement, travels to Michigan State on Saturday, a matchup that intrigues the letter men.
lead_paragraph: Each week, two of college’s football’s seasoned observers, Pre-Snap Read‘s Paul Myerberg and Robert Weintraub of Football Outsiders, get together over e-mail to discuss the biggest games and story lines around the country.

abstract: A new poll shows that 2012 presidential race is narrowly divided and that the outcome could still turn on unexpected events and how the candidates are perceived after their three debates next month.
lead_paragraph: A new poll shows that 2012 presidential race is narrowly divided and that the outcome could still turn on unexpected events and how the candidates are perceived after their three debates next month.

headline: Poll Finds Obama Is Erasing Romney’s Edge on Economy
abstract: President Obama has taken away Mitt Romney’s advantage as the candidate voters say is most likely to restore the economy, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has taken away Mitt Romney’s longstanding advantage as the candidate voters say is most likely to restore the economy and create jobs, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News, which found a modest sense of optimism among Americans that White House policies are working.

headline: Critics Find a Target in the Circles of USA Today’s Redesign
abstract: Each section has a bold circle in the top, left-hand corner: some found it odd, but Gannett described them as “symbols of who we are.”
lead_paragraph: The day after USA Today unveiled its new edition, the design community was in a fluster about the newspaper’s new look and puzzled by the bold circles that appear in the top, left-hand corner of every section.

headline: After Libya Attacks, Questions About Presidential Briefing Habits
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama sat down with intelligence officials on Friday for his Presidential Daily Briefing. That might not sound all that surprising, but despite its title, this does not actually happen daily.
lead_paragraph: President Obama sat down with intelligence officials on Friday for his presidential daily briefing. That might not sound all that surprising, but despite its title, this does not actually happen daily.

headline: Hitching an Old-Fashioned Ride the Newfangled Way
abstract: To promote the third season of “Boardwalk Empire” in Manhattan, the show’s marketers leveraged Uber, the mobile taxi-hailing app, to arrange rides in vintage cars for the show’s fans.
lead_paragraph: To promote the season premiere of HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire,” a fleet of a dozen town cars spent two days transporting fares to their destination in Manhattan. The third season of the Emmy-winning show, chronicling Prohibition-era Atlantic City, N.J., begins Sept. 16.

headline: Reviewing the Nissan Altima and Honda Accord
abstract: Two titans of the midsize sedan segment look to nibble away at the market share of the Toyota Camry.
lead_paragraph: Two of the three best-selling midsize sedans in the America, the Honda Accord and Nissan Altima, are reviewed in Sunday’s Automobiles section.

headline: New Novel of Harlem Renaissance Is Found
abstract: A Columbia graduate student’s discovery of an unknown 1941 novel by Claude McKay has been authenticated.
lead_paragraph: A Columbia graduate student and his adviser have authenticated the student’s discovery of an unknown manuscript of a 1941 novel by Claude McKay, a leading Harlem Renaissance writer and author of the first novel by a black American to become a best seller.

headline: Turned Away, He Turned to the Bible
abstract: Matthew Vines, 22, uses a widely seen video and speeches to plead with others to consider the plight of the modern gay Christian.
lead_paragraph: ONE year after Matthew Vines was forced to leave the Wichita, Kan., church he had attended since birth — not because he is gay, but because he tried to convince people there was nothing wrong with that — he was sitting facing a crowd of 235 Christians, most of them gay or lesbian, at the Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: Showcasing an Eclectic Musical Biography and Some, Not All, of That Jazz
abstract: Bobby McFerrin opened the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra’s 25th-anniversary season with a program of works special to him.
lead_paragraph: The brassiest moment in “My Audio Biography,” Bobby McFerrin’s collaboration with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, running through Saturday at the Rose Theater, subjects a hallowed text to some studious whimsy. It’s the third movement of Beethoven’s Seventh Symphony, arranged for big band by Jazz at Lincoln Center’s artistic director, Wynton Marsalis. With its galloping triplets, the arrangement moves faithfully, up until a growlingly barrelhouse section, the concert hall equivalent of a nudge in the ribs.

headline: Alice, Still Fighting to Save the World
abstract: In the fifth installment of the “Resident Evil” series, the leading lady is stripped of her superpowers and reunited with characters who were killed in previous movies.
lead_paragraph: The fifth entry in a series as indestructible as Alice (Milla Jovovich), its caffeinated heroine, “Resident Evil: Retribution” finds her still on the mysterious ship where “Resident Evil: Afterlife” left her. Almost a decade has passed since the endlessly mutating T-Virus began transforming most of humanity (and zoology) into drooling, pimply cannibals, but Alice — part human, part viral, all airbrushed — is still fighting to save the world. She must be as tired as we are.

headline: Chic in Review | Gaga’s Fame in a Bottle
abstract: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Song of the Cheaters
abstract: It appears that, after more than a century of debate, Harvard students are still unsure of what “cheating” means.
lead_paragraph: AFTER 125 Harvard students were accused of cheating last month on the final exam of a course titled “Introduction to Congress,” there was predictable hand-wringing over the declining moral standards of the academic elite. “A college education has become a transaction: a means of earning a degree for your résumé, rather than a place to explore the life of the mind,” The Boston Globe bleakly proclaimed. The Associated Press asked whether Harvard should finally institute an honor code, a system that many peer institutions have had in place for years but that Harvard has long resisted.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
abstract: The introduction of Apple’s iPhone 5; a European proposal to regulate banks and the start of a trial for an ex-UBS trader were among the week’s top business news stories.
lead_paragraph: The introduction of Apple’s iPhone 5; a European proposal to regulate banks and the start of a trial for an ex-UBS trader were among the week’s top business news stories.

headline: United States Wins Buffett Cup
abstract: The Buffett Cup, fashioned after the Ryder Cup in golf, was played in Omaha from Monday to Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The fourth Buffett Cup was played in Omaha from Monday to Thursday. Fashioned after the Ryder Cup in golf, it featured the following teams:

headline: House-Made Pasta, and Gifts From Mom
abstract: An ebullient mood at Ristorante Giorgia sets the tone for the zesty herbs used to flavor the ravioli, tender veal and roasted cod.
lead_paragraph: EVEN before you enter Ristorante Giorgia, the omens look good: colorful petunias and marigolds cascading out of their red flower boxes next to the entrance, and pots of fresh rosemary, mint, sage, oregano, thyme and basil within snipping distance of the kitchen. Inside, the mood is immediately ebullient. New arrivals are greeted with hugs as they make their way among the crowd of tables; does everyone in here know one another, or does it just seem that way? If the bread and olive oil on the table are any indication, it is going to be a fine night.

headline: What Congress Owes the Constituents
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Representative Rush Holt, a New Jersey Democrat, and other readers respond to a Sunday Review article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: You May Call It Cheating, but We Don’t
abstract: My husband doesn’t object to my wandering eye, allowing me to explore the boundaries of our marriage.
lead_paragraph: MY husband and I have been together for 12 years. We talk throughout the day. We like each other a lot in addition to being in love. We plan to be together for the rest of our lives. I feel profoundly lucky.

headline: Granholm and Her Curls on ‘The Dating Game’
abstract: Jennifer Granholm, the former Michigan governor, was on “The Dating Game” in 1978, and YouTube has immortalized her 19-year-old self.
lead_paragraph: As the former governor of Michigan, Jennifer Granholm was in the driver’s seat during one of the state’s most economically painful periods, and now she’s in the anchor’s seat on Current TV. But before that, Ms. Granholm was in the hot seat as a contestant on “The Dating Game” in 1978.

headline: An Unconventional Romance
abstract: The Bollywood movie “Barfi!” is billed as a romantic comedy, and there are several nods to Buster Keaton and Charlie Chaplin.
lead_paragraph: The lovers in Anurag Basu’s engagingly odd “Barfi!” — he’s deaf and mute, she’s autistic — are a particularly pure expression of a cherished Bollywood theme: love is the supreme goal. (Cue the songs: the movie does.) Stripped of conventional social expectations, Barfii (Ranbir Kapoor) and Jhilmil (a deglamorized Priyanka Chopra) have nothing to follow but their hearts, and nothing to battle but kidnappings, death and venality.

headline: A Pasta Dish From the Slopes of a Volcano
abstract: The classic dish spaghetti alla Norma, with its mountain of pasta, tumble of eggplant and dusting of cheese, brings needed sizzle to California pinot noirs.
lead_paragraph: I considered spaghetti alla Norma back in February, when we tasted wines from the slopes of Mount Etna in Sicily.

headline: Seeking Justice for Mom and Dad
abstract: A boy who witnessed the killing of his parents studies martial arts and embarks on a mission in “Bangkok Revenge.”
lead_paragraph: “Fight,” says Chanticha (Aphradi Phawaputanon), a nurse, to a critically injured boy in the hospital. “You have to fight.”

headline: Pinot Hunting in the Anderson Valley
abstract: This California valley continues to revel in its off-the-grid aura, even as it has been embraced by an increasing number of pinot noir producers over the last decade.
lead_paragraph: CALIFORNIA winemakers share a calling with the Cistercian monks of the Middle Ages: a relentless quest to find the best places to grow pinot noir. Over centuries, the monks settled on the heart of Burgundy, now famous as the Côte d’Or, along with a few scattered sites in Germany that may only now be coming to fruition. In California, the search goes on.

headline: The Lows of Higher Ed
abstract: Oh, to be young and gifted and $100,000 in the hole. Is that what going to college is about these days?
lead_paragraph: Welcome back, college students! Always nice to see you.

headline: Not Hollywood, but Once Famous for Movies
abstract: Universal Studios got its start in 1912 in Fort Lee, N.J., before going Hollywood, and its 100th birthday is being observed in its birthplace.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL STUDIOS, which got its start in 1912 in Fort Lee, moved most of its production to California in 1915, but its 100th birthday is being celebrated here. The 11-year-old  Fort Lee Film Commission has planned a variety of events to mark the centennial and “to make people aware they’re in a special place,” according to its executive director, Tom Meyers.

headline: The Unbridled Shower: Celebrating Divorce
abstract: With only about a 50-50 chance of a first marriage lasting, there seems to be a societal desire to commemorate, and even celebrate, what has become an increasingly common milestone in people’s lives.
lead_paragraph: I’M not divorced. Yet. But when my husband tosses criticisms at me like wedding rice, divorce, were it to assume a human form, begins to look a lot like Channing Tatum.

headline: Rothman Exits as Head of Fox Film Division
abstract: Mr. Rothman’s departure comes as Fox tries to put behind it some disappointing releases and move forward with two “Avatar” sequels.
lead_paragraph: 8:10 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Shoulder to Cry on and a Lot of Tough Talk
abstract: On “Iyanla: Fix My Life,” a troubled reality star seeks out Iyanla Vanzant, a self-help guide who has an evident distaste for polish.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn Lozada begins her appearance on “Iyanla: Fix My Life” perfectly primped — hair, makeup, outfit, all pristine. It was filmed in July, 11 days after she married the football star Chad Johnson. Their not-always-romantic courtship had been documented in “Basketball Wives,” the VH1 reality battle royale of which she’s the volatile star. (She was previously engaged to the basketball player Antoine Walker.)

headline: Battle Renewed Between Sabathia and Price
abstract: If it seems as if the Yankees’ ace and the Rays’ ace face each other a lot, it’s because they do.
lead_paragraph: C.C. Sabathia often says he prefers not to pay much attention to the starting pitcher he’s facing on a given night. When the opponent is the Tampa Bay Rays, however, it’s a good bet Sabathia already knows who is on the mound against him.

headline: For a Slick Operator, One Spin Too Many
abstract: The play “Farragut North,” better known by its screen adaptation, “The Ides of March,” involving a spin doctor for a major presidential candidate, is at the Zella Fry Theater in Union.
lead_paragraph: A contemporary drama about a young political spin doctor who spins out of control on the campaign trail, “Farragut North” is better known today as “The Ides of March.” The screen adaptation of Beau Willimon’s play, which was released last year under that title, starred Ryan Gosling as the press secretary and George Clooney as the governor he strives to elect as president.

headline: XOXO Fest, An Experimental Tech Conference, Gets Underway
abstract: The XOXO Fest in Portland, Ore., this weekend raised money using Kickstarter. Its methods are a theme for the music festival/start-up conference.
lead_paragraph: What, exactly, is XOXO Fest, a hybrid of a conference, music showcase and local marketplace happening this weekend in Portland, Ore.?

headline: Signs of High Demand for the iPhone 5
abstract: Did you forget to set the alarm on your iPhone to wake you up with a gentle marimba ringtone at 3 a.m. eastern time Friday? If so, your chances of getting the iPhone 5 early got a little dimmer.
lead_paragraph: Did you forget to set the alarm on your iPhone to wake you up with a gentle marimba ringtone at 3 a.m. Eastern time Friday?

abstract: Schools are clearly a critical piece — no, the critical piece — in any anti-poverty strategy, but they can’t go it alone.

headline: One Has Left Arkansas, but Football Still Bonds Petrinos
abstract: Two brothers, Paul and Bobby Petrino, still discuss Arkansas’s coming opponents, even as they no longer share a spot on the Razorbacks’ sideline.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — One of Paul and Bobby Petrino’s favorite ways to have fun was far less complicated than the offensive strategies it produced.

headline: Sinful Ways to Start the Day
abstract: Three new places in or near Westchester County offer excellent high-calorie and high-octane reasons to get out of bed.
lead_paragraph: SEPTEMBER means back to school and back to work — and back to morning regimens of low-fat yogurt and sensible breakfast cereals. But before you can say “stress factor,” we’ll be craving that big glazed doughnut or monster muffin, and triple or quadruple shots of caffeine. Here, in anticipation of slipping back into old habits, are three new places in or near Westchester County that offer excellent high-calorie and high-octane reasons to get out of bed. All are child-friendly and have good spots to tie up your dog.

headline: Contenders for America’s Most Popular Car: The Latest Wave of Midsize Family Sedans
abstract: Contenders for America’s most popular car.
lead_paragraph: Contenders for America’s most popular car.

headline: Bill Cunningham | On Their Feet
abstract: New York Fashion Week guests at the clothing shows provided a dazzling display of today's shoe designs.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week guests at the clothing shows provided a dazzling display of today's shoe designs.

headline: Once a Vagabond Driver, Now an IndyCar Title Contender
abstract: Ryan Hunter-Reay, who lost three rides in three years, all before age 25, is now driving for the former racer Michael Andretti.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Hunter-Reay was a racecar driver who needed a road map. He was not yet 25 when he lost his third ride in three years in the flagging Champ Car series in 2005, and he had to contemplate his future, perhaps one without racing.

headline: Fashion Week Inside and Out
abstract: The views from inside fashion shows, and outside on the sidewalk, during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The views from inside fashion shows, and outside on the sidewalk, during New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Cavemen Embrace Aprons and Whisks
abstract: In some circles, haute restaurants and ambitious recipes are the latest markers of machismo.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY had a long-postponed dinner with a dear male friend of mine. After comparing cholesterol scores and the frequency of workouts, we got down to business.

headline: What Books Said to One Another
abstract: In “Crossing Borders: Manuscripts From the Bodleian Library,” at the Jewish Museum, centuries-old texts in many languages reflect a multitude of influences.
lead_paragraph: If you listen closely at the subtly startling new exhibition at the Jewish Museum, “Crossing Borders: Manuscripts From the Bodleian Libraries,” you can hear manuscripts murmuring across millenniums.

headline: Movie Frenzy, but Still Comfy, Eh?
abstract: The Toronto International Film Festival mixes the highbrow and the lowdown through 11 busy days.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The Toronto International Film Festival is where towering achievement meets buckets of blood, where the cinematic highbrow jostles alongside the middle and lower realms for 11 crammed, ecstatic, enervating days and nights. The essential industry event of the fall, now in its 37th year, it is the promised land for distributors looking for product, producers hunting for money and journalists looking for the next big films and faces. Despite the red carpet events and what feels like a tighter embrace of the mainstream, the festival continues to feel appreciably less glamorous than Cannes. It’s homier, more relaxed, which is why you may end up seated near David Geffen at dinner one night or find yourself waiting for vegetarian takeout alongside Paul Dano and Zoe Kazan.

headline: Georgia: In Suing State, A.C.L.U. Defends Klan
abstract: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit against Georgia on Thursday for denying the Ku Klux Klan’s application to participate in an “adopt a highway” program.
lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit against Georgia on Thursday for denying the Ku Klux Klan’s application to participate in an “adopt a highway” program. The lawsuit says the state violated the freedom of speech of a chapter of the Klan in Union County, near the North Carolina border. State transportation officials in June denied the chapter’s application to clean trash along a stretch of Route 515 in the Appalachian Mountains, saying the program was for only “civic-minded organizations in good standing.” Debbie Seagraves, the executive director of the A.C.L.U. Foundation of Georgia, said: “There will always be speech and groups conveying hateful messages that are distasteful to some. That is why the First Amendment protects free speech for all.” The State Transportation Department said it had expected the lawsuit and stood by its decision to deny the application.

headline: Colleges in Three States Report Bomb Threats
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: False alarms forced students and staff members to flee at the University of Texas, Austin; North Dakota State University, Fargo; and Hiram College in northeast Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Three college campuses in North Dakota, Ohio and Texas were evacuated on Friday after receiving bomb threats. The false alarms forced students and staff members to flee in the middle of classes at the University of Texas, Austin; North Dakota State University, Fargo; and Hiram College in northeast Ohio. In Austin, Rhonda Weldon, a spokeswoman, said a man called claiming “to have placed bombs all over campus” that would detonate in 90 minutes, and officials decided to order the university’s 51,000 students and 24,000 staff and faculty members to evacuate “out of an abundance of caution.” Classes were canceled for the day. At North Dakota State, which has 14,000 students, officials ordered an evacuation after receiving a bomb threat, but the campus was reopened by 1 p.m., officials said. At Hiram, with 1,300 students, crews with bomb-sniffing dogs checked all of the buildings. It was not clear who made the threats or whether they were connected, officials said.

headline: Taking It to the Grave
abstract: A man wants to know whether, when he dies, he should be buried with his first wife, who died at 26, or his current wife.
lead_paragraph: I married the love of my life at a young age. We were high school sweethearts, together for 12 years and married for 6. Sadly, she passed away when we were 26. Five years later, I met a wonderful woman to whom I am now married, and we have two beautiful children. My second wife understands the deep love I shared with my first wife and respects our bond. When I die, should I be buried with my true love or in a family plot with my second family? Brian, New York

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 8 through 12 with 1,301 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 8 through 12 with 1,301 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,170 said they were registered to vote.

headline: The First Issue in Any Massage
abstract: Most women ask for female massage therapists, spa managers say, and the same goes for men. But culture and nationality also play a role.
lead_paragraph: IT’S often the first, and most awkward, question at a spa: “Do you prefer a male or female massage therapist?”

headline: As Succession Talk Stirs, Ford Focuses on New Car
abstract: Mark Fields says he will not be distracted by reports that he is a favorite to succeed Alan Mulally as chief executive when he retires.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — If Mark Fields is ruffled by speculation that he is the favorite to become the next chief executive of Ford Motor, he isn’t showing it.

headline: The Lion, the Artist and the Studio
abstract: The artist Jerry Pinkney is the subject of a soon-to-open retrospective at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.
lead_paragraph: Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: He Struck Gold in Cast Iron
abstract: The interior designer Paul Fortune, who styles and cooks, picks a cast-iron skillet as his favorite object.

headline: Cracks Spur Board to Urge Check of Dreamliner Engines
abstract: The recommendation comes after cracks were found in an engine shaft on two of Boeing’s jets and possibly on a cargo plane.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board on Friday called for frequent inspections on engines in Boeing’s new 787 Dreamliner planes after cracks were found in an engine shaft on two jets and possibly on a 747-8 cargo plane.

headline: Still Dreaming Her Dream
abstract: “Sweet Charity,” the musical about an optimistic dance-hall hostess who keeps falling for no-good men, is at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport through Oct. 28.
lead_paragraph: Pay attention to Charity Hope Valentine’s middle name. The heroine of the musical “Sweet Charity” is prone to wishful thinking. She’s also a giving person, and the object of her striving is love, so Charity and Valentine are also cleverly apt names. Or painfully obvious ones.

headline: Standing Up at an Early Age
keywords: ['Football', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo became an advocate for others at an early age because he learned “differences didn’t matter.”
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo has been praised in many quarters for supporting the legalization of same-sex marriage. His stance is not new, but it reached a wider audience after a Maryland legislator urged the Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti to silence him.

headline: A Label That Has Regained Its Luster
abstract: Even as the “Made in the U.S.A.” label has grown scarce, it has acquired cachet as a signifier of old-school craftsmanship, even luxury.
lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the Chrysler K-car? Dave Schiff, a founder of Made Collection, a new flash-sale site that sells only American-made goods, hopes not.

headline: Throwing Stones at Glass Ceilings
abstract: A review of “The Good Girls Revolt,” a history of the sex-discrimination suit at Newsweek four decades ago.
lead_paragraph: “The Good Girls Revolt: How the Women of Newsweek Sued Their Bosses and Changed the Workplace.” By Lynn Povich. 288 pages. PublicAffairs. $25.99.

headline: When Good Things Happen to Bad Seasons
abstract: Some of the best baseball stories right now involve unknown players on also-ran teams.
lead_paragraph: If you live in a baseball market where your team is already out of it, it’s likely that for a while there has been talk about next year, about “rebuilding.” I played for my share of those teams, and I know that this is the time of year when you can get a sense of what that rebuilt team might look like once they stop rebuilding. Because, as team rosters expand from 25 to 40 in September, this is when many young players get a true shot. They are penned into the lineup and allowed to play, to make mistakes, to compete against the best, every single night. The team is playing for the future, but the future gets to play, now.

headline: The Willing Nanny, the Happy Family: Too Good to Be True
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The relationship of Flavia Wasescha, a job-seeker, and Venus Clemons, looking for domestic help, began with an Internet want ad and ended unsatisfactorily.
lead_paragraph: The e-mail arrived two weeks ago.

headline: Standing Out From the New Girls
abstract: Allison Williams, the actress from the show “Girls,” whose father is the NBC News anchor Brian Williams, was a darling of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: ON Sept. 5, the day before New York Fashion Week began, she shimmered onstage at the Style Awards at Lincoln Center, glamorous in an above-the-knee white cocktail dress by the designer Christian Siriano, ballerina bun piled high and burgundy lips.

headline: California Tries to Guide the Way on Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Officials in California have begun to set up an online marketplace where millions of residents will be able to shop for medical coverage.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The meeting came to order, the five members of the California Health Benefit Exchange seated onstage with dozens of consumer advocates and others looking on. On the agenda: what to name the online marketplace where millions of residents will be able to shop for medical coverage under President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Fed Responds to a Grim Reality
abstract: In a meaningful departure from past policy, the Federal Reserve said it would focus on reducing unemployment at the risk of provoking higher inflation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Federal Reserve’s vice chairman said in a 1994 speech that the central bank “had a role in reducing unemployment,” colleagues were publicly dismissive. The very word “employment” did not appear in a policy statement until 2008. The Fed was focused on inflation, officials said time and again.

headline: Feeling the Oompah as Oktoberfest Beckons
abstract: On Long Island, beer gardens in Franklin Square and Farmingdale, longtime German favorites, are being joined by new ones in Stony Brook and Smithtown.

headline: Cutting Government, Blindfolded
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The more details that are released about the budget sequester scheduled for next year, the worse it looks.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney has been rousing military-minded voters with warnings of giant defense cuts in January, but he’s only telling half the story. An alarming White House report issued Friday shows that the full impact of next year’s ham-handed budget cuts would affect virtually every government function, not just the Pentagon.

headline: County Judge Strikes Down Some Restrictions on Public Unions in Wisconsin Law
abstract: A Dane County Circuit judge said the state law violated federal and state Constitutions with regard to city, county and school district workers.
lead_paragraph: A county judge in Wisconsin on Friday struck down much of the 2011 state law pushed through by Gov. Scott Walker that severely restricts the ability of public employees to bargain collectively.

headline: Mets Put Brewers’ Surge Into Wild-Card Picture on Pause
abstract: After falling to a season-worst 12 games under .500 on Aug. 19, Milwaukee has regained hopes of returning to the playoffs — despite a loss to the Mets on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The flat-screen televisions in the middle of the Milwaukee Brewers’ clubhouse were strangely dark on Friday afternoon.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for Sept. 14, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: No Rush to War
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is making a mistake by trying to browbeat President Obama into attacking Iran.
lead_paragraph: Amid the alarming violence in the Arab world, a new report about the costs of a potential war with Iran got lost this week. It says an attack by the United States could set back Iran’s nuclear program four years at most, while a more ambitious goal — ensuring Iran never reconstitutes its nuclear program or ousting the regime — would involve a multiyear conflict that could engulf the region.

headline: Ospreys in Okinawa
keywords: ['Military Aircraft', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Residents are venting their frustration with the Marine Corps presence and the plan to deploy dozens of aircrafts on the island.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people rallied on Sunday in Okinawa to protest plans to deploy the MV-22 Osprey, the trouble-plagued tilt-rotor aircraft, at the United States Marine Corps base in the city of Ginowan. The Marines want to bring in 24 Ospreys to replace a fleet of Vietnam-era helicopters, but Okinawans, turning out in one of the largest anti-American protests in years, are bristling.

headline: Walmart Opts Out of New York Mall After Facing Labor Opposition
abstract: A Walmart spokesman said on Friday that the company was “unable to agree upon economic terms” to be the anchor store in a new mall being constructed in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The prospect that Walmart, the world’s largest retailer, would open its first big-box store in New York City suffered a setback on Friday, with the company saying it would not be a part of a new mall being constructed in Brooklyn.

headline: American Retailers Face Challenges in Expanding to Canada
abstract: American retailers extending their reach northward may seem like an obvious move, but until recently, the Canadian market was hard to crack.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Nordstrom and Target are about to open stores in Canada, J. Crew and Tory Burch just did so, and Ann Taylor and Kate Spade are scouting locations.

headline: Turkish Cooking in a Friendly Setting
abstract: Turkish restaurants are a rarity in Fairfield County, and Bereket, in Bridgeport, is authentic, unabashedly plain and frugally priced.
lead_paragraph: “BEREKET,” our waitress explained, means “good luck,” — not a bad name for a venture that is less than three years old. The friendly, unpretentious staff and surroundings made me want to second that wish. In a later phone conversation with the restaurant’s manager, I was told Bereket also means “an excess,” as in “more than enough of a good thing.” Take your pick.

headline: Legislators Tainted by Scandal Find Defeat at the Polls
abstract: Two state legislators facing inquiries into financial wrongdoing lost Democratic primary elections this week, and a third who is accused in a bribery case won by an unexpectedly narrow margin.
lead_paragraph: In a state with a scant history of electoral upsets, it was not in any job description, but it might as well have been: Once an incumbent, always an incumbent.

headline: Money-Laundering Inquiry Is Said to Aim at U.S. Banks
abstract: Regulators, led by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, are said to be close to taking action against JPMorgan Chase for insufficient safeguards.
lead_paragraph: Federal and state authorities are investigating a handful of major American banks for failing to monitor cash transactions in and out of their branches, a lapse that may have enabled drug dealers and terrorists to launder tainted money, according to officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Two Days in September
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Lehman Brothers fell four years ago, and Occupy Wall Street rose last year. Where are we now?
lead_paragraph: Anniversary No. 1: Exactly four years ago, Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy protection. In the days and weeks that followed, we saw the unfolding of the dramatic — and ultimately successful — effort by the federal government to rescue the banking system. But, once the dust settled, we began to see something else: like the stock market crash of 1929, Lehman wasn’t an isolated event. Rather, it was a signal that deep problems had enveloped our economy — problems that wouldn’t be solved quickly or easily. That is why the Lehman bankruptcy still resonates. It was the moment everything changed.

headline: Votes Aren’t All Tallied, but Conclusions Are Drawn
keywords: ['Elections, Legislature', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Those who warned that Republicans backing gay marriage in New York would face consequences saw proof they were right.
lead_paragraph: Senator Stephen M. Saland, a lawyer from Poughkeepsie, has served in the New York State Legislature for 32 years. In 2010, he won re-election by 19 percentage points. And since then, he has raised $788,000 for his campaign war chest — more than 40 times what his challenger in the Republican primary raised.

headline: No Fury Like a Woman Bored
abstract: “Hedda Gabler,” Ibsen’s classic about anomie and the bottomless misery of a stage monster, is being performed at Hartford Stage.
lead_paragraph: On average, Oslo gets about 2.5 inches of rainfall in September — around one inch less than Hartford. But you wouldn’t know that from the loud onstage downpour underway as you take your seat for Jennifer Tarver’s production of “Hedda Gabler” at Hartford Stage.

headline: While Ryan Throws Hardballs, Romney Makes Friends on Morning TV
abstract: Paul D. Ryan, the Republican vice presidential candidate, uses an appearance to attack President Obama, while Mitt Romney and his wife chat it up with TV hosts.
lead_paragraph: PAINESVILLE, Ohio — One of the advantages of the partnership between Mitt Romney and Paul D. Ryan is their ability to offer varied messages on the campaign trail — unusually varied, as shown on Friday. The running mates punched a list of campaign goals — rallying the conservative base, turning up the heat on President Obama and reaching out to women watching morning television — when each day counting down to Nov. 6 matters.

headline: Bed-Stuy Pride
abstract: A prop master and a cinematographer reconnected at Do or Dine restaurant in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, to discuss the film industry and far-flung travels.
lead_paragraph: The garish yellow awning out front still says, “B’s West Indian,” but the restaurant Do or Dine, which opened in June 2011 in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, has outgrown its original winking misdirection. In July, one of the chef-owners, Justin Warner, won Season 8 of the cable reality show “Food Network Star.” And by now the high-concept, lowish-budget restaurant has become a destination for Manhattanites, as well as a standby for locals, with or without oversize baseball caps. How do you tell the difference? “Manhattan customers are very used to being catered to in their whims,” said Luke Jackson, 33, another owner, whereas locals are more concerned with essential pleasures: the food and the atmosphere. All choose from a menu whose puckish inventiveness (foie gras doughnuts, banana split-pea soup) has drawn sighs of delight and exasperation. Last Tuesday, the disco mirror ball spun and the sound system played ghosts of hip-hop past.

headline: Prosecutors Still Interviewing Campaign Donors in Liu Fund-Raising Inquiry
abstract: The government says it has narrowed its focus to about 100 people who gave money to the campaign of John C. Liu, New York City’s comptroller.
lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor said on Friday that investigators were continuing to interview donors to the campaign of the New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, which suggests that the authorities are trying to amass more evidence to put pressure on the defendants in the fund-raising case.

headline: Olajuwon Will School Knicks in Low-Post Moves
abstract: Hakeem Olajuwon, a two-time N.B.A. champion and a leading teacher of low-post moves, will visit the Knicks’ training facility next week to give lessons to the team’s big men.
lead_paragraph: Hakeem Olajuwon, a two-time N.B.A. champion and a leading teacher of low-post moves, usually conducts his instruction on his ranch in Katy, Tex. But next week, Olajuwon will visit the Knicks’ training facility in Greenburgh, N.Y., to give lessons to the team’s big men.

headline: Soul-Searching in a Christian Community Over Views on How to Live
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Cohousing Communities', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: John and Linda Parsons found themselves disappointed after their initial attraction to a Christian-themed cohousing development in Washington State.
lead_paragraph: BREMERTON, Wash. — In 2005, John and Linda Parsons decided to downsize. They were each about 50 years old, with two sons nearing college age. The time seemed right to leave their house on Bainbridge Island, near Seattle. They would sacrifice square footage for a lower mortgage.

headline: Organizers Say Ironman Will Not Return to New York City
abstract: The race, a 2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bike ride and a 26.2-mile run, was deemed too expensive and complicated to host and too difficult for spectators to watch.
lead_paragraph: Ironman, the organizer of the world’s best-known triathlon, will shut its race in the New York area after just one year.

headline: Meet the Quiet Jets, Who May Be a Lot Like the Old Jets
abstract: Coach Rex Ryan, viewed by some as a master of mind games, is promising that his team will be taken seriously.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The new Jets ditch practice to attend leadership retreats. They score 48 points in victory and then act as if they were shut out. They speak of good vibes and great feelings and how last year was last year and this year is just, well, different.

headline: How the Chicago Public School District Compares
abstract: The Chicago Teachers Union ended its strike on Tuesday after reaching a tentative deal with Chicago Public Schools.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Teachers Union ended its strike on Tuesday after reaching a tentative deal with Chicago Public Schools.

headline: Twitter Turns Over User’s Messages in Occupy Wall Street Protest Case
abstract: The social media company gave the messages to a judge but is appealing their provision to prosecutors; the case may have wide effects on law enforcement’s access to material placed on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Friday turned over to a judge a printed stack of messages written by an Occupy Wall Street protester in October, around the time he and hundreds of others were arrested after walking on the roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Cherry Ice Cream Smile
abstract: Joon Pahk and Brad Wilber team up to entertain us.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a lot going on in this puzzle for me, and that’s a big compliment considering that we are talking about a themeless Saturday puzzle.

headline: As N.H.L. Nears Lockout, Doan Re-Signs With Coyotes
abstract: With N.H.L. teams on track to begin a lockout at midnight Saturday, the highly regarded free-agent forward Shane Doan re-signed with the Phoenix Coyotes.
lead_paragraph: With N.H.L. teams on track to begin a lockout at midnight Saturday, the league engaged in a bevy of activity almost everywhere except the bargaining table.

headline: Diplomats’ Bodies Return to U.S., and Libyan Guards Recount Deadly Riot
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens reportedly took shelter in a hot, smoke-filled room and lost consciousness there during the attack on the diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As four flag-draped coffins bearing the bodies of the Americans killed in Libya arrived in the United States on Friday, new details emerged of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens’s final hours, alone, locked in a smoke-filled room in a diplomatic mission under siege.

headline: Talking to the City With Chalk
abstract: For the past 15 years, Robin Lane has been scrawling a topical message in chalk on the same spot on a sidewalk in Manhattan as newsy provocations for his neighbors to discuss.
lead_paragraph: ON Thursday evening, Robin Lane was out there with his stick of chalk, standing at his spot on the northeast corner of Second Avenue and 33rd Street in Kips Bay, Manhattan.

headline: South Africa Warns Against Violence as Protests Fester
abstract: Amid calls for a national miners’ strike, South Africa’s justice minister said the unrest would dent the country’s image and hurt its economy.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — In an attempt to stanch a spreading crisis in South Africa’s platinum and gold mining regions, the government said Friday that it would crack down on illegal gatherings and arrest people who congregate with weapons.

headline: A Concert Finder for the Open-Minded
abstract: Timbre, an app that came out this month, presents the user with a simple list of bands playing nearby and provides samples of the music.
lead_paragraph: APP Timbre

headline: The Brooklyn Game Had Its Own Beat
abstract: The Nets are arriving in a different era in Brooklyn. In simpler times, Brooklyn ballers only needed a ball, a park and a dream.
lead_paragraph: Before I was to play in the public school gym or the local Y, and at about the same time I had my first crush on Annette, the Mouseketeer, I used to gaze at the tall, gray steel backboard with the orange rim. For my first shot, I used a dodgeball. I didn’t have, let alone own, a real ball, a Voit.

headline: After Life in New York, Banker Returns to India for Turn at Fashion
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: When an investment banker came back from the United States, she needed to remake her wardrobe. Now, she manages brand strategy for a leading Indian fashion house.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI

headline: Lia Lee Dies; Life Went On Around Her, Redefining Care
abstract: The story of Lia Lee, the severely brain-damaged daughter of Hmong refugees, inspired a book that affected the way American medicine is practiced across cultures.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, when Anne Fadiman met Lia Lee, then 5, for the first time, she wrote down her impressions in four spare lines that now read like found poetry:

headline: The American Diplomatic Compound in Benghazi
abstract: Libyans found the body of J. Christopher Stevens in a safe room in the American Diplomatic Compound in Benghazi.
lead_paragraph: Libyans found the body of J. Christopher Stevens in a safe room in the American Diplomatic Compound in Benghazi.

headline: A Suicide in a Troubled Jail Mirrors New Orleans’s Ordeals
abstract: William Goetzee, a Coast Guard officer in New Orleans whose life was intertwined with the city’s ordeals, committed suicide in 2011 in the notorious Orleans Parish Prison.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Over the past year, in churches full of citizens railing at the state of the city jail, and in courtrooms where the thousands of young men who populate that jail rotate glumly through the sentencing process, a middle-aged woman could be seen sitting quietly. Her name is Donna Gauthier and she had not given much thought to the criminal justice system, other than to assume that if you had the misfortune of ending up in it, they would at least take care of you.

headline: Some Romney Proposals Await Fuller Detail
abstract: A presidential candidate who is not short of campaign promises is specific on some proposals, but vague on others.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney says he will cut government spending by some $500 billion a year by the end of his first term, while protecting military spending. But he has not detailed many of the deep cuts to domestic programs that budget analysts say would be needed to achieve that.

headline: Google Has No Plans to Rethink Video Status
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Google said it would not comply with a White House request to reconsider the anti-Islam video that has set off violent protests, saying it did not violate its terms of service regarding hate speech.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said on Friday that it would not comply with a White House request to reconsider the anti-Islam video that has set off violent protests in the Arab world in light of its rules banning hate speech on YouTube, which it owns.

headline: Romney Stumbles in Explaining Iran Policy
abstract: Mitt Romney, in an interview, used imprecise language on what his red line is on Iran’s nuclear program, saying it was acquisition of a weapon, not “capability,” as his aides have said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney has a clear “red line” in mind, a point beyond which Iran cannot go toward producing a nuclear weapon. It is sharply different, his campaign insists, from President Obama’s.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Questions about a speakeasy called the Alimony Prison, and a gender switch revealed at death.
lead_paragraph: Debtors’ Delight

headline: Afghan Insurgents Attack Base Where Prince Harry Serves
abstract: While it was not clear who the attackers were, the Taliban have vowed to kidnap or kill the prince, who is third in line to the British throne.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents using guns and rockets or mortars launched an audacious attack on the largest NATO base in Helmand Province shortly after midnight Saturday morning, killing two American service members, according to a spokesman for the international forces here.

headline: School Confronts Porn Arrest of Doctor
abstract: Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., acknowledged that its former employee Dr. Richard Keller, who was arrested on a child-pornography charge, had been disciplined several times since 1999.
lead_paragraph: A prestigious Massachusetts prep school and a pediatric hospital said on Friday that they had no indication that any of the children they served were harmed by a doctor who worked for both institutions and now stands accused of receiving child pornography.

headline: Shave, Shul and Schumann
abstract: Next to “great shaving,” which allows him to “look in the mirror and get ideas,” the piano is Rabbi David M. Posner’s hobby.
lead_paragraph: David M. Posner is retiring next year as senior rabbi at  Temple Emanu-El on Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, a Reform Jewish synagogue that counts Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg among its 3,000 members. Rabbi Posner, 64, who grew up in Brownsville, Brooklyn, started there immediately after his ordination from Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati, in 1973. He lives with his wife and childhood sweetheart, Sylvia — he calls her Syl — in a building that is a 15-minute walk from work, and said he expected to feel both happiness and relief after delivering his last High Holy Days sermons beginning on Sunday.

headline: Advantage, Obama
abstract: Wasn’t this election supposed to be a nail-biter? Recent character moments and poll numbers suggest that President Obama is ahead.
lead_paragraph: Elections often turn on character moments and the slopes of lines.

headline: Two Aces, One Unsettling Pattern
abstract: Once again, C.C. Sabathia was matched against the Rays’ ace, David Price. Once again, Price came out on top.
lead_paragraph: Since making his first start against the Yankees in early June 2009, David Price has held up his billing as the Tampa Bay Rays’ unquestioned ace — a 6-foot-6 left-hander and former top overall draft pick with the jerky delivery and the fastball that sings.

headline: The Champs-Élysées, a Mall of America
abstract: The grand boulevard, overrun with clothing outlets and burger joints, has largely lost its distinctive character and has become less French.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — André Malraux, the novelist and minister of culture under Charles de Gaulle, told a French-American journalist in the 1960s that the Champs-Élysées — then considered the most beautiful avenue in the world — had “an American basement.” Today, American business and its brands are prominently aboveground on a Champs-Élysées that has largely lost its distinctive character and has become far less French.

headline: SEAL Veteran With Zest for Adrenaline
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: In 2010, Tyrone S. Woods began working with security details protecting diplomatic personnel, from Central America to the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Tyrone S. Woods, one of four Americans killed this week when militants stormed a diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, was “one of those adrenaline junkies” who was “built to do what he did,” said Dr. Timothy Rasmusson, his former brother-in-law.

headline: Peter Lougheed, Ex-Premier of Alberta, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Lougheed turned Alberta into a major player in oil and gas and a pioneer in the development of oil sands.
lead_paragraph: Peter Lougheed, the Alberta premier who harnessed his province’s vast oil and gas resources to transform its economy, died Thursday in Calgary, Alberta. He was 84.

headline: Inflatable Dams
abstract: To help prevent the dumping of raw sewage into New York’s waterways during a storm, the city has installed inflatable dams in two locations.
lead_paragraph: To help prevent the dumping of raw sewage into New York’s waterways during a storm, the city has installed inflatable dams in two locations.

headline: The Face of Indefinite Detention
abstract: Adnan Latif, who died in his cell at the Guantánamo Bay prison camp on Sept. 8, was the ninth detainee to die. He was cleared three times for release, but there was no way to get out.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE he died on Sept. 8, Adnan Farhan Abdul Latif had spent close to 4,000 days and nights in the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. He was found unconscious, alone in his cell, thousands of miles from home and family in Yemen.

headline: A Leader in China Reappears in Public
abstract: Xi Jinping, who is expected to take over the Communist Party, was last seen in public on Sept. 1, raising questions about his health.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s next designated leader, Xi Jinping, reappeared in public on Saturday, two weeks after mysteriously disappearing from view.

headline: Mexico: Bodies Found on Bridge
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The bodies of nine men, one of them hanging from a bridge and all shot in the head, were found Friday in Nuevo Laredo, across from Laredo, Tex., the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of nine men, one of them hanging from a bridge and all shot in the head, were found Friday in Nuevo Laredo, across from Laredo, Tex., the authorities said. Ruben Darío, a spokesman for the Tamaulipas State prosecutor’s office, said the bodies were all found near the bridge, with a message left near them, though he would not disclose what it said. In May, five men and four women were found hanging from another bridge in the city. This latest crime occurred a day after the top leader of the Gulf Cartel, one of Mexico’s largest, was captured by the Mexican Navy in Tamaulipas, leading security analysts to warn of possible violence resulting from the power vacuum.

headline: In the Bowels of the City, Blocking Wastewater Overflows
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Levees and Dams']
abstract: New York City has embraced unusual technology to reduce overflows of raw sewage into New York Harbor during a major rainfall: two inflatable dams costing $15.7 million.
lead_paragraph: It happens dozens of times a year, undermining water quality, closing beaches and endangering aquatic life: Hit by major rainfall, New York’s sewers release raw sewage and polluted storm water into New York Harbor. These “overflow events” account for an estimated 27 billion gallons of pollutants annually in the city’s waters.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 15, 2012.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Lonely Redemption
abstract: For years Sandy Lewis has railed against Wall Street’s deceit. But vindication isn’t sweet.
lead_paragraph: ESSEX, N.Y. — Striding barefoot through the fields of his farm in the Adirondacks, S. B. Lewis, known as Sandy, is talking without pause, gesturing this way and that in a soft summer rain.

headline: Seeking Chic, Brilliant Intern to Thread Needles (No Pay)
abstract: Many unpaid jobs in the fashion and magazine industries perpetuate inequality and may violate labor laws.
lead_paragraph: In February, Xuedan Wang, a 2010 graduate of Ohio University, received modest attention after she filed a lawsuit against the Hearst Corporation claiming that the company violated labor laws when it did not pay her for the work she had done as an intern at Harper’s Bazaar, one of its magazines, over four months last year. Speaking to New York magazine last week, on the occasion of Fashion Week, Ms. Wang, who goes by Diana, explained that she had spent more than half of her life dreaming of Bazaar and approximately 12 months working at a pharmaceutical company in Columbus in order to save enough money to realize her Manhattan vision.

headline: Billboards Protecting Their Heads
abstract: Dr. Marcus M. Reidenberg, 78, has for a few years been engaged in an ongoing photographic project: documenting the uniquely decorated hard hats of welders, carpenters, bricklayers and others around New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Marcus M. Reidenberg, 78, has for a few years been engaged in an ongoing photographic project: documenting the uniquely decorated hard hats of welders, carpenters, bricklayers and others around New York.

headline: Sid Watkins, Safety Innovator in Formula One Racing, Dies at 84
abstract: Dr. Watkins is credited with helping to save lives through methods on and off the track.
lead_paragraph: Formula One racing is one of the world’s fastest motorsports, and in the 1970s it was one of the most dangerous. Fiery crashes occurred so frequently that drivers were often seriously injured or killed.

headline: A Comedian and a Cardinal Open Up on Spirituality
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Religion and Belief', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The comedian Stephen Colbert and Cardinal Timothy Dolan of New York spoke at Fordham University, sharing how joy and humor infuse their spiritual lives.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Stephen Colbert and Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York bantered onstage Friday night before 3,000 cheering, stomping, chanting students at Fordham University, in what might have been the most successful Roman Catholic youth evangelization event since Pope John Paul II last appeared at World Youth Day.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: A man suspected of helping to plot the 1999 hijacking of an Indian civilian aircraft, Indian Airlines Flight 814, was arrested by the police Thursday in the Kishtwar district of the state, IBN Live Web site reported. Mehrajuddin Dand, who is in police custody for four days, admitted to working with the organized-crime boss Dawood Ibrahim, who is one of the most wanted men in India, the report said, quoting unnamed sources.

headline: Beginning a Journey That Could Make Family History
abstract: Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a student at Topeka High School in Kansas, is one of eight high school seniors around the world who are blogging about their college searches.
lead_paragraph: My full name is Leobardo Espinoza Jr., but everyone here calls me Leo. It’s shorter to say and easier for everyone to understand. I was born in California and moved to Topeka, Kan., when I was in the sixth grade.

abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the weekly addresses and the latest happenings in Washington.

headline: Sept. 14: Obama Forecast Declines on Poor Manufacturing Report

lead_paragraph: President Obama’s odds of winning the Electoral College fell for the second consecutive day on Friday according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast. His chances of winning the Electoral College are now listed at 76.2 percent, down from 78.6 percent in Thursday’s forecast.

headline: Morocco Emerges as Key U.S. Ally in Troubled Region
abstract: In the face of the latest upsurge of anti-American feeling in the Middle East, the U.S. is short of reliable local allies. As Washington continues to wrestle with the consequences of the Arab Spring, Morocco has emerged as an island of stability in a sea of troubles.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anti-American protests that have spread across the Arab world are overshadowing Washington’s latest steps to cement its ties with one of its closest allies in the region, Morocco.

headline: Small Business Health Insurance: Costs Still Going Up
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: For many, the real impact of the Affordable Care Act, should it survive, is still two years away.
lead_paragraph: The news for small businesses — not particularly surprising and not particularly good — in the Kaiser Family Foundation’s latest study of employer-sponsored health insurance is that the trend lines are unchanged. Costs continue to go up, and the number of companies offering insurance does not.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s opposition movement drew tens of thousands to another large anti-Putin demonstration on Saturday, sending the message that its ranks are undaunted by a battery of new government sanctions and the two-year prison sentences handed down last month to the punk-rockers of Pussy Riot.

abstract: A new report from the Congressional Research Service finds that “changes over the past 65 years in the top marginal tax rate and the top capital gains tax rate do not appear correlated with economic growth.”
lead_paragraph: My Capital Ideas column in this week’s Sunday Review mentions a new report from the Congressional Research Service — a nonpartisan government group that provides analysis to Congress — on the relationship between tax cuts and economic growth.
