headline: House Honors Americans Killed in Attack on Consulate in Libya
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A bipartisan resolution is expected to pass through the House next week, recognizing the four Americans killed in the attack this week on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan resolution is expected to pass through the House next week, recognizing the four Americans killed in the attack this week on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya. Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the Republican leader, drafted the resolution late Friday evening, along with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the Democratic whip, to honor those killed in the attack and to condemn the anti-American violence that rippled throughout Egypt and Yemen.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Third Saturday of College Football
abstract: Reporters from The New York Times provided updates and analysis of Saturday’s college football action.
lead_paragraph: The stars remained aligned for another Saturday of college football. Paul Myerberg is in Manhattan. Tim Rohan is in East Lansing, Mich., for tonight’s game between Notre Dame and Michigan State. Ray Glier is in Fayetteville for Arkansas-Alabama. Stick around for updates and analysis.

headline: Forward Passing, Behind the Back
abstract: A Chicago Bears quarterback known as Bull, John Doehring could fling the ball behind his back more than half the length of the field.
lead_paragraph: It has always amazed me how little literary attention has been paid to professional football’s early days. Baseball historians have put the game under a microscope. There is probably a book out there that will tell you what Babe Ruth ate for breakfast on the day he swatted his 714th home run. The story of the N.F.L.’s formative years, on the other hand, is still largely untold.

headline: For a 2011 Draft Pick, the Sitting and Fretting Could Finally Be Over
abstract: Marvin Austin, an injury-plagued defensive tackle drafted in the second round in 2011, could play his first regular-season N.F.L. game on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Marvin Austin thought about it. How could he not? As the days and weeks and months went by, Austin, the Giants defensive tackle who was drafted in the second round in 2011 but has not played an N.F.L. regular-season snap, could not help wondering if his professional career might end before it ever began.

headline: Take the Bus, and Watch the New Ideas Flow
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Jarrod Moses of United Entertainment Group says he and his colleagues travel by bus to meetings around the country. It builds trust and gets the creative juices flowing.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Jarrod Moses, founder and chief executive of the United Entertainment Group, a marketing agency, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A Player’s Concussion, a Family’s Ordeal
abstract: Mitch White, a former N.F.L. player, must learn to adjust his life to the effects of a brain injury. He joins more than 3,000 players suing the N.F.L. over concussions.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Mitch White watched football last Sunday, a framed New Orleans Saints jersey mounted on a wall over his shoulder at his home. White watches football differently from most people. He likes to analyze the offensive line, fitting for a tackle out of Oregon State who was a sixth-round draft pick of the Saints in 2001. And on most days, around the hour the early games reach halftime, White needs to lie down for a nap.

headline: New International Envoy, Meeting With Syrian President, Says Crisis Is Worsening
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Lakhdar Brahimi, the special envoy representing the United Nations and the Arab League, said President Bashar al-Assad was “more aware than me of the scope and the seriousness of the crisis.”
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The new United Nations peace envoy to Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, said after a meeting with President Bashar al-Assad on Saturday that the civil war held consequences for “the region, and the whole world,” while acknowledging that he had not yet formulated a plan to address the escalating violence.

headline: On the Sideline, the Jets’ Odd Couple Coach Alike and Think Alike
abstract: The Jets coaches Rex Ryan and Mike Westhoff are united by a vision, an obsession with winning.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Two football coaches go shark fishing off the coast of Florida. One is Rex Ryan, the other is Mike Westhoff. They sit on Westhoff’s boat for hours, sharing laughs while casting lures, but the sharks are not biting. They catch nothing. Well, almost nothing.

headline: South Africa Raids Homes for Weapons of Miners
abstract: Police officers swarmed the living quarters of workers at a platinum mine, searching for illegal weapons as part of a new government push to end a series of violent strikes.
lead_paragraph: CALITZDORP, South Africa — Hundreds of police officers swarmed the living quarters of workers at a platinum mine 60 miles northwest of here on Saturday, searching for illegal weapons as part of a new push by the government to end a series of violent wildcat strikes that have unsettled the nation.

headline: Mira Nair’s ‘Reluctant Fundamentalist’
abstract: The director Mira Nair discusses her latest film, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist.”
lead_paragraph: The director Mira Nair discusses her latest film, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist.”

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Sharpen your pencils for Split Decisions.
lead_paragraph: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Many people look forward to the Split Decisions puzzles, and it’s really a shame that they don’t come along more often.

headline: Pope Makes Plea for Religious Freedom
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI, speaking in Lebanon amid a wave of violence across the Muslim world, said religious freedom was fundamental to stability.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday implored young Christians not to emigrate from Lebanon, saying they were “meant to be protagonists” as the country moved forward, and urging them to forge closer bonds with Muslim youth.

headline: A Wide-Open Field, and the Nascar Chase Is On
abstract: This season’s playoff field is as unpredictable as any, with no dominant driver through the regular season and with a few surprise entries in the mix.
lead_paragraph: The Nascar driver Jeff Gordon vowed to grow a mustache if he managed to climb from deep in the standings to earn a berth in this year’s Chase for the Sprint Cup. After he eked out the final spot in the 12-car field in the last race of the regular season, Gordon’s stubble is showing heading into Sunday’s playoff opener at Chicagoland Speedway.

headline: Fundamentals From Mira Nair
abstract: Mira Nair discusses her film “The Reluctant Fundamentalist” at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The director Mira Nair has  comedies, multicultural dramas and period pieces in her filmography, but she hadn’t tackled the thriller genre until now. Her latest film, “The Reluctant Fundamentalist,” opened at the Venice Film Festival before playing here in a gala presentation. It was acquired by IFC Films this week for distribution. An adaptation of of Mohsin Hamid’s novel, the film follows a young Pakistani man (Riz Ahmed) who goes to the United States to pursue the American dream. But after the 9/11 attacks, the way he is perceived in the country, and subsequently the way he perceives the country, shifts. In the video above, Ms. Nair, who hails from India, speaks about the film and ways she hopes its subject will create both a dialogue and a bridge of understanding between the United States and Pakistan.

headline: No Deal in N.H.L. Dispute as Lockout Deadline Passes
abstract: Though the league did not make an announcement after the deadline, which was midnight, it was presumed that the league had shut down.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of fitful negotiations, rejected offers and prickly rhetoric, the deadline for the N.H.L. to avoid a lockout passed without a resolution.

headline: Man Linked to Film in Protests Is Questioned
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Nakoula Basseley Nakoula, one of the men behind the anti-Muslim film trailer that has sparked violent protests, was taken in for questioning by federal probation officers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of the men behind the anti-Muslim film trailer on YouTube that has set off violent protests at Western embassies across the Middle East was taken in for questioning by federal probation officers early Saturday morning, law enforcement officials said.

headline: U.S. Is Preparing for a Long Siege of Arab Unrest
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Arab world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After days of anti-American violence across the Muslim world, the White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Middle East.

headline: A U.S. Envoy Who Plunged Into Arab Life
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: J. Christopher Stevens, who was killed at a diplomatic mission in Libya, had an affection for Arab culture and street life that made him many friends and contacts.
lead_paragraph: J. Christopher Stevens, the American ambassador to Libya who was killed in an assault on a diplomatic mission there last week, was happy to gossip, but was revered for listening. A northern Californian with a toothy grin, he had a passion for the Arab world and its language, and he went out of his way to use it, whether with officials or shopkeepers, in an effort to show respect.

headline: Now, Wie Seeking to Be First on the Leader Board
abstract: Michelle Wie, who started a wave of teenage stars on the women’s tour, now wants to be known as a champion golfer. She’s at plus-1 after 36 holes at the Women’s British Open.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — With no golf to occupy her, Michelle Wie went shopping Friday in Liverpool and bought two pairs of pants. Not unlike other labels she has acquired, one pair did not fit.

headline: A Chinese Leader Returns Amid Tumult
abstract: Xi Jinping reappeared on Saturday as diplomatic tensions boiled over, with hundreds of demonstrators throwing rocks and eggs at the Japanese Embassy in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The reappearance on Saturday of Xi Jinping, a top Chinese leader who had vanished from public view, removes one question mark facing the Communist Party, but a wave of protests against Japan is a sign that internal power struggles are far from over.

headline: Kendrick, Phillies Handyman, Sparks Playoff Push as Starter
abstract: Kyle Kendrick, a pitching handyman since 2007, became a regular starter in August and sparked a Phillies playoff push.
lead_paragraph: The end of July had been so seismic for the Philadelphia Phillies that it was easy to miss their first trade of August. By then, they had already traded two veteran outfielders, Shane Victorino and Hunter Pence, and re-signed an ace starter, Cole Hamels, for six years. They were rebuilding for the future and recommitting to their present, all at once.

headline: Finding What Needs Fixing
abstract: The chief of DJO Global, a medical device company, says that throughout his career, he’s often found situations that need fixing, and raised his hand to solve them.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was in seventh grade, my father sold his word processing company in Washington, D.C. My parents always wanted to live on a boat in retirement, and I was the last child at home, so it was feasible.

headline: In Britain, a Stunner of a Summer, Quite
abstract: Andy Murray’s victory in the United States Open capped a summer of accomplishment for British athletes, from tennis to the London Games to the golf course.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — British sports are in the midst of a glorious Indian summer, the tennis player Andy Murray’s victory in the United States Open final taking place on the same day Britain’s 65 Olympic medalists and 120 Paralympic medalists were honored in a London parade. Then the best golfers in the world descended on Royal Liverpool Golf Club for the Women’s British Open, the year’s final major.

headline: How to Solve a Career Cliffhanger
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Soap Operas', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: A former soap-opera writer finds a new line of work — as a writing coach for high school students applying to colleges.
lead_paragraph: THE numbers didn’t add up: Ten years of writing soap operas on network television. Four Emmy Awards. One Writers Guild Award for script of the year. Then four months out of work. And zero job offers.

headline: With the Crowds Gone, It’s Down to Serious Fishing
abstract: The annual Striped Bass and Bluefish Derby knits a Martha’s Vineyard town of 15,000 back together after its residents live among a summer population swelling to 105,000.
lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — Striped bass are nocturnal, and every year at this time, Kathi Pogoda becomes nocturnal too.

headline: Texas Tech Confronts Coaching Turbulence

lead_paragraph: Kirby Hocutt’s first major public appearance as the athletic director of Texas Tech in March 2011 was to introduce the men’s basketball coach, Billy Gillispie.

headline: After Injury, Beard Embraces New Outlook, and Team
abstract: In 2010, Alana Beard sustained what could have been a career-ending injury. Two years later, she is with the playoff-bound Los Angeles Sparks.
lead_paragraph: During Alana Beard’s pregame introduction and after every basket she made, the crowd at Verizon Center in Washington cheered.

headline: 30 Seconds With Dwyane Wade
abstract: The Miami Heat star discusses his new memoir, his team’s chances of repeating as N.B.A. champion, losing sleep and other topics.
lead_paragraph: Dwyane Wade, a seven-time N.B.A. All-Star, has won two championships with the Miami Heat and an Olympic gold medal. But he wants the top of his résumé to read like the title of his new memoir, “A Father First: How My Life Became Bigger Than Basketball.”

headline: Some Republicans Try Out a New Campaign Theme: Bipartisanship
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Political Advertising', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Getting the blame for gridlock has prompted a different approach for some candidates as Election Day draws near.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A woman who appears in an advertisement supporting Representative Jon Runyan, a New Jersey Republican, boasts about how he works “with both parties.”

headline: Padres to Honor Jerry Coleman
abstract: The Milwaukee Brewers unveiled a statue of their longtime radio voice on Aug. 31, and now the San Diego Padres are doing the same. The Brewers honored Bob Uecker, and the Padres planned to honor Jerry Coleman on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The Milwaukee Brewers unveiled a statue of their longtime radio voice on Aug. 31, and now the San Diego Padres are doing the same. The Brewers honored Bob Uecker, and the Padres planned to honor Jerry Coleman on Saturday.

headline: Forgoing College to Pursue Dreams
abstract: Thiel Fellowships pay young people to forgo college and to plunge into real-world projects. So what has become of those who managed to snag fellowships?
lead_paragraph: EDEN FULL should be back at Princeton by now. She should be hustling to class, hitting the books, acing tests. In short, she should be climbing that old-school ladder toward a coveted spot among America’s future elite.

headline: Death at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The case of a Yemeni citizen, who was held in the American prison in Cuba for years yet never charged with a crime, is a disgrace to the United States government.
lead_paragraph: Adnan Farhan Abdul Latif, a Yemeni citizen and one of the first detainees sent to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in January 2002, died there earlier this month. There is no official autopsy report yet, but in his decade in prison he had gone on hunger strikes and made several suicide attempts.

headline: In Dueling Ads, Candidates Seek to Politicize Issues of China and Manufacturing
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Political Advertising', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: United States-China relations continue to surface as an issue on the campaign trail, particularly in battleground states like Ohio where manufacturing is a major force in the local economy.
lead_paragraph: United States-China relations continue to surface as an issue on the campaign trail, particularly in battleground states like Ohio where manufacturing is a major force in the local economy. Now both President Obama and Mitt Romney are running television commercials that trade accusations over who is softer on China, and who is more to blame for sending American jobs there.

headline: Role-Playing at the Range, Bin Laden in Their Sights
abstract: The Sealed Mindset gun range in suburban Minneapolis offers the pricey role-playing experience of killing Osama bin Laden.
lead_paragraph: NEW HOPE, Minn. — Gripping a modified AR-15 assault rifle, Nathan Schneider threw open a bedroom door and crossed the threshold, his barrel blazing as a man dressed like Osama bin Laden fell motionless on the floor.

headline: European Bank Overhaul Meets Opposition From Finance Ministers
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A plan by the European Union to overhaul bank supervision and help troubled lenders hit a roadblock at a meeting of finance ministers.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — A plan by the European Union to overhaul bank supervision and help troubled lenders directly ran into a wall of opposition on Saturday as finance ministers from major nations like Germany, Poland and Sweden raised objections.

headline: Keeping Score: Steals Drought Unlikely to End Soon
abstract: Billy Hamilton, a shortstop in the Reds minor league system, thrilled the baseball world this season by stealing 155 bases this season. But stolen bases are largely a thing of the past.
lead_paragraph: Billy Hamilton, a shortstop in the Reds minor league system, thrilled the baseball world this season by stealing 155 bases, a professional record. But as exciting as his play was, there remains the question of how he would fit in the majors now that stolen bases are largely a thing of the past.

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The scheduled execution of a convicted murderer has prompted pleas for clemency from thousands of people who argue that he should be spared because he had been sexually abused by his victim.

headline: Tucson Schools Overhaul a Program to Help Struggling Hispanic Students
abstract: The new Mexican-American Student Services program also aims to mend fences broken in the acrimony over the dismantling of the Mexican-American studies department last school year.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — The forecast for the year ahead is dire, so officials in the public school district here, the oldest in the state, summoned parents to an urgent meeting one evening to lay out the options: close schools and increase class sizes or impose across-the-board pay cuts, making it harder for the district to recruit quality teachers.

headline: It’s Not About the Video

abstract: The unrest in the Islamic world is more about power politics than blasphemy.
lead_paragraph: THE greatest mistake to be made right now, with our embassies under assault and crowds chanting anti-American slogans across North Africa and the Middle East, is to believe that what’s happening is a completely genuine popular backlash against a blasphemous anti-Islamic video made right here in the U.S.A.

headline: Scandal Poses a Riddle: Will India Ever Be Able to Tackle Corruption?
abstract: A brazen brand of crony capitalism has created huge fortunes for a few, at the expense of the nation as a whole, which is falling short in energy infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — His business rivals never fully understood how Manoj Jayaswal got so rich so fast, except that he often seemed joined at the hip with powerful politicians. He hosted them at lavish parties, entertained them at his daughter’s opulent Thai wedding and stood among them at India’s presidential palace, where a year ago he was praised as a leader in the India growth story.

headline: The Foreign Relations Fumbler
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: If Mitt Romney keeps misfiring on foreign policy, he’s going to blow up his presidential credentials.
lead_paragraph: DIPLOMACY is a minefield, and Mitt Romney spent the last week blowing up his foreign policy credentials to be president. He raised doubts about his capacity to deal with global crises, and we were left hoping that if that 3 a.m. call ever went to him, he’d have set up call forwarding.

headline: Young Lives, Lost in the Fog of War
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Children and Childhood', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Indiscriminate suicide bombings are robbing Afghanistan’s children of their dreams.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — These days, Abdul Farhad tries to sleep with the lights on in his bedroom and his eyes wide open, because as soon as he closes them he is back in his shop in central Kabul and it is 11:30 a.m. on the eighth of September.

headline: Sometimes, a Candidate Is Meant to Look Plastic
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Those cashing in on the Republican and Democratic conventions included vendors selling pins, T-shirts and dolls. Will saving these trifles make anyone rich in the future?
lead_paragraph: Those cashing in on the Republican and Democratic conventions included vendors selling pins, T-shirts and dolls. Will saving these trifles make anyone rich in the future?

headline: Afghans Act to Fill Top Security Posts
abstract: Afghan lawmakers approved all three of President Hamid Karzai’s nominees for the government’s top security jobs on Saturday, avoiding a prolonged power vacuum.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan lawmakers approved all three of the president’s nominees for the government’s top security jobs on Saturday, avoiding a prolonged power vacuum as the country confronted multiple reminders of the fragility of its security.

headline: World Hunger: The Problem Left Behind
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Food', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Fertilizer', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Economic gains in many sectors have yet to solve the problem of feeding the world. In Africa alone, government policies and fertilizer costs are inhibiting agricultural progress.
lead_paragraph: THE drought-induced run-up in corn prices is a reminder that we’re nowhere near solving the problem of feeding the world. The price surge, the third major international food price spike in the last five years, casts more doubt on the assumption that widespread economic development leads to corresponding gains in agriculture.

headline: G.M.O.’s: Let’s Label ’Em
abstract: In November, California will vote on labeling genetically modified organisms. The implications of passage will reverberate throughout the food world.
lead_paragraph: IT’S not an exaggeration to say that almost everyone wants to see the labeling of genetically engineered materials contained in their food products. And on Nov. 6, in what’s unquestionably among the most important non-national votes this year, Californians will have the opportunity to make that happen — at least in theory — by weighing in on Proposition 37.

headline: Berlusconi Magazine to Publish Duchess Photos
abstract: The images of Kate Middleton sunbathing topless first appeared in the French magazine Closer, which is also owned by former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s Mondadori group.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An Italian magazine owned by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi announced Saturday that it planned to publish photographs of the former Kate Middleton, the Duchess of Cambridge, sunbathing topless, just as its sister French magazine did on Friday.

headline: The Road to Retirement
keywords: ['Retirement', 'United States Economy', 'Social Security (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Editorials']
abstract: The recession and its aftermath spell insecurity and hardship for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Even before the Great Recession, Americans were not saving enough, if anything, for retirement, and policy experts were warning of a looming catastrophe. The economic downturn and its consequences — including losses in jobs, income, investments and home equity — have made that bad situation much worse.

headline: Kick-Starts From a Phone and the Fed
abstract: The economy could benefit from two very different events last week: the announcement of the Federal Reserve’s latest bond-buying plan and Apple’s introduction of the iPhone 5.
lead_paragraph: HELP for the beleaguered economy came last week from two powerhouses: the Federal Reserve and ... Apple.

headline: Surviving the Pain at the Roots
abstract: My life was full of trauma and abuse, but pulling the hair from my body made me feel calm and safe.
lead_paragraph: I came out of the womb scratching. Mitts had to be put on my hands so I would stop clawing my skin. When I was seven and got mad I would bite myself, raising welts on my arms. This was already well into the time when I would have to touch certain spots on the cabinets, on the sidewalk, with my fingers and toes. At 12, after a seriously traumatic event, I began to pull out my hair. Every day since then, for the past 18 years, the hairs on my body have gone one by one, in the thousands, as I have tried to cope with overwhelming anxiety from a chaotic series of experiences that from birth have made me feel inside as if my very life is at stake if I do not pick and pull and bite and scratch.

headline: In Britain, One Player Blows Away the Field
abstract: Jiyai Shin of South Korea held a five-stroke lead after 36 holes of the Women’s British Open in Hoylake, England.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — Fairways as narrow as tongue depressors did not much bother Jiyai Shin, who hit all but one Saturday during the delayed second round of the Women’s British Open. Royal Liverpool Golf Club’s humpback greens were no worry, either; Shin did not miss any en route to a masterly eight-under-par 64, which left her at minus nine at the tournament’s halfway point.

headline: Mitt Romney and Foreign Policy
abstract: Readers comment on my column about Romney’s lapses on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column argues that Mitt Romney’s foreign policy lapses last week are indicative of a larger problem: This is a world he doesn’t get, or gets wrong. Romney has clearly thought a good deal about domestic issues in the six years he’s been studying to be president, but there’s not much indication of interest or expertise in foreign affairs. And that’s putting it mildly.

headline: Don’t Show Me the Money!
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: What happened to the tacit social prohibition against talking about money?
lead_paragraph: THESPIAN friends perform “The Seagull” in their garden. Only minutes into the first act, a lovely young woman named Masha, sick of hearing the lovesick schoolteacher Medvedenko whine about his penury, blurts out, “All you ever do is talk and talk about money.” That’s when it dawns on me: I’m sick of the subject, too. For the rest of Act I, I find myself ruminating about the glut of financial data that daily clogs the news: Libor and MF Global Holdings; HSBC’s money-laundering of Mexican drug-cartel money; “the London Whale” whose huge trades cost J.P. Morgan Chase billions; leveraged buyouts and mortgage-backed securities and derivatives and stimulus packages, Bain Capital and the tottering euro and the Greek bailout. Saul Bellow referred to this quotidian fretting about world affairs as “crisis chatter.” Today’s crises are all about what is euphemistically called “the financial services industry” — that is to say, they’re all about money.

keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Mobile Applications']

lead_paragraph: AT two inches wide and one-third of an inch tall, a display ad shown on a smartphone isn’t much of a canvas for a creative marketer seeking to promote a product or service.

headline: For India’s Children, Philanthropy Isn’t Enough
abstract: Even a generous donor cannot save the children of one Indian family from poverty.
lead_paragraph: MEENA DEVI is only 10 years old, but she’s the head of her household. She cooks, cleans and takes care of her 11-year-old brother, Sunil, while a 14-year-old brother, Anil, works at a faraway brick kiln in a neighboring state. The three have been orphans since their mother died of starvation three years ago. They have an aunt in their village, but the most she’s ever done is send over food to their mud hut.

abstract: The Giants talk often about wanting to (finally) get their running game going, but this might not be the week it happens.

headline: An Adverb That Defies Certainty
abstract: The word ‘almost’ is like blush after makeup, just that requisite fuzziness, like ambiguity in an instance of total candor.

headline: Thousands Attend Rally for Chicago Teachers as Union Nears Contract
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Strikes', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Organized Labor', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The gathering was the largest show of union force since the strike began, even as negotiations continued and schools were expected to reopen on Monday.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As union and school board lawyers toiled in private here on Saturday to finish a contract that could soon lift the first teacher strike this city has seen in 25 years, a rally — not quite victory party, not quite vitriolic protest — was roaring just miles away.

headline: The Computer as Music Critic
abstract: Was pop music better, back in the day? Computers weigh in.
lead_paragraph: THANKS to advances in computing power, we can analyze music in radically new and different ways. Computers are still far from grasping some of the deep and often unexpected nuances that release our most intimate emotions. However, by processing vast amounts of raw data and performing unprecedented large-scale analyses beyond the reach of teams of human experts, they can provide valuable insight into some of the most basic aspects of musical discourse, including the evolution of popular music over the years. Has there been an evolution? Can we measure it? And if so, what do we observe?

headline: At Rally, Elizabeth Warren Takes More Aggressive Stance
abstract: Elizabeth Warren, campaigning for Senate in Massachusetts, attacks the votes of the incumbent, Scott P. Brown, a Republican.
lead_paragraph: 9:35 a.m. | Updated BOSTON — During a rally on Saturday, Elizabeth Warren questioned the record and credibility of Senator Scott P. Brown, energizing a crowd of more than 700 people as the Senate race in Massachusetts turned more aggressive and pointed.

abstract: The journalistic practice of giving equal weight to both sides of a story, regardless of any established truth, has many readers fed up.

headline: Obama Ad Tries to Answer: Are You Better Off Than Four Years Ago?
abstract: Recent polls have shown that more Americans feel that they are not better off. But President Obama is telling them that they are.
lead_paragraph: A new ad from President Obama confronts head on one of the most potentially damaging questions lingering over his re-election hopes: Are you better off than you were four years ago?

headline: Dear Bankers: Thanks for Wrecking Our Lives ...
abstract: On the anniversary of Occupy Wall Street’s encampment at Zuccotti Park, excerpts of letters to bank executives.
lead_paragraph: TOMORROW is the first anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement’s encampment at Zuccotti Park. Some of the protesters there created a Web site for Americans who couldn’t join them in Lower Manhattan. Called Occupy the Boardroom, the site invited people across the country to write detailed letters to the executives and directors of banks. The site’s developers promised to deliver them as e-mail and in person.

headline: Ed Hochuli
abstract: The locked-out N.F.L. referee Ed Hochuli on football rules, science fiction and “Sons of Anarchy.”
lead_paragraph: Ed Hochuli is a trial lawyer and one of the 121 referees the N.F.L. has locked out of work because of disputes over pay and pensions. Known for his bodybuilder biceps, he was the model for the official in the Madden N.F.L. video games. After some  replacement referees’ blunders in season-opener games, fans are calling for his and his colleagues’ swift return.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Discrimination', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Editorials']
abstract: As the first anniversary of the repeal of “don’t ask, don’t tell” approaches, it is clear that there have been no disastrous consequences.
lead_paragraph: As the country approaches the first anniversary of the repeal of “don’t ask, don’t tell” on Sept. 20, politicians and others who warned of disastrous consequences if gay people were allowed to serve openly in the military are looking pretty foolish.

headline: Must Great Leaders Be Gregarious?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The ability to lead depends on vision, not beer drinking, schmoozing or other social skills.
lead_paragraph: DISTANT. Aloof. Concealed inside “a layer of self-protective ice,” as Jonathan Alter put it. President Obama has been roundly criticized for his introverted personality.

headline: Don’t Tell Anyone, but the Stimulus Worked
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy']
abstract: With Democrats too timid to utter the word “stimulus,” most Americans don’t realize how much they were been helped by the law.
lead_paragraph: Republicans howled on Thursday when the Federal Reserve, at long last, took steps to energize the economy. Some were furious at the thought that even a little economic boost might work to benefit President Obama just before an election. “It is going to sow some growth in the economy,” said Raul Labrador, a freshman Tea Party congressman from Idaho, “and the Obama administration is going to claim credit.”

headline: The Power of Political Communion
abstract: Democrats need to reclaim the spiritual tradition of liberal Catholicism.
lead_paragraph: AS the 2012 presidential race enters the homestretch, both parties vow that this election is not just a choice between different policies. It is a cosmic decision between “two different visions, two different value sets,” as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told delegates at the Democratic National Convention. Behind the competing catchphrases lurks another contest, one that illuminates this war of worldviews. It is a tale of two Catholicisms.

headline: An Annual Ritual on Martha’s Vineyard
abstract: With the summer crowds gone, the Massachusetts island starts its 67th annual Striped Bass and Bluefish Derby, which draws hundreds, if not thousands, of competitors.
lead_paragraph: With the summer crowds gone, the Massachusetts island starts its 67th annual Striped Bass and Bluefish Derby, which draws hundreds, if not thousands, of competitors.

abstract: In exchange for a fee, district attorneys’ offices have been allowing debt collectors to use their letterhead when going after people behind on their bills.
lead_paragraph: The letters are sent by the thousands to people across the country who have written bad checks, threatening them with jail if they do not pay up.

abstract: The man, an American citizen, expressed interest online in carrying out a deadly attack, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old suburban Chicago man, who the authorities say was enamored with Osama bin Laden and intent on killing Americans, has been arrested after attempting to detonate what he thought was a car bomb outside a Chicago bar, officials said Saturday.

headline: Harvard Wins Opener, but Scandal Spoils Mood
abstract: Weeks after several athletes were accused in a large-scale cheating scandal, Harvard won its season opener by defeating San Diego, 28-13.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The 139th season of Harvard football opened with a first-time matchup and a major academic scandal overshadowing the university, its defending Ivy League champion football team and its N.C.A.A.-high 40 other varsity sports teams.

headline: Attack by Fringe Group Highlights the Problem of Libya’s Militias
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: Ansar al-Shariah, the brigade of rebel fighters that witnesses say led the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, holds that democracy is incompatible with Islam.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Ansar al-Shariah, the brigade of rebel fighters that witnesses say led the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, holds that democracy is incompatible with Islam. It has paraded the streets with weapons calling for an Islamic state, and a few months ago its leader boasted publicly that its fighters could flatten a foreign consulate.

headline: Yankees Beat Rays to Keep Pace in East
abstract: Ivan Nova pitched six solid innings, a positive sign for the Yankees in a disappointing season for him, and earned his first win since Aug. 11.
lead_paragraph: In the Yankees’ clubhouse on Friday, Ivan Nova fidgeted. He said he felt restless and anxious, believing he had more to prove in his rocky season.

headline: Challenged on Medicare, G.O.P. Loses Ground
abstract: President Obama and his campaign are arguing that the Romney-Ryan approach to Medicare would leave older Americans vulnerable to rising health care costs.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Maria Rubin is one of the coveted independent voters in this swing state — so independent that she will not say whether she is voting for President Obama or Mitt Romney. She does share her age (63) and, more quickly, her opinion on Medicare: “I’m not in favor of changing it, or eliminating it.”

headline: Rays Pitcher Wins Expectations Game
abstract: Fernando Rodney, a relief pitcher for Tampa Bay, has put up impressive career numbers — 43 saves and a 0.66 earned run average — to the delight of Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: The cap on Fernando Rodney’s head — perpetually tilted, ever off-kilter — has been about the only thing askew for him this season.

headline: Jerome Kilty, Who Made a Career of Interpreting Shaw, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Kilty was best known for “Dear Liar,” a play based on letters between George Bernard Shaw and Mrs. Patrick Campbell.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Kilty, an actor and playwright known for writing epistolary dramas — most notably “Dear Liar,” his adaptation of 40 years of amorous correspondence between George Bernard Shaw and one of the London theater’s most temperamental actresses — died on Sept. 6 in Norwalk, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Several Arrests at Occupy Wall Street March
abstract: The police arrested several of the roughly 250 people who marched toward Zuccotti Park in the first of three days of events for the one-year anniversary of the movement.
lead_paragraph: On the first of three days of events planned for the one-year anniversary of Occupy Wall Street, about 250 people marched down Broadway from Washington Square toward Zuccotti Park, accompanied by a large number of police officers on foot, in marked and unmarked cars, and riding scooters.

headline: Michael Wreszin, Biographer of American Radicals, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Wreszin wrote biographies of Dwight Macdonald and other American antiwar activists.
lead_paragraph: Michael Wreszin, a biographer of radical 20th-century American intellectuals who were prominent antiwar activists, among them the social critic Dwight Macdonald, died on Aug. 12 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Tide Put Beating on Razorbacks; So Do Razorbacks
abstract: Playing without their starting quarterback, Tyler Wilson, Arkansas was shut out by No. 1 Alabama, adding to the turmoil surrounding the Razorbacks’ program.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — Tyler Wilson, Arkansas’s No. 1 quarterback, marched into the auditorium where the Razorbacks hold their postgame news conferences still in his shoulder pads and still wearing his No. 8 jersey. He did not play in Saturday’s humiliating 52-0 loss to No. 1 Alabama because of a concussion, but he had plenty to say in a 67-second rant.

headline: A First: Organs Tailor-Made With Body’s Own Cells
abstract: Tissue engineers have succeeded in making artificial organs that use a patient’s cells to become a living part of the body, with hope for eventual organ regeneration.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Andemariam Beyene sat by the hospital window, the low Arctic sun on his face, and talked about the time he thought he would die.

headline: Struggling at Plate Since Injury to Head
abstract: Mets Manager Terry Collins suggested Wednesday that Jason Bay, whose average was the worst of any position player with 100 at-bats, might still be feeling the effects of two concussions.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — There are moments, Mets Manager Terry Collins said, when Jason Bay swings a bat like the dangerous hitter he used to be. The grand slam Bay drove to right-center in Miami off Mark Buehrle on Sept. 2, igniting a Mets victory, was one of those moments.

headline: Tony Goldman, SoHo Pioneer, Dies at 68
abstract: Mr. Goldman was a real estate visionary who saw himself as a long-term investor in the revitalization of historic neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Tony Goldman, whose investor’s eye for spotting battered neighborhoods prime for rejuvenation led him to help revive SoHo in Manhattan in the 1970s and South Beach in Florida in the ’80s, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 68.

headline: World’s No. 2 Player Leads Armenia to a Gold Medal
abstract: When Armenia’s team returned home from the Chess Olympiad, its members were greeted by the president and treated to a parade in the capital.
lead_paragraph: Eastern Europeans have dominated chess for decades, and one reason may be that they come from countries where the average citizen is simply more passionate about the game.

headline: A Gentle Giant Stays Behind
abstract: The many sacrifices of Algernon Squier, a towering Civil War hospital steward.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 15, 1862, Gen. Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson and his Confederates trapped the 12,700-man federal garrison in Harpers Ferry, Va. “We were as helpless as rats in a cage,” moaned one Union soldier. The federal commander, Col. Dixon S. Miles, had little choice but to surrender. Moments after the decision, the explosion of a stray artillery shell resulted in his mortal wounding. A subordinate made the final arrangements.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Sept. 15: Waiting on Wisconsin
abstract: President Obama’s numbers in several swing states have risen, but Wisconsin, home to Paul D. Ryan, is a mystery, with no polls published there since the conventions.
lead_paragraph: Saturday was a much quieter day for polling than we’ve grown accustomed to — and the FiveThirtyEight forecast was unchanged to the decimal place, with President Obama given a 76.2 percent chance of winning the Electoral College, the same as in Friday’s forecast.

headline: College Football Replay: Sept. 15
abstract: The day in college football included an upset of No. 13 Virginia Tech and a near-upset of No. 12 Ohio State.
lead_paragraph: The day in college football included an upset of No. 13 Virginia Tech and a near-upset of No. 12 Ohio State.

headline: Giving Conservative Films a Head Start, Right Here
abstract: The success of the documentary film “2016: Obama’s America” reflects a new marketing strategy on the part of some conservative political and religious filmmakers: open in Texas first.
lead_paragraph: In assessing the box office performance of new releases, Hollywood bean counters have long considered both foreign and domestic grosses. But maybe they should add a third category: Texas.

headline: Sadler Reminds Texas Who He Was
abstract: Paul Sadler, who was once one of the most powerful Democrats in the Legislature, is running against Ted Cruz for the United States Senate.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, Representative Paul Sadler of Henderson, one of the most powerful Democrats in the Texas Legislature, announced he was not running for re-election. He was the chairman of the House Public Education Committee and a force that even the state’s governor had learned to be mindful of when it came to anything involving schools.

headline: Looks Can Be Deceptive and Lead to Surprises
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment']
abstract: The oddsmakers may believe certain November races are over, but any number of factors, from evolving voting districts to overconfidence, could lead to surprises.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Championing the Farm to Table Food Movement
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Representative Eddie Rodriguez of Austin, a Democrat, has been joined by Republicans to reduce restrictions on the local production of healthy food.
lead_paragraph: On a mission to advance the local food movement, a Democrat from Austin is finding common ground with Republicans and rural Texans.

headline: How Olajuwon Became Invested in the Knicks
abstract: Hakeem Olajuwon and the Knicks Coach Mike Woodson formed a bond when they played together for the Rockets. The two will work together to strengthen the offense of the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: Mike Woodson made a request early. Even before he knew he would be coaching the Knicks again, Woodson looked into the future. He needed help. He called Hakeem Olajuwon, his longtime friend and a Hall of Famer known for teaching fundamentals.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: Sept. 9-15
abstract: A look back at the week in politics, including reactions to an attack on the United States Consulate in Libya.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the week in politics, including reactions to an attack on the United States Consulate in Libya.

headline: In Event of Lockout, Swedish League Faces Challenge in Attempt to Bar N.H.L. Players
abstract: The Swedish Elitserien has been the only top European league to say that it will not sign N.H.L. players to short-term contracts. But Sweden’s general counsel for competition plans to challenge the ban.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish Elitserien has been the only top European league to say that it will not sign N.H.L. players to short-term contracts if the N.H.L. locks them out, as is expected to happen when the current labor deal expires at midnight Saturday. But many believe the Elitserien would have to join other leagues in welcoming N.H.L. players under contracts of any length, since the Elitserien’s contract with its players union does not include bans on short-term deals.

headline: Mejia Bunts Well and Pitches Poorly in Mets’ Loss
abstract: The Mets wanted to see how well Jenrry Mejia would pitch now that he was back in the majors. The answer on Saturday was pretty badly.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The suicide squeeze bunt that Mets pitcher Jenrry Mejia dropped down in the fourth inning Saturday night not only gave him a lead against the Milwaukee Brewers, but also gave him an odd distinction. Thirty-five games into his major league career, Mejia picked up his first major league run batted in before his first major league win.

headline: Notre Dame Makes a Statement by Stuffing Michigan State
abstract: In his third career start, Everett Golson withstood Michigan State’s defense, completed 14 of his 32 passes for 178 yards and scored two touchdowns for Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — Two years ago here, a smirking Mark Dantonio shook Brian Kelly’s hand. In Kelly’s third game as Notre Dame’s coach, Dantonio had called a fake field goal in overtime to win, beginning a two-year run that redefined Michigan State as calm, cool and clutch. After that, the Spartans won 10 of their next 11 games decided by 10 points or fewer, while Kelly’s Fighting Irish went 8-5 in each of his first two seasons as Notre Dame faltered in its seemingly endless quest to regain a place atop the college football mountain.

headline: College Football Around the Country
abstract: The good, the bad and the strange from the world of college football.
lead_paragraph: CHRIS THOMPSON The Florida State running back scored on runs of 74 and 80 yards on successive carries to lead the No. 5 Seminoles to a 52-0 victory over Wake Forest.

headline: A Conversation With: Anand Sharma
abstract: India’s minister of commerce and industry explains recent reforms.
lead_paragraph: After a week in which India’s government announced a series of controversial reforms, including raising diesel and cooking gas prices, and opening the door to foreign investors in the country’s retail, broadcast, aviation and power sectors, Anand Sharma, the minister of commerce and industry, sat down for a brief interview to explain the moves.

headline: Audacious Raid on NATO Base Shows Taliban’s Reach
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The assault late Friday on one of the best-defended posts in Afghanistan was troubling because the attackers were able to penetrate the base, killing two and causing more than $200 million in damage.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An audacious Taliban attack on a heavily fortified base in southern Afghanistan did far more damage than initially reported, destroying or severely damaging eight attack jets in the most destructive single strike on Western matériel in the 11-year war, military officials said Sunday.

headline: Letter From Bad Check Restitution Program
abstract: Thousands of letters are sent each year to people across the country who have written bad checks, threatening them with jail if they don’t pay up. They often bear the seal and signature of the local district attorney’s office but are actually from debt-collection companies.

headline: A Call From The Kremlin
abstract: Shortly after I was fired as editor for refusing to cover Vladimir Putin’s flight with cranes, my phone rang. It was the president.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Secretly I had felt that I had made Vladimir Putin up. I had spent years studying his interviews, his speeches and his ad-libbed statements, and he had come out flat and gray. Some people claimed he had a secret dimension, others said he possessed charm — I saw no evidence of it. But then, I had never talked to the man: As a journalist, I had apparently been blacklisted by the Kremlin at the very beginning of his reign — I could not even get accredited to a press conference.

headline: Russia’s Political Weekend: ‘We Will All Answer for This.’
abstract: As tens of thousands take to the streets of Moscow, a Russian MP stripped of his office repudiates Putin’s system in a rare J’accuse from the floor of the Duma, .
lead_paragraph: The anti-Putin opposition was on the streets again on Saturday in Moscow, as our colleagues Ellen Barry, David Herszenhorn, James Hill and others documented in full. One of the people they quoted, Gennady Gudkov — described by Ellen as a rumpled veteran of Russia’s post-Communist fray — was stripped of his parliamentary seat on Friday. In this video of his farewell speech, in Russia (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n8c_vqEdI0o&feature=youtu.be), he told the attentive if scant members of the Duma, Russia’s parliament, exactly what he thinks is going on behind the scenes in their country.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Confirms Addition of Nicki Minaj and Keith Urban
abstract: The two will join Mariah Carey and Randy Jackson for a level of musical firepower that reflects both the show’s continuing importance to the music business and the need to freshen its appeal with viewers.
lead_paragraph: The Fox network on Sunday morning made official the long-reported final additions to the judging lineup for “American Idol,” television’s dominant show of the past decade, and the new names were, as expected, the rap star Nicki Minaj and Keith Urban, one of the most popular singers in country music.

headline: Underwater, a Train, a Dinette and Don’t Forget the Chevy
abstract: What lies beneath New York’s waterways has not been documented with precision, but it provides grist for a new exhibition and talks at the South Street Seaport Museum.
lead_paragraph: Nicki Pombier Berger, who is listed as one of the speakers at an event called Underwater New York, is unequivocal: She is “terrified” of diving. She has never wanted an up-close-and-personal look at what she will be talking about at the South Street Seaport Museum, namely, the stuff that has piled up over time at the bottom of the Hudson River or the East River or New York Harbor — the jetsam of New York.

headline: For Both Campaigns, a Need to Control the Message
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Political Advertising', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The events in the Middle East have forced both campaigns to improvise and abandon the economic playbook they had imagined using.
lead_paragraph: There is almost nothing more valuable to a presidential campaign than controlling the message.

headline: Disruptions: Let Silicon Valley Eat … Ramen Noodles?
abstract: Silicon Valley would like the world to think it doesn’t care about money. But these start-ups aren’t nonprofit organizations.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to spend much time in Silicon Valley to start hearing that the people don’t care about money. People here are just trying to make the world a better place. Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists eat ramen noodles for dinner and drive old, clunky Hondas to work. If they do make money, that’s just a tiny cherry on top of their altruistic Tofutti soy whip sundae.That’s what people here would like the world to think. Let’s be realistic, these start-ups aren’t nonprofit organizations.

headline: Israeli Leader Says Iran Is Closer to Building a Nuclear Bomb
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, appearing on two American Sunday talk shows, reiterated that the best way to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon was to draw a “red line” that, if crossed, would trigger military intervention. He also denied that he was injecting himself into the American presidential contest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel reiterated on Sunday that the best way to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon was to draw a “red line” that, if crossed, would trigger military intervention. He also denied that he was injecting himself into one of the most divisive foreign policy issues of the American presidential campaign.

headline: Israeli Leader Makes Case Against Iran on U.S. TV
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu went on TV on Sunday to make his case about Iran even more urgently to a broader American audience.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Having been rebuffed privately by President Obama last week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took to the airwaves in the United States on Sunday to warn that Iran was only six or seven months from having “90 percent” of what it needed to make an atomic bomb.

headline: Romney Cancels Appearance After Crash
abstract: The Romney campaign cancels the candidate’s sole weekend campaign stop because of a deadly plane crash.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Mitt Romney abruptly canceled his sole campaign event on Sunday, in the swing state of Colorado, after an airplane crash at the small airport where he had been scheduled to land.

headline: ‘Resident Evil: Retribution’ Leads Box Office
abstract: But two art-house films — “The Master” and “Arbitrage” — attracted crowds in limited release.
lead_paragraph: “Resident Evil: Retribution,” the fifth installment of this video game-based series, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, while two art-house films — “The Master” and “Arbitrage” — attracted crowds in limited release, a reflection of how starved filmgoers are for sophisticated cinema.

headline: No Easy Answers on How to Fix the Banks in Europe
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Disagreements between finance ministers left open the question of how long Spain could go without outside financial assistance.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Beleaguered countries like Spain have been counting on a quick and neat way to fix their banks without taking on more crippling debt.

headline: Acne: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Replacement Official Removed From Crew for Being a Saints Fan
abstract: Brian Stropolo, a side judge scheduled to work Sunday’s Saint-Panthers game, had posted pictures of himself on his Facebook page in Saints apparel at a tailgate party during a preseason game.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. said it has been generally pleased with the performance of replacement officials. They were not pleased Sunday, however, to see one of them wearing New Orleans Saints apparel on his Facebook page — hours before he was supposed to be part of the crew at the Saints’ game against the Carolina Panthers.

headline: Earnings in United States Are Beginning to Feel a Pinch
abstract: The estimated drop in corporate profits removes what had been an economic bright spot in an otherwise cloudy picture.
lead_paragraph: The boom in American corporate profits, which has far outpaced the gains in the broader economy since the end of the last recession, is faltering.

headline: A Doctor Tied to Her Patients and the Mob
abstract: “The Mob Doctor” is Fox’s new fast-moving, medical series set in Chicago starring Jordana Spiro in the title role.
lead_paragraph: The Fox series “The Mob Doctor,” which begins on Monday night, is an odd hybrid, a medical drama merged with a Mafia morality play. It’s hard to tell from one episode how sustainable this gimmick will be, but from the pilot one thing is sure: the writers never encountered the adage “less is more.”

headline: Butterflies Roam at a Concert Hall in Infancy, Still Without a Roof
abstract: A new, unfinished hall in Williamsburg was home to classical music and butterfly-kite performance art.
lead_paragraph: You will not immediately be able to know, when it opens a little over a year from now, that there is anything very special about the Original Music Workshop. Aside from a few large windows, from the outside it will look like any of the old factory buildings scattered throughout Williamsburg.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Acne
abstract: The gladiator sandal gets a super sized makeover.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: In Connecticut, Wall Street Community May Limit Obama Victory
abstract: President Obama is almost certain to win the state’s 7 electoral votes, but by a significantly smaller margin than he did in 2008.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Connecticut, the Constitution State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Paul Bass, the editor of The New Haven Independent; Gary Rose, an associate professor of political science at Sacred Heart University; Ronald Schurin, an associate professor of political science at the University of Connecticut; and Kevin F. Rennie, a columnist for The Hartford Courant and a former Republican state senator and representative.

headline: A Little Bit of Europe Big Enough for New York
abstract: The Moving Sounds festival showcases notable European composers who are not particularly well known in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Twice on Friday night, Andreas Stadler, the director of the Austrian Cultural Forum in New York, delivered the same speech, more or less, at the Czech Center on the Upper East Side. Each time, he was welcoming an audience to a concert presented on the second night of Moving Sounds, a festival of contemporary-classical and electronic music that the forum has mounted annually since 2009.

headline: I Get Mail
abstract: Feeling depressed.
lead_paragraph: Yes, it’s a psychology journal.

headline: For Open Winner, It Only Looks Easy
abstract: Playing 36 holes on a day that ran the gamut of seasons, Jiyai Shin posted scores of 71-73 to finish at nine under par at the Women’s British Open, nine strokes ahead of her fellow South Korean Inbee Park.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — A wave that formed 35 years ago with the Japanese star Chako Higuchi’s victory in the 1977 L.P.G.A. Championship crested on the Wirral Peninsula on Sunday when Jiyai Shin of South Korea won the Women’s British Open in a rout.

headline: LeGrand,  ‘Buc for Life,’ Receives Warm Ovation Before Giants-Bucs Game
abstract: Eric LeGrand, the former Rutgers player who was paralyzed in a game against Army in 2010, was part of the coin toss for the Buccaneers before they played the Giants on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eric LeGrand might be the only person who can wear a Tampa Bay Buccaneers jersey for the coin toss at MetLife Stadium and be cheered by Giants fans.

headline: Ron Paul on Money Market Funds
abstract: What’s a fractional reserve bank, anyway?
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong has a post on Paul Ryan’s hysterical reaction to QE3, which is worth reading just for this:

headline: Heck, He’s Abandoned the Whole Austro-Hungarian Empire
abstract: Or maybe the Holy Roman Empire.
lead_paragraph: Liz Cheney Claims Obama Has “Abandoned” Czechoslovakia (Which Hasn’t Existed Since The Early ’90s).

headline: Choosing All of the Above, the Yankees Stay on Top
abstract: Russell Martin hit a three-run homer and Hiroki Kuroda pitched six effective innings in a win over the visiting Rays that kept the Yankees a game ahead of the Orioles in the American League East.
lead_paragraph: It was in Tampa Bay earlier this month that questions flared up regarding how the Yankees’ offense should play the rest of the season. Should they bunt more, as the hitting instructor Kevin Long initially advocated after a tough loss at Tropicana Field? Should they employ the small-ball tactics that Alex Rodriguez espoused a day later after a victory, or should they continue to play the way they had, slugging their way to victories as Manager Joe Girardi insisted they would?

headline: Mary Katrantzou: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: With Frantic Fourth, Manning and Giants Slip Past Bucs
abstract: The Giants scored 25 points in the fourth quarter and Eli Manning finished with 510 passing yards to offset a miserable first half in which he threw three interceptions.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants Coach Tom Coughlin’s sideline histrionics are legendary moments of football cinema. The death stares, the icy glares and the occasional (but impressive) hurling of perfectly creased play charts all dovetail nicely with Coughlin’s perpetually ruddy complexion, making for an entertaining spectacle as he upbraids his charges.

headline: Pakistanis Try to Storm U.S. Outpost; One Is Killed
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The outbreak of violence in Karachi came after days of peaceful demonstrations against the release of a video, made in America, that mocked the Prophet Muhammad.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — One person was killed and dozens of people were injured when anti-American protesters tried to storm the American Consulate in the southern port city of Karachi and clashed for several hours with the police and paramilitary troops on Sunday evening, rescue workers and police officials said.

headline: Why I Love Mormonism
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Philosophy', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Does Joseph Smith’s theology suggest that one of our presidential candidates could be a deity?
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent what is rapidly becoming nine years in New York City. It’s been a total blast. But as a transplanted Englishman one thing to which I’ve become rather sensitive in that time is which prejudices New Yorkers are permitted to express in public. Among  my horribly overeducated and hugely liberal friends, expressions of racism are completely out of the question, Islamophobia is greeted with a slow shaking of the head and anti-Semitism is a memory associated with distant places that one sometimes visits — like France.

headline: A ’60s Landmark in the Eyes of Children
abstract: Clarinda Mac Low stages improvisations in the spirit of the 1960s New York institution the Judson Dance Theater.
lead_paragraph: It’s fitting that “40 Dancers do 40 Dances for the Dancers,” a project conceived and directed by Clarinda Mac Low, was ruled by children — at least on opening night. Part of Ms. Mac Low’s intention for the event, as she states in program notes, is to recreate “a child’s-eye view of the 1970s New York ‘avant-garde’ arts world.” As the daughter of the poet, composer and performance artist  Jackson Mac Low, who died in 2004, she writes from experience. The children performing on Thursday evening at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church — notably, the adorable Ignacio Achugar-Granoff — offered some of the evening’s most genuine encounters.

headline: In a Dark Church, Nuances of Sound Turn Symphonic
abstract: Eleh, as he is called, played a show of electronic compositions in Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: Eleh, as he is called, walked down the aisle of Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral in Brooklyn Heights after all the lights had been shut off and sat cross-legged before his equipment: an old Sequential Circuits analog keyboard synthesizer; a modular synthesizer about the shape of a large cash register, with red, yellow, orange, purple and black patch cables; and a hand-held digital multimeter to measure sound frequencies. You could see his outline only in the tiny readout lights of his gear. He is compact, of middling height and has short hair. Healthy. Maybe mid-30s.

headline: Surging Brewers Beat Mets as Braun Hits Career-High 40th Homer
abstract: Chris Young allowed two solo shots by Ryan Braun and another by Aramis Ramirez as Milwaukee gave itself a chance to gain ground in the National League wild-card race.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Like many players who reach milestones, Ryan Braun tried to frame his accomplishments in the context of a victory. The Milwaukee Brewers needed to beat the Mets on Sunday afternoon to maintain their place in the clacking multicar train of the race for the second National League wild card, and Braun helped that along with two of Milwaukee’s three solo home runs off Chris Young in a 3-0 victory.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Temperley
abstract: Hair stylist Malcolm Edwards wasn’t afraid to tailor match a spread of L’Oréal product with different natural hair textures to reach consistent results.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Grace Kelly gone London rogue.

headline: At Harlem Hospital, Murals Get a New Life
abstract: The new pavilion at Harlem Hospital Center will showcase restored murals by black artists of the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: When the Works Progress Administration commissioned murals for Harlem Hospital Center in 1936, it easily approved the sketches submitted by seven artists, which depicted black people at work and at play throughout history. The hospital, however, objected, saying four of the sketches focused too much on “Negro” subject matter and that blacks “may not form the greater part of the Community” in years to come.

headline: Time Travel With Einstein: Glass’s Opera Returns to the Stage
abstract: “Einstein on the Beach,” the pathbreaking 1976 opera by the composer Philip Glass and the director Robert Wilson, is receiving an exhilarating revival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: As the audience milled into the Brooklyn Academy of Music for Saturday night’s performance of “Einstein on the Beach,” an exhilarating revival of the pathbreaking 1976 opera by the composer Philip Glass and the director Robert Wilson, the piece seemed already to have started.

headline: Itsy Bitsy Bit
abstract: Adam G. Perl bakes us a pie.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome back to another week of puzzling! I always enjoy Mondays. Well, not the concept (getting up for work or school after a relaxing weekend), but the puzzles. It feels like a fresh start after wrestling with the increasingly difficult week, tackling the Friday and Saturday grids, investing time in the Sunday … and then, poof! All that is gone, and we have a nice, simple Monday puzzle to sail through. It restores my faith in humanity, I tell you.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
abstract: Data to be released includes the current account deficit for the second quarter, housing starts and existing home sales for August and the weekly jobless claims.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include the current account deficit for the second quarter (Tuesday); housing starts for August and existing home sales for August (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, the Philadelphia Fed index for September and leading economic indicators for August (Thursday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: A Future With Swords, Not iPhones
abstract: In the new NBC series “Revolution,” a hardy band of survivors wield bows, arrows, swords and wits in a future devoid of electricity.
lead_paragraph: Armageddon comes in every shade of black: nuclear war, global warming, pandemic, alien invasion, zombie takeover or, even in some cases, a quirk of physics.

abstract: The model Elza Luijendijk from IMG Models transforms with makeup by Maria Comparetto for Benefit and hair by Cos Sakkas for Toni & Guy.

headline: History Measured in War, Sex and Berets
abstract: The era of Ken Follett’s new novel is illuminated only slightly by the characters who wander through it.
lead_paragraph: The second volume of Ken Follett’s Century Trilogy, “Winter of the World,” improves on “Fall of Giants,” the first. For one thing, it weighs in at 940 pages, which by Follett standards is concise. For another, it dispenses with some of the waxenness of its 985-page predecessor and breathes life into its fictional characters, many of whose parents appeared in the first book. The second-generation “Winter of the World” crew does enough procreating to ensure that Mr. Follett’s third installment will be crowded too.

headline: Distinguished Family Turns Out in Force
abstract: Robert Sirota’s chamber works were played by the composer and members of his family.
lead_paragraph: The name Sirota has been one to reckon with in New York musical circles for some years now. Nadia Sirota, a stellar young violist who has served as muse to prominent composers like Nico Muhly and Judd Greenstein, also cuts a high profile as a presenter on the Web-radio station Q2. Jonah Sirota, another violist and Nadia’s older brother, is a member of the respected Chiara String Quartet. The Rev. Dr. Victoria R. Sirota, Nadia and Jonah’s mother, is an accomplished organist and the canon pastor of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

headline: Woman’s Day Turns 75 While Looking Forward
abstract: In its celebration, the magazine is striving for what its editor called “a delicate balance,” capitalizing on longevity without appearing too long in the tooth to be contemporary.
lead_paragraph: A MAGAZINE that was introduced when the newest technology to reach consumers was the radio soap opera wants to demonstrate its relevance to readers — and advertisers — with a commemoration of its 75th anniversary that is focused as much on the present and future as the past.

abstract: Despite millions of users, apps are not a surefire moneymaker for cautious studios.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Can smartphone apps become hit movies and television shows?

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the revival of Philip Glass’s opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: The Puppetry of Quotation Approval
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: When quotations can be unilaterally taken back, the political Kabuki is all but complete.
lead_paragraph: Now that it’s become clear that many journalists covering politics and government agree to quotation-approval as a condition of access, it’s tough not to see the pageant of democracy as just that: a carefully constructed performance meant to showcase the participants in the best light.

headline: Selexicons: Your Contributions to ‘That Should Be a Word’
abstract: Molly Ringwald, words for famous people who switch careers and reader submissions.
lead_paragraph: One of the great pleasures — and perils — of my “That Should Be a Word” column in The One-Page Magazine comes from the requests I receive to coin a word, generally stemming from an irritation that my suggestions, it seems, cannot mollify. (“I need a word for that person who stands at the party with you and is just nodding — they’re not even listening!” “Okay — nodinage?” “No, that’s not it!”)

headline: Kurdish Separatists Suspected After 8 Turkish Police Officers Are Killed in Blast
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Alawite Muslims', 'Mines, Explosive', 'Kurds', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Eight police officers were killed and nine were wounded when their vehicle hit a land mine that officials say was probably planted by Kurdish separatist rebels.
lead_paragraph: HATAY, Turkey — Eight police officers were killed and nine were wounded when a land mine exploded early Sunday in southeastern Turkey, the semiofficial news service Anatolian Agency reported.

headline: Shock Value
abstract: Does art retain the power to shock? Must artists contrive to provoke? Join the discussion with artists, critics, reporters and readers.
lead_paragraph: Does art retain the power to shock? Must artists contrive to provoke? Join the discussion with artists, critics, reporters and readers.

headline: Teachers Union in Chicago to Extend Strike Into 2nd Week
abstract: Union leaders said they needed more time to consider a contract deal reached over the weekend, infuriating Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who told city lawyers to seek an injunction to end the strike.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chicago Teachers Union extended its strike into a second week on Sunday, after significant divisions emerged among union delegates over a deal that only a day before had been described by the union’s leader as “a good contract.”

headline: Despite a Slowdown, Smartphone Advances Are Still Ahead
abstract: The iPhone 5 that Apple introduced last week with only incremental changes seemed to signal that the smartphone industry has entered an era of technological bunny hops.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the original iPhone in 2007 was a quantum leap for cellphones. Phones had never worked or looked like that.

headline: Andre Brown Breaks Through for Giants
abstract: Andre Brown barely made the Giants’ roster out of training camp, bu he certainly elevated his status Sunday in a victory over Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: A capsule look at the Giants’ victory over the Bucs on Sunday.

headline: As Grocery Dies Off, Down-and-Out Town Lives On, if Barely
abstract: After years of watching his Central Valley town grow more and more desperate, a grocery store owner in California decided it was time close down.
lead_paragraph: MENDOTA, Calif. — Westside Grocery, serving this self-described Cantaloupe Center of the World since the 1940s, removed its gasoline pumps around 1980, the result of increased regulation. Fresh steaks and pork chops went by the wayside in the 1990s: too few could afford them.

abstract: Readers look at the causes and effects of cheating, and suggest how to deter it.
