headline: Canada Auto Workers Chief Renews Threat Strike
abstract: If there is no agreement by midnight on Monday, the union’s leader said, a strike against all three American auto makers in Canada will begin.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Despite making progress with the Ford Motor Company of Canada during contract talks over the weekend, Ken Lewenza, the president of the Canadian Auto Workers union, renewed his threat on Sunday to strike all three Detroit automakers.

headline: Outside the Ring
abstract: Thirty years after the Korean boxer Duk-koo Kim died following his loss to Ray “Boom Boom” Mancini in Las Vegas, their families continue to heal.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years after the Korean boxer Duk-koo Kim died following his loss to Ray “Boom Boom” Mancini in Las Vegas, their families continue to heal.

headline: London Fashion: Rethinking Luxury
abstract: Tom Ford’s collection on Sunday felt completely contemporary, yet still in the Ford glamor mode.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s good to see Tom Ford nail down a hot look again. Two years ago he staged a private little show in his New York store, asking friends like Julianne Moore, Rachel Feinstein and Rita Wilson to model his first women’s line since leaving Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent. It was a memorable night. Each outfit was a return-to-elegance occasion, as individual as the women involved, and Mr. Ford got a lot of press for withholding photos until the clothes arrived in stores. But then last fall he seemed to reprise styles from his YSL days. Editors expected more. So did Mr. Ford.

headline: Patriot Game
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Republican National Convention', 'Democratic National Convention']
abstract: The Gregory Brothers present a video-game-inspired musical mash-up of President Obama and Mitt Romney’s speeches from the recent nominating conventions.
lead_paragraph: The Gregory Brothers present a video-game-inspired musical mash-up of President Obama and Mitt Romney’s speeches from the recent nominating conventions.

headline: ‘Patriot Game’
abstract: In an Op-Doc video, presidential candidates score points for comments on God and country.
lead_paragraph: The Republican and Democratic nominating conventions are over and the race for the general election is under way in earnest.

headline: Online Mentors to Guide Women Into the Sciences
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Mentors', 'E-Learning', 'Women and Girls', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Engineering and Engineers']
abstract: By connecting female college students with accomplished women working in science and technology fields, a new program hopes to increase the number going into these fields.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of prominent women working in science, technology, engineering and math will become online mentors for college students next month, part of a six-week program to encourage young women to pursue careers in STEM fields.

headline: New Territory for Ads, With a Moving Target
abstract: Advertisers are using MetroCards, bus windows and interactive digital technology to reach commuters.
lead_paragraph: In the next month or two, subway and bus riders will find advertising where they have never seen it before: on the face of their MetroCards, always with them and inescapable — at least for that moment they pay their fare.

headline: On Web, a Fine Line on Free Speech Across the Globe
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: As companies set their own rules legal experts say they must be flexible to strike the right balance between democratic values and law.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For Google last week, the decision was clear. An anti-Islamic video that provoked violence worldwide was not hate speech under its rules because it did not specifically incite violence against Muslims, even if it mocked their faith.

headline: For a Fee, Streaming Local TV
abstract: Aereo hopes to offer an alternative for viewers who prefer to grab their favorite shows piecemeal from a number of online sources.
lead_paragraph: On the ninth floor of an old tire factory in Downtown Brooklyn, Joe Lipowski, chief technology officer of a company called Aereo, proudly showed off a steel sheet covered with TV antennas.

headline: Steelers and Errors Send Jets’ Offense Back to Reality
abstract: The Jets offense that had sputtered during the preseason, only to suddenly rev up against the Bills, stalled against one of the game’s most formidable defenses, generating just 219 yards.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — It was perhaps inevitable that the Jets, whose surprisingly easy season-opening victory over the Buffalo Bills prompted at least one player to proclaim that the Jets had put the league on notice, would eventually slip back a bit toward the competition.

headline: A Step Back
abstract: Thirty years after the Korean boxer Duk-koo Kim died following his loss to Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini in Las Vegas, their families continue to heal.
lead_paragraph: As a boy, Ray Mancini would pore over his father’s scrapbook, a collection of brittle-brown newspaper clippings and sepia-toned glossies, inevitably pausing to study the photograph of his father as a young fighter, his features bloodied and swollen, the right eye clenched shut like the seam of a mussel shell.

headline: Beyond Obamacare
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Unless we start allocating health care resources more prudently, the exploding cost of Medicare will swamp the federal budget.
lead_paragraph: WE need death panels.

headline: Karzai Denounces Coalition Over Airstrikes
keywords: ['Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan condemned American-led forces for killing eight women in airstrikes and denounced his American allies for continuing to hold Afghan prisoners.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two of the most contentious issues dividing the United States and President Hamid Karzai’s administration re-emerged as the Afghan leader condemned American-led forces for killing eight women in airstrikes on Sunday and denounced his American allies for continuing to hold hundreds of Afghan prisoners.

headline: Rallies Planned for Occupy Wall Street Anniversary
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Ralliers plan three days of events in Manhattan to highlight issues like risky speculation, foreclosures and corporate money in politics.
lead_paragraph: The crowd sat in a circle at the edge of Battery Park on Friday, as two young women held up a large map of the financial district that had been divided into sectors and marked with assembly points. They explained the plan for early Monday: protesters will gather at those points, then converge in an attempt to surround the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: A Big Void, and Closing It Well
abstract: For a Yankees team likely to play into October, Rafael Soriano has proved more than able to fill the closer’s role that opened up when Mariano Rivera injured his knee.
lead_paragraph: It has been 140 days since Mariano Rivera last threw a pitch, and the unspoken reality is that the Yankees have not missed him. For all of Rivera’s brilliance, the Yankees could not have expected him to do more than his successor has done.

headline: London Fashion: Electric Millinery
abstract: Philip Treacy’s hat show on Sunday night paired his designs with costumes worn by Michael Jackson.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a way, Philip Treacy’s hat show on Sunday night paid homage to the camp extravaganza that used to be common in London and Paris. The last great instigators were Alexander McQueen and Isabella Blow, both close friends of Mr. Treacy’s. He dedicated the show to them, and to Michael Jackson.

headline: Where Daniel the Cuckold and Zig Zag Clown Vie for Office
abstract: Do strange nicknames confer an electoral advantage? Some candidates for office in Brazil, including Ladi Gaga, Christ of Jerusalem and several Batmans, seem to think so.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Batman is running for office in the Brazilian city of Uberlândia. Not one but two James Bonds are seeking city council seats, in Ponta Grossa and Birigui. Elsewhere in Brazil, voters are being urged to cast ballots for candidates with names like Daniel the Cuckold and Elvis Didn’t Die.

headline: An Unscenic Urban Walk: From Lower Manhattan to Kennedy Airport
abstract: The ninth annual trek drew a number of tourists, though part of its appeal, said one traveler, is that only a true child of the city would be interested.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhoods turn starkly at first, from the prix fixe brunches and kitchen appliance stores of the tour’s initial leg in Manhattan to the dominoes games and dimly lighted bars that follow.

headline: Hating on Ben Bernanke
abstract: While the Federal Reserve changes course to help the economy, the Romney camp gets even more extreme.
lead_paragraph: Last week Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, announced a change in his institution’s recession-fighting strategies. In so doing he seemed to be responding to the arguments of critics who have said the Fed can and should be doing more. And Republicans went wild.

headline: Human Muscle, Regrown on Animal Scaffolding
keywords: ['Series', 'Muscles', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Medicine and Health', 'Research', 'Veterans', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Stem Cells']
abstract: Researchers are using extracellular matrix, a natural scaffolding that underlies all tissues and organs, from animals to engineer the growth of replacement tissue like limb muscle lost in injuries.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — In the months after a roadside bomb in Afghanistan blew off part of his left thigh, Sgt. Ron Strang wondered if he would ever be able to walk normally again.

headline: Extracellular Matrix
abstract: After 12 operations, Sgt. Ron Strang of the Marines was chosen for an experimental therapy to regrow some of his thigh muscle using a material called extracellular matrix, or E.C.M.
lead_paragraph: After 12 operations, Sgt. Ron Strang of the Marines was chosen for an experimental therapy to regrow some of his thigh muscle using a material called extracellular matrix, or E.C.M.

headline: Declassified Documents Shed Light on a 1982 Massacre
abstract: Declassified documents reveal conversations between high-level American and Israeli officials before, during and after a massacre in Beirut’s Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in 1982.
lead_paragraph: Declassified documents reveal conversations between high-level American and Israeli officials before, during and after a massacre in Beirut’s Sabra and Shatila refugee camps in 1982.

headline: A Preventable Massacre
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'United States International Relations', 'Sabra and Shatila Massacre, Lebanon (1982)', 'Palestinians']
abstract: In 1982, the United States failed to exert strong diplomatic pressure on Israel that could have ended a massacre of Palestinians in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: ON the night of Sept. 16, 1982, the Israeli military allowed a right-wing Lebanese militia to enter two Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut. In the ensuing three-day rampage, the militia, linked to the Maronite Christian Phalange Party, raped, killed and dismembered at least 800 civilians, while Israeli flares illuminated the camps’ narrow and darkened alleyways. Nearly all of the dead were women, children and elderly men.

headline: The First Test for Albany’s Ethicists
abstract: The tangled controversy surrounding Assemblyman Vito Lopez has presented the ethics commission with its first big challenge.
lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York’s State Legislature passed a long-overdue ethics law to clean up Albany. The law contained one grave flaw, a supposedly independent Joint Commission on Public Ethics that is made up entirely of political appointees. The tangled controversy surrounding Assemblyman Vito Lopez has presented the commission with its first big test.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An amateur video that surfaced Sunday appears to show a crowd removing the motionless body of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens from a window of the American mission in Benghazi, Libya, after it was attacked last week by Islamist militants, adding new details to reports that Mr. Stevens had died of smoke inhalation while locked in a safe room.

headline: In Search of Excellent Teaching
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Editorials', 'Strikes']
abstract: Though controversial and difficult, measuring student achievement is essential.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago teachers’ strike was prompted in part by a fierce disagreement over how much student test scores will weigh in a new teacher evaluation system mandated by state law. That teachers’ unions in much of the country now agree that student achievement should count in evaluations at all reflects a major change from the past, when it was often argued that teaching was an “art” that could not be rigorously evaluated or, even more outrageously, that teachers should not be held accountable for student progress.

abstract: New York Republicans have some practical lessons for the rest of the party.
lead_paragraph: In a Time magazine column the other day, Joe Klein scolded the Democrats for being overly preoccupied with identity politics. In its admirable drive to be inclusive, he argued, the party has treated its constituents not as a population united by common ideals and interests, but as an array of caucuses to be pandered to: African-Americans, gays, Latinos, women, youth and so on. Klein wrote that “if I’m a plain old white insurance salesman, I look at the Democratic Party and say, What’s in it for me?”

headline: Jimmy Carter’s Brief Shining Moment
abstract: Remembering President Jimmy Carter at the Camp David peace accords, and 10 months later.
lead_paragraph: By the time you’ve reached your 50s, you’ve lived through a good deal of history, although when it’s happening, it often seems to be just another edition of the nightly news. Of all the video clips linked here, the ones that struck me most were of former President Jimmy Carter, in September 1978, looking so vital at the Camp David peace accords, and then, just 10 months later, so deflated during his “crisis of confidence” speech. It’s a dramatic example of history taking its toll on a president.

Do you think public figures should expect to be ambushed by photographers, or should they be off limits when they aren’t in public?

headline: Carlyle Hires Goldman Executive as Co-Head of Its Infrastructure Fund
abstract: The private equity firm said on Monday that it had named Robert Mancini — the chief executive of the power company Cogentrix and a managing director at Goldman Sachs — as the co-head of its $1.14 billion infrastructure fund.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group apparently likes the assets it bought from the power company, Cogentrix. So much so that it has hired its chief executive to help lead further investments in the sector.

lead_paragraph: Directions: Fill in the blanks in this article about summer rapidly coming to an end, “Under Cover of Darkness, a New Season Slips In.”

headline: A Shift in Strategy in Romney’s Latest Ads
abstract: New TV ads from Mitt Romney’s campaign focus on specific ideas to revive the economy, create jobs and reduce the nation’s long-term debt, with less emphasis on assailing President Obama.
lead_paragraph: New ads by Mitt Romney‘s presidential campaign began running Monday as part of a shift in strategy to focus more on the his specific ideas to revive the economy, create jobs and reduce the nation’s long-term debt.

headline: Activist Fund Takes Aim at Office Depot
abstract: Starboard Value said on Monday that it had taken a 13.3 percent stake in Office Depot, and called upon the struggling retailer to shift its strategy to one that reduces spending, focuses on smaller stores and sells noncore assets.
lead_paragraph: Starboard Value, an activist hedge fund, said on Monday that it had taken a 13.3 percent stake in Office Depot, and it called on the struggling retailer to shift its strategy to one that reduces spending, focuses on smaller stores and sells noncore assets.

headline: Waste Connections to Buy R360 for $1.3 Billion
abstract: Waste Connections said on Monday that it would buy R360 Environmental Solutions, an oil field treatment services company, for about $1.3 billion in cash, as it seeks to increase its toehold in the American energy boom.
lead_paragraph: Waste Connections said on Monday that it would buy R360 Environmental Solutions, an oil field treatment services company, for about $1.3 billion in cash, as it seeks to increase its toehold in the American energy boom.

headline: Monday Reading: Budget Airlines Fly South of the Border
abstract: Budget airlines fly south of the border, getting a mortgage after a bankruptcy, when children get medals for standardized tests and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Welcoming Gretchen Rubin to Motherlode
abstract: Gretchen Rubin, author of "Happier at Home" and "The Happiness Project," will riff weekly on how picture books impact parenthood on the Motherlode blog.
lead_paragraph: Gretchen Rubin, author of "Happier at Home" and "The Happiness Project," will riff weekly on how picture books impact parenthood on the Motherlode blog.

headline: Sept. 16: Watching the Clock and Awaiting the Unknown
abstract: Since the conventions we’ve been in something of a waiting game, watching to see whether Mr. Obama’s numbers hold their current position or if Mitt Romney can make gains as the days leading to Nov. 6 slip by.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s chances of winning the Electoral College fell slightly on Sunday in the FiveThirtyEight forecast, to 74.7 percent from 76.2 percent on Saturday.

headline: Schiano, Coughlin and the Unwritten Rules
abstract: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin scolded the rookie Bucs coach Greg Schiano for breaking an unwritten rule by having his team try to tackle Eli Manning on a kneel-down at the end of the game.
lead_paragraph: O.K., it’s time to get out the unwritten rule book. You know, the one that you can’t see because it doesn’t exist.

headline: Workers of the World Reunite!
abstract: The Socialist International’s latest congress in Cape Town turned into a good old tussle between North and South.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN, South Africa —

headline: Shell Stymied in 2012 Arctic Oil Quest
abstract: From encroaching ice to problems with a spill containment vessel, a series of problems has derailed Shell’s hopes of harvesting oil this year.
lead_paragraph: Saying that a spill response dome aboard a vessel has been damaged, Shell announced Monday that it would defer its plan to drill for oil in the Arctic off the Alaskan coast this year. In seeking approval to drill, the company fought a long battle against environmentalists and others who say that doing so in the pristine icy region is too risky. In a statement, Greenpeace claimed vindication and called Shell’s high-stakes program a “monumentally reckless gamble.” But the company says it will press on and seek a safety permit for the vessel next year.

headline: Mission Viejo
abstract: Can Panama City’s Old Town survive its own success?
lead_paragraph: In Panama City’s oldest standing neighborhood, the rooftops are bright red. Some are made of tile, in the style of the conquistadors who established the quarter in 1673, others of corrugated metal — temporary patches rusted crimson during decades of neglect. Together, they represent the storied past and seedy present of Casco Viejo, a neighborhood Panamanians call Casco and view as both a shrine and slum. These days, empty lots once home to squatters and stray dogs are giving way to valet parking, part of a process that may make the neighborhood more popular, if less compelling. Even hotel developers are torn.

headline: The Bull Tied to Occupy Wall Street
abstract: The Day: “Charging Bull,” the 7,000-pound bronze statue on Broadway in the financial district, has been a protective captive of the police since the Occupy protests began.
lead_paragraph: With a full year having passed since it came into being, Occupy Wall Street is noting the moment in a manner that reflects one of the things it does best. It is celebrating itself.

headline: Concord Conned, Etc.
abstract: The strange history of the Ryan delusion.
lead_paragraph: Alec MacGillis has a long, interesting piece on the Paul Ryan phenomenon — on how Washington managed to convince itself that he was a Serious, Honest Conservative when he was nothing of the sort. There’s a lot of useful information in the piece. But I’d question MacGillis’s central thesis — namely, that Ryan was mainly exploiting the Beltway’s innumeracy.

headline: As Chicago Strike Goes On, the Mayor Digs In
abstract: If union delegates do not accept a proposed contract at a scheduled vote on Tuesday, then a court will hear the city’s case for a preliminary injunction on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As the president of the Chicago Teachers Union emerged from a meeting of her union delegates on Sunday night to announce that, no, school would not be starting up again and that, no, the delegates were not ready to sign off on what had seemed like a deal, Mayor Rahm Emanuel watched her on a television in City Hall.

headline: Square Closes Financing Round
abstract: While several large venture capital firms have led Square’s past financing rounds, this deal featured less traditional backers, like Rizvi Traverse Management, Citi Ventures and Starbucks.
lead_paragraph: Square, the San Francisco-based mobile payments company led by the Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, announced on Monday that it had closed its latest financing round.

headline: A Fight to the Death to Commemorate Sherlock’s Birth
abstract: Members of the Sherlock Holmes Society celebrated the 125th anniversary of the story in which Arthur Conan Doyle introduced his famous fictional consulting detective by traveling — in costume — to the waterfall in Switzerland where Holmes was believed, for a time, to have met his demise.
lead_paragraph: You “Downton Abbey” enthusiasts who express your dedication to that show by gathering at parties, enjoying finger sandwiches and engaging in drinking rituals will have to step up your game, because the Sherlock Holmes fans have got you beat. BBC News caught up  with 70 members of the Sherlock Holmes Society (a group that claims more than 1,200 members worldwide) who celebrated the 125th anniversary of the novel in which Arthur Conan Doyle introduced his famous fictional consulting detective by traveling — in costume — to the waterfall in Switzerland where Holmes was believed, for a time, to have met his demise.

headline: On Our Radar: Nuclear Plants and Flood Risks
abstract: An engineer accuses federal regulators of falsely invoking security concerns in redacting parts of a report on the potential for dangerous flooding from dam failures upstream from nuclear plants.
lead_paragraph: An engineer within the Nuclear Regulatory Commission accuses its regulators of deliberately covering up information related to the vulnerability of nuclear power plants that sit downstream from large dams and reservoirs. [The Huffington Post]

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Smithsonian: A celebration of the oft-neglected fondue pot. “If you still have yours kicking around in the closet, I encourage you to crack it out,” because “it’s a wonderfully social way to enjoy food.” — Glenn CollinsThe Washington Post: To ease that arduous transition from summer to fall, Jason Wilson offers the McClelland Cocktail, made with real sloe gin. Why is it called the McClelland? If you know, tell us. — Eric Asimov

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: YouTube’s Balancing Act, and an App Aims for Stardom
abstract: Also, a film based on a video game wins the weekend’s box office contest; and the practice of letting sources approve their quotes results in a palpable loss to journalism.
lead_paragraph: Google rejected a request from the White House last week to pull “The Innocence of Muslims” from its YouTube service in light of the spreading protests of the video in the Muslim world. At the same time, it did temporarily block the video from Egypt and Libya, where the protests have been the most fierce – and that, in a nutshell, is the tricky situation Google faces in trying to fashion a policy on the acceptability of content viewed around the world, Somini Sengupta writes. Google quickly determined that the video — which depicts the Prophet Muhammad as a child molester and thug, among other things — did not violate its hate speech rules or any law, but nonetheless took it down in Egypt and Libya “given the very sensitive situation” there.

headline: College, Still Worth It
abstract: The more income you earn, the more likely you are to have gone to college.
lead_paragraph: Adam Looney and Michael Greenstone at the Hamilton Project have put together a beautiful chart illustrating once again why college is worth it, despite the current fad of claiming otherwise.

headline: Trade Case May Produce Few Results
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Automobiles', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The case against China on cars and auto parts will have little immediate impact, but it is one of the few legal options available.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Obama’s trade case against China on cars and auto parts will have little immediate impact on jobs and companies in the United States, but it is one of the few legal options available to the United States as China’s auto industry faces overcapacity problems and looks overseas to increase sales.

headline: Truth Panel in Thailand Says Conflicts Are Festering
abstract: A panel investigating deadly protests in 2010 that left more than 90 dead blamed the powerful Thai military and a shadowy group of militants, the black shirts.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — An independent commission set up by the Thai government to investigate deadly clashes in Bangkok two years ago warned Monday that conflicts in Thai society were still simmering and that the country risked another “escalation to violence.”

headline: Switching Contraceptives Effectively
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Medicine and Health', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Women choose to switch methods of birth control frequently, research shows, and without proper guidance on how to make these changes safely, gaps often occur in contraceptive protection that can result in an unintended pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: The United States has one of the highest rates of unwanted pregnancies in the developed world — nearly half of pregnancies here are unintended, and there’s been no improvement in the situation for a decade.

headline: Why Kashmiri Muslims Blame America for Anti-Muslim Film
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Kashmiri protestors and Islamic leaders on recent hate for the United States.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR– Three young men picked a shady, grassy spot, out of earshot from the crowds bustling about the University of Kashmir campus, to talk on Saturday afternoon.

lead_paragraph: Complete Genomics, a struggling DNA sequencing company in Silicon Valley, said on Monday that it had agreed to be acquired for $117.6 million by BGI-Shenzhen, a Chinese company that operates the world’s largest sequencing operation.

headline: Five Ways to Teach the Constitution Through Current Events
abstract: Make the Constitution relevant in your classroom by empowering students to think critically, defend their arguments with evidence and speak their opinions by wrestling with real-life issues.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 17 is Constitution Day, the day when the writers at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia signed the United States Constitution in 1787.

abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Fire Hazard Prompts Ford to Recall 5,500 Edge Crossovers With 2-Liter EcoBoost
abstract: It was the third recall this summer for Ford crossovers equipped with EcoBoost engines.
lead_paragraph: Ford recently informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration of its plan to recall almost 5,500 Edge crossovers from the 2012 model year equipped with 2-liter EcoBoost engines. Details of the action were included in a report posted to the Web site of the safety agency over the weekend.

headline: What’s in a Label? Not Necessarily Sustainability
abstract: More and more consumers want to “buy green,” but amid a cacophony of claims, packaging and logos, it’s best to beware. Whom do you trust?
lead_paragraph: As consumers increasingly vote with their wallets for sustainable goods and groceries, producers are doing more to signal the eco-friendliness of their wares. But amid the many different certification logos, package designs and environmental claims, experts warn that all that glitters is not green.

headline: The Times Needs a Policy on Quotation Approval, and Soon
abstract: It’s time to reset the bar on the unfortunate practice of quotation approval by news sources.
lead_paragraph: David Carr wrote a great column in Monday’s New York Times on the topic of news sources demanding that they approve quotations in stories. Mr. Carr’s “The Media Equation” had the headline “The Puppetry of Quotation Approval,” and it laid out just what an unfortunate practice has developed. He wrote: “Inch by inch, story by story, deal by deal, we are giving away our right to ask a simple question and expect a simple answer. It may seem obvious but it is still worth stating: The first draft of history should not be rewritten by the people who make it.”

headline: Introducing The Next Level: Can You Teach Entrepreneurship?
abstract: And why do so many companies crash and burn after roaring starts?
lead_paragraph: Talk about needing an exit strategy. I needed one from the humidity, heat and mosquitoes of the Okefenokee Swamp. But how does one go from Swamp Road in Waycross, Ga., to running a global company? I’m sure there are other routes, but for me the fastest roads out were entrepreneurship and education.

headline: Report Faults Military’s Strategies on Drug and Alcohol Abuse
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Despite a well-documented increase in the abuse of alcohol and prescription medications among military personnel over the past decade, the Defense Department’s strategies for screening, treating and preventing remains behind the times, a major new report finds.
lead_paragraph: Despite a well-documented increase in the abuse of alcohol and prescription medications among military personnel over the past decade, the Defense Department’s strategies for screening, treating and preventing those problems remains behind the times, a major new report finds.

headline: From Justice Thomas, a Little Talk About Race, Faith and the Court
abstract: Justice Thomas opened up in a public interview at the National Archives, talking about his race, his faith and relations among the justices after a contentious Supreme Court term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas has not asked a question from the bench in more than six years, and he seldom appears in public in Washington, a city he says is full of cynics, smart alecks and people who have agendas rather than convictions.

lead_paragraph: Business Day Live: September 17th, 2012 — Political progress in Europe, but popular discontent over austerity. | Corporate earnings start to falter. | Looking for the next daytime talk show star.

abstract: Guinness World Record holder pulled a train weighing 38, 000 kilograms, two and a half meters with his ponytail.

headline: Venus Williams Helps Kastles Repeat Team Title
abstract: Venus Williams won the decisive women’s singles event as the Washington Kastles won their second straight World Team Tennis championship.
lead_paragraph: She may not have won a singles title in 2012, but as Venus Williams watched Coco Vandeweghe’s final forehand fly long Sunday afternoon, the look on her face showed anything but disappointment. And unlike after any of her 43 career singles titles, Williams had an entire team mobbing her after championship point.

headline: European Plan to Put More Women on Boards Runs Into Opposition
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Legislation to impose sanctions on companies that do not allocate 40 percent of the seats on their boards to women may be blocked before it is officially proposed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A planned European Union law to impose sanctions on companies that do not allocate at least 40 percent of the seats on their boards to women has drawn enough opposition from Britain and other countries to risk being blocked before it is officially proposed.

headline: Tips For Managing Your Increasingly Lumpy Income
abstract: Fewer people earn regular, old-fashioned paychecks with regular old-fashioned pensions anymore. If you’re one of them, you need a different financial plan.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Embracing a Bit of the Garden Variety
abstract: Looking back on the New York collections, one underlying theme that stood out among the younger set of designers was the embrace of collage.
lead_paragraph: Looking back on the New York collections, one underlying theme that stood out among the younger set of designers was the embrace of collage. Designers like Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte were mixing fabrics in a single look, and Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler specifically acknowledged the randomness of images on Tumblr as an influence of their photo print dresses.

headline: Couscous Dinners, Ready When You Are
abstract: These hearty vegetarian make-ahead dishes are just right for breaking a holiday fast or simply getting ahead of the week’s meals. Today: couscous with beans, tomatoes, squash and peppers.
lead_paragraph: When I was researching my book “Provençal Light,” I went to Yom Kippur services at the Orthodox synagogue in Avignon for purely secular reasons: I wanted to sit upstairs with the women and eavesdrop on their discussions about what they had cooked for the meal to break the fast. If I was lucky, I would strike up a conversation and perhaps get an invitation to dinner. As it turned out, I was successful on both counts.

headline: At Democratic Residence, Wallets Open for G.O.P.
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Campaign Finance', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A $200,000 gift to help Mitt Romney from a resident of the San Remo apartments on the Upper West Side helped dwarf neighbors’ donations for President Obama’s efforts.
lead_paragraph: The San Remo apartment building, a pair of ivory towers at the edge of Central Park, is one of the most sought-after addresses on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, which is as blue a political district as there is. So for the past few elections, the San Remo has been an A.T.M. for Democratic presidential campaigns, sometimes among the most generous addresses in the country.

headline: Coach’s No-Nonsense Ways Don’t Translate in Malaysia
abstract: Peter Butler has faced backlash after booting three players from Terengganu in the Malaysian league and accusing them of fixing matches or being unprofessional.
lead_paragraph: Peter Butler, a former West Ham United star, was a tough-tackling no-nonsense midfielder in the early days of the English Premier League, but he is taking on his biggest opponent yet — match fixing, corruption and unprofessionalism in Malaysian soccer. At least that is how he sees it. But not all in the country would agree.

headline: Numberplay: Gas Stations
abstract: Will you have enough fuel to make the trip?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by frequent Numberplay contributor Marco Moriconi, who rates the puzzle “moderately difficult.”

headline: Kovalchuk and Jagr Join Teams in Europe
abstract: The exodus of big N.H.L. stars to Europe accelerated Monday as the Devils’ Ilya Kovalchuk signed with a K.H.L. team and the Stars’ Jaromir Jagr suited up for the club he owns in the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: The exodus of big N.H.L. stars to Europe accelerated Monday, the second day of the lockout.

headline: Forest Fire Research Questions the Wisdom of Prescribed Burns
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Forest and Brush Fires', 'Biodiversity']
abstract: The United States Forest Service uses small fires to reduce the chances of big fires. Scientists are arguing whether this strategy helps or hurts the forests and the creatures that live in them.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — On a forested mountainside that was charred in a wildfire in 2003, Richard Hutto, a University of Montana ornithologist, plays a recording of a black-backed woodpecker drumming on a tree.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Ryan Hunter-Reay Rallies to Win IndyCar Championship
abstract: Overcoming a poor week of qualifying, the driver for Andretti Autosport surged late to finish fourth on Saturday at Fontana, Calif., fast enough to win the championship.
lead_paragraph: Though IndyCar fans were not treated to a wheel-to-wheel duel between Ryan Hunter-Reay, who entered the final race of the season 17 points from first place, and Will Power, the series leader, the finale to the 2012 IndyCar season was not without its nail-biting moments.

headline: What’s Up With Quote Approval? A Call for Reporters and Sources to Weigh In
abstract: Are quotes sacrosanct and usually accurate, or are they constantly and chronically wrong in some aspects?
lead_paragraph: In Monday’s Media Equation column, I wrote about the trend toward sources requiring quote approval, a practice that seems to be growing like kudzu.

headline: Emmys Watch: Abi Morgan on ‘The Hour’ and How ‘West Wing’ Saved Her
abstract: The writer Abi Morgan, nominated for the BBC America mini-series “The Hour,” talks about her love of American television and how “The West Wing” got her through two pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading to the awards show on Sunday night. Previous entries in this series include Don Roy King, director of “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: London Design Festival 2012
abstract: The festival is back, celebrating its 10th anniversary, and there is — no surprise — lots to see, with over 200 events planned.

headline: Examining the Ubiquity of Private Equity
abstract: A Q.&A. with Jason Kelly, author of “The New Tycoons: Inside the Trillion Dollar Private Equity Industry That Owns Everything.”
lead_paragraph: Jason Kelly, as a reporter at Bloomberg News, has been chronicling the moves of the world’s largest buyout shops and their billionaire founders long before the private equity industry became a political football in the presidential election.

headline: America’s Bloodiest Day
abstract: More Americans died on Sept. 17, 1862, at the Battle of Antietam, than any other day in history.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to his wife, the Union general Alpheus Williams recorded his feelings on the eve of the fighting at Antietam Creek, Md. “There was a half-dreamy sensation about it all,” he wrote, “but with a certain impression that the morrow was to be great with the future fate of our country. So much responsibility, so much intense, future anxiety.” The morrow was indeed great — a pivotal moment in the struggle between North and South.

headline: Romney Aide Concedes Campaign Has Been Short on Specifics
abstract: The Romney campaign plans a more positive message highlighting some of the candidate’s positions on important issues.
lead_paragraph: 7:27 p.m. | Updated  A top strategist for Mitt Romney conceded Monday that the campaign has not provided enough specifics about the candidate’s vision for the country and pledged a renewed effort in the last 50 days of the race to better communicate with voters.

headline: Germany Making Jews Feel Unwelcome
abstract: The controversy over the legality of circumcision threatens to undo decades of trying hard to make Jews feel at home in this country — and succeeding.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A Jewish friend once told me something that I recalled when writing this week’s Letter from Europe about Germany and circumcision.

headline: TimesCast | September 17, 2012
abstract: Anti-American protests spread to Lebanon and Afghanistan. | The first anniversary of Occupy Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Anti-American protests spread to Lebanon and Afghanistan. | The first anniversary of Occupy Wall Street.

headline: Baby Boomers Who Celebrate Birthdays This Week
abstract: Twiggy turning 63 is the hardest to keep in my mind alongside the image of the 1960s pixie model who looked about 12.
lead_paragraph: Nothing makes the average baby boomer feel better than to know that a famous boomer is getting older, too. Of all the names on this week’s birthday list, I think Twiggy turning 63 is the hardest to keep in my mind alongside the image of the 1960s pixie model who looked about 12. Sept. 23 is Bruce Springsteen’s birthday. In an appreciation, Matt Richtel, a Times colleague, writes that one of the finest things about Mr. Springsteen’s music is his stories, which show, rather than tell. “He let me fill in the blanks, interpret, reach my own conclusions about life, keep my dignity intact,'’ Matt writes. “He turns 63 this week. A gift to us.”

headline: A Yearning for Springsteen’s Gift
abstract: I guess it’s not so much that I miss Springsteen. He’s a genius out there doing his thing, what feels right, and more power to him. But I do miss us.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers had a homecoming

abstract: Rick Santorum said social conservatives will “never have the elite smart people on our side.” Meanwhile, the Romney campaign seems to have given up on the “reality-based community.”
lead_paragraph: At the Values Voter Summit this weekend, Rick Santorum said that social conservatives would “never have the elite smart people on our side.” He also ruled out anyone who dedicates her life to teaching and research: “our colleges and universities, they’re not going to be on our side.”

headline: Shell Delays Arctic Oil Drilling Until 2013
abstract: A testing mishap further delayed the company’s six-year, $4.5 billion effort to drill off the coast of Alaska, although it will not stop preliminary work on several wells in the region this year.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With the prospect of rich new oil fields in tantalizing reach, Shell Oil announced on Monday that it was forced to put off completing wells in the Alaskan Arctic for another year after a spill containment dome was damaged during a testing accident.

headline: Orca Mothers Coddle Adult Sons, Study Finds
abstract: Female killer whales stop reproducing by their 40s but can live into their 90s. New research suggests that the prolonged menopause lets them focus on caring for their sons.
lead_paragraph: Humans, pilot whales and killer whales are the only known species in which females have a prolonged period of menopause — a time of life when they cannot reproduce. Now, a study in the journal Science reports the purpose that menopause serves in orcas: for females to care for their sons and make sure their genes are passed on to future generations.

headline: Better Eating, Thanks to Bacteria
abstract: Sandor Katz, a writer who promotes the benefits of fermented foods like kimchi or sauerkraut, samples new experiments in the Momofuku test kitchen.
lead_paragraph: SAY this about Sandor Ellix Katz: the man knows how to get you revved up to eat bacteria.

headline: For Gastronomists, a Go-To Microbiologist
abstract: Rachel Dutton, a Harvard scientist, has been a resource for chefs with a curiosity for the microscopic.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: In ‘Obesity Paradox,’ Thinner May Mean Sicker
abstract: A slow but steady accumulation of evidence is inspiring some experts to re-examine assumptions about the role of body fat in certain chronic diseases.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Mercedes Carnethon, a diabetes researcher at the Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern University, found herself pondering a conundrum. Obesity is the primary risk factor for Type 2 diabetes, yet sizable numbers of normal-weight people also develop the disease. Why?

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Jonas Abney joined Maxifier, New York, in a new post, vice president for United States sales. He had been head of publisher development and publishing operations at Zumobi.
lead_paragraph: Jonas Abney joined Maxifier, New York, in a new post, vice president for United States sales. He had been head of publisher development and publishing operations at Zumobi. Maxifier is minority-owned by the Dentsu Digital Holdings division of Dentsu.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Whose voice is that in the new Walgreens commercials?
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Sandor Katz Is Answering Your Fermentation Questions
abstract: The fermentation expert Sandor Katz is answering questions about the wide world of fermented foods.
lead_paragraph: He isn’t a chef, but in recent years Sandor Ellix Katz has become one of the unlikely rock stars of the American food scene. At 50, the author of the Web site “Wild Fermentation” and the how-to guide “The Art of Fermentation” has emerged as an evangelist for the pleasures and health benefits of sauerkraut, kimchi, kefir, kvass, umeboshi plums and hundreds of other fermented delights.

headline: Filing Trade Suit, Obama Raps Romney on China
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: President Obama, under renewed fire from Mitt Romney for not standing up to China on behalf of American workers, used a rally in this battleground state to announce a new trade case against Beijing.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI – President Obama, under renewed fire from Mitt Romney for not standing up to China on behalf of American workers, used a rally in this battleground state on Monday to announce a new trade case against Beijing. He said it was Mr. Romney who had sent jobs to China through his zealous practice of outsourcing at Bain Capital.

headline: Adele Records the Theme for the New James Bond Film
abstract: It remains unclear if she wrote the music and lyrics to “Skyfall” or is simply performing the vocals, but the song is expected to be released after the movie is released in November.
lead_paragraph: Forget Adele’s Grammy Awards and the fact that every teenage woman in the world knows the lyrics to most of her blockbuster album, “21.” You know the singer has finally arrived because she has recorded the theme for the new James Bond film, “Skyfall,” according to the Total Film Web site.

headline: Walkabout – 9/17: Travelers to the Middle East Ponder Plans, and Students Go Abroad
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Wait and See While protests against an American-made online video mocking the Prophet Muhammad continue in the Middle East, North Africa and South Asia, experts are not encouraging Americans to abandon their travel plans to those countries (except for Libya, which the  State Department recommends avoiding). Rather, they suggest that travelers be patient while events unfold. (The Washington Post)

headline: Myanmar Releases Hundreds of Prisoners
abstract: The government said it had released 514 prisoners, many of whom were reported to have been political prisoners.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s government said Monday that it was releasing more than 500 prisoners, the latest in a series of amnesties by President Thein Sein’s administration.

headline: Welcoming Gretchen Rubin to the Motherlode Blog
abstract: Gretchen Rubin will be writing weekly riffs on her parenthood takeaways from classic children’s picture books.
lead_paragraph: One unexpected thing that makes Gretchen Rubin, author of “The Happiness Project” and “Happier at Home,” happy?

headline: Examining Pre-Packaged Conventions
abstract: A “Conventions Storybook” documents the recent party conventions for this age of instantaneous and continuous news.
lead_paragraph: Politicians today live in the era of the sound bite, which may give way to the Twitter message (and then something else altogether) — either way, instantaneous news seems to be the only way our news is consumed now, and this ravenous cycle guarantees that stories sometimes fly by unnoticed, undigested.

headline: An App to Help You Find Parking On the Spot
abstract: Parking Panda is offering a smartphone app to make it easier to find parking in markets like San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Parking Panda, an online service that helps you find and reserve parking spaces, has added the San Francisco market to its inventory and introduced a mobile app to help you find parking on the spot.

headline: Why ‘Little Bear’ Made Me Burst Into Tears
abstract: When Little Bear asked his mother to tell him a story about “the things I once did,” the sudden reference to the speedy passage of time cut me to the heart.
lead_paragraph: “What kind of story would you like to hear?” said Mother Bear.“Tell me about me,” said Little Bear. “Tell me about things I once did.”–Else Holmelund Minarik, “Little Bear”

headline: Brewing Obama’s Ale, Step by Step
abstract: Follow Garrett Oliver of Brooklyn Brewery as he starts making a batch of White House Honey Ale.
lead_paragraph: This month, after word got out that the White House was brewing its own beer, President Obama’s staff released its recipe for White House Honey Ale. Diner’s Journal asked Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, to make a batch that we could sample and assess. And on Friday, Mr. Oliver started the brewing – a monthlong process that we’ll occasionally drop in on, offering a glimpse of brewing both for those who know the art and for those who don’t.

headline: Stelter and Carter on This Fall’s Search for the Next Oprah
abstract: Katie Couric’s talk show is the latest attempt to become a dominant force in daytime television, as Oprah Winfrey once was. Brian Stelter and Bill Carter discuss the high rewards and high hurdles she faces.
lead_paragraph: Katie Couric has begun a daytime talk show, joining a crowded field that is becoming more crowded with newcomers like Steve Harvey and Jeff Probst and a returning host like Ricki Lake. In this video clip, Brian Stelter and Bill Carter discuss the high rewards, and the high hurdles, to becoming a dominant figure in daytime television, as Oprah Winfrey once was.

headline: Expanding Ball Toy Poses Hazard to Children and Pets
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'Consumer Protection', 'Digestive Tract', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Pets', 'Toys']
abstract: Popular toys called Water Balz expand greatly in size when exposed to liquid, posing a hazard to pets and small children who may swallow them when they are the size of marbles, pediatricians warn.
lead_paragraph: They are known as Water Balz, and at first glance they look like marbles: small and spherical, brightly colored. But these balls are made of superabsorbent polymer, and they are capable of rapidly expanding to the size of a racquetball when doused in water.

headline: ‘We’re Not Perfect,’ a Synagogue’s Ads Proclaim
abstract: Beth Hillel Congregation of Wilmette, Ill., takes a modest approach in its campaign to solicit new members.
lead_paragraph: Madison Avenue loves to extol the perfection of products, from a whipped icing that is “the perfect blend of fudge and vanilla” to a luxury car that is devoted to “the relentless pursuit of perfection.” A new campaign, however, takes a much more modest tack by declaring, “We’re not perfect.”

headline: Look of The Moment | Astrid Bergès-Frisbey
abstract: How to wear nautical at night: the Spanish actress in a navy drop-waist dress by Chanel.
lead_paragraph: The Look: In the Navy. A glittering drop-waist dress with a powder-white pouf skirt and coordinating collar and cuffs offers a lesson in how to wear nautical at night.

headline: ‘Silver Linings Playbook’ Wins People’s Choice Award in Toronto
abstract: “Silver Linings Playbook,” the latest film from David O. Russell, received the People’s Choice Award at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: “Silver Linings Playbook,” the latest film from David O. Russell, received the BlackBerry People’s Choice Award at the Toronto International Film Festival. The movie, based on a novel by Matthew Quick, stars Bradley Cooper  and Jennifer Lawrence as unstable Philadelphians.

headline: Really?: Adding Milk to Tea Destroys its Antioxidants
abstract: Researchers have been surprised to find that adding milk may strip tea of some of its beneficial effects.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: House Tours in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: The October tours are part of a larger event that includes lectures by designers.
lead_paragraph: Ten homes in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be open for tours on Oct. 6 and 7 as part of a collaboration between Dwell Media and New York Magazine to showcase New York’s design and architectural talent.

headline: Tip Sheet | 5 Ways To Find Your College Fit
abstract: The author, a campus president at Johnson & Wales University, is also a mother. She offers first-hand professional and personal advice about navigating the college admissions process.
lead_paragraph: Mim L. Runey is president of the Providence Campus and chief operating officer of Johnson & Wales University.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Mary Katrantzou
abstract: “The clothes have a message on their own,” said the stylist Eugene Souleiman, which meant that all that was necessary was one strong makeup element: the inky eye paired with high, tight hair.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Blue-eyed Speedracer.The Makeup: “A ballpoint-blue inky eye that feels like a tattoo,” is how the makeup artist Val Garland described the look at Mary Katrantzou. To create this effect, she used a custom mix of M.A.C. Lipmix in a blue and a pinky red. “One simple idea,” Garland said. The rest of the face was M.A.C. mineralized foundation and a flesh-colored lip.

headline: Chicago Board of Education’s Request for Injunction Against the Chicago Teachers Union
abstract: Lawyers for the Chicago Board of Education have filed a motion seeking a legal injunction to end the teachers’ strike that has entered its second week.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Chicago Board of Education have filed a motion seeking a legal injunction to end the teachers’ strike that has entered its second week.

headline: When the Ice Melts
abstract: The melting polar ice changes the shape of the Earth and how fast it spins. Will the days get shorter or longer?
lead_paragraph: Q. Could the melting of ice at the poles affect the tilt and rotation of the Earth?

headline: Wasps Find One Way to Support Humans
abstract: Female wasps in Australia sting and paralyze a poisonous spider, the redback, on which they lay their eggs.
lead_paragraph: An Australian wasp provides an important service to humans, researchers report: It paralyzes a poisonous spider, the redback.

headline: Where iPhone 5 Loses Its Way, Navigation Services Step In
abstract: Like most Android devices, the latest generation of Apple’s smartphone cannot retain route instructions when reception fades, a flaw exploited by third-party subscription services.
lead_paragraph: In the battle between Google’s Android smartphone and the Apple iPhone, free navigation is one of the most fiercely contested fronts. At least one area where Apple might have created a decisive advantage over Google has gone begging, however, in the latest generation of the iPhone, unveiled last week.

headline: Trial Begins for Police Chief in Chinese Scandal
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Wang Lijun, a key player in the fall of the politician Bo Xilai, tried to seek refuge in a United States Consulate, igniting the country’s biggest political scandal in a generation.
lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — The trial of the former police chief who was a key player in the fall of the politician Bo Xilai began in secret on Monday in this southwestern provincial capital, where he attempted to seek refuge in a United States Consulate in February.

headline: Ground Breaker
abstract: With concrete and quips, Rudy Ricciotti is shaking up architecture.
lead_paragraph: In a scorching summer day in Marseille, France, the architect Rudy Ricciotti races down a dirt path in his battered black vintage Porsche and pulls up in front of a dusty construction site on the city’s port-side docks.

headline: Protests Over Anti-Islam Film Taper Off, but Effects Linger
abstract: Though the protests are smaller in size and taking place in fewer countries, some say the backlash from the unrest could take other forms.
lead_paragraph: Protests against an anti-Islam film spilled into a second week on Monday, although they appeared to be tapering off in size and taking place in fewer countries compared with last week.

headline: Street Style: Saddlebags
abstract: The best of reader’s photos from the week of Sept. 10.
lead_paragraph: The best of reader’s photos from the week of Sept. 10.

headline: Long Wait and Worry for a Visitor to Yosemite
abstract: Weeks after his vacation, a park visitor frets while watching for symptoms of hantavirus infection.
lead_paragraph: Bears were the only thing to worry about during our stay at a tent cabin in Yosemite National Park in August, or so my husband and I thought. We scrupulously emptied the car of food and anything a bear might mistake for food, including empty wrappers and scented items like soap. We cleaned every crumb of trail mix from our tent. We stashed everything that might attract a bear in metal lockers provided by the park.

headline: Rushdie Relives Difficult Years Spent in Hiding
abstract: In “Joseph Anton” Salman Rushdie recounts the death threat against him and his years in hiding.
lead_paragraph: In 1989 the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini declared that Salman Rushdie’s novel “The Satanic Verses” was offensive to Islam and issued a fatwa against the author, sentencing him to death. For nine years Mr. Rushdie lived under the shadow of assassination, deprived of the freedom of ordinary life and made to fear for himself and his family. It was a nightmare weirdly like something out of one of his own surreal novels, and underscored the very themes he’d been grappling with for years in his fiction: namely, the emotional costs of exile and being cut off from one’s past; the consequences of globalization and the cultural clash between East and West; and the increasingly phantasmagorical nature of contemporary history.

abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: Despite Lack of Surprises, Apple Sells 2 Million New iPhones
abstract: Apple’s new iPhone 5 lacked surprises with most of its secrets spilled ahead of introduction, but that didn’t weaken early sales. Orders for the iPhone 5 surpassed two million in its first 24 hours on sale, double the previous record, held by the iPhone 4S, according to Apple. It is also beating Nokia to the market.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s announcement of its new iPhone 5 lacked surprises. Most of its secrets spilled ahead of introduction, but that didn’t weaken early sales of the phone. People ordered more than two million iPhone 5s its first 24 hours on sale, double the previous record, held by the iPhone 4S, according to Apple.

headline: Answers About Hostage Negotiation, Part 3
abstract: Taking Questions: The third and final set of answers from Capt. Frank A. Bolz Jr., a retired New York Police Department hostage negotiator.
lead_paragraph: This is the third and final set of responses from Capt. Frank A. Bolz Jr., a founder of the New York Police Department’s hostage-negotiating unit, to readers’ questions. We are no longer accepting questions.

headline: Masks Come Off for 2 Callers Who Gave WBAI Grief
abstract: After decades of being the mystery callers who constantly hounded various hosts on WBAI, the two men behind the calls finally stepped forward.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the liberal talk radio station WBAI has been hounded by a couple of conservatives calling in to taunt program hosts about their left-leaning politics and telling them in their thick Brooklyn accents to – and this was their stock phrase — “Go back to Cuba, you commies.”

headline: Little Difference Seen in Asthma Strategies
abstract: There has been no general agreement on the best way to adjust the dosage of inhaled corticosteroids used by adults with asthma.
lead_paragraph: There has been no general agreement on the best way to adjust the dosage of inhaled corticosteroids used by adults with asthma. Doctors determine the dose by assessing symptoms like lung function or by using biomarkers like exhaled nitric oxide, or they simply let patients decide how much is needed.

headline: In Greece, Restlessness Amid a Push for Cuts
abstract: Protests and strikes are gaining steam as Prime Minister Antonis Samaras renews efforts to come up with a tough new 11.5 billion euro austerity package.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Public opposition to austerity budgets deepened in Greece on Monday, with judges stopping work, doctors going on strike and public transport staff and schoolteachers planning action for later this week. The moves are a prelude to a general strike called by the country’s main labor unions for Sept. 26.

headline: U.S. Warns Judge’s Ruling Impedes Its Detention Powers
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The government said the ruling last week has jeopardized its ability to detain certain prisoners captured in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration warned Monday that a judge’s ruling last week blocking a statute authorizing the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects has jeopardized its ability to continue detaining certain prisoners captured during the war in Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: Mike Shanahan, the press officer for the International Institute for Environment and Development and an energetic participant in the invaluable Earth Journalism Network, sent a compelling reaction to my piece on the brutal murder of an environmental journalist in Cambodia that is posted here as a “Your Dot” contribution:

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Whom and What to Read to Make You Like Poetry (and Also Sci-Fi)
abstract: Stephen Burt, the Harvard professor and poet, has many brilliant peers in his generation of poetry critics, and if one doesn’t inspire you to read poetry, another might.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Burt, the Harvard professor and poet whom I wrote about in Sunday’s Education Issue, is a fanboy and an evangelist of poetry. As I wrote in the magazine, Burt defends his positivity by saying, “There’s so little airtime available for any poetry these days that when I get space and time in which I can do whatever I want, I don’t want to say, ‘X sucks.’ I almost always prefer to say, ‘Please check out Y,’ or ‘Z isn’t what you think,’ or ‘Look at what A, B and C have in common.’ ”

headline: Top Amateur in No Rush to Make Leap to Pros
abstract: Lydia Ko, the leading amateur at the Women’s British Open, said she would like to play amateur golf for a couple of years.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England

headline: Talking All Around the Food
abstract: The new $195 menu at Eleven Madison Park comes with a guided tour of New York City history, narrated by servers. But the result can be wearying, and not always flattering to the feast.
lead_paragraph: YOU know a movie is in trouble when a voice-over narrator has to explain the plot that the combined efforts of screenwriter, director and editor failed to make clear. Something like that is going on at Eleven Madison Park, which just eliminated its $125 prix fixe option and now offers only one menu, a $195 blowout that lasts about four hours.

headline: Deferred Prosecution Agreements and Cookie-Cutter Justice
keywords: ['Deferred Prosecution Agreements', 'Law and Legislation', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: Deferred and nonprosecution agreements allow prosecutors to take a more nuanced approach. Yet use of the government’s “sledgehammer” seems to have largely disappeared, so that a full-scale prosecution of a large corporation is at best a rarity.
lead_paragraph: Lanny A. Breuer, the head of the Justice Department’s Criminal Division, last week spoke to the New York City Bar Association, extolling the virtues of deferred and nonprosecution agreements as the new standard for how the Justice Department deals with criminal conduct by corporations.

headline: The ‘Anthropocene’ as Environmental Meme and/or Geological Epoch
abstract: A debate builds over the notion that humans have become a geological force powerful enough to leave a permanent record.
lead_paragraph: Paul Voosen, who’s one of my favorite science journalists these days, has written a fine piece examining the scientific and societal debate over the Anthropocene, the proposed term for this era in which human decisions (or indecision) will leave a durable mark in planetary systems and even in the planet’s stratified rock.* (The video above explores the Anthropocene as environmental meme.)

headline: ‘Chaplin’ Off to Quiet Start at Broadway Box Office
abstract: The musical biography of the silent-film star took in $460,925 at the box office in its first full week.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway musical “Chaplin” grossed a modest $460,925 in ticket sales in its first full week of performances since opening to largely negative reviews on Sept. 10, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers.

headline: Vasiliev Joins American Ballet Theater as Principal Dancer
abstract: American Ballet Theater has recruited Ivan Vasiliev as a principal dancer, and will cast him during next year’s season at the Metropolitan Opera and on tours.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater has recruited Ivan Vasiliev as a principal dancer, and will cast him during next year’s season at the Metropolitan Opera and on tours, the company said on Monday. Mr. Vasiliev and the ballerina Natalia Osipova created a stir nearly a year ago when they announced they were leaving Moscow’s Bolshoi Ballet for the Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg. Mr. Vasiliev, who was born in 1989 in Vladivostok, Russia, made his debut at the Bolshoi in 2006 as Basilio in “Don Quixote” and made guest appearances at Ballet Theater last year. His roles with the company included Solor in “La Bayadère,” Franz in “Coppélia” and Ali in “Le Corsaire.”

headline: Metallica in London
abstract: I loved this shot during the finale at Jonathan Saunders, capturing the movement and shine of some sequined dresses.
lead_paragraph: I loved this shot during the finale at Jonathan Saunders, capturing the movement and shine of some sequined dresses. Get ready for more metallic tones from Burberry.

headline: A Possible Breakthrough in Explaining a Mathematical Riddle
abstract: A Japanese mathematician has released 500 pages of work on a problem known as the abc conjecture. Other mathematicians are excited, but bewildered by the proof.
lead_paragraph: Numbers, addition, multiplication — the basic stuff of grade-school arithmetic — are suddenly the excited talk of cutting-edge mathematicians.

headline: Patriots’ Injury Highlights a Receiving Shift
abstract: The Patriots’ ineffectiveness without tight end Aaron Hernandez, who was lost to injury, and the diminished role of Wes Welker show an offense in transition.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Belichick selected tight ends Rob Gronkowski and Aaron Hernandez two rounds apart in the 2010 draft, the rest of the N.F.L. took note. At the time, the New England offense rarely focused on the tight end, instead revolving around wide receivers like Randy Moss and Wes Welker.

headline: Preparing to Tilt on Level Ground
abstract: Workers put together “Armor for the Joust of Peace,” from about 1500, in the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Workers putting together “Armor for the Joust of Peace,” from about 1500, in the Great Hall at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday. The armor was bought by the Met in 1904, one of the museum’s earliest acquisitions. It has not been on display in nearly 25 years. Click here to see a larger version..

headline: An Atom Smasher Is Squeezed Through a Museum’s Doors
abstract: A machine that was part of the Manhattan Project, which led to the development of the atomic bomb, was carefully delivered to the New-York Historical Society to be part of an upcoming exhibition.
lead_paragraph: If physics has to do with the actions and reactions of something, then this is about physics. But really it is about a thing — a thing that was at the heart of breakthrough physics experiments that led to the crash program for the atom bomb in World War II.

headline: For Maimed Veterans, Animal Tissue Offers Hope of Repair
abstract: One Marine finds new mobility after receiving a graft from the bladder of a pig that helped regrow some of the muscle he lost in a bomb blast in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of veterans of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars have been maimed in explosions and have lost so much muscle from an arm or a leg that amputation is sometimes the best alternative. But in today’s paper, our colleague Henry Fountain tracks a new treatment still in development that helped one Marine regain much of his lost mobility — using material from a pig’s bladder.

headline: An Extra Dose of N.F.L. Parity
abstract: Only six teams will have 2-0 records after Week 2 ends Monday tonight, provided that Atlanta and Denver don’t produce a rare tie.
lead_paragraph: There will be only six undefeated N.F.L. teams after Week 2 ends late tonight, with either Denver or Atlanta joining Houston, San Diego, Philadelphia, Arizona and San Francisco (provided that Denver and Atlanta don’t produce a rare tie).

headline: Over 2,000 Miles, Hauling the Memory of the Mother Road
abstract: A convoy of vintage commercial trucks traced the shadow of Old Route 66 from Illinois to California.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.– The Historic Highway Convoy 2012, consisting of 30 vintage trucks of modest and mighty proportions, had spent eight days and 2,000 miles on the road, tracing the remnants of Old Route 66, before rumbling into the Inland Empire on Saturday morning.

abstract: Hardly any surprise that Mary Katrantzou and Peter Pilotto showed prints, but the spring affair with stripes continues across the pond.
lead_paragraph: Hardly any surprise that Mary Katrantzou and Peter Pilotto showed prints, but the spring affair with stripes continues across the pond. Mr. Pilotto’s stripes looked fragmented or blended with checks. Jonathan Saunders did straight-forward versions but also some lovely diagonal bands on silk dresses.

headline: Dictionary Translates Ancient Egypt Life
keywords: ['Egyptian Civilization', 'Dictionaries', 'Books and Literature', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: The first dictionary of Demotic Egyptian, the language common people spoke in ancient Egypt while the pharaohs were drawing their hieroglyphics, has just been completed.
lead_paragraph: Ancient Egyptians did not speak to posterity only through hieroglyphs. Those elaborate pictographs were the elite script for recording the lives and triumphs of pharaohs in their tombs and on the monumental stones along the Nile. But almost from the beginning, people in everyday life spoke a different language and wrote a different script, a simpler one that evolved from the earliest hieroglyphs.
