headline: My Grandmother’s Cappelletti
abstract: I grew up making cappelletti and ravioli alongside my mother and grandmother, and in my own way, I’m passing that tradition on.
lead_paragraph: 1:54 p.m. | Updated By the time I came along, both my mother’s and my father’s families had been in the United States for two generations. I never felt particularly “Italian,” in spite of my very ethnic last name. Mine was not a family settled into an Italian-American enclave and gathered around weekly, shouting at one another in a style familiar from so many films, and eating pasta with the sauce they called “Sunday gravy.” No, they assimilated, and quickly.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bad Piggies Trailer and Android App Art
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday’s selection includes Hewlett-Packard putting new emphasis on design, a NASA group that’s trying to come up with warp drive for space travel and a new game from Rovio featuring those insufferable pigs from Angry Birds.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Exaggerating Your Race Results
abstract: Why do athletes shave a few minutes off their times, or add a few pounds to the amount they can bench press?
lead_paragraph: It was my first half marathon, and I was anxious and jittery. I had never run more than 12 miles, and this race went on for 13.1. How was I supposed to hold a pace for that distance?

headline: Google Buys Nik to Lure Photographers to Google Plus
abstract: In its latest defensive move against Facebook, Google said on Monday that it had bought Nik Software, which makes tools like the Snapseed mobile app for editing and sharing photos. Nik has a following among serious photographers, a group that Google Plus is trying to attract.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Monday that it had acquired Nik Software, a company that makes tools for editing and sharing photos. It is Google’s latest defensive move against Facebook and part of its strategy to become a photo-sharing hub.

headline: An Opera’s Real Story Is Its Choreography
abstract: Where other operas have a story, “Einstein on the Beach,” in revival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has stage images that move to music.
lead_paragraph: Although “Einstein on the Beach,” the 1976 collaboration between Robert Wilson and Philip Glass that is in revival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is labeled “an opera in four acts,” the tag that Mr. Wilson gave to some of his earlier theatrical works might also serve: “dance play.”

headline: He’s Wild and Crazy, but a Subtle Guy, Too
abstract: A new boxed set of comedy DVDs, “Steve Martin: The Television Stuff,” illustrates his evolution from a comedian working in intimate settings to one playing to a mass audience.
lead_paragraph: No stand-up comic has arguably ever been bigger than Steve Martin. His albums sold in the millions. His act drew crowds in the tens of thousands. Critics adored him. Then, at the height of his success, he quit.

headline: The Politics of Intimacy
abstract: The romance between a Hollywood actress and a Washington politician, born in the 2008 campaign, is put to the test in “Us.”
lead_paragraph: Every election season is a reminder that the personal is political; now, in Michelle Clunie’s “Us,” a two-person play at the Lion Theater, we see how the political can be very personal indeed.

headline: A Wave of Staggering Loss, in a Country Unprepared
abstract: Ric Burns’s “Death and the Civil War,” part of “American Experience” on PBS, looks at the unprecedented number who died in the fighting.
lead_paragraph: PBS’s “American Experience” can feel formulaic, but the episode on Tuesday, “Death and the Civil War,” makes itself wrenching and riveting by throwing out some of the formulas that have become familiar in documentaries about the war.

headline: Suddenly There Came a Clapping
abstract: An original musical about Poe’s last days brings to light the man, with the clichés scrubbed away, and his work.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The last, distraught days of Edgar Allan Poe are charted with spellbinding vitality in “Red-Eye to Havre de Grace,” a highlight of the theatrical offerings at this year’s Live Arts Festival here. At times funny, at times heartbreaking, and from quirky start to haunting finish a feast of entrancing visual allurements, this exquisite show is among the most original musical theater works I’ve seen in years.

headline: Vaccine’s Power Wanes After Last Dose
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Medicine and Health', 'Research', 'Tetanus', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Whooping Cough']
abstract: Children usually receive five doses of DTaP, the combination vaccine that protects against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis. Researchers report that its power declines rapidly after the final dose.
lead_paragraph: Before age 7, children usually receive five doses of DTaP, the combination vaccine that protects against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis. The acellular pertussis vaccine now in use has fewer side effects than the older whole-cell version.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Christopher Kane
abstract: The look for spring: androgynous and sexy.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Sleep…walking Beauty.

headline: Be a Star, Then You Can Judge
abstract: By naming Christina Aguilera as a judge, “The Voice” changed music competition reality shows.
lead_paragraph: Years from now, Christina Aguilera will be remembered for her glamour, her scandalous take on femme-pop and her Brobdingnagian voice. But she should also be remembered as the person who almost single-handedly reshaped music-competition reality programming. Her legacy as a judge on “The Voice,” on NBC, may well turn out to be deeper and more profound than the one she’s forged in her music career.

headline: Trauma: Manga as Medical Tool
keywords: ['Blood', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Medicine and Health', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: In his quest to get surgeons to adopt a little-known generic drug to save hemorrhaging patients, a British doctor has produced a new tool: a manga comic.
lead_paragraph: In his unending quest to get surgeons to adopt a little-known generic drug to save hemorrhaging patients, a British doctor has produced a new medical-education tool: a manga comic.

headline: Mariah Carey, ‘Never a Fan of This Type of Thing,’ Tells How ‘Idol’ Drew Her In
abstract: The show’s new superstar-stocked judging panel, including Ms. Carey, Nicki Minaj and Keith Urban, met the press on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The new superstar-stocked judging panel of “American Idol” was already at work Monday auditioning hopefuls at Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan for a second day, having begun on Sunday immediately after announcing its new additions for the season.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, India, Indonesia and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, India, Indonesia and South Korea.

headline: Music From Pink, Dwight Yoakam and Aimee Mann
abstract: In her new album, “The Truth About Love,” Pink continues to put unruly lyrics in neat pop packages.
lead_paragraph: PINK

headline: Village Voice Appoints a Music Editor
abstract: Brian McManus, a former editor at Philadelphia Weekly, will replace Maura Johnston, who was fired last week, around the same time that The Voice’s editor said he was quitting.
lead_paragraph: The Village Voice has named a new music editor, three days after it emerged that the weekly’s editor was departing and its music editor had been fired.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Makes Some Intriguing Bets on Romney
abstract: An outside group believes Mitt Romney has a chance to win two states Barack Obama captured in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney may have had a bad run in polls in recent weeks, but he still has supporters who are bullish about his chances in some states that President Obama won handily in 2008.

headline: Ford and Canadian Workers in Tentative Deal
abstract: After reaching the accord with Ford, the autoworkers union said it had extended contract negotiations with General Motors of Canada and Chrysler Canada.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The Canadian Auto Workers union reached a tentative contract deal with the Ford Motor Company of Canada on Monday just hours before a midnight strike deadline.

headline: Financial Strains Said to Threaten Stability of Palestinian Authority
abstract: As the Palestinian Authority marks the 19th anniversary of the signing of the Oslo Accords, it is facing a financial crisis that experts say could threaten its future operations and stability.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As the Palestinian Authority marks the 19th anniversary this month of the signing of the Oslo Accords, the agreement with Israel that brought it into existence, the authority is facing a financial crisis that experts say could threaten its future operations and stability.

headline: All the TV News Since 2009, on One Web Site
keywords: ['Television', 'Archives and Records', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Internet Archive plans to make more than 350,000 programs available on its Web site beginning Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by a pillar of antiquity, the Library of Alexandria, Brewster Kahle has a grand vision for the Internet Archive, the giant aggregator and digitizer of data, which he founded and leads.

headline: Christopher Kane Has a Gift for You
abstract: The clothes at Christpher Kane looked put together with the care of a beautifully wrapped package, and, of course, they played with the notion of women as pretty objects, tied with bows.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before the Christopher Kane show, in a high-rise near Oxford Street, the casting director Russell Marsh was playing Burt Lancaster to a bunch of blank-faced girls. He was giving them orders, drill-sergeant style, about not mussing up their clothes. Mr. Marsh probably gives such instructions routinely, but the spring collection of Mr. Kane was visibly delicate — in tissue paper-like silks and crepes, and in pale sugary pinks, yellow and dead white.

headline: Iranian Cleric Says Rushdie’s Murder Could Stop Insults to Islam’s Prophet
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: An Iranian religious foundation reportedly raised the price on the novelist Salman Rushdie’s head to $3.3 million, claiming that his murder would stop others from disrespecting Islam’s founding prophet.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Michiko Kakutani explains in her review of the novelist Salman Rushdie’s new memoir, an Iranian religious foundation reportedly raised the price on his head over the weekend to $3.3 million. The cleric who leads the foundation claimed that Mr. Rushdie’s murder would stop others from disrespecting Islam’s founder, The Associated Press reported from Tehran.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Burberry
abstract: A look at some of the products behind the unassuming sexiness of the Burberry girl.
lead_paragraph: The Look: Sunny English girl thrown into the ’40s.

headline: In Video Clip, Romney Calls 47% ‘Dependent’ and Feeling Entitled
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A video of Mitt Romney at a fund-raiser shows him saying that those who pay no federal taxes would vote for President Obama “no matter what.”
lead_paragraph: 12:26 a.m., Sept. 18 | Updated

headline: Seeking Positives on a Final Homestand
abstract: The Mets returned to Citi Field to start one last homestand in a season that has wandered well off track.
lead_paragraph: The Mets returned to Citi Field on Monday to start one last homestand in a season that has wandered well off track.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Burberry Prorsum
abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week photo diary of Linda Brownlee.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Grappling With Details of Medicare Proposals
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Election-year proposals to transform Medicare have older Americans asking many questions, and getting few answers.
lead_paragraph: When Claire Celsi’s father-in-law died in July, the one thing her mother-in-law did not have to worry about was the $300,000 hospital bill. Medicare covered most of it.

headline: Liu Supporters Invoke the Holocaust and Nixon in Faulting an F.B.I. Inquiry
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Supporters of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, criticized an investigation into Mr. Liu’s fund-raising practices, invoking the name Nixon and even the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: A former congressman on Monday called the federal investigation into the fund-raising practices of John C. Liu, the city comptroller, a “Nixonian” form of “harassment and persecution.”

headline: Baseball’s 500,000th Error Finds Jose Reyes
abstract: The march to Major League Baseball’s dubious milestone of 500,000 errors, while not official, illuminated the fact that the best fielders often make the most errors.
lead_paragraph: As baseball approached its unofficial 500,000th error, one thing was clear: a shortstop would most likely make it, since that position is most closely associated with the statistic.

headline: A Child’s Cancer Story Inspires Taylor Swift
abstract: Taylor Swift’s heart-rending song “Ronan,” about the too-short life of a little boy, was based on his mother’s blog and her family’s quest for his cancer treatment.
lead_paragraph: By now you may have heard Taylor Swift’s heart-rending song “Ronan,” about the too-short life of a little boy. Ms. Swift gave it an emotional performance on the Stand Up to Cancer telethon on Sept. 7, and it has been topping the charts ever since.

headline: Congressional Republicans Raise Questions About New York Investigations
abstract: Congressional Republicans issued a letter to the New York attorney general, raising questions about his investigations into private equity firms and politically active tax-exempt groups.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans on Monday issued a letter to Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, raising questions about his investigations into private equity firms and politically active tax-exempt groups.

headline: Burberry: View From a Bridge
abstract: The trench coat remains the main event at the British company.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bailey may have opened the Burberry show with a creamy white cape over a pleated silk bodysuit — the perfect outfit for a bareback circus rider — but a trench coat remains the main event at the British company. In a collection called “Corsets and Capes,” Mr. Bailey gave a clean, tighter, sensual line to his many coats (including a style that bled from red into pink), cute satin shorts and handsome lace dresses. The winners were the sleek trenches in leather, satin or micropleated satin, though perhaps the optimistic colors — inky blue, fuchsia, copper, pink, lipstick red — were the centerpiece of a polished, newsy show. You half wondered if London, seen from a Thames River bridge at night, was the inspiration for the jewel palette.

headline: Assembly Releases Documents Listing Sexual Harassment Settlement
abstract: A list of Assembly expenditures included a settlement paid to two women who had accused Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez of sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The State Assembly on Monday released a list of its 2012 expenditures from the part of its budget that was used to pay a secret sexual harassment settlement this summer.

headline: Catholics Then, Muslims Now
abstract: Prejudice against Muslim immigrants resembles the anti-Catholic views of 60 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Toronto

headline: Maverick Minister in India Is as Perplexing as She Is Powerful
abstract: Mamata Banerjee, the chief minister of West Bengal, is praised and maligned in equal measure. But Indians agree that she has the ability to bring down India’s governing coalition.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — When Mamata Banerjee, a 5-foot-tall dynamo in flip-flops, finally defeated the Communists last year after decades of misrule here, she became one of the most powerful but unpredictable politicians in India. Now the country is left to guess whether she will announce on Tuesday that she intends to try to pull down India’s governing coalition.

headline: Newsweek’s ‘Muslim Rage’ Cover Mocked Online
abstract: Seizing on Newsweek’s invitation to discuss its provocative cover story under the Twitter hashtag #MuslimRage, thousands of Muslim users of the social network mocked the premise
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After a week of violent protests over an online video demeaning the Prophet Muhammad, the American news media has conducted a searching psychoanalysis of the Muslim mind to ask why such an offense should trigger such wrath. Essayists have generalized about resentments dating back to the 8th century, an anachronistic discomfort with modernity, or the excesses of Islamist politics, among other familiar themes.

headline: Czechs See Peril in a Bootleg Bottle
abstract: The Czech Republic has banned the sale of liquor containing 20 percent or higher alcohol content after at least 20 people were killed from consuming methanol-tainted spirits.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — The Czech Republic has banned the sale of liquor containing 20 percent or higher alcohol content after at least 20 people were killed and dozens of others were seriously injured from consuming methanol-tainted spirits.

headline: Louis Simpson, Poet of Everyday Life, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Simpson won the Pulitzer Prize in 1964 for “At the End of the Open Road,” and taught for many years at Berkeley and Stony Brook.
lead_paragraph: Louis Simpson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet who told characteristically American tales of common people and often cast a skeptical eye on the American dream, died on Friday at his home in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 89.

headline: My Grandmother's Cappelletti
abstract: To teach a cousin too young to learn to make cappelletti and ravioli from my grandmother, our family created a video recipe, and a memory.
lead_paragraph: To teach a cousin too young to learn to make cappelletti and ravioli from my grandmother, our family created a video recipe, and a memory.

headline: Savoring Success by Expanding the Brand
abstract: McCormick & Company, the spice maker, has opened a retail store for the first time in its long history.
lead_paragraph: AS savings accounts shrank in recent years, spice racks expanded, with Americans cooking more to save money.

headline: Success of Crowdfunding Puts Pressure on Entrepreneurs
abstract: Crowdfunding is a popular and lucrative source of money for entrepreneurs, but it is not always easy to turn a good idea into a profitable product.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — An effort to build a sleek aluminum charging dock for the iPhone generated fervor online when it was announced last December. The project’s creators raised close to $1.5 million through Kickstarter, a crowdfunding Web site, and promised to start shipping their Elevation Dock in April to those who had backed the project.

headline: Manhattan’s Power Breakfast Must Move
abstract: The Loews Regency Hotel, whose breakfast room is a celebrated haunt of political deal-makers, will shut for perhaps a year for renovations.
lead_paragraph: The breakfast room at the Loews Regency Hotel has long been a favorite forum for New York’s political elite. But is that daily gathering of power brokers over $24 omelets and $8 coffees a movable feast?

headline: In a School Built on Trust, Metal Detectors Inject Fear
abstract: Bushwick Community High School in Brooklyn has thrived as a place for last-chance teenagers, but despite years of serenity, city Education Department officials tightened security.
lead_paragraph: It looms inside the door of the school on Palmetto Street, a hunk of metal and a rubber belt. Innocuous, right?

headline: Breaking Up the Echo
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hearing both sides of an argument doesn’t tend to sway those with rigid views.
lead_paragraph: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Maneuvering in an Unsettled Mideast
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Readers respond to news and opinion articles about the Arab unrest.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Occupy Wall Street: A Frenzy That Fizzled
abstract: The protests that began a year ago changed little, and were not much more than a fad that left a lasting chant: We are the 99 percent.
lead_paragraph: It will be an asterisk in the history books, if it gets a mention at all.

headline: Pennsylvania: Board Denies Clemency
abstract: Pennsylvania’s Board of Pardons denied on Monday an application for clemency by Terrance Williams, a convicted murderer who is scheduled to be executed on Oct. 3.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania’s Board of Pardons in Harrisburg denied on Monday an application for clemency by Terrance Williams, a convicted murderer who is scheduled to be executed on Oct. 3. Clemency requires unanimous approval by the five-member board, and the vote was only 3 to 2 in favor of the application. Shawn Nolan, Mr. Williams’s attorney, argued that Mr. Williams had been beaten and sexually abused during childhood, and had killed Amos Norwood in Philadelphia in 1984 after the victim sexually abused him from the age of 13. Tom Dolgenos of the Philadelphia district attorney’s office said the allegations of sexual abuse were “hearsay” raised by Mr. Williams years after his 1986 trial in an attempt to prevent the execution. Mr. Williams is now seeking a stay of execution in a state court.

headline: Israeli Diplomat Is Man in Middle
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Ambassador Michael B. Oren, who happens to have been born and bred in New Jersey, is representing a prime minister who has infuriated the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel engaged in an unusually public dispute with the Obama administration over Iran, Mr. Netanyahu’s man in Washington, Michael B. Oren, has been working rooms all over town.

headline: Friends You Can Count On
abstract: Why your friends seem to have more friends than you do: a mathematical explanation.
lead_paragraph: You spend your time tweeting, friending, liking, poking, and in the few minutes left, cultivating friends in the flesh. Yet sadly, despite all your efforts, you probably have fewer friends than most of your friends have. But don’t despair — the same is true for almost all of us. Our friends are typically more popular than we are.

headline: ‘Scream’ to Go on View at MoMA
abstract: After paying nearly $120 million for it at auction, the new owner of Edvard Munch’s “Scream” is lending it to the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Edvard Munch’s 1895 version of “The Scream” — which became the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction when it brought nearly $120 million at Sotheby’s in May — will go on view at the Museum of Modern Art, courtesy of its new mystery owner, for six months, starting on Oct. 24.

headline: Libya, Violence and Free Speech
abstract: It shouldn’t come as a surprise to us that not everyone in the world worships the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: Back when Salman Rushdie was made the object of a fatwa because his book “The Satanic Verses” was regarded by many Iranians as a blasphemy against the prophet, I went to a conference where a panel discussion was devoted to Rushdie’s situation. A member of the audience raised his hand and, without a trace of irony, asked, “What’s the matter with those Iranians? Haven’t they ever heard of the First Amendment?”

headline: Massachusetts: Health Official Resigns
abstract: The commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Public Health resigned on Monday amid allegations that a chemist at a state drug laboratory mishandled evidence samples.
lead_paragraph: The commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, John Auerbach, resigned on Monday amid allegations that a chemist at a state drug laboratory mishandled evidence samples, potentially affecting 34,000 criminal cases. Gov. Deval Patrick ordered the laboratory shut down late last month as prosecutors, the state police and the state attorney general’s office investigate whether Annie Dookhan, a chemist, breached protocol, potentially causing wrongful convictions in state cases. Mr. Auerbach is the most senior official to step down in the scandal; last week, the laboratory’s director resigned and another official there was fired.

headline: Speaking the Truth to the Vatican
abstract: The Vatican could stop worrying about what Roman Catholic nuns are up to if it just looked at the work being done at Providence House in New York.
lead_paragraph: After years of drug addiction, serial theft and hard prison time, a 54-year-old mother named Renee is entering a revolutionary phase of her life — transition from a rehabilitation sanctuary in Coney Island to the possibility of self-reliance in the outside world. The sanctuary is one of several outposts of Providence House, a recovery program run by the Sisters of St. Joseph, a society of street-tough, adaptive New York nuns. The program has nurtured more than 12,000 women parolees and their children back from the brink.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for Sept. 17, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: A Pier to Pay for a Park
abstract: Legislators need to find a way to save the deteriorating Pier 40, one of the largest sources of revenue of the cherished Hudson River Park.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers cherish their access to the piers and green spaces that make up the Hudson River Park, which stretches from Pier 99 near 59th St. to Battery Place. Established by state law in 1998, the park gives urbanites a chance to stroll along one the nation’s great rivers.

headline: Voters Annoyed by Hard-to-Read Ballots
abstract: Voters in last Thursday’s primary were handed ballots with candidates’ names printed in an eye-straining 7-point type, akin to the ingredient list on the side of a cereal box.
lead_paragraph: Some states want their voters to take ID cards to the polls.

headline: Chicago Standoff
abstract: An unnecessary strike is brought on by distrust and provocations from both the city and the teachers’ union.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago teachers’ strike should serve as an object lesson about the dangers of incendiary language in labor negotiations. The strike, which appeared to be near settlement over the weekend, has continued after angry union delegates failed to vote to return to work on Sunday. The dispute need never have reached this point, with 350,000 students starting a second week out of classes.

headline: Iranian Official Says Blasts Targeted Nuclear Sites
abstract: Iran’s top atomic energy official said that explosions were intended to cut power to two uranium enrichment facilities and claimed saboteurs had infiltrated an international inspection agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran’s most senior atomic energy official revealed on Monday that separate explosions, which he attributed to sabotage, had targeted power supplies to the country’s two main uranium enrichment facilities, including the deep underground site that American and Israeli officials say is the most invulnerable to bombing.

headline: Stuck in the Present, Mets Look to the Future
abstract: The Mets had a few positives this season — R. A. Dickey, David Wright and a no-hitter — but they finished 15 games under .500, and neither Dickey nor Wright is signed past 2013.
lead_paragraph: Something big was brewing at Citi Field on Monday. At least that is how it looked. The Mets installed three rows of temporary seats behind the backstop, on either side of home plate, the way they did at Shea Stadium for the playoffs and World Series. There were so many folding chairs and so much plexiglass that you almost expected the league president to ask for Jay Howell’s glove.

headline: Russell E. Train, Conservationist Who Helped Create the E.P.A., Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Train was among a select group of officials who shaped the world’s first comprehensive program for scrubbing the skies and waters of pollution.
lead_paragraph: Russell E. Train, a renowned conservationist who played a central role in the creation of groundbreaking laws and effective enforcement in response to rising concerns about environmental protection in America, died on Monday at his farm in Bozman, Md. He was 92.

headline: Professors and the Students Who Grade Them
abstract: Are college students' evaluations of their instructors a useful way to assess professors? What might be more effective?

abstract: A neuroradiologist responds to an Op-Ed article, “Dying to Play.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Protecting the Gulf Coast
abstract: An Environmental Defense Fund official says wetlands are crucial, in addition to levees.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Deterring Cyberthreats
abstract: A cybersecurity expert responds to an editorial about how governments respond to cyberthreats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bucs’ Schiano Defends Final Play of Loss to Giants
abstract: To some, Coach Greg Schiano crossed an unspoken line Sunday when his defensive unit crashed the Giants’ victory formation in the final seconds of their 41-34 win.
lead_paragraph: Through Pop Warner, high school and college, football players are coached to compete until the final whistle and take nothing for granted. Greg Schiano instilled that kind of fight into his teams in turning around a downtrodden program during his 11 years at Rutgers. He has said he intends to bring that never-say-die philosophy to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in his first season as their coach.

headline: Widow Takes On Congressman Who Ousted Her Husband
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Shelley Adler is challenging Representative Jon Runyan, who rode a wave of Tea Party support to unseat her husband in New Jersey’s Third District in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Shelley Adler was still mourning her husband’s death when the thought hit her: Why not run for his old Congressional seat? But when she approached her husband’s longtime political adviser and close friend, he gently discouraged her.

headline: Restoring the Walls, and the History, at Hitler’s Wolf’s Lair
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Polish government has decided that the Wolf’s Lair, the outpost where Hitler commanded the Third Reich for years, holds valuable history lessons that need to be preserved.
lead_paragraph: KETRZYN, Poland — For nearly three years, Hitler commanded the Third Reich from a vast network of bunkers and buildings hidden in the forest here, guiding his genocidal war effort from an encampment called the Wolf’s Lair.

headline: On a Challenging Day, Romney Seeks to Shift to His Policy Specifics
abstract: Until now, Mitt Romney’s campaign had been focused almost entirely on criticizing President Obama.
lead_paragraph: An effort by Mitt Romney to give his campaign new direction — built around new ads intended to highlight how a Romney presidency would take the nation on a better course than President Obama — was quickly overshadowed on Monday by the video of Mr. Romney’s unscripted remarks at a fund-raiser several months ago.

headline: New York’s Medicaid Reforms
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Editorials']
abstract: Proving which initiatives work could turn the state into a model for others on how to cut Medicaid without harming the beneficiaries.
lead_paragraph: New York State has substantially changed its Medicaid program in the past year and a half in ways likely to improve the health of its poorest residents and rein in the program’s enormous costs.

headline: M.T.A. Chief’s Latest Bold Move: Using Twitter by Himself
abstract: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is unfettered compared with most public officials on Twitter, who usually have a team operating their account.
lead_paragraph: It began inconspicuously enough — a Ronald Reagan quote here, a whiff of harmless promotion there — the mark of a seasoned city official wading cautiously into social media.

headline: Jets Turn Backs on a Game That Slipped Right Through Their Hands
abstract: The Jets’ defense, expected to carry the team while it installs a new offense, struggled in Sunday’s loss to the Steelers.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On the ninth play of a 14-play drive that ate up more than 10 minutes of the fourth quarter, Pittsburgh running back Isaac Redman took a handoff and proceeded to shrug off what seemed like half the Jets’ defense. His right knee appeared to scuff the grass at Heinz Field while he was trapped in the backfield, and safety Yeremiah Bell wrestled the ball from Redman as he made the tackle. After an officials’ review, the Steelers kept the ball, and Redman got 6 yards.

headline: Look How Far We’ve Come Apart
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Political polarization in America is at its highest level since the late 19th century. Can we do anything about it?
lead_paragraph: In the witches’ brew of fearmongering, unkeepable promises and poll-tested metaphors that both parties serve up to the electorate every four years, you can always find this predictable dash of inspiration: the image of Americans uniting and working together for the sake of the country. President Obama said in Charlotte, N.C. that America is “about what can be done by us, together.” In Tampa, Paul Ryan said, “Whatever your political party, let’s come together for the sake of our country.” And Mitt Romney closed his convention speech with three invocations of “That America, that united America.”

headline: Thurston Howell Romney
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Welfare (US)']
abstract: Did you hear about Mitt Romney’s comments from a fund-raiser earlier this year? They seemed to suggest that Romney doesn’t understand America.
lead_paragraph: In 1980, about 30 percent of Americans received some form of government benefits. Today, as Nicholas Eberstadt of the American Enterprise Institute has pointed out, about 49 percent do.

headline: How to Fix the Schools
abstract: In Chicago, they’re fighting over the wrong things. Just look at what the top-performing education systems do.
lead_paragraph: No matter how quickly the Chicago teachers’ strike ends, whether it is this afternoon or two months from now, it’s not going to end well for the city’s public school students. Yes, I know; that’s the hoariest of clichés. But that doesn’t mean it’s not true.

headline: College English Dept. Fights Class-Time Cuts
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Reading and Writing Skills', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Members of the English department at Queensborough Community College voted against a universitywide proposal and were met with fierce opposition from the college administration.
lead_paragraph: When members of the English department at Queensborough Community College voted last week against a plan to curtail their basic writing courses to three hours a week from four, they said they wanted to send the school a message: “We support our students,” Elise Denbo, a lecturer in the department, said Monday. “Sometimes they need extra time.”

headline: Pettitte Rejoins Jeter in Another Stretch Run
abstract: Andy Pettitte’s scheduled start Tuesday against the Toronto Blue Jays will be his 42nd against a team he has beaten 21 times.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees trotted onto the field to celebrate another victory in their ritual hand-slapping conga line on Sunday, Andy Pettitte grabbed Derek Jeter from behind in a bear hug, and the two players, both dealing with injured left ankles, laughed as they headed to the clubhouse.

headline: For Young Jews, a Service Says, ‘Please, Do Text’
abstract: Organizers of an offbeat Jewish service in Miami Beach used the language of the tech generation to try to keep young adults connected to their roots.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — Settling into their seats for Rosh Hashana service, the twentysomethings instinctively reached for their cellphones to turn them off, anticipating an admonition they hear often at synagogue.

headline: Stop Fretting
abstract: Andrew Reynolds climbs to his debut.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you grew up when I did (I’m not going to be specific, but I will say that I am old enough to have been a devoted fan), you weren’t a fan of the rock and roll music unless you owned, played, memorized the liner notes of, and basically worshipped the album “Led Zeppelin IV.” This was the iconic album that contained the song “STAIRWAY TO HEAVEN,” which became the song of a generation and is celebrating the 40th (now 41st) anniversary of its release in November of 1971.

headline: Condé Nast Plans French Vanity Fair
abstract: “We need to have the French point of view,” said Xavier Romatet, president of Condé Nast France. “We need to be much more close to the French culture.”
lead_paragraph: Vanity Fair magazine, which has been battling declining newsstand sales in the United States, is looking for more readers in Europe. Next year, Condé Nast is starting a monthly edition of Vanity Fair in France. The magazine will share the name of the American publication, but nearly 90 percent of the content will be original.

headline: Gaza: Hamas Court Convicts 4 in Murder of Activist
abstract: A Hamas military court on Monday convicted four Palestinians of taking part in the 2011 kidnapping and killing of a pro-Palestinian Italian activist in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: A Hamas military court on Monday convicted four Palestinians of taking part in the 2011 kidnapping and killing of a pro-Palestinian Italian activist in the Gaza Strip. Two of the defendants received life sentences for kidnapping and killing the activist, Vittorio Arrigoni, in April 2011. A third man was sentenced to 10 years for taking part in the kidnapping, and a fourth defendant was sentenced to a year for sheltering the kidnappers, said Khalil Shahin of the Palestinian Center for Human Rights. At the time, an extremist Salafist group claimed responsibility for kidnapping Mr. Arrigoni, 36, and demanded that Hamas release all Salafists from its prisons. Mr. Arrigoni was found dead before the kidnappers’ deadline had expired. The suspects were later captured by Hamas’s security force. Mr. Arrigoni was a member of the International Solidarity Movement, a pro-Palestinian activist organization with foreign volunteers in the West Bank and Gaza.

headline: Mets, Unable to Help Dickey to His 19th Win, Continue to Struggle at Home
abstract: After falling to the Philadelphia Phillies, the Mets have now lost seven straight games at Citi Field and have not scored more than three runs at home since Aug. 12.
lead_paragraph: The Mets have returned to Citi Field, where they will have roughly a week and a half to leave some sort of lasting positive impression upon their fans before the off-season.

headline: One Day, Growing Spare Parts Inside the Body
abstract: A surgeon is working on a different method of organ regeneration, so far only in animals — using another part of the body to nourish the replacement as it grows and is ready for transplanting.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Dr. Tracy Grikscheit held a length of intestine in her gloved hands, examining it inch by inch as if she were checking a bicycle tube for leaks.

headline: Behind the ‘People Who Pay No Income Tax’
abstract: Mitt Romney is right that about half of American households do not pay federal income tax. That reflects the way the tax burden has been designed — including provisions championed by Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Mother Jones has published a video of Mitt Romney at a private fund-raiser making incendiary remarks about Obama voters – and, well, about half of the electorate.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Alternate-side cleaning is suspended for Rosh Hashana.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Gulati Talks About New Women’s Coach and New Women’s League
abstract: U.S. Soccer president Sunil Gulati said Monday that he wants to have a coach in place for the women’s national team before Halloween, and that there is a still chance there will be a new league for the team’s players to work in as soon as next spring.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Soccer president Sunil Gulati said Monday that he wants to have a coach in place for the women’s national team before Halloween, and that there is a still chance there will be a new league for the team’s players to work in as soon as next spring. Completing the first task, it seems, will be much easier.

headline: Last Chapter for a Court With a Place in History
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The federal courthouse in Meridian, Miss., built in 1933 and with a rich history from the civil rights era, is one of six scheduled to close, mostly in the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: MERIDIAN, Miss. — Across the street from a barbershop and upstairs from a post office sits a big empty room where Mississippi once began to face up to itself.

headline: Polls: Warren Ahead in Massachusetts
abstract: Elizabeth Warren may be gaining ground in her bid to unseat Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts, two new polls suggest.
lead_paragraph: Despite criticism of her campaign by some of her Democratic allies, Elizabeth Warren may be gaining ground in her bid to unseat Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts, two new polls suggest.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House has ruled that young immigrants who will be allowed to stay in the United States as part of a new federal policy will not be eligible for health insurance coverage under President Obama’s health care overhaul.

abstract: Mouse leukemia retroviruses, a culprit named in two earlier studies, were not found in any of the blood samples taken from people with chronic fatigue syndrome.
lead_paragraph: Chronic fatigue syndrome is not caused by a mouse retrovirus, according to a study initiated by the National Institutes of Health to settle what had become a contentious scientific question.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — If you grab the hand of a two-armed robot named Baxter, it will turn its head and a pair of cartoon eyes — displayed on a tablet-size computer-screen “face” — will peer at you with interest.

abstract: The new frontier in robotics is machines like this one, named Baxter, which is designed to work alongside humans safely and cheaply.

headline: In Car Country, Obama Trumpets China Trade Case
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Automobiles', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization. He announced the action in the industrial battleground of Ohio.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — In a vivid display of the powers of incumbency, President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization, announcing the action in this industrial battleground where Mitt Romney has pressed his argument that the president has not done enough to protect American workers.

keywords: ['Birth Certificates', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A challenge toPresident Obama’s eligibility to appear on the Kansas ballot officially ended on Monday after a state board adjourned without ruling because the objection had been withdrawn last week.

headline: Suicide Bomber in Afghanistan Strikes Minibus, Killing Mostly Foreign Workers
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: A suicide bomber killed 14 people on Tuesday, including 10 foreigners, most of whom worked as flight crew members under contract with the United States government.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed 14 people on Tuesday, including 10 foreigners, most of whom worked as flight crew members under contract with the United States government, officials said. The attack brought to at least 28 the number of deaths attributed to unrest sweeping the Muslim world as a result of a video parodying the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: News Quiz | September 18, 2012
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Conversation With: Haryana Chief Minister Bhupinder Singh Hooda
abstract: Haryana’s chief minister, now in his second term, on investment, pro-farmer policies and crime in his state.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI– Bhupinder Singh Hooda has been chief minister of Haryana since 2005, and is currently serving his second term. The state, which hugs India’s capital, is said to be the site of the epic battle described in the Mahabharata; it is now home to just over 2 percent of India’s people, some 25 million.

headline: Champions League: A Seasoned Dortmund Starts Fresh
abstract: Despite success at home, Borussia Dortmund and its young stars seemed out of their element in last year’s Champions League. That may not be the case this time.
lead_paragraph: Sixteen years is a long time in soccer. Between one decade and the next, players, coaches or even entire teams and leagues that came to dominate and influence the very sport have to eventually accept the simple facts of fate and step aside as time picks its next champion. On Tuesday, Borussia Dortmund hosts Ajax in their first Champions League encounter since a fateful quarterfinal in 1996, during a forgotten time when both clubs were considered big players in Europe’s premier competition. Today, both sides will be hopeful of three points, and another shot at European success.

headline: Benetton Ads Address Youth Unemployment by Offering Help to ‘Unemployees’
abstract: The Italian apparel company is known for its provocative ads, but in this case the company is also going to spend $650,000 for awards for projects proposed by unemployed young people.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Benetton, the Italian apparel retailer, has been known for provocative advertising that attracts publicity by stirring up discussion of contentious topics like politics, religion and the treatment of AIDS patients.

abstract: How would the technology for like Project Glass work for the wearer?

lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “In Nepal, After Revolt, ‘Art Was Changed Forever.’”

headline: Dole Food to Sell 2 Businesses to Itochu for $1.7 Billion
abstract: Dole, the world’s largest fruit company, said it would put the cash proceeds from the sale of its packaged foods and Asian fresh fruit businesses toward paring down its debt and the costs of reorganizing its struggling business.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Dole Food will sell its packaged foods and Asian fresh fruit businesses to the Japanese trading house Itochu Corporation for $1.7 billion in cash.

headline: Purple Haze and Radical Ways
abstract: Remembering two ’70s moments that left an impression: the death of Jimi Hendrix, and Patty Hearst on the run.

headline: The Readers Always Write
abstract: Readers of the new Blooming blog liked most of the new features and responded with hundreds of comments, but many were critical of an essay about boomers and millennials.
lead_paragraph: Starting up a new feature like the Booming blog, we’re very interested in hearing comments from you, the readers, about what you like and what you don’t. The good news is you liked most of the new features we’ve created and responded with hundreds of comments. The bad news — at least for me — is many of you would like to tear me from limb to limb for what I wrote about boomers and millennials.

headline: How to Solve the Swing-State Puzzle
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Electoral College']
abstract: Handicapping the 2012 election, in the “tipping-point” states.
lead_paragraph: When I first considered Barack Obama’s re-election chances in this magazine, last November, he was about a 50-50 contender against the Republican field. As I noted then, this was an unusual spot for a sitting president. A year before their own re-election races, Roosevelt, Eisenhower, Nixon, Reagan, Clinton and both Bushes were all favored. One year out, it seemed as if things could break either way for the president in 2012.

headline: Visions of a Blind Photographer
abstract: Seeking to cope with immense personal tragedy, Sonia Soberats, who lost her vision in between losing a son and daughter, turned to photography.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes when she’s taking pictures, Sonia Soberats forgets she cannot see.

headline: Do Great Leaders Have to Be Outgoing?
abstract: Tell us how you feel about this question, and describe the qualities of leaders you admire. What leadership qualities do you have?
lead_paragraph: This is the question asked in a recent Opinion piece that compared Bill Clinton, a famous extrovert, with Barack Obama, an introvert, and suggested that “introverts make great leaders, too.”

headline: Somalia’s New Man
abstract: Is the world’s most notorious failed state finally on the mend?
lead_paragraph: One of Hassan Sheik Mohamud’s inaugural acts as president of Somalia was to survive an assassination attempt. After winning a decisive vote among parliamentarians last Monday, Mohamud took the helm of the long-suffering state. On Wednesday, a wave of explosions and gunfire struck the hotel in Mogadishu where he was meeting with Sam Ongeri, the foreign minister of neighboring Kenya. While the dignitaries survived, eight others were killed.

headline: Breaking Down Victor Cruz’s 80-Yard Touchdown
abstract: In the Giants’ 41-34 win over Tampa Bay, there was no play more vital than Eli Manning’s 80-yard touchdown strike to Victor Cruz. Let’s take a closer look.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the season, I’ll  break down a big play from each week. In the Giants’ 41-34 win over Tampa Bay on Sunday, there was no play more vital than Eli Manning’s 80-yard touchdown strike to Victor Cruz. Let’s take a look.

headline: Coalition Sharply Reduces Joint Operations With Afghan Troops
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A spike in attacks on international troops by Afghan soldiers and police officers pushed the American-led military coalition to curb ground operations with its Afghan counterparts.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a significant blow to a core element of the Western exit strategy from Afghanistan, the American-led military coalition said Tuesday that it had temporarily curtailed joint operations with the Afghan Army and police forces.

headline: Pakistani Government Relents in Judicial Standoff Over Zardari Corruption Case
abstract: Pakistan’s government on Tuesday agreed to write a letter to the authorities in Switzerland regarding charges against President Asif Ali Zardari.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — After months of legal battles, Pakistan’s government relented on Tuesday to judicial demands that it agree to write a letter to the authorities in Switzerland regarding corruption charges against President Asif Ali Zardari.

headline: Some Big Corporations Don’t Pay Taxes, Either
abstract: Despite complaints from executives and Republican candidates, American corporations are not overtaxed, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: A Start-Up Figures Out Photoshop Abuses
abstract: A Dartmouth computer scientist and a former Adobe executive have created a start-up company in digital image forensics, Fourandsix Technologies. Its product determines whether photographic images have been altered. The core market is law enforcement and news organizations. The open question, the company’s president said, is how large a business there may prove to be for its technology in fields like health care, mobile payments and social media.
lead_paragraph: Hany Farid, a professor at Dartmouth College, has built a career and a reputation as a leading researcher in digital image forensics. He has made software tools for a number of impressive projects in recent years. One was a pixel-sleuthing program to detect how much fashion photographs have been burnished with Adobe’s Photoshop editing program to remove wrinkles and flab, while plumping up lips and breasts. Another was software for the automated detection of child pornography on the Web to help law enforcement agencies.

abstract: An auction of short-term debt sold out at slightly lower rates, but uncertainty persisted over whether Spain would ask for aid from its European partners.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Spain took advantage of improved bond-market sentiment in the euro zone to sell government debt on Tuesday, but questions still lingered about whether, or when, it would seek European help to lower its borrowing costs.

headline: A Business Owner Expects the Worst From Health Insurance Overhaul
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Ultimately, Kurt Summers says, the reaction of many small-business owners to the health care overhaul comes down to fear: “I’m sitting at my desk with payroll and expenses wondering, ‘What are my customers thinking?'”
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decision upholding most of the Affordable Care Act came as a blow to Kurt Summers, a small-business owner in Austin, Tex. Soon after the decision was announced, he warned his fellow citizens, through the auspices of The Washington Post, that unless “we elect officials to both Congress and the White House who understand the importance of small business and who will return some sanity to Washington” — and repeal the health law — he will most likely have to postpone his considerable ambitions for his company.

abstract: Exaggerating your race results, grappling with details of Medicare proposals, five ways to find your best-fitting college and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Sept. 17: Electoral College May Not Help Obama
abstract: As of Monday, the FiveThirtyEight forecast showed that President Obama was more likely to lose the Electoral College while winning the popular vote than the other way around.
lead_paragraph: The FiveThirtyEight presidential forecast for Monday was essentially unchanged, with President Obama having a 74.8 percent chance of winning another term. Taken on the whole, Monday’s data was consistent with the current “story” the forecast model is telling about the race, which is that Mr. Obama’s polls have declined slightly from their post-convention highs, but are also still slightly better than his preconvention polls.

headline: Jon Stewart and Bill O’Reilly to Debate Next Month
abstract: The debate between the hosts of “The Daily Show” and “The O’Reilly Factor,” called “The Rumble in The Air-Conditioned Auditorium,” will take place on Oct. 6 in Washington and will be broadcast on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: The election season has added another debate – one less likely, perhaps, to determine the next president of the United States, but with greater chances of intentional hilarity and use of the word “pinhead.” Bill O’Reilly, the Fox News personality and host of “The O’Reilly Factor,” and Jon Stewart, the satirist and anchor of Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show,” will face each other in a 90-minute contest of mental nimbleness and verbal dexterity, to be held in Washington on Oct. 6 and broadcast on the Internet, its organizers said.

headline: Inflation Expectations: A Feature, Not A Bug
abstract: They’re how the thing is supposed to work.
lead_paragraph: And now for something completely different: I’m a bit puzzled by the tone of this FT report on how QE3 is doing so far, US inflation fears rise after QE3, which seems to imply that a rise in breakeven rates — the difference between the interest rate on ordinary bonds and inflation-protected bonds — is a danger sign. (Breakeven rates are a simple gauge of expected inflation).

headline: Is Occupy a Fad?
abstract: What you need to know today about Wall Street, deals, hedge funds, private equity and the law.
lead_paragraph: Occupy Wall Street: From Frenzy to Fad?  |  Occupy Wall Street celebrated its one-year anniversary on Monday as protesters filled the Financial District. But the movement — which initially struck a chord, or a nerve, depending on your view — doesn’t seem to be generating the same buzz anymore. As Andrew Ross Sorkin writes, Occupy Wall Street may now be more of a footnote in financial history:

headline: Welcome, All, the Days of Forgiveness to Car Owners
abstract: The Day: The Jewish New Year began 11 days spread over a month and a half when alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended.
lead_paragraph: Monday was the first day of Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, and for observant Jews it ushered in a solemn 10-day period of reflection and repentance. For some of them and for others of different religions, it also ushered in a longer period of gratification and joy. These are New Yorkers, nonbelievers included, who share a bond that transcends faith.

headline: Romney Says Remarks on Voters Help Clarify Position
abstract: Facing criticism for saying 47 percent of voters believe they are “victims,” Mitt Romney sought to steer the conversation toward a debate about government’s role in people’s lives.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney on Tuesday fully embraced the substance of his secretly recorded comments that 47 percent of Americans are too dependent on government, saying that his views helped define the philosophical choice for voters in his campaign against President Obama.

headline: British Legislators Waver on Afghan War
abstract: The British government faced a second day of tough questioning over military strategy in Afghanistan after NATO limited joint patrols with Afghan government forces. Did the government know about the decision in advance, and where does it leave a policy based on training the Afghans to take over their own security?
lead_paragraph: LONDON – “How many more wasted lives?” asked the rhetorical headline in Britain’s Daily Mail on Tuesday, above photographs of the latest two British soldiers to die while serving in Afghanistan.

headline: Providence Equity’s Nelson and Netflix’s Hastings Join the Giving Pledge
abstract: Jonathan M. Nelson of Providence Equity Partners and Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix and a Facebook board member, are among the latest signatories to the Giving Pledge, joining a growing number of billionaires who plan to give away most of their wealth.
lead_paragraph: Businessmen like Jonathan M. Nelson and Reed Hastings normally focus on generating the maximum amount of profit from their work as possible. But the two men have joined Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates in pledging to dole out most of their wealth to charity.

headline: Teachers End Chicago Strike on Second Try
abstract: Union delegates endorsed a proposed contract, allowing 350,000 children to return to classes on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chicago Teachers Union agreed on Tuesday to end its strike in the nation’s third-largest school system, allowing 350,000 children to return to classes on Wednesday and bringing to a close, at least for now, a tense standoff over issues like teacher evaluations and job security that had upended this city for more than a week.

headline: Taxes Over The Life Cycle
abstract: Look at the middle-aged.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thoma has the best data post so far on the execrable Romney speech, linking to the Hamilton Project work on taxes. This work makes a crucial point: even aside from the fact that there are other taxes besides the income tax, even aside from the larger point that lower-income working Americans are hardly grifters, the fact is that the vast majority of Americans do pay income taxes at some point in their life:

headline: An Enigma in the Mortgage Market That Elevates Rates
abstract: A 30-year mortgage with a 2.8 percent interest rate could already exist, but something in the banking system is holding it back. And right now, few agree on what that “something” is.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a 30-year mortgage on which you only pay 2.8 percent in interest a year.

headline: Daily Report: The Perils of Successful Crowdfunding
abstract: Crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter are letting designers and other creative people connect with audiences who want to finance their dreams, reports Jenna Wortham on Tuesday in The New York Times. But for the creators of these projects, getting the money is sometimes the easy part. They then have to turn their dreams into reality.
lead_paragraph: Crowdfunding sites like Kickstarter and IndieGogo are letting designers and other creative people connect with audiences who want to finance their dreams, Jenna Wortham reports on Tuesday in The New York Times. But for the creators of these projects, getting the money is sometimes the easy part. They then have to turn their dreams into reality, with a crowd keeping an eye on their progress.

headline: Real Photo, Fake Family
abstract: Crimes Scene Extra: A photo that was used in a scam aimed at a would-be nanny turned out to be that of a California family with no idea that their picture was being used for a nefarious purpose.
lead_paragraph: So, who was that family?

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Romney Caught on Tape, and Detecting ‘Photoshopped’ Images
abstract: Also, the one-year anniversary of Occupy Wall Street is celebrated with a protest march in Lower Manhattan that led to arrests of 181, including five journalists.
lead_paragraph: Secretly taped comments,  in which Mitt Romney said that nearly of half of Americans were dependent on government assistance and felt entitled, were released by the liberal magazine Mother Jones on Monday and threatened to derail the Romney campaign as it tried to redefine its message 50 days before the election, Jim Rutenberg and Ashley Parker wrote. Speaking to wealthy donors at a Florida fund-raiser in May, Mr. Romney said “47 percent of the people” will vote for Mr. Obama “no matter what,” adding that they are “dependent upon government, who believe that they are victims, who believe the government has a responsibility to care for them.”

headline: N.F.L. Blueprints for Getting Out of 0-2 Holes
abstract: Just like a snowflake, every 0-2 N.F.L. team is unique, if not necessarily pretty. No doubt the most surprising of the winless teams is the New Orleans Saints.
lead_paragraph: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

headline: North Stars
abstract: The Montreal neighborhood of Mile End, long a working-class Jewish enclave, is getting quietly but unmistakably hip, with dozens of restaurants, bars and boutiques now dotting its streets.
lead_paragraph: The Montreal neighborhood of Mile End, long a working-class Jewish enclave (and the namesake of two culty New York delis), has changed considerably in recent years, getting quietly but unmistakably hip, with dozens of restaurants, bars and boutiques now dotting its streets.

headline: Manchester United’s 4th-Quarter Loss Widens
abstract: Manchester United’s net loss for its fourth quarter widened significantly from the year-ago period, the soccer club said on Tuesday in its first earnings report as a publicly traded company.
lead_paragraph: Manchester United‘s net loss for its fourth quarter widened significantly from the year-ago period, the soccer club said on Tuesday in its first earnings report as a publicly traded company.

headline: A Son Searches for His Father’s Truth
abstract: In “The Scientists,” Marco Roth looks for answers about his father’s death from AIDS.
lead_paragraph: “What really knocks me out,” Holden Caulfield said, “is a book that, when you’re all done reading it, you wish the author that wrote it was a terrific friend of yours and you could call him up on the phone whenever you felt like it.”

headline: Trial of Ex-Police Chief in China Scandal Ends in a Sign of Leniency
abstract: The chief, Wang Lijun, who is connected to the downfall of Bo Xilai, confessed to the most serious charge against him, but his cooperation in the case suggested he would be spared the death sentence.
lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — A former Chinese police chief helped to cover up the murder of a British businessman by the wife of Bo Xilai, the Communist official toppled from power this year, but he also secretly collected evidence used to convict her, according to a lawyer for the police chief and an official account released Tuesday at the end of his trial.

headline: Getting Bluefin Tuna Off the Hook
abstract: Researchers are seeking to replace longlines for catching swordfish and yellowfin tuna with gear that results in a smaller incidental catch of Atlantic bluefin tuna.
lead_paragraph: The longline fishery is aptly named. Fishermen will unroll a surface longline into the ocean that can extend for 40 miles and is segmented with baited hooks and buoys. They’ll let it float for a number of hours, hooking whatever swims along that has a taste for the bait.

headline: Is Skepticism Too High for the Kalamazoo Promise to Work in New York?
abstract: Iris Chen, the current head of the I Have a Dream Foundation, says, “I am not a big believer in free rides.”
lead_paragraph: The article in this past Sundays’s magazine about the Kalamazoo Promise, a program announced in November 2005 that pays for the city’s high-school graduates to go to public colleges in Michigan, is accompanied by a sidebar that imagines what it would take to do the same for students in New York City.

headline: Couscous With Tomatoes, Okra and Chickpeas
abstract: Don’t let okra’s slimy reputation put you off: Whole small pods add great texture, flavor and nutrition to this dish, without the slime.
lead_paragraph: Okra is popular in the North African cuisines of Tunisia and Algeria, where it is also dried. Because you don’t cut it up, the okra doesn’t become slimy. It contributes great flavor to the stew. Very high in dietary fiber, okra is a great source of vitamins A, C, B complex and the phytonutrients glutathione, xanthin, lutein and beta carotene, all believed to have antioxidant properties. For the best texture and flavor, look for the smallest pods you can find.

headline: Wanted: Jewish Ballplayers
abstract: Team Israel fielded a group of mostly American players with Jewish ties to compete in the World Baseball Classic and also drum up support for baseball back home.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — Though Israel’s national baseball team has many excellent pitchers, catchers, infielders and outfielders, the roster has a shortage of something that might be considered essential: Israelis.

headline: Usher and Shakira to Join ‘The Voice’ Next Season
abstract: They will substitute for Christina Aguilera and Cee Lo Green next spring. It is evidence, along with the news of new big-name judges for “American Idol,” that stars are eager to hitch themselves to TV talent shows.
lead_paragraph: The judging wheel on television’s glut of singing-competition shows continues to spin, with two new superstar-singers, Usher and Shakira, signing on for NBC’s next edition of “The Voice” in the spring.

headline: Groups Prepare to Fight AT&T Over FaceTime Restrictions
abstract: A group of public interest organizations say they will soon file complaints against AT&T, alleging that the carrier is violating government rules by restricting the way customers use FaceTime, Apple’s video-conferencing tool that is built into iPhones and iPads.
lead_paragraph: A group of public interest organizations said Tuesday that they would soon file complaints against AT&T, alleging that the carrier was violating government rules by restricting the way customers can use FaceTime, Apple’s video-conferencing tool, which is built into iPhones and iPads.

headline: Rangers Wing Considers Playing in Sweden
abstract: Carl Hagelin of the Rangers is exploring playing for his hometown club in Sweden, SK Sodertalje, but he has not made a decision, his agent said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Carl Hagelin of the Rangers is considering playing for his hometown club in Sweden, SK Sodertalje, but he still has not made a decision, his agent said Tuesday morning.

headline: Heritage Foundations
abstract: The sumptuous hotels sprouting up near Unesco World Heritage sites.
lead_paragraph: Hangaroa Eco Village & SpaEaster Island, a World Heritage site known for its ancient stone monoliths, has long been home to land disputes. In 2010, members of the Hito native clan staged a six-month occupation of Hangaroa, claiming the property had been taken from their ancestors illegally. Chilean police ended the protest, and now the hotel is open for business, with 75 rooms built of volcanic rock and a lobby that resembles a Polynesian canoe. The owners plan to donate funds to local charities. Doubles from $550; hangaroa.cl.

headline: Couscous With Tomatoes, Cauliflower, Red Peppers and Olives
abstract: Cruciferous vegetables make few appearances in North African tagines, but this dish is an appealing vehicle for nutritious cauliflower.
lead_paragraph: Cauliflower is one of the few cruciferous vegetables you find in North African tagines. The spicy tagines make a good vehicle for this nutrient-rich food and are one of the few types of dishes in which cauliflower can be cooked until quite soft and not lose its appeal.

headline: Myanmar’s Opposition Leader Urges End to Sanctions
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi began a trip to the United States that is a sign of the great shift in relations in the past year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, called for the lifting of American sanctions against her country on Tuesday, beginning an emotional visit to the United States that punctuated the remarkable shift in relations with Myanmar over the past year.

headline: ‘Mies Julie’ to Start New Season at St. Ann’s Warehouse
abstract: The hit of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe will be the first production at St. Ann’s temporary new home in Dumbo, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The South African production “Mies Julie,” based on the Strindberg play and an award-winning hit at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last month, will have its American premiere this fall as the first production in St. Ann’s Warehouse’s temporary new home in Brooklyn, the theater’s leaders said on Tuesday.

headline: Image of the Day: September 18
abstract: Women staged a protest in New Delhi against the government’s decision to allow foreign direct investment in multi-brand retail.

headline: The 47 Percent
abstract: At a private fundraiser, Mitt Romney said 47 percent of Americans are “dependent upon government” and “pay no income tax.” Who are they?
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney often accuses the Occupy Wall Street movement of dividing the country with its 99 percent slogan. A newly uncovered video of the candidate speaking at a private fundraiser shows him dividing the country more evenly: Between the 47 percent “who are dependent upon government, who believe that they are victims” and who “pay no income tax”—and everyone else.

headline: On Our Radar: William and Kate Visit Threatened Tuvalu
keywords: ['Freedom of Information Act', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Island youths plan to deliver a message about how their homes are threatened by rising sea levels.
lead_paragraph: Inhabitants of Tuvalu, an island country deeply threatened by rising seas, hope to convey their plight to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge as they arrive on the final stop of their royal tour. [R.T.C.C.]

headline: Does Long-Term Care Insurance at a Young Age Make Sense?
abstract: Younger people are buying long-term care insurance, but there are many risks for those who are not certain they’re committed for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: The average age of people buying long-term care insurance has been falling, as people seek to balance the possible need for nursing home or in-home care with the considerable cost of the insurance premiums. Even some very young people are buying the insurance, and a few of them are making claims under their policies, according to an industry group.

headline: For a Student Veteran, Graduation Is the Next Mission
abstract: When Thomas Gibbons-Neff got back from Afghanistan and into Georgetown, he came to understand that the battle was not over.
lead_paragraph: It was the fall of 2011, and I was the quintessential fresh-out-of-the-fleet 23-year-old Marine. I was preparing for Georgetown University’s New Student Orientation, my first official re-entry into academia and a day of assemblies and awkward greetings with a bunch of kids who would have been barely teenagers when I was spending my first weeks in Afghanistan.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Faith Divide

headline: For Social Companies, a Battle to Own Photography
abstract: The latest acquisition by Google, of Nik Software, the photo editing company, shows the battle on the Web to become the home of photo sharing.
lead_paragraph: The chant we’ve been hearing from the tech giants in recent years has been the same: “Mobile, mobile, mobile.” Yet there’s a greater evolutionary force behind this. “Photos, photos, photos.”

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Creativity', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Three-Dimensional Devices and Effects']
abstract: The XOXO Festival in Portland, Ore., over the weekend brought 400 people together to discuss the many ways that the Internet is helping to “creatively disrupt” traditional businesses and industries. Here are a few of the highlights.

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s national government was plunged into turmoil on Tuesday night, facing an uncertain future after a crucial regional ally threatened to withdraw her support from the governing coalition to protest a package of fuel price increases and pro-business economic changes.

keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']

lead_paragraph: Comments made by Mitt Romney at a private campaign fund-raiser about the nearly half of Americans who have no income tax liability have heated up a debate over who pays and who takes from the federal government.
