lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A high-profile ruling by a federal trial judge last week blocking enforcement of a law authorizing the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects is on hold for now.

headline: Tip Sheet | 8 Things Admissions Officers Wish You Knew About Applying to College
abstract: Admissions officers, in an attempt to prevent common missteps, advise college applicants to start their college searches early and remember that college “fit” goes both ways.
lead_paragraph: Whether students are applying to a small, private college or a large, public university, there are some universal missteps that college applicants make year after year, much to the dismay of the institution’s gatekeepers who decide whether the student should be admitted.

headline: New Romney Ad Targets Women
abstract: Called “Dear Daughter,’’ the ad features imagery of a woman holding a newborn as the narrator ticks through the many ways the Romney campaign says “Obama’s policies are making it harder on women.”
lead_paragraph: As Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign was consumed once again by events out of its control — the release of Mr. Romney’s blunt discussion with donors in May — it was seeking to at least remain focused in the one place on TV where it has ultimate control of what is on screen: Its television advertising.

headline: Life During Fatwa: Hiding in a World Newly Broken
abstract: The writer Salman Rushdie discusses why a memoir of his years in hiding is titled “Joseph Anton,” what a toll that period took on his personal life and how to determine if you are being followed while driving.
lead_paragraph: Salman Rushdie’s “Joseph Anton” is a memoir of the roughly 10 years he spent in hiding, under police protection, after the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called for his death in 1989 because his novel “The Satanic Verses” was deemed offensive to Islam. The memoir’s title, cobbled together from the first names of Joseph Conrad and Anton Chekhov, is the alias he used while under the fatwa. In the book, which is written in the third person, Anton emerges as a character Mr. Rushdie regards both fondly and critically.

headline: Get a Jump on Fall Color With States’ Travel Tools
abstract: Vermont and Massachusetts are among the states offering travelers a guide to peak color areas.
lead_paragraph: For travelers who can’t remember whether a hot summer means that the leaves change early, a couple of states are hoping to clarify matters with accessible travel tools.

headline: The Impact of the 2004-5 Lockout on the Russian Superliga
abstract: A look at how the the locked-out N.H.L. players who skated in the Russian Superliga in 2004-5 fared.
lead_paragraph: With the locked-out N.H.L. players Evgeni Malkin, Sergei Gonchar, Ilya Kovalchuk, Ruslan Fedotenko, Alexei Ponikarovsky and Lubomir Visnovsky on their way to the K.H.L. after just two days of the latest lockout, it behooves us to look back at what happened in the Russian league during the last N.H.L. lockout, in 2004-5.

headline: A Faded Piece of Papyrus Refers to Jesus’ Wife
abstract: A Harvard historian of early Christianity said the papyrus, written in Coptic in the fourth century, contains a phrase never seen in any piece of Scripture: “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife ...’ ”
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A historian of early Christianity at Harvard Divinity School has identified a scrap of papyrus that she says was written in Coptic in the fourth century and contains a phrase never seen in any piece of Scripture: “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife ...’ ”

lead_paragraph: Microsoft has hired Nancy Tellem, a former top CBS television executive, to oversee the production of original video content to be delivered to the company’s Xbox video game console, according to people with knowledge of the move who did not want to be named ahead of an official announcement.

headline: When The Inner Party Believes The Prolefeed
abstract: How little they know.
lead_paragraph: As many people have been pointing out, Mitt Romney’s talk about the 47 percent was no different from what you hear all the time from Rush Limbaugh and the like. But bear in mind that Romney was talking to the financial super-elite, and gave every appearance of believing what he said. (I’m usually scornful of analyses based on how someone “comes across”, and would never put much weight on it, but the Romney of this video was a lot looser and more articulate than the guy we usually see).

headline: Shocking or Subtle, Still Radical
abstract: Both Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” and Debussy’s “Jeux” were radical works that still have the power to shock.
lead_paragraph: On May 15, 1913, at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in Paris, just two weeks before the premiere of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” provoked a riot among outraged audience members, the Ballets Russes presented the premiere of another daring ballet, also choreographed by Vaslav Nijinsky, also conducted by Pierre Monteux. It was Debussy’s “Jeux,” the composer’s last work for orchestra, commissioned by the company director, Sergei Diaghilev. Though not well received, the ballet was much discussed in Parisian cultural circles, until, that is, it was eclipsed by the scandal of the “Rite of Spring” (“Le Sacre du Printemps”).

headline: What Bush Knew, and Romney Doesn’t
abstract: The Republican nominee has failed to distance himself from his predecessor’s failures, but he’s also failed to imitate his successes.
lead_paragraph: I used my Campaign Stops column last week to make the case (not for the first time) that Mitt Romney is struggling to defeat Barack Obama in large part because the public’s memory of how the Bush era ended remains a major drag on the Republican Party’s political prospects, and Romney hasn’t done nearly enough to define himself as a post-Bush figure. But with the whole political world talking about the leaked fundraiser tape in which Romney channels an inaccurate and self-defeating right-wing talking point to basically write off 47 percent of America as irresponsible, dependent, guaranteed-to-vote Obama moochers, it’s worth pointing out that the current Republican nominee has also conspicuously failing to learn from George W. Bush’s substantial political successes.

headline: A Team With an American Accent
abstract: Only 3 of the 28 players on the Israeli team in the World Baseball Classic are from Israel, the rest being Americans with professional baseball experience and Jewish roots.
lead_paragraph: Only 3 of the 28 players on the Israeli team in the World Baseball Classic are from Israel, the rest being Americans with professional baseball experience and Jewish roots.

headline: Scourge of the Lionfish, Part 4: From Beautiful Novelty to Marine Invader
abstract: Just two decades ago, the beautiful and otherworldly red lionfish started showing up in south Florida and the Caribbean. Now they’re a plague.
lead_paragraph: Carl Safina is founder of Blue Ocean Institute at Stony Brook University and a MacArthur Fellow. His books include “A Sea in Flames: The Deepwater Horizon Oil Blowout,” and “The View From Lazy Point; A Natural Year in an Unnatural World,” which won the  2012 Orion Award. His series “Saving the Ocean” will be premiering this fall on PBS television.

headline: Reader Recipes: Family Traditions
abstract: The Times asked readers for their family’s favorite traditional recipes.
lead_paragraph: The Times asked readers for their family’s favorite traditional recipes.

headline: Holding On to Heritage Before It Slips Away
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes']
abstract: Family recipes, handed down by immigrants, link generations and keep a heritage alive.
lead_paragraph: MENTION the Bahamas, and most people naturally envision idyllic seascapes with pearly beaches and turquoise waters. For me, though, any talk of my mother’s homeland always brings to mind the tang of sour limes and the sweetness of freshly cut coconut, the tastes that flavored my childhood.

headline: Twitter Updates Its Apps, Including for the iPad
abstract: Twitter on Tuesday rolled out a series of design updates to its applications and Web site, including redesigning its outdated iPad app.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Tuesday rolled out a series of design updates to its applications and Web site, including redesigning its outdated iPad app. The updates offer a more consistent experience across mobile devices and the Web.

headline: Randy Newman Weighs In on Race and Presidency in New Song
abstract: In a new satirical song, Randy Newman tackles what he sees as a deep strain of racism in the electorate.
lead_paragraph: You can always trust Randy Newman to talk about the elephant in the room. The award-winning songwriter, who supports President Obama, has weighed in on the role of race in the presidential election, releasing a satirical song on Tuesday poking fun at voters who long for the days when a white man was in the White House.

headline: FiveThirtyEight Forecast: G.O.P. Senate Hopes Slipping
abstract: Democrats now hold about a 70 percent chance of retaining control of the Senate, according to the new FiveThirtyEight forecast.
lead_paragraph: Democrats are now favored to retain control of the Senate when the new Congress convenes in January, according to the FiveThirtyEight forecast, breaking a summer stalemate during which control of the chamber appeared about equally likely to go either way.

headline: Foreign Ministers Call for Stronger Ties Within Europe
abstract: The foreign ministers, led by Germany’s Guido Westerwelle, have called for a big increase in economic, political, diplomatic and even military integration within the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Testing the theory that it often takes a crisis to bring Europeans together, 11 foreign ministers, led by Guido Westerwelle of Germany, have called for a big increase in economic, political, diplomatic and even military integration within the European Union.

headline: Pitching an Employee-Owned Assisted Living Facility
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Nursing Homes', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Small Business']
abstract: It’s an interesting market segment, a clear investment structure and the entrepreneur inspired confidence. I want to know more.
lead_paragraph: For our last pitch, I reviewed a bridal brokerage company focused on finding brides and grooms to take over abandoned weddings. This week, I review a pitch for an employee-owned assisted-living facility.

headline: The Witness Trees
keywords: ['Forests and Forestry', 'Logging Industry', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: Surveyors’ records from 1752 to 1889 give researchers a sense of what tree species dominated in a West Virginia forest before logging and farming got under way.
lead_paragraph: Reaching into the past, Melissa Thomas-Van Gundy paints a vivid picture of a highlands forest dense with white oak, flaming sugar maple and American beeches, with a scattering of yellow poplar, wild cherry and spruce pine and, here and there, a singular crab apple, elm or soaring sycamore tree.

headline: Edible Selby | Rise and Shine
abstract: A 110-year-old brick building in the Brooklyn Navy Yard is home to Kings County Distillery, known for its minimalist flasks of bourbon and unaged moonshine.
lead_paragraph: When you grow up in a dry town in Kentucky, you develop a particular appreciation for moonshine. Or at least that was true for Colin Spoelman, the master distiller behind Kings County Distillery, which brews corn whiskeys in a 110-year-old brick building in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. “There were no liquor stores or bars,” Spoelman says of his hometown of Harlan. “People actually went to the bootlegger to buy alcohol.” Spoelman and his business partner, David Haskell, both 33, began making high-quality moonshine out of Spoelman’s apartment five years ago. Now their minimalist flasks of bourbon and unaged moonshine are poured at Roberta’s, Marlow & Sons and Il Buco, and sold at liquor stores all over New York City and beyond. “I think people appreciate our product in part because there isn’t marketing behind it,” Spoelman says. “Our strategy is not to have a strategy.” More…

headline: What’s in a Number? For the Ford Fusion, Marketing Gold
abstract: Alan R. Mulally, chief executive of Ford, was joined in Times Square on Tuesday by Ryan Seacrest to mark the Ford Fusion Hybrid’s receiving a combined fuel-economy rating of 47 m.p.g.
lead_paragraph: With the rest of the country fixated on another 47 — or 46.4, if we’re splitting hairs — Ford created a blockwide buffer in Times Square on Tuesday where the number represented but one thing: a marketing opportunity.

headline: Uploading Trouble: Teaching About the Video that Roiled the Muslim World
abstract: In these activities, teachers and students can explore both the basic sequence of events unfolding in the Middle East and the far-reaching consequences, from the American presidential campaign to the decision-making of Internet companies like Google.
lead_paragraph: Anti-American protests spread like wildfire last week throughout the Muslim world, raising profound questions about free speech, technology and the limits of diplomacy.

headline: BrisketTown to Open in Williamsburg
abstract: Daniel Delaney, who served smoked brisket under the name Brisketlab at a series of pop-ups, is opening a counter-service restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Delaney went from being the filmmaker to becoming the subject. A few years ago, he started doing videos of food trucks for a Web-based series called VendrTV, and became so hooked on barbecue, most notably Texas-style smoked brisket, that he is now part of the story. His camera is gathering dust while he hauls slabs of meat into an 18-foot smoker he acquired in Texas.

headline: How Do the 47% Vote?
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Will those paying no federal income tax “vote for the president no matter what”? Probably not. A lot don’t vote, and of those who do, many vote Republican.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney asserted that the 47 percent of Americans who had no federal income tax liability would “vote for the president no matter what.”

headline: NBC’s ‘Revolution’ Is Fast Out of the Gate, but Will Its Audience Stay?
abstract: NBC got good news in the ratings for its new science-fiction show, aided by the lead-in of “The Voice,” but there is a history of such shows starting strong and then fading. “The Mob Doctor” on Fox had a rocky start.
lead_paragraph: Riding the lead-in from “The Voice,” the new NBC drama “Revolution” posted strong ratings for its debut on Monday night, scoring the best numbers for a drama premiere in three years.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Roksanda Ilincic
abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week photo diary of Victor Frankowski.

headline: Mother Jones Releases Complete Video of Romney at Private Fund-Raiser
abstract: On Tuesday afternoon, Mother Jones magazine released the complete version of the video that showed Mitt Romney speaking to donors at a May 17 fundraiser. The magazine had originally released clips from the video on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon, Mother Jones magazine released the complete version of the video that showed Mitt Romney speaking to donors at a May 17 fund-raiser. The magazine had originally released clips from the video on Monday evening. The videos have kept traffic to Mother Jones’s Web site at record levels.

headline: ‘The Most Desperate Battle Ever Fought’
abstract: What a regiment of inexperienced Indiana soldiers saw at Antietam.
lead_paragraph: The men of the 27th Indiana Volunteer Regiment had been in only a few small battles when they reached the cornfield near a Maryland creek named Antietam. The battle that followed, changed not only the course of their lives, but the course of the Civil War itself.

headline: TimesCast Politics | Fallout Over Video
abstract: Mitt Romney is caught on a hidden camera. | The long journey for the footage online. | Fresh ads from each campaign. | A new Senate model from the FiveThirtyEight blog.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is caught on a hidden camera. | The long journey for the footage online. | Fresh ads from each campaign. | A new Senate model from the FiveThirtyEight blog.

headline: Mercurial Leader Withdraws Support From Governing Coalition
abstract: Mamata Banerjee withdrew support from the Congress Party-led coalition government.
lead_paragraph: “India’s national government was plunged into turmoil on Tuesday night and faced an uncertain future,” after Mamata Banerjee, “a crucial regional ally angrily withdrew support from the governing coalition,”Jim Yardley and Gardiner Harris wrote in The New York Times. Ms. Banerjee decided to walk out to protest the government’s recent “package of fuel price hikes and pro-business economic changes,” they wrote.

headline: Turkish Public Sours on Syrian Uprising
abstract: Although many Turks at first agreed with their government’s support for the Syrian opposition, many now believe it is undermining Turkey’s economy and security.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — As the war in Syria rages next door, Turks have grown increasingly weary of nearly daily reports of troubles at home: Iranian spies working with Kurdish insurgents, soldiers ambushed and killed, millions spent caring for a flood of refugees, lost trade and havoc in border villages.

headline: With Romney Videos, Mother Jones Keeps Readers Coming Back
abstract: The magazine attracted millions of viewers to its parceled-out videos of Mitt Romney talking at a fund-raiser.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good day to be at Mother Jones.

headline: Euro or No, Economics of Everyday Greek Life Is Eroding
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Even if Greece gets yet another lifeline from its European partners, many Greeks have reached their own conclusion: It doesn’t matter, because of deep-seated problems.
lead_paragraph: LEVIDI, Greece — Gregoris Skouros stepped out of the sawed-off cargo container that hard times have forced him to make his home in on an agricultural plain near this tiny village, a two-hour drive south of Athens.

headline: Making Parents Part of the Gay Wedding Day
abstract: A new column about gay and straight etiquette addresses a gay couple’s questions about the walk down the aisle and the first dance.
lead_paragraph: Our new Civil Behavior advice column will be written by Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners” (Workman, 2011) and the “The Essential Book of Gay Manners & Etiquette” (HarperCollins; 1995). Mr. Petrow will answer questions about issues of particular interest to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, as well their straight friends, co-workers and family members. The situations will be geared to a boomer-aged audience. This first column involves a wedding of gay men, the role of their parents and the question of who should have the first dance — the Moms and sons or Dads and sons. Mr. Petrow has written or edited more than a dozen books and covered the H.I.V./AIDS epidemic for more than 25 years. He started his career at The Wall Street Journal and has since held editorial positions at Life magazine, HotWired, Time Inc., Everyday Health and The Times’ Same Sex Marriage Topic page. He lives in Chapel Hill, N.C. —MICHAEL WINERIP

headline: Mitt Romney’s No-State Solution
abstract: Mitt Romney said privately in May that “there’s just no way” for an independent Palestinian state to be established on the West Bank territory Israel has occupied since 1967.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:50 p.m. As my colleague Sarah Wheaton reports, Mitt Romney said privately in May that “there’s just no way” for an independent Palestinian state to be established on the West Bank territory Israel has occupied since 1967. The Republican presidential candidate’s comments, during a discussion with donors in Florida, were secretly recorded by someone at the private event, and published on Tuesday by Mother Jones, a liberal magazine.

headline: Russia Demands U.S. End Support of Democracy Groups
abstract: The Kremlin views American financial support for a wide range of civil society programs as thinly veiled meddling in the country’s internal affairs.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has ordered the United States to end its financial support for a wide range of pro-democracy, public health and other civil society programs here, in an aggressive step by the Kremlin to halt what it views as American meddling in its internal affairs.

headline: Reaction to the Death of Steve Sabol
abstract: Players, journalists and others react to the news that Steve Sabol, the president of N.F.L. Films, had died of brain cancer at the age of 69.
lead_paragraph: Players, journalists and others reacted to the news that Steve Sabol, the president of N.F.L. Films, died of brain cancer Tuesday at the age of 69. Share your thoughts in the comments section.

headline: Rangers’ Nash Intends to Play in Switzerland During Lockout
abstract: Forward Rick Nash, acquired by the Rangers in a big off-season trade, is expected to sign with H.C. Davos, the team he played for during the 2004-5 lockout.
lead_paragraph: Forward Rick Nash, the Rangers’ top off-season acquisition, is headed to Switzerland to play for H.C. Davos during the N.H.L. lockout, his agent confirmed Tuesday.

headline: Fried Sushi Cakes With Scallops
abstract: Jean-Georges Vongerichten shows Mark Bittman how to make fried sushi cakes with scallops, honey soy sauce and chipotle mayonnaise.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Georges Vongerichten shows Mark Bittman how to make fried sushi cakes with scallops, honey soy sauce and chipotle mayonnaise.

headline: Media Feed Bias Against Latinos
abstract: A newly released survey of Americans’ attitudes toward Hispanics says prejudice against the country’s fastest-growing minority is perpetuated by negative media portrayals.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — As I write in my latest Female Factor column, Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are making big moves in the final stretch of the presidential campaign to recruit and win over Hispanics. At the same time, a new national study shows that a large number of Americans, influenced by negative images in the media, take a dim view of Hispanics.

headline: Excellence on the Plate, Even Without a Chef’s Edge
abstract: Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s recipe for fried cakes of sushi-style rice topped with chipotle mayonnaise and raw scallop may just be a contender for “best of the year.”
lead_paragraph: IF you’re a chef — a great one — you will go to almost any length to gain marginal improvement in a recipe. You’ll find the best provider for every given ingredient, and if you can gain an edge by fussing with those ingredients, you will. (Chances are you’re not the one doing the work anyway.) These kinds of differences define the food of the most talented chefs, at least those successful enough to indulge their talents.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Viktoria Kvalsvik at Meadham Kirchhoff
abstract: The model Viktoria Kvalsvik transforms with makeup by Florie White for M.A.C. and hair by James Pecis for Fudge.

headline: French Court Rules Against Magazine on Royal Photos
abstract: The court ordered the publisher of the magazine Closer to hand over all digital copies of images of the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, sunbathing topless in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court on Tuesday rebuked the magazine Closer for publishing “particularly intrusive” photographs of the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, ordering its publisher to cease all publication, distribution or sales of the pictures, and to hand over all digital copies of the images to the royal family.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Instagram vs. Snapseed, and iPad Mini Photo
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes a way to keep peace on Facebook when political opinions get out of hand, a report that Jonathan Ive of Apple will design a camera that will be auctioned for charity and an analysis of the differences between two well-known photo apps.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Steve Sabol, Cinematic Force for N.F.L., Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Sabol, a producer, writer, director and cameraman, took his father’s idea and, through cinematic ingenuity, helped propel the National Football League’s enormous popularity.
lead_paragraph: Steve Sabol, who was the creative force behind NFL Films, his father’s innovative enterprise that melded cinematic ingenuity, martial metaphors and symphonic music to lend professional football the aura of myth and help fuel its rise in popularity, died on Tuesday in Moorestown, N.J. He was 69.

headline: BMW, Hedging Bets on Electric, Stresses Fuel Efficiency
abstract: BMW, one of the most visible champions of battery power, has been hedging its bets and trying new ways to get more out of conventional gasoline and diesel motors.
lead_paragraph: MAISACH, Germany — The big fashion trend in Paris next week may be retro: internal combustion.

headline: Replacement Officials Face Growing Criticism
abstract: Officiating in pro football’s Week 2 saw extra timeouts awarded and incomplete passes called as fumbles, but the N.F.L. said current officials were acting “admirably.”
lead_paragraph: In a normal season, a group of N.F.L. referees taking a few minutes under the lights of “Monday Night Football” to figure out where a ball should be placed after a defensive holding penalty would be amusing. But with replacement officials making scenes like that one too common and sometimes struggling with the rules of the game, the amusement has begun to fade.

headline: Rekindling the Spirit of the ’60s, Even for Those Who Can’t Remember
abstract: The documentary “Radio Unnameable” pays tribute both to Bob Fass, an influential voice in broadcasting since the 1960s, and to the times whose ideals and follies he helped articulate.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Feb. 11, 1967, hundreds — maybe thousands — of people congregated in the international terminal of Kennedy Airport, not to embark on flights to far-flung places but rather, well, it isn’t entirely clear or relevant. The gathering was an impromptu party, a nonpolitical demonstration, a happening named, in the spirit of the times, a fly-in. Now we might be inclined to see it as a prehistoric flash mob, an example of the power of communication technology to create instantaneous, ephemeral but nonetheless meaningful communities.

headline: Brief Lives, Violently Extinguished
abstract: Wrenching footage of missile attacks and their civilian victims in Vibeke Lokkeberg’s film transcends the politics of the conflict that underlies the bloodshed.
lead_paragraph: A brutally uncompromising blast of outrage, Vibeke Lokkeberg’s “Tears of Gaza” is less a documentary than a collage of suffering. Dropping us smack in the middle of the Israeli attacks on Gaza in the winter of 2008-9, the film tramples politics beneath the raw weight of civilian testimony. Woven together, these monologues of bereavement and confusion, illustrated with images so terrible they repel rational explanation, form a tapestry of human misery that’s impossible to shake off.

headline: Mitt Romney, Class Warrior
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Editorials', 'Income Tax']
abstract: Turning the rich against the poor is Mr. Romney’s campaign tactic and his plan for governing.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that Mitt Romney was right. There is class warfare being waged in the 2012 campaign. It is Mr. Romney who is waging it, not President Obama, and he’s stood the whole idea on its head.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Sept. 20
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Sunglasses', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Accessories make the street-style look. So let’s pick up some of their tricks.
lead_paragraph: Accessories make the street-style look. So let’s pick up some of their tricks.

headline: Blue Jays Suspend Shortstop 3 Games for Gay Slur Written on Eyeblack
abstract: The Blue Jays suspended Yunel Escobar for three games on Tuesday for wearing eyeblack with an anti-gay slur written in Spanish during a game on Saturday in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Blue Jays suspended shortstop Yunel Escobar on Tuesday for three games for wearing eyeblack tape during Saturday’s game on which he had written a gay slur in Spanish.

headline: Open Agenda | P! in Chinatown
abstract: Part commercial gallery, part project space, P! invites art-lovers and locals alike to participate in its exhibits.

headline: Le Cirque
abstract: Inside the Manhattan restaurant owned by Sirio Maccioni.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Manhattan restaurant owned by Sirio Maccioni.

headline: It’s Been Awhile, Hasn’t It?
abstract: While the service at Le Cirque is exemplary, the kitchen gives the impression that it has stopped reaching for excellence and possibly no longer remembers what it is.
lead_paragraph: SIRIO MACCIONI was smiling at the patrons of Le Cirque once again, the way he has done for nearly four decades. He had been scarce over the summer, but on this September night he stopped at every table, fussing over loyal customers and pretending to recognize new ones.

headline: As Google Fills In Blank, a German Cries Foul
abstract: A former first lady of Germany is suing the search engine over Google’s autocomplete function and rumors that she was once an escort.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In an earlier, more innocent era, the shocking rumors about the past of a former first lady of Germany would have stayed put in the drawing rooms of the political elite. Nowadays, they appear unbidden on Google.

headline: Emmys Watch: Christine Baranski on ‘The Good Wife’ and Competing With Maggie Smith
abstract: Christine Baranski, nominated for an Emmy for best supporting actress in a drama for “The Good Wife,” talks about the role, her relationship on the series with Josh Charles and turning 60 as a working performer.
lead_paragraph: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards show on Sunday night. Previous entries in this series include Don Roy King, the director of “Saturday Night Live,” and Abi Morgan, nominated for writing “The Hour.”

headline: Feeling Rummy (in a Good Way)
abstract: September’s back-to-school time — and for many adults, it’s also back-to-the-bar time. What’s your favorite end-of-summer drink?
lead_paragraph: September is back-to-school time — and for many adults, it’s also back-to-the-bar time. The last two weeks of August felt a little sleepy at the small bar where I work. But a few days ago, I had a busy, cheerful shift and felt happily back to business. Local teachers who’d been out of the neighborhood all summer were back in force, regulars who’d been lucky enough to take long vacations had returned, old friends who hadn’t stopped by for months came in to catch up over a few pints. And I sensed a subtle summer’s-over — effectively, if not calendrically — shift in my customers’ drink orders. Just a few weeks ago, I was shaking up margaritas and pouring crisp, bright cider over ice. Last week, even though it was sunny and warm, there was a greater call for darker beers and brown liquor.

headline: How to Avoid a Smartphone’s Bite
abstract: Whether you’re a casual user or you like to stay constantly connected, here are tips for using a smartphone overseas without going broke.
lead_paragraph: Travel and smartphones go together — and these days, texting, updating Facebook and good old tweeting-while-eating are the least of it. Instant access to Yelp, TripAdvisor and endless other apps helps with everything from choosing an entree, tracking down discounts, posting a photo and checking the traffic ahead. Add a healthy dose of old-fashioned phone calls from poolside or mountain trail, and you might say staying connected has become something close to a constitutional right.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: A pop-up of a Florence, Italy, restaurant comes to New York; a new bar lounge in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Opening

headline: The Daily Shoe | Mulberry
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s shoe: a spring sandal with a quirky print.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Boost for an App That Replaces Digital Picture Frames
abstract: A new app called Familiar is starting to catch on with people who use it as a digital picture frame. The company’s apps displayed over 20 million photos for its users during August, up from one million in January, and the start-up just raised $1.3 million from venture capitalists.
lead_paragraph: A couple years ago, I gave my mother a digital picture frame so she could look at a rotating series of family photos. The picture frame eventually ended up unplugged and tucked away in a corner because it was so hard for her to update with fresh photos.

headline: Don’t Worry About the Poor, the 47 Percent, Peace…
abstract: In the Mother Jones video, Mitt Romney dismisses those who think they’re entitled to health care, food and housing.
lead_paragraph: Juliet Lapidos commented earlier on the Mitt Romney/Mother Jones video that you just can’t stop watching, and we’ve also published an editorial about it. But I’d like to highlight a couple of lines from the video that we have not examined elsewhere.

headline: The Social Cost of Carbon: How to Do the Math?
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A new study contends that the federal government’s formula for calculating the social costs of fossil fuel emissions fails to factor in a range of negative impacts.
lead_paragraph: This year’s presidential campaign has shown that a gulf exists between the two candidates on America’s energy future — at least in theory.

headline: Controversial Statue of John Paul II Gets Makeover
abstract: An adapted version of a controversial sculpture of Pope John Paul II that irked many Romans when it was unveiled in their city in May of last year was presented to reporters on Tuesday, after a restyling that lasted nine months.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An adapted version of a controversial sculpture of Pope John Paul II that irked many Romans was presented to reporters on Tuesday, after a restyling that lasted nine months.

headline: American Real Estate Investors Seek Opportunities in European Debt Crisis
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Private Equity', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Private equity firms have been vying to buy portfolios of European bank debt on commercial real estate at deep discounts, and hope eventually to earn generous returns.
lead_paragraph: While the world is anxiously watching to see how the European debt crisis will unfold, many real estate investors in the United States are eagerly seeking opportunities to reap profits from the Continent’s distress.

headline: Eli Lilly Trades Parking Lot for a Downtown Feel
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Mixed-Use Developments', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The drug maker Eli Lilly hopes that a new mixed-use development near its headquarters in Indianapolis will help it recruit and retain workers.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Virtually since its founding in 1876, the drug maker Eli Lilly’s stature as this city’s most prominent corporate resident has rarely been questioned. Still, it has been decades since the people who work at the company’s headquarters have been offered a strong connection to the city’s downtown, which has steadily developed into one of the most engaging business, trade and entertainment destinations in the Midwest.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: Oyster shucking at Jimmy’s No. 43 to benefit Slow Food; a tasting reception with more than 30 female chefs participating; food films with a conscience at the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Benefits

headline: Executive at Goldman Is Retiring
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Goldman Sachs said Tuesday that David A. Viniar, the bank’s longtime chief financial officer, would retire at the end of January and be replaced by Harvey Schwartz, a senior executive at the bank.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs introduced on Tuesday what may be the first of the next generation of leaders to run the storied Wall Street firm, saying that its longtime chief financial officer, David A. Viniar, would retire at the end of January and be replaced by Harvey M. Schwartz, a 48-year-old executive.

headline: Excerpt: 'Detroit'
abstract: A scene from Lisa D’Amour’s play at Playwrights Horizons.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Lisa D’Amour’s play at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Jerusalem and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Israel, Pakistan, India and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Jerusalem, Pakistan, India and Syria.

headline: The Timeless Dancer, Forever Stretching
abstract: In “An Evening With Lucinda Childs,” part of the Platform 2012: Judson Now series, Ms. Childs performed two of her early works at Danspace Project on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In her indispensable 1980 study of postmodern dance, “Terpsichore in Sneakers,” Sally Banes wrote that perhaps the most striking thing about Lucinda Childs’s solo works “is her absolutely compelling performance presence.” Well, not much has changed.

headline: Dance Magazine Names Lifetime Achievement Award Winners
abstract: Three dancers and a former Times critic will be honored in December.
lead_paragraph: Dance Magazine has named the winners of its annual lifetime achievement awards. They are Julie Kent, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater; Renee Robinson, a member of the Alvin Ailey company since 1981; the tap dancer Dianne Walker; and the former New York Times dance critic Anna Kisselgoff. The honors will be bestowed on Dec. 3 at the Ailey Citigroup Theater.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 18
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including an electrifying soccer match between Real Madrid and Manchester City and women’s cycling.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including an electrifying soccer match between Real Madrid and Manchester City and women’s cycling.

headline: Brazil’s Pied Piper of Street Art
abstract: Bel Borba, an artist from Salvador da Bahia, Brazil, is spending a month making public art in New York neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: It was an odd sight for an industrial street in the Ridgewood section of Queens, so of course the delivery-truck drivers, the workers from nearby manufacturing plants and other curious passers-by felt compelled to stop, look and ask questions. On the maroon-colored external wall of a furniture factory, the Brazilian artist Bel Borba was busy making a large mosaic of white tile, portraying a globe surrounded by objects that looked like a cross between sunflowers and mechanical fans.

headline: Museum of Vancouver Hosts Tobias Wong Exhibition
abstract: Mr. Wong’s trademark provocative objects straddle the world of art and conceptual design.
lead_paragraph: A show featuring the work of Tobias Wong, a straddler between the worlds of art and conceptual design, will open Wednesday at the Museum of Vancouver, in British Columbia. Mr. Wong, who took his own life in 2010 in New York City at age 35, was born and raised in Vancouver. Several of his trademark provocative objects have been displayed at the Museum of Modern Art and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, but this will be the first exhibition devoted exclusively to his creations, said the show’s curator, Todd Falkowsky.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Mulberry
abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Dance Festival Leader Focuses on Creation
abstract: The Lyon Dance Biennial unfolds under the new leadership of the choreographer Dominique Hervieu.
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — Every two years for the last 28 years the Lyon Dance Biennial has arrived in mid-September in this busy, bustling city with a certain amount of fanfare. It begins with the Défilé, a carnival-like procession that regularly draws more than 300,000 revelers to the streets, and continues for around three weeks with a dense pileup of performances, public balls, meetings with artists, films and talks, which seem to use every one of Lyon’s 30-odd theaters.

headline: Giants Criticize Replacement Officials
abstract: The Giants are becoming increasingly impatient with the work of the replacement officials.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – The N.F.L.’s lockout of its regular officials has not had any obvious impact on the outcome of a Giants game. That is not keeping the team’s players from becoming increasingly impatient with the use of replacements who have worked at lower levels and are not accustomed to the speed of the pro game.

headline: Man Who’s Everywhere May Really Be Nowhere
abstract: Kanye West is a busy guy, and the album “Cruel Summer” demonstrates the range of his distractions.
lead_paragraph: Forgive Kanye West: he’s been terribly distracted. There’s the immersion in the fashion world: “Dinner with Anna Wintour/Racing with Anja Rubik.” There’s his sneaker line with Nike: “Hold up, I ain’t trying to stunt, man/But the Yeezys jumped over the Jumpman.” There’s the still unrealized creative aspirations: “I just meditate,” he raps, “about how I could build a new Rome in one day.” And of course, there’s the new girlfriend, Kim Kardashian: “My girl a superstar all from a home movie.”

headline: David B. Henry
abstract: Mr. Henry is the chief of the Kimco Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust that owns nearly 930 community shopping centers in North and South America.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Henry, 63, is the vice chairman, chief executive and president of the Kimco Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., that owns and operates nearly 930 neighborhood and community shopping centers in North and South America, totaling 136 million square feet.

headline: The Caucus Click: Obama and Letterman
abstract: President Obama spoke to David Letterman during a taping of the “Late Show” on Tuesday, set to air later tonight.
lead_paragraph: More on President Obama’s appearance on Media Decoder.

headline: Blackstone to Buy Control of Vivint, a Home Security Provider
abstract: The Blackstone Group has agreed to buy control of Vivint, a provider of home security services, for more than $2 billion, Vivint’s chief executive said in an interview on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group has agreed to buy control of Vivint, a provider of home security services, for more than $2 billion, Vivint’s chief executive said in an interview on Tuesday.

headline: Bel Borba
abstract: A look at the work of the Brazilian multimedia artist.
lead_paragraph: A look at the work of the Brazilian multimedia artist.

headline: Dust-Up Over Ad in Kentucky House Race Featuring Executive Dressed as Miner
abstract: The man dressed as a miner in the ad for Republican Andy Barr is a coal company executive who has contributed thousands of dollars to politicians, mostly Republicans, and has rubbed shoulders with the likes of Mitt Romney at fund-raising events.
lead_paragraph: The man wearing a hard hat and jean overalls draped over a neon green T-shirt has his arms folded and stares sternly into the camera. Standing on a graveled railroad track, he speaks bluntly of the decline of the coal industry as images of Ravenna, Ky., flash across the screen. The blame, he says, is with President Obama, Representative Ben Chandler, a Democrat from Kentucky, and the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Behind Goldman Sachs’s Success Is a Focus on Survival
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Goldman Sachs has made an effort to heal self-inflicted wounds and maintain its dominance in investment banking.

Today, however, Goldman Sachs has retained its clients and its dominance. And recent missteps by its competitors are putting the investment bank in pole position to profit when a recovery comes.

headline: Judge Is Told to Examine Effect of Law on Voter ID
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Elections']
abstract: The judge who upheld a new voter ID requirement in Pennsylvania gets two weeks to determine if the state is doing enough to make IDs available to voters.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court on Tuesday sent back to a state judge his ruling upholding a new voter identification law and gave him two weeks to determine whether the state was doing enough to provide voters who lack the required photo IDs with alternative forms of identification. If not, the court said, he must bar the law from taking effect.

headline: A Changing Greenland

headline: The Great American Tax Debate
abstract: Maybe the way to start building a consensus about how much people should be taxed is to make the connection between the taxes people pay and the benefits they finance.
lead_paragraph: Come November, the economy — and who would be better to fix it — will probably be at the forefront of voters’ minds. But like pretty much every election of the last 60 years, voters’ choice will be colored by their views about taxes. If you believe the rich pay too little, chances are you will vote for Barack Obama. If you think tax rates on wealthy Americans are still too high, you will vote for Mitt Romney instead. Speaking to his donors at a fund-raiser, Mr. Romney argued he has no chance of gaining the vote of the nearly half of Americans who pay no federal income tax. But he probably has a good chance of capturing the vote of their fellow citizens who think paying no tax is unfair.

headline: Harlem’s Fashion Row Celebrated Five Years at New York Fashion Week

headline: Rising Tower Emerges as a Billionaires’ Haven
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The building at 157 West 57th Street, which will be New York’s tallest tower with residences when completed, has attracted the world’s superrich looking for a better way to preserve their wealth.
lead_paragraph: One57, a 1,004-foot tower under construction in Midtown Manhattan, will soon hold the title of New York’s tallest building with residences. But without fanfare from its ultraprivate future residents, it is cementing a new title: the global billionaires’ club.

headline: Coal Company Plans to Close Several Mines
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mines and Mining', 'Coal', 'Mid-Atlantic States (US)']
abstract: One of the nation’s largest coal producers announced on Tuesday that it planned to idle eight mines in Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia, reducing its annual production by 16 million tons.
lead_paragraph: Alpha Natural Resources, one of the nation’s largest coal producers, announced on Tuesday that it planned to idle eight mines in Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia, reducing its annual production by 16 million tons. The move will include laying off 1,200 of 13,000 employees. The company said that it was trying to meet the “evolving demands of a changing global coal market” and that it would continue selling coal in the United States while focusing new efforts on overseas markets.

headline: Look in Your Mirror
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: If it’s wrong to insult Islam, it should be wrong to insult any religion. That doesn’t seem to be the case in the Arab world.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, David D. Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief for The Times, quoted one of the Egyptian demonstrators outside the American Embassy, Khaled Ali, as justifying last week’s violent protests by declaring: “We never insult any prophet — not Moses, not Jesus — so why can’t we demand that Muhammad be respected?” Mr. Ali, a 39-year-old textile worker, was holding up a handwritten sign in English that read: “Shut Up America.” “Obama is the president, so he should have to apologize!”

headline: At a Campus Scarred by Hazing, Cries for Help

lead_paragraph: BINGHAMTON, N.Y. — One student said she feared for her boyfriend’s health and ability to do his schoolwork because he was coming home from fraternity pledging around 4 a.m. with gashes and cuts on his hands and elbows that reopened daily.

headline: California and the Fourth Amendment
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Forensic Science', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The costs of taking DNA samples from people arrested but not convicted dwarf the benefits. It is also, unfortunately, unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is scheduled to reconsider whether California violates the Fourth Amendment’s prohibition against searches and seizures by requiring police to take DNA samples from people arrested but not yet convicted of felonies. California’s law is ostensibly aimed at accurately identifying those arrested, solving crimes and exonerating the innocent. It is also, unfortunately, unconstitutional.

headline: Hello, We Must Be Going
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Congress has decided politicking and vacationing is more important than getting the people’s work done.
lead_paragraph: After a five-week recess and the hard labor of political conventioneering, members of the House managed to stop briefly at the Capitol last week to enact a temporary budget to avoid a government shutdown. But, after Friday, they will be back home politicking nonstop until Election Day, and the Senate is also expected to cancel its scheduled October duties in Washington. Lawmakers call their latest hiatus from the job of legislating “an extended district work period,” but it will be spent mostly bragging to voters about imaginary accomplishments.

headline: Priest’s Dip Into Politics Raises Outcry
abstract: A letter printed in a Church of St. Catherine of Siena bulletin endorsed Mitt Romney for president, prompting a complaint with the I.R.S. and a petition with more than 20,000 signatures.

lead_paragraph: The Joyce Theater is buying its longtime home in Chelsea for $20 million and selling its SoHo location for about $27 million, according to theater officials.

headline: The iPhone 5 Scores Well, With a Quibble

headline: Samsung-Apple Fight Moves to Marketing
abstract: Samsung’s campaign takes on the iPhone 5 directly, claiming its new Galaxy phone is better.
lead_paragraph: Samsung may have lost the most recent round in the United States in its legal fight with Apple over cellphone technology, but that hasn’t stopped it from mounting a new assault against Apple that relies on a more public tactic — full-page ads.

headline: Britain: Prince Loses Ruling on Letters
abstract: A tribunal in London ruled that letters written by Prince Charles lobbying government ministers on a range of contentious political issues must be made public within a month.
lead_paragraph: A freedom-of-information tribunal in London ruled Tuesday that letters written by Prince Charles lobbying government ministers on a range of contentious political issues must be made public within a month. The ruling was a victory for The Guardian, the newspaper that led a seven-year campaign for the release of letters that the prince, who is heir to the throne, had written to seven government departments. The letters, known as “black spider memos” among the ministers who received them because of the prince’s handwriting, have prompted widespread criticism from politicians and constitutional experts, who have accused Prince Charles, 63, of breaching the longstanding convention that members of the royal family should not intervene on matters of government policy.

headline: Christie’s Budget Faulted as Fiscal Outlook Is Called Weak
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s frequent assertions of a “New Jersey Comeback” have come under fresh scrutiny, now from Standard & Poor’s, which downgraded the state’s financial outlook to negative from stable.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey rose to stardom in the national Republican Party by promoting himself as a fiscal conservative willing to make the “hard choices” to restore sound budgeting to his state.

headline: N.F.L. Loses Storyteller Who Shaped Sport He Loved
abstract: Steve Sabol brought passion, detail and humor to his tales, whether he was explaining a shot or the fitting of Coach Hank Stram for a microphone during a Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: The death of Steve Sabol, the president of NFL Films, leaves us with one less storyteller. Yes, he was a cameraman, cinematographer, producer, editor, writer and director — encompassing skills that he and his father, Ed, employed to build a mythmaking apparatus better than the propaganda machines of most nations.

headline: Tom Sims, Pioneer in Sport of Snowboarding, Dies at 61
abstract: Mr. Sims was credited with inventing one of the earliest snowboards and, as a world-champion competitor, with helping to further the acceptance of snowboarding in the sporting world.
lead_paragraph: Tom Sims, who was credited with inventing one of the earliest snowboards and, as a world-champion competitor and manufacturer, with helping to further snowboarding’s widespread acceptance in the sporting world, died Sept. 12 at a hospital near his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 61.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress feel mighty proud of themselves this week, mainly because they appear to be avoiding a government shutdown — an outcome taken as an actual accomplishment in this turbulent and acrimonious legislature. But by the end of this week, lawmakers plan to leave town and not return until after the election, leaving behind a staggering pile of bills, many of pressing importance to voters across the nation.

lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Six months ago, the Harvard men’s basketball team was a source of uncommon athletic pride on campus. The team was ranked among the nation’s top 25 for the first time, and when it earned the program’s first berth to the N.C.A.A. tournament in 66 years, students and players spilled into Harvard Square chanting and celebrating.

Cuomo has called for an investigation into a confidential settlement of sexual harassment claims against a state legislator, but during his tenure as attorney general, his office authorized the settlement of a racial discrimination case that included a confidentiality clause.

lead_paragraph: “Energy. Color. Pattern. These are all the things we’re seeing on the London runways,” says Suzy Menkes, the IHT’s fashion critic. “And what’s exciting here is the way that the prints are done up with digital work and with all sorts of modern techniques.”

headline: Desperately Trying to Stay Stuck in the Middle
abstract: In Lisa D’Amour’s play “Detroit,” a Pulitzer Prize finalist at Playwrights Horizons, a couple who fear they are sliding out of their economic class meet a couple who have other problems.
lead_paragraph: A friendly suburban barbecue spirals into a delirious, dangerous bacchanal in the superb play “Detroit,” by Lisa D’Amour, which sizzled open at Playwrights Horizons on Tuesday night. A sharp X-ray of the embattled American psyche as well as a smart, tart critique of the country’s fraying social fabric, Ms. D’Amour’s dark comedy is as rich and addictively satisfying as a five-layer dip served up with a brimming bowl of tortilla chips.

The interface looks snazzy, and you can download books galore by some of your favorite constructors. Click here to see the app in the Apple App Store, and click here to see Mr Leban demonstrate it.

lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Jay Wortham found it under the cabinet below the kitchen sink after his mother died in August — a blue bottle of insect repellent.

headline: When It Comes to Filmmaking, Yonkers Seeks a Bigger Part
abstract: The city’s mayor, Michael Spano, says he wants to improve Yonkers’s standing as a filmmaking location, and is promoting the use of a local warehouse soundstage.
lead_paragraph: YONKERS — When it came time to make the movie based on the Neil Simon play “Lost in Yonkers,” the director bypassed the actual city and filmed it mostly in Ohio. But that setback, some 20 years ago, has not deterred officials from claiming that Yonkers is ready for its close-up.

headline: Prosecutors Deny Priest Was Urged to Lie in Abuse Case

headline: In Race to Bottom, It’s Mets vs. Mets
abstract: The Mets are on pace to set a record for the lowest home-field winning percentage after the All-Star break. The old mark? It was set by the ’79 Mets.
lead_paragraph: Rain postponed the Mets’ game Tuesday night at Citi Field, providing a break in a mind-boggling stretch of home-field ineptitude that could, by season’s end, earn them an embarrassing entry in the record books.

headline: China’s Anti-Japanese Protests Overshadow Japan Airlines I.P.O.
abstract: JAL’s offering caps two years of intense reorganization that eliminated 21,000 jobs, or about a third of the airline’s work force, and cut pilots’ salaries by 30 percent.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan Airlines made a lackluster return to the stock market Wednesday after the biggest initial public offering this year since Facebook, its share price weighed down by investor jitters over the airline’s prospects in a cutthroat industry, as well as anti-Japanese protests in China that threaten travel between the two countries.

headline: Our Revolting Elites
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What does it say about our culture that the people funding presidential campaigns seem to regard their downscale fellow countrymen as a kind of alien race?
lead_paragraph: Were Mitt Romney’s now-famous comments at a fundraising dinner in May — in which he appeared to write off 47 percent of Americans as self-pitying freeloaders with no self-respect — a window into the elusive “real Romney” and proof that his moderate-seeming façade has always been a sham?

headline: Early Polls Point to Pettitte as Yankees’ Go-To Pitcher
abstract: Which starting pitcher would get the call if the Yankees faced a wild-card game and survival?
lead_paragraph: In an election season of interminable polling, it would be interesting to pose a multiple-choice question exclusively to increasingly edgy Yankees fans: for one wild-card game of suspense and survival, which starter would be most comforting, if only under these presumed conditions?

headline: Romney Campaign Borrowed $20 Million to Get Through Convention
abstract: The money helped carry Mitt Romney through the Republican convention, when he was formally nominated and could tap into tens of millions of dollars in general election funds.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney borrowed $20 million for his presidential campaign in August, a campaign official said on Tuesday, money that helped carry Mr. Romney through the Republican convention until he could tap into tens of millions of dollars in general election money his campaign raised.

headline: 131 Escape in One of Mexico’s Largest Jailbreaks
abstract: Prison officials are under suspicion after the inmates escaped through a tunnel in Piedras Negras.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The inmates were massed in the prison carpentry workshop when somebody gave the signal. Wedging themselves into a tunnel almost 10 feet below ground, 131 prisoners slid one by one along 23 feet to emerge at the base of the north watchtower.

headline: With Tax Comments, Romney Wades Into a Conservative Rift
abstract: Despite conservatives’ goal of reducing the burden on the poor with tax credits, Mitt Romney tapped into an anxiety that “takers” are overtaking “makers.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney decided to fully join the battle on social programs, warning in an interview Tuesday with Fox News that the nation’s spending was putting it “on a pathway that looks more European than American.”

headline: Middle East Comments Could Vex a Romney Administration
abstract: Mitt Romney’s views on the Middle East and Iran may have already been well known, but comments of his that were captured on video at a fund-raiser could bring difficulties if he wins the presidency.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — No one has ever had any illusions about where Mitt Romney stands on the two hottest disputes in the Middle East: the argument over the creation of a Palestinian state, and the debate over what can be done to assure that Iran does not get a nuclear weapon.

headline: After Libya, Renewed Questions About the Potency of Al Qaeda
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The attack in Benghazi has set off a new debate in Washington and across the Middle East about whether Al Qaeda has been reinvigorated or lives on as a useful boogeyman.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The attack on the United States mission in Benghazi, Libya, that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens has set off a new debate here and across the Middle East about whether Al Qaeda has been reinvigorated amid the chaos of the Arab Spring or instead merely lives on as a kind of useful boogeyman, scapegoat or foil.

headline: Syria Orders Schools to Open, but Classes Give Way to War
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Instead of projecting calm, the schools reflected what had happened in the rest of the country during the summer: the fighting had grown worse and the routines of daily life more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — At one Syrian school, in the Damascus suburbs, students were so scarce this week that teachers spent most of the last few days sitting around and drinking tea.

headline: Seeking a Truce on the Links
keywords: ['Golf', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A golf industry group is asking politicians to stop attacking rivals’ affinities for the sport, saying the rhetoric does real harm to the industry.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has never seemed particularly perturbed by Republicans’ attacks on the frequency of his golf outings. But for the golf industry, the politics of golf is not just a game.

headline: In China, Panetta Says American Focus on Asia Is No Threat
abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta declared Wednesday that the United States was not trying to contain a rising China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta declared Wednesday that the United States was not trying to contain a rising China, and he emphasized that with patience and effort current tensions between the giant rivals on opposite sides of the Pacific could be resolved.

headline: Negotiators Meet in Bid to Revive Iran Talks
abstract: The top nuclear negotiators for Iran and the big powers held private discussions in Istanbul as part of an effort to restart stalled talks over Iran’s disputed uranium enrichment.
lead_paragraph: The top nuclear negotiators for Iran and the big powers met face to face for the first time in nearly three months on Tuesday, part of an effort to revive the stalled talks over Iran’s disputed uranium enrichment activities as new military tensions roil the Middle East.

headline: Beyoncé and Jay-Z Host Obama Fund-Raiser
abstract: Beyoncé, President Obama said, was a role model to his girls, while he felt a sense of kinship with Jay-Z because “we both have daughters and our wives are more popular than we are.”
lead_paragraph: On a day when Mitt Romney’s videotaped remarks at a Republican fund-raiser dominated the campaign, President Obama attended two fund-raisers of his own in New York City, one hosted by the music super-couple Beyoncé Knowles and Jay-Z.

headline: In Kudankulam, Waiting for the Government to React
abstract: Anti-nuclear protesters hope to pressure the government to negotiate.
lead_paragraph: Pressure mounted on the Indian government to resume talks with antinuclear activists after a second protester died in southern Tamil Nadu in demonstrations against the Kudankulam Atomic Power Project, India’s biggest nuclear plant.

headline: For Weight Loss, Less Exercise May Be More
abstract: Men in a Danish study who worked out for 30 minutes a day lost more weight than those who worked out vigorously for a full hour each day.
lead_paragraph: Most people who start working out in hopes of shedding pounds wind up disappointed, a lamentable circumstance familiar to both exercisers and scientists. Multiple studies, many of them covered in this column, have found that without major changes to diet, exercise typically results in only modest weight loss at best (although it generally makes people much healthier). Quite a few exercisers lose no weight. Some gain.

headline: Education Site Expands Slate of Universities and Courses
abstract: Coursera, just five months old, has drawn a number of notable institutions into its free online learning system, including Brown, Columbia and Wesleyan.
lead_paragraph: Coursera, a start-up online education company that has enrolled 1.35 million students in its free online courses since it began just five months ago, is now more than doubling, to 33, its partners, universities that will offer classes on its platform. All together, Coursera will provide more than 200 free “massive open online courses,” known as MOOCs.

headline: Wisconsin Offers Window on Hurdles Ahead for Romney
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012']

lead_paragraph: RACINE, Wis. — To Mitt Romney, the 10 electoral votes in Wisconsin may be more essential than extra, a critical backup plan if a first-tier battleground state falls out of reach.

headline: A Tight Race in Wisconsin
abstract: A new poll shows the race for Wisconsin’s open Senate seat is deadlocked.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — In the battle for control of the United States Senate, the Democratic Party’s quest to hold its majority relies in large part on protecting two of its open seats in Wisconsin and Virginia.

headline: The Bose in the Boson
abstract: Some Indians are asking, with a straight face, that the “boson” in “Higgs boson” be capitalized to honor the work of the Indian physicist Satyendra Nath Bose.
lead_paragraph: DELHI — Calcutta — or “Kolkata,” as we are now told to spell it — is the most self-consciously intellectual and parochial of Indian cities. Given that Indians in general live with a belief, often unsupported by empirical evidence, in their intellectual superiority, the subject of Bengali geniuses can be especially touchy.

lead_paragraph: NEWS Testing the theory that it often takes a crisis to bring Europeans together, 11 foreign ministers, led by Guido Westerwelle of Germany, have called for a big increase in economic, political, diplomatic and even military integration within the European Union. Stephen Castle reports from London.

headline: Who Can Turn the World On With Her Smile?
abstract: Remembering “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” which in the 1970s “was liberating for women.”

headline: Sex in the 60s
abstract: A sexual drought that is far from the bounty of youth has many reasons. Desire isn’t one of them.
lead_paragraph: I am single, and therefore I spend a lot of time thinking about sex, which is very different than it was 40 years ago when I was in my 20s and spent a lot of time having sex. You have no doubt heard this before, but in the ‘70s there was a tremendous amount of sex to be had in New York; it was the way it was when they talk about the oysters in the harbor, all you had to do was put out a hand and scoop it up: Hello there, lady, I just saw you walking down the street, would you like to have sex? No thank you, Gallant Gent, I have to organize my sock drawer, which will certainly take an hour, and by that time you will have given three women herpes, the worst sexually transmitted disease Greenwich Village has ever known, may science soon find a cure.

headline: Malcolm X as Visual Strategist
abstract: Malcolm X was keenly aware of the power of images to transform the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Robert L. Flora’s black-and-white portrait of Malcolm X, the national spokesman for the Nation of Islam, stands as one of the great meta-images about photography — an astute commentary on our insatiable hunger for pictures. Taken in Los Angeles in May 1963, the photo depicts the civil rights leader and his associates as they await the verdict of an all-white jury deliberating the fate of 14 Black Muslims accused of assaulting police officers. The pictorial magazines and tabloid newspapers they voraciously read to pass the time nearly crowd out the image.

headline: Should Students Be Able to Grade Their Teachers?
abstract: Should student evaluations should be used by administrators, along with other data, to make decisions about teacher salary and job tenure?
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday students in Chicago public schools returned to classes after missing more than a week of school because their teachers were on strike. One of the questions at the heart of the strike: How should teachers be evaluated?

headline: New Cracks Are Forming in Coalition Leading India
abstract: The turmoil surrounding India’s government intensified on Wednesday, with a former ally calling for the prime minister to seek a fresh electoral mandate.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The turmoil surrounding India’s national government intensified Wednesday, with a growing number of regional partners threatening to withdraw their support from the government and a former ally calling for the prime minister to seek a new electoral mandate.

headline: Rebels Are Said to Defeat Syrian Forces in Battle at Border
abstract: Syria’s civil war again spilled into border areas as rebels reportedly drove government troops from a northern frontier crossing.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For the second time in a week, the civil war in Syria spilled across border areas on Wednesday as rebel forces were reported to have driven government troops from a northern frontier crossing in an apparent effort to expand supply and infiltration routes in the campaign to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: French Magazine Runs Cartoons That Mock Muhammad
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Magazines']
abstract: France planned to close its embassies in 20 countries on Friday after illustrations in a satirical magazine set off new outrage by Muslims.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Calling itself a defender of free speech and a denouncer of religious backwardness, a French satirical newspaper on Wednesday published several crude caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad, images viewed as a provocation by many Muslims and condemned by the French government as irresponsible at a time of violence and unrest across the Islamic world.

headline: Past Forward: Why Students Still Want to Get Into ‘Hot’ Colleges
abstract: Years ago, it was UVA, Stanford, and Vanderbilt. Now, the “hot” colleges include Harvey Mudd, the College of Charleston, and Elon. What’s your definition of a “hot” college?
lead_paragraph: Harvey Mudd. The University of Richmond. The College of Charleston. Elon. They may be unfamiliar names to many, but according to Marjorie Hansen Shaevitz, a college admissions counselor and the author of “Admission Possible: The Dare to Be Yourself Guide for Getting Into the Best Colleges,” they are all examples of schools that “have suddenly come into the hot scene” for high-school seniors applying to college, something they’re working at right now (most early-admissions deadlines are Nov. 1).

headline: Passing Up the Opportunity to Appear on ‘Shark Tank’
abstract: Did Sean Tice and Kristy Hadeka make the right decision whey they refused to trade 5 percent of Brooklyn Slate for an appearance on the reality show?
lead_paragraph: Last week, I met with two entrepreneurs from a growing company called Brooklyn Slate. Sean Tice and Kristy Hadeka, whose company makes cheese boards out of slate, shared their stories with me, and many of them  would have sounded familiar to anyone who has struggled to build a business. But there was one story that I had not heard. Mr. Tice and Ms. Hadeka had come close to appearing on the ABC reality show “Shark Tank,” where entrepreneurs pitch their companies to a group of wealthy investors, including Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks.

headline: Heineken Wins Support for $4.6 Billion Bid for Asia Pacific Breweries

lead_paragraph: President Obama has been on the decline in the FiveThirtyEight forecast. On Tuesday, his chance of winning the Electoral College dropped to 72.9 percent, from 74.8 percent on Monday. Mr. Obama is now well off his peak in the forecast, 80.8 percent, which he reached on Sept. 12.

With all the focus on teachers, however, one group that is often forgotten as a key learning resource are the students themselves.

headline: The Louvre’s New Islamic Galleries Bring Riches to Light
abstract: The museum’s new galleries for Islamic art, which open to the public on Saturday, are the most radical architectural intervention at the Louvre since I. M. Pei’s glass pyramid.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When I. M. Pei’s glass pyramid opened at the Louvre more than 20 years ago, many argued that this 70-foot-tall structure had destroyed the classical beauty of one of the world’s great museums. But today, as crowds wait on long lines outside the pyramid, which serves as the Louvre’s main entrance, what once seemed audacious has become as accepted a part of the city’s visual landscape as the Eiffel Tower or the Arc de Triomphe.

lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, Brandie Smith, the curator of endangered giant pandas at the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington, was at her computer, taking part in a charged conference call that revolved around a squawk.

abstract: A former first lady of Germany, Bettina Wulff, has sued Google because the search giant’s autocomplete function provides the words “Bettina Wulff prostitute” and “Bettina Wulff escort” when her name is typed in, reports Nicholas Kulish in Wednesday’s New York Times.

abstract: Japan’s reversal on a plan to eliminate its use of nuclear power came after intense opposition from business groups and communities that host the country’s nuclear plants.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In an abrupt turnabout, the Japanese government on Wednesday stopped short of formally adopting the goal it announced just last week — to phase out nuclear power by 2040 — after the plan drew intense opposition from business groups and communities whose economies depend on local nuclear power plants.

lead_paragraph: “Maaah-vin,” Barbra Streisand said on Tuesday night, affectionately addressing a portrait of Marvin Hamlisch that was projected on the stage of Juilliard’s Peter Jay Sharp Theater. “The name itself just makes me smile.”
