headline: On Our Radar: Warm Eastern Waters
abstract: From Maine to North Carolina, ocean temperatures off the East Coast in the first six months of this year were the hottest ever recorded.
lead_paragraph: Sea surface temperatures off the East Coast from North Carolina to the Gulf of Maine in the first six months of 2012 were the hottest ever recorded, NOAA reports. Above-average temperatures were found from the sea surface to the ocean bottom and out beyond the Gulf Stream, the agency says. [Mother Jones]

headline: Timely | Melody Maker
abstract: The first thing you notice about Rae Morris is her voice, something the 20-year-old singer from Blackpool, England, is just getting used to.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you notice about Rae Morris is her voice, something the 20-year-old singer from Blackpool, England, is just getting used to. “I only started singing two years ago,” she says from Los Angeles, where she is interviewing producers for her first album. “I was always the girl at school with the not-cool croaky voice.” Once she started writing songs, singing (while playing the piano) came easily, and she racked up some 200 live shows in a year. (Her parents drove her to almost every one.) And after signing to Atlantic Records and gaining Christopher Bailey’s endorsement as one of the Burberry Acoustic musicians, she now finds herself a long way from home, in a studio in the Hollywood Hills. “Can’t believe I’m here, to be honest. I keep having to pinch myself,” she says. “You don’t get this weather in Blackpool, that’s for sure.”

headline: What They Said: Mamata Banerjee Pulling Out of the UPA
abstract: Opposition and allies in the governing coalition react to Ms. Banerjee’s decision to withdraw support.
lead_paragraph: The regional party of Mamata Banerjee, the maverick leader of West Bengal who has threatened to pull out of the governing coalition, raised even more pressure on the national government by demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Manmohan Singh on Wednesday.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Voter ID Law
abstract: The requirement is in jeopardy–and that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: In August, a Pennsylvania Commonwealth Court judge upheld the state’s new voter ID law—despite the fact that state officials presented no evidence of in-person voter fraud, and didn’t even try to claim that voter fraud would likely occur this November in the absence of an ID requirement.

headline: Gadgets to Help New Parents Sleep
abstract: New consumer devices can monitor everything from kilocalories to REM sleep. Have you tried any gadgetry to measure your sleep, and did it help?
lead_paragraph: If you’re a new or young parent, you probably already know that your sleep is disrupted. But when Emily Waltz, a new mother,  realized her sleep was still poor even after her young son learned to sleep through the night, she wired herself up to a series of new consumer devices designed to measure everything from her REM sleep to the number of kilocalories she was burning daily, and wrote about it for the Web site of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers  (IEEE), a professional association for the advancement of technology.

headline: Well Hello, Mr. Soul
abstract: Driving Around with Neil Young
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of people, I often read something in the magazine that involved a writer going to see this or that music/film/theater icon and think about how lucky that writer was. This week it was my turn.

headline: Two or Three Cats
abstract: Two clever new picture books about friendships and rivalries between cats.
lead_paragraph: One book features three cat friends. The other is about two cat rivals. One offers inspired nonsense. The other deals with a (relatively) realistic situation. But with eye-poppingly bright and friendly illustrations, winning stories and clever execution, these two new picture books stand apart from the rest of the cat pack.

headline: From Surviving Katrina to Spreading the Word About Entrepreneurship
keywords: ['Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Small Business', 'Entrepreneurship', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: After Hurricane Katrina wiped out his construction business in New Orleans, Kevin Langley refocused his life as he rebuilt his company, traveling the world as head of the Entrepreneurs’ Organization.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Katrina wiped out Kevin Langley’s New Orleans construction business. As both the city and the business struggled to recover, Mr. Langley came to believe that entrepreneurship was the solution to many of New Orleans’s — and the world’s — ills.

headline: Can Entrepreneurship Solve the World’s Problems?
abstract: After Katrina, Kevin Langley, who is in the construction business in New Orleans, tried to apply the lessons he learned to other struggling areas.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Katrina wiped out Kevin Langley’s New Orleans construction business, he saw the role that business owners and entrepreneurs played in trying to put the city back on its feet. Inspired, Mr. Langley became global chairman of the Entrepreneurs’ Organization and wound up going on a world tour of troubled locations where he sought to inspire, mentor and connect entrepreneurs. Please read Ian Mount’s small-business conversation with Mr. Langley and tell us whether you think entrepreneurship is the answer.

headline: Libyan Militia Blamed for Attack on U.S. Consulate Denies Responsibility
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Sufism (Religion)']
abstract: Mohammad Ali al-Zahawi, commander of the Libyan brigade believed to have lead the assault on the American mission in Benghazi, denied responsibility in an interview with the BBC.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Mohammad Ali al-Zahawi, commander of the Libyan brigade believed to have led the assault on the American mission in Benghazi, on Tuesday made his first public statement since the attacks, telling the BBC’s Arabic language news channel that his group was not responsible for the assault and had no ties to Al Qaeda. Nor, he said, did it have ties to other groups that might share its name, Ansar al-Sharia, which means simply Supporters of Islamic Law.

headline: Harf Zimmermann, Landscaping With Light
abstract: Zimmermann considers light more important than composition or the technical aspects of his photography. The best light is very early in the day. “The morning is new and fresh and nobody has seen it before. I’m the first and only one.”
lead_paragraph: For last weekend’s cover story about the University of Virginia, we sent the Berlin-based photographer Harf Zimmermann to visit the school’s campus. Zimmermann is known for his picturesque landscapes and has photographed the Hudson River and the island of Socotra for the magazine and T, respectively.

headline: Wheelies: The Multistrada Edition
abstract: Ducati’s latest sport-touring bikes were unveiled in a Web preview on Tuesday.

headline: HTC, Once Atop Market, Gambles on Windows Phone
abstract: As the first manufacturer to support Google’s Android software, HTC, the Taiwanese handset maker, was briefly the top American smartphone maker before it was surpassed by Apple and Samsung. Now HTC is pushing another underdog: Microsoft’s Windows Phone software.

lead_paragraph: The United States received one of the more favorable possible first-round 2013 Davis Cup match-ups when the draw ceremony was conducted in London Wednesday morning, finding themselves hosting Brazil in a tie to be held February 1-3. The location of the tie has not yet been confirmed.

headline: Blast in Pakistan Leaves 10 Dead
abstract: A car bomb apparently aimed at a military vehicle killed 10 people and wounded 27 at a busy intersection in Peshawar on Wednesday, as rowdy anti-American protests continued across the country.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A car bomb apparently aimed at a military vehicle killed 10 people and wounded 27 others at a busy intersection here on Wednesday.

headline: Nets’ First Season in Brooklyn Is Made for TV

headline: After a Year on a Hilltop, Balancing the Books
abstract: In the minus column, $16,000 in savings erased. On the plus side, an incalculable personal investment.
lead_paragraph: It’s been six weeks since we returned to the New Jersey suburbs after living for a year in an off-the-grid cabin in the woods of Maine with our three kids and two cats. Reflecting on the year in my final Green post on the experience, the question that matters most is: Was it worth it?

headline: Distortion in Tax Code Makes Debt More Attractive to Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Banks use more debt than equity to finance their activities because a tax break makes the debt cheaper and encourages banks to gorge on more.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a leaked video, we know that Mitt Romney divides the country into those who pay taxes and those who don’t, the makers and the moochers.

headline: Vowel Play | Peter Coffin at Venus Over Manhattan
abstract: For anyone lamenting the disappearance of the artist’s hand in contemporary sculpture today, Peter Coffin has just the piece for you.
lead_paragraph: For anyone lamenting the disappearance of the artist’s hand in contemporary sculpture today, Peter Coffin has just the piece for you: a twelve and a half foot tall wooden construction built to resemble the universal symbol for “O.K.” Much like his Italian counterpart Maurizio Cattelan, Coffin lives on the absurdist fringe of conceptual art where critics are left wondering whether he’s a savant or are they the idiots for taking him seriously. “Vowels are fundamental sounds,” Coffin explains of “A, E, I, O, U,” the nonsensical title of his new exhibition, which opens at Venus Over Manhattan on Sept. 21. “Just reading the vowels has an effect like mouthing the words to a song without the consonants. The vowels are ethereal and consonants are anchors.” Many of his artworks strive for the appearance of self-generation, be it the aforementioned hand that looks as though it was whipped up in a tornado or a dodecahedron made of starfish cast in gold. Coffin is quick to point out that this complex five-sided shape is, according to Euclidean geometry, what Plato believed to be a building block of the cosmos, but then immediately offers another read where the starfish “could’ve come together the way skydivers do for fun in free fall.”

headline: Cartoons Spark Press Freedom Debate in France
abstract: A French magazine on Wednesday published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad after a week of Muslim protests against a video that insulted Islam. Is Charlie Hebdo defending the right of free expression or is it just throwing oil on the fire?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Press freedom or provocation? That was the question preoccupying France as a satirical weekly went ahead on Wednesday with a decision to publish cartoons featuring the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: Elmore Leonard to Be Honored by National Book Foundation
abstract: Mr. Leonard will receive the medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters.
lead_paragraph: Fall is awards season in the publishing industry, and on Wednesday the National Book Foundation announced the recipients of its annual lifetime achievement awards. The medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters will be presented to the novelist and screenwriter Elmore Leonard for his work in fiction. “For over five decades, Leonard’s westerns, crime novels, serialized novels and stories have enthralled generations of readers,” the foundation said in a statement. Harold Augenbraum, the executive director of the foundation, said Mr. Leonard has produced “vibrant literary work with an inimitable writing style.”

headline: New iOS 6 Loses Google Maps, but Adds Other Features
abstract: The new Apple iOS 6, available Wednesday, substitutes its own maps for Google Maps, which may disappoint some people, but David Pogue says the other features make it worth downloading.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the iPhone 5 isn’t the only big news for phone fans this week. Wednesday, Apple is also making iOS 6 available to anyone with a recent iPhone (3GS, 4, or 4S), iPod Touch (fourth generation) or iPad (2 or 3). It comes installed on the iPhone 5 and the new fifth-generation iPod Touch.

abstract: Over the next year, the Library plans to merge THOMAS, the online home for most of the its 151 million holdings, with the Legislative Information System, its private page for members of Congress and their staffs, to bring its online presence into the 21st Century.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress released a beta Web site on Wednesday that it says will replace its existing online catalogs in about a year.

headline: Polaroid Develops a New Instant Camera
abstract: Polaroid’s latest move to revive the field of instant photography is the Z2300 instant digital camera, which prints 2- by 3-inch prints on the spot.
lead_paragraph: Polaroid’s latest move to revive the field of instant photography (and Polaroid itself) is the Z2300 instant digital camera.

headline: Emancipation’s Price
abstract: The Battle of Antietam made freedom central to the Civil War, but also demonstrated its high cost.
lead_paragraph: Historians would later render their own judgments, but in the aftermath of the Battle of Antietam, each side took fast solace in the outcome. For men like John Dooley, a private in the First Virginia Infantry, it was the wondrous achievement of 15,000 or so “ragged, barefoot, hungry” Confederate soldiers who had “repulsed, prostrated, and demoralized” Gen. George B. McClellan’s “immense army,” more than triple the size of the Confederate corps. For Abraham Lincoln, the stalemated outcome was an imperfect opportunity to release his Emancipation Proclamation, a statement he had impatiently waited weeks to make.

headline: Syria’s Dark Horses, With Lathes: Makeshift Arms Production in Aleppo Governorate, Part I
abstract: The development of local arms-producing industries in Syria provides a good indicator of the stubborn determination and evolving organization of the fighting groups trying to unseat President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: There are many indicators of the stubborn determination and evolving organization of the fighting groups in Syria seeking to unseat President Bashar al-Assad. One of them is this: the development of local arms-producing industries in Syrian cities and the countryside. In a war in which the antigovernment fighters have sought outside support and been disappointed by what has been offered, especially from the West, the society that produced the fighters has also undertaken the production of matériel for guerrilla war, a social project of such a scale that it has contributed to the armed opposition’s momentum and confidence this year. The progression is both intriguing and relevant to those seeking to understand the Free Syrian Army, as the loosely organized antigovernment fighters are called. This is not just for the view that local production provides of latter-day warfare with do-it-yourself arms. It offers insights into something else — the social forces within an uprising that is reordering the Middle East.

headline: Class, Politics, and the 47 Percent
abstract: It’s misleading to suggest that the country splits evenly into income-based voting blocs.
lead_paragraph: Among the many fallacies in Mitt Romney’s now-infamous “47 percent” speech is that “people who pay no income tax” will “vote for the president no matter what.” More than one-fifth of non-filers are elderly, a constituency likely to favor Mr. Romney.

headline: Convicted New York Legislator Accused of a Final Swindle
abstract: A deal in which Pedro Espada Jr. received money from Soundview Healthcare’s liquidation suggests he violated his bail terms and should lose his freedom, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: It was no surprise when the Soundview Healthcare Network in the Bronx began to liquidate its assets this summer. After all, its founder and chief executive, Pedro Espada Jr., the bombastic former state legislator, had been convicted of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from the nonprofit organization, and soon afterward, seemingly a casualty of corrupt management, it stopped accepting patients and began laying off staff members.

headline: Some Religious Leaders See a Threat as Europe Grows More Secular
keywords: ['Circumcision', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Religion and Belief', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The dispute over ritual circumcision in Germany reflects the secularization of European life that, in the eyes of some religious leaders, has mutated into a form of intolerance.
lead_paragraph: HOF, Germany — This sleepy town not far from the Czech border, in a hilly corner of Catholic Bavaria, is an unlikely place to find an active synagogue, and an even unlikelier focal point for a controversy that some see as a threat to religious tolerance in Europe and even the place of Jews in Germany.

headline: The Get | Georg Jensen’s Magic Showpiece Earrings
abstract: The Danish company’s newest offering makes beautiful use of yellow gold, white pearls and diamonds.
lead_paragraph: Typically associated with exquisite silver accessories for the home, the Danish company Georg Jensen took a different approach to jewelry making with its latest offering. The Magic showpiece earrings shown here have a familiar baroque look, and make beautiful use of yellow gold, white pearls and diamonds, but it’s their ability to break down into a daintier drop size that really amazes. Abracadabra, indeed.

headline: The End of a Kansas Tradition: Moderation
abstract: Kansas has been a reliably conservative state for years, but until recently, Kansans had a strong tradition of centrist Republicanism.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Kansas, the Sunflower State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Joseph A. Aistrup, a professor of political science at Kansas State University; Burdett A. Loomis, a professor of political science at Kansas University; H. Edward Flentje, a professor in Wichita State University’s Hugo Wall School of Urban and Public Affairs; and David Kensinger, president of Roadmap Solutions, Gov. Sam Brownback’s policy organization.

headline: 36 Hours in Baltimore
abstract: From art to crabs, dive bars to “The Wire,” Natty Boh to the home of Poe, this is a textured town with multiple identities.
lead_paragraph: “YOU can look far and wide, but you’ll never discover a stranger city with such extreme style,” John Waters once noted about his hometown. Maybe that’s why Baltimore’s trumpeted glass-and-steel Inner Harbor development, with its chain restaurants, neon-loud amusements and brand-name shopping, feels so counterintuitive as a symbol for the city. But walk in any direction and the city’s charm reasserts itself. Indeed, Baltimore’s best draws tend to be left-of-center: offbeat theater, grandly decrepit neighborhoods on the cusp of gentrification, a world-class museum devoted to outsider art and a dive-bar culture that must be one of the nation’s finest.

headline: Baltimore Scenes
abstract: A museum for outsiders, the original Washington Monument and a diner are stops on this tour.
lead_paragraph: A museum for outsiders, the original Washington Monument and a diner are stops on this tour.

abstract: Ten of the world’s largest pharmaceutical companies said they would form a nonprofit group to help accelerate drug development.
lead_paragraph: Ten of the world’s largest pharmaceutical companies said on Wednesday that they would cooperate on research aimed at accelerating drug development, starting with streamlining clinical trials.

headline: Video of Romney Turns Spotlight on a Magazine
abstract: A left-leaning magazine is garnering attention with the release of a video showing Mitt Romney calling 47 percent of the public “dependent” on government and feeling like victims entitled to help.
lead_paragraph: Mother Jones, the left-leaning magazine that was founded above a McDonald’s restaurant in San Francisco 36 years ago, found itself lavished this week with the kind of attention usually reserved for larger news outlets. And that is not a bad thing for a nonprofit publication with a circulation of just over 200,000 and a business model partly dependent on its readers’ largess.

headline: A Madison Square Treat, From Rome
abstract: When the Mad. Sq. Eats festival opens on Friday, a Roman snack may upstage its New York counterparts.
lead_paragraph: New York has enjoyed a spectacular shift in the quality, quantity and variety of its street food in the past five years. Rome, however, has more or less remained wedded to fried rice balls and square pizza slices despite its millennial history of fast and cheap street food.

headline: Two Out-of-Print Nora Ephron Books to Be Published as Single Volume

lead_paragraph: Two out-of-print books by Nora Ephron will be reissued on Oct. 16 in a single-volume paperback and e-book edition, the publisher, Vintage Books, said on Wednesday.

headline: A Bellwether of Chinese Revolution
abstract: Why do the recent calls for reform in economics, politics, administration, even sports, by the Communist Party secretary of Guangdong matter? Because pressure to change often comes from the south in China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In Asia, much hinges on China. And in China, much has traditionally hinged on change from the south — from Guangdong province, an outward-looking giant of more than 100 million people next to Hong Kong. Its $840 billion economy is about as big as that of the Netherlands or Indonesia.

headline: James Gandolfini to Star in New Pilot for ‘HBO’
abstract: If it is picked up as a series, “Criminal Justice” would feature Mr. Gandolfini in his first ongoing television role since his heralded run on “The Sopranos.”
lead_paragraph: Just when he thought he was out, they pull him back in: HBO said on Wednesday that it had ordered the pilot episode of a new series that would star James Gandolfini in his first continuing role at that network (or anywhere else) since his heralded run on “The Sopranos,” confirming a report that appeared on Deadline.com. The new series, called “Criminal Justice,” is adapted from a BBC drama of the same title which, in two five-episode seasons, chronicled the lives of two different characters charged with murder; the HBO version will be written by Steven Zaillian (“Moneyball,” “Schindler’s List”) and Richard Price (“The Wire,” “Clockers”) and directed by Mr. Zaillian.

headline: G.O.P. Blocks Veteran Jobs Bill
abstract: Patty Murray, the bill’s sponsor, said many Republicans won’t acknowledge that “the treatment of our veterans is a cost of war.”
lead_paragraph: Veterans won’t be getting a new, billion-dollar jobs program, not from this Senate. Republicans on Wednesday afternoon blocked a vote on the Veterans Job Corps Bill after Jeff Sessions of Alabama raised a point of order — he said the bill  violated a cap on spending agreed to by Congress last year. The bill’s sponsor, Patty Murray of Washington, said that shouldn’t matter, since the bill’s cost was fully offset by new revenues. She said Mr. Sessions and his party colleagues had been furiously generating excuses to oppose the bill, and were now exploiting a technicality to deny thousands of veterans a shot at getting hired as police officers, firefighters and parks workers, among other things.

headline: Tailgating Recipe: Smoked Bologna With Bacon
abstract: A Houston Texans fan reminds us that bologna is not just for children and can be a staple at tailgating parties.
lead_paragraph: As a child, one of my favorite brown-bag lunches was a very simple sandwich of a few slices of bologna and some mayo on Wonder Bread. (Crust left on, thank you very much.) And it was a breakfast treat when Dad would fry up some bologna slices to go with the bacon and eggs. (A few cuts in the edges prevented the bologna from rolling up in the pan.)

abstract: Samsung continued its advertising attack on the Apple iPhone 5 with some digs in a new television advertisement posted online Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Samsung may have lost a big patent suit to Apple, but the company is winning in the snark wars with its latest television advertisement.

headline: Gran Cuisine
abstract: Two of the season’s most enticing cookbooks come from a pair of unknown grandmothers, legends only within their immigrant families for simple, soulful recipes that taste of home.
lead_paragraph: Two of the season’s most enticing cookbooks come from a pair of unknown grandmothers, legends only within their immigrant families for simple, soulful recipes that taste of home. Salma Hage moved with her family from Northern Lebanon to London in 1967, and “The Lebanese Kitchen” (Phaidon, $50) catalogs all the aromatic dishes she took with her, including eight types of hummus and a wintry twist on tabbouleh with fennel, walnuts and pomegranate syrup. And in “My Abuela’s Table” (Hardie Grant, $30), Daniella Germain sweetly illustrates her Mexican grandmother’s greatest hits, which she’d swoon for as a tot in her native Australia. Germain even draws a step-by-step guide for making picadas — breakfast tortillas topped with chile sauce, onion and cheese — “just the way my abuelo liked it.” Below, a recipe from each book.

headline: Tentative Deal on E-Book Prices Is Reached in Europe
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'E-Commerce', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The European Commission said it would end an e-book pricing investigation of Apple and four e-book publishers if they temporarily allowed online retailers to sell at a discount.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The European Commission said Wednesday that it was prepared to drop its investigation into the fixing of e-book prices by Apple and four European publishers after the companies agreed to let online retailers like Amazon sell e-books at a discount for two years.

headline: An Alert System for Security Breaches
abstract: With security breaches on the rise, companies are beginning to offer new alert systems that tell consumers when their usernames, passwords, credit cards, Social Security numbers and the like pop up on on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: It was, no doubt, the year of the security breach.

headline: Romney Says He Can Help the Poor
abstract: The Republican candidate tries to confront the notion that he is not the candidate of the poor and others who are economically challenged.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA – Mitt Romney on Wednesday confronted the most damaging perception from a secretly taped video: that he had written off those who rely on government assistance.

headline: Dave Matthews Band’s Latest Opens at No. 1
abstract: It is the band’s sixth consecutive studio album to debut at No. 1, and the first by any group to achieve such a run.
lead_paragraph: The Dave Matthews Band leads a wave of new releases taking over the top slots of Billboard’s album chart, as record companies begin their fall assault of major new releases.

headline: Stone Links: God and the Philosophers
abstract: In this week’s links: Thomas Nagel on Alvin Plantinga, Anthony Gottleib on evolutionary explanations, and more.
lead_paragraph: For decades, and from different standpoints, Thomas Nagel and Alvin Plantinga have valiantly resisted various strains of philosophical reductionism. This week the two came together at The New York Review of Books, where Nagel reviews Plantinga’s latest book, “Where the Conflict Really Lies.”

headline: The Missing Two Minutes in the Romney Video? Everyone Has a Theory
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: On Wednesday morning, Twitter users created a viral hashtag, #Missing2Min, that speculated and cracked wise about what occurred during the moments missing from the recording posted by Mother Jones.
lead_paragraph: The video of Mitt Romney’s speech at a fund-raiser in Boca Raton, Fla., released by Mother Jones magazine this week has been discussed broadly across the political spectrum. It has even apparently darkened the mood of Mr. Romney’s campaign team. There seemed to be little Mr. Romney could do but clarify that his remarks “were not elegantly stated” and fully embrace the ideas that drove them.

headline: F.T.C. Still Expects to Resolve Google Antitrust Inquiry by Year’s End
abstract: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commissions said on Wednesday that investigators expected to meet a deadline they disclosed earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission intends to decide by the end of the year whether to bring legal action against Google for anticompetitive practices, Jon Leibowitz, the chairman of the commission, said on Wednesday in Washington.

headline: One on One: Ricky Gervais, Comedian Turned App Developer
abstract: Ricky Gervais will unveil a new app on Wednesday. The app, Just Sayin’, lets people record two-way voice conversations and broadcast them to Twitter and Facebook. Bits caught up with the comedian to try to understand who would possibly need such a thing.
lead_paragraph: Add Ricky Gervais to the growing list of celebrities turned entrepreneurs. On Wednesday, Mr. Gervais, the creator of “The Office” television series, will unveil a new app, called Just Sayin’, that lets people record two-way voice conversations and broadcast them to Twitter and Facebook. In this e-mailed interview, the comedian discusses why the world would possibly need such a thing, the best conversation he overheard but did not have a chance to record and whether he plans to make himself available for tech support.

headline: The Caucus Click: A Gift From Romney
abstract: Mitt Romney presents an aide, Charlie Pearce, with a pink tie before boarding his airplane in Atlanta. The tie had been given to Mr. Romney’s wife, Ann, by a donor, to give to Mr Romney. The candidate decided it wasn’t quite his taste, so he passed it along to Mr. Pearce.

headline: Pettitte Is Early Attraction but Suzuki Steals Show
abstract: Andy Pettitte held the Blue Jays scoreless for five innings in the first game of a day-night doubleheader and Ichiro Suzuki drove in the winning run in the eighth inning of the second game.
lead_paragraph: During a simulated tour of the American League East, Andy Pettitte pitched in empty stadiums in St. Petersburg, Fla., Baltimore and Boston, all the while aching to be part of a real game in a stadium packed with boisterous fans.

headline: BP’s Chief and Putin Meet, a Sign of Movement in a Joint Venture’s Dispute
abstract: The British company has been trying to untangle itself from a troublesome partnership with Russian billionaires.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — BP may finally be close to resolving a long-running business dispute over its joint venture in Russia.

headline: ‘My Name Is Asher Lev’ Coming to Off Broadway
abstract: The acclaimed production from the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is scheduled to open at the Westside Theater in November.
lead_paragraph: The Long Wharf Theater’s critically praised production of “My Name Is Asher Lev,” a play based on the Chaim Potok novel about a young artist who clashes with Hasidic Jewish parents, will transfer for an Off Broadway commercial run at the Westside Theater starting in November, the lead producer, Darren Bagert said on Wednesday. The adaptation is by the playwright and director Aaron Posner, who before Potok’s death in 2002 collaborated with him on a stage version of another well-known novel of his, “The Chosen.”

headline: Photo Replay: Sept.19
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including Andy Pettitte’s return to the mound.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including Andy Pettitte’s return to the mound.

headline: The Online Life of the Secret Romney Recordings
abstract: An anonymous Twitter user who claims to have produced the secret recordings of Mitt Romney in May alerted the Romney campaign in late August, as well as members of the media and prominent Democrats, about parts of the video.
lead_paragraph: An anonymous Twitter user who claims to have produced the secret recordings in May of Mitt Romney speaking at a private meeting of wealthy donors in Florida alerted the Romney campaign on Twitter last month, as well as members of the news media and prominent Democrats, about parts of the video.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Companies Make New Content Deals
abstract: Companies sharpen their focus on content creators. Paperless Post pushes the envelope, literally. Digital etiquette dos and don’ts.f
lead_paragraph: Companies sharpen their focus on content creators. Paperless Post pushes the envelope, literally. Digital etiquette dos and don’ts.

headline: The ‘Redistribution’ of Wealth
abstract: President Obama’s advocacy of long-accepted government policy is not Marxist.
lead_paragraph: Guided by pollsters like Frank Luntz, the Republican party upgraded all rich people into “job creators,” and tarnished the estate tax by calling it the “death tax.” Its candidates prefer “energy exploration” to oil drilling, and insist on the “religious freedom” of church groups to deny freedom of reproductive choice to their employees. Carefully choosing words to disguise or express contempt is so vital to the party’s strategy that Republicans won’t even properly use the name of the Democratic Party, cutting off the final “ic.”

headline: Photos of The Moment | Alberta Ferretti
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: A Design School Showcases Jack Lenor Larsen
abstract: A show on the celebrated textile designer’s work at the New York School of Interior Design gives an overview of his career.
lead_paragraph: Jack Lenor Larsen, the celebrated textile designer who remains a major figure in his field, even after selling his company in 1997 to Colefax and Fowler, is getting a retrospective at the New York School of Interior Design. “Jack Lenor Larsen: 40 Years,” which will open Thursday, provides an overview of his career as a designer, collector and author.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from India, Syria, Pakistan and England.
lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Syria, Pakistan and England.

headline: In Belgium, a Converted 19th-Century Mill
abstract: An 1850 mill house with four bedrooms, set on nearly three acres not far from Brussels, is on the market for $2.2 million.
lead_paragraph: An 1850 mill house with four bedrooms, set on nearly three acres not far from Brussels, is on the market for $2.2 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Belgium
abstract: Belgium’s housing market has been steady and strong, nearly unaffected by the global economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: CONVERTED MILL ON THREE ACRES IN WALLOON BRABANT, BELGIUM

headline: Familiar Faces in the Burton House of Horror and Humor
abstract: Tim Burton discusses four of the less visible performers who have worked with him frequently over the years.
lead_paragraph: Tim Burton discusses four of the less visible performers who have worked with him frequently over the years.

headline: Out on a Limb: Building Muscle Models in Science Class
abstract: In this lesson, students learn about a soldier undergoing experimental treatment to help him regrow muscle missing from his leg. Then, students build models to reinforce concepts surrounding cells, tissues, and organs.
lead_paragraph: Overview | Unlike some animals, we cannot regenerate diseased or missing body parts. Or can we? In this lesson, students learn about a soldier undergoing experimental treatment to help him regrow muscle missing from his leg. Then students build models to reinforce concepts surrounding cells, tissues and organs.

headline: Netflix Picks Up New Ricky Gervais Series ‘Derek’
abstract: On “Derek,” Mr. Gervais, a creator and star of comedies like “The Office” and “Extras,” and a three-time host of the Golden Globe Awards, plays its title character, a naively simple man who works in a nursing home.
lead_paragraph: Ricky Gervais has no need to fear offending viewers of traditional American television with his latest series, because it won’t be broadcast there: Netflix said on Wednesday that it had acquired the rights to show “Derek,” a new comedy program written, directed by and starring Mr. Gervais, following its run on Channel 4 in Britain.

headline: Supreme Court Denies Request to Block Electoral Maps in Texas
abstract: The Supreme Court allowed November’s elections in Texas to proceed under interim electoral maps approved by a federal court San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed November’s elections in Texas to proceed under interim electoral maps approved by a federal court in San Antonio.

headline: Europe Aims to Encourage Young to Be Entrepreneurs
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Entrepreneurship', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: An advertising and informational campaign introduced Wednesday aims to encourage young Europeans to take the risk of starting their own businesses.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If and when the euro crisis ends, Europe will still face an existential economic question: Who will provide the jobs of the future?

headline: Freedom After Fire Ants and Tumult
abstract: “Life After Death,” by Damien Echols of the West Memphis Three murder case in Arkansas, is a dual memoir, partly about his prison life and partly about his tumultuous upbringing.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen and a half years after he was sentenced to death for participating in the murders of three 8-year-old boys in Arkansas, Damien Echols finds himself in Faireyland. Mr. Echols’s new book, “Life After Death,” has a Shepard Fairey-inspired cover design that’s as coolly lionizing as Mr. Fairey’s “Hope” poster for President Obama. The book has a champion in Johnny Depp, who has compared Mr. Echols’s writing to Dostoyevsky’s. And his story is the subject of a forthcoming documentary, “West of Memphis,” even though that story has been exhaustively told in the three “Paradise Lost” films that paved the path to Mr. Echols’s release from death row.

headline: The Breast-Feeding Professor Is a Red Herring
abstract: When the university professor Adrienne Pine nursed her sick baby on the first day of class, she stirred up a controversy, but public breast-feeding is far from the most important issue she raises.
lead_paragraph: Many parents of infants have decided that “breast is best.” What  they haven’t agreed on is where and when breast-feeding is appropriate, or even acceptable. In past months, women have been chastised for nursing at a water park, a library, and a Georgia church. The feeding practice that’s encouraged (some would say pushed) by hospitals, pediatricians and fellow parents doesn’t always meet with approval when it goes public.

headline: Pill Found Promising in Treatment of M.S.
abstract: Clinical trials indicate that BG-12, developed by Biogen Idec, may be safer and more effective than existing treatments for patients in the early stages of the disease.
lead_paragraph: A new oral medication to treat patients in the early stages of multiple sclerosis has shown considerable promise in two clinical trials, researchers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Training With Knicks, McIlroy Works on Jump Shot
abstract: Rory McIlroy spent last week training informally alongside the Knicks at the invitation of his fitness trainer, Steve McGregor, who works with the team.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Rory McIlroy remains more likely to sink a 10-foot putt than a 10-foot jump shot, but the gap is closing.

headline: Scouting Report
abstract: C. Wonder and Costume National have new stores, and Shop the Night Away will offer widespread discounts.
lead_paragraph: OPENINGS

headline: How a God Finds Art (the Abridged Version)
abstract: New York City Ballet began its fall run at the Koch Theater with a three Greek ballets by Balanchine and an explosive performance by Robert Fairchild.
lead_paragraph: At the start of Tuesday night’s New York City Ballet performance the curtain rose on Robert Fairchild in the title role of George Balanchine’s oldest surviving ballet, “Apollo.” In this seminal work you see the young god discovering art; and Mr. Fairchild plays the ballet, coolly but keenly, as an adventure. His performance made an auspicious start for City Ballet’s four-week fall season at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: Obama’s Lead Looks Stronger in Polls That Include Cellphones
abstract: In polls that include cellphones, President Obama seems poised for victory. In ones that don’t, his position is more tenuous.
lead_paragraph: As I observed on Tuesday, and as The New Republic’s Nate Cohn also found, Barack Obama seems to have received a much clearer bounce in some types of polls than others.

headline: Buffett Cup in Omaha
abstract: In the Buffett Cup last week in Omaha, Europe led the United States by eight points going into the individual section.
lead_paragraph: In the Buffett Cup last week in Omaha, Europe led the United States by eight points going into the individual section. However, the Americans won that by 39 points to 27 to snatch victory in the tournament.

headline: What You Get for ... $430,000
abstract: A condo in Tennessee, a Colonial in New York and a bungalow in Montana.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE

headline: Homes for $430,000
abstract: Properties in Tennessee, New York and Montana.
lead_paragraph: Properties in Tennessee, New York and Montana.

headline: Stark, Minimalist and Beckett All Over
abstract: “Sounding Beckett,” directed by Joy Zinoman, features three Samuel Beckett plays written rather late in his life.
lead_paragraph: She could be Miss Havisham. This ageless ghost of a woman with long, scraggly gray hair, dressed in a tattered, once-elegant gown, shuffling — noisily, rhythmically — back and forth across a bare floor in the growing dark. But Miss Havisham is a Dickens character and a villain, while May (Holly Twyford), the woman we see onstage, is a Samuel Beckett character and a leading lady. And while Miss Havisham is the eternal spurned bride, May is the eternal daughter. She has an elderly, bedridden mother who speaks in the tones of a cruel god (the voice of Kathleen Chalfant).

headline: Veterans’ Jobs Bill Blocked in the Senate
abstract: Eager to shoot down President Obama’s legislative agenda just weeks before the election, Senate Republicans blocked a measure that would have provided $1 billion over five years to help veterans find work.
lead_paragraph: Eager to shoot down President Obama’s legislative agenda just weeks before the election, Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked a measure that would have provided $1 billion over five years to help veterans find work in their communities.

headline: New York Public Library Shifts Plan for 5th Ave. Building
abstract: Responding to objections raised by scholars, writers, artists and others, the New York Public Library has revised its plan to remove most of the books from its flagship research center.
lead_paragraph: Responding to objections raised by scholars, writers, artists and others, the New York Public Library has revised its plan to remove most of the books from its flagship Fifth Avenue research center to make room for a circulating library. Library officials said that an $8 million donation would help pay for enough new storage space to keep 3.3 million of its 4.5 volumes at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, at 42nd Street.

headline: Click if You Can Afford It
abstract: Brad Pitt has one. So do Jude Law and Miley Cyrus. For celebrities, a Leica camera adds cachet.
lead_paragraph: SEAL flashed one on a recent stroll through Central Park with his children. Dakota Fanning huddled with hers on the set of her film “Very Good Girls.” Elisabeth Shue brought hers out at the Toronto International Film Festival last year.

headline: Daily Journal Writing Without the Inconvenience of Paper
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Mobile Applications', 'Reading and Writing Skills']
abstract: With mobile apps eliminating many of the obstacles to writing daily journal entries, there is no excuse for letting the past slip away.
lead_paragraph: Despite being a wordy sort of fellow, I’ve never put pen to paper daily to create a meaningful diary. I did make some tentative attempts when I was an adolescent, sure, but I never got hooked on a journal. With my sievelike memory, this means some precious moments of my past are now hazy. If I had a diary, I’d simply be able to look up what happened.

headline: Beauty Salons to Go
abstract: Mobile grooming services are designed to come to busy working women.
lead_paragraph: NEDA ARMIAN, 42, is an independent film producer based in Manhattan who takes meetings over lunch, while simultaneously reading e-mails and scripts. “A couple days a week, I work late because of the time difference with Los Angeles,” she said. “It’s just part of the routine.”

headline: Living in Their Art
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']

lead_paragraph: A couple’s homestead in Catskill, N.Y., has grown into an art museum of sorts over the years.

abstract: Portia Munson and Jared Handelsman make art from their land, combing the natural wealth of their 83 acres of woods and gardens in Catskill, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: CATSKILL, N.Y.

headline: Jukebox Apps for the Party-Pleasing D.J.
abstract: An intrepid D.J. decided he wanted to let partygoers select songs much like a jukebox, which he was finally able to do once he found the iPad app Tune Drop.
lead_paragraph: My mission was to supply the music for a friend’s big birthday party. Sounds simple enough, right? Set up a playlist on an iPod and throw in a little Motown, because everybody likes Motown. Plug it into the sound system at the bar we had rented out and hit play. Instant revelry.

headline: Misinformed Monetary Mitt
abstract: Some guy told him something, so it must be true.
lead_paragraph: Leave aside what the now-famous video tells us about Mitt Romney’s character; in a way the shocking thing is how uninformed he seems to be. The 47 percent number was the kind of thing you hear in yahoo forums like talk radio and the Wall Street Journal editorial page; and then there’s what he said about US debt.

headline: Letting Children Share in Grief
keywords: ['Grief (Emotion)', 'Parenting', 'Death and Dying', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Children and Childhood', 'Hospice Care']
abstract: The idea that children should be as involved in the mourning process as adults reflects an increasingly common belief that they are better off when their grief is acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: A FEW decades ago, children often didn’t attend funerals. The thinking was that they should be sheltered from the pain of losing a loved one. And as Americans started living longer, the need to even broach the subject of death was delayed because many grandparents survived deep into their golden years.

headline: Children and Minimalism, Coexisting

lead_paragraph: A home in San Francisco is renovated to accommodate children, while also maintaining its modern look.

headline: Senate Republicans Not Eager to Discuss Romney Video
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: At a news conference on Capitol Hill, Republican Senate leaders declined to answer questions on the Romney video.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders in the Senate on Wednesday were intent on showing Mitt Romney how it’s done: blast President Obama for his lack of leadership, castigate his economic record, then flee.

keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

headline: Shopping for Tribal Patterns
abstract: Shanan Campanaro, the artist and designer who founded Brooklyn wallpaper and fabric company Eskayel, finds tribal inspiration without leaving New York.
lead_paragraph: Shanan Campanaro, the artist and designer who founded Brooklyn wallpaper and fabric company Eskayel, finds tribal inspiration without leaving New York.

headline: Tribal Patterns
abstract: The artist and designer Shanan Campanaro explores Brooklyn for tribal fabrics to inspire her own wallpaper and fabric ideas.
lead_paragraph: SHANAN CAMPANARO, the artist and designer who founded the Brooklyn wallpaper and fabric company Eskayel, has discovered that studying the traditions of other cultures — particularly their tribal patterns — often triggers ideas for new designs.

headline: Nation of Takers
abstract: Take that 47, and double it.
lead_paragraph: Do today’s Republicans really believe that 47 percent of Americans are “takers”, living off money confiscated from the “makers”?

headline: Ai, Reporter
keywords: ['Art', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'United States International Relations', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Video of Chinese protesters in Beijing surrounding the American ambassador’s car on Tuesday was uploaded to YouTube by Ai Weiwei, a Chinese artist and dissident.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Thursday 3:06 p.m. On Tuesday in Beijing, amid protests over the sovereignty of several tiny islands also claimed by Japan, a small group of protesters briefly surrounded the American ambassador’s car outside the United States Embassy, pelting it with objects. As our colleagues Thom Shanker and Ian Johnson reported, Ambassador Gary Locke said later, “I never felt in any danger.”

headline: A Living Room Suspended Over Columbus Circle
abstract: The Japanese artist Tatzu Nishi discusses his design for a living room around the towering statue at Columbus Circle.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Public Art Fund is unveiling “Discovering Columbus,” by the Japanese artist Tatzu Nishi. Since 1997, Mr. Nishi, 52, has been fabricating domestic environments around artworks and public monuments, like the kitchen he built around a Picasso hanging on the wall of a museum in Nagoya, Japan.

headline: You Had a Monster Hit. Now What?
abstract: The singer Carly Rae Jepsen is out to prove that she has more to offer than the smash hit “Call Me Maybe.”
lead_paragraph: For months there’s been little else in pop besides the Carly Rae Jepsen song “Call Me Maybe.” It’s the sort of hit that stifles dissent, that blinds with its brightness, that answers to no friction applied against it.

headline: Naomi Wolf Sparks Another Debate (on Sex, of Course)
abstract: Is this the fall of the onetime angel in the house of feminism, or is Naomi Wolf restoring sex to the country’s continuing conversation about gender-wide frustration?
lead_paragraph: “WHO gets to say it? Who gets to own it? Who gets to say what happens to it?”

headline: A Bunk Bed Born of a Couch
abstract: The space-saving Multibed Castello takes the concept of a convertible sofa to a new level.
lead_paragraph: The convertible couch has been taken to a whole new level. Milano Smart Living, an Italian producer of high-end, space-saving furniture that moved into the New York Design Center last week, is selling a sofa that unfolds into a bunk bed. Named for the Italian word for castle, Multibed Castello springs open with the touch of a finger.

headline: Alessi Welcomes the Next Generation
abstract: The company introduces new designs by Cranbrook Academy and ECAL students.
lead_paragraph: Not content with corralling the talents of leading designers and architects, Alessi is getting a head start with the next generation.

headline: Mitt Says Dave Hates Him. Not So, Says Dave, Who Invites Him to Appear.
abstract: According to comments by Mitt Romney that were secretly taped, David Letterman is jealous because Jay Leno has had more interviews with Mr. Romney. Mr. Letterman’s response: “Why hate a guy who’s suffered through that?”
lead_paragraph: Does David Letterman hate Mitt Romney?

headline: Furnishings Inspired by Art
abstract: “After,” a exhibit of furnishings by Kelly Behun and Alex P. White, opens at R20th Century.
lead_paragraph: “After,” a collection of eight furniture pieces and two wallpaper patterns by the interior designer Kelly Behun and her colleague, Alex P. White, currently on exhibit at R20th Century, pays tribute to the artists, living and dead, who have influenced them.

headline: Earthy Lamps With a Disco Vibe
abstract: The lamps, designed by Robert Lewis, are available at the Future Perfect.
lead_paragraph: Robert Lewis’s mica pendant lamps, now occupying the window of the Future Perfect in NoHo, have a disco-geodesic look — which is no surprise considering their origins. Mr. Lewis, a self-taught lighting designer whose pieces can be found at the Ace Hotel in Palm Springs and in several Kiki de Montparnasse boutiques, made the first model while living in Miami in the mid-’90s. “I was looking for a way to build something without a metal frame,” he said. “I ended up with an archetypal Buckyball structure, where the pattern holds itself.”

headline: Sales at Knolls, Jacques Carcanagues and Others
abstract: Discounts offered on midcentury modern furniture, area rugs and more.
lead_paragraph: Knoll’s annual sale starts Friday, with 15 percent off iconic midcentury modern furniture, through Sept. 29 (the Richard Schultz 1966 chaise lounge, originally $2,713, will be about $2,306); 76 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), 11th floor, (212) 343-4087.

headline: Cuomo Seeks Artist’s Touch in Replacing Tappan Zee Bridge
abstract: The artist Jeff Koons is the best known among a team of experts announced by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Wednesday to make sure that designs for the new bridge will “live up to the beauty and splendor of the Hudson River.”
lead_paragraph: ALBANY – The artist Jeff Koons is best known for his whimsical sculptures of giant puppies made of flowers, and balloon animals fashioned from stainless steel.

headline: Spinning the Family Name
abstract: Children of the rich and famous find work and news media attention at the turntable.
lead_paragraph: ON the eve of New York Fashion Week, Target held a splashy party in a former carriage house on West 15th Street that had been transformed into four brightly colored pop-up shops. It was as if a suburban mall had momentarily alighted in the meatpacking district.

headline: Trulia Prices I.P.O. at $17 a Share, Above Expected Range
abstract: Trulia priced its initial stock offering at $17 a share on Wednesday, surpassing expectations as the real estate search site raised $102 million.
lead_paragraph: Trulia priced its initial public offering at $17 a share on Wednesday, surpassing expectations as the real estate search site raised $102 million.

headline: “How I Got These Boots”
abstract: Davy Rothbart reads from an essay in which he picks up a hitchhiker on his way to the Grand Canyon.
lead_paragraph: Davy Rothbart reads from an essay in which he picks up a hitchhiker on his way to the Grand Canyon.

headline: Ending Its Summer Melt, Arctic Sea Ice Sets a New Low That Leads to Warnings
abstract: The apparent low point for 2012 was reached Sunday, when sea ice covered 24 percent of the surface of the Arctic Ocean, down from the previous low of 29 percent set in 2007.
lead_paragraph: The drastic melting of Arctic sea ice has finally ended for the year, scientists announced Wednesday, but not before demolishing the previous record — and setting off new warnings about the rapid pace of change in the region.

headline: Tim Burton, at Home in His Own Head
abstract: The director of “Beetlejuice,” “Batman” and the new “Frankenweenie” may be cinema’s most widely embraced loner.
lead_paragraph: LONDON

headline: The Films of Tim Burton
abstract: Images from Tim Burton’s filmography, including his latest movie, “Frankenweenie.”
lead_paragraph: Images from Tim Burton’s filmography, including his latest movie, “Frankenweenie.”

headline: Fox and TBS Close In on New Baseball Deals
abstract: Fox Sports is close to a deal with Major League Baseball that would let it add more regular season and playoff games.
lead_paragraph: Fox Sports is close to a deal with Major League Baseball that will let it add more playoff and regular-season games, justifying its plan to create a new cable sports network, said three people with knowledge of the negotiations. By contrast, TBS will get fewer games in its pending deal.

headline: As ‘Daddy,’ Mark Madoff Lives On
abstract: I look for ways to talk and even laugh about my husband with our children, and I take my cues from them in dealing with our grief.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 11, 2010, my husband, Mark Madoff, hung himself from an exposed beam in the living room of our downtown apartment. Even now I still wake up every morning with a jolt, as if I am hearing the news for the first time that my husband has killed himself. I’m rattled for a good five seconds as my brain acknowledges and accepts that Mark is gone. Oddly enough, the painful jarring of my heart is what gives me the strength to get up and start my day. I get up and push forward not only for myself but also for my children, Audrey and Nicholas.

headline: Bloomberg’s Fortune Jumped to $25 Billion, Forbes Estimates

lead_paragraph: Are you better off than you were a year ago? For Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the answer is almost certainly yes.

headline: On the Road, a Poet of Lost and Found
abstract: Davy Rothbart, a founder of Found magazine, brings his voyeurism to New Haven in his 75-city tour with his brother Peter.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Davy Rothbart had misplaced his usual hype music, so Rage Against the Machine would have to do. Mr. Rothbart, a writer and a creator of Found magazine,  the repository for forgotten notes and photos, normally listened to Metallica’s “One” to get himself pumped for a show. But on Monday evening he popped a CD with “Bombtrack” into the player in his rented Dodge minivan and began fist-pumping along.

keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Hats and Caps']

headline: Q. and A.: China’s Leadership Transition and Xi Jinping
abstract: The transfer of political power in China, which could begin in a matter of weeks, is arguably the most important political leadership change in the world this year — in a year of turnovers and elections. But what do the mysteries surrounding it mean? What will it presage for China and for the world?
lead_paragraph: Sometime soon — perhaps next month in October — the most populous nation in the world will begin its biggest leadership transition in a decade. Dozens of the most senior positions in China’s Communist Party, government and army will change hands in a process that will last months (in the case of the army, perhaps even years.) Here are some questions and answers about this important event. Join the conversation with your own answers and questions in the Comments below.

headline: The Inconvenient Truth Behind the Diaoyu/Senkaku Islands
abstract: Guest blogger Han-yi Shaw argues that Japan in effect stole the Diaoyu/Senkaku islands from China in 1895 as booty of war.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had a longstanding interest in the Diaoyu/Senkaku islands, the subject of a dangerous territorial dispute  between Japan and China. The United States claims to be neutral but in effect is siding with Japan, and we could be drawn in if a war ever arose. Let me clear that I deplore the violence in the recent anti-Japan protests in China:  the violence is reprehensible and makes China look like an irrational bully. China’s government should rein in this volatile nationalism rather than feed it. This is a dispute that both sides should refer to the International Court of Justice, rather than allow to boil over in the streets. That said, when I look at the underlying question of who has the best claim, I’m sympathetic to China’s position. I don’t think it is 100 percent clear, partly because China seemed to acquiesce to Japanese sovereignty between 1945 and 1970, but on balance I find the evidence for Chinese sovereignty quite compelling. The most interesting evidence is emerging from old Japanese government documents and suggests that Japan in effect stole the islands from China in 1895 as booty of war. This article by Han-Yi Shaw, a scholar from Taiwan, explores those documents. I invite any Japanese scholars to make the contrary legal case. – Nicholas Kristof

headline: On Planet Proenza

lead_paragraph: IN a world of fashion design densely populated by difficult, messy individuals, one can well understand the temptation to team up and clean up, à la Dolce & Gabbana or Viktor & Rolf. You and your partner may not agree on every inch of rickrack, but he’ll probably stop you from alcohol-fueled anti-Semitic rants and affairs with a tanned pornographic-film star half your age.

On Thursday night, Ms. Parker, a board member of the New York City Ballet, will be among the hosts of a party that brings together fashion and dance. And Mr. Garavani, who retired from his fashion house in 2008, has created the costumes for four works that will be presented that night.

headline: Mr. and Mrs. Jesus Christ?
abstract: Does a new discovery of an ancient papyrus mean that Jesus was married? Probably not.
lead_paragraph: AT an academic conference in Rome on Tuesday, Karen L. King, a church historian at Harvard Divinity School, presented a finding that, according to some reports, threatened to overturn what we know about Jesus, as well as the tradition of priestly celibacy. She identified a small fragment of fourth-century papyrus that includes the words, “Jesus said to them, ‘My wife...’ ” Another clause appears to say, “she will be able to be my disciple.” Some experts have concluded that the manuscript, written in Coptic, is authentic.

headline: Endeavour’s Last Journey, Through Contentious Space
abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour traveled 122,883,151 miles in 25 missions, but its final 12 miles in Los Angeles may prove to be its most difficult.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The space shuttle Endeavour traveled 122,883,151 miles during its 25 missions, bursting out of the atmosphere at more than 17,000 miles an hour. On the last flight of its 20-year career, a three-day victory lap across the country on the back of a transport aircraft, it will log a few thousand miles more before touching down for the final time on Friday at Los Angeles International Airport.

Knopf, including detective novels, the autobiography of Walter Cronkite and the works of Gabriel García Márquez, died on Tuesday in Westerly, R.I. He was 84.

headline: Louisiana: Arrest in Bomb Threat
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Police', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: On Friday morning,William Bouvay Jr., 42, called the 911 dispatcher and said that multiple bombs around Louisiana State University would detonate within two hours, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested a man suspected of phoning in a bomb threat to Louisiana State University on Monday, prompting a campuswide evacuation. The man, William Bouvay Jr., 42, of Baton Rouge, La., was taken into custody shortly before midnight on Tuesday, the campus police department said in a statement. On Friday morning, Mr. Bouvay had called the 911 dispatcher and said that multiple bombs around the campus would detonate within two hours, the authorities said. Law enforcement agencies determined that the call had been made from a deactivated cellphone that could make only emergency calls; they were able to pinpoint the area from which the call was made through GPS technology. Mr. Bouvay, who was in the area, agreed to go in for questioning, but ultimately confessed and told the police where the phone could be found, the police said. They declined to discuss possible motives for the calls, but said Mr. Bouvay had been arrested in 2004 for making harassing phone calls to a former girlfriend who worked at the university.

headline: A Reminder to Look(!) Both Ways
abstract: New York’s new traffic safety awareness campaign will feature a warning stenciled along curbsides at more than 100 of the city’s most dangerous intersections.
lead_paragraph: The British have a history of being unlucky on American shores, and in the winter of 1931, Winston S. Churchill was no exception. Alighting from a cab on Fifth Avenue on the Upper East Side, Churchill, accustomed to his home country’s driving conventions, looked right on the then-two way avenue when he should have looked left.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For Fred Couples, who is laid up with a sore back, the timing of his notification of admittance to the World Golf Hall of Fame last week was ideal. “It will push me to play a couple more years,” said Couples, 52, winner of 23 titles on the PGA and the Champions tours.

lead_paragraph: SPIRIT LAKE INDIAN RESERVATION, N.D. — The man who plays Santa Claus here is a registered child sex offender and a convicted rapist. One of the brothers of the tribal chairman raped a child, and a second brother sexually abused a 12-year-old girl. They are among a number of men convicted of sex crimes against children on this remote home of the Spirit Lake Sioux tribe, which has among the highest proportion of sex offenders in the country.

abstract: Some of President Obama’s most significant recent policy announcements have been keyed to voter blocs, as his campaign seeks to make the most of his incumbency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, government lawyers and economists worked behind the scenes to develop a trade case against China. Then last month came a eureka moment: They confirmed the existence of a Chinese subsidy program for automobiles and parts that in their view violated international trade rules. They finished a complaint, circulated it among agencies and proposed a time frame for filing.

headline: Santiago Carrillo, a Spanish Communist Leader, Dies at 97

lead_paragraph: Santiago Carrillo, who evolved from a bomb-throwing opponent of Gen. Francisco Franco and his fascist forces into a Spanish Communist leader who promoted a more moderate, democratic European Communist Party independent of the Soviet Union, died on Tuesday at his home in Madrid. He was 97.

headline: High Court in Italy Backs Convictions for Rendition

lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s supreme court on Wednesday upheld the convictions of 23 Americans in the 2003 abduction of an Egyptian cleric in Milan, making it the first case to successfully challenge the contentious American program of extraordinary rendition.
