abstract: Early reviewers criticized the new Apple Maps app, saying it botched simple searches and did not come with information about public transportation.
lead_paragraph: Millions of iPhone customers may soon find themselves losing touch with an old friend: Google’s maps.

headline: Vox Pop Trumps the Parish Bulletin
abstract: When a priest tried to disseminate a proxy endorsement of Mitt Romney at his Manhattan church, violating the separation of church and state, the public rightly objected.
lead_paragraph: Separation of church and state should be a cherished no-brainer under the Constitution, but that never seems so in an election year when some clergyman or other cannot resist the temptation to speak out as a political boss.

headline: Ineffective Counsel in Georgia
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Capital Punishment', 'Editorials', 'Sixth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: How bad must a lawyer be before the courts will do something about it?
lead_paragraph: Robert Wayne Holsey, on death row in Georgia for killing a police officer, is seeking a new sentencing hearing because he received ineffective counsel. He should get one. His own lawyer told a Georgia trial court reviewing the case that he “probably shouldn’t have been allowed to represent anybody” while he was ostensibly providing a defense.

headline: Segregation Prominent in Schools, Study Finds
abstract: White students account for just over half of all students in public schools, down from four-fifths in 1970, but they are still largely concentrated in schools with other whites.
lead_paragraph: The United States is increasingly a multiracial society, with white students accounting for just over half of all students in public schools, down from four-fifths in 1970.

headline: Rubén Zuno Arce, Guilty in Drug Killing, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Zuno was a central defendant in the 1985 torture and killing of Enrique Camarena Salazar, an American drug enforcement agent, in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Rubén Zuno Arce, a central defendant in the 1985 torture and killing of an American drug enforcement agent in Mexico, a crime that increased tension between Mexico and the United States in part because of Mr. Zuno’s ties to Mexican government officials, died on Tuesday in a federal prison in Coleman, Fla. He was 82.

headline: AT&T Chief Speaks Out on Texting at the Wheel
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Smartphones', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The chairman and chief executive of AT&T, Randall L. Stephenson, said an accident involving someone close to him that was caused by texting while driving spurred him to speak out.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Randall L. Stephenson, the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, spoke Wednesday morning at a conference in New York to hundreds of major investors, including Fortune 500 executives. The topic was the state of the telecom businesses, but he began with a request on a different topic: Please don’t text and drive.

headline: A Tight End Who Cuts Loose
abstract: Martellus Bennett, who joined the Giants in the off-season, is a skilled tight end whose talents off the field make him one of the most intriguing players in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: Since joining the Giants in the off-season, tight end Martellus Bennett has proved to be a singular character. An outspoken player on a roster known for being almost allergic to controversy, Bennett is also a key part of the Giants’ offensive plans. He is big and athletic and has the potential to become a favorite target for quarterback Eli Manning. But there are so many reasons beyond his raw talent that Bennett is one of the most intriguing players in the N.F.L.

headline: Jeter, After Resting in Game 1, Returns to Shortstop
abstract: Derek Jeter, who has been playing with an ankle injury, sat out the first game of a day-night doubleheader before returning to shortstop for the first time since Sept. 12.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, for the first game of a day-night doubleheader at Yankee Stadium, Derek Jeter rested. He wore a blue hooded sweatshirt and the expression of a child forced to miss a class field trip because of the flu. He had his spikes on, but for the first time since June 27, Jeter did not need to use them.

headline: A Closer Look at ‘Redistribution’
abstract: It remains unclear precisely how Mitt Romney’s views on redistribution differ from those of Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: Amid the fallout over Mitt Romney’s comments that 47 percent of Americans believed they were “victims” and are dependent upon government, the Republican Party is stepping up attacks that President Obama favors redistributing wealth, citing a 1998 audio clip of him saying, “I actually believe in redistribution.”

headline: The United States and the Muslim World
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Editorials']
abstract: Despite attacks against American embassies and violent protests, Washington must remain engaged with struggling Arab democracies.
lead_paragraph: The anti-Islam video that set off attacks against American embassies and violent protests in the Muslim world was a convenient fuse for rage. Deeper forces are at work in those societies, riven by pent-up anger over a lack of jobs, economic stagnation and decades of repression by previous Arab governments.

headline: Foes of Modified Corn Find Support in a Study
abstract: A study that linked genetically engineered corn to cancer in rats was criticized by some scientists but was seized on by backers of a California ballot measure to require labeling for genetically modified crops.
lead_paragraph: Rats fed either genetically engineered corn or the herbicide Roundup had an increased risk of developing tumors, suffering organ damage and dying prematurely, according to a new study that was immediately swept up into the furor surrounding crop biotechnology when it was released Wednesday.

headline: One Year Later, Military Says Gay Policy Is Working
abstract: It has been a year since “don’t ask, don’t tell” was repealed and by most measures the change has been a success, military officials and gay service members say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every Tuesday and Friday morning in a dining area tucked behind Dunkin’ Donuts in the Pentagon’s main food court, a gay coffee group meets to talk, do a little business and tell a few jokes.

headline: Struggling Young Adults Are Question Mark for Campaigns
abstract: Millions of working-class young adults, many in battleground states, are a potent but often overlooked voting bloc, experts say.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Millions of struggling working-class young adults, many in battleground states like Florida, Colorado and Wisconsin, are up for grabs in this election, making up what experts call one of the most potentially powerful but often overlooked voting blocs.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 32
abstract: The artist draws things he saw in New York and California.
lead_paragraph: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: U.P.S. Bills Stores as Small-Business Solution
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business', 'Delivery Services']
abstract: During lean times for shippers, United Parcel Service uses an ad campaign to emphasize the wide range of services its retail stores provide.
lead_paragraph: FEWER people are mailing their own packages these days, so shippers are looking for innovative ways to win new customers and persuade current clients to spend more. And what could be a more enticing image than homemade pie?

headline: An Autocrat, but Still an Improvement?
abstract: How should the U.S. relate to regimes that, although authoritarian, have moved toward prosperity, like Paul Kagame's in Rwanda?

headline: Squinting at the Polls in New York City
abstract: Voters should not have to struggle to read the candidates’ names on the ballot because of the tiny print.
lead_paragraph: Many New Yorkers who went to the polls last Thursday were a little surprised to find a large magnifying sheet inside their voting booths. One glance at the ballot explained why. The names of the candidates were tiny, like the lower lines in the optometrist’s eye chart or the small print on a credit card notice. Even voters with excellent vision found themselves squinting in search of their preferred candidates.

headline: To Help Sanchez and Holmes, Healthy Keller May Be the Key
abstract: The consensus among the Jets is that it will be much easier for Santonio Holmes and Mark Sanchez if the tight end Dustin Keller, who has a hamstring injury, is able to play.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets tight end Dustin Keller showed up Wednesday for practice in full gear, high-stepping over a row of barriers before running 30-yard sprints with elegant, exaggerated strides. That part of the day seemed to go smoothly.

headline: Joshua Morse III, Law School Dean Who Defied Segregation, Dies at 89
abstract: In a time of often violent racial strife in the Deep South, the former dean of the University of Mississippi School of Law challenged prejudice and parochialism.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Morse III, who as dean of the University of Mississippi School of Law in the 1960s defied segregationist tradition by admitting the school’s first black students, a move that led to the desegregation of Mississippi’s legal profession and judiciary, died last Friday at his home in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 89.

headline: Key Giants to Miss Panthers Game
abstract: Because of injuries, the Giants will be without wide receiver Hakeem Nicks, running back Ahmad Bradshaw and offensive lineman David Diehl when they face Carolina on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: The Giants will be without several key players when they face the Carolina Panthers on Thursday night: wide receiver Hakeem Nicks, running back Ahmad Bradshaw and offensive lineman David Diehl were among five players who did not make the trip to Charlotte, N.C., because of injuries.

headline: Ex-Commander in Afghanistan Eyed for Africa
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In the wake of the Arab Spring, the Africa Command is seen as one of the most challenging theaters of operation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gen. David M. Rodriguez, a former top Army commander in Afghanistan, has been chosen by the Pentagon to take charge of the military’s Africa Command, which in the wake of the Arab Spring has become one of the Defense Department’s most challenging theaters of operation.

headline: Fewer Children Are Found Exposed to Violent Crime
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Crime Rates', 'Children and Childhood', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: From 1993 to 2010, the number of children living in households where another member had been a victim of a nonfatal violent crime decreased by 68 percent, according to a government report.
lead_paragraph: Exposure to violence has a profound effect on children, making them more prone to emotional problems like depression and anxiety and increasing the chances that they will either become victims of violence themselves or commit crimes in later life. But a new government report suggests that the number of children in the United States who are exposed to violent crime has dropped precipitously in the last two decades, a decline that one expert termed “breathtaking.”

headline: In Discarding of Kidneys, System Reveals Its Flaws
abstract: Experts say bureaucracy and inefficiencies result in a system of medical rationing for organ donations that is costing lives.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Last year, 4,720 people died while waiting for kidney transplants in the United States. And yet, as in each of the last five years, more than 2,600 kidneys were recovered from deceased donors and then discarded without being transplanted, government data show.

headline: After Death, Helping to Prolong Life
abstract: To John P. LeMay, the job of asking for permission to recover tissue and organs puts him “in that sacred spot where life and death meet.”
lead_paragraph: EDINA, Minn. — Just down the hallway, in Room 356, Curtis Kelly’s body lay covered to the chest by a white blanket, his torso rising and falling with the help of a ventilator. A neurologist at Fairview Southdale Hospital had declared him brain-dead nearly six hours earlier.

headline: Recap: Red Bulls (0) vs. Kansas City (2)
abstract: The Red Bulls lost to visiting Sporting Kansas City, 2-0, Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — The only number that normally matters in soccer is the final score. Statistics are usually superfluous, but Wednesday night at Red Bull Arena, statistics told the story.

headline: Guilty Pleas in Scheme to Help Applicants Cheat on Written Driving Test
abstract: A couple who ran a driving school in Brooklyn admitted to using hidden cameras and pagers to help non-English-speaking applicants cheat on tests for commercial driver’s licenses.
lead_paragraph: A couple who ran a driving school in Brooklyn for more than a decade pleaded guilty on Wednesday to concocting an elaborate scheme to help non-English speakers cheat on written tests to obtain New York State commercial driver’s licenses.

headline: An Earthy Take on a Heavenly Book
abstract: “Job,” Thomas Bradshaw’s latest play, hews close to the Bible and eagerly dives into forbidden subject matter.
lead_paragraph: God moves in unmysterious ways at the Flea Theater these days. There he was, manning (if that verb may be so applied) the box office on the night I arrived to see Thomas Bradshaw’s “Job,” in which he plays an important supporting role to the notoriously afflicted title character. And there was God’s son, Jesus, serving as an usher downstairs.

headline: What’s That in Italy?
abstract: The heated return of John R. Conrad.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t seen constructor John R. Conrad for nigh on five years now, but he has returned today with a RING OF FIRE for us to jump through.

headline: Drawn to Food and Liquor, Burglar Gains a Stiff Term
abstract: Shawn McAleese, who broke into several Manhattan restaurants and stole cash, computers, vodka and hamburgers, was sentenced to 56 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: He was a serial burglar — with a taste for vodka, sake, pork belly and hamburgers — who broke into several Manhattan restaurants and bars just before sunrise.

headline: Judge Details a Rule Requiring Pro Bono Work by Aspiring Lawyers
abstract: Under the rule, students must do 50 hours of unpaid legal work under the supervision of experienced lawyers before applying for a license.
lead_paragraph: The state’s chief judge on Wednesday announced the details of a new rule — the first of its kind in the nation — requiring law students to perform 50 hours of unpaid work as a condition of practicing in New York.

headline: Rhode Island: Central Falls Mayor Quits and Is to Plead Guilty to Corruption
abstract: Prosecutors say that Mayor Charles D. Moreau directed work boarding up at least 167 properties in the city, buffeted by a wave of foreclosures in exchange for gifts.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of the financially struggling city of Central Falls resigned Wednesday and agreed to plead guilty to federal corruption charges. Prosecutors say that Mayor Charles D. Moreau directed work boarding up at least 167 properties in the city, buffeted by a wave of foreclosures, to a friend and political supporter, Michael G. Bouthillette, in exchange for gifts. Mr. Moreau, a four-term Democrat, was given an advisory role when the city went into receivership in 2010. It went under bankruptcy protection last year, from which it is expected to emerge next month. Mr. Bouthillette was also charged. Prosecutors said they would seek prison time for both men, but did not specify how much.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for Sept. 19, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: When Justice Makes You Gasp
abstract: “The Exonerated,” in a revival at the Culture Project, recounts the tales of six former death-row inmates, using their own words. And 10 years after its premiere, it is still unsettling.
lead_paragraph: There’s a distinct sound made by audience members watching “The Exonerated.” It’s a sharp exhale, part incredulous, part angry, and delivered with a wince or a shake of the head. That sound is a visceral reaction to stories of people unjustly sentenced to die. It staves off the compulsion to cry out, or maybe just to cry.

headline: Defrocked Priest Sues New York Archdiocese for Libel Over Sexual Abuse Statement
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Libel and Slander', 'Priests', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: Charles M. Kavanagh, 75, says a news release by the archdiocese this May implied a pattern of sexual abuse accusations that he says never happened.
lead_paragraph: A once-prominent Roman Catholic monsignor who was removed from the priesthood in 2010 for sexual abuse of a minor took the unusual step on Wednesday of filing a federal lawsuit against the New York Archdiocese, claiming he had been libeled in a church statement.

headline: Inspectors Certified Pakistani Factory as Safe Before Disaster
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Fires and Firefighters']

lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A prominent factory monitoring group heavily financed by industry gave a clean bill of health to a Pakistani apparel plant last month, just weeks before a fire engulfed the premises and killed nearly 300 workers, many of them trapped behind locked exit doors.

headline: Belarus: Election Monitors Denied Visas
abstract: Belarus denied visas for two observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, representing a rocky resumption of ties with the election-monitoring group.
lead_paragraph: Belarus, which is preparing to hold a parliamentary election over the weekend, denied visas for two observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, representing a rocky resumption of ties with the election-monitoring group. The O.S.C.E. is returning to Belarus for the first time since it was expelled after a contentious 2010 presidential election.

headline: In a City Plagued by Violence, a Spike in Crime Opens Eyes Nationwide
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Gangs', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: In Marseille, where 20 people have been killed in the last nine months, drug dealers have begun using combat weapons to defend their territory.
lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — Walid Marzouki and his girlfriend stopped their black Renault Twingo at a red light on the deserted Boulevard Casanova late one night in August. Another car pulled alongside. The driver opened his window, pulled out an automatic rifle and killed Mr. Marzouki, using more than 20 rounds.

lead_paragraph: Fans at Citi Field rose to their feet Wednesday night, cheering with expectation, excitement and some incredulity as the Mets stood one out from their first home victory since Aug. 26.

lead_paragraph: Amanda Palmer, the rock musician known for using social media to build financial and fan support, has reversed course in the face of fierce criticism and decided to pay volunteer musicians who were invited to join her band city by city on a tour.

lead_paragraph: The rich got richer and the poor got poorer in New York City last year as the poverty rate reached its highest point in more than a decade, and the income gap in Manhattan, already wider than almost anywhere else in the country, rivaled disparities in sub-Saharan Africa.

lead_paragraph: Saeed Jalili, Iran’s top negotiator in talks with the big powers over his country’s disputed uranium enrichment program, called negotiations with Catherine Ashton, his counterpart, “constructive and helpful,” the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported on Wednesday. The talks on Tuesday in Istanbul, their first face-to-face meeting in three months, produced no breakthroughs, and it remained unclear when they would meet again.

headline: Spanish Bond Sale Succeeds as Data Show Euro Zone Slump Accelerating
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Stocks and Bonds']

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Spain sold debt on Thursday in an auction that met with strong investor demand despite questions about the country’s bailout plans, and a report suggested the contraction of the 17-nation euro zone economy was accelerating.

headline: Come September
abstract: A transitional time calls for its own (weird, tangy) transitional drinks.
lead_paragraph: Oh, the days grow short when we reach September. Kurt Weill and Maxwell Anderson got that right in “September Song,” didn’t they? Cheerful it’s not, but for a year in my early 20s, the only music I could stand to hear was Weill’s. I was adrift, and politically charged cabaret numbers — often sung in a language I did not understand — somehow anchored me. I downed plenty of whiskey back then (and still do), but as with music, my taste in drinks was growing up. It was then that I first made a martini, first tasted absinthe and could, for the first time, call myself a regular at a New York bar — one where an indulgent bartender might sometimes pop onto the sound system the Lotte Lenya tape I just happened to have in my backpack.

headline: Food of the Ancients
abstract: To find the original cuisine of Mexico, head to the heart of the Yucatán Peninsula. Then ask for directions.
lead_paragraph: I’ve traveled to the Yucatán Peninsula a dozen times looking for “real” Mayan cuisine, driving through the center and up and down both (or is it all three?) coasts, but the food that’s at the soul of the Yucatán is not easily discovered. What you get as an outsider is feast food like cochinita pibil — a sometimes-wonderful chili-marinated pork buried and cooked in an earthen pit — which is not enough to have you rush down there and start eating.

headline: Do You Really Expect Your Business to Get You Through Retirement?

headline: Reinventing Cuba

lead_paragraph: Photographs from an island on the brink.

headline: Where Is Cuba Going?
abstract: Not long ago, there were smart people who doubted that such a thing as a post-Fidel Cuba could even exist. What comes after the Castros is as much of a mystery as ever.
lead_paragraph: On the plane, something odd but also vaguely magical-seeming happened: namely, nobody knew what time it was. Right before we landed, the flight attendant made an announcement, in English and Spanish, that although daylight saving time recently went into effect in the States, the island didn’t observe that custom. As a result, we had caught up — our time had passed into sync with Cuban time. You will not need to change your watches. Then, moments later, she came on again and apologized. She had been wrong, she said. The time in Cuba was different. She didn’t specify how many hours ahead. At that point, people around us looked at one another. How could the airline not know what time it is where we’re going? Another flight attendant, hurrying down the aisle, said loudly, “I just talked to some actual Cubans, in the back, and they say it’ll be the same time.” That settled it: we would be landing in ignorance. We knew our phones weren’t going to work because they were tied to a U.S. company that didn’t operate on the island.

headline: Tip of the Week: Managing Hefty iPad Apps
abstract: You can see just how much space each app takes up on your iPad.
lead_paragraph: Want to see which apps on your iPad are hogging too much space, and then throw a few off the tablet to make room for more? On the Home screen, tap the Settings icon and then tap General on the Settings screen. On the General screen, tap Usage to see a list of the iPad’s apps and the space each one uses. To delete an app right there, tap its name in the list and tap Delete App on the next screen.

headline: Double Police Killing Raises Question: Should Officers Be Armed?
abstract: The killing of two unarmed British policewomen has revived a debate over whether officers should now be routinely armed. The government and the police themselves are resisting.

headline: Steve Martin Awards Third Annual Bluegrass Prize

abstract: Lawyers at a hearing on the death of the poisoned Russian whistle-blower Alexander V. Litvinenko said the British authorities wanted his possible contacts with MI6 kept quiet.
lead_paragraph: A slow-moving effort to hold an inquest into the poisoning death of a Russian whistle-blower, Alexander V. Litvinenko, moved ahead on Thursday in London, with the British authorities insisting in a preliminary hearing that possible contacts between him and the British secret intelligence service MI6 should not be disclosed.

headline: The End of Team Anna?
abstract: Anna Hazare distances himself from any political party formation.
lead_paragraph: The anticorruption activist Anna Hazare said he will not back the formation of a political party by a group of his young supporters, marking a formal split with the former members of Team Anna.

headline: MaxMara: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Mother Jones Drives the Debate, and BSkyB Found ‘Fit and Proper’
abstract: Also, Fox closes in on a deal with Major League Baseball; and Ai Weiwei, the dissident Chinese artist, becomes a reporter.
lead_paragraph: With its release of a secretly recorded tape of Mitt Romney’s description of the 47 percent who are “dependent” on government, the magazine Mother Jones this week has been driving the political debate. That’s particularly good thing, Christine Haughney writes, for the 36-year-old left-leaning magazine, which has a circulation of just over 200,000 and a business model that is partly dependent on its readers’ contributions. One reader visited the magazine’s Washington bureau and dropped off a check.

headline: The Trouble With Fedspeak
abstract: Success can be misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: So Fed hawks are all upset that expected inflation has risen since Bernanke announced QE3 — as indeed it has. Here’s the TIPS spread, the difference between the interest rate on ordinary 10-year bonds and inflation-protected securities:

headline: Focusing Solely on Results, and Finding a $635 Million Budget Hole
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Term Limits (Political Office)']
abstract: The Day: Because of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s impatience with the process for a taxi program, the city’s budget suddenly has a $635 million hole punched into it.
lead_paragraph: One of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s strengths is his impatience with process — pragmatism from a man who cares more about results than about the means used to achieve them.

headline: Peugeot in Talks to Sell Logistics Business
abstract: A deal would help PSA Peugeot Citroën of France endure declining sales in Europe while bolstering Russian Railways’ links between Europe and Asia.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French automaker PSA Peugeot Citroën said Thursday that it was negotiating to sell its Gefco logistics business to J.S.C. Russian Railways as it struggles to stay afloat in the faltering European car market.

headline: Single-Study Syndrome and the G.M.O. Food Fight
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Organic Foods and Products']
abstract: Scientists raise many questions about a new study finding health problems in rats fed genetically modified corn, but it is widely promoted nonetheless.
lead_paragraph: [Updated, Nov. 28, 8:45 p.m. | The Seralini study has been retracted. Read the letter from the journal editor.]

headline: Valuing What Anschutz Entertainment Might Be Worth
abstract: News that the Anschutz Entertainment Group is being put up for sale sent the sports and entertainment worlds buzzing madly late on Tuesday. But what exactly would any prospective buyer be getting for what will likely be a multibillion-dollar purchase?
lead_paragraph: News this week that the Anschutz Entertainment Group is being put up for sale was a surprise in the sports and entertainment segment.

headline: Designing for Multiple Screen Sizes Is About Consistency
abstract: In a quest to gain more mainstream users Apple, Amazon and Twitter are learning that consistent design is more important than anything else.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago I taught a class at New York University in the Interactive Telecommunications Program, called, “1, 2, 10.”

headline: Daily Report: Apple Releases Its Mobile Maps, Glitches and All
abstract: Millions of iPhone customers may soon find themselves losing touch with an old friend: Google’s maps. As Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield report in Thursday’s New York Times, Apple released a software update for the iPhone that, among other changes, replaces the Google maps that have been on the phone since 2007 with Apple’s own maps.
lead_paragraph: Millions of iPhone customers may soon find themselves losing touch with an old friend: Google’s maps.

headline: Jesse Jackson Jr. Selling His Washington Home
abstract: The appearance of a real-estate listing for a home owned by Representative Jesse Jackson Jr., on a leave of absence from Congress while treating his depression, contributed to speculation that he would not return to finish his term.
lead_paragraph: The appearance of a real-estate listing for the Washington home owned by Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., who is on a leave of absence from Congress while under treatment for depression, contributed to speculation on Wednesday that he would not return to finish his term.

headline: Tax Credit in Doubt, Wind Power Industry Is Withering
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The American wind sector has been buffeted by weak demand for electricity, stiff competition from gas and uncertainty over a tax credit that has become a campaign wedge issue.
lead_paragraph: FAIRLESS HILLS, Pa. — Last month, Gamesa, a major maker of wind turbines, completed the first significant order of its latest innovation: a camper-size box that can capture the energy of slow winds, potentially opening new parts of the country to wind power.

headline: The Fed Purchase Test
abstract: What didn’t happen in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Aha. It seems that many people don’t realize that the view that the Fed is the only thing holding down interest rates has been tested — and failed. So, a bit more.

headline: Fixated
abstract: If you can dream it, chances are someone built it, or sells it, or serves it in Tokyo, land of the cheerful obsessive.

lead_paragraph: College Humor: Bongos and bacon: Nick Offerman from “Parks and Recreation” cuts loose with a slam poem about a certain salty pork product. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Pawlenty Is Leaving Romney Campaign for Lobbying Post
abstract: Tim Pawlenty is leaving the Romney campaign to take a job in Washington as a top lobbyist for a group representing banks and financial companies.
lead_paragraph: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, is resigning as a national co-chairman of Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign to take a job in Washington as a top lobbyist for a group representing banks and financial companies.

headline: Poor Pain Control for Cancer Patients
abstract: Researchers found that nearly two-thirds of cancer patients said they were in pain or receiving pain medications, and roughly a third felt they needed more painkillers to fully treat their symptoms. Why aren’t doctors helping more?
lead_paragraph: Recounting her father’s struggle with cancer was difficult for the young woman, even several years after his death. He’d endured first surgery and then chemotherapy and radiation, she told me, and the cancer had gone into remission. He was thrilled, but the aggressive treatment left him with chronic, debilitating pain. Once active, he struggled to get around in his own home.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘I Hear America Singing’
abstract: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches Walt Whitman’s poem “I Hear America Singing” with “Occupy Wall Street: A Frenzy That Fizzled,” a DealBook column that assessed the impact of the Occupy movement one year after it started.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing matches Walt Whitman’s timeless poem “I Hear America Singing” with “Occupy Wall Street: A Frenzy That Fizzled,” a DealBook column that assessed the impact of the Occupy Wall Street movement on its first anniversary.

headline: Via YouTube, a New Conservation Genre
abstract: In an era of drought, the water-conservation public service announcement is becoming an art form.
lead_paragraph: The drought of 2012, which continues to spread westward, is making its mark on the national consciousness in many ways. Rising food prices. Interrupted livelihoods. Fields of stunted, desiccated crops.

headline: Mets Know How to Mark an Anniversary
abstract: David Wright is chasing Ed Kranepool for most hits in Mets history, but the team’s 50th anniversary season has become a comic tribute to its inaugural season, in 1962.
lead_paragraph: Ed Kranepool got his 1,418th, and final, hit for the Mets in the last game of the 1979 regular season. The team was terrible, finishing with a 63-99 record. The Mets were six years removed from their last postseason appearance and seven years away from their next. They were, to put it bluntly, in the middle of nowhere, which is where the Mets often reside.

headline: Stephen King’s ‘Misery’ Back From the Dead in Bucks County
abstract: A play based on the Stephen King novel is scheduled to open in November in New Hope, Pa..
lead_paragraph: “Misery is alive, Misery is alive!” Kathy Bates cries with wild-eyed joy in her Academy Award-winning performance in the 1990 horror movie “Misery,” ecstatic that the heroine of her favorite books has been brought back from the dead. “I’m going to put on my Liberace records!”

headline: Rumble in Milan
abstract: The Italian spring shows have started and already there’s magical connectivity to London’s sports-chic.
lead_paragraph: The Italian spring shows have started and already there’s magical connectivity to London’s sports-chic, at least from Tom Ford and Thomas Tait. It flared this morning at MaxMara, where silky blouson jackets came with detachable hoods, and striped knitted T-tops looked sporty with slim wrap skirts in brown suede or a crisp silk version that combined an animal print, a floral and a check. The collection’s safari-themed jackets and jumpsuits, its stenciled calf-hair clogs with ankle ties, were a loose interpretation of that style. Looking at those silk-backed knit tops and slim skirts you mainly saw cool ways to smarten up your look.

headline: Trulia Jumps 40% in Debut
abstract: Trulia, the real estate information site, rose 30 percent in its debut to open at roughly $22, defying the recent lackluster performance of newly public stocks.
lead_paragraph: 4:24 p.m. | Updated

headline: Romney to Do Bus Tour in Critical State of Ohio
abstract: The Republican candidate steps up his campaigning, focusing on a state that many believe could be decisive.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney’s campaign — which in recent weeks has come under criticism for having a schedule light on public events and heavy on closed-door fund-raisers — has announced that the candidate will start to ramp up his campaign schedule in coming days.

headline: IHT Readers’ Close Encounter With the News
abstract: We asked readers of the International Herald Tribune for pictures and memories of their experiences with the paper to help celebrate the IHT’s 125th anniversary. One response made us realize that at times our readers have come dangerously close to the worst kind of news. Have you had such an experience?
lead_paragraph: Last week Rendezvous called on readers of the International Herald Tribune to share their favorite memories or photos about the paper to help us celebrate our 125th anniversary on Oct. 4. We’ve had some great responses so far, and we hope that many of you are still searching for the ideal backdrop for your own IHT portrait to rival the George Clooney photo we posted.

headline: Your Worst Financial Mistake
abstract: Two-thirds of Americans admit to making “really bad” financial decisions.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have managed, so far, to avoid making a truly devastating financial mistake. I wish I could say this is because we’re super savvy about money. But the truth is that, while we are diligent about saving, cautious with debt and try to do our homework on investments, there’s a strong element of luck involved.

headline: ‘Cat’ Revival With Scarlett Johansson Is Set, With Benjamin Walker as Brick
abstract: The revival of Tennessee Williams’s 1955 drama will open on Jan. 17, 2013.
lead_paragraph: Scarlett Johansson will play Maggie the Cat on Broadway this winter in Tennessee Williams’s “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” starring opposite Benjamin Walker (“Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson”) as her alcoholic husband, Brick, the show’s lead producer, Stuart Thompson, announced on Thursday. The theater and television actor Ciaran Hinds will play Brick’s irascible father, Big Daddy Pollitt, and the Tony Award winner Debra Monk (“Curtains,” “Redwood Curtain”) will play Big Mama.

headline: RIM Innovates and Then Waits as Apple Moves Ahead
abstract: RIM announced a bunch of innovative features for its next smartphone last May. The only problem is, the iPhone has them now and the BlackBerry won’t arrive until sometime next year.
lead_paragraph: Among the features of the new Apple iPhone 5 are a more movie-friendly display format, two tiny grills on the bottom that shield noise-canceling microphones, a more powerful processor and a slim, all-black case.

headline: Image of the Day: September 20
abstract: A devotee offering milk to a snake during a Hindu festival.

headline: Week 3 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
abstract: Like Cam Newton before him, Robert Griffin III was not first on owners’ minds in the draft room. But at Week 3, Griffin is leading leagues in total fantasy points. He is a favorable matchup pick this week.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Emma Thompson: By the Book
abstract: The actress and author of a new children’s book, “The Further Tale of Peter Rabbit,” has contemplated throwing the writer Michel Houellebecq across a room.
lead_paragraph: The actress and author of a new children’s book, “The Further Tale of Peter Rabbit,” has contemplated throwing the writer Michel Houellebecq across a room.

headline: With Each Role, a New Page
abstract: The actor Patrick Page performs excerpts from some of his shows.
lead_paragraph: The actor Patrick Page performs excerpts from some of his shows.

headline: Stars of ‘The Carol Burnett Show’ Reuniting on SiriusXM
abstract: Carol Burnett and her co-stars Vicki Lawrence and Tim Conway will take part in a town hall event for SiriusXM radio hosted by Amy Schumer.
lead_paragraph: Keep your earlobes – and maybe a couple of tissues – within reach for a sentimental reunion of the stars of “The Carol Burnett Show” that SiriusXM radio is planning for next week. The satellite broadcaster said on Thursday that it would host a town hall event with Ms. Burnett, the five-time Emmy Award-winner, and Vicki Lawrence and Tim Conway, her co-stars from that long-running CBS variety series. (Not coincidentally, the event is timed to a new TimeLife DVD release for the show, including a 22-disc boxed set.) The town hall, which will incorporate questions from an audience of SiriusXM listeners, will be hosted by Amy Schumer, the standup comic, Comedy Central roast-ess and author of numerous jokes that would surely turn the head of genteel Starlet O’Hara.

headline: Smile and Be a Villain; Despair and Be One, Too
abstract: Experienced with Shakespeare’s antagonists, Patrick Page also brings to his current bad guy, in “Cyrano de Bergerac,” personal insight into unhappiness and depression.
lead_paragraph: PATRICK PAGE has dreamed of performing the title role in “Cyrano de Bergerac” on Broadway for as long as he can remember. It is his favorite play, “the greatest part ever written,” he said, and he has been in three productions of it over the past 25 years, including twice as Cyrano. But when he learned that a new Broadway revival was already committed to star a Tony Award winner, Mr. Page chose not to sulk. Instead, he sought to join the production as one of Cyrano’s antagonists, the aristocrat de Guiche. And soon the job was his, the latest in a career of villains from Richard III and Iago to, most recently, the spandex-and-foam-suited Green Goblin for 21 months in the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.”

headline: A Fight for the Future of Pensions
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Travel and Vacations', 'HOTELS AND MOTELS', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']

headline: Who Deserves a Vote?
abstract: State Rep Daryl Metcalfe of Pennsylvania thinks only “lazy” people can’t obtain IDs to comply with a new voter ID law.
lead_paragraph: Some Republicans are distancing themselves from Mitt Romney’s “47 percent” comment. Senator Scott Brown said “that’s not the way I see the world” and Senate candidate Linda McMahon said she disagrees with the “insinuation that 47 percent of Americans believe they are victims who must depend on the government for their care.”

headline: Jaguar F-Type and Porsche 918 Spyder Come Into Focus
abstract: The formal introduction of the F-Type is scheduled for the Paris motor show next week, while the 918 Spyder shed virtually all camouflage for a run around the Nürburgring.
lead_paragraph: Two of the most anticipated sports cars of the year have come into focus before their official introductions.

headline: A Writer’s Unusual Rituals Yield Results
abstract: The novelist Ayad Akhtar is confounding expectations in his screenplays and his debut play, “Disgraced,” set for the Claire Tow Theater.
lead_paragraph: AYAD AKHTAR protects his furniture. On a late summer afternoon in his book-crowded Upper Manhattan home office he gently but firmly dissuaded his agent, a photographer and me from sitting in a particular armchair. It doesn’t seem antique or especially delicate, yet the chair plays an essential role in Mr. Akhtar’s writing process.

headline: Romney Is Latest in a Long Line to Trip Over a Tongue
abstract: As critics pummel Mitt Romney over his secretly recorded comments at a fund-raiser, he can at least take comfort in this: he’s not the first.
lead_paragraph: As critics pummel Mitt Romney over his secretly recorded comments at a fund-raiser, he can at least take comfort in this: He’s not the first.

abstract: The Spring 2013 women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The Spring 2013 women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week, scheduled to commence at 6 p.m. Milan time. Delays may occur.

headline: Haim Hefer, Israeli Songwriter and Poet, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Hefer, who could be an acerbic critic of Israeli political leaders, helped forge a national identity in contemporary Hebrew with his lyrics and newspaper columns written in verse.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Haim Hefer, an Israeli songwriter and poet who for many Israelis embodied the spirit of the generation that fought for their nation’s independence, died on Tuesday in Tel Aviv. He was 86.

headline: Some New Math for Romney
abstract: The new language, which Mr. Romney has never before used on the campaign trail, is an attempt to take the sting out of secretly recorded remarks that he made a fund-raiser in May, about how 47 percent of Americans see themselves as “victims” dependent on government help.
lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — Forget the 47 percent: Mitt Romney is now tossing in the remaining 53.

headline: The Secret Little Sister of the Italian Lakes
abstract: Lago d’Orta, not far from Milan, is a secluded jewel of a lake that’s little known outside Italy.
lead_paragraph: LIKE a siren, the beautiful little island called to us. And so we swam, like crazed Olympic sprinters, from a cobblestone Italian town square to a serene island monastery in the middle of glittering Lago d’Orta.

headline: A Glittering, but Not Flashy, Italian Lake
abstract: Quieter than some of its sister lakes, Lago d’Orta offers serene charm.
lead_paragraph: Quieter than some of its sister lakes, Lago d’Orta offers serene charm.

headline: A Strategy of Tattletales at the I.R.S.
abstract: Enforcement of tax laws requires finding a fair and effective way to overcome the information asymmetry between taxpayers and the I.R.S. But whistle-blowers are only one approach.
lead_paragraph: No one likes a tattletale. But tax whistle-blowers sure are getting compensated for the animosity they evoke.

headline: Smithsonian Seeks to Remake Stodgy Image
abstract: The Smithsonian Institution, the world’s largest museum complex, doesn’t lack for crowds, but it hopes to lure more young people with an ad campaign and a new Web site.
lead_paragraph: So what exactly does a bear do in the woods?

headline: Needles or Port? A Cancer Patient Decides
abstract: To port or not to port? Cancer patients often must decide whether to brave constant needle pricks or consent to a surgically implanted port.
lead_paragraph: The first question many cancer patients are asked at a doctor’s office or an infusion center is “Do you have a port?” I shake my head no, but add the words “not yet.” To port or not to port: That is the question facing me when I arrive on the hospital hall dedicated to clinical trials.

headline: Art at the Palais, Décor by Lagerfeld
abstract: Visitors to the 26th edition of the Biennale des Antiquaires in Paris can indulge in object envy amid art and objects from five millenniums. If you can’t afford the art, take home a poster.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Through Sunday, visitors to the 26th edition of the Biennale des Antiquaires can indulge in object envy at a fair that Souren Melikian of The International Herald Tribune says has “shed its fussy appearance of yore.” The art for sale by the 122 dealers goes as far back as the 3rd millennium B.C. and is as recent as the 21st century — a first for this biennale. And then there is the jewelry. Look out for rose gold, Suzy Menkes writes.

headline: A Restrained Leap Into the Stravinsky-thon
abstract: The New York Philharmonic opened its season with works for piano and orchestra by Gyorgy Kurtag and Beethoven and Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring.”
lead_paragraph: Typically the New York Philharmonic opens its season with a gala concert that is broadcast in public television’s “Live From Lincoln Center” series. But in a significant departure Alan Gilbert opened his fourth season as the Philharmonic’s music director on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall with a substantial subscription program, offering works for piano and orchestra by Gyorgy Kurtag and Beethoven, and ending with Stravinsky’s formidable “Rite of Spring.”

headline: Theater Talkback: Lives of the Artists
abstract: Every so often – and more frequently on stage than in film – the interiority of artistic creation is translated into a visible, physical language that raises goose bumps.
lead_paragraph: The most gratifying scene in the generally less-than-gratifying “Chaplin: The Musical,” which opened last week at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, comes when the show’s title character turns into Charlie Chaplin. Of course this young man, portrayed by the winsome Rob McClure, had always been someone who bore that name (or that of the less familiar-sounding Charles Chaplin).

headline: Pawlenty to Become Wall Street Lobbyist
abstract: Tim Pawlenty, the former Republican governor of Minnesota, was named chief executive of the Financial Services Roundtable on Thursday, replacing Steve Bartlett.
lead_paragraph: Tim Pawlenty was hoping to spend plenty of time in the White House next year. Now, rather than living there, the onetime presidential contender will visit regularly as a top Wall Street lobbyist.

headline: A  Recording Studio That Fits in a Pocket
abstract: The iPhone is capable of making remarkably good recordings, but its built-in microphone is not. One solution is the Mikey Digital, from Blue Microphones.
lead_paragraph: The iPhone is capable of making remarkably good recordings, but its built-in microphone is not. One solution is the Mikey Digital, from Blue Microphones.

headline: Jersey City, a Love Story
abstract: I had bangs and a publishing job. And I had been caught red-handed doing something ironic with a cupcake.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, a new bar opened around the corner from my apartment, near Graham Avenue and Metropolitan in Brooklyn. I was there for a birthday party when a photographer snapped a photo of a friend faux-feeding me a cupcake. A few days later, the picture appeared alongside a review of the bar in The Village Voice. The headline called it “Aging Hipster Heaven.”

headline: Clinton to Appear on ‘Face the Nation’
abstract: The interview coincides with the annual meeting of President Bill Clinton’s philanthropic organization, the Clinton Global Initiative.
lead_paragraph: President Bill Clinton plans to return to the Sunday talk-show circuit with an appearance on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Pandora Keeps Growing, but Apple’s Plans Add to the Uncertainty
abstract: Pandora, with 55 monthly users, is a leader in Internet radio. But it wouldn’t take much for a behemoth like Apple to become a player in the field.
lead_paragraph: Apple may soon be heading into the crowded field of Internet radio, a development considered momentous enough in the world of digital music that the day after Apple’s plans emerged earlier this month, Pandora Media’s stock plunged 17 percent and has still not recovered.

headline: Bill Clinton in Houston
abstract: Bill Clinton spoke to supporters in Houston in 1995.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton spoke to supporters in Houston in 1995.

headline: Hotels Are Combining Politics and Bedfellows
abstract: Hotels are seeking to capitalize on the political season by offering election-themed promotions.
lead_paragraph: Hotels are seeking to capitalize on the political season by offering election-themed promotions that they hope will appeal to guests whatever their political leanings.

headline: Why the Pistons Will Be Better Next Season
abstract: Greg Monroe, Brandon Knight and Andre Drummond should make the Detroit Pistons more competitive than they have been in years.
lead_paragraph: For the better part of the last decade, the Detroit Pistons were an immutable force in the N.B.A. Led by Chauncey Billups, Ben Wallace, Rip Hamilton and Rasheed Wallace, the team amassed seven straight 50-win seasons from 2001-2 through 2007-8, six consecutive trips to the conference finals, and, in 2004, a five-game victory over the powerful but fracturing Los Angeles Lakers in the N.B.A. finals.

lead_paragraph: Inside the casually elegant Greek restaurant in the East Village.

abstract: Boukiés in the East Village offers robust, reasonably priced small plates (mezethes) that are meant “not to sate but to tease.”

headline: America’s Greenest Presidents
keywords: ['Energy Efficiency', 'Global Warming', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Land Use Policies', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Theodore Roosevelt took the top spot in a poll of environmental groups, followed by Richard M. Nixon and Jimmy Carter.
lead_paragraph: What do Theodore Roosevelt, Richard M. Nixon and Jimmy Carter have in common? They are viewed as environmentally progressive presidents — at least by the 12 groups that ranked them in a survey released this week. Still, the challenges faced by presidents who stand up for the environment have shifted greatly over time, some of those organizations point out, making it hard to compare one leader’s achievements with another’s.

headline: It’s Official: Capitol to Display Douglass Statue
abstract: The District of Columbia achieved a small victory in the fight for equal representation Thursday as President Obama signed a law allowing a statue of the abolitionist Frederick Douglass to be displayed in the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: The District of Columbia achieved a small victory in the fight for equal representation on Thursday as President Obama signed a law allowing a statue of the abolitionist Frederick Douglass to be displayed in the Capitol.

keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The postal truck driver who was charged testified that he was initially unaware of the accident in Manhattan in July 2011.
lead_paragraph: A postal truck driver whose seven-ton vehicle rolled over and killed a former State Supreme Court special referee as she rode her bicycle in Manhattan last year was acquitted on Thursday of leaving the scene of a fatal accident.

headline: Why Can’t I Remember What This Week’s Question Is?
abstract: Generalizing about memory problems and other cognitive slowdowns is risky, but by middle age, the brain has probably begun to change, and in some ways not for the better.
lead_paragraph: Anybody can leave his wallet in a restaurant and have to return sheepishly the next day to pick it up. It takes a special kind of somebody to realize that he left his wallet in the restaurant, but not remember which restaurant it was, other than that it was that Italian one – what is its name again? – with the nice breadsticks. Or, come to think of it, was it that Greek place? Oh, wait. Maybe it was the car wash.

headline: Revisiting a Lunch at Perilous Heights
abstract: Though it’s been 80 years since someone took that iconic photo of men having a vertiginous lunch high above Manhattan, it’s not certain who that someone was.
lead_paragraph: Though it’s been 80 years since someone took that iconic photo of men having a vertiginous lunch high above Manhattan, it’s not certain who that someone was.

headline: Syria’s Dark Horses, With Lathes: Makeshift Arms Production in Aleppo Governorate, Part II
abstract: Syrian rebel workshops are diversified in the weapons they produce, including lighter explosive rounds.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, At War dove deeper into the underground industry in one part of Syria that this year has been producing improvised weapons for fighting groups seeking the overthrow of President Bashar al-Assad. That post focused on a machine-gun turrets and an artillery piece, known as Dadool, both of which were designed and made in Tal Rifaat, a small city north of Aleppo.

headline: HBO Names Plepler as Chief and Promotes Top Managers
abstract: The change in leadership amounts to a shift upward for the entire top management team at the network.
lead_paragraph: 5:21 p.m. | Updated HBO announced a transition in its top management on Thursday, elevating Richard Plepler to the role of chief executive, replacing Bill Nelson, who will step down at the end of the year.

abstract: Mr. Mondale accepts the Democratic nomination for president.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Mondale accepts the Democratic nomination for president.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Record Label Continues Its Online-Offline Royalties Experiment
abstract: The label, Big Machine, will be paid by Entercom Communications when its songs are played on the air in exchange for a getting lower rate for online streaming. It already has a similar deal with Clear Channel.
lead_paragraph: Three months after the record company behind Taylor Swift signed a historic deal with Clear Channel Communications, establishing for the first time a royalty for labels and recording artists when their songs are played on the radio, the company has signed a similar deal with another broadcaster.

headline: Sundance Institute to Honor Ebert
abstract: The film critic is being recognized for his advocacy of independent cinema.
lead_paragraph: The Sundance Institute said on Thursday that it would award the film critic Roger Ebert with its second Vanguard Leadership award, in recognition of his advocacy of independent cinema. The award is the centerpiece of the institute’s next Celebrate Sundance benefit, to be held in Los Angeles in June.

headline: Would John Kerry Have Picked Samuel Alito?
abstract: If Mitt Romney’s elected president, he could turn the Supreme Court decidedly conservative for another generation.
lead_paragraph: The average retirement age of Supreme Court justices over the past generation is 80. While they have announced no plans to retire, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is 79 and Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony Kennedy are 76. It is likely the next president will fill one or more seats. If Mitt Romney has the chance to replace Justice Ginsburg, that could turn the court decidedly conservative for another generation. If President Obama is re-elected and has the chance to replace Justice Scalia or Justice Kennedy, that could turn the court more moderate.

headline: Cheap Loans Could Spell Long-Term Headaches
abstract: Low interest rates have led many corporations to load up on debt, but this could lead to a flood of bankruptcies once maturities hit.
lead_paragraph: The debt issued today is the stuff of tomorrow’s bankruptcy cases.

headline: Kaine and Allen Face Off in Debate
abstract: A sunny but policy-vague George Allen faced off with a wonkish Tim Kaine Thursday in a Virginia Senate debate that highlighted the perils of policy specifics when the Democratic candidate suggested he would entertain a minimum federal tax for all households.
lead_paragraph: A sunny but policy-vague George Allen faced off with a wonkish Tim Kaine on Thursday in a Virginia Senate debate that highlighted the perils of policy specifics when Mr. Kaine, the Democratic candidate, suggested he would entertain a minimum federal tax for all households.

headline: Progress Seen in Resolving U.S.-Afghan Dispute Over Detainees
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: President Obama and President Hamid Karzai had a conversation touching almost every hot-button issue that has complicated American plans to draw down its forces, senior American and Afghan officials said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Obama and the Afghan leader, Hamid Karzai, had what an American official called a “serious and positive” discussion on Wednesday night that the Afghans confirmed had made progress toward resolving an increasingly acrimonious dispute over detaining terrorism suspects, which had their two governments and their militaries at loggerheads for weeks.

headline: Ground Broken for Last Segment of High Line
abstract: Construction is expected to begin this fall on the final half-mile leg of the High Line, to extend the walkway and park west along 30th Street from 10th to 12th Avenue and then north to 34th Street.

headline: In Calls for Market Reform, Multiple Voices
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A number of events in Washington this week put the spotlight on high-frequency trading, the proliferation of new exchanges and other concerns about the structure of the market.
lead_paragraph: The call for market reform, once confined to the industry fringes, is growing louder.

headline: A Tool for Comparing Post-Law School Prospects
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Law Schools', 'Legal Profession', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Nerdwallet is offering an online tool to help prospective students compare law schools.
lead_paragraph: Law schools have been getting a lot of attention lately, and not of the good kind. Too many law school graduates can’t find decent-paying, long-term legal jobs and are having trouble paying back their student loans.

headline: Writing Rules! Advice From The Times on Writing Well
abstract: Recent Times features, including a new series on the art of writing, inspire us to create this list of 10 “rules” for writing well. In it you’ll find links to advice on everything from using punctuation to reading the way writers do.
lead_paragraph: The Times has recently published a few features that we consider gifts to English teachers everywhere, including a summer “How To” section of the Sunday Book Review, and a new series, called “Draft,” on the art of writing, which features essays by grammarians, historians, linguists, journalists, novelists and others.

headline: Revisiting a Lunch at Perilous Heights
abstract: It’s been 80 years since someone took that iconic photo of men having a vertiginous lunch high above Manhattan, and it’s still not certain who that someone was.
lead_paragraph: It is a defining image of New York City’s history, one that captured the essence of an era, even if it was, in part, a staged scene. On a warm autumn day in 1932, 11 workmen sat perched on a steel girder at Rockefeller Center, smoking, eating sandwiches and reading the newspaper some 800 feet up in the air. Nearby, a camera’s shutter clicked: think men in overalls and flat caps, and boots dangling above the rooftops of Midtown Manhattan. The moment captured in black and white was both heroic and mundane. It was a triumph for the city in the throes of economic crisis and has become one of the most famous images in the world.

headline: London Design Festival Part II
abstract: One of the best things about the festival is that while you see new things by established names, you also see work — much of it interesting, and some of it excellent — by young designers.

headline: College Coaches Divided on Reporting of Injuries
abstract: Whether to discuss, report or even ask about injuries to college football players has sparked debate among coaches, especially in the Pac-12 Conference.
lead_paragraph: After Southern California’s practice Wednesday, Coach Lane Kiffin stood before reporters and wiped sweat from his brow. No one had yet mentioned the dreaded I-word, an increasing source of consternation in recent weeks for Kiffin and his college football counterparts.

headline: Amish Sect Leader and Followers Guilty of Hate Crimes
abstract: A federal jury found Samuel Mullet Sr. and 15 followers guilty of conspiracy and hate crimes in a series of beard- and hair-cutting attacks in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Mullet Sr., the domineering leader of a renegade Amish sect, and 15 of his followers were convicted  on Thursday in Cleveland of federal conspiracy and hate crimes for a series of bizarre beard- and hair-cutting attacks last fall that spread fear through the Amish of eastern Ohio.

headline: Emmys Watch: Jesse Tyler Ferguson on ‘Modern Family’ and Playing it Straight
abstract: Jesse Tyler Ferguson of “Modern Family” discusses the Emmy Awards and his character’s similarity to Vanna White.
lead_paragraph: We will be talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards show on Sunday night. Previous entries in this series include Don Roy King, the director of “Saturday Night Live,” Abi Morgan, nominated for writing “The Hour,” and Christine Baranski, nominated for best supporting actress for “The Good Wife.”

lead_paragraph: LONDON — It may be the age of austerity for many in Britain. For a former doctor, Geoffrey Lipman, it is anything but.
