headline: This Week’s Movies | Sept. 21, 2012
abstract: The New York Times critics on “Trouble With the Curve,” “End of Watch” and “How to Survive a Plague.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critics on “Trouble With the Curve,” “End of Watch” and “How to Survive a Plague.”

headline: Disdain for Workers
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: These days we are getting to really see the beliefs of the party that is of the wealthy, by the wealthy, and for the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: By now everyone knows how Mitt Romney, speaking to donors in Boca Raton, washed his hands of almost half the country — the 47 percent who don’t pay income taxes — declaring, “My job is not to worry about those people. I’ll never convince them that they should take personal responsibility and care for their lives.” By now, also, many people are aware that the great bulk of the 47 percent are hardly moochers; most are working families who pay payroll taxes, and elderly or disabled Americans make up a majority of the rest.

headline: How Green Was My Lawn
abstract: Environmentalism, which became a prominent issue after the publication of “Silent Spring” in 1962, has lost its once enthusiastic backing.
lead_paragraph: Stony Brook, N.Y.

headline: Vanessa Redgrave to Star With Jesse Eisenberg in His New Play
abstract: Rattlestick Playwrights Theater will mount Mr. Eisenberg’s play, “The Revisionist,” Off Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Redgrave has joined the cast of “The Revisionist,” a new play by the actor Jesse Eisenberg that is scheduled to open Off Broadway at the Cherry Lane Theater on Feb. 6 and run through March 31. Mr. Eisenberg, an Oscar nominee for his portrayal of Mark Zuckerberg in “The Social Network,” will also star in the three-character play, which will be directed by Kip Fagan and staged by the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

headline: Season of Mists, if Not in Manhattan
abstract: What’s missing in New York City is a seasonal fog, the kind that foretells autumn.
lead_paragraph: New York City delivers plenty of weather, but never enough fog. Everything west of the Hudson sometimes blurs in a brown summer haze, and there is the steam that rises from rain falling on hot summer streets. But fog, not so much. We don’t mean an old-fashioned London fog, which must have felt like cold exhaust from some infernal smelter. Nor do we mean the soul-dampening eider-fog that blankets the coast of Maine or the banks of low battleship gray clouds that devour June in parts of Southern California.

headline: For Scandal-Weary Italians, Another Scandal
abstract: Italians who thought they had seen everything when it came to politics were taken aback when photographs were published of regional officials having a “return of Ulysses” party.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In this ancient city, most citizens view their politicians with a time-honored, world-weary disdain. But this week, images of regional officials cavorting at a toga party with a “return of Ulysses” theme have tested the patience of even Europe’s most cynical voters.

headline: For Woods and McIlroy, the Admiration Is Mutual
abstract: After the first round of the Tour Championship, Tiger Woods was tied for the lead with Justin Rose at four under par. The world No. 1 golfer, Rory McIlroy, trailed Woods by three strokes.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The player with the swashbuckler’s walk was approaching the final green Thursday when a fan cried out, “Come on, Ray Lewis.”

headline: In Manufacturing Shift, Made in U.S. but Sold in China
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A company in Brooklyn called Watermark Designs is making luxury plumbing parts, like faucets, and exporting them.
lead_paragraph: Standing over a small tank of water in a Brooklyn factory, Zbigniew Solecki plunged a gleaming faucet into the water, then shot air at 60 pounds per square inch into it. He watched for rising bubbles, a sign that an unseen fissure had, unacceptably, let the air stream out. It is a rite of passage that Mr. Solecki performs dozens of times a day.

headline: Behind the Scenes, Some Lawmakers Lobby to Change the Volcker Rule
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In public letters and closed-door meetings, more than 100 lawmakers have appealed to the Federal Reserve and other authorities over the Volcker Rule, records show.
lead_paragraph: As regulators put the finishing touches on new rules for Wall Street, they remain entangled in a partisan fight over the overhaul.

headline: Day of Political Maneuvering and Fights Stalls Congress’s Close
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Congress’s expected departure for the campaign trail was held up by the political fortunes of two senators battling for survival.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress’s expected departure for the campaign trail was held up on Thursday by the political fortunes of two senators battling for survival, Scott P. Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, and Jon Tester, Democrat of Montana.

headline: Cabrera Within Reach of a Rare Baseball Feat
abstract: Third baseman Miguel Cabrera of the Detroit Tigers has a realistic chance to win the first triple crown in the major leagues since Carl Yastrzemski in 1967.
lead_paragraph: The last time a batter won baseball’s triple crown, Neil Armstrong had not yet walked on the moon. The Beatles were still together, the Vietnam War was raging and baseball was the undisputed king of American sports.

headline: Searching for a Companion, With a Smile and a Sign
abstract: Adam Orna, 39, is single and marriage-minded and is taking an unorthodox tack in his hunt for love: he hands out roses while carrying a sign reading “Please Date Me.”
lead_paragraph: His life, to anyone who comes across him as he sits in Union Square Park, is not exactly a complete mystery.

headline: Still Too Close to Call for Two Backers of Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Legislature', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Election officials began to count paper ballots on Thursday in two Republican primary battles involving senators who voted last year to legalize same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Election officials began to count paper ballots on Thursday in two Republican primary battles involving senators who voted last year to legalize same-sex marriage, but both races remained too close to call at the end of the day.

headline: Territorial Disputes Involving Japan
abstract: Territorial disputes between Japan and its neighbors have escalated in recent months, prompting protests and diplomatic tensions.
lead_paragraph: Territorial disputes between Japan and its neighbors have escalated in recent months, prompting protests and diplomatic tensions.

headline: After Attack in Libya, an Ambush Struck Rescuers
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: The assault on American diplomatic facilities in Benghazi was moblike at first but became a sophisticated onslaught.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The survivors of the assault on the American Mission in Benghazi, Libya, thought they were safe. They had retreated to a villa not far from the main building where the surprise attack had occurred, and a State Department team had arrived to evacuate them. The eruption of violence had ended, and now they were surrounded by friendly Libyan brigades in what seemed to be a dark, uneasy calm.

headline: A Family Pulled Into the Fray Over an Agent’s Death
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Firearms']
abstract: The family of Brian A. Terry, a Border Patrol agent who died in a shootout linked to Operation Fast and Furious, has sought answers after revelations over his death.
lead_paragraph: NACO, Ariz. — “There’s the sign,” Kent Terry Jr. exclaimed as the chartered bus pulled into the Border Patrol station, a compound on an expanse of sand and brush bearing the name of his younger brother, who was killed in a shootout linked to a botched gun-smuggling operation known as Fast and Furious.

headline: Commander Who Pepper-Sprayed Protesters Is Sued Again
abstract: On Thursday, two people filed suits against Inspector Anthony Bologna as well as the city and the police commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Deputy Inspector Anthony Bologna, the police commander sued in July for pepper-spraying Occupy Wall Street protesters, has been sued again.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: May Wah Vegetarian Market
abstract: May Wah Vegetarian Market, in Chinatown, is a purveyor of meat-free meat dishes.
lead_paragraph: May Wah Vegetarian Market, in Chinatown, is a purveyor of meat-free meat dishes.

headline: The Candidates Face Hispanic Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Editorials']
abstract: On immigration, Mitt Romney dodges the issue while President Obama admits that he has fallen short.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney and President Obama made direct appeals to Latino voters this week, appearing on successive days at a candidate forum sponsored by Univision, the national Spanish-language television network. The discussion ranged widely, touching on subjects as varied as the Middle East and student loans. But it focused heavily on immigration, a difficult subject providing rich opportunities for evasion and disappointment.

headline: With Usual Referees Away, Players Try to Stretch the Rules
abstract: The National Football League’s replacement referees struggled to control games in Week 2 more than they did in Week 1, perhaps because players tried to exploit their inexperience.
lead_paragraph: When Jared Allen, a defensive end for the Minnesota Vikings, got a split-second head start on his way to a sack of Jacksonville quarterback Blaine Gabbert in the first week of the N.F.L. season, it highlighted more than just the Jaguars’ belief that the play should have been blown dead before Allen smashed Gabbert to the ground.

headline: Temerity at the Top
abstract: If we want to encourage more economic growth, we could start by not bashing the few super-ambitious people at the top.
lead_paragraph: I guess we’re all supposed to be talking about how to build the middle class these days and look askance at the top 1 percent. But would you mind if I interrupted this cultural moment to point out that capitalism is an inherently elitist enterprise?

headline: In Midtown, Taking Aim at Occupy Wall St. and Obama
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Americans for Prosperity, a group inspired by the Tea Party and founded by billionaires, rallied to defend the wealthy and call for change.
lead_paragraph: Three days after the Occupy Wall Street movement marked its first anniversary, a couple of dozen opponents responded on Thursday, staging a brief but rowdy morning rally on a sidewalk in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: California Debt Higher Than Earlier Estimates, a Task Force Reports
abstract: When Jerry Brown became governor of California he estimated the state’s debt at $28 billion, but that amount is now estimated to be as much as 12 times greater.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown of California announced when he came into office last year that he had found an alarming $28 billion “wall of debt” looming over the state, which had to be dismantled.

headline: Fast, Furious and Foolish
keywords: ['Drug Cartels', 'Arms Trade', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Firearms', 'Editorials']
abstract: What was the Justice Department thinking in steering guns into Mexico?
lead_paragraph: The recklessness of federal officials in their harebrained scheme to assist in illegal gunrunning to Mexican drug cartels was laid bare in a scathing report by the Justice Department’s inspector general. Primary blame for the botched program — known as Operation Fast and Furious — was placed on a group of Arizona-based prosecutors and officials of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives who lost track of hundreds of weapons that were allowed to pass into Mexico in hopes of tracing them to cartel leaders.

headline: Veterans in Los Angeles, Still in the Cold
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: The government is not meeting its responsibility to house homeless veterans on land that was meant for just that purpose.
lead_paragraph: When is the Veterans Affairs Department going to meet its responsibility to house chronically homeless veterans in Los Angeles on the large tract of government-owned land that should have been put to this use long ago?

headline: Yum Brands Puts Focus on Hunger Relief
abstract: KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut, all owned by Yum Brands, are continuing their sixth annual World Hunger Relief fund-raiser to benefit the United Nations World Food Program and other groups.
lead_paragraph: CORPORATE philanthropy may seem straightforward, with companies cutting checks to grateful charities, then receiving nothing but plaudits from consumers and the media.

headline: Bill to Keep Graduates in U.S. Fails in the House
keywords: ['Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A Republican bill to provide permanent resident visas for foreigners who graduate from American universities with advanced degrees in science and technology failed to pass the House on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A Republican bill to provide permanent resident visas for foreigners who graduate from American universities with advanced degrees in science and technology failed to pass the House on Thursday, a setback for technology companies that had strongly supported it.

headline: Talking About Taxes
abstract: A reader urges President Obama in his coming debate with Mitt Romney to explain where taxes go.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sleepy Islands and a Smoldering Dispute
abstract: A clash over contested territory has set off worries about the effect on business ties between China and Japan.
lead_paragraph: ISHIGAKI, Japan — In the fishing harbor here, Japan has increased the number of sleek, white Coast Guard cutters to fend off the Chinese patrol boats that have stepped up their challenge of Japan’s control of disputed nearby islands, one sign of a smoldering conflict that has threatened relations between Asia’s two giants.

headline: Where ‘Chicken’ Actually Tastes Like Chicken
abstract: With products like frozen, sunny-side-up eggs made of soy and whey protein, May Wah Vegetarian Market in Chinatown is a beacon for vegans, vegetarians and, yes, those who eat real meat.
lead_paragraph: IT was the vegan “beef chunks” that lured Chana Widawski to May Wah Vegetarian Market in Chinatown on a recent evening. “I’m an outdoors person and a big camper,” she explained. The chewy dried brown nuggets had been a hit with friends on a recent canoe trip — “Everyone loved them,” she said — and she was back for more.

headline: Unlikely Journey Takes Tour Rookie to Playoffs
abstract: After high school in California, John Huh took a roundabout route (via South Korea) to the PGA Tour and the FedEx Cup playoffs.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At the turn of the Tour Championship’s first round Thursday, John Huh was even par, seemingly as relaxed as if he were playing with the Cal State Northridge Matadors.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Why Presidents Love Foreign Affairs
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Because presidents are weak at home and exert their power abroad, voters should take foreign policy more seriously as a campaign issue.
lead_paragraph: I’d like to apologize to American voters. I’m one of the 5 percent. The 5 percent, that is, who vote in presidential elections based on the foreign policy views of the candidates. It might seem to the other 95 percent of you that we pull the strings. At his taped fund-raiser, for example,Mitt Romney complained that the common folk weren’t asking him enough foreign policy questions. It certainly must appear as if we control presidents once they’re elected — after their first year in office, all we read about is that they’re attending some fancy-pants summit meeting or using force somewhere exotic.

headline: Global Warming for a Cold Family
abstract: Jake Gyllenhaal makes his New York stage debut as the wastrel uncle to an overweight, affection-starved teenage girl in Nick Payne’s “If There Is I Haven’t Found It Yet.”
lead_paragraph: Amiable, scruffy, erratic, well-intentioned, full of promise and self-sabotaging — such is the nature of Terry, the stoner character with which the movie star Jake Gyllenhaal has chosen to make his very creditable New York stage debut. Such is also the nature, for better or worse, of the play in which he appears.

headline: Mourning a Beloved Cat and the Road Not Taken
abstract: Ethan Lipton’s comedy compares the bonds humans share with their pets with the relationships they have with one another.
lead_paragraph: If your favorite time killers include overindulging in cute kitty videos on the Web — you know who you are, and you are legion — you will surely lend a sympathetic ear to the befuddled and bereaved hero of “Red-Handed Otter,” a modest but nicely observed comedy by Ethan Lipton that opened on Thursday night at the Cherry Lane Theater, in a production from the Playwrights Realm.

headline: Joba Chamberlain Gets His Groove Back
abstract: After some initial struggles, Joba Chamberlain is once again an important part of the Yankees’ bullpen.
lead_paragraph: Joba Chamberlain’s return from nearly 14 months on the disabled list was initially met with a burst of enthusiasm. But that cooled quickly.

headline: Relative of a Man Crush
abstract: A smooth entry into the weekend by Barry C. Silk.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Contest For a Good Cause Alert! The King of Crosswords, Merl Reagle, is holding a crossword contest starting September 30 in conjunction with the Alzheimer’s Foundation of America to benefit a cause that is very personal and special to him. You can work some of the most fun puzzles around while helping to raise money for a very worthwhile cause. Registration requires a $25.00 donation, and you can sign up by clicking here.

headline: Hoping to Replace Mayor, and Taking Him to Court
abstract: Likely candidates for the 2013 Democratic primary are vying for attention and to demonstrate how much they differ with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, by suing him.
lead_paragraph: One sure sign that the 2013 Democratic primary for New York City mayor is under way: the likely candidates, seeking to differentiate themselves from Michael R. Bloomberg, are suing him.

headline: After Years of Disappointment, Giants’ Brown Embraces His Chance
abstract: Andre Brown ruptured his Achilles’ tendon in 2009 and was waived by five teams, but with the injury to Giants’ starting tailback Ahmad Bradshaw, Brown finally has a chance to rush in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Adrienne Winns was at a restaurant in Fayetteville, N.C., when she watched a family dream come true. Her son, Andre Brown, had told her to look for him as a member of the Giants’ special teams, so she did her best to get a glimpse of him in his relatively anonymous role.

headline: The A-Little-Bit-Less Undecided
abstract: Don’t look now, but voters who weren’t sure if they preferred Obama or Romney are making up their minds.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a big couple of weeks for our presidential candidates. Jihadi murders, protests, diplomatic crises, a secret video, accusations of Islamist sympathy — and all of this with just over six weeks left until Election Day.

headline: Before Debates, Romney Faces a Daunting Path
abstract: There are 46 days left in this presidential race for Mitt Romney to change the dynamic of a campaign that by many indicators is tilting against him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are seven days until early voting begins in Iowa, less than two weeks until the first debate and 46 days left in the race for Mitt Romney to change the dynamic of a campaign that by many indicators is tilting against him.

headline: Reeling Mets Strike Bottom
abstract: To make a miserable night complete, the Mets’ loss to Phildelphia on Thursday mathematically eliminated them from playoff contention.
lead_paragraph: After a summer full of degradation and defeat, the Mets on Thursday burrowed to a previously unfathomed nadir. On no other night this year was their humiliation as complete.

headline: Canadian Auto Workers Union and G.M. Agree on Contract
abstract: The Canadian Auto Workers Union agreed on a tentative contract with General Motors, but said that it was still in talks with Chrysler.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — General Motors of Canada and the Canadian Auto Workers Union announced a tentative contract on Thursday night, about 72 hours after the union settled with the Ford Motor Company of Canada. But the union and Chrysler Canada appeared far apart in their negotiations.

headline: Gangnam Style, Original and in Imitation
abstract: “Gangnam Style,” a music video by a South Korean rapper known as PSY, has been viewed over a billion times on YouTube. It’s also been redone by motivated fans in video imitations as over the top as the original.
lead_paragraph: “Gangnam Style,” a music video by a South Korean rapper known as PSY, has been viewed over a billion times on YouTube. It’s also been redone by motivated fans in video imitations as over the top as the original.

headline: Student Fatally Stabbed in Manhattan
abstract: Officials said Theodore Beckles, 19, was stabbed outside Independence High School on West 56th Street during an argument with other students.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old student died after being stabbed outside his high school in Manhattan on Thursday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Viral Video Gets Propaganda Treatment
abstract: A South Korean phenomenon behind a dance video called “Gangnam Style” got an even clearer sign of success when North Korea parodied the video.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Ordinarily, a star turn on “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” teaching Britney Spears his dance might be one of the surest signs that a performer has made it. But this week, Park Jae-sang, the South Korean phenomenon behind a dance video called Gangnam Style, got an even clearer sign of success. North Korea — so cut off from the world that satellite shots show most of the country plunged in darkness at night — parodied the video.

headline: Questions Surround Two Yankees Pillars
abstract: The Yankees still count on Mark Teixeira and C. C. Sabathia three years after they helped the team win the World Series. But neither, for the moment, is quite the same.
lead_paragraph: Look around baseball, and you appreciate more and more what the Yankees did in 2009. They spent big on three free agents before that season — C. C. Sabathia, Mark Teixeira and A. J. Burnett — and immediately won the World Series.

headline: Panetta Announces Warmer Military Ties on New Zealand Trip
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Leon E. Panetta became the first Pentagon chief to visit since 1982, an absence prompted by a breakdown in ties after the country prohibited nuclear warships from its territorial waters.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta arrived in this South Pacific island nation Friday, becoming the first Pentagon chief to visit here in three decades, an absence prompted by a breakdown in ties after New Zealand prohibited American nuclear warships from its territorial waters.

headline: Trying to Go 3 for 3

lead_paragraph: Miguel Cabrera of the Detroit Tigers has a chance to win the American League Triple Crown.

headline: Life Spans Shrink for Least-Educated Whites in the U.S.
abstract: A long rise in Americans’ life spans has reversed itself for white people who lack high school diplomas, an increasingly troubled group that has lost four years of life expectancy since 1990.
lead_paragraph: For generations of Americans, it was a given that children would live longer than their parents. But there is now mounting evidence that this enduring trend has reversed itself for the country’s least-educated whites, an increasingly troubled group whose life expectancy has fallen by four years since 1990.

headline: With Suzuki in Prime Form, Yankees Complete a Sweep
abstract: Ichiro Suzuki homered and drove in three runs in New York’s victory on Thursday, completing a sweep against the Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: Three and a half hours before the start of Thursday’s game, Ichiro Suzuki began his elaborate daily stretching routine on the navy carpet of the Yankees’ clubhouse. He carried the custom over from Seattle, along with a black humidifying box for his bats and, lately, the free-swinging offensive approach that has earned him more than 3,800 hits in his professional career.

headline: Brown and Warren Spar in Tense Televised Debate Over Massachusetts Senate Seat
abstract: Senator Scott P. Brown and Elizabeth Warren traded accusations in the first of four encounters that could determine one of the hardest fought races in the country.

Brown and Elizabeth Warren traded accusations over taxes, energy policy and contraception coverage in a tense but civil debate on Thursday night, the first of four encounters that could determine the outcome of one of the hardest fought Senate races in the country.

headline: Nigeria: Airline Suspends Flights
abstract: The country’s biggest airline, Arik Air, suspended its domestic flights on Thursday in a dispute with unions, adding to the chaos in Nigeria’s aviation industry.
lead_paragraph: The country’s biggest airline, Arik Air, suspended its domestic flights on Thursday in a dispute with unions, adding to the chaos in Nigeria’s aviation industry. Arik’s shutdown leaves Nigeria with only a handful of small airlines of uncertain reputation still operating. It follows the collapse this month of the country’s other major airline, Air Nigeria, in a mountain of debt and unpaid salaries. Arik halted its flights as workers, including employees at Nigeria’s aviation agencies, the airport authority and the meteorological office, went on strike over what an Aviation Ministry spokesman said were the company’s unpaid bills to the government, amounting to more than $25 million.

headline: ESPN Targets American Cricket Fans
abstract: Cricket’s appeal is strong and growing, sports network said.
lead_paragraph: Cricket fans in the United States have a reason to rejoice: the sports network ESPN is now focusing on the game.

headline: Somalia: Blasts Kill at Least 14
abstract: Two suicide bombers set off explosives on Thursday in a Mogadishu cafe frequented by Somali journalists and civil servants, killing at least 14 people and wounding 20, according to news reports.
lead_paragraph: Two suicide bombers set off explosives on Thursday in a Mogadishu cafe frequented by Somali journalists and civil servants, killing at least 14 people and wounding 20, according to news reports. The Committee to Protect Journalists, an advocacy group based in New York, said at least three journalists, including the news director for Somali National Television, were among the dead at the cafe, called The Village, not far from the presidential palace. No group immediately claimed responsibility, but suspicions fell on the Shabab, the militant Islamic group that has carried out a wave of bombings since it was driven from the capital last year. The group has threatened more mayhem since the selection of a new president, and it tried to assassinate him before his inauguration last week.

headline: A Troubling Trend in Life Expectancy
abstract: The life expectancy of whites without a high school degree has fallen in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The life expectancy of whites without a high school degree has fallen in recent years.

lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney entered the final months of the presidential campaign with a cash balance of just $35 million, racing to find new large donors and rally low-dollar contributors in August even while he raised tens of millions of dollars for the Republican Party.

lead_paragraph: Peter Magubane has always lived by simple words, adopted from a former editor: “If you want a picture, you get that picture, under all circumstances.”

lead_paragraph: When talking about Mongolia, the words “mining,” “strategic” and “change” seem to crop up almost immediately.

headline: The New Man and the Me Decade
abstract: The author Tom Wolfe eviscerated baby boomers but also took the 19th century utopians to task for failing to anticipate Levittown.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 23, 1976, New York Magazine published “The Me Decade,” a cover story by Tom Wolfe that eviscerated baby boomers as the most ludicrous, self-absorbed and spoiled generation in the history of mankind. (The article begins with a 1,500-word description of an unnamed boomer at a spiritual gathering at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles trying to will away her hemorrhoids). As I’ve written elsewhere, this wasn’t entirely fair. At the time, there were 29 million boomers averaging about 20 years old — awfully young to be judged so harshly. Mr. Wolfe, on the other hand, was 45 and at the top of his game.

headline: ‘Justice O’Connor, Welcome to the Court’
abstract: Sandra Day O’Connor was criticized by both sides of the political spectrum when she became a Supreme Court justice but has grown in stature since.

abstract: “To Kill a Mockingbird” by Harper Lee is about race, and the story of this country cannot be told without race as a centerpiece.

We received more than 500 responses — thoughtful, passionate and surprisingly varied. More on that in just a minute. But first, this week’s question: What do you think is the greatest American novel since World War II?

headline: IHT Quick Read: Friday, Sept. 21
abstract: News, fashion, arts and sports coverage in today’s International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: NEWS The Conservative prime minister of Britain, David Cameron, has hitched his political fortunes to the coalition government’s ability to cut the national budget. Despite his efforts to curb public outlays and reduce one of Europe’s biggest budget deficits, government spending is higher than when he took office two years ago. And the cuts — a public sector pay freeze, a reduction in outlays for local governments and staff cuts at government ministries, to name a few — have drawn howls of protest. Landon Thomas Jr. reports from London.

headline: Troop ‘Surge’ in Afghanistan Ends With Mixed Results
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The milestone, which still leaves 68,000 American troops in Afghanistan, went nearly unremarked in the country, with no statement from President Hamid Karzai or the United States military commander, Gen. John R. Allen.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American military says it has now fully withdrawn the last of the 33,000 “surge troops” sent to pacify Afghanistan two years ago, but they are leaving behind an uncertain landscape of rising violence and political instability that threatens to undo considerable gains in security, particularly in the former Taliban strongholds in the south and southwest.

headline: My Problem With Company Retreats
abstract: I think that if an organization needs a company retreat to rebuild morale or excitement, there is something fundamentally wrong with the organization.
lead_paragraph: Aside from eating rabbit, I think there’s only one thing I’m allergic to: company retreats.

headline: How ‘Silent Spring’ Ignited the Environmental Movement
keywords: ['Poisoning and Poisons', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Books and Literature', 'Environment', 'Pesticides']
abstract: What was it that allowed Rachel Carson to capture the public imagination and to forge America’s environmental consciousness?
lead_paragraph: On June 4, 1963, less than a year after the controversial environmental classic “Silent Spring” was published, its author, Rachel Carson, testified before a Senate subcommittee on pesticides. She was 56 and dying of breast cancer. She told almost no one. She’d already survived a radical mastectomy. Her pelvis was so riddled with fractures that it was nearly impossible for her to walk to her seat at the wooden table before the Congressional panel. To hide her baldness, she wore a dark brown wig.

lead_paragraph: ISHIGAKI, Japan — South Korean patrol boats fired warning shots at North Korean fishing vessels in contested waters in the Yellow Sea on Friday, but the North’s boats fled without casualties, the South Korean military said.

headline: Fallout From ‘47 Percent’ Comment Hits Senate Campaigns
abstract: If there was any doubt that Mitt Romney’s secretly recorded comments about the “47 percent” had jumped beyond the presidential campaign, it was erased with the first question of the Virginia Senate debate on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt that Mitt Romney‘s secretly recorded comments about the “47 percent” had jumped beyond the presidential campaign, it was erased with the first question of the Virginia Senate debate on Thursday.

headline: Sept. 20: Obama’s Convention Bounce May Not Be Receding
abstract: President Obama’s position inched forward in the FiveThirtyEight forecast on Thursday, as he continues to do well in swing states and in surveys that use industry-standard polling methodology.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s position inched forward in the FiveThirtyEight forecast on Thursday. His chances of winning the Electoral College are 76.1 percent, according to the forecast, up from 75.2 percent on Wednesday. Mr. Obama’s projected margin of victory in the national popular vote also increased slightly, to 3.4 percentage points.

headline: Daily Report: Wal-Mart Deletes the Kindle
abstract: Wal-Mart will no longer sell Amazon’s Kindles, a sign of how seriously it takes Amazon as a competitor in the consumer goods market.
lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation’s largest retailer, said Thursday that it was dropping Amazon’s Kindle tablets and e-readers, a sign of how seriously it views Amazon as a competitor in the consumer goods market, report Stephanie Clifford and Julie Bosman on Friday in The New York Times.

headline: Israeli Soldier Killed as Border Is Breached, Reviving Worries on Sinai Lawlessness
abstract: Another soldier was seriously wounded, and the Israeli military said it killed the three attackers, whom a spokesman called “well equipped.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — One Israeli soldier was killed and another was wounded on Friday morning in a battle with three men who stormed into Israel from the Sinai Peninsula, the second such deadly border attack in less than two months, reviving concern about the ability of Egypt’s new Islamist government to control growing lawlessness in the area.

headline: Going Rogue
abstract: Claire Danes plays an endearingly intense spy on “Homeland,” so where better to film season 2 than in the work-hard-play-hard city of Tel Aviv?
lead_paragraph: The last time I saw the C.I.A. agent Carrie Mathison, Claire Danes’s compulsive bipolar character in Showtime’s “Homeland,” she was strapped to a hospital table having electroconvulsive therapy as Season 1 ended. The next time I saw her she was waiting in line at an airport that was draped in Lebanese flags, getting ready to board Season 2 and, to be honest, she still looked shocked.

headline: Still Fighting the War, in an Orchard
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A transplanted New Yorker’s encounter at a Virginia orchard indicates that even on the apple front, rebel sympathies die hard.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: On Identifying a Rape Victim, Naming a Prophet, and Nate Silver’s Role
abstract: The public editor takes up readers’ questions that have showed up in her e-mail this week.
lead_paragraph: Readers have written to me about a number of issues in the past week. Here’s a roundup of some of their questions and complaints (paraphrased here for clarity), and my answers and comments.

headline: Essentials | Tel Aviv
abstract: T offers up a black book for the White City.
lead_paragraph: Tel Aviv, Israel’s intoxicating cultural capital, is only 103 years old — or, if you count Jaffa, it’s only 7,603 years old. By turns exultant and exhausting, the city is open around the clock, and seems always to be changing, especially lately, as Tel Aviv’s hotels and restaurants are finally living up to its fabled beaches and nightlife. To go along with our fall travel cover story, T offers up a black book for the White City.

headline: Telecom Services Blocked to Curb Protests in Kashmir
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Internet and cellphone service suspended by state authorities in Kashmir for several hours on Friday.
lead_paragraph: New Delhi– The state government of Jammu and Kashmir ordered telecom companies to block access to YouTube and Facebook in the Kashmir Valley, effective midnight Thursday, to curb potential protests over an amateur video that has angered Muslims.

headline: Common Core Practice | Medical Manga, a Family Grocery and a Restaurant Review
abstract: We’re experimenting with the new standards by publishing actual tasks two teachers and their 9th grade humanities students try each week. This is our first; please come tell us what you think!
lead_paragraph: Go to related article »

headline: Influencing Dodd-Frank
abstract: Two years after passing Dodd-Frank, lawmakers are still tinkering behind the scenes. | Xstrata has until Monday to decide whether to accept Glencore’s sweetened merger offer. | New York’s attorney general, who runs a new task force on mortgage abuses, said the group would act soon. | A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago raises concerns about high-frequency trading.
lead_paragraph: Influencing Dodd-Frank  |  Two years after passing a spate of financial rules, lawmakers are still tinkering behind the scenes with Dodd-Frank. In a show of partisan haggling, more than 100 lawmakers have lobbied the Federal Reserve and other authorities over the Volcker Rule, writes Ben Protess of DealBook. A top aide to Senator Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, has been reaching out to the Treasury Department and the Fed in an effort to limit the impact on local financial firms. While the Fed encouraged the aide to air his views publicly, internal government documents indicate some of the discussions took place in private. In a draft of the Volcker Rule, regulators adopted Mr. Brown’s approach.

headline: Friday Reading: The High Cost of Out-of-Pocket Medicare Expenses
abstract: The high cost of out-of-pocket Medicare expenses, life span shrinks for some whites, how to apply to a performing arts school and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Etro: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Universal-EMI Deal Passes in Europe, and Relief at News Corp.
abstract: Universal Music Group won Europe’s approval for its $1.9 billion acquisition of EMI Music, Wal-Mart said it would stop carrying Amazon’s Kindle, and PBS has a chance to win an Emmy for best drama.
lead_paragraph: Universal Music Group won Europe’s approval on Friday for its $1.9 billion acquisition of the British-based EMI Music, Ben Sisario and James Kanter report. The approval came after Universal agreed to a series of concessions meant to foster competition even as the sale itself will reduce the number of major music labels to three from four. The concessions include the selling off about a third of EMI’s assets including most of Parlophone, its flagship label in Europe, with acts like Coldplay, Pink Floyd and Kylie Minogue. A consolation for the newly enlarged Universal is that it will keep the Beatles.

headline: Bullfighting: Hallowed Tradition or Animal Torture? France Rules
abstract: Anti-bullfighting campaigners suffered their second setback in a month when French judges ruled today that the activity did not contravene the Constitution. As aficionados celebrate, what’s the next step for the animal rights lobby?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a setback for animal rights campaigners, France’s top judges ruled on Friday that bullfighting does not contravene the Constitution.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Gothamist: The $1 pizza slice has become the gold standard for bargain eating in New York. But here’s another contender: the $1 oyster. — Patrick Farrell

headline: The Escape Artists
abstract: This weekend: a three-day, word-of-mouth event in upstate New York promises to let attendees channel their inner Peter Pan.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: BlackBerrys Fail Overseas
abstract: Research in Motion said it had restored BlackBerry e-mail and other services in Europe, the Middle East and Africa after a technical problem.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Research in Motion said that an unidentified technical problem cut off BlackBerry e-mail and other services to some of its customers in Europe, the Middle East and Africa for several hours on Friday.

headline: Notes on the Political Economy of Redistribution
abstract: The median is the message.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is getting beaten up, and rightly so, for claiming that redistribution is un-American. Of course we redistribute, and we’ve been doing it on a substantial scale for generations. Medicare, for example, is in effect a strongly redistributive program: it’s supported by a payroll tax (and other revenue) in which the amount you pay in depends on your income, but it supplies a benefit that depends only on your medical costs. From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs!

headline: This Week’s Movies: Sept. 21
abstract: The New York Times critics on “Trouble With the Curve,” “End of Watch” and “How to Survive a Plague.”
lead_paragraph: In This Week’s Movies, the New York Times critics offer their thoughts on “Trouble With the Curve,” “End of Watch” and “How to Survive a Plague.” View all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Polls And Money
abstract: This is not going as planned.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago I speculated that Obama’s strengthened position after the conventions could turn into a self-fulfilling prophecy via the money channel, as donors scramble to realign themselves with the probable winner. Sure enough, it seems to be happening:

headline: Who Made That Bumper Sticker?
abstract: Plus: The danger of a political debate at 60 m.p.h.
lead_paragraph: One day in the mid-1940s, Forest Gill, the owner of a print shop, knelt down in a Kansas City parking lot and measured a car’s bumper. Ever since the automobile age began, drivers had advertised their opinions with handmade placards tied to their cars with bits of twine. Gill realized that he could make “bumper signs” forever obsolete.

headline: The Internet? We Built That
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Research', 'Open-Source Software', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Big Government and Big Capital, meet Big Peer Network.
lead_paragraph: Who created the Internet and why should we care? These questions, so often raised during the Bush-Gore election in 2000, have found their way back into the political debate this season — starting with one of the most cited texts of the preconvention campaign, Obama’s so-called “you didn’t build that” speech. “The Internet didn’t get invented on its own,” Obama argued, in the lines that followed his supposed gaffe. “Government research created the Internet so that all the companies could make money off the Internet.” In other words: business uses the Internet, but government made it happen.

headline: My Hollywood Affliction
abstract: Acting dreams dashed by prostate problems? It could be worse.
lead_paragraph: I came to Los Angeles when I was 25 to be an actor. I thought I was ready for anything: unemployment, rejection, acting classes. I didn’t expect illness.

headline: The Pop Diplomacy of Quincy Jones
abstract: Making hits with Michael and peace with Tupac.
lead_paragraph: You once wrote that Michael Jackson stopped working with you because he felt threatened by the credit you were getting for his music. Considering he was never able to repeat the success he had with “Off the Wall,” “Thriller” and “Bad,” how much credit do you deserve?  Well, what do you think?

headline: The 9.9.12 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: A Rust-Belt Miracle

headline: A Tidy Sum
abstract: Cheap labor; free cake.
lead_paragraph: I’m a math teacher at an international school in Mombasa, Kenya, and a woman who cleans some of the teachers’ apartments offered me her services. Here’s the problem: She is asking for only 300 Kenyan shillings, or about $3.50, for two hours of work. She will be cleaning my bathroom and my kitchen, as well as the floor and my clothing. To me, her work is worth much more than $3.50, and it feels wrong to accept without providing what I believe to be fair payment. If I pay her more, however, she might raise her prices for other customers or pressure my co-workers to pay more than they are willing. What should I do: accept the price she has offered or pay her adequately for her services? NAME WITHHELD, MOMBASA, KENYA

headline: Growing Up Together
abstract: Slightly below the radar, the Betsy-Tacy children’s book series has captivated generations of fans.
lead_paragraph: At the Betsy-Tacy Convention in Mankato, Minn., in 1997, I disgraced myself at the trivia contest. In front of my daughter, Josephine, then 7 years old, and several hundred similarly dedicated “Betsy-Tacy” fans, I answered the question “What was the decoration on Betsy Ray’s wedding cake?” with the very wrong answer: a bell. The cake was in fact decorated with a dove; the bell, it will be recalled, was hanging decoratively in the living room.

headline: When the Dust Settles
abstract: Claire Vaye Watkins’s stories show a concern for knowing the past and surviving the present.
lead_paragraph: The most notable feature of “Battleborn,” the first story collection by Claire Vaye Watkins, is its physical landscape, especially as it affects the people who stake their claims on its inhospitable terrain. The reader is introduced to Reno’s founders, both the notorious and the anonymous; to figures who are insiders as well as outsiders; to personalities with historical pedigrees and to ones concocted to perfectly fit the crime. The point of view roams, but the Nevada setting provides a hard ground on which the reader counts for stability. Although the individual stories stand alone, together they tell the tale of a place, and of the population that thrives and perishes therein.

headline: Mind the Gap
abstract: Zadie Smith’s novel presents characters of varying (and sometimes mixed) races, ethnic groups and classes.
lead_paragraph: Zadie Smith’s latest novel, “NW,” introduces four characters: Leah, Felix, Keisha (renamed Natalie) and Nathan, all of whom grew up in the same impoverished part of northwest London. The postal code for the area is the NW of the title, and Caldwell — the housing project where the characters were raised — is the only fictional place on a very real map. The project consists of five tower blocks, each named for a giant of English philosophy: Smith, Hobbes, Bentham, Locke, Russell. Given the grimness of the locale, the names are only slightly less amusing than the titles of real tower blocks in Kilburn, which are named for Austen, Dickens and Fielding. There are times when the ironies of fiction cannot match those that reality provides.

headline: A Greater Asia
abstract: Pankaj Mishra’s group portrait of the thinkers whose ideas shaped contemporary China, India and the Muslim world.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, the Chinese dissident artist Ai Weiwei exhibited 12 bronze animal heads representing the signs of the Chinese zodiac outside the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan. The heads were enlarged replicas of a set designed in the 18th century by two European Jesuits for the emperor Qianlong and displayed in the gardens of the Yuanmingyuan, the emperor’s Old Summer Palace. At the time of the exhibition, Ai had disappeared into detention in China. The political controversy overshadowed the work itself, which posed its most searching questions not to the Chinese government, but to the West.

headline: The Way She Was
abstract: Alex Witchel describes how her vibrant mother’s personality vanished despite her robust body.
lead_paragraph: In this haunting, unflinching and at times unexpectedly hilarious memoir, Alex Witchel offers up a fiercely honest account of how her adored mother slowly began “disappearing in plain sight.” “All Gone” is a potluck dish containing a variety of ingredients: childhood stories, complete with a cast of vibrantly portrayed relatives; practical knowledge gleaned from Witchel’s desperate battle against the relentless advance of her parent’s small-stroke-induced dementia; and, yes, real recipes passed down by her mother and grandmother. (I’ve tried a few, and they’re very good. I particularly recommend the chicken with prunes.)

headline: Last Call
abstract: A “lost” novel by James M. Cain, the author of “The Postman Always Rings Twice” and “Double Indemnity.”
lead_paragraph: When you strike a match the flame burns blue closest to the source of combustion. For most of his prolific career James M. Cain had the blue flame burning in his explorations of greed, passion and murder. Novels like “Double Indemnity” and “The Postman Always Rings Twice” sizzled with it. And Hollywood always came calling. His work drew the best and brightest talents, and the results were classic. As recently as last year “Mildred Pierce” was produced for the second time in 60-plus years, in an Emmy-winning television run. Cain expertly mined the fine line between desire and lust and the consequences incurred by crossing it. And that skill is timeless, whether on the page or on-screen.

headline: Ruling Opens Door for Lundqvist to Play in Sweden
abstract: Sweden’s top league, the Elitserien, has been ordered to lift its ban against short-term contracts, clearing the way for locked-out N.H.L. players to play there.
lead_paragraph: Sweden’s top league, the Elitserien, has been ordered by the government to lift its ban against short-term contracts, opening the way for locked-out N.H.L. players to play in the only European league that had blocked their entry.

headline: An Outdoor Shower That Only Looks Permanent
abstract: The shower’s handmade panels are held together by a stainless-steel frame that takes less than 30 minutes to put together.
lead_paragraph: The winters can be harsh where Jim Lobley lives in western Massachusetts, but he still wanted to shower outdoors. “I thought it would be great to have something I could set up wherever, and not have to dig trenches and put up a permanent installation,” said Mr. Lobley, who had his own design-build firm. “And then in the fall, I could just roll up the hoses and bring them inside and wouldn’t have to worry about things freezing.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SIBLING EFFECT: What the Bonds Among Brothers and Sisters Reveal About Us,  by Jeffrey Kluger. (Riverhead, $16.) Kluger, a science writer and senior editor at Time magazine, weaves his own experiences of growing up in a contentious, at times dysfunctional family into a fascinating analysis of scientific research on birth order, twins, blended families and parental divorce.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE END OF MEN: And the Rise of Women,  by Hanna Rosin. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Women around the world are increasingly dominant in work, education, households, and even love and marriage, Rosin argues in this optimistic narrative.

headline: Up Front
abstract: Michael Connelly on the work ethic of writing that he learned as a newspaper reporter.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Michael Connelly has made hundreds of appearances in the Book Review — most of them, of course, on the best-seller list, where his Harry Bosch mysteries are in regular rotation. (“The Black Box,” his latest, will be published in November.) But this week Connelly gets his first byline in our pages, writing about “The Cocktail Waitress,” a posthumously published novel by James M. Cain. In some ways the review completes a circle for Connelly, who started his career writing for newspapers and who took early inspiration as a novelist from hard-boiled authors like Cain.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
abstract: New books by Guy Gugliotta, Janet Groth, Siri Hustvedt and Bryan Sykes.
lead_paragraph: FREEDOM’S CAP  The United States Capitol and the Coming of the Civil War.  By Guy Gugliotta.  Hill & Wang, $35.

headline: Making Sense
abstract: Though not strictly a memoir, David Byrne’s book about music explores his own personal and professional experiences.
lead_paragraph: David Byrne is a brilliantly original, eccentric rock star, and he has written a book to match his protean talents. It is not exactly a memoir — “the ‘aging rocker bio’ is a crowded shelf,” as he puts it in his acknowledgments. It is not exactly a series of essays about music, either, though it is some of that. It’s a little bit of both, proudly or unashamedly exposing Byrne’s biases and aimed at a particular audience: his own fans. Since he appeals to people generously diverse in age and interests, however, that’s a pretty big potential readership.

headline: Where Is He Now?
abstract: The actor and travel writer Andrew McCarthy takes a deeply personal journey amid some of the world’s most far-flung places.
lead_paragraph: Early on in “The Longest Way Home,” Andrew McCarthy recounts a vivid childhood memory of venturing alone into the yard one winter night. Intent on making a snow angel, he instead finds himself on his back mesmerized by the stars. It isn’t their beauty that transports him; it’s the unspeakable vastness of their glorious existence. In this moment, McCarthy is no longer a boy “prone to worry and fret,” but rather a wise young soul who knows to his very bones what it is to be alive, his entire being flooded with the exquisite perception that we are at once profoundly connected to the wide and cluttered world and utterly, inexorably alone in it. If I had to cut out the heart of this book, that’s where I’d put the knife, on that boy in the snow on that dark night long ago. It’s an intimate realization that glimmers with universality and sets us up for the question McCarthy grapples with mightily in the course of this engaging debut: How do we manage to nurture our deepest bonds at the same time that we honor our most necessary solitude?

headline: ‘Ben Stiller Show’ Reunion Is Set for New York Comedy Festival
abstract: Ben Stiller and colleageues Janeane Garafolo, Bob Odenkirk, Judd Apatow and Andy Dick will mark the 20th anniversary of their short-lived Fox sketch series at the Paley Center for Media on Nov. 10.
lead_paragraph: In a different universe television audiences would be preparing for Fox’s 21st season of “The Ben Stiller Show,” the freely associative sketch show that mashed up Woody Allen comedies and monster movies and wondered what structure Bruce Willis would get trapped in for “Die Hard 12,” instead of morosely noting that it was canceled after half a season in 1992 (and an earlier MTV incarnation in 1990).

headline: As Lockout Drags On, Owners’ Resolve Could Be Tested
abstract: Six days into the National Hockey League lockout, the prospects of no season and the loss of money and publicity from the Winter Classic could induce owners to settle for a deal.
lead_paragraph: Six days into the N.H.L. lockout, the first week of preseason games has been canceled, some teams have announced temporary layoffs and the league office has reduced its employees’ workweeks and salaries.

headline: Standard Chartered Signs Pact With New York Regulator
abstract: Executives of the British bank agreed last month to pay $340 million to settle claims that it moved hundreds of billions of dollars in tainted money and lied to regulators. Until Friday, though, the final details were not hashed out.
lead_paragraph: 8:51 p.m. | Updated

headline: Since Suicide, More Resources for Transgender and Gay Students
abstract: Rutgers University has rolled out more specialized housing options and other resources for its gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender students in the wake of Tyler Clementi’s death.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — It has been two years since Tyler Clementi, a gay freshman at Rutgers University, committed suicide after learning that his roommate had ridiculed his sexuality and invited friends to spy on him and another man through a webcam. That terrible episode brought the school national attention, none of it welcome: previously known as a large and diverse state school, Rutgers became associated with homophobia and cruelty.

headline: 5-Year Plans, Last-Minute Changes
abstract: Many audience members are unaware that operas are planned, and largely cast, five years ahead. But there have always been exceptions.
lead_paragraph: EVERY once in a while an e-mail lands in the in-boxes of journalists who cover the Metropolitan Opera, with the subject line announcing a “cast change advisory.” The e-mails are simple and straightforward, and they tend to make people very unhappy.

headline: G.M. Recalls Chevy Malibus, Saturn Auras and Pontiac G6s for Rollaway Risk
abstract: The sedans, from the 2007-10 model years, may roll when the gear selector is in Park.
lead_paragraph: 11:49 a.m. | Updated

headline: IPhone 5 Fever? Don’t Count Samsung Out
abstract: It doesn’t have the media coverage or the passionate fan base, but the giant South Korean manufacturer has built an impressive lead in global mobile phone sales.
lead_paragraph: By many measures, Samsung Electronics should be on the ropes. Last month, it lost an important patent battle with its rival Apple after a jury in the United States ruled that Samsung had illegally copied aspects of Apple’s groundbreaking iPhone. Apple introduced its newest model, the iPhone 5, to enthusiastic reviews and a worldwide consumer frenzy, with customers lining up to buy the new model days before it arrived in stores on Friday. This week, Apple shares hit a record high and cracked the $700 threshold.

headline: In a Footstep, Making a Cello for Beethoven
abstract: The instruments of a Beethoven string quartet are the dancers’ bodies in “Danza Permanente,” a piece by D D Dorrvillier that is coming to the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: MUSICIANS play, and dancers dance. But the choreographer D D Dorvillier is flipping that notion upside down in a work that transposes a late Beethoven string quartet into a dance for four.

headline: Joaquín Almunia on Europe’s Tough Terms for Approving Universal-EMI Deal
abstract: In an interview, Mr. Almunia, the driving figure in the negotiations in Brussels over the future of EMI, explains why Europe insisted that Universal sell its assets globally, not just in Europe.
lead_paragraph: 12:39 p.m. | Updated The most important man in music at the moment is not a hit-spotting executive in New York or London, but, rather, a diminutive Spanish bureaucrat whose decisions about the breakup of EMI will largely determine the shape of the industry for years to come.

headline: Mister Rogers Changed My Life
abstract: All I ever wanted to do was to reach children the way Mr. Rogers once reached me.
lead_paragraph: I was that 4-year old who would sit in front of the television and talk to Mister Rogers every day. Mister Rogers liked me, just the way I was. I swore he was looking right at me. He smiled, explained things in a calm voice, and told me I was special.

headline: Made in Brooklyn, Exported to China
abstract: A luxury faucet-maker in Brooklyn finds a steady market in China. | Shrinking life expectancy for the least-educated whites.
lead_paragraph: A luxury faucet-maker in Brooklyn finds a steady market in China. | Shrinking life expectancy for the least-educated whites.

headline: Sept. 23 — 29
abstract: A selection of events.
lead_paragraph: WHEN abstraction in art was still new and confounding, sophisticates sometimes referred to music as an illuminating comparison. Harmony, dissonance, rhythm, melody, counterpoint and other musical features were seen to have parallels in seemingly nonrepresentational visual compositions. Musical composers, on the other hand, had a longstanding tradition of evoking mental imagery by sonic means. So it came about in 1928 that VASILY KANDINSKY, the artist often credited for creating the first purely abstract paintings, designed movable sets and changing lighting to accompany a performance of Modest Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition.” Presented in Dessau, Germany, the show was a great success.

headline: Art Tells of Upheavals as Louvre Opens a New Wing
abstract: The Louvre shines a light on a vast collection of Islamic art, including scores of important works that have been out of sight for decades.
lead_paragraph: Paris—This weekend the Louvre is introducing “the most radical architectural intervention since the pyramid in 1989,” Carol Vogel writes. “Designed to house new galleries for Islamic art, it consists of ground- and lower-ground-level interior spaces topped by a golden, undulating roof that seems to float within the neo-Classical Visconti Courtyard in the middle of the Louvre’s south wing, right below the museum’s most popular galleries, where the Mona Lisa and Veronese’s ‘Wedding Feast of Cana’ are hung.”

headline: The iPhone 5 Now on the Loose
abstract: The grumbling over a new Apple maps service didn’t deter customers from once again jamming stores to get the latest iPhone. The latest Apple device went on sale at 8 a.m. local time Friday in Apple retail stores and those of its wireless carrier partners. Crowds were heavy, especially at flagship Apple stores like the one on Fifth Avenue in New York.
lead_paragraph: 2:25 p.m. | Updated Adding commentary from an Apple product manager.

headline: Book Review Podcast
abstract: This week, Junot Díaz talks about “This Is How You Lose Her”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alex Witchel discusses her memoir “All Gone”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Junot Díaz talks about “This Is How You Lose Her”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alex Witchel discusses her memoir “All Gone”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Dear FloFab: Splitting the Check (or the Friendship?)
abstract: Florence Fabricant answers diners’ questions.
lead_paragraph: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Lawmaker Didn’t Break Ethics Rules in Bank Case, Investigator Finds
abstract: The findings represent some of the final steps in what has been a three-year investigation into Representative Maxine Waters’s actions during the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, did not violate House ethics rules when she contacted the Treasury Department in 2008 to set up a meeting on behalf of top executives from a bank her husband owns stock in, a special investigator announced on Friday.

headline: Shrink to Fit
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Population']
abstract: New York City will soon choose an architect to design micro-units of under 300 square feet. That may sound small, but many New Yorkers already live quite contentedly in cubbyholes.
lead_paragraph: IN July, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his competition to create a building of residential “micro-units” in Manhattan, each ranging from 275 to 300 square feet, the plan ignited the imagination of countless architects and developers.

headline: After Long Absence, a U.S. Defense Secretary Visits New Zealand
abstract: Leon E. Panetta became the first Pentagon chief to visit the country in three decades, an absence prompted by a breakdown in ties after New Zealand prohibited American nuclear warships from its territorial waters.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta arrived in this South Pacific island nation on Friday, becoming the first Pentagon chief to visit here in three decades, an absence prompted by a breakdown in ties after New Zealand prohibited American nuclear warships from its territorial waters.

lead_paragraph: The latest version of Apple’s smartphone went on sale Friday.
