headline: The Bodice Ripper That Started It All
abstract: The rivalries and resentments that animate “Homeland” and “Downton Abbey,” among the best-drama nominees at the Emmy Awards, churned within a popular mini-series a decade ago, “The Forsyte Saga.”
lead_paragraph: AMONG the best drama nominees at the Emmy Awards ceremony on Sunday night, “Homeland,” an of-the-moment political thriller, and “Downton Abbey,” a soapy period drama, could hardly be more different.

headline: Image of the Day: September 21
abstract: French embassies, consulates, cultural centers and schools remained closed in many countries including India for security reasons.

headline: Holy Herring, It’s Sea Otter Awareness Week!
abstract: Sea otters are kind of like prairie dogs of the ocean. The New York Aquarium has two of them that want to meet you.
lead_paragraph: The demands placed on today’s civic-minded citizen can be crushing. No sooner have you put away your truck tires (World Rubber Day was Sept. 12) and your eye patch (International Talk Like a Pirate Day, Sept. 19) than it’s time to gear up for World Contraception Day next Wednesday.

headline: Sotheby’s Signs Deal With Beijing Company
abstract: A 10-year joint venture will pave the way for a major expansion in China.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to capitalize on the tremendous growth of the Chinese art market, Sotheby’s said on Friday it had entered into a 10-year joint venture with the Beijing GeHua Art Company, a state-owned enterprise, to become the first international auction house in mainland China.

headline: An Alternate Interpretation of Romney’s ’47 Percent’
abstract: Many assume the Republican presidential nominee was channeling the arrogance of the One Percent. But he may have been voicing the pain of people a lot poorer.
lead_paragraph: ASSISI, Italy — When Mitt Romney’s closed-door remarks calling 47 percent of Americans “victims” emerged this week, it caused a protracted firestorm. What was he thinking? Was this a pivotal moment in the campaign? Was it even possibly the end?

headline: Montana and Citizens United
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s absolutist reading of the First Amendment has changed the rules for judicial elections in Montana.
lead_paragraph: The G.O.P. of Sanders County, Montana is expected to endorse a candidate soon in the state’s Supreme Court election, ending a 77-year-old prohibition.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “The Price of Politics” by Bob Woodward lands at No. 2 on the nonfiction list this week, and now all 17 of his books have been hardcover best sellers.
lead_paragraph: POINTING FINGERS: Campaign season wouldn’t feel like campaign season without a best seller from Bob Woodward, and — right on cue — his latest, “The Price of Politics,” lands at No. 2 on this week’s hardcover nonfiction list.

headline: There’s Something About Richard
abstract: Richard Plepler, the new chief executive of HBO, occupies a role that goes well beyond television and extends into New York’s political, media and entertainment cliques.
lead_paragraph: ON Sept. 5, Cipriani 42nd Street was decked out as if for a 1920s New Year’s Eve soiree: black candelabras with hydrangeas arranged like Art Deco sentinels, a model of a vintage airplane hanging overhead. A woman sang Cole Porter tunes while guests slurped freshly shucked oysters and sipped gin. Some partygoers reclined on metallic gold couches, their shadows cast by illuminated votives. All was designed to invoke the Prohibition-era setting of “Boardwalk Empire,” the HBO show about to enter its third season.

headline: Regulators Extend Deadline for Xstrata’s Answer to Glencore
abstract: Xstrata’s board will now have until Oct. 1 to decide whether to accept Glencore’s sweetened merger offer.
lead_paragraph: British regulators have granted Xstrata extra time to respond to Glencore’s merger offer, as the mining giant weighs the sweetened bid.

headline: Onward, if Not Upward, for the Mets
abstract: The Mets will be here almost all of next week. (Here are some matchups to be mindful of.)
lead_paragraph: So, did you hear the one about the coming Fan Appreciation Day at Citi Field? The Mets aren’t playing.

headline: A Picnic in a Parking Space
abstract: In cities around the world, participants in Park(ing) Day are changing parking spaces into living spaces. Are you?
lead_paragraph: The day to turn a parking space into a park is finally here.

headline: Fixing the Passbook Connection in iOS 6
abstract: Many people are experiencing a problem when trying to start Passbook, the new iOS 6 rewards card and ticket management program. Here is how to fix it.
lead_paragraph: The new Apple software upgrades have resulted in some strange glitches – in my case many of my mail settings spontaneously changed so I couldn’t get or send e-mail.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Moschino
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Doing the Right Thing, Whatever That Is
abstract: Things can seem black and white when you’re outside a situation, and yet so difficult when you’re entangled in it. How do we address ethical issues in our everyday lives?
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY found myself in a position where I had some moral qualms about a writing assignment. No, it wasn’t for this publication, and no, I wasn’t being asked to make up quotes or leave out pertinent facts. But I was being asked to phrase things in a way I didn’t feel totally comfortable with.

headline: Gamblers Watch for Trends as They Study New Officials
abstract: As replacement referees officiate the first few weeks of the National Football League season, bettors are trying to figure out how the league’s labor dispute might help their wallets.
lead_paragraph: Sports gamblers everywhere unite in the perpetual quest to find an edge, and never more so than when they bet on the N.F.L. This search knows no bounds; several years ago, when the league cracked down on helmet-to-helmet hits, handicappers ignored the typical hand-wringing from fans upset about losing their usual fill of brutality and instead just wanted to know how the rule change would affect their bets.

headline: The Price Whistle-Blowers Pay for Secrets
abstract: Lawyers and government officials caution would-be whistle-blowers to first understand what they are getting into.
lead_paragraph: A $104 million award for a whistle-blower is probably enough of an incentive to make most people divulge secrets about their employer, or even their friends, for that matter. The award, the largest ever paid by the Internal Revenue Service, went to Bradley C. Birkenfeld last week for revealing secrets about the Swiss banking system.

headline: Prime Minister Singh Defends Reforms
abstract: Excerpts from Manmohan Singh’s Speech.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, who has long been criticized for being media shy and for not engaging with the public, defended his economic policy changes in a rare nationally televised address Friday night, explaining the need for the reform measures, including foreign investment in the retail sector, and urged citizens to support them.

headline: The President and the Pastors
abstract: What a meeting between Lincoln and a group of ministers in September 1862 shows about his thinking on freedom on the eve of announcing the Emancipation Proclamation.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 8, 1862, more than 40 ministers in Chicago signed a nine-page “Memorial of all Christian Denominations,” urging Lincoln to emancipate the slaves on moral and religious grounds, which two of them, the Rev. William W. Patton and the Rev. John Dempster, personally delivered to Lincoln five days later. The three had a long conversation, which the ministers duly reported back to their colleagues and which was later published in The Chicago Tribune and other papers.

headline: Chief Censor in Myanmar Caps His Red Pen
abstract: U Tint Swe, head of Myanmar’s Press Scrutiny and Registration Division, is closing down the office after 48 years amid democratic reforms.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Return of Yunior
abstract: Junot Díaz discusses “This Is How You Lose Her,” his new book of stories.
lead_paragraph: In the New York Times Book Review, Leah Hager Cohen reviews Junot Díaz’s “This Is How You Lose Her,” a collection of stories that brings back Yunior, the narrator of several earlier stories by Mr. Díaz and a character in his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel “The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao.” Ms. Cohen writes:

headline: Of Nigeria, but Casting a Wider Net
abstract: With “Doctor Bello,” the Nigerian film industry is hoping for a global hit and mainstream legitimacy.
lead_paragraph: ON the surface the production that commandeered a few dormant rooms at the Coler-Goldwater Specialty Hospital on Roosevelt Island this year resembled many other low-budget film projects in New York City. Crew members were each handling multiple jobs. Those from out of town were spending their short nights on friends’ couches. The catering consisted of a box of Dunkin’ Donuts and a carton of coffee, both empty by late morning.

headline: Time Has Been Kind to ‘Heaven’s Gate’
keywords: ['Movies', 'New York Film Festival', 'Venice International Film Festival']
abstract: The release of a digital version of “Heaven’s Gate” has given Michael Cimino, its director, a sense of vindication.

headline: Hostage Situation Unfolds Over Facebook
abstract: A man suspected of holding at least one hostage in a Pittsburgh office tower has been apparently updating his Facebook account as the drama unfolds.
lead_paragraph: A man who took a person hostage in a Pittsburgh office tower and was apparently updating his Facebook account as the drama unfolded has surrendered to the police.

headline: Without Palin to Mock, Prime-Time ‘S.N.L.’ Has Modest Ratings
abstract: In 2008, a special political edition of “Saturday Night Live” drew a huge audience to see Tina Fey’s impersonation of Sarah Palin. On Thursday night, the audience was much smaller, and the comedies that followed didn’t do much better.
lead_paragraph: Political news did not help NBC Thursday night as the first edition of “Saturday Night Live” in prime time for the election year failed to ignite NBC’s comedy lineup.

headline: A Doctor’s Ministry, Bridging Science and Spirit
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Dr. Joseph Dutkowsky, an orthopedic surgeon specializing in the care of children, occupies contested territory, both intellectually and theologically, at the top of his profession.
lead_paragraph: Forty years ago, long before the recent afternoon when Dr. Joseph Dutkowsky knelt at the warped feet of his 4-year-old patient, he was a small-town teenager approaching his Catholic confirmation and needing to select a patron saint. He made an unlikely choice, a newly canonized figure, St. Martin de Porres, the illegitimate child of a former black slave in 16th-century Peru.

headline: A Coffee Shop, as Seen on TV, Becomes a Must-See for South Koreans
abstract: Think Coffee in Greenwich Village has become an unexpected stop for South Korean tourists thanks to the power of television.
lead_paragraph: South Korean tourists come to New York to cruise to the top of the Empire State Building and wander through the exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art. But another must-do activity is a little less expected: a visit to Think Coffee.

headline: Who Is Owed by the United States
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Foreign Investments', 'Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Despite running budget deficits of more than $1 trillion a year, the United States has been able to borrow at very low interest rates. Over the past year, the Federal Reserve, the American central bank, did not buy any Treasury securities, but the government had no trouble raising the needed cash from domestic and foreign investors. That was true even though China, the largest lender to the United States, was selling Treasury securities.
lead_paragraph: Despite running budget deficits of more than $1 trillion a year, the United States has been able to borrow at very low interest rates. Over the past year, the Federal Reserve, the American central bank, did not buy any Treasury securities, but the government had no trouble raising the needed cash from domestic and foreign investors. That was true even though China, the largest lender to the United States, was selling Treasury securities.

headline: Luxembourg by Bike: 3 Days and 100 Miles
abstract: Riding border to border through a dozen towns, picture-perfect farmland and one alphorn trio serenade.
lead_paragraph: IF and when you decide to bicycle across Luxembourg, I cannot promise that you will be rescued from a cloudburst by the unexpected appearance of a tunnel on the bike path, nor that in the tunnel you will be welcomed by an alphorn trio.

headline: Cycling Around Luxembourg
abstract: Follow a reporter’s path across this tiny, scenic country wedged between Belgium and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Follow a reporter’s path across this tiny, scenic country wedged between Belgium and Germany.

headline: Fancy Footwear in Milan
abstract: There was the distinct impression that the designers at Tod’s, the luxury footwear label, have been paying attention to recent trends in footwear.
lead_paragraph: There was the distinct impression that the designers at Tod’s, the luxury footwear label, have been paying attention to recent trends in footwear. At the company’s spring presentation, which was held at an opulent 1930s mansion that is now a museum, a display of loafers came with surprisingly colorful soles, including versions in yellow, burnt orange and green, reflecting a recent trend in men’s shoes.

headline: Cash Crops, Emphasis on the Cash
abstract: The new video game FarmVille 2 is a slicker, more attractive — and more money-hungry — version of the original.
lead_paragraph: From afar, the first FarmVille game on Facebook seemed to be a manipulative horror, a collection of psychological tricks that preyed on our desire to find something predictable in life. It was a simple test that doled out predictable rewards: Plant some seeds with a mouse click, and they would sprout minutes, hours or days later — faster if you paid for them to hurry or if you bugged friends for help.

headline: Voter Harassment, Circa 2012
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Editorials', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Groups aligned with the Tea Party and other conservative causes are using Jim Crow-era tactics at the ballot box.
lead_paragraph: This is how voter intimidation worked in 1966: White teenagers in Americus, Ga., harassed black citizens in line to vote, and the police refused to intervene. Black plantation workers in Mississippi had to vote in plantation stores, overseen by their bosses. Black voters in Choctaw County, Ala., had to hand their ballots directly to white election officials for inspection.

headline: Off the Map in the Black Garden
abstract: On a spartan journey to the breakaway Caucasus region of Nagorno-Karabakh, the author finds ghost cities, mountain tableaus and strands of personal connection to the area.
lead_paragraph: STANDING on a limestone ridge in the foothills of the Lesser Caucasus Mountains, I surveyed the landscape that lay before me. To the west, illuminated by a late-day sun and with ever more craggy peaks as a backdrop, was Vankasar Mountain, capped by a solitary, ancient church. To the east, yellow grassland and scrub stretched to the horizon. And then there was the ghost city of Agdam, its thousands of ruined buildings representing the last exchanges of a late 20th-century conflict that many people have never heard of.

headline: Restaurant Report: La Barrique in Rome
abstract: This spring, La Barrique added a full kitchen to complement its well-chosen wine list. Now, diners can choose from dishes like mint and prawns and rabbit confit.
lead_paragraph: La Barrique, a wine bar in Rome’s Monti district, has improved with age. It opened in 2001 with a fairly basic wine list, but grew more and more sophisticated, ultimately offering one of the city’s most impressive selections of Champagnes, and Italian and German wines. After adding a full kitchen in the spring, La Barrique now offers hot meals, too.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Spoilers
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the sensitive nature of spoilers in movies and television shows.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the sensitive nature of spoilers in movies and television shows.

headline: Scuba Diving In a Cousteau Water World
abstract: Ashlan Gorse, an “E! News Now” anchor, didn’t learn to scuba dive until she met her boyfriend, Philippe Cousteau Jr. Here’s what she’s discovered since then.
lead_paragraph: “I’VE always been a water baby,” said Ashlan Gorse, an anchor for “E! News Now.”

headline: Time Warner Will Carry NFL Network
abstract: Time Warner Cable has agreed to carry the NFL Network after a nine-year impasse.
lead_paragraph: 6:00 p.m. | Updated Time Warner Cable agreed Friday to carry the NFL Network, ending an occasionally contentious nine-year impasse.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Boca in Buenos Aires
abstract: Billed as the first soccer hotel in the world, this new place to stay offers more than just a sports-themed experience.
lead_paragraph: THE UPSHOT

headline: Business Day Live: A Manufacturing About-Face
abstract: Made in Brooklyn, but shipped to China. | Shrinking life expectancy for the least-educated whites.
lead_paragraph: Made in Brooklyn, but shipped to China. | Shrinking life expectancy for the least-educated whites.

headline: Tijuana Rebuilds on Its Art
abstract: Culture is energizing this border town, known for its seedy side. “I think people are starting to believe in art. I think people are starting to believe in Tijuana,” says a gallerist.
lead_paragraph: ANY city whose most widely known symbol is a painted donkey is used to being the butt of jokes. But Tijuana, often derided as a lowbrow center of debauchery and more recently as a hub of drug-related violence, is transforming itself through something that has quietly always been a strong suit: culture.

headline: Fat Dad: Joy in Holiday Recipes
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Yom Kippur']
abstract: Growing up, I always looked forward to the Jewish holidays, even though my family was not religious. Those were pretty much the only times we had real food in our house, since my father was always dieting. Here are a few of my holiday favorites.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I always looked forward to the Jewish holidays, even though my family was not religious. Those were pretty much the only times we had real food in our house, since my father was always dieting.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to articles about seeing fall leaves and shoes for travel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding “Where Fall Deals Grow on Trees” (Sept. 9), I would add Topnotch Resort in Stowe, Vt., to the list of leaf-peeping trips. Perhaps not the least expensive place, but the heated pool facing Mount Mansfield is worth it, especially at sunset! Lake Winnipesaukee, in New Hampshire, is also stunning in early October. In upstate New York, we’re checking out Tahoe Resort in the Adirondacks in a few weeks to leaf-peep and hopefully grab one last swim.

headline: The Getaway: Fee-for-All
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Travel Restrictions', 'HOTELS AND MOTELS', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Have you found your travel bills peppered with extra fees? The Getaway columnist Stephanie Rosenbloom looks at some reasons behind these charges, and offers tips on how to get around them.
lead_paragraph: Have you found your travel bills peppered with extra fees? The Getaway columnist Stephanie Rosenbloom looks at some reasons behind these charges, and offers tips on how to get around them.

headline: Fleeced by Fees When You Travel?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Budget Travel', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'HOTELS AND MOTELS']
abstract: That newspaper at your hotel door? That blanket on the plane? The chair at the beach? They could cost you, whether you know it or not. And it adds up.
lead_paragraph: FEE to hold your airline reservation for a few days: $20. Peak air-travel surcharge: $47. Rental car GPS: $13 a day. Beach chaise longue: $20 a day. Resort fee: $25 a day.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Sept 21
abstract: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the sensitive nature of spoilers in movies and television shows.
lead_paragraph: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the sensitive nature of spoilers in movies and television shows.

headline: Manufacturing Shift
abstract: Business Day Live: Jim Dwyer, ‘About New York’ Columnist, talks to Louise Story about a Brooklyn manufacturer whose custom luxury fixtures have caught the eye of buyers in China.
lead_paragraph: Business Day Live: Jim Dwyer, ‘About New York’ Columnist, talks to Louise Story about a Brooklyn manufacturer whose custom luxury fixtures have caught the eye of buyers in China.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Etro
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: Countless Oktoberfest celebrations are taking place at restaurants, bars and beer gardens around the city. One to notice is OktoberfestNYC, which runs Saturday through Oct. 7 in a pop-up German beer hall at 1 Penn Plaza, at 33rd Street and Eighth Avenue. A 6,000-square-foot tented beer garden will house long tables where German beers and food will be served. The pop-up is open 5 p.m. to midnight Monday through Friday and 11 a.m. to midnight on weekends.

headline: Iranian Dissidents Convince U.S. to Drop Terror Label
abstract: The Mujahedeen Khalq, an opposition group that mounted an extraordinary campaign to get off the State Department’s list of terrorist organizations, has succeeded, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rarely in the annals of lobbying in the capital has so obscure a cause attracted so stellar a group of supporters: former directors of the C.I.A. and the F.B.I., retired generals and famous politicians of both parties.

headline: At Unveiling of Barclays Center, Talk of a Nets Championship
abstract: The Nets held a ceremonial opening at their new arena in Brooklyn, where their owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, predicted a championship within three years.
lead_paragraph: On a stage packed with dignitaries, one man stood tallest, so tall that the microphone had to be raised by a foot to meet his chin. When he spoke, the message was no less striking.

headline: Man Fatally Shot by Police Had Pointed Gun at Officer
abstract: Tyjuan Hill was shot and killed by the police during a scuffle on Thursday that stemmed from a prostitute-solicitation sting operation, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who was shot and killed by a New York City police sergeant Thursday night had pointed a loaded handgun at the sergeant before the shooting, the police said on Friday.

headline: Stargazing, Spies and Clandestine Warmongering in World War II
abstract: Did astrology help ensure Hitler’s defeat?
lead_paragraph: Last month the Israeli astrologer Miriam Binyamini predicted, based on her reading of the stars, that war between Israel and Iran is not imminent. Unsurprisingly, the forecast incited some mockery in the letters section of The Jerusalem Post. “Our defense forces and home front can now relax and breathe a deep sigh of relief,” one correspondent wrote. “However, despite our gratefulness to astrologer Binyamini for the above glad tidings, I feel she was morally remiss for not also activating her star-gazing skills for a matter of lesser importance, but still rather hurtful, when she failed to alert us to the rise of the dollar against the shekel.”

headline: Gentle Soul in a World of Bold Fruit
abstract: In spite of experts’ warnings of its demise, the gran reserva style of Rioja has endured.
lead_paragraph: ONLY a few years ago, some Spanish wine experts were suggesting that the gran reserva style of Rioja would fade to extinction in a decade or so. Their rationale seemed clear. The worldwide consumer swoon in the last 20 years for plush, dark, bountiful flavors had marginalized these smooth, pale, harmonious wines, which are aged for years in barrels and convey their complexities more through finesse and shimmering textures than bold fruit flavors.

headline: Chimney Rock Declared a National Monument
abstract: Nearly 5,000 acres in Colorado will be set aside for protection, which has cultural significance for the modern-day Pueblo and some other tribes.
lead_paragraph: President Obama signed a proclamation on Friday designating nearly 5,000 acres of high desert at Chimney Rock, the site of a striking rock formation in southwestern Colorado, as a national monument. Ken Salazar, the interior secretary, and Tom Vilsack, the agriculture secretary, flew to Colorado for the ceremonial designation.

headline: Taking an Ordinary Dish and Making It Heavenly
abstract: The creamy salt cod dish brandade de morue is considered normal, everyday stuff, but when well prepared, it borders on ethereal.
lead_paragraph: IN France, the creamy salt cod dish called brandade de morue (creamed salt cod), despite its elegant-sounding name, is considered ordinary. Good, but fairly ordinary. As familiar as shepherd’s pie or tuna casserole in North America.

headline: Pommes de Terroir
abstract: The lowly potato is giving root to a lofty food culture in southern Sweden.
lead_paragraph: Near dusk on a summer evening in Cape Bjare, Sweden, I stood in an elegant farmhouse and considered three large bowls of boiled potatoes. These were not hearty russets or Yukon Golds. They were small, delicate new potatoes, three of about two dozen varieties that are grown and harvested young on this green peninsula jutting into the North Sea. My host was Peter Ekelund, a native of Cape Bjare and one of the founders of Absolut Vodka. With farmers from the area, Ekelund has been making a new vodka out of the Cape’s star crop, and he was eager to introduce me to what many here call their “potato culture.” A tasting was in order.

headline: The Caucus Click: Biden Goes Pumpkin Picking
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his wife, Jill, bought a 36-pound pumpkin and some pies at the Spring Ledge Farm Stand in New London, N.H., while campaigning in the swing state on Friday.

headline: No Web Site Is an Island
abstract: A technical malfunction at GoDaddy and an outage at Facebook sent a ripple across the Internet, demonstrating just how complex relationships on the Web have become. A cyberattack or technical snag on one Web site now has the power to take down thousands, if not millions, of other sites.
lead_paragraph: Late one night last June, Facebook’s Web site ground to a halt. All around the Web, thousands of other sites with a Facebook “Like” button slowed to a crawl. Last week, a technical malfunction at GoDaddy took down its Web site and millions more, many of which did not use a GoDaddy service.

headline: From Parents, a Living Inheritance
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Some parents help their adult children financially, while others cannot or do not — and that often unspoken distinction among families can determine who gets ahead.
lead_paragraph: For all of the conversation this week about Mitt Romney’s views on federal income taxes and personal responsibility, his insistence that “I have inherited nothing” may be the most thought-provoking.

headline: Romney Releases 2011 Tax Returns
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Mitt Romney paid $1.95 million in taxes on his 2011 investment income of $13.7 million, his campaign revealed on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Read the most current version of this story here.

headline: Measuring the Achievements of Adults Who Don’t Get Family Financial Help
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Credit and Debt', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: Should people who have had no financial help from their families get more credit for their accomplishments than people who did?
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a look at a group of haves and have-nots we don’t focus on very often: adults who get financial help from their parents and those who do not.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $16 Million
abstract: A six-story, six-bedroom Modernist brick house is on a prime historic block steps from Central Park.
lead_paragraph: A six-story Modernist brick town house that has weathered the burden of an ugly duckling reputation in its relatively short history at 7 East 69th Street sold for $16 million, in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: To the Rescue
abstract: Ben Hatke talks about “Legends of Zita the Spacegirl.”
lead_paragraph: New to the paperback graphic books best-seller list this week is “Legends of Zita the Spacegirl,” by Ben Hatke, at No. 6. It is the second adventure of Zita, an Earth girl, who gets involved in some deep-space adventures. In the first, she had to rescue her best friend. In this one, she must deal with a robot imposter and a “star heart,” a galactic menace that strips down planets to bedrock. Spoiler alert: she comes through with a save, but there are enough loose ends to warrant another installment, which is already in the works. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Hatke talked about his work. (As always, the complete best-seller lists can be found here, along with an explanation of how they are assembled.)

headline: Christopher Columbus Up Close
abstract: “Discovering Columbus” is an apartment built 60 feet over Columbus Circle by the artist Tatzu Nishi.
lead_paragraph: “Discovering Columbus” is an apartment built 60 feet over Columbus Circle by the artist Tatzu Nishi.

headline: Weighing the Right Thing to Do
abstract: Bucks readers discuss whether the potential financial reward of becoming a whistle-blower would outweigh other concerns.
lead_paragraph: As Paul Sullivan recounts in his Wealth Matters column this week, anyone considering the financial rewards of becoming a whistle-blower should fully consider all the possible fallout. A lawyer who has represented whistle-blowers, John Phillips, explained it this way: “You may find yourself unemployable. Home foreclosures, divorce, suicide and depression all go with this territory.”

headline: Charted Waters
abstract: At a sailing school in Ireland, Verlyn Klinkenborg relearns the ropes.
lead_paragraph: We troop down to the harbor at the once industrial end of town, nautical mousquetaires wearing sea boots and knit caps, salopettes and foul-weather jackets, bundled in life vests with crotch straps and tethers. We pass black boot prints tarred with waste oil and a great heap of wharfish refuse, tangles of long-discarded fishing nets, thick manila hawsers. And then we come to the jetty, a wide concrete ramp leading down to the broad water of Baltimore Harbor in the parish of Rath and the Islands, County Cork, Ireland. Two aluminum skiffs are waiting, rafted together. We climb across to the outer skiff, then we’re off to the sailboats. There is a light breeze. The boats rest on their moorings like half-depleted helium balloons.

headline: At His Penthouse, a Tête-à-Tête With Columbus
abstract: With “Discovering Columbus,” an apartment built 60 feet over Columbus Circle in New York City, Tatzu Nishi has achieved a nifty bit of Surrealist displacement.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever wanted to see what the city’s pre-eminent statue of Christopher Columbus looks like standing on a large coffee table in an upscale New York living room with killer views, now is your chance. Under the auspices of the Public Art Fund, the Japanese artist Tatzu Nishi has built a convincingly appointed penthouse-worthy space around the 13-foot-high marble sculpture of Columbus that has presided over Columbus Circle from a height of 60 feet since it was completed by Gaetano Russo in 1892. In doing so, Mr. Nishi has achieved a nifty bit of Surrealist displacement without moving the sculpture an inch — albeit not quite as nifty as I’d hoped.

headline: Wheels Calendar for Sept. 21-23
abstract: Racecars rally outside of Olympia, Wash., Ford trucks kick up mud in Tennesee and British cars convene in the Catskills this weekend.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: The Jesus Conspiracy
abstract: The Gospel of Judas, Jesus’s wife, and the paranoid style in Jesus scholarship.
lead_paragraph: It’s been six years since National Geographic revealed, amid much fanfare and discussion, the existence of a heretofore-unknown document that seemed to retell the New Testament narrative from the point of view of Judas Iscariot. That experience should have been a cautionary tale about the intersection of Biblical archaeology and media sensationalism: The first wave of coverage suggested that the document painted Judas as a misunderstood hero who was “only obeying his master’s wishes when he betrayed Jesus with a kiss,” but the evidence soon mounted that this sensationalistic claim relied on dubious translation decisions, and that the Judas in the fragmentary gospel might well actually be the embodiment of a Gnostic “king of demons” rather than Jesus’s most loyal friend.

headline: Obama and Ryan Trade Blasts Over Medicare at AARP Convention
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: President Obama and Representative Paul D. Ryan each accused the other of posing a threat to the future of the Medicare program, with Mr. Obama getting a better reception.
lead_paragraph: WOODBRIDGE, Va. — President Obama traded charges with Representative Paul D. Ryan on Friday over the financing of Medicare, as each candidate sought to appeal to older voters by warning them, with arguments both familiar and new, that his opponent would threaten the future of this signature federal health care program.

headline: A Letter to My Friend Glen Doherty
abstract: A Navy SEAL says goodbye to his best friend, Glen Doherty, who was killed during the attack on the American mission in Benghazi, Libya.
lead_paragraph: Glen A. Doherty, a security contractor and former member of the Navy SEALs, was killed in Libya on Sept. 12, 2012, while defending the American Mission in Benghazi, Libya. During a memorial service for Mr. Doherty and the three other Americans killed in the attack — the Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, Tyrone S. Woods and Sean Smith — President  Obama said of Mr. Doherty: “He believed that his life he could make a difference, a calling that he fulfilled as a Navy SEAL…in Benghazi, as he tended to others, he laid down his life, loyal as always, protecting his friends.”

headline: Bonus Riff: Ladies and Gentlemen, Please Welcome the Internet
abstract: “The Internet is a web of networks with shared software standards, allowing users on one network to reach anywhere into a global thicket.” — The Times, 1993.
lead_paragraph: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fxfhInhkvtM

headline: A List of N.H.L. Players Heading Overseas

headline: Greenland’s ‘Ice Quakes’ May Set a Record
abstract: Glacial earthquakes have been spreading northward, from the warmer southern parts of Greenland to the colder northern parts, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: One of the more amazing facts about the ongoing destruction of the Greenland ice sheet is that it is producing earthquakes that can be detected worldwide. Now, fresh evidence is at hand to show that these “ice quakes” are spreading to previously quiescent parts of Greenland. We’re only in September, but it seems increasingly likely that 2012 will set a record for such quakes.

headline: Europe Hints at Impatience in Settling Google Case
abstract: The top antitrust regulator for the European Union said there were limits to how much longer his office would try to negotiate a settlement with Google over its Internet search engine.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s top antitrust regulator, Joaquín Almunia, said Friday that there were limits to how much longer his office would try to negotiate a settlement with Google over whether its Internet search engine favored the company’s own Web offerings to the detriment of competitors.

headline: BP Offers to Acquire Larger Stake in Rosneft
abstract: The giant oil company BP said it would enlarge the stake if it could first sell its interests in a private joint venture in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — BP has offered to acquire a bigger stake in the Russian state oil company Rosneft if it can sell its interests in a private joint venture here, the president of Rosneft said on Friday.

headline: Ed Weeks of ‘The Mindy Project’
abstract: Ed Weeks has moved to Los Angeles from London for his American breakthrough in the new comedy “The Mindy Project.”
lead_paragraph: COULD it really have been so simple? A handsome Londoner arrives in Hollywood not far into a career as a writer and player on comedy shows like “Olivia Lee: Dirty, Sexy, Funny” and as half of the sketch duo Tommy and the Weeks. Soon he has sold a script to a major network and then snagged a leading role in one of the season’s most anticipated sitcoms on another.

headline: Emmys Watch: Damian Lewis on ‘Homeland’ and ‘The Forsyte Saga’
abstract: Damian Lewis discusses fake tans, first fans and the new season of “Homeland.”
lead_paragraph: We have been talking to Emmy nominees leading up to the awards show on Sunday night. Previous entries in this series include Don Roy King, the director of “Saturday Night Live”; Abi Morgan, nominated for writing “The Hour”; Christine Baranski, nominated for best supporting actress for “The Good Wife”; and Jesse Tyler Ferguson, nominated for best supporting actor for “Modern Family.”

headline: Living Along | The West Side Highway
abstract: An area transformed with the help of newer condos, some of them gleaming high-rises, others converted from older buildings.
lead_paragraph: An area transformed with the help of newer condos, some of them gleaming high-rises, others converted from older buildings.

headline: On the Waterfront, Minus the Stevedores
abstract: The area along the West Side Highway has become a mostly residential enclave, with the Hudson River Park offering a verdant front yard in the place of vanished piers.
lead_paragraph: IN the landscape of modern New York, there is much that might bemuse a time traveler visiting from the past.

headline: Taking the Long View of Cinerama
abstract: One new Blu-ray DVD, “This Is Cinerama,” commemorates an ultra-wide-screen experience, and another remembers Cinemiracle, a Cinerama imitator.
lead_paragraph: THE commercial life span of Cinerama was relatively short, roughly from 1952 to 1962, although the trademark continued to be applied to a number of less dazzling wide-screen processes until 1974. But for those who have experienced the full grandeur of its folly — three strips of 35-millimeter film, projected side by side on a giant, curved screen that effectively took possession of the spectator’s full range of peripheral vision — Cinerama endures as a transporting, almost mystical experience.

headline: At Holocaust Center, Hollande Confronts Past
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: In his address at the memorial, President François Hollande urged the nation to turn to the “transmission,” or passing on, of a difficult history.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande inaugurated a new Holocaust memorial center on Friday with an address that underscored the direct approach he has taken to France’s collaborationist past, a grim and still uncomfortable chapter that French leaders and politicians have often preferred to skirt.

headline: As the U.S. Borrows, Who Lends?
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Government Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Over the last year, China and the Fed have reduced holdings of United States Treasury securities as Japan has bought more.
lead_paragraph: A YEAR ago, when the United States government was borrowing huge amounts of money and paying very low interest rates to do it, critics scoffed that a lot of Treasury bonds were being purchased by China, and even more of them were ending up in the hands of the Federal Reserve, the American central bank.

headline: India’s Premier Pleads for Support of His Plans in Televised Address
abstract: The prime minister made a rare televised address to defend steps he has taken to revive the economy that have prompted anger and protests.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Manmohan Singh made a rare nationwide televised appeal on Friday night to defend a series of unpopular measures, intended to revive the floundering Indian economy, that have stirred mass protests across the country and almost toppled his coalition government.

headline: Facebook Can ID Faces, but Using Them Grows Tricky

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook on Friday confronted a new obstacle over what to do with one of its most vital assets — pictures.

headline: Turkish Court Convicts 330 From Military in Coup Case
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The officers, including three former top generals sentenced to 20 years each, had been accused of planning to overthrow the government nearly a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Turkish court convicted 330 military officers, including three former top commanders, and sentenced them to prison terms of as long as 20 years on Friday after a trial in which they were accused of a wide-ranging plot to overthrow the government nearly a decade ago. Thirty-four were acquitted.

headline: What’s at Stake in Massachusetts
abstract: Even when Senator Scott Brown votes for sensible bills, he is overwhelmed by other members of his party who routinely kill them.
lead_paragraph: Senator Scott Brown portrayed himself as the model of a modern moderate in last night’s Massachusetts Senate debate, reminding listeners of the many bipartisan positions he has taken since filling Teddy Kennedy’s seat. And his opponent, Elizabeth Warren, had the strongest possible retort: it doesn’t matter.

headline: A Star Turn for Graham Zusi
abstract: Graham Zusi is enjoying a breakout season for Kansas City and is a major reason the club will be in contention for both the M.L.S Cup and the Supporter’s Shield, which is awarded to the team with the most points in the regular season.
lead_paragraph: As Sporting Kansas City easily defeated the Red Bulls on Wednesday night to pad their lead in the Eastern Conference, it also reaffirmed that Graham Zusi is indeed one of the league’s best players.

headline: A Bus Called Wanda
abstract: Telling tales across Georgia.
lead_paragraph: There were scorch marks on the landing outside the guest room at cousin Alvin’s, but I slept well on the first night in Savannah, Ga. A young woman named Elna Baker was in the bedroom across the landing. The next afternoon someone let on that my room was where “that young man set himself on fire, though he died across the hall in the kitchen” and added that Elna’s room was where “that poor heartbroken girl killed herself.” I didn’t tell Elna, but nor did I sleep at all on the second night. I’d wanted to go deep into the heart of storytelling, and now, clearly, I was there.

headline: Evolving Species
abstract: What do 30,000 Australian wool growers have in common with Jackie Kennedy’s favorite pajama maker?
lead_paragraph: WHAT do 30,000 Australian wool growers have in common with Jackie Kennedy’s favorite pajama maker? Now there’s a stretch. But, along with the dinners and parties (on Friday, a performance by Beth Ditto at the Versace house), there is a second tier of events, mainly to promote new collaborations, start-up labels or, in the case of a Woolmark event, merino wool and its long connection to Italian fashion.

headline: So You Want to Be a Broker
abstract: There are 20,000 real estate agents in New York City. Three new sales agents tell why they are getting into the business.
lead_paragraph: ROBIN GOLDBERG, a sales associate at Sotheby’s International Realty, became a licensed agent after making a midlife career change in December 2010: she is, she says, in her 50s and previously worked in finance and fashion. A native New Yorker who grew up in the Bronx, she has lived in a loft in Little Italy for 35 years; her husband, Richard Goldberg, is a wine consultant, and they have two children, 18 and 21.

headline: Jets’ Scott Threatens Reporter
abstract: Linebacker Bart Scott told a reporter in the Jets’ locker room on Friday that he would smack him.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – Jets linebacker Bart Scott had to be restrained by a team media-relations official Friday after threatening to punch a reporter in the locker room. The altercation began when the reporter, Dan Leberfeld of Jets Confidential, tried taking a photograph of Scott, who has staged a boycott of the news media for the last three weeks, while he casually chatted with a reporter.

lead_paragraph: Reaction to Thursday’s announcement by the Cuomo administration that New York State must review potential public health effects before deciding whether to allow fracking is split along fairly predictable lines.

headline: Now Online | T Fall Travel 2012
abstract: The fall issue of travel provides a different lens on some familiar places and experiences.
lead_paragraph: The fall travel issue of T begins in Tel Aviv, where we visit Claire Danes on the set of the hit spy series, “Homeland.” Next it’s off to Cape Bjare, Sweden, for a look at how the peninsula’s prized potatoes are giving root to a new culinary scene. Such specialization is an art in Tokyo, our third stop, where restaurants and bars with a fascinatingly specific focus — one establishment is dedicated entirely to Tom Waits — break down the city’s vastness. Along the way, we check into Panama City’s hottest hotels, meet the young winemakers who are putting California’s Central Coast on the map and take the pulse in Montreal’s hippest neighborhood. Finally, we set sail at a French boating academy in Ireland with Verlyn Klinkenborg, and Joan Juliet Buck goes on tour with The Moth. See more from the issue >>

headline: Editor’s Letter
abstract: I hope this issue, which was expertly and elegantly conceived by Jeffries Blackerby, provides a different lens on some familiar places and experiences.
lead_paragraph: A number of months ago, my colleagues Abby Aguirre and Jane Herman began making the case that there were things afoot on California’s central coast, good things, which merited real attention. I balked. They agitated. Both of them are from California and alert to and delighted by developments back home. I am also a Californian, though that has led me to be a bit blasé about the state’s significant charms. (I know: when one is tired of redwoods, one is tired of life.) Abby and Jane prevailed, of course, and Tanvi Chheda was dispatched to produce a guide to the region. This August, as I drove up Highway 1, I followed Chheda’s suggestions to the word — and the olive oil and the apricot. It was a gift. I saw an area I have taken for granted my whole life (in that way natives do) in an utterly gorgeous, entirely new light.

abstract: Much of the cast for the show came together to record a video tied to the campaign of Bridget Mary McCormack for the Michigan Supreme Court. Ms McCormack’s sister, Mary McCormack, was also on the show and in the video.

headline: Romney’s Taxes Compared With Everyone Else’s
abstract: The Romneys paid a higher effective tax rate than the average middle-income American, though a significantly lower rate than the average rich, or very rich, American.
lead_paragraph: The Romney campaign revealed Friday afternoon that Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, paid a 14.1 percent effective federal tax rate in 2011, paying $1.9 million in taxes on $13.7 million in income, much of it from investments. (That $13.7 million in income most likely puts him in the top 0.01 percent of earners, by the way.)

Each model year brings new models to fill showroom spaces vacated by cars and trucks that have been discontinued. For 2013, more than a dozen nameplates will not be returning, and two automotive brands have also expired.

Ryan faced a tough and at some points hostile audience on Friday at the AARP convention here, drawing applause when he introduced his mother but eliciting wide boos and shouts of “No!” when he called for the repeal of Obamacare, as well as scattered shouts of “47 percent” and “liar” as he attacked other aspects of President Obama’s policies.

headline: Avoiding Sugared Drinks Limits Weight Gain in Two Studies
abstract: New York City’s ban on large sweetened beverages has been hotly disputed, but these clinical trials show that replacing sugary drinks can slow weight gain in children.
lead_paragraph: Amid fervid criticism that New York City risks becoming a nanny state, city health officials this month banned the sale of supersize sugar-laden drinks in restaurants and movie theaters. Now scientists have handed the ban’s advocates a potent weapon: strong evidence that replacing sugared drinks with sugar-free substitutes or water really can slow weight gain in children.

headline: NBC Gets Early but Mixed Results for New Shows
abstract: A look at the ratings for NBC’s new slate of shows offers mixed news for the also-ran network.
lead_paragraph: With the other broadcast television networks opting to roll out most of their fall programming later in the season, NBC has taken the opposite tack by unveiling most of its new shows right out of the gate. The results so far? Mixed.

headline: An Award and More Support for Pussy Riot
abstract: The husband of one of the jailed members of the Russian punk group accepts the LennonOno Grant for Peace on the group’s behalf.
lead_paragraph: The husband of a jailed member of Pussy Riot, the Russian feminist punk-rock group, received an award from Yoko Ono and Amnesty International in New York on Friday. Pyotr Verzilov, the husband of Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, accepted the LennonOno Grant for Peace from Ms. Ono at Liberty Hall in the Ace Hotel. Actually, Mr. Verzilov’s and Ms. Tolokonnikova’s daughter, 4-year-old Gara, accepted the glass sculpture, twirling with it in her pink velveteen dress.

headline: For a Big Band, the Road Is Like Home

headline: Man Mauled After Leaping Into Tiger Area at Bronx Zoo
abstract: The 25-year-old man who jumped into the habitat from the monorail suffered “a severe bite to the leg” and cuts to his back and was in critical condition, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:30 p.m. | The monorail glided through the hilly and leafy Bronx Zoo as riders settled in Friday afternoon to enjoy a close-up view of 43 wooded acres, hoping to glimpse antelopes, rhinoceroses, elephants and other exotic Asian animals.

headline: So Which Borough Is Baker Street In?
abstract: Jonny Lee Miller joins a long line of actors interpreting the role of Sherlock Holmes, in CBS’s new modern-day series “Elementary.”
lead_paragraph: SHERLOCK HOLMES, popular culture’s most famous private detective, may not be an actor-proof role, but almost anybody can play it once — anybody, that is, with a passable English accent; a long, narrow face; a penetrating gaze; and the ability to rattle off complicated sentences at head-splitting speed. In the movies the great sleuth has been portrayed by, among others, Michael Caine, Christopher Plummer, Nicol Williamson, Robert Stephens, John Neville, Jonathan Pryce, Peter Cushing, Ian Richardson, and, most recently, Robert Downey Jr., all of whom sensibly took the part in just one or two films. (Mr. Downey has bravely signed on for a third.) The true test of a Holmes, though, is whether an actor’s interpretation can bear the weight of repetition, because Holmes was, after all, a series character, who appeared in 56 short stories and 4 novels between 1887 and 1927. The author Arthur Conan Doyle sometimes wearied of the character, and once even tried to kill him off, but the public wouldn’t allow Doyle to leave his hero forever at the bottom of the Reichenbach Falls. Holmes came back, and has been coming back ever since, again and again and again.

headline: Charting OG Ron C on Frank Ocean
abstract: The Houston DJ and record executive OG Ron C gives Frank Ocean’s acclaimed debut album, “Channel Orange,” the chopped-and-screwed subgenre treatment.
lead_paragraph: On a new mixtape, the Houston DJ and record executive OG Ron C gives Frank Ocean’s acclaimed debut album, “Channel Orange,” the chopped-and-screwed subgenre treatment. Called “Channel Purple,” the remix slices and dices the music, slows it to a crawl and stretches it out like rubber. The artist Andrew Kuo charts his reaction. (Frank Ocean performs at the I’ll Be Your Mirror festival, presented by All Tomorrow’s Parties, at Pier 36 in New York on Friday night.)

headline: Final Debate: McCain and Obama
abstract: The final debate between John McCain and Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: The final debate between John McCain and Barack Obama.

headline: Melky Cabrera Is Out of Race for Hitting Title
abstract: It took a rule change, but Melky Cabrera, who is serving a 50-game suspension, will not be eligible for the National League batting title.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball and the players union changed a rule on Friday regarding batting titles, and outfielder Melky Cabrera of the San Francisco Giants is no longer eligible for the award.

headline: Endeavour Arrives in Los Angeles
abstract: The space shuttle Endeavour is taking the last flight of its 20-year career, a three-day victory lap across the country on the back of a transport aircraft.
lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour is taking the last flight of its 20-year career, a three-day victory lap across the country on the back of a transport aircraft.

headline: The Coldest Journey on Earth
abstract: This week, Sir Ranulph Fiennes, the world’s greatest living explorer, announced he will lead a team of six men to make the first crossing of Antarctica during the Antarctic winter. This is one of the last great journeys remaining on our planet.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Kumar, a physician and researcher at Concordia Station, writes from Antarctica, where he conducts scientific experiments for the European Space Agency’s human spaceflight program.

headline: Ann Romney’s Plane Makes Emergency Landing
abstract: A private plane carrying Ann Romney, the wife of Mitt Romney, made an emergency landing in Denver on Friday afternoon after the cabin filled with smoke.
lead_paragraph: 10:15 p.m. | Updated A private plane carrying Ann Romney, the wife of Mitt Romney, made an emergency landing in Denver on Friday afternoon after the cabin filled with smoke.

headline: Glacier Retreat Prompts Vatican Approval of New Alpine Ice Prayer
abstract: Swiss villagers convinced the Vatican to allow them to change a glacier prayer to keep up with climate change.
lead_paragraph: 5:30 p.m. | Updated with a tweet |Jack Cushman, a Times journalist with a longstanding interest in the environment, just sent me a recent National Geographic web feature on a Vatican decision, prompted by the warming climate, to approve a change in a centuries-old annual Catholic ritual and prayer in a couple of villages high in the Swiss Alps. The longstanding rite was aimed at stopping the rapid advance of nearby glaciers during a period now called the Little Ice Age. Now, with the glaciers rapidly retreating, the revised prayer speaks of the value of the ice.

headline: The Week in Pictures for the New York Region for Sept. 21
abstract: Subjects include the one-year anniversary of Occupy Wall Street, an unconventional walking tour from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport and a cyclotron’s arrival at the New-York Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the one-year anniversary of Occupy Wall Street, an unconventional walking tour from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport and a cyclotron’s arrival at the New-York Historical Society.

headline: Get-Out-the-Vote Ad Campaign Focuses on Protecting the Right to Vote
abstract: The National Urban League campaign, which includes a range of celebrities, is more than a typical “be sure to vote in November” pitch.
lead_paragraph: In presidential election years, late September and early October usually bring a wave of conventional public service advertising campaigns that are intended to encourage Americans to vote in November. A campaign scheduled to begin on Monday, from the National Urban League, adds an element that is torn from today’s headlines.

headline: Reviewing the Mazda CX-5
abstract: The CX-5 is an important vehicle for Mazda, as it continues to roll out the Skyactiv technology that should help it meet federal fuel economy standards. The crossover is certainly efficient, but it sacrifices power.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Cheryl Jensen reviews the 2013 Mazda CX-5, the new compact crossover positioned to challenge longtime segment leaders like the Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4 and Ford Escape.

keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Camps and Camping', 'Canoes and Canoeing']
abstract: Couples are renting summer camps as post-Labor Day or pre-Memorial Day wedding destinations.
lead_paragraph: FOR some wedding couples, Labor Day’s passing simply signals that there is still plenty of time to lace up those sneakers, pack the bug spray and wed at a summer camp.

headline: Follow Our Live College Football Blog on Saturday
abstract: Paul Myerberg of The Times is back Saturday to host the best college watch party in the country and offer up his analysis and insights on all of the big games and a lot of the not so big ones.
lead_paragraph: The only thing better than watching college football on Saturday is watching the games with your friends on a college football Saturday. Paul Myerberg of The Times is back Saturday to host the best college watch party in the country and offer up his own analysis and insights on all of the big games and a lot of the not so big ones.

headline: The Etiquette of Electric Car Ownership
abstract: What to do when your electric car needs a charge and all the available plugs are taken?
lead_paragraph: Imagine, for a minute, you pull into a gas station near your workplace in the morning with your gas warning light on and a long drive ahead of you after work. You drive toward the pumps hoping to fill up, but every one of them is occupied — and the drivers of all the other cars have wandered off to chat or buy something in the convenience store, so that every hose is in use.

abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Taxes Are Not a Charitable Donation
abstract: Apparently, Mitt Romney really doesn’t see much difference between giving to charity and giving to the government.
lead_paragraph: Almost all federal taxpayers who itemize their charitable deductions on their returns deduct the full amount, in order to keep their tax burden as low as possible. Mitt Romney didn’t do that in 2011, according to tax returns released today, leaving $1.8 million un-deducted so he could tell voters he paid a federal tax rate of at least 13 percent. That’s a luxury reserved only for wealthy politicians who can afford to pay an extra few hundred thousand for image purposes.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Sept. 21
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Cloaked in the Horror of a Double Murder
abstract: A mother and daughter move into a house in a neighborhood with a grim history in this unwieldy hybrid of “Psycho” and standard teenage horror films.
lead_paragraph: The decrepit structure that gives the risible “House at the End of the Street” its title is a gloomy, seemingly unoccupied home that has remained vacant since a mommy and a daddy were murdered there by their daughter, who was supposedly brain-damaged in an accident.

headline: Court Told of ‘Risk Seeking’ on UBS Desk
abstract: The American manager of Kweku M. Adoboli, a former UBS trader on trial on fraud and false accounting charges, testified on Friday in a London court.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The American manager of Kweku M. Adoboli, a former UBS trader, told a court here on Friday that he was surprised by the size of some of the positions on the bank’s London trading floor.

headline: I Was a Welfare Mother
abstract: Applying for government benefits was exactly a way of taking responsibility for myself and my son during a difficult time in our lives.
lead_paragraph: Bethel, Conn.

headline: Heedlessly Romantic
abstract: The actions of courtship are particularly difficult to parse when viewed through the prism of etiquette.
lead_paragraph: YOUNG love burns bright. But fast moves drop jaws. Consider the perturbations of Taylor Swift this summer.

headline: Letters Inspire an Intertwining of Boulez and Cage
abstract: Just as Cage-centenary saturation is about to set in for some music lovers, the Composer Portraits series brings works by him and Boulez to the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: The centenary of the great American avant-garde composer John Cage this year has brought a torrential outpouring of tribute concerts: a timely reaction that has been as welcome as it has been slightly bewildering, given Cage’s still-contentious status among a broad general audience. For new-music partisans, at least, the development has been an unbounded cornucopia. (Who would ever have imagined a year in which Cage oversaturation might threaten to set in?)

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A three-bedroom stand-alone condo in Stamford, Conn., and a two-bedroom loft condo in Hoboken, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom stand-alone condo in Stamford, Conn., and a two-bedroom loft condo in Hoboken, N.J.
