abstract: A Harlem condo, an Upper West Side co-op and a Williamsburg town house.
lead_paragraph: A Harlem condo, an Upper West Side co-op and a Williamsburg town house.

headline: Tip Sheet | How to Transform Design Skills Into a Career
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Careers and Professions', 'Design', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Kara M. Taussig, an admissions adviser for Harrington College of Design in Chicago, offers a few career considerations for the creative and curious.
lead_paragraph: Kara M. Taussig is an admissions adviser for Harrington College of Design in Chicago.

headline: University of Shmacked
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Parties (Social)', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A series of “I’m Shmacked” party videos on YouTube presents the highlights and low moments of college life in full color.
lead_paragraph: THE first “I’m Shmacked” college video appeared a year ago. Featuring Temple University students bubbling up a bong, throwing back shots and eating pizza before a hip-hop concert in Philadelphia, it gave viewers a rare glimpse inside at least one part of that school’s social life, a college culture that obviously includes, not too surprisingly, drugs, drinking and dancing.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Versace
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a curvy, strappy heel.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Producer Says New Financing Is Lined Up
abstract: Ben Sprecher, the lead producer, would not identify the new investors in the show, one of the most troubled in Broadway history.
lead_paragraph: A lead producer of the $12 million Broadway musical “Rebecca” said on Friday that he had received new financial commitments from investors to make up a $4.5 million gap in its capitalization budget, and that he had informed cast members that rehearsals could start next week. The investment contracts, however, are still awaiting signatures, according to the producer, Ben Sprecher, who had to cancel an earlier Broadway outing of “Rebecca” last winter because of a lack of funds.

headline: An Opera Better Heard Than Seen
abstract: “Einstein on the Beach,” the 1976 Philip Glass and Robert Wilson operatic spectacle, endures more for its music than for its staging.
lead_paragraph: I can’t count the number of times I have sat at my computer, opened YouTube and typed a strange phrase into the search box: “knee 1.”

headline: He’s Playing Our Song
abstract: He told me there was someone loving me all those years. Him.
lead_paragraph: ONE Monday night in May three years ago, I was waiting outside Enid’s, the best macaroni and cheese joint in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, for yet another mystery date to arrive.

headline: Comfort Food à la Grecque
abstract: MP Taverna offers Greek cuisine in a casual, spacious atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: MICHAEL PSILAKIS, the chef at Anthos, in Manhattan, showed diners that Greek food could be as sophisticated and creative as any other cuisine. The upscale restaurant, which he opened with Donatella Arpaia, won a Michelin star, laudatory reviews and the fervent gratitude of city foodies.

headline: Singing From the Heart
abstract: Barbra Streisand raises funds for her heart health center in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: IT’S as if she never went away.

headline: Video: How to Make Frico
abstract: The Italian cheese crisp is easy to make and lends itself to endless variations.
lead_paragraph: This week’s column is all about how to make frico — an Italian cheese crisp. Once you get the basic frico recipe down, it’s the kind of thing that lends itself to endless variations. Adding zucchini, as I did here, is one way to go, but there are so many others. Here are some examples to get your creative juices flowing:

headline: A Late-Night Option for Mideast Classics
abstract: Efes Mediterranean Grill, opened by three brothers originally from Turkey, offers a solid menu of traditional recipes at a bargain price.
lead_paragraph: EFES MEDITERRANEAN GRILL is the kind of restaurant everyone wants in the neighborhood, with a simple, satisfying menu, bargain prices and hours of operation that extend until midnight.

headline: A Day Later, Collins Takes It Back
abstract: A day after seeming to question his players’ commitment following a 16-1 loss, the Mets’ manager Terry Collins has expressed regret for questioning their integrity.
lead_paragraph: Late Thursday night, Terry Collins, simmering with anger, seemed to question the commitment of his players after the Mets were trounced by the Philadelphia Phillies, 16-1.

headline: Congressmen Seek More Oversight of U.S. Antidoping Agency
abstract: Two members of Congress introduced legislation that they said would bolster athletes’ due process protections during doping cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two veteran members of Congress introduced bipartisan legislation Friday that would increase Congressional oversight of the United States Anti-Doping Agency, including forcing the agency to provide annual summaries of its enforcement activities.

headline: From Blossom to Amy but Still Always Mayim
abstract: Mayim Bialik, star of the 1990s TV show “Blossom,” is now an Emmy nominee for best supporting actress for her role as the deadpan neurobiologist in “The Big Bang Theory.”
lead_paragraph: IT is 9:30 on a weekday morning, and the scene inside the one-bedroom house in Los Angeles’s Studio City neighborhood feels like an advertisement for the neo-hippie home-schooling life.

headline: Angry Libyans Target Militias, Forcing Flight
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: Thousands of Libyans marched through Benghazi and seized control of the headquarters of several militias, demanding that they be disarmed after an American ambassador was killed.
lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Galvanized by anger over the killing of the popular American ambassador here last week, thousands of Libyans marched through this city on Friday, demanding the disarming of the militias that helped topple the dictatorship but have troubled the country with their refusal to disband.

headline: Chic in Review | Lana Del Rey’s Ode to H&M
abstract: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Poking Fun at Apple’s New Maps
abstract: Now that plenty of iPhone customers have had a chance to use the new Apple maps for a few days, the reactions have been strong, and often sarcastic.
lead_paragraph: When Apple introduced iOS 6, its latest mobile operating system, on Wednesday, it made one of the biggest changes to the software in years: It replaced Google’s maps with its own. And now that plenty of iPhone customers have had a chance to use the new Apple maps for a few days, the reactions have been strong — and often sarcastic.

headline: Breakdown: The Lab Race
abstract: At a time when the racing industry is in crisis over the widespread doping of racehorses, testing laboratories play a vital role in cleaning up the sport.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the racing industry is in crisis over the widespread doping of racehorses, testing laboratories play a vital role in cleaning up the sport.

headline: Indiana at the Forefront of Drug Testing
abstract: Indiana has one of the most comprehensive out-of-competition test programs of race horses in the country.
lead_paragraph: Indiana has one of the most comprehensive out-of-competition test programs of race horses in the country.

headline: Team Matches at Buffett Cup
abstract: After the usual team, pair and individual events, the Buffett Cup featured an extra set of seven-board team matches.
lead_paragraph: The Buffett Cup, bridge’s version of the Ryder Cup, had an additional competition this year. After the usual team, pair and individual events, there was an extra set of seven-board team matches. The 12 points at stake were divided 6 and 6, so this did not affect the final result, a victory by the United States.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Nap Time
abstract: Pajama pantsuits were out in force on many guests attending the recent New York collections.
lead_paragraph: Pajama pantsuits were out in force on many guests attending the recent New York collections.

headline: A Time for Gazing at Navels, as Well as a Few Other Things
abstract: The Live Arts Festival in Philadelphia features a few shows with nudity, both real and figurative.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — “I think that nudity is a cyclical phenomenon,” muses the dead rocker Jim Morrison, cavorting in a funky green room in purgatory in the dance-theater piece “27,” at the Live Arts Festival here. “In the realm of art and theater I do think that I’m not personally convinced that nudity is always a necessary part of a play or film. But I do think that the artist should feel free to use it if he feels like it.”

headline: A Burly Eccentric, an Aging Rogue and a Star Swooping in for the Kill
abstract: Noche Flamenca’s ensemble numbers look better at the midsize Joyce Theater, which is less intimate than the troupe’s previous performance spaces.
lead_paragraph: There are artists from whom we expect novelty, development. We want to see what they’ll come up with next, how they’ll grow. Soledad Barrio is not that kind. What we want from her is more of the same. And what’s amazing is how she always delivers.

headline: A Mix of Influences From the Southwest
abstract: According to the executive chef, Timothy Scott, Geronimo in New Haven serves the cuisine of Santa Fe, N.M., with Apache, Navajo, Mexican and Anglo-American influences.
lead_paragraph: THE bar scene at Geronimo Tequila Bar and Southwest Grill in New Haven is exuberant. The restaurant sells more than 300 varieties of tequila and 27 of mezcal, and excellent margaritas are downed by the glass or the pitcher in a dizzying array of flavors and shades. A lively buzz spills from the spacious patio bar, and an arriving stranger — already cheery — greeted me with a hug as I departed one weekday evening. Can such a place also offer good food? Not every dish is a winner, but many are sensational.

headline: Week in Pictures for Sept. 21
abstract: Subjects include the first anniversary of Occupy Wall Street, an unconventional walking tour from Manhattan to Kennedy Airport, and a cyclotron’s arrival at the New-York Historical Society.

headline: Come for the Drinks, Stay for the Drama, at the Public
abstract: The Public Theater is nearing completion of a $40 million renovation that adds a bar and a lounge, among other features.
lead_paragraph: Not everyone at the Public Theater was thrilled about plans to put a snack bar smack-dab in the center of Joe Papp’s historic theater lobby. But Oskar Eustis, the Public’s artistic director, considered it important. “There is nothing that will make people congregate like food and beverage,” he said. “If we have that, people will stay around.”

headline: Padres Watch as Minor Leaguer Powers Israel
abstract: Nate Freiman hit two two-run homers on Friday afternoon to lead Israel over Spain and reach the World Baseball Classic qualifying tournament’s title game.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — Israel’s hopes of qualifying for the World Baseball Classic’s main draw in March are following the same path as Nate Freiman’s home runs, which is to say the team is ascending quickly.

headline: Blowing a Kiss Toward Asia
abstract: Cathy Horyn reviews the Prada, Versace, Etro and MaxMara collections shown during Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: MILAN

headline: Russia Moves to Broaden Definition of High Treason
abstract: The lower house of Parliament approved the measure, which characterizes acts that undermine “constitutional order, sovereignty and territorial and state integrity” as high treason.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s lower house of Parliament on Friday unanimously approved amendments substantially broadening the legal definition of high treason, so it applies not only to acts that jeopardize state security but also to those that undermine “constitutional order, sovereignty, and territorial and state integrity.”

headline: Bigger Bottles Find Their Place
abstract: A few wines from Long Island are being sold in magnums, and one producer is bottling wine by the liter.
lead_paragraph: Most wines made on Long Island are sold in a standard 750-milliliter bottle; larger bottles are a low priority for most vintners there because they tend to be costly and sell slowly when they contain premium wines. A few wines made on the Island, however, are sold in magnums, which contain one and a half liters, and one producer is bottling wine by the liter.

headline: Four L.I.U. Players Suspended After Being Accused of Assault
abstract: Four Long Island University basketball players, including last season’s Northeast Conference player of the year, have been suspended from the team indefinitely after being arrested Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Four Long Island University basketball players, including last season’s Northeast Conference player of the year, have been suspended from the team indefinitely after being arrested Thursday night and accused of being involved in a fight on campus.

headline: Looking Back at a Massacre in Lebanon
abstract: Responses to an Op-Ed essay about a 1982 rampage at two Palestinian refugee camps.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Remembering Anna Piaggi’s Ability to Inspire
abstract: The Italian editor Anna Piaggi was perhaps the last great example of a fashion eccentric who managed to inspire designers as much as she was inspired by them.
lead_paragraph: The flashbulbs have not dimmed for a moment in the front rows of Milan Fashion Week despite the notable absence this season of the late Italian editor Anna Piaggi, perhaps the last great example of a fashion eccentric who managed to inspire designers as much as she was inspired by them.

headline: F1 Drivers Interrogate the Press
abstract: Formula One drivers arrived in Singapore to take part in the series’ only night race, and it felt during the press meetings as if the night-hours had made some of them drop their usual barriers to expressing their skepticism toward the media.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Formula One has arrived in Singapore for its only night race of the year, and that means the whole paddock is kind of out-of-step. Most of the Formula One drivers, team personnel and reporters are living on European time as just about all the track action takes place on European time, although it’s six hours later in Singapore — that is in the dark. The result of this strange time lag is that there is something of a mood change amongst the denizens of F1.

headline: Seafood and More, in Old-Fashioned Décor
abstract: Rockin’ Fish, in Northport, serves one menu all day, but it’s filled with bargain-price appetizers, hit entrees and crowd-pleasing desserts.
lead_paragraph: ROCKIN’ FISH tried to open quietly, without fanfare, on July 1, but by the end of the day, the small Northport storefront had served around 300 meals, according to Rob Haddow, the owner and chef, speaking on the phone after my visits.

headline: Hunt Ends for a Nazi Now Believed to Be Dead
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: A German court accepted as authentic documents showing that Aribert Heim had lived in hiding in Cairo, becoming a Muslim and dying of cancer in 1992.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The hunt for Aribert Ferdinand Heim, a Nazi fugitive and concentration camp doctor, has officially come to a close, the German authorities said Friday, after they determined that the man known as Dr. Death for his unnecessary operations had died in Egypt in 1992.

headline: All This in the Name of Fashion
abstract: New York City Ballet’s fall gala featured new costumes by Valentino and a new ballet by Peter Martins to showcase them.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet’s gala on Thursday night managed to do disservices to both ballet and fashion. Three dances were presented with new costumes by the fashion designer Valentino, as was a world premiere; a Balanchine ballet was performed with its three lead roles redistributed among eight dancers; and Valentino was honored in film and, finally, onstage. This should have amounted to something substantial. The proceedings, however, kept suggesting that couture and ballet have less in common than we might hope.

headline: At the Track, Racing Economics Collide With Veterinarians’ Oath
abstract: Horse-racing veterinarians are both doctor and drugstore; the more drugs they prescribe, the more money they make.
lead_paragraph: Only after Bourbon Bandit broke a leg racing last November did his owner, Susan Kayne, learn the full extent of prescription drugs that veterinarians had given him at Belmont Park on Long Island.

headline: Marriage Survives a Decapitation
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: She is a retired correction officer, he is accused of cutting off a stranger’s head with a chain saw — no one said marriage was easy.
lead_paragraph: She is a retired New York City correction officer with a job at a security firm. He is a convicted drug dealer from Brooklyn who has admitted and denied — in that order — cutting off a stranger’s head with a chain saw.

headline: New York City Ballet Gala
abstract: New York City Ballet’s fall gala featured new costumes by Valentino and a new ballet by Peter Martins to showcase them.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet’s fall gala featured new costumes by Valentino and a new ballet by Peter Martins to showcase them.

headline: Derek Lowe, the Odd Man Out
abstract: Derek Lowe has a lot of postseason experience, but if the Yankees reach the postseason, Lowe, who has an 8-11 record, may not make the roster.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees signed Derek Lowe off waivers on Aug. 13, they believed his substantial playoff experience would serve the team well down the stretch.

headline: A Reporter Meets His Censor
abstract: It was a surreal, Wizard of Oz moment — meeting the Burmese censor of my articles in the International Herald Tribune. I had expected to peer behind the curtain and see an ill-tempered older man with thick glasses, a green eyeshade and a permanent scowl. I was wrong.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — During more than four years covering Myanmar I’ve always been curious about one particular building in Yangon, the office of the chief censor, a place of fear and mystique for Burmese journalists because they never quite knew what the censors would accept — and what would end up deleted with a thick red marker.

headline: Romney’s Family Trust Invested in Chinese Oil Company
abstract: Mitt Romney’s 2011 tax returns show that his family trusts had invested in shares of a Chinese-owned state oil company but got rid of those investments this summer, as his anti-Chinese rhetoric heated up.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Mitt Romney has become increasingly critical of China, saying the country is engaging in unfair trade practices and vowing to crack down on them in ways that are much more severe that the current administration.

headline: A Purple Heart, a Bronze Star and Kickoff Coverage
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Purple Heart (Military Decoration)', 'College Athletics', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Football', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Daniel Rodriguez, a walk-on wide receiver and a decorated veteran of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, will cover kickoffs for No. 10 Clemson when the Tigers play No. 4 Florida State.
lead_paragraph: When No. 10 Clemson plays at No. 4 Florida State on Saturday night, Daniel Rodriguez, a walk-on wide receiver, will be a member of the Tigers’ kickoff coverage unit. The sure-to-be frenzied atmosphere is not likely to affect him much.

headline: When a Country’s Situation Is So Bleak, Can Telling a Story Make a Difference?
abstract: The Congolese choreographer Faustin Linyekula, in a solo show at Gould Hall, mixes storytelling and dance as he recounts a visit to his childhood village.
lead_paragraph: “I am a storyteller,” the Congolese choreographer Faustin Linyekula said to those assembled in Gould Hall on Tuesday night. “But I am not here to tell stories. I am here to dance.” In “Le Cargo,” his first solo performance, Mr. Linyekula engaged in both activities — and connected them.

headline: Field Reports: The Hazing at Binghamton U.
abstract: H. Carl McCall, the chairman of the SUNY board of trustees, an alumna and a current student respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Out of Many Themes, One Topic
abstract: The Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn., is presenting “united states,” a program of exhibitions and single works examining many issues facing America.
lead_paragraph: Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: Quote Approval: An Old Story
abstract: An Adelphi University communications professor says the practice isn’t new, and goes beyond corporations and politicians.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Obama’s Health Care Law Would Drive Romney’s Tax Bill Up
abstract: For most taxpayers, the 2.9 percent Medicare tax levied on wage income will be the same in 2013 as it was in 2011. But starting that year, high-income taxpayers will pay more – and in the Romneys’ case – much more.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans pay more in payroll taxes – which finance Social Security and Medicare – than they do in income taxes. The rich are different.

headline: Watching a Hit Sitcom, and Seeing Undecided Voters
abstract: For the Obamas and the Romneys, saying they like “Modern Family,” ABC’s hit sitcom, is an easy way to signal that they identify with white middle-class suburbia.
lead_paragraph: It’s not so surprising that Michelle Obama said “Modern Family” was one of her family’s favorite shows. And it’s only a little surprising that Ann Romney claimed that she and her husband, Mitt, were also devoted fans.

headline: Bodies, Sand and Changing Times
abstract: “Beach Life,” an exhibition of works by Eric Fischl at the Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton, dovetails not only with the local landscape but with a sociology of beachgoing.
lead_paragraph: If being a starving or unsuccessful artist sounds harrowing, being a successful one comes with its own pitfalls. Take Eric Fischl, for instance. One of the most successful figurative painters of his generation, Mr. Fischl, who was born in 1948, attended the California Institute of Arts when it was a hotbed of post-1960s Conceptualism, but followed a less popular path and remained a painter. In the course of his career, he has been denounced by feminists, who saw his nudes as throwbacks to earlier eras in which women were objectified by male painters, and by postmodernists, who considered his large canvases luxury objects that exemplified rather than opposed the excesses of the 1980s art market.

headline: Giants Believe Their Depth Can Carry Them to Great Heights
abstract: Standout performances by Andre Brown, Ramses Barden and others who were once low on the Giants’ depth chart showed that the Giants are more than just their stars.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants knew when they entered the season that they had star power. Two returning 1,000-yard receivers, Hakeem Nicks and Victor Cruz, served as targets for Eli Manning, and the defense relied on three premier pass-rushing ends, Jason Pierre-Paul, Justin Tuck and Osi Umenyiora.

headline: Congress Heads for Home With Rancor Still Evident
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Senate gave final passage early Saturday morning to a stopgap spending measure that will ensure the government’s lights stay on through March.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate gave final passage early Saturday morning to a stopgap spending measure that will ensure the government’s lights stay on through March, and then closed the doors of one of the least productive Congresses in generations until after the November elections.

headline: An Intimate Space to Fill a Need
abstract: Hamilton Stage for the Performing Arts, a converted former Bell Telephone building, will open this fall under the umbrella of the Union County Performing Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: WITH the opening this fall of Hamilton Stage for the Performing Arts, one of five performance spaces under the umbrella of the nonprofit Union County Performing Arts Center in Rahway, the center is filling a specific niche.

headline: Deception and Betrayal, All in the Family
abstract: Suzan-Lori Parks directed “Topdog/Underdog,” her Pulitzer Prize play, in the shining first production of the 2012-13 season of the Two River Theater Company in Red Bank.
lead_paragraph: There is a gunshot in “Topdog/Underdog,” the shining first production of Two River Theater Company’s 2012-13 season.

headline: Please Hold for Mr. Putin
abstract: A Russian tradition flatters writers in a culture where literature has special prestige. But the surprise also promotes the cult of the unpredictable czar.
lead_paragraph: MASHA GESSEN, a Russian journalist, was recently fired for refusing to cover President Vladimir V. Putin’s hang-glider flight with migrating cranes, an exploit that was much mocked. Last week, she received an unexpected phone call, which she recounted in a blog post for The International Herald Tribune, this newspaper’s global edition. “My phone rang. ... I listened to silence for two minutes.” Finally: “Don’t hang up. I will connect you.” Frustrated, she shouted: “Do you want to introduce yourself?” A famous voice replied: “Putin, Vladimir Vladimirovich. I heard you were fired and that I unwittingly served as the reason for it.” He invited her to meet.

headline: William Duckworth, Internet Composer, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Duckworth, a post-Minimalist who wrote “Time Curve Preludes,” grew to embrace the Internet as a focus of electronic works.
lead_paragraph: William Duckworth, a composer, author and performer who was best known for his choral works, piano cycles and, in recent years, interactive electronic projects using the Internet, died on Sept. 13 at his home in West New York, N.J. He was 69.

headline: For Ambitious Governor, a Clinton Stands in the Way
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo considers a 2016 presidential bid, the eyes of the Democratic Party are fixed on Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, who could count on broad support if she ran.
lead_paragraph: Since taking office last year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has done many things well, positioning himself for a possible presidential run.

headline: New Fears in Los Angeles as Highway Closes Again
abstract: The closing of Interstate 405 in Los Angeles last year did not result in the nightmare that was expected, but officials fear they will not be so lucky this time.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One year ago, a 10-mile stretch of Interstate 405 — the most heavily traveled highway in the nation, and the not-so-proud symbol of the Los Angeles traffic jam — was shut down for most of a weekend. The city went on full alert. Emergency workers were mobilized, contingency plans were made and motorists were warned — in the most dire terms — to stay off the road for what was called Carmageddon.

headline: With a Birdie Barrage, Furyk Leads the Tour Championship
abstract: After birdying five of the first seven holes, Jim Furyk shot a six-under 64 for a one-shot lead over Justin Rose heading into the third round of the Tour Championship.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jim Furyk’s scorecard looked as if a keyboard were stuck on 3. Or as if he had inadvertently submitted the results of a round at the compressed par-58 course down the street from East Lake Golf Club.

headline: Deconstructing a Celebrated Outlaw
abstract: Books about the bank robber Willie Sutton, freedom of assembly and the impeachment of a New York governor.
lead_paragraph: WHY did Willie Sutton rob banks? “Because that’s where the money is,” is the answer everyone knows, even though Sutton insisted that the quote was made up.

headline: Espada Still Free on Bail, Despite New Accusations

lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Brooklyn declined to revoke bail on Friday for former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., who was accused by prosecutors this week of siphoning additional money from a nonprofit group that he had been convicted of stealing from.

abstract: Gambia’s president, Yahya Jammeh, freed the men, former officials in his government, after the Rev. Jesse Jackson visited and made a personal plea.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Two Gambian-Americans serving long prison sentences are now in the United States after the Rev. Jesse Jackson made a personal plea to Gambia’s erratic president, Yahya Jammeh, to release them this week.

abstract: The allegations against Dr. Richard Keller have raised questions at the prominent institutions on his résumé, particularly Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In a court appearance on Friday, Dr. Richard Keller, the former medical director at a prestigious Massachusetts prep school and a part-time pediatrician at Boston Children’s Hospital, agreed to remain in jail pending a trial on a single federal count of receiving child pornography. He has been in jail since his arrest on Sept. 13.

lead_paragraph: When the federal government began providing billions of dollars in incentives to push hospitals and physicians to use electronic medical and billing records, the goal was not only to improve efficiency and patient safety, but also to reduce health care costs.

headline: Lincoln’s Great Gamble
abstract: Why we should celebrate the Emancipation Proclamation.
lead_paragraph: Countless school children have been taught that Abraham Lincoln was the Great Emancipator. Others have been taught — and many have concluded — that the Emancipation Proclamation, which Abraham Lincoln announced on Sept. 22, 1862, has been overemphasized, that it was inefficacious, a sham, that Lincoln’s motivations were somehow unworthy, that slavery was ended by other ways and means, and that slavery was on the way out in any case.

lead_paragraph: The long and colorful battle between the National Arts Club and its eccentric former president, O. Aldon James Jr., reached a new phase on Friday, as the state attorney general sued Mr. James for more than $2 million, charging that he misused the club’s money and real estate for his own benefit.

lead_paragraph: Since 2006, inflation-adjusted Medicare payments for emergency-room services have increased more quickly than hospital costs.

lead_paragraph: Bill Shankly, the manager credited with transforming Liverpool F.C. from paupers of northern England to princes of Europe, was once affronted by the suggestion that someone felt he viewed soccer as a matter of life and death.

headline: In Queens, Indian Graves and Ancient Trees
abstract: Douglaston, Queens, is an unusual cityscape of wetlands, tidal creeks and picturesque houses, many of them in a historic district.
lead_paragraph: As the train from Pennsylvania Station approaches Douglaston, Queens, the cityscape abruptly gives way to grassy wetlands and wandering tidal creeks. To the north is the blue expanse of Little Neck Bay. To the east, the Douglaston Peninsula. It was once farmed by the Matinecoc Indians, settled by the Dutch and developed into a residential community in the early 20th century. Salt marshes dominated the shoreline until 1906; today, Shore Road winds past picturesque houses and gardens and a cooperatively run beach, pier and playing field.

headline: Syria: Assad Assails Help for Rebels
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: An Egyptian magazine published what it said was an exclusive interview with President Bashar al-Assad in which he criticized Turkey, Qatar and Saudi Arabia for supporting his government’s opponents.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian magazine, Al Ahram al-Arabi, on Friday published what it said was an exclusive interview with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in which he criticized Turkey, Qatar and Saudi Arabia for supporting his government’s opponents, saying they were pursuing the “Libyan model” for Syria. Mr. Assad asserted that he was open to dialogue with his opponents and that the government had already pursued substantial political reforms. Also on Friday, an opposition group, the National Coordination Committee for Democratic Change, reported that three of its members had been arrested in Damascus, the capital.

headline: As Losses Stack Up, Big Ten Sees Relevance Head South
abstract: The college football season is young, but Big Ten teams have already put themselves in a 4-8 rut against teams from Bowl Championship Series conferences or Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: The season is young, but already the Big Ten has made an impression as a middling conference.

headline: Security Council Urges West Africa to Develop a Plan to Assist Mali
abstract: The humanitarian and security situation in northern Mali has eroded under Al Qaeda and the other extremist groups controlling the region, the United Nations Security Council said Friday.
lead_paragraph: The humanitarian and security situation in northern Mali has eroded under Al Qaeda and the other extremist groups controlling the region, the United Nations Security Council said Friday as it expressed its “grave concern.” It urged West African states to develop a “feasible” collective plan to confront the situation. The initial West African proposal stressed the need to begin any joint military effort from Bamako, the capital, which Mali rejects. World leaders attending the United Nations General Assembly meeting will discuss the problems facing the sub-Saharan region on Wednesday, but no new initiatives on Mali are expected.

headline: A Day for Dogs and Diners
abstract: David Garza, who runs the Henry Street Settlement, a social service agency, starts and ends his Sundays by walking his Tibetan mastiff and golden retriever.
lead_paragraph: David Garza, 48, runs the Henry Street Settlement, a social service agency on the Lower East Side, but his Sundays belong to Park Slope, Brooklyn, where he grew up. He still lives on the same block, with his wife, Gina Meggo-Garza, 46, a L’Oreal executive; daughter, Alexandra Garza, 20, a student at Smith College; and two dogs, Beck, a Tibetan mastiff, and Phoebee, a golden retriever. After working in retail and in television production, Mr. Garza joined Henry Street in 2001 and became its executive director in 2010. Though he spends the occasional weekend in the Catskills, he devotes most Sundays to revisiting old neighborhood haunts and exploring new ones.

headline: Has Apple Peaked?
abstract: The nasty glitch in the iPhone 5 suggests that the law of big companies even applies to the most valuable one in America.
lead_paragraph: If Steve Jobs were still alive, would the new map application on the iPhone 5 be such an unmitigated disaster? Interesting question, isn’t it?

lead_paragraph: The editor of a Web site that encourages Mormons to question church history and doctrine has been told that he faces a church trial and possible excommunication because he is an apostate who is trying to lead church members astray.

lead_paragraph: José Curbelo, a Cuban-born pianist and bandleader who went on to manage the biggest stars of Latin dance music, died on Friday in Miami. He was 95.

lead_paragraph: Franklin D. Raines, who resigned as chief executive of Fannie Mae in late 2004 amid revelations of extensive accounting improprieties at the mortgage finance company, has been dismissed from a long-running civil suit brought by Fannie Mae investors hoping to recover damages.

headline: Hoopla in the Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn
abstract: The opening of the new sports and entertainment center is good news, but it is worth reminding the developers of other promises they need to keep.
lead_paragraph: With an official ribbon-cutting on Friday, Brooklyn celebrated the opening of a lavish sports and entertainment center featuring the Brooklyn Nets (formerly of New Jersey). This is generally good news for the borough and the city. It elevates what had been an underdeveloped area into a vibrant hub for basketball fans, shoppers and followers of such superstars as Jay-Z, who owns a club in the complex. For an older generation, the arrival of a major-league sports team may help fill the emptiness left by the departure of the Dodgers for Los Angeles in 1957.

headline: G.O.P. Ticket Is Picture of Health, Doctors Say
abstract: Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan are healthy and fit, according to medical summaries released on Friday by the Romney campaign.
lead_paragraph: Medical summaries by doctors who have regularly examined Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan were released Friday by the Romney campaign and show both men to be conspicuously healthy and fit. Both men, however, have significant family histories of heart disease and have been closely monitored for it.

headline: Congress’s Unpopular Watchdog
abstract: With big-money politics presenting an ever greater ethical threat, the House must keep open the Office of Congressional Ethics.
lead_paragraph: The Office of Congressional Ethics, a proven force for good on Capitol Hill, is in need of a fresh lease from House leaders if it is to continue conducting discreet preliminary investigations of corruption allegations against lawmakers. The quasi-independent office has tallied an impressive 101 ethics inquiries in its four years of existence.

headline: Myanmar’s Fragile Democracy
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Along with the United States government, businesses will have important roles to play to encourage reform.
lead_paragraph: Now that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s revered opposition leader, has given the go-ahead, the United States should further ease sanctions against that country, which is beginning to embrace democracy. Sanctions are intended to encourage positive change and will have value only if affected governments trust that the penalties will be lifted as they make progress.

headline: Turn Out the Lights on the Mets
abstract: To a lifelong Mets fan, September baseball at Citi Field means a surreal excursion into a cavernous shell abandoned by optimism long ago.
lead_paragraph: It is with no traditional autumnal sense of baseball anticipation that my son Nick and I ride the rumbling 7 train to Citi Field for a couple of games with the hated Phillies. We are father-and-son rubber-neckers drawn to the spectacular car wreck that is our team.

headline: Russia: Dogs Poisoned in Moscow
abstract: The Moscow police are searching for a band of vigilante “dog hunters” who have set traps with poisoned meat to kill stray dogs. But the poison has killed pets instead.
lead_paragraph: The Moscow police are searching for a band of vigilante “dog hunters” who have set traps with poisoned meat to kill stray dogs. But the poison has killed pets instead, and on Friday the police opened a criminal investigation. Last week, residents of a Moscow neighborhood complained that several pets had mysteriously died just as warnings to pet owners began to appear in a local park. “If you don’t follow the rules of walking your dog — it will die,” said one of the fliers, a Russian news agency reported. Packs of stray dogs are a common sight in Russia; the government estimates that tens of thousands roam Moscow’s streets. The police say that several dogs have been killed recently, but Moscow residents say that the number is actually in the dozens.

headline: Sept. 21: Presidential Race Changes, but Swing States Stay the Same
abstract: Emblematic of Mr. Obama’s good-but-not-great polling day were a set of polls, which had him ahead in four of the five swing states: Ohio, Virginia, Colorado and North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: We make an effort to be disciplined about the way that we characterize the polls each day. Generally speaking, if the FiveThirtyEight forecast moves appreciably toward President Obama, the tenor of the article is going to be favorable to him — and likewise for Mitt Romney, if the same is true for him.

headline: Claudine Mawby Walker Dies at 90; Hollywood ‘Triplet’
abstract: Ms. Mawby Walker, her twin, Claudette, and their other sister, Angella, were three English girls who were child stars in the days of Jackie Coogan and the Little Rascals.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood publicity agents called them the Mawby Triplets. They were a set of adorably blond little English girls who appeared in some of the earliest talking films, cherubs adorning the celluloid canvases of the 1920s and ’30s. Cast in movies with stars like Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Gloria Swanson and John Barrymore, they were, for a time, among the most famous children in the world.

headline: Rich as the Devil, but No Gordon Gekko
abstract: The income disparity in New York has hardly diminished, but pop culture’s recent portrayals of the class wars haven’t been indicative of the boiling debate.
lead_paragraph: The television series “666 Park Avenue,” whose title invites little thematic speculation, arrives next week on ABC and will be, to the best of my knowledge, the second time an architecturally significant apartment building in Manhattan has been deployed as a fictional vessel for Satanism. The reason would seem fairly clear; you just can’t situate allegories of demonic venality or depraved ambition as persuasively in places like Philadelphia, White Plains or San Diego. Had New York City as we now know it existed in 1600, civilization would have been forever left to reckon with the Macbeths of East 78th Street.

lead_paragraph: The following analytics will appear on the letters page in the Sept. 23 issue of the magazine.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Punjab: Gulzar Singh Ranike, a minister in the Punjab state government, resigned on Sunday in the wake of allegations that he misappropriated public funds, The Times of India reported. Mr. Ranike and an associate were accused of transferring 25 million rupees, about $ 460,000, from funds intended for a border area development program.

headline: Irreplaceable for Giants? It Applies Only to Eli
abstract: Several times in his career, Eli Manning has dealt with the loss of seemingly indispensable receivers.
lead_paragraph: In his latest post at CapitalNewYork.com, Greg Hanlon wrote on the N.F.L. version of the old saying that graveyards are full of indispensable men.

headline: Dame Patrol in Milan
abstract: The striking detail of Bottega Veneta’s spring collection was a persistent hint of toughness — in spite of the feminine florals, soft knits and silvery fringe that spilled from the waists of cocktail dresses.
lead_paragraph: Tanked with caffeine from the espresso bar that Bottega Veneta sets up before its morning shows, I regarded the opening dress — a silk floral print with shoulder pads and a thin belt — and wondered if the designer, Tomas Maier, had been reading James M. Cain over the summer. The jazzy music kept this thought going through several tough little day dresses with a 1940s slant. The impression gradually dissolved as Mr. Maier shifted to almost naïve-looking blouses and skirts in white poplin, and then a sporty tank dress in black jersey spliced with black snakeskin.

headline: A New Inning, Late in the Game
abstract: Kevin McClatchy, who owned the Pittsburgh Pirates, comes out and speaks out about the tightly shut closet door in the four major sports leagues.
lead_paragraph: LIGONIER, Pa.

headline: Coming Out in the World of Sports
abstract: The former owner of a major league baseball team talks about his closeted past and putting an end to it.
lead_paragraph: Kevin McClatchy, who spent 11 ½ years as the managing general partner and chief executive officer of the Pittsburgh Pirates, spoke extensively with me at his home in Ligonier, Penn., about why he hid being gay for so long and about the persistent secrecy in professional sports. Here, in addition to his comments in my Sunday column, are a few excerpts from our conversation.

headline: A Timeline of Incremental Progress
abstract: Gay and lesbian athletes have been a part of sports history.
lead_paragraph: Big-time sports lag behind other areas of American society in terms of the number of gay and lesbian participants who feel they can be open about their sexual orientation. Not once, for example, has an active male player in any of the four major professional sports leagues in America publicly acknowledged being gay. But retired football, basketball and baseball players, along with active players in other sports, have come out. And there are plenty of lesbian athletes in women’s professional sports. Here are some milestones from the last four decades :

headline: The Barriers to Openness
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: There are reasons for gay athletes’ hesitation about publicly identifying themselves.
lead_paragraph: It’s a statistical impossibility that there aren’t at least a few gay men playing in one of the four major American sports leagues right now. It’s an equal impossibility that there haven’t been hundreds of them over time.

headline: The Official Attendance Can Become Empty of Meaning
abstract: Teams in Major League Baseball and other sports leagues report the number of tickets sold, not the number of tickets used.
lead_paragraph: The Mets announced that the attendance at their game Thursday night against the Phillies was 20,010. Even a casual glance at the game on television, though, suggested that there were no more than a few thousand fans at Citi Field. Were the Mets fibbing?

headline: Time Running Short for the Nazi Hunters
abstract: Although a German court has decided that a wanted Nazi death camp doctor died 20 years ago, other elderly war criminals from that era are still on the run and Nazi-hunters have not given up hope of bringing them to justice.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The decision by a German court to close the file on a notorious Nazi fugitive known as Dr. Death is a reminder that time is running out to bring war criminals from World War II to justice.

headline: The Weekend Word: Tax Day
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the president’s weekly address and the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Bottega Veneta: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Photos of The Moment | Bottega Veneta
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Mets’ Knuckleballer Has an Honor at His Fingertips
abstract: The Mets badly want R.A. Dickey to reach 20 victories. But three of the last six Cy Young Awards were given to pitchers with no more than 16 victories.
lead_paragraph: Terry Collins, the Mets’ manager, sat gloomily at a news conference after his team lost to Philadelphia on Monday. His staff ace, R. A. Dickey, had lost despite allowing only two earned runs in seven innings. The Mets badly want Dickey to reach 20 victories, the magic threshold for a starting pitcher.

headline: Inequality Kills
abstract: And you can see it in the numbers.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Geier makes a point I should have noticed. She points to the shocking story in yesterday’s Times about sharply declining life expectancies for less-educated whites, and points out that these declines took place at a time of rapidly rising income inequality. And we have lots of evidence that low socioeconomic status leads to higher mortality — even if you correct for things like availability of health insurance.

headline: A Misguided Moral Crusade
abstract: A campaign to end demand for prostitution will harm trafficking victims and sex workers more than it helps them.
lead_paragraph: BEATEN. Burned. Branded with a bar code or with a pimp’s name carved into her thigh. Thrown into the trunk of a car for punishment. Forced to provide sexual services for countless callous and violent men. This is the dominant image of young people in the sex trade, and it is fueling deeply flawed campaigns against prostitution.

headline: Fendi: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Highlights and Analysis: College Football Saturday
abstract: The New York Times provided updates and analysis of Saturday’s college football action.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get together and talk college football. Paul Myerberg is in Manhattan. There are other people in other places. Stick around for updates and analysis.

headline: Self-contradictory Fed Bashing
abstract: When is it OK to target asset prices?
lead_paragraph: David Glasner continues to be unhappy with the Bernanke/QE bashers, this time going after claims that the Fed’s monetary policy was too easy before the crisis.

headline: Relocation of A’s Has All the Plans but No Permit
abstract: Lew Wolff, the owner of the Oakland Athletics, said his team needed a new stadium in San Jose, Calif., to keep the club above baseball’s poverty line.
lead_paragraph: The first baseball stadium that caught Lew Wolff’s fancy was Sportsman’s Park in St. Louis, where he lived as a boy. He had a Knothole Gang pass and took the streetcar almost every day, watching the Cardinals of the National League and the Browns of the American League. On school days, he would take his homework.

headline: Double Payments Bedevil Veterans’ Pension System
abstract: Technology and practices at the Department of Veterans Affairs that make it hard for some people to collect benefits apparently also result in overpayments.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In July 2010, a Department of Veterans Affairs employee named Kristen Ruell was updating a benefit claim when she noticed something odd. What should have been an increase of about $2,000 in a monthly payment to the widow of a veteran showed up on her computer screen as $21,000.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: In N.F.L., the Show Goes On and On
abstract: With two weeks of sluggish games already played, a question that strikes at the core of the N.F.L.’s appeal is being raised: Are the replacement officials diminishing the entertainment value?
lead_paragraph: Watching football on television dictates diets and schedules and even basic household responsibilities like washing dishes or putting the kids to bed. It dominates happy hours and alters Circadian rhythms, depending on what time zone one happens to be in.

headline: Jil Sander: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: The Fans Are Irrelevant in the Business of the N.H.L.
abstract: Several N.H.L. teams, apparently, have lost tens of millions of dollars a year but have not failed enough yet.
lead_paragraph: The last time the N.H.L. and its team owners locked out the players, the Tampa Bay Lightning were the reigning Stanley Cup champions; this time around, it’s the Los Angeles Kings.

headline: A Tiny Mediterranean Nation, Awash in Immigrants With Nowhere to Go
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Malta has the highest ratio of immigrants per capita of any European Union member, but it lacks the resources to house them and by law cannot let them move off the island.
lead_paragraph: VALLETTA, Malta — On a recent evening, the immigrants living in the steel shipping containers out by the abandoned airport here began to bed down for the night, pulling their mattresses outside to escape the suffocating heat.

headline: As Punts Get Longer, So Do Returns
abstract: Though N.F.L. punters are booting the ball farther than ever, returners scored 20 touchdowns in 2011, their second-highest season total, and this year already have five.
lead_paragraph: It was a rookie mistake made by a 21-year-old punt returner who had the audacity to break one of football’s golden rules.

headline: Variety: An Ancient Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon bring us news from an ancient land.
lead_paragraph: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Those of us who make the New York Times crossword puzzle appear in your newspaper were up way past our bedtimes last night running the Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament benefiting the Pleasantville Fund for Learning, so this one will be short.

headline: Eating for Health, Not Weight
abstract: The best diet is low in unhealthful carbs and low in fat as well as in red meat and processed foods.
lead_paragraph: ALMOST half of Americans are on a diet — not surprising, since two-thirds are overweight or obese, a frightening statistic that inspired Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to push through a ban on large soft drinks in New York City. The country is preoccupied with calories. McDonald’s, for instance, is now posting them. But our widespread hope for weight loss makes us vulnerable to all kinds of promises, even ones that aren’t true, when it comes to food.

headline: In Shark-Infested Waters, Resolve of Two Giants Is Tested
abstract: Nationalists in China and Japan have seized on a territorial dispute and placed it at the heart of the debate on the balance of power in the region.
lead_paragraph: SENKAKU/DIAOYU ISLANDS — The voyage to these remote islands at the center of one of Asia’s most heated territorial disputes is a bone-jarring seven-hour boat ride from one of Japan’s southernmost ports, a long enough journey that the fishermen who brave the often stormy seas regularly sail in pairs for safety. The trip from the mainland of China, which also lays claim to the islands, is even longer.

headline: Rebels Announce Move of Headquarters From Turkey to ‘Liberated’ Syria Territory
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The practical effect of a move to “liberated areas” of Syria by the main umbrella group for those fighting President Bashar al-Assad remains unclear, and the new location carries risks.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Commanders of the Free Syrian Army, the main umbrella group for fighters opposing President Bashar al-Assad, said Saturday that they had moved their headquarters from Turkey into “liberated areas” inside Syria, in what they portrayed as a major step forward in their efforts to aid, coordinate and control disparate groups of rebels.

headline: Mitt Romney Says, “I Am The Confidence Fairy!”
abstract: What, don’t you have faith?
lead_paragraph: I’ve coined a few successful turns of phrase over the years, but none, I think, as successful as the confidence fairy — a term I used to refer to the belief that things like austerity in the face of depression would actually be expansionary, because of … CONFIDENCE.

headline: A New Capital for U.S. Golf (Pop. 13,000)
abstract: Davis Love III and three of the 12 players on the United States Ryder Cup squad live in St. Simons, Ga., an island that is home to several championship courses.
lead_paragraph: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga. — The golfer Davis Love III is like the Spanish moss draped over the stately trees on the Avenue of Oaks. He has been hanging around this barrier island for so long that he has become part of the scenery, a low-maintenance presence invisible to the local residents.

headline: Virginia Republican Adopts Cuts in Defense as His Issue
keywords: ['Series', 'Budget Control Act (2011)', 'Defense Contracts', 'Elections, Senate', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: George Allen, Virginia’s Republican nominee for Senate, has made opposition to automatic reductions in military spending his campaign’s centerpiece.
lead_paragraph: STAFFORD, Va. — Just outside the gates of the storied Quantico Marine Base, George Allen, the Republican nominee for a Senate seat from Virginia, sat down in the offices of a moving van company with more than a dozen defense contractors from his state last Monday to listen to them fret over government spending cuts.

headline: Middle Schools Add a Team Rule: Get a Drug Test
keywords: ['Interscholastic Athletics', 'Education (K-12)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Tests (Drug Use)', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Required screening for participation in athletics or other activities can begin as early as middle school, confusing students and stirring objections from parents.
lead_paragraph: MILFORD, Pa. — As a 12-year-old seventh grader, Glenn and Kathy Kiederer’s older daughter wanted to play sports at Delaware Valley Middle School here. She also wanted to join the scrapbooking club.

headline: Facebook Invitation Draws Thousands, and a Melee, to Dutch Town
abstract: A sleepy Dutch community was still recovering on Saturday from the aftermath of a sweet sixteen party whose invitation went viral drawing partygoers by the thousands as well as riot police.
lead_paragraph: A sleepy Dutch community was still recovering on Saturday from the aftermath of a sweet sixteen party whose invitation, for no clear reason, went viral, spawning a YouTube video, drawing impromptu partygoers by the thousands as well as riot police, and causing the young celebrant and her family to flee town.

headline: With Rich Donors, a More Candid Romney Emerges
abstract: Mitt Romney’s remarks at fund-raisers highlight the differences, both subtle and significant, in how he talks to voters and donors, his two key constituencies.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In Chicago, Mitt Romney regaled wealthy donors with a boyhood memory of volunteering to clean up a litter-strewn football field, the kind of humanizing tale he typically avoids on the campaign trail.

headline: Wind Sprints to the Cliff
abstract: Three months before a tax credit is due to expire, officials in Oregon will cut the ribbon on what some say is the largest onshore wind farm in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The wind industry’s main trade association is predicting that new installations will fall to zero without a renewal of the production tax credit, which applies only to projects finished by New Year’s Eve. Since renewal is iffy, some wind machine factories are already shutting down, as my colleague Diane Cardwell reported on Friday.

headline: Miley Makes Case for N.L. Rookie of the Year
abstract: Wade Miley has been a steady presence all year long in Arizona’s rotation, going 16-10 with a 3.25 E.R.A. He should win the N.L. award over Bryce Harper.
lead_paragraph: Ken Griffey Jr. was 19 as a rookie for Seattle in 1989. He hit .264 with 16 homers and 61 runs batted in, a strong showing for his age that foreshadowed greatness. But Gregg Olson, Baltimore’s closer, had a better season and was rookie of the year.

headline: University Is Uneasy as Court Ruling Allows Guns on Campus
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Gun Control', 'School Shootings', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Some faculty members warn of a climate of fear and intimidation if concealed weapons are permitted on the University of Colorado campus after a State Supreme Court ruling.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — During her 19 years teaching English at the University of Colorado Boulder, Karen Jacobs never gave much thought to whether one of her students was carrying a gun.

headline: Free Speech in the Age of YouTube
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The worldwide storm over an incendiary anti-Islamic video has stirred fresh debate over what kind of expression is allowed where.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco

headline: Washington Versus America
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The capital has gotten rich, but it has come at rest of the country’s expense.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I moved to Washington, D.C., in 2002, you could sense that the nation’s capital had turned a corner after decades of decline. But the Washington of 10 years ago still looked basically like the city that had been scarred by riots in the 1960s and then emptied by white flight, with a prosperous northwest divided from a blighted south and east, and frontiers of gentrification that weren’t that many blocks from the Capitol itself.

headline: In Times Sq., Reminders of an American Missing in Iran
abstract: To coincide with the Iranian president’s visit to the United Nations, a billboard in Times Square and displays in subway stations have started showing a picture of a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in 2007.
lead_paragraph: When President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran arrives in New York for the United Nations General Assembly, delegates may see the face of an American missing in Iran for more than five years.

headline: When a Severe Injury Shakes a Team to Its Heart
abstract: The neck injury to Tulane’s Devon Walker stirred grim memories for players who were reluctant to resume games.
lead_paragraph: Ken Dallafior, a former Detroit Lions offensive lineman, froze in front of his television Sept. 8 when he saw Tulane safety Devon Walker lying on the field after a collision with a teammate.

headline: N.H.L. Fines Red Wings Executive for Lockout Remarks
abstract: In an interview, Jim Devellano likened N.H.L. players to cattle and violated a leaguewide order barring team owners and officials from commenting on the lockout.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. announced Saturday that it had fined the Detroit Red Wings an undisclosed amount for comments about the lockout made by Jim Devellano, a club senior vice president, in an interview published this week.

headline: The Son Also Sets
abstract: For whom the bell tolls? Mitt, if his Hemingway wannabe strategist doesn’t stop the moveable feast of mistakes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

headline: Avoiding Student Loan Default
abstract: The government needs to do a better job of getting out the word about federal programs that help students in debt.
lead_paragraph: The federal student loan program offers flexible payment plans that are supposed to keep borrowers out of default even when they have lost their jobs and can afford almost nothing in monthly payments. But these programs will never serve their intended purpose until the government does a better job of getting out the word about them and makes them easier to use.

headline: When GPS Tracking Violates Privacy Rights
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Global Positioning System', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: A damaging court ruling would obliterate privacy rights and the Fourth Amendment’s warrant requirement.
lead_paragraph: For the right to personal privacy to survive in America in this digital age, courts must be meticulous in applying longstanding privacy protections to new technology. This did not happen in an unfortunate ruling last month by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

headline: Anticipating the Next Pandemic
abstract: Whenever an outbreak occurs, we all ask ourselves whether it might herald the Next Big One.
lead_paragraph: Bozeman, Mont.

headline: Underdogged
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why does Mitt Romney try to represent himself as downtrodden?
lead_paragraph: “I definitely think Mitt goes in as an underdog,” Ann Romney said in a television interview earlier this month. Mr. Romney’s campaign happens to be imploding at the moment, but his supporters have been calling him an underdog since the primaries. In February, Mr. Romney said he was the underdog in Michigan, his home state. In June, Gov. Scott Walker said Mr. Romney was the underdog in Wisconsin. Sometimes, being just any old underdog isn’t enough. “He’s the tremendous underdog,” said a Republican committeeman in New Hampshire.

headline: In Malta, Immigrants Left in Limbo
abstract: The tiny Mediterranean nation lacks the resources to adequately house them and by law cannot let them move to the mainland.
lead_paragraph: The tiny Mediterranean nation lacks the resources to adequately house them and by law cannot let them move to the mainland.

headline: 2 Islamist Militias Disband in Libya Amid Anger Over Killings
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: The groups announced Saturday that they were disbanding, bowing to a wave of anti-militia anger that has swept parts of the country since a deadly attack on an American diplomatic mission.
lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Two Islamist militias in the eastern city of Darnah announced Saturday that they were disbanding, bowing to a wave of antimilitia anger that has swept parts of Libya since a deadly attack on an American diplomatic mission on Sept. 11.

headline: Exploiting the Prophet
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Christians didn’t riot after seeing a photograph of Jesus steeped in urine, so why are Muslims up in arms about insults to the Prophet Muhammad?
lead_paragraph: “PISS CHRIST,” a famous photograph partly financed by taxpayers, depicted a crucifix immersed in what the artist said was his own urine. But conservative Christians did not riot on the Washington Mall.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Conflicts Over Religion
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Education (K-12)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Atheism']
abstract: Readers discuss faith-based disagreement, vitriol and violence.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss faith-based disagreement, vitriol and violence.

headline: Deciding When a Pet Has Suffered Enough
abstract: Euthanasia is often the de facto solution for animal pain, even when palliative care is a better option.
lead_paragraph: Lyons, Colo.

headline: ‘Defenders’ of the Faith
abstract: Readers post their comments on my column about Islam and blasphemy, and about whether the Arab Spring is being hijacked.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at the violent protests around the Islamic world after the airing of the inane video trailer mocking the Prophet Muhammad. I try to look at why there’s such outrage at blasphemy in the Islamic world, and whether extremists are trying to hijack the Arab Spring. If I’d had a bit more space, I would have made one more point. The history of Islam is largely of being the dominant religion in its sphere, closely allied with rulers, while Christianity and Judaism have long experience as minority faiths. I think that one consequence is that Christianity has more expectation of sacrilege or mockery, while that’s more of a shock to many Muslims, particularly to Sunnis living in Sunni countries.

headline: Hard Lines, Red Lines and Green Lines
abstract: Aung San Suu Kyi hit the nail on the head last week when she said it is the fear of losing power that corrupts. It’s everywhere these days.
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: Photos of The Moment | Fendi
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Edwin P. Wilson, the Spy Who Lived It Up, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Wilson’s larger-than-life world of business and espionage collapsed with his arrest in 1982 on charges of selling Libya 20 tons of powerful explosives.
lead_paragraph: Part spy, part tycoon, Edwin P. Wilson lived large.

headline: A Little Night Music
abstract: As summer wanes, the evening air is alive with the symphonies of a cornucopia of insects.
lead_paragraph: This is the season of the night fiddlers, when you know summer is fraying away. The air brims with their eerie music, although we rarely see the musicians — katydids and crickets playing their marimbas, as they lift their wings high and rub a sharp edge of one wing over a ridge of pegs on the other. It’s as if they’re combing strands of song from their wings.

headline: C.E.O.’s and the Pay-’Em-or-Lose-’Em Myth
abstract: The argument that C.E.O.’s will leave if they aren’t compensated well, perhaps even lavishly, is bogus, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: CORPORATIONS are forever defending big executive paydays. If we don’t pay up, the argument goes, our sharpest minds will jump to our rivals.

headline: California Takes On the Retirement Crisis
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown could put his state, and the nation, on a path to greater economic security if he signs a new retirement plan.
lead_paragraph: When you think of California as a trendsetter, retirement policy is probably not the first thing that comes to mind, but that may soon change.

headline: Rethinking Sleep
abstract: It’s not the quantity of sleep that restores and refreshes, but the quality.
lead_paragraph: SOMETIME in the dark stretch of the night it happens. Perhaps it’s the chime of an incoming text message. Or your iPhone screen lights up to alert you to a new e-mail. Or you find yourself staring at the ceiling, replaying the day in your head. Next thing you know, you’re out of bed and engaged with the world, once again ignoring the often quoted fact that eight straight hours of sleep is essential.

headline: Dr. William C. Dement
abstract: The father of sleep medicine, Dr. William C. Dement, on playing jazz on a houseboat and a water pistol wake-up.
lead_paragraph: Considered the father of sleep medicine, Dr. William C. Dement, 84, has studied slumbering since the 1950s. He has written countless scientific papers and books and is the founder of the Stanford Sleep Disorders Clinic, the world’s first sleep laboratory. Undergraduates still pack into lecture halls every semester to take his “Sleep and Dreams” course, and he has a cameo role in the film “Sleepwalk With Me,” which is currently in theaters.

headline: The New World
abstract: Maps showing possible new additions to the world’s list of independent nations.
lead_paragraph: We appear to be on the brink of a nation-state baby boom. These new countries will not be the product of a single political change or conflict, as was the post-Soviet proliferation, nor will they be confined to a specific region. If anything, they are linked by a single, undeniable fact: history chews up borders with the same purposeless determination that geology does, as seaside villas slide off eroding coastal cliffs. Here is an interactive map of what could become the world’s newest international borders.

headline: Assessing Manager of the Year Races
abstract: To win manager of the year, a manager typically must win a lot more games than people expected, overcome an unforeseen obstacle or win in historic fashion.
lead_paragraph: To win this award, a manager typically must do one of the following: win a lot more games than people expected (like the Padres’ Bud Black in 2010), overcome an unforeseen obstacle (like the Angels’ Mike Scioscia in 2009, after the death of pitcher Nick Adenhart) or win in historic fashion (like the Mariners’ Lou Piniella in 2001, when his team won 116 games).

headline: Jets Rookie Wide Receiver Is in a New World of Zigs and Zags
abstract: Stephen Hill, the Jets’ rookie wide receiver, is seeing things he never did while playing three seasons in a run-oriented offense at Georgia Tech.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Last Sunday in Pittsburgh, Stephen Hill grappled with the Steelers’ cornerbacks. He pushed to create separation on his routes. He shoved them as he blocked on running plays. They pushed and shoved him right back. By game’s end, Hill was exhausted. He had lined up at receiver for 40 of the Jets’ 51 offensive plays, and Mark Sanchez had thrown his way only twice — a deep ball that was broken up and a pass that bounced at his feet.

headline: America the Anxious
abstract: The British may be dour, but across the pond, the obsessive American pursuit of happiness is creating a nation of nervous wrecks.
lead_paragraph: “The search for happiness is one of the chief sources of unhappiness.” — Eric Hoffer

headline: Unlikely Joint Effort by U.S. and Venezuela Leads to a Drug Lord’s Arrest
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Venezuela’s national drug police took part in an operation directed from Washington to capture one of South America’s most wanted kingpins.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — To President Hugo Chávez, the United States has long been The Enemy, the imperialist power that seeks to undermine his Socialist-inspired revolution, that plots to oust him from office — and that he loves to taunt.

headline: Paint by Numbers or Connect the Dots
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: Mark B. Templeton of Citrix, the Internet software company, sees two possible paths in a career: a low-risk one that others may want for you, or one where you gradually find your own way.
lead_paragraph: This interview with   Mark B. Templeton, president and C.E.O. of Citrix, the Internet software company, was conducted and edited by   Adam Bryant.

headline: Commander of the Apps, Except the One for Guilt
abstract: New smartphone apps can summon an army of personal assistants to help with daily tasks. But this new on-demand economy is making one user a bit uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: IN San Francisco recently, I was running late for a meeting, desperate for a ride. But no buses or cabs were in sight.

headline: Critics Press Cambodia to Fight Violence on its Forest Frontier
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Logging Industry', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: More critics press Cambodian government to get serious about the wave of crimes against critics of forest and land policies.
lead_paragraph: [Sept. 23, 11:40 p.m. | Update | The Earth Journalism Network and Society of Environmental Journalists have launched a petition pressing the Cambodian government for a full investigation of the murder.]

headline: For the Home Workshop, a GPS for Power Tools
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Tools', 'Global Positioning System']
abstract: An M.I.T. student and his colleagues have created a prototype for a device that guides power tools much as GPS guides a driver on a highway.
lead_paragraph: WOODWORKING is a tricky skill to master. Students learn to measure carefully before they reach for a saw, and to cut as true to the design as hand and eye allow. But, even so, precise cutting is a painstaking job, full of pitfalls and mismatched moldings.

headline: Princeton President Announces She Will Step Down
abstract: Shirley M. Tilghman, the second woman to lead an Ivy League institution, will remain on the faculty of Princeton University after stepping down as president in June.
lead_paragraph: The president of Princeton University, Shirley M. Tilghman, announced on Saturday that she would step down in June. Dr. Tilghman, a molecular biologist and a professor, became the second woman to lead an Ivy League institution when she emerged as the surprise choice to head the university in 2001.

headline: App Smart Extra: An Auxiliary Memory
abstract: Evernote and Momento are two apps you can use for journal keeping that offer a lot more than other, simpler apps.
lead_paragraph: This week’s App Smart column introduced to you some journal writing apps for iOS and Android. Compared to the fuss of pen and paper, and considering that we tend to carry our smartphones and tablets more or less everywhere these days, these apps are very convenient. A good journal app may actually tempt you to write a diary even if you’ve never done so before.

headline: The Return of Joe the Greek
abstract: When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. sat down at a diner on Saturday, wouldn’t you know it, he met another table of Greek-Americans — which gave him the chance to set the record straight on an earlier bit of campaign cheese some portrayed as a gaffe.

headline: Boogaard’s Parents File Lawsuit Against the N.H.L. Players’ Association

lead_paragraph: The parents of Derek Boogaard, the N.H.L. enforcer who died in May 2011 of an accidental overdose of prescription painkillers and alcohol, have sued the N.H.L. Players’ Association.

headline: Ryan Criticizes Obama’s Cuba Policy and Explains His Shift on the Issue
abstract: As a young congressman, Representative Paul D. Ryan had supported ending the trade embargo with Cuba. Now, he is critical of President Obama’s “appeasement” of the Cuban government.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — On a morning intended to reassure hard-line anti-Castro voters, who are a powerful force in South Florida Republican politics, Representative Paul D. Ryan made a pilgrimage to a restaurant here at the heart of the Cuban exile community in Little Havana. Part of the reason: to criticize what he called President Obama’s “appeasement” of the Cuban government.

headline: A Return to Minnesota, but Probably Not a Deli

lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, Minn. — The walls inside Tinucci’s deli and dining room are covered with family photographs dating to the 1930s, along with two decades of newspaper reviews. Nothing indicates the event that put the unpretentious establishment ever so briefly in the national spotlight almost two years ago.

headline: In New York, Reverence for Myanmar’s Opposition Leader
abstract: Burmese immigrants and visitors from as far away as Miami came to see Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who spoke at Queens College on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Just after midnight on Saturday, a crowd began descending on a narrow stretch of sidewalk at Queens College. The people came from all over New York and from as far away as Miami and North Carolina, but originally, they and their families were from Myanmar. They stood in line overnight to see the leader of that country’s opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who came to New York on Saturday as part of her first visit to the United States in some 40 years.

lead_paragraph: FROM up in the carob trees come the strains of great movie themes: the sad hum of “Love Story,” the creepy lull of “Rosemary’s Baby,” the jazzy screech of “Chinatown.” Below, just outside the grand entrance of the building where Adolph Zukor and Cecil B. DeMille once did business, Sumner M. Redstone’s retinue sips Champagne in the hot afternoon sun.
