headline: Blowing the Whistle on Online Returns
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Guarantees and Warranties', 'E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: A New Yorker is frustrated in trying to return items bought online to a nearby Foot Locker store — and asks the Haggler for help.
lead_paragraph: THE Haggler’s last column looked at a practice that employees at Staples call “walking the customer” — essentially, escorting shoppers out of the store, empty-handed, when it’s clear they have no intention of buying a warranty for some steeply discounted computer. You’ve heard of the bait and switch? This is the bait and ditch. Staples officials, you may recall, would say only that they don’t require sales staff members to sell warranties, but e-mails from other Staples employees that arrived after the column’s publication suggest that pressure to sell extras is intense.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 23
abstract: Campaign surrogates for each of the candidates have been dispatched to the Sunday shows this week, focusing less on the unrest in the Arab world and more on the economy and current climate of the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: Campaign surrogates for each of the candidates have been dispatched to the Sunday shows this week, focusing less on the unrest in the Arab world and more on the economy and current climate of the campaign trail. But first, the candidates themselves will appear on Univision’s “Al Punto” for an in-depth look at their policies and platforms. Telemundo’s “Enfoque” will air an extended version of a sit-down with Mitt Romney, who goes into detail about what some view as problems within his campaign and United States foreign policy toward Mexico and Latin America.   Representative Xavier Becerra of California will be on hand to deliver a Democratic rebuttal.

headline: 30 Seconds With Nick Buoniconti
abstract: The Hall of Famer Nick Buoniconti, the linebacker who anchored the No-Name Defense for the Miami Dolphins when they went undefeated in 1972, talks about his work in supporting research for spinal cord injuries and being a player agent, and other topics.
lead_paragraph: Nick Buoniconti was the linebacker who anchored the No-Name Defense for the Miami Dolphins when they went undefeated in 1972. His Dolphins teams made three consecutive Super Bowl appearances, winning two. Buoniconti, 71, was inducted to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2001.

lead_paragraph: As Israel tries to qualify for next year’s World Baseball Classic, it has turned to a team of predominantly American players. It recalls the time when Jim Calhoun did just the opposite, looking to Israel for talent as he was building a men’s basketball powerhouse at Connecticut.

headline: In Kennedy Recordings, History’s Raw Materials
abstract: Secret recordings made by President Kennedy, which include Oval Office discussions about Cuba and space exploration, will now be made accessible to the general public.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — President John F. Kennedy opened the newspaper one day in 1963 and learned to his horror that military aides had built a hospital bedroom for his pregnant wife at an air base on Cape Cod in case she went into labor. He thought the $5,000 spent on the furniture was wasteful and would be a public-relations disaster that would prompt Congress to cut his military budget. The angry president picked up the phone.

headline: Fighting for First, for as Long as It Takes

lead_paragraph: When the game seemed over, Ichiro Suzuki led off the bottom of the 13th inning with an infield single. A misty rain had begun to fall, like the soft spray in a carwash. The low sun through the clouds covered the stadium in a strange orange glow.

Mr. McGraw immediately ran back to his dressing room, grabbed his wife, Faith Hill, and showed her Mr. Strait’s baby face, beaming from beneath a tall white cowboy hat.

abstract: It’s unlikely that Japan, China and Taiwan would agree among themselves to relinquish their claims to some remote and barren islands, but there are several international courts, tribunals and treaties that could sort things out.

headline: College Football Around the Country

lead_paragraph: TAYLOR HEINICKE The quarterback set a Division I record by passing for 730 yards as Old Dominion beat New Hampshire, 64-61. Heinicke had 55 completions on 79 attempts, setting team records for both and coming two completions short of the Football Championship Subdivision record. Sam Durley of Eureka (Ill.) College set the N.C.A.A. single-game mark with 736 passing yards in a Division II game Sept. 1.

headline: Seminoles Stand Atop A.C.C. After Offense vs. Offense Duel
abstract: Florida State amassed 667 yards on offense, rallying from a two-touchdown deficit, and beat Clemson in a matchup of top-10 teams to remain the only unbeaten team in the A.C.C.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — It was a harmless, clichéd joke — Florida State Coach Jimbo Fisher saying he had appealed to use 13 or 14 defenders to slow Clemson’s offense — that now seemed facetious. The same compliment could have been paid to Fisher’s offense, but no defender laughed now. If either No. 4 Florida State or No. 10 Clemson had such an advantage, it might not have mattered, as each offense hummed along Saturday.

headline: Notre Dame Improves to 4-0 for the First Time in a Decade
abstract: In a game that featured 8 turnovers — 6 by Michigan — and 10 penalties, Notre Dame made more than its fair share of mistakes. The Wolverines just made more.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Notre Dame’s return to national prominence took another step forward Saturday night. It was far from graceful, but the 11th-ranked Fighting Irish are 4-0 for the first time in a decade after knocking off No. 18 Michigan, 13-6.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: Tehelka’s cover story this week, “The Invisible Dead,” is about malaria, which the magazine calls Chhattisgarh’s silent killer. Officially, the story says, there have been no malaria deaths in the state this year; investigating such claims, the writers found what they call “a snare of lies and Stalinist statistics.”

headline: In Praise of What Has Been Lost at U.S. Embassies
abstract: Embassies used to be essential places for journalists and diplomats to trade real information. All that changed even before the Chris Stevens tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Rendezvous regular Mark McDonald asked for fresh U.S. embassy stories. Here is an old one from back when America waded into Vietnam, China was a forbidding foe, and Cold War rivals could have easily blown each other off the map.

abstract: Home teams have beaten the point spread in 61.3 percent of their games this season, and the replacement officials may have something to do with it.
lead_paragraph: As the N.F.L.’s replacement officials try their luck again today, here’s a trend to monitor:

headline: ‘I’m Spoiled, but I’m Not a Brat’
abstract: Spoiled children like me aren’t the problem. It’s spoiled children who think they’re entitled to their privilege who are trouble.
lead_paragraph: While growing up, I would routinely choose to play Pokémon over doing the dishes. The fact that I had a choice never struck me as strange. While I certainly had chores — cleaning my room when it became unlivable, walking the dog I had begged for, attending the piano lessons my parents had paid for — I had very few household responsibilities. You could say I was spoiled. And thanks to the recent discourse surrounding my generation’s upbringing, I’ve just discovered that I’m one of millions of 21st-century American kids who have been shielded from hardship by overprotective parents.

headline: Nebraska G.O.P. Draws a Tougher Map for Obama
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2008', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment']
abstract: After President Obama carried Nebraska’s Second District in 2008, Republicans redrew the district lines to make it even more Republican-leaning in 2012.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Nebraska, the Cornhusker State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with John R. Hibbing, a professor of political science at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and Paul Landow, a professor of political science at the University of Nebraska at Omaha.

headline: Getting Some Air in Milan
abstract: Everyone in Milan seems taken with minimalism this season.
lead_paragraph: Everyone in Milan seems taken with minimalism this season. “Firmness… sparseness as elegance,” the Marni show notes began. Scraping away most of the Marni trinkets and funky layers, Consuelo Castiglioni presented a very spare collection indeed. The newsy portions included sleeveless dresses that floated over the body, with their shape enhanced by crisp fabrics and flattering pleats and folds. Nothing seemed too much in this appealing show. The checked outfits that opened the show had a slight 3-D effect, and Ms. Castiglioni included a few more eye tricks later with dresses in a green half-circle print cut and assembled on a diagonal. But she was right to concentrate on her sculptural A-line pieces in solid neutral tones, some as simple as a loose cotton top over flared matching shorts and others with a kind of crazily deconstructed peplum.

headline: Jil Sander: Minimalism With a Kick
abstract: One could find all kinds of meaning in Jil Sander’s show and her return to the label after an eight-year absence.
lead_paragraph: One could find all kinds of meaning in Jil Sander’s show and her return to the label after an eight-year absence. There was the white set with a concave, spherical ceiling that resembled an architect’s idea of a modern, corporate conference room. One woman — Ms. Sander herself — was going to speak that day and the audience, seated around the square platform, was going to listen.

headline: Expectations and the Confidence Fairy
abstract: Not the same.
lead_paragraph: Some readers have asked whether there isn’t an inconsistency between my view that the Fed can promote economic recovery by changing expectations about future policy, and my ridicule of austerity proponents who invoke “confidence” as a reason to believe that austerity will actually be expansionary. But there isn’t really any inconsistency; it’s an orders of magnitude thing.

headline: Mr. Mental Recession
abstract: Why does Romney love Phil Gramm?
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong is upset by the illogic of John Taylor and Phil Gramm’s attack on the Fed. Indeed: it boggles the mind that they believe that a downside of expansionary policy now is that it will require contractionary policy once the economy has recovered. Um, isn’t that exactly what you want monetary policy to do — boost the economy when it’s weak, take away the punchbowl when the party gets going?

headline: Betrayed by Those Wonderful People Out There in the Dark
abstract: From the silent movies to the talkies to the digital age, Ty Burr chronicles the cult of movie stars and their fans.

But not many film historians can see the whole equation as Ty Burr does in “Gods Like Us,” his lively and provocative chronicle of the genesis of movie stars and the metamorphosis of movie stardom. He offers original thinking about the audience factor.

headline: Joy Turns to Despair at National Zoo as Newborn Panda Is Found Dead
abstract: A week after the giant panda cub was born to great fanfare, it was found dead of causes that were not yet clear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A giant panda’s distress call sent keepers at the National Zoo rushing to the aid of her tiny, lifeless cub on Sunday, and the elation over the cub’s birth just a week earlier turned to despair over its death.

headline: With a Servant’s Pregnancy Comes a Man’s Chute From High Society
abstract: In “Mary Broome,” a comedy by Allan Monkhouse, known for his acerbic take on the English bourgeoisie, a man leading a life of privilege is suddenly thrust into poverty.
lead_paragraph: Class conflict gets a workout in the Mint Theater  Company’s lively, penetrating revival of “Mary Broome,” the troupe’s latest invigoration of a largely forgotten work. The play’s author, Allan Monkhouse (1858-1936), also a novelist and critic, was known for his acerbic dissections of the English bourgeoisie. “Mary Broome” — a comedy that first appeared in Manchester in 1911 and was last staged in Manhattan in 1919, at the Neighborhood Playhouse on Grand Street — cuts right to its heart.

headline: Visual Aside Accompanies Sounds of an Ensemble
abstract: St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble performed Mozart’s “Gran Partita” amid an attempt to step up the visual presentation.
lead_paragraph: The third movement of Mozart’s “Gran Partita,” his Serenade No. 10 for winds in B flat, is one of the most quietly, simply sublime passages in music. It begins with a simple four-note figure that rises and then falls into a gently pulsing, syncopated carpet of sound.

headline: Robust Cello and Viola, With a Few Whoops
abstract: The New Juilliard Ensemble, led by Joel Sachs, continues to provide important training for students. Saturday’s program dabbled in dissonance, sound art and an exploration of animated films.
lead_paragraph: When the New Juilliard Ensemble made its debut in September 1993, Edward Rothstein, writing in The New York Times, described the splintered nature of the city’s new-music scene at the time and the intense competition for audiences and financing.

headline: After a Fitting Tribute, Liverpool’s Inspired Play Falls Short
abstract: Liverpool’s chance to remember the victims of the 1989 Hillsborough disaster after a report exonerated its supporters unfolded beautifully, poignantly and without incident.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — In the buildup to the Liverpool versus Manchester United match Sunday, there was little talk of the soccer game; the eyes of the world focused not on the field but the spectators surrounding it.

headline: Even When There’s a Him Around, Balanchine Is Still About Her
abstract: New York City Ballet performed four Balanchine pieces at Lincoln Center, incorporating that choreographer’s complexity and leanings.
lead_paragraph: The biographies of George Balanchine tell us of his several wives, of his other loves, and of his devotion to the female dancer. His ballets, though, make his feeling for women yet more complicated. Even in moments of amorous surrender one part of his women stays unreachable. And one part of his men always craves, in female terms, what they cannot have.

headline: NFL Networks Added, but Not Available to All
abstract: Some Time Warner Cable customers did not get the NFL Network, or its companion service, NFL RedZone, by the time games began Sunday. A nine-year impasse between the companies ended Friday with a deal to carry both channels.
lead_paragraph: 7:12 p.m. | Updated

headline: When Silenced, They Speak Out in Art
abstract: “Voices of Strength: Contemporary Dance & Theater by Women From Africa” at New York Live Arts explores the link between feminism and art.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night at New York Live Arts the two-part “Voices of Strength: Contemporary Dance & Theater by Women From Africa” unveiled its second program, a shared evening of works by Maria Helena Pinto and Bouchra Ouizguen. These choreographic voices — the first from Mozambique, the second from Morocco — each had something to impart about the link between feminism and making art.

headline: Giorgio Armani: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', "Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index", 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Data to be released will include the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for July, consumer confidence for September and new-home sales for August.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released will include the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for July, and consumer confidence for September (Tuesday); new-home sales for August (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, durable goods for August, second-quarter gross domestic product (final) and pending home sales for August (Thursday); and personal income and spending for August, the Chicago purchasing manager index for SeptemberThomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for September (Friday).

headline: You Have a Role in This Play: Peeping Tom
abstract: “Habit,” an art-theater project from David Levine, takes place in a structure within the Essex Street Market; audiences look through its windows or walk in.
lead_paragraph: When I first looked in on them, around 4:30 p.m., they were all asleep. Or unconscious. Or dead. It was hard to tell. An hour and some minutes later, the three of them were knocked out again, but this time in different positions, different places and, come to think of it, different clothes. And that was when things started to get interesting.

headline: A Jazzman Looks at Loss and Finds Inspiration
abstract: Dave Douglas’s new album, “Be Still,” is underpinned by a recommendation from his mother, who died last year.
lead_paragraph: Dave Douglas dealt sparingly with the emotional back story at 92YTriBeCa on Wednesday night, in the auspicious first outing by his new quintet. During a concert built around the Protestant hymns on his gorgeous and contemplative new album, “Be Still” — due out on Tuesday on Greenleaf, his independent label — Mr. Douglas spoke of his motivation only in passing. The album, he said simply, “came about because all these hymns and songs were songs that my mother recommended that I play.”

headline: Iraq, Afghanistan … Iran? We’ve Been Here Before.
abstract: Four years ago, Barack Obama called the conflict in Afghanistan “a war we have to win.” His administration has decimated Al Qaeda and killed Osama bin Laden, but few would say it’s a war that America has won.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ten years ago, President George W. Bush and top officials in his administration assured Americans that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction and that an American invasion of that country was justified and wouldn’t be that difficult.

headline: Yankees End Homestand With Loss, but With Lead Intact
abstract: The Yankees had yet another opportunity to pull out a late-inning victory, but the Athletics held on to end New York’s seven-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: There would be no dramatic comeback or postgame delirium at Yankee Stadium, in contrast to the previous two days. The Yankees, for the third time this series, had an opportunity to win with a hit. But the Oakland Athletics held on for a 5-4 win Sunday.

headline: Kind of Like ‘Will & Grace,’ but Both Guys This Time
abstract: A lot of the themes and situations on the new CBS program “Partners” have been seen before in other shows.
lead_paragraph: Some shows need a script doctor. The new sitcom “Partners,” based on the working relationship of its creators, David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, calls out for a couples counselor. Maybe he could explain why this celebration of friendship feels so sour and joyless.

headline: After Jail and Release, New Fame as an Author
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Damien Echols, one of the defendants in the notorious West Memphis Three murder case and the author of a new memoir, finds himself an unlikely and uncomfortable celebrity.
lead_paragraph: On a Thursday afternoon walk along Canal Street, Damien Echols was reflecting on how this busy thoroughfare once nourished him in the first few months after his August 2011 release from a super-maximum-security prison in Arkansas.

headline: The Pettiness, the Paparazzi, the Pressure
abstract: Kareena Kapoor plays a Bollywood queen struggling to weather the vicissitudes of showbiz in Madhur Bhandarkar’s “Heroine.”
lead_paragraph: Stardom is a vale of tears in Madhur Bhandarkar’s “Heroine,” about the ups and downs, and downs and downs of Mahi Arora (Kareena Kapoor), a Bollywood queen with a self-destructive flair for making headlines. Pulpy but attenuated, “Heroine” tries to do too much: deliver an exposé of the back-stabbing film business while also drawing a portrait of a woman caught in its vice.

headline: Jets Make the Most of a Second Chance
abstract: Nick Folk’s 33-yard field goal with 6 minutes 4 seconds left in overtime boosted the Jets, who lost Darrelle Revis to a left knee injury in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — All the Jets wanted was for this game to end already, this ugly, sloppy, chaotic game that had claimed their best player, Darrelle Revis, confirmed that their Week 1 offensive eruption was an aberration and would send them scurrying afterward to gulp Pedialyte as if it were water in the desert.

headline: A Touch of Melancholy From the Top of the World
abstract: The Danish group Efterklang joined with the Wordless Music Orchestra to perform a symphonic realization of its new album, “Piramida,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Time was, if you were an ambitious pop band looking to upholster your music with orchestral finery, you enlisted an arranger who traveled in similar circles: a Jack Nitzsche, Clare Fischer or Michael Kamen. Presumably, no rock star ever phoned Aaron Copland.

headline: Buffett Cup in Omaha
abstract: At the Buffett Cup in Omaha this month probably the best defense occurred in the diagramed deal.
lead_paragraph: At the Buffett Cup in Omaha this month probably the best defense occurred in the diagramed deal. It was played in three no-trump four times, but the contract failed only once.

headline: Perpendicular to the Keel
abstract: Is John Dunn’s puzzle disappearing before our very eyes?
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Unusual Puzzle Alert! The Tuesday, Sept. 25 puzzle will be offered in both Across Lite and as a PDF. Because of the unusual nature of this puzzle, some elements of the grid and the cluing will not reproduce the same way in Across Lite. If you normally solve online in Across Lite, we strongly recommend that you print out the PDF and solve it that way.

headline: Belarus Votes as Europe Keeps a Watch for Signs That Sanctions Can End
abstract: The question was not whether President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s supporters would continue to dominate Parliament, but whether electoral changes would pass muster with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — Belarus held parliamentary elections on Sunday, though the outcome was hardly in doubt: supporters of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko have traditionally won, and now hold, all 110 seats in the chamber.

headline: More ‘Treme’ Is on the Way
abstract: Thecreators of the series announced that HBO had ordered a fourth and final season one day before the Season 3 premiere, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the HBO drama “Treme” were given multiple reasons to celebrate over the weekend as David Simon and Eric Overmyer, the creators of the series, announced that HBO had ordered a fourth and final season one day before the Season 3 premiere, The Times-Picayune of New Orleans reported. In a speech before a show screening at the Joy Theater in New Orleans on Saturday Mr. Simon told the audience that the fourth season would be shortened, with a total episode count to be determined. “We are going to be back for a season 3.5,” Mr. Simon said. He also announced that all of the actors who portray the varied characters that populate the show’s post-Katrina New Orleans, will return, “To a person they all came back,” he said. “We’re happy for a chance to finish the story on our own terms.”

headline: Television’s Fall Season Endures
abstract: The idea of a fall season of TV premieres, originally tied to the model year for cars, has survived changing viewer habits and the constant flow of new cable programs.
lead_paragraph: For years, Alan Wurtzel, the head of research for NBC, has questioned the enduring validity of a television season — the ritual competition of network series, which begins again Monday night.

headline: A Connecticut Building for Sanaa
abstract: Designs for a new building by the architecture firm Sanaa, to be used as a spiritual and community center, are to be submitted for approval on Monday by Grace Farms Foundation in New Canaan, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Designs for a new building by the architecture firm Sanaa, to be used as a spiritual and community center, are to be submitted for approval on Monday by Grace Farms Foundation in New Canaan, Conn. The plans for the building, called the River, which must be approved by the town’s Planning and Zoning Commission, call for construction on a sliver of the 75-acre Grace Farms property that the foundation is preserving as permanent open space. The building is to have landscaping by the Philadelphia firm Olin. Sanaa, founded in Tokyo in 1995, is the architecture firm of Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa, who received the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2010.

headline: Another Lesson in Consistency, as Vettel Wins in Singapore
abstract: Sebastian Vettel won the race in Singapore, but Fernando Alonso, by finishing third, proved once again how important consistency is in the race for the 2012 drivers’ title.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — It has been the leitmotif of the season: The key to who will win the drivers’ title will likely come down to consistency, not necessarily victories. Sebastian Vettel took only his second victory of the season in his Red Bull car at the Singapore Grand Prix on Sunday, but he moved back into second place in the series.

headline: To Complete a Sweep, the Mets Overcome the Sun, the Wind and the Marlins
abstract: After intentional walks in the seventh and ninth innings to get to Ruben Tejada, he singled in the ninth to score Scott Hairston and lift the Mets to a victory.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ struggling offense sprang to life Sunday as Ruben Tejada’s bases-loaded single with two outs in the ninth inning drove in Scott Hairston for the winning run in a 3-2 victory against the Miami Marlins.

headline: Kerik Is Leaving His Cell to Testify at a Bronx Trial
abstract: Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner imprisoned on federal charges of tax fraud and other crimes, is set to take the stand in a perjury case.
lead_paragraph: Bernard B. Kerik, the disgraced former police commissioner of New York, will return to the city in the coming days, though certainly not triumphantly, and not yet as a free man.

headline: Manchester United 2, Liverpool 1
abstract: Kristian Walsh was at Anfield on Sunday for Manchester United’s 2-1 victory over Liverpool. But of course the day was about much more than that.
lead_paragraph: Kristian Walsh was at Anfield on Sunday for Manchester United’s 2-1 victory over Liverpool. But of course the day was about much more than that. Read his article on the game, the Hillsborough tributes and the fans’ behavior here, and come back to comment.

headline: Schiano Does It Again
abstract: Tampa Bay Coach Greg Schiano, criticized for ignoring an unwritten rule last week, doubled down this week by attacking the Cowboys’ victory formation.
lead_paragraph: Tampa Bay Coach Greg Schiano remains unimpressed with your victory formation. He was criticized by Giants Coach Tom Coughlin and many others last Sunday for ignoring an unwritten rule about not attacking an offense when the quarterback is poised to kneel to kill off the final seconds of a game.

headline: For Vice President, a Heartbeat Away From the Public Isn’t Close Enough
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Politicians have always pressed the flesh, but few relish doing so as heartily as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Yes, Joseph R. Biden Jr. gives a lot of stump speeches.

headline: Sept. 23: Does Omaha Matter?
abstract: A new Nebraska poll is not very important, as fun as it might be to speculate about cases where Omaha could make the difference.
lead_paragraph: It’s something of a tradition for newspapers to release polls on Sundays late in a presidential campaign. This Sunday, there were polls out in Ohio, Florida and Pennsylvania — but as it’s Nebraska day at FiveThirtyEight, let’s start with one from the Cornhusker State.

headline: Reinventing Ethics
abstract: The Ten Commandments and the Golden Rule are no longer adequate. We need fresh approaches to right and wrong.
lead_paragraph: What’s good and what’s bad? There are plenty of reasons to believe that human nature changes slowly, if at all — all’s still fair in love and war. For millennia, religious believers have attributed our nature to God’s image, as well as to God’s plan.  In recent years, evolutionary psychologists peered directly at our forerunners on the savannahs of East Africa; if human beings change, we do so gradually over thousands of years.  Given little or nothing new in the human firmament, traditional morality — the “goods” and “bads” as outlined in the Ten Commandments or the Golden Rule — should suffice.

headline: Mobile Services and Cable TV Are Unexpected Allies
abstract: A little-noticed result of Verizon’s $3.9 billion airwave purchase is that cable companies can now use the carrier’s retail presence to sell cable packaged with phone and wireless service.
lead_paragraph: BASKING RIDGE, N.J. — Tucked amid rows of office cubicles at the sprawling Verizon Wireless headquarters here and hidden behind a locked door sit the company’s best kept retail secrets.

headline: Obama and Romney Offer a Possible Preview of Their First Debate
abstract: In separate interviews for the CBS News program “60 Minutes,” the candidates criticized each other over foreign and domestic policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney criticized President Obama in remarks broadcast on Sunday for refusing to meet with Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, during this week’s United Nations General Assembly meeting, saying it sends a message that the administration is distancing itself from an important Middle East ally.

headline: Using Twitter to Promote the Fall TV Season
abstract: To showcase its new fall season, the CW network will use Twitter to preview the season premiere of the program “Emily Owens, M.D.”
lead_paragraph: Lots of people are accustomed to watching television while simultaneously posting updates to Twitter or Facebook or looking up information online, or what is known in media circles as “the second screen experience.” But why watch two screens when you can start with one?

headline: Emmy Awards 2012 Red Carpet
abstract: Looks from the crimson runway at the 64th annual Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the crimson runway at the 64th annual Emmy Awards.

headline: Helicopter Coaching Hurts Could-Be Leaders
abstract: The short leash the Jets have on quarterback Mark Sanchez has given him little room to stretch and grow as a leader.
lead_paragraph: Phil Simms remembers a harsh lesson in leadership as if it happened yesterday. During a mundane practice in 1987, the season after the Giants won Super Bowl XXI, the offense, especially the offensive line, seemed to be sleepwalking.

headline: Spotlighting Women Who Lead
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Advertising Age’s first ever list of the 100 most influential women in the industry coincides with the 100th anniversary of a trade organization that supports women in advertising.
lead_paragraph: It would be nearly impossible to write about the 100th anniversary of the Advertising Women of New York and Advertising Age’s first ever list of the 100 most influential women in the industry without mentioning the last season of the AMC drama “Mad Men.”

headline: Conservatives Want to ‘Let Ryan Be Ryan’ on Campaign Trail
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s slow fade into the afterthought role usually played by running mates has given Republicans a new outlet for frustration over the state of the race.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s selection as the Republican vice-presidential nominee is now yielding something Mitt Romney’s campaign can do without: second-guessing about how Mr. Ryan is being put to use.

headline: Seminoles See Dawn of New Glory Days
abstract: With the quarterback E. J. Manuel and the running back Chris Thompson leading the way, Florida State looked like a national championship contender in its victory against Clemson.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — What E. J. Manuel would call the biggest victory of his career had been secured when he galloped free down the sideline, with a clear path to the end zone. All night, he had listened to the former Florida State quarterback Charlie Ward’s advice — take what the defense gives you — and with this run, Manuel joined Ward as the only Seminole to throw for 300 yards and rush for 100 in a game.

headline: Skills Honed in Illicit Trades, and Put to Better Use
abstract: Defy Ventures, a nonprofit organization that provides entrepreneurial training to people with criminal backgrounds, held its first sales exposition on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: As a heroin dealer in Rhode Island, Jose Vasquez made $2,000 a day. He said he had a way with his customers. He took his best clients out for dinner and bought them presents on their birthdays.

headline: Yankees Not the Best in Tight Races
abstract: Over the decades, the Yankees have been baseball’s top team, though not because of a dominance in close pennant and division races.
lead_paragraph: For all the American League and division titles in their glorious history, the Yankees were for decades seldom involved in a day-to-day, night-to-night pennant race that boiled down to the season’s final weekend, if not the final game.

headline: Proposed Bill Could Change Royalty Rates for Internet Radio
abstract: Internet radio services like Pandora hope legislation recently introduced in Congress will lower the rates they pay copyright holders to the levels paid by satellite radio.
lead_paragraph: Willing buyer, willing seller. Those four words would seem innocuous, but in the world of Internet radio nothing is more contentious.

headline: Romney Blames Obama for His Campaign Challenges
abstract: Asked why he was behind in some polls, Mitt Romney accused the Obama campaign of distorting his record. He also attributed his light campaign schedule to the president’s decision to opt out of the federal campaign finance system.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Mitt Romney, who has been criticized by members of his party in recent weeks for not campaigning aggressively enough and who trails President Obama in polls in most swing states, placed the blame for his campaign’s struggles squarely on the president himself Sunday afternoon.

headline: With Win, Snedeker Also Takes Tour Title
abstract: Needing to win the Tour Championship to beat out Rory McIlroy for the FedEx Cup, Brandt Snedeker came up with three big birdies on the back nine at East Lake Golf Club.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Before the most critical round of his professional career, Brandt Snedeker stopped by the Shepherd Center, a rehabilitation hospital for patients with spinal cord or brain injuries, and spent 30 minutes with his longtime instructor’s son, Tucker Anderson.

headline: The Satanic Video
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Books and Literature', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: What Salman Rushdie can tell us about America’s Muslim problem and the future of the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: THE alchemy of modern media works with amazing speed. Start with a cheesy anti-Muslim video that resembles a bad trailer for a Sacha Baron Cohen comedy. It becomes YouTube fuel for protest across the Islamic world and a pretext for killing American diplomats. That angry spasm begets an inflammatory Newsweek cover, “MUSLIM RAGE,” which in turn inspires a Twitter hashtag that reduces the whole episode to a running joke:

headline: America’s Inevitable Retreat From the Middle East
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: The symbolic import of last week’s Middle East violence is unmistakable: four decades after Saigon, the drama of waning American power is being re-enacted.
lead_paragraph: THE murder of four Americans in Libya and mob assaults on the United States’ embassies across the Muslim world this month have reminded many of 1979, when radical Islamists seized the American mission in Tehran. There, too, extremists running wild after the fall of a pro-American tyrant had found a cheap way of empowering themselves.

headline: ‘Frankenweenie’ Digital Book Updates the Movie Tie-In
abstract: “Frankenweenie: An Electrifying Book,” free on Apple’s iBookstore, contains original art and production photos and also features music, videos and interviews with some of the movie’s creators, including Tim Burton.
lead_paragraph: Coffee-table books, while entertaining to thumb through, tend to gather dust when they languish on said table. So to showcase the animated movie “Frankenweenie,” Disney Publishing Worldwide took an interactive approach, bypassing the traditional oversize tome and heading straight for the iPad.

headline: The Optimism Cure
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Mitt Romney reveals that his real economic plan relies on magic.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is optimistic about optimism. In fact, it’s pretty much all he’s got. And that fact should make you very pessimistic about his chances of leading an economic recovery.

headline: Government Issues Order to Disband Libya Forces
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: Libya’s interim government ordered the breakup of all militias that do not fall under its authority, and demanded that those militias pull out of military compounds and public property within 48 hours.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Libya’s interim government on Sunday ordered the breakup of all militias that do not fall under its authority, and demanded that those militias pull out of military compounds and public property within 48 hours.

headline: Discovery of Skeleton Puts Richard III in Battle Once Again
abstract: Supporters who believe Richard III’s reputation was smeared hope the potential discovery of his skeleton will lead to a reassessment of his brief but violent reign.
lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — For more than 500 years, King Richard III has been the most widely reviled of English monarchs. But a stunning archaeological find this month here in the English Midlands — a skeleton that medieval scholars believe is very likely to be Richard’s — could lead to a reassessment of his brief but violent reign.

headline: Jennifer Jaff, Advocate for the Ill, Dies at 55
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Legal Profession', "Crohn's Disease", 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Ms. Jaff was a lawyer whose nearly four-decade struggle with Crohn’s disease, an incurable gastrointestinal disorder, led her to become a leading advocate for people with chronic illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Jaff, a lawyer whose nearly four-decade struggle with a debilitating disease led her to become a leading advocate for people with chronic illnesses, died on Sept. 14 at her home in Farmington, Conn. She was 55.

headline: Public Television Takes Role in Curbing Dropout Rates
abstract: More than 100 public television stations showed a seven-hour telethon on Saturday that asked viewers to work with community organizations to lower the nation’s high school dropout rate.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 public television stations reaching two-thirds of the nation’s viewers turned over their air on Saturday to an unusual seven-hour telethon broadcast live from WNET-TV’s Lincoln Center studio in New York.

headline: The Cost of the N.F.L.’s Will to Win
abstract: The N.F.L.’s carefully maintained sheen loses a bit of luster with each call that has to be overturned and with each extended conference.
lead_paragraph: One of the N.F.L.’s locked-out officials was at home Sunday waiting and watching, like everyone else, for the weekly blooper reel to begin.

headline: Rape in Hudson River Park Is Latest in a String of Jarring Crimes
abstract: For some, the rape of a young woman in Hudson River Park on Saturday only hardened the belief that the city can still be dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Just after 6 a.m. on Sunday, Georgie Lau cut a solitary figure as he walked down Harrison Street toward the Hudson River in Manhattan, a fishing rod in one hand and a bucket in the other. Before him was a patch of Hudson River Park where, little more than 24 hours earlier, a young woman had been raped after going to sit near the water by herself in the early morning.

headline: A Vexing Flaw in the Subway Is Finally Fixed
abstract: Beginning on Tuesday, New York City’s fussiest subway transfer point, the one that goes one way but not the other, will cease to be a daily frustration for straphangers.
lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, it has stood out as a singularly vexing flaw of the subway system, a glaring inequity that has frustrated generations of riders and has even puzzled transit officials, who have wondered how the situation ever came to be.

headline: Marv Kessler, Coach and Basketball Instructor, Dies at 80
abstract: Kessler, a product of Brooklyn’s schoolyards, spent more than half a century in basketball as a player, coach, scout and, most prominently, a camp instructor who molded young athletes.
lead_paragraph: Marv Kessler, a product of Brooklyn’s schoolyards who spent more than half a century in basketball as a player, a coach, a scout and, most prominently, a camp instructor who molded young athletes like Patrick Ewing and Stephon Marbury, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Another E-Commerce Site Tests Advertising on TV
abstract: The social shopping Web site Fab.com this week is beginning its experiment in TV advertising with a budget of $1 million. Last week, the online eyeglasses store Warby Parker began a TV test.
lead_paragraph: Decades ago, commercials for Fab detergent were a ubiquitous presence on television.

headline: Genetically Modified Food
abstract: William Y. Brown of the Brookings Institution responds to a column by Mark Bittman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Central Park Rape Case
abstract: The writer Letty Cottin Pogrebin responds to coverage of the recent rape of a woman in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Money Talk Is Good
abstract: Why our interest in money may be an indulgence, but also essential.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rationing Health Care to Control Costs
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Strong, diverse reactions from readers to an Op-Ed essay about cutting Medicare spending.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Uncertainty in Wake of Injury to Revis
abstract: The Jets’ star cornerback, who already missed time this season with a concussion, sustained a knee injury against the Dolphins.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Things figure to get a lot tougher for the Jets if cornerback Darrelle Revis cannot get back on the field. Revis, considered the league’s top cornerback, left Sunday’s 23-20 overtime victory against the Miami Dolphins in the third quarter with a left knee injury.

headline: Politics, Principle and an Attack on the Courts
keywords: ['Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: A right-wing campaign to oust an able judge in Iowa raises worrisome questions.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, in what should have been a quiet judicial retention election, Iowa voters threw out three State Supreme Court justices for taking seriously their duty to protect fundamental rights. The three had provoked right-wing wrath for joining a unanimous 2009 ruling overturning the state’s prohibition on same-sex marriage. Conservative forces succeeded in ousting them by tapping antigay sentiment and attacking “activist” judges. Those same forces — aided openly this time by the state’s Republican Party — are now calling for the removal of David Wiggins, another capable judge who joined in the marriage decision.

headline: What Do Teachers Deserve? In Idaho, Referendum May Offer Answer
abstract: Chicago’s fight may be over, but in Idaho, the debate over schools has morphed into a harsh discussion about whom the voters should trust.
lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho — In the struggle to fix the nation’s public schools, the old red-state, blue-state idea is looking as dated as Dick and Jane. You can hear the change in the voice of Gov. C. L. Otter, a Republican here in one of the most deeply conservative corners of the country, when he expresses a brotherhood bond with Rahm Emanuel, the Democratic mayor of Chicago and former Obama administration chief of staff.

headline: The Shocking News About Cod
abstract: No species can rebound when it has been stripped of its most fertile members as the cod has been.
lead_paragraph: The ideal fish for human consumption would mature quickly and reproduce in staggering numbers. This does not describe the Atlantic cod. Cod mature late — at 4 to 6 years old — and they can live as long as 25 years. Female cod do, in fact, produce astonishing numbers of eggs. But older cod lay two or three times as many eggs as younger cod. This means that a healthy cod population must include relatively large numbers of older fish.

headline: Deadly Attack in Libya Was Major Blow to C.I.A. Efforts
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Among personnel pulled from Benghazi after the assault on the American mission were intelligence operatives and contractors who were crucial to surveillance on militants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans has dealt the Central Intelligence Agency a major setback in its intelligence-gathering efforts at a time of increasing instability in the North African nation.

headline: On the Wrong Side
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'Arms Trade', 'Editorials']
abstract: Iraq is engaging in a dangerous game by enabling the flow of arms from Iran to Syria.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of Iraq’s Shiite-led government have often advised the United States not to worry about their ties with Iran, where Shiites are also in the majority. But the assurances are getting harder to swallow. Baghdad is showing a distressing willingness to side with the region’s most repressive regimes, not just Iran but also Iran’s chief ally, the brutal Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Woods and McIlroy Struggle in Final Round but Have Some Reasons to Celebrate
abstract: Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy, tournament co-favorites, shot 72 and 74 Sunday in the Tour Championship.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Let the record show that before this past weekend, Tiger Woods could not have owned the East Lake Golf Club course more if he had held the deed to the property.

headline: Liking It or Not, States Prepare for Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A handful of states whose Republican governors oppose President Obama’s health care overhaul are quietly working to have an insurance exchange ready before the deadline next month to create one.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Like many Republican governors, Jan Brewer of Arizona is a stinging critic of President Obama’s health care law. When the Supreme Court upheld it in June, she called the ruling “an overreaching and unaffordable assault on states’ rights and individual liberty.”

headline: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt on iPhone
abstract: Once the best of friends, Google and Apple are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Once the best of friends, Google and Apple have become foes, battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace. Last week, the hostilities took a new turn when they spilled right onto smartphone screens.

headline: To Sell Agenda, Cuomo Puts Team on the Road
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s trip to the Adirondacks on Sunday to promote tourism is similar to other excursions in which top officials have gone around the state to highlight his priorities.
lead_paragraph: NORTH HUDSON, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, dressed in khaki cargo pants and a navy windbreaker that said “Team Cuomo/We Deliver,” paddled expertly from the rear seat of a canoe on Sunday afternoon. He had just gone fishing, catching an eight-inch brook trout, and now it was time for another adventure.

headline: Running as Outsiders, With a Catch: They’re In
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Members of Congress would prefer not to advertise it — they are doctors and cowboys and anything else, while their opponents are Washington insiders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of his campaign advertisements, Joe Heck emphasizes his long career as a physician taking care of elderly patients. Dan Benishek, in an ad, refers with a tinge of sadness to the “career politician” who is competing with him for a House seat. Ann Kirkpatrick informs viewers that she is extremely fond of driving.

headline: Covering the World of Business, Digital Only
abstract: After losing millions as publisher of The Atlantic, David Bradley opts to present business news with Quartz, the media company’s new, strictly digital forum.
lead_paragraph: Business titans are generally not prone to self-appraisal, and when they do take stock, it usually begins and ends with a list of their conquests.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 3
abstract: The Jets overcame the Miami Dolphins in overtime, 23-20, but the game was not without injuries to key playmakers.
lead_paragraph: The Jets overcame the Miami Dolphins in overtime, 23-20, but the game was not without injuries to key playmakers.

headline: From Star to Spoiler, Yankees’ Nunez Tries to Look Ahead After a Costly Error
abstract: In less than 24 hours, Eduardo Nunez, a 25-year-old infielder, went from being responsible for a victory to being a main reason for the Yankees’ loss to the Athletics.
lead_paragraph: Life in the majors for a young player can bring with it many challenges and a number of lessons. Eduardo Nunez, a 25-year-old Yankees infielder, is a prime example of such a learning curve.

headline: Uranium Substitute Is No Longer Needed, but Its Disposal May Pose Security Risk
abstract: The government has stockpiles of a nuclear fuel called uranium 233 that is no longer needed, and some experts worry that a plan for its disposal will pose a security risk.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the dawn of the civilian nuclear age in the 1950s, one of the pressing questions was how to find enough fuel for reactors and bombs. The government and the private sector seized on a man-made substitute for natural uranium, producing about 3,400 pounds of an exotic and expensive material called uranium 233.

headline: At United Nations, Renewed Focus on Syria, if Not New Ideas

abstract: Despite at least three high-level meetings planned during the General Assembly, no broad new initiatives to end the war are expected.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The raging conflict in Syria will take center stage starting Monday as some 120 world leaders converge on the United Nations for what is sometimes called “diplomacy’s annual trade fair.”

headline: More Access to Contraceptives in City Schools
abstract: A pilot program aimed at high school students has encountered little resistance from parents since it began last year, New York City health officials said.
lead_paragraph: A New York City pilot program to distribute morning-after pills and other contraceptives to high school students has encountered little resistance from parents since it began early last year, health officials said Sunday.

headline: A Couple Hailing a Cab in Midtown Is Struck by a Car
abstract: Rubin and Denise Baum were hit by a car Saturday while trying to hail a cab — nearly 40 years after they first met while both hailing a cab. Mr. Baum died from his injuries.
lead_paragraph: She met her future husband nearly four decades ago, on West 34th Street. It was a beautiful summer afternoon, and they were both trying to hail a cab.

headline: Costly Phone Calls for Inmates
abstract: The time is long past for the F.C.C. to give state prisoners access to reasonably priced interstate telephone service.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress and civil rights groups are pushing the Federal Communications Commission to rein in telephone companies that, in many states, charge inmates spectacularly high rates that can force their families to choose between keeping in touch with a relative behind bars and, in some cases, putting food on the table.

headline: Sinai Group Claims Role in Attack on Israel
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: An obscure militant group based in the Sinai region claimed responsibility for a cross-border attack Friday that killed an Israeli soldier.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An obscure militant group based in Egypt’s North Sinai region claimed responsibility over the weekend for a cross-border attack that killed an Israeli soldier last week. The claim called fresh attention to the uphill struggle the newly formed Egyptian government is facing to control the restive Sinai region.

headline: Israel Falls in Qualifier Final, but Team Plays for Much More
abstract: Israel’s road to the World Baseball Classic tournament ended Sunday with a loss to Spain in the 10th inning. But the team consistently drew crowds of Jewish fans with displays of support and pride.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — Just an inning earlier, Jay Dermer waved the flag of Israel high over his head, holding both ends so that it stretched taut in triumphant fists. Israel had just taken a two-run lead against Spain in a World Baseball Classic qualifying game, and the 1,500 or so Jewish fans at Roger Dean Stadium on Sunday celebrated with equal parts pleasure and pride.

headline: Foxconn Factory in China Is Closed After Worker Riot

abstract: Foxconn Technology said on Monday that it had closed one of its large Chinese plants after police were called in to to break up a fight among factory employees.
lead_paragraph: Foxconn Technology, a major supplier to some of the world’s electronics giants, including Apple, said that it had closed one of its large Chinese plants early Monday after police were called in to break up a fight among factory employees.

headline: Data Barns in a Farm Town, Gobbling Power and Flexing Muscle
abstract: When Internet factories come to town, they can feel less like their sleek, clean and convenient image and more like old-time manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: QUINCY, Wash. — Set in the dry hills and irrigated farmland of Central Washington, Grant County is known for its robust harvest of apples, potatoes, cherries and beans. But for Microsoft, a prime lure was the region’s other valuable resource: cheap electrical power.

headline: Winners of the Thelonious Monk Competition Announced
abstract: Jamison Ross’s victory reinforces perceptions of the Monk Competition as a proving ground for artists already active professionally.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —Jamison Ross took first prize in the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Drums Competition, awarded at the Kennedy Center on Sunday night. Mr. Ross, 24, from Jacksonville, Fla., brought a relaxed but commanding sense of swing to his performance with a competition house band, consisting of the saxophonist Jon Gordon, the pianist Geoffrey Keezer and the bassist Rodney Whitaker.

headline: Aspiring U.S. Diplomats Stiffen Their Resolve After Ambassador’s Death
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: What are aspiring U.S. diplomats saying about the murder of the U.S. ambassador to Libya and three other Americans? The attack might have reasonably led many of them to rethink their career paths. But graduate students now in the Foreign Service pipeline seem to have strengthened their plans to seek diplomatic postings abroad.
lead_paragraph: The recent killing of the U.S. ambassador to Libya, J. Christopher Stevens, along with three other Americans at the mission in Benghazi, now appears to have been a premeditated assault, not merely collateral damage from yet another anti-American protest. The deadly ambush reinforced the idea that many diplomats — even those guarded by security personnel and working in fortified buildings — can quickly find themselves in harm’s way.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama flies to New York on Monday afternoon for the United Nations General Assembly, he will dispense with the usual battery of one-on-one meetings with world leaders so he can tape an appearance on “The View” and return by midweek to the battleground state of Ohio. Left to help smooth over any ruffled feathers will be Tom Donilon.

headline: Has Manmohan Singh Gambled Enough?
abstract: The prime minister is hampered by voters’ resistance to reform, economist argues.
lead_paragraph: After a week of high political drama in New Delhi, the prime minister of India, Manmohan Singh, spoke to the nation on Friday evening, making the case for economic reform that had, until then, languished during his tenure.  The speech capped a week in which the government announced a series of long-delayed measures, most notably raising the price of diesel and opening up foreign direct investment for retailers who sell multiple brands and in aviation and broadcasting.

headline: An Autobiography Told With Others’ Photos
abstract: For the first time, the famed gallerist Howard Greenberg will show photographs from his personal collection, in two exhibits in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Howard Greenberg is known for the erudite exhibits at his gallery, Howard Greenberg Gallery, and his role in shaping both the market for photography and the photographic canon. For the first time, photographs from his personal collection are being exhibited, at the Musée de l’Elysée in Lausanne, Switzerland, through June 2013, and the Henri Cartier-Bresson Foundation in Paris, opening Jan. 15. He spoke with James Estrin last week. The interview has been edited.

headline: Getting Ready for the Storms of the North Pacific
abstract: Preparation and chance battle as a new expedition departs for the North Pacific to look for storms and big waves.
lead_paragraph: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes.Thursday, Sept. 647.601 degrees north latitude, 122.333 degrees west longitudeAnsel Adams always said that chance favors the prepared, but these days I wonder how far ahead he looked before taking his photos. Four years ago, my lab at the University of Washington started building a new buoy to measure the turbulence in breaking ocean waves. Now the chance to use it is fast approaching. Preparation is foremost on my mind.

headline: Sustainable Innovation: Gates Foundation Reinvents the Toilet

headline: What Would You Pay for a Vanity License Plate? $90,000?
abstract: 18. BRUCE LEE. W1N W1N. BATMAN. In Hong Kong, these and other vanity plates — including copious combinations of double and triple initials — have raised millions at transportation department auctions.

headline: Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong Seeks Treatment After Rant
abstract: A statement on the band’s Web site said Mr. Armstrong was being treated for substance abuse after he halted the band’s performance on Friday at the iHeartRadio Music Festival to deliver an angry tirade.
lead_paragraph: While the occasional onstage outburst or round of instrument destruction would seem to be well within the purview of a modern-day rock star, this behavior has led the Green Day front man Billie Joe Armstrong to seek rehabilitation after a profanity-laden rant at a performance over the weekend, the band announced on its Web site.

headline: A Voice From Myanmar, Worthy of a Hero’s Welcome
abstract: The Day: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who has emerged from house arrest in Myanmar to become the opposition leader in Parliament, embodies the never-ending struggle for human dignity and decency, everywhere.
lead_paragraph: Long ago, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi lived for a few years in New York. On her arrival in the late 1960s, she was surprised to find a city that was exactly as she had pictured it, skyscrapers and all. “I thought, ‘Oh, it looks just like a postcard,’” Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi said on Saturday. “Somehow, I never really believed it would be quite like that.”

headline: Former Israeli Premier Gets Suspended Sentence
abstract: Ehud Olmert, a former prime minister of Israel, was sentenced by a Jerusalem court on Monday to a one-year suspended jail term and a maximum fine of about $19,000 for breach of trust.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, a former prime minister of Israel, was sentenced by a Jerusalem court on Monday to a one-year suspended prison term and a maximum fine of about $19,000 for breach of trust. The relatively light sentence ended a long-running prosecution that forced Mr. Olmert from office. It also opened the way for a possible political comeback.

headline: For the Love of Country
abstract: Russian politicians believe they deserve to be loved by virtue of being in power. Criticism rankles them and protest feels like betrayal.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — “Why can’t you just love Russia?” a member of Parliament demanded of me during a recent talk show on Russian television after I said something about the difficulty of covering President Vladimir Putin. This is one of those questions that presumes the respondent is guilty. It is also a question that has become central to Russian political rhetoric.

headline: Can Jets Contend Without Revis?
abstract: The Jets need their defense to be special to have a memorable season, and it will be hard to be special without Darrelle Revis.
lead_paragraph: The Jets will soon learn the severity of the knee injury that cornerback Darrelle Revis sustained in a victory at Miami on Sunday.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: NPR: Three things you always wanted to know about salt. Question 2: “Do I really need 10 kinds of salt in my pantry?” – Glenn Collins

headline: Maybe Another Economist With The Same Name?
abstract: Things I didn’t say.
lead_paragraph: I guess I should take it as a compliment that people who want to attack my record feel the need to make stuff up. Greg Mankiw posts the abstract of a piece claiming that Brad DeLong and I endorsed the early, optimistic Obama administration forecast for unemployment and growth. What? I was famously pessimistic at the time:

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Cable Reigns at the Emmys, and Power Games Behind the ‘Cloud’
abstract: “A cable eclipse of the networks,” the power consumption of data centers, and what the expansion of Verizon’s spectrum means for cable companies.
lead_paragraph: The Emmys were awarded Sunday night, and there was an upset in the highly competitive drama category, as the newcomer “Homeland,” on Showtime, denied “Mad Men,” on AMC, an unprecedented fifth win, Brian Stelter reported. The ABC show “Modern Family,” however, increased its streak of Emmys as best comedy to three.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Salvatore Ferragamo
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Samantha Casolari.

headline: Dave & Buster’s Sets Range for I.P.O.
abstract: Dave & Buster’s Entertainment, the restaurant and arcade chain, is seeking to sell 7.7 million shares in its I.P.O. at $12 to $14 a share. At the midpoint of that range, the private equity-backed company is set to raise $100 million.
lead_paragraph: Dave & Buster’s Entertainment, the restaurant and arcade chain, announced on Monday that it was seeking to sell 7.7 million shares at $12 to $14 a share during its initial public offering.

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Sympathy For The Doofus
abstract: It’s not just Romney.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is catching a lot of flack from his own side now, which seems premature; although the odds are now against him, this is by no means over. But let me say that even if he does spend election night weeping in his car elevator, his critics from the right are being unfair. Yes, he’s a pretty bad candidate — but the core problem is with his party, not with him.

headline: Fast Forward to the Fierce ’90s
abstract: The Milan collections came to a close today with revved up runways at Cavalli and Dan and Dean Caten of the label Dsquared, which had little to do with the season’s dominant trends of clean lines and Japanese-influenced sparseness. But they still made for a lively ending.
lead_paragraph: Minimalism is not for everyone. The Milan collections came to a close today with revved up runways at Cavalli and Dan and Dean Caten of the label Dsquared, which had little to do with the season’s dominant trends of clean lines and Japanese-influenced sparseness. But they still made for a lively ending.

headline: The Statistical State of the Presidential Race
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: How predictive are late September polls to the actual outcome of a presidential race? A close look at poll numbers going back to 1936 reveals some strong themes.
lead_paragraph: With fewer than 45 days left in the presidential campaign, it’s no longer a cliché to say that every week counts. And there are a few polling-related themes we’ll be watching especially closely this week.

headline: Development’s Opponent Sets Off a Real Estate Battle of His Own
abstract: Daniel Goldstein, who fought against the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, has been in a conflict with his neighbors over an extension planned for his South Park Slope home.
lead_paragraph: The Barclays Center will open its doors this week, buoyed by world-famous performers; slick new uniforms for its basketball team, the Brooklyn Nets; and a formidable advertising campaign.

headline: New Week, Same Ad Themes: China and Taxes
abstract: The Obama campaign is tying Mitt Romney’s tax returns to his “47 percent” comments, while the Republican has put out his second ad that attacks the president’s China policies.
lead_paragraph: Both presidential campaigns have new ads out, but the themes are familiar. The Obama campaign is tying Mitt Romney’s tax returns to his “47 percent” comments, while the Republican has put out his second ad that attacks the president’s China policies.

headline: Avoiding West Nile
abstract: Getting infected with West Nile virus, transmitted by mosquitoes, is believed to confer lifelong immunity, but the effect may dwindle over the years, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can you get West Nile virus more than once? Are there different strains? Is a vaccine possible?

headline: Photos of The Moment | Giorgio Armani
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
