headline: Madison Avenue and 23rd Street, 2:17 P.M. Sunday
abstract: N.Y. See: Along the route of Sunday’s Muslim Day parade, an American-flag headscarf and a sign urging tolerance in the wake of the Libya attacks.

headline: Cable TV Finds an Ally in Mobile Devices
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Mobile Applications', 'Cloud Computing', 'Data Centers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Cable TV's unexpected ally: the mobile device. | At a data center, a peek inside the computing cloud. | How changing technology empowered boutique book publishing.
lead_paragraph: Cable TV's unexpected ally: the mobile device. | At a data center, a peek inside the computing cloud. | How changing technology empowered boutique book publishing.

headline: Business Day Live: Mobile Services and Cable TV Are Unexpected Allies
abstract: Cable TV’s unexpected ally: the mobile device. | At a data center, a peek inside the computing cloud. | How changing technology empowered boutique book publishing.
lead_paragraph: Cable TV’s unexpected ally: the mobile device. | At a data center, a peek inside the computing cloud. | How changing technology empowered boutique book publishing.

headline: I Swear I’m Going to Stop Doing That
abstract: One of the hardest things about being a boss, I find, is keeping that smile on my face, answering the phone with the perfect greeting no matter how crummy I feel, and staying calm even when the situation calls for running in circles and screaming.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I attended the opening of our town’s newest library, which is magnificent, and on the way home I said I was glad to live in a fairly small place that manages to have six libraries. “You forgot one,” she said, and she mentioned another that I’m not going to name here.

headline: Seeking Allies, Teachers’ Unions Court G.O.P., Too
abstract: As traditional political alliances have shifted, teachers’ unions are navigating a delicate political landscape where they increasingly pursue friends in unlikely places.
lead_paragraph: The strike by public school teachers in Chicago this month drew national attention to a fierce debate over the future of education and exposed the ruptured relationship between teachers’ unions and Democrats like Mayor Rahm Emanuel.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Denny Hamlin Dominates Second Race of Sprint Cup Chase
abstract: Hamlin won his fifth race of 2012, dominating the field at New Hampshire Motor Speedway on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday in Loudon, N.H., Denny Hamlin would not have his raceday success dictated by grid position.

headline: Your Hazy Future Is No Excuse for a Lack of Planning
abstract: Just because you can’t imagine who you’ll be in 20 years doesn’t mean you shouldn’t imagine a few possibilities and make a financial plan accordingly.
lead_paragraph: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: A $4.5 Million Gift for Princeton Art Museum
abstract: The gift is from Allen R. Adler and his wife, Frances Beatty Adler.
lead_paragraph: The Princeton University Art Museum has received a $4.5 million gift from Allen R. Adler, a longtime member of the museum’s advisory council and his wife, Frances Beatty Adler, vice president of Richard L. Feigen & Company, a New York art gallery, and chairwoman of the Drawing Center in SoHo.

headline: Al Gore Sees ‘Dirty Weather’ Ahead
abstract: Mr. Gore’s Climate Reality Project plans another live streaming event to call attention to weather extremes and link them to human-caused emissions.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Al Gore was in New York — well, he appeared in a video screened there — to promote the second iteration of “24 Hours of Reality,” an event streamed online to help people connect the dots between climate change and its diverse impacts around the globe. This year’s version, scheduled for Nov. 14-15, is titled “24 Hours of Reality: The Dirty Weather Report.”

headline: My Reddit “AMA”
abstract: Nicholas Kristof will be holding an “AMA” (Ask Me Anything) on Reddit on Monday, September 24 at 2:30 pm.
lead_paragraph: Today at 2:30 pm I will be holding an “AMA” (Ask Me Anything) on Reddit. I invite all my readers, including my critics, to submit questions regarding my coverage as a columnist on the editorial page, the PBS documentary based on the book I co-wrote with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, “Half the Sky,” or my extracurricular activities (hiking the Pacific Crest Trail, sampling mouse shish kebabs, etc). I look forward to a stimulating conversation!

headline: Apple Sells Five Million New iPhones
abstract: Apple on Monday said it had sold 5 million new iPhones just three days after the phone’s release, beating first-weekend sales of its predecessor, the iPhone 4S, by about one million, but still missing some analysts’ forecasts. Still, the number sold over the weekend is about as many smartphones as some competitors, like Nokia, can say they’ve sold over all.
lead_paragraph: Apple on Monday said it had sold five million new iPhones just three days after the phone’s release, beating first-weekend sales of its predecessor, the iPhone 4S, by about one million, but still missing some analysts’ forecasts.

headline: Gensler Calls for Overhaul of Libor
keywords: ['Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Gary Gensler, chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, suggested that authorities should retool or replace the London interbank offered rate.
lead_paragraph: A senior regulator called for an overhaul of a crucial interest rate on Monday, telling the European Parliament that the integrity of consumer borrowing is at stake.

headline: Times Company Completes Sale of About.com
abstract: The Times Company bought About.com in 2005 for $400 million, and it helped increase profit through the lean years of the recession.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company, which has been trying to shed its assets and focus on its newspaper and Web site, announced Monday morning it had completed the sale of About Group for $300 million in cash to IAC/InterActiveCorp. The About Group includes the Web sites About.com, ConsumerSearch.com and CalorieCount.com.

headline: A Dynamic Duo: Beets and Beet Greens
abstract: Fresh beets can be had for a few more months, but the time for making the most of their delicious and versatile greens is running out. Today: a beet greens frittata.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Greenmarket Web site has a handy table that shows what’s available during each month of the year. It tells me, for example, that fresh beets are available from June through November (beets from storage are available through February), but that you can count on the greens only through September. That gives me this week to provide you with my annual set of beet and beet green recipes, one of my favorite subjects.

headline: Bishops’ Edict Angers Catholics in Germany
abstract: Germany’s Roman Catholic Bishops have decreed that those who leave the church may no longer qualify for religious ceremonies. Activist groups say the edict would deepen unease and anger within the ranks of Catholic churchgoers prompted by sexual abuse scandals and accusations of cover-ups.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Matters of faith have been much on German minds in recent times with debate raging among its Muslim and Jewish minorities over a court’s challenge to the practice of infant circumcision and, as I wrote in my latest Page Two column, over the country’s response to the contentious, American-made video denigrating the Prophet Muhammad that has stirred anger across the Muslim world.

headline: The New Season: Big-Name Dance Makers on Parade
abstract: Must-see stops on the European dance circuit: New works by Alexei Ratmansky, Michael Clark and William Forsythe. And what will Matthew Bourne do with “The Sleeping Beauty?”
lead_paragraph: There’s a feast of dance coming up in the next few months, with some of the most interesting offerings coming from the big ballet companies. That’s often because they are taking a resolutely contemporary approach — more on which shortly.

headline: Image of the Day: September 24
abstract: The 19th livestock census underway in the northern state of Punjab.

headline: Can a Sports Car Be Green?
abstract: Can a sports car be good for the environment?
lead_paragraph: It’s time for a new car. Your current set of wheels — an old BMW Z3 roadster — is perfect for your job (pizza delivery) but has miserable fuel economy: 20 miles per gallon. You decide you no longer care about being cool. You care about the earth. You’re up for anything.

headline: ‘Ann,’ Holland Taylor’s Play About Ann Richards, Will Open on Broadway
abstract: The portrait of the former Texas governor will open at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in March.
lead_paragraph: “Ann,” a play based on the life of Ann W. Richards, the colorful Democratic governor of Texas who died in 2006, is coming to Broadway. The play will open on March 7, 2013, at Lincoln Center Theater’s Vivian Beaumont Theater, producers Bob Boyett and Harriet Newman Leve announced Monday.

headline: Former Soccer Player Joins Lawsuit Against N.C.A.A.
abstract: Angelica Palacios, who played soccer for Ouachita Baptist University, has joined the high-profile head injury lawsuit against the N.C.A.A., widening the group of plaintiffs beyond male football players.
lead_paragraph: Angelica Palacios can still remember the concussion that ended her collegiate soccer career.

headline: Iran’s President Spreads the Outrage in New York
abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said Monday that Israelis have no historical roots in the Middle East and that the existence of Israel is just a passing phase in the region’s history.
lead_paragraph: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran stoked the anger of Israel, the United States, Syrian insurgents and gay rights advocates on Monday, using the first full day of his final visit to the United Nations as Iran’s leader to assert that he has no fear of an Israeli attack on his country’s nuclear facilities, regards the Israelis as fleeting aberrations in Middle East history, is neutral in the Syria conflict and considers homosexuality an ugly crime.

headline: Drivers Spend Less Time Getting to Work, Survey Finds
abstract: The mean travel time for New York public transportation riders was more than 47 minutes, compared with under 32 minutes for people who drove themselves, a Census Bureau survey found.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:37 p.m. |  Most New York City residents do not lack for access to some form of public transit. And advocates are always extolling the virtues of subway, bus, rail or ferry over sitting — and stewing — in gridlock inside a car.

headline: At Estée Lauder, a Brand Is Developed Just for China
abstract: The cosmetics company plans to sell a skin care brand called Osiao that caters to the tastes of consumers in Asia.
lead_paragraph: How does an American-based company make deeper inroads in China after it has already introduced some of its popular, long-established brands?

headline: The Dead of Antietam
abstract: How Mathew Brady’s photographs changed the way Americans look at war.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 19, 1862, just two days after the Battle of Antietam, Alexander Gardner, an employee of the photographer Mathew Brady, began documenting the battle’s grim aftermath. One of Gardner’s photographs, titled “Dead Horse of Confederate Colonel; both killed at Battle of Antietam,” depicted a milky-white steed lying on the field in an eerily peaceful repose. Another showed a line of bloated Confederate bodies along the Hagerstown Pike. Titled “View in the Field, on the west side of Hagerstown road, after the Battle of Antietam,” it is one of the most reproduced photographs of Civil War dead.

headline: After U.S. Inquiries, Discover Agrees to Refund Some Credit Protection Fees
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The credit card company has agreed to pay $200 million in refunds to more than 3.5 million cardholders who bought credit protection services over the phone.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Discover Financial Services has agreed to pay $200 million in refunds to more than 3.5 million cardholders who bought credit protection services over the phone, plus an additional $14 million in civil penalties to banking regulators.

headline: Look of The Moment | Top 10 Emmy Dresses
abstract: At the Emmy Awards, amongst the colorful confections and glittering gowns, were those who stood out in subtler ways.
lead_paragraph: At last night’s 64th Annual Emmy Awards the red carpet was busy with television’s brightest wearing colorful confections and glittering gowns. Canary and citrus shades of yellow dominated — T’s cover girl Claire Danes winning in sunny, strapless Lanvin — while midnight lace and armor-like embellishments proved that subtlety (and flattery) are still an actress’s preferred awards ceremony statement.

headline: I.M.F. Praises Central Banks, but Sees Slowing Ahead
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, warned that it would probably cut its estimates of global growth yet again this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, warned on Monday that the institution would probably cut its estimates of global growth yet again this year because of the tepid recovery in the United States, a slowdown in emerging economies and continued troubles in the euro zone.

headline: Coaches Taking Out Frustration on Officials
abstract: Despite an edict from the National Football League to respect the replacement officials, coaches and players have grown increasingly frustrated with them.
lead_paragraph: It seems, in hindsight, a fitting end to a chaotic day of football. The most accomplished and highest-profile coach in the N.F.L. running after an official, seeking an explanation for what happened on the play that had just sent his team to defeat. And then that coach, the New England Patriots’ Bill Belichick, reached his right arm out to stop the line judge Esteban Garza as he headed for the tunnel. In that brief contact was crystallized the mounting frustration of coaches and players with replacement officials.

headline: Tax Policy, Briefly, Is a Laughing Matter
abstract: As a matter of protocol, the secretary of state usually steers clear of electoral politics. But Hillary Rodham Clinton drew knowing laughs in New York on Monday when she said a few words about tax policy.
lead_paragraph: As a matter of protocol, the secretary of state usually steers clear of electoral politics. But Hillary Rodham Clinton drew knowing laughs from an audience in New York on Monday when she said a few words — in an international context, mind you — about tax policy.

headline: Low Waters and High Anxiety
abstract: Vessel operators appeal for federal dredging of Lakes Superior and Michigan-Huron so ships can carry more cargo.
lead_paragraph: This summer’s drought has continued to draw down water levels in Lakes Superior and Michigan-Huron (hydrologically speaking, Michigan and Huron are the same body of water). New forecasts suggest that water levels in the two lakes may soon hit an all-time low, aggravating an economic quandary: with such low levels, cargo ships have to forgo millions of dollars of freight.

headline: Video | Welcome to The Learning Network
abstract: A 1-minute-48-second video that gives a big-picture overview of what we do. We hope you’ll pair it with our more detailed post, 12 Ways to Use The Learning Network This School Year, and share both with other teachers.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month we published a detailed list of 12 Ways to Use The Learning Network Blog This School Year. Now, we’re pleased to follow it with this 1-minute-48-second video that gives a big-picture overview of what we do.

headline: Mean Joe, Meat Loaf and Moon Unit
abstract: Celebrities turning a year older.
lead_paragraph: Compared to last week’s list, which generated a bittersweet tribute to Bruce Springsteen, this coming week yields a less starry list of birthdays. The nicknames are pretty good, though, including “Mean” and “Meat Loaf.” Ms. Zappa is not a boomer, but she is listed because because it struck me that Frank Zappa, a musical force in the 1960’s and ‘70s, has a daughter who is 45 and who possesses a pretty colorful name herself, Moon Unit.

headline: Wall Street Scandals Fill Lawyers’ Pockets
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Legal Profession', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The white-collar bar is thriving with cases like the collapse of MF Global and the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate.
lead_paragraph: As Wall Street has faced a string of scandals, bank executives, investors and customers have suffered. But one group is thriving: lawyers.

headline: As Wall Street Fights Regulation, It Has Backup on the Bench
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: As the financial industry confronts a wave of new government regulations, it has sympathetic ears in a key federal appeals court.
lead_paragraph: Deep in enemy territory, Wall Street has found a powerful ally.

headline: All’onda, the Next Act for 2 Altamarea Alumni
abstract: The chef Chris Jaeckle is teaming up with Chris Cannon to open a Venetian-style restaurant in November.
lead_paragraph: The name All’Onda refers to the style of risotto — “of the waves,” meaning soupy — served in Venice and at this restaurant, scheduled to open in November with Chris Jaeckle, the former chef de cuisine at Ai Fiori, in the kitchen. “I like the idea of Venice,” Mr. Jaeckle said. “It expands the horizon because there are so many global influences in Venice, with spices, even Indian.”

headline: Jets Lose Revis to Torn Knee Ligament
abstract: Cornerback Darrelle Revis tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee in Sunday’s game against the Dolphins and is likely to be out for the season.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — After uttering the words he hoped he would not have to say, Rex Ryan looked down at the lectern and away from the cameras. A second went by. Then two. Then three, as if by taking time to collect his thoughts Ryan would somehow reverse the harsh sentence rendered Monday, when tests confirmed that the All-Pro cornerback Darrelle Revis had torn the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee and would require surgery, ending his season after three games.

headline: With Smartphone Deals, Patents Become a New Asset Class
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Intellectual Property', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The recent multibillion-dollar patent purchases by Apple and Google, though exceptional, were possible because of a broader trend: patents have become a new asset class.
lead_paragraph: David Berten has spent his legal career as a mercenary student of technological change. He has educated himself in one field after another: chemical coatings, genetics, navigation systems, semiconductors and digital communications software.

headline: Is ‘Illegal Immigrant’ the Right Description?
abstract: An activist wants The Times to stop using the term “illegal immigrant” in its reporting.
lead_paragraph: Jose Antonio Vargas is a man on a mission. The journalist turned immigration activist wants news organizations to stop using the term “illegal immigrants,” which he finds disparaging and inaccurate. He’s particularly focusing on The Times and The Associated Press to change their policies.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Missoni
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: In Southern California, Courting Vegans and Vegetarians
abstract: A new wave of omnivore’s restaurants are preparing meatless dishes that exist side-by-side on the menu with steak.
lead_paragraph: A new wave of omnivore’s restaurants are preparing meatless dishes that exist side-by-side on the menu with steak.

headline: Don’t Be Afraid of the Eggplant
abstract: Although the fruit is currently flooding farmers’ markets in all shapes and shades of white, purple and magenta, it’s still underused by home cooks.
lead_paragraph: BACK in the 1970s, when the vegetarian movement began growing like wheat grass, eggplant moved into the mainstream. Casseroles of eggplant Parmesan and moussaka adorned numerous potlucks, mostly because the eggplant’s mild taste and chew — especially when breaded and fried — managed to imitate cutlets of veal and chicken.

headline: Making Vegan a New Normal
abstract: From power tables in Beverly Hills to pubs in the San Fernando Valley, the surge in popularity of plant-based diets is drastically changing the dining landscape.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Hotel Chain Scouts for Regional Art and Artists
abstract: SpringHill Suites is sending the travel photographer/blogger Ken Kaminesky across the United States as a part of a campaign devoted to the search for art.
lead_paragraph: A lodging chain whose customers are often on the road is sending a travel photographer and blogger out for a promotion devoted to the search for art across America.

headline: TimesCast | U.N. General Assembly
abstract: World leaders gather in New York as the United Nations General Assembly opens. | President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt speaks to The New York Times ahead of his first speech at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: World leaders gather in New York as the United Nations General Assembly opens. | President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt speaks to The New York Times ahead of his first speech at the United Nations.

headline: Skimming the Brooklyn Book Festival
abstract: A visitor with an eye on logistics and a willingness to leave events early could hear a great deal about sex, politics, violence and other literary subjects.
lead_paragraph: With more than 100 panels scheduled in and around Brooklyn’s Borough Hall over the course of eight hours on Sunday, the seventh annual Brooklyn Book Festival offered more choices than any one person could take in. But with an eye on logistics and a ruthless willingness to leave events early — the way one might drop a book after 50 pages if it doesn’t grab you — it was possible to hear a great deal about sex, politics, violence and other literary subjects.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: Sept. 16-22
abstract: A look back at the week in politics, as all four candidates were out on the trail.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the week in politics, as all four candidates were out on the trail.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A question about two synagogues in Illinois.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Black Bag Advertising, San Francisco, was acquired by Essence Digital. The deal is part of expansion plans in the United States for Essence Digital, which is based in London.
lead_paragraph: Black Bag Advertising, San Francisco, was acquired by Essence Digital. Financial terms were not disclosed. The deal is part of expansion plans in the United States for Essence Digital, which is based in London and has an office in New York.

headline: Romney Camp Talks of Dialing Down Fund-Raising
abstract: The Romney campaign said it might reduce its fund-raising efforts so the candidate could spend more time on the trail
lead_paragraph: When President Obama and Mitt Romney decided to decline public financing for the general election and raise hundreds of millions of dollars on their own, the upside was clear: No spending limits and effectively unlimited resources to spend taking their message to voters.

headline: A Yahoo Series About Cyberterrorism
abstract: Anthony E. Zuiker, creator of “CSI,” created a nine-part Web series for Yahoo Screen.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve created “CSI,” you don’t have a lot left to prove in the entertainment business. But Anthony E. Zuiker isn’t resting on his television laurels. He writes multiplatform “digi-novels” and is a partner in a YouTube channel, BlackBoxTV, that has more than 333,000 subscribers.

headline: Safeguarding Social Security Checks as They Go Electronic
abstract: Consumer groups urge the government to increase safeguards for seniors as Social Security checks go electronic.
lead_paragraph: Consumer groups — along with paper-producing interests – -are urging the federal government to improve safeguards for Social Security recipients, as the government phases out paper checks for beneficiaries in favor of electronic deposits.

headline: At U.N., New Syria Envoy Gives Bleak Appraisal
abstract: Lakhdar Brahimi, the new Syria peace envoy, told Security Council diplomats that there was no immediate prospect for a diplomatic breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Prospects for any settlement in the Syria conflict remain dismal, but not impossible, the new Syria peace envoy said Monday, telling Security Council diplomats that the government of President Bashar al-Assad still clung to the notion that pre-revolution Syria could be resurrected.

headline: Under Investigation, and Doing the Investigation
abstract: In dealing with corporate misconduct, the government may be leaning too much on the law firms hired by the companies under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Whenever there is a report of corporate misconduct, a predictable response is that the company in question says it has hired a reputable law firm to conduct a thorough investigation, and it pledges to cooperate with the authorities to resolve the situation quickly.

headline: Going Back to War, Trading a Gun for a Pen
abstract: Civilians have been writing about military affairs for generations, and many have done a superb job. Do veterans have an edge over nonveterans when it comes to covering war?
lead_paragraph: The documentary filmmakers Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington embedded in Afghanistan with one mission: to document war. The result was the gripping documentary “Restrepo.” For nearly one year, they lived in peril alongside the United States Army. Their project won the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival in 2010 and was nominated for an Academy Award in 2011.

headline: The Straw Bale Dilemma: How Smooth Is Smooth?
abstract: With a chain saw, a wooden mallet and a big needle, volunteers cut, pack, align and smooth straw bale insulation. But straw by definition cannot be perfectly plumb.
lead_paragraph: To raise a straw bale wall, several tools are essential: a chain saw, a three-foot-long iron needle and a large wooden mallet that Wyle E. Coyote would be proud of.

headline: A Beeswax Dental Filling That Lasted 6,500 Years
abstract: A lump of beeswax, in a jawbone found a hundred years ago in Slovenia and studied only now, appears to be the earliest evidence of a dental filling.
lead_paragraph: Ancient dentistry has been discovered in a 6,500-year-old human jawbone: a lump of beeswax that appears to be the earliest evidence of a dental filling.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 24
abstract: A view of the day in sports, including the shotgun world championships.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports, including the shotgun world championships.

headline: For Tig Notaro, an Album and Book Deal Based on a Memorable Set
abstract: The comedian Tig Notaro turned a year of tragedies, which included her mother’s unexpected death and learning she had breast cancer, into a memorable set. Now a book deal and album release are in the works.
lead_paragraph: 2:25 p.m. | Updated  For the comedian Tig Notaro, 2012 has been her “annus horribilis,” the year in which her mother died unexpectedly and Ms. Notaro learned she had breast cancer. But she turned the events into material for a stand-up routine last month in Los Angeles that quickly became one of the most-talked-about moments in the comedy world. Louis C.K. tweeted: “In 27 years doing this, I’ve seen a handful of truly great, masterful sets. One was Tig Notaro last night at Largo.” Now the set will live on in two forms: as an album online and as the basis of a book.

headline: Styled to a T | Oki Sato
abstract: T styles Oki Sato of the Tokyo/Milan studio Nendo. His cerebral, poetic products are everywhere this year, at companies like Bisazza, Moroso and Lasvit.

headline: Street Style: Gender-Bending
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Sept. 17.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Sept. 17.

headline: Walkabout – 9/24: Rescuing Climbers in Nepal and Avoiding Pickpockets
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Climbers Perish in Nepal Avalanche At least nine climbers on Mount Manaslu in Nepal died in an avalanche on Sunday, at the start of the climbing season. (The Associated Press)

headline: I.M.F.’s Call for More Cuts Irks Greece
abstract: Greeks are increasingly angry over the prospect that public salaries and pensions will be sharply cut again in a last-ditch bid to secure a 31.5-billion-euro loan installment.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As Greece enters a pivotal week in its economic crisis, tensions between the Greek government and the country’s international lenders have reached a boiling point. The government is resisting a push by the International Monetary Fund to impose additional austerity measures that Greek leaders fear could destabilize the shaky coalition government.

headline: Mitt Romney on 60 Minutes
abstract: Now I know why he avoids getting into specifics. When he does, he doesn’t make sense.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t learn anything about either Mitt Romney or President Obama by watching their dueling appearances last night on 60 Minutes. But now I know for sure why Mr. Romney avoids getting into specifics–on his tax policies, his spending priorities, his foreign policy and so on. When he does get specific, he doesn’t make much sense.

headline: Year After Pepper-Spraying, Awaiting a New Cry: A Newborn’s
abstract: An Occupy Wall Street protester is expecting a baby with a man who helped her after she was pepper-sprayed by a police inspector.
lead_paragraph: Buried in the news release on Monday morning that yet another Occupy Wall Street protester is suing the Police Department’s pepper-spraying deputy inspector, Anthony Bologna, was this heartwarming tidbit: Kaylee Dedrick, Inspector Bologna’s co-star in a viral video in which he wields his lachrymatory canister, is about to have a baby with the fellow protester who came to her aid.

headline: Amid Criticism, CNN Defends Reporting on Ambassador’s Journal
abstract: The State Department said CNN violated an agreement with J. Christopher Stevens’s family.
lead_paragraph: Despite a third day of vociferous criticism from the State Department, CNN executives on Monday strongly defended the decision to base some of their reporting about Libya on the private diary of J. Christopher Stevens, the ambassador who was slain in an attack on the United States consulate in Benghazi on Sept. 11.

headline: Feathered Freeloaders at the Ant Parade
abstract: Antbirds on a Panamanian island seem to be evolving from amateur, part-time parasites, skimming off the spoils of marauding army ants, to following the swarms for their every meal.
lead_paragraph: BARRO COLORADO ISLAND, Panama — Here in the exuberantly dour understory of the Panamanian rain forest, the best way to find the elusive and evolutionarily revealing spotted antbird is to stare at your boots.

headline: Scene City: Fashion for a Cause
abstract: amfAR Holds Gala During Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: amfAR Holds Gala During Milan Fashion Week.

headline: The Reporter Had a Life Jacket, but the Governor Knew How to Ply a Paddle
abstract: A Times reporter describes sharing a canoe with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: NORTH HUDSON, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo positioned himself in the stern of a canoe on Sunday while I clung to dry land a few feet away, befuddled by the straps on my life jacket. “We’re going to make an outdoorsman out of him,” Mr. Cuomo declared.

headline: Her Basic Instinct Is to Sell
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Parties (Social)', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: Sharon Stone proves she can sell anything, in euros or dollars.
lead_paragraph: MILAN

headline: The Economics of Law School
abstract: The trend away from law schools has prompted much discussion about what structural changes may be needed.
lead_paragraph: Law schools have come under fire during these tough economic times, with critics saying that they leave too many graduates in debt, chasing too few employment opportunities. But it could be worse. Consider the plight of veterinarians.

headline: Evolving Global Strategy Gives Law Firm an Edge
abstract: By focusing on global deal-making, Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, based in London, says it has been able to better compete with the major American firms.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — EDWARD BRAHAM took over the corporate practice at the London-based law firm Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer at a rough time for deal-making. In the midst of the global economic slump in early 2009, banks were reluctant to lend money and companies did not want to spend their cash.

headline: Three “Fake” J.M.W. Turner Paintings Authenticated
abstract: The paintings — previously thought to be fakes or not fully by the hand of the master and hidden in storage for decades by the National Museum Wales — have now been reclassified as the real things.
lead_paragraph: Three J.M.W. Turner paintings previously thought to be fakes or not fully by the hand of the master and hidden in storage for decades have now been reclassified as the real things. And unlike most painting authentication cases, which proceed in scholarly seclusion for years, this one played out on television.

headline: At Brooklyn Invitational, Disrupting Notions of Motorcycle Culture
abstract: The fourth-annual Brooklyn Invitational, featuring builders from around the United States and an atmosphere that was emphatically of its place, was the anti-Sturgis.
lead_paragraph: A send-off to a long, hot summer was orchestrated on Sept. 22, as thousands of motorcyclists descended on the waterfront of North Williamsburg for the Brooklyn Invitational Custom Motorcycle Show. The attendance and variety of motorcycle culture on view further cemented the position of the show, in its fourth year, as among the most important in North America.

headline: Early Menopause Is Linked to Heart Risk
abstract: A study of a large multiethnic population found an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke among women who reached menopause before age 47.
lead_paragraph: In a new analysis of a multiethnic population, early menopause has been shown to be associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke.

headline: Building a Bat Cave to Battle a Killer
abstract: Scientists hope that luring bats to an artificial bunker in Tennessee will help them find a cure for white nose syndrome, which has killed five million bats.
lead_paragraph: CLARKSVILLE, Tenn. — For about six years, Cory Holliday, the Nature Conservancy’s cave specialist in Tennessee, has feared that white nose syndrome, a devastating fungal disease that kills hibernating bats by the millions, would come to Bellamy Cave. Last winter it did.

headline: Fava Bean Falafel Technique
abstract: Cook Taste Eat's free e-mail contains a video and hands-on cooking instruction.
lead_paragraph: Cook Taste Eat's free e-mail contains a video and hands-on cooking instruction.

headline: Willie Geist to Co-Host Third Hour of ‘Today’
abstract: Willie Geist, a co-host of the rollicking MSNBC morning show “Morning Joe,” is moving to “Today” as a co-host of the franchise’s 9 a.m. hour.
lead_paragraph: Willie Geist, a co-host of the rollicking MSNBC morning show “Morning Joe,” is moving over to NBC’s flagship “Today” show as a co-host of the franchise’s 9 a.m. hour.

headline: Blueprint of a Meal, From In-Box to Table
abstract: Michael Mina brings back an early model of digital content: a free e-mail that contains a video and hands-on cooking instruction, and is part of a larger plan.
lead_paragraph: As cooking on the Web moves beyond recipe sites, Cook Taste Eat, a new enterprise from the San Francisco chef Michael Mina that opened Monday, brings back an early model of digital content: a free e-mail that lands in your in-box each morning. That e-mail contains a video and hands-on cooking instruction, like the one above, and is part of a larger plan.

headline: The Drama of Aging and Caregiving, on YouTube
abstract: “Ruth & Erica,” a YouTube drama, is the latest in a series of movies, TV shows and books that focus on aging.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t want to take care of them,” Erica confesses in Episode 12 to the man she’s just slept with, speaking about her elderly parents.

headline: In Bolivian Amazon, a Yardstick for Modern Health
abstract: Researchers have been studying the Tsimane, the largest indigenous group in the Amazon still living in traditional ways, to tease out insights into diseases ailing modernized societies.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MARÍA, Bolivia — There seems to be little that distinguishes the indigenous Tsimane of northern Bolivia from dozens of other native Amazonian peoples. They still live in small communities, fishing daily, hunting and relying on subsistence farming. They remain relatively isolated from the outside world. They still have large families and fall victim to parasites, worms and infectious diseases. And until a decade ago, few had contact with doctors.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Roberto Cavalli
abstract: Scenes from the Milan fashion week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Doctor Empathy a Factor in Diabetes Care
abstract: A study of 20,961 diabetes patients in Italy found that those whose doctors scored as more empathetic in a well-validated questionnaire had a lower rate of complications.
lead_paragraph: People with Type 2 diabetes may be healthier if they have a doctor who shows high levels of empathy.

headline: A Call for Caution on Antipsychotic Drugs
abstract: Drugs such as Abilify and Seroquel have been around for a long time, but until recently they were not widely used.
lead_paragraph: You will never guess what the fifth and sixth best-selling prescription drugs are in the United States, so I’ll just tell you: Abilify and Seroquel, two powerful antipsychotics. In 2011 alone, they and other antipsychotic drugs were prescribed to 3.1 million Americans at a cost of $18.2 billion, a 13 percent increase over the previous year, according to the market research firm IMS Health.

headline: During National Plug In Day, Getting the Silent Treatment
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: In Los Angeles, 300 attendees picked from a test-drive fleet that included the Nissan Leaf, Tesla Model S, Chevy Volt, Coda sedan and Mitsubishi i-MiEV, as well as motorcycles from Zero and Brammo.
lead_paragraph: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — For four conspicuously quiet hours on the second-annual National Plug In Day, electric cars and motorcycles swarmed the flat, oak-shaded boulevards wending through office parks just south of Los Angeles International Airport.

headline: Really?: Always Consume Carbs Before Surgery
abstract: Having a drink containing carbohydrates up to two hours before surgery may aid recovery, but more research is needed.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTS

headline: The Caucus Click: The Candidate (and His Bodyguard) Say Hello
abstract: Taiven Pickerall, 4, is held up in her wheelchair by her mother, Skylar, to greet Mitt Romney and his Secret Service agents at a Romney campaign event in Pueblo, Colo., on Monday.

headline: In $2 Million Ad Campaign, FreshDirect to Emphasize Food Quality
abstract: The company’s campaign, created by the DiMassimo Goldstein ad agency in New York, is aimed at busy consumers who care enough about the quality and provenance of the food they buy to pay FreshDirect’s prices.
lead_paragraph: FreshDirect, the online home-delivery grocer, is preparing a new advertising approach as it seeks to, er, um, freshen its brand image.

headline: Groupon Moves Into Restaurant Reservations With Savored Deal
abstract: As Groupon continues its quest to become a big platform for merchants, it appears that the online coupon purveyor is moving into restaurant reservations — and a little into OpenTable’s domain.
lead_paragraph: Over recent months, Groupon has sought to expand its core business of daily deals with a number of new business propositions, including with ventures like a mobile payment system.

headline: Small-Business Lessons From Harley-Davidson’s Turnaround
keywords: ['Business Schools', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Small Business']
abstract: Often, these kinds of activities are led by those who have been through M.B.A. programs — but M.B.A.’s don’t always understand how smaller companies work.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, I read an article in the Wall Street Journal about how Harley-Davidson turned itself around using “lean” manufacturing strategies. Lean, or just-in-time, manufacturing is the Toyota production system, which started with W. Edwards Deming and his work with statistical quality control. Whenever I see this kind of article about a large company, I think about how the thoughts and principles can be applied to the smaller companies I work with.

headline: Pavel Datsyuk Makes His Debut With CSKA Moscow
abstract: Pavel Datsyuk, locked out like the rest of N.H.L. players eight days ago, scored a goal off a soccer-style header that was waved off Monday in his debut with CSKA Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Pavel Datsyuk scored a goal off a soccer-style header that was waved off Monday in his debut with CSKA Moscow, but emerged victorious anyway as Datsyuk’s army club beat Avangard Omsk, 1-0. Igor Radulov’s second-period goal, set up by his more famous brother, Alexander, was the difference.

headline: Williams v. Williams
abstract: On Wednesday, Pennsylvania is scheduled to execute Terrance Williams, the first time in 50 years that it will put someone to death who is still fighting his sentence.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania is scheduled to execute Terrance Williams next Wednesday, Oct. 3, the first time in 50 years that it will put someone to death who is still fighting his sentence.

headline: A Law Firm Where Money Seemed Secondary
abstract: At Cravath, Swaine & Moore, associates were paid based on seniority, with no bonuses and no resentments.
lead_paragraph: When I crossed the threshold of Cravath, Swaine & Moore 36 years ago next month, fresh from the bar exam and Harvard Law School, I entered a new world and began what turned into a life-changing experience.

headline: So Many September Songs
abstract: What’s your favorite version of “September Song”?
lead_paragraph: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lTBu44Ui2Fg

headline: How ‘Shrek’ Persuaded Me to Let the Words Fly
abstract: “Shrek” author William Steig inspired me to use a more broad and extravagant vocabulary around my children.
lead_paragraph: Soon he came upon a peasant singing and scything. ‘You there, varlet,’ said Shrek. ‘Why so blithe?’” – William Steig, “Shrek”

headline: After a Slack Period, Hotels Are Sprucing Up
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'HOTELS AND MOTELS', 'Business Travel']
abstract: With the industry’s continuing recovery — occupancy and rates are moving higher — owners can more easily afford upgrades.
lead_paragraph: Hotel owners in the United States are increasing their spending on improvements to their properties this year, upgrading guest rooms, restaurants, technology and other amenities.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Roberto Cavalli
abstract: A pair of standout sandals for spring secure the foot in elaborate and stylish form.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The Trade-Off That Created Germany’s Job Miracle
abstract: In the German city of Ingolstadt, unemployment has virtually disappeared. But there is also a less secure job market and an income gap.
lead_paragraph: INGOLSTADT, GERMANY — More than a quarter of the work force in Spain or Greece is without jobs, but this city on the Danube north of Munich has the opposite problem: not enough workers.

headline: Culture Keeps Firms Together in Trying Times
abstract: Faced with risk-taking peers and an uncertain economy, a handful of prestigious law firms like Cravath, Swaine & Moore stick with partnership-driven philosophies that emphasize teamwork.
lead_paragraph: IN the year before it collapsed, Dewey & LeBoeuf went on a recruiting binge. The law firm poached 37 partners from rivals with multimillion-dollar, multiyear guarantees. Existing partners typically learned about new colleagues via e-mail.

headline: BPA Levels Tied to Obesity in Youths
abstract: A study has found that the risk of obesity is higher among children with high urinary levels of the chemical, which is widely used in food packaging.
lead_paragraph: Bisphenol A, or BPA, is a chemical widely used to prevent metal corrosion in food packaging, and more than 90 percent of Americans have detectable BPA in their urine. Now a new study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association has found that high levels of urinary BPA are associated with an increased risk of childhood obesity.

headline: When Surgeons Leave Objects Behind
abstract: Every year in the United States, 4,000 cases of “retained surgical items” — clamps, scalpels, scissors and sponges — are left inside a patient’s body after surgery.
lead_paragraph: On an overnight shift in 2005, Sophia Savage, a nurse in Kentucky, felt a crushing pain in her abdomen and started vomiting.

headline: Cervical Cancer: El Salvador Gets a Screening Test That Women Can Administer at Home
abstract: A new way to screen poor women for cervical cancer was introduced this month in El Salvador, using a test that was originally developed in China.
lead_paragraph: A new way to screen poor women for cervical cancer was introduced this month in El Salvador, using a test that was originally developed in China.

headline: Girl’s Blasphemy Case in Pakistan Sent to Juvenile Court
abstract: A judge said a Christian girl accused of burning pages from a holy book was 14 years old, not an adult as her accusers claimed, removing the threat of a death sentence.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani judge transferred the case of a Christian teenage girl accused of blasphemy to a juvenile court on Monday, removing the threat of a death sentence and signaling that the case was slowly winding down.

headline: Interviewing Egypt’s Islamist President: Answers to Reader Questions
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Following a lively discussion online about their interview with President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt, two New York Times reporters, Steven Erlanger and David D. Kirkpatrick respond to reader questions.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated | Tuesday, 9:14 a.m. The interview with President Mohamed Morsi published this weekend prompted more than 1,200 questions and comments on our Web site and a surge of interest on Twitter. Thank you to everyone who participated, and the authors — David D. Kirkpatrick and I — are taking the opportunity to answer some of the most central and thought-provoking questions here.

headline: Work Begins to Unearth an Ancient Mosaic
abstract: The 1,600-square-foot Roman mosaic, which consists of colorful geometric patterns, probably dates from the third or fourth century.
lead_paragraph: A giant Roman mosaic, made up of thousands of marble cubes just half a cubic inch in size, is being unearthed in southern Turkey.

headline: A Naughty Word, and a Scolding From a Seatmate
abstract: I’m not much of a talker on flights. I figure people want to be left alone. But on one recent flight my seatmate was a girl about 6 years old; she was charming, but talked nonstop.
lead_paragraph: I’M a television producer, so I’m flying almost all the time.

headline: In Spain, Austerity and Hunger
abstract: As Spain tries to meet its budget targets, it has been forced to introduce one austerity measure after another.
lead_paragraph: As Spain tries to meet its budget targets, it has been forced to introduce one austerity measure after another.

headline: In China, Sister of Ex-Police Official Bemoans His Conviction
abstract: The sister of Wang Lijun, a former police chief who played a central role in a seismic political scandal, criticized his sentence of 15 years in prison, saying it was unfair and symptomatic of the lack of justice in China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The sister of a former police chief who played a central role in a seismic political scandal criticized his sentence of 15 years in prison in an interview on Monday, saying it was unfair and symptomatic of the lack of justice in China.

headline: Spain Recoils as Its Hungry Forage Trash Bins for a Next Meal
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Poverty']
abstract: As the economy worsens, some residents of Spain are turning to garbage bins in search of discarded food.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — On a recent evening, a hip-looking young woman was sorting through a stack of crates outside a fruit and vegetable store here in the working-class neighborhood of Vallecas as it shut down for the night.

headline: Lincoln Center’s President to Leave
abstract: Reynold Levy, the president of Lincoln Center, whose tenure has included a transformed campus, has announced that he is resigning at the end of 2013.
lead_paragraph: Reynold Levy, the president of Lincoln Center who shepherded an ambitious redevelopment of its 16-acre campus during hard economic times, will step down at the end of next year.

headline: Bias Persists for Women of Science, a Study Finds
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Women and Girls', 'Research', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Researchers found that university science professors widely regard female students as less competent than male ones.
lead_paragraph: Science professors at American universities widely regard female undergraduates as less competent than male students with the same accomplishments and skills, a new study by researchers at Yale concluded.

headline: U.S. Warning to Hospitals on Medicare Bill Abuses
abstract: The Obama administration cited “troubling signs” of abuse from the use of electronic records and vowed to prosecute fraud cases.
lead_paragraph: Saying there are “troubling indications” of abuse in the way hospitals use electronic records to bill for Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement, the Obama administration warned on Monday that it would not tolerate what it called attempts to “game the system” and vowed to vigorously prosecute doctors and hospitals implicated in fraud.

abstract: Photos from Syria, Sri Lanka, Philippines and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Sri Lanka, Philippines and Nepal.

headline: Big Law Steps Into Uncertain Times
abstract: The importance of lawyers has never been greater, yet the legal industry has come under great pressure. One result may be a change in the business model.
lead_paragraph: The legal profession sits at the nexus of dealmakers’ worlds, from Wall Street to Silicon Valley to Washington. As regulations change and the threat of litigation rises, the importance of lawyers has never been greater.

headline: Del Posto to Pay $1.15 Million to Settle Workers’ Suit
abstract: Mario Batali and his partners will pay $1.15 million as part of a settlement with 31 current and former employees at the four-star Italian restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Del Posto, an Italian restaurant in Chelsea run by Mario Batali and Joe and Lidia Bastianich, has agreed to pay $1.15 million as part of a settlement with 31 current and former employees.

headline: A Place Where Science and Science Fiction Can Be of One Mind
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'Science Fiction', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Arizona State University opens the Center for Science and the Imagination, a meeting ground for scientists and sci-fi writers.
lead_paragraph: As befits a meeting ground for scientists and science fiction writers, the new Center for Science and the Imagination grew out of happenstance: a chance meeting last year between the novelist Neal Stephenson and Arizona State University’s president, Michael M. Crow.

headline: Ethan Bronner Discusses the ‘Core Issue’ About Voting
abstract: A Times reporter offers his response to a recent public editor column on false balance and voter identification laws.
lead_paragraph: When I wrote recently about the problem of “false balance” in news stories, I quoted the national legal affairs correspondent Ethan Bronner, whose Sept. 9 story was criticized by some readers.

headline: Excerpt: 'L'Elisir d'Amore'

lead_paragraph: Anna Netrebko as Adina and Matthew Polenzani as Nemorino in Act II of the Donizetti opera at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Lessons of 107 Birthdays: Don’t Exercise, Avoid Medicine and Never Look Back
abstract: Juliana Koo’s party at a fancy hotel included a sprawling family portrait and a serenade from a former musical director of “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: Last year, for Juliana Koo’s 106th birthday party, the choreographer Jacques d’Amboise rehearsed her great-grandchildren in a number that they performed. “He scared them,” recalled Mrs. Koo’s daughter Genevieve Young.

headline: Demolition Derbies for Lovelorn
abstract: The new Fox series “The Mindy Project” and “Ben and Kate” are about pursuing romance, not finding it.
lead_paragraph: True love may be everlasting, but it’s not very funny.

headline: Cowboys vs. the Mob in Las Vegas of the ’60s
abstract: Dennis Quaid stars in CBS’s “Vegas,” which feels like a typical crime drama, despite the touches meant to make it stand out.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tight race, but my vote for the drabbest and least informative title among the new fall television shows goes to CBS’s “Vegas” over some tough competition, including “Arrow,” “Revolution,” “Elementary,” “Partners” and “Nashville,” which is at least the entire name of a city.

headline: Chinese Social Media Accounts Clash With Official Reports on Riot at Foxconn Factory
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'iPhone', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: Reports on social media sites in China dispute what FoxConn Technology company officials said led to a riot at one of its manufacturing facilities that involved up to 2,000 employees.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues David Barboza and Keith Bradsher reported, China’s official state-run news agency said 5,000 police officers were called to Foxconn Technology, one of China’s largest manufacturing plants, to help quell a riot by employees that led to a shutdown of the plant on Monday.

headline: Original Review: ‘Sweet Bird of Youth’
abstract: Brooks Atkinson’s 1959 Broadway review of Tennessee Williams’s play.
lead_paragraph: Brooks Atkinson’s 1959 Broadway review of Tennessee Williams’s play.

headline: At Carnegie, Ripples of a Chicago Strike
abstract: The Chicago Symphony has gone on strike less than two weeks before it is scheduled to play opening night at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Opening night at Carnegie Hall is one of the biggest musical events of the season, and this year the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and its star music director, Riccardo Muti, received the plum assignment.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: An American Paradox
abstract: A history professor writes about those who tout self-reliance yet are dependent on government benefits. Readers are invited to respond.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Getting in Touch With Her Selves
abstract: Tami Stronach blended whimsy and sobriety in “Me and Not Me,” which had its premiere at Dance New Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: Tami Stronach’s “Me and Not Me,” the premiere in her program at Dance New Amsterdam last week, involves two women, one child-size bicycle and basketfuls of yellow flowers. Only one of the women, Lindsey Dietz Marchant, rides the bicycle. All she wants to do is play. The other woman, Ms. Stronach, appears to have more on her mind.

headline: The Universe Unseen, on Display in Chelsea
abstract: “Dark Matters,” a new collection of paintings and sculptures by the artist Shea Hembrey, is “a collective meditation on the unseen structure of our universe.”

headline: Graphic: White-Collar World
abstract: A small group of “big trouble” lawyers repeatedly show up on the dockets of major corporate scandals across the decades, both as government prosecutors and as defense counsel.
lead_paragraph: ARTHUR L. LIMAN, the renowned litigator, was once described as a “big trouble” lawyer because businessmen in hot water sought his counsel. Ubiquitous during the latter part of the 20th century, Mr. Liman appeared at the defense table alongside prominent clients like the Wall Street financier Michael Milken. The public knew him best, perhaps, as the chief counsel to the Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair.

headline: Top Afghan Security Official Wins Case Challenging Corruption Accusation
abstract: A court in Kabul ruled that an official in the attorney general’s office had falsely accused Rangin Dadfar Spanta, the national security chief, of corruption.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A judicial panel here ruled in favor of Afghanistan’s national security chief on Monday in an unusual case of a senior government official turning to the courts and the public to prove that allegations of corruption against him were untrue.

headline: The Works of Shea Hembrey
abstract: A collection of images from Shea Hembrey’s exhibit, “Dark Matters.”
lead_paragraph: A collection of images from Shea Hembrey’s exhibit, “Dark Matters.”

abstract: The Obama administration warned in a letter to hospital associations that it would not tolerate what it called “gaming the system.”
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration warned in a letter to hospital associations that it would not tolerate what it called “gaming the system.”

headline: The Delight Isn’t Always in the Details
abstract: Milan likes to make a big show of its tailoring and handcraft.

headline: Showtime Jumps to Capitalize on Emmy Glory for ‘Homeland’
abstract: The four wins for “Homeland” at the Emmys have created a coming-of-age moment for Showtime, a network long in the shadow of HBO.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Here’s what happens when you win an Emmy Award for best actress, as Claire Danes did on Sunday night. You give dozens of backstage interviews, answering the same questions again and again. Then your limo driver takes you to lavish parties, where you say “thank you” again and again and take photos with well-wishers. But all you really want to do is see your mom and dad, who watched your acceptance speech from a hotel suite miles away.

headline: Stories From the Unchained Tour
abstract: Joan Juliet Buck and members of a storytelling group embark on a tour across Georgia.
lead_paragraph: In a film by Matthew T. Perry, Joan Juliet Buck — who wrote about her time on tour across Georgia with the Unchained Tour for our fall travel issue — expounds on the experience as wandering bard.

headline: In a Monk Showcase, the Best Is Saved for Last
abstract: What is the measure of a great jazz drummer? The answer was worth mulling over at the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition, won by Jamison Ross.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jamison Ross sauntered onstage at the National Museum of Natural History here on Saturday with the solicitous gleam of a casino floor manager, his bulky frame encased in a suit and his face bearing a wide-open smile. Graciously, he initiated a round of applause for his fellow hopefuls in the 25th-annual Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition, and another for the event’s unflappable house band. Then he sat down, picked up a pair of brushes and counted off “Bye Bye Blues,” an uncomplicated song recorded by dozens of American entertainers from the 1930s on.

headline: Festival of the Deeply Untrendy
abstract: I’ll Be Your Mirror, an offshoot of the All Tomorrow’s Parties festival, promoted an aggressive collision of musical forms along the East River last weekend.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday at 1 p.m., not long after the start of Day 3 of I’ll Be Your Mirror, the musicians in the instrumental rock band Psychic Paramount prepared to begin. They turned on their amplifiers and their fog machines and quickly set off the building’s smoke alarm.

headline: Conservative ‘Super PACs’ Synchronize Their Messages
abstract: In this year’s tight race, the independent groups working to defeat President Obama have reached a consensus: Going off message is simply too risky.
lead_paragraph: Independent political groups have long been the guerrilla warriors of presidential elections, tossing explosive advertisements into the middle of a campaign like hand grenades, with little regard for the strategy of the candidate they support.

headline: 3Taps Files Antitrust Action Against Craigslist
abstract: On Monday, 3Taps, a company that collects public data and organizes it for developers to use, filed an antitrust lawsuit against Craigslist, accusing the company of engaging in anticompetitive business practices.
lead_paragraph: Craigslist may be the world’s largest listings Web site, but after knocking down developers who try to build services on top of the Web site, it may also one of the least liked.

headline: Two Billionaire Buyers Revealed at One57
abstract: Two fashion tycoons are the first known billionaire buyers at the Midtown tower that will be New York’s tallest building with residences, according to people familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: Two fashion tycoons who are longtime friends and business partners are the first known billionaire buyers at One57, the Midtown tower under construction that will be New York’s tallest building with residences, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Panel Reminds Doctors to Screen for Alcohol Misuse
abstract: A panel of medical experts reaffirmed a recommendation intended to direct patients with risky drinking behaviors into counseling.
lead_paragraph: Primary care doctors and nurses should screen their adult patients to determine whether they are misusing alcohol, and provide counseling when risky behavior is detected, a panel of medical experts reaffirmed on Monday.

lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: An Old Warrior With No Taste for Nuclear War
abstract: In “Ike’s Bluff: President Eisenhower’s Secret Battle to Save the World” Evan Thomas examines the contradictions of Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th president.
lead_paragraph: Until very recently, Dwight D. Eisenhower has done a remarkably good job of hiding in plain sight. The Eisenhower era, the Eisenhower jacket and the still in-the-works Eisenhower memorial (planned for Washington) attract more news attention than the man himself does.

lead_paragraph: The giant panda cub that died Sunday morning had uneven coloring and hardness in her liver, officials at the National Zoo in Washington said Monday.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Julia Frauche at Dolce & Gabbana

lead_paragraph: A former Intel executive who leaked secret information about his employer to Raj Rajaratnam, the fallen hedge fund billionaire, avoided prison on Monday when a judge sentenced him to two years’ probation.

headline: In Belarus Election, President’s Supporters Win Every Seat in Parliament
abstract: Voter turnout was reported to be 74 percent, despite calls for a boycott by two opposition parties. The election, as many in post-Soviet authoritarian states, was widely seen as rigged.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — Supporters of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko won every seat in Parliament in an election over the weekend that, as many in post-Soviet authoritarian states, was widely seen as rigged, if perhaps a little less so than before.

headline: Wallace May Join Knicks’ Veteran Corps
abstract: Rasheed Wallace, 38, may come out of retirement to join the Knicks, his agent said Monday. Wallace’s last N.B.A. season was in 2010 with Boston, where he averaged 9 points a game coming off the bench.
lead_paragraph: If Rasheed Wallace comes out of retirement to join the Knicks, it will be because he feels the team is the perfect match for his veteran leadership and talent. That is what his agent, Bill Strickland, said Monday.

headline: Lyor Cohen Resigns From Warner Music
abstract: His departure adds another piece to the chess game of top music executives who are now free agents as the industry adjusts to changes after the Universal Music Group’s absorption of most of EMI.
lead_paragraph: Lyor Cohen, the dominant creative executive at the Warner Music Group for the last eight years, has resigned from the company, Warner announced on Monday. His departure adds another piece to the chess game of top music executives who are now free agents as the industry adjusts to changes after the Universal Music Group’s absorption of most of EMI.

headline: What Do Sharks Do in the Deep? Device May Tell
abstract: A team of scientists is tagging great white sharks off Cape Cod in an effort to understand their migratory patterns and breeding habits and better protect them.
lead_paragraph: CHATHAM, Mass. — Beachgoers on Cape Cod may have spotted several sharks this summer, but when Chris Fischer and his crew — former subjects of History channel’s “Shark Wranglers” — went looking for the great whites here this month, there were none.

headline: For Winner, Long-Ago Snub Still Stings
abstract: Brandt Snedeker, who secured the FedEx Cup with a win at the Tour Championship last weekend, has not forgotten how it felt to to be omitted from a prestigious amateur team nearly a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The U-S-A cheer that greeted Brandt Snedeker on the 18th tee box Sunday at East Lake Golf Club was a long time coming. Long before his Ryder Cup debut this week, Snedeker seemed a lock to represent the United States against Britain and Ireland in the 2003 Walker Cup.

headline: For Oreo Campaign Finale, a Twist on Collaboration
abstract: Kraft Foods, the maker of Oreo cookies, and a team of agencies will be working live with consumers to produce the final ad of the brand’s Daily Twist campaign.
lead_paragraph: IF, as the saying goes, an apple a day keeps the doctor away, what, if anything, does an ad a day do?

headline: Italy: Regional Leader Resigns
abstract: Renata Polverini, the president of the Lazio region, which includes Rome, resigned Monday in the wake of a political finance scandal that includes accusations of the misuse of public money.
lead_paragraph: Renata Polverini, the president of the Lazio region, which includes Rome, resigned Monday in the wake of a political finance scandal that includes accusations of the misuse of public money. The scandal has tainted several local politicians associated with former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s party and is another blow to the party’s waning fortunes. Ms. Polverini, who has not been implicated in the scandal, said Monday that her administration, elected in 2010, had governed well. “I leave with my head held high,” she said.

headline: Two Marines Face Charges
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The Marine Corps said Monday that two noncommissioned officers accused of urinating on the bodies of dead Taliban fighters in Afghanistan last year would be court-martialed.
lead_paragraph: The Marine Corps said Monday that two noncommissioned officers accused of urinating on the bodies of dead Taliban fighters in Afghanistan last year would be court-martialed. The Marines, Staff Sgt. Joseph W. Chamblin and Staff Sgt. Edward W. Deptola, are based at Camp Lejeune, N.C. Three other Marines were disciplined last month for their roles in the episode, which provoked outrage in Afghanistan after a video of it became public.

headline: Tracing the Root of the Ryder Cup Back to Its Seed
abstract: The Ryder Cup golf tournament has become one of the most keenly anticipated team events in sports, but its origins are somewhat muddled.
lead_paragraph: The Ryder Cup, which will be held for the 39th time this week at Medinah Country Club near Chicago, has become one of the most keenly anticipated team events in sports. But the origins of the event are somewhat muddled.

headline: Ex-Regulator Has Harsh Words for Bankers and Geithner
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Adding to a growing collection of financial crisis histories, Sheila Bair, former head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, takes aim at some regulatory colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Sheila C. Bair, who tormented Wall Street and its Washington allies as a banking regulator, is taking a fresh swipe at her foes in retelling the dark days of the financial crisis.

headline: Tereska Torrès, 92, Writer of Lesbian Fiction, Dies
abstract: Ms. Torrès was best known for “Women’s Barracks,” considered a landmark in lesbian fiction.
lead_paragraph: Tereska Torrès, a convent-educated French writer who quite by accident wrote America’s first lesbian pulp novel, died on Thursday at her home in Paris. She was 92.

headline: India: Deluge Strikes Northeast
abstract: While parts of India struggle with crop failures and water shortages, the northeastern states of Sikkim and Assam have been hit by heavy rains and flash floods that have caused landslides and claimed at least 27 lives in recent days.
lead_paragraph: While parts of India struggle with crop failures and water shortages, the northeastern states of Sikkim and Assam have been hit by heavy rains and flash floods that have caused landslides and claimed at least 27 lives in recent days. Heavy rainfall last week has caused “enormous” damage in Sikkim, an official said. The region is now largely cut off from the rest of India because of the flooding and landslides, which have closed roads. In Assam, floods have affected nearly 1.3 million people, spread across 1,972 villages, said a state disaster official. The state has set up 166 relief camps, which now shelter more than 200,000 people.

headline: After Graduating From College, It’s Time to Plow, Plant and Harvest
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Careers and Professions', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: The last Agricultural Census in 2007 showed a 4 percent increase in the number of farms, the first increase since 1920, and some college graduates are joining in the return to the land.
lead_paragraph: RED HOOK, N.Y. — It was harvest time, and several farm hands were hunched over a bed of sweet potatoes under the midday sun, elbow deep in soil for $10 an hour. But they were not typical laborers.

headline: Mayor’s Tale of Recovery Hasn’t Been Reality for Some
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Recession and Depression', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: New York’s leaders and titans are a wonderfully self-congratulatory lot. To listen to them, you might guess that the recession was a summer thunderhead long ago blown out to sea.
lead_paragraph: “Four years ago, New York City was the epicenter of the financial collapse. But since then — despite being burdened with huge job losses on Wall Street — we have been the epicenter of the national economic recovery.”

headline: On Stump in Ohio, Ryan Criticizes Obama’s Military and Foreign Policies
abstract: It was clear on Monday that the Romney-Ryan campaign believes that with six weeks to go before the election it can still score points off Mr. Obama’s handling of turmoil across the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Ohio – Representative Paul D. Ryan took aim at President Obama’s military policies on Monday, likening the differing national security philosophies of Mitt Romney and Mr. Obama to those of Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter, while lambasting a United States Army plan to halt Pentagon funding for several years for the nation’s only main battle tank, which employs 800 people at a plant in this northwest Ohio town.

headline: Dead Men Share No Secrets
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Terrorism', 'Targeted Killings', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

headline: We Are the 96 Percent
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: Democrat or Republican, we are all both makers and takers.
lead_paragraph: WHENMitt Romney told the guests at a fund-raiser in Florida in May that America is divided between people who pay no income taxes and depend on government and pretty much everyone else, he missed the deeper truth. It is not just that most of the 47 percent Mr. Romney talked about do pay payroll taxes and that many of them have paid income taxes in the past. The reality he glossed over is that nearly all Americans have used government social policies at some point in their lives. The beneficiaries include the rich and the poor, Democrats and Republicans. Almost everyone is both a maker and a taker.

headline: Results for G.O.P. Backers of Gay Marriage: Two Victories and, It Appears, a Loss
keywords: ['Elections, Legislature', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Counts of absentee ballots in tight New York races showed that one incumbent challenged by a social conservative, Stephen M. Saland, won, but another, Roy J. McDonald, seemingly lost.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — One of the four Republican state senators who voted for same-sex marriage claimed victory Monday in a close primary against an opponent critical of his vote, while another of the four appeared increasingly certain to lose his party’s nomination over the issue.

headline: Republican Team Attacks Obama on Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Seeking to retake the offensive in the campaign, Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan criticized President Obama’s handling of recent events in the Middle East and North Africa.
lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo. — Mitt Romney’s campaign is trying yet again to find solid footing, shifting its line of attack toward a subject President Obama has widely been thought to hold the advantage: foreign policy.

headline: About-Face for Bankers’ New Lobbyist
abstract: To say that the choice of Tim Pawlenty to represent the banking industry is odd would be an understatement, but his appointment is the clearest sign yet of the flexible ethic that makes the revolving door in Washington spin faster.
lead_paragraph: “I went to Wall Street and told them to get their snout out of the trough because they are some of the worst offenders when it comes to bailouts and carve-outs and special deals.”

headline: Cuomo Says Private Companies Could Run State Racetracks
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday that a newly formed board overseeing horse racing in New York could bid out Belmont and the state’s two other racetracks to private gambling companies.
lead_paragraph: New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday that the first charge of a newly formed board of directors to run horse racing in the state would be to determine whether its three racetracks should be bid out to private gambling companies.

headline: Gerard I. Nierenberg, Negotiation Expert, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Nierenberg’s frustration with the adversarial nature of legal disputes led him to develop methods of negotiating that he promoted in training seminars and popular books.
lead_paragraph: Gerard I. Nierenberg, a lawyer whose frustration with the adversarial nature of legal disputes led him to develop methods of negotiating that he promoted in training seminars and popular books, including “The Art of Negotiating” and “How to Read a Person Like a Book,” died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: Proportion Control
abstract: Separating the myth from the math in the golden ratio, the second-most famous irrational number.
lead_paragraph: No other number attracts such a fevered following as the golden ratio. Approximately equal to 1.618 and denoted by the Greek letter phi, it’s been canonized as the “Divine Proportion.” Its devotees will tell you it’s ubiquitous in nature, art and architecture. And there are plastic surgeons and financial mavens who will tell you it’s the secret to pretty faces and handsome returns.

headline: A Successful Yom Kippur Fast, With a Medical Assist
abstract: In recent years, hundreds of frail Jews have turned to intravenous feeding on Yom Kippur to avoid violating the prohibition against eating on that day.
lead_paragraph: It will look like a scene out of a hospital ward.

lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The images and video began to appear on Chinese social networking sites early Monday: buildings with shattered windows, overturned police cars, huge crowds of young people milling about in the dark and riot police in formation.
