headline: For Reliever Aardsma, Two-Year Wait Is Almost Over
abstract: The pitcher David Aardsma, who had surgery on his hip and elbow, expects the Yankees to take him off the disabled list soon, but when and how he will be used is not clear.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — David Aardsma’s next major league pitch will be his first since Sept. 19, 2010, after having surgery on his left hip and right elbow. That pitch, however, will not come Monday night. Even though the Yankees flew Aardsma here from their training complex in Tampa, Fla., in time for the game against the Minnesota Twins — presumably to add an arm to their heavily used bullpen — they did not activate him.

headline: The Conservative Mind
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conservatism has lost half of its intellectual firepower. Republicans need to recover traditional conservatism or risk becoming irrelevant.
lead_paragraph: When I joined the staff of National Review as a lowly associate in 1984, the magazine, and the conservative movement itself, was a fusion of two different mentalities.

headline: 3 Georgians Accused of Trying to Stage Prison Videos
abstract: Georgian officials sought to take control of a week-old prison abuse scandal, arresting three activists from an opposition party.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — Georgian officials tried Monday to take control of a week-old prison abuse scandal, arresting three activists from an opposition party, Georgian Dream, and releasing video clips that purported to show them offering the police money to stage scenes of horrific abuse.

headline: New Rules Upend House Re-Election Races in California
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: It’s Democrat against Democrat and Republican against Republican in some California Congressional races. It’s not primary time. It’s a general election under the state’s new rules.
lead_paragraph: PLEASANTON, Calif. — Running against the Vietnam War, Representative Pete Stark entered Congress the year Richard M. Nixon was re-elected president. Since then, ensconced in Democratic strongholds here in the Bay Area, Mr. Stark was easily re-elected 19 times.

headline: Apple Maps Errors Send Japanese to Homegrown App
abstract: Buyers of the iPhone 5 have turned to Mapion, a map application for smartphones produced by a Japanese company.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Hikarie, Tokyo’s new must-visit shopping destination, opened in April, it was already old news on Mapion’s map application. An elite team at the company, which is based here, had marked the glass tower a year earlier, keeping the service a step ahead in this fast-changing city.

headline: Pirates Are Trying to Salvage a Promising Season Gone Bad
abstract: Pittsburgh was one of baseball’s feel-good stories for much of the season, moving as many as 16 games over .500 on Aug. 8, before losing 31 of its next 43 games, including Monday’s loss to the Mets.
lead_paragraph: When the Pirates took the field Monday, they could have taken solace knowing that the Mets understood their pain. Misery has always loved company.

headline: Assembly Punishes Worker for Online Posts
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The State Assembly reprimanded Bill Eggler, who had been posting blog comments defending Speaker Sheldon Silver under cover of the name Sophia Walker.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Assembly on Monday reprimanded an employee who had used a pseudonym while posting comments on the Internet defending Speaker Sheldon Silver’s handling of a sexual harassment scandal.

headline: Before Palestinians Act at U.N., Israeli Officials Urge Other Steps
abstract: Dan Meridor, the deputy prime minister, emphasized the need to return to the negotiating table, while Defense Minister Ehud Barak called for annexation of three large settlement blocs.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With the Palestinians planning to make their case this week to upgrade from organizational status to nonmember status at the United Nations General Assembly, one senior Israeli minister condemned the move as “the easy and wrong way out” on Monday, while another said the time had come for Israel to consider its own unilateral move toward a separate state: annexing parts of the West Bank and withdrawing from others.

headline: At Special Olympics, a Race for Better Health
abstract: A $12 million donation to expand health care for Special Olympics athletes is money well spent if it can draw more attention to the need.
lead_paragraph: When Special Olympics holds its competitions in the United States and around the world, it often enlists volunteer doctors and nurses to give its athletes basic health screenings. What they routinely uncover is evidence of a persistent gap in health care for people with mental disabilities. In basic areas — like dental work, eye and foot care and hearing exams — their unmet needs are appalling. Of 76,900 athletes examined between 2007 and 2011, more than 37 percent had untreated tooth decay. More than half had gait abnormalities, often a sign of ill-fitting shoes. More than 20 percent had never had an eye exam.

headline: A Smart Step for Justice
keywords: ['Interrogations', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Editorials']
abstract: Videotaping custodial interrogations in murder, serious sex crime and felony assault cases is a laudable breakthrough in law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: In a significant law enforcement breakthrough with likely national implications, the New York Police Department has adopted a broad policy of videotaping custodial interrogations in murder, serious sex crime and felony assault cases.

headline: Discarded Kidneys
abstract: A new proposal seeks a more efficient distribution system for patients on the waiting list for a transplant.
lead_paragraph: More than 93,000 patients are on the waiting list for a kidney transplant, and last year more than 4,700 patients died while waiting. That makes it especially tragic that more than 2,600 kidneys were recovered from deceased donors last year and then discarded.

headline: Why Romney Is Slipping
abstract: By refusing to supply America with intelligent answers, all the reliable national polls now show that his campaign is driving voters away.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney said in an interview aired on Sunday that his campaign “doesn’t need a turnaround.” He told CBS News’s “60 Minutes” that he is tied with President Obama; he has a “very effective campaign; it’s doing a very good job;” and all he needs to do to win is keep repeating his plan to restore economic freedom.

headline: The Trouble With Intentions
abstract: Despite themselves, writers are often engaged in acts of unwitting self-contradiction.
lead_paragraph: On their own, sentences are implacably honest. They may be long, short, simple, complex, clear, ambiguous, even incoherent. But they don’t try to hide those qualities. They are what they are and they say what they say. It’s as plain as the words on their faces. The trouble is that most sentences have writers, a fact that readers are well aware of. That makes it hard to consider sentences entirely on their own. Other questions arise. What’s she saying? What did he mean?

headline: Housing Authority Leader Offers Plan to Raise Money
abstract: In an address to a civic group on Monday, John B. Rhea, the chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, described a plan that he said could earn hundreds of millions of dollars for the agency.
lead_paragraph: Acknowledging the “considerable challenges” bedeviling his agency, John B. Rhea, the beleaguered chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, unveiled a plan Monday to squeeze hundreds of millions of dollars out of parking lots, walkways, open spaces and other areas.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for Sept. 24, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Mayor of an Ailing Indiana Mill Town Turns to a Chicago Veteran for Advice
abstract: Mayor Karen Freeman-Wilson, struggling to revive Gary, Ind., has sought advice from many quarters, including from former Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago and his graduate students.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Karen Freeman-Wilson was elected the mayor of Gary, Ind., last year, she found herself confronting some grim truths about her hometown. Revenues in an already emaciated city budget were shrinking by millions of dollars. About a quarter of the buildings, she said, were empty. All the while, people were moving away.

headline: Safer Flights, but Risk Lurks on the Runway
abstract: About 1,000 times a year, a plane or a vehicle moves onto an active runway by mistake, and regulators have been slow to address the problem.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airways Flight 844 from Minneapolis had just landed at Chicago’s Midway International Airport last December and was about to cross a runway on its way to the terminal when the co-pilot noticed a business jet barreling toward him. He shouted for the captain to stop. The plane, carrying 74 passengers, screeched to a halt just short of the runway as the smaller jet crossed before their eyes.

headline: Romney and the Forbes 400
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The Republican presidential candidate and the country’s richest of the rich share a fondness for capital gains.
lead_paragraph: Last week, sandwiched between Monday’s leak of the video in which Mitt Romney dismissed “the 47 percent” and Friday’s release of the Romneys’ 2011 tax returns — showing that they had paid an effective tax rate of 14 percent — Forbes magazine published its annual list of the 400 wealthiest Americans.

headline: As Election Nears, Polls Are Better Predictors
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Elections (US)']
abstract: How predictive are late September polls to the actual outcome of a presidential race? A close look at poll numbers going back to 1936 reveals some strong themes.
lead_paragraph: With fewer than 45 days left in the presidential campaign, it is no longer a cliché to say that every week counts. This is probably the last week, for instance, in which Mitt Romney can reasonably hope that President Obama’s poll numbers will deteriorate because of a deflating convention bounce.

headline: How the Center of the Earth Got a Little Off Kilter
abstract: At Ecuador’s Middle of the World park, tourists stand on a yellow line that is said to be precisely at Earth’s midpoint. Except that it is not. The Equator is hundreds of feet north.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO DE PICHINCHA, Ecuador — Those who visit the Middle of the World, a government-owned park that pays tribute to the Equator, are not drawn by the trinket shops or cafes offering roasted guinea pig. They want to stand on a yellow line painted on the ground here that is said to be precisely at Earth’s midpoint — 0 degrees latitude, 0 minutes, 0 seconds.

headline: U.S. Hearings Again Sought for 3 Detainees
abstract: Lawyers for the men, imprisoned by the United States military in Afghanistan for years, are filing documents they say undermine a ruling against their clients.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for three men who have been imprisoned by the United States military in Afghanistan without trial for nearly a decade are renewing their quest for hearings in American courts. They say new information has emerged that undermines an appeals court ruling against them two years ago.

headline: Convicted Lobbyist Aids U.S. in Inquiry
abstract: Richard J. Lipsky, a lobbyist convicted of bribing former State Senator Carl Kruger, is asking a judge for leniency when he is sentenced.
lead_paragraph: A prominent New York lobbyist convicted of bribing former State Senator Carl Kruger has been secretly cooperating with the federal authorities and is asking a judge for leniency when he is sentenced on Friday, newly filed court documents show.

headline: For Suzuki, Respect for Bats Is Key to Hitting
abstract: Ichiro Suzuki treats his bats like fine instruments, delicately caring for them in a moisture-free, shock-proof case for every Yankees game.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — During a game for the Orix Blue Wave in Japan in 1999, Ichiro Suzuki struck out and returned to the dugout unusually frustrated. In a fit of anger, he destroyed his black Mizuno bat. Embarrassed, Suzuki wrote a letter of apology to the craftsman who had made his bats by hand from Tamo wood, grown on the Japanese island of Hokkaido. Such was the respect that Suzuki felt for the process that created the bats, which he wielded with such skill.

headline: Should the U.S. Be a Political Player in Russia?
abstract: Is it proper and useful for the United States to finance projects to promote democracy in Russia and elsewhere?

headline: Officials and League Remain Divided
abstract: After a weekend of negotiations between the N.F.L. and its locked-out officials, significant differences remain between the two sides, according to a memo from the league’s general counsel.
lead_paragraph: After a weekend of negotiations between the N.F.L. — including Commissioner Roger Goodell — and its locked-out game officials, significant economic and noneconomic differences remain between the sides, according to a memo sent to the teams by Jeff Pash, the league’s general counsel and lead negotiator.

headline: Washington State, Women’s Rights and Big Cities
abstract: As social issues became more prominent on the national political scene, Washington’s social liberalism pushed the state toward the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Washington, the Evergreen State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Mark A. Smith, a professor of political science at the University of Washington.

headline: City to Add Pre-K Efforts in Poor Areas Next Year
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, announced two programs to expand early childhood education for underprivileged youth.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Monday that the city would open a new type of preschool in Brooklyn next year, introducing a cradle-to-kindergarten approach to education for very young children in poor neighborhoods.

headline: Formless Lump
abstract: What’s that peeking out of the grid in Ian Livengood’s puzzle?
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Unusual Puzzle Alert! The Tuesday, Sept. 25 puzzle will be offered in both Across Lite and as a PDF. Because of the unusual nature of this puzzle, some elements of the grid and the cluing will not reproduce the same way in Across Lite. If you normally solve online in Across Lite, we strongly recommend that you print out the PDF and solve it that way.

headline: A Buried Family Secret, Not for the Faint of Heart
abstract: In “Red Dog Howls,” a New York man discovers a devastating family secret after he finds a box of letters that lead to a grandmother he had never known.
lead_paragraph: Generally speaking, when you hear a mournful folk melody played on a violin as the lights go down at the theater, it is wise to set aside any expectations of frothy pleasures — debonair quipping, pratfalling, tap-dancing chorus girls — and prepare for something more somber.

headline: She’s Old and Faded; He’s Young and Trapped
abstract: The Goodman Theater in Chicago has revived Tennessee Williams’s “Sweet Bird of Youth,” starring Diane Lane and Finn Wittrock.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — First glimpsed writhing buglike beneath satin sheets, she looks awfully small to be a towering legend of the screen. Breakable, too, as if a pair of strong arms could crush those fine bones to dust, leaving behind only a trail of mascara and remnants of that last, botched appointment with the hairdresser. Hey, this dame can’t even breathe without the help of an oxygen mask.

headline: Corrections: September 25, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 25, 2012.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Congressman’s Campaign Office Vandalized
abstract: Representative Michael G. Grimm, a Republican who is seeking re-election in November to a second term, labeled the break-in a “politically motivated crime” and an “assault on democracy.”
lead_paragraph: The campaign headquarters of Representative Michael G. Grimm on Staten Island was broken into over the weekend, and a computer server containing “confidential campaign files and polling data” was erased, the campaign said in a statement.

headline: Ex-Informer to Serve 20 Years for Dealing Drugs and Guns
keywords: ['Police Brutality and Misconduct', 'Informers', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Firearms', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Ivan Chavez pleaded guilty to illegally selling firearms and to selling drugs to a police officer who was accused of stealing guns from a station house.
lead_paragraph: A former confidential informer for the New York Police Department pleaded guilty on Monday to dealing drugs and selling guns illegally as part of a plea deal under which he will be sentenced to 20 years in prison.

headline: While U.N. Beckons Clinton, Obama Takes In ‘The View’
abstract: President Obama was in campaign mode as he arrived in New York to attend the United Nations General Assembly, leaving the diplomatic duties to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Monday flew up to New York from Washington, rode in his motorcade to ABC’s studios and sat down for an interview on “The View.” Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was not far away, in the Waldorf-Astoria, meeting with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan.

headline: Court Session in Patz Case Is Delayed for 6 Weeks
abstract: The next court appearance for the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz has been delayed, giving prosecutors and his defense team another six weeks before the case is presented to a grand jury.
lead_paragraph: The next public court appearance for the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz in 1979 has been put off for six weeks, a move that has the effect of giving prosecutors and his defense lawyer more time to investigate before the case is presented to a grand jury for indictment.

headline: Slight Dip in SAT Scores for the Class of 2012
abstract: For the high school class of 2012, the average score on the critical reading section of the SAT college entrance exam, 496, was down 1 point from the previous year, as was the average writing score, 488.
lead_paragraph: For the high school class of 2012, the average score on the critical reading section of the SAT college entrance exam, 496, was down 1 point from the previous year, as was the average writing score, 488. The average math score, 514, was unchanged. Also unchanged: only 43 percent of the 1.66 million test-takers achieved the benchmark score, 1550, that indicates readiness for college. Among students whose parents have bachelor’s degrees, though, 60 percent were college ready. The College Board, which administers the test, says those with the benchmark score have a 65 percent likelihood of achieving a B- or higher grade average in their first year in college.

headline: Louisiana: Accord Is Reached on Prison Overhaul
abstract: The Justice Department and the sheriff who runs the Orleans Parish Prison have reached an agreement on changes at the institution.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department and the sheriff who runs the Orleans Parish Prison have reached an agreement on changes at the institution, where violence, suicides, unclean conditions and poor medical treatment are commonplace, said Thomas E. Perez, assistant attorney general for the civil rights division. The department said on Monday that it sought to intervene in a class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of prisoners. Sheriff Marlin Gusman, who oversees the prison, supported the federal involvement, which set the stage for the negotiated changes. The next step toward a final settlement will be finding money to pay for the overhaul.

headline: Alabama: Ex-Professor Gets Life Term in Shooting
keywords: ['School Shootings', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A former professor was sentenced to life in prison without parole for fatally shooting three colleagues and wounding three others at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, in 2010.
lead_paragraph: A former professor was sentenced on Monday to life in prison without parole for fatally shooting three colleagues and wounding three others at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, in 2010. The professor, Amy Bishop, pleaded guilty to avoid the death penalty. Jury deliberations — which state law requires in capital cases, even in plea deals — lasted for 20 minutes on Monday. Ms. Bishop opened fire during a meeting after being denied tenure. She could still face a trial in Massachusetts, where she is charged with killing her brother in 1986.

headline: Grant Will Aid Effort to Find Old DNA Evidence
keywords: ['Bar Codes', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: The federal money goes to the New York Police Department and the Innocence Project, which works to exonerate people who have been wrongfully convicted.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual partnership, the New York Police Department and a legal organization dedicated to exonerating people who have been wrongfully convicted have jointly received federal grant money to overhaul how the police store evidence in old cases.

headline: With Doubleheader Split, The Orioles Lose Ground
abstract: Adam Jones went 4 for 4 to help Baltimore move within a half-game of the A.L. East by winning the first game of two on Monday against the Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: As the baseball season moves into its final stretch, the story lines are becoming clearer. Three National League teams — San Francisco, Cincinnati and Washington — have clinched spots in the postseason, and Atlanta seems assured of joining them as a wild-card team. That leaves St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot. The Brewers’ loss to the Nationals on Monday afternoon made the Cardinals’ task a little easier.

headline: Syrian War’s Spillover Threatens a Fragile Iraq
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Arms Trade', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: Syria’s civil war is straining sectarian tensions in Iraq nine months after American forces left, and it is causing Iraq’s Shiite-led government to move closer to Iran.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The civil war in Syria is testing Iraq’s fragile society and fledgling democracy, worsening sectarian tensions, pushing Iraq closer to Iran and highlighting security shortcomings just nine months after American forces ended their long and costly occupation here.

headline: Names of the Dead
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,105 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,105 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Two Nets Take Stock of Future in Brooklyn
abstract: Brook Lopez and MarShon Brooks opened the Nets’ first team store in Brooklyn on Monday, which seems almost poetic until you consider how close they were to becoming former Nets.
lead_paragraph: Two guys with Brook in their name opened the Nets’ first team store in Brooklyn, which seems almost poetic until you consider how close they were to becoming former Nets.

headline: Mets Top the Pirates for Mejia’s First Win
abstract: The Mets prolonged the Pittsburgh Pirates’ swoon Monday night with a 6-2 victory that featured a solid performance by Jenrry Mejia and two home runs by Ike Davis.
lead_paragraph: The Mets prolonged the Pittsburgh Pirates’ swoon Monday night with a 6-2 victory that featured a solid performance by Jenrry Mejia and two home runs by Ike Davis. The win was the Mets’ fourth in a row, their longest winning streak since they took four in a row in late June.

headline: New Ruling on Katrina Favors Corps of Engineers
abstract: A federal appeals court reversed itself, ruling Monday that the Army Corps of Engineers is not liable for devastation caused in Hurricane Katrina from a government-built navigation canal.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court reversed itself, ruling Monday that the Army Corps of Engineers is not liable for devastation caused in Hurricane Katrina from a government-built navigation canal.

headline: Pettitte Lifts Yankees in Another Scoreless Effort
abstract: Andy Pettitte’s comeback tour from a broken left leg continued Monday when he pitched six scoreless innings to lead the Yankees over the Minnesota Twins to stay atop the American League East.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — After witnessing another impressive performance by a former teammate and a fellow quadragenarian, Joe Girardi reached out from the dugout steps and shook Andy Pettitte’s right hand, congratulating him for the superb work Pettitte had done with his left.

headline: Are Financial Fair Play Rules Destined to Be Broken?
abstract: UEFA has finally started to show there is more to their drive for financial sustainability in European soccer than words, but holes remain in its Financial Fair Play rules.
lead_paragraph: As the UEFA president Michel Platini preached prudence and wisdom to Europe’s soccer elite last month, the setting seemed rather incongruous, almost undermining the words he spoke.

headline: Word of the Day | translucent
abstract: This word has appeared in 200 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: translucent •\tranz-ˈlü-sənt\• adjective

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Sees Investor Fade, as if Dreamt
abstract: A major investor for the $12 million musical “Rebecca,” a mystery man named Paul Abrams, seems to have died before raising $4.5 million for the show, leading to questions about whether he existed at all.
lead_paragraph: The business of Broadway has always been cloaked in mystery. Most of its 40 theaters are run by three private organizations that operate out of public view. Producers keep deal-making under wraps. The biggest mystery of all is why so many sophisticated investors go along with business-as-usual on Broadway when few shows turn a profit.

headline: Striking Chicago Musicians Reach Tentative Agreement
abstract: The agreement means the Chicago Symphony Orchestra will proceed with rehearsals and concerts as planned, including those at Carnegie Hall next week.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra strike appears to have ended after two days. The orchestra and its players, in a joint statement released Monday night, said they had reached a tentative three-year agreement that would take effect retroactively to Sept. 17 if the board of trustees and musicians ratify it.

headline: Harsh Prison Sentences for 3 Vietnamese Bloggers
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Vietnam has hit three prominent bloggers with lengthy prison terms, reinforcing its reputation as one of the world’s most restrictive countries for freedom of speech and the press.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Vietnam has hit three prominent bloggers with lengthy prison terms, reinforcing its reputation as one of the world’s most restrictive countries for freedom of speech and the press.

headline: Swisher Leads Yankees’ Power Surge at Minnesota
abstract: Nick Swisher hit the first of the Yankees’ four homers against Twins starter Liam Hendriks on Monday.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It took almost 32 years, but Nick Swisher is finally a grown man.

headline: News Quiz | September 25, 2012
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: North Korea’s Leaders Promise Improvements to Educational System
abstract: North Korea’s Parliament convened on Tuesday amid speculation that the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, might use the session to reshuffle his government and discuss economic reforms.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leadership ended a rare second session of Parliament in a single year on Tuesday without making the announcements on economic reforms that many analysts had expected.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Tuesday, Sept. 25
abstract: News, arts and fashion coverage in today’s International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: NEWS As Greece enters a pivotal week in its economic crisis, tensions between the Greek government and the country’s international lenders have reached a boiling point. The government is resisting a push by the International Monetary Fund to impose additional austerity measures that Greek leaders fear could destabilize the shaky coalition government. Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr. report.

headline: UB Group Companies’ Stock Up on Deal Talk
abstract: Spirits and fertilizer company stocks rise.
lead_paragraph: United Spirits, part of Vijay Mallya’s cash-strapped group of companies, confirmed Tuesday it was in deal talks with global alcohol giant Diageo in a notice to the Bombay Stock Exchange. United Spirits’ stock price rose on the news, to 1098.80 rupees a share at noon in India, up 3.6 percent for the day. United Spirits stock hit a 52 week high of 1,099.95 rupees a share on Monday on rumors deal talks were underway.

headline: Bat Cave to the Rescue?
abstract: What is white nose syndrome?
lead_paragraph: WHO is Cory Holliday?

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 25, 2012
abstract: Can you choose the best synonym for “inexorable,” as it is used in the article?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Shrink to Fit.”

headline: India Enters ‘Era of Regionalism’
abstract: As political turbulence roils the central government, state parties gain strength.
lead_paragraph: The Indian government has, for the moment, averted a political crisis. Despite full-throated resistance from the Bharatiya Janata Party and at least a dozen regional parties, which organized nationwide protests last week to oppose economic policy changes introduced by the government, it managed to cobble together sufficient support in Parliament to stay afloat.

headline: History in Little Rock
keywords: ['Baby Boomers', 'Brown v Board of Education (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: In 1957, hundreds of Army troops protected nine black teenagers as they integrated all-white Central High School.
lead_paragraph: The day marks an important milestone in civil rights history and the birth of one of the best known television personalities of our lifetime.

headline: Hey, Big Saver!
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Ben Bernanke needs you to stop playing it safe.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know what the future of the American economy looks like — when the unemployment rate will return to below 6 percent, or when annual growth will climb back above 3 percent — it’s helpful to stop thinking for a moment about those families in serious financial distress. That’s because the future of the U.S. economy relies, in large part, on another group of people living in fear: the millions of Americans who have a little disposable income.

headline: Retreating to Memory With a Song
abstract: A toddler’s questions prompts a mother to recall her own mother’s love for music and the liberating power found in song.
lead_paragraph: Every morning these last few weeks, my 3-year-old son digs through a pile of old CDs on a bookshelf in our guest bedroom. He toddles between rooms, carrying one and then another of the plastic cases to the breakfast table, asking, “You like this one, Mama?”

headline: Fragments of Fukushima
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Photography']
abstract: Eighteen months after the Fukushima nuclear disaster in Japan, the photographer Kosuke Okahara has created a collection of haunting images of a land irreparably altered and the people who stayed behind.
lead_paragraph: The first time the Tokyo-based photographer Kosuke Okahara visited a town near the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan, he grabbed his dosimeter, a device used to measure radiation levels, and looked at his watch to see how much time he could spend at the location.

headline: Is Trying Too Hard to Be Happy Making You Sad?
abstract: How important is happiness to you? Do you sometimes try so hard to be happy, or show friends that you’re happy, that it makes you anxious or unhappy?
lead_paragraph: In her opinion piece “America the Anxious,” Ruth Whippman argues that Americans’ relentless pursuit of happiness is actually causing us much anxiety. She begins her piece with a quote by the author-philosopher Eric Hoffer: “The search for happiness is one of the chief sources of unhappiness.”

headline: A Conversation With: Landesa Founder Roy Prosterman
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Legal Profession', 'Rural Areas', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Former lawyer speaks on his land rights advocacy group and their work in India.
lead_paragraph: More than four decades ago, Roy Prosterman left a high-paying job at a white-shoe law firm in search of a different kind of job satisfaction. He ended up finding it in Landesa, a Seattle-based nonprofit that he founded, which works to secure land rights for the rural poor in countries around the world. Founded in 1966, the group is better known by its former name, Rural Development Institute.  Today, Landesa has 120 employees; it has operated in more than 50 countries, including China, Vietnam and Russia, and says 100 million families have benefited from its work. Thirty percent of the group’s $13 million annual budget is spent in India.

headline: Syrian Shells Land Near Israeli Border
abstract: Mortar shells launched from Syria landed in the Golan Heights near Israel’s northern border on Tuesday. No one was injured and no damage was caused by the shells.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Several mortar shells launched from Syria landed in the Golan Heights near Israel’s northern border on Tuesday morning, prompting the Israeli military to file a complaint with United Nations forces operating in the area.

headline: Part 2: Answers From Princeton’s Dean of Admission
abstract: Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, lends her expertise about college admissions by answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice. Part 2.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Ms. Rapelye is no longer taking questions.This week, The Choice has invited Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer your questions about college admissions. Ms. Rapelye, who received a bachelor’s degree from Williams College and a master’s degree from Stanford University, has 30 years’ experience in college admissions.

headline: Republicans Champion ‘Voluntary Taxes’
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans will do anything to avoid raising taxes, and their latest bill to encourage voluntary contributions is nothing more than a distraction, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: After Monday Night Fiasco, a Call for Goodell to Apologize
abstract: The poor officiating by the replacement referees in the Packers-Seahawks “Monday Night Football” game was one of the more embarrassing episodes in N.F.L. history.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of reaction to one of the most embarrassing episodes in N.F.L. history, when some egregiously poor calls in the fourth quarter culminated with a disputed last-second touchdown heave that gave the Seattle Seahawks a 14-12 victory over the Green Bay Packers on “Monday Night Football.”

headline: Diageo in Talks to Buy Stake in United Spirits
abstract: The world’s largest spirits company is in discussions to buy a stake in United Spirits, which has around a 40 percent market share in India.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Diageo, the world’s largest spirits company, said on Tuesday that it was in talks to buy a stake in United Spirits of India.

headline: Bond Investors Register Nervousness About Spain
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Government Bonds', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: An auction of short-term debt took place at sharply higher yields, a sign of uncertainty over whether Spain would ask for help from the European Central Bank.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Spain’s borrowing costs rose on Tuesday at an auction of short-term debt, showing investors’ uncertainty about the country’s strategy for emerging from crisis.

headline: On Our Radar: Toyota Retrenches on Electric Cars
abstract: The automaker says it misread market demand and will scale back its plan for mass sales of all-electric vehicles. It will add more hybrid models, however.
lead_paragraph: Toyota scraps plans for wide sales of a new all-electric minicar, saying that it had misread the market and the ability of battery technology to satisfy consumers. Now it plans to sell only about 100 battery-powered eQ vehicles in the United States and Japan. [Reuters]

headline: Near Disputed Islands, Japan Confronts Boats From Taiwan
abstract: The Coast Guard used water cannons Tuesday to disperse fishing boats from Taiwan in waters claimed by Tokyo, widening a territorial dispute that has already pitted Japan against China.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese Coast Guard used water cannons on Tuesday to disperse fishing boats from Taiwan in waters claimed by Japan in the East China Sea, widening a territorial dispute that has already pitted Japan against China and threatened vital trade relations in the region.

headline: The Big Banks Say They Are Meeting Their Lending Commitment
abstract: But they still aren’t explaining what exactly that commitment is.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, I published a post entitled, “Are the Big Banks Keeping Their Commitment to Small Businesses?” It had to do with a commitment that 13 of the largest banks in the country made last September to increase their small-business lending by $20 billion over the following three years.

headline: Early and Often
abstract: Even if the nonstop commercials and coverage didn’t tip you off, there are certain words in the air that unmistakably say, “It’s election time!”
lead_paragraph: Even if the nonstop commercials and coverage didn’t tip you off, there are certain words in the air that unmistakably say, “It’s election time!”

abstract: A summary of what’s on today’s editorial page.
lead_paragraph: From the editorial page

headline: China Launches Carrier, but Experts Doubt Its Worth
abstract: Beijing put its first aircraft carrier into service Tuesday, a move intended to signal its growing military might.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a ceremony attended by the country’s top leaders, China put its first aircraft carrier into service on Tuesday, a move intended to signal its growing military might as tensions escalate between Beijing and its neighbors over islands in nearby seas.

headline: Qatar’s Latest Investment Stirs the French
abstract: Qatar invests tens of billions of dollars on foreign assets that range from high-end property to soccer clubs. Now, the emirate’s plan to spend a relatively small sum on regenerating France’s impoverished suburbs has sparked a national debate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A decision by the French government to allow Qatar to invest millions of euros in France’s depressed and neglected suburbs has prompted concerns across the political spectrum about the motives of the wealthy Arab emirate.

headline: Relations between Egypt and the U.S.
abstract: Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s first democratically elected president, said that it is up to Washington to revitalize the alliance with Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Morsi, Egypt’s first democratically elected president, said that it is up to Washington to revitalize the alliance with Egypt.

headline: The Future of Big Law
abstract: DealBook looks at the future of lawyering in a special section. | The former chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has some choice words for bankers and fellow regulators. | Banco Santander is expected to take its Mexican unit public after the market closes. | Tim Pawlenty is an odd choice to lead the Financial Services Roundtable.
lead_paragraph: The Future of Big Law  |  With business still tepid in the aftermath of the financial crisis, and with the industry reeling from the failure of Dewey & LeBoeuf, DealBook looks at the future of lawyering in a special section, “Big Law Steps Into Uncertain Times.” That future may involve an entirely new business model, one without any partners, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in his column.

headline: Love Potion Opens Season at the Met
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera season opened with a psychologically charged new production of Donizetti’s enduring comedy “L’Elisir d’Amore,” starring Anna Netrebko.
lead_paragraph: Another Metropolitan Opera opening night, another new production of a Donizetti opera starring the charismatic soprano Anna Netrebko. Or so it seems these days.

headline: Tuesday Reading: When Surgeons Leave Objects in Your Body
abstract: When surgeons leave objects behind, runway safety remains concern for airports, Q&A on the West Nile Virus and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Coulda Been Worse
abstract: Given that it was terrible.
lead_paragraph: Josh Lehner does something I’ve been meaning to do: he compares US economic performance since the financial crisis with other episodes of major financial crisis. And guess what? We actually look better than most (sorry about the small print):

headline: EconoTrolls
abstract: Beasts of bad economics.
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith has a very funny and highly accurate description of the menagerie. If you think he’s making fun of you, he probably is.

headline: A Monster, but No Epic Battle
abstract: Papo & Yo is a fable that plays off events from the creator’s childhood with an alcoholic father.
lead_paragraph: The author Michael Lewis once rebuffed the notion that he should write a novel by saying, “Whereas journalists once felt humbled by the novel, we now live in an age in which the novelist lives in a state of anxiety about nonfiction.” Mr. Lewis, the writer of “Liar’s Poker” and “Moneyball,” was talking to Robert S. Boynton for the interview anthology “The New New Journalism.”

headline: Obama Tells U.N. New Democracies Need Free Speech
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: President Obama used his last major address on a global stage before the November election to deliver a defense of freedom of speech, challenging fledgling democracies to ensure that right.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama on Tuesday used his last major address on a global stage before the November election to deliver a strong defense of America’s belief in freedom of speech, challenging fledgling Arab and North African democracies to ensure that right even in the face of violence.

headline: Turkey’s Military Politics
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A Turkish court’s conviction of 325 senior officers for plotting to overthrow the state offers no catharsis.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Turkish court’s conviction on Friday of 325 senior military officers for plotting to overthrow the state has left me with mixed feelings. Like many Turks, I’ve been pondering a host of questions: Was this justice or revenge? Is this the final curtain on a military that for decades believed it knew better than the elected politicians? Or was the 21-month courtroom drama the latest show trial, manipulated by a government that itself entertains delusions of grandeur?

headline: Fashion, the Next Dimension
abstract: Using Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat.
lead_paragraph: With Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat. How close is this to becoming a reality? In an exclusivevideo, Cave takes The Moment behind the scenes of his epic shoot to get the full 360 degree view. And to experience the final results, go to sc-3d.com.

headline: Daily Report: Riot at Foxconn Factory Highlights Labor Unrest
abstract: Analysts say worker unrest in China has grown more common because employees are more aware of their rights, and yet have few outlets to challenge or negotiate with their employers, David Barboza and Keith Bradsher report in Tuesday’s New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A riot at a factory in Taiyuan, China, late Sunday was noteworthy because the site is managed by Foxconn Technology, one of the world’s biggest electronics manufacturers and an important supplier to major Western technology companies, David Barboza and Keith Bradsher report in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: Leading Off: A Fiasco to End the Referee Fiasco?
abstract: The long line of people complaining about the replacement officials is now more like an angry mob. Have we reached the tipping point?
lead_paragraph: To be sure, the conga line of complaining about the replacement referee fiasco had started before Monday night’s N.F.L. game got even ESPN’s Jon “Everyone’s Doing a Great Job!” Gruden all riled up. The line was headed right to the gilded — and now probably fortified — door of Commissioner Roger Goodell, whose baronial arrogance makes him so easy to blame for just about anything. But the ending to that dreadful game Monday night may be his crowning achievement.

headline: Adding Up the Government’s Legal Bills for Fannie and Freddie
abstract: The government faces years of legal bills to defend Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac executives accused of misleading investors about subprime mortgages.
lead_paragraph: The government’s takeover of the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in 2008 may turn out to be a very expensive proposition.

headline: In West Bengal, Cashless Microfinance Opens Doors for Women
abstract: Women receive what they need to ply a trade, including basic education, before qualifying for a loan.
lead_paragraph: CANNING, West Bengal — A debt crisis in India’s microfinance sector in Andhra Pradesh in 2010 revived the question of how to help the hard-core poor without forcing them into a debt trap. Now it appears that microfinance institutions may have had an alternative all along.

headline: No Thank-You Note, but Several Lawsuits for a Pepper-Spraying Inspector
abstract: The Day: Anthony Bologna gave Occupy Wall Street a mighty jump start last Sept. 24 when he blasted protesters with pepper spray. But have its people paid tribute to the inspector?
lead_paragraph: Never mind the celebratory demonstrations last week. This Monday was the important anniversary for Occupy Wall Street. On that day a year ago, the movement truly kicked into gear. It owed an enormous debt to a police deputy inspector named Anthony Bologna, who has received not a word of thanks for having put it on the map.

headline: Home Prices Rise Again, This Time on the Low End
keywords: ['United States Economy', "Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller Home Price Index", 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The housing market is still gathering strength, new data showed, and the gains appear to be spreading even to the cheapest homes in many cities.
lead_paragraph: The housing market continues to gather strength, and the biggest gains in price now appear to be among the least expensive homes, whose values fell the most in the downturn and have weighed against any would-be recovery.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: It’s Showtime’s Time, and N.F.L.’s Monday Night Hangover
abstract: Also, word of worker unrest at China was spread by social media; and the owner of Deadline, an online Hollywood news site, is the leading contender to buy Variety.
lead_paragraph: The Emmy awards won by the tense, terrorism-centric Showtime series “Homeland” could not have come at a better time for the network, or the series, Brian Stelter writes. The awards — including best drama, best actress (Claire Danes), best actor (Damian Lewis) — represent a coming of age for the network, which had never received a series prize for comedy or drama and has long been in the shadow of the Emmy-award-laden HBO. With the second season of “Homeland” beginning on Sunday, the subscription network was immediately setting out to capitalize on the wins. “I think there might be some extra activity at the call centers this week,” said David Nevins, president for entertainment at Showtime.

headline: Rare Trout Survives in Just One Stream, DNA Reveals
abstract: Researchers had thought that five wild populations of greenback cutthroat trout were out there.
lead_paragraph: The rare greenback cutthroat trout, Colorado’s state fish, is even more imperiled than scientists thought, a new study suggests. By analyzing DNA sampled from cutthroat trout specimens pickled in ethanol for 150 years, comparing it with the genes of today’s cutthroat populations, and cross-referencing more than 40,000 historic stocking records, researchers in Colorado and Australia have revealed that the fish survives not in five wild populations, but just one.

headline: Absurd Ending Fuels Disgust With Replacement Refs
abstract: The late calls by replacement officials in Monday night’s N.F.L. game, on the final play especially, marred an otherwise magical finish and struck at the very integrity of the sport.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The play that best defines this N.F.L. season occurred at the end of another game in which replacement officials looked less like actual referees and more like the Keystone Kops. It was bizarre enough to almost defy description.

headline: Report Cites High Civilian Toll in Pakistan Drone Strikes
abstract: The report urges the United States to “conduct a fundamental re-evaluation of current targeted killing practices” in Pakistan including “short- and long-term costs and benefits.”
lead_paragraph: A new report on targeted killing by C.I.A. drones in Pakistan’s tribal area concludes that the strikes have killed more civilians than American officials have acknowledged, alienated Pakistani public opinion and set a dangerous precedent under international law.

headline: Can Vegans and Carnivores Get Along? Moby Thinks So
abstract: The musician recalls a time when the two camps sat at separate tables.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve been a vegan for 24 years,” Moby, the musician, told me on the phone the other day. “With two lapses. I had yogurt in 1992, and I have to say, it was really good. And then I was at a friend’s restaurant in Portland, Oregon, a few years ago, and they made me some vegan sushi, but they accidentally brought me crab sushi. So I had a bite of crab sushi, and then my friend who ran the restaurant came running out yelling, like, ‘No! It’s got crab!’”

headline: How I Made My Memoir: Book Coming From Neil Patrick Harris
abstract: A nonfiction project from Neil Patrick Harris, the Emmy-winning star of “How I Met Your Mother” and host of many an award show, will be published by Crown Archetype in spring 2014.
lead_paragraph: By now Neil Patrick Harris’s bucket list must be short enough to fit on a Post-it note: host the Academy Awards; write a memoir; get the Criterion Collection to release a special cinephile edition of “Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle.” And he can cross one more item off that agenda: the Crown Archetype imprint of Random House’s Crown Publishing Group is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has acquired a new nonfiction book from Mr. Harris, the stage and screen performer; Emmy Award-winner; host of the Emmys, Tonys, TV Land Awards and Spike Video Game Awards; and star of CBS’s “How I Met Your Mother.”

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times: Spain, which has one of the world’s best cuisines, also has an unemployment rate of over 50 percent among young people, and many have resorted to foraging through the trash for food. — Emily Weinstein

headline: In Munich, Classing Up Oktoberfest
abstract: A few well-curated itineraries show off the more tasteful side of the holiday experience.
lead_paragraph: Ah, autumn. That traditional time of pigskin, piping hot pretzels, copious quantities of beer and blitzed bonhomie. No, we’re not talking about college football season. We’re talking about Oktoberfest, another fall tradition that’s not exactly known for its high quotient of class. There you are, sitting cheek-by-jowl with a bunch of lederhosen-ed Bavarians — or, more likely, stag-partying Britons and study-abroad Americans — on a wooden bench in a frigid tent in some biergarten in the middle of Munich, slogging through steins and trying to hail the dirndl-clad beermaid (bierfrau?) to get another wurst. It’s the worst.

headline: U.N. Leader Opens General Assembly on Somber Note
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said conflicts roiling the Middle East were a major concern.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the United Nations formally opened its annual General Assembly on Tuesday with a speech conveying a broad sense of crisis because of pressing problems including armed conflict in the Middle East, disruptive climate change and religious intolerance.

headline: New York City Schools Provide Morning-After Pills
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Education (K-12)', 'Parenting', 'Plan B (Contraceptive)', 'Teenage Pregnancy', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Should high schools provide access to emergency contraception to students?
lead_paragraph: In 13 New York City schools, the morning-after pill is available to students without parental permission, although parents are given the opportunity to opt their teenagers out of the health program (and the provision of any contraceptives) at the beginning of the school year.

headline: Trampoline Injuries Down, but Caution Is Urged
abstract: Trampoline injuries appear to be declining, but the American Academy of Pediatrics continues to advise against recreational trampoline use.
lead_paragraph: Trampoline injuries, which rose steadily through the middle of the last decade, appear to be on the downswing, according to a new study in the journal Pediatrics that looked at trampoline-related emergency room visits. But the drop in injuries appears to be a result of a decrease in trampoline sales rather than greater awareness of the dangers of trampolines and safer use, the authors said, and the American Academy of Pediatrics continues to advise against recreational trampoline use, a position it has taken since 1977.

headline: As the People’s Priest, He Fought for the Forgotten of the Bronx
abstract: The Rev. John C. Flynn, who was revered as an advocate for neighborhoods and people in South Bronx, died on Monday at 83.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. John C. Flynn could have been a monsignor, but as he told the story in later years, he refused the elevation because he already held a title more to his liking: the people’s priest.

headline: Small Presses Take Brooklyn
abstract: The Brooklyn Book Festival, which ended Sunday, was a showcase for the many small presses that have sprouted in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Book Festival, which ended Sunday, was a showcase for the many small presses that have sprouted in Brooklyn.

headline: Some Bettors Get Relief on Game Decided by Botched Call
abstract: One sports betting Web site was refunding wagers on the Packers, who appeared to be robbed of a win last night against the Seahawks by a ruling from replacement officials.
lead_paragraph: While it remains to be seen what, if anything, Commissioner Roger Goodell and the N.F.L. are going to do about the controversial ending to the game Monday night between the Seattle Seahawks and the Green Bay Packers, the gambling world — which was boosted by the replacement referees’ decision on the game’s final play, as significant money was bet on the Packers — appears to be showing at least a little compassion.

headline: Comparing the Job Losses in Financial Crises
abstract: When shown alongside the track records of other financial crises, the American job losses caused by the recent financial crisis don’t look so terrible.
lead_paragraph: For a while I was regularly updating a chart each month showing how far employment plummeted in the latest recession and how little ground has been recovered since the recovery began in June 2009. Compared with other recent recessions and recoveries, the last few years have looked especially disastrous:

headline: A Critical View of the Financial Crisis
abstract: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericsson’s chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Times’s James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at big law’s future.
lead_paragraph: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericsson’s chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Times’s James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at big law’s future.

headline: Hit-and-Run Driver Kills Cyclist in Queens
abstract: The driver struck a cyclist on Queens Boulevard in Kew Gardens around 6 a.m. and drove off, leaving him fatally injured.
lead_paragraph: The police are looking for a driver who fatally struck a 38-year-old bicyclist on Queens Boulevard on Tuesday morning and drove off. The collision occurred around 6 a.m. near the intersection of Hoover Avenue in Kew Gardens, the police said. The cyclist, whose name was not immediately released, was pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center. No information about the driver’s vehicle was immediately available.

abstract: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericsson’s chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Times’s James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at the future of big law.
lead_paragraph: Sheila C. Bair on her harsh history of the financial crisis. | Ericsson’s chief, Hans Vestberg, on surviving disruption. | The Times’s James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman look at the future of big law.

keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Foreign Aid', 'Microfinance', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Mitt Romney suggested that American foreign aid should be dependent on progress in certain areas.
lead_paragraph: 3:39 p.m. | Updated  Mitt Romney laid out the broad outlines of his plan to foster work opportunities and free enterprise in developing nations on Tuesday morning, suggesting during a speech at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York that he would make foreign aid conditional on progress on these fronts.

abstract: Atlantic blue crabs, or “tasty beautiful swimmers,” are currently in their fat and plentiful prime. Pair them with corn and tomatoes for a September feast.

abstract: Women working in the unorganized sector demand social security benefits from the government.

headline: Short Film by Target Draws Big-Name Talent
abstract: An ambitious example of “branded entertainment,” the 12-minute-long “Falling for You,” which stars Kristen Bell and is directed by Phil Abraham, will showcase more than 100 items Target is promoting for the fall season.
lead_paragraph: Target on Tuesday will announce its most ambitious foray into so-called “branded entertainment,” a 12-minute-long film, “Falling for You,” that will showcase more than 100 home, beauty and fashion items the company is promoting for the fall season.

headline: How Many Government Programs Have You Benefited From?
abstract: Research from Cornell University says that 96 percent of us have used one or more of these 21 government programs.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney stirred up a hornet’s nest with his comments about the 47 percent of Americans who he thinks are dependent on the government.

headline: Video Reports From Japan, Taiwan and China on Confrontation Off Disputed Islands
abstract: Three views of a confrontation in disputed waters on Tuesday were offered by broadcasters in Japan, Taiwan and China.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Hiroko Tabuchi reports from Tokyo, the Japanese Coast Guard fired water cannons on Tuesday at a flotilla of Taiwanese fishing boats off a chain of islands claimed by Japan, Taiwan and China. Japan’s state broadcaster, NHK, captured some of the confrontation on video.

abstract: With Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat.
lead_paragraph: With Lily Kwong as his 3-D model, the photographer Simon Cave imagines a fashion world that is anything but flat.

headline: Man Charged With Hate Crime After Antigay Attack
abstract: Keith Patron, 44, got into an argument with a man inside a McDonald’s in the West Village, the police said, made antigay statements and cut him with a razor.
lead_paragraph: A 44-year-old man has been arrested on charges of hate-crime assault for the antigay slashing last week of a 22-year-old man in a McDonald’s in the West Village, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Oil and Nature: A Landscape Reconfigured
keywords: ['Art', 'Chemicals', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Photography', 'Pipelines', 'Refineries']
abstract: An exhibition at the Aperture Gallery explores how the petrochemical industry has reshaped the Mississippi River corridor in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: In the stark white space of the Aperture Gallery in Chelsea, billboard-size photographs present an array of haunting scenes. A chemical plant with a cemetery in the foreground. An empty basketball court alongside a turreted oil refinery. A lush swamp filled with trees, one of which has a Shell Oil sign nailed to it.

headline: Producer Hopes to Bring ‘Black Orpheus’ to Broadway
abstract: Stephen C. Byrd, a Broadway producer, says he has seen the film at least 25 times and is developing a stage musical based on it.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway producer Stephen C. Byrd, who mounted a multiracial “Streetcar Named Desire” last season and an all-black “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” in 2008, is developing a new stage musical based on the 1959 film “Black Orpheus,” which won the Academy Award for best foreign-language picture in 1960.

headline: Some Things Never Change
abstract: Conventions of 1912 were described as having “psychopathic” conditions. In 1966, a columnist wrote that George Romney was “almost too good to be true.” And in 1974, Richard Nixon got the editorial cartoon treatment. Take a peek into our archive to see how has the IHT covered U.S. politics in the past.
lead_paragraph: The International Herald Tribune celebrates its 125th birthday in October, and over the coming weeks we’ll be sharing highlights from our archives.

lead_paragraph: See dozens of your souvenirs and the stories behind them.

headline: Antibiotic Prescription? It May Depend on Where You Live
abstract: Older men and women in the South are more often prescribed antibiotics than older Americans elsewhere, suggesting greater rates of antibiotic overuse in that part of the country.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that older men and women in the South are more often prescribed antibiotics than older Americans elsewhere, even though there is no evidence that the South has higher rates of pneumonia and other diseases for which antibiotics are necessary. The findings suggest there are greater rates of antibiotic overuse in that part of the country.

headline: Sept. 24: Deep Red Polling Mystery
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The totality of the evidence from states that are almost certain to go for Mitt Romney seems to be most consistent with a 5- or 6-point national lead for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: The FiveThirtyEight forecast was essentially unchanged on Monday, with Barack Obama holding a 77.7 percent chance of winning the Electoral College.

headline: On Eve of Paris Motor Show, Mercedes-Benz Provides Further Details on Yacht Design
abstract: The company announced further details on Tuesday about a yacht design that it said would be produced early next year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a sour European automotive market, Mercedes-Benz is diversifying into other forms of mobility. On the eve of the international motor show here, where the German automaker is scheduled to introduce several new automobiles, it shared further details on the designs for a new yacht.

headline: The Count and the Gymnasts
abstract: How a Swedish nobleman came to lead a regiment composed of German athletes in the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: During the Battle of Antietam on Sept. 17, 1862, Col. Ernst von Vegesack, the commander of the 20th New York Volunteer Infantry Regiment, sat prominently on horseback, while the unit’s banner, emblazoned with the words “Bahn Frei,” German for “clear the way,” streamed high over a ridge near the Dunker Church.

headline: A Young Immigrant Struggles for a College Education
abstract: As summer gives way to fall, one young illegal immigrant’s hopes of a college education and a stable, prosperous future are clouded by anxieties of deportation and other obstacles.
lead_paragraph: For graduating high school seniors, the months that stretch out between the end of spring and those first signs of fall can be magical — senior prom, graduation, soaking up summer then cramming in the last bits of time with childhood friends.

headline: Delusions of Wonkhood
abstract: He uses PowerPoint!
lead_paragraph: Dave Weigel has some fun with credulous journalists who are sure that Paul Ryan must be a Very Serious Wonk because — wait for it — he uses PowerPoint. With pie charts!

headline: Barnes & Noble to Introduce New Video Service for Nook Devices
keywords: ['Barnes & Noble Nook', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Television', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Customers will be able to stream and download movies and television shows for a fee, and store the content in a Nook cloud.
lead_paragraph: Barnes & Noble said on Tuesday it would introduce a new video store for its Nook products this fall, the latest expansion of the bookseller’s digital content.

abstract: Alas, Europe.
lead_paragraph: From Eurostat.

lead_paragraph: Times columnist James B. Stewart — a former lawyer — and reporter Peter Lattman look at the future of big law.

headline: Chinese Dissident Artist Says the Authorities Still Have His Passport
abstract: Without his passport, Ai Weiwei cannot travel to the United States next month for artistic events or start a job as a visiting professor in Germany.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Ai Weiwei, the rebel artist and acid critic of the Chinese Communist Party who was detained by the government last year, said Tuesday that the authorities were still holding his passport, which means he cannot travel to the United States for long-planned artistic events there next month or start a job as a visiting professor in Germany.

headline: Business Day Live: Law Firms Under Pressure
abstract: James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman of The New York Times look at the pressures facing the legal industry.
lead_paragraph: James B. Stewart and Peter Lattman of The New York Times look at the pressures facing the legal industry.

headline: N.F.L. Supports Decision Not to Overturn Winning Touchdown
abstract: The N.F.L. issued a statement Tuesday morning declaring the Packers-Seahawks game result final and supporting the decisions of its replay-booth referees.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. issued a statement Tuesday morning declaring the Packers-Seahawks game result final and supporting the decisions of its replay-booth referees, who did not overturn the controversial call of a game-winning touchdown for the Seahawks.

headline: A Form of Dementia That Is Often Misdiagnosed
abstract: Even many health care professionals remain unfamiliar with Lewy body dementia, though it affects about 1.3 million people in this country.
lead_paragraph: Lori Roberts’s father, who used to deliver the mail in Mitchell, S.D., has undergone startling personality changes. “He used to be very easygoing,” Ms. Roberts said. “Now he’s gotten kind of physical with my mom and my brother, pushing and shoving.” The other day, when her exhausted mother visited him in the nursing home he had recently entered — by sad coincidence, it was their 53rd wedding anniversary – he loudly insisted that she take him to Mexico, immediately.

headline: If You Like Roy Orbison . . .
abstract: Andrew Bird, a talented multi-instrumentalist from Chicago, has been described as having one of the most vivid imaginations in modern indie rock.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to music of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Russia Eases Limits on Visas for Americans
abstract: Multiple entries and stays of up to six months are now allowed.
lead_paragraph: Americans traveling to Russia face looser restrictions under a new visa agreement that the two countries reached this month.

headline: First Night of the New Season Has NBC and CBS Swapping Places
abstract: CBS showed some weakness for the premiere of “Partners” and “Hawaii Five-O,” and ratings took a nosedive for ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars.”
lead_paragraph: The first night of the official network television season turned the competition almost on its head as NBC dominated in the advertiser-preferred ratings, ABC dominated with older viewers, CBS saw its Monday lineup take a dive and Fox took a general battering.

headline: One Word: Plastics
abstract: The accessories designer Kristine Johannes brings something new to the landscape of luxury handbags.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to bring something new to the landscape of luxury handbags, the accessories designer Kristine Johannes deliberately avoided the one material that most obviously defines it: leather. “I just got sick of skins,” says Johannes, whose previous stints at J. Crew and Devi Kroell required a good amount of working with hides and exotics. “There are so many amazing man-made materials, I thought, ‘Why does the standard evening bag have to look like X?’ “ Which is how Rauwolf, Johannes’s line of angular plexiglass evening clutches, came to be so Y. Produced in an Italian factory that specializes in accessory parts like belt buckles and shoe heels, the seven bags in the fall collection take their cues from cut gemstones, with sharp lines, reflective surfaces and facets as dizzying as diamonds. “In a way, plexi is like stone,” Johannes says. “It comes in all of these thicknesses and gets carved down and filed down and heat treated to do what you want it to do.” The glassy-blue Shalimar clutch above has a magnetic closure, a sharp hourglass shape and — bonus points — doubles as a mirror for the quick makeup check. $2,300; rauwolfnyc.com.

headline: British Bankers Group May Give Up Control Over Libor
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: The British Bankers’ Association is expected to give up its responsibility for the global interest rate at the center of a recent manipulation scandal, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British banking group is preparing to give up its control over the interest rate at the center of a recent manipulation scandal, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Romney at the Clinton Global Initiative
abstract: The candidate has fine ideas on foreign aid. But they’re not exactly new.
lead_paragraph: The Republican nominee’s speech at the Clinton Global Initiative was surprisingly reasonable. Granted, Mr. Romney got in a few digs at President Obama, but they were subtle and almost funny. And he was a bit light on details, but the occasion didn’t really call for granularity.

headline: After Waters Inquiry, House Panel Recommends New Ethics Rules
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In the course of an investigation into Representative Maxine Waters, the special committee determined that the House rules were not sufficient to prevent certain conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: Saying that public trust is at stake, a special House ethics panel on Tuesday called for new rules to prevent lawmakers and their staffs from violating conflict of interest standards and proposed other new measures designed to keep partisan squabbles from undermining future investigations of such wrongdoing.

headline: The Sin of Sowing Hatred of Islam
keywords: ['Muslim-Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Transit Systems', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Ads that incite hatred against Muslims may be legal, but they are wrong and repugnant.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, on the morning of Sept. 11, I noticed a woman wearing a traditional Muslim head covering on the packed platform of the train station in Scarsdale, N.Y. Her attention was focused on a billboard ad that announced “19,250 deadly Islamic attacks since 9/11/01” and pre-empted those who might dispute that claim with the refrain: “It’s not Islamophobia, it’s Islamorealism.” I could only imagine what she was feeling.

headline: Charbroiling Burgers: An Air-Quality Scourge That May Be Worse Than Diesel Trucks
abstract: Authors of a study claimed that fewer particulate emissions were produced by running commercial diesel engines than by charbroiling hamburgers.
lead_paragraph: In Freakonomics-like fashion, researchers at the University of California, Riverside, have concluded that producing a charbroiled hamburger emits the same mass particulate matter as a heavy-duty diesel truck traveling 143 miles.

headline: State of the Race: Yankees Facing a Welcome Foe

headline: Maybe the Monkey Needs a Sports Star’s Name
abstract: “Animal Practice,” on NBC, and “The Neighbors,” on ABC, are new comedy shows on Wednesdays.
lead_paragraph: There’s only an hour on Wednesday night between the end of “Animal Practice” on NBC and the start of “The Neighbors” on ABC. That may not be enough time for you to recover from the brain cell loss the first one induced and prepare yourself for the even more severe brain cell loss the second will cause.

And what will it take to create more opportunity?” We don’t, say the authors, have nearly as much economic and social mobility in this country as we’d like to believe.

abstract: In August, it was revealed that the body of Sherman Hemsley was not buried and was instead being kept refrigerated at a funeral home amid a dispute between his former manager and a man who says he is the actor’s brother.
lead_paragraph: The legal fight over the estate of Sherman Hemsley, “The Jeffersons” star who died in July, has escalated to a new level of bizarreness, as a judge ruled that a man claiming to be the actor’s brother must undergo DNA testing, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Blasts Hit Syrian School as War Is Focus at the U.N.
abstract: The conflict’s scope widened as Syrian government shells landed in the disputed Golan Heights region held by Israel.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Insurgent bombs exploded at a Damascus school building on Tuesday, and Syrian government shells landed in the disputed Golan Heights region held by Israel, underscoring the Syrian conflict’s growing scope as it dominated much of the discussion on the first formal day of the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Hidden in a Nook, Mastery in Plain Sight
abstract: A little-known sushi bar in TriBeCa, brimming with remarkable sashimi and sushi, is a secret no longer.
lead_paragraph: MANY people who love restaurants dream about discovering an extraordinary one that nobody else knows about and keeping it secret. I’d always thought I was one of them until the Friday night not long ago when I ate with a guest in an empty sushi bar in TriBeCa. During the two hours we sat there, no customers arrived to claim the six other counter seats or the four chairs at a nearby table.

headline: Iran Reveals More About What It Calls Foreign Sabotage
abstract: An announcement by the Intelligence Ministry did not specify the intended targets, but said they included nuclear, defense, industrial and telecommunications installations.
lead_paragraph: Iran said Tuesday that it had amassed new evidence of attempts by saboteurs to attack Iranian nuclear, defense, industrial and telecommunications installations, including the use of computer virus-infected American, French and German equipment.
