headline: From Methane to Plastic to Methane, Without Waste
keywords: ['Contests and Prizes', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Methane', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: At the end of its life cycle, a toy or shampoo bottle could turn back into methane at a wastewater plant.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that you could go online and rent something in your neighbor’s garage rather than buy something new that you will need to use only a few times a year. Or that you could use microwave technology to transform timber residue or other waste biomass into a valuable industrial material like graphite.

headline: A Deadline in the Missouri Senate Race
abstract: Tuesday is the last day that Representative Todd Akin, a Republican, can drop out of the Senate race against Senator Claire McCaskill in Missouri.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday is the last day that Representative Todd Akin, a Republican, can drop out of the Senate race against Senator Claire McCaskill in Missouri.

headline: One of a Kind
abstract: Kit Kemp, hotel owner and interior designer, details her approach to distinctive decorating in a new book.
lead_paragraph: In the eight hotels that Kit Kemp owns with her husband, Tim — among them the Crosby Street Hotel in Manhattan and the Dorset Square Hotel in London — no two rooms are alike. This is because Kemp, who designed the spaces, eschews the common practice of selecting a single scheme to be repeated throughout, instead embarking on a painstaking process of decorating every room to be utterly distinct from the next. She selects each, say, 1960s Lucite lamp, piece of boiled-wool upholstery and Filipino totem sculpture, then pulls them all together in a highly individualized, homey whole that is greater than the sum of its parts. In a new book, “Kit Kemp: A Living Space” (Hardie Grant, $50), Kemp details her approach to design (for residential as well as hotel projects), and sums it up as, “Keep it personal.” Her secret? Finding “little touches — like using a kerosene can, instead of classically cut crystal, as a lamp base in a romantic bedroom.”

headline: In Paris, an Exhibition Dedicated to Hair
abstract: A new show at the Musée du Quai Branly in Paris celebrates the importance of hair in art, fashion, style, ritual, sexuality, religion and culture, from antiquity to today.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hair, as the song from the musical goes, can be “long, straight, curly, fuzzy, snaggy, shaggy, ratty, matty, oily, greasy, fleecy.”

headline: BBC Causes Uproar by Reporting Queen’s Opinion
abstract: In what is considered a breach of etiquette, a BBC correspondent said that Queen Elizabeth had once told him she was “pretty upset” about a radical cleric in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Succumbing to what appears to have been a disastrous urge to brag about his super-important connections, a BBC correspondent unexpectedly declared in a radio interview on Tuesday that Queen Elizabeth II had once told him she was “pretty upset” about the presence of a radical Islamist cleric in North London.

headline: Paul Taylor to Receive Bessie Lifetime Achievement Award
abstract: The ceremony will be held on Oct. 15 at the Apollo Theater and hosted by Elizabeth Streb.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Paul Taylor will receive a lifetime achievement Bessie, the nickname for the New York Dance and Performance Awards, Dance/NYC, which helps produce the award ceremony, said on Tuesday. Alice Teirstein, the founding director of the Young Dancemakers Company and a longtime faculty member at the Fieldston School, will be honored for service to the dance field. The ceremony will be held on Oct. 15 at the Apollo Theater, hosted by Elizabeth Streb and featuring performances by the Trisha Brown Company and Souleymane Badolo. Presenters include Marina Abramovic, Ron Brown, Brenda Bufalino, Archie Burnett, Bebe Neuwirth, Charles Reinhart, David Thomson, and Wendy Whelan.

headline: Why the Health Care Tax Credit Eludes Many Small Businesses
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Small Business']
abstract: The G.A.O. concluded that the credit was too small to sway business owners. Moreover, it said, claiming the credit is a task so complicated as to discourage many companies from trying.
lead_paragraph: The Agenda has now profiled three small businesses that are struggling in different ways with providing health insurance to employees. The companies are very different — they trade in very different parts of the economy, and couldn’t be located much further apart geographically — but they do have one thing in common: Though all three have fewer than 25 employees, not one has qualified for the tax credit in the Affordable Care Act that was intended to help small businesses pay for health insurance. Indeed, the credit is one element of the controversial health law that has already fallen short of expectations.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Mitt Romney’s 2011 tax return highlights the use of a questionable tax planning technique that may have avoided Medicare tax liability on up to $2 million of services income derived from his past employment at Bain Capital.

headline: State of the Race: How the Cards Haunt the Brewers
abstract: While the Brewers have been piling up victories, so have the Cardinals, the same Cardinals who ended the Brewers’ run to the World Series last season.
lead_paragraph: For the Milwaukee Brewers and their fans, the 2012 season started under a cloud and remained that way pretty much until September, when that cloud parted and a magical run began. Could the Brewers be this year’s Team of Destiny? Could they be the St. Louis Cardinals of last season? As the wins piled up, it seemed inevitable. Ryan Braun is still the league most valuable player, the bullpen remembered how to pitch, the Pirates remembered they are the Pirates. Playoffs, here we come.

headline: Enjoying the Heat in Brooklyn
abstract: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s annual Chile Pepper Fiesta will be held Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s celebration of chiles marks its 20th anniversary this year with more peppers than ever. Dozens of varieties are being cultivated in the herb garden, which visitors can tour as part of the fiesta on Saturday. A farmstand will sell the chiles, from the mild aji to the impossibly hot bhut jolokia, or ghost pepper.

headline: As Scandal Grows, Party of Berlusconi Cleans House
abstract: Following the resignation of an Italian regional president, leaders of the conservative party of Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister, said they would open councils’ accounts to auditors.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The conservative party of Italy’s former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, announced a series of housecleaning measures on Tuesday following a financing scandal that prompted the resignation of the party’s representative in the important Lazio region on Monday.

headline: Oysters Party Like It’s the ’40s
abstract: A new party service employs servers with buckets of oysters on ice rather than a stationary raw bar.
lead_paragraph: Rifko Meier, a Dutch art dealer and entrepreneur, created the Oyster Girls, a clever idea for parties that met with some success in his native Amsterdam. Now he’s brought them to New York. In place of a stationary raw bar, servers with buckets of oysters on ice hung around their waists circulate in the crowd and open shellfish on the spot for guests. They are also equipped with little containers of various sauces and a pail for shells. Each server can handle 100 oysters, Mr. Meier said.

headline: Bookshelf
abstract: Three very different new releases have captured our attention this fall.
lead_paragraph: “The Phaidon Archive of Graphic Design” (Phaidon, $235) is the commercial art canon embodied: 500 topic sheets on everything from a 700-year-old Buddhist text to the album art of Beck’s “The Information.” “Thanks for the View, Mr. Mies” (Metropolis Books, $30) explores how Modernist architecture improves lives in the Lafayette Park section of Detroit, which has the world’s largest concentration of Mies van der Rohe buildings. (It’s also one of the most racially integrated neighborhoods in what might well be America’s most segregated city.) Peter Trachtenberg’s memoir “Another Insane Devotion” (Da Capo, $24) — about love, sex, marriage and especially cats — is a hallmark of brainy discursiveness, set into motion when the author loses Biscuit, a wan cat whose sniffles sound like “a whisk broom briskly sweeping.”

headline: Protesters Take to Street in Madrid
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Thousands besieged Parliament as Spain’s two largest regions posed challenges to the country’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The pressures facing the government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy mounted on several fronts on Tuesday, as thousands of demonstrators besieged Parliament and Spain’s two largest regions took steps that underscored their deepening economic troubles and displeasure with his austerity plans.

headline: Taking Processing Out of Take-Away
abstract: Hu Kitchen, near Union Square, serves evolved take-away.
lead_paragraph: Hu Kitchen, near Union Square, is proof of how far quick take-away food has come. The name sounds Asian, but Hu stands for “human,” and the philosophy is to serve food, most of it prepared on the premises, that puts a minimum on processed ingredients.

headline: Ericsson’s Chief on Surviving Disruption
abstract: Business Day Live: Hans Vestberg, chief executive of Ericsson, discusses the fast-changing communications industry.
lead_paragraph: Business Day Live: Hans Vestberg, chief executive of Ericsson, discusses the fast-changing communications industry.

abstract: A connection for uptown No. 6 trains opened Tuesday.

headline: RIM Shows Off New BlackBerry 10 Phones, but Gives No Firm Release Date
abstract: A new prototype of RIM’s BlackBerry 10 phones includes more refined software than a previous version. But in displaying the new phones, the company’s chief executive, Thorsten Heins, did not say exactly when they would be released. Their introduction into the marketplace has been delayed twice.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Research in Motion said on Tuesday that its coming line of BlackBerry 10 phones would include the company’s popular BlackBerry Messenger service, a feature still absent on its tablet computers.

headline: Pakistani Papers Banned by Afghanistan in East
abstract: The Afghan Interior Ministry said the publications, in English, Pashto and Urdu, were “functioning as mouthpieces and propaganda tools for the Taliban.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the often ill-tempered war of words between Afghanistan and Pakistan, the Afghans have just taken a new tack: outlawing Pakistani words.

headline: Juan Luis Guerra Tops List of Latin Grammy Nominations
abstract: The veteran Dominican singer-songwriter picked up six nominations, even competing with himself in the song of the year category.
lead_paragraph: The veteran Dominican singer-songwriter Juan Luis Guerra leads the list of contenders for this year’s edition of the Latin Grammy Awards, picking up six nominations on Tuesday. In the song of the year category, Mr. Guerra even ended up competing against himself, with two of his compositions vying for that honor. The Mexican brother-sister pop duo Jesse & Joy followed with five Latin Grammy nominations, while the Colombian rocker Juanes, Guatemala’s Ricardo Arjona and the Brazilians Caetano Veloso and Ivete Sangalo were among the artists getting four.

headline: President Obama Addresses U.N.
abstract: Barack Obama spoke about Iran,the wave of new protests around the Arab world and the recent attacks on American Embassies.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama spoke about Iran,the wave of new protests around the Arab world and the recent attacks on American Embassies.

headline: Dumb Baseball Injury Chronicles: Dry Eyeballs?
abstract: Josh Hamilton has earned himself a prominent spot on the season’s list of stupid baseball injuries, a roster that also includes David Price and Ramon Ramirez.
lead_paragraph: If caffeine addiction were a major sin, a lot of us would be in big trouble. So, it would seem a bit hypocritical to snicker at the Rangers’ Josh Hamilton for revealing that caffeine was at the root of his recent five-game sick leave. On the other hand, not many of us ingest enough caffeine to dry out our eyeballs and give us blurry vision — something rather critical to a baseball player — so all ridicule seems to be fair game.

headline: Candidates Address Class Size and Teachers’ Unions at Education Forum
abstract: The issue of class size in schools was injected into the presidential race as Mitt Romney said that while governor of Massachusetts, he was able to do more with less during an economic downturn.
lead_paragraph: Though education has not been a major focus in the presidential campaign, the charged issue of class size was injected into the race on Tuesday as Mitt Romney said that while governor of Massachusetts, he was able to do more with less during an economic downturn.

headline: Behind a Restaurant Emergency, a Troubleshooter
abstract: When restaurants have a stove or refrigeration emergency, they send out distress calls to specialists to find and fix the problem.
lead_paragraph: ON a hot and humid Thursday, Brian Follander found himself in a familiar position, sprawled on a restaurant kitchen floor, staring into the nether regions of a stove that would not light.

headline: Past Forward: The Fight Over Fracking
abstract: A look at Western Pennsylvania and what fracking may actually mean for people’s lives.
lead_paragraph: With a skeptical eye fixed on industry in an era of rapid technological development two generations ago, Rachel Carson “made a powerful case for the idea that if humankind poisoned nature, nature would in turn poison humankind,” as Eliza Griswold put it in last weekend’s magazine, marking the 50th anniversary of the publication of Carson’s seminal book, “Silent Spring.”

headline: Sea Calls, but So Does Love
abstract: The warmhearted play “Marius” is a bit short on plot, but this revival, by the Storm Theater Company, doesn’t want for talent.
lead_paragraph: The warmhearted play “Marius” is a bit short on plot, but this revival, by the Storm Theater Company, doesn’t want for talent. Here, affection takes precedence over action, and the show’s deepest pleasures are reserved for those with patience.

headline: A Musical in Celebration of Saving Face in China, That Booming New Market
abstract: Anna Grace Carter’s new musical, “Rent a White Guy,” follows a recent college graduate who finds that being a Caucasian in China can be a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Over the centuries China has given the world many treasures: Confucianism, pandas, table tennis, a superhumanly synchronized Olympics opening ceremony, pretty much everything ever sold at Walmart.

headline: Which Presidential Candidate Is Better for College Applicants?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Pell Grants', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Student Loans', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Mark Kantrowitz, an expert on paying for college, explains how the 2012 presidential election could affect college applicants.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a college-bound student who has been (loosely) following the 2012 presidential campaign, this is an excellent time to tune in (and catch up).

headline: The Biggest Controversy, but Far From the First
abstract: There have been plenty of calls by the N.F.L. replacement officials this season that puzzled fans, coaches and players, but five stand out.
lead_paragraph: The first three weeks of the N.F.L. season have been defined not by gripping games or outstanding performances, but by the performance of the league’s replacement officials, who many say are turning the sport into a mockery. No calls brought more attention and embarrassment than the ones in the debacle Monday night in Seattle, where the officials awarded the Seahawks a game-winning touchdown as time ran out against Green Bay, despite Golden Tate’s interfering with a Packers defender and then another Packers defender seeming to have initial possession of the ball. But there are plenty of others that have prompted a head scratch — or seven. Here are five that stand out.

headline: In Paris, Restos for Fashion’s Restless
abstract: David Flynn and Nicolas Clerc of the hot new cafe Télescope share their favorite spots.
lead_paragraph: Coffee is having something of a fashionable moment in Paris, a city long derided for its substandard roasts. And at the vanguard of the bean revolution are David Flynn and Nicolas Clerc of the hot new cafe Télescope, which proved an instant hit when it opened behind the Palais Royal’s illustrious arcades in April. Clerc, a Parisian photographer, and Flynn, the American co-founder of the monthly barista throwdown Frog Fight, also happen to be very attuned to the city’s evolving culinary scene. They’re as discerning about the food they eat as the coffee they brew and drink.

headline: Qaeda Operatives Killed in Drone Strike, Official Says
abstract: The strike, by a United States drone in Pakistan’s North Waziristan region, killed five people, including the two militants, a Pakistani official said.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — An Al Qaeda operative of Turkish origin and an Iraqi reported to be a liaison between Al Qaeda and the Taliban were among five people killed on Monday in a United States drone strike in Pakistan’s lawless North Waziristan region, a Pakistani security official confirmed Tuesday.

headline: TV Trends That Deserve the Unwelcome Mat
abstract: New ideas today, clichés by tomorrow? Series like “666 Park Avenue,” “New Girl” and “The New Normal” contribute to unwelcome trends.
lead_paragraph: Many of television’s worst infestations — newscasters with hairpieces; reality shows with “Extreme” in the title; commercials featuring talking lizards, cats or infants — began quietly. Early attention or government action might have stopped them, but then ubiquity set in, and suddenly they were a fact of life.

headline: MaryAnne Gilmartin
keywords: ['Atlantic Yards (Brooklyn)', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Ms. Gilmartin is an executive vice president at Forest City Ratner Companies. Its Barclays Center arena, part of the Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn, is to open this week.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Gilmartin, 48, is executive vice president for commercial and residential development at Forest City Ratner Companies, which was a development partner of The New York Times’s headquarters. Its Barclays Center arena, part of the Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn, is to open this week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Bulgaria, Afghanistan, Syria and Bolivia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Bulgaria, Afghanistan, Syria and Bolivia.

headline: At a Desert Party, Everything Happens
abstract: “The Forgiven” explores a clash of worlds between Moroccans and Western visitors who converge at a weekend-long bacchanal in a desert villa.
lead_paragraph: It’s a thin line, Chrissie Hynde sang, between love and hate. Reading Lawrence Osborne’s new novel, “The Forgiven,” you may sometimes feel that you are straddling that line in a vertiginous way, like Philippe Petit walking a high wire between the World Trade Center towers.

headline: Obama and Romney Talk Foreign Policy
abstract: At the U.N. General Assembly, the president seemed to respond to his right-wing critics.
lead_paragraph: Today was foreign policy day on the campaign trail, as President Obama addressed both the United Nations General Assembly and the Clinton Global Initiative, and Mitt Romney addressed the latter group. And what a day it was not.

headline: With a Push From Google, California Legalizes Driverless Cars
abstract: California became the third state to explicitly legalize cars that drive themselves. Google, which is building the cars and has been heavily lobbying lawmakers, says they are safer because they reduce human error.
lead_paragraph: California drivers could soon see cars on the road driving themselves, courtesy of Google and the state government.

headline: Vitality Reborn, New Orleans Draws Developers
abstract: Several retail projects show a new confidence by outside developers and retailers in New Orleans’ post-Katrina economic strength.
lead_paragraph: It has been seven years since Hurricane Katrina brought New Orleans to its knees and a month since Isaac threatened to push the city down again.

headline: Rascals to Reunite for Three Shows
abstract: The show, which will run three nights in December, will tell the group’s history through archival footage, narration and dramatic film segments.
lead_paragraph: Steven Van Zandt has been trying to persuade his musical heroes the Rascals – the influential white soul group known for hits like “Good Lovin’ ” and “Groovin’ ” — to reunite since the early 1980s.  But the four original members, who started the band as the Young Rascals in New Jersey in 1965, agreed to perform together only once since – at a private benefit concert in 2010.

headline: Dear Seth, You’re a (Fill in Here)
abstract: Is the Frugal Traveler a writer akin to the Apostle Paul? Or just a “provincial” hack? Depends on which commenter you believe.
lead_paragraph: Do either of these Zagat-style summaries remind you of a certain travel writer you know?

headline: Cathy Horyn’s Milan Report
abstract: Cathy Horyn reflects on spring 2013 collections, including Jil Sander, Prada and Giorgio Armani.
lead_paragraph: Cathy Horyn reflects on spring 2013 collections, including Jil Sander, Prada and Giorgio Armani.

headline: Dining Calendar
abstract: Le Taste of France Show on Pier 54, the annual Pie Social at Bubby’s, a Chinese harvest festival and more.
lead_paragraph: Benefits

headline: Grooving to the Beat and Bang of the Subway
abstract: The talented Ephrat Asherie, known in the dance world as Bounce, has choreographed “Single Ride,” about what it’s like to experience the New York City subway.
lead_paragraph: What is it about a subway ride that ignites a choreographer’s imagination? In recent years the subway-inspired dance has become as frequent as the L train at rush hour. Remember Camille A. Brown’s energetic yet contrived “Groove to Nobody’s Business” for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater? Just about every retelling of what it’s like to experience the New York City subway proves that while there’s a lot to see — stations bustle with constant activity — there really isn’t much to say.

headline: Apple’s Competitors Pile On With Map Critiques
abstract: Google said it hasn’t made a move to restore its maps to the iPhone, but it declined to say whether the company had submitted a new maps app to Apple’s App Store. And why would Google show its cards? Here is an opportunity for the company to show that phones using Android have a more robust maps product. Some of Apple’s other competitors are already playing this game.
lead_paragraph: Eric E. Schmidt, Google’s chairman, told reporters in Tokyo on Tuesday that the company had done nothing to get its maps back onto the iPhone since Apple removed them in its new iOS 6 operating system for mobile devices. He said Apple should have stuck with Google’s maps, but, according to Bloomberg, he declined to say whether the company had submitted a new maps app to Apple’s App Store.

headline: Off the Menu
abstract: Marcus Samuelsson teams with Restaurant Associates at Lincoln Center and the M. Wells team is back, at MoMA P.S. 1.
lead_paragraph: Opening

headline: Estonia Gets Highest Marks for Internet Freedom
abstract: Many countries are increasingly clamping down on what their citizens can say online, but Estonia ranks at the top of countries for freedom on the Internet, according to a survey by an American advocacy group.
lead_paragraph: What’s up with Estonia? The tiny Baltic nation affords its citizens the greatest measure of digital freedom as measured by Freedom House, a Washington  advocacy group.

headline: Music in Review
abstract: Kimiko Ishizaka played Bach at the W.M.P. Concert Hall. The Talea Ensemble played three American premieres at the Bohemian National Hall.
lead_paragraph: KIMIKO ISHIZAKA

headline: A Veteran of Judson Dance Recalls Its Wild 1960s Heyday
abstract: Carolee Schneemann, one of the original members of Judson Dance Theater in the 1960s, revisited her creations in video and performance.
lead_paragraph: Naked men and women gamboling through water and grass; nearly naked people taking pleasure in one another, lolling on the floor in raw chicken and fish. Ah, the ’60s.

headline: Radio-Tagged Socks for the Obsessive
abstract: Blacksocks, a Swiss company, attaches a radio ID tag to its socks so that by using an RFID reader, you can always put the correct pair together.
lead_paragraph: How do you know when you have slipped from detail-oriented, past anal-retentive, all the way to obsessive-compulsive?

headline: Efterklang, Tonight at the Apple Store in SoHo
abstract: And why you should go see them.
lead_paragraph: I had the great fortune this weekend of seeing the Danish band Efterklang perform at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The band (whose name means “reverberation” or something close to it in Danish) performed with an orchestra, backup singers and a horn section. To reach the theater where the concert was held, you had to meander through the Egyptian exhibit: past ornate sarcophaguses and hieroglyphic friezes. I’d never been to any kind of presentation in a museum, particularly on a Saturday night. I kind of half-expected some crank in the audience (all seated reverently) to rise and declaim his apocalyptic visions, as in ‘‘The DaVinci Code’’ or ‘‘12 Monkeys.’’ That didn’t happen, quite. But for an encore, the singer, Caspar Clausen, exhorted the crowd to stand and groove for at least a few minutes. The crowd obliged.

headline: Q&A: Combining Two Facebook Pages
abstract: Facebook does not offer a way to automatically merge two personal accounts, but you can do it manually.
lead_paragraph: Q.

headline: Pop-Punk Bands, Now Grown Up
abstract: Green Day and No Doubt, bands that played the iHeartRadio festival in Las Vegas, have released new albums.
lead_paragraph: The iHeartRadio festival is a hootenanny where the biggest acts in every genre convene for a two-day affair presented by Clear Channel, the gargantuan radio conglomerate, in support of its streaming radio application. As concerts or festivals go, it’s not punk.

headline: Insouciant Elegance and Nonchalant Fireworks, Fueled by Ballet Power
abstract: The San Francisco Ballet’s season in London demonstrated that company’s commitment to new choreography with technical aplomb and stylistic versatility.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The San Francisco Ballet season at Sadler’s Wells in London, which ended on Sunday, was an impressive, and tactical, display of ballet power. The company arrived with three programs and 10 ballets for its weeklong run —no small feat on the artistic or financial front. With the exception of Balanchine’s 1956 “Divertimento No. 15,” all the dances were created during the past four years. The company’s commitment to new choreography was clear; its technical aplomb and stylistic versatility shiningly apparent.

headline: Vivid Dispatches From Syria’s Front Lines
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Three correspondents for British news organizations filed vivid television reports from inside Syria in the past week.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen months have passed since an adviser to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria scolded a BBC correspondent in Damascus for reporting that video posted on YouTube by activists appeared to contradict official accounts of a crackdown on protesters broadcast on state-run television. “The events are happening in Syria,” Bouthaina Shaaban insisted, one week into the uprising, “therefore, it’s Syrian television who tells the truth, nobody else.”

headline: A Coastal Tax Fight
abstract: The Times’s Kim Severson travels to Sapelo Island to visit Hog Hammock, population 50. The Gullah-Geechee residents have lived there since slavery, but may have to sell off their land over taxes.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Kim Severson travels to Sapelo Island to visit Hog Hammock, population 50. The Gullah-Geechee residents have lived there since slavery, but may have to sell off their land over taxes.

headline: Taxes Threaten an Island Culture in Georgia
abstract: Increasing economic pressures are forcing the saltwater Geechees of Sapelo Island, Ga., to wonder if their fragile community will finally succumb to cultural erosion.
lead_paragraph: SAPELO ISLAND, Ga. — Once the huge property tax bills started coming, telephones started ringing. It did not take long for the 50 or so people who live on this largely undeveloped barrier island to realize that life was about to get worse.

headline: Sarah Silverman Talks About Voter ID Ad
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A new video, called “Let My People Vote,” touched a nerve and has been viewed more than 1.4 million times since last Thursday. With plenty of four-letter words and a sense of outrage, Ms. Silverman encourages voters to make sure they have the proper identification to vote in November.
lead_paragraph: In a follow-up to her “Great Schlep” video from the last presidential election, Sarah Silverman decided to take on new voter identification laws that could prevent some people from voting this time around.

headline: MoMA Plans to Be Open Every Day
abstract: In response to growing attendance, the Museum of Modern Art plans to be open every day, beginning in May.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after the Metropolitan Museum of Art said it was considering staying open seven days a week, the Museum of Modern Art announced that starting in May it would be open every day, including Tuesday, the one day it has traditionally been closed.

headline: In the Studio | Anthony Vaccarello
abstract: The fluidity of the ocean served as an inspiration for his spring collection, which includes looks for all hours of the day.
lead_paragraph: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Santander’s Mexican Unit Sells U.S. Shares at $12.18 in Dual Listing
abstract: The Mexican arm of Banco Santander priced the U.S. portion of its initial public offering at about $12.18 on Tuesday, according to a person briefed on the matter, within its expected price range as the lender held one of the biggest stock sales ever by a Mexican company.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican arm of Banco Santander priced the American portion of its initial public offering at $12.18 on Tuesday, within its expected price range, according to a person briefed on the matter who declined to be identified.

headline: A Place of Desperation, Where Both Patients and Patience Are Tested
abstract: “The Waiting Room” looks at health care and suffering in an emergency room in Oakland, Calif.
lead_paragraph: The crowded emergency room of Highland Hospital in Oakland, Calif., is the setting of Peter Nicks’s wrenching documentary “The Waiting Room.” Shot in 2010 over five months, the film, which has no narrator, titles, statistical analysis or overt editorializing, observes a composite day there during which nearly 250 patients — most of them uninsured — pour in.

headline: Parking Rules: Yom Kippur
abstract: Special rules will be in effect on Wednesday in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Wednesday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Folk Stories From Many Lands, Conjured With a Colorful Spin
abstract: The animator Michel Ocelot gives a culturally diverse assortment of folk tales his own spin in “Tales of the Night.”
lead_paragraph: The French animator Michel Ocelot specializes in giving folk tales his own spin, and he does so in “Tales of the Night,” his latest modest, charming offering. A framing device involves a man considered too old for filmmaking and a pair of teenagers too young. In an abandoned theater they conjure stories, each from a different culture and ending with a twist.

headline: What’s Wrong With Blasphemy?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Suppose there had not been a single riot in response to “The Innocence of Muslims.” Would the makers of the film have done anything wrong?
lead_paragraph: Suppose there had not been a single riot in response to the now infamous video “The Innocence of Muslims,” Not a single car burned, not a single embassy breached, not a single human being physically hurt. Would the makers of this risible little clip have done anything wrong? If so, to whom, and why?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hacking Public Transit, and Twitter Rethinking Follower Counts
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selection includes Samsung challenging the jury foreman in the Apple patent verdict, questions about Microsoft’s energy use at a Washington State data center and to trying to go a full month paying for everything with only a smartphone.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Student Accused of Invasion of Privacy at Princeton
abstract: A Princeton University student has been charged with invasion of privacy for allegedly taking sexually explicit photographs of a fellow student while he slept.
lead_paragraph: A Princeton University student has been charged with invasion of privacy after a fellow student accused him of taking sexually explicit photographs of him while he slept.

headline: In Romney-Obama ‘Redistribution’ Debate, a Gray Area
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Demographics alone suggest that regardless of who is the next president, the government is going to wind up distributing more of the nation’s wealth than it does today.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney may be right about President Obama’s Robin Hood tendencies. Future historians could well conclude that Mr. Obama led the biggest redistribution of wealth in decades.

headline: The Roses Are a Draw. (So Is the Dress Code.)
abstract: Abbey House Gardens is known for its 2,000 varieties of roses, its mix of landscaped and wild paths, and the six days during the summer when clothing is optional.
lead_paragraph: MALMESBURY, England — Sunday was the last clothing-optional day of the season at Abbey House Gardens in this ancient Wiltshire village, and a cold and torrential rain had confounded many visitors’ clothes-free plans.

headline: Gardner Returns for Pinch-Running Duty
abstract: Brett Gardner, who had inflamed tissue and a bone spur removed from his non-throwing elbow July 24, was activated by the Yankees Tuesday as a possible pinch runner.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Brett Gardner still has not taken batting practice on the field, and he might not be ready to hit in a game until next week. But the Yankees need Gardner’s legs more than his bat, and his legs are fine.

headline: Maurice H. Keen Dies at 78; Redefined Chivalry
abstract: Mr. Keen was a scholar who re-examined the code used among knights and determined it was meant to protect the warrior class rather than to emphasize good deeds.
lead_paragraph: Honorable men, as they were called in the golden age of chivalry, were rich enough to outfit a squadron of knights and brutal enough to lead them into battle, often culminating in the killing and plundering of civilian populations. The code of chivalry defined honor in ways that are familiar to people today — as honesty, loyalty, courage — and in ways that are not. It was honorable, for example, to show mercy to a defeated enemy, but only if the enemy was a social equal.

headline: The Geechees of Sapelo Island
abstract: Sapelo Island, a tangle of salt marsh and sand reachable only by boat, holds the largest community of people who identify themselves as saltwater Geechees.
lead_paragraph: Sapelo Island, a tangle of salt marsh and sand reachable only by boat, holds the largest community of people who identify themselves as saltwater Geechees.

headline: Board Votes for Bigger Type on City Ballots
abstract: After complaints that the font size of names on the primary ballots was too small, New York City’s Board of Elections voted to increase the type on the general-election ballots.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama and Mitt Romney may soon loom a little larger in the eyes of New York City voters.

headline: Dr. Griffith Edwards, Addiction Specialist, Dies at 83
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Dr. Edwards, a British psychiatrist, reshaped thinking about heavy drinking, the psychology of drug use and the implications for public policy.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Griffith Edwards, a psychiatrist who helped establish addiction medicine as a science, formulating definitions of drug and alcohol dependence that are used worldwide to diagnose and treat substance abuse, died on Sept. 13 in a hospice near his home in Greenwich, England. He was 83.

headline: Out of the Pool, Phelps Finds the Water at Medinah
abstract: Michael Phelps, the 22-time Olympic swimming medalist, played in Tuesday’s celebrity scramble at Medinah Country Club, where the Ryder Cup will begin on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — Michael Phelps’s wedge shot was a little thin, but it got airborne, giving rise to abundant applause from the fans in the grandstand behind the Medinah Country Club practice range. Phelps, the 22-time Olympic swimming medalist, felt like a fish out of water Tuesday when he swung his clubs alongside golfers who formed a major titleholder’s row.

headline: Tolerance, Up in Flames
abstract: A cinema attack was not about American influence or anti-Muslim videos. Pakistani extremists are attacking, and destroying, their country’s own values and traditions.
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: Zebra-nomics
abstract: The N.F.L. is willing to tarnish its reputation for the price of a 30-second commercial during the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Oh, the horror: on the greatest national stage we have, in the last second of a close game, a bunch of replacement referees from the Lingerie Football League and other far outposts of the sport took a game away from the rightful winners.

headline: Anticipating Fallout From Lobbyist’s Legal Cooperation
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'State Legislatures', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: With the revelation that Richard J. Lipsky, convicted of bribery, was assisting federal authorities, officials in Albany and New York City wondered what new scandal might emerge.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The halls of the New York State Capitol have for years provided a happy hunting ground for prosecutors and ethics investigators.

headline: Russia: 2 Police Officers Found Guilty in Police Brutality Case in Kazan
abstract: A regional court handed down the first guilty verdicts in a case that exposed the systematic torture of suspects in a police department in the capital of the Tatarstan Republic.
lead_paragraph: A regional court handed down the first guilty verdicts on Tuesday in a police brutality case that exposed the systematic torture of suspects in a police department in Kazan, the capital of the Tatarstan Republic. A judge said two officers, Ilshat Garifullin and Ramil Nigshatzyanov, illegally arrested Sergei Nazarov of Kazan, accused of stealing a cellphone. Mr. Nazarov later died. Four other officers are accused of sodomizing him with a Champagne bottle in an interrogation. Mr. Garifullin was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, and Mr. Nigshatzyanov to two years. The four officers charged in the assault have yet to stand trial.

headline: Executive Change at Yahoo Suggests Thirst for Acquisitions
abstract: The replacement of the company’s chief finance officer, Tim Morse, who had a history of cost-cutting, with Ken Goldman of Fortinet could indicate that Yahoo is ready to expand.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Yahoo’s newly installed chief executive, Marissa Mayer has given employees free cafeteria food, replaced their BlackBerry phones with iPhone and Android smartphones and closed a long-awaited deal with Alibaba that gives Yahoo $625 million.

headline: ‘New Girl’ Watch: A Season Premiere and a Balancing Act
abstract: “New Girl” returned for its second season on Fox Tuesday night and again attempted a difficult balancing act.
lead_paragraph: A lot of sitcoms these days involve characters struggling against economic, romantic or psychological limitations, but no comedy goes straight for the heart of melancholy quite like “New Girl,” which returned for its second season on Fox with two episodes Tuesday night. Focusing on a group of roommates caught halfway between Judd Apatow-style immaturity and full-fledged adulthood, it’s an ode to vulnerability and confusion, a celebration of inappropriate choices and the fine art of tiptoeing around your friends’ feelings.

headline: Obama at the Clinton Global Initiative
abstract: President Obama spoke at the annual meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke at the annual meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative.

headline: Romney at the Clinton Global Initiative
abstract: Mitt Romney spoke at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney spoke at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York.

headline: Stuyvesant Students Describe the How and the Why of Cheating
abstract: Former and current students at Stuyvesant High School say lower-level cheating is part of the culture, and students employ several rationales for choosing to be dishonest.
lead_paragraph: The night before one of the “5 to 10” times he has cheated on a test, a senior at Stuyvesant High School said, he copied a table of chemical reactions onto a scrap of paper he would peek at in his chemistry exam. He had decided that memorizing the table was a waste of time — time he could spend completing other assignments or catching up on sleep.

headline: As Libya Presses Some Militias to Disband, Fighters Attack a Hotel in Tripoli
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The attack on a hotel housing newly elected lawmakers came as an American team arrived in Tripoli to investigate the death of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.
lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Libyan militia fighters assaulted a hotel in Tripoli housing members of the newly elected General National Congress on Tuesday, dramatizing the challenge the government faces in enforcing its ultimatum that all unauthorized brigades must submit to its authority or disband by the start of the day.

headline: NBC Unpacks Trove of Data From Olympics
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Olympic Games (2012)', 'Tablet Computers', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Studies of more than 50,000 people who watched the Games depict vast shifts in how people watch television, especially with second devices like tablets or smartphones.
lead_paragraph: ONE afternoon in early August, a 41-year-old working mother in Los Angeles didn’t get much work done.

headline: Sizing Up a Crown That Is Rarely Worn
abstract: The Tigers’ Miguel Cabrera is tantalizingly close to doing what Babe Ruth and Hank Aaron could not: enter baseball’s musty triple crown fraternity, which has admitted no new members in 45 years.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A bronze plaque outside a players’ entrance to Comerica Park honors Ty Cobb as the greatest Tiger of all, a so-called “genius in spikes.” Among Cobb’s achievements was the triple crown, which he won in 1909 by leading the American League with a .377 batting average, 107 runs batted in and 9 — yes, 9 — home runs.

headline: The Internet: Puppet Theater for a New Age
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Identity Fraud', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Sock puppetry, or adopting an imaginary persona to praise your own writings and criticize your enemies, is a time-honored art that thrives online.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, there’s nothing like a friend to stick up for you. Even an imaginary friend.

headline: N.F.L. Chief Caught Between Bad Calls and Owners’ Hard Line
abstract: Roger Goodell, commissioner of the National Football League, is caught between the fiasco of this season’s replacement officials and a lockout being enforced by deep-pocketed team owners.
lead_paragraph: When Roger Goodell became the commissioner of the National Football League in 2006, he made protecting certain aspects of the sport’s good name his consuming aim. He was concerned with the fan experience at stadiums as well as the behavior of players in bars. Goodell wanted a league populated by upstanding citizens who provided captivating entertainment while, not incidentally, generating great business, too.

headline: Boy Scouts Assert ‘Good Faith Effort’ to Protect Youths
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The group issued a report by a professor of psychiatry who reviewed internal files about inappropriate sexual behavior by youth leaders.
lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts of America, facing what could be an avalanche of unfavorable attention in coming weeks from the court-ordered release of internal files about inappropriate sexual behavior by youth leaders, issued a report on Tuesday by a professor who reviewed the files and found what she called “a good faith effort” to protect boys from harm.

headline: Former Programmer Demands That Goldman Cover His Legal Fees
abstract: A former Goldman Sachs programmer who faces new charges of stealing computer code is demanding that the investment bank cover his mounting legal fees.
lead_paragraph: A former Goldman Sachs programmer charged a second time with stealing valuable computer code from the investment bank is fighting back, demanding that his former employer cover his mounting legal fees.

headline: An Electric Carmaker Struggles as Its Production Lags
abstract: To ease a financial crisis, Tesla, the maker of a high-performance electric car, said it had renegotiated the terms of an energy loan from the government.
lead_paragraph: As Tesla Motors, a maker of electric cars, burns through cash and misses production targets, it is turning to investors and taxpayers for extra financial help.

headline: Amateur Hour in Pro Football
abstract: The lockout of referees in the National Football League and some questionable calls made recently by replacements are the talk of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Does Roger Goodell really want his legacy as commissioner of the National Football League to be that he allowed a hugely popular and profitable sport to become a laughingstock? Obviously not. Then why isn’t he orchestrating a rapid settlement in the dispute between team owners and the league’s regular referees over paychecks and pensions?

headline: Backlash to the Backlash
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Muslim moderates have been fighting back. While it’s not clear whether the trend can be sustained, it’s certainly worth watching.
lead_paragraph: One of the iron laws of Middle East politics for the last half-century has been that extremists go all the way and moderates tend to just go away. That is what made the march in Benghazi, Libya, so unusual last Friday. This time, the moderates did not just go away. They got together and stormed the headquarters of the Islamist militia Ansar al-Sharia, whose members are suspected of carrying out the attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi that resulted in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens.

headline: More Children in Homeless Shelters
abstract: The city and state governments need to restore cuts and reinstate programs that helped destitute families get on back their feet.
lead_paragraph: Almost 20,000 children now go to bed every night in New York City’s homeless shelters, up from 16,000 last year. If homelessness is hard on adults, for the young, it can be disastrous, starting a slide into a lifetime of problems. Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Gov. Andrew Cuomo could reduce these numbers by restarting programs that help homeless families move from shelters to permanent rental housing.

headline: In Massachusetts, Brown Attacks Warren’s Character
abstract: With the high-stakes Senate race still very close, Senator Scott P. Brown is seeking to convert almost everything into a character attack on Elizabeth Warren.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Video emerged on Tuesday showing supporters of Senator Scott P. Brown making tomahawk gestures with their arms and yelling Indian war whoops at supporters of Elizabeth Warren, his Democratic challenger, outside a pub on Saturday. The gestures were meant to mock Ms. Warren’s assertions, for which she has offered no documentation, that she has Native American ancestry.

headline: Abuse of Electronic Health Records
abstract: Federal regulators need to make sure that easier billing doesn’t lead to Medicare fraud by billing for services never provided.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has issued a strong and much-needed warning to hospitals and doctors about the fraudulent use of electronic medical records to illegally inflate their billings to Medicare. Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. and the health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, cited “troubling indications” that some providers are billing for services never provided and vowed to prosecute. They sent a letter to five major hospital trade associations on Monday, two days after an article in The Times described in detail how greater use of electronic records might be making it easier for hospitals and doctors to submit erroneous payment claims.

headline: Comparing the Deficit Proposals
abstract: President Obama and Mitt Romney have very different approaches to deficit reduction. Figures below are drawn from similar base lines reflecting realistic fiscal situations, as generally agreed to by research organizations and the Congressional Budget Office.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Mitt Romney have very different approaches to deficit reduction. Figures below are drawn from similar base lines reflecting realistic fiscal situations, as generally agreed to by research organizations and the Congressional Budget Office.

headline: Prosecutor Deals Blow to Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
abstract: The Bronx district attorney’s office has refused to prosecute some people who were arrested for trespassing at public housing projects after discovering that many were innocent.
lead_paragraph: In a significant blow to New York City’s use of stop-and-frisk tactics, the Bronx district attorney’s office is no longer prosecuting people who were stopped at public housing projects and arrested for trespassing, unless the arresting officer is interviewed to ensure that the arrest was warranted.

headline: A G.O.P. Reunion, With Plans for More Togetherness
abstract: The Republican ticket will start campaigning together more often, which suggests that aides fear that Mitt Romney, on his own, is not generating enough attention and excitement.
lead_paragraph: VANDALIA, Ohio — For the first time in almost a month, Mitt Romney reunited on Tuesday with the man who many Republicans thought would charge up the presidential campaign: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the charismatic PowerPoint-wielder who can draw thousands to rallies that are really mostly giant question-and-answer sessions where they can ask “Paul,” in effect, how to save the party, and the country.

headline: President Obama at the U.N.
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Editorials']
abstract: In his address to the General Assembly, Mr. Obama delivered a much-needed firm defense of free speech and condemnation of anti-American violence.
lead_paragraph: The anti-American violence in the Muslim world demanded a firm push back from President Obama, who finally delivered it on Tuesday in the last United Nations General Assembly speech of his term.

headline: Justices Uphold Map for West Virginia Voting
abstract: The Supreme Court said slight variations in a new map of the West Virginia Congressional districts do not violate “one person, one vote” principles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that small population variations among a state’s Congressional districts do not run afoul of the principle of “one person, one vote,” even though advances in computer mapping technology have made it possible to achieve near-perfect equality in representation.

headline: Relic of an Era, Revitalized
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The River North section of Chicago, once a dormant area of warehouses, has evolved into an aspiring rival to Silicon Valley, with Motorola Mobility the latest tech company to sign a lease.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Once a dormant area of empty warehouses, the River North section of Chicago has evolved into a nexus of dining, night life and, most recently, an aspiring rival to Silicon Valley. Its 45 square blocks are home to the headquarters of Groupon, the Chicago offices of Google and several hundred technology start-ups.

headline: Replacements Face New Scrutiny
abstract: The day after a controversial touchdown call decided a game, the National Football League upheld the ruling, drawing new and increased scrutiny to the replacement referees.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The latest, most egregious, least debated replacement referee fiasco prompted dozens of e-mails and thousands of comments in its aftermath. The N.F.L. felt compelled to release a statement in which it included excerpts from its rulebook. Even President Obama weighed in.

headline: New Limits Considered in Airwaves
abstract: In an effort to compete with companies like AT&T and Verizon, smaller telecommunications firms asked the F.C.C. to limit ownership of spectrum that is valuable in urban areas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From East Hampton to Malibu, the only limit on how much beachfront property one can own is usually however much one can afford.

headline: One Coalition Stays True to Todd Akin: Home-Schoolers
abstract: The Republican candidate for Senate in Missouri has been largely abandoned by the party establishment, but home-schoolers have remained loyal.
lead_paragraph: HARRISONVILLE, Mo. — On a recent Wednesday, when many teenagers here were doing homework or playing after-school sports, 17-year-old Ania Bishop, in an ankle-length skirt with American flags, was cheering at a political rally for Representative Todd Akin.

headline: Deportation Deferrals Put Employers of Immigrants in a Bind
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: Asked by program applicants to verify a job, farmers and small businesses are worried about exposing themselves to prosecution for hiring illegal workers.
lead_paragraph: Manuel Cunha has been fighting for three decades to persuade the federal government to provide more legal immigrant workers for farmers in California’s verdant San Joaquin Valley. So he was initially excited when President Obama announced in June that he would suspend the deportations of hundreds of thousands of young illegal immigrants.

headline: Thriving in School
abstract: Representative Michael Honda, a California Democrat, responds to a column by Joe Nocera.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Test for Obama as Deficit Stays Over $1 Trillion
abstract: President Obama and Mitt Romney have very different ideas on reducing the budget deficit, but experts have doubts that either plan is up to the challenge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four years ago, Barack Obama campaigned for president on a promise to cut annual federal budget deficits in half by the end of his term. Then came financial calamity, $1.4 trillion in stimulus measures and a maddeningly slow economic recovery.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for Sept. 25, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Teenager Joins Bullpen in Orioles’ Playoff Push
abstract: Dylan Bundy, a 6-foot-1 right-hander who was the fourth pick of the 2011 draft, made his Camden Yards debut on Tuesday night, pitching a scoreless ninth in a 4-0 loss to the Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Jim Thome, the Orioles’ 42-year-old designated hitter, has slugged 611 home runs. The creases around his eyes date him, like rings around a tree trunk, and he has earned the right, after 22 seasons, to arrive at the ballpark later than most teammates.

headline: To Save a Life: A Call for More Kidney Donors
abstract: Dr. Herbert Pardes of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital discusses the pressing need for kidney donations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Need of Help, and Grateful for It
abstract: Readers say welfare is an important resource for the truly needy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Father’s Bribery Case Hangs Over Daughter’s House Bid
abstract: Assemblywoman Grace Meng is favored to win a Congressional seat in a heavily Democratic Queens district, but the corruption case against her father has cast a shadow over her campaign.
lead_paragraph: Grace Meng, a New York assemblywoman campaigning for a seat in Congress, stood in front of the steps of City Hall last month to accept the endorsement of former Mayor Edward I. Koch. She was flanked by nine supporters, each holding aloft a red, white and blue sign that read “Grace.”

headline: Is Alzheimer’s Type 3 Diabetes?
abstract: Evidence suggests that Alzheimer’s might be another form of diabetes, and links both to the overconsumption of junk food.
lead_paragraph: Just in case you need another reason to cut back on junk food, it now turns out that Alzheimer’s could well be a form of diet-induced diabetes. That’s the bad news. The good news is that laying off soda, doughnuts, processed meats and fries could allow you to keep your mind intact until your body fails you.

headline: Why Not Debtors’ Prison?
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: In a dog-eat-dog world, President Obama is the cat, and Mitt Romney is chasing his own tail.
lead_paragraph: So it has come to this:

headline: California: Brown Signs Bills to Keep Parks Open
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown signed several bills on Tuesday that will keep California parks open for the next two years and will provide greater oversight of the embattled state park system.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown signed several bills on Tuesday that will keep California parks open for the next two years and will provide greater oversight of the embattled state park system. Officials discovered this year that parks employees had hidden $54 million, even as 70 parks faced closings because of budget cuts. The bills signed on Tuesday would institute a two-year moratorium on park closings and provide $30 million to finance maintenance and parks at risk of closure, in addition to $10 million to match private donations made this year to keep parks open.

headline: Do Drone Attacks Do More Harm Than Good?
abstract: Strikes have fueled anti-American sentiment, but also have taken out some terrorist targets. Are they making the U.S. safer or just more hated?

headline: Corrections: September 26, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 26, 2012.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Nets Have Big Goals to Conquer Heat
abstract: As they embark on their Brooklyn adventure, the Nets have their sights set on overtaking the Miami Heat, the defending National Basketball Association champions.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Brooklyn’s Industrial Space Retools for a New Era
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Developers and the city are marketing Sunset Park to nimble companies seeking high-tech amenities instead of gargantuan machinery floors.
lead_paragraph: The hulking industrial buildings that line Sunset Park’s waterfront once bustled with manufacturing and military activity. Elvis Presley deployed to Germany from the Brooklyn Army Terminal in 1958, one of three million troops to pass through the Cass Gilbert-designed building. The area was once so busy that it had its own rail line and police and fire departments.

headline: The Brooklyn Army Terminal Enters a New Era
abstract: Occupancy rates are up at the 1919 edifice, which was once the largest military supply base in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Occupancy rates are up at the 1919 edifice, which was once the largest military supply base in the United States.

headline: House Panel Recommends New Rules on Ethics
keywords: ['Ethics (Institutional)', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After concluding its investigation of Representative Maxine Waters, the panel advocated a tightening of rules to prevent conflicts of interest and to keep partisan politics out of future inquiries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saying that public trust was at stake, a special House ethics panel on Tuesday called for new rules to prevent lawmakers and their staffs from violating conflict of interest standards, and proposed other measures to keep partisan squabbles from undermining future investigations of possible wrongdoing.

headline: American Airlines Faults Its Pilots for Disruptions
abstract: American Airlines is delaying and canceling flights as its pilots call in sick and seek last-minute inspections in a labor dispute with management.
lead_paragraph: Airlines typically try to keep flying through bankruptcy. But simmering labor tensions at American Airlines have boiled over from the negotiating room to the airports in recent weeks, disrupting operations and leaving a trail of delayed and canceled flights that the airline says is the fault of its pilots.

headline: In Afghanistan, American Trainers Keep Their Armor On
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In the field, where small teams of American advisers are now working with Afghan units, even minor misunderstandings are treated as potentially violent confrontations.
lead_paragraph: In the field, where small teams of American advisers are now working with Afghan units, even minor misunderstandings are treated as potentially violent confrontations.

headline: Training Afghan Allies, With Guard Firmly Up
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: After recent attacks by Afghan forces against Western soldiers and Marines, American military advisers are extremely wary, laying bare the challenge of preparing the Afghans to fight on their own.
lead_paragraph: BAD PAKH, Afghanistan — When American military advisers fly into Afghan Army outposts like the one nestled on the floor of this forested valley, they keep their body armor on and their weapons loaded.

headline: Here We Go Again
abstract: Get your puzzle kicks with Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This will be a short one, because I will spend tomorrow fasting and atoning for all of my puzzle transgressions and I am cranky about it. It will also be short because while Peter A. Collins is eagerly anticipating the start of FOOTBALL season, I am not a follower of football, so the theme of this puzzle was largely lost on me. Perhaps the football fans out there will pick up the discussion.

headline: Tougher Penalties Sought in Russia for Drunken Driving After Accident
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A public outcry erupted after a weekend accident in Moscow in which a car crashed into a bus stop at 125 miles per hour, killing seven people.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian legislators called on Tuesday for stronger measures against drunken driving after a gruesome weekend accident in which a car crashed into a bus stop at 125 miles per hour, killing seven people, five of them teenagers with learning disabilities.

headline: Despite Second-Half Slump, Wright Equals a Milestone
abstract: Third Baseman David Wright has been enduring a second-half slump, but in Tuesday’s loss to the Pirates, Wright tied Ed Kranepool atop the Mets career hits list with 1,418.
lead_paragraph: David Wright tied Ed Kranepool atop the Mets career hits list Tuesday night when he sent a single to right field during his team’s 10-6 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates at Citi Field. Kranepool, one of the original Mets, collected 1,418 hits over his 1,853-game career. Wright matched him after 1,255 games.

headline: Fight for Second Wild Card in the National League
abstract: Atlanta seems assured of earning the wild-card spot in the National League, leaving St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot.
lead_paragraph: As the baseball season moves into its final stretch, the story lines are becoming clearer. Three National League teams — San Francisco, Cincinnati and Washington — have clinched spots in the postseason, and Atlanta joined them as a wild-card team with a win Tuesday. That left St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot.

headline: Seeking Cures, Patients Enlist Mice Stand-Ins
abstract: In what could be the ultimate in personalized medicine, animal models, referred to by researchers as avatars, are being used to help determine the best treatment for a patient.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Megan Sykes, a medical researcher, has a mouse with a human immune system — her own. She calls it “Mini-Me.”

headline: Obama Without Romney
abstract: What if the choice on Nov. 6 was just to vote up or down on the president’s performance?
lead_paragraph: Imagine, for a moment, that the 2012 election really was the pure referendum that Mitt Romney’s campaign strategists apparently expected it to be. Imagine that both the Republican challenger and his party were completely invisible on the campaign trail, that the press was allowed only to cover the incumbent, and that on Nov. 6 the choice was whether to vote “up” or “down” on President Obama’s performance. How would the last three weeks have played out for the president?

headline: Suburban Mother Pleads Guilty to Running a Brothel on the Upper East Side
abstract: Anna Gristina, 45, who came to be called the Soccer Mom Madam, accepted a plea offer that will allow her to be released without additional jail time.
lead_paragraph: A suburban New York mother who became a tabloid and television sensation after she was charged in February with running an Upper East Side brothel pleaded guilty on Tuesday to one count of promoting prostitution.

headline: RIM Keeps on Loving You in a Video
abstract: Research in Motion lures developers of apps for the BlackBerry 10 with a cringe-worthy rendition of “Keep on Loving You.”
lead_paragraph: In order to persuade consumers to buy its new BlackBerry 10 phones next year, Research In Motion must first convince developers to create apps for its new operating system.

headline: Goodbye, Mr. Goodell
abstract: Bad referees, poor conduct, labor disputes, angry fans: the National Football League is in crisis. To save the game, its commissioner must resign.
lead_paragraph: Richmond, Va.

headline: Google Working on Maps for iPhone and iPad
abstract: Google is developing a maps application for iPhone and iPad that it’s seeking to finish by the end of the year, according to people involved with the effort who declined to be named.
lead_paragraph: People pining for a Google Maps app on their Apple devices will get one eventually, but likely not for another couple months or so.

headline: ‘NCIS’ Watch: How to Resolve a Cliffhanger
abstract: The “NCIS” season premiere shows why the series remains popular even if it refuses to shake things up too much.
lead_paragraph: The perennially popular CBS drama “NCIS” ended last season with the ultimate cliffhanger. Practically every major character was set up to be killed off as NCIS headquarters was bombed and the venerable Ducky (David McCallum) suffered a heart attack.

headline: How Exercise Can Help You Master New Skills
abstract: Physical exercise may help the brain to consolidate and store muscle memories, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Can you improve your body’s ability to remember by making it move? That rather odd-seeming question stimulated researchers at the University of Copenhagen to undertake a reverberant new examination of just how the body creates specific muscle memories and what role, if any, exercise plays in the process.

headline: Using Tech Tools at West Virginia
abstract: The Prozone performance analysis system is changing the way professional and college coaches prepare their players for matches.
lead_paragraph: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — Marlon LeBlanc, the head coach of the West Virginia University men’s soccer team, looked up at eight framed, autographed jerseys lining his office walls. Among them are a No. 28 shirt from the Philadelphia Union right back Raymon Gaddis and a D.C. United jersey of the former defender Devon McTavish. The collection comes from W.V.U. alumni who graduated to become professional players.

headline: Word of the Day | traumatic
abstract: This word has appeared in 471 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: traumatic •\trə-ˈma-tik, trȯ-\• adjective

headline: Yankees Lose Lead and Chance to Expand Edge
abstract: The Yankees squandered a chance Tuesday to extend their lead in the American League East after being unable to hold on to an early lead over the Twins, who had a four-run seventh inning.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — With the Yankees embroiled in what at times has felt like a 22-game playoff series against the Baltimore Orioles, Joe Girardi has asked the left-handed reliever Boone Logan to pitch in 14 of those games. That has pushed Logan’s total appearances this season to 77, a career high, and it also qualifies as the most times Girardi has called on a pitcher in his six seasons as a manager.

headline: Alderson Speaks on Davis Rumors and Future of Wright and Dickey
abstract: The Mets general manager, interviewed on SNY during the Mets’ game Tuesday night, touched on trade speculation of the team’s top players.
lead_paragraph: General Manager Sandy Alderson was interviewed by Gary Cohen and Ron Darling of SNY during the top of the fifth inning of the Mets’ game Tuesday night.

headline: Barnes & Noble Tablets Aim for Niche Below iPad
keywords: ['Barnes & Noble Nook', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Tablet Computers', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: In a moves meant to expand its digital offerings, the company on Tuesday introduced two new color tablets and said a video store for its Nook products would make its debut this fall.
lead_paragraph: In a series of moves meant to expand Barnes & Noble’s digital offerings, the company on Tuesday introduced two new color tablets and said a video store for its Nook products would make its debut this fall.

headline: A Tough Loss for Hughes
abstract: Phil Hughes had everything going for him going into the seventh inning. But he was pulled from the game with the bases loaded, and things went downhill for the Yankees from there.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — It is tough to be diplomatic when you struck out your last batter, you still felt strong when you left the mound, and the game unraveled in front of your eyes.

headline: Kashmiris, Disabled by Conflict, Battle for Compensation
abstract: Near the Line of Control, hundreds handicapped by militancy struggle to survive.
lead_paragraph: KASHMIR — Shaida Banu attends stitching lessons in Silikot village near the Line of Control on the Indian side of Kashmir. A tailor teaches embroidery and patchwork in a large schoolroom with sewing machines and a chalkboard. Not far is a cordoned-off plot of mines laid out to prevent militants entering from the Pakistan side.

headline: News Quiz | September 26, 2012
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Even Panda Diplomacy Isn’t Working
abstract: Panda diplomacy, usually so reliable a tactic in times of crisis, has been one of the casualties in the uproar over some disputed islands in East Asia: A Japanese zoo is balking at taking a pair of giant pandas offered by China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The overhead pictures of Taiwanese and Japanese ships circling each other and shooting off their water cannons have made the seagoing confrontations appear almost playful. Chinese ships have had similar standoffs with the Japanese Coast Guard.

headline: Reformers Do Win Elections in India
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Elections', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: New data dispels a long-standing myth about pro-growth politics.
lead_paragraph: Mamata Banerjee and other chief ministers who are opposing the new economic policies of the Manmohan Singh government probably have not read Chapter 3 of the latest book edited by two renowned Indian economists Jagdish Bhagwati and Arvind Panagariya.

headline: Belgian Has Come a Long Way to Hit It a Long Way
abstract: Nicolas Colsaerts’s road to the Ryder Cup was not a straight shot. He qualified for the European Tour at 18, then dropped to 1,305th in the world before becoming the first Belgian to qualify for this week’s tournament.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — Of the 12 players on the European team this week, only one is a Ryder Cup rookie, Nicolas Colsaerts of Belgium. But that does not mean he is bereft of Ryder Cup experience.

headline: Syrian Insurgents Mount Fierce Attack on Military Compound in Damascus
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Large explosions at a military site in the Syrian capital on Wednesday were followed by a gunfight that left an Iranian television correspondent dead, his station reported.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Suicide bombers struck a military headquarters in a busy square in central Damascus on Wednesday morning, the second insurgent assault on a government military installation in two days and the largest attack in the capital since July, when explosions killed several key aides to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: Results are based on 1,196 likely voters in Florida, 1,162 likely voters in Ohio and 1,180 likely voters in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: The latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS News polls included a total of 4,153 telephone interviews conducted from Sept. 18 through Sept. 24 with adult residents of Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania. Of these, 3,771 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Polls Show Obama Is Widening His Lead in Ohio and Florida
abstract: Mitt Romney’s burden is no longer just to win undecided voters, but also to woo back those who seem to be growing a little comfortable with the idea of a second term for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — For weeks, Republicans in Ohio have been watching with worry that the state’s vital 18 electoral votes were trending away from Mitt Romney. The anxiety has been similar in Florida, where Republicans are concerned that President Obama is gaining the upper hand in the fight for the state’s 29 electoral votes.

headline: The Latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS Poll
abstract: The full results of the latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS Poll surveyed voters in Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: The full results of the latest Quinnipiac University/New York Times/CBS Poll surveyed voters in Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Wednesday, Sept. 26
abstract: News, fashion, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: NEWS The pressures facing the Spanish government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy mounted on several fronts on Tuesday as thousands of demonstrators besieged Parliament. Raphael Minder reports from Madrid.

headline: Markets Falter in Europe Amid Protests on Austerity
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Demonstrators took to the streets Wednesday in Greece to protest new cuts being discussed, and protesters in Spain surrounded Parliament for a second day over the prime minister’s austerity program.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — After a period of relative calm, European markets shuddered once again on Wednesday as protests erupted across Greece and demonstrators surrounded the Spanish Parliament for a second day to protest the austerity program of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Sept. 26, 2012
abstract: Can you find the actual number of voters who chose neither presidential candidate in a poll, if given the total number of people polled and the percentages of those who said they’d vote for President Obama or Mitt Romney?
lead_paragraph: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthew at Math for America from the infographic “Likely Voters Weigh In on the 2012 Presidential Election.”

headline: Former Murdoch Aides Appear in Court
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Two of the most senior former executives at newspapers owned by Rupert Murdoch, both close at one time to Prime Minister David Cameron, were set to appear in court on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two of the most senior former executives at newspapers owned by Rupert Murdoch, both once close to Prime Minister David Cameron, appeared at the Old Bailey courthouse in central London on Wednesday facing charges relating to the phone hacking scandal convulsing parts of the British press.

headline: Football Follies: Mixed Up Signals Make for Absurd Game
abstract: How do you think the N.F.L. should handle the situation of replacement referees?
lead_paragraph: According to the article, WHAT happened during the play that “best defines this N.F.L. season”?

headline: Euro Update: The Perils of Pointless Pain
