abstract: Are we reaching the point where the afflicted nations can bear no more?
lead_paragraph: So, I’m in jet lag city, which means that it’s time for a euro update. (I’ve been pretty focused on the US election, since it is, after all, my country; but still keeping an eye on the other side of the pond).

headline: An Election and Exiles
abstract: The Kennedy-Nixon debates began in 1960, and the Mariel boatlift ended in 1980.
lead_paragraph: On this day in 1980 the Mariel boatlift came to an end. For me as a reporter, it is one of those events where life intersected with history. And it is the anniversary of the first Kennedy-Nixon debate, which began the ascent of television’s role in politics.

headline: If the Shoe Fits, Don’t Wear It Unless It’s Comfortable
abstract: From the law firm to the library, it’s important for women to remember that it’s not necessarily the size of the heel, but the coziness in the sole.
lead_paragraph: All women love shoes. Except me. I’m a middle-aged, middle-class woman who doesn’t give a rip about footwear. I might be the only one.

headline: Losing Fear and Learning to See
abstract: On a demanding assignment off Peru’s coast, in search of a coveted guano, the reporter Simon Romero couldn’t stomach more than an afternoon. The Chilean photographer Tomás Munita, undaunted, stayed weeks.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — The motor boat cut through choppy waters before reaching Isla de Asia, off Peru’s coast. We arrived half-drenched and shivering to a stunning scene: Quechua-speaking laborers with pickaxes trying to collect hardened guano, the bird dung so coveted in the 19th century as a fertilizer that nations waged wars over the islands where it is found.

headline: What Are Your Sleep Habits?
abstract: Tell us how well you sleep, when you sleep, how your waking life affects your sleeping life, and your reaction to the ideas in this article.
lead_paragraph: A piece from the Sunday Review about “rethinking sleep” has been on the most e-mailed list all week. It states that getting eight consecutive hours of sleep every night may not be as essential as we think. Instead, the author proposes, taking short naps throughout the day may actually be more beneficial and improve cognitive function.

headline: Death By PowerPoint, Continued
abstract: More Ryan awesomeness.
lead_paragraph: Update: OK, the word is that this was really clumsy satire.

headline: Part 3: Answers From Princeton’s Dean of Admission
abstract: Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, lends her expertise about college admissions by answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice. Part 3.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Ms. Rapelye is no longer taking questions.

headline: Mutual Respect, Not Bad Blood, Links Ryder Cup Captains
abstract: Despite the friendly touch between José María Olazábal and Davis Love III, the pressure is on at the Ryder Cup.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — The Ryder Cup, golf’s biggest magnifying glass, has long exposed the cracks between its participants, the captains in particular. They, more than their players, are the real faces of this event, holing none of the putts but bearing the brunt of the attention and promotional burden in the two-year buildup to each Cup.

headline: Week 3 Film Review: Rams’ Offense Overmatched
abstract: Against the Bears, Sam Bradford played a bit anxiously at times and also had a tendency to ignore half the field in locking onto his initial reads.
lead_paragraph: Andy Benoit puts some Week 3 games under a microscope, with the benefit of film analysis.

headline: Labor-Market Scars Left by Redistributive Public Policy
abstract: Redistributive public policy not only depressed the labor market but changed the composition of the work force so that it includes more people who are married and more skilled, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Rian Johnson Builds a Better Time Machine
abstract: What the director of ‘Looper’ learned from ‘Macbeth.’
lead_paragraph: “Looper” is a film about fate, regret, decisions, revenge and the old maxim that the child is the father of the man, but mostly it’s about time travel, so let’s travel back in time: to 10 years ago, before the director Rian Johnson’s celebrated 2005 debut film, “Brick” (or his follow-up, “The Brothers Bloom”), to the moment he first had the idea for “Looper.” Back then, it was conceived as a short film, about 10 minutes long, which he never actually shot. But the script would eventually provide the opening voice-over for “Looper”: “Time travel has not yet been invented. But 30 years from now, it will have been.”

headline: The Creators of ‘Homeland’ Exorcise the Ghost of ‘24’
abstract: Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa discuss the influence of Chicken Little.
lead_paragraph: “Homeland,” the geopolitically astute spy thriller on Showtime, features three bedeviled protagonists: Carrie Mathison (Claire Danes), a brilliant and bipolar C.I.A. agent; Saul Berenson (Mandy Patinkin), her mentor; and Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis), a former prisoner of war who tried (and failed) to assassinate the vice president. Much of what made “Homeland” successful in its first season was the artful way in which the show plucked from real-time history, a trick that the show’s creators, Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa, honed while working together on “24.” We talked to them about the challenges of writing a show that so closely mirrors the real-world shadow wars.

headline: Andre Braugher Has a Homework Assignment for You
abstract: The ‘Last Resort’ star shares his sea-captain reading list.
lead_paragraph: How exactly do you prepare to play the defiant captain of a nuclear submarine who goes rogue? If you’re Andre Braugher, you read. “I got a stack of books and tried to figure out who sea captains are, what life on the sea is like and what goes into the making of a captain who can endure this kind of exile,” he says of preparing for “Last Resort,” an ABC series about a sub captain who commandeers a tropical island. “It’s an apprenticeship by proxy.” Should you ever find yourself in a similar position, here is Braugher’s recommended reading list:

headline: What ‘Back to the Future’ and ‘Terminator’ Owe to ‘La Jetée’
abstract: The French art film that’s spawned more blockbusters than any comic book.
lead_paragraph: Chris Marker, who died earlier this year at 91, was an enigmatic figure, reluctant to be photographed and prone to biographical embellishment. A creature of the European postwar avant-garde, Marker would seem an unlikely influence on modern Hollywood. But his 28-minute “photo-novel,” “La Jetée” — a shuffle of mostly still black-and-white images now marking its 50th birthday — has spawned more would-be blockbusters than any comic book or series of fantasy novels.

headline: For Veterans, a Surge of New Treatments for Trauma
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Veterans']
abstract: The military has responded to the mental health crisis among veterans with more treatment, including alternative therapies and mindfulness training.
lead_paragraph: Suicide is now the leading cause of death in the army. More soldiers die by suicide than in combat or vehicle accidents, and rates are rising: July, with 38 suicides among active duty and reserve soldiers, was the worst month since the Army began counting. General Lloyd Austin III, the army’s second in command, called suicide “the worst enemy I have faced in my 37 years in the army.” This Thursday, the Army is calling a “Suicide Stand-Down.” All units will devote the day to suicide prevention.

headline: What Do You Do With the Brilliant Jerk?
abstract: Based on sheer loyalty, most entrepreneurs are inclined to try to find a way to make things work. That’s almost always a mistake.
lead_paragraph: My most recent experience with a Brilliant Jerk occurred when I was helping a group of 25 doctors thrash out their shared values as they tried to become a real company.

headline: Daily Report: Relic of an Era, Revitalized for Tech Start-Ups
abstract: Chicago’s River North’s transformation is extending to one of the neighborhood’s most storied — and decidedly low-tech — commercial addresses. The Merchandise Mart, a Depression-era behemoth of limestone, concrete and steel that has long been synonymous with fabric bolts and furniture, is becoming a destination for the city’s digital set.
lead_paragraph: Once a dormant area of empty warehouses, the River North section of Chicago has evolved into a nexus of dining, nightlife and, most recently, an aspiring rival to Silicon Valley. Its 45 square blocks are home to the headquarters of Groupon, the Chicago offices of Google and several hundred technology start-ups.

headline: N.F.L. Has Bigger Problems Than Officials
abstract: The replacement officials have been abysmal, but the loss of part of Matt Schaub’s ear is an example of the N.F.L.’s biggest long-range problem.
lead_paragraph: Is football the next boxing? Michael Silver of Yahoo Sports makes that connection in recommended reading today:

headline: Stone Links: Thinking Dutch
abstract: In this week’s links: The Dutch passion for philosophy; the difference between good and bad novels of ideas; and Bourdieu’s map of “food-space,” updated.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch, it seems, like their philosophy. In an essay for Filosofie Magazine, Frank Mulder discusses the public role of philosophy in the Netherlands.

headline: Imagining a Warmer Arctic
abstract: On a large scale, the biggest impact of the shift may be the changes in the Arctic’s ability to function as a cooling system for the globe’s oceans.
lead_paragraph: From more snowfall (which can act as an insulating blanket, keeping ice warm) to more storms and stronger winds and waves, a look at the implications of a potentially ice-free Arctic. [Scientific American]

headline: Fallen South African Politician Charged With Laundering
abstract: Julius Malema, the former leader of the African National Congress youth wing, is charged in connection with state contracts with an engineering company linked to him.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Julius Malema, the firebrand former leader of the African National Congress youth wing, appeared in a court in his home province of Limpopo on Wednesday to face a charge of money laundering in connection with state contracts with an engineering company linked to him.

headline: Iran Will Boycott Oscars to Protest Anti-Muslim Video
abstract: Iran’s announcement, coming after it won an Oscar for best foreign-language film earlier this year, left some in Hollywood scratching their heads.
lead_paragraph: The boycott appears straightforward: Mohammad Hosseini, Iran’s culture minister, on Tuesday confirmed that his country would not submit a film for consideration at next year’s Oscars in protest of “Innocence of Muslims,” the anti-Islam YouTube video that has sparked deadly riots. He specifically cited the “failure” of Oscar organizers to take an official position on the incendiary “film.”

headline: Breaking Down LaRon Landry’s Pick-Six for Jets
abstract: A closer look at a play that might have saved the game against Miami, and that might have saved the Jets’ season.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Bales will pick a big play from each week and break it down. In Week 2, he analyzed Victor Cruz’s 80-yard catch-and-run for a score against Tampa Bay:

headline: Off the Runway | More on Where to Go Between the Shows in Paris
abstract: For modernists and classicists alike, a guide to new cultural happenings, restaurants and watering holes in the city of lights.
lead_paragraph: Fashion folk who simply never O.D. on their métier will want to high-heel it to the Cité de la Mode et du Design (34 Quai d’Austerlitz, 75013) to catch the last days of “Cristobal Balenciaga, Fashion Collector,” which features looks by the master alongside historical garments he collected. Next door, Rei Kawakubo designed the unusual scenography for “Comme des Garçons, White Drama,” which showcases her all-white S/S ’12 collection ensconced in large-scale bubble formations. Through Oct. 7.

headline: Former Prime Minister in Japan Elected to Lead Opposition Party
abstract: Shinzo Abe, a nationalist former prime minister, won the race to lead Japan’s Liberal Democractic Party, giving him a chance of regaining the nation’s top job.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Shinzo Abe, a nationalist former prime minister, was elected to lead Japan’s main opposition party on Wednesday, giving him a chance of regaining the nation’s top job — a prospect that could worsen the country’s tense relations with China and its other Asian neighbors.

headline: In Spain, It’s Not Just the Economy
abstract: Spain’s financial crisis has spurred discontent in Catalonia and other autonomous regions, prompting concerns for the unity of the Spanish state. Some analysts suggest the democratic settlement that replaced the Franco dictatorship may have to be revised.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is becoming increasingly evident to Spain’s nervous European neighbors that the mounting crisis enveloping the government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy goes much deeper than the economy.

headline: The King of Good Times Dismantles His Empire
abstract: Vijay Mallya’s carefully-built businesses are on the block.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Suddenly, everything in the sprawling empire of Vijay Mallya seems to be up for sale.

headline: Cambodia’s Landless Class
abstract: As more and more poor Cambodians have their land taken away, many fear the end of the traditional village life that once guaranteed food and a family home for all.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH — In a union office for garment workers on the outskirts of the capital on a recent afternoon, Tith Srey Mom and her sister Mach were pondering what to do next. After losing a 10-year legal battle to keep their 200-square-meter plot of land, they were being evicted. All legal avenues had been exhausted. All they could do was wait for the police to come and forcibly remove them.

headline: Using a Social Media Rating to Help People, Not Judge Them
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: As people are evaluated more by their social media ratings, companies have a responsibility to use the information to help customers, not simply judge them.
lead_paragraph: Today, we are expected to maintain a good credit rating. A few years from now, we might be judged by how much we post on Twitter or update Facebook.

headline: A Groundhog Breaks the Rules
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: The animal in the tree certainly looks like a groundhog, but it isn’t acting like one.

headline: Sept. 25: Romney’s Narrow Path Without Ohio
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: With President Obama leading in polls of Ohio, Mitt Romney would need to make gains in other Midwestern states, like Iowa and Wisconsin, that are traditionally easier wins for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: With President Obama consistently holding a lead in polls of Ohio, Mitt Romney may need to devise a strategy to win the Electoral College without it.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: The Nook as ‘iPad Lite,’ and Lessons From the Olympics
abstract: Also, a trial date is set for Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson and a royal slip-up by the BBC.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 217 million people watched Olympic coverage on NBC networks during the London games and eight million people downloaded NBC’s mobile apps for the Olympics, according to new figures released by the network, part of a vast trove of consumer research based on viewing during the games. Watching video on tablet computers – no surprise – also surged and the most popular events on any device were women’s gymnastics and the women’s soccer final. The good news for the network: the popularity of the live feed during the day didn’t seem to cannibalize viewers from NBC’s primetime package.

headline: Romney Makes Direct Claim of Compassion as ‘47 Percent’ Drives Ads
abstract: Mitt Romney talks directly to the camera for nearly a minute to say that while both sides care about working families, only his plan will help. It directly contradicts an earlier Obama spot.
lead_paragraph: 11:10 a.m. | Updated Mitt Romney’s “47 percent” remarks are continuing to drive ad messages on both sides in the presidential race.

lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Your Chance to Appear on ‘Sesame Street’
abstract: Two new titles for the Xbox 360 Kinect video game system allow users to enter a scene from Sesame Street or Nat Geo TV.
lead_paragraph: Watching TV is old news. Now it can watch you back, provided you have one of two new titles in stores: Kinect Sesame Street TV or Kinect Nat Geo TV ($30 each, from Microsoft Studios).

abstract: The Republican National Committee said on Tuesday that it is financing a multimillion-dollar ground game on behalf of Mitt Romney and Representative Paul D. Ryan in an effort to match the expansive infrastructure of the Obama campaign.
lead_paragraph: Every night, state-based field operatives hired by the Republican National Committee are collecting daily absentee ballot reports from elections officials in Colorado, Florida and North Carolina.

headline: A Guy Thing
abstract: A new male-centric housewares collection offers limited-edition pieces within a reasonable price range.
lead_paragraph: Jonah Takagi’s mixed-media coffee tables and pendant lights can be found at edgy design stores like Matter and the Future Perfect. But the 33-year-old designer’s house is full of Ikea basics and estate-sale finds, not unlike most of his fashionable 30-something guy friends. So it’s with them — and himself — in mind that he started Field (field-online.com), a new male-centric housewares collection designed by, well, himself and his friends, which include Hallgeir Homstvedt, Jonathan Nesci and Oscar Diaz. “I saw an opportunity to make new vintage pieces, ones that will age well and hold their own alongside a cast-iron desk or shop lights,” says Takagi.

headline: Deaths Rise for Drivers, Bikers and Walkers on City Streets
abstract: After years of consistent decline, traffic fatalities from July 2011 through June 2012 increased to a total of 291, a rise of 23 percent from the previous year.
lead_paragraph: For years, the New York City Transportation Department has held a trump card in the roiling debate over its many roadway interventions: When officials said the measures, like pedestrian plazas and bike lanes, had made streets safer, the numbers appeared to back them up.

headline: New Polls Show Ohio and Florida Senators Maintaining Lead Over Challengers
abstract: In the battle for control of the United States Senate, the Democratic Party has little room for error and is particularly intent on protecting senators who are standing for re-election in presidential battleground states.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — In the battle for control of the United States Senate, the Democratic Party has little room for error and is particularly intent on protecting senators who are standing for re-election in presidential battleground states.

headline: A Year Later, the Braves Celebrate
abstract: The Braves recovered from their epic collapse in 2011, and the lockout of N.F.L. referees has Commissioner Roger Goodell in everyone’s cross hairs.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while the sports calendar reminds us that so much can change as we make only one trip around the sun. On Tuesday night it was the Atlanta Braves marking time and metaphorical distance, putting a mere 12 months between their mesmerizing twin swan dive (with the Red Sox) out of last year’s baseball playoffs and clinching a spot in this year’s. It is instructive to think back over that 12-month stretch, remembering when baseball had a wild-card format that allowed for such thrilling finishes. (Sigh.) And in the N.F.L., remember when fans were giddy to have their favorite game saved from the teeth of a greedy league lockout? The N.B.A.'s was just getting rolling back then and N.H.L. owners were still dreamily planning for their chance to mess up their sport.

headline: Luxury Cosmetics Maker Weighs the Benefits of Selling Items on TV
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Luxury Goods', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Small Business', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']

lead_paragraph: EvePearl is a Manhattan makeup studio, boutique and e-commerce business with 10 employees that sells cosmetics containing skin-care nutrients. The products are developed by the company’s namesake and founder, a 46-year-old Emmy-winning TV makeup artist. She created her first foundation and concealer products seven years ago while working for Barbara Walters, Meredith Vieira, and the rest of the hosts on “The View.”

headline: Does Louisville Need More Highways?
abstract: A planned expansion of highways and bridges in and around Louisville, Ky., raises a decades-old urban question: What revitalizes a city?
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — More and more Americans, educated 20-somethings and empty nesters among them, want to live downtown. Plenty of downtowns are coming back; many are thriving. Even so, we remain a nation in thrall to suburbs, highways, cars. On a recent visit here I was struck by this paradox.

headline: More Than an Island
abstract: Jason Chin gracefully combines science and illustrative art in this story of the Galápagos, beginning with an island’s “birth” six million years ago.
lead_paragraph: Writing scientific narrative nonfiction for young children is challenge enough, but creating engaging picture books for older children about the natural world isn’t easy either. How to pull in the “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” reader? Credit to Jason Chin, who succeeded at both in “Coral Reefs” (2011) and “Redwoods” (2009). He does so again in his latest, “Island: A Story of the Galápagos.”

headline: The Domino Effect in Nature, and Visual Storytelling
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Environment']
abstract: A renegade science communicator spreads his gospel to Vancouver, with a clever environmental video one result.
lead_paragraph: My friend Randy Olson, the filmmaker and science-communication evangelizer devoted to prodding folks out of the “nerd loop,” has been at it again — this time running one of his three-day video-making boot camps for graduate students in the TerreWEB program (on communication of global-change science) at the University of British Columbia. One student, Megan Callahan, came up with a particularly effective video on the interconnections in ecosystems. Randy sees this film, describing the domino-like relationship of species in an ecosystem, as the best single video to emerge in his years-long coaching effort. I’d like to get your view, and I’m sure he would, too. Here’s his “Your Dot” post, along with a link to more on his blog, The Benshi:

headline: When Parents Can’t Enroll in Medicaid, Children Stay Uninsured
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Parenting', 'Poverty', "State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)"]
abstract: When states fail to expand Medicaid for parents, there’s an unintended impact on children.
lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau just released new data on poverty, income and health insurance for last year, and the numbers aren’t pretty. Overall poverty remained at the highs we’ve seen for the past three years, with the picture still particularly bleak for children: 15 percent of Americans and 1 in 5 children live in poverty. Lack of insurance is closely tied to that number. Nearly 14 percent of children living in poverty lacked health insurance last year, compared with under 10 percent for children overall, a number that stayed flat despite the decrease in the rate for everyone under 65.

headline: 3 Myths About Booking Travel From the Source
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Reservations (Airlines, Hotels, Etc.)', 'HOTELS AND MOTELS']
abstract: From cost to choice to flexibility, debunking three outdated notions about booking direct.
lead_paragraph: FRONTIER AIRLINES caused a stir recently when it announced that travelers who do not book directly with the airline will pay higher fees, receive half as many frequent flier miles and will not be allowed to select a seat in advance of check-in. Whether cutting out the middleman is consumer-friendly is a matter of debate. But the news got me thinking: should travelers assume that the best deals always come from online — even offline — travel agencies?

Ms. Boianjiu, 25, spent two years in the military and later studied at Harvard. In a recent e-mail interview, she discussed the ways she’s reflected in her characters, her sense of humor, whether she feels obligated to speak out about politics and more. General Electric announced a line of new models on Wednesday, with two interesting environmental twists.

headline: Broadway Baby? No Way! She’s 11 Already!

lead_paragraph: The theater director James Lapine personally auditioned 150 little girls to be the star of the new Broadway revival of “Annie,” and finally chose his orphan after a half-dozen callbacks with the young actress Lilla Crawford.

headline: Trainers in Afghanistan Arm Themselves Against Both Sides
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Military trainers in Afghanistan are still doing the work of transferring control to the Afghan forces, but they are now doing it with increasing distance and ever-present body armor.
lead_paragraph: In The Times today, Matthew Rosenberg (@mrosenbergNYT) reports from Bad Pakh, Afghanistan, on the new protective strategy used by military advisers to the Afghan Army: keep body armor on and weapons loaded, all the time. He writes of the advisers in a base in Bad Pakh: “Their guard was up even though they were there for a day of training Afghan soldiers without once leaving the confines of a fortified base — even when chatting with the Afghan officers over a lunch of goat meat and yogurt.”

headline: McCaskill Hits Akin for ‘Legitimate Rape’ Comments in New Ad
abstract: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri criticizes her opponent, Representative Todd Akin over comments he made in August, and Mr. Akin gets some support from Republicans for his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: When Republicans started calling for Todd Akin to bow out of the United States Senate race in Missouri last month, Senator Claire McCaskill, his Democratic opponent, tried to avoid talking about his “legitimate rape” controversy on the campaign trail. But now that the final deadline for Mr. Akin to withdraw has passed, with Mr. Akin locked in as the Republican nominee, she is swinging as expected.

headline: N.F.L. Reaches Labor Deal With Referees
abstract: With a new eight-year deal in place, regular officials will work Thursday’s Ravens-Browns game, and the officials’ union will vote Friday to ratify the contract and work Sunday’s games.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League reached agreement on an eight-year labor deal with its game officials late Wednesday night, effectively ending a lockout that forced unprepared replacement officials onto the field, creating three weeks of botched calls, acute criticism, furious coaches and players, and a blemish — however temporary — on the integrity of the country’s most popular sport.

headline: How Is Romney Still Competitive?
abstract: President Obama beats Mitt Romney in just about every issue in the polls. So how is Mr. Romney’s candidacy still viable?
lead_paragraph: The latest poll from Ohio shows that President Obama’s lead over Mitt Romney has grown, to 10 percentage points. Mr. Romney is going to have a lot more trouble getting to the White House without winning Ohio—in fact, no Republican president has ever won the race without it.

abstract: Howard Taubman’s 1962 review of the Broadway production of Edward Albee’s play.

headline: A Wine’s Home Is Its Castle
abstract: When is a chateau not a chateau? The French wine industry is in a kerfuffle over Americans who would usurp the term “chateau” for wine labels.
lead_paragraph: PARIS—Driving through the vineyards of Bordeaux, I often have to chuckle at what passes for a “chateau.”

headline: Opening the Religious Tent to All
abstract: Among the readings at a synagogue that has attracted both gays and straights, Jews and Christians, was a poem by Yevgeny Yevtushenko.
lead_paragraph: So much has happened in our lifetimes that seemed impossible not so long ago, beside our own aging. Who could have guessed 40 years ago, when a band of gay Jewish men came together in Greenwich Village to worship because they were welcome nowhere else, that today gay marriage would be legal in this state and others? Who could have guessed 20 years later, after AIDS had killed a generation of gay men, faster than they could be properly mourned, that Congregation Beit Simchat Torah would be a “real’’ synagogue, with a lesbian rabbi? Who could have guessed that before long Beit Simchat Torah would be a magnet for both gays and straights, Jews and Christians, especially on the High Holy Days — Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur — when most synagogues are open only to members with tickets? And that their open-door policy would draw crowds so large it meant using New York City’s historic Town Hall for the first holiday and the cavernous Jacob Javits Convention Center for the second? Attending on the first night of Rosh Hashanah, and welcomed as a “practicing heterosexual,’’ I noted that the audience had at least two things in common: A belief that religion could and should be an open tent. And enough years on this earth to know that there is a time to sow and a time to reap, and that the second required both grace and courage. Among the readings was the poem “Autumn” by Yevgeny Yevtushenko.  Here are the first three stanzas, in slightly different translation. A complete version of the poem, in yet another translation, can be found here if you scroll to the bottom.

headline: Beyond Wall St., Curbs on High-Speed Trades Proceed
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']

lead_paragraph: A restful vacation is obviously good for you, but can your hotel room alone make you feel better? The MGM Grand Hotel & Casino in Las Vegas thinks so.

headline: Pitching a Surveillance System for Tugboats
abstract: This presentation hits on virtually all of the items that make a great pitch.
lead_paragraph: In my last post, I reviewed a pitch for an employee-owned assisted-living facility. This week, I review a pitch for a safety surveillance system for tugboats.

headline: In-Store | Move-In Condition
abstract: At Tina Seidenfaden Busck’s gallery, in an 18th-century residential building in the heart of Copenhagen, you can make yourself at home.
lead_paragraph: THE APARTMENT At Tina Seidenfaden Busck’s gallery, in an 18th-century residential building in the heart of Copenhagen, you can make yourself at home.

headline: Andy Williams Through the Years
abstract: Highlights from the entertainer’s long career.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the entertainer’s long career.

headline: How to Prepare for Retirement
abstract: Preparing for retirement has become considerably more complicated since the Great Recession.
lead_paragraph: As boomers move toward retirement — the oldest of our generation are now 66 — the complexities of preparing multiply. Unfortunately, matters have become considerably more complicated since the Great Recession. Of all demographic groups, people ages 55 to 64 have suffered the most financially, losing 10 percent of household income. I’ve had several friends say that they’re never going to be able to retire, that they’ll have to work until they drop. Hopefully not. Today’s expert is Doug Wheat, a certified financial planner with Family Wealth Management, based in western Massachusetts. One of the things that drew him to this work was having to manage his mother’s finances after his father died. Among the questions he is prepared to discuss are:

headline: At U.N., Egypt and Yemen Urge Curbs on Free Speech
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Two new Middle Eastern leaders, despite being swept to power by popular uprisings, issued rebuttals to President Obama’s defense of Western values at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The new presidents of Egypt and Yemen — both of whom were swept to power by uprisings demanding democratic rights — issued clear rebuttals on Wednesday to President Obama’s ardent defense of Western values at the United Nations, arguing that cultural limits on rights like freedom of speech had to be respected.

headline: Commentator Arrested for Defacing Anti-Jihad Subway Poster
abstract: The group behind the provocative advertisements in some subway stations had anticipated that they would be defaced.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian-American columnist, who rose to prominence on social media last year for her commentary during the revolution in Egypt, was arrested in the Times Square subway station on Tuesday for spraying pink paint on a pro-Israel poster that calls Islamist opponents of the Jewish state “savage.”

headline: Let Them Eat Crow
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: Brooks and Collins talk about Medicare, Social Security, the N.F.L. and Marie Antoinette.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, you’ve been very forthright in your criticism of the Romney campaign, and I cannot possibly pretend I haven’t been enjoying it. Is it disconcerting to be getting all those mash notes from liberals?

headline: ‘Today’ Producer Says Ouster of Ann Curry Was His Choice
abstract: Jim Bell, in his first public comments about the decision to remove Ms. Curry, denied reports that linked the decision to demands from the show’s co-host, Matt Lauer.
lead_paragraph: 8:24 p.m. | Updated  For the first time since removing Ann Curry from “Today” on NBC, the show’s executive producer on Wednesday defended that decision and sought to define the cause of its recent ratings setbacks, including the end of its 16-year weekly winning streak.

headline: Immigration Reporter Julia Preston’s Views on ‘Illegal Immigrant’
abstract: A Times reporter would like more flexibility but finds the term accurate and useful.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I opened up the question of whether the term “illegal immigrant” is disparaging or simply accurate. The response has been robust, and I’m paying attention to all of it – in e-mails, on Twitter, in comments on my blog posts and in conversations.

headline: Clinton Suggests Link to Qaeda Offshoot in Deadly Libya Attack
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton suggested an affiliate of Al Qaeda in North Africa was behind the attack on the United States mission in Benghazi.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday suggested there was a link between the Qaeda franchise in North Africa and the attack at the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, that killed the American ambassador and three others. She was the highest-ranking Obama administration official to publicly make the connection, and her comments intensified what is becoming a fiercely partisan fight over whether the attack could have been prevented.

headline: Priest Included in Philippines Investigation of Ivory Smuggling
abstract: A National Geographic article on the ivory wars prompts an investigation of a priest in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: 7:04 p.m. | Updated below |

headline: Will We Scream for Color Control Creams?
abstract: Can it be that some are already bored with the influx of blemish balm creams, or B.B. creams, into the American market? Get ready for color control creams, or C.C. creams.
lead_paragraph: Can it be that some are already bored with the influx of blemish balm creams, or B.B. creams, into the American market? Get ready for color control creams, or C.C. creams.

headline: Burning a Forest to Save It
abstract: As drought and runaway blazes become a more frequent problem globally, a learning network is teaching firefighters from abroad how to carry out controlled burns.
lead_paragraph: Controlled burning of grasslands and forests has been used for thousands of years to stimulate plant germination, replenish the ground with valuable nutrients, thin out trees and burn dry pine needles and tree limbs on the ground. When humans were not intentionally setting fires, lightning strikes completed the job.

headline: Scouting Report
abstract: The Gap and GQ are set to unveil a collection by new American men’s-wear designers; Saint James and Aesop open new shops; and fashion meets art at the Dumbo Arts Festival.
lead_paragraph: OPENINGS

headline: Why Credit Scores Aren’t Always What They Seem
abstract: Consumers who buy access to their credit score may get one that differs from the one lenders use.
lead_paragraph: When consumers buy access to their credit score, there’s a good chance they’re not seeing the same score a lender sees, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau reports.

headline: Carhenge: A Bucket-List Destination for Those With Time, and Gas, to Burn
abstract: The sculpture in western Nebraska is near no major highways, but that did not prevent a reporter from taking a detour during a recent road trip.
lead_paragraph: ALLIANCE, Neb. — The first thing I have to report about Carhenge is that to see it, you really have to want to see it.

headline: Producer Announces That ‘Rebecca’ Rehearsals Will Start on Monday
abstract: Three actors in the $12-million musical confirm start date, though there’s no decisive word yet on whether all the funding has been secured.
lead_paragraph: The producers of the troubled Broadway musical “Rebecca” notified cast members on Wednesday that rehearsals would begin on Monday morning, yet it remained unclear if the producers had closed the $4.5 million gap in the show’s $12 million budget that they had deemed necessary for rehearsals to start.

headline: Anne Hathaway to Sing at Joe’s Pub
abstract: The concert will celebrate the renovation of the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Anne Hathaway will perform a one-night-only concert, “Perfectly Marvelous: The Songs of Cabaret With Anne Hathaway and Friends,” on Oct. 24 at Joe’s Pub. The event is to celebrate the recent renovation of the Public Theater in Manhattan. Member tickets went on sale Tuesday and single ticket sales will go on sale next Tuesday.

headline: Blackbird
abstract: A review of the club Blackbird, which replaced the Lakeside Lounge in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the beloved music club Lakeside Lounge closed this year, East Village habitués feared it would be replaced by another artisan bar serving $20 cocktails. Luckily, the owners of Blackbird, which opened in August, are honoring the bar’s musical roots.

headline: Egyptian Commentator Arrested for Defacing Ad Calling Israel’s Opponents ‘Savage’
abstract: Mona Eltahawy, an Egyptian-born columnist and blogger, was arrested for defacing an anti-Islam ad in New York.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian-American columnist, who rose to prominence on social media last year for her commentary during the revolution in Egypt, was arrested in the Times Square subway station on Tuesday for spraying pink paint on a pro-Israel poster that calls Islamist opponents of the Jewish state “savage.”

headline: Drawing Inspiration From ‘Silent Spring’ (Or How to Illustrate a 50-Year-Old Book)
abstract: Last weekend’s story about Rachel Carson’s work presented us with an unusual task: how create a visual component to the article without using archival photos?
lead_paragraph: Last weekend’s article about the influential environmentalist Rachel Carson, written by Eliza Griswold, presented the art department with an unusual task: how to come up with a visual complement without using archival photos? Carson’s seminal book, ‘‘Silent Spring,’’ came out 50 years ago, after all.

headline: TimesCast Tech | Driverless Cars
abstract: California legalizes driverless cars. | Meg Whitman bets on old and new businesses to revive Hewlett-Packard. | Centrifuges, blowtorches and liquid nitrogen invade the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: California legalizes driverless cars. | Meg Whitman bets on old and new businesses to revive Hewlett-Packard. | Centrifuges, blowtorches and liquid nitrogen invade the kitchen.

headline: Two Old Friends Prepare a Three-Part Premiere
abstract: Garth Fagan and Wynton Marsalis discuss their new collaboration, “Lighthouse/Lightning Rod,” which will open at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — Last week the jazz trumpeter and composer Wynton Marsalis walked into an office building here that once housed a Knights of Columbus chapter, rode an elevator to a high-ceilinged studio and discovered his septet, a 12-member modern dance company, a giant spatula and a 21-foot-tall woman.

headline: Malicious Code Can Wipe Out Some Samsung Phones
abstract: A simple line of malicious code embedded in a Web page can cause some Samsung Galaxy smartphones to lose all their data, security researchers revealed this week.
lead_paragraph: A simple line of malicious code embedded in a Web page can cause some Samsung Galaxy smartphones to lose all their data, security researchers revealed this week. But Samsung says a fix has been out for months.

headline: The Wealth of Washington
abstract: Seeking explanations for D.C.’s influence-peddling arms race.
lead_paragraph: In a post pivoting off my weekend column on Washington’s extraordinary recent growth, Dylan Matthews of Wonkblog marshals data showing that the soaring wage premium for Washingtonians doesn’t correlate directly with increases in the federal government’s share of G.D.P. The two have spiked together in the last few years, but the D.C. economy achieved separation from national trends in the Reagan and Clinton years and lift-off under George W. Bush, a long three decade period when government’s share of the national income was relatively flat. What does correlate, though, is the growth in Washingtonian wealth and the steady expansion of lobbying: As Matthews notes, “the growth in inflation-adjusted lobbying spending, as measured by OpenSecrets, tracks the D.C. wage premium’s rise since the 1990s quite well.”

headline: Half-Shell Heroes Return to Action
abstract: The Ninja Turtles have been updated to appeal to today’s audiences, but the legend remains the same, and the toys are flying off the shelves.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Daily Shoe | Dries Van Noten
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a microcheckerboard lace-up mule.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Yankees’ Rodriguez Rests Sore Left Foot
abstract: Alex Rodriguez said he should be able to play for the Yankees on Thursday against the Blue Jays in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Alex Rodriguez was not in the starting lineup for the Yankees on Wednesday afternoon because of a sore left foot. Rodriguez fouled a ball off the top of his foot in his final at-bat in Tuesday’s 5-4 loss to the Minnesota Twins, and it swelled. X-rays were not deemed necessary by the Yankees, and Rodriguez said he should be able to play Thursday against the Blue Jays in Toronto.

headline: Brewing Obama’s Ale: So Far, So Good
abstract: Garrett Oliver of Brooklyn Brewery updates his progress on making White House Honey Ale.
lead_paragraph: Diner’s Journal has asked Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster at Brooklyn Brewery, to make a batch of White House Honey Ale — President Obama’s home brew — for us to sample and size up. Mr. Oliver started on Sept. 14, and is filing reports on its progress:

headline: Eintracht Frankfurt: Germany’s Surprise Team
abstract: Eintracht Frankfurt won promotion to the Germany’s Bundesliga and is now challenging the powerhouse clubs for the early-season league lead.
lead_paragraph: With no fewer than 24 transfers over the course of the summer off-season, it would have been easy to make the simple assumption that Eintracht Frankfurt Coach Armen Veh thought his squad was not ready for the step up to the Bundesliga. So much so that of the starting 11 that had finished second in the 2.Bundesliga only months before, only 4 remained for the opening game against Bayer Leverkusen. The squad lacked experience, organization and cohesion.

headline: Kids Draw the News: Tornadoes in New York City
abstract: Children’s drawings of the city’s recent severe weather.
lead_paragraph: Children’s drawings of the city’s recent severe weather.

headline: Huffington Post Continues Expansion With Site in Italy
abstract: L’Huffington Post made its debut on Tuesday in Italy, becoming the fifth version of the Internet news outlet outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister of Italy who left office last year in the depths of the economic crisis, resurfaced this week in a new place: the Italian-language Web site of The Huffington Post.

headline: In Further Opening, U.S. to Ease Ban on Imports From Myanmar
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States said it would begin to ease one of the last major sanctions on Myanmar because of the military-led government’s progress toward a more democratic system.
lead_paragraph: The United States announced Wednesday that it would begin to ease a longstanding ban on imports from Myanmar, one of the last major economic sanctions on the country, because of the advances made by its military-led government in moving toward a more democratic system.

headline: In Ohio, Obama Takes On Romney Over China and Jobs
abstract: President Obama trumpeted his recently opened unfair-trade case against China in a bid to shore up support in Ohio before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio — President Obama joined his Republican rival, Mitt Romney, in this crucial swing state on Wednesday, trumpeting his recently filed unfair-trade complaints against China in a bid to shore up support here before Election Day.

headline: Spanish Ire, Symbolized by a Carrot
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Politics and Government', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Spanish politics make it harder for Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy to meet financial obligations to the rest of the euro zone. Consider the carrot rebellion.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — As Spanish domestic politics threaten to spin beyond the control of the central government, they are also making it harder for Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy to meet Spain’s financial obligations to the rest of the euro zone.

headline: As Time Wanes, Glencore-Xstrata Deal Hinges on Leadership
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The fate of a proposed $90 billion merger of the commodities trader Glencore and the mining company Xstrata may come down to who gets the corner office.
lead_paragraph: The $90 billion merger of Glencore and Xstrata is on shaky ground as the two sides struggle to come to terms over the makeup of the combined management team.

headline: More Are Watching Internet Video on Actual TVs, Research Shows
abstract: More people are now watching Internet video — everything from cat videos to streaming prime-time shows — on big-screen televisions than on computers, according to a new report from the NPD Group, a market research company.
lead_paragraph: No more squinting at YouTube videos or Hulu shows on a tiny laptop or desktop screen. More people are now watching Internet video — everything from cat videos to streaming prime-time shows — on big-screen televisions than on computers, according to a new report from the NPD Group, a market research company.

headline: Paris, With a Slouch or a Sashay
abstract: I found the Dries Van Noten show curious but interesting — mostly for its inky colors and plaids, but curious for its runny silhouette. Dare I say grunge?
lead_paragraph: New York seems miles away as the Paris collections, the fourth and final stop of the spring 2013 shows, began in a downpour — a literal one, that is. People arrived at Rochas on Wednesday shaking like poodles, and left to face lagoons of water in the streets. One woman came prepared with a beige vinyl sou’wester that matched her skirt. I hugged the sidewalk on the Champs-Élysées, staying under the trees, and got back to my hotel just before it let loose again. I opened a bottle of red wine.

headline: Dean Foods Explores Sale of a Dairy Unit
abstract: Dean Foods announced Wednesday that it was exploring the sale of its Morningstar unit as the company takes steps to reduce its debt.
lead_paragraph: 4:24 p.m. | Updated

abstract: For some in the business of celebrity dressing, sizzling weather, and perhaps global warming, have played an increasing role for red carpet events.
lead_paragraph: For some in the business of celebrity dressing, sizzling weather, and perhaps global warming, have played an increasing role for red carpet events.

lead_paragraph: IT’S a good thing Nicole Kidman has options.

headline: Images of Clashes at Anti-Austerity Protests in Europe
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Strikes']
abstract: Anti-austerity protesters clashed with police officers in the Greek and Spanish capitals.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Liz Alderman and Niki Kitsantonis report, tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Athens to protest salary and pension cuts on Wednesday. The rally, which began peacefully, turned violent in the early afternoon when a small group of demonstrators threw Molotov cocktails at police officers and firebombs at government buildings near the Greek Parliament.

headline: Photo Replay: Sept. 26
abstract: A view of the day in sports included some dapper Ryder Cup fans and an interesting reward for a Sumo champion.
lead_paragraph: A view of the day in sports included some dapper Ryder Cup fans and an interesting reward for a Sumo champion.

headline: Scott Brown Says He ‘Regrets’ His Staff’s ‘Unacceptable’ Behavior
abstract: Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts issued a warning to his campaign staff members who participated in the tomahawk chops and Indian war whoops — and to all of his staff — that such conduct would not be tolerated.
lead_paragraph: 8:43 p.m. | Updated BOSTON — Senator Scott P. Brown’s campaign issued a statement Wednesday evening saying he “regrets” what he called “unacceptable” behavior by some staff members who participated in the tomahawk chops and Indian war whoops at a campaign rally.

headline: Climate Change, Metal and Waterways
abstract: Rising metal concentrations in the Upper Snake River watershed seem to dovetail with the effects of a warming climate.
lead_paragraph: High in the Rocky Mountains, just west of the Continental Divide, metal concentrations in the Upper Snake River have been climbing over the last 30 years, in some cases increasing as much as fourfold. Strong evidence links this trend to climate change, according to a recent study led by the United States Geological Survey and University of Colorado at Boulder.

headline: Richard Rhodes Writes a Play About Reagan, Gorbachev and Nuclear Weapons
abstract: “Reykjavik” will have a staged reading, followed by a panel discussion, at the Baruch Performing Arts Center on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: Richard Rhodes, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of 24 books, has written his first play, and it spins off of his research into the history of nuclear weapons. Mr. Rhodes’s “Reykjavik,” about the historic 1986 meeting between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev in that city, will have a free staged reading on Thursday at 6:30 pm at the Baruch Performing Arts Center. Mr. Rhodes and several other experts in nuclear disarmament will appear at a panel discussion following the reading.

headline: New Home for Barnes Foundation a Bright Shade of Green
abstract: The Phildelphia site is given the highest rating by the United States Green Building Council.
lead_paragraph: Critics have differed on the merits of the new home for the Barnes Foundation, the world-class art collection that was relocated from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown museum quarter this year after a long-running court battle. But at least one arbiter has now given the museum an unqualified stamp of approval.

headline: A Tory, His Bike and an Ill-Chosen Insult
abstract: Told he could not ride his bicycle in a certain area, the politician Andrew Mitchell told two officers they were “plebs,” according to a police report.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For an ambitious politician, it is rarely a good idea to lose your cool — and never with the police. But Andrew Mitchell apparently compounded the error further by deriding police officers as his social inferiors, and that has turned a small incident into a big political headache for Prime Minister David Cameron and his ruling Conservative Party.

headline: 3 Bidders Left to Run World Trade Center Observatory
abstract: The competition has been fierce because the observatory will be one of the highest and presumably most lucrative in the nation.
lead_paragraph: And then there were three.

headline: Sabathia Gives Twins Fits and Bullpen a Rest
abstract: C. C. Sabathia (14-6) struck out 10 in eight solid innings as the Yankees moved closer to clinching the American League East.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Joe Mauer, a former most valuable player, came into Wednesday’s game with a .326 batting average — second only to Miguel Cabrera in the American League — and was hitting a staggering .418 in September. But by the time his fourth at-bat came around against C. C. Sabathia, he had struck out three times and did not look so dangerous.

headline: Dear Waldorf, Mummy Stole Your Teapot Back in 1935. So Sorry.
abstract: When the Waldorf-Astoria advertised an amnesty program for the return of items like hotel knives, coffee pots or perhaps ashtrays that left in guests’ luggage — no questions asked — it worked.
lead_paragraph: A silver coffee pot, a couple of knives, a fork, a coaster for a bottle of wine: the goods were spread out on the table the way the police would spread out guns or drugs hauled in from a raid that would make the 11 o’clock news.

headline: For $10,000, the Allure of Bentley With Room Service
abstract: The style and heritage of the luxury automaker are reflected in a suite designed by the brand in tandem with the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The landmark St. Regis hotel in New York has opened its new Bentley suite, designed in a collaboration between the hotel and Bentley’s interior designers. It joins specialty suites at the hotel branded by Christian Dior and Tiffany. Like the cars that inspired it, the Bentley suite is not an inexpensive proposition; rates start at $9,500 a night, excluding taxes.

headline: 2nd Youth Charged in Vandalism at Congressman’s Campaign Office
abstract: Neither of the teenagers knew the windows broken were a politician’s, investigators say.
lead_paragraph: 5:26 p.m. | Updated A second teenager was arrested on Wednesday and charged with vandalizing Representative Michael G. Grimm’s campaign headquarters on Staten Island over the weekend. The boy, Avery Gerena, 16, of Staten Island, told the police that he did not know the office was Mr. Grimm’s when he threw a rock through its window, according to a criminal complaint.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Zoe Colivas at Rochas
abstract: The model Zoe Colivas transforms with makeup by Lucia Pieroni for Clé de Peau and hair by Eugene Souleiman for Wella.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Zoe Colivas of Elite Paris before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Lucia Pieroni for Clé de Peau and hair by Eugene Souleiman for Wella.

abstract: Photos from Greece, Syria, India and Senegal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, Syria, India and Senegal.

headline: A Map App, as Sleek as iPhone 5, Is Often Off
abstract: Apple has replaced Google’s maps with its own, built from scratch, but in the new app entire locations have been mislabeled or erased. We try to track down the problems.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I used Apple’s new Maps app on my iPhone to guide me to a speaking engagement.

headline: A Maps App With Problems
abstract: Apple’s new Maps app for iPhones and iPads devices was built from scratch, and it is full of problems.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s new Maps app for iPhones and iPads devices was built from scratch, and it is full of problems.

headline: Musical Memories of Andy Williams
abstract: Andy Williams was my father’s music, the slow, grown-up stuff you were forced to listen to until the real music came on.
lead_paragraph: To be honest, I wasn’t a fan of Andy Williams. But I wasn’t a critic, either. Coming of age in the 1960s, I was pretty much rock ‘n’ roll, 24/7. Andy Williams, Perry Como, Bing Crosby, Tony Bennett — they blurred together for me. It seemed like they all owned the same cashmere sweater. I had the same problem with Dinah Shore and Doris Day. While it’s true they sang music you could slow dance to — meaning you got to lean against a girl — for me, it was bar mitzvah music, the slow, grown-up stuff you were forced to listen to until the real music came on. Slow dancing for me was John Lennon’s “Julia.”

headline: Andy Williams, a TV Star When Variety Shows Were Just Hanging On
abstract: The singer, who died at 84 on Wednesday, had a show on each of the three networks. In a second run at NBC, he moved to modernize the show, adding a psychedelic set and music guests that rocked a bit more. The Osmonds were always welcome, however.
lead_paragraph: In this YouTube clip, Andy Williams is with Antônio Carlos Jobim to sing “The Girl From Ipanema.”

abstract: Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s appearance at the United Nations attracted protesters who shared the streets with those representing other causes.
lead_paragraph: Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s appearance at the United Nations attracted protesters who shared the streets with those representing other causes.

headline: In Louisville, a Mixed Message
abstract: The city plans to enlarge its downtown highways, even as it hopes to attract 20-somethings and empty nesters with urban amenities.
lead_paragraph: The city plans to enlarge its downtown highways, even as it hopes to attract 20-somethings and empty nesters with urban amenities.

headline: The Sheltering Dress
abstract: Both Dries Van Noten and Marco Zanini of Rochas showed a dress style that was eye-catching in its capaciousness.
lead_paragraph: Both Dries Van Noten and Marco Zanini of Rochas showed a dress style that was eye-catching in its capaciousness. Neither a tent nor a caftan, it swept to the floor. Mr. Van Noten showed his printed chiffon version as a cover for clothes.

headline: It’s Finally Pink on Top of Music Charts
abstract: With lots of hit songs over the last 12 years, the singer finally reached No. 1 with her sixth album, “The Truth About Love.”
lead_paragraph: This week on the music charts, Pink finally reaches No. 1 and “Gangnam Style” by the South Korean rapper Psy goes from viral-video status to genuine hit single (although its video is still plenty viral).

headline: Finding Fame, and Sometimes Fortune, in Social Media
abstract: While some of the Internet-famous have moved to the movie or TV screen, others have found a niche — and sometimes a comfortable living — on Twitter, Tumblr or Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Social media have made it easier than ever to catapult from obscurity to prominence. In recent years, the Web has blossomed into a more egalitarian version of “American Idol,” where nobodies compete for attention alongside somebodies.

headline: The Reguero Theater Gets Its Close-Up
abstract: Snapshots of an old theater in Cuba: “a pastiche of railway cars, faded murals, cast iron and fantasy.”
lead_paragraph: We’ve received many comments from readers about the pictures by Andrew Moore that accompanied John Jeremiah Sullivan’s cover story about Cuba. One in particular, from Virgina Schofield, piqued our interest. Schofield, who is 73, grew up in Cuba and has a special connection to the Reguero Theater that Moore photographed in Morón (above). Her maternal grandfather, Miguel Reguero, spent his small inheritance to build that theater, and her mother occasionally played the piano in productions there. When the enterprise bankrupted Schofield’s grandfather, he moved the family to La Gloria, where her mother met Walton Schofield, whose parents were from England. “I always say my last name is Schofield because of that theater,” Schofield says, referring to the circumstances that led her parents to meet.

headline: The Caucus Click: Guarding the National Debt
abstract: Secret Service members stood watch near a clock showing the national debt at a campaign event for Mitt Romney on Wednesday in Westerville, Ohio.

headline: Video: Street Protests at the United Nations
abstract: Demonstrators against President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran were the most numerous among the groups representing causes as the General Assembly met.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of demonstrators gathered outside the United Nations on Wednesday, chanting slogans and beating drums as President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran gave his final address before the General Assembly.

headline: Leaving Polarization at the Door
abstract: The opening show at the Rauschenberg Foundation’s gallery space in Chelsea offers a dose of inclusion in a fractured era.
lead_paragraph: Robert Rauschenberg, who died four years ago after a career as big-spirited and optimistic as any in postwar art, was not considered first and foremost a politically motivated artist.

headline: For the Absent-Minded, a Few Forget-Me-Nots
abstract: Many apps make the creation of to-do lists painless, but some are better than others at reminding users of impending tasks.
lead_paragraph: I have a certain notoriety among friends because of my poor memory, which is particularly bad when it comes to to-do lists. It’s so bad, in fact, that I’ve resorted to all sorts of mental and linguistic tricks. It’s not uncommon to hear me leave the house muttering “monkeys, Ferrari, alien death ray” to help me remember to buy peanuts, park the car inside and make an appointment with the doctor.

headline: A Sherlock Holmes, Out of Rehab and Teaming Up With a Lady Watson
abstract: “Elementary,” a contemporary take on Sherlock Holmes, transplants the London sleuth to New York City.
lead_paragraph: When CBS added “Elementary” to its fall schedule a lot of people asked whether television really needed another Sherlock Holmes show when the one we already have, courtesy of BBC and PBS, is so good.

headline: Right Place and Sound for a ’70s Time Warp
abstract: The doom-metal band Saint Vitus, back together after essentially a 16-year layoff, finally played the Brooklyn bar that was named for it.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s do something kind of old, like me?” suggested Dave Chandler of the doom-metal band Saint Vitus on Tuesday night from a stage that had been built more or less in his honor. “I wrote it right around the time that dirt was invented?”

headline: Proposal Sets Circumcision Regulations in Germany
abstract: The proposal comes in response to calls by lawmakers for legal clarity in the wake of a regional court ruling that equated the practice of ritual circumcision with bodily injury to minors.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s Justice Ministry took a firm step on Wednesday toward safeguarding the right of parents to circumcise their male children, distributing its proposal to state officials and other experts to be debated before it is drafted into law.

headline: Column on Romney-Ryan Meant as Satire Is Taken as Fact
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: A satirical column takes on a life of its own, becoming part of the political conversation after being taken as factual reporting.
lead_paragraph: No, Representative Paul D. Ryan has not given the nickname “Stench” to Mitt Romney, despite a host of credulous journalists and bloggers who accepted as fact a column that Politico intended as satire.

headline: Scenes From the London Design Festival
abstract: Having just marked its 10th year, the festival is poised between being a regional showcase bubbling with spontaneous interventions and a smooth international canvas.

lead_paragraph: Characters in this month’s selection of new books make great company: a wily ex-con, a master gardener, female Israeli soldiers and the real women who sued Newsweek so they could be writers. Even an abusive father and a hostage taker bring something to the party.

headline: Nuclear Sub Goes Rogue, Visits Island
abstract: Andre Braugher plays the captain of a Navy ballistic missile submarine that has gone rogue in ABC’s “Last Resort.”

lead_paragraph: The venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz is adding another Washington insider to its team, reflecting Silicon Valley’s growing focus on regulatory matters.

headline: Starting the Season With an Autumn Evening of Sweet Serenades
abstract: Kodaly was the program at Alice Tully Hall for the second time this month when the Chamber Music Society performed his Serenade for Two Violins and Viola.
lead_paragraph: By now the versatile Hungarian master Zoltan Kodaly may be better remembered as an “ethnomusicologist and educationist,” as The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians labels him, than as a composer, a few orchestral favorites aside. Even steady concertgoers can traverse entire seasons in New York without hearing his music. So the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center deserves praise for its continued championing of the Serenade for Two Violins and Viola (1920), which it recorded for Delos in 1993.

headline: Green Ribbons at an Organic Fair
keywords: ['Sustainable Living', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Agriculture and Farming']

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google Oceans, and Promises ‘The Jetsons’ Made Us
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday’s selection includes a report that says few sales can be traced to social media, a cheaper way to charge an iPhone 5 and an argument that Apple must change its strategy when it comes to television.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Old Friends Whose Past Is Always Present
abstract: Paul Thureen, Hannah Bos and Oliver Butler of the Debate Society prepare for their newest work, “Blood Play.”
lead_paragraph: THAT the playwrights Hannah Bos and Paul Thureen, mainstays of the fast-emerging company the Debate Society, create such meticulously realized and unified worlds is even more remarkable when you consider their history — something that, for a moment recently, they seemed reluctant to do. “You shouldn’t tell that story,” Ms. Bos, 33, instructed Mr. Thureen, 34, when the conversation turned to the eight months they dated, at Vassar College in the late 1990s.

headline: In It for the Long Haul in Bushwick
abstract: Five friends made a commitment to fix up a raw space in Bushwick and live there for a decade.
lead_paragraph: Five friends made a commitment to fix up a raw space in Bushwick and live there for a decade.

headline: Making Family Out of Friends
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Lofts']
abstract: Five creative 20-somethings carve out a place to call home in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: IN a slowly gentrifying section of Bushwick, Brooklyn, where gunshots are no longer heard and the local brothel has been turned into a family home, five friends made a 10-year commitment.

headline: China Politics Stall Overhaul for Economy
keywords: ['Series', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: China’s Communist Party appears so distracted by its leadership transition that it is not pursuing the bold agenda that may be necessary to prevent severe economic pain.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When it comes to confronting economic slowdowns, the Chinese government has not been shy about making bold moves. Faced with the contagion of global recession four years ago, policy makers created a $585 billion stimulus package that helped inoculate the nation against the economic malaise still sapping the United States and Europe.

headline: Market Ready

keywords: ['Television', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: “666 Park Avenue,” a new television series about an evil building, takes design cues from a city icon.
lead_paragraph: In New York City, the notion of selling your soul to get into a magnificent building is not an unfamiliar one. Eternity in hell for a classic six on Riverside Drive with a view of the Hudson? Deal!

headline: Russians Eagerly Participate in Medical Experiments, Despite Risks
abstract: Even though tests sometimes go awry, patients in Russia are eager to join drug trials because often they are the only way to receive modern medical care.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Like a dream patient conjured up in the boardroom of a pharmaceutical company, the Russian grandmother accepted the risks of the drug she was taking without complaint and cheerily endured even extraordinary side effects.

headline: Eero Saarinen’s Unstoried Talent
abstract: A new book showcases furniture designed by the Finnish architect.
lead_paragraph: Among the plethora of monographs available on decorative objects, one subject has been overlooked: the furniture designs of Eero Saarinen. While the architectural projects of Saarinen, the Finnish architect and industrial designer, have been covered, there is “only the occasional reference — often inaccurate — to his furniture,” said Brian Lutz, the author of “Eero Saarinen: Furniture for Everyman” (Pointed Leaf Press, $85). Mr. Lutz is well positioned to tell this story, having worked for the modern furniture companies Knoll in New York and Artek in Finland. His research took almost 10 years and involved numerous conversations with important figures in the production and development of Saarinen’s furniture, including Florence Knoll Bassett, Niels Diffrient and Don Albinson. The 224-page book, which will be officially released Oct. 16, features a preface by Ms. Knoll Bassett, a foreword by Mr. Diffrient and more than 200 photographs and illustrations. Information: (212) 941-1800 or pointedleafpress.com.

headline: Sipping, Looking and Maybe Buying
abstract: A new cafe from Fair Folks & a Goat opens on Houston Street.
lead_paragraph: Aurora and Anthony Mazzei, a married couple who live in Manhattan, specialize in clever ways to present design. Operating under the name Fair Folks & a Goat, they have opened a tea salon in an Upper East Side apartment and a bed-and-breakfast and a cafe in New Orleans, stocking each location with design pieces for sale.

headline: Fashion-Forward Housewares

lead_paragraph: Zara, the clothing retailer, has become an indispensable resource for those who want to look on-trend without spending a fortune. And on Oct. 9, they can look to the company for décor as well, when Zara Home comes to the United States.

headline: Rented Computers Captured Customers Having Sex, F.T.C. Says
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission agreed to a settlement with seven companies and a Pennsylvania-based software maker, which had distributed software on rental computers that spied on more than 420,000 customers, secretly capturing “webcam pictures of children, partially undressed individuals, and intimate activities at home.”
lead_paragraph: If you rented a computer, you probably should not have been blogging without your shirt on.

The moment was captured by a photographer they had hired, and the men liked the photo so much they used it to announce their engagement.

A local real estate agent was walking by and noticed the couple. “He basically said, ‘You want it? It’s yours.’ ” Mrs. Wing said.

lead_paragraph: Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, U.S. Bancorp and PNC have been hit by a wave of cyberattacks that have caused Internet blackouts and delays on online banking sites.

headline: Resort’s Snow Won’t Be Pure This Year; It’ll Be Sewage
keywords: ['Navajo Indians', 'Skiing', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Water Pollution', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Sewers and Sewage']
abstract: Arizona Snowbowl will become the first ski resort in the world to use 100 percent sewage effluent to make artificial snow. Members of the Navajo tribe say the snow will ruin sacred ground.
lead_paragraph: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. — Klee Benally, a member of the Navajo tribe, has gone to the mountains just north of here to pray, and he has gone to get arrested. He has chained himself to excavators; he has faced down bulldozers. For 10 years, the soft-spoken activist has fought a ski resort’s expansion plans in the San Francisco Peaks that include clear-cutting 74 acres of forest and piping treated sewage effluent onto a mountain to make snow.

headline: 5 Reasons to Intervene in Syria Now
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'No-Fly Zones', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama needs to apply his own doctrine on foreign conflict spots where it would benefit the United States most: Syria.
lead_paragraph: WHETHER you agree or disagree with President Obama, there is no doubt that he has formulated a coherent approach to the use of American power. The Obama Doctrine involves getting into a conflict zone and getting out fast without ground wars or extended military occupations. This approach proved its effectiveness in Libya last year.

headline: Fighting Over God’s Image
abstract: Unlike in Muslim culture, religious images abound in America. But it wasn’t always so.
lead_paragraph: THE murders of four Americans over an amateurish online video about Muhammad, like the attempted murder of a Danish cartoonist who in 2005 had depicted the prophet with a bomb in his turban, have left many Americans confused, angry and fearful about the rage that some Muslims feel about visual representations of their sacred figures.

headline: Political Shifts in Bavaria, Land of Tradition, Could Have Wide Repercussions
abstract: Bavaria’s traditional culture may be falling victim to its economic success, as the governing party’s philosophy is tested by newcomers.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — With two mighty blows from a large wooden mallet, Christian Ude, the popular mayor of Bavaria’s capital here, tapped the first keg of Oktoberfest and officially opened this year’s festival. As tradition dictates, the first beer went to the man he hopes to unseat in next year’s election, state premier Horst Seehofer.

headline: As Power Flows to Regional Bosses, Questions Rise on India’s Economy
abstract: India’s political calculus is again in flux, with the economy in a tailspin and power radiating to regional political chieftains, who are considering a new national political alignment.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It seems like eons ago, but Prime Minister Manmohan Singh and his coalition government once inspired very high expectations. They were going to stoke India’s economy, improve education, help the poor, build modern transportation and energy systems and, perhaps most improbably, prove that India, the most populous and messiest of democracies, could be successfully governed.

headline: The Human Cost of the Second Amendment
abstract: Gun advocates say that guns don’t kill people, people kill people. The truth is that people with guns kill people, often very efficiently — just ask an E.R. nurse.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin, Aurora, Virginia Tech, Columbine. We all know these place names and what happened there. By the time this column appears, there may well be a new locale to add to the list. Such is the state of enabled and murderous mayhem in the United States.

headline: Toyota Moves to Revamp Its Lexus Luxury Line
abstract: After falling behind from a product shortage, the automaker is planning to rejuvenate its Lexus brand by making the line more appealing to younger and more adventurous buyers.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With a strong comeback under way in mainstream sedans and S.U.V.’s, Toyota Motor is now hoping to rejuvenate its Lexus brand by appealing to younger and more adventurous buyers.

headline: Billy Barnes Dies at 85; Helped Revive Revues
abstract: Mr. Barnes’s comic revues in the late 1950s and early ’60s skewered beatniks, television and other contemporary targets.
lead_paragraph: Billy Barnes, a composer and lyricist whose varied work included satirical Broadway revues, “Laugh-In” routines and poignant songs that became popular standards for artists like Barbra Streisand, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: To Build for the Future, a Division II Power Goes Back to Its Past
abstract: Under Terry Bowden, North Alabama became a haven for players who needed a fresh start. Under Bobby Wallace, the program is taking a different approach.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, the former Auburn coach Terry Bowden arrived at North Alabama and began to jump-start the careers of former top football recruits.

abstract: The Beach Boys 50th anniversary reunion tour ends this week in London. Also apparently ending: the much-discussed detente between the founding members Mike Love and Brian Wilson.
lead_paragraph: The Beach Boys 50th anniversary reunion tour ends this week in London. Also apparently ending: the much-discussed detente between the founding members Mike Love and Brian Wilson.
