headline: In Obama’s Speech, Their Voices
abstract: These former sex slaves said the president gave the voiceless a voice in his landmark speech against human trafficking. Let’s hope this is a turning point.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama made a landmark speech against modern slavery on Tuesday, many of us in the news media shrugged. It didn’t fit into the political narrative. It wasn’t controversial, so — yawn — it wasn’t really news.

headline: Friendships Wrapped in the Army-Navy Rivalry
abstract: Rollie Stichweh is going to be inducted into the Army Sports Hall of Fame, and his friends and former opponents from Navy, Roger Staubach and Ed Orr, will be there.
lead_paragraph: Roger Staubach and Rollie Stichweh switched uniforms before going to the mess hall at West Point in 1964.

headline: Workers at J.F.K. Say Security Inspections Are Rushed
abstract: Workers who are supposed to check plane cabins after flights say they are compelled to compromise safety so that planes can return to the sky quickly.
lead_paragraph: After passengers exit each plane at John F. Kennedy International Airport, squads of caterers and cleaners troop on and prepare the aircraft for the next flight.

headline: Police Comb a Dense Forest for a Suspect in a Killing
abstract: After killing his daughter-in-law, according to the police, Eugene Palmer disappeared into Harriman State Park, which covers more than 46,000 acres.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Palmer was always a loner, his neighbors in the Rockland County town of Haverstraw said. Armed with a shotgun, they said, Mr. Palmer often menaced people who strayed uninvited onto his hilly, overgrown property, and he was known to retreat into the woods near his home to camp and hunt.

headline: Mr. Romney Addresses Foreign Aid
abstract: A speech on the value of foreign aid and its purpose was encouraging, but there were also gaps and unanswered questions.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks before the election, Mitt Romney has finally made a substantive contribution to the national security debate, offering ideas about how he would handle foreign aid. For a campaign troubled by fumbles and incoherent proposals, this counts as progress. But, even here, there are details he needs to flesh out.

headline: Cuomo Backs Republican Who Lost Primary After Vote for Gay Marriage
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Endorsements', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']

lead_paragraph: New York’s Democratic governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, offered an emphatic endorsement on Wednesday to an upstate Republican state senator who lost a primary this month that became a referendum on the senator’s vote in favor of same-sex marriage.

headline: Boogaard Lawsuit May Shake Up Hockey
abstract: A lawsuit filed by Derek Boogaard’s family accuses the players union of squandering a chance at a financial claim. But it also contains serious charges that could be explored.
lead_paragraph: It is a single lawsuit and, at that, a legal action in its infancy. That said, the lawsuit brought by the family of Derek Boogaard against the N.H.L.’s players union could lead to some novel and tumultuous territory for the sport.

headline: Losing Faith in Stop-and-Frisk
abstract: The Bronx district attorney should be applauded for refusing to prosecute bad arrests.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx district attorney’s office showed sound judgment when it told the New York Police Department that it would no longer prosecute people stopped for trespassing, unless the officers could demonstrate that the arrests were warranted.

headline: Former Hospital Executive Charged in Kickback Scheme
abstract: The former chief executive officer of the Hospital for Special Surgery received kickbacks from hospital vendors, a hospital employee and a British-based health care organization, an indictment says.
lead_paragraph: A former chief executive of the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan has been charged with receiving about $1.4 million in illegal payments in an extortion and kickback scheme carried out between 1996 and 2007, according to an indictment unsealed Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Romney Ad Reaches Out to Working Class
abstract: Mitt Romney stepped up his efforts to repair the damage from his “47 percent” comments, trying to reassure voters that he cares about the poor and middle class.
lead_paragraph: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — Mitt Romney stepped up his efforts to repair the damage from his “47 percent” comments, releasing a new television ad on Wednesday in which he speaks directly to the camera about his compassion and tries to reassure voters that he cares about the poor and middle class.

abstract: The Donald Rumsfeld-inspired guide to what might happen over the 40 days leading up to Election Day.

abstract: Donations from the leading contributors to Democratic Super PACs.
lead_paragraph: Donations from the leading contributors to Democratic Super PACs.

headline: Visas for Scientists, With a Catch
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'United States Economy', 'Editorials', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A Republican bill that supported one visa program by killing off another thankfully didn’t pass. Immigrants need more than one legal path into the country.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t hard to find Republicans in Congress willing to support immigration generally, but rarer to hear them talk about actually allowing more foreigners to come here. When they do, you have to listen for the catch. Take Representative Lamar Smith of Texas, leader of the Republican immigration restrictionists, who recently offered a bill to provide 55,000 permanent-residency visas, or green cards, each year to immigrants with advanced degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

headline: Surviving Where Slaves Held Fast
abstract: The Gullah and Geechee people could be forced out of an island off Georgia because of exorbitant real estate taxes from local government.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Congress took note of one of the nation’s great sagas of endurance — descendants of slavery who survived for generations on the barrier chain of Sea Islands along the southeast coast. The government created a cultural heritage corridor from North Carolina to Florida to celebrate the Gullah and Geechee peoples, as they are known.

headline: Boogaard Complaint for Damages
abstract: A copy of the Complaint for Damages by the family of Derek Boogaard against the N.H.L. players union.
lead_paragraph: A copy of the Complaint for Damages by the family of Derek Boogaard against the N.H.L. players union.

headline: Budget Cuts to Hobble State Archives in Georgia
abstract: As Georgia’s state archives prepares to reduce its staff and accessibility drastically next month, archivists worry about a long-term impact on public records nationwide.
lead_paragraph: MORROW, Ga. — The Georgia Archives, which holds both historical curiosities and virtually every important state government document ever created, is about to become nearly impossible to visit.

headline: A Call for Help, Then a Fatal Police Shooting
abstract: When Mohamed Bah holed himself in his Harlem apartment, relatives called the police, who, after a violent confrontation, shot and killed Mr. Bah on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Bah had not seemed himself lately. Day after day, the 28-year-old taxi driver failed to show up for work and skipped his classes at Borough of Manhattan Community College. When his mother called from Guinea, Mr. Bah acted as though he did not know her, the police said Wednesday.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Finally a Draw for Democrats
abstract: With the election just weeks away, Democratic “super PACs” are finally getting the kind of wealthy donors who have made Republican outside groups a pivotal force in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: James Simons, a Long Island investor and philanthropist, has not given a cent to President Obama’s re-election campaign this year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning numbers for Sept. 26, 2012, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: As Jobless Figures Go Up, Officials Dispute the Data
abstract: In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, leaders have echoed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in saying federal unemployment estimations do not reflect reality and need to be rethought.
lead_paragraph: In some statehouses in the Northeast, it is open season on the federal number-crunchers who calculate the unemployment rate every month.

headline: Even in Paris
abstract: The playoff puzzle from the 2012 Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament toggles the mind.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Did this one flip your switch? Were you turned ON or OFF by Joel Fagliano’s topsy-turvy puzzle? I thought it was a great Thursday challenge myself, and so did the people who watched the three finalists compete for the trophy in the 2012 Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

headline: Senate Republicans Challenge Obama’s Recess Appointments
abstract: A friend-of-the-court brief filed in Washington challenges the legality of President Obama’s appointments to the National Labor Relations Board, and reignites the debate over presidential power and what counts as a recess.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans have filed a friend-of-the-court brief challenging President Obama’s appointments to the National Labor Relations Board, reigniting a confrontation over presidential power.

headline: Corrections: September 27, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 27, 2012.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: San Franciscans Divide Over Pint-Size Apartments
abstract: Lawmakers put off a vote to allow units as small as 220 square feet. Proponents called the apartments affordable housing, but critics said lower-income residents will not benefit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This city of sprawling Victorian homes and expansive harbor views has erupted into a fight over itty-bitty apartments.

headline: The Evolution of Tiger as a Teammate
abstract: Tiger Woods, who is making his seventh Ryder Cup appearance this week at Medinah Country Club, has been on one victorious team in the biennial event, in 1999.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill.

headline: Rebels Make Gains in Blunting Syrian Air Attacks
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: For the rebels, managing to deny the use of an important airfield has undermined the government’s ability to exert its full authority in some parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: ABU AD DUHUR, Syria — The rebels huddled before darkness near the edge of the Syrian air force base. They were about 40 men, hiding beside small buildings on the flatlands south of Aleppo.

headline: Man Accused in Plot to Buy Jet Material
abstract: Federal prosecutors filed documents on Monday saying that Ming Suan Zhang, 40, tried to purchase thousands of pounds of aerospace-grade carbon fiber to illegally take to China.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese man traveled to the United States looking to buy thousands of pounds of the kind of high-grade carbon fiber that makes fighter jets fly faster and maneuver better, the authorities said. His two accomplices, working from Taiwan, had helped set up the deal, scouring the Internet to find a company willing to sell.

headline: In Ravens’ Territory, Pennant Fever Returns
abstract: As the Orioles make a run at a playoff berth, Baltimore is relearning how to care about and keep up with a pennant contender.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — At 10 a.m. on a recent Saturday, Aaron Kluttz, 52, wearing a bright orange Brooks Robinson jersey, looked up at the ticket prices posted on the north side of the B&O Warehouse. The warehouse looms above the right-field wall of Oriole Park at Camden Yards.

headline: In Texas Conviction, an Immigrant Rallying Cry
keywords: ['Illegal Immigrants', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Mexican-Americans']
abstract: Rosa Jimenez, an illegal Mexican immigrant in a Texas prison for a crime she says she did not commit, has become a cause célèbre for critics of the American criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: GATESVILLE, Tex. — In January, Rosa Jimenez, an illegal Mexican immigrant, will have spent 10 years in prison in the bleak scrublands of Central Texas for a crime she says she did not commit: forcing a wad of paper towels down the throat of a toddler in her care, making him choke and ultimately die.

headline: A Jet Goes From One Backfield to the Other
abstract: The Jets forged ahead without the injured Darrelle Revis, rearranging their secondary, then recruiting the running back Joe McKnight to learn how to play cornerback on the fly.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets forged ahead Wednesday without Darrelle Revis, their injured cornerback, rearranging their secondary, then recruiting a running back to pull on a green practice jersey and learn how to play cornerback on the fly.

headline: Republicans Intensify Drive to Win Over Jewish Voters
abstract: In battleground states like Florida, Ohio and Nevada, Republicans are trying to persuade Jewish voters who might typically be expected to support Democrats to vote for Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Using billboards, television advertisements and finely honed voter lists, Republicans here and in other battleground states have intensified an effort to lure a small but potentially significant group of new or wavering voters from President Obama.

headline: Wright Breaks Mets’ Hits Record; Dickey Seeks Milestone of His Own
abstract: David Wright passed Ed Kranepool as the Mets’ career hit leader with an infield single in the third inning of the Mets’ victory. R. A. Dickey will try for his 20th win of the season on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: There is a curious dichotomy in the world of baseball, in which individual accomplishments are enthusiastically celebrated, yet the open pursuit of individual interests can be considered uncouth. Everyone knows the team comes first.

headline: Tensions Intensify in Greece
abstract: Clashes erupted in central Athens and across Greece on Wednesday as trade unions called a nationwide strike to contest new salary and pension cuts being discussed by the government and its international creditors.
lead_paragraph: Clashes erupted in central Athens and across Greece on Wednesday as trade unions called a nationwide strike to contest new salary and pension cuts being discussed by the government and its international creditors.

headline: Cyberwarfare Emerges From Shadows for Public Discussion by U.S. Officials
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'Computer Security', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The federal government’s announcement of a program to enlist contractors to develop technology is seen as a turning point in a long-secret program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, even as the United States carried out sophisticated cyberattacks on Iran’s nuclear program and the Pentagon created a Cyber Command, officials have been hesitant to discuss American offensive cyberwarfare programs openly. Since June, in fact, F.B.I. agents have been investigating leaks to The New York Times about the computer attacks on Tehran.

headline: In Illinois, a European Is at Home
abstract: Luke Donald, an Englishman, went to Northwestern University and has a home near Medinah Country Club, the site of the Ryder Cup.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — Their volunteer shift at Medinah Country Club was over and Bill Arbogast and John Mudrock, two retirees with gray mustaches, were camped out by the seventh green, putting together their lists of the two Ryder Cup teams and trying to match the Europeans with their nationalities.

headline: Nets Helped Clear Path for Builder in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Atlantic Yards (Brooklyn)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The purchase of the New Jersey Nets in 2004 gave Bruce C. Ratner the leverage he needed to pull off his Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, a real estate megadeal.
lead_paragraph: Bruce C. Ratner did not pretend to be much of a basketball fan when he paid $300 million in 2004 for the New Jersey Nets. Before long, the team had the worst record in the National Basketball Association, and he had a reputation as one of the worst owners in professional sports.

headline: With Swisher and Cano, It’s Trust and Symmetry
abstract: The right side of the Yankee infield, with Nick Swisher and Robinson Cano, came up big against the Twins, both in the field and at bat.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Robinson Cano and Nick Swisher crossed paths in the Yankees’ clubhouse after the game Wednesday afternoon, Swisher stylishly dressed in an open-collar white shirt, dark sport coat and aviator sunglasses, and Cano in a towel headed to his locker. They stopped and pantomimed a fist-bumping routine, which Cano finished with a playful fake punch to the top of Swisher’s head.

headline: Boy, 16, Charged in Killing of His Mother
abstract: The police declined to say why they believed that Darwin Jackson killed his mother, Tihesha Savage, whose body was found stuffed in a bin.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old Bronx boy was charged on Wednesday night with second-degree murder in the killing of his mother earlier in the day, the police said.

headline: Dodgers and Brewers Prevail to Pick Up a Game on St. Louis
abstract: Los Angeles beat the San Diego Padres, 8-2, and Milwaukee beat the Cincinnati Reds, 8-1, to move to three and a half games behind St. Louis in the wild-card race.
lead_paragraph: Only two weeks remain in the season, and the National League playoff race has come down to the second wild-card spot: Cincinnati and San Francisco have clinched their divisions, and Washington and Atlanta are assured of playoff berths. St. Louis has the upper hand for the wild-card berth, but the Dodgers and Milwaukee gained ground with victories Wednesday. Two others, Philadelphia and Arizona, have slim hopes of stealing that spot, but another fringe contender, Pittsburgh, was eliminated with a loss to the Mets.

headline: Liberty-Sun Playoff Has a Big East Feel
abstract: Five members of the Sun once played for UConn, while the Liberty have three former Rutgers players.
lead_paragraph: Before the Connecticut Sun played their first game, Teresa Weatherspoon, the Liberty’s point guard at the time, anointed the two teams as rivals.

headline: India Wins (While Pakistan Keeps Losing) in Fight Against Polio
abstract: Polio, which seems like it should be a disease from a bygone era, persists mainly now in just three countries — Pakistan, Afghanistan and Nigeria. The Taliban has been blocking vaccinations in Pakistan. India, meanwhile, has had no new cases of polio in more than a year.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — India and Pakistan compete — often angrily, and usually at full volume — in just about everything. Cricket. Nuclear weapons. They dispute a marshy creek that runs between their two countries. And they spend fortunes to bivouac military units on a glacier so high, cold and forbidding that it is sometimes called “the third pole.” That standoff at 22,000 feet has famously been likened to “a struggle of two bald men over a comb.”

headline: Four Sluggers Pose Threat to Cabrera’s Triple Crown
abstract: To achieve baseball’s triple crown, Miguel Cabrera will have to fend off four sluggers who could finish this season atop the home run leader board.
lead_paragraph: As Miguel Cabrera continues to pursue baseball’s first triple crown since 1967, most of the remaining uncertainty surrounds the home run title, as his leads in batting average and runs batted in appear fairly safe. Cabrera, the Tigers’ third baseman, is among a group of flawed yet powerful sluggers with a chance at finishing on top in homers.

headline: Word of the Day | engaging
abstract: This word has appeared in 891 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: engaging •\in-ˈga-jiN, en-\• adjective

headline: Autoworkers Reach Deal With Chrysler
abstract: Chrysler’s Canadian unit is the last of the Detroit automakers to agree on a tentative contract with the Canadian Auto Workers Union.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Completing its negotiations with the three Detroit automakers, the Canadian Auto Workers Union said on Wednesday night that it had a tentative agreement with Chrysler Canada.

headline: In Old Delhi, the Ancient Art of Kabootarbaazi (Pigeon Rearing) Lives On
abstract: Once used by Mughal rulers to communicate, pigeons are now raised for competition.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI–One of the winding alleys of the Chitli Qabar neighborhood in Old Delhi leads to a four-story, narrow white house, where several cats hungrily ply the stairs almost constantly.

headline: Darkness and Death, No Magic to Help
abstract: The bitter citizens of a small English town are the focus in “The Casual Vacancy,” J. K. Rowling’s new novel for adults.
lead_paragraph: With J. K. Rowling’s new novel, “The Casual Vacancy,” we are firmly in Muggle-land — about as far from the enchanted world of Harry Potter as we can get. There is no magic in this book — in terms of wizarding or in terms of narrative sorcery. Instead, this novel for adults is filled with a variety of people like Harry’s aunt and uncle, Petunia and Vernon Dursley: self-absorbed, small-minded, snobbish and judgmental folks, whose stories neither engage nor transport us.

headline: Relief and Resentment After N.F.L. Deal
abstract: Despite the satisfaction of a deal between the N.F.L. and it’s officials, coaches and players still feel the sting of replacement officials’ bad calls.
lead_paragraph: As the N.F.L. and its referees drew closer to a new labor agreement late Wednesday, reports flew across the Internet — each, it seemed, only slightly different from the last. The deal was done. Then it was not. Then it was close. Then it was really close. Then all it needed was a signature.

headline: Fighting for Idlib
abstract: Facing a foe with superior weapons and firepower, the Syrian rebels wage an impassioned and complex fight.
lead_paragraph: Facing a foe with superior weapons and firepower, the Syrian rebels wage an impassioned and complex fight.

headline: News Quiz | September 27, 2012
abstract: See what you know about the news of the day.
lead_paragraph: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Thursday, Sept. 27
abstract: News, fashion, arts and sports in today’s International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: NEWS After a period of relative calm, European markets shuddered once again on Wednesday as protests erupted across Greece and demonstrators surrounded the Spanish Parliament for a second day to protest the austerity program of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy. Liz Alderman and Niki Kitsantonis report from Athens.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Sept. 27, 2012
abstract: Can you choose the word pair that best completes the sentence?
lead_paragraph: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Discovery of Skeleton Puts Richard III in Battle Once Again.”

headline: A Conversation With: Tinkle Magazine Editor Rajani Thindiath
abstract: The popular children’s magazine recently published its 600th issue, and circulation is growing.
lead_paragraph: Tinkle, India’s first English-language comic book for children, published its 600th issue last month. Anant Pai, a former news executive known fondly to readers as Uncle Pai, introduced the magazine in April 1980.

headline: Going Viral With ‘Gangnam Style’
abstract: What is the viral hit “Gangnam Style” about, according to this short blog post?
lead_paragraph: Go to related blog post »

headline: Why Am I Going Gray?
abstract: The idea of hair “going gray” is a bit of a misnomer, as the only thing going anywhere is a pigment called melanin.
lead_paragraph: At the height of a presidential campaign, you have to take your nonpartisanship where you can get it, and so let’s cast our gaze not at the head of state but at the state of the head. There we will find that most democratic of processes, the graying of the hair, which recognizes neither party (see Clinton, Bill and Bush, Barbara) nor sex (see previous parentheses).

headline: The Mount Rushmore of Ricky Roma
abstract: Joe Mantegna, Al Pacino, Liev Schreiber and Bobby Cannavale talk about tackling the iconic character in ‘Glengarry Glen Ross.’
lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise that “Glengarry Glen Ross,” the 28-year-old Pulitzer winner by David Mamet, is returning to Broadway: what better time to remount a show about ruthless real estate agents off-loading bum property onto suckers as the nation claws its way out of a recession? At the play’s center is Ricky Roma — the salesman’s salesman, a shark in a sharkskin suit. There have been three legendary takes on the role: Joe Mantegna, who originated it on Broadway in 1984 (and won a Tony); Al Pacino in the 1992 film (Oscar nomination); and Liev Schreiber, in the 2005 revival (also won a Tony). Next up: Bobby Cannavale, who’ll play Roma opposite Pacino in a new Broadway production this fall. (No pressure.) In interviews conducted by phone or e-mail (and edited and condensed), Mickey Rapkin consulted each of them about inhabiting Roma — and walking in one another’s loafers.

headline: Alicia Keys Goes From Spark to Fire
abstract: How the “Girl on Fire” turned a tossed-off phrase into a song.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Keys got the spark for the title track of her new album at a very meta-moment: while reading about herself. “It came from this interview that I did, and the woman wrote something like, ‘She’s like a girl on fire,’ ” Keys said recently at her studio. “And I was like: I love that. And I remember thinking, I’m writing a song called ‘Girl on Fire’ for sure.”

headline: Desaparecidos Makes the Perfect Protest Music (Again)
abstract: A decade-dormant punk band awakens.
lead_paragraph: The perfect protest album for 2012 happens to have been released 10 years ago by Desaparecidos, a band named after the dissenters who “disappeared” under Pinochet and other Latin American dictators. Desaparecidos was formed by Conor Oberst (more recently of Bright Eyes) and four friends from the Omaha music scene, and their only record, “Read Music/Speak Spanish,” catalogs the ills of modern America, including the failure of exurban expansion (“Greater Omaha”) and the warping influence of consumerism (“Mall of America”). It also eerily presaged the specter of drone warfare (“The Happiest Place on Earth”).

headline: The Inspiration Issue
abstract: The creation stories behind the best movies, books, TV shows, music and plays on the horizon, featuring Alicia Keys, Michael Chabon, Quentin Tarantino, Al Pacino, Junot Díaz, Carrie Brownstein, Carly Rae Jepsen, Debra Winger, Patti LuPone and (a lot) more.
lead_paragraph: The creation stories behind the best movies, books, TV shows, music and plays on the horizon, featuring Alicia Keys, Michael Chabon, Quentin Tarantino, Al Pacino, Junot Díaz, Carrie Brownstein, Carly Rae Jepsen, Debra Winger, Patti LuPone and (a lot) more.

headline: Great Moments in Inspiration
abstract: Chinua Achebe, Ken Burns, Carrie Brownstein, Lupe Fiasco and more.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Bourdain Chef/Author, “Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly”“It was as a young man entering my teenage years, picking up Rolling Stone magazine and reading the first Hunter Thompson article of what would later become ‘Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.’ For me, that was an electrifying moment that changed how I looked at the world. When you’re an insecure, reasonably neurotic, postpubescent young man entering high school, the Thompson character was a comforting one. But I think in the end Thompson was also an important cautionary tale, because when I finally did have success with a book, I had only to look at my original hero to see the perils of playing the part. He was stuck playing the Raoul Duke character for the rest of his life.”

headline: Debra Winger and Patti LuPone Meet Their Matches
abstract: The stars of ‘The Anarchist’ on knowing when to say ‘yes.’
lead_paragraph: David Mamet’s new play, “The Anarchist,” coming to Broadway this fall, is the story of a prisoner (Patti LuPone) and her parole adviser (Debra Winger). Here the two leads talk about saying yes, saying no and how to pretend you’ve been in prison most of your life.

headline: Gordon Parks: ‘A Lasting Love’
abstract: A new five-volume set from Steidl presents an unparalleled survey of Gordon Parks’s career, and just in time for his 100th birthday.
lead_paragraph: What can you know about Gordon Parks by looking at his photos? He was a sophisticated photographer and one of the most eloquent voices for the poor and oppressed in the middle part of the 20th century. He was a lover of beauty, particularly in women, and he knew how to tell a good story (both in photographs, film and in a conversation between friends). You can easily discern these things by looking at his work. If you can find the images.

headline: Fiscal Confrontation Undermines the U.S.
abstract: The continuing failure to address government debt, and the looming fiscal cliff, threaten the status of the dollar, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: O.J. Simpson, Racial Utopia and the Moment That Inspired My Novel
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: From Columbia, Md., to “Telegraph Avenue.”
lead_paragraph: “Telegraph Avenue” is set in Oakland and Berkeley, but it was born in Los Angeles, on Oct. 3, 1995, the day Judge Lance Ito unsealed the O. J. Simpson verdict and made it known to the world.

headline: Putting Words in Halle Berry’s Mouth
abstract: The author of ‘Cloud Atlas’ celebrates the strange process of seeing his novel turned into a film.
lead_paragraph: “So how does it feel?” is the question you hear when your book completes the long ascent from production purgatory to movieplex. Well, first there’s a primal kick: actors speak dialogue you wrote years ago, and all those nonexistent people are now real. They find flashes of humor or menace you never spotted, and soon all memory of how you imagined the character before the actor muscled in is gone.

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen Writes a Song You Can’t Escape
abstract: ‘Call Me Maybe’ and its many interpreters, from Katy Perry to Cookie Monster
lead_paragraph: Before February, few people outside Canada had ever heard of a “Canadian Idol” runner-up named Carly Rae Jepsen. Then Justin Bieber filmed a homemade video to her song “Call Me Maybe,” which went viral and turned the song into the biggest hit of the summer. (Jepsen’s own rendition has received 260 million YouTube hits.) Here, the 26-year-old reflects on how it started.

headline: Mickalene Thomas Rediscovers Her Mother — and Her Muse
abstract: The Brooklyn-based artist faced a personal tragedy and found beauty.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based artist Mickalene Thomas has often used her mother, Sandra Bush, a former fashion model, as a muse going all the way back to the work she made as a Yale M.F.A. student a decade ago. Mama Bush, as her mother is known, has stood in for everything from a 1970s diva to a nude odalisque in some of Thomas’s exuberant, rhinestone-encrusted collage-paintings; in the 2009 video piece “Ain’t I a Woman (Sandra),” Bush vamps to Eartha Kitt in a bold red-and-black sweater with big shoulder pads.

headline: Emma Straub Becomes a Movie Star
abstract: A Brooklyn novelist inhabits a Hollywood diva after stumbling on an obit.
lead_paragraph: In December 2009, Emma Straub came across The New York Times’s obituary for Jennifer Jones, a film star from the 1940s and ’50s who was known for her rocky relationships and her struggles with depression. “I had never heard of her, and I had never seen any of her movies, but I read it and I was like, ‘There’s a novel,’ ” Straub says. She was working on another book idea, but she was haunted by Jones’s story. “I just kept coming back to the idea of this woman’s life. This woman who made the decision to become a movie star.”

headline: The Spy Behind ‘Argo’ Out-Hollywoods Hollywood
abstract: How the CIA’s creation of a fake movie inspired a real one.
lead_paragraph: “The idea came from desperation,” says Tony Mendez, a retired C.I.A. officer and the real-life inspiration for the character played by Ben Affleck in the coming movie “Argo.” As the head of the C.I.A.’s deceptively boring-sounding Graphics and Authentication Division, Mendez was responsible for foreign agents and their cover stories — which is why he was called upon in 1979 to construct a plan to evacuate six U.S. diplomats hiding at the Tehran homes of two Canadian diplomats.

headline: Quentin Tarantino Tackles Old Dixie by Way of the Old West (by Way of Italy)
abstract: Bringing bleak spaghetti westerns to a drama of the antebellum South.
lead_paragraph: This year, Quentin Tarantino’s Christmas present to the world is “Django Unchained,” the violent story of a slave (Jamie Foxx) on a mission to free his wife (Kerry Washington) from the plantation of the man who owns her (Leonardo DiCaprio). Tarantino’s biggest influences for the film, he says, were not movies about American slavery but the spaghetti westerns of the Italian director Sergio Corbucci. Here Tarantino explains how Corbucci’s movies — including “Django,” which lent its name to Tarantino’s title character — became the inspiration for his own spaghetti southern. (Interview by Gavin Edwards.)

headline: One Room. Four Walls. A Million Ideas. How?
abstract: Inside the writers’ rooms of ‘The Daily Show,’ ‘General Hospital,’ ‘Family Guy’ and ‘The Walking Dead.’
lead_paragraph: Inside the writers’ rooms of ‘The Daily Show,’ ‘General Hospital,’ ‘Family Guy’ and ‘The Walking Dead.’

headline: What Inspires Junot Díaz?
abstract: Artifacts that the writer keeps handy to defeat all the little hobgoblins that try to drive him crazy every time he sits down to write.
lead_paragraph: Artifacts that the writer keeps handy to defeat all the little hobgoblins that try to drive him crazy every time he sits down to write.

headline: Dressing ‘The Tempest’
abstract: The costume designer Kym Barrett goes from ‘The Matrix’ to ‘The Tempest’ at the Met.
lead_paragraph: The costume designer Kym Barrett goes from ‘The Matrix’ to ‘The Tempest’ at the Met.

headline: Junot Díaz Hates Writing Short Stories
abstract: The writer has to be receptive to everything. Except his inner critic.
lead_paragraph: Every writer is cursed or blessed with a unique creative metabolism: the distinctive speed and efficiency with which he or she converts the raw fuel of life into the mystical, dancing blue smoke of art. Junot Díaz’s metabolism is notoriously slow. His fuel just sits there, and sits there, and maybe every once in a while gives off a tiny ribbon of damp smoke, until you start to worry that it all got rained on and ruined — and then, 5 or 10 years later, it suddenly explodes into one of the most mesmerizing fires anyone can remember.

headline: Late Night Laughs and Conspiracy Theories
abstract: “The Tonight Show” had its premiere and the Warren Commission wrapped up its investigation into the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 27 is the day “The Tonight Show” had its premiere and the Warren Commission wrapped up its investigation into the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: What Experiences Have You Had With Gender Bias in School?
abstract: Do you think girls are naturally better at some school subjects, and boys better at others? Have you had teachers who seemed to believe this?
lead_paragraph: Researchers have found that science professors at American universities widely regard female students as less competent than male students with the same accomplishments and skills, and as a result are less likely to offer them mentoring or jobs.

headline: Waterlogged Northeast on Road to Recovery
abstract: Road connections have been restored in some areas and floodwater is receding, officials say.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — The northeastern states of Sikkim and Assam, which have been  inundated with flash floods and landslides in the past week, have begun the long road to recovery, officials said Thursday.

headline: Labor Group Revives George Allen Gaffe in New Ad
abstract: A labor group backing George Allen’s opponent in Virginia is trying to revive the controversy over the word “macaca” by printing the word next to Mr. Allen’s picture in a new series of ads.
lead_paragraph: As George Allen battles to regain his seat in the United States Senate from Virginia, one important name has not been mentioned — until now.

headline: Guidance Office | Ask a Financial Aid Expert About Scholarships
abstract: Mark Kantrowitz, an expert on paying for college, will answer select reader questions about scholarships.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Mr. Kantrowitz is no longer taking questions.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ and Labor Group Team Up in Anti-Romney Radio Ad
abstract: The new ad from Priorities USA Action and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, plays some of the audio from a secretly taped video of Mitt Romney speaking about 47 percent of voters.
lead_paragraph: A Democratic “super PAC” is joining forces with a labor group to begin a $1.25 million radio ad campaign on Thursday that starts with a direct attack on Mitt Romney as an out-of-touch millionaire who has insulted nearly half of the country.

headline: What Will You Remember About the Replacement Era?
abstract: The era of the replacement officials is over, and now you wonder, Did it really happen? We’ve compiled video evidence.
lead_paragraph: It sometimes seemed to be one long bad call.

headline: Cerberus to Sell $2.5 Billion Stake in Japanese Bank
abstract: The private equity firm will start selling its $2.5 billion stake in Japan’s struggling Aozora Bank this year in a much-anticipated exit for Cerberus more than a decade after its initial investment.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management will start selling its $2.5 billion stake in Japan’s struggling Aozora Bank this year, the Asian lender said on Thursday, in a much-anticipated exit for the firm more than a decade after its initial investment.

headline: N.F.L. Week 4: Game Probabilities Are Back
abstract: Brian Burke is back with the game probabilities for the N.F.L. season, and he offers a primer on his system of prediction.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth season I’ve been invited to share my game probabilities with Fifth Down readers, so it might be time for a short refresher course.  The model I use to predict outcomes is based on team efficiency stats and home field advantage. The overall idea behind the model is to tune things to predict the future rather than explain the past. The distinction may seem subtle, but it’s the key to accuracy and understanding how the sport really works.

headline: Data Points to Further Gloom in Euro Zone
abstract: Confidence among European businesses and consumers continued to decline in September, the European Commission reported.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The outlook for the euro zone remained unsettled Thursday, as data showed that confidence among European businesses and consumers continued to fall in September.

headline: Q. and A.: Farming for an Uncertain Future
abstract: Wes Jackson, a co-founder of the Land Institute, reflects on population growth, resource depletion and the accumulation of carbon — and what it means for contemporary agriculture.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 40 years ago, while teaching environmental studies at California State University in Sacramento, Wes Jackson began reflecting that something about the country’s agricultural practices wasn’t quite right. Soon that instinct grew into a powerful itch.

headline: Painting, Rebooted
abstract: Wade Guyton, who creates art on computers, is the subject of a midcareer survey at the Whitney Museum.
lead_paragraph: THE artist Wade Guyton works on the edge of Chinatown in a commodious light-filled space with windows looking over the Bowery. One portion is dominated by desks with little on them but Macs. Nearby is the biggest printer Epson makes — a hulking Stylus Pro 11880 inkjet. There is no smell of turpentine, no haphazard array of easels, no cans of paint or stacks of used canvases. In fact, there are none of the things one would expect in a painter’s studio. Instead all the creating is executed on computer screens and printers.

headline: Tip of the Week: Checking the Mail Service
abstract: Think your Web mail service might be down? Here’s how to check on it.
lead_paragraph: Web-based mail services like Google’s Gmail or Microsoft Hotmail/Outlook.com can keep you up to date with e-mail and online calendar services wherever you can get an Internet connection. These sites may have occasional technical trouble that can prevent you from getting your messages. If your mailbox seems suspiciously quiet for a period of time, you may want to check the status of your mail service to make sure it is up and running.

headline: Taming the High-Speed Traders
abstract: High-frequency trading, which dominates the market in the United States, is getting more oversight abroad. | Expectations are low as Research in Motion, maker of the BlackBerry, gets ready to report its quarterly results. | The biggest Democratic Super PAC donor is James H. Simons, the billionaire hedge fund quant and onetime math professor. | The negotiations between Glencore and Xstrata are centering on the question of who will run the new company.
lead_paragraph: Taming the High-Speed Traders  |  High-frequency trading, which dominates the market in the United States, and has been associated with some high-profile problems in this country, is getting more oversight abroad, in places like Germany, Australia and Canada. As Nathaniel Popper of The New York Times puts it, “countries around the globe are now using America as a model for what they don’t want to look like.” Our own Securities and Exchange Commission, though, is taking a look at how high-speed trading glitches are handled, according to The Wall Street Journal. (On Tuesday, the S.E.C. is hosting a meeting in Washington to talk about ways to limit problems.)

headline: Notes On Internal Devaluation (Wonkish)
abstract: What a Keynesian perspective really says.
lead_paragraph: Still in jet-lag city. Talking to people, and also reading what comes across the threshold, it occurs to me that there’s widespread misunderstanding of what a more or less Keynesian view of Europe’s problems actually implies. People seem to think that it means that (a) internal devaluation can never work (b) any sign of recovery, even a partial rebound, proves Keynes/Krugman wrong (this is a critical part of Baltic boosterism, where the partial recovery of Latvia and Estonia is supposed to be some kind of incredible triumph).

headline: France and Britain Weigh the Price of Nuclear Deterrence
abstract: Britain and France are second-ranking powers that “punch above their weight,” in part because they have nuclear weapons. But some would like to cut the cost of this ticket to the top table without jeopardizing their world power status at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There were reports on Thursday of stirrings within the British military about the need to scale back the country’s nuclear deterrent in order to spend the money on confronting more conventional threats.

headline: U.N. Says Syrian Refugee Numbers Are Surging

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The number of Syrians fleeing to neighboring countries for safety and aid is likely to exceed 700,000 by the end of the year, according to the United Nations and humanitarian agencies that are struggling to keep pace with the surge in numbers in recent weeks.

headline: The Challenger
abstract: Two weeks out, polls show Henrique Capriles is in a dead-heat with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela. Can Capriles pull off an upset?
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Even on TV, the energy of the crowd comes through. The opposition candidate Henrique Capriles Radonski is ripping into his stump speech, and the townspeople in the city of Maturin, in Eastern Venezuela, are eating it up: “Today,” he bellows, “I want you to think about your problems, and think: Has the government brought solutions to your problems?!”  The crowd shouts back: “Nooooo!”

The average official’s salary will rise to $173,000 in 2013 from $149,000 in 2011.

headline: Up Front

lead_paragraph: In this week’s Book Review, Mark Lilla considers Charles R. Kesler’s “I Am the Change: Barack Obama and the Crisis of Liberalism.” In a recent e-mail interview, he talked about America’s current political landscape and discussed why grappling with the “new nature of capitalism” is the most pressing intellectual and political task facing us:

headline: The Great Disconnect
abstract: Charles R. Kesler’s book so exaggerates the historical significance of Barack Obama that he becomes both Alien and Predator.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time there was a radical president who tried to remake American society through government action. In his first term he created a vast network of federal grants to state and local governments for social programs that cost billions. He set up an imposing agency to regulate air and water emissions, and another to regulate workers’ health and safety. Had Congress not stood in his way he would have gone much further. He tried to establish a guaranteed minimum income for all working families and, to top it off, proposed a national health plan that would have provided government insurance for low-income families, required employers to cover all their workers and set standards for private insurance. Thankfully for the country, his second term was cut short and his collectivist dreams were never realized.

headline: Shades of Yesterday: New Vinyl Versions of Beatles’ Albums on the Way
abstract: Stereo versions will be released on Nov. 13, with mono versions coming next year.
lead_paragraph: Though EMI put considerable effort into both the sound and packaging of the remastered Beatles catalog in 2009, and then staked out a new market with its iTunes downloads in 2010, many fans of the group have argued that such newfangled ways of hearing the band are inauthentic – that the experience just isn’t the same on anything but vinyl, the format on which the albums were originally released.

headline: A Win-Win for Paul Allen’s Seahawks and a Sports Start-Up
abstract: SportStream, which counts Paul Allen, the billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, among its investors, is taming social media to make it more useful for sports fans. A game involving Mr. Allen’s Seattle Seahawks provided a good illustration of how it works.
lead_paragraph: Paul Allen was among the minority of people who seemed to feel pretty good on Monday night after a blown call by referees awarded a game-winning touchdown to the Seattle Seahawks, the NFL team Mr. Allen owns. Twitter erupted in disbelief and outrage after the win, but Mr. Allen called it an “amazing game.”

headline: Show and Tell
abstract: Call it Decorating 2.0: a new interior design book comes with an app.
lead_paragraph: “Times change,” says Carey Maloney, a partner in the New York design firm M (Group). And decorating books, he says, should change with them. Maloney and his partner, the architect Hermes Mallea, design houses and apartments for clients who collect Modiglianis and Roman sculpture, but for the first book on their work, the last thing they wanted was a standard coffee-table monograph, full of beautiful but static photographs and clichéd pronouncements like “Keep your silver polished.” And since the things in rooms, whether museum-quality or flea-market finds, are what fascinate Maloney and Mallea the most, the resulting book is called “Stuff: The M (Group) Interactive Guide to Collecting, Decorating With, and Learning About, Wonderful and Unusual Things” (Pointed Leaf Press, $65). While there are plenty of photographs of the firm’s work, they’re shown in the context of the book’s 40 collecting topics, each of which has its own “file folder” page. For example, the page for collecting maps, above, is followed by the photo, top, of a bedroom that is decorated with maps. And since Maloney felt strongly that the book had to have a digital component — “It was important that it look like 2012, not 2010,” he emphasizes — the topics pages have Digimarc watermarks. A free app can scan the topics pages and take readers to links on a wide and quirky range of resources — which, for maps, includes links not just to high-end dealers but also to a Web page on map tattoos.

headline: More Jobs Than We Knew
abstract: An additional 386,000 jobs were created between April 2011 and March 2012, representing a 20 percent increase over previous estimates, the government says.

headline: Leading Off: N.F.L. Undervalued Competence, Paid in Integrity
abstract: In time, the outrage over the replacement referees will fade, but for now, people shouldn’t forget the N.F.L.’s failures.
lead_paragraph: Now that the N.F.L. has been successfully tarred and feathered and forced to admit its referee lockout was an unmitigated disaster — well, O.K., the league will not admit that, but you can read it in the egg yolk dripping down the facade — there are a few things to take away from the entire debacle. Yes, the league is every bit as arrogant and heavy handed as any big corporation that feels it has no one to answer to, and it deserves all scorn shoveled its way. And yes, fans can congratulate themselves for mustering the outrage to howl the league to its senses.

headline: 36 Hours in Dubrovnik, Croatia
abstract: With its medieval Old Town and bird’s-eye views of the Adriatic, Dubrovnik is no longer anyone’s best-kept secret.
lead_paragraph: FIRST, the bad news: Dubrovnik is no longer anyone’s best-kept secret. Some 17 years after the end of Croatia’s war of independence, the city’s medieval walled Old Town is gridlocked with tourists during the summer. Yet go in the fall and you’ll quickly see what the fuss is about. Jutting out on a peninsular chunk of the Dalmatian coastline, the former Republic of Ragusa is a Venetian Gothic marvel. Columned porticoes and loggias rim marble-paved Renaissance squares buffed to a sheen by centuries of foot traffic. Yes, many businesses unabashedly cater to cruise ship passengers and other mainstream tourists, but there are plenty of creative local standouts.

And one can’t help but wonder if this is in some reference to Baumbach’s relationship with his real-life paramour, Greta Gerwig, who stars as the titular character and who is increasingly becoming the go-to actress for offbeat, likeable female roles (“Damsels in Distress,” “Greenberg“).

headline: Standard Chartered’s Next Worry: A $1 Billion Indonesian Loan
abstract: The British bank, which agreed last month to pay the New York State’s top banking regulator $340 million to settle money-laundering allegations, may be at risk of losing money on a $1 billion loan to an Indonesian mining company to make an investment that has since soured.
lead_paragraph: Standard Chartered is facing another potential headache.

headline: Not The Election They Were Expecting
abstract: Guess who’s enthusiastic.
lead_paragraph: A brief, mostly subjective note: This really isn’t looking like the election anyone expected. Obviously it’s not the election Romney and the Republicans expected and wanted; but it’s also looking very different from what Democrats expected.

headline: Barclays Arena Rivals the Garden’s Glow
abstract: Big-name performers are adding tour dates at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, where costs can be lower and profit margins higher than at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Jay-Z takes the stage on Friday night at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, it will be more than the triumphant homecoming of a native son, performing eight sold-out nights in a sparkling new arena near the housing project where he grew up. It is also the official opening of an 18,000-seat performance space that will fundamentally transform the music scene in New York City.

headline: Video: A Classic Thai Basil Daiquiri (Just Add Liquid Nitrogen)
abstract: Dave Arnold, the director of culinary technology at the International Culinary Center, makes a molecular gastronomy version of a classic Thai basil daiquiri.
lead_paragraph: Wondering how to keep the Thai basil in your daiquiri from turning black? Just splash it with a frosty puff of liquid nitrogen.

headline: Gala Girl
abstract: My job was a whirlwind of cold calls and symphonies.
lead_paragraph: The summer after I graduated from college, I moved to New York for a fund-raising job with an institution I soon learned to call “the world’s leading performing arts center.” I was a fiction and art history major but during my interview, the director of major gifts asked the only question that really mattered: “Are you comfortable speaking on the telephone?”

headline: Israeli Foreign Ministry Calls for More Sanctions on Iran
abstract: A leaked report appears to be a rare Israeli acknowledgment that there might be time to halt the Iranian nuclear program without military action.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An internal report prepared by Israel’s Foreign Ministry calls for an additional round of international sanctions against Iran, an Israeli official confirmed on Thursday, in what appeared to be a rare Israeli acknowledgment that there might still be time to try to stop the Iranian nuclear program by means other than military action.

headline: An Outbreak of Sportsmanship in Italy
abstract: In a game in Italy’s Serie A on Wednesday, the German striker Miroslav Klose performed a supreme act of sportsmanship.
lead_paragraph: It took Lazio’s German striker Miroslav Klose fewer than four minutes to show some class in Wednesday’s Serie A game at Napoli in Italy.

headline: Atlanta and Chicago Orchestras Settle Labor Disputes
abstract: Musicians and management at the Atlanta Symphony and the Chicago Symphony approve new contracts.
lead_paragraph: The musicians of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and their management have reached agreement on a two-year contract, and the board of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra has signed off on a new pact, already ratified by the orchestra, ending two labor disputes in the classical music world.

abstract: A preview from the film starring Tom Hanks and Halle Berry, adapted from the novel by David Mitchell.
lead_paragraph: A preview from the film starring Tom Hanks and Halle Berry, adapted from the novel by David Mitchell.

headline: New York Lags Behind Other Cities in College Graduation Rate
abstract: New York City is sixth among the 10 biggest cities in America in the percentage of residents with college degrees, according to a report by the comptroller’s office.
lead_paragraph: College graduation rates in New York City are so low that more of the city’s residents who have college degrees were born abroad than in New York, a report released on Thursday shows.

headline: The New Season: Opera-Hopping Around Europe
abstract: The opera calendar in Europe this autumn holds plenty of temptations. Here are a handful of notable productions.
lead_paragraph: As with all the arts, the new opera season is gathering steam across Europe. Here, for music-loving travelers, are some of the productions on the calendar that have caught my fancy, in chronological order.

headline: Iranian Diplomat Harassed in New York
abstract: A spokesman for Iran’s foreign ministry was harassed by a small group of protesters near the United Nations on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 4:18 p.m. A spokesman for Iran’s foreign ministry was harassed by a small group of protesters near the United Nations in New York on Wednesday, after an address to the international body by the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

headline: Mixed-Race America
abstract: The population of mixed-race Americans grew by 32 percent from 2000 to 2010.
lead_paragraph: That map is from a new Census Bureau report about the population of mixed-race Americans, which grew 32 percent from 2000 to 2010. The population of single-race Americans, by contrast, grew 9.2 percent.

headline: George and Martha, 50 Years Together
abstract: Theater notables who saw the 1962 production of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” share their recollections, reservations and realizations.
lead_paragraph: IT may be 2 a.m. when George and Martha stumble home at the beginning of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,” but the evening is just getting started. Fueled by a bathtub’s worth of alcohol and culminating in the surfacing of some very ugly truths, Edward Albee’s faculty-mixer-as-blood-sport drama riveted audiences in October 1962 and vaulted the 34-year-old playwright from Off Broadway darling to the cover of Newsweek magazine.

headline: Rarely Seen Rolling Stones Film Resurfacing in Expanded Form
abstract: A 1965 film, “Charlie Is My Darling,” has been expanded, along with its title.
lead_paragraph: With “Crossfire Hurricane” about to offer an expansive view of the Rolling Stones’ 50-year history when it opens at the London Film Festival on Oct. 18, a more fine-grain look at an important moment in the group’s early history – the rarely seen 1965 film “Charlie Is My Darling” – is about to have a handful of screenings and a DVD release.

headline: Emancipation in Indiana
abstract: Most people in the Hoosier State didn’t take kindly to Lincoln’s new stand on slavery.
lead_paragraph: Indiana was a free Union state, but one with strong pro-slavery sentiments. The editorial reactions of Indiana Democratic newspapers to President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation were predictably hostile. The Huntington Democrat, a northern Indiana weekly paper, lashed out in indignation at the president’s capitulation to abolitionist pressure. The proclamation would prompt the South’s “servile population” of “savage negros” to rise up in “insurrection, rapine, murder, arson, and what not,” the paper predicted.

headline: Camera+, a Top-Selling iPhone App, Expands to iPad
abstract: Camera+, an iPhone app that has been a top seller in the App Store for years, expanded to the iPad on Thursday. Not many people shoot photos with an iPad, but the core features of the app are its editing suite and integration of Apple’s iCloud online storage service. The company also released an update for the iPhone version of the camera app to include cloud synchronization, so photos taken on an iPhone will also appear in the iPad app.
lead_paragraph: Camera+, an iPhone camera app that has been a top seller in the App Store for years, expanded to the iPad on Thursday. Not many people shoot photos with an iPad, but the core features of the app are its editing suite and integration of Apple’s iCloud online storage service. The company also released an update for the iPhone version of the camera app to include cloud synchronization, so that photos taken on an iPhone will also appear in the iPad app.

headline: M.T.A. Chief, in Public Clash, Calls Board Member a Liar
abstract: The comment by the chairman, Joseph J. Lhota, to Charles G. Moerdler came during a discussion over a proposal to change the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s meeting calendar.
lead_paragraph: He has assailed state officials, the cast of “Jersey Shore” and, as the so-called rat czar under MayorRudolph W. Giuliani, the city’s outsize vermin population.

headline: Volkswagen Introduces the Golf Triumvirate
abstract: The seventh generation of the compact hatchback was formally unveiled on Thursday along with BlueMotion and GTI variants that were introduced as concepts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Pop quiz: What is the highest-selling Volkswagen model of all time? If you guessed the Beetle, you would be wrong by about 8 million cars.

headline: It’s Time to Talk About What Troops Leave Unsaid
abstract: Sometimes we think it’s better to linger in silence, hoping that our problems will go away. But when we don’t talk about our problems, they get worse. And we get worse, too.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes we think it’s better to linger in silence, hoping that our problems will go away.

headline: Chilling Out in Northern Michigan
abstract: With the summer crowd gone, the bar at Trattoria Stella in Traverse City, Mich., is a place for an idyllic afternoon of quiet, calm and good drinks.
lead_paragraph: What you often want on a vacation is a sense of discovery. It can be as challenging as a Class IV rapid on the middle fork of the Salmon River, or as simple as a glass of wine in a welcoming bar where both the music and the lights are low.

headline: Rapid Transit Indeed: Rafting Six Continents

lead_paragraph: There are white-water rafting trips and then there are white-water rafting voyages. Mountain Travel Sobek offers the latter: a 25-day, six-continent journey along nine rivers with class III through V rapids.

headline: The Get | Pamela Love for Nine West Boots
abstract: Pamela Love applies her signature jewelry motifs to classic motorcycle boots.
lead_paragraph: When the jewelry designer Pamela Love set out to design shoes for the first time, in a three-piece collection for Nine West, she took inspiration from the grungy clothes worn by Royal Trux rocker Jennifer Herrema; the classic motorcycle boots made by Harley Davidson and Yves Saint Laurent; and the raffish hippie look, as seen in movies like “Easy Rider” and “Midnight Cowboy.” “When I think of the Pamela Love girl, she’s probably not wearing six-inch heels or strappy sandals,” Love says. “She’s sort of tough, sort of fashion-forward, sort of practical. She wants a pair of shoes that she can wear to death and beat to the ground.”

headline: New Theater Award at Columbia to Honor Kennedy
abstract: The $100,000 award, recognizing a play or musical inspired by American history, is being established at Columbia University in honor of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: A $100,000 theater award, recognizing a play or musical inspired by American history, is being established at Columbia University in honor of the Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the university and one of Mr. Kennedy’s sisters, Jean Kennedy Smith, announced on Thursday.

headline: A Cancer Patient’s Best Friend
abstract: I’m always being prescribed medicine, but I never thought I’d get a prescription for a puppy.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my dream was to one day become a veterinarian. In fourth and fifth grade, I volunteered every day after school at a veterinarian’s clinic. I didn’t view it as an “internship” — in my mind, I was apprenticing for a certain future in the field. When I was 10, I asked for an incubator for Christmas. By spring, I was carting around a dozen baby chicks in my purple doll stroller. In middle school I walked dogs at the local animal shelter. But as I got older, there was college, summer travel, then my first real job, at a law firm in France. I was entering the “real world,” as they say in commencement speeches. And there was no room in my adult life for a dog.

headline: Mutually Assured Donations
abstract: Democrats are getting in on the super PAC game.
lead_paragraph: After months of watching super-rich Republicans open their checkbooks to super PACs, which pretend to be independent groups to get around limits on political donations, Democrats are finally seeing some of their own supporters anteing up.

headline: The New Arena Is a Whale. Or Is It a Tire? Perhaps a Turtle?
abstract: Last week’s question “What does the brand-new Barclays Center look like?” led to a slew of submissions from City Room readers. Here are some of our favorites.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s deceptively simple question “What does the brand-new Barclays Center look like?” unleashed a tsunami of tragicomic visions from the depths of the City Room readership’s collective unconscious.

headline: By the Book: Michael Chabon
abstract: The author of “Telegraph Avenue” and his wife, Ayelet Waldman, rarely read the same books. “She reads everything . . . and I read the same books over and over again.”
lead_paragraph: The author of "Telegraph Avenue" and his wife, Ayelet Waldman, rarely read the same books. “She reads everything . . . and I read the same books over and over again.”

headline: September, November: 40 Precious Days to Spend on Early Vote
abstract: A stream of voters arrived at election offices across Iowa to cast their ballots, and waves of absentee ballots have started landing in mailboxes in 30 other states.
lead_paragraph: 1:21 a.m. | Updated DES MOINES — A stream of voters arrived at election offices across Iowa to cast their ballots. Waves of absentee ballots have started landing in mailboxes in 30 other states. And more than a month before what the calendar says is Election Day, President Obama began delivering his closing argument to voters.

headline: Seeing Things | RTH
abstract: In West Hollywood, a gem of a shop that’s a mix of trading post, curio store, and fashion boutique.
lead_paragraph: Tucked inside a tiny brick cottage on La Cienega Boulevard in West Hollywood, Calif., RTH is a gem of a shop that’s a mix of trading post, curio store and fashion boutique. It is an anomaly on its block, sandwiched between a skin care salon and an Oriental rug dealer. Blink, and you might miss it.

headline: Ideas for English Language Learners | Election 2012
abstract: Another in our monthly “Ideas for E.L.L.’s series, this one listing ways to use Times articles, video and interactives to teach about the race to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Research shows a critical quality of an engaging lesson is relevance to student lives. With an election focused on issues like jobs, health care, education and immigration — all deeply important to the lives of E.L.L. students — we asked our expert, Larry Ferlazzo, to devote this month’s installment of “Ideas for E.L.L.s” to Election, 2012, only 40 days away.

lead_paragraph: Lynn Zinser, who writes the Leading Off column and covers sports for The Times, appeared on “CBS This Morning” on Thursday to discuss the N.F.L.’s labor deal with the referees.

headline: What Makes Google’s Maps So Good
abstract: Nobody ever raved about Google’s mapping app for phones until they saw how hard it was for Apple to come up with a rival. Conversations with executives at Google make clear that the company’s maps represent years and years of hand-tuning and manual effort.

headline: It Must Be the Polls
abstract: President Obama’s leading in the polls. But the Romney campaign says the polls are all wrong.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every national poll shows President Obama leading Mitt Romney. Gallup, Ipsos and Bloomberg all have the president up by six points. The RAND Corporation puts Mr. Obama up by seven and a half. Only Rasmussen has Mr. Romney up nationally among likely voters, by two points. Swing state surveys also give Mr. Obama the advantage, with new polls from The New York Times, CBS and Quinnipiac showing Mr. Obama up between 9 and 11 points in Florida, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

headline: The 47 Percent Here?  Far Fewer Escape City’s Income Tax
abstract: A city analysis found that for 2010, about one-third of the New York households that filed tax returns paid nothing in city income tax.

abstract: A billionaire financier may be getting over his qualms about giving to outside groups.
lead_paragraph: 10:28 p.m. | Updated The billionaire George Soros is committing $1 million to Priorities USA Action, the “super PAC” supporting President Obama, two people with knowledge of the matter said Thursday, a significant donation that could help spur more contributions in the closing weeks of the election campaign.

headline: Sudan and South Sudan Sign Accord, but Several Issues Are Unresolved
keywords: ['International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The presidents of Sudan and South Sudan signed a long-awaited cooperation agreement Thursday, paving the way for the much-needed resumption of oil exports. But analysts said the deal came up short.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — The presidents of Sudan and South Sudan signed a long-awaited cooperation agreement on Thursday, paving the way for the resumption of oil exports and casting their ailing economies a desperately needed lifeline. But several analysts said the deal came up far short.

headline: Seat León: An Exercise in Dressing Up a Golf
abstract: Marketed primarily in Spanish-language markets, the redesigned León shares systems — and surprisingly, fit and finish — with its stablemate, the Volkswagen Golf.

headline: Longer Unemployment, Fewer Interviews
abstract: A study finds that a job applicant’s chances of obtaining an interview fall sharply between the first month of unemployment and the eighth, and then they level out.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written before about about how the longer you’re unemployed, the less likely you are to find a job. That’s probably because of some combination of several factors: skill deterioration; better workers are more likely to get hired faster, leaving a pool of less qualified workers as the ones who disproportionately make it to long-term unemployment in the first place; and the stigma of unemployment, or at least the assumption by employers that the longer-term unemployed will be lower quality because of the previous two factors.

headline: McLaren Reveals a Breathtaking Supercar, and Little Else
abstract: Few specifics were shared at the highly anticipated unveiling of the P1 concept, an heir to the legacy of the F1 hypercar.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two years ago, Lotus made a rather large and unexpected splash here by introducing six new models that promised to transform the niche sports-car producer into a global contender. Most of those plans have come to grief, as the company’s chief executive was sacked and the company canceled its display at the biennial Paris salon.

headline: European Automakers Face a Stunted Future
abstract: Even if auto sales recover slightly in 2013, the optimistic view at the Paris Motor Show on Thursday was that it could be years before the market returns to levels seen before the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The optimistic view at the Paris Motor Show on Thursday was that auto sales were so bad that they could not possibly get any worse.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Temperature on the ‘Beach’
abstract: What is it like to perform under the direction of Robert Wilson? An actor shares the experience of “Einstein on the Beach” with Charles Isherwood.
lead_paragraph: I emerged from the final performance of “Einstein on the Beach” on Sunday exhilarated and exhausted, elated and with a distinct feeling of relief. The four and a half hours spent in contemplation of this elusive but entrancing opera was without question among the most memorable theatrical experiences I’ve had in the past few years.

headline: ANDRA URSUTA: ‘Magical Terrorism’

lead_paragraph: Scientists hope that luring bats to an artificial bunker near Clarksville, Tenn., will help them find a cure for white nose syndrome, which has killed five million bats.

headline: Part 4: Answers From Princeton’s Dean of Admission
abstract: Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, lends her expertise about college admissions by answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice. Part 4.
lead_paragraph: This week The Choice has invited Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer your questions about college admissions. Ms. Rapelye, who received a bachelor’s degree from Williams College and a master’s degree from Stanford University, has 30 years’ experience in college admissions.

headline: Dickey Wins 20th Game for the Mets
abstract: The Mets’ bullpen survived a two-run ninth inning and eventually saved R. A. Dickey’s win, making him the first Mets pitcher since Frank Viola in 1990 to win 20 games.
lead_paragraph: He is baseball’s most unlikely star — a 37-year-old reclamation project who throws the only knuckleball in the majors, speaks more like a professor than an athlete, wins game after game on a bad team and has increasingly turned his career into an American sports fable.

headline: The Media Bias That Matters
abstract: How the press’s horse race fixation may be delivering the election to Obama.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a post dismissing conservative paranoia about the polls showing the president pulling away, Jonathan Chait makes an important argument-against-interest:

headline: When Sex Is Better Said Than Seen
abstract: In the comedy “Vulgaria” the Hong Kong filmmaker Pang Ho-Cheung would rather talk about sex than show it.

headline: Marlins Giving Player His First At-Bat, Seven Years Later
abstract: The first pitch to Adam Greenberg in his major league career, in 2005, hit him below his ear. Miami has signed him to a one-day contract and he is expected to bat next week against the Mets.
lead_paragraph: It is the fundamental rule of baseball: everybody gets a turn. Even the greatest hitters come to bat only one time through the order. When the manager calls your name, you get a chance to stand in the box, stare down the pitcher and do something.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Money Market Accounts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner on Thursday urged the Financial Stability Oversight Council, a special committee of senior regulators that he leads, to push ahead with rules aimed at strengthening America’s money market funds.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner on Thursday urged the regulatory team that he leads to push ahead with new rules aimed at money market funds, which manage $2.6 trillion.

headline: Not in Script for Kremlin: A Real Race for Governor
abstract: The Russian region of Ryazan seemed primed for a real race until an insurgent candidate was removed from the race.
lead_paragraph: RYAZAN, Russia — A funny thing happened during the elections this fall for governor in the Russian region of Ryazan: for a few weeks, no one knew who would win.

headline: Looking for Love and Total Emancipation
abstract: Shari Berman’s dramedy “My Life as Abraham Lincoln” struggles to sort out many things about her past, including flashbacks of being assassinated as Lincoln in a school play.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: BlackBerry Maker Posts a Narrower Loss, and Stock Jumps in After-Hours Trading
abstract: Research in Motion said its net loss for the latest quarter was $235 million, a comedown from a year ago but an improvement on the previous quarter. Its shares surged after hours.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Research in Motion, the troubled manufacturer of the once-dominant BlackBerry smartphone, reported another sizable quarterly loss on Thursday, but a smaller one than the previous quarter. However, the company continues to face a difficult future as it struggles to get a new phone out the door.

headline: A Bipartisan Vote Against European Air Fees
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Just before dashing out of town, Senate Republicans and Democrats voted to defy European emission fees imposed on American carriers.
lead_paragraph: Approved unanimously on Saturday before Congress adjourned for a fall campaign hiatus, the Senate bill drew relatively little attention. It was the “European Union Emissions Trading Scheme Prohibition Act of 2011,” the latest attempt to exempt American airlines from paying fees imposed by the European Union to cover the greenhouse gases their planes emit while flying to and from European airports.

headline: A Spice Treatment for Lamb Chops
abstract: There is no finer partner for Bordeaux than lamb, even if the lamb was not pastured in Pauillac.
lead_paragraph: Bordeaux is usually in the glass, not the recipe. Except for lamb. There is no finer partner for a good wine from the region, even if the lamb was not pastured in Pauillac.

headline: Occupy Wall Street: A View From the Inside
abstract: “American Autumn: An Occudoc” offers a review of the protests that first encamped in Zuccotti Park then swept across the nation and around the world.

abstract: Following earlier pressure from hedge fund manager John A. Paulson, Hartford Financial Services Group sells its individual life insurance business for $615 million in cash.
lead_paragraph: Prudential Financial has agreed to acquire the individual life insurance business of the Hartford Financial Services Group for $615 million in cash.

headline: Greece Agrees on New Package of Budget Cuts and Taxes
abstract: The Greek government’s proposal — $15 billion in cuts and $2.6 billion in new taxes — could set off a new wave of protests.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — After weeks of wrangling, Greece’s coalition government said it had reached a basic agreement on Thursday over highly unpopular new austerity measures that could set off a new round of social unrest.

headline: Flea Market Renoir May Have Been Stolen
abstract: A painting believed to have been created by Renoir and found at a flea market for a bargain price may actually have been stolen from a Baltimore museum many years ago.
lead_paragraph: A flea market shopper who seemed to have snagged the deal of the century by paying $7 for what is apparently a Renoir worth more than $75,000 may have bought stolen goods, The Washington Post reported. The sale of the painting, “Paysage Bords de Seine,” scheduled for this Saturday at the Potomack Company in Alexandria, Va., has been postponed as the F.B.I. conducts an investigation.

headline: Loading Up and Heading Out
abstract: After some confusion and setbacks, scientists set off in a ship bound for the North Pacific. But where is the Waverider buoy that needs their attention?
lead_paragraph: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes.Wednesday, Sept. 2632.715 degrees north latitude, 117.156 degrees west longitude

lead_paragraph: As soon as I’d checked in at the door of Eleven Madison Park on Wednesday night, the host directed me to the trough.
