headline: Expect the World, Through an Aesthetic Prism
abstract: An exhibition of Jeremy Deller’s work, at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia, inspires examination of the interchange between art and the world.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The British artist Jeremy Deller, the subject of a thought-provoking exhibition at the Institute of Contemporary Art here, is the anti-Damien Hirst. Born in 1966, he came of age during the surge of the Young British Artists, when Mr. Hirst, Chris Ofili, the Chapman brothers, Tracey Emin and like-minded artists were producing extravagantly provocative works that the mega-collector Charles Saatchi acquired in bulk and packaged in the exhibition “Sensation,” which greatly offended Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani when it came to the Brooklyn Museum in 1999.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Might David H. Petraeus, the most prominent military leader of his generation, leave his job as director of the Central Intelligence Agency to become the president of Princeton University?

headline: A Political Football in the Classroom
abstract: “Won’t Back Down,” an education drama that takes a good-versus-evil tack, stars Maggie Gyllenhaal and Viola Davis.
lead_paragraph: If “The Simpsons” has taught us anything, it is that pious expressions of concern for “the children” are usually evidence of a political agenda in overdrive. “Won’t Back Down,” a new schoolhouse melodrama starring Maggie Gyllenhaal and Viola Davis, presents an especially blatant example of this rule. A movie that insists, repeatedly and at high volume, that “it’s all about the kids” might just cause you to wonder what else it is about, and this one is not shy about showing its ideological hand.

abstract: The First Amendment matters for many reasons, some of them not on the world stage.

headline: Where to Go Outside and Play in New York City
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The city has a surprising number of family-friendly outings in nature, as writers of a new guidebook discovered.
lead_paragraph: LIVING in a 750-square-foot apartment in Morningside Heights poses challenges for Cheryl and William de Jong-Lambert and their two children, but they do not think of themselves as cooped up. They get outside and usually stay there. A run to the store for milk often becomes an outing.

headline: Will Waterboarding Make a Comeback?
abstract: A Romney campaign policy paper says the candidate should pledge to rescind President Obama’s executive order on torture.
lead_paragraph: Last September, Mitt Romney’s advisers were so determined to attack President Obama from every direction and to revive long-discredited neo-con theories about interrogation that they actually encouraged the candidate to come out strongly pro-torture in his presidential campaign.

headline: Hackers May Have Had Help With Attacks on U.S. Banks, Researchers Say
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: The hackers claiming responsibility for cyberattacks on American banks over the past week must have had substantial help to disrupt and take down major banking sites, security researchers say.
lead_paragraph: The hackers claiming responsibility for cyberattacks on American banks over the past week must have had substantial help to disrupt and take down major banking sites, security researchers say.

headline: Good Bordeaux For $50 or Less
abstract: Good, moderately priced Bordeaux is out there, wines that convey if not the grandeur of the region’s best wines at least a sense of what’s so good about them.
lead_paragraph: FOR many would-be Bordeaux drinkers, the highly praised 2009 vintage was the watershed: the point at which they could take no more. Prices rose so high on the critical enthusiasm and international demand that, no matter how good the vintage was, many Americans turned their backs on the year and on Bordeaux.

headline: Anti-Epic Flirts and Jokes
abstract: “Stars in Shorts” is a collection of seven films, none longer than 25 minutes and starring notables like Judi Dench and Keira Knightley.
lead_paragraph: If anthologies of short films are almost always a mixed bag, they hold out the hope that if you don’t like what you’re watching, relief may come in a few minutes. With a roster led by Colin Firth, Keira Knightley and Judi Dench, “Stars in Shorts,” a seven-film anthology, lives up to its name. Its most consistent pleasures derive more from its performances than from storytelling.

headline: Growing Up in a Town of Weak Beer and Toxic Water
abstract: In “Full Body Burden” Kristen Iversen lays out the sickening facts of life for those living near the Rocky Flats nuclear plant in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: Like prison wardens and World Cup goalkeepers, book critics toss and turn over the ones that got away. The books they should have pounced upon, that is, but did not.

headline: Facebook Lets Users Buy Real Things for Friends
abstract: Facebook announced that people could send real gifts to the homes or workplaces of Facebook friends. Cupcakes, sunglasses or fruit can be bought. It’s an experiment to get people to spend money on the site.
lead_paragraph: Facebook on Thursday announced a new tool that offers users the opportunity to buy gifts for one another. It is the company’s latest test of whether users are willing to spend money on the social network – and it remains to be seen whether it will make money for the company.

abstract: The swimmer Michael Phelps has been making the rounds at the Ryder Cup and is expected to address the U.S. team before play begins Friday.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. – Of all Michael Phelps’s accomplishments – the 22 Olympic medals, including 18 golds, and the 29 world records – one goal eluded him. He never competed in a world championship or Olympics on American soil.

headline: Saudi Forces Kill Two in Manhunt in Eastern Province
abstract: A man wanted by the government, and a youth with him, were shot and killed when security forces raided a house in the country’s restive eastern region of Qatif.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s security forces killed a man who was wanted by the government in the country’s restive eastern region of Qatif on Wednesday, and also shot dead a youth who was with him.

headline: Familiar Faces in Pop-Country Trio’s New York Debut
abstract: Blue Sky Riders — a trio of the songwriters Kenny Loggins, Gary Burr and Georgia Middleman — are having their debut New York performances at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency.
lead_paragraph: Blue Sky Riders, a sturdy pop-country trio consisting of Kenny Loggins, Gary Burr and Georgia Middleman, is the latest illustration of a continuing phenomenon in which Nashville is the late-career catch basin for singers and songwriters from both coasts. It makes sense. There never was much stylistic difference between introspective New York folkies and laid-back Southern California dudes whose close harmonies in guitar-based arrangements were marginally less rural in sound and attitude than modern country music. Homogenization was the thing.

headline: A Fighting Puritan, Wielding an Arsenal Against Infidels
abstract: James Purefoy plays the title character in “Solomon Kane,” based on the Robert E. Howard novel.
lead_paragraph: An Elizabethan English Puritan with mad sword skills named Solomon Kane sounds ludicrous, but his creator, the pulp writer Robert E. Howard (1906-36), excelled in outrageous fantasy. Best known for Conan the Barbarian, Howard described Solomon as “a strange blending of Puritan and Cavalier, with a touch of the ancient philosopher, and more than a touch of the pagan.” There isn’t much philosophizing in the 2009 British movie “Solomon Kane,” which, in between the smoting and smiting, introduces a character whose name — evoking at once King Solomon and Cain — telegraphs that this is one caped crusader who brings both piety and Old Testament-style wrath.

headline: Video: The Powerful N.F.L. Is Humbled
abstract: The N.F.L.’s debacle with replacement referees proves that the league is not invincible.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s debacle with replacement referees proves that the league is not invincible.

abstract: A listing of noteworthy cultural events for children, teenagers and families in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: THE MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Cable Haiku and Carbon Fiber Failures
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selection includes visually mapping the “Star Wars” stories and characters, a do-it-yourself iPhone 5 accessory and a tale of how easy it is to forget that simple tech tasks can go wrong.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: The Sensational and the Political
abstract: In two varied exhibitions, Thomas Hirschhorn reappropriates the news and surveys his public art.
lead_paragraph: In his installations the Swiss artist Thomas Hirschhorn waxes didactic on politics and philosophy, even as he bombards us with sensational imagery. But in Mr. Hirschhorn’s current double showing in Chelsea, at Gladstone Gallery and at the future Dia project space, those two approaches have been teased apart.

headline: Some Melting-Pot Law Office: Newcomer From Next Door Brings Culture Clash
abstract: “Made in Jersey” is a new CBS courtroom drama with the British actress Janet Montgomery as a New York lawyer who hails from New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The title is terrible, and so is the accent, but surprisingly, the new CBS drama “Made in Jersey” as a whole isn’t.

headline: Taking a Time-Bending Leap Into a Final Season
abstract: The Fox sci-fi mystery show “Fringe” is wrapping up its five-year run with 13 new episodes even further into the future.
lead_paragraph: Jack Bauer never had it this bad on “24.”

headline: Facing Pain in a Father’s Footsteps
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The filmmaker David Fisher and his three siblings retrace the steps of their Hungarian Jewish father, Joseph, a Holocaust survivor.
lead_paragraph: In “Six Million and One,” the Israeli documentarian David Fisher’s third film in a family trilogy that includes “Love Inventory” (2000) and “Mostar Round-Trip” (2011), he and his three siblings retrace the steps of their Hungarian Jewish father, Joseph, a Holocaust survivor. Joining Mr. Fisher are his sister, Estee Fisher Heim, and his brothers, Gideon and Ronel. Their father was interned in Gusen and Gunskirchen, Austria, after a brief time at Auschwitz. While imprisoned he kept a memoir that was discovered 12 years after his death.

headline: Which Language Rules to Flout. Or Flaunt?
abstract: What if our English teachers were wrong?
lead_paragraph: Here’s a chilling thought: What if our English teachers were wrong? Maybe not about everything, but about a few memorable lessons. So many millions of writers have needlessly contorted their prose to avoid ending a sentence with a preposition. So many well-intentioned editors have fought to change “a historic” to “an historic.” If it turns out that the guidelines we cling to (“to which we cling”?) are nonsense, maybe the texters have the right idea when they throw out the old rules and start fresh.

headline: Where an Incorrect Answer Can Extinguish Everything
abstract: Franco Zeffirelli’s flamboyant production of Puccini’s “Turandot” returns to the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: One of the enigmas of Puccini’s “Turandot” is why anyone would seek to marry a man-hating princess with a track record of decapitating her suitors. But the unattainable beauty proves irresistible, luring dozens of admirers to their deaths.

headline: Waiting to Play Golf, U.S. Team Excels at Table Tennis
abstract: The Americans’ prowess at table tennis has become a major line of questioning in the pre-Ryder Cup interview sessions.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. – Don’t be fooled, Bubba Watson said Thursday with a twinkle in his eye.

headline: A Thai Tale Wrapped in a Smoky Noir
abstract: Pen-ek Ratanaruang’s “Headshot” is a familiar story of good and evil with some contemporary touches.
lead_paragraph: The world turns literally upside down in “Headshot,” a dreamy, elliptical neo-noir about a cop turned killer turned something else altogether. This 180 shift in perspective occurs early in the movie, which the Thai writer and director Pen-ek Ratanaruang adapted from a novel by his compatriot Win Lyovarin. It’s a contemporary if shopworn story of good and evil, decency versus corruption and one man fighting the machine when topsy-turvy and not. Mr. Pen-ek has said it’s also a political tale, if not transparently so for those unfamiliar with Thai history. For the uninitiated, the kick won’t be the story or its meanings but rather its silky fusion of pulp fiction material and art cinema style.

headline: Determined to Give a Craftsman His Due
abstract: A historian’s collaborative efforts have helped to restore the reputation of the jewelry maker Gustav Manz.
lead_paragraph: The jewelry maker Gustav Manz produced thousands of works in gold, silver and platinum, operating a Manhattan workshop from around 1901 to 1944. But his name shows up hardly anywhere.

headline: An Artsy Blast Before Winter
abstract: The “Flow” exhibition on Randalls Island features outdoor works by five up-and-coming artists.
lead_paragraph: It should be no big secret that the Miser is a huge fan of Governors Island; more than a few recent columns have pointed readers there. But to be fair, it’s not the city’s only culturally rich island park. Before winter’s bluster starts making outdoor adventures less palatable, it’s time to consider other, equally distinctive destinations.

headline: Week 4 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
abstract: Chris Johnson was one of the top running back draft picks in fantasy football this season, but he ranks as one of the worst performers and is among our unfavorable matchup picks for Week 4.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Loud, Proud and Painted
abstract: The show “Mickalene Thomas: Origin of the Universe,” at the Brooklyn Museum, is dominated by that artist’s big, collagelike paintings.
lead_paragraph: Mickalene Thomas’s brash, exuberant paintings don’t care what you think of them; they are much too busy simply — or not so simply — being themselves. Their sense of independence is driven home by this artist’s invigorating exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, along with the realization that the museum’s populist program sometimes hits the nail on the head.

headline: Romney Adds Note of Inevitability to Stump Speech
abstract: To hear Mitt Romney tell it, a Romney administration is not a question of if, but when.
lead_paragraph: To hear Mitt Romney tell it, a Romney administration is not a question of if, but when.

headline: One Dead in Meningitis Outbreak Among Men Who Have Sex With Men
abstract: Three other men in New York City have been sickened, one critically, by the infection in the last month, the city health department said.
lead_paragraph: One man has died of meningitis and three others have fallen ill, one critically, over the last month in an outbreak of the infection among men who have sex with men, the New York City health department said on Thursday.

headline: Girls Will Be Girls
abstract: Answers to questions about dealing with teenagers, a friend, a boyfriend and strangers.
lead_paragraph: I am in my early 30s, and was on a flight home after a brutal workweek abroad. I fell asleep quickly but was awakened by two teenage girls, who were laughing and pointing at me, as well as taking my picture and uploading it onto social media. I asked them to stop, but they didn’t. So I reported them to the flight attendant, who kindly changed my seat. But the mocking began all over again when I saw them at customs, where they had gathered with several more teenagers and a teacher chaperon. Any thoughts on dealing with girls like these? Elizabeth

headline: In What Universe Does This Guy Turn Into Bruce Willis?
abstract: In Rian Johnson’s “Looper,” a young hit man (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) confronts his older self thanks to time travel.
lead_paragraph: “Looper,” an obstreperously entertaining, bullet- and attitude-ridden science-fiction pastiche, opens in a futuristic world that looks and sounds paradoxically out of the past. Set in 2044, in a dystopia with Turner Classic Movies flavor, it puts a spin on the familiar figure of the existentially troubled gun for hire while leaving a layer of dust on many of the other genre fundamentals it plays with. Some of it you’ve seen and heard before, intentionally so, though it adds a weird wrinkle: an attempt to transform Joseph Gordon-Levitt, his nose prosthetically bobbed and a smirk surfing his thinned upper lip, into the wisecracking Bruce Willis of the “Moonlighting” years.

headline: A Beethoven Quartet, Better Heard Than Seen
abstract: The choreographer D D Dorvillier, drawing on one of Beethoven’s late string quartets, has called “Danza Permanente” her attempt to make music visible in silence.
lead_paragraph: The systematic dreariness of D D Dorvillier’s “Danza Permanente” is depressing — schematic and soporific. In the first place, the ambience onstage is disagreeable. Four dancers metronomically plod their way through long routines, occasionally counting out loud. Usually they avert their eyes from one another and the audience — but sometimes they connect conspiratorially, like prisoners who are hoping the guards will not notice their escape plan. The escape, of course, came when they stopped.

headline: A Festival Whose Age Is Just a Number
abstract: The 50th New York Film Festival is as eclectic as ever, with Hollywood products like “Life of Pi,” foreign award winners like “Amour” and independent offerings like “Frances Ha.”
lead_paragraph: There is talk going around these days —  again — about the death of movies, and the 50th New York Film Festival, which starts Friday night, might have offered an occasion for fond, gloomy retrospect. This festival was born in what is now invoked as a heroic era of local and global film culture — a feverish atmosphere perhaps best recalled by the writer Phillip Lopate in his 1998 book, “Totally Tenderly Tragically” — and its home at Lincoln Center frequently seems haunted by the ghosts of golden ages past. Remember the first festival in 1963, when we were dazzled and perplexed by Luis Buñuel’s “Exterminating Angel,” Roman Polanski’s “Knife in the Water” and Alain Resnais’s “Muriel”?

headline: Boldest Color for Total Effect
abstract: The Met’s exhibition of the Rinpa artists of Japan is expansive, while the Japan Society’s is more narrowly focused.
lead_paragraph: Have any artists ever, anywhere, caught the hello-ness of spring and the farewell-ness of autumn more sweetly and sharply than the Rimpa painters of Japan? Two shimmering fall exhibitions, one at Japan Society and the other at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, argue persuasively that no, no artists ever have.

headline: Always Ready With a Barb
abstract: Camille Paglia, critic and provocateur, has a new book on art history. She also hates the Met’s Egyptian galleries.
lead_paragraph: IT was a typical fall Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with visitors massing on the steps and milling awe-struck around the Great Hall. Among them was the cultural critic Camille Paglia, a pint-size martinet in a black military-style jacket who strode purposefully through the crowds with a scowl on her face and a reporter in tow.

headline: That First Play Without Dad
abstract: “Him,” the playwright Daisy Foote’s first play to be produced since the death of her father and mentor, Horton Foote, is in previews at Primary Stages.
lead_paragraph: “WHEN my father died, my therapist phoned,” Daisy Foote recalled. “And I said, ‘It’s so awful! It’s the end of everything!’

headline: Paintings Close to Home for an Italian Renaissance Master
abstract: A Piero della Francesca show is planned for the Frick Collection next year; the Brooklyn Museum will auction an Yves Klein painting, and the Hirshhorn will sell a Picasso; and the New Museum plans the next Ideas City festival.
lead_paragraph: In his day Piero della Francesca was as well known a mathematician as he was an artist. But while his head for numbers may have been admirable, it was his paintings that endured. In the early 20th century American collectors like Isabella Stewart Gardner, Robert Sterling Clark and Philip Lehman bought work by this Italian Renaissance master, known simply as Piero.

headline: Boy Meets Girl, Boy Finds Out She’s 118
abstract: In the vividly animated “Hotel Transylvania,” Dracula has a daughter who falls for a human backpacker who strays into their monsters-only inn.
lead_paragraph: The story flags, but the animation in “Hotel Transylvania,” a misunderstood-monsters story aimed at the “Aladdin” and “Little Mermaid” crowd, is never less than vivid. Younger children are unlikely to get all the references to monsters of yore, but if nothing else, the film will give their parents an opportunity to educate them about the Invisible Man and Quasimodo.

headline: The Novelist, His Muse, and Her Japanese Gangster
abstract: hris Benker’s “Yakuza and the Mermaid” mashes up fiction and reality in a tale of a mediocre writer with an unfinished thriller.
lead_paragraph: Several things are murdered in “The Yakuza and the Mermaid” — a Japanese gangster, a Cole Porter song — to no clear purpose beyond the amusement of the film’s writer, photographer, editor and director, Chris Benker. Which is fine, but if wallowing in the creative hiccups of tortured scribblers is your moviegoing goal, there are much better options.

headline: Kentucky House Candidate Unveils Graphic Attack Ad
abstract: A TV commercial that likens President Obama to Hitler and Ted Bundy because of his support for abortion rights is running in Kentucky despite its graphic images and provocative religious references.
lead_paragraph: A commercial that all but calls President Obama a murderer — likening him to Hitler and Ted Bundy because of his support for abortion rights — is running on television stations in Kentucky despite its graphic images and provocative religious references.

headline: A Collegiate A Cappella Group Puts on a Show
abstract: “Pitch Perfect” tells the story of the Bellas, a singing group fresh off a notable humiliation in a national competition.
lead_paragraph: “Pitch Perfect” has a pitch problem.

headline: M.T.A. Amends Rules After Pro-Israel Ads Draw Controversy
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s board barred ads that could “incite or provoke violence.”
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved new guidelines for advertisements on Thursday, prohibiting those that it “reasonably foresees would imminently incite or provoke violence or other immediate breach of the peace.”

headline: A Grifter Mom Tries to Reform
abstract: Famke Janssen’s “Bringing Up Bobby” focuses on a con artist desperate to support her 10-year-old son.
lead_paragraph: Working a variety of bad accents and the wardrobe of a 1930s moll, Milla Jovovich takes a break from fighting zombies in the “Resident Evil” franchise to play Olive, a Ukrainian-born single mother who lives for two things: conning and her 10-year-old son, Bobby (Spencer List). When not drooling over her bratty offspring — who helps zip up her unmentionables — Olive can be found stealing indiscriminately, even fleecing a church group to finance a nonexistent ministry.

headline: Why They Come Here
abstract: “Harvest of Empire,” based on a book by the columnist Juan González, looks at Central Americans forced by poverty or war into emigrating.
lead_paragraph: “Harvest of Empire” has a journalistic pedigree and a punch that comes from political advocacy. Based on a book — also “Harvest of Empire” — by Juan González, a columnist for The Daily News, this documentary presents information about the history of Latino immigration to the United States.

headline: Osaka Mayor’s Radical Message Has Broad Appeal in a Weary Japan
abstract: The charisma of Toru Hashimoto, Osaka’s new mayor, has made a new party a feared force in Japanese politics, seemingly overnight.
lead_paragraph: OSAKA, Japan — It took more than six decades, including nearly 20 years of economic stagnation, to persuade Japan’s change-averse voters to kick out the governing party long enough to move to a true two-party democracy in 2009. Now, just three years later, many voters have embraced a largely unknown new party led by a brash young leader who promises a drastic overhaul of the government.

headline: British Authorities to Announce Changes in Libor Oversight
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Martin Wheatley, managing director of the Financial Services Authority, will outline plans to increase oversight of the rate-setting process in response to a manipulation scandal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British authorities are set to announce significant changes to the interest rate at the heart of a recent manipulation scandal as they aim to improve the accuracy and reliability of the benchmark.

headline: Kerik Is Reluctant Witness in Perjury Trial of Brothers Who Remodeled His Home
abstract: The relationship between the defendants, Frank and Peter DiTommaso, and Bernard B. Kerik, the disgraced former police commissioner, will be the focus of the trial.
lead_paragraph: When Bernard B. Kerik, the disgraced former police commissioner, testifies at the perjury trial of two brothers who prosecutors say remodeled Mr. Kerik’s home in exchange for his help with regulators, he will do so as a reluctant witness.

headline: The Real 666 Park Avenue
abstract: TV’s “666 Park Avenue” is a fiction. The real thing, a hidden maisonette, is quite fabulous.
lead_paragraph: THE title building of the new ABC series “666 Park Avenue” is a fiction; the network is using shots of the Ansonia as a backdrop.

headline: The Rental Alternative to Foreclosure
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Foreclosures', 'Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A “deed for lease” or “mortgage to lease” is an alternative to foreclosure, but only a select few can take advantage of this option.
lead_paragraph: FOR homeowners who have been buffeted about by the foreclosure process, the suggestion that they willingly hand their deed to the lender and rent the home instead may only add insult to injury.

headline: In Paris, Sharp Turns From the Cutting Edge
abstract: Gareth Pugh’s collection had a darkly Spanish flare, and Balmain showed intricately constructed dresses that were delightfully ostentatious.
lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: For Medinah, the Biggest Thing Ever
abstract: Medinah has been the site of five major championships, but that didn’t stop Rees Jones and Davis Love III from tweaking the course for the Ryder Cup.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — The Medinah Country Club has long been a magnet for big events. It was the site of the United States Open in 1949, 1975 and 1990, and the site of the P.G.A. Championship in 1999 and 2006.

headline: Names of the Dead
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,106 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,106 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: A 20-Game Winner
abstract: Action from the Mets’ 6-5 victory over the Pirates, in which R. A. Dickey struck out 13 in becoming the franchise’s sixth pitcher to win 20 games in a season.
lead_paragraph: Action from the Mets’ 6-5 victory over the Pirates, in which R. A. Dickey struck out 13 in becoming the franchise’s sixth pitcher to win 20 games in a season.

headline: Answers From Princeton’s Dean of Admission
abstract: Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, lends her expertise about college admissions by answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Choice has invited Janet Lavin Rapelye, the dean of admission at Princeton University, to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer your questions about college admissions. Ms. Rapelye, who received a bachelor’s degree from Williams College and a master’s degree from Stanford University, has 30 years’ experience in college admissions.

headline: At Balenciaga, Lots to Talk About
abstract: At the Balenciaga show, Nicolas Ghesquière put plenty of new options on the runway.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Balenciaga show was just over as François Pinault, the art patron and founder of PPR, slipped out of the backstage area, past a throng of waiting guests. A sustained roar followed as the models, still in their new ruffles and tweeds, cheered.

headline: World’s Tallest Ferris Wheel Planned for Staten Island
abstract: The wheel, which is expected to open in 2015, will be 625 feet tall and displace the Singapore Flyer for the record.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Thursday that the world’s tallest Ferris wheel would rise above the Staten Island waterfront. The 625-foot-tall ride will displace the Singapore Flyer, at 541 feet the record-holder of the moment.

headline: Officials Welcomed; Ravens Hang On
abstract: During warm-ups before Baltimore’s 23-16 victory, Ravens Coach John Harbaugh hugged the referee Gene Steratore, who is entering his 10th season.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — About an hour before the Baltimore Ravens kicked off to the Cleveland Browns to begin their game Thursday night, a roar circulated through the lower bowl of M&T Bank Stadium.

headline: Raising Frogs for Freedom, Prison Project Opens Doors
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Washington State’s Sustainability in Prisons program enlists inmates to help rescue imperiled species like the Oregon spotted frog.
lead_paragraph: LITTLEROCK, Wash. — The birdman of Alcatraz became famous. But the frogmen of Cedar Creek are still anonymous beyond the tiny cult world of amphibian science. For now, they say.

headline: Gas Drilling Jitters Unsettle Catskills Sales
abstract: The prospect that New York State will open the region to hydraulic fracturing, a controversial process known informally as fracking, has spooked potential buyers.
lead_paragraph: HANCOCK, N.Y.

headline: ‘Through the Yellow Hour’
abstract: Scenes from Adam Rapp’s latest play.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Adam Rapp’s latest play.

headline: The Myth of Fixing the Libor
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: It is unlikely that the London interbank offered rate can be repaired, no matter what Britain’s top financial regulator asserts.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes modern finance has a great need for something, and so bankers invent products that appear to fill that need. When it turns out that the invention was actually something else entirely, people are shocked.

headline: Rimpa Painters
abstract: Images from new exhibitions at Japan Society and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Images from new exhibitions at Japan Society and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Authorities Question Head of Google in Brazil Over Video
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A Brazilian court issued an arrest warrant for the head of Google in Brazil over a YouTube video it wanted blocked because it criticized a local mayoral candidate.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Brazil questioned Google’s senior executive there on Wednesday over a YouTube video that criticized a local mayoral candidate, and a court ruled that YouTube must block the video.

headline: ‘Origin of the Universe’
abstract: Images from a new exhibition of works by Mickalene Thomas.
lead_paragraph: Images from a new exhibition of works by Mickalene Thomas.

headline: Popcorn in Hand, Mayor Rides Ferry to Staten Island
abstract: The voyage offered a chance for Michael R. Bloomberg to rub his Paul Stuart-clad shoulders with the public, although, surrounded as he was by bodyguards and reporters, only one citizen had the courage to approach.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg famously travels by helicopter and private jet, with an occasional foray into the subway. Most of the time, he is chauffeured around town behind the tinted windows of his city-issued S.U.V.

headline: Prison-Crime Witness Now on the Defensive
abstract: After two decades of investigating prison-based crimes, A. P. Merillat, an expert witness, has been condemned by Texas’ highest criminal court for giving false testimony.
lead_paragraph: A. P. Merillat has spent two decades investigating crimes in Texas prisons, and his testimony about the violence that inmates serving life sentences can inflict has helped send at least 15 murderers to death row.

headline: Detroit’s Lead Is 2; Gonzalez Wins 21st
abstract: The Tigers nearly wasted Doug Fister’s streak of striking out nine straight batters, blowing a lead late before beating Kansas City, 5-4, on Thursday in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: The playoff picture in the American League began to take shape Thursday, as Texas beat Oakland to add to its cushion in the West. The Angels could not make a move on the Athletics, though, losing to Seattle to leave them two games out of a wild-card spot, with Tampa Bay now also two back. Detroit increased its lead in the Central with a win over Kansas City, as the White Sox lost to the Rays. The Yankees lost, but their rival in the East, Baltimore, was off.

headline: Iran Envoy Is Assaulted by Protesters Near the U.N.
abstract: A spokesman for the Iranian Mission at the United Nations was shoved and shouted at by a small group of Iranian exiles protesting a speech at the General Assembly by Iran’s president.
lead_paragraph: Iranian exiles and the Iranian government can make for a combustible combination, as a spokesman for the Iranian Foreign Ministry discovered after an address by the country’s president to the United Nations during this week’s General Assembly.

headline: Behind the Scenes of a Deal That Everyone Wanted Done
abstract: Some involved in negotiations thought an agreement with the officials union would have been reached this week regardless, but a debacle in Seattle helped accelerate talks.
lead_paragraph: By Monday afternoon, the N.F.L. had been in 10 days of intensive negotiations with the union for its game officials.

headline: A Flood of Applications, With a Trickle of Approvals
keywords: ['Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: A little more than two dozen immigrants nationwide have received approval for a two-year deferral of deportation under a program that President Obama announced in June.
lead_paragraph: Justino Mora had been checking his e-mail several times a day for weeks to see if there was any word from a federal immigration agency on his application for a reprieve from deportation.

headline: Administration Statements on the Attack in Benghazi
abstract: Statements made by officials in the Obama administration about the Sept. 11, 2012, attack on the mission in Benghazi, Libya.
lead_paragraph: Statements made by officials in the Obama administration about the Sept. 11, 2012, attack on the mission in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: The Arab Spring Still Blooms
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The Arab revolutions have not turned anti-Western. They are still about social justice and democracy.
lead_paragraph: THE violent demonstrations that have spread across the Muslim world in recent weeks have convinced many in the United States and Europe that the Arab revolutions that began in late 2010 are now over and that the democratic project has failed. Bitterness and a sense of impending catastrophe are replacing the enthusiasm that followed the toppling of dictators in Tunisia and Egypt last year.

headline: Growth of Suburban D.C. Is Felt Politically in Maryland
abstract: An army of government workers and government contractors live in suburban Maryland and favor Democrats by significant margins.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Here is a look at Maryland, the Old Line State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Donald F. Kettl, the dean of the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland; and Theodore F. Sheckels, a professor of communications and English at Randolph-Macon College in Ashland, Va.

headline: When Growth Outpaces Happiness
keywords: ['Happiness', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Reform and Reorganization', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Privatization']
abstract: It is startling to find that Chinese people’s feelings of well-being have declined in a period of such momentous improvement in their economic lives.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

headline: ‘Sex and the City’ Creator Lists Apartment
abstract: Darren Star has put his three-bedroom condo with walls of windows facing Central Park and the Hudson River on the market for $15 million.
lead_paragraph: THE sophisticated glass-sheathed condominium at One Central Park West exudes sensuality, and why not? Since 2005, it has been the East Coast lair of the producer Darren Star, the creator of a string of frothy television series headlined by “Sex and the City,” the cult classic that zeroed in on the high-wire exploits of four romance-addicted New York City career women. He also produced the film version of “Sex and the City” and its sequel.

headline: Farewell to a Mustache Forever Linked to the Mets
abstract: Surrounded by fans, Keith Hernandez shaved his trademark facial hair in exchange for a $10,000 donation to a Brooklyn day care center for Alzheimer’s patients.
lead_paragraph: Without his mustache, would Clark Gable have been as silkily charming when he told Scarlett O’Hara he frankly did not give a damn? Would Groucho Marx have delivered his one-liners with the same zing?

headline: Governors Island and Its Future
abstract: The island off the southern tip of Manhattan is a wasteland no more. These days it’s a very busy place.
lead_paragraph: Governors Island was, for many years, little more than a tantalizing wasteland — a 172-acre chunk of rock and mostly abandoned military structures. Politicians and urban planners dreamed of ways to turn this underused space into a compelling daytime destination for New Yorkers, but nothing really happened until the state, in 2010, ceded most of the island to New York City.

headline: A Big Right Arm and a Little Man on His Shoulder
abstract: The Atlanta Braves have won each of Kris Medlen’s last 22 starts, dating to 2010, tied for the longest streak in major league history.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The hottest starting pitcher in baseball is a 5-foot-10 right-hander with spiked hair, a flat-brim cap, a rebuilt elbow and a little man on his shoulder giving him all the answers.

headline: The Wait for Postal Default
abstract: The United States Postal Service is about to run out of money because Republicans in the House have failed to act.
lead_paragraph: While House members are back home campaigning straight to Election Day, voters might want to alert them that the United States Postal Service is about to default on a $5.6 billion loan obligation — mainly because the House took off without allowing the service to modernize its archaic business practices.

headline: Obama Fills in Blanks of Romney’s Plans, and G.O.P. Sees Falsehoods
abstract: The Obama campaign is taking advantage of the unknown details of Mitt Romney’s policy proposals by filling in the blanks, but some charges are more specific than the facts warrant.
lead_paragraph: The Obama campaign has run advertisements charging that Mitt Romney’s Medicare plan “could raise seniors’ costs up to $6,400 a year” and that his tax proposal “would give millionaires another tax break and raises taxes on middle-class families by up to $2,000 a year.”

headline: A Duty of Health Care Workers
abstract: A survey finds that too many medical personnel fail to get flu shots, which puts patients at risk.
lead_paragraph: Health care workers should know better than anyone that it is important to get vaccinated against the flu virus to protect their own health and prevent the possibility of infecting patients. There were some encouraging signs in an analysis issued Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that doctors and nurses are beginning to get the message. But other health care workers — a broad group that includes clinical personnel like nurse practitioners and physician assistants and various nonprofessional aides and assistants — show remarkable indifference to performing what ought to be considered their civic duty.

headline: A City Place for Country Doctors
abstract: Gregory Turner and Veronica Helgans went looking for a pied-à-terre on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, Gregory Turner wanted a second home in the city.

headline: Europe’s Austerity Madness
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Unemployment', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Here’s why the protesters in Spain and Greece are right that inflicting more and more pain serves no useful purpose.
lead_paragraph: So much for complacency. Just a few days ago, the conventional wisdom was that Europe finally had things under control. The European Central Bank, by promising to buy the bonds of troubled governments if necessary, had soothed markets. All that debtor nations had to do, the story went, was agree to more and deeper austerity — the condition for central bank loans — and all would be well.

headline: The Geography of Nope
abstract: It takes a truly small-minded politician to upset the balance of our public lands.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — In a part of Italy where chestnut trees are thick in the Apennine foothills, I once asked a neighbor in the little community where we lived how I might kill a wild boar. This impulse was driven by appetite, mostly — glimpses of those feral beasts on my morning runs that had me dreaming of a blood-red ragu made of local cinghiale.

headline: State Is Trying to Put Brakes on High Cost of University
abstract: Some of Texas’ public universities are offering a $10,000 degree program or a four-year tuition guarantee.
lead_paragraph: Ashton Curlee, the ambitious daughter of two teachers, received official notification of her acceptance to the new Texas Science Scholar Program at the University of Texas of the Permian Basin on the first day of college.

headline: Man Tied to Anti-Islam Video Held on Probation Charge
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The man suspected of making the anti-Islam video that set off deadly protests across the Muslim world is accused of violating an order in a bank fraud case that restricted his use of the Internet.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The man thought to have been behind the crude anti-Islam video that set off deadly protests across the Muslim world in recent weeks was arrested Thursday for violating terms of his probation in a 2010 bank fraud case.

headline: The Psych Approach
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Books and Literature', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: There are strong links between our childhood experiences and adult lives. The emotional basis of success should have a bigger role in education.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, Vincent Felitti and Robert Anda conducted a study on adverse childhood experiences. They asked 17,000 mostly white, mostly upscale patients enrolled in a Kaiser H.M.O. to describe whether they had experienced any of 10 categories of childhood trauma. They asked them if they had been abused, if their parents had divorced, if family members had been incarcerated or declared mentally ill. Then they gave them what came to be known as ACE scores, depending on how many of the 10 experiences they had endured.

headline: One57’s Billionaires, and the Dust-Ups They Cause
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: New owners seeking to custom-finish their places before moving in may create headaches for neighbors.
lead_paragraph: AS problems go, this is a pretty good one to have.

headline: A Blurring of Golf’s Battle Lines
abstract: The Europeans and the Americans often have more in common with opposing players than with teammates.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill.

headline: Talking at Cross Purposes
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian leaders spoke at the United Nations of threats and grievances, but offered no hope for negotiations.
lead_paragraph: The alternate universes of the Israeli and Palestinian leaders were on display Thursday at the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: N.B.A. Ready to Act on Flopping
abstract: After years of complaints, the N.B.A. finally appears ready to outlaw “flopping” — the act of exaggerating contact to induce a foul call.
lead_paragraph: ELIZABETH, N.J. — After years of complaints, the N.B.A. finally appears ready to outlaw flopping — the act of exaggerating contact to induce a foul call.

headline: Trial Begins in Bus Crash That Killed 15
abstract: Prosecutors described the bus driver, Ophadell Williams, as having been negligently sleep deprived, while his lawyer portrayed him as hardworking with nothing to hide.
lead_paragraph: When Ophadell Williams should have been resting for his night shifts, a prosecutor said on Thursday, he was instead driving around in a rented car with little sleep in the days before his tour bus crashed into a signpost stanchion in the Bronx, “peeling off the roof like a sardine can and wreaking death and destruction.”

headline: Fearing Fiscal Cliff, Investors Cash In and Seek Safety
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Taxation', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Investors are bracing for what might happen after the election, when politicians will have to negotiate a deal on tax cuts and the deficit or face automatic cuts.
lead_paragraph: After riding a quarter-long rally fueled by central bankers in Europe and the United States, investors are taking a more defensive posture on fears that politicians could derail the momentum.

headline: Rumblings of a Tomato Trade War Between the U.S. and Mexico
keywords: ['Tomatoes', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Commerce Department took steps to end a 16-year-old agreement with Mexico that makes Mexican tomatoes a bargain in American supermarkets.
lead_paragraph: The Commerce Department took steps to end a 16-year-old agreement with Mexico that makes Mexican tomatoes a bargain in American supermarkets.

headline: Ammunition for a Trade War Between U.S. and Mexico
keywords: ['Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Tomatoes', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies']
abstract: The Department of Commerce took steps to end a 16-year-old agreement with Mexico that makes Mexican tomatoes a bargain in American supermarkets.
lead_paragraph: Estimates are that nearly one out of two tomatoes eaten in the United States comes from Mexico — a statistic Florida growers would like to change, even at the risk of a trade war.

headline: A’s Fail to Gain Ground In a Showdown Series
abstract: The A’s split four games with the Rangers, leaving Oakland in the same position it was in when the series started — four games behind the division leaders.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Oakland Athletics left here stuck in the muck after a 9-7 loss Thursday to the first-place Texas Rangers in an American League West showdown. The A’s split four games with the Rangers, leaving Oakland in the same position it was in when the series started — four games behind the division leader.

headline: Syrian Rebels Take Their Battle to the Skies
abstract: For the rebels, managing to deny the use of an important airfield has undermined the government’s ability to exert its full authority in some parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: In an article published in The New York Times on Thursday, C.J. Chivers (@cjchivers) wrote about the battle for Abu ad Duhur, an air base south of Aleppo, Syria. Rebels have targeted the base to keep its planes from going out on missions. Rebel forces have been trying for months — at times claiming success — to shoot down government planes and helicopters in midflight.

headline: At Home, and Accused of Trespassing
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: A number of people are suing the city after being arrested as trespassers in housing projects, even though they were there rightfully.
lead_paragraph: Few things can be more galling than the takeover of public housing projects by hoodlums who use law-abiding people as camouflage for criminal activity.

headline: The First Pairings Are Set
abstract: The Ryder Cup captains have established the first pairings, and the first ball will be struck by either Rory McIlroy or Graeme McDowell.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — The first ball of the 39th Ryder Cup will be struck Friday by either Rory McIlroy or Graeme McDowell, both of Northern Ireland, whom the European captain, José María Olazábal, is sending out against the Americans Jim Furyk and Brandt Snedeker in the first pairing of foursomes at Medinah Country Club.

headline: Charges of Bias in Admission Test Policy at Eight Elite Public High Schools
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'Education (K-12)', 'Equal Educational Opportunities']
abstract: A coalition of educational and civil rights groups said in a federal complaint Thursday that a test disproportionally excluded black and Hispanic students from New York City’s elite public schools.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of educational and civil rights groups filed a federal complaint on Thursday saying that black and Hispanic students were disproportionately excluded from New York City’s most selective high schools because of a single-test admittance policy they say is racially discriminatory.

headline: United States Economy Still Weak, but More Feel Secure
keywords: ['Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A closely watched measure of consumer confidence surged to its highest level since February, even as job growth and the overall economy had weakened.
lead_paragraph: Both economists and the Romney campaign are puzzling over the same paradox: The recovery has flagged and yet the country’s mood appears to be improving.

headline: This Wake-Up Cup Is Fair-Trade Certified
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coffee']
abstract: In recognition of Fair Trade Month in October, Green Mountain Coffee is seeking to educate its customers about fair-trade certification.
lead_paragraph: GREEN MOUNTAIN COFFEE has been helping consumers wake up for more than three decades, but a new advertising campaign is meant to be an eye-opener of a different sort.

headline: Challenging Crossings
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Thomas Fuller, a New York Times reporter, visits Vietnam’s capital to document the daily duel between motorcycles and pedestrians.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Fuller, a New York Times reporter, visits Vietnam’s capital to document the daily duel between motorcycles and pedestrians.

headline: Why Did the Tourist Cross the Road? The Real Riddle Is ‘How’
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: A decade or so of capitalist fervor has transformed Hanoi’s once-quiet tree-lined boulevards and side streets into roaring rivers of rubber and steel.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — Tourists who check in to the Meracus Hotel, a compact and friendly establishment in the Old Quarter of Hanoi, are handed a tip sheet by the receptionist titled “How to cross roads.”

headline: Romney and Obama in Ohio

keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']

headline: Rover Finds Signs of Old Streambed
abstract: NASA’s Mars rover Curiosity has spotted pieces of an old streambed where water rushed by billions of years ago, scientists reported at a news conference on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Mars rover Curiosity has spotted pieces of an old streambed where water rushed by billions of years ago, scientists reported at a news conference on Thursday. “It just seemed like someone came along the surface of Mars with a jackhammer and lifted up a sidewalk that you might see in downtown L.A.,” said John Grotzinger, the mission’s project scientist. From the size of the rounded pebbles embedded in the slab, the scientists estimated that water was flowing about a yard a second and was between ankle and hip deep. NASA has found bountiful evidence of liquid water on early Mars when it might have been warmer, but this was the first observation of an ancient streambed. Curiosity is looking for carbon-based molecules which, together with liquid water, could have provided all of the necessary building blocks for life.

headline: Afghanistan: Joint Missions Rise Again
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The number of missions in which Afghan security forces work in partnership with American and allied troops is growing again, Pentagon and military officials said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The number of missions in which Afghan security forces work in partnership with American and allied troops is growing again, although restrictions ordered after a spate of “insider attacks” have not been lifted, Pentagon and military officials said Thursday. In a significant restriction on a core element of the Western exit strategy from Afghanistan, the American-led military coalition said last week that all joint operations with Afghan forces conducted below the battalion level had to first go through a formal approval process — an effort to stem attacks by members of the Afghan security forces that have killed 51 American or allied service members this year. Officials now say those approvals were being handled efficiently enough that the number of partnered operations was returning to normal. Before the order, about 90 percent of all missions were conducted jointly. The number is now climbing again, said officials, who declined to offer specifics.

headline: Time to Confront Reality, Now That They’re Elected

headline: Mexico: Suspected Drug Boss Captured
abstract: The Mexican Navy said Thursday that its marines had captured a top leader of the Zetas drug gang, Iván Velázquez Caballero.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican Navy said Thursday that its marines had captured a top leader of the Zetas drug gang, Iván Velázquez Caballero. Mr. Velázquez Caballero had been feuding with another Zeta leader, Miguel Ángel Treviño Morales, a Navy spokesman said. The feud had caused a surge in violence in parts of northern Mexico. Mr. Velázquez Caballero was caught on Wednesday night in San Luis Potosí, north of Mexico City. The Navy has made several high-profile arrests recently, but experts say that lieutenants quickly rise to take the place of captured crime bosses, bringing struggles that generate new violence.

headline: Irving Adler, Teacher Fired in Red Scare, Dies at 99
abstract: Mr. Adler, a former New York City teacher, became a prolific writer of books on math and science for young people after being forced from the classroom during the early 1950s.
lead_paragraph: Irving Adler, a former New York City teacher who became a prolific writer of books on math and science for young people after being forced from the classroom during the Red Scare of the early 1950s, died on Saturday in Bennington, Vt. He was 99.

headline: The Unraveling of Government
abstract: The parties have too much power. But we can take some of it back.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated over the inability of political leaders to find common ground on even the most pressing national issues, Americans have developed a long list of people or political practices to blame for the fact that government doesn’t seem to work anymore. But the real problem is something that’s not high on most such lists, something that’s far more crucial.

headline: China: Dissident Artist Rejects Fines
abstract: Ai Weiwei, the persecuted artist and critic of the Chinese Communist Party, said Thursday that he would not pay taxes and penalties that the government said he owed.
lead_paragraph: Ai Weiwei, the persecuted artist and critic of the Chinese Communist Party, said Thursday that he would not pay taxes and penalties that the government said he owed. Mr. Ai made his statement after a court in Beijing rejected his appeal of a lower court’s verdict saying he would have to pay back taxes. He was detained for 81 days last year, and after his release, Beijing officials said Mr. Ai owed $2.4 million in back taxes and penalties. Mr. Ai paid a bond of $1.3 million to contest the government order. Tax officials are expected to keep the bond, which means Mr. Ai will owe $1.1 million. It was unclear what would happen if he did not pay. The government still holds Mr. Ai’s passport, and he has been forced to cancel overseas appearances.

For years, soccer has struggled there. A national league folded in 2004 amid bankruptcy and bad feeling, and the shiny new A-League that started a year later has yet to establish a solid foundation.

headline: John Sununu’s a Teddy Bear
abstract: Just don’t get him started on the president.
lead_paragraph: You recently described the vaguely Southern accent the president uses in speeches as “phony as his jaunt when he runs up and down Marine One.” What exactly is a phony jaunt?  Every time you see him climbing up or down stairs, he elevates his arms and does this pumping, trying to look like a well-trained and trim dynamic individual. It’s something he does all the time, particularly when he’s climbing up to a podium to speak or address a crowd. This president understands that he got elected on the basis of style and not substance, and I think he’s trying to preserve style.

headline: How a Diner Gets the Most Out of Social Media
abstract: Servers have been trained to offer to take a group picture if they see a smartphone on the table. This is a terrific way to generate Instagram and Facebook photos.
lead_paragraph: Squeeze In is a modest little breakfast-and-lunch diner with four locations in the greater Reno, Nev. area. The restaurants are open seven days a week, 7 a.m. to 2 p.m. While online commenters rave about the food, I can’t get over how creatively this little chain has managed its social media. It has a Web site and a custom mobile site. It promotes the business through Foursquare, Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest and Instagram.

headline: Internal Devaluation and the Road to Wigan Pier
abstract: What Churchill wrought.
lead_paragraph: Greg Ip, in correspondence, directs me to Chapter 3 of the latest IMF World Economic Outlook, which among other things contains an analysis of a case that bears directly on the attempts of euro area countries to restore economic health through fiscal austerity and internal devaluation: Britain’s return to the gold standard after World War I.

headline: Leopard Poaching on the Rise, Group Warns
abstract: A demand for coats and other luxury leopard items in Asia has caused poaching of the animals to soar to more than 200 leopards a year in India alone, a report says.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the poaching of endangered species, elephants, tigers and rhinos tend to be in the limelight. But a new report sets out to plug the information gap on a different species that is imperiled by a tide of demand related to rising affluence in Asia: leopards.

headline: Ousted From Party in China, Bo Xilai Faces Prosecution
abstract: Beijing officials announced Friday that the disgraced politician had been expelled from the Communist Party and would be prosecuted on criminal charges. The state news agency also said the party congress was scheduled for Nov. 8.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese leaders announced Friday that Bo Xilai, a disgraced Communist Party aristocrat, had been expelled from the party and would be prosecuted on criminal charges. The leaders also said they had scheduled the 18th Party Congress, the climax of China’s once-a-decade leadership transition, to start Nov. 8.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Help Remembering What To Do
abstract: For all its faults, Siri is actually pretty good at tracking things you need to do. And Android users might like Gtasks.
lead_paragraph: This week’s App Smart column talked about apps that help you organize and remember important tasks. Smartphones are great for storing to-do lists and reminding you of the items on them, a big help  if, like me, this is something you’re not very good at naturally.

headline: Debate Challenge? What to Call Your Opponent
abstract: Will it be “Mr. President” or “the president” when Mr. Romney refers to his rival? Will Mr. Obama talk about the “governor” or “my opponent”? Or will “Mitt” and “Barack” slip out?
lead_paragraph: As Mitt Romney and President Obama huddle with their debate coaches this weekend, they will each have to make a simple — but potentially critical — decision ahead of Wednesday’s face-off.

headline: Merkel’s Ex-Finance Minister to Oppose Her

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s leading opposition party on Friday nominated a quick-witted former finance minister to challenge Chancellor Angela Merkel in next year’s general election, in a jolt to a race that had appeared heavily weighted in favor of the incumbent.

headline: A Dangerous Gateway to Mount Everest
abstract: Nepal has been home to numerous airplane crashes in the past decade.
lead_paragraph: An aircraft full of trekkers headed to Mount Everest crashed in Nepal’s capital, Katmandu, on Friday morning, killing all the 19 people on board. This accident is just the latest in a string of recent fatal airline accidents in Nepal, and has once-again raised questions about the safety of air travel to one of the most iconic tourist destinations in Asia.

headline: At the U.N., Agitation, Outrage and Business as Usual
abstract: The Day: New Yorkers love few things more than to hate the United Nations, and they really love to hate it in a week like this one, when world leaders convened for the General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Here in the “capital of the world,” which is New York’s characteristically modest description of itself, people seem to have survived their annual immersion in foreign affairs with but the faintest disruption to their lives. We knew all along that they could do it, despite the overblown forecasts of impending disaster, including the menace they were instructed by television to dread most of all: traffic jams.

headline: Tim Cook Apologizes for Apple’s Maps
abstract: Complaints and jokes about Apple’s new maps have not stopped since the company released iOS 6 last week, a software update that replaced Google’s maps with its own. Now the company’s chief executive, Tim Cook, is apologizing.
lead_paragraph: After more than a week of complaints and jokes about Apple’s new mapping service, the company’s chief executive apologized to customers on Friday for the frustration it has caused.

headline: Uncomfortable Truths
abstract: Brazil’s truth commission must establish once and for all that there was a systematic effort to torture and kill opponents of the military regime that ruled from 1964 to 1985.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO — It was more than two decades ago, but I still remember the shocked look my brother and I shared when our father first told us he had done time in prison for working against Brazil’s military government. In disbelief, we went straight to our mother. She was surprised: “I thought we were going to wait until they were older.”

headline: Security Fears Hobble Inquiry on Libya Attack
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism']

lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Sixteen days after the death of four Americans in an attack on a United States diplomatic mission here, fears about the near-total lack of security have kept F.B.I. agents from visiting the scene of the killings and forced them to try to piece together the complicated crime from Tripoli, more than 400 miles away.

headline: Shotgun Wedding Suburban Jungle
abstract: In Lisa Zeidner’s satirical novel, a heavily armed woman disrupts a suburban marriage ceremony. Lisa Zeidner’s new novel about the middle class deploys sympathetic characters and edgy satire.
lead_paragraph: Do the self-satisfactions of the middle class and its rituals somehow prove irresistible to a novelist? Is it just too tempting to consider how a big social gathering might go disastrously wrong? Consider Ayelet Waldman’s “Red Hook Road,” in which a young couple meet a tragic end hours after taking their vows, or, in a more playful register, Ali Smith’s “There but for the,” which sends a dinner party spinning out of control when a guest locks himself in a room and refuses to leave. Lisa Zeidner’s funny, chaotic new novel, “Love Bomb,” is pitched in tone somewhere between Waldman’s and Smith’s: realistic in its depiction of sympathetic characters facing a crisis, while edgy in its satire of a well-off New Jersey suburb and its sometimes hapless police force.

headline: The End of the Middle

lead_paragraph: There are two major flaws in “The Betrayal of the American Dream,” a new book about the dismantling of the middle class. The first is its diagnosis of what’s causing the country’s economic troubles. The second is its prescriptions.

headline: Perspective Is at Play in Who Is ‘Better Off’
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Those who have done well don’t seem more likely to vote for President Obama, and those with less money appear to be least likely to vote for Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: “This president cannot tell us that you are better off today than when he took office,” Mitt Romney said as he accepted the Republican presidential nomination. Since then, “Are you better off?” has become a central theme of the campaign, and is likely to surface next week at the first presidential debate.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: New F.T.C. Rules for Children Online, and Being a Replacement Official
abstract: Also, the man thought to be responsible for the crude video that set off riots in the Muslim world is arrested, and Facebook wants you to say “happy birthday” with a card.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission is expected to tighten rules soon about Web sites that collect information about children, Natasha Singer writes, greatly increasing the need to obtain parental permission for common practices like using cookies to track young users’ activities online, or their location via a mobile phone, or accepting photographs submitted by children under 13. The current federal rule, which dates to 1998, requires parental consent before Web sites can collect personal information like phone numbers or physical addresses from children, but those rules can appear antiquated considering how technology has changed over more than a decade.

headline: Potus v. Scotus
abstract: Jeffrey Toobin examines the ideological battles between President Obama and the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: The Oct. 22, 2007, cover of Time magazine displayed a portrait of Chief Justice John Roberts above the line does the supreme court still matter? “As the dust rises and the opinions, concurrences and dissents pile up, the court turns its attention to ever smaller cases related to ever narrower points of law,” David Von Drehle lamented in the accompanying article. “The court’s ideology is playing a dwindling role in the lives of Americans.”

headline: State of Disunion
abstract: The tension between individualism and community as an enduring theme in American history.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post columnist E. J. Dionne Jr. has ascended to a sufficiently elevated plane of the Higher Punditry that his author’s biography no longer mentions he received a doctorate from Oxford, where he was a Rhodes scholar. Even so, he still comes across as a precocious student, bubbling with boyish charm and enthusiasm for ideas, though sometimes a bit glib and preening. His books are clever, upbeat and interesting, particularly when he examines current political concerns through the lens of history, religion and philosophy. But while readers will admire Dionne’s intellectual dexterity in diagnosing the historical origins of our present political problem of division and dysfunction, they may also wish he could make a more substantive case for how we might move beyond it.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – It was one of the more curious asides of this week’s annual procession at the United Nations General Assembly of heads of states airing their differences, setting out their political stalls and maneuvering for position both internationally and before their audiences and voters at home.

headline: Gay Center to Make Its Village Home More Open and Less Noisy

lead_paragraph: The love that now dares speak its name can still sometimes be hard to hear.

headline: From the Old South to the New Right
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Strom Thurmond, champion of segregation, was also a major figure in modern conservative politics.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina died in 2003 at the age of 100, he seemed to embody the term “political survivor.” Think of someone who began his career as a Roose­velt Democrat and finished it as a Reagan Republican, who campaigned for president as a white supremacist and ended up supporting a national holiday for Martin Luther King. Decades passed, one generation replaced another, but Thurmond soldiered on, swapping causes, even political parties, with a juggler’s eye. Where many politicians become objects of contempt or indifference over time, with Thurmond the reverse was true: the longer he lasted, the more revered he became.

headline: Pro-Life, Pro-Left
abstract: Before there was a religious right, there was a religious left.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, Mark Hatfield, one of America’s most prominent evangelical politicians, wanted to abolish the draft and clandestinely wore a Eugene McCarthy pin under his lapel. A Republican senator from Oregon, Hatfield had fans in evangelical churches around the country. When organizers of the 1973 National Prayer Breakfast invited him to address Richard Nixon, Henry Kissinger and other conservative luminaries (the Vietnam War was a “national sin and disgrace,” he told them), he based his remarks on a text written by a renegade seminarian named Jim Wallis — a former member of Students for a Democratic Society who believed that being “pro-life” meant hating war and poverty as much as abortion.

headline: Save Us
abstract: Steve Stern’s fiction weaves the mischievous and the wondrous.
lead_paragraph: Steve Stern’s characters — Shimmele, Avi, Fagie, Morty, Mendy, Mushie — are escape artists. They want to escape doting, caviling parents, the injunctions of Mosaic law and a stifling “atmosphere where sedulous study was valued above action.” They want, in other words, to escape Judaism.

headline: Odd Men Out
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A satire of the Iraq war and the often chaotic world of those not facing enemy fire.
lead_paragraph: In the American wars of the 20th century, soldiers of the rear echelon were derided as “in the rear with the gear,” or worse. However, the whole concept of a “rear,” predicated on a definable “front,” started slipping in Vietnam and met its official death in Somalia. By the time of the Iraq occupation, the place where clerks did their clerking and infantrymen got a plate of hot chow was no longer in a relatively safe rear area but in the forward operating base, or FOB, smack in the middle of everything, and the soldiers stationed there became known as Fobbits.

headline: For Marchionne and Winterkorn, a Parisian Showdown Is Averted
abstract: On Friday, the chiefs of Fiat and Volkswagen resolved a dispute over leadership of an industry lobbying group.
lead_paragraph: A dispute at the highest levels of the principal lobbying group for Europe’s automotive industry was resolved with a handshake on Friday, as Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Fiat and Chrysler, met with Martin Winterkorn, chief executive of Volkswagen, on the convention floor at the Paris motor show.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THIS IS HOW YOU LOSE HER,  by Junot Díaz. (Riverhead, $26.95.) The stories in this collection are about love, but they’re also about the undertow of family history and cultural mores, presented in Díaz’s exciting, irresistible and entertaining prose.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ANATOMY OF A DISAPPEARANCE,  by Hisham Matar (Dial, $15.) Matar’s fiction revolves around his parents, and especially his father, a Libyan dissident who was kidnapped by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s agents in Cairo in 1990. In his elegiac second novel, a boy struggles with the mysterious abduction of his father, exiled from an unnamed Arab country, and with his confused, preadolescent desire for his father’s much younger second wife.

headline: Book Burdening
abstract: Offering ideas; denying gratitude.
lead_paragraph: I recently started reading a wonderful and compelling book about sports. Before I finished it, I bought a copy and gave it to my 14-year-old nephew. As I got further into the book, I came upon a homosexual relationship that I thought might not be appropriate for my nephew to be reading, as he was brought up in a very religious household. I’m now feeling irresponsible for not having finished the book before giving him a copy. I am inclined to tell his parents my feelings, but he may have already read the book and perhaps thought nothing of it. Do I confess all? KATHRYN KORS-JACOBSON, CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: How Not to Fire a President

headline: Who Made That Trampoline?
abstract: It all started with a kangaroo named Victoria.
lead_paragraph: In 1960, George Nissen rented a kangaroo named Victoria from an animal-supply outfit on Long Island so that he could train her to hop on a trampoline he set up in Central Park. After a week of waltzing with Victoria, clasping her front paws as he taught her to bounce in time with him, Nissen finally produced a mind-bending photograph. In it, Nissen and the kangaroo stare into each other’s eyes as they levitate over the trampoline. The photo was reprinted around the world and helped establish the trampoline as a global phenomenon.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Michael Chabon’s best-selling new novel, “Telegraph Avenue,” started out a dozen years ago as an unproduced television pilot.
lead_paragraph: PILOT EXPERIMENT: Michael Chabon’s new novel, “Telegraph Avenue” — it’s at No. 7 on the hardcover fiction list — tells the story of two families, one black and one white, in Oakland and Berkeley, Calif. Twelve years ago, when Chabon’s novel “The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay” was starting to make some noise (it went on to win a Pulitzer in 2001), newspaper profiles mentioned that the author was wrapping up another project: a television pilot called “Telegraph Avenue,” about a black family and a white family in Oakland and Berkeley, Calif. How did Chabon get from there to here? “When I first considered the possibility of transforming the script into a novel,” he said via e-mail, “I went through the usual process, apparently requisite to my beginning any novel, of lying to myself about how easy it was going to be. I told myself I would just be able to ‘novelize’ it. Two and a half years later, battered and discouraged and ready to quit, and ready to kill the optimistic idiot who got me into this mess, I belatedly realized my mistake. A pilot is there to set the table. To set it beautifully, and with a proper and adequate complement of utensils for the coming meal. But in terms of nourishment it only really sets out some canapés, maybe a dish of olives. A novel has to serve a full, seven-course meal with sherbet in the middle and maybe a last little passed tray of petits fours. I had to start all over again, and reconceive the entire thing.”

headline: Longshoremen’s Lament
abstract: Automation and large machines have cut deeply into the human workforce on the waterfront, loading and unloading the millions of containers that enter the Port of New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Automation and large machines have cut deeply into the human workforce on the waterfront, loading and unloading the millions of containers that enter the Port of New York and New Jersey.

headline: On the Waterfront, Rise of the Machines
abstract: At the Port of New York and New Jersey, where longshoremen’s jobs have systematically been diminished by automation, the remaining human workers cling to the hope of relevance.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — IN the rising light of a mid-September morning, the CSAV Pyrenees, a blue-water freighter sailing out of Suape Port in Brazil, was lashed to its lines at Berth 59 of the Port Newark Container Terminal. At rest beneath a looming row of gantry cranes, the ship had come to port on a half-day call to discharge a load of South American cargo: 421 containers’ worth, each one weighing as much as a family of elephants — or slightly more than 40,000 pounds.
