headline: Now That’s More Like It
abstract: The N.F.L. referees return, R.A. Dickey wins his 20th game and, for a night, everything seems right.
lead_paragraph: If at times the sports world seems ready to be subsumed by the forces of big business, to give us all the feeling that we’re being played for deep-pocketed fools, turned upside down by leagues and owners until every last coin falls into their vaults, well, Thursday was the antidote. Times two.

headline: Giving Jittery Frogs a Chance to Chill
abstract: Prison inmates working with Oregon spotted frogs give them a chance to remain motionless, a skill they will need to defend themselves in the wild.
lead_paragraph: Frogs have a reputation, earned or not, of being skittish creatures. Their physiology would almost seem to make the case by itself. With quads like that, you’d be jumpy, too, right?

abstract: The TransCultural Express program will feature a variety of American and Russian culture.
lead_paragraph: Creating a cultural exchange between the United States and Russia, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Mikhail Prokhorov Fund have announced a three-year partnership.

headline: Philanthropists Weigh the Returns of Doing Good
abstract: “Impact investing,” which treats philanthropy as an investment, has brought an interest in determining whether the money is having the effect the philanthropists intended.
lead_paragraph: ALL philanthropists want their donations to mean something, be it for a new wing for a hospital or to finance a program aimed at doing social good. Increasingly, though, philanthropists are looking for a way to measure the impact of their dollars.

headline: The Bond of Blueberry Jam
abstract: “Putting up” just-past-ripe berries and stone fruits in summer, and cooking apple and pumpkin butters all day over a low flame in fall, allows me to reach back to tradition and bond with my daughter, neighbors and friends.
lead_paragraph: I started making jam with my daughter, Anna, the summer she was 3 1/2. She’s now a high school senior. That summer we had discovered a small blueberry farm that sold plump, fresh blueberries by the carton during their exceedingly short growing season. We sat at a four-seat counter in a hot, tiny room adjacent to the field and enjoyed the freshest blueberry ice cream we’d have in our lives, before loading the car with berries to take home for jam.

headline: The Dirtiest Part of a Catcher’s Job
abstract: Examining the decisions a catcher makes while bracing for a potential collision at home plate, through the eyes of Russell Martin of the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: As Russell Martin squatted into his crouch, he calculated the risk. It came in the form of a 6-foot-1, 210-pound player named Mike Trout. Fast, solidly built and eager to make another mark in his eye-opening rookie season in the majors, Trout stood about 80 feet away, near third base.

headline: Amid Guns and Blood, an Ethicist Finds Religion in Eastwood’s Films
abstract: A religion professor argues that there is a strong moral, even theological, vision to Clint Eastwood’s movies, raising questions for philosophers as well as for movie lovers.
lead_paragraph: Although a lifelong film buff, Sara Anson Vaux took a dim view of Clint Eastwood for decades. But in 1992 Dr. Vaux, who teaches religion at Northwestern University, saw “Unforgiven,” Mr. Eastwood’s highly praised Western about an assassin drawn out of retirement for one last payday.

lead_paragraph: This week, the New York Times critics look at the futuristic thriller “Looper,” the education drama “Won’t Back Down,” and the Thai drama “Headshot.” All of this week’s reviews can be found here.

headline: Only the Songs Remain the Same

lead_paragraph: WHEN the 23rd annual New York Cabaret Convention begins three nights of performances on Oct. 17 at Rose Hall at Jazz at Lincoln Center, it will start a new chapter both for the convention and the nostalgic genre it celebrates. The future of both depends on cabaret’s reinvention into something more contemporary than a museum for the American songbook.

headline: Redefining Southern Women With Spine
abstract: For a Lifetime movie, a Broadway director reconfigures a 1989 film weepie with a black ensemble.
lead_paragraph: THE 1989 film “Steel Magnolias,” the story of small-town Louisianans negotiating life’s bumps and blessings, is a pop culture classic. A three-hanky comedy-drama, it is fondly remembered for female bonding and zippy one-liners about sanity, men and bitchiness. So Kenny Leon, the director known for spinning black stories into critical and commercial gold, was excited about an offer to direct a TV film version with black actresses, but wanted sound artistic reasons to tinker with the material.

headline: The British Are Coming, Once Again
abstract: The television series “Call the Midwife,” from the BBC, will have its American premiere on PBS.
lead_paragraph: THERE are many things we can learn from PBS’s splendidly refined British import “Downton Abbey,” like how to serve soup and what to do when a Turkish diplomat dies in your bed. But there are other areas of life, entire chapters of existence, to which it offers no guide.

headline: Unplugged, Singer Taps Deep Into Her Roots
abstract: Beth Orton prepares to release her first album in six years, “Sugaring Season.”
lead_paragraph: BETH ORTON was falling in love. At Retrofret, a vintage instrument dealer in Brooklyn, she grew smitten last last month with a Gibson Southern Jumbo from the 1940s: a spruce-topped, dreadnought-size guitar with a throaty low register and a price tag above $7,000.

headline: Audi Crosslane: A Hybrid Mongrel That Leans Electric
abstract: Audi said the use of lightweight materials and reliance on an electric motor for motive power would help the concept achieve fuel economy of over 200 miles per gallon.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Crossover” can mean just about anything in the automotive industry. But with the Crosslane Coupe Concept, introduced here on Thursday, Audi shoehorned a remarkable number of referents into what was already something of a catch-all notion.

abstract: An iconic modernist chair is reimagined by contemporary designers and auctioned to benefit the breast cancer research.

headline: Lennon Art Show Will Benefit Citymeals-on-Wheels
abstract: The exhibition in SoHo is timed to what would have been Lennon’s 72nd birthday.
lead_paragraph: About 100 limited-edition drawings by John Lennon will be on view in a free exhibition that starts next week in SoHo.

headline: A Soda Fight Moves to a Sitcom Town
abstract: In what is surely the first dramatic adaptation of the mayor’s ban on large sugary drinks, the sitcom “Parks and Recreation” took on the issue of a soda tax.
lead_paragraph: A pragmatic city politician wants to reduce the size of sodas. The soft-drink industry fights back, saying the plan will hurt businesses and infringe on consumers’ rights.

headline: Off the Charts: Looking Better, or Looking Bad?
abstract: With the economy an issue in the presidential campaign, the answer to the question of how the economy is doing may depend on one’s point of reference. The charts show four economic indicators, using a relatively short time frame that shows substantial improvement, and a much longer one, showing that current conditions are well below prerecession levels.
lead_paragraph: With the economy an issue in the presidential campaign, the answer to the question of how the economy is doing may depend on one’s point of reference. The charts show four economic indicators, using a relatively short time frame that shows substantial improvement, and a much longer one, showing that current conditions are well below prerecession levels.

headline: Rules of War
abstract: The Lincoln administration’s battleground regulations have reached far beyond American shores.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the American debate about war — about torture, drone strikes, the killing of civilians in Afghanistan and Pakistan — has also been a debate about the international laws of war. But much of this law, as John Fabian Witt shows in his magnificent new book, was originally made in America.

headline: Abraham to Zachary
abstract: Ranking the presidents is a favorite parlor game of the politics-obsessed.
lead_paragraph: One night a few months ago, my 7-year-old son — who during the Republican primaries developed a mildly obsessional interest in presidential history — asked me to rank the American chief executives in order of greatness. With bedtime looming, I resolved to make it quick. Rattling off the successes (George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, Franklin D. Roosevelt) proved easy, as did listing the failures (James Buchanan, Andrew Johnson, Herbert Hoover, Richard Nixon). But filling in the middle drove me crazy. Should William McKinley place higher or lower than Gerald Ford? Martin Van Buren above or below Rutherford B. Hayes? Yawning, and under pressure from my eager son, I randomly plugged in Millard Fillmore, Chester A. Arthur and the Harrisons and called it a night.

headline: In Battle Over Myanmar Mine, Folk Heroines Emerge
abstract: In a sign of how things are changing in Myanmar, two village women have won national prominence for defying a copper mine project backed by the military.
lead_paragraph: WETHMAY, Myanmar — They were trailed by plainclothes police officers and called “cows” by government officials. They spent four nights in prison, until a public outcry prompted their release.

headline: There’s a Play at the Plate
abstract: A look at some of the memorable plays in baseball involving catchers and home plate collisions.

headline: Sick Dolphin, Stranded in Queens, Dies on Arrival at Rescue Center
abstract: After several hours on the beach in Far Rockaway, the dolphin was taken to the Riverhead Foundation on Long Island for treatment Friday afternoon but never made it to a tank.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:48 p.m. |  A female common dolphin, six feet long and nearly 140 pounds, bobbed ashore at Far Rockaway, Queens, on Friday morning and flopped onto the beach.

headline: Man Thought to Be Behind Anti-Muslim Film Is Arrested
abstract: Nakoula Basseley Nakoula, who has many aliases, prosecutors say, was arrested Thursday on parole violations.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The man thought to have been behind the anti-Islam video that set off deadly protests across the Muslim world in recent weeks was arrested on Thursday for violating terms of his probation in a 2010 bank fraud case.

headline: Where the Bubbles Come From, and How to Get There
abstract: The grapes are ripe and the vintners are welcoming in the Champagne region of France. Have you visited European vineyards during the harvest? Have a favorite? Share your experiences with Rendezvous readers in the comments.
lead_paragraph: PARIS—When I visited Champagne recently to have a look at the newly renovated Abbey of Hautvillers and to taste some Dom Pérignon, the harvest was just about to get under way.

headline: On a Night Crowded With Hits, ‘Big Bang’ and ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ Stand Out
abstract: The CBS comedy had the highest ratings for Thursday night, while ABC’s hospital drama had strong results despite fears that interest might be fading. A new ABC drama, “Last Resort,” has a promising debut.
lead_paragraph: The television season’s first Thursday — a night always packed with hit shows — delivered some of the most-watched episodes of premiere week with established favorites like “The Big Bang Theory” and “ Grey’s Anatomy” coming back strong.

abstract: There was a time, maybe a decade ago, when we complained, “Where have all the groupies gone?” Those days are over.
lead_paragraph: CROWDEDNESS is a reality of modern life (I tell myself as we chug across the Seine, or the morning salute of car horns begins outside my hotel window), and so it is in fashion.

headline: Common Core Practice | A King’s Skeleton, a Musical Mystery, a Territorial Dispute

headline: Vatican Says Papyrus Referring to Jesus’ Wife Is Probably Fake
abstract: The Vatican called the fragment of a Coptic text “problematic and controversial,” and most likely an “inept forgery.”
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican has raised doubts about a recently released fragment of a Coptic text in which Jesus alludes to having a wife, describing it as “problematic and controversial,” and most likely a fake.

headline: Fracking Suspense Cuts Into Second-Home Sales
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Shale', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: Some would-be buyers delay purchases in upstate New York out of concern that natural gas drilling could despoil the landscape.
lead_paragraph: As I report in the real estate section of The Times, many would-be buyers are deferring purchases of second homes in upstate New York out of concern that hydraulic fracturing might be allowed nearby. For now, no one knows whether Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration will allow this controversial natural gas drilling process to go forward.

headline: Raf Simons and the Remapping of Dior
abstract: In just six months at Dior, Raf Simons has shown that he’s more than a creative director. He’s a decorator, an architect, and a definitive tastemaker. His July couture collection put Dior again in the spotlight. Today, he gave Dior a modern blueprint for its ready-to-wear and accessories.
lead_paragraph: In just six months at Dior, Raf Simons has shown that he’s more than a creative director. He’s a decorator, an architect and a definitive tastemaker. His July couture collection put Dior again in the spotlight. Today, he gave Dior a modern blueprint for its ready-to-wear and accessories.

headline: Knicks Appear Closer to Signing Rasheed Wallace
abstract: Rasheed Wallace, who has not played in the N.B.A. since 2010, could soon sign with the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks appear to be one step closer to signing Rasheed Wallace, who could be the latest and yet another veteran player this off-season to join the team just before training camp. A person with direct knowledge of the situation said Wallace took his physical with the Knicks’ training staff Thursday.

abstract: The former ambassador to the U.N. stuck to Romney campaign talking points on Fox News.
lead_paragraph: John Bolton, the former ambassador to the United Nations most famous for saying the 38-floor U.N. headquarters could be 10 floors smaller “and it wouldn’t make a bit of difference,” shared his thoughts today on the recent unrest in the Middle East and North Africa.

abstract: In this week’s photo for the baby boom generation, smiling models display an atomic age bomb shelter.
lead_paragraph: Every week The Shot offers a photo of the people, places or things of our generation. Do you have memories related to this image? Share them with us in the comments.

headline: Borrowing From Your Family, by Design
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Many families have created no-interest loan funds to help members pay off educational and other expenses.
lead_paragraph: It’s much tougher than it used to be for young Americans to make their financial way in the world, given the increasing cost of college and the challenge of finding a job with benefits and a wage high enough to cover the basics plus the servicing of any student loan debt.

headline: The Debate Expectations Dance
abstract: Presidential debates are coming up, and it’s time to lower expectations for your campaign and raise the bar for your opponent.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Ripping the stuffing out of your opponent means it is another day on the campaign trail.

headline: Referees Feel the Love, at Least for One Game
abstract: With an agreement to end the lockout reached, regular N.F.L. officials were unanimously celebrated and praised as they returned to the field on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Gene Steratore and his brother, Tony, founded a janitorial supply business in 1988. They still run the company, but during autumn weekends they are usually focused on their part-time jobs as N.F.L. officials.

headline: Viewing the Economy Through Campaign Glasses
keywords: ['Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Over the short term, several trends would appear to favor President Obama; longer term, they seem to reflect Mitt Romney’s views.
lead_paragraph: ACCORDING to numerous economic indicators, the American economy is getting better.

headline: China Alters Its Strategy in Diplomatic Crisis With Japan
abstract: There are hints that the government was tacitly encouraging the nationalistic demonstrations against a former enemy, and has now decided to rein them in.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After allowing anti-Japanese demonstrations that threatened to spin out of control, China has reined them in and turned instead to hard-edged diplomacy over disputed islands in the East China Sea to lessen any potential damage the conflict might have inflicted on the nation’s softening economy and a delicate leadership transition.

headline: Displaying the Dinosaurs of the Digital Age
abstract: The Computer History Museum in Mountain View, Calif., has a new 25,000-square-foot permanent exhibition dedicated to innovations and artifacts throughout the history of computing.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Not everyone’s pulse will quicken with a glimpse of a 1956 I.B.M. Ramac actuator and disk stack. For many, too, the 1959 Telefunken RAT 700/2 analog computer will just look like a cross between an antediluvian switchboard and the control panel for a German submarine. And while those of us of a certain age who are technically inclined might recall elegant, finely made slide rules with fondness, can even a hint of nostalgia be summoned for the glowing five-inch screen of a barely luggable, suitcase-size 1981 Osborne computer?

headline: Bill Cunningham | Turnabout
abstract: Freedom of expression in dress was out in full force during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Freedom of expression in dress was out in full force during New York Fashion Week.

abstract: Mark Lilla talks about Charles Kesler’s “I Am the Change.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Mark Lilla reviews “I Am the Change: Barack Obama and the Crisis of Liberalism” by Charles R. Kesler. Mr. Lilla writes that he needs help in understanding the conservative view of the president, whom he sees as “a moderate and cautious straight shooter.” Mr. Lilla continues:

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Justice League of Scientists
abstract: Richard P. Feynman has come back to my reading list in the form of “The Manhattan Projects,” which enters our softcover list at No. 8.
lead_paragraph: In all my years of reading comics, I never thought that one of my favorite characters would be the real-life physicist Richard P. Feynman. I learned quite a bit about him last year, when I read the biography “Feynman,” published by First Second. As I said then, “much of the science went over my head, but the story was always captivating as were the scenes from his everyday life.”

headline: Iranian News Agency Plagiarizes The Onion
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'News and News Media', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Apparently unaware of the unwritten rules of both ethical journalism and satire, an Iranian news agency published an edited copy of a report from The Onion on Friday, without crediting the original.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated: Saturday, 6:13 p.m. Apparently unaware of the unwritten rules of both ethical journalism and satire, an Iranian news agency published an edited copy of a report from The Onion on Friday, without crediting the original or acknowledging that it was fiction.

headline: For Bank of America, More Trouble From Merrill Lynch Merger
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Executive Compensation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: The $2.43 billion that Bank of America will pay in the Merrill Lynch case ranks as one of the 10 largest settlements in in a securities class-action lawsuits, behind the settlement over the disastrous AOL-Time Warner merger.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America has resolved one of the largest and most embarrassing pieces of litigation related to its merger with Merrill Lynch in 2008. But the settlement comes with a pretty hefty price tag, since the bank has agreed to pay $2.43 billion to end the lawsuit. That monetary award ranks it as one of the largest settlements in a securities class-action case, behind the settlement over the disastrous AOL–Time Warner merger.

headline: F.C.C. Backs Proposal to Realign Airwaves
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission approved a process to pay television broadcasters to give up airwaves that would then be auctioned to cellphone companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government took a big step on Friday to aid the creation of new high-speed wireless Internet networks that could fuel the development of the next generation of smartphones and tablets, and devices that haven’t even been thought of yet.

lead_paragraph: The Universal Music Group closed on its $1.9 billion acquisition of EMI Music on Friday, a week after receiving regulatory clearance in Europe and the United States and more than 10 months after it first made the deal with Citigroup.

headline: Netanyahu’s Bomb Diagram During U.N. Speech Stirs Confusion in Israel
abstract: The meaning of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s drawing at the United Nations is unclear to many people in Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When the prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, drew his red line on a cartoonish diagram of a bomb from the podium of the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday, he intended to illustrate in simple terms the point at which Iran’s uranium enrichment program must be stopped, at least in Israel’s view, to thwart a final sprint to a nuclear weapon.

headline: Upsides and Downsides of Family Loans
abstract: Can a family loan fund help shield borrowers and lenders from some of the common pitfalls of person-to-person family loans?
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I provide a primer on creating a family loan pool. The advantages here are many. There is potentially more money available if many family members contribute. Many people can participate in setting the rules and distribution of loans, so emotion is less likely to get in the way. And it may be easier to enforce those rules if an entire clan is standing behind the loan.

headline: Adopting the Classroom as a Stage
abstract: The School of American Ballet is drawing younger, active dancers (and even students) to teach. Peter Martins, the artistic director and chairman of faculty at the School of American Ballet, recruits still-active dancers as teachers.
lead_paragraph: EVERYONE knows that a dancer’s performance career ends with age. But what about a dance teacher’s? At the School of American Ballet, a generational shift is under way. Not only do former and current New York City Ballet members, including Arch Higgins, Darci Kistler, Katrina Killianand Jonathan Stafford, dominate its staff, but Peter Martins, the artistic director and chairman of faculty at the school, has put programs in place to pump even more new blood.

headline: Quail Is Worth a Second Thought
abstract: If you can roast a chicken, roasting a quail is absolutely no problem, and it is ready in half the time. Married with grapes, a burnished quail is extraordinarily aromatic.
lead_paragraph: MOST people I know happily order quail in a restaurant, but rarely think of cooking them at home. I often wonder why, because nothing could be easier. If you can roast a chicken, roasting a quail is absolutely no problem, and it is ready in half the time.

headline: Sept. 30 — Oct. 6
abstract: A selection of events.
lead_paragraph: ABC takes aim at lovers of the macabre on Sunday with the premiere of its drama “666 Park Avenue,” but the creepiest program on television actually comes along on Friday, when Animal Planet’s “MONSTERS INSIDE ME” returns (8 p.m. Eastern).

headline: Rookies Give Americans an Early Edge
abstract: Strong showings from Keegan Bradley, Phil Mickelson, Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson helped the United States take a lead over Europe at the Ryder Cup at Medinah Country Club.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — Clearly the Ryder Cup is not such a steep learning curve, after all.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: Le Taste of France on Pier 54, at West Street and 13th Street, celebrates French gastronomy and culture Saturday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Chefs will prepare special dishes paired with French wines and liquors. A French flea market, live music, wine tastings, games and a French bulldog show are part of the schedule. On Saturday from 6:30 to 11 p.m., Le Soiree turns the event into a big dinner party where guests can meet chefs. Tickets for the day session are $30 in advance, available online or $40 at the door. The Sunday evening program is $149 a person.

headline: New French Budget Focuses on Slicing Deficit
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Income Tax', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Although he was elected on a pro-growth platform, the first budget from President François Hollande instead emphasizes freezing government spending and raising taxes on corporations and the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande, a Socialist who was elected this year on a pro-growth platform, presented a budget on Friday that would produce the biggest cut in the public deficit in 30 years while raising the top rate for the wealthiest taxpayers to 75 percent from the current 41 percent.

headline: In Paris, Ford Fiesta Tries On the New Family Face
abstract: The subcompact hatchback received a midcycle refresh, bringing it in line with recent styling trends at Ford.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 2013 Ford Fiesta subcompact hatchback arrived here on Thursday bearing signs of the automaker’s unified styling strategy, with a little bit of Fusion, Focus Electric and Evos concept reflected in its face.

lead_paragraph: September 27, 2012 - Real estate listings languish over fracking fears in Catskills.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: How to Read Like an Economics Columnist
abstract: Adam Davidson, “It’s the Economy” columnist, talks about the books he is reading, the books he has loved and the unread book on his bedside table that eats at his conscience.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: This is the first installment of a new series on the 6th Floor. Once a week, a magazine contributor will be quizzed about books they’re reading or have read or hope one day to finally get around to reading. First up is Adam Davidson, who writes the It’s the Economy column.

headline: (Psst: We Feel Bad About Our Arms)
abstract: Time to face the truth: we shouldn’t all go sleeveless like Michelle Obama.
lead_paragraph: I HAD expected to keep mum about my problem with Michelle Obama until after the election, but my frustration has gotten the better of me. I can contain it no longer.

headline: Rich Rome: The Venues
abstract: Dine with Colosseum views and visit a chocolate boutique on this well-funded tour.
lead_paragraph: Dine with Colosseum views and visit a chocolate boutique on this well-funded tour.

headline: Revelations in High-End Rome
abstract: Accustomed to seeing the city on limited funds, the author plunges into its pricier pleasures.
lead_paragraph: IT was one of those absurdly hot Roman afternoons when the sun-blasted plazas empty out and the sherbet-hued town houses, peach and lemon and lime, look ready to melt into the cobbled streets. Weary of the touristy Tridente district, I crossed the tony Piazza San Lorenzo in Lucina and slipped into a tiny new art-house cinema, savoring the air-conditioning. Within seconds I was lost in a movie that I had never heard of: “Cracker Bag,” a moody coming-of-age film from Australia. The credits rolled and I fixed my eyes on the screen, eagerly awaiting the next movie — another obscure film from another far-off land.

headline: The Beauty of Frugal Rome: Some of the Best Things Are Free
abstract: The Frugal Traveler wanders, chats and even crashes his way into Eternal City bargains.
lead_paragraph: THE young waitress, hair tied up and black T-shirt tugged over one shoulder, was marking up the menu with her suggestions for a 10-euro tasting flight at Open Baladin, a spot in the historic center of Rome that serves over 100 Italian-made beers.

headline: Frugal Rome: The Venues
abstract: Wine, history and more, all for less.
lead_paragraph: Wine, history and more, all for less.

headline: A Spanish SoHo Springs Up in Seville
abstract: A fashionable moniker is just the beginning of this reinvented neighborhood’s story.
lead_paragraph: A fashionable moniker is just the beginning of this reinvented neighborhood’s story.

headline: A Soft-Pedaled Escape From Paris
abstract: As cyclists roll east from the city along a canal, the scenery flickers from artful graffiti to tidy parks to verdant canopies.
lead_paragraph: IT was easy to imagine that we’d pedaled our bicycles deep into a Pissarro painting, one of his sun-dappled, late-19th-century Impressionistic scenes of riotous summer vegetation outside Paris. Rows of soldier-straight poplars lined the narrow Canal de l’Ourcq, their leaves rustling in a breeze that tempered the warm August air. The surrounding woods smelled heavy and green, and the canal’s still, dark waters reflected the slender poles of a few fishermen on its grassy banks.

headline: Another Voice Had Come Between Us
keywords: ['Love (Emotion)', 'Global Positioning System', 'Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Automobiles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The competent voice of the GPS unit in our rental car was a delight for my husband, but I just wanted to throw her out.
lead_paragraph: ON a romantic trip through the English countryside, my husband fell in love with another woman. He met her at a car rental agency on the outskirts of London, where she arrived with the upgrade package.

headline: Revisiting Mexican Flavors in a California Surf Town
abstract: A high school reunion lures a New Yorker back to Southern California, where she begins a Mexican food odyssey at a place called Beach Liquor.
lead_paragraph: YOU know what doesn’t change in 20 years? The smell of eucalyptus. To some people, that soft, sweet green scent is the smell of massages and yoga classes. To me, it’s teenage angst. To me, the smell of high school, the smell of nervousness, awkwardness, acne, hormones, the smell of being a teenager is all wrapped up in the smell of eucalyptus.

headline: Waves and Wildlife in Costa Rica
abstract: On a peninsula in northwest Costa Rica, aspiring wave riders go to surf school alongside an exotic jungle habitat.
lead_paragraph: IT’S not every day that you step out from a sunset surf session straight into a jungle habitat of howler monkeys dangling in leafy guarumo trees, cicadas conducting a symphony, and a pair of white-nosed coati — raccoon-like animals with striped tails and masks — strolling across a dirt road, sending geckos darting out of their path. It was so enchanting that I even forget to swat at the mosquitoes hovering about, getting ready to divebomb my legs.

headline: A World Traveler (57 Times) on the Andes
abstract: As executive producer of “The Amazing Race,” Bertram van Munster says he has traveled around the world 57 times. In an interview, he talks about his adventures in the Andes.
lead_paragraph: IF there was anyone who could be forgiven for being unmoved by the sight of the Andes Mountains, it would be Bertram van Munster. As executive producer of the Emmy award-winning reality show “The Amazing Race,” whose new season premieres on Sunday, he says he has circled the world 57 times.

headline: Hotel Review: TRYP Hotel in New York
abstract: This property boasts a collection of kid-friendly (bunk beds!) rooms and a location that’s about a 10-minute walk from Times Square.
lead_paragraph: THE UPSHOT

headline: Restaurant Report: Manfreds & Vin in Copenhagen
abstract: This crowded wine bar offers one of the great bargains in what has become one of the most exciting food cities in the world.
lead_paragraph: The disco ball lighting up the glassed-in wine room in the back of Manfreds & Vin, a crowded wine bar in Copenhagen’s fashionably scuffed Norreborro district, doesn’t help much when it comes to making out the labels. But it does set the mood: you’re not here just to navigate a serious collection of hard-to-find natural wines from cult vintners with limited productions, you’re here to have fun.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: A reader responds to an article about a destination in Guatemala.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding “Pools, Caves and Chocolate” (Sept. 16), I found this article to misrepresent the experience of visiting Semuc Champey, which is a standard stop on the tourist trail in Guatemala. It’s a pity that the author has to recycle tired travel-writing tropes of “discovery” to make her observations seem more exciting. I understand that one of the appeals of Semuc Champey is its remoteness, that it’s not completely overrun with other tourists, but the author seems to be indulging in some kind of fantasy in which she and her boyfriend discover an untouched Eden.

headline: Heather Thompson and Edward Burke
abstract: The couple, who have extensive history in diplomatic work, are married in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: EDWARD BURKE was taking photographs of a group of young women from South Africa who were visiting the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African Art, where he is the public affairs specialist. As he framed a shot through the lens, his focus jumped to the chaperon: the tall, lithe Heather Joy Thompson.

headline: Museum Tower in Dallas Says It Is Trying to Solve Glare Problem
abstract: Sunlight reflected from the condominium is sending excessive light into a sculpture center’s galleries and burning plants.
lead_paragraph: The 42-story glass-skinned condominium in Dallas known as Museum Tower, which is sending a harsh reflective glare into the nearby Nasher Sculpture Center, addressed the issue in a paid letter printed in Friday’s Dallas Morning News.

headline: Brontë’s Lovers, Facing Even More Storms
abstract: A new “Wuthering Heights,” from Andrea Arnold, examines the Brontë novel from a racial perspective.
lead_paragraph: WITH more than a dozen film versions, Emily Brontë’s “Wuthering Heights” is something of a cultural touchstone for ill-fated love. The title alone conjures up images of a brooding Heathcliff and a delicate Cathy clinging to each other or suffering alone on the Yorkshire moors. For many fans, the characters are synonymous with Laurence Olivier and Merle Oberon in the 1939 movie. And yet, at least when it comes to screen adaptations, the novel may be the most misunderstood book of all time.

headline: Wheelies: The Hot Seat Edition
abstract: Lewis Hamilton, the 2008 Formula One champion and driver for McLaren, will join Mercedes in 2013, and Sergio Pérez will leave Sauber to fill the seat vacated by Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: The Morning Sky Hinted at Misery, and Then, It Delivered
abstract: Friday was one of those days that was the very definition of dreary or gloomy or whatever your preferred bleak adjective may be.
lead_paragraph: It was a day that defined gloom. There was the color scheme: An ominous palette of grays and blacks when your too-early alarm clock had you hoping for a primary-color sunrise.

headline: Romney Continues to Hit Obama on Defense Cuts and Foreign Policy
abstract: Speaking to his second military group in two days, Mitt Romney hammered President Obama over cuts to military spending, as well as of his handling of foreign policy issues.
lead_paragraph: RADNOR TOWNSHIP, Pa. — Speaking to his second military group in two days, Mitt Romney on Friday hammered President Obama over cuts to military spending, as well as of his handling of foreign policy issues.

headline: For Brooklyn’s New Arena, Day 1 Brings Hip-Hop Fans and Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Music', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: The Barclays Center’s grand opening was punctuated by protesters, music-goers and throngs of curious onlookers hoping to share in the excitement.
lead_paragraph: After nine years as the focal point of a pitched confrontation over urban development, power and basketball, the Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with the hip-hop superstar Jay-Z performing at a sold-out concert while activists outside the arena reminded attendees of the unfulfilled promises of the center’s developer.

headline: That’s Some Key
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The key to Gramercy Park has long been a token of privilege available to only a handful of city residents. These days, it is a bigger status symbol than ever.
lead_paragraph: THERE are 383 aspirational keys in circulation in the Big City, each of them numbered and coded, all of them equipped to unlock any of four wrought-iron gates offering privileged access to undisturbed siestas or tranquil ambulation inside the tree-lined boundaries of Gramercy Park. At age 181, the only truly private park in Manhattan is lovelier and more ornamental than ever; yes, the colorful Calder sculpture swaying blithely in the breeze inside the fence is “Janey Waney,” on indefinite loan from the Calder Foundation.

headline: Are Americans Better Off?
abstract: September 28, 2012 — James B. Stewart on which Americans are better off now than four years ago.
lead_paragraph: September 28, 2012 — James B. Stewart on which Americans are better off now than four years ago.

headline: Some Analysts Start to Like RIM
abstract: Though most analyst sentiment is negative for Research in Motion’s prospects, some analysts are turning positive.
lead_paragraph: Investors, perhaps pleased by any bit of good news from Research in Motion, pushed up the beleaguered BlackBerry maker’s share price on Friday almost 7 percent after a quarterly financial report that, while loss ridden, was not as bad as feared.

headline: 'Lawrence,' Before and After Restoration
abstract: A clip from “Lawrence of Arabia,” showing the look of the scene before the film’s digital restoration and after.
lead_paragraph: A clip from “Lawrence of Arabia,” showing the look of the scene before the film’s digital restoration and after.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Christian Dior
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a pretty, mixed-media pump.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Maison Martin Margiela: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: What Sands of Time Did Not Erase
abstract: The 1962 film “Lawrence of Arabia” was repaired and refurbished, all 320,000 frames of it, to a quality beyond what Blu-ray can capture.
lead_paragraph: NO studio today would make a film like “Lawrence of Arabia” — 227 minutes long, featuring a cast of hundreds riding camels through the desert, shot on location (there were no computer graphics in 1962). Yet Sony Pictures’ new 50th-anniversary restoration — playing at the New York Film Festival on Sunday and in more than 600 theaters nationwide starting Thursday — seems fresh and modern, in its political themes and its stunning visual clarity.

headline: The Party Politics of the Father-Daughter Dance
abstract: A law interpreted as banning father-daughter dances has become a fall political football in one community.
lead_paragraph: When a Rhode Island P.T.O. set out to plan a “Me and My Guy” dance, as well as a mother-son baseball game, it was unaware that the state and district had concluded that laws prohibiting sex discrimination in “any and all other school functions and activities” meant no father-daughter or mother-son events. One single mother complained, the A.C.L.U. responded, and the school district immediately apologized — the dance took place as scheduled with all genders of parents and children welcome to attend. But the ban itself has become, as Jess Bidgood reported for The Times, a “fiercely debated political flashpoint” with divisions falling along what have become predictable partisan lines.

headline: Project Basement: Receiver Connectors Rule
abstract: Shopping for a receiver was once a simple matter, but now there are new considerations, like connectivity and the ability to upgrade software.
lead_paragraph: Shopping for a receiver used to be a pretty simple matter. You listened to those in your price range and bought the one that sounded best.

headline: ‘Honey Boo Boo’ Has the Ratings, if Not the Critics
abstract: As “Here Comes Honey Boo Boo” on TLC ends its first run, the ratings show viewers loved what the critics hated.
lead_paragraph: When TLC’s reality series “Here Comes Honey Boo Boo” made its debut in August, it was met with such derision by some television critics, that it seemed like the title should be changed to “Look Out! Here Comes Honey Boo Boo.”

headline: Artist’s Foundation Seeks Return of ‘Sphere’ to World Trade Center Site
abstract: No permanent home has been announced for a sculpture damaged in the 2001 terrorist attack and now itself serving for some as a memorial.
lead_paragraph: “The chorus voicing a pledge for the return of the ‘Sphere’ to its original place at the W.T.C. has reached as far as Landshut, Lower Bavaria, Germany,” the letter begins. That’s a consequential destination because it is the home of Fritz Koenig, the sculptor of the World Trade Center “Sphere,” and of his museum and foundation.

headline: Spain Needs $76 Billion to Recapitalize Its Banks, Audit Finds
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The independent banking assessment was well below the potential 100 billion euros, or $128.6 billion, in bailout money Spain negotiated with the euro zone in June.

headline: A ‘Downton Abbey’ Prequel in the Works
abstract: How did that distinguished Earl of Grantham, Robert Crawley, hook up with the American Countess Cora?
lead_paragraph: How did the distinguished Earl of Grantham, Robert Crawley, hook up with the American Countess Cora? Did he marry for love or her inheritance?

headline: Giving With an Eye on the Impact
abstract: Bucks readers recount their experience in donating money with the idea of making a measurable impact.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week discusses philanthropists who not only want their donations to do good, they are looking for a way to measure the impact of their giving.

headline: Norton To Publish Philip Roth Biography
abstract: The publisher won the rights to the volume, by Blake Bailey, at auction, and will publish a memoir by Mr. Bailey as well.
lead_paragraph: W.W. Norton & Company will publish the previously announced authorized biography of Philip Roth, the press announced on Thursday.

headline: Beyond the 6-Speed: More Ratios for Automatic Transmissions
abstract: General Motors and Ford are expected to cooperate on developing new automatic transmissions, possibly with 10 speeds, designed for improved fuel economy
lead_paragraph: Detroit

headline: Till Death, or 20 Years, Do Us Part
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: It may be time to acknowledge the harsh truth that nearly half of marriages in the United States end in divorce and many others are miserable, and consider something like a 20-year marriage contract.
lead_paragraph: IT makes little sense to explore a new era of family values based around Hollywood couplings. Or, worse yet, around mere rumors of the way movie stars conduct their marital affairs.

headline: Beets Are Back, With Greens
abstract: Beets, a longtime favorite on the Well blog, make their return, this time in a frittata, in salads and with beet greens.
lead_paragraph: The beet has always been a celebrated treat on Well. We’ve put them in everything from smoothies and lasagna to birthday cake and risotto.

headline: U.S. Move to Give Egypt $450 Million in Aid Meets Resistance
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Lawmakers wary of foreign aid in general, and of Egypt’s new leadership in particular, protested the planned infusion of cash, which the Obama administration disclosed to Congress on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration notified Congress on Friday that it would provide Egypt’s new government an emergency cash infusion of $450 million, but the aid immediately encountered resistance from a prominent lawmaker wary of foreign aid and Egypt’s new course under the leadership of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Versatile Housing, in Both Kind and Cost
abstract: In Port Jefferson Station, L.I., homes range from apartments, to tiny cottages on small plots, to substantial properties on several acres.
lead_paragraph: AS it slices east to west through Port Jefferson Station, the thoroughfare called Nesconset Highway, or Route 347, is a dividing line in more than just a physical sense. According to the Census Bureau, the southern portion of town actually has a different name: Terryville.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.5 Million
abstract: A five-story Greek Revival-style house, with fireplaces and a roof deck, was owned by the “24” actor Kiefer Sutherland.
lead_paragraph: Apparently bulletproof when it comes to investing in antique West Village real estate in need of renovation, Kiefer Sutherland, a k a the infamous Jack Bauer of “24” and presently starring in “Touch” on Fox television, has sold his five-story brick town house at 763 Greenwich Street for $17.5 million, in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Little Bit of Hepburn
abstract: Star Jones makes sure she looks ladylike on television.
lead_paragraph: Star Jones, 50, has appeared on television the last two decades. She is currently a panel member on “Today’s Professionals,” a weekly segment of “Today” on NBC, with Donny Deutsch and Dr. Nancy Snyderman. A native of Badin, N.C., Ms. Jones, a former prosecutor, lives in Manhattan.

headline: Charging Ahead on an Electric Highway
abstract: Can you take an electric car on a road trip? To find out, a reporter drives the Model S on a 530-mile journey through California, stopping at Tesla’s Supercharger stations for fill-ups along the way.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

headline: One Big Step for Tesla, One Giant Leap for E.V.’s
abstract: The automobile has not undergone a fundamental change in design or use since Henry Ford introduced the Model T, but the Tesla Model S has the potential to be a game-changer.
lead_paragraph: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: A Quieter Side of Swizz Beatz
abstract: The hip-hop producer Swizz Beatz is exploring a quieter side as a painter, and slowly establishing himself as a prominent collector of contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: ON a muggy August morning, the hip-hop producer known as Swizz Beatz stepped from the SoHo apartment he shares with Alicia Keys, and climbed into an S.U.V. with his 5-year-old son. In the front seat was his uncle and bodyguard, a man who spent two decades in prison and has the biceps to prove it.

headline: What’s Going On With My Bank?
abstract: Attacks by hackers on some major bank Web sites have disrupted at least one small business, its founder says, and the longer it goes on, the more worrisome it becomes.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was kind of a busy day, but late in the afternoon I tried to log in to my bank’s Web site to see what checks had posted (I bank with PNC). I couldn’t get in. Web sites don’t load now and then, and I didn’t give it much thought.

headline: Carmakers Try to Figure Out the New Generation
abstract: How do you make a car appeal to young people raised on digital gear? That's the central question facing the automakers at the Paris Motor Show.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The digital generation is apathetic about cars. And that’s a problem for automakers.

headline: Paper or Plastic? Some Communities Say Neither
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Plastics', 'Shopping Bags', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Governments around the country are approving restrictions and fees on paper and plastic shopping bags in an effort to encourage consumers to bring their own.
lead_paragraph: Bill Hoffman, owner of Aptos Jewelers in Aptos, Calif., sells bracelets, rings and pendants for thousands of dollars each. He balks at the notion of charging customers an extra 10 cents for a shopping bag, but Mr. Hoffman has no choice. It is the law.

headline: That Loaded Gun in My Carry-On? Oh, I Forgot
abstract: An increasing number of people in the United States are being caught boarding airplanes carrying guns, hand grenades and other dangerous items, federal authorities say.
lead_paragraph: The list of potentially lethal weapons was certainly eye-opening: 47 guns (38 of them loaded, including six with rounds in their chambers), three inert hand grenades, supplies of black powder, hunting knives, timing fuses and a sword.

headline: Going the Distance
abstract: No single new model can overhaul the auto industry, but the Model S, along with its charging network for long-distance travel, suggests that Tesla is playing for keeps.
lead_paragraph: No single new model can overhaul the auto industry, but the Model S, along with its charging network for long-distance travel, suggests that Tesla is playing for keeps.

abstract: Scenes from the Paris fashion week photo diary of Nacho Alegre.

headline: As Apple’s Maps Stumbles, AOL’s MapQuest Flourishes
abstract: Apple’s map application debacle has been a boon for an unlikely suspect: MapQuest. The map company, owned by AOL, seemed to have been eclipsed in the era of in-car GPS and smartphones, but it is experiencing a resurgence.
lead_paragraph: As Apple struggles to improve its Maps application, which has been irritating and amusing users with its shortcomings and inaccuracies, the company is urging its users to seek transit and traveling directions elsewhere.

headline: Mets Post Third Consecutive Decline in Attendance
abstract: The Mets sold 2,242,803 tickets in 2012, 109,793 fewer than in 2011.
lead_paragraph: During their meltdown after the All-Star Game, the Mets tried everything to get fans to go to Citi Field: T-shirts on Tuesdays, half-price tickets for those who brought Pepsi cans and free tickets for children.

abstract: The founder of Milk Studios helps organize a Paris Fashion Week party at Les Deux Magots.

headline: A Big Settlement, Flexible Ethics and Special Section on the Law
abstract: Bank of America agreed to a $2.43 billion settlement. | A British trade group gave up its Libor power. | Andrew Ross Sorkin questioned the flexible ethics of bankers’ new lobbyist. | A special section explored the intense competitive pressures confronting law firms.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America agreed to a $2.43 billion settlement. | A British trade group gave up its Libor power. | Andrew Ross Sorkin questioned the flexible ethics of bankers’ new lobbyist. | A special section explored the intense competitive pressures confronting law firms.

headline: Hot-Button Issue: The ‘Hot’ Factor
abstract: For President Obama and Mitt Romney, taxes, health care, jobs and international affairs may be subject to debate. On some social media sites, the topic is who’s hot.
lead_paragraph: JOHN F. KENNEDY was a striking man — by most accounts, the best-looking person ever to occupy the White House — but he lived in an age before Facebook, Tumblr, YouTube, chat groups and discussion threads made that a subject to debate with as much fervor as health care reform and offshore tax havens. Not so this year’s presidential candidates.

headline: In Florida, Biden Attacks Romney on Social Security and Medicare
abstract: Campaigning in Florida, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. widened his attack against Mitt Romney to accuse him of favoring higher taxes on Social Security benefits to pay for tax cuts for the rich.
lead_paragraph: Campaigning in Florida, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. widened his attack against Mitt Romney on Friday to accuse him of favoring higher taxes on Social Security benefits to pay for tax cuts for the rich.

headline: California Issues 10,000th Rebate for Zero-Emissions Incentive Program
abstract: The 10,000th rebate was claimed by the buyer of a 2012 Nissan Leaf.
lead_paragraph: Start undressing California’s Clean Vehicle Rebate Project, a program intended to spur the sales and leases of zero-emission vehicles, and front-page topics come into view — reduction of greenhouse gases and job creation chief among them. So when the program recorded its 10,000th rebate earlier this month, it merited some pomp.

headline: West Virginia Displays Art of Quarterbacking
abstract: The observation and creativity skills that made Geno Smith a talented art student in grade school have served him well as West Virginia’s quarterback.
lead_paragraph: From across the room, the teacher heard 3-year-old Geno Smith read a children’s book aloud.

headline: What’s an Allowance For?
abstract: A friend invites your child to the movies. Will he spend his money, or yours?
lead_paragraph: R. wrote me that she spent the summer feeling like “a constant A.T.M. machine” for her 14-year-old. If a young teenager wants to hang out at the mall, see a movie, or get a smoothie,  inevitably there’s cash involved. Fourteen, she notes, is too young to get a “real job” but not too young to spend what’s adding up to real money.

headline: For Flutist in West Bank, a Rare Chance
abstract: A young flutist, Dalia Moukarker, looks forward to becoming one of just a handful of West Bank Palestinians to study abroad.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE more than three years ago she was a quiet, serious-minded 16-year-old flutist in the West Bank with posters of the Berlin Philharmonic flute soloist Emmanuel Pahud on her bedroom wall. Travel restrictions made it a struggle to go for lessons in Jerusalem. Finding space to practice in an apartment crowded with four siblings was difficult. Despite her hard work, her prospects seemed limited.

headline: Come Hither, City Quail
abstract: Tracking down quail in the urban jungle is less complicated than expected.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s City Kitchen column, I needed a few quail. It turned out that hunting them down in the urban jungle was less complicated than I imagined. Indeed, the first butcher I called had just received a delivery of fresh quail. Out of curiosity, I investigated a handful of other local options.

headline: Friday Night Music: Transatlantic Sessions (Sarah Jarosz)
abstract: Ring them bells.
lead_paragraph: Seems appropriate given my current location:

headline: The Image as Obsession, No Matter the Method
abstract: The cinematographer Agnès Godard shoots on video for the first time in “Sister,” directed by Ursula Meier.
lead_paragraph: PARIS

headline: Filmmaker Sets Focus Very Close to Home
abstract: Gotham Chopra, who made a film about his father, says Deepak Chopra is seen most clearly not in isolation but in public.
lead_paragraph: UNDERSTANDING one’s parents might be as difficult as fathoming the cosmos, but it’s something most of us try to do, in one way or another. Doing this through the lens of a camera for a documentary film, as a number of children of famous parents have in works like “My Architect,” by the son of Louis Kahn; “William Kunstler: Disturbing the Universe,” by the radical lawyer’s two daughters; and “The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby,” by Carl Colby, can be an effective, if grandiose method. It allows the filmmaker to use the tried-and-true tools of the profession while also making a very public statement.

headline: Tall in the Saddle in 2 Eras at Once
abstract: John Wayne stars in four “Three Mesquiteers” installments from the 1930s: “Overland Stage Raiders,” “Red River Range,” “The Night Riders” and “Three Texas Steers.”
lead_paragraph: LOUISE BROOKS is barely recognizable in “Overland Stage Raiders,” the 1938 Republic western that would prove to be her last film: the magnetizing star who went to Germany to make “Pandora’s Box” and “Diary of a Lost Girl” (both released in 1929) has let her daringly close-cropped hair grow out into conventional waves, her nose and chin seem sharper, and the fire in her eyes has dimmed. But there she is, providing the perfunctory love interest in a low-budget feature meant for Saturday morning children’s matinees, playing against a good-looking but gawky young man who a few years later would become one of the biggest stars in the business, John Wayne.

headline: Obama Orders Chinese Company to End Investment at Sites Near Drone Base
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Wind Power']
abstract: President Obama cited national security risks in his actions on wind projects near a Navy base where drone training is conducted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, citing national security risks, ordered a Chinese company on Friday to divest its interest in four wind farm projects near a Navy base in northern Oregon where training missions for drone aircraft are conducted.

headline: As It Followed a Car Chase, Fox News Showed a Suicide
abstract: The episode, which occurred despite a five-second delay, led to a detailed apology from the host at the time, Shepard Smith.
lead_paragraph: 6:16 p.m. | Updated The Fox News Channel, in the course of following a car chase live in Arizona, on Friday broadcast the suicide of the man who was being pursued by the authorities.

lead_paragraph: Subjects include an excursion in the Adirondacks with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s visit to New York and a long-awaited subway transfer station in Manhattan.

headline: Roasting Peppers
abstract: Roasting your own peppers are so much better than what you can buy in a store. Melissa Clark shows how.
lead_paragraph: Roasting your own peppers are so much better than what you can buy in a store. Melissa Clark shows how.

headline: Iran Ridicules Netanyahu’s Bomb Theatrics, and Calls on Israel to Renounce Nukes
abstract: The Iranians were responding to the General Assembly speech on Thursday by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who described Iran as an apocalyptic threat.
lead_paragraph: Iran said Friday that Israel’s latest warnings at the United Nations of an impending Iranian atomic weapons threat were baseless theatrics, and called on Israel to disband its own unacknowledged nuclear weapons arsenal and sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty just as Iran had done 44 years ago.

headline: Danger Lurks Between Peppers Sweet and Hot
abstract: It can be risky cooking with peppers that are neither hot nor sweet — your dinner could end up mellow or leave you in need of a fire extinguisher.
lead_paragraph: THERE are sweet peppers; there are hot peppers; and then there are those peppers that fall somewhere in between. They are the Russian roulette of peppers, the kinds that you can never be quite sure about until you take a bite.

headline: Inside the Mind of Worry
keywords: ['Brain', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Fear (Emotion)']
abstract: The basic architecture of the brain ensures that we feel first and think second.
lead_paragraph: Cambridge, Mass.

abstract: With help from friends at home and abroad, a young Palestinian flutist has found a way to escape the walls around her West Bank village.
lead_paragraph: With help from friends at home and abroad, a young Palestinian flutist has found a way to escape the walls around her West Bank village.

headline: ‘Peter and the Starcatcher’ To Close in January
abstract: The play, which moved to Broadway from the New York Theater Workshop, will have played 320 performances there when it closes on Jan. 20.
lead_paragraph: After flying from downtown to Broadway and winning five Tony awards, “Peter and the Starcatcher” will close, the producers announced on Friday.

headline: Romney Speaks With Netanyahu
abstract: After a phone call with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Mitt Romney told reporters that he did not believe military action against Iran would be necessary but that he would not “take that option off the table.”
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, Mass. — Moments after finishing a phone call with  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Mitt Romney told reporters on his private campaign plane Friday that he did not believe military action against Iran would be necessary, but added that he would not “take that option off the table.”
