keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: Cowboy cars in Santa Fe, lowriders in Northern California and Japanese collector cars outside of Boston are among the highlights in this weekend in automotive culture.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Returning to Cozy Tradition For a Season’s 2nd Welcome
abstract: The New York Philharmonic offered the violinist Itzhak Perlman and a program of traditional favorites on Thursday, the second of its season-opening nights.
lead_paragraph: When is an opening night not an opening night? Perhaps when it is the second of two.

headline: Barclays Center: An Arena With Many Faces
abstract: Diagrams of the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, the first new large indoor arena for sports and entertainment built in New York City since 1968.
lead_paragraph: Diagrams of the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, the first new large indoor arena for sports and entertainment built in New York City since 1968.

headline: Video: Last Call for Peppers
abstract: In this week’s video, I show two techniques for roasting and peeling fresh peppers.
lead_paragraph: It’s the end of fresh-pepper season, so if you haven’t had your fill of gorgeous sweet and hot peppers this summer, the time is now. In this week’s video, I show two techniques for roasting and peeling them — both in the broiler and on an open flame on the stovetop. You could also use your grill if the weather is clear in your backyard.

headline: Tim Cook’s Apology Is an Important Step Forward
abstract: Whatever the story, the Apple chief’s apology for the condition of the new maps app conveys a note of humility that has been missing so far. Without it, the Apple Maps fiasco felt even worse than it was.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, apologized for releasing the flawed Maps app on iOS 6. I don’t mean a flimsy P.R.-speak apology — I mean a heartfelt one that seems fully cooked.

headline: Advertising Week Begins Monday, Focusing on Technology and Returning Veterans
abstract: The ninth annual event has new sponsors, including Twitter and Pandora, and a program called Operation Deploy that is meant to find jobs in the ad industry for returning veterans.
lead_paragraph: It has been said many times that the most popular words in the advertising business are “new and improved.” But the phrase offers a way to describe changes in store when the ninth annual Advertising Week takes place in New York next week.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Spring 2013 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Chic in Review | Raf Simons’s New Look
abstract: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Baton Rouge Newspaper Sees an Opportunity in New Orleans
abstract: With the Times Picayune cutting back to three print editions a week, the Baton Rouge advocate is making an aggressive move to court New Orleans readers.
lead_paragraph: It’s a Hail Mary pass for New Orleans newspaper lovers dreading the day that the city no longer has a daily paper. Starting on Monday, the first day that The Times-Picayune no longer prints every day, The Advocate from Baton Rouge will offer home delivery of a New Orleans edition.

headline: At Summit Series in Moscow, Canadians Ask, “Where’s the Beef?”
abstract: Team Canada was brimming with groceries when it arrived in Moscow for the Summit Series in 1972. But most of the beer and the steaks disappeared after their arrival.
lead_paragraph: In Canada, all that matters is this: we won.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Nepal, West Bank, Spain and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Nepal, West Bank, Spain and Israel.

headline: Even Health Dept. Isn’t Safe From Bedbugs
abstract: The appearance of a single bedbug led to the fumigation of a floor at the headquarters of the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
lead_paragraph: A single bedbug led to fumigation of one floor of the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene’s headquarters in Long Island City, Queens, on Friday.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A three-bedroom lodge in Hopewell, N.J., and a four-bedroom house in Bellmore, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom lodge in Hopewell, N.J., and a four-bedroom house in Bellmore, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Manhattan Valley co-op, a Financial District condo and a Wallabout house.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan Valley co-op, a Financial District condo and a Wallabout house.

headline: The ‘Illegal’ Trap
abstract: Is the term ‘illegal’ immigrant improper, or useful?
lead_paragraph: A vigorous discussion is taking place online about the word “illegal” as an adjective for certain immigrants. An immigrant activist named Jose Antonio Vargas, a former reporter, is urging news organizations like The New York Times to stop using it. He says the word is inaccurate, improper and demeaning.

headline: Catholic Leader Is Turned Away at Exhibit He Deemed Offensive
abstract: William Donohue, president of the Catholic League, said he was barred from a gallery displaying “Piss Christ,” a 1987 photo of a crucifix immersed in urine.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, William Donohue, the president of the Catholic League, held a news conference outside an art gallery in Midtown Manhattan to denounce one of the works of art on display there: a 1987 photograph of a crucifix immersed in a jar of urine. But, when Mr. Donohue tried to enter the exhibition, the gallery would not allow him in, he said in a blog post on Friday.

headline: Judge Strikes Down a Dodd-Frank Trading Rule
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Wall Street posted another victory in the battle over regulation, as a federal judge on Friday struck down the so-called position limits rule, a central piece of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street posted another victory in the battle over regulation on Friday after a federal judge struck down a central piece of the Obama administration’s financial overhaul.

headline: Artists’ Books and Oil Pumps
abstract: At the NY Art Book Fair this weekend at MoMA PS1, Mishka Henner’s aerial photography of oil pumps in Texas will be on display.
lead_paragraph: This weekend the seventh annual NY Art Book Fair takes place at MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens. One of the exhibitors is ABC Artists’ Books Cooperative. And one of its featured projects is ABCED, a 33-volume series of artist books created in celebration of the artist Ed Ruscha’s 75th birthday this December. In the 1960s, Ruscha published a series of artist books — collections of his own photographs sold in small editions — that influenced generations of artists, including Mishka Henner, one of the cooperative’s 25 members.

headline: 2012 Paris Motor Show
abstract: With auto sales bottoming out in Europe, the mood during press previews for the biennial Paris salon reflected a hope that 2013 might mark the beginning of a slow recovery. Here is a look at some of the models that were shown.
lead_paragraph: With auto sales bottoming out in Europe, the mood during press previews for the biennial Paris salon reflected a hope that 2013 might mark the beginning of a slow recovery. Here is a look at some of the models that were shown.

headline: Hybrid Strategy: Divide and Conquer
abstract: Honda is broadening its hybrid strategy by improving its existing single-motor system, adding a new two-motor system and developing a three-motor system aimed at high performance and improved handling.
lead_paragraph: BOTH Honda and Toyota are far more committed to the hybrid car than to the battery electric vehicle, a fact that Toyota made clear this month when it scaled back its Scion iQ electric car project. And Honda is so enthusiastic about hybrids that, as its chief executive, Takanobu Ito, outlined in a recent speech, it will have three separate systems with up to three electric motors.

headline: At Dior, Raf Simons Asserts His Authority
abstract: At Dior, Raf Simons knows how to use minimalism.
lead_paragraph: Is it fair to ask, in the blur of fashion shows, if something can be new?

headline: How to Help Iran Build a Bomb
abstract: Opinion is strong that an attack on Iran by Israel would not slow Iran’s nuclear program, but speed it up.
lead_paragraph: ADVOCATES of airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities have long held that the attacks would delay an atom bomb for years and perhaps even buy Israel enough time to topple the Iranian government. In public statements, the Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, has said that an attack would leave Iran’s nuclear program reeling, if not destroyed. The blow, he declared recently, would set back the Iranian effort “for a long time.”

headline: Lumière | Paris à la Hollywood
abstract: Paris is celebrating the American film industry’s love affair with the City of Light with a new exhibition, “Paris Viewed by Hollywood.”
lead_paragraph: Not all that we see on-screen of Paris is Paris.

headline: Chloé Gets a Salute in Paris
abstract: “Chloé Attitudes” an exhibition organized by Judith Clark, the English curator, is an impressive survey of Chloé’s history, organized by themes of lightness, graphic prints and energy.
lead_paragraph: “Chloé Attitudes” is the name of a new exhibition that opened in Paris at the Palais de Tokyo with a cocktail party Friday night during Fashion Week, though there was little attitude in the way you might associate with the fashionista crowd.

headline: The Roman Who Loved the Greeks
abstract: A Greek-loving, man-adoring Roman emperor is the center of a new play by Javierantonio González.
lead_paragraph: Being the sex slave of Rome’s gay emperor has its drawbacks.

headline: Hold the Crepes, Bring On the Eggplant
abstract: At Mermaid restaurant, where the food could best be described as Mediterranean, an owner rotates through the two dining rooms, making sure diners at every table feel special.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Eddie Ulas Konca and Cevail Sarac first planned to start a restaurant together, they thought it would be a waterfront seafood spot in Huntington. Circumstances changed, and when they opened their restaurant, Mermaid, last year, it was in Hewlett, and nowhere near the water. The name was less apt, but they kept it anyway because they liked it.

headline: A Romantic Who’s Inspired by Streisand
abstract: Ann Hampton Callaway sings from the Streisand songbook — including numbers Ms. Callaway wrote herself — at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Although the singer Ann Hampton Callaway doesn’t sound at all like Barbra Streisand, to whom she paid fervent tribute on Wednesday evening in her new show, “The Streisand Songbook,” at 54 Below, the two share a fundamental, unshakable romanticism. Both favor overarching, dramatic love songs, and both have the vocal equipment to infuse them with fairy tale magic.

headline: In Bridge, Game of Chicago at Regency Whist Club
abstract: Alan Greenberg, known as Ace, celebrated his 85th birthday this month.
lead_paragraph: Alan Greenberg, known as Ace, who celebrated his 85th birthday this month, was the chief executive of Bear Stearns for many years. Although he still has board positions with JPMorgan Chase and Viacom, he has more time for bridge now than when he was with Bear Stearns.

headline: 150 Films, and Parking Spaces, Too
abstract: Movies at the 20th annual Hamptons International Film Festival include a drama directed by David Chase, creator of “The Sopranos.”
lead_paragraph: KAREN ARIKIAN, executive director of the Hamptons International Film Festival, referred to the event as “small” several times in a recent phone conversation. And in comparison to annual festivals in Cannes, Berlin and some other cities, the one on Long Island does seem rather diminutive.

headline: Week in Pictures for Sept. 28
abstract: Subjects of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include an excursion in the Adirondacks with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s visit to New York.

headline: This Sunday: A Video Introduction to the Inspiration Issue
abstract: Hugo Lindgren introduces Sunday’s magazine, on camera.
lead_paragraph: In the magazine’s Inspiration Issue, we tell you about the best books, movies, TV shows, music and art on the horizon, and the stories that led to their creation. Michael Chabon writes about how the O.J. Simpson verdict inspired “Telegraph Avenue,” Alicia Keys describes how she wrote the song “Girl on Fire,” Junot Díaz shares the artifacts that help him write and much more.

headline: California’s Budget
abstract: The director of California’s Department of Finance says Gov. Jerry Brown has put the state on a path toward fiscal stability.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: When Crossing the Street
abstract: A reader recalls the advice she gave her young daughter.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Vivid Glimpse of a Lost America
abstract: An exhibition at the Suffolk County Historical Society features 275 works by Currier & Ives, including the image of a disaster that gave the company its initial boost.
lead_paragraph: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.

headline: In New York, the Ballet and Opera Are Stuffy No More
abstract: At a time when even the most august cultural institutions are being challenged by an ailing economy, a program or guest list larded with the names of celebrity designers, runway models and athletes can be a powerful draw.
lead_paragraph: At a time when even the most august cultural institutions are being challenged by an ailing economy, a program or guest list larded with the names of celebrity designers, runway models and athletes can be a powerful draw.

headline: Why the Beaver Should Thank the Wolf
abstract: Wolves and other predators have a powerful effect on the well-being of the ecosystems around them.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco

headline: Forging Ahead at the Paris Auto Show
abstract: Despite a faltering economy, big automakers showcase glistening new auto lines in France. Reporter Jerry Garrett talks to auto executives to find out how new offerings will survive the slump.
lead_paragraph: Despite a faltering economy, big automakers showcase glistening new auto lines in France. Reporter Jerry Garrett talks to auto executives to find out how new offerings will survive the slump.

headline: Going Hollywood
abstract: Stuffy no more, the New York City Ballet and the Metropolitan Opera are drawing younger names to bring in the money.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Olivia Palermo sauntered down the red carpet at Lincoln Center a week ago, she seized the occasion, the gala opening of the New York City Ballet, as a glittering photo op, a chance to shine in her multitiered Dior gown — and, oh, incidentally, to offer homage to Valentino Garavani, who stepped out of official retirement to create the costumes.

headline: Should U.S. Stay Out of Mideast Affairs?
abstract: Readers react to an Op-Ed essay calling for America to stop intervening.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The V.A.’s Responsibility to Homeless Veterans
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Homeless Persons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: Readers chastise the government for not providing the housing and services needed by disabled veterans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Old Favorite Returns, Freshness Still In Its Step
abstract: Four works create breadth in the first program of the annual Fall for Dance festival.
lead_paragraph: Less than half of the quadruple bill that opens this year’s Fall for Dance season is much good — and yet, like so many Fall for Dance programs over the years, it’s refreshing. This intensely popular annual festival at City Center presents several works by different artists on each program; this year’s, for the first time, are spread over 12 evenings in three weeks. The emphasis is always on the modern and the unfamiliar; even when you decide you don’t care for some offerings, you’re usually still taken somewhere new. (Those of you who need your dance fixes from the “Don Quixote” pas de deux, go elsewhere.)

headline: Reviewing the Tesla Model S
abstract: The automobile has not undergone a fundamental change in design or use since Henry Ford introduced the Model T, but the Tesla Model S has the potential to be a game-changer.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Bradley Berman reviews the 2012 Tesla Model S in a more thorough manner than any other journalist has yet.

headline: Apple’s Plans for Internet Radio Run Up Against Big Music Publisher
abstract: Sony/ATV, a joint venture between Sony and the estate of Michael Jackson, is directly negotiating for digital rights to its music, opting out of the blanket license system that had been standard.
lead_paragraph: The rough news for Apple lately is not just about its much-derided new maps program.

headline: Talent Shows
keywords: ['Officiating (Sports)', 'Football', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Organized Labor', 'Income Inequality', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The N.F.L. strike is a metaphor for the battle in American business.
lead_paragraph: IT was a thoroughly modern economic game, this three-way tiff between N.F.L. owners, players and referees. The N.F.L.’s unionized officials asked for significant wage and pension changes from America’s leading sporting league. In response, the N.F.L. locked out the unionized refs and brought in replacements. The replacement refs struggled. In turn, players spoke out against the replacement refs — especially after an egregious error that ended a marquee game between Green Bay and Seattle. Players, fans and members of the media demanded that the N.F.L. capitulate and pay whatever it took to bring back the regular refs. Finally, a deal was done.

headline: A Diner Redefines Itself
abstract: City Limits, in White Plains, recently emerged from a four-month renovation without its traditional diner counter but retaining its expansive menu.
lead_paragraph: THESE days, calling City Limits a diner may be a misnomer. After a four-month renovation, it reopened in August, with the traditional diner counter removed and a new earth-tone color scheme.

headline: The Tip of Putin’s Wedge Between Urban and Rural
abstract: Igor R. Kholmanskikh leads a movement comprised mostly of “Russia’s rednecks” in the service of President Vladimir V. Putin, who is seeking to divide the Moscow-based opposition.
lead_paragraph: YEKATERINBURG, Russia

headline: A Look at Computer History
abstract: The Computer History Museum in Mountain View, Calif., displays more than 1,000 technological artifacts.
lead_paragraph: The Computer History Museum in Mountain View, Calif., displays more than 1,000 technological artifacts.

headline: At Paris Motor Show, the Home Team Continues to Flout Styling Norms
abstract: Concepts from PSA Peugeot Citroën led a class of vehicles that reminded the world of French automakers’ love of a grand gesture.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French have historically rebelled against the conventions of automobile design, and for that we have cars like the Citroën 2CV and Renault Dauphine to admire and, at times, revile.

headline: Dazzled by a Cute Picture, More Nannies Fall for Swindle
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A teenager describes how, hooked by a photograph of a boy in a monster suit and the prospect of a job, she was defrauded of nearly $3,000.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Canales, 19, said she had only one hesitation about having her name used in this article. “Please,” she said, “don’t make me look like a moron.”

headline: Oklahoma’s Deal With Fox Sports Worth Nearly $60 Million Over 10 Years
abstract: The arrangement falls short of a full-fledged Sooners channel, like the University of Texas’s Longhorn Network, which ESPN created.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the University of Oklahoma announced a deal with Fox Sports that broadened the availability of its sports within the state and spread them throughout Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana. A national component was also added.

headline: Waiting for Teixeira
abstract: Mark Teixeira could return to the Yankees for the final series of the regular season.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It has been a month since Mark Teixeira injured his left calf during a game against the Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium. Going into Friday’s game against the Jays at the Rogers Centre, the Yankees had lost two and a half games off their lead in the American League East during that time.

headline: Nash Hurt in Switzerland
abstract: Rangers forward Rick Nash was hurt playing for HC Davos in the Swiss National League A, leaving a game against HC Lugano after nine minutes.
lead_paragraph: 8:09 a.m. Saturday | Update The Rangers reported Friday night that Nash’s injury was related to his shoulder, not his head.

headline: Remembering the Dream Team’s Remarkable Supporting Cast
abstract: The new documentary “The Other Dream Team” capably illustrates the narrative from the Lithuanian players, who in four years went from winning gold for their Soviet oppressors to a hair-raising bronze medal victory over what passed for a Russian team.
lead_paragraph: This has been quite the commemorative 20th anniversary year for the 1992 Dream Team, often referred to as the first and only collection of N.B.A. stars worthy of the signature. There was a documentary film shown on NBA TV. There was Jack McCallum’s excellent best-seller — “Dream Team” — that needed no subtitle but tacked on the rather verbose “How Michael, Magic, Larry, Charles, and the Greatest Team of All Time Conquered the World and Changed the Game of Basketball Forever.”

headline: N.H.L. Negotiations Stick With Side Issues
abstract: National Hockey League and players’ union negotiators reported modest progress on player safety and drug testing, but the sides remained far apart on the core economic issues in the lockout.
lead_paragraph: League and union negotiators in the N.H.L. lockout, meeting for their first formal bargaining session since Sept. 12, reported modest progress on side issues Friday.

headline: In His Sculptures, Vitality; In His Portraits, Precision
abstract: More than 40 works are on view in an exhibition of figures, busts, bas-reliefs and drawings by the 20th-century sculptor and portraitist Gaston Lachaise.
lead_paragraph: Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Beach or No Beach, Bridgewater Is Thriving in Louisville
abstract: Teddy Bridgewater was close to staying near home and attending University of Miami. Two years later, he is the starting quarterback for undefeated Louisville.
lead_paragraph: When asked to identify the key to success for the Louisville sophomore quarterback Teddy Bridgewater, most observers mention his poise, his athleticism, his detailed knowledge of the Cardinals’ offense. Yet it is possible that the secret behind Bridgewater’s excellent play, which has landed him on some early Heisman Trophy watch lists, can be found in his socks.

headline: 2 Plead Guilty as Kingpins in Drug Gang
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The guilty pleas of the two leaders and of six co-defendants just before trial, following the recent guilty pleas of 26 others, leave just one person still facing charges in the case.
lead_paragraph: Days before the start of a trial that had been expected to last three months, eight members of a large PCP drug ring that operated in Harlem pleaded guilty on Thursday evening to charges that will send some of them to prison for decades.

headline: A Dickens Classic for the Ages
abstract: Poverty, grotesque comedy and violence characterize the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey’s production of “Charles Dickens’s Oliver Twist.”
lead_paragraph: Snatches of songs punctuate the action in “Charles Dickens’s Oliver Twist,” but this is not a predominantly upbeat show like Lionel Bart’s musical “Oliver!” The poverty, social hypocrisy and violence that rule Oliver’s world here are relieved only intermittently by streaks of dark humor and, of course, by the boy’s miraculous deliverance.

headline: In Film and Union’s Ads, Dueling Views of Teachers
abstract: The United Federation of Teachers is spending $1 million for commercials in New York City as a new film called “Won’t Back Down,” which is about the education system, is released.
lead_paragraph: Teachers’ unions have come under fire from politicians like Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago and Mitt Romney in recent months. But rarely has opposition to teachers’ unions worn a face as sympathetic as that of Maggie Gyllenhaal, the Academy Award-nominated actress who plays a crusading parent confronting a bullying, bureaucratic union in a new movie, “Won’t Back Down.”

headline: 2 Democrats, 2 Incumbents and One Tough House Race
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a hotly contested race, the Democratic Party has lined up behind Howard Berman, a respected voice on foreign policy, but his opponent, Brad Sherman, has local appeal.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Howard Berman, the ranking Democrat on the House Foreign Relations Committee, has made more than 150 trips abroad during his three decades in Washington.

headline: Washington Democrats Make a Move on Maine
abstract: Washington Democrats moved into the Maine Senate race on Friday with a sizable advertising buy to attack the Republican seeking to succeed Senator Olympia J. Snowe.
lead_paragraph: Washington Democrats, after months of sitting on the sidelines, moved into the Maine Senate race on Friday with a sizable advertising buy to attack the Republican seeking to succeed Senator Olympia J. Snowe, the moderate Republican who is retiring at year’s end.

headline: Australians Surge in Quest for New Class of Computer
abstract: Teams based at the University of New South Wales have made advances toward building a quantum computer, which could help tackle a new class of problems.
lead_paragraph: Competing teams of Australian scientists have given that country a significant lead in an increasingly intense international competition to build a working quantum computer.

headline: For Fat Sandwiches, an Uncertain Future
abstract: For decades, a cluster of vehicles has served the hulking assemblages called Fat Sandwiches to Rutgers students from a university-owned parking lot, but development plans may shake things up.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

headline: Cooperation Is Cited as Lobbyist in Bribery Case Is Sentenced to 3 Months
abstract: The judge who sentenced Richard J. Lipsky, who had been secretly assisting federal investigators, said Mr. Lipsky deserved “substantial credit for his cooperation.”
lead_paragraph: Richard J. Lipsky, the prominent New York lobbyist who pleaded guilty in a political corruption case and had been secretly assisting federal investigators, was sentenced to three months in prison on Friday by a judge who said he deserved “substantial credit for his cooperation.”

headline: Home Protection
abstract: A look at three techniques that Russell Martin of the Yankees and other Major League catchers use on plays at the plate.
lead_paragraph: A look at three techniques that Russell Martin of the Yankees and other Major League catchers use on plays at the plate.

headline: A Father to Baseball
abstract: Your teammates are your in-season family, and your instinct is to support your brother even if you do not like his politics, his swagger or his batting average.
lead_paragraph: It is the end of the regular season, and time for goodbyes. I remember walking off the field in 2002, after we played our last game. One of my Phillies teammates said it was “a sad time” because you will never play with this same group again. So we gave out big hugs, knowing this nuclear family would forever be dispersed.

headline: Overhaul Special Education for Preschool
abstract: New York State lawmakers need to restructure a costly, fraud-riddled program.
lead_paragraph: New York State clearly needs to strengthen oversight of the fraud-riddled program that spends $2 billion a year on special education services for preschool children with learning or other disabilities. The State Education Department got off to a good start this month when it issued a preliminary reform proposal.

headline: For Some U.S. Players, Waiting Pays Off
abstract: Bubba Watson, Webb Simpson, Matt Kuchar and Dustin Johnson watched the morning pairings on television. In the afternoon, they showed what they can do.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — They were plenty rested after sitting out the morning matches, and when their turn finally came to show what they could do, Bubba Watson, Webb Simpson, Matt Kuchar and Dustin Johnson broke fast out of the gate at Medinah Country Club.

headline: Lager, I.P.A. or Pilsner, It’s Beer of the Local Variety
abstract: Four new breweries are changing Connecticut’s reputation as something of a laggard in the production of craft beers.
lead_paragraph: MENTION craft beer and places like California, Colorado and Oregon, where start-up breweries have thrived for decades, come to mind; not so Connecticut, where small-batch brewing has lagged behind. But with four new breweries — and two more preparing to release beers by year’s end — the way we think about the state’s locally made beer is finally poised to change.

headline: The Economy and the Blame
abstract: Growth is weak and unemployment is high, but Mitt Romney is having a hard time convincing voters that President Obama is responsible.
lead_paragraph: As Mitt Romney sees it, this week’s economic data ought to be bad news for President Obama. The economy slowed to a crawl in the second quarter and the current quarter looks like more of the same. A nascent housing recovery was offset by setbacks in manufacturing. A drop in military spending previewed the pain that is to come if lawmakers don’t find a way to avert even deeper automatic cuts that Republican lawmakers insisted on for 2013.

headline: Seattle’s Tall Secondary Is Batting Away Conventional Wisdom
abstract: Tall and underappreciated, Seattle’s secondary is proving that big defenders do not necessarily lack speed and agility, but have the ability to terrorize receivers with their size.
lead_paragraph: RENTON, Wash. — The youngest, tallest, most underappreciated secondary in professional football consists of two players chosen in the draft’s fifth round, another plucked from the Canadian Football League and another whose diminutive stature almost led to the worst kind of group nickname: Three and a Half Men.

headline: An Unfinished Campaign Against Polio
abstract: Eradicating the world of the virus should be a top priority of the United Nations and should lead to immunizing all children against infectious diseases.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the global fight to eradicate polio vowed at the United Nations on Thursday to step up their efforts to eliminate the virus from the three countries where the disease still has a foothold — Afghanistan, Pakistan and Nigeria. The challenge is that those countries are troubled by political unrest, violence and social customs that can interfere with the delivery of vaccines to the children and adults who need protection.

headline: Thoroughbred Survival at the Racetrack
abstract: A report warns that far tighter controls for horse safety are needed to prevent further compromise of racing’s integrity.
lead_paragraph: An alarming rise in thoroughbred fatalities last winter at Aqueduct Racetrack is prompting a much-needed overhaul of inept, pro-industry regulation of a sport that increasingly puts horses’ lives at risk in the pursuit of profit. A report by a panel of experts said the lives of 11 of 21 horses that died at the track might have been saved if the state had had proper safeguards against overmedicated and substandard horses’ running for purses inflated by profits from the new adjacent casino at Aqueduct.

headline: Breaking Their Fast With a Downtown Twist
abstract: Five friends gathered at Kutsher’s Tribeca on Franklin Street after Yom Kippur.
lead_paragraph: Kutsher’s Tribeca on Franklin Street was designed for a downtown crowd that still craves Jewish home cooking: it bills itself as a modern Jewish bistro, the hip offspring of the original Kutsher’s Country Club resort in the Catskills. For this year’s High Holy Days, it offered special meals, including a Yom Kippur break-fast menu of smoked fish and other favorites alongside nontraditional touches like duck schmaltz French fries. On Wednesday, families small and large and groups of friends filled the plush booths and tables set between blond-wood panels and glowing lights.

headline: The College Rankings Racket
abstract: The U.S. News & World Report’s annual list promotes status at the expense of affordable education.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. News & World Report’s annual college rankings came out earlier this month and — knock me over with a feather! — Harvard and Princeton were tied for first.

headline: One Year Later, Roles Reverse as Red Sox Try to Spoil Orioles’ Playoff Plans
abstract: Boston, having languished for most of the season, has the chance to play spoiler to the Orioles, who are tied for the lead in the wild card race, though the Red Sox fell short to start their weekend series.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — A year ago Friday, on the final day of the 2011 regular season, the Boston Red Sox played here needing to win to keep their playoff hopes alive. The Orioles, who had lost 93 games, refused to let that happen.

headline: Shifting Reports on Libya Killings May Cost Obama
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Changing explanations of the attack on the diplomatic compound in Libya have left President Obama exposed on foreign policy, where he had enjoyed an advantage over Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s shifting accounts of the fatal attack on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, have left President Obama suddenly exposed on national security and foreign policy, a field where he had enjoyed a seemingly unassailable advantage over Mitt Romney in the presidential race.

headline: Hailing Wheelchair-Accessible Cabs
abstract: WOW Taxi allows passengers to call for wheelchair-accessible yellow cabs using a smartphone app, a Web site, a text message or a voice call.
lead_paragraph: APP WOW Taxi

headline: Cambodia Is Seeking 2nd Statue
abstract: Cambodia’s request for American help in the repatriation of a Khmer warrior at the Norton Simon Museum came as Sotheby’s and federal prosecutors argued in court over the fate of a matching work.
lead_paragraph: The Cambodian government has asked the United States to help it recover a 10th-century Khmer sandstone statue from the Norton Simon Museum in California. It says the work was looted from a Cambodian temple complex during the country’s political upheavals in the 1970s.

headline: A Career in Obstetrics, With On-the-Job Training
abstract: A childbirth is never far away in “Call the Midwife,” and some of the scenes are about as detailed as you can get, short of fitting the kid with a helmet-cam in utero.
lead_paragraph: It’s the fall TV season, which means that babies are thick in the air, since childbirth scenes are a sure way to draw “aws” and “ews” from jaded viewers. Babies arrived this week on the premiere of the Fox series “The Mindy Project,” about a young obstetrician, and on the wretched TLC reality show “Here Comes Honey Boo Boo.” Another birth is surely coming on the NBC series “The New Normal,” about a male couple and their mother-for-hire, and the first lady appears to be pregnant on ABC’s “Scandal.”

headline: Hard Times, With Regret But Without Apology
abstract: The R&B singer Bettye LaVette speaks about her long career and struggle to become a star.
lead_paragraph: WEST ORANGE, N.J. — Bettye LaVette makes no apologies for her life. Sitting cross-legged on an Art Deco chair in her living room here, sipping wine, she was animated and gritty as she talked about the decades she spent singing in clubs and cursing her “buzzard luck,” while her contemporaries, like Aretha Franklin and Diana Ross, became superstars.

headline: Sept. 28: A Circular Relationship Between Political and Economic Views
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Economy']
abstract: We often talk about the important role that the economy plays in the election. But Americans perceptions of the economy are also colored by their political views.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s probability of winning the Electoral College fell slightly in Friday’s FiveThirtyEight forecast, from 83.9 percent to 82.7 percent on Thursday.

headline: As Madoff Money Is Distributed, Mets Wonder What Might Have Been
abstract: Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the Mets who are heavily in debt, will not receive a multi-million dollar payout connected with a settlement in the conviction of Bernard L. Madoff.
lead_paragraph: Under better circumstances, the owners of the Mets would have an extra $67.3 million in their bank accounts today, money that could help their losing team after another miserable season.

headline: Lavish Home, Corner of Fire and Brimstone
abstract: “666 Park Avenue,” which has its premiere on ABC on Sunday, features Vanessa Williams and Terry O’Quinn as owners of an apartment building where heating shouldn’t be a problem.
lead_paragraph: How powerful is the Devil? Powerful enough, apparently, to get a not particularly necessary series like “666 Park Avenue” onto network television.

headline: Museum Gathers Piano, Paintings and Video in a Blended Work
abstract: The pianist Mikhail Rudy is the central performer in a staged version of Mussorgsky’s suite “Pictures at an Exhibition” at the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: Some artistic engagements seem inevitable; others, highly unlikely. A brief, intriguing recital presented on Thursday evening by Mikhail Rudy, a Russian pianist born in Uzbekistan and based in France since the 1970s, managed to be both at once.

headline: Forces of Nature: Lightning, Water, Music and Movement
abstract: The Garth Fagan Dance company is performing the premiere of “Lighthouse/Lightning Rod” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: A lighthouse guides a ship to safety. A lightning rod diverts a bolt from a structure by providing a direct path to the ground. Still, the opening images of “Lighthouse/Lightning Rod,” a new work by the choreographer Garth Fagan, with loose, exuberant music by the jazz composer and trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, hint at danger as much as at security.

headline: Confirming the Beats Of a Throbbing Pulse
abstract: City Ballet paid tribute to the collaboration between George Balanchine and Igor Stravinsky with a program of their joint works on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine and Igor Stravinsky gave ballet a new pulse. When the curtain rises on “Stravinsky Violin Concerto,” it’s as if the five stationary dancers — four men and one woman — were taking a moment to match their heartbeats to the music. The ballerina takes the first step, a bent-knee kick to the side, and in that instant the music and the dance become one.

headline: Russian Parliament Bars Opposition Lawmaker From Speaking
abstract: Russia’s Parliament voted Friday to bar Ilya V. Ponomarev from speaking on the floor for one month after he called members of the majority party “swindlers and thieves.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s Parliament voted Friday to bar a prominent opposition lawmaker, Ilya V. Ponomarev, from speaking on the floor for one month after he called members of the majority party “swindlers and thieves.”

headline: A Little Madhattery in Manhattan, Inspired by Strayhorn
abstract: The Gerald Clayton Sextet, whose set on Thursday night included “Under Madhatter Medicinal Groupon,” a playfully syncopated tribute to a Billy Strayhorn tune, is playing through Sunday at Jazz Standard.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Gerald Clayton began his first set at Jazz Standard on Thursday night with a piece called “Future Reflection,” assigning its annunciatory melody to a front line of trumpet and two saxophones.

headline: Colombia Absolves Kidnapping Victim Accused of Misdeeds
abstract: The authorities said Sigifredo López, a former state legislator suspected of helping to arrange his own kidnapping by rebels in 2002, had been wrongly accused.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Bringing to a close a case that stunned Colombia and focused attention on a brutal episode in the country’s long-running guerrilla war, Colombian authorities this week absolved a former state legislator just months after accusing him of helping to arrange his own kidnapping by rebels.

headline: A Bowling Hustler With a Big Left Hook
abstract: Rocky Salemmo, who has supported himself for most of his adult life by bowling for bets, can tell you all the sneaky, conniving ways to rattle an opponent, or the best way to flee when you’re losing.
lead_paragraph: FIVE frames into the match, Rocky Salemmo was taking a beating.

headline: Romney, Appealing to Wider Audience, Recalibrates Message
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Taxation', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Reform and Reorganization']
abstract: In a sign that he is trying to attract more moderate general election voters, Mitt Romney is refining how he discusses taxes and health care.
lead_paragraph: The language Mitt Romney used this week to describe his plan to cut income tax rates was somewhat unusual, at least by the standards of recent Republican presidential campaigns.

headline: 2 Who Rode Casino Bus Tell of Crash
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Buses', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The passengers, testifying at the trial of the bus driver charged in a 2011 crash on Interstate 95 that killed 15 passengers, gave details of the wreck.
lead_paragraph: The bus swerved. It shook. It veered from one side of the road to the other.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Rethinking Patents, and Too Much Money
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selection includes a startup that failed to live up to its hype after raising $41 million, a snappy new YouTube show that reviews apps and an argument that patents should be abolished because they eventually stifle innovation.
lead_paragraph: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Damages, but No Profits, Awarded for a Song
abstract: A federal judge ruled that Peggy Harley, who claimed a song she had written was recorded without permission, was entitled to $2,386.11 in damages but not a share of any profits.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Peggy Harley of Queens claimed in a lawsuit that a song she had written was recorded without her permission by another singer who was later nominated for a Grammy Award, she demanded millions of dollars in damages and a share of any profits.

headline: Judge Approves New Entrance Exam for City Firefighters
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The approval ends a long stalemate over hiring practices and increases the likelihood that the fire department will hire thousands of minority applicants.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge approved a new entrance exam for New York City firefighters on Friday, ending a long stalemate over hiring practices and increasing the likelihood that the department will hire thousands of minority applicants.

headline: Apple Apologizes for Misstep on Maps
abstract: The problems with Apple’s new mobile maps were embarrassing, but the company has a tendency to bungle services that rely heavily on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: IPhone users grew more annoyed all week. When they used Apple’s new mobile maps, they found nonsensical routes and misplaced landmarks. Bloggers and talk-show hosts mocked the sometimes bizarre errors.

headline: More Major-League Players With New York Roots
abstract: In response to a previous column, many readers sent in the names of favorite Major League Baseball players with a New York connection.
lead_paragraph: The Fans Have Spoken

headline: Corrections: September 29, 2012
abstract: Corrections appearing in print for September 29, 2012.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: An Arm and a Leg and Then Some
abstract: On not being big lovers of all things Barbie. Oh yes, and a puzzle by Joe DiPietro.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It occurred to me after doing this puzzle that I should probably hand back my GIRLIE GIRL card. Apparently I’m not using it properly, having not been a fan of Barbie dolls as a child.

headline: Braves Honor Jones, as Eyes Turn to Mets’ Wright
abstract: Before Friday night’s loss to the Mets, the Braves honored Chipper Jones at a sold-out Turner Field, amid speculation about whether David Wright could be his replacement in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — It only made sense that on the night Chipper Jones was honored by the Atlanta Braves for his exceptional career, it was the Mets who got a front-row seat for the ceremony. After all, Jones helped build his Hall of Fame resume by demolishing their pitching. He has a lifetime .311 batting average against the Mets, with 49 homers and 159 runs batted in in 242 games.

headline: At Annual U.N. General Assembly, a Stage for All the World
abstract: At the annual session, those with global issues to press — no matter how tough the sell — worked to get their messages across to an international audience of leaders.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The annual United Nations General Assembly debate, which comes to a close on Monday with a final flurry of speeches, might be called a convention of knotty causes, some of them distinct long shots.

headline: Federal Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Ex-Gov. Spitzer
abstract: A federal judge dismissed a libel lawsuit against former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the online magazine Slate for a column Mr. Spitzer wrote in 2010 about an insurance bid-rigging scandal.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday dismissed a libel lawsuit against former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the online magazine Slate for a column Mr. Spitzer wrote in 2010 about an insurance bid-rigging scandal.

headline: Finding Joys Close to the Nest
abstract: On Sundays, the documentary filmmaker Ric Burns hews mainly to the Columbia University neighborhood where he has lived since 1976, these days with his wife, their two sons and their three dogs.
lead_paragraph: Dogs and sons and work and a city that loves to be loved — are there really enough hours in a Sunday for more than that? For the documentary filmmaker Ric Burns, 57, whose “Death and the Civil War” had its premiere on public television this month, Monday often arrives before he has begun to exhaust that quartet. Mr. Burns, best known for his 1999 series “New York: A Documentary Film,” hews mainly to the Columbia University neighborhood where he has lived since 1976 — these days with his wife and collaborator, Bonnie Lafave; their two sons, Adam, 12, and Simon, 14; and their three dogs, the newest a Gordon setter puppy named Fiona.

headline: Marines Train to Protect Embassies
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Fleet Antiterrorism Security Team Marines trained for close-quarters combat this week in Chesapeake, Va.
lead_paragraph: Fleet Antiterrorism Security Team Marines trained for close-quarters combat this week in Chesapeake, Va.

headline: Training for Consulate Attacks, in Case There’s a Next Time
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Pentagon sent two teams of Marines to protect American embassies in Libya and Yemen. This week, the Marines put on a show to demonstrate what those units are trained to do.
lead_paragraph: CHESAPEAKE, Va. — The “riot” erupted suddenly on the Virginia-North Carolina border in a remote pocket of marshland and pine. “Go back to America!” the protesters shouted, hurling rubber rocks at a large plywood structure meant to be a United States consulate. “We don’t want you here! This is our country!”

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: The winning lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: 40 Days of Night
abstract: The problem for Republicans that has led to President Obama widening his lead in the polls has a name: Willard Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is losing badly. And he has only himself to blame.

headline: Files Offer Glimpse Into Shooting Suspect
abstract: Prosecutors say the suspect in the killing of 12 people at a Colorado movie theater made a threat toward his psychiatrist several weeks before the shooting.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Two months after a gunman killed 12 people inside a Colorado movie theater, a very heavily redacted trove of legal documents in the case was unsealed on Friday, offering a few new details — including allegations from prosecutors that the defendant made a threat toward his psychiatrist several weeks before the shooting.

headline: Same-Sex Couples Granted Protection in Deportations
keywords: ['Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigrants', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security Secretary clarified the meaning of “family relationships” in immigration-policy language: the reference does include gay partners.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security has stated in writing that foreigners who are same-sex partners of American citizens can be included under an Obama administration policy suspending deportations of some immigrants who pose no security risk.

headline: Execution Halted for Killer Claiming Abuse by Victim
abstract: A Pennsylvania judge ruled that the prosecution had withheld evidence that Terrance Williams’s victim had sexually abused minors, including Mr. Williams.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A Pennsylvania judge on Friday granted a stay of execution and a new sentencing hearing to a convicted murderer who was scheduled to die by lethal injection on Wednesday.

headline: College Football Matchups
abstract: There is a paucity of top 25 matchups this weekend, which raises the question: why rank just 25 teams?
lead_paragraph: There is a paucity of top 25 matchups this weekend, which raises the question: why rank just 25 teams? If 75 teams, say, or even all 124 were ranked, then every game would feature two “ranked teams,” and we could dispense with pretending that No. 14 Ohio State versus No. 20 Michigan State is some sort of epic collision.

headline: Three Paths to Higher Mileage
abstract: Honda Plans to offer three hybrid systems, using one, two or three electric motors depending on the vehicle’s intent.
lead_paragraph: Honda Plans to offer three hybrid systems, using one, two or three electric motors depending on the vehicle’s intent.

headline: Human Faces of ‘The Backlog’ at the Department of Veterans Affairs
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: A crushing inventory of claims for disability, pension and educational benefits has overwhelmed the Department of Veterans Affairs. For some of the people behind the claims, the long wait has been too long.
lead_paragraph: It’s a story about putting faces to numbers. In his Page 1 article in today’s paper James Dao (@jimdao) lays out:

headline: Brian De Palma on 'Passion'
abstract: Brian De Palma, the director of “Passion,” discusses his film starring Noomi Rapace and Rachel McAdams playing at the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Brian De Palma, the director of “Passion,” discusses his film starring Noomi Rapace and Rachel McAdams playing at the New York Film Festival.

headline: Education Department Report Shows More Borrowers Defaulting on Student Loans
abstract: The report, which focused on the first three years of payments, indicated that borrowers in default owe a total of $76 billion on federal loans.
lead_paragraph: The percentage of borrowers who defaulted on federal education loans within the first three years of payments rose to an average of 13.4 percent last year — 22.7 percent for those who attended for-profit colleges — according to statistics released on Friday by the Department of Education.

headline: Citizen Held After 9/11 Wins Right to Be Tried
abstract: A federal judge has ruled that the United States wrongly imprisoned an American under a law designed to keep trial witnesses from fleeing and that his case should go to trial.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Idaho has ruled that the United States, after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, wrongly imprisoned an American under a law designed to keep trial witnesses from fleeing and that since there was evidence that the government may have willfully misused the law against him, his case should go to trial.

headline: Seeing the Beauty in the Bronx
abstract: Daniel Hauben, 56, a painter who grew up in the Bronx, infuses his scenes of the oft-maligned borough with a touch of whimsy.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Hauben, 56, a painter who grew up in the Bronx, infuses his scenes of the oft-maligned borough with a touch of whimsy.

headline: Battered and Beautiful: His Bronx
abstract: Daniel Hauben, who has spent his career illuminating the lush landscapes and working people of the Bronx, was commissioned to paint 22 works for the new library at Bronx Community College.
lead_paragraph: AFTERNOON sunlight splashed down into the main reading room of the Bronx Community College’s new library, where nearly every desk was occupied, the enthusiasm of the semester still as fresh as the paint.

headline: Opening Night in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with a performance by Jay-Z and protests outside the arena.
lead_paragraph: The Barclays Center in Brooklyn began its first day of life on Friday with a performance by Jay-Z and protests outside the arena.

headline: Romney Team Tries Hanging a Jimmy Carter Label on Obama
abstract: Though there are some surface similarities between the Carter and Obama administrations, experts say the comparison can go only so far.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A president struggling simultaneously to cope with anti-American tumult in the Middle East and fix stubborn economic trouble at home: Is President Obama replaying the one-term presidency of Jimmy Carter?

headline: On the Second Day, Tiger Sits
abstract: For the first time in his Ryder Cup career, Tiger Woods will sit out a match.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — For the first time in his Ryder Cup career, Tiger Woods is sitting out a match. The United States captain, Davis Love III, benched Woods and Steve Stricker for Saturday’s foursomes after the pair lost both their matches Friday. They will be replaced by Webb Simpson and Bubba Watson, who will be in the first group out, against the European duo of Justin Rose and Ian Poulter.

headline: The Growing Role of Kurds in Syria
abstract: The Syrian government gave control of some areas to local Kurdish militias in exchange for their support.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian government gave control of some areas to local Kurdish militias in exchange for their support.

headline: Robert Newton, Maker of Racing Tires, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Newton wanted a tire that could hold up on the track, so he developed his own and built Hoosier Racing Tire in 1957 with his wife.
lead_paragraph: Robert Newton, who with his wife, Joyce, founded Hoosier Racing Tire, the Indiana company whose tires have become fixtures at car-racing tracks around the country, died on Wednesday at his home in Lakeville, Ind. He was 85.

headline: Chastened King Seeks Redemption, for Spain and His Monarchy
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With the country in an economic slump and the monarchy itself under fire, King Juan Carlos is reinserting himself into Spain’s public life and embracing his role as an economic booster.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — With Spain mired in an economic slump, many Spaniards are questioning their king, long revered for his role in bringing democracy to the nation but now being scrutinized for his deluxe lifestyle and opaque fortune.

headline: Chris Economaki, Rumbling Voice of Auto Racing, Dies at 91
abstract: A longtime writer and broadcaster, Mr. Economaki was considered the dean of American motorsports journalism.
lead_paragraph: Chris Economaki, whose gravelly broadcast voice and prolific pen — specifically, his manual Royal typewriter — narrated the rise of auto racing from county-fair dirt tracks to a global multibillion-dollar business, died on Friday in a nursing home in Wyckoff, N.J. He was 91.

headline: Schedule of Debates
abstract: Debates will take place from 9 to 10:30 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Debates will take place from 9 to 10:30 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Kurds Prepare to Pursue More Autonomy in a Fallen Syria
abstract: Some in the long divided and oppressed ethnic group are getting ready to fight for an autonomous region in the event that President Bashar al-Assad’s government falls.
lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — Just off a main highway that stretches east of this city and slices through a moonscape of craggy hills, a few hundred Syrian Kurdish men have been training for battle, marching through scrub brush and practicing rifle drills.

headline: From Jordan’s Playbook: When Down, Sit Out
abstract: Tiger Woods could take some sage advice from honorary team member Michael Jordan after being one of the only Americans to lose Friday at the Ryder Cup golf tournament.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill.

headline: Debate Advice From the Beltway
abstract: Political insiders weigh in on what they think Mitt Romney and President Obama need to accomplish in the first debate.
lead_paragraph: Political insiders weigh in on what they think Mitt Romney and President Obama need to accomplish in the first debate.

headline: Presidential Debate Moments
abstract: Sam Tanenhaus, editor of the Book Review, talks about some of the most memorable presidential debate moments of the televised era.
lead_paragraph: Sam Tanenhaus, editor of the Book Review, talks about some of the most memorable presidential debate moments of the televised era.

headline: Before Debate, Tough Crowds at the Practice
abstract: Mitt Romney’s team hopes to create moments in the debate on Wednesday, while President Obama is aiming for a workmanlike performance, aides said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a conference room at the Democratic headquarters, President Obama has been preparing for the debate next week, but the reviews of his staff are already in. Too long, they tell him. Cut that answer. Give crisper explanations. No one wants a professor; they want a president.

headline: In the Bronx, Throwing $97 Million Down 18 Holes
abstract: In the Bronx, where more than 30 percent of people live below the poverty line, the city is spending $97 million to build an unnecessary 18-hole golf course to be operated by Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Were we to commit ourselves to making a master list of what New York City needs more of, it is fair to say that many of us would wear a third or fourth pencil down to the nub before settling on an 18-hole golf course and the increased presence of Donald J. Trump. And yet, with the renovation of a major portion of Ferry Point Park in the southeastern section of the Bronx, this is what New Yorkers will receive.

headline: Keeping Pace With Orioles, the Yankees Bounce Back
abstract: Hiroki Kuroda struggled on the mound but received help from Nick Swisher and Russell Martin at the plate as the Yankees beat the Blue Jays to stay one game ahead of Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The lopsided tally from Baltimore beamed on the out-of-town scoreboard on the right-field wall of the Rogers Centre and, as early as the first inning, the Yankees could see they would get no help from the Red Sox. The Orioles were on their way to an easy victory over Boston, and the pressure rose on the Yankees to keep pace with Baltimore.

headline: To Fight Crime, a Poor City Will Trade In Its Police
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Organized Labor', 'Police', 'Government Employees', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Officials in Camden, N.J,. say that their unionized police department is too expensive, so they are disbanding it to free up millions for a nonunionized force to safeguard the city.
lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, N.J. — Two gruesome murders of children last month — a toddler decapitated, a 6-year-old stabbed in his sleep — served as reminders of this city’s reputation as the most dangerous in America. Others can be found along the blocks of row houses spray-painted “R.I.P.,” empty liquor bottles clustered on their porches in memorial to murder victims.

headline: New York May Restart Review of Gas-Drilling Rules
keywords: ['Drilling and Boring', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Natural Gas', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shale']
abstract: New York State is further slowing its effort to craft rules governing fracking.
lead_paragraph: New York State appears to be further slowing its effort to produce rules governing fracking, shorthand for the suite of drilling methods used to extract natural gas from deep shale deposits. The pressure to drill has fallen sharply along with gas prices, and in the face of inevitable litigation. [Sept. 30, 11:13 p.m. | Updated | Danny Hakim describes the reaction of drilling supporters and foes to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s latest move on fracking.]

headline: For Rays and White Sox, One More Reversal in Upside-Down Year
abstract: After having lost eight of nine, the Chicago White Sox, for one night at least, stopped its slide and Tampa Bay’s late-season surge.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The September narratives for the White Sox and the Tampa Bay Rays seemed written Friday morning. The Rays were in the midst of a late-season charge for the second straight year, winners of eight straight to trim a six-game deficit on Sept. 18 to two in the American League wild-card race.

headline: Yemen’s Leader Praises U.S. Drone Strikes
abstract: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi’s support of drone attacks in Yemen cemented his status as a favored counterterrorism partner of the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The president of Yemen gave an unqualified endorsement of American drone strikes in his country during a visit here on Friday, cementing his status as a favored counterterrorism partner of the United States.

headline: X-Rays for Cano
abstract: Robinson Cano’s left hand was hit by a pitch in Friday’s victory over the Blue Jays, but he stayed in the game.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Robinson Cano was struck in the back of the left hand with a pitch in the sixth inning of Friday’s 11-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays. He remained in the game, which was a good sign, but he wasn’t able to get an X-ray until late on Friday, so there was no definitive word on the extent of the injury immediately after the game.

headline: Greek Premier Sees Hope, but Only if Europe Helps
abstract: In an interview, Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece said there was “zero risk” that Greece will leave the euro, but warned of growing unrest in Europe.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — He waited his whole life for this moment, and many European leaders see him as Greece’s last best hope for stability. But for Antonis Samaras, leading his country is no fun at all. “Do you think anyone can be happy being prime minister of Greece?” he asked in a low voice in an interview here on Friday, placing his elbows on his knees. “This is the toughest job in the world. It’s just pain.”

headline: Iranian Group Now Off Terror List
abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton formally removed an Iranian opposition group from the State Department’s list of designated terrorist organizations on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton formally removed an Iranian opposition group from the State Department’s list of designated terrorist organizations on Friday. The decision, first reported last week, is expected to make it easier to find new countries for more than 3,000 members of the group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, who are currently in Iraq. The department took into account the group’s public renunciation of violence and “the absence of confirmed acts of terrorism” by the group, known as the M.E.K., for more than a decade. But the department said it would not forget the M.E.K.’s past acts of terrorism, “including its involvement in the killing of U.S. citizens in Iran in the 1970s and an attack on U.S. soil in 1992.” It also expressed “serious concerns” about accusations that the group had committed abuses against some of its own members.

headline: France: Roma Camp Burned
abstract: A mob set fire to an encampment of 35 foreign Roma in a Marseille neighborhood on Thursday night, the French authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A mob set fire to an encampment of 35 foreign Roma in a Marseille neighborhood on Thursday night, the French authorities said. Local officials and rights groups were outraged, but there were no arrests, a police spokesman said. Residents of a housing project forced the Roma, also known as Gypsies, out of an adjacent field, the spokesman said, before setting fire to their possessions. Residents told local news media that they were responding to several recent thefts that they attributed to the camp’s inhabitants. As many as 20,000 foreign Roma are said to live in France, most of them Romanians or Bulgarians.

headline: Government Can Decide How to Allocate Natural Resources, Supreme Court Rules
keywords: ['Auctions', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Politics and Government', 'Radio Spectrum', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources']
abstract: National assets can be sold, if revenue maximization is not the goal, court says.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI–India’s Supreme Court upheld the government’s right to sell natural resources as it sees fit, saying it wasn’t necessary for the administration to use auctions.

headline: Honey Producers Lament a Bad Season for Bees
abstract: Environmental campaigners are stepping up the fight to save the world’s bees in the wake of a terrible honey season in Europe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s been another bad year for bees.

headline: The Weekend Word: Exposure
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the president’s weekly address and the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Vidya Balan and Jairam Ramesh Team Up For Toilets
abstract: Bollywood actress roped in as sanitation and hygiene ambassador in government’s campaign to make India open-defecation-free.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI– A traveling village fair is scheduled to kick off next week in India, but instead of cotton candy and tchotchkes, it will sell an important message: Use soap to wash your hands, and don’t defecate in the open.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: Chief Minister Omar Abdullah dismissed reports of a brewing “battle” between himself and Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party over the issue of providing security to sarpanches, the elected heads of village councils, Kashmir Live reported. A group of  sarpanches from Kashmir met with Mr. Gandhi in New Delhi on Thursday to discuss security concerns after the killing of three village council members in the Kashmir valley earlier this week.

headline: Accusations of Football Bounties for 10-Year-Olds
abstract: The allegations against leaders of a youth football team in California sound so outlandish that it seems as if they might be from a “Saturday Night Live” skit.
lead_paragraph: The allegations against leaders of a youth football team in California sound so outlandish that they seem to be from a “Saturday Night Live” skit. Imagine the former Saints defensive coordinator Gregg Williams telling a group of 10-year-olds that there may be a trip to Dairy Queen after the game, “but only after you affect the head, kill the head.”

headline: Jay-Z Comes Home to Repay a Debt to Brooklyn
abstract: The artist was at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn for the first show of a sold-out eight night run in the new rusty bunker that will house the Brooklyn Nets.
lead_paragraph: For many years, Jay-Z closed out his concerts with “Encore,” a soothing, triumphant number from “The Black Album,” which at the time of its release in 2003 was billed as something of a retirement. “From Marcy to Madison Square,” he rapped, sketching an arc that had taken him from a Brooklyn housing project to headlining the most symbolically important arena in the country.

headline: Ristretto | Paris is Brewing
abstract: A round-up of the newest, more ambitious coffee shops springing up across the city.
lead_paragraph: Finally, Paris has a coffee scene. The city has always been the paradox of the industry, a great cafe town where an otherwise discerning audience happily throws back watery shots of ashy swill. I first wrote about Paris coffee in 2010, and after returning to the topic last year I decided to sit on my hands until somebody in the city figured out what it was missing.

headline: A Champions League Sojourn
abstract: A UEFA Women’s Champions League game against F.K. Spartak took the writer to a new place: Serbia.
lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — I have to admit, I looked up Serbia on the map when I found out we would be going there for Champions League. This was a business trip, like any time I’ve traveled to play a game, but it turned out to be a fascinating experience, leaving me wishing I could extend my stay and be a tourist for a couple days.

headline: Arthur O. Sulzberger, Publisher Who Transformed The Times for New Era, Dies at 86
abstract: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger guided The Times and its parent company through a period of expansion and change on a scale not seen since the newspaper’s founding.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who guided The New York Times and its parent company through a long, sometimes turbulent period of expansion and change on a scale not seen since the newspaper’s founding in 1851, died early Saturday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 86.

abstract: As publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Ochs “Punch” Sulzberger saw the paper through a trying strike, expanded its sections and printed the Pentagon Papers.
lead_paragraph: As publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Ochs “Punch” Sulzberger saw the paper through a trying strike, expanded its sections and printed the Pentagon Papers.

abstract: A vast and well-preserved labyrinth of storehouses, schools and courtyards in Aleppo was damaged on Saturday as fierce clashes between security forces and insurgents continued.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Fire swept through the old central souk, or marketplace, of Aleppo, Syria, on Saturday, damaging a vast and well-preserved labyrinth of medieval storehouses, shops, schools and ornate courtyards as fierce clashes between security forces and insurgents vowing to carry out a “decisive battle” for the city continued.

headline: Political and Class Issues Complicate a Colorado Land Dispute
abstract: Bill Koch’s effort to acquire some public land, including a piece that cuts through his 4,500-acre ranch, has run into hostility from his neighbors.
lead_paragraph: PAONIA, Colo. — This is a story of a quiet billionaire and a middle-class mountain town, of class divisions, small-town quarrels and competing visions of the future of the West. But at its core, like so many stories here in the aspen-dappled hillsides, it is really all about land.

abstract: The Times is back today to host the best college football watch party in the country. Mike Huguenin will offer up his own analysis and insights on all of the big games.
lead_paragraph: The Times is back today to host the best college football watch party in the country. Mike Huguenin will offer up his own analysis and insights on all of the big games and a lot of the not so big ones.

headline: From Two Great Showmen, Straightforward Hollywood Glamour
abstract: This was one of those rare seasons when the designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf went for straightforward fashion, instead of the conceptual variety.
lead_paragraph: This was one of those rare seasons when the designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf went for straightforward fashion, instead of the conceptual variety. While it was not the usual three-ring circus, this collection, loosely themed around Hollywood glamour, offered a good opportunity to reiterate the signatures of the house. It was also a reminder that Mr. Horsting and Mr. Snoeren, besides being great showmen, are in the business of selling clothes.

headline: Bound to Sea but Buried in Debt, Spain’s Fishermen Blame Bloc’s Policies
abstract: A decline in fish stocks, rising operating costs and a sharp economic downturn have devastated much of Spain’s coastal economy and intensified criticism of subsidies.
lead_paragraph: CÁDIZ, Spain — Millions of Spaniards took advantage of cheap financing to buy new houses during Spain’s decade-long economic boom and housing bubble beginning in the late 1990s. The country’s fishermen, many encouraged by European Union subsidies, did much the same for their own homes away from home: new boats.

headline: Soriano’s Renaissance Gives Cubs a Quandary
abstract: Alfonso Soriano, a 36-year-old outfielder with bad knees, might not fit into the team’s rebuilding plans. But his emergence as a team leader might.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Alfonso Soriano arrived in the big leagues as a gangly second baseman for the mighty Yankees. Fourteen years later, he is an aging left fielder for the Cubs, a team approaching 100 losses this season.

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Omar Khadr, the only Canadian citizen held at the Guantánamo Bay detention center in Cuba, was returned to Canada early Saturday morning, the Pentagon and the Canadian government announced.

headline: Triple Crown Would Paint a Clearer M.V.P. Picture
abstract: Ryan Braun is already a standout for National League most valuable player. The American League field is a bit more crowded.
lead_paragraph: Let’s answer the big question right away: if Miguel Cabrera wins the triple crown, he should be the American League’s most valuable player. To lead the league in batting average, homers and runs batted in and not be named M.V.P. simply does not feel right.

headline: Bettman Undisputed N.H.L. Enforcer

lead_paragraph: How much power does N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman have? Is he merely the instrument of the owners, taking orders and doing what he is told, or is it the other way around?

headline: ‘Punch’ Sulzberger, R.I.P.
abstract: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger transformed The New York Times and stood up to the government in the Pentagon Papers case. He was king, and we miss him.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, better known as Punch, transformed this newspaper and had a vast impact on journalism. He oversaw the emergence of an array of feature sections that put this newspaper on a solid financial footing, and he risked everything when he defied the White House and published the top-secret Pentagon Papers from the Vietnam War. But on hearing just now that he passed away overnight at the age of 86, I kept thinking of Punch mostly as a really good and decent man who oozed likability as well as leadership. (Here’s his obituary)

headline: At the Stedelijk, Tales of 2 Staircases
abstract: ‘‘An artist who has never fallen down these stairs doesn’t count in the history of the avant-garde,’’ a journalist once wrote of the staircase at the Stedelijk, the contemporary art museum in Amsterdam that has reopened after nine years. Now the museum has another showcase staircase, this one in its audacious new wing.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM—When the Stedelijk, the Amsterdam museum for modern and contemporary art and design, recently reopened here after having been shut for nine years, it was both a resuscitation of an old hangout and the birth of a new stage for art.

lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Santonio Holmes says life would probably be even better if penalty yardage on defensive backs could be tacked onto his statistics, and he would be awarded touchdowns on defensive pass-interference calls in the end zone.

headline: A Freeway’s Closing Fails to Scare All of Los Angeles
abstract: The weekend closing of a 10-mile stretch of Interstate 405 — Carmageddon II, as it has been called — did not create an apocalypse of congestion, but it also didn’t keep Angelenos off the roads.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last year, before a 10-mile stretch of the nation’s busiest freeway, Interstate 405, was closed for an entire weekend in July, city officials warned of potentially endless gridlock (or more endless than usual). Carmageddon, they called it. And Angelenos listened. For one weekend in this city of cars, everyone walked. The city’s roads had never felt emptier. It was, most thought, kind of nice.

headline: Islamist Rebels Flee Key Port City in Somalia
abstract: The withdrawal from Kismayo, the last major stronghold of the Islamist rebels, came a day after Kenyan troops invaded and marched toward the city center and seaside port.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Under the cover of darkness, the Shabab militant group withdrew from the port town of Kismayu early Saturday, abandoning its last major stronghold and vowing to take the war underground.

headline: Mr. Sulzberger, Publisher and Projectionist
abstract: A personal reminiscence of the man who led The New York Times for 34 years.
lead_paragraph: In 1995, at the funeral of the extraordinary journalist James Reston, I watched Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of The New York Times escort Katharine Graham of The Washington Post up the long aisle of the National Cathedral in Washington. I was struck by their grace and dignity, by how symbolic they were of great journalism, and by how much our profession owed to the man who had published The Times for nearly 30 years.

headline: Resurgent Driver Returns to Scene of Only Win
