headline: Faced With Strengthened Rivals in Atlantic Division, Celtics Load Up
abstract: The Celtics loaded up over the summer with the intention of extending their dominance over not only the Knicks, but the rest of the improved Atlantic Division as well.
lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Mass. — Wyc Grousbeck has been the head of the Boston Celtics ownership group for a decade. In that span, he has presided over a team that lost 18 straight games, a team record, and over another that lost 16 games in an entire season en route to an N.B.A. championship.

headline: A Trans-Atlantic Trip Turns Kafkaesque
abstract: American Airlines should no longer be flying across the Atlantic. It does not have the know-how or the equipment, and its employees have clearly lost interest in the endeavor.
lead_paragraph: You, American Airlines, should no longer be flying across the Atlantic. You do not have the know-how. You do not have the equipment. And your employees have clearly lost interest in the endeavor. Like the country whose name graces the hulls of your flying ships, you are exhausted and shorn of purpose. You need to stop.

Brown is responsible for organizing and orchestrating the quadrennial verbal smackdowns that can define candidates. The first 2012 presidential debate will be televised live on Wednesday night. headline: Why Obama Is Winning

lead_paragraph: LAST winter, I had lunch with a junior White House official who works on economic issues. The unemployment rate had just dipped to 8.3 percent, and I asked if he was encouraged by the figure, and hopeful that it might be down another point by Election Day.

headline: The World We’re Actually Living In
abstract: In President Obama and Mitt Romney, we have a choice between someone who understands the complex world we live in and someone who doesn’t.
lead_paragraph: FOR the first time in a long, long time, a Democrat is running for president and has the clear advantage on national security policy. That is not “how things are supposed to be,” and Republicans sound apoplectic about it. But there is a reason President Obama is leading on national security, and it was apparent in his U.N. speech last week, which showed a president who understands that we really do live in a more complex world today — and that saying so is not a cop-out. It’s a road map. Mitt Romney, given his international business background, should understand this, but he acts instead as if he learned his foreign policy at the International House of Pancakes, where the menu and architecture rarely changes.

The quarterback took a shotgun snap, handed the ball to the player next to him and watched the runner hop a few steps through the line before being tackled for a 3-yard gain. The crowd barely stirred. The television announcers gave the sequence little more than a cursory mention. There was not even a replay shown.

It’s a word, one that has gone sadly out of vogue over recent decades and been mostly absent from this campaign.

headline: The Myth of Male Decline
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', 'Sociology', 'Education', 'Discrimination', "Women's Rights", 'Wages and Salaries', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Reports of a matriarchy are exaggerated. In many arenas, the progress of women has stalled.
lead_paragraph: SCROLL through the titles and subtitles of recent books, and you will read that women have become “The Richer Sex,” that “The Rise of Women Has Turned Men Into Boys,” and that we may even be seeing “The End of Men.” Several of the authors of these books posit that we are on the verge of a “new majority of female breadwinners,” where middle-class wives lord over their husbands while demoralized single men take refuge in perpetual adolescence.

lead_paragraph: When the spinning finally ended, the veteran Nadia Petrova of Russia fell to her knees having won a dizzying final at the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Ariake Coliseum in Tokyo, defeating the defending champion, Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland, 6-0, 1-6, 6-3. headline: Democracy in the Former Soviet Republics

lead_paragraph: No leader of the former Soviet republics has been more pro-Western than President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia. He moves easily in Washington and dreams of bringing his country into full NATO membership. But his government’s handling of prisons and its approach to parliamentary elections set for Monday are raising doubts about his commitment to democracy and reform.

headline: 30 Seconds With Brad Richards: Locked Out but Dialed In
abstract: The Rangers veteran Brad Richards is skating and training and hoping the N.H.L. lockout ends soon.
lead_paragraph: Before the N.H.L. lockout, the Rangers’ Brad Richards was hoping to build on his performance in last season’s playoffs. The alternate captain in his first season with the team, he had six goals and nine assists in 20 postseason games. During the regular season, Richards compiled 25 goals and 41 assists. He won the Stanley Cup with the Tampa Bay Lightning in 2004, when he was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player during the playoffs.

headline: Can Opium or Illness Explain a Keats Poem?
abstract: A new biography discusses John Keats’s opium use, but there is no need to find a chemical source for his extraordinary creativity.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 21, 1819, John Keats wrote to his brother George that he was “scarcely content to write the best verses for the fever they leave behind. I want to compose without this fever.” The fever is no metaphor. In another letter dated that same day, he had sent a friend a copy of his poem “To Autumn,” written just then, one of the greatest poems in the English language and the last of Keats’s great odes. For Keats, poetry was never emotion recollected in tranquillity, as it was for Wordsworth. It was often tranquillity refigured by his fevered mind.

abstract: Why do some tout individualism yet depend on public money?

headline: Georgians Confront Revolution’s Legacy in Vote
abstract: Nine years after reformers took power, Georgians are gearing up for parliamentary elections on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Nine years after reformers took power, Georgians are gearing up for parliamentary elections on Monday.

headline: What I Learned From Playing the Gipper
abstract: Having stood in for Ronald Reagan in practice debates with Walter F. Mondale, I have a unique perspective on the contests between President Obama and Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee for president in 1984, asked me to help him prepare for his debates with President Ronald Reagan by playing the Reagan role, I accepted with enthusiasm.

headline: Tension, Though No Violence, as Protestants Parade in Belfast
abstract: A parade to commemorate a 1912 accord that helped lead to the partition of Ireland was watched over by a heavy police presence.
lead_paragraph: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — The parades to celebrate the centenary of the signing of the Ulster Covenant — the 1912 petition against home rule that helped lead to the partition of Ireland — passed peacefully on Saturday amid the biggest police operation here in more than 20 years.

headline: Peter Praeger, a Surgeon With a Health Food Company, Dies at 65
abstract: Dr. Praeger was a co-chief of cardiothoracic surgery at Hackensack University Medical Center and chief executive of Dr. Praeger’s Sensible Foods, a maker of frozen natural foods.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Peter Praeger, a heart surgeon who saved a man’s life and as a result wound up owning a gefilte fish company — and who as a result of that wound up starting a successful natural-foods company — died on Sept. 22 in Hackensack, N.J. He was 65.

headline: Ex-South Korea Leader Haunts Presidential Bid
abstract: Park Geun-hye, seeking the presidency as the candidate of the New Frontier Party, is riding on her father’s residual popularity but also carrying the burden of his more negative legacy.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — No matter how South Koreans cast their ballots in the Dec. 19 presidential election, one thing is certain: Their decision will depend at least in part on their view of a former president who has been dead for 33 years.

headline: To Encourage Biking, Cities Lose the Helmets
abstract: Does requiring safety gear make a safe activity seem dangerous?
lead_paragraph: ONE spectacular Sunday in Paris last month, I decided to skip museums and shopping to partake of something even more captivating for an environment reporter: Vélib, arguably the most successful bike-sharing program in the world. In their short lives, Europe’s bike-sharing systems have delivered myriad benefits, notably reducing traffic and its carbon emissions. A number of American cities — including New York, where a bike-sharing program is to open next year — want to replicate that success.

headline: Potentially Deadly Virus Related to SARS Appears to Be Not Easily Spread
abstract: The World Health Organization issued an initial alert last Sunday saying that researchers had discovered the new virus in a 49-year-old Qatari man visiting London.
lead_paragraph: A new strain of a potentially deadly virus related to SARS, which has killed one man in Saudi Arabia and left a Qatari man critically ill in London, does not appear to spread easily from person to person, the World Health Organization says.

headline: Women as Priests
abstract: Photographs of women who have rebelled against the Roman Catholic Church’s decree that females cannot serve as priests.
lead_paragraph: REFORMERS within the Roman Catholic Church have been calling for the ordination of women as priests. The Vatican, however, refuses to consider the possibility and uses its power to silence those who speak out. Catholic clergy in Europe, Australia and the United States who have voiced public support for female ordination have been either dismissed or threatened with removal from administrative posts within the church.

headline: Women as Priests
abstract: Photographs of women who have rebelled against the Roman Catholic Church’s decree that females cannot be priests.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of women who have rebelled against the Roman Catholic Church’s decree that females cannot be priests.

headline: Valium’s Contribution to Our New Normal
abstract: Valium and similar drugs gave us a new way to slay our inner demons, medicating our way to a happier life.
lead_paragraph: IT wasn’t funny, really, but everybody laughed at the scene in the 1979 film “Starting Over” when Burt Reynolds’s character had a panic attack in the furniture department of Bloomingdale’s (something to do with terror at the prospect of buying a couch). “Does anyone have a Valium?” his brother called out as Burt hyperventilated. The punch line: Every woman in the store reached into her purse and pulled out a little vial of pills.

headline: Tracking Voting-Age Hispanics
abstract: The rate of Hispanic cizitens has grown sharply in most states, but voter turnout among Hispanics is generally lower than it is among other demographic groups.
lead_paragraph: The rate of Hispanic cizitens has grown sharply in most states, but voter turnout among Hispanics is generally lower than it is among other demographic groups.

abstract: Female leaders can be just as horrible for women as men — just look at Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: ARE female leaders better for the world’s women?

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Meg Whitman’s Toughest Campaign: Retooling H.P.
abstract: The former eBay chief and gubernatorial candidate has found her Act III at Hewlett-Packard. But the challenge of re-energizing the company for a new information era is daunting.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: From Farm to Landfill
abstract: Unless food waste is reduced, agriculture will always be the Red Queen, running as fast as it can to stay in one place.
lead_paragraph: Feeding the planet is nearly always discussed as if it were mainly a matter of growing more food. It is not going to be that simple. In 2012 this planet will produce a record grain yield of 2.4 billion tons. That is a 1 percent increase over last year, a number slightly smaller than expected because of a devastating drought in this country that will result in a harvest 70 million tons short of earlier projections. One percent is a slender margin of growth when it comes to feeding a global human population where at least one in seven people go hungry.

abstract: Scenes from the Paris fashion week photo diary of Adrian Crispin.

headline: When Humility and Audacity Go Hand in Hand
abstract: Jacqueline Novogratz of the Acumen Fund, which invests in businesses aiding the world’s poor, says, “We think about our values in pairs, and there is a tension or a balance between them.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Jacqueline Novogratz, chief executive of the Acumen Fund, which invests in businesses aiding the world’s poor, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Nationals’ Charms Proved Hard to Ignore
abstract: The author, a long-suffering Cubs fan, found himself pulling for the Nationals, and his feelings grew more complicated once the team started playing well.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I have a confession to make. I’ve been unfaithful — to my Chicago Cubs.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 34
abstract: The artist draws things he saw in Maryland, New York, California, Nevada, Delaware and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Escaping One’s Own Shadow
abstract: How to avoid our tendency as writers to repeat sentence patterns and words.
lead_paragraph: Before we get started, you should know this about me: I’ve written short stories, news articles, essays, reviews and a couple of nonfiction books. In pursuit of my ambitions, I’ve put in long hours of reading, writing and rewriting. But because life unfolds the way life does, I also have a day job as a think tank researcher, where I spend about half of my time writing or reading in genres and styles that are — how can I put this? — less juicy than the ones I practice and aspire to produce.

headline: Gaultier Pays Tribute to ’80s Pop Stars
abstract: Jean Paul Gaultier’s show paid tribute to pop stars of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Jean Paul Gaultier’s show tonight was an absolute hoot. Paying tribute to pop stars of the 1980s, the designer dressed his models to look like Grace Jones, Madonna, Michael Jackson, David Bowie and Annie Lennox, with hilarious accuracy.

headline: End of the Line for the Senators, and a Childhood
abstract: The first incarnation of the Washington Senators, the team of the author’s childhood, left for Minnesota in 1960.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, my 10-year-old son, Brendan, asked if I would take him and his younger brother Patrick to a trading card show. When I was Brendan’s age, in 1955, I boasted the largest card collection in my Washington neighborhood — hundreds filling two large boxes. The cards in those days were not for collecting. They were for bartering, trading and learning the career statistics of favorite players.

headline: Lifting Schools, via Healthier Food
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Careers and Professions', 'Education (K-12)', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: The chief of Revolution Foods aims to provide healthy school meals. The company now creates a daily volume of 200,000 breakfasts, lunches, snacks and dinners.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in San Antonio, and loved to spend time at my grandparents’ cattle ranch about 90 miles away in Hunt, Tex.

headline: Follow a Career Passion? Let It Follow You
abstract: When it comes to careers, young people are often advised to find their true calling. But for many, the sense of fulfillment grows only over time, as they become better at their jobs.
lead_paragraph: IN the spring of 2004, during my senior year of college, I faced a hard decision about my future career. I had a job offer from Microsoft and an acceptance letter from the computer science doctoral program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. I had also just handed in the manuscript for my first nonfiction book, which opened the option of becoming a full-time writer. These are three strikingly different career paths, and I had to choose which one was right for me.

headline: In Colorado, a Land Dispute
abstract: The industrialist Bill Koch’s effort to acquire some public land is setting off a debate about private property and public access, privilege and tradition.
lead_paragraph: The industrialist Bill Koch’s effort to acquire some public land is setting off a debate about private property and public access, privilege and tradition.

headline: A New Team Stirs Memories, but Not a Passion
abstract: I find myself happy for the city where I grew up but unable to truly share in the excitement.
lead_paragraph: At the house where my parents live in Washington, there was a telltale sign of summer in the late 1960s and early ’70s: two dirt patches interrupted the lawn behind the tall magnolia that leaned like the Tower of Pisa in the middle of our backyard.

headline: How to Erase a Debt That Isn’t There

headline: Loss Sets Back the Yankees as the Orioles Tie in the East
abstract: The Yankees lost a tough-to-swallow decision to the lowly Blue Jays, squandering an opportunity to inch closer to a playoff berth and a divisional crown.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — When the Yankees loaded the bases with nobody out in the first inning Saturday, it looked as if they might cruise to an easy victory and then sit back over dinner and wait for the result from Texas. A Yankees win and a Los Angeles Angels loss to the Rangers in Arlington later on would have clinched a wild-card berth for the Yankees.

keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Search Engines', 'Budget Travel', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: It’s a travel sweepstakes with a twist: Flightfox.com asks users to find the lowest fares for other travelers planning trips — and gives a finder’s fee to the winner.
lead_paragraph: TRAVEL search sites have made it easy to find the lowest available fares ever since the Web’s early Jurassic period, when pioneers like Expedia and Travelocity opened shop. Many others, like Kayak and Hipmunk, have since joined in.

headline: Repair the Infrastructure, or Pay More Later
abstract: A reader responds to “The Big Myth of Painful Choices” (Economic View, Sept. 23).

headline: For the Wealthy, a 28 Percent Solution
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Capital Gains Tax']
abstract: One way to overhaul the tax code, Richard H. Thaler says, is to eliminate deductions for income above $1 million, and to treat all sources of that income equally.
lead_paragraph: EVERYONE knows that America’s tax code is a mess, yet despite considerable talk when elections come around, we’ve done nothing substantial to fix it. What is odd is that there is broad agreement on what should be done. We should strive to get the “lowest possible tax rates on the broadest base,” as five well-known conservative economists put it recently.

headline: As Money Pours Down, It’s No Wonder That Stocks Are Up
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Cause and effect are hard to prove, but it seems reasonable that central banks’ recent moves are providing the spark for stock market rallies worldwide.
lead_paragraph: THE markets are getting plenty of help from the world’s big central banks. Will it be enough to keep the current rally going?

headline: After 8 Touchdowns, West Virginia’s Smith Is His Only Critic
abstract: West Virginia’s Geno Smith made this season’s first bid for the Heisman Trophy, completing 45 of 51 passes for 656 yards and 8 touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — By his estimation, Geno Smith had erred. He had six incompletions. West Virginia did not score on its first drive and stalled, briefly, on others. He forced passes when he could have scrambled. Generally, he could have made better decisions.

headline: Car Talk
abstract: Rev your engines for this Sunday puzzle by Elayne Cantor and Victor Fleming.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Even when my car’s battery kicked the bucket in the middle of a raging snowstorm with no notice, I still swore my allegiance to her (yes, it’s a “her”). Seemingly spontaneous flat tires, a “Report for service now” gauge that lit up randomly, causing me to spend an unusual amount of time at the dealership service center … no matter. We were partners in my quest to See Everything Within Driving Distance. She has delivered me and my kids to emergency rooms in the middle of the night, and borne the burden of a houseful of camp paraphernalia as I drove my kids to camp.

headline: So Far Unfruitful, Fusion Project Faces a Frugal Congress
keywords: ['Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Physics', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Physicists eager to achieve controlled fusion with a giant laser at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory will have to offer Congress some explanations if they are to get more money to keep the project alive.
lead_paragraph: For more than 50 years, physicists have been eager to achieve controlled fusion, an elusive goal that could potentially offer a boundless and inexpensive source of energy.

headline: Golf’s Dynamic Duos

lead_paragraph: The Ryder Cup team of Phil Mickelson and Keegan Bradley electrified Medinah Country Club with three consecutive wins in the team competition on Friday and Saturday, calling to mind earlier noteworthy partners in the golf’s long history.

headline: A Familiar Face Returns, Heating Up the Sheriff’s Race in Webb County
abstract: Former Sheriff Rick Flores has come home to Webb County, Tex., to run against the current sheriff, who narrowly defeated Mr. Flores in 2008, and campaign passions are high.
lead_paragraph: LAREDO — The Rick Flores who sat alone in a supermarket parking lot last week and waited for a handful of supporters to wave campaign signs with him bore little resemblance to the Rick Flores of old — the swashbuckling, 10-gallon-hat-donning Texas border sheriff whose quips to his critics were as sharp as the creases in his uniform.

headline: Parents Pitch In to Help Schools Face Budget Cuts
abstract: In West Austin, private donations have helped schools create an outdoor classroom and hire more teachers.
lead_paragraph: The space used to be a vacant field, sandwiched between Casis Elementary School and a parking lot.

headline: Texas’ Traffic Policy for the Future, Powered by the Graying of Its Baby Boomers
abstract: The over-65 driving population will grow by anywhere from 218 percent to 268 percent between 2005 and 2040.

headline: Old Houston Salutes an Irreverent Heart Surgeon
abstract: On Sept. 18, the Texas Heart Institute celebrated its 50th anniversary by honoring its 93-year-old founder, Denton A. Cooley.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, there are moments in Houston that provide a vivid glimpse of the city that was — that aggressively entrepreneurial, insanely individualistic and relentlessly optimistic place of lore. Such a moment was visible the night of Sept. 18, when the Texas Heart Institute celebrated its 50th anniversary by honoring its founder, Denton A. Cooley, whose name is almost always accompanied by the description “world-famous heart surgeon.”

headline: Twins Cut Ties With Japanese Shortstop
abstract: Minnesota had high hopes for Tsuyoshi Nishioka, but they never came close to being fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Flush with revenue from the opening of Target Field in 2010, the Minnesota Twins made a major foray into the Japanese market that winter, signing the flashy shortstop Tsuyoshi Nishioka from the Chiba Lotte Marines.

headline: Eugene D. Genovese, Historian of South, Dies at 82
keywords: ['Communism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Slavery', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)']
abstract: Mr. Genovese, a Marxist who became a conservative Catholic, argued that slavery had a paternalistic side.
lead_paragraph: Eugene D. Genovese, a prizewinning historian who challenged conventional thinking on slavery in the American South by stressing its paternalism as he traveled a personal intellectual journey from Marxism to conservative Catholicism, died on Wednesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 82.

headline: More Suspicious Voter Forms Are Found
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Irregularities have been found in 10 Florida counties on registrations submitted by a company working for the state Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The number of Florida counties reporting suspicious voter registration forms connected to Strategic Allied Consulting, the firm hired by the state Republican Party to sign up new voters, has grown to 10, officials said, as local election supervisors continue to search their forms for questionable signatures, addresses or other identifiers.

headline: Spring Crush in Paris
abstract: Using sports fabrics, Junya Watanabe created a collection as simple as it was innovative. Rei Kawakubo staged a Comme des Garçons show whose operative word was “crush,” according to the designer.
lead_paragraph: Junya Watanabe’s show on Saturday morning had the kick of an energy drink. Using sports fabrics like mesh and nylon, Mr. Watanabe created a collection as simple as it was innovative, with neon-bright mini dresses and jackets with an array of zipped vents, cool shifts made from interlocking pieces of mesh and jersey, and some lovely fluted dresses with slivered insets. About 25 percent of the fabrics came from Puma for a one-time collaboration with Mr. Watanabe. (It was unclear whether the Puma pieces would be produced, but I will find out more tomorrow in the Comme des Garçons showroom.)

headline: Leonard Lerman, a Pioneer in DNA Study, Is Dead at 87
keywords: ['Biology and Biochemistry', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Research', 'Science and Technology', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: Mr. Lerman, a molecular biologist, discovered how to manipulate DNA, and in doing so, helped other scientists further pursue the genetic code.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Lerman, a molecular biologist whose discovery of how to manipulate DNA was a vital preliminary step in enabling others to decipher the basic building blocks of the genetic code, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 87.

headline: Pointing the Way to Victory, One Fist Pump at a Time
abstract: Playing in his first Ryder Cup, Keegan Bradley has been a shot in the arm for American golf, a hyperkinetic player whose power, putting and passion have inspired his teammates.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill.

headline: A Thrilling Scene at No. 17
abstract: The 17th hole at Medinah Country Club provided great theater by Europeans staging a stirring comeback.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — Two days before the start of the Ryder Cup, Steve Stricker was a passenger in a cart that spun out on a bank on the 17th hole, forcing him to bail out. Was it an omen?

headline: Elite and Deft, Xi Aimed High Early in China
abstract: An early move to rural China offers a window on the political savvy of Xi Jinping, who is on the cusp of taking over as China’s supreme leader.
lead_paragraph: ZHENGDING County, China — Thirty years ago, a young government official with a plum job in Beijing made an odd request: reassignment to a poor rural area.

headline: Offense Carries Bulldogs After Their Defense Fails
abstract: With 560 yards, the Bulldogs’ offense gave Georgia a lift over Tennessee while the defense struggled to hold back the Vols’ charge.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — Tennessee slid its protection on the offensive line toward the Georgia all-American linebacker Jarvis Jones and, all at once, Jones was trying to fend off three blockers in a triple team. Tyler Bray, the Tennessee quarterback, stood in the pocket and watched a Georgia linebacker turn a receiver loose underneath in a blown coverage, and then the scene in the Bulldogs’ secondary turned to mayhem as a Tennessee receiver ran wide open for another big play.

headline: Cabrera’s 43rd Homer Carries Tigers Closer to a Division Title
abstract: Miguel Cabrera kept up his triple crown chase with his 43rd home run, and Detroit’s lead in the American League Central grew to two games with four to play.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — With his stocking feet propped up on his desk and the Ryder Cup broadcast on the television next to him, Detroit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland scanned the list of pitchers he had available for Saturday’s afternoon game with the Minnesota Twins. Beginning with starter Justin Verlander, Leyland counted off eight names.

headline: Romney Shifted Right on Energy as Presidential Politics Beckoned
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Energy and Power', 'Fuel Efficiency']
abstract: Mitt Romney is more apt today to talk about his support for oil drilling than about the environmental policies that he advocated while governor of Massachusetts.

headline: Land With Baseball Diamond in 1989 Movie to Grow by 24 Fields of Dreams
abstract: Two buyers plan to turn farmland in Dyersville, Iowa, into a year-round ballpark for youth baseball and softball teams.
lead_paragraph: The Field of Dreams is about to get a new reality. After nearly a year of negotiations with local and state officials in Iowa, Denise and Michael Stillman expect in the coming weeks to close on their purchase of the 193-acre farm that includes the baseball diamond and home featured in “Field of Dreams,” the 1989 movie starring Kevin Costner.

headline: Stealing Watson’s Thunder With a Roaring Crowd

lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — One of Bubba Watson’s childhood friends, Giants kicker Lawrence Tynes, is expected to split the uprights with thousands of people screaming. So why should golfers be any different?

lead_paragraph: Presidential elections are high-stakes affairs. So perhaps it is no surprise that when supporters of one candidate do not like the message they are hearing from the polls they tend to blame the messenger.

headline: For Rose and McIlroy, Ryder Cup Is Test of Stamina
abstract: Only Justin Rose and Rory McIlroy will play in all five matches in the Ryder Cup. Davis Love III didn’t want the Americans to be worn out.

headline: Kimbrel’s Turnaround Year Reignites Debate on Relievers and Cy Young Award
abstract: Craig Kimbrel bounced back from a painful ending to last season to earn his 41st save in the Braves’ win over the Mets.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Within days of the Atlanta Braves’ 2011 season going up in flames, Manager Fredi Gonzalez phoned Craig Kimbrel, one of the players who struck the matches.

headline: Japanese Novelist Denounces ‘Cheap Liquor’ of Nationalism
abstract: The Japanese novelist Haruki Murakami, listed by oddsmakers as the favorite to win the 2012 Nobel Prize in literature, has called for Japan to reflect on its historical legacy in light of heated disputes with China and South Korea. He also denounced a rising nationalism in the region as “cheap liquor” supplied by “politicians and polemicists.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The 2012 Nobel Prize in literature will soon be announced, and oddsmakers are listing the Japanese novelist Haruki Murakami as the favorite.

headline: College Football Around the Country
abstract: A look at some of the more interesting moments in college football around the country.
lead_paragraph: BENNY CUNNINGHAM The Middle Tennessee State running back, right, had 217 yards and 5 touchdowns during a 49-28 win at Georgia Tech.

headline: 5 Are Dead After Clash Between U.S. and Afghan Troops
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Two Americans and three Afghans died just days after Pentagon officials confirmed that joint operations between American and Afghan forces were returning to normal.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Only two days after joint operations between American and Afghan forces were said to be returning to normal, five people — two Americans and three Afghans — were killed when a pitched battle broke out between soldiers of the two sides, American and Afghan officials said Sunday.

headline: Bo Xilai’s Son Defends His ‘Upright’ Father
abstract: Bo Guagua, the son of the disgraced former Communist Party leader Bo Xilai, has posted a statement online about the “upright” father whom he knew to be “devoted to duty.” The elder Bo, expelled last Friday from the party, is due to stand trial on criminal charges; his wife, Gu Kailai, was convicted of murder in August.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The son of the disgraced former Communist Party leader Bo Xilai has ended a long silence about his father’s fall from grace in China, posting a statement online about the “upright” father whom he knew to be “devoted to duty.”

headline: U.S. Advisers Train Afghan Allies With Caution
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Even when staying within bases with allied forces in Afghanistan, U.S. forces keep body armor on and weapons loaded.
lead_paragraph: Even when staying within bases with allied forces in Afghanistan, U.S. forces keep body armor on and weapons loaded.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Best of long-form journalism this week.
lead_paragraph: In Tehelka, Sai Manish writes about the mismanagement of natural disasters in the northeastern state of Sikkim. One year after an earthquake wreaked havoc in the state, a deluge has caused landslides, landing yet another blow of devastation. The author argues that the lack of timely government intervention has intensified the effect of such disasters. He writes:

headline: In Defense of the Doormat Dad
abstract: If my 2-year-old has a meltdown because we’re leaving a park, I let him stay longer. If he wants to jump on our kiddie trampoline until 11 p.m. instead of going to bed, I indulge him. If he insists on taking a 60-minute bath, I sit there beside the tub.
lead_paragraph: If Benjamin, my 2-year-old, has a meltdown because we’re leaving a park, I let him stay longer. If he wants to jump on our kiddie trampoline until 11 p.m. instead of going to bed, I indulge him. If he insists on taking a 60-minute bath, I sit there beside the tub.

headline: Greek-Spanish Pension Split Illustrates Europe’s Dilemma
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: While Greece agreed last week to cut pensions, Spain said it would raise its payouts, a stark example of why Europe’s debt and deficit problems have proved so difficult to resolve.
lead_paragraph: The differences in approach could not be more distinct — or telling.

headline: A Public Service Reminder: Simpson-Bowles Is Terrible
abstract: Sacred to the people who’ve been wrong about everything.
lead_paragraph: Nate Silver gives Mitt Romney a 16 percent chance of winning, and gives Republicans a 22 percent chance of taking the Senate. A month is an eternity in politics, it ain’t over until it’s over, yada yada, but the main suspense right now is whether the Democrats can retake the House — I’m eagerly waiting for Nate’s take.

headline: Spider-Man Moves to Brooklyn to Fight Bedbugs and Eviction
abstract: The web-slinging superhero, who was born in Queens and usually works in Manhattan, moves to another borough to protect its good citizens from evil villains, such as bedbugs.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Moore and his hero, Spider-Man, were both born in 1962.

headline: Disruptions: Your Brain on E-Books and Smartphone Apps
abstract: Modern technology can do strange things to your brain. Just ask the man who tried to turn a magazine page with a finger swipe.
lead_paragraph: Last week, my brain played a cruel trick on me. While waiting for my flight to take off, I was reading The New Yorker, the paper version, of course — I know the rules. I became engrossed in an article and swiped my finger down the glossy page to read more.

headline: Tales of Hope and Regret Test the Standard of Time
abstract: “Winners” and “Losers,” two plays by Brian Friel presented as “Lovers,” are being staged at the Beckett Theater.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t wait for the future, Joe.”

headline: ‘Hotel Transylvania’ Leads Weekend Box Office
abstract: The animated film from Sony surpassed expectations by selling about $43 million in tickets at North American theaters.
lead_paragraph: Pent-up demand for a new animated movie and a long and lively marketing campaign powered Sony’s “Hotel Transylvania” to No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend. The film, which cost at least $85 million to make, outperformed expectations to take in about $43 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. (An elated Sony e-mailed reporters on Sunday morning to announce “a monster hit on our hands!!!!!!”)

headline: Turning Up the Volume on Global Poverty
abstract: The Global Citizen Festival to combat poverty drew more than 60,000 people to Central Park for a concert featuring Neil Young and Crazy Horse, Foo Fighters, the Black Keys, Band of Horses and K’Naan.
lead_paragraph: Cranked-up guitars and sobering statistics shared a Central Park audience of more than 60,000 people on Saturday at the Global Citizen Festival, a five-hour concert on the Great Lawn devoted to ending extreme poverty worldwide. The concert was also webcast internationally.

headline: Ryan Sees ‘Media Bias’ in Campaign Coverage
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Paul D. Ryan acknowledges missteps by the Republican ticket, but also suggests media bias is having an impact on the race.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the Republican presidential ticket has received some scolding from fellow conservatives for being insufficiently bold, the vice presidential nominee, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, suggested on Sunday that part of the problem might be in getting the message past the mainstream news media.

headline: A Mockumentary Pulls In Real Players
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Toronto International Film Festival', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: Jane Edith Wilson, an actress, managed to secure a 10-minute talk with Michele Bachmann, and a hug from Mitt Romney.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — During the Jan. 3 broadcast of ABC’s “World News Tonight” Diane Sawyer introduced a heartbreaking segment from the Iowa caucus, featuring a distraught voter being consoled by Mitt Romney. “Save the small families of America,” she begged through tears, as Mr. Romney hugged her and promised he would.

headline: Debates Can Shift a Race’s Outcome, but It’s Not Easy
abstract: History shows that candidates have different ways to score in presidential debates and change voters’ minds, but only twice have debates appeared to alter the election’s result.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — History shows that candidates have different ways to score through presidential debates: the forceful put-down, the surprising show of skill, the opponent’s fumble, superior post-debate tactics.

headline: McIlroy Nearly Misses Tee Time
abstract: Rory McIlroy, the world’s No. 1 ranked player, needed a police escort to avoid missing his tee time against Keegan Bradley.
lead_paragraph: MEDINAH, Ill. — For two years, the captains of the United States and European Ryder Cup teams have obsessed over every detail of the event, from the clothing their players will wear to the food they’ll eat to the voices they’ll hear from in the team room.

headline: The Daily Shoe | Céline
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: hairy blue sandals.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Teixeira Is Set to Rejoin the Yankees
abstract: Mark Teixeira, who reported no problems with his strained left calf after playing in an instructional league game Saturday, is scheduled to return to the Yankees on Monday and will probably be in the starting lineup.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Mark Teixeira is scheduled to rejoin the Yankees on Monday and will probably be in the starting lineup, Manager Joe Girardi said. But Jayson Nix might be out for the next two weeks, if their season lasts that long.

headline: Disgraced Chinese Official’s Son Defends Him
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Bo Guagua, 24, made his most explicit defense of Bo Xilai, a former Communist Party official in China, since a sordid political scandal involving the entire Bo family broke in the spring.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The youngest son of Bo Xilai, the former Communist Party leader who is expected to be tried on a wide range of criminal charges, has released a statement defending his father as “upright in his beliefs and devoted to duty.”

headline: Attacks on 6 Banks Frustrate Customers
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The cyberattacks, by a group claiming Middle Eastern ties, caused Internet blackouts and delays in online banking, and the banks did not explain clearly what was going on.
lead_paragraph: Six major American banks were hit in a wave of computer attacks last week, by a group claiming Middle Eastern ties, that caused Internet blackouts and delays in online banking.

headline: As Kenyan Forces Press Militants Across Border, a Church Is Attacked Back Home
abstract: The attack on a church in Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, came two days after Kenyan forces invaded the last major stronghold of the Shabab militant group in Somalia.
lead_paragraph: MOMBASA, Kenya — A 9-year-old boy was killed and several other children were wounded on Sunday when a grenade was hurled into a church in Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, two days after Kenyan forces invaded the last major stronghold of the Shabab militant group in Somalia.

headline: Purveyors of Office Space and Lively Arts
abstract: The cultural arm of a real estate company, Brookfield Office Properties, spends more than $3 million a year at its North American office buildings, staging free performances and exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: One recent Monday morning the pianist Taka Kigawa took his place at a keyboard in the lobby of 1 Liberty Plaza, an office building near Wall Street, and worked through Debussy’s Preludes, Book II. A small audience — perhaps a dozen people at first, more than 100 an hour later — sat at tables or stood on the periphery, sipping coffee, listening to Mr. Kigawa and watching the parade of businessmen and tourists drift past the large window to the pianist’s left.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Faces Broadway Postponement
abstract: An executive involved with the musical said the show was being postponed because lead producers were unable to close a $4.5 million gap in a $12 million budget.
lead_paragraph: 4:35 p.m. | Updated An executive involved with the Broadway musical “Rebecca” said on Sunday that the show would be postponed because its lead producers were unable to close a $4.5 million gap in its $12 million budget.

headline: Right-Wing Extremists’ Popularity Rising Rapidly in Greece
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Vigilantes']
abstract: With anger rising over austerity measures, the popularity of the extremist Golden Dawn party is growing, even as it undertakes a campaign of vigilantism.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The video, which went viral in Greece last month, shows about 40 burly men, led by Giorgos Germenis, a lawmaker with the right-wing Golden Dawn party, marching through a night market in the town of Rafina demanding that dark-skinned merchants show permits.

headline: Poll Shows Obama and Romney Close in Iowa
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A new poll in Iowa showed a tight race in the closely contested swing state.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama and Mitt Romney are essentially tied in Iowa, according to the latest poll conducted for the The Des Moines Register.

headline: Orchestra and Laptop on a Voyage of Discovery
abstract: The San Francisco Symphony performed a piece by the 26-year-old new-music composer Samuel Carl Adams as well as a rendition of Mahler’s Fifth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The composer Samuel Carl Adams said, not really joking, that the San Francisco Symphony is “partially responsible for my existence.” His parents — the composer John Adams and the photographer Deborah O’Grady — met while working at the orchestra. More recently the younger Mr. Adams, 26, has been living in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where he pursues his wide-ranging interests, including playing bass in new-music groups and creating sound designs for multimedia works.

headline: Using Fame to Shine a Spotlight on the Suffering
abstract: “Half Sky: Turning Oppression Into Opportunity for Women Worldwide,” on PBS stations Monday and Tuesday, uses well-known actresses to advocate for basic rights for women in several nations.
lead_paragraph: No network, including PBS, is above using celebrities as audience bait in the interests of making a difficult documentary subject a little more commercial.

headline: Being Where the Interceptions Are
abstract: Michael Boley is the first Giants defender to have three interceptions through the first three games since 1978, and Boley pointed to hours of film study to explain his success.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When linebacker Michael Boley produced one interception in each of the Giants’ first three games, the obvious common denominator was that he was in the right place at the right time. Not as readily apparent was the depth of understanding, attention to detail and level of experience that led Boley, an eight-year veteran, to be ideally positioned for each play.

headline: Romney’s Faith May Help in Idaho, Where He Doesn’t Need It
abstract: Idaho hasn’t voted for a Democratic presidential candidate since 1964, and it will probably be one of the states where Mitt Romney improves on Senator John McCain’s 2008 performance by the largest margin.
lead_paragraph: We continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of each state’s political landscape and how it’s changing. Here is a look at Idaho, the Gem State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with David Adler, director of the Andrus Center for Public Policy at Boise State University.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Model-Morphosis | Cara Delevingne at Costume National
abstract: The model Cara Delevingne transforms with makeup by Sally Branka for M.A.C. and hair by Paul Hanlon.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Cara Delevingne of Women Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Sally Branka for M.A.C. and hair by Paul Hanlon.

headline: A Rout Leaves the Jets Hurting and Cursing
abstract: For the second straight week, the Jets’ impotent offense was overshadowed by a critical player going down, this time Santonio Holmes, whose left foot buckled after he made a catch in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets’ season has deteriorated into a tragicomic mix of fluky injuries and M.R.I. tubes, of turnovers and incompletions, of hoping for the best but assuming the worst.

headline: A Vote for Reason
abstract: The psychologist Jonathan Haidt has argued that reason is little more than a tool of persuasion. But in a democracy, it is something more.

headline: For Yankees, a Playoff Berth and Unfinished Business
abstract: After beating the Blue Jays on Sunday, the Yankees clinched a playoff spot when the Rangers split a doubleheader with the Angels, but the Yankees still have their sights set on the division title.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Two hours before the Yankees took the field Sunday afternoon, the stereo in the visitors’ clubhouse at Rogers Centre blared an old De La Soul tune called “The Magic Number,” but few of the players even noticed the significance.

headline: Following an Artist’s Footsteps in the Sand
abstract: “The Double Steps” from Isaki Lacuesta weaves a fable around an American-born artist who painted in the Sahara.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish director Isaki Lacuesta clearly set out to create an art movie with “The Double Steps,” a self-conscious exercise set in Africa, largely by swapping one set of cinematic conventions for another. The movie won top honors at 2011 San Sebastián Film Festival (and feels very much as if it was made for the festival circuit). It hinges on an American-born artist and writer, François Augiéras (1925-71), who lived and worked in the Sahara and who covered an abandoned army bunker in frescoes, hoping, as some introductory text puts it, to make it “the Sistine Chapel of the desert.” “Today,” the on-screen text continues, “some travelers are preparing to find, finally, Augiéras’s lost frescoes.”

headline: Putting Philippine Justice on Trial
abstract: “Give Up Tomorrow” details the doubts surrounding a late-1990s rape and murder case in the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: The miscarriage of justice recounted in “Give Up Tomorrow,” filmed over six years, is so comprehensive as to be disorienting. Paco Larrañaga, a Filipino-Spanish student from a privileged family who was convicted in 1999 as the ringleader of a 1997 double murder and rape of two sisters in the Philippines, was, for starters, miles away on a different island when the crimes took place, according to 35 witnesses.

headline: World Mind Sports Games in France
abstract: One of the arts of defense is trying to make declarer think you hold one hand when you actually have something very different.
lead_paragraph: One of the arts of defense is trying to make declarer think you hold one hand when you actually have something very different.

headline: A Gnome Is Home, but More Travel Beckons
abstract: Travelocity is giving away a trip around the world as part of a marketing campaign featuring Roaming Gnome.
lead_paragraph: A PERIPATETIC brand character has returned home before heading out on the road again.

headline: Trolling for Laughs and Singles Online
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: HBO Digitals, on the online service HBO Go, are short series with episodes ranging from 3 to 17 minutes long.
lead_paragraph: HBO has taken heat over the years for the perceived arrogance of the slogan “It’s not TV, it’s HBO.” But now it’s at least a little bit true. Hidden away on HBO Go, the online video site for the cable channel’s subscribers, are four shows that aren’t TV, although they might have been.

headline: Winners Named for Dayton Literary Peace Prize
abstract: The novelist Andrew Krivak, who wrote “The Sojourn,” and Adam Hochschild, the author of “To End All Wars,” have won the 2012 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for fiction and nonfiction.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Andrew Krivak, who wrote “The Sojourn” (Bellevue Literary Press), and Adam Hochschild, the author of “To End All Wars” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt), have won the 2012 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for fiction and nonfiction. The runners-up are Ha Jin, for “Nanjing Requiem” (Pantheon Books), and Annia Ciezadlo for “Day of Honey” (Free Press).

headline: Cool and Complex: Many Moving Parts Running Smoothly Askew
abstract: The second of five programs in the Fall for Dance festival at City Center featured Pam Tanowitz’s “Fortune,” Twyla Tharp’s “Sinatra Suite,” Martha Graham’s “Chronicle” and Peter Quanz’s “Luminous.”
lead_paragraph: The audience gave such lusty applause to all four offerings in Fall for Dance’s program on Saturday night at City Center that it sounded as if for each piece the theater was populated solely by the performers’ friends and family. Afterward, however, while leaving the theater, you could hear people discussing ardently which items had worked for them, which they’d tolerated and which they hadn’t cared for. I was relieved to find that I wasn’t the only person who hadn’t loved everything.

headline: Orioles’ Party Is Put Off, but Only for a Few Hours
abstract: The Orioles won their final home game of the regular season, and an Angels loss in Game 2 of a doubleheader helped Baltimore clinch its first playoff berth since 1997.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Moments after the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6-3, on Sunday afternoon, the players stood in shallow right field.

headline: Frank Gehry Joins Toronto Development
abstract: David Mirvish, a former art dealer who is among the leading collectors, theater producers and real estate developers in Canada, has teamed up with Frank Gehry, the 83-year-old Los Angeles-based architect, to reimagine the downtown entertainment district of Toronto.
lead_paragraph: David Mirvish, a former art dealer who is among the leading collectors, theater producers and real estate developers in Canada, has teamed up with Frank Gehry, the 83-year-old Los Angeles-based architect, to reimagine the downtown entertainment district of Toronto.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Data will include manufacturing and construction reports and the monthly unemployment figures, and automakers and retailers will release sales numbers for September.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include the I.S.M. manufacturing index for September and construction spending for August (Monday); A.D.P. employment for September, I.S.M. service index for September (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for September and consumer credit for August (Friday).

headline: A Gypsy, Fiery Yet Cool
abstract: Richard Eyre’s production of Bizet’s “Carmen” returns to the Metropolitan Opera in a revival starring the Georgian mezzo-soprano Anita Rachvelishvili.
lead_paragraph: To say that the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of the Richard Eyre production of Bizet’s “Carmen” on Friday evening got off to a slow start wouldn’t be quite right. Michele Mariotti, conducting in his Met debut, tore into the prelude, honoring the precedent set by Yannick Nézet-Séguin when the production was new, in 2009.

headline: Slipping Into and Out of Something Comfortable
abstract: RoseAnne Spradlin Dance’s “beginning of something” brings the performers to the edge of the audience.
lead_paragraph: When RoseAnne Spradlin’s “beginning of something” opened at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, it was the continuation of something special. This feverishly exciting work, which sold out the tiny Chocolate Factory last year, was a fine choice for the Replay Series at this theater.

headline: Achieved Great Fame
abstract: Hitch your wagon onto Susan Gelfand’s star with this Monday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — A nice, smooth way to start our solving week: four people whose first and last names start with the letter “A” make up a fantasy celebrity A LIST in Susan Gelfand’s Monday puzzle.

lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Medlen Leads Braves, and Jones Says Goodbye to Home Fans
abstract: The Braves won for a major league record 23rd straight time in games started by Kris Medlen, as Sunday’s victory over the Mets marked the regular-season home finale for Chipper Jones.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Mets entered the visitors’ clubhouse Sunday morning in N.F.L. jerseys. They proceeded to swing the bats as if Mark Sanchez, Jason Witten and James Harrison — among the names on players’ backs — had body-snatched them.

abstract: A recent episode of HBO’s “Real Sports” reported on fan-on-fan violence at American sporting events. The N.F.L. was no small part of the segment.

headline: In Vermont, a Venerable Paper Fights for Readers
abstract: The Burlington Free Press, the state’s largest daily, is struggling after making some radical changes in June, including a redesign and an online pay wall.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Vermonters may be quick to boast about their locally sourced foods, their ability to tolerate bitter winters and their celebrated entrepreneurs like Ben & Jerry’s and Burton Snowboards. But lately, they have not extended that praise to their newspaper.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: On Monday and Tuesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City because of Sukkot.
lead_paragraph: On Monday and Tuesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City because of Sukkot. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Shift by Cuomo on Gas Drilling Prompts Both Anger and Praise
abstract: Recent developments have created a sense in Albany that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, once poised to approve hydraulic fracturing in several struggling New York counties, is now consigning the practice to oblivion.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A few months after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was poised to approve hydraulic fracturing in several struggling New York counties, his administration is reversing course and starting the regulatory process over, garnering praise from environmental groups and stirring anger among industry executives and upstate landowners.

abstract: September 26, 2012 - Meg Whitman bets on old and new businesses to rebuild Hewlett-Packard.
lead_paragraph: September 26, 2012 - Meg Whitman bets on old and new businesses to rebuild Hewlett-Packard.

lead_paragraph: They might need to fumigate the building, at least before the Giants play there next.

headline: Rangers Lock In Playoff Spot and Help Others, Too
abstract: The Rangers roared back in the second game of a double-header against the Angels to assure themselves, and two other teams, a spot in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Texas Rangers have proved dominant and resilient during their nearly season-long occupation of first place in the American League West. But anxiety was beginning to build at the Ballpark here, and after the Rangers dropped the first game of a doubleheader Sunday, the calendar couldn’t flip fast enough for them.

headline: Fostering Tech Talent in Schools
keywords: ['Vocational Training', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Microsoft is taking an unusual approach to tackling a shortage of computer science graduates — one of the most serious issues facing the technology industry, and a broader challenge for the nation’s economy.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Leandre Nsabi, a senior at Rainier Beach High School here, received some bluntly practical advice from an instructor recently.

headline: Analysts Weigh In on Getting Anthony and Stoudemire in Sync
abstract: Carmelo Anthony and Amar’e Stoudemire, two Knicks’ players who are in their prime, have not shown they can click at the same time, though they are essential components of a team that shed its young players in the off-season.
lead_paragraph: A curious off-season in which the Knicks let young players go and replaced them with veterans will end on Monday, when the team gathers for media day, marking the official opening of training camp. For the Knicks, the big question will be whether the added experience will add up to something special.

headline: Reubin Andres, an Advocate of Weight Gain, Dies at 89
abstract: Dr. Andres, noted in the study of diabetes, gained his widest attention for challenging the conventional standards of late-life weight maintenance.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Reubin Andres, a gerontologist who advanced the study of diabetes but gained his widest attention for arguing controversially that weight gain in older people increases longevity, died on Sept. 23 at his home in Baltimore. He was 89.

headline: Eddie Bert, Jazz Trombone Player, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Bert played in pit orchestras on Broadway, onstage with jazz legends and on dozens of recordings.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Bert, a jazz trombonist whose virtuosity and versatility allowed him to fit comfortably in a wide range of musical contexts, from the infectious swing of Benny Goodman to the wild experimentation of Charles Mingus, died on Thursday at his home in Danbury, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Kodak Plans to End Line of Inkjet Printers
abstract: The company, which is in bankruptcy, said it would focus on selling services to businesses.
lead_paragraph: As part of its bankruptcy reorganization, Eastman Kodak is planning to wind down sales of consumer inkjet printers next year, products that were once called a crucial part of its turnaround effort.

headline: Video: Meg Whitman on Fixing Hewlett-Packard
abstract: In a video interview, Meg Whitman, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, explains what she needs to tell Wall Street at this week’s analysts meeting.
lead_paragraph: Few leadership attributes are as important as clear self-definition and a strong sense of direction. Meg Whitman, whose company I wrote about in Sunday’s New York Times, is among the clearest. In this video interview, she explains everything she needs to tell Wall Street at this Wednesday’s analyst meeting.

headline: Tired Cries of Bias Don’t Help Romney
abstract: The mainstream media are frequently faulted as biased against conservative causes. But it seems a dubious notion when the ownership of the megaphone is increasingly up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, conservatives have become agitated about Mitt Romney’s drop-off in the polls. So did they think the stumble was because of the ill-fated “47 percent” slip of the lip, or the hasty effort to gain a political edge after the death of an American ambassador in Libya, or more problematically, a campaign that can’t seem to stop pratfalling no matter what the news?

headline: California Is First State to Ban Gay ‘Cure’ for Minors
abstract: Gay rights advocates say disputed therapies to “overcome” homosexuality have caused emotional harm to teenagers.
lead_paragraph: California has become the first state to ban the use for minors of disputed therapies to “overcome” homosexuality, a step hailed by gay rights groups across the country that say the therapies have caused dangerous emotional harm to gay and lesbian teenagers.

headline: Soft Sales Crimp Outlook for Electric Cars
abstract: Volkswagen, which has great sway in the auto industry, is focusing on plug-in hybrids while it plays down the immediate future for all-electric cars.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Many auto executives were not that enthusiastic about battery-powered cars at their outset, and now that sales of electric vehicles made by Tesla and Renault have been disappointing, some carmakers are playing down the technology.
